column2: Holding Morton, crack second division Scottish Football Club to a 3-3 draw, the Murrayfield Amateurs sprang a surprise in a first-round Scottish Cup game on the latter's ground today. Hamilton Academicals visited Moor Park in another first-round match, winning by 7-1.

President Roosevelt's plan for governmental reorganization advanced another step toward active Congressional consideration today when the Senate Rules Committee recommended adoption of a House resolution setting up a joint committee of both houses to study the proposals and draft legislation.

Cincinnati is taking in good cheer the privation of, a water shortage that has caused lines a half mile long to form at designated points, await, ing their turn. Every conceivable type of receptackle is used and the word still echoes through the city, "Boil all water used in cooking and drinking."

Governor Lehman moved today to have New York State provide aid for floodstricken States. Upon his recommendation the Legislature passed a bill appropriating $100,000 at his disposal to provide assistance.

The $50,000,000 Seed Loan Bill was passed by the Senate today and sent to the White House for signature after debate had stirred a spirited discussion on the powers of the Federal Government to appropriate money for the relief of distressed under the general welfare clause of the Constitution.

George Washington University, with a speedy passing attack and a tight zone defense, won from Army at basketball today in a hard-fought contest by a score of 33 to 29. The visitors went into the lead at the outset when their speed, coupled with the keen shooting of Kiesel and O'Brien, netted them a pair of field goals.

The first wool auction series of 1937 closed quietly today. A total of 6,305 bales was offered, of which 4,343 were sold. Several offerings were withdrawn owing to firm limits. The Mering selection was exceptionally good throughout the sales. Crossbreds, including slipes, were in smaller supply but well represented.

Dr. Joseph Manning Steiner, long a prominent Roentgenologist in New York and a resident of White Plains, N. Y., who had served as head of the X-ray departments of Doctors and Roosevelt Hospitals, died yesterday in Greenville, Ala., according to word received here. Last Fall he relinquished his work here because of ill health and moved to the South.

A special meeting of stockholders of the New York Central Railroad Company on March 30 was authorized yesterday by the directors. It will consider the issuance of not more than $55,000,000 of bonds and authorization to the board to make the bonds convertible into capital stock.
Electric power production was lower last week, against an unchanged seasonal trend and the adjusted index has declined to 107.2 from 107.6. For the week ended Jan. 25, 1936, the number was 98.3.

None of the funds collected by the sale of tickets to the President's birthday balls to be held in 5,000 cities on Saturday night for the support of the fight on infantile paralysis will be diverted to the Red Cross flood relief fund, it was announced today.
The World Economic Conference gave a feeble sign of life today, as the disarmament conference did yesterday, When the League of Nations Council convoked its bureau (steering Committee) for May 6.

John J. Burns, who recently resigned as general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, asserted yesterday the necessity for Federal regulation of the securities business, at a luncheon in the Lawyers' Club, 115 Broadway.

Mrs. William F. Sanford, 25 years old, wife of an official of the New York Trust Company and niece of Joseph W. Wear, Philadelphia banker and former chairman of the American Davis Cup Committee, fell or jumped to her death at 8:40 o'clock last night from a bedroom in her apartment on the ninth floor of a ten-story building at 167 East Eighty-second Street.
Mr. and Mrs. Winfield S. Fell of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Marjorie Fell McAllister, to Lee H. Schwartz, son of Samuel Schwartz.

The reasons which the President has given in terminating the joint studies by TVA and private utility company experts looking to a joint transmission pool are the same reasons that have animated Senator Norris and Mr. Lilienthal of the Authority in opposing the pool. Briefly, they turn on the charge that the utilities, in pursuing injunction actions against TVA during the pool conference period, have been guilty of bad faith.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following navy orders today, dated Jan. 25: CAPTAINS Adams, R. R., Navy Yard, New York, N. Y., to home, relieved of all active duty on June 29. Staton, A., staff, the Command and General Staff School, Fort Leavenworth, Kan., to home, relieved of all active duty June 29.

The possibility suggested this week by Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manfacturers of America, that producers of trade-marked foods may undertake selective selling caused considerable interest among dry goods jobbers yesterday, who have been pioneers in the plan. The jobbers are thoroughly sold on selective distribution and feel that it can be well adopted in other fields.

Sir Halley Stewart, philanthropist, business man and former Member of Parliament, died last night of influenza at his home in Harpenden, Hertfordshire, only eight days after celebrating his ninety-ninth birthday.

The War Department released the following orders today dated Jan. 26: Covell, Lt. Col. W. E. R., Pittsburgh, Pa., detailed with organized reserves, in addition to other duties, about May 14. Cramer, Lt. Col. M. C. Judge Advocate General's Department, two months leave June 30.

A new quarterly publication, The Arbitration Journal, was issued for the first time yesterday. With headquarters at 521 Fifth Avenue, it is published by the American Arbitration Association in collaboration with the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and the Inter-American Commercial Arbitration Commission.
Because of the excessive fees asked by some doctors a bill has been introduced in Congress to fix charges as follows: For hypodermic injections and consultations-one to five cordo bas.
Martin Erdmann, a former partner in the banking house of Speyer Co., died suddenly yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his home, W 57 East Fifty-fifth Street, at the age of 73.
Rehabilitation followed tonight in the wake of almost stationary or receding flood waters along the State's 380-mile Ohio River border.

Stock corporations organized in Germany hereafter will have to have a capitalization of at least 500,000 marks, and existing corporations with less than 100,000 marks capital must be reorganized. A decree to this effect has just been issued.

Turpentine steady, 42c; no sales; receipts, 56 barrels; shipments, 35 barrels; stock, 30,702 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 233; receipts, 563; shipments, 23; stock, 79,450. Quote: B, $8.90-$9.10; D, $9.10; E, $9.1525; F, G, H, I, $9.50-65; K, M, $9.60-65; N, $9.70; WG, $10.35; WW, X, $12.50.

The Commerce Department's report on production and factory sales of automobiles during 1936 throws an interesting sidelight, both on the status of the industry which a labor feud threatens to hold up, and on the vicissitudes of that industry before and during the depression.

Count Robert van der Straten-Ponthoz, the Belgian Ambassador, and Countess van der Straten-Ponthoz have arrived at the RitzCarlton from Washington. A. Ludlow Kramer Jr. has left the Pierre to pass several weeks with Mr. and Mrs. Giraud Van Nest Foster of this city at Swingalong, their plantation at Wilson, La.

Bruce Wilson, educational director of the Federal Housing Authority, speaking yesterday afternoon at the forty-third annual convention of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania, said that this year it is expected that 400,000 or 450,000 new homes will be built in America. Through more efficient merchandising and a drive toward building low-cost houses, he said, the market could be greatly expanded.

The loss to the world's economic system through the depression between 1930 and 1934 was estimated at 149,000,000,000 to 176,000,000,000 old gold dollars by Professor Wladimir Woytinsky, European economist, in a report on "The Social Consequences of the Economic Depression," just published by the International Labor Office.

W. H. Thom, coach of 1936 United States Olympic wrestling team, suggested today that the Federal Government finance all Olympic squads as one way of avoiding the financial difficulties encountered last year in sending the athletes to Berlin.
E. R. Gay has been elected a vice president of the St. Regis Paper Company. Directors have decided to merge the Harrisville Paper Company and the Oswego Board Company into St. Regis Paper.
The Senate passed today the Kleinfeld bill, postponing the date of the Fall primary election this year from Sept. 14 to Sept. 16.

The substantial recovery in freight and passenger revenues which took place last year were reflected in preliminary statements for 1936 issued yesterday by the New York Central and Baltimore Ohio railroads.
Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission contended today that the public lost $65,898,000 of $263,862,000 which it paid into investment trusts sponsored by Ross Beason and associates.

Predictions that "one of the most prosperous periods" this country has ever known is facing us and that a tide of sentiment in favor of wholesalers is rapidly rising were made yesterday by speakers at the opening session of the twoday annual convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute at the Hotel New Yorker.

It is the Max Gordon Plays and Pictures Corporation which has bought the screen rights to "The Women" and the price was $125,000. Since it was also Mr. Gordon who produced the play, the deal was pretty much in the family.

A fifteen-game schedule for the six members of the Eastern Intercollegiate Lightweight Football League next Fall was announced today by the league president, George Little, Rutgers director of physical education. The schedule was adopted at a league meeting, at which Little was re-elected president. Henry W. Clarke of Lafayette was chosen secretary.
Benjamin Bergen, member of one of Long Island's oldest families, died early yesterday in the old homestead at 211-46 Ninety-fourth Road, Queens Village, in which he was born eighty-seven years ago.

A contingent of 200 Brooklyn College students, under the supervision of Professor Louis A. Warsoff, is making a five-day tour of inspection of governmental offices and points of interest in the capital.

The Brooklyn Prep quintet, led by John Harpz, right guard, easily defeated the Poly Prep five, 30 to 18, on the latter's court yesterday. The winners led for the greater part of the contest. Harpz was the high scorer with four field goals and a foul for 9 points.

Hearn Department Stores, Inc., reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Oct. 31, 1936, a net profit of $150,537 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other deductions, but before surtax on undistributed earnings.
Enesco's Symphony in E flat and Dukas's Symphony in C will be featured in Marion Rous's reading at Steinway Hall this morning. The reading will be repeated tomorrow afternoon.

The first test case under the new Public Order Act, which bans the wearing of political uniforms, went against a member of Sir Oswald Mosley's British Union of Fascists who said he was merely wearing the livery, of a vendor of Sir Oswald's paper, Action.

R. G. Packard, in 53 E. 66th St.; Miss Miriam Tilden, in 414 E; 52d St.; Miss Marion Nuttal, in 45 E. 60th St.; Clarence Timm, in 205 E. 78th St.; Miss Witona Ayres, in 307 E. 44th St.; Pease Elliman, Inc., broker. Hugh W. Cann, in 30 E. 70th St.: Mrs. Laurance Harris, in 64 E. 86th St.; Miss Leonie Graton, in 135 E. 34th St.; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., broker.

George E. Little, director of physical education at Rutgers University, announced today that there would be no change in the Rutgers varsity football coaching staff next year. The announcement sets at rest rumors that J. Wilder Tasker would not be head coach next season.

Because all involved were Irishmen, "and I wasn't hurt much," Mike McTighe, former light-heavyweight pugilist, withdrew charges in the Felony Court yesterday against two men accused of having attacked him on the night of Jan. 16 in a Third Avenue elevated train. The men were released on suspended sentences on a disorderly conduct charge.

Interest due on Feb. 1 on city of Warsaw 7 per cent sinking fund external gold bonds of 1928 is to be paid in zlotys at the Bank of Poland. As these funds cannot be transferred to this country due to exchange restrictions, the Exchange has ruled that commencing today and until further notice these bonds will be traded on a "flat" basis and must carry the Feb. 1 and subsequent coupons.

An advance of 41 per cent in 1936 over 1935 in private construction in the New York metropolitan area is shown by figures on actual contracts awarded, compiled by the F. W. Dodge Corporation. Private building in the area amounted to $175,311,700 during 1936 as compared to $124,734,600 for 1935, the Dodge concern reports.

People have been seeking in abnormal psychology a clue to the incredible treason trial in Moscow. But the psychological puzzles are not the only ones. Take, for instance, the colossal ineptitude of STALIN'S enemies as killers.

Lawrenceville's hustling basketball team defeated George School, 38 to 19, today. The home five took a 3-0 lead, but soon relinquished it and trailed the rest of the way. Lawrenceville held an 8-3 advantage at the end of the first period.

High Lark, undefeated son of Blue Larkspur from J. J. Coughlin's stable, won his third straight race today, leading nine other three-year-olds to the wire in the six-furlong handicap at the Fair Grounds. The bay colt, which made his racing debut on Jan. 4, showed a world of speed as he covered the three-quarters of a mile in 1:12 flat under 118 pounds.

Stung by criticism from Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme, who recently accused officials of Harrison Township of operating a "marriage mill," the Town Council tonight set a limit on the hours licenses may be issued and marriages performed in the Town Hall.

Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, retired, executive director of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, reported that contributions to the flood relief fund to date totaled $235,149.38. Those listed yesterday were:

Three union organizers were injured late tonight when a taxicab in which they were escaping from "vigilantes" who chased them from Saginaw, thirty miles away, was crowded off the Dixie Highway on the outskirts of this city.

BOPP, MARGARET A. (June 30. 1935). Gross assets, $8,563; not, $7,854. To Margaret H. Callen, specific jewelry; Margaret A. and Elizabeth Bopp, $500 each and one-half of jewelry; Edwin J. Callen, $500 husband, August S. Bopp, residuary estate. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $460 mortgages, notes, cash and insurance $7,767; miscellaneous property, $335. William E. Bardusch, attorney, 63 Wall St., Manhattan.

Resolutions favoring the extension of the State mortgage moratorium, establishment of a Federal mortgage discount bank and a State mortgage bank and the extension of the Deficiency Judgment Act were adopted yesterday at the allday session of the Metropolitan Real Estate Conference at the Hotel Commodore.

Emile Vandervelde, Vice Premier and Health Minister, resigned today, creating a situation of great uncertainty for the Cabinet of Premier Paul van Zeeland. The resignation was accepted and it is believed that Arthur Wauters, another Socialist, will be Mr. Vandervelde's successor.

A horse that changed hands three times within the last year and had to wait six years for his place in the sun, cracked the Hialeah sevenfurlong track record today in the race immediately following a test in which the same mark was equaled. Sweep Like, owned by T. D. Buhl of Detroit, was the recordbreaker and gave that young owner a double on the day.
The following statement was made today by Wyndham Mortimer, first vice president of the International Union, United Automobile Workers, in charge of organization activities at Flint Mich.:
Army engineers drafted tentative plans today for evacuating whole areas along the Mississippi in case floods threaten to break through the levees on the river's southern reaches.
Secretary Perkins asked Congress today for larger authority for dealing with existing or threatened strikes and lockouts, as management and labor refused to yield ground in the automotive strike.
THE race to publish 1937's first bound volume history of 1936 has been won by Robert M. McBride Co. with "American Hurly-Burly: The Dramatic Highlights of Last Year's Parade of Events" ($2.50).

Joseph B. Weaver, for two years director of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, expects to resign soon, Secretary Roper stated today, adding that several persons were being considered for his post, but no selection had been made.

An attempt to control the price of gasoline, the sale of which is in the hands of American and -British oil companies in Cuba, will be made by the government, according to a resolution adopted by the Cabinet this afternoon. Asserting that the present high price is due to collusion, the resolution said:
The University Club five of Stamford defeated the New York A. C., 3025, tonight, and went into a tie for second place with the Winged Foot team in the Eastern Athletic Club League.

The loan tax fund of the school district of Philadelphia purchased yesterday a new issue of $3,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent bonds of the School District of Philadelphia, Pa., on a bid of 100.003. The bonds will be dated Feb. 1, 1937, and mature on Feb. 1, 1967.

Under broadening mill and commission-house activity, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved into new high ground again yesterday and closed with net gains of 12 to 16 points. Reports that cotton was being moved from danger points in Memphis and anxiety over the possible damage to warehouses in the Mississippi Valley stimulated buying operations.

The high hopes entertained in Nazi circles for the Austro-German accord, signed last July, which re-established relations on a normal and friendly basis," have not been realized. Anschluss is not perceptibly nearer; recent news of the limited results of the prolonged trade negotiations between the two countries would indicate, in fact, that an economic union is no nearer, if it is not more remote, than before the heralded agreement was signed.

Brooklyn Central's formidable team defeated the Mount Vernon mermen, 34-23, tonight in the opening dual meet of the Metropolitan Y. M. C. A. Swimming League. Four of the six individual events were carried off by the invaders, while the Central relay team triumphed in the 160-yard test. William Thorne of Central annexed the 40-yard free style, Edward Brand the 100 back stroke, John Sole the 100 breast stroke and Henry Phferr the 220 free style.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth French, daughter of Mrs. John French of this city and Woodstock, Vt., and the late Mr. French, to Ethan Allen Hitchcock.

An address on the future of prices of securities made by H. M. Gartley of H. M. Gartley, Inc., market analysts, before 500 members and dinner guests of the American Statistical Association on Tuesday night was inadvertently omitted by THE NEW YORK TIMES from the report published yesterday morning.

I agree with everything Admiral Phelps wrote condemning mandatory embargo provisions in neutrality laws except that we entered the last war in order to change the form of the German Government. This argument was used by President Wilson to disaffect German morale; certainly a worthy propaganda instrument of war.
Mrs. Emma S. Birchall, widow of Warren Randolph Birchall of Montclair, died here on Monday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Perry S. Strassburger of 63 Hawthorne Place.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday it was stated that three teams from the University of Pennsylvania had won the $200 prize and the two honorary mentions in the annual collaborative competition arranged by the Association of the Alumni of the American Academy in Rome.

Major Frank A. Conklin, a veteran of the World War and for twenty years a clerk in Kings County Court, died yesterday morning in the Northport (L. I.) Hospital, where he had been a patient for three months. He was 53 years old and resided at 469 Eastern Parkway Brooklyn.
Flood-choked Evansville, encouraged by a slowing of the rise in the Ohio River, struggled today against an increasingly grave water shortage, with accompanying threats of disease.

Delegates to the annual convention of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations; composed of 267 groups throughout the city, pledged their support to the Child Labor Amendment yesterday- and adopted resolutions bearing upon the solution of economic and social problems in this country and abroad.
Movie stars topped their own bosses and many business men in a list of 1935 salaries reported today to Congress.

Taking an early lead, the Andover Academy basketball team scored a 30-to-20 victory over Lawrence Academy today. Andover was ahead, 18-9, at the half, and in the third quarter Anderson and Mayo each tossed in three field goals to give the local team a more comfortable advantage.

Seeded players marched along in triumphant style during the third day's play in the eleventh annual De Witt Clinton High School interscholastic indoor tennis tourney at the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday as Clinton, the host school, gained a commanding lead in the team score.

The report of the Twin City Rapid Transit Company for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $649,487 after interest, amortization, depreciation and taxes assignable to operations, including Federal and State taxes and Federal taxes on undistributed profits.

Increases in the surpluses of all companies in the "Glens Falls Group"-the Glens Falls Insurance Company, the Glens Falls Indemnity Company,, the Commerce Insurance Company and the Glens Falls investing Corporation-were reported today at the annual meetings of stockholders.
The Right Rev. Frank W. Creighton, Suffragan Bishop of Long Island, was chosen Coadjutor Bishop of the Episcopal diocese of Michigan on the second ballot at the convention of the diocese today.

Gerald McLoughlin, a stenographer on the staff of District Attorney Geoghan of Kings County, and active in Catholic church and social circles, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at his home, 333 East Sixteenth Street, Brooklyn. He was 53 years old.

Dr. John H. Northrop of the Rockefeller Institute of Princeton University, recent Chandler medalist and son of the founder of the School Nature League, will be a speaker at the twentieth anniversary meeting of the league in the American Museum of Natural History today at 3 P. M.

The French Theatre of New York's sixth offering this season which opened at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre last evening with "Si Je Voulais" by MM. Geraldy and Spitzer made a triple appeal, part of which formed the subject of conversation among the audience in the foyer between the acts.

It was announced today that the Federal Power Commission, sitting with the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission, will start hearings on March 3 to investigate the ownership, operation and control of the Associated Gas and Electric System and some thirty associated companies.
Louis N. Sherwell, since 1916 a teacher of Spanish at Stuyvesant High School, died yesterday morning at the Hospital for Joint Diseases after an illness of a month.

Further developments in experimentation by Dr. William H. Woglom on transplanted rat cancer, announced originally in March, 1934, were disclosed yesterday by Dr. Francis Carter Wood, director of the Columbia Institute of Cancer Research, in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University.

The cornerstone of the new twostory brick structure to be occupied as a department store by the Frederick Loeser Company of Brooklyn will be laid by Mayor John C. Norris of Garden City at formal exercises Friday afternoon.

Gilt-edge issues were steadier in a generally irregular stock market here today, influenced by the approaching termination of the account. In the foreign list, European bonds were firm. International issues were overshadowed by the overnight news from Wall Street.
A petition for divorce from Walter C. Hagen, professional golfer, was filed in Chancery Court here today by Mrs. Edna C. Hagen of 1 Roselle Avenue, Deal.

Authority to use about $250,000, the estimated balance in local relief funds obtained from the annual sale of buddy poppies last Spring, as contributions to the American Red Cross for flood relief purposes has been granted to 3,500 local posts of the Veterans of Foreign Wars by Commander-in-Chief Bernard W. Kearney of Gloversville, N. Y.

The old-age benefit tax, assessed under Title 8 of the Social Security Act on employes and employers, and from which are paid pensions to persons over 65 years old, was ruled within the taxing power of Congress and constitutional by Federal Judge George C. Sweeney here today.

The Red Cross passed the $1,000,000 mark today in its drive to raise $10,000,000 for flood sufferers. Included in the $1,222,182 reported at noon was a $25,000 contribution from Adolphus Busch of St. Louis, who also made a contribution in the Midwest division.

JUST recently the dashing Major Fred McLaughlin, who owns the Chicago Black Hawks of the hockey circuit, announced that he was pretty well fed up with Canadian domination on ice and he proposed to foster native talent with the idea of coming up with a full-fledged (eagle-feathered?) home-bred team sooner or later. Probably it will be later.

An uncommonly entertaining concert, the seventh of the Town Hall Endowment Series, was given last night in Town Hall by Igor Stravinsky and Samuel Dushkin, violinist, when the program consisted of works by the distinguished Russian composer either originally composed or arranged for violin and piano from the contents of various of his orchestral scores.
Completion of the Pennsylvania Railroad's $250,000,000 main - line electrification by extension to Harrisburg, Pa., is about to be undertaken, M. W. Clement, president, announced yesterday.

Many aspects of salt water sports angling will be discussed at the national fisheries convention of the Eastern Fisheries Association in Atlantic City Feb. 4-5, it was announced yesterday by H. F. Turner, an official of the commercial fishing group.

About 10,800 Chevrolet employes returned to part-time duty here today, with assurances of two or three days' work a week temporarily pending settlement of the strike which has made 38,000 General Motors workers in this city idle since New Year's Eve.

Receding waters in the Cincinnati and Louisville flood areas encouraged merchants in those areas to look forward to an early resumption of normal business, with the possibility that some of the largest establishments which have been closed four days will reopen next Monday, according to reports reaching representatives of these stores in the local markets.

The marriage of Miss Marion Bagley, daughter of John Joseph Bagley of Waterbury, Conn., and the late Mrs. Bagley, to Cyril Hyde Condon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Condon, also of that city, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of Corpus Christi, 535 West 121st Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John P. Monaghan.

Attorney General Cummings said today that President Roosevelt had commuted the sentences of Wilbur Foshay and H. H. Henley of Minneapolis, making them eligible for parole at once. They now are serving fifteen years in Leavenworth Penitentiary for fraudulent use of the mails.

Compensation of the principal executives of the American Colortype Company for the year ended Dec. 31, 1936, was disclosed yesterday in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public by the New York Stock Exchange.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, in two rulings yesterday on points not previously passed on by courts of this State, upheld the legality of powers used by the State Superintendent of Banks in making assessments upon stockholders of banks closed during the depression.

The teams which are battling for second position in the American group of- the National Hockey League-Lester Patrick's Rangers and Art Ross's Boston Bruins-will clash tonight at Madison Square Garden, resuming a rivalry that is recognized as one of the keenest feuds in the league. The Rangers have the edge in the battle for standing, enjoying a three-point margin, and the Bruins are out to reduce it.

Securely held by policemen to prevent him from entering court with an arm extended in the Communist salute, former Captain Levas of the Third Infantry Regiment created a disturbance at the Security Tribunal today.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the School Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

Maintaining their undefeated records, the Harvard and Yale Clubs continued their battle for first place in Group I of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Class C competition yesterday. Harvard routed the Union League players, 5-0, at the Harvard Club, while Yale turned back the Heights Casino combination, 4-1, at Heights Casino.

The furnishings in the twelvestory Brooklyn Elks clubhouse which have been on sale in the building, 110 Livingston Street, since Monday netted more than $150,000, it was disclosed yesterday by Samuel C. Rudolph-of Los Angeles, who had bought up the furnishings and who was in charge of the auction.

The voluntary agreement reached between the representatives of American and Japanese textile manufacturers is both welcome in itself and encouraging as a symptom. The Japanese manufacturers agreed to limit their exports of cotton piece goods to approximately 155,000,000 yards in 1937 and to 100,000,000 in 1938.

Rupert Beckett, chairman of the Westminster Bank, the third of the "Big Five" banks to hold its annual meeting; today added his voice to the chorus of warning against the recent skyrocketing of certain commodity prices, accompanied by a speculative advance in a number of shares.

Del Bissonette, former Brooklyn first baseman, will manage the Des Moines club of the Western League this year and Mike Gazella, who served the Yankees as utility infielder, will pilot the Moline, Ill., entry in the newly organized Three-I League.

Subscriptions and commitments totaling $17,148,000 of the original issue of $27,829,500 of New York World's Fair 4 per cent debentures were reported to the fair's bond sales committee, headed by Richard Whitney, at a meeting yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore.

For the first time in seven years New York will have an aviation show, beginning tonight. Preparations have been in progress for more than a week in Grand Central Palace. Mayor La Guardia will cut a ribbon at 5:45 P. M. today to admit himself as the first visitor.

It apparently requires something more than a major flood threat to disrupt Mardi Gras plans of fun-loving New Orleans. In fact, the city is pushing ahead with the most ambitious arrangements ever mapped for the week of merry festivities, which will end Feb. 9 with the annual crowning of Rex, King of Carnival, and his Queen.

Former Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany celebrated his seventyeighth birthday in solitude today. In the first place, his morbid dread of germ carriers caused the cancellation of invitations to members of his family and close friends for the usual family festivities.

A fugitive from a Quebec jail fought a gun battle today with fifty pursuers who surrounded his farmhouse refuge, and surrendered only when his ammunition ran out and in response to the plea of a priest.

An abrupt reversal in form featured the market for domestic bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as a broad recovery movement developed under the leadership of United States Government obligations.

The House Banking Committee approved today a measure to extend for two years governmental authority to guarantee debentures issued by the Federal Housing Administration. Under present provisions the guarantee expires July 1.
The health of Huntington became the prime concern of all to night as the flood waters of the Ohio River began subsiding slowly from a 69.03 foot stage, highest in the city's history.

The foreign trade zone at Stapleton, S. I., which has been authorized by the Department of Commerce, will be opened for business on Feb. 1 without ceremony, it was revealed yesterday. When the zone is functioning and freight starts to move, exercises may be held in which Federal and municipal officials will participate. it was said.

Declaring that he would not "make the few remaining years left to him unbearable," Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan refused yesterday to attach the present salary of a former Bank of United States director in order to give partial satisfaction of a $90,000 judgment obtained by the State Banking Department. The former director is William Fischman.

To the metropolitan squash racquets title which she won last week Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Apawamis today added the New Jersey State championship. In the final on the Short Hills Club court she defeated the defending champion, Miss Charlotte Darling of Philadelphia, 5-15, 15-8, 15-6, 15-10.

The women's Westchester squash racquets team proved unbeatable in the Class B group matches of the women's division of the Metropolitan Association today. In the first of a series which will be continued on Feb. 3 and Feb. 24, Westchester lost only three of fourteen matches played in morning and afternoon sessions at the Bronxville Field Club.

Merchantable potato stocks on Jan. 1 were reported today by the Department of Agriculture to total 78,011,000 bushels, compared to 105,669,000 a year ago and the 192933 average of 98,253,000. Stocks in important producing States were: Maine, 21,470,000 bushels; New York, 7,194,000; Pennsylvania,

The "old man of the Giants" has' sent his signed contract in to Secretary Eddie Brannick and, despite the venerable nature of the signee, Brannick insisted yesterday that the signature had been affixed in a firm and well-rounded hand.

A fierce drive in the last ten minutes of play gave Long Island University a 30-24 triumph over the University of Tennessee at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 6,000 last night. It was the Blackbirds' nineteenth victory in twenty starts and supplied a smashing finale to a show that presented a contrast between basketball's old and new.

Lawrenceville School's polo team overwhelmed the WilkesBarre Whips, 20-7, today. The Laurentians captured the lead in the first chukker and never were in danger. Romfh starred on both the attack and defense. He tallied nine points. Harvey shone for the losers. The line-up:

Public offering of $250,000 of 4 per cent debentures due in 1966 and 12,500 shares of common stock of $1 par value of the Susquehanna Capital Corporation in the form of units consisting of $500 of debentures and twenty-five shares of common stock will be made today by Robert E. Johnston and J. S. Judge Co., Inc. Each unit will be priced at $572.50.

The State Mortgage Commission leased the Liberty Theatre at 67 Liberty Avenue, Brooklyn, to a client of Albert Strauss, who plans to open it about March 1. The property will be rehabilitated and an income produced for the first time since 1933 for certificate holders,

Two destroyers and one submarine, last of the 1936 building program, will be built in navy yards, Secretary Swanson said today. The destroyers Wainwright and Buck will be built respectively at the Norfolk and Philadelphia yards and the submarine Swordfish will be constructed at Mare Island.

73d St., 320 E., 25x102.2; New York Savings Bank to 320 East 73d Street Corp., 15 E. 41st St., care of E. M. Strong ($12.50). 62d St., 42-44 W., 60x100.5, one-half interest; Barthman Realty Corp. to trustees estate of F. William Barthman, 70 Pine St. care of Knowlton Durham (quitclaim). Suffolk St., 98-100, 50.6 1/2x100; Central Savings Bank to M. M. J. M. Realty Corp.. 174 West St. ($25).

MANHATTAN BECKER, HENRY C. (Jan. 20)-Estate, not more than $5,000. To Jeanette W. Becker, widow, executrix, 302 W. 12th St., residue. BURT, FRANCES M. (Jan. 24)-Estate, $1,400. To Annie Reily., 249 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, and Minnie Stephen, friend, executrix, 3,242 Decatur Av., Bronx., jewelry and residue equally; one other bequest.

Three boys who had helped to capture a man as he fled from the scene of a hold-up and later stood ready to testify against him were honored yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner Byrnes MacDonald in the offices of Samuel J. Foley, Bronx District Attorney. Mr.
A fire lieutenant and six firemen were reprimanded after they had been found guilty at a department trial for failure to respond to an alarm of fire, it was learned yesterday.

Walter Runciman, President of the British Board of Trade, will sail today with Mrs. Runciman on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, having completed his talks with President Roosevelt at the White House.
Evacuation of 2,906 convicts from the flooded State prison here was completed without a fatality, an official announcement disclosed today.

The following Coast Guard orders for the week ended Jan. 27 were announced today: COMMISSIONED OFFICERS Captain H. R. Searles, to command Bering Sea patrol force, season 1937. Lieut. D. E. McKay, the Tahoe, assigned to headquarters, effective in time to report on March 15.
Frank MacDonell, chairman of the State Athletic Board of Control, announced today that claims of foul in Michigan boxing rings no longer will be permitted.

Employes of the Electric Storage Battery Company, who have been on a "sit down" strike for four weeks, resumed work today on three 65,000 watt storage batteries ordered by the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company and now urgently needed there because of flood conditions.

Receipts by the Red Cross in its drive to raise $10,000,000 to finance flood relief work reached $2,831,361 today. Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, retired, chairman of the American Red Cross, announced the day's total.

Edward A. Pierce, senior partner of E. A. Pierce Co., bought the New York Stock Exchange memo bership held by Stuyvesant Fish of Callaway, Fish Co., the Exchange announced yesterday. Balloting on the proposed transfer is set for Feb. 11.
General Ignacio Rengifo, Minister of War in the Abadia administration, died here today after an operation. He was born in Call sixty-five years ago.
The election of Charles J. Rhoads, former Commissioner of Indian Affairs, as president of the board of trustees and directors of Bryn Mawr College was announced today. He succeeds Dr. Rufus M.

Tyler Hewitt Bennett, one of the most successful life insurance underwriters in this country, died yesterday morning in Reconstruction Hospital, apparently of poisoning by radium taken in a tonic for five years.

The nation's canners were cautioned today by. Carlos Campbell, research expert of the National Canners Association, not to allow rising food prices to cause them unwisely to increase production and distribution costs. Mr. Campbell, director of the association's statistics division, addressed members at their annual convention.

Added support has been given to the drive for a new Hunter.College building to replace the one at Sixtyeighth Street and Park Avenue which was damaged by fire last February, it was revealed yesterday at a tea given by the associate alumnae at the Hunter alumnae rooms in the Hotel Woodward, Fifty-fifth Street and Broadway.

The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 27, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,485,000,000, an increase of $1,000,000, compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $3,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1936.

Celebration in this city of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the National Organization for Public Health Nursing was begun yesterday at a meeting of its board of directors, followed by a tea, at the headquarters of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, 99 Park Avenue.
Formal agreement between the Central Government and the rebellious Shensi Province elements was signed at Tungkwan yesterday, according "to . official .advices received here by military circles.
Canadian legislation for unemployment insurdance, minimum wages, limitation of working hours and regulation of marketing was declared unconstitutional today.

While the current floods have brought a temporary halt to production in the limited industrial areas they have affected, the rehabilitation work necessary in those sections will stimulate demand for all kinds of construction materials and industrial equipment, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, advised his headquarters here yesterday.

W. D. Anderson Jr., president of the Bibb Manufacturing Company, died here today of pneumonia. He was 36 years old. Mr. Anderson, who sucneeded his father, now chairman of the board, as president of the $20,000,000 textile concern last March. became ill a week ago.

A substantial improvement was made in bank clearings during the week ended on Wednesday, despite floods and labor difficulties in the mid-West. The total for the twenty-one principal cities, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $6,002,580,000, against $5,243,782,000 in the corresponding week last year.

Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Blair gave a dinner for twenty tonight at their home in honor of Miss Sarah Jane Sanford and Mario Pansa. Captain Arthur Boyd Rochfort and Captain Cecil Boyd Rochfort were hosts at a dinner tonight at the Beach Club,

The Jackson Heights team retained the lead in the Group 1 competition of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association series last night. By virtue of a close contest, the Jackson Heights players scored, 3 to 2, on their home courts against the New York A. C., thus registering their seventh triumph in eight starts this season.

President Roosevelt is understood to be giving serious consideration to the early submission to Congress of legislation governing hours, wages, working conditions and competitive practices throughout business and industry, all by single statute based upon a Congressional definition of interstate commerce to be contained in the act itself.
The Hackley School five defeated Pawling today, 39-13. The winners held their rivals to one field goal in the first half, leading by 21-5, as the period closed.

Churches were called upon to refrain from using any method of raising money that might be classified as "gambling" in a report presented yesterday at the closing session of the two-day annual meeting of the National Lutheran Council at the Hotel McAlpin.

Governor Lehman sent to the State Senate today the nomination of Municipal Court Justice Frank A. Carlin as judge of the City Court to fill the vacancy caused by the elevation of Judge Thomas F. Noonan to the Supreme Court.
The Department of Health reported a further decline in the number of influenza and pneumonia cases for the twenty-four-hour period ended-at 10 A. M. yesterday.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Charles Lavin, formerly a member of H. L. 149, residing at 552 53d St., Brooklyn, died Jan. 26. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, Jan. 30. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery. The deputy chief of the 10th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

TODAY-New England: Cloudy, followed by snow over the north and central portions and snow, probably changing to rain over the south; slowly rising temperatures, with thawing extending over the south. New York State:
President and Mrs. Roosevelt were hosts tonight at the annual Congressional reception. One of the largest crowds in White House social history attended.

Augusto Rosso, Italian Ambassador to Moscow, today married Mrs. F. Wilkinson Bunker, Washington society matron, bringing to final dissolution a pre - depression Bachelor Diplomats Club in the United States capital.
Stockholders of the Hewitt Rubber Corporation authorized yesterday the issuance of two shares of common stock of $5 par value for each share of $10 par value now outstanding.

Indications that Brazil's export trade in cotton textiles is expanding were given in a report today by the Deapartment of Commerce. In a recent two-month period, one large mill in Rio de Janeiro made one shipment valued at $18,000 to Cuba, another of $6,000 to British Malaya, and several smaller shipments to Portugal.

The National City Bank of New York, as fiscal agent, has notified holders of Republic of Finland twenty-two-year 6 per cent external loan bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1945, that $254,000 of these bonds have been drawn for redemption at par and accrued interest on March 1.

WARMING up for his main event with Bob Pastor this evening at the Garden, it appears that Joe Louis was upset by a preliminary punch in the Pompton Lakes area. The eyewitness accounts of the stirring incident vary a trifle, but trial lawyers and dignified jurists know that such variations are to be expected.

The House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce today started hearings on the bill introduced by Representative Samuel B. Petting ill of Indiana, calling for the repeat of the long and short haul clause of the Interstate Commerce Act.

The American Federation of Labor estimated in a report published today that 8,894,000 men and women were still without normal employment during October but that 8,907,000 of the more than 17,000,000 unemplayed at the low point of the depression had gone back to work.

The Canadian Pacific Railway. owns 61 per cent of the voting control of the Associated Screen News, Ltd., according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The controlled company produces films and distributes them throughout Canada.

The increasing likelihood of early reopening of the larger stores in some sections of the inundated areas, particularly Cincinnati and Louisville, led to the belief yesterday that the delayed shipments to these stores will be forwarded in volume next week.

General Motors Corporation returned to the courts today in its fight to regain possession of its plants seized by sit-down strikers. On the company's petition Circuit Judge Paul V. Gadola of Genesee County signed an order this afternoon directing Homer Martin, president,

The listing policies of the New York Stock Exchange were under fire for more than three hours today, during which Senator Burton K Wheeler, chairman of the Committee on Interstate Commerce, and Richard Whitney,

The War Department released the following orders today dated Jan. 27: COLONELS Slaughter, H. H. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, nine days' leave, Feb. 25. Woodbury, E. N., C. A. C., to retirement, upon his own application.

In an open letter to Dr. Stephen S. Wise and Dr. Samuel Margoshes, editor of The Jewish Day, Felix Poplawski, president, and Thomas Jachimiak, secretary, of the New York district of the Guild of Polish Newspapermen in America, took the two Jewish leaders to task

Louis Leeker captured the final block in his three-cushion billiard match with Clifford Bash, 34-33, last night at Jack Doyle's Broadway Academy. The final score for the meeting was 100-93 in Leaker's favor. Herbert Courtney turned back Ted Murray, 200-163, at pocket billiards.

Building plans filed yesterday ineluded specifications for a six-story tenement to house eighty-four families in Jackson Heights. The structure will cost $300,000, according to the architect's estimate.

Otto Knauss, former sales manager for Igleheart Brothers, Inc., Evansville, Ind., has been named vice president and general sales manager of the milling company. William Nathan, who has been associated with Louis Meyers Son, Inc., gloves, for more than thirty years, has been appointed sales manager for the metropolitan area here.

A sentence of four to eight years in Sing Sing was imposed by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday on John Breen, 56 years old, a WPA worker who was described by Fire Marshal Brophy as a dangerous pyromaniac.

The policy of the Russian Government is one of "friendly cooperation with Democracies abroad," Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Russian Ambassador to the United States, declared last night at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Biltmore,arranged by the American Russian Institute for Cultural Relations with the Soviet Union.
The Department of Parks announced it would open this morning without ceremony the first part of the Gorman Memorial Park, at 190th Street between Broadway and Wadsworth Terrace.

MANHATTAN ABBEY, SIDNEY (Jan. 13, 1935). Gross assets, $348,404; net, $282,452. To Lina Kaufmann, sister, personal effects and four-thirtieths residue: Hattie MayerDinkel, sister, personal effects and sixthirtieths residue; Sophie K. Stern, niece. personal effects and fourteen-thirtieths residiue; Fannie von Gumppenberg, niece.
In a newspaper symposium of opinions gathered shortly after the election on Nov. 3, the question was asked what the person interviewed

The prediction that the Ohio River here, at a stage of 53.15 this afternoon, would reach its crest tonight at something under 531/2 feet brought hope today to Evansville citizens, weary from flood fighting and lack of sleep, and with. pressure of rescue work relieved, the city's coordination organizations began rehabilitation work.

Mrs. Jackson Dykman and Charles C. Vogelhofer won the mixed-pair championship for the P. Hal Sims and George Tilton trophy at last night's session of the second annual Atlantic National Bridge Championships, held at the Hotel Edison.
Fluttering birds in the falling snow: Softly the whirring wingtips throw A flurry of flakes, and shattering The tremulous slant, and scattering A white dust as they wheel and light

With United States Steel leading steel stocks in broad gains yesterday, a new high level of 93 was set and the stock ended at 91 5/8, up 3 1/8 for the day. Bethlehem set a new high record of 81 1/2 and ended at 80 7/8, up 3 points, and other issues also made sizable gains.

The most pronounced rise of the season in cotton prices in the Liverpool market was a factor in the continuation of the upward movement on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, and the list ended 8 points higher to unchanged.

Zenka staged her customary strong finish today to take the mile and a sixteenth test for players, which topped the Fair Grounds card. Carrying F. A. Riley's silks, the 8-year-old mare scored; by two lengths to register her second straight victory of the year. Second money went to Wee Emma, with Copper Tube third in the field of twelve.

Miss Marion S. Durand will give a luncheon today at Trouville for Miss Adelaide Brownlee and Miss Mimi Richards of Sewickley, Pa., who are sailing on the Roma tomorrow for a Mediterranean cruise. Mrs. Newbold Morris, who has been with her brother,
Dr. Wesley Alvah O'Leary, assistant State Commissioner of Education the and a specialist in vocational training, died today of heart disease at his home, 129 Malden Terrace here, at the age of 63.

Showing the largest increase since last July. total December sales of reporting wholesale firms averaged 18.9 per cent higher than in December, 1935, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. For the entire year of 1936 these firms had an average increase of 10.1 per cent.

The old Swedish Methodist Episcopal Church, known as the Lexington Avenue Church. has sold its property at the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street for cash to an unnamed investor who will demolish the building and erect a new structure there.

Jake Schaefer of San Francisco overcame several bad breaks with spectacular shots to win tonight's sixth block of his world championship 28.2 balkline billiard match with Willie Hoppe of New York, 250153. Schaefer's score is 1,500 points while Hoppe has 1,178 in the 2,500point duel.

Style trends and the various problems facing the custom tailoring industry throughout the country will be discussed by members of the Merchant Tailors Designers Association at their national convention, which will be held in Washington for four days, starting on Feb. 9.
A "sit-down" in the compounding deapartment of the B. F. Goodrich Company, tire manufacturers, caused executives to order all opernations suspended indefinitely tonight.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 27, unless specified: Brazos, at Mare Island Yard. Chaumont, at Honolulu. Cummings, Yorktown to Charleston Yard. Hatfield, at La Pallice.

Dr. Charles Weber, for more than fifty years a cancer specialist in Cincinnati, died at Good Samaritan Hospital today from the effects of carbon monoxide poisoning caused by a defective furnace in his home. He was 79 years old. For years he Mr. conducted a private sanitarium here.

Accused of stealing two handmade sailboat models fashioned by President Roosevelt, Samuel McWhinnie, 42 years old, today awaited a hearing on burglary charges before a Staatsburg justice of the peace.

For the second year in succession Paul Waner, Pittsburgh baseball star, won the annual Winter lefthanders' golf championship at the Miami-Biltmore Country Club today. He defeated A. R. Trumbo of Ottawa, Ill., in the eighteen-hole final by 4 and 2.

Senator Guglielmo Marconi's latest process of microwave therapeutics is being successfully applied in the treatment of Pope Plus's legs. The process consists fundamentally of electric massage carried out with alternating current of a frequency of several million kilocycles.
The Blue Dale Dress Company, Inc., 253 West Thirty-fifth Street, so-called "runaway" dress company, consented yesterday to the entry of a final order signed by Supreme Court Justice Philip J.

Flashing some of the form that once stamped him as world's featherweight champion, Kid Chocolate last night decisively outpointed John Mirabella of Brooklyn in the eight-round bout featuring the weekly boxing show at the Star Casino. A crowd of 3,500 attended.

While the State held in readiness all its available resources to answer at a moment's notice calls for aid from States ravaged by floods, Governor Lehman in a proclamation today appealed to the people of New York to contribute generously to the relief of the stricken in the flood areas.

The Salvation Army locally has received $8,275 for emergency flood relief, according to Commissioner Alexander M. Damon, territorial commander. Four two-ton trucks laden with relief supplies were dispatched yesterday to Cincinnati,. two of them containing food and the others clothing.

Nazis here greeted the League of Nations resolutions regarding Danzig with mixed feelings today. They did not conceal their disappointment that a semblance of League control was to be preserved and that the Senate President had promised to cooperate with the League's High Commissioner on the basis of the present statute. On the other hand,

Moving against an upward seasonal trend, lumber production was lower last week and the adjusted index has declined to 65.1 from, 69.9 in the previous week and compares with 79.9 for the week ended Jan. 25, 1936.
A steadily rising total of known dead and homeless is disclosed by a round-up of the flood situation in the various cities and States. Conditions are shown as follows:

More individual promotion and lower prices are necessary if the wool textile industry is to "gain a larger share of the consumer dollar in the better times that are at hand," Louis Surut, president of the Woolen Corporation of America, declared yesterday.
Convicts marched from the State prison farm at Cummins today to aid regular army troops, National Guardsmen and civilians in the fight to save flood-menaced levees of Arkansas and Tennessee.

SHOULD one make a distinction between poetic prose and the best prose? Having just read Philip Guedalla's "The Hundred Years" (Doubleday, Doran, $3), I am half convinced that one should. The. book is impressive,

A bill providing for fines and expulsion from the newspaper profession of publishers and editors who permit "any untruth" about a person to 1 appear in their editorial columns was passed by the Tennessee Senate today.

General Pedro Antonio Irias, who fought side by side-with the notorious outlaw leader Agustino Sandino and served as his personal secretary, surrendered to the National Guard today. He said he had lived ten years in the mountains eating monkeys, lizards, deer, grass and tree bark and was always in fear of being killed.
Former Supreme Court Justice Arthur S. Tompkins of the Appellate Division, Second Department, was reported in a serious condition this evening from the effects of a leg amputation in Nyack Hospital.
The Ohio River crept back toward its banks tonight, allowing Cincinnati to concentrate on its problems of public health and the task of restoring what the flood swept away.

The marriage of Mrs. Marie Schoonmaker Smith of Center Island, Oyster Bay, widow of Herbert Ludlam Smith, to Hobart Hayes Putnam of Garden City took place here this afternoon at the home of her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ludlam Smith Jr.

Mr. and Mrs. John Williams Doty of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Doty, to George Burton Cumming of South Kent, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Pierson Cumming, which took place on Jan.
The Public Works Administration checked up today to learn how it was doing as a landlord. Completing a report of the Boulevard Gardens, low-rent housing project in New York City, the PWA found:

The Westminster School hockey team blanked the St. Thomas Seminary skaters, 9-0, today. The winners, with Howell. Betts and Moore showing the way, kept the puck in their rivals' territory most of the game. Wood excelled for the losers.
Charles Evans Doane, Federal Commissioner and prominent member of the local bar, died today in Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore. He had been in ill health for three months. He was 56 years old.
Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Corbett of Norwalk have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ethel Isabella Corbett, to George Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Klein of Bridgeport.
Matthieu M. Proujan, 35 years old, of 114 West Eleventh Street, an attorney employed by the Works Progress Administration, was arrested last night and charged with offering to accept unlawful fees.

Offering will be made today of 40,000 shares of 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle Properties Corporation, a subsidiary of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, by Falvey, Waddell Co., Inc., as underwriters.

A number of stores were included among the commercial units leased, according to reports from brokers yesterday, who also noted a continuance of the demand for floors and lofts in the midtown district for firms in the garment and fur industries.
Playing before a capacity crowd of 1,200 at the Johns Hopkins Gymnasium tonight the University of Baltimore scored a major upset by defeating the University of Tennessee five, 37 to 33.

Richard Hageman's opera "Caponsacchi" was presented at a formal dress rehearsal yesterday morning at the Metropolitan Opera House for members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild. More than 2,000 persons, a majority of them women and members of the organization, witnessed the production. Admission was only by invitation. Mr. Hageman conducted.

Playing a close defensive game, the Boston Bruins held the New York Rangers to one goal at Madison Square Garden last night. At the same time they managed to score one themselves, with the resuit that the rival sextets had nothing better to show for their efforts after an overtime struggle than a 1-to-1 tie.

A thousand lawyers and judges assembled at the annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria were told last night by Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, that the law should be made a learned profession and should be practiced for the common good instead of to make money.

Favorable dividends and earnings were announced yesterday by two leading oil companies. Directors of the Texas Corporation voted to place the stock on a $2 annual basis by declaring a dividend of 50 cents a share. Previously the stock was on a yearly rate of $1 to holders of record April 1.

The navy's twelve newest sky cruisers winged westward tonight bent on a new record, the greatest nonstop, over water, massed air flight in history, from San Diego to Honolulu. With 1,125 nautical miles of open sea traversed the flight commander radioed at 8:30 P. M. (11:30 P. M., E. S. T.): "We've passed the halfway mark with no trouble."

The formative stages of the restaurant racket were revealed yesterday by a young woman who told how Jules Martin, murdered field captain for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, "opened a union in Forty-sixth Street" and by a burly waiter who bad rebuffed a "messenger from the mob."

About fifteen American-born today faced immediate deportation as aliens, Senator Elbert D. Thomas's office explained in connection with a bill which he introduced yesterday to clarify the law governing their cases. Under the changes, American-born children of naturalized parents could lose their status as Americans only by a voluntary act.

With securities valued at market prices, total assets of Carriers and General Corporation, an investment trust, on Dec. 31 last were $9,359,416, compared with $7,041,962 at the pre end of 1935, according to the company's general report yesterday.

A suit for an injunction and an accounting brought by Bruce Grant, member of the staff of The Chicago Times, against Jack Lait, editor of The Mirror, was settled out of court yesterday. Federal Judge John W.

Hog prices declined 10 to 25 cents today to the lowest level in two months. Top sales at $10 a hundredweight were the lowest since Dec. 4 and were 30 cents under the early high point on Wednesday, while the day's average was 15 cents lower at $9.80.

Mount Holyoke College will go on the air next month with a series of seven fifteen-minute weekly broadcasts over the Springfield Station WSPR and the Colonial network. The radio programs, planned by a faculty committee, will be linked to the college centenary, to be celebrated next May.

A sharp increase in home building this year was predicted today by Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, in a report to Congress which disclosed that the FHA in three years had insured loans totaling over $1,100,000,000.

Declaring that "there undoubtedly exists today a tension in the relations between employer and employe, which was not typical in the past," Ordway Tead, editor of economic books, Harper Brothers, and former president of the Society for the Advancement of Management, urged business executives yesterday to revise their attitude toward workers.

Judge Clarence G. Galston in the Federal court in Brooklyn denied yesterday an application on behalf of Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, to reopen a default in a libel proceeding in which the court awarded possession of the Spanish freighter

A passenger and a Pullman porter were injured and half a dozen other passengers were shaken when three rear coaches of the Pennsylvania Railroad's flier, The Constitution, were derailed at 7:59 o'clock tonight at Millham Junction on the outskirts of this city.

The first work of the scientific committee of the board of standards of the toilet goods industry is now under way, it was announced yesterday by the Toilet Goods Association. This work covers the value and quantity of ingredients and it is expected that a list will be published very shortly of "raw materials which should not be used or which should only be used with cautionary labels."

Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Senate's Railroad Investigating Committee, charged today that "the railways and the banks and the house of Morgan would like to stop this investigation" by writing a restrictive clause into a relief appropriatiton bill.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday its consent to proposed simplification of the N? agara Hudson Power system, which involves consolidation of the Mohawk Hudson Power Corporation and the present Niagara Hudson Power Corporation.

Five hundred strikers early today dictated the departure from town of C. H. Shoemaker, plant manager for the Canadian Johns-Manville Company, the second company official ordered out of Asbestos this week.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth H. Seibert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hill Seibert of the Lakeville colony of this community, to Timothy A. Corcoran of New York took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Sears Kelley of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Kelley, to Bradford Price, son of Mrs. Emery L. Ferris of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late Edmund Price.
The government assigned G-men tonight to investigate union lead- Charges era' charges that strike-breakers were sent across State lines to the scene of a General Motors strike at Anderson, Ind.

While the course of bond prices continued moderately higher, on the average, in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, the recovery movement was much less uniform than on the preceding day and was marked by numerous

Liquidation continued- in the wheat market today with prices dropping to new low levels for the current movement and to the lowest in about a month as the result of fairly general selling both here and abroad. Foreign markets led the decline with Liverpool off 2 to 2 3/8 cents a bushel and Winnipeg 1/2 to 1 1/2 cents lower.
In '85 I began a series of tales in the "Civil and Military Gazette" which were called "Plain Tales from the Hills." They came in when and as padding was needed.

John Palmer Barstow, stove manufacturer, leader in civic affairs and banking, died here today after a short illness. He also was prominent as an alumnus of Brown University, having served for seven years on the advisory council of the Associated Alumni. He was 56 yars old.

Hertz Co., Inc., brokers and dealers here, were enjoined today by Justice F. Dickinson Letts of the District Court of the United States from further sales of securities of the Maryland Natural Gas Utilities Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced.

Halloran H. Brown, fruit grower of Monsey, N. Y., and president of the New York State Horticultural Society, addressing the society here this afternoon, appealed to farmers and fruit growers to depend more upon their own endeavors for success rather than upon the government.
The Dionne quintuplets, 32 months old today, played outdoors in below-zero weather after Dr. Allan R. Dafoe had finished his monthly job of weighing and measuring them.
The Government may engage in banana planting, according to the provisions of a law presented to Congress by the Minister of Industries under the land expropriation article of the new Constitution.

Arthur C. Whitaker, Mayor of this city from 1912 to 1921 and an optometrist here, died of pneumonia last night in Bridgeton Hospital, sixteen days after an abdominal operation had been performed. He was 65 years old.
Michigan and Pennsylvania are not the only States of the Union where, for one reason or another, mass action in violation of plain statutes is going unpunished.

The annual report of the Ward Baking Corporation and subsidiaries, issued yesterday, showed for 1936 a net profit of $1,838,936 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, surtaxes on undistributed income and other charges.

Thomas J. Mooney lost the first round of his new battle for freedom and vindication today when a State Supreme Court referee held the former labor leader had not proven his charges of perjury and frameup in his conviction twenty years ago of the Preparedness Day bombing.

Sir Stafford Cripps's Socialist League was "disaffiliated" by the Labor party yesterday by an overwhelming vote of the Labor executive and thereby cut off from any further voice in the party councils.

A new one-story taxpayer containing ten stores, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, at the northwest corner of Sixty-third Drive and Austin Street, Rego Park, was purchased by a group headed by Nathan Wilson from Morris Bienenstock, builder, for cash above a mortgage of $30,000.
The stock markets were quieter today, with prices generally weaker due to the approach of the end of the account, which tended to restrict new buying..

Augustus Vanderoef Heely, a founder of the Plainfield Trust Company, of which he was a vice president and a director, died today at his home here. He was 77 years old. Mr. Heely was born in New York City, the son of Laurence A. and Mary Eleanor Moore Heely.

President Roosevelt's birthday tomorrow will be the occasion for the fourth consecutive year of a nationwide series of entertainments governed by a national committee, with Colonel Henry F. Doherty as chairman, and various local committees in more than 6,000 communities throughout the country.

Representatives of De Witt Clinton High School, perennial winners of the team honors in the interscholastic indoor tennis tourney sponsored by their school, clinched the laurels again in the eleventh edition of the annual event at the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday.

J. R. Leonard, winner of the title for the past two years with Malcolm Kirkbride, was eliminated with Rex Fincke Jr. from the national racquets doubles championship yesterday as play started at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Once again the price of victory in 1934 came high to Miss Dorothy Paget's Golden Miller today. For the third straight year he was assigned top weight for the ninety-ninth running of the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree, March 19.

Although gross revenues of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad increased 10.9 per cent in 1936, its net loss for the year was slightly greater than it was in 1935, according to preliminary figures issued yesterday.

The Kingdom of Norway filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $29,000,000 of twenty-sixyear 4 per cent sinking fund external loan coupon bonds, due Feb. 1, 1963.

Miss Anne Rebe Wertheim, daughter of Maurice Wertheim of Cos Cob, Greenwich, and 33 East Seventieth Street, New York, and Mrs. Alma Morgenthau Wiener of New York, has completed plans for her marriage to Dr. Louis Langman of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Langman of Camden, Me.

President Roosevelt announced that he would visit Warm Springs, Ga., in March, gave most of his time to directing flood-relief efforts of various government agencies, discussed neutrality with Secretary Hull and Senator Pittman and the maritime strike with Senator McAdoo.

The flood has caused nearly a banking holiday in Louisville. The big downtown banks, with plenty of cash in their vaults, are closed, principally because trade and industry have stopped. Some banks opened emergency windows to make change.

Fear of air raids has caused the government to call-a halt on construction of its new office building on Whitehall designed to nouse under one roof the Air Ministry, the Ministry of Labor, the Board of Trade and the Ministry of Transport.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today under date of Jan. 26: CAPTAINS Bingham, D. C., detached from Army War College. Fort Humphreys, D. C., about May 1 to home; relieved of all active duty. Nichols, N. E., detached as captain of the yard, Navy Yard, Boston, Mass., about May 1 to home: relieved of all active duty.
Jewish students attempting to enter Warsaw University grounds today were turned back by Fascist pickets at the gates. Several who insisted on entering were pushed out and the beaten.
The people of this capital were asked today to repay a thirty-sevenyear-old debt to the people of the United States and subscribe to a relief fund in aid of Ohio and Mississippi Valley flood victims.
The Supreme Court refused today to restrain Asbury Park from leasing to Walter Reade, theatre operator, all of the municipal Boardwalk amusement features for a period of five years.

New York City's first aviation show in more than seven years was opened yesterday at dusk when Mayor La Guardia cut a silk ribbon at the entrance to the exhibitions of the latest developments in aeronautics at the Grand Central Palace.

Governor Lehman's proclamation today on the flood situation was as follows: Proclamation: TO THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK. This is an appeal for funds for the Red Cross. Our country is confronted with one of its worst disasters of recent years. Floods have overwhelmed a fertile and thickly populated part of the country great in size.

Long trains of empty cars sped tonight into flood areas from north, east, south and west under orders of the office of the Association of American Roads here. Slow freight and way trains, moving away from the flood regions, were ordered sidetracked to permit the empties to "high ball" through.

Australian batsmen compiled 72 runs for the loss of one wicket today in the first innings of their fourth match of a test cricket series against England. Warm, sunny weather brought a crowd of 25,000 to watch the opening day's play.
Governor responsible Frank Murphy of Michigan refused today to guarantee protection to members of the Flint Alliance in their efforts to return to work in plants of the General Motors Corportion.

The National Labor Relations Board made public today charges that the General Motors Corporation and certain subsidiaries "have for a considerable period engaged in aggravated forms of industrial espionage, threats and coercion, violated the rights of their employes by unlawful searches of their possessions and unlawfully sought to prevent their employes from joining labor organizations of their own choosing."
" Samson et Dalila" was heard for the fourth time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The Saint-Saens Biblical opera was well received by an audience of good size.

Benjamin Franklin High School's basketball team won its seventh consecutive game tonight by defeating Greenwich High School, 44-20. The New York City players excelled at both pass work and shooting. William- Gates of Franklin starred with 13 points.

The average fresh-water fisherman is a curious paradox. If he does not catch fish you can hear his cries of anguish, protestation and lament ringing throughout the and. But when you try to interest him in doing something to improve his sport he not only becomes strangely inarticulate,' but practically holds himself incommunicado.

Miss Miriam Kereven Britt, daughter of Mrs. Charles C. Britt of Overbrook and of the late Dr. Britt, was married this afternoon to Rowland Neal Grauch, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Grauch of Wynnewood.
The seven members of the Swiss Universities ski team, scheduled to compete in the East next month, are due to arrive on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen on Monday.
A Senator's right to talk himself hoarse about any subject that strikes his fancy appeared closer tonight to being limited than ever before in American history.

Adoption of the $436,000,000 rapid transit unification plan drawn by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr., would leave the city no better off than under the existing dual contracts with the Interborough and the B. M. T., and would endanger the five-cent fare, the Transit Commission was told yesterdays by George V. S. Williams,

A ninepoint program covering a broad field of economic and social cooperation between industry and the administration in 1937 was adopted today by the Business Advisory Council, meeting here with Secretary Daniel C. Roper of the Commerce Department.

Lou Ross and Helmar Delin of the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. upset Vladimir Kotal and John Mill ler of the West Side Y. M. C. A., top-seeded team, in the second round of the New York State A. A. U. four-Wall championship handball tourney at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night.
A steamer bearing 100 passengers was reported drifting helplessly off Portugal tonight as the death toll in gales sweeping Western Europe rose to at least fifty-seven lives in maritime disasters.

" The Country Wife," which a couple of days ago laboriously announced a Saturday closing, now rises to say that due to the usual "unprecedented demand," it will remain at Henry Miller's for at least a fortnight more.

There may be four series of trials for the America's Cup yachts this year from which to select the defender to meet T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II, instead of three, as was the case in 1930 and 1934. The new racer for Harold S. Vanderbilt, which he decided to name Ranger, the Yankee and the Weetamoe are the candidates for Cup defender.

The marriage of Miss Emily Heron Dripps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dunning Dripps of Germantown, to Thomas Carpenter Stewart, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Somerville Stewart of the Bellevue Stratford, took place this afternoon.

Sean O'Casey's "The Plough and the Stars" has come to the screen of the Radio City Music Hall in a freely translated version which has realized part of the play's intent but missed more of it. Mr. O'Casey was not interested in glorifying the Easter rebellion of 1916; he thought it tragic and foolhardy and pitiful.

Broad-shouldered Jimmy Thomson, one of the longest hitters in golf, combined booming shots and a deft putting touch today to post a 67 for leadership half-way through the 36-hole qualifying test in the $5,000 San Francisco match play open tournament.

At its meeting this week the League of Nations Council advanced on one political front, the Eastern Mediterranean, and retreated on another, the Baltic. The Franco-Turkish controversy over the sanjak (district) of Alexandretta was successfully compromised by reserving special authority to the League in Syria.

War, crime and greed would cease if more attention were paid to the study of nature than to history dates in public schools, Dr. Hugh Findlay, head of the Department of Landscape Architecture at Columbia University, declared yesterday afternoon at the twentieth annual meeting of the School Nature League at the American Museum of Natural History.

Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday increased $732,523, according to the weekly statement of the bank issued today. Deposits of chartered banks went up $3,367,767.

Two brilliantly contested matches marked the semi-final round of the annual Winter golf championship of Florida for the Ponce de Leon Cup on the St. Augustine links today, when two previous winners of the crown fell by the wayside.
President Leon Cortes and his Cabinet had luncheon on the German warship Schleswig-Holstein today while the ship manoeuvred at sea. They returned to Port Limon this afternoon.

Governor Lenman signed today the Farrell bill putting the Triborough Bridge and the projected Whitestone-Bronx Bridge under a joint State authority and providing for a $53,000,000 refinancing program.
