New business booked by the structural steel fabricating industry in December reversed the seasonal trend and was the largest in volume for a month last year with the exception of July, according to the American Institute of Steel Construction.

Leading all the way, the St. Nicholas of Tolentine High School basketball team turned back St. Agnes Academy of College Point, 16 to 11, in the St. Nicholas of Tolentine gymnasium last night. The victors were ahead at 8-5 at the intermission.

With buyers and sellers weighing the possible effects on trade of floods in the middle Western States and strikes in some of the industrial centers, there was less sales activity in the wool goods markets this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Mills, however,

THE HUNDRED YEARS, by Philip Guedalla. (Doubleday, Doran, $3.) An account of the leading movements of the last century as they affected the people of Great Britain, France, Germany, Russia and the United States.
Governor Hoffman announced today the resignation from the New Jersey Planning Board of Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University.

Noisy interruptions during the annual meeting of shareholders of the Bank of France, raising of the discount rate from 2 to 4 per cent and renewed denial, in authoritative quarters, of any intention by the government to adopt the low level for the gold content franc, which can, under the present law, oscillate between 43 and 49 milligrams, marked today's financial history.

The declining trend of bank credit which began toward the end of December continued in the week to ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City for that period, which was published yesterday.

It is a favorite radical doctrine that concentration of corporate control has gone so far in this country that competition has been virtually disappearing. The automobile industry in particular has been pointed to from time to time as illustrating a merely formal competition between the major units.
The inhabitants of this country are Netherlanders or Hollanders and do not wish to be called "Germans" or "frontier Germans" in books that can be considered German Government publications.
The annual statements of the Aetna Insurance Company and its affiliated companies, published yesterday, showed a substantial rise in premium income, assets and surplus.

The House Ways and Means Committee, dividing on party lines, voted today, 18 to 7, to recommend the extension of President Roosevelt's tariff bargaining powers under the Reciprocal Foreign Trade Agreement Act for three years after June 12.
The Department of Commerce reported today that exports of automotive products during November were valued at $21,928,831, compared to $16,556,320 in October and $22,403,722 in November, 1935.

Mrs. Anna Hauptmann, widow of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, testified for forty-five minutes before the Kings County grand jury yesterday in connection with the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping case, in which Ellis H. Parker Sr., the New Jersey detective; his son, Ellis Jr., and three others have been indicted.

The Coro d'Italia Ball for the benefit of the Italian choral organization in New York, held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza under the auspices of the Italian Ambassador and the Italian Consul General in New York, drew a large gathering of members of society as well as representatives from the diplomatic world.

Robert Bruns, 218, of Germany threw Fred Grubmier, 205, Des Moines, Iowa, in the feature finish wrestling bout at the Hippodrome last night before 2,000 spectators. The German pinned his opponent with a body slam in 16 minutes 44 seconds.

A new menace in the form of undermined buildings confronted floodbeleaguered Louisville tonight in the midst of rejoicing that the Ohio River waters that have covered about three-fourths of the continued a slight recession.

The British Embassy has received from the Foreign Office in London what is termed a "friendly communication" for the Italian Government, expressing appreciation of the Italian memorandum of Jan. 25 on non-intervention in Spain.

For the first time an Austrian court adopted the Third Reich's anti-Semitic "race" principles yesterday when Judge Mifka decreed a divorce between two German nationals-a Protestant and a Jewess-both Austrian residents, on the husband's plea that the difference in "race" between a German Protestant and a German Jewess was itself grounds for divorce.

F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., reported yesterday that they had completed the distribution at the market of 58,200 shares of common stock of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company. of which 32,000 shares were offered on behalf of the company and the rest on behalf of others. These shares are part of the 600,000 shares previously outstanding.
Ward Church, prominent as a New Haven lawyer and a North Haven grand juror and justice, ended his life today by shooting himself through the head at his home.

Leaving a note in which he declared that he did not know what caused his act, Samuel Brandoff, 31 years old, an unemployed printer, killed himself and a 19month-old son, Edward, by gas in their apartment at 505 West 132d Street yesterday afternoon.

Communications with the floodstricken communities along the Ohio River and its tributaries are gradually being brought back to a condition approaching normal, but transportation facilities to the same regions are still badly disrupted, it was indicated yesterday in the reports to local offices.

The nation's record flood crept forward last night toward the next danger area, the levees between Cairo, Ill., and Memphis on the Mississippi River, as army and civilian workers piled sandbags and gumbo mud on 300 miles of set-back levee walls in a desperate effort to avert disaster.

Representative Wright Patman of Texas, speaking yesterday afternoon at the final session of the forty-third annual convention of the Northwestern Retail Lumbermen's Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania, explained the Robinson-Patman Act as a measure designed to eliminate "chiseling, cheating and racketeering in business."

Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Dimock of Enderby, Manhasset, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Dimock, to Richard W. Lippman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Lippman of 19 West Seventy-third Street.

Aiming to give a British sovereign for the first time in history a permanent "understudy," a new Regency Bill, presented to Parliament today at the request of King George VI, would entrust that office to the next adult heir. If occasion arose, the Regent would be the Duke of Gloucester.

To the-Editor of The New York Times: There were millions of Republican voters like myself who took some consolation in the thought that perhaps the overwhelming majority who reelected Mr. Roosevelt had the better judgment; and that the second administration of our popular President would please all who love this land and its institutions.

Probably the finest field ever to compete in the twenty-third running of the Millrose 600 has been entered for the event at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 6. Charles Beetham, senior from Ohio State, and Eddie O'Brien of Syracuse, who between them hold many American titles from 400 to 800 meters, will race against John Woodruff, Olympic 800-meter champion.

The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives has now completed hearings and voted favorably on a bill which would extend for three more years the Administration's power to make reciprocal trade treaties. Comparatively little outright opposition to this proposal was revealed to the committee, but it did hear echoes of two points made by Republicans during the

A program for peace involving a strict establishment of the "cash and carry" system for all shipments to belligerents, drastic legislation to eliminate private profits from war and a strong national defense was presented to the House Committee on Military Affairs today by Bernard M. Baruch, New York financier and former head of the War Industries Board.
Miss Agnes Foreman, a leader in the social, civic and business life of Chicago, died today of a heart attack in her apartment in the Pearson Hotel. Miss Foreman was the youngest

Norman Hickman, manager. of sales, has been elected a director of the American. Metal Company, Ltd. At the annual meeting of the Campbell Soup Company, Harry F. Jones, advertising manager, was elected to the board of directors.
A strong wool market for "many months," stimulated by "war clouds in Europe," was foreseen here today by C: J. Fawcett, general manager of the National Wool Marketing Corporation.

Hayward A. Hibberd, a vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York, said today he was inclined to believe that the bank's name probably helped sell an investment trust over which it had scant Dowers.
The Rev. Richard F. Carr, minister of the Friends Church here for the last forty years, died yesterday at Northern Westchester Hospital. He was 76 years old.

Roger Deering, son of the late Charles Deering, president of the International Harvester Company, and grandson of William Deering, founder of the company, left a net estate of $9,490,184 when he died Feb. 2, 1936, at Albuquerque, N. M., it was disclosed by the non-resident transfer tax appraisal filed here yesterday.

A threatened strike of about 25,000 union coal miners now working in "captive" mines operated by leading steel companies of the country became a major factor today in a gradually developing labor situation with which the administration is becoming increasingly concerned.

For the first time since the Security Tribunal began the trial of the leaders of the Leftist revolt in November, 1935, a defendant admitted without qualification today that Communists had taken part in the uprising.
Information received here of conditions in the Venezuelan oil fields, where the strike of field and refinery workers was reported settled, raises doubt as to the sinal outcome.

Net profit in 1936 of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York amounted to $479,294, according to the annual report submitted to shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Edward Gayne, a retired police sergeant, died on Wednesday at his home, at 514 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 74 years old. He retired eleven years ago after serving thirty-three years, being last attached to the Seventy-fourth

Staging a rally in the fourth quarter, the New York Cathedral College quintet topped the Staten Island Division five of Manhattan College, 40-35, at the Holy Spirit Gymnasium in the Bronx last night. The losers led at the half, 18-6. At the end of the third period, the score was tied at 29-all.

Dr. Walter Damrosch was honored yesterday at a birthday party. He will be 75 years old tomorrow. The conductor and composer, who appeared to be the picture of health, and who said he was not really planning to celebrate until he reached the century mark, took occasion during the fete at the Hotel Pierre to make an engagement with several girls who dropped in to wish him well, to visit them at their school.

Stephen C. Simms, director of the Field Museum since 1928, died of a heart attack yesterday in his apartment here. He was 73 years old and had been a member of the staff of the museum since its founding in 1893.
The Baltimore Orioles failed to break the jinx the New York Rovers have displayed in Baltimore all season and lost tonight's Eastern Amateur Hockey League game, 1--0.

Threat of legal action to compel Helen Jepson, who yesterday signed a five-year contract with Samuel Goldwyn, to make one picture for Grand National in accordance with what the studio claims is a tentative contract was made known today.
A normal supply of plate and safety glass was assured for the automobile industry today with settlement of a strike at five plants of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company.

Despite purchases of gold amounting to about $109,000,000 in the last few weeks, which have been retired to the "sterilization" account and thus are not the basis for credit expansion, the Treasury's offering of bills dated Feb. 3

With unfilled orders of $123,690,- lower; 462 on its books at the close of higher; 1936, the largest volume by far since the World War, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday for last year a net income better than for any year since 1930 and a fourth-quarter net income better than for any quarter since the second quarter of 1930.

A series of volumes containing the complete stories of outstanding film hits, together with dialogue, facts about the productions and some of the incidents attending the shooting of the scenes, will be edited by Sidney Skolsky and published by Random House. "The Best Motion Pictures" of 1937 will be the first of the. volumes to appear.

The flood sufferers, through the medium of the American Red Cross, benefited by $3,443.85 when Mrs. Emil Denemark's Aftermath charged through the stretch at Hialeah today to score by a nose at $42.60 for $2.

Chinese porcelains and pottery from the collections of Mrs. S. K. de Forest and of C. Ruxton Love Jr., both of this city, were sold for $23,557.50 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Steve Sundra of the Newark Bears, who will receive another trial with the Yankees in the Spring at St. Petersburg, was the leading pitcher of the International League in effectiveness, the averages for the circuit, released for publication today, reveal.
The House of Lords, represented by five judges sitting as the highest court in the country, decided today that the British Government was entitled to pay its gold bonds in devalued dollars.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Crime in Politics," Courtney Ryley Cooper. Annual meeting of the New York Women's League for Animals at the home of Mrs. Orme Wilson, 3 East Sixty-fourth Street, 4 P. M. Speakers: Fannie Hurst, Dr. George G. Goodwin. Presentation of medal to Mrs. Anna Bermudez to commemorate courage of her son who lost his life trying to save a pet cat in a fire.

The invasion of France through the Netherlands and Belgium and even the smashing of the Maginot line were considered as possibilities during the debate on national defense in the Chamber of Deputies today. It is the thought of a German attack that recurs in this debate, revealing the peril that Deputies think is growing.

Arthur Joseph Hungerford Pollen, naval gunnery expert who won an award of [Pound]30,000 for his inventions during the World War, died today at the age of 70. Besides inventing the "A C" automatic fire-control system, he was a prolific writer on naval affairs.
Florence Chumbecas, American dancer who appeared on Broadway several years ago in "The Band Wagon," will be married tomorrow to Harry Foster, London theatrical agent, at Marylebone Registry Office.
Selected American Shares, Inc.-Net assets rose approximately $3,500,000 during 1936 despite dividends of about $2,400,000, which included a capital profits distribution of $3.25 a share in December.

The plight of the vast metropolitan army of skiers continues to be acute because of the scarcity of snow. However, the "toe strappers" and expert runners, who have been living in hope of good skiing since the last week in December, may be rewarded for their patience this week-end, as the forecast is for snow squalls in upper New York State and New England.
The sale of Casa Genotta, Playwright Eugene O'Neill's Spanish-type residence, to Mr. and Mrs. George Alfred Cluett of Williamstown, Mass., and New York City was announced today.

The Marine Corps announced the following changes for week ended Jan. 27: Col. H. M. Smith, Headquarters Department of Pacific, San Francisco, to Headquarters, Washington, D. C.; authorized to delay in reporting to April 1.

The House passed the Ramspeck bill to put all postmasters under civil service today after an abortive revolution against the first step in President Roosevelt's plan to extend the civil service "upward, outward and downward."
Leasehold deals involving business properties on Fifth and Madison Avenues featured activity on the East Side yesterday.

Representative Joseph E. Casey, Democrat of Clinton, Mass., asked Congress today to permit the New England States and New York to enter into a compact to establish a commission empowered to regulate and enforce milk distribution.

The Group Sales Corporation of New York was forbidden today by an order issued by the Federal Trade Commission, to represent that certain products which it sells are products of well known and extensively advertised silk, acetate and rayon manufacturers when such products are not actually made by such manufacturers.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederic R. Coudert gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 124 East Fiftysixth Street. Mrs. Coudert was assisted in receiving by Mrs. Alexis Carrel Coudert.

A suit for $20,000,000 damages was filed in Superior Court today against the National City Bank of New York as executor of the estate of Percy A. Rockefeller, and against Louis R. Cheney, Hartford industrialist.

In a fourhour speech before the military collegium of the Supreme Court Prosecutor Andrey Vishinsky summed up the charges against the seventeen men on trial as "Trotskyist plotters" and concluded with a demand for the death penalty for all of them.

The New York Young Republican Club celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary last night at its annual meeting at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street. Among the honor guests were George Brokaw Compton and Benjamin Day, former Commissioner of Immigration..

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that in furtherance of his campaign to bring the calendar of the Court of Special Sessions up to date he will appoint three young city officials and a Bronx Assistant District Attorney as thirty-day magistrates, so that regular magistrates can be assigned to duty in Special Sessions.

Wholesale prices declined in the week ended on Jan. 23 for the first time since late in Octbber, 1936, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, now is 85.3, compared with 85.7 the previous week and 80.2 a year ago.

Basing its decision on the possible adverse effect on the bond market of the widespread comment in newspapers concerning the flood, the Board of Commissioners of the Orleans Levee District, La., postponed the sale of $3,784,000 of refunding bonds of the district, which was scheduled for yesterday.
Jack Bromwich, 17, Australia's latest ambidextrous tennis sensation, upset the veteran Jack Crawford in the semi-final round of the Australian championships today.
Elizabeth Burns found herself without a primary class to teach after Mayor E. E. Oliver ordered schools closed, so she is conducting a "refugee school."

The oil-purchasing subsidiaries of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday advanced the price of crude oil an average of about 12 cents a barrel, effectiv immediately, throughout Oklahoma, Texas, Kansas,
Leftist troops cleared West Park on the edge of Madrid in a surprise attack this morning, leaving the Insurgents only about forty yards of trenches in one corner.
A touching feature of the flood is its reflection of the good nature and adaptability of the Negro and his ever-present sense of humor.

Reversing Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme of Westchester, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled unanimously yesterday that the Westchester mortgage rehabilitation trustees may continue to function as trustees until their successors are designated.

On a seasonally adjusted basis, industrial activity in December advanced to a new high level for the recovery period, according to the monthly review issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
Three tons of salt were distributed among 500 Onondaga Indians by William F. Egan of Nedrow, Federal Indian agent, under terms of an old treaty.

Despite the loss of their standout center, Howie Morenz, with a broken leg, the Canadiens pulled further than ever in front in the International Division of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 to 5.

" Justice for all, special privileges for none." This has been a popular cry in American politics from the days of JEFFERSON down. During all that time, it must be admitted, the principle has been more honored in the breach than in the observance. It has been violated in the interests of separate groups, at the expense of the whole community. Let us freely grant what the partisan orators have been asserting.

Dr. George H. Locke, president of the American Library Association in 1926 and internationally known as a bibliophile, died today. He was 66 years old. Dr. Locke had been chief librarian of the Toronto Public Library since 1908.

Presiding Judge Manton of the Second United States Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Cities Service Company to stay the auction sale of more than 200 gasoline stations of the Warner-Quinlan Company, scheduled for Feb. 5.

The recent Federal court decision upholding the right of physicians to give contraceptive advice for the well-being of patients has removed the last restriction on birth control, according to speakers yesterday at the sixteenth annual luncheon of the American Birth Control League at the Hotel Roosevelt.
Major Lawrence (Biff) Jones, veteran army officer and football coach, was announced today as the suceessor to Dana X. Bible as head football coach and athletic director at the University of Nebraska.

Georges Enesco, the Rumanian composer and conductor and one of the leading musicians of the world today, appeared for the first time last night in Carnegie Hall as conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.
Before 6,000 fans, who braved threatening weather, Happy Bolivar, 4year-old gelding, beat Boilermaker today to win the-$1,200 added Linda Vista Handicap at Santa Anita Park.
The statement on the listing of securities upon the New York Stock Exchange made to the Senate subcommittee of the Committee on Interstate Commerce by J. M. B. Hoxsey today was as follows:

Tension in the lower Mississippi Valley was eased a little today as the Mississippi slowed up in its climb toward the levee tops. The river is now rising at the rate of half a foot a day, whereas until yesterday it had surged upward a foot every day.
Sir Bede Clifford, Governor of the Bahamas, will leave on Sunday for Miami to attend the running of the Bahamas Handicap at Hialeah ar Park, for which he will present the cup on Feb. 6.

Mrs. Leontine Marie Fish, a leader of the Red Cross here since 1918, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. She gave up her apartment at 15 Park Avenue when she became ill a year and a half ago and had lived since with her daughter, Mrs. Gordon W. Burnham Jr., in Manhasset, L. I.
Japan will launch a determined drive to win the Davis Cup, international world team tennis trophy, this year by competing in the North American zone with a four-man squad.

Maria Kurenko, soprano, will be heard tomorrow night in a recital of Russian songs at the Town Hall. She will sing compositions by Glinka, Dargomijsky, Cui, Glazounoff, Lourie, Metner, Rimsky-Korsakoff, Borodine, Moussorgsky, Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky.

President Roosevelt will visit Warm Springs, Ga., site of the foundation he established for the treatment of victims of infantile paralysis, early in March, if the affairs of his office permit, the White House said today.
General Kazushige Ugaki is understood to have informed the Emperor he would be unable to form a Cabinet.
More salaries, bonuses and other payments made by various corporations to officers and employes in 1935 were reported to Congress today by Secretary Morgenthau.

Trading in apartment house properties continued yesterday along the upper West Side and Washington Heights sections. The Central Savings Bank sold the four tenements at 6 to 12 West Sixty-sixth Street, about 125 feet from Central Park West. to the Sixty-six Corporation, a syndicate represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney.

The fifteenth annual benefit performance of the Vassar Club of New York will be given this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Wagner's "Lohengrin" will be performed, with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in theleading roles.
News photographers got a good feature picture at the White House today, but it cost Secretary Ickes and Senator Guffey $2 each.

Hialeah Park was thronged this afternoon for the first in a series of special races to aid the flood sufferers. Joseph E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club, has announced that other special races to swell the flood relief fund will be held tomorrow, Monday and next Friday.

The marriage of Miss Katharine Martindale, daughter of Mrs. Harry Turner Martindale of Montclair, to Richard John Pilch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic R. Pilch of Bloomfield, took place this evening in the First Presbyterian Church at Bloomfield.

A day and a half behind schedule, the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania arrived yesterday with 527 passengers, many of whom described the crossing from Southampton and Cherbourg as the worst they had ever experienced.

Miss Lila Agnew Stewart, organizer and director of pageants at charity entertainments in this city for many years, including the President's Birthday Ball, died early yesterday morning after a brief illness at her apartment in the WaldorfAstoria.

Contributions from all sections of the community, from rich and poor, flowed into the offices of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross at 315 Lexington Avenue yesterday. They brought the total that has been received there for the relief of flood sufferers to $414,093.44.

Testimony that an operative of the Pinkerton National Detective Agency, in the guise of a government officer seeking violators of the NRA Code, had "trapped" him into making reports on labor conditions at the plant of the Electric Auto Lite Company in Toledo was presented to the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage today by Charles Rigby, member of the United Automobile Workers and a "grievance man" for the union in that factory.

Bob Pastor, former New York University student, tonight realizes one of his ambitions. The Washington Heights lad, with two years of professional fighting behind him, meets Joe Louis, famed Brown Bomber of the ring, in Madison Sauare Garden.

The Colombian Steamship Line announced yesterday the retirement of Captain David T. Smith as master of the flagship Colombia and commodore of the fleet. Captain Smith has accepted a post as chief traveling inspector of the Maritime Commission, it was announced. He will be succeeded by Captain William M. Lee.

Tom K. Smith, president of the American Bankers Association, said today at the opening session of a regional bankers' conference here that the Social Security Act raised a "very major question" in the future investment of bank funds.

James E. Ten Eyck, son of the veteran Syracuse crew coach, has been appointed to the Princeton University coaching staff in the capacity of freshman crew coach and supervisor of sculling, it was announced tonight by Professor Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the university council on athletics.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced today that, in cooperation with employes, it had worked out a group insurance plan involving $30,000,000 to protect workers at its plants here and at Chicago and Indiana Harbor.
The preliminary report of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, covering the period Feb. 12 to Dec. 31, 1936, and subject to corrcetion and adjustment, was issued yesterday.

With the Ohio rising slowly again and straining to batter down its walls and levees, Cairo was more like an ant hill today than a place of human habitation. All along the twelve miles of levee protecting the city and the drainage district just outside men toiled up and down the levee slopes under the back-breaking weight of bags of sand and clay.

An offer of the American Federation of Labor to investigate the charges of members of the International Seamen's Union that the present officials of the union are not acceptable to a majority of Atlantic and Gulf Coast members was accepted yesterday.

Conde Nast gave a dinner last night at his home, 1,040 Park Avenue, for the Hon. and Mrs. Walter Runciman, who will sail for London today on the Aquitania, and later took his guests to the performance of "Samson et Dalila" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Stockholders of the Ferro Enamel Corporation approved in Cleveland on Wednesday an increase in common stock from 150,000 to 300,000 shares and a change from no-par value to $1 par. The 137,000 outstanding shares are to be exchanged share for share for the new stock.

Horace W. Schantz, former president pro tem. of the Pennsylvania Senate and a prominent figure in State politics for two decades, died at the Allentown Hospital today of pneumonia. He was 61 years old. Raised on a Lehigh County farm, he attended Perkiomen Seminary, Princeton University and then taught school. He became a member of the Lehigh County bar in 1902 and soon after began a politial career that ocntinued throughout his life.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve reserve banks showed the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank was at a new high figure for the year.

According to reports circulating insistently today, negotiations between the Vatican and the United States Government for establishing an apostolic nunciature in Washington and an American Embassy accredited to the Vatican are approaching a successful conclusion.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: Each of the following Corps of Engineers Reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 61st Engineer Battalion (Separate) (RAI)2d Lt. William H. Siegel, 325 Madison St., New York, N. Y.

Colonel Jacob Ruppert had either a collision or a conversation with the Iron Man of his Yankee baseball club yesterday, but so far as could be ascertained neither good nor ill resulted. Lou Gehrig did not sign his 1937 contract and the Colonel must risk another meeting-perhaps a series of meetingsbefore he gets the coveted signature.
The first match for the Rumson Country Club's Eastern Championship Ice Boat Pennant may be sailed tomorrow and Sunday on Lake Musconetcong, N. J., which is southwest of Lake Hopatcong at Netcong.

Stocks closed irregular with steel and oil shares strongest; turnover, 2,342,530 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly higher, corporate and foreign issues steady; transactions, $13,120,600.

Racing dates for three meetings at Narragansett Park in 1937, totaling seventy-one days, were granted today by Francis J. Kiernan, chief of the division of racing in the Department of Revenue and Regulation.
Working with temperatures comparable to the intense heat on the surface of the sun and with pressures many thousand times as great as that of the atmosphere at the surface of the earth, Dr. C. G.

Dr. James H. Kimball of the United States Weather Bureau, who has furnished weather data on all the important transatlantic flights from New York, made it clear yesterday in an address before the annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, Inc.,

Miss Sarah Jane Sanford and her fiance, Mario Pansa, were honored at dinner by Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien tonight at Villa Del Sacramento. Other guests included John Sanford, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford, Mrs. Daniel Hagood Haynes, Donna Cora Caentia,

Five men who on Jan. 21 pleaded guilty to a conspiracy to defraud the government by means of short deliveries of lumber to the WPA furniture factory at 67 Boliver Street, Brooklyn, were sentenced yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch, in the Federal Court, in Brooklyn.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $19,513,797, represented by 52 mudicipalities, but there are only two issues of $1,000,000 or more. This compares with the revised total of $17,260,508 for this week.

The key to the Jewish emigration problem in Poland is economic and social rather than political, Foreign Minister Josef Beck told the writer today. Colonel Beck spoke from his day. Colonel Beck spoke from his sickbed, where he is recovering from grippe.

The Douglas W. Paige trophy, symbolic of the team-of-four championship at the second annual Atlantic National Bridge Championships, was won last night by the team headed by Ely Culbertson. The play ended at 2 A. M.

A curious impression was given last night by the performance at the Town Hall of the exceptionally gifted Raya Garbousova, the young Russian 'cellist, who showed herself an artist of such exceptional taste, distinction and temperament when she made her New York debut in the same auditorium two seasons ago.

The nation's rubber capital, where the passive resistance protest popularly termed a "sit-down" was first applied successfully in major labor controversies, witnessed tonight an innovation, the "sit-down pass," in a B. F. Goodrich Company dispute.

Several hundred persons active in Southern societies of this city attended the annual Blue Ridge Ball last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The ball, as in past years, had been arranged for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Greene County, Va.

The police of the State of Chiapas, near the Guatemalan border, arrested a Catholic Bishop, the Right Rev. Gerardo Anaya y Diaz de Bonilla, today. The arrest ostensibly was made because he did not have permission to reside in the State.

St. Augustine's strengthened its hold on first place in the Brooklyn Division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball tournament by routing St. Michael's, 38-13, on the victor's court last night. It was the eighth triumph in as many league starts for St. Augustine's.

President Roosevelt has prepared three special messages to Congress, he announced today, but would tell the subject. of only one This deals with a report by the National Resources Committee. It had been announced that this message was in preparation.

Getting off to an early lead, the St. John's University quintet had an easy time registering its ninth victory of the season at the expense of the Crescent Athletic Club, 30-21, before a small crowd in the De Gray gymnasium last night.
The New York American six will have a new goalie in place of Lorne Chabot for the week-end games with the Montreal Canadiens, Manager Red Dutton announced yesterday.

A nominal bid of $1,000 was made at auction yesterday by P. Walker Morrison, Lazarus Joseph and Leon Leighton, trustees, in taking over the fifteen-story apartment house at 891 Park Avenue, between Seventy-eighth and Seventy-ninth Streets. The foreclosure action was brought against the Liberdar Holding Corporation and others, defendants, to satisfy a judgment of $207,468 and interest. B. Hollander Son were the auctioneers.

Henry L. Doherty, chairman of the national committee arranging balls in honor of President Roosevelt tomorrow night, wrote the President today that he was contributing $100,000 to be divided equally between flood relief and infantile paralysis funds.

A priest's concern at the absence of a faithful parishioner from mass for three successive days resulted yesterday in the finding of the body of Mrs. Anna Gorska, said to have been 95 years old, in the kitchenof her neat three-room flat at 109 Grand Street, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

Four authors of outstanding merit, whose works were considered to have been read insufficiently by the general public, were listed yesterday afternoon by the Book-of-theMonth Club, 385 Madison Avenue, as the winners of four $2,500 awards.

Joe Louis and Bob Pastor did not meet yesterday at the official weighing before the State Athletic Commission. An old ring trick of "getting the other fellow's goat" prevented the meeting, but without upsetting the equilibrium of the impassive Louis, who was to have been the victim of the.plan.
There appears no reason why Judge Mack's decision in the Electric Bond and Share case should have any important effect marketwise.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I congratulate you on your editorial "Neutrality Again." The well-intended but wholly ill-advised movement to create by act of Congress a condition of fool-proof neutrality is, indeed, as President Roosevelt has so well stated, "likely to drag us into war instead of keeping us out."

Four bandits, whose weapons included a sawed-off shotgun, a machine gun and revolvers, stole an $11,080 payroll shortly after 1 o'clock this afternoon from the offices of the Trio Dye Works, Inc., 168 East Fifth Street, here.

Free copies of Myron Brinig's new novel, "The Sisters," are offered by Farrar Rinehart, the publishers, of 232 Madison Avenue, to the first fifty persons not connected with the book business or any newspaper who write to them and agree to write a report on the book. Publication date is Feb. 1.

Housing and business properties in three boroughs passed to new control in deals reported yesterday. After an ownership of more than forty years the vacant plot 20 by 75 feet at 15 Greenwich Avenue, just west of Eighth Street and Sixth Avenue, was sold by Marie Sargousse of Paris, France, to B. Bernard. The property is assessed at $19,000 and will be improved with a one-story taxpayer. L. Tangredi, broker, conducted the negotiations by cablegram.

Following the failure of General Kazushige Ugaki to get army support to enable him to form a Cabinet, another retired general, Senjuro Hayashi, was chosen for the task today by the Emperor. Though the man made Premier is a military leader, he is a political neutral and one of the most moderate of army men, whose principal qualification is that he has not been connected with the army's past factions or feuds.

More than $3,300 has been received in the last week from 350 contributors in response to an appeal of The Brooklyn Tablet, official organ of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, for donations to aid clergy, religious and laity in Spain, it will be announced in today's issue of The Tablet.

Hope Miller, young American soprano, last night gave the last of two subscription recitals at the Steinway Concert Hall before a large audience which enthusiastically applauded the artist for her fine interpretations. Celius Dougherty supplied expert accompaniments.

Cuban exports to the United States last year exceeded $100,000,000 for the first time in six years, the Department of Commerce disclosed today. Shipments to the American market in 1936 were valued at $113,687,794, compared with $96,088,798, $78,340,317 and $56,073,845 in the three years preceding.
A bill which would make it a misdemeanor for a woman to stand in front of a bar where alcoholic beverages were being served was introduced today by Senator Edward J Coughlin, Brooklyn Democrat.

Lawrence W. Schmidt, vice president of the Administrative and Research Corporation of New York, today urged legislation to guide investment trusts, but opposed "detailed regulation" at the present time.

Motion pictures as an esthetic influence received official collegiate recognition today when the University of Illinois announced plans to give the movies a place beside literature and drama on its curriculum.

Dr. Jacob Braun, nose and throat specialist, died yesterday in the Park West Hospital after a fiveweek illness. Dr. Braun, who was 54 years old, lived at 103 Newbold Place, Kew Gardens, Queens, and had offices at 270 West End Avenue.
The signing of an agreement for a credit of [Pound]40,000,000 today in London was announced tonight by the French Ministry of Finance.

Curtailment of retail trade progress was spread over so many districts this week as the result of floods, unsettled labor conditions and recurrent storms that reports of a rise in sales from the preceding week-were in the minority, according to the review issued yesterday

The Society of the Daughters of the Cincinnati held their annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Antonie P. Voislawsky, 1,148 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Gustavus Town Kirby was elected president. The other officers chosen were: vice president, Mrs.

A special assembly of the League of Nations will be held late in May to admit Egypt to the League, according to a report from a good British delegation source, which has been corroborated in the League secretariat.

Louisville's flood dead stood at 190 tonight, its monetary loss through damage to property at about $100,000,000 and there was no danger of buildings collapsing due to undermining, Governor B. Chandler of Kentucky was told.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Turnure are among those who will entertain at the "Forty-niners Ball" at the Surf Club tomorrow night. Colonel and Mrs. Robert H. Montgomery of Greenwich, Conn., will take a party to the ball.

A truce was declared in the three-month-old J. I. Case Company labor dispute today. Company officials and representatives of the United Automobile Workers of America immediately conferred on proposals for a permanent settlement.

Making a sweep of the eight first places and yielding only two seconds, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's swimming team routed Manhattan, 58 to 11, in a dual meet at the Park Central Hotel pool yesterday.

Evacuation of the entire city of Paducah, Ky., was ordered today by State Health Commissioner A. T. McCormack after he received reports that the city was uninhabitable. Dr. McCormack said Major Vego Vanres, commanding the 125th Wagon Train, Kentucky National Guard, and the McCracken County Board of Health had informed him that 8,000 of Paducah's 32,000 citizens were still in the flooded city without drinking water, lights and heat.

Kings or the kitchen in Atlanta hotels spread a gourmet's feast today, including such trifles as turkey with truffles, but there was a catch to it. "It's more for the eye than for the stomach," explained whitecapped E. Floretn, one of the chefs whose culinary masterpieces were shown at the all-Southern Hotel Exposition.

An indictment charging murder in the first degree was found yesterday by the grand jury in General Sessions against Joseph Berger, 29 years old, of 643 Warwick Street, and Gabriel Klar, 34, of 618 Chester Street, both of Brooklyn, in the stabbing of Frank Cicero on the night of Jan. 17

The arrival of $7,372,100 of gold from England was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Reserve Bank also reported that $2,330,000 gold engaged in England about a week ago, but not previously reported, was scheduled to arrive here on Monday.

A waiter described yesterday how racketeers led by Jules Martin, who said "Jimmy Hines and the Dutchman" were behind him, spent all of 1933 trying to take over Waiters Union Local 1 at the point of a gun and make it part of the restaurant extortion conspiracy.

Miss Lydia Wellington Brown, debutante daughter of Coleman Peace Brown of Anselma, was honored tonight at a ball given by her grandmother, Mrs. Winfield A. Arter, and by her aunt, Mrs. William Baker Whelen of 1,520 Spruce Street, in the ballroom of the Barclay Hotel.

After a long session yesterday Federal Judge Caffey indicated that he would authorize on Monday the submission of copies of a plan for reorganizing the Roxy Theatres Corporation to security holders through the mails. He also said he would set a date for a hearing on it. The plan was proposed by the Pounds committee of bondholders.

Governor Frank Murphy said he felt confident tonight that important developments toward ending the 29-day sit-down strike in two Fisher Body plants of the General Motors Corporation would be announced soon.

Indiana felt better today as the Ohio River's flood crest moved slowly down stream. Diminishing stages were reported all along the State's southern boundary to Evansville where a slight rise was recorded.

The most famous pair in American racquets went down in defeat in the national doubles championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday but the son of one of them carried on the tradition of the family to gain the final round of the tournament.
Joe Louis, Detroit's Brown Bomber, won from Bob Pastor on points in the fight at Madison Square Garden last night, the New York heavyweight surprising a crowd of 18,864 by lasting the ten rounds.

Some members of Legislatures and Congress privileged to libel respectable citizens who have no redress are peculiarly sensitive to criticism by newspapers. The State Senate of Tennessee has outstripped most of these drawers of leviathan with a hook.

Forcing the service manager of an automobile sales agency to accompany them on a hold-up while he was giving them a demonstration of the car, two ingenious robbers yesterday stole a $2,000 payroll of the Nelson Brothers Coal Company, 398 Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn.

The arrangements for tomorrow's celebration of the fourth anniversary of National Socialism's accession to power are now complete. All Germany will be beflagged, and already garlands of evergreen and swastika bunting decorate the line of the procession here.

Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., announced yesterday that the directors had authorized submission to stockholders of a contract with Adolph Zukor calling for his continuance in charge of all production activities of the corporation. Mr.

The legion of "blood brothers," 116 permanent volunteers, stood ready today to give their blood on any occasion when an emergency transfusion is needed. All are members of the American Legion and represent every community in Alleghany County.

A committee of experts headed by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, was directed by President Roosevelt to go into the heart of the flood region and survey the rehabilitation started where the waters have begun to recede.

The Cuba Railroad Company, which defaulted on a $4,297,000 bond maturity on Dec. 1, last, announced yesterday that it had filed a petition under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Law in the Federal Court in Newark, N. J. The line is a subsidiary of the Cuba company.

Outside observers, both friendly and unfriendly, have contended from time to time that what has been established in Russia is not a communistic State at all, but simply a Socialistic one. It is significant that Mr. TROYANOVSKY, the Russian Ambassador to the United States, now not merely admits but insists that this is so.

Kenichi Sasaki, a tailor, was arrested today when he offered to sell to a pawnbroker six of the fifty-eight solid gold scales stolen from one of the two massive gold dolphins atop the historic castle at Nagoya. The scales were stolen Jan. 7.

Marvin Kantrowitz, De Witt Clinton High School net star and top seeded entrant, passed out of that school's eleventh annual interscholastic indoor tennis tournament at the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday. A telegram did the trick.
Track conditions will play an important part tomorrow for the Miami Beach Handicap, mile feature at Hiaieah Park,

Thomas G. Anthony of 30 Charlton Street, assistant to the chairman of the board of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company, died on Thursday in St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. He was 59 years old.

The Eastern State; speed skating championships, scheduled here tomorrow and Sunday, were called off today by Patrick B. Kearney, president of the Saratoga Winter Club, who said continued lack of snow and ice had reduced interest in the event.

The United States Steel Corporation yesterday denied on its behalf statements contained in Washington reports of a threatened strike of coal miners in "captive" mines operated by steel companies because of the probability of refusal of some of the companies to comply with the United Mine Workers of America's request for a $2 assessment against the miners' wages.

Endorsement of President Roosevelt's good neighbor policy, and acceptance of a fivepoint program to entrench world peace were the final actions taken today at the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War.

Dr. Lester K. Ade, State Superintendent of Public Instruction, called upon 103 new graduates of the Pennsylvania State College to help "awaken the social conscience of our future citizens" in an address at the annual mid-year commencement exercises tonight.

Adam Walsh, under whose guidance Bowdoin College gained the State of Maine football championship in 1935 and 1936, was among the honored guests at a dinner of Bowdoin's local alumni association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night. About 200 graduates attended the affair.

This is the last day on which to obtain 1937 license plates, which must be displayed on all passenger cars and motor trucks used after midnight tomorrow, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. pointed out yesterday.

Republican leaders in Congress today introduced resolutions calling upon the Social Security Board to recommend major changes in the Social Security Act, with particular emphasis on the size of the reserves, the postponement of increased payroll taxes and the expansion of the system to take in farm and domestic workers.

Recurrent reports of the German acquisition of Portuguese Angola were categorically denied today by spokesmen for the Foreign Office and the office of Joachim von Ribbentrop, Ambassador to London, who is in charge of the German colonial campaign.

The first in a series of six Friday evening concerts devoted to the orchestral works and concertos of Haydn and Mozart, under the sponsorship of the WPA Federal Music Project, was given last night at the project's new Theatre of Music, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street. The initial program was warmly received by a near-capacity assemblage.

Confidence that the onrush of flood waters in the lower Mississippi River can be checked between its junction with the Arkansas and the Gulf of Mexico was expressed yesterday by Eli T. Watson, head of the investment concern of Eli T. Watson Co., Inc., at 60 Wall Street.

The annual report of the Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland and subsidiaries for 1936 shows net assets on Dec. 31 equivalent to $4,194 for each $1,000 debenture, compared with $3,273 at the end of the preceding year; $1,209 for each share of Class A preferred stock, against $860 a year before, and $22.59 for each Class B common share, compared with $15.34 a year before.
Sir Percival Phillips, last of Great Britain's five official front-line World War correspondents to remain an active reporter, died of acute nephritis today at the age of 59.

New sales records were established last year by each of the three branches of the oil burner industry, W. F. Brannan, president of the Oil Burner Institute, announced yesterday. Domestic burner sales of 218,000 units were 40 per cent ahead of 1935 figures, the distillate burner sales amounting to more than 400,000 units were up 50 per

In the briefest campaign it nas held, lasting only three weeks, the New York City. Young Men's Christian Association collected $193,545 in contributions and confidently expected renewals in its annual drive for funds, it was announced yesterday at the final report luncheon of the campaign in the Hotel Commodore. The sum is 90 per cent of the campaign quota of $215,836.

With every box and table reserved and only a few admission tickets left, the annual birthday ball for President Roosevelt tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria promises to eclipse in attendance and brilliance the three previous balls given for infantile paralysis relief.
With several outstanding contender scratched because of the off-going, H. C. Hatch's Sweepstaff annexed the $1,500 El Camino Real, at a mile and one-sixteenth at Santa Anita Park today.

Thirteen of the seventeen defendants in the "Trotskyist" treason trial here were sentenced to death at 3:30 A. M. today. The four others, including Karl Radek and Gregory Sokolnikoff, received prison terms up to ten years.

Assertions that Congress had constitutional power to protect rights of employes to organize and choose representatives for collective bargaining in cases where denial of these rights "tends to lead to industrial strife which would affect commerce" were made in briefs filed by the Department of Justice with the Supreme Court today preparatory to argument of the Wagner act test cases next month.

The New York State Bar Association was warned at its annual dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night by Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General of the United States, that democracy was being "frustrated" by the monopoly" of the Supreme Court by lawyers.

Swift Co. of Chicago have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 250,000 shares of $25 par value capital stock to be offered to employes, shareholders, customers and friends, it was announced today.

The pulp and paper industry has improved substantially, but returns are "entirely inadequate," R. A. McInnes, head of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Assooiation, told delegates at the annual meeting here today. He was re-elected to the presidency.

Judge and Mrs. Charles J. Carroll of 97 Norman Avenue, Brooklyn, and Highland Falls, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Regina Carroll, to Raymond J. Pellman, son of Mrs. Bernard Pellman of Cincinnati, Ohio.

A new department of human relations to "correlate academic studies with the actual problems of living" and consider concrete social problems in a series of "community seminars" in North Jersey centers was announced today by the University of Newark.

" You Only Live Once," Director Fritz Lang's first picture since "Fury," will be presented this morning at the Rivoli with a cast including Sylvia Sidney, Henry Fonda, William Gargan, Jean Dixon, Barton McLane and Warren Hymer.... Kay Francis returns today to the screen of the Strand in the Warners' "Stolen Holiday,"

America's five standout milers-all of whom have done 4:11 or better-made ready today for the first major meet of the new season, the sixteenth annual Prout Memorial Games of the Massachusetts K. of C. at the Boston Garden tomorrow night. The Hub probably never has had an indoor carnival with as much class as this one.

J. P. Haines, representative of the National Industrial Traffic League, contended today the "long-andshort-haul" clause of the Interstate Commerce Act imposed hardships upon industry and commerce in the Middle West.

The In and About New York Music Educators Club will meet this afternoon at the Great Northern Hotel. The third in a series of free concerts will be given tomorrow afternoon at the Newark Museum. The program will include Mary and Virginia Drane, duo-violinists, and Floyd Townley, tenor.

Secretary Perkins announced early today that Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, had rejected her proposal that a conference be held over the week-end between union and management for the purpose of finding a basis for resumption of negotiations for the settlement of the automobile strike.
A joint committee of both houses of Congress was set up today to consider President Roosevelt's recommendations for the reorganization of the Federal Government.

Miss Sibyl Cram of Bangor became the bride of John J. B. Fulenwider of Parlin, N. J., today at the home of her parents, Wingate Franklin Cram, president of the Bangor Aroostook Railroad, and Mrs. Cram.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Curtiss of Norfolk have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Curtiss, to Herbert Scoville Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Scoville of Hill House, Taconic, Conn., and New York.

Roxbury defeated Hopkins Grammar School of New Haven in basketball today, 40 to 20. Zilly and Hayden played well on the offense and Wilson and Bruett on the defense for Roxbury, while Naimo was best for Hopkins. The score at half time was Roxbury 15, Hopkins 8. The line-up:
James Franklin Elder, a thirty-third degree Mason and dean of the Most Wise Masters of United States Masons, died today at the Edgemere Hotel here after a brief illness. He was 88 years old.
President Roosevelt appointed a committee to direct flood rehabilitation, and stated at a press conference that he favored giving the Department of Labor the power of subpoena in labor cases.

Samuel Greenbaum, owner of hat factory at 7 Elizabeth Street pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday in the so-called "ashcan hat" racket and was fined $50 by Justices Hackenburg, Brady and Renaud.
Seven candidates for membership In the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York have been approved by the executive committee, of which Richard W. Lawrence is chairman.

Prices of farm products made two new high records today at the Department of Agriculture. Officials here said the general level of farm prices on Jan. 15 was the highest since June, 1930, and that the level of prices paid to farmers

Enrique Giraud Carreno, a member of the outlawed Joven Cuba, was condemned to death by the Urgency Court today for complicity in the kidnapping of Antonio San Miguel, elderly vice president of the Guantanamo Eastern Railroad, on June 5, 1935.

Victories over teams which are well down in the standing kept the New York A. C. and the Harvard Club tied for first place in Class of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League yesterday, each with twelve triumphs and two defeats.

Designed to show the full capital investment of the Dominion Government in the property but not the valueless common stock nor advances to meet deficits or interest on advances, the proposed new capital structure for the Canadian National Railways was presented today to the House of Commons by C. D. Howe, Transport Minister.

Two of Broadway's more-popular shows are going away after tonight's performances, both of them heeding the siren call of the road. Item A: "Idiot's Delight," with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, the play by Robert E. Sherwood which picked up the Pulitzer Prize last Spring and has had two New York runs to a total of 300 times.
George E. Fichtner, president of the Boonton Full Fashioned Hosiery Company and former director of the Boonton National Bank, died on Thursday night in the Cornell Medical Center, after an operation.

A last-minute appeal to Chancellor Adolf Hitler to cooperate with the rest of Europe was delivered by the Chancellor of the Exchequer and prospective Prime Minister, Neville Chamberlain, tonight on the eve of the Chancellor's anxiously awaited speech to the German Reichstag.

The Board of Estimate agreed yesterday to appropriate $650,000 for enlargement of the Willets Point Boulevard station of the Queen I. R. T. elevated to provide additional transit facilities for the World's Fair.
The bond market, as reflected in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, turned hesitant and irregular yesterday, following its gains of the preceding two days.

Spokesmen for various organized labor groups were cheered by more than 5,000 trades unionists at a mass meeting at St. Nicholas Palace, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street, last night when they denounced Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of "racketeering" in labor unions. Every mention of Mr. Dewey's name was booed.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, visited the headquarters of the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association at 138 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon to aid the organization's 1937 campaign to raise $150,000 in budgetary funds.

A miniature tidal wave, pushed from the broad expanse of Pamlico Sound by a northwest wind of near hurricane force, surprised the residents and did considerable damage in Hatteras Village, ninety miles northeast of here, early today, according to a telephone message from Richard Daily, veterann observer at the weather station there.

Police Lieutenant Joseph L. Unger died at his home, 216-11 Fortythird Avenue, Bayside, yesterday morning. He had been ill four months, following an operation. Lieutenant Unger was born in Manhattan sixty-two years ago and had lived in Bayside about fifteen years.

A warning that today's sentiment may afford tomorrow's laugh seems sadly implicit in the exhibition of old valentines which the Museum of the City of New York will open to the public this morning. The deceptively dignified Georgian exterior of the museum, at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, conceals for the moment a sort of Cupid's bower in which are displayed antique missives of paper lace and affection that have long outlasted their senders.

Application of the Middle West Corporation for acquisition of 12,687 1/2 shares of no par common stock of the Missouri Gas and Electric Service Company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A majority of Congress voted today that Representative Pedro Vergara of Rio Grande do Sul had not sufficient evidence in support of his charge yesterday that Representative Paulo Martin of Rio de Janeiro was representing Argentine interests in combating legislation for wheat cultivation in Brazil.

Exact laboratory methods for testing the performance of airplanes under various conditions, similar to those now employed in the testing of automobiles, were urged yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, at Columbia University, by E. P. Warner, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Aeronautics.

The perennial plan to fix the date of Easter and all other movable fetes is back in the hands of the League of Nations' permanent advisory committee on transit and communications, to which it was referred for further study by the recent Council session.
A blanket of gas from punctured mains covered the inundated waterfront tonight with what Fire Chief Barney Houston described as "a fire peril more deadly than anything Cincinnati ever faced before."
Continued storms at sea, floods and icy winds rapidly pushed up tonight Europe's death toll from the wintry weather of the last few days.

The Engineers Public Service Company, including subsidiaries companies, in a preliminary report for 1936 shows a balance applicable to all classes of stock of the company, after all deductions, $2,946,392, compared with $1,605,867 in 1935. The preferred dividend requirements of the company for 1936 totaled $2,323,537, unchanged from 1935.

The stock markets were influenced today by the ending of the account. Only a small volume of business was done, although one or two sections displayed some activity. Recent new issues and a number on the way also were blamed for the falling-off of business on the Stock Exchange.
Clergymen will preach tomorrow on the flood in the Middle West, offer prayers for the flood sufferers and urge their parishioners to contribute for the relief work being. carried on by the Red Cross.

John J. Meade of 512 West 112th Street, secretary to the Manhattan Department of Public Works since 1926, died in Harlem Hospital yesterday from a fractured skull. Mr. Meade slipped while ascending to his second-floor apartment and fell to the concrete floor of the hallway. His age was 42.

A suit charging non-support and seeking $100,000 damages was filed in Superior Court today by Mrs. Mary Prendergast Towne against her divorced husband, Joseph Merdith Towne. She contended that the divorce which Mr. Towne obtained in Reno, Nev., was illegal in Connecticut.
The advance in crude oil prices begun in the Southwest on Thursday by the subsidiaries of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey was met yesterday by virtually all other oil companies in that area.

Contracts totaling $26,147 were awarded by the Navy Department today for construction of these works: F. T. Crowe Corporation of Seattle, for a dumbwaiter at the Puget Sound Navy Yard Hospital, $1,547. Tarello Tile Company of New Bedford, Mass., for terrazo floors at Newport (R. I.) Hospital, $1,785.

Leaders of the Pacific Coast maritime unions announced last night that the end of their strike was in sight and that a vote of the members of the seven affected unions would be called on the offers made by the shi lines, according to The Associated Press.

The Board of Estimate of New York City unanimously passed a resolution introduced yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor, calling for the appropriation of $250,000 to go to the American Red Cross for flood relief in the Ohio and Mississippi valleys.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 972,000 bales, against 916,000 a week ago, 927,000 two weeks ago, 920,000 three weeks ago and 741,000 a year ago; of which American 398,000 bales, against 374,000 a week ago, 364,000 two weeks ago, 339,000 three weeks ago and 389,000 a year ago.

Mgr. David J. Hickey, Vicar General of the Brooklyn-Long Island Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, who suffered a heart attack last Sunday after celebrating the- 10 A. M. mass in St. Francis Xavier Church, Sixth Avenue and Carroll Street, Brooklyn, of which he is pastor, was in a critical conedition last night in the church rectory at 225 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn.

The Very Rev. Hughell E. W. Fosbroke will complete on Monday twenty years as dean of the General Episcopal Theological Seminary, Chelsea Square. The official celebration of the anniversary will be a testimonial dinner that evening at the seminary to be given in his honor by its trustees, faculty and students.
The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced only 0.1 point in the last week to 138.2 on Tuesday from 138.1 (revised) the Tuesday previous.
Three indictments accusing twenty persons of election fraud conspiracy in the Nov. 3 general election were returned today by a Federal grand jury investigating alleged vote juggling.
Overcoming a half-time deficit of 27--18, the Columbus Council K of C. quintet repulsed the Seventh Regiment team, 41 to 39, in an Eastern Athletic Club League game on the latter's floor last night.

The estate of Mrs. Rebecca A. D. Swope, widow of Luther Swope and sister of the late Ella Virginia von E. Wendel, last of the Wendel sisters, increased $1,439,425 in value since June 2, 1932, when the estate was appraised. It was valued at $18,143,012 on Jan. 23, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.
Frankie Terranova, 131 1/2, East Side, halted Lew Feldman, 133 1/4, Brownsville, in the fifth round of the main bout of the boxing show at Henderson's Flatbush Arena in Brooklyn last night.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

A special committee of two architects and an engineer, appointed by Mayor Neville Miller of Louisville, Ky., has inspected the store building of the Kaufman-Straus Company in that city and has found the structure is in "no danger whatever,"
William P. Abbott, one of the patrons of the Boy Scout movement in Rockland County, died at his home here last night. Mr. Abbott was a retired lumber dealer of St. Paul, Minn. His age was 81.

Strong opposition to the Tydings-Miller "resale price-maintenance" bill, which would permit manufacturers to fix retail prices of their products, was expressed at a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee today by Major Benjamin H.

William Hogarth Hill, vice president and director of the American Radiator Company and chairman of the board of the Fox Furnace Company, an affiliate of the former corporation, suffered a heart attack in the elevator of the American Radiator Building, 40 West Fortieth Street, yesterday morning and died in his office on the sixteenth floor.

Major Lawrence (Biff) Jones, who was named head gridirion coach at Nebraska yesterday, is the second army officer to abandon a military career for football in the last year or so. Major Robert Neyland retired to become football coach at the University of Tennessee last season.

Wagner's "Lohengrin" had its second presentation of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance, a special one, was given in aid of the Vassar College Scholarship Fund before an enthusiastic capacity audience.

The most striking fact in the initiation of the "new educational adventure" at Harvard is that the president of another leading university (Princeton) was invited to serve as chairman of a commission to give expert advice as to the creation of a. new type of graduate school, and that he not only accepted but, with his associates, presented recommendations upon which in large part the plans for the new school will be based.

The Rev. Edward M. Weigel, the oldest Redemptorist priest in the United States and believed to be the third oldest in the world, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, the Bronx, as a result of a paralytic stroke suffered on Jan. 15.

Miss Helen Margaret Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles I. Johnson of Mount Vernon, N. Y., was married to Robert Lee Coshland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee B. Coshland of 415 Central Park West, last evening at the Hotel Delmonico by Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott of the Society for Ethical Culture.

The Board of Estimate reaffirmed its stand yesterday against the proposed construction of an electric generating plant at Brooklyn College, but Mayor La Guardia, ardent proponent of the power project, announced that he had not yet given up his fight.
The St. Francis College basketball team defeated Seth Low, 34-24, on the Columbia University court last night. Pat Gleason, right guard, led the scorers with 11 markers.
Mrs. G. L. Steer, wife of one of the special correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Ethiopia during the ItaloEthiopian war, died in childbirth in London tonight.

Roger Livesey, leading man to Ruth Gordon in "The Country Wife," playing at Henry Miller's Theatre, married yesterday morning Ursula Jeans, English stage and screen star. The ceremony was performed in "The Little Church Around the Corner," by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, in the presence of Miss Gordon.

Pursuant to the recent action of he New York Clearing House in ?oting to put into effect on Monay a schedule of charges for the service of receiving or delivering securities, the Federal Reserve Bank of New fork announced yeserday that it would impose similar charges, also effective on Monday.

Karl D. Gardner, vice president and general manager of the W. T. Grant Company, was elected president of the company at the meeting here yesterday of its board of directors. He succeeds B. A. Rowe, who has MEYER retired from- the presidency, but who will continue his affiliation

New York State is more vulnerable to floods than even the Mississippi Valley, although it is not threatened at the present time, the State Flood Control Commission asserted today in its first annual report to the Legislature.

A project for putting the full force of the taxing power of the Federal Government into the drive for re-employment was discussed in expert quarters here today after President Roosevelt confirmed reports that he was seriously considering new legislation dealing with the employment situation, but added that his mind was still open as to method.

Honus Wagner, commissioner of semi - professional baseball, announced yesterday completion of plans for an international series next year, with championship teams of the United States, Canada, Mexico and Cuba competing.
Wagner College's basketball team rallied late in the game but lost to Hamilton, tonight, 42 to 40, in the last few seconds.

Following orders to the army to enforce a price of 27 cents for gasoline, American and British companies agreed tonight to permit sales at this rate per gallon for fifteen days. The government meanwhile will check their books to verify the cost of the product.
Sixteen-year-old Louis Johnson was reported recovering in a hospital here today after surgeons had removed the end of a broom handle ski pole upon which the youth had been impaled.

Retail trade here was brisk during the week, with practically all departments sharing in the increase over last year's figures for the comparable period. Department store executives estimated the average gain at around 15 per cent, with the comparative level of trade
Refreshed and apparently in fine shape after recuperating from his long illness, Associate Justice Harlan F. Stone returned to Washington today.

The interest of New York, at any rate youthful New York, in small aircraft, aircraft engines and the many instruments and other aids to flying was shown yesterday as eagerly questioning young folk crowded around the shining exhibits at the National Aircraft Show in Grand Central Palace.

College students are again forsaking the professions for business and industrial employment, according to an analysis of seniors' plans at Yale University made by Ralph R. Wolf Jr., senior placement assistant in the Department of Personnel Study, in The Yale Alumni Weekly.

A 3-year-old boy who liked to see fires and play with matches last night started a bonfire with the afternoon newspapers in his bedroom that led to the death of his 4-month-old brother, asleep in his crib in the room.
The imminent danger of civil war in the province of Shensi, precipitated by the kidnapping of CHIANG KAI-SHEK last December, has been averted or at least postponed.

By lunch time today England had scored 18 runs against Australia without losing a wicket in the first innings of the fourth cricket test match. The Antipodeans were dismissed in the morning for 288 in their first innings.

Ossie M. Solem made his first appearance here today in his new capacity as head football coach at Syracuse University. He arrived early this morning following a speech before the Rochester Alumni Club last night.

The marriage of Miss Rosalie M. Knapp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Spring Knapp of 300 Park Avenue and Roslyn, L. I., to Joseph Charles Dey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Charles Dey of Norfolk, Va., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Brick Presbyterian Church.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to listing the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company's nopar common stock. The Exchange has been notified by the Guaranty Trust Company of advice to the Guaranty that an extraordinary general meeting of shareholders of the Triplex Safety

The annual earnings of the National Steel Corporation last year were the largest in the history of the company, according to the preliminary statement announced yesterday. The net profit for 1936 amounted to $12,541,842, after Federal income taxes and other charges, including provision of $629,307 for Federal undistributed profits tax, the report disclosed.
The Federal Reserve Board met again today to consider the possible danger of an inflationary credit expansion in the country's bulging supply of idle bank funds.
Rockefeller Center, Inc., filed plans yesterday for roof gardens on top of the Radio City Music Hall and the Center Theatre. The improvement will cost $37,000.

Pierre Lyautey, French journalist and author of several books and pamphlets on Morocco, arrived yesterday on the French liner Lafayette on his way to South America, where he will deliver lectures at Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires on European conditions, including the Spanish civil war.

Reorganization of the Home Title Insurance Company, Brooklyn, based on a plan of deferment of claims and part payment, will be recommended by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, he announced yesterday, if the creditors virtually are unanimous in favor of such action.

Charles Marcil, dean of the House of Commons, died early tonight after being confined to his bed several weeks with a heart ailment. He was 76 years old. The veteran parliamentarian, Liberal House member for Bonaventure continuously since 1900, was unable to take his seat this year.

Special meetings of stockholders of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its subsidiary, the Mohawk Hudson Power Corporation, called to approve a consolidation of the two companies, were adjourned yesterday until 1 P. M. today in order to provide for uninterrupted trading in securities on the New York Curb Exchange.

Under active month-end calling by spinners, prices on the cotton market in Liverpool continued strong yesterday. The near months on the Cotton Exchange here held within narrow limits, but in contrast with arbitrage buying and mill price-fixing in March the 1937 crop months were under pressure.

IT was a baseball gathering, but the talk was about fights, and Al Schacht soon had the floor. He needed all of it because he was not only describing a fight famous in baseball annals but going through the motions. His subjectmatter was the one-round collision between Ty Cobb, the Georgia Peach, and Billy Evans, the elegant arbiter of those days.
About 3,000 were thrown out of work today when the General Motors plant here shut down because strikes in Eastern factories of the corporation had halted supplies of materials.

One signed contract was deposited on the desk of Business Manager Ed Barrow of the Yankees yesterday, but an unsigned one, accompanied by a letter which arrived at the same time, was far more-important.

A second-degree assault indictment against Vito Marcantonio, former Representative in Congress from the East Harlem district, and one of his Republican aides, John Salas, was dismissed yesterday by Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions on the recommendation of Irving Mendelson, Assistant District Attorney.

The Pennsylvania Railroad announced tonight that twelve pieces of fire-fighting apparatus and 100 firemen would be taken to Louisville tomorrow night from Harrisburg and Pittsburgh. One engine left Harrisburg tonight and another will be loaded at Altoona tomorrow morning and proceed to Pittsburgh.
On Thursday the House of Representatives passed without a roll-call the bill putting all postmasters in the classified service. But first there was a strong showing of discontent with the measure.
Turpentine firm, 42c; sales. 27 barrels; receipts, 202 barrels; shipments, 178 barrels; stock, 30,624 barrels.

Twelve big navy sky cruisers bored through a terrific storm that momentarily stopped them "cold" and sailed into Honolulu today to complete with military precision the greatest nonstop ocean mass flight ever attempted.

Hog prices were steady to 5 cents lower, the demand being slow, which offset the effect of a falling off in the movement. The top was steady at $10 a hundredweight, which was paid sparingly and the practical top to all interests was $9.85.

The recent weakness of the French franc on the international exchange market was followed on Thursday by advance in the French bank's official discount rate from 2 per cent to 4. It had been reduced from 5 to 2 since the franc's devaluation.

Six sanitary engineers attached to the New York City Department of Sanitation will leave Newark by airplane today to supervise emergency sanitation administration in the flooded areas of the Ohio Valley. The engineers will report for duty at Louisville, Ky.

A service of thanksgiving to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the consecration of Samuel Provost, first Bishop of New York, and William White, first Bishop of Pennsylvania, will be held Thursday at 10:30 A. M. in old St. Paul's

The struggle between man and the river continued here today.
