Inside the walls a pick-and-shovel army of relief workers struggled to keep pace with the steadily rising Ohio, now close to the top of the original sixty-foot levee which has been raised three feet by erecting a jerry-built window box along its entire length.

Mrs. Myrtle Huddleston was the mother of an 11-year-old boy when she succeeded in her third attempt to conquer the twenty-odd-milewide Santa Catalina Channel on Feb. 6, 1927. She had taken up swimming less than a year before as a means of reducing.

The greater part of the fund gathered in memory of King GEORGE V is to be devoted to the provision of playingfields everywhere in town and country where the children may "play in happiness and safety for all time."

Ordering yesterday the reinstatement of a patrolman dismissed by Police Commissioner Valentine, the Appellate Division warned the Commissioner that there must be proof of guilt before any punishment may be inflicted.

With their automobile headlights illuminating the scene, two armed men, wearing black masks, invaded the Lyndhurst Auto Sales Company, 50 Park Avenue, at 8:45 o'clock tonight and shot dead its proprietor, Frank Paolillo, 40 years old, of 80 Herman Street, East Rutherford, N. J., known to the police as a racketeer during and since prohibition.

The Federal Government lost yesterday another move in its attempt to obtain surplus funds of old Russian insurance companies here. The Appellate Division unanimously dismissed the government's suit for $332,994 held by the Manhattan Company, as agent or depositary of the old Northern Insurance Company of Moscow.

The Alaska Rural Rehabilitation Corporation, administrator of the Federal farm colony in the Matanuska Valley, filed suit in Federal Court today demanding $3,000 worth of personal property from Charles E. Ruddell, described by Manager Ross L. Sheely as "the most expensive colonist."
Approval of an agreement for the merger of the Savings Bank of Central Queens into the Jamaica Savings Bank was announced today by the State Banking Department.

Officers of county organizations of the American Labor party were announced yesterday at State headquarters of the party, 151 West Fortieth Street, indicating that this new legal party intended to take an active part in the coming city campaign. The county officers follow:

Indications that President Roosevelt would back Secretary Perkins in her demand for the right to subpoena parties in labor controversies were given today at a White House press conference at the same time that William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared his disapproval of any such legislation.

Federal agents announced today they had squelched before it could be executed the plan of a 38-year-old school teacher to extort $10,000 from Edward G. Bremer, St. Paul banker, who was kidnapped in 1934 for $200,000 ransom.

The Pope's condition has not improved since the turn for the worse set in yesterday. Not only has there been a recrudescence of pain in both legs, especially the left, but the varicose process again has gained ground in the right leg and the pain is reported to have spread to his arms also.

Two sales on the Palmer estate at Port Cheater, N. Y., completing the sale of the property were announced yesterday by brokers. The place consisted originally of 135 acres and four residences, occupied by the late Nicholas F. Palmer,
A deal is reported pending for a long lease on the property at the southwest corner of Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street, extending over to Seventh Avenue. The owner is the Wendel Foundation.

The lives of domestic animals, such as dogs and cats, have been altered by humans, therefore they should receive more attention from humans, Fannie Hurst, the novelist, declared yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the New York Women's League for Animals.

Robert Rand, Acting Corporation Counsel for New York City, today challenged the jurisdiction of the United States District Court in proceedings for reorganization of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad.

Ward's Reports, Inc., estimated today that output of the motor-car plants for the current week would total 76,620 units, which is a slight increase over last week's, estimated at 73,509 cars and trucks. Production for the same week a year ago was 90,195.
The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for the common stock of the Samson United Corporation, and for the common stock of the Union Wire Rope Corporation.
Part documentary film, part propaganda, "Spain in Flames," at the Cameo, is a grim and horrible record of the ravages of the Spanish civil war.

Combining long drives with deadly putting, Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., defeated redhaired Miss Patty Berg, 3 and 2, today in the 36-hole final of the Charlotte Harbor Championship of Champions.

Americans must meet the propaganda of communism with man for man, parade for parade and, if necessary, with bullets for bullets, the Rev. Edward L. Curran, president of the American Committee Against Communism of the International Catholic Truth Society,

The youth who daily further from the East Must travel Wordsworth. And, in the autumn of '89, I stepped into a sort of waking dream when I took, as a matter of course, the fantastic cards that Fate was pleased to deal me.

Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, announced today that the fund has withdrawn from the convention of the department of superintendents of the National Education Association in New Orleans because of discrimination against Negro members. The convention is to be held Feb. 21-26.

Fire started yesterday morning in a cargo of cotton aboard the Clyde Mallory liner Shawnee, on the way from Miami and Jacksonville to New York, causing her master to send a wireless call for help. Two hours later he flashed word that the fire had been put out and all was well aboard. Five ships had reached her side.

Heinrich Himmler, commander of the German police, revealed in an intervied appearing in a Berlin newspaper today that some prisoners in concentration camps will never be released. "There are two classes of men in concentration camps," he said.
Manhattan College and Long Island University, both unbeaten on the Hippodrome court, will attempt to keep their records unblemished in the basketball double-header at the Sixth Avenue arena tonight.

Emphasizing that the manage. ment of the New York- World's Fair for 1939 is in -the hands of business men, Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair, urged members of the Bond Club of New York at a luncheon yesterday at the Bankers Club to support the campaign for the sale of $27,829,500 debentures.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad asked authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission today to borrow $5,000,000 from the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York and to issue a promissory note for the same amount.

Miss Aleen Cust, first woman member of England's Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons, died suddenly here today. She arrived from England on Jan. 5 to spend the Winter here. Born in Tipperary, Ireland, fiftyeight years ago, Miss Cust was a sister of Sir Charles Cust, third Baronet of Brownlow.

J. C. Lyons of the New York A. C. was one of the victors yesterday as the M, M. Sterling squash tennis tournament got under way at the New York A. C. courts. Lyons captured his first-round match from Donald Lawson of the Crescent A. C. by 15-7, 18-14.

Under the ever-heightening impact of the Ohio River's vast flood, the Mississippi rose slowly last night as along 1,000 miles of its course men fought to hold the levee line. Army engineers, making ready for the possible evacuation of bottom-landers, ordered the removal of household goods and ivestock along a 150-mile-long area extending from Hickman, Ky., to the mouth of the White River in Arkansas.

Airplanes, extinct monsters and mosquitos were among the nearly 500,000 specimens added last year to the collections of the National Museum, a branch of the Smithsonian Institution, according to the annual report of Dr. Alexander Wetmore, director.

Senator Ellender, Democrat, of Louisiana, today said that he had receiped an opinion from the Securities and Exchange Commission that the Johnson Act did not prohibit sales of Canadian Government bonds in the United States.

The Rev. Dr. John R. Crosby, rector of St. Luke Protestant Episcopal Church, Seaford, and author of several books, died today. He was 54. Dr. Crosby passed much of his life in India, where he was affiliated with the Indian Government Archaeological Survey.
Payment of $398,000 in overdue interest by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was d allowed today in an order signed by Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the Federal Court.

The 111th anniversary reception and ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore. More than 1,000 members of sixty-six historic military organizations, wearing uniforms recalling every American war fought since the Revolution, took part in the grand march.
The former Lowe property of 400 lots on Plainview Road, Hicksville, L. I., has been sold to the Commuters Housing Corporation for development, the Lewis Land Corporation reports.

The United Hunts Racing Association will hold its annual Spring meeting over its course at Roslyn, L. I., June 12, it was announced yesterday following a special meeting of the board of directors. The date is subject to the approval of the hunts committee. The meeting, called by Preidens Raymond Guest, was held at the Recess Club. In addition to making plans for the Spring meet, Mr. Guest welcomed the three newly
Motor vehicle accident deaths reached an all-time record total of 38,500 in 1936, the National Safety Council said today, exceeding the nation's previous mark of 37,000 set in 1935.

Holding their opponent scoreless for the first sixteen minutes of the last half after trailing by 15-9 at the intermission, the Pratt Institute basketball forces rallied to subdue the Lowell Textile five, 32 to 23, for their ninth success in ten starts on their home court last night.

The condition of the marrow of the bones of Tyler Hewitt Bennett, retired insurance agent who died on Thursday at the age of 70 in Reconstruction Hospital, "highly suggests radium poisoning," Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales, Acting Chief Medical Examiner, said yesterday after an autopsy.

LOUISVILLE--Clearing of debris-littered streets was started as the flood waters gradually receded. Small cavities were ap-. parent in several streets. Dr. J. B. Buschmeyer, hospital superintendent, said he believed the dead numbered 400. Officials reckoned the damage at $100,000,000. Care of the homeless is a major problem. HICKMAN-The Mississippi, rising an inch an hour, ascended to within 16 1/2 inhes of the top of a 60-foot seawall.

Captain James M. Calllcutt of Fort Hamilton last night won the military jumping competition which featured the first informal horse show given by the Metropolitan Equestrian Club at the Squadron A Armory. Mounted on his big hunter, Ard Patrick, he topped a big field over a difficult course of ten jumps.

Those reporters whose business it is to interview Speaker Bankhead daily on House business have definitely gathered he is at heart opposed to the request of Secretary of Labor Perkins that the power of subpoena be extended to her department.

The registration provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935, bringing under government regulation holding companies that control billions of dollars of interstate gas and electric business, were upheld as constitutional yesterday by Judge Julian W. Mack in the United States District Court.

" Roundlot" sales on the New York Stook Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 21 amounted to 9,689,160 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. This compared with 7,725,430 shares in the preceding week.

Sinking fund and redemption operations scheduled for March 1 and affecting the holders of three issues of bonds of the government of the Argentine nation have been announced by the fiscal agents for the respective loans.

Members of the Vassar Club of New York, of which Mrs. Arthur Butler Graham is president, will give their fifteenth annual luncheon today at the Waldorf-Astoria. Michael MacWhite, Minister to the United States from the Irish Free State, and William H. Edwards, trustee of Vassar College, will be the speakers.

Passengers sailing today for a Mediterranean cruise to Egypt, Palestine and Syria on the Italian liner Roma include Mr. and Mrs. Chester Braham, Mrs. J. D. Buhrer, Mrs. Gertrude O. Cowles, Mrs. Carter R. Darrow, Mr. and Mrs. George A. Ferris,

Rail, mail, telegraph and telephone service between the flood devastated Ohio-Mississippi Valley and the outside world was improving yesterday as thousands of utilities technical experts and workmen grappled with the problem of washed-out tracks, downed wires and drenched equipment, according to reports received in New York City yesterday.
Senator McKellar of Tennessee, an advocate of the administration's power program as represented by the Tennessee Valley Authority, today called on Dr. Arthur E. Morgan to

A bill to authorize the impression of the slogan "New York World's Fair, 1939," on all State automobile license plates for 1938 and 1939, was introduced today by Senator John J. Dunnigan and Assemblyman Herbert A. Rapp.

Two new one-year contracts signed by glass producers and the Federation of Flat Glass Workers today concluded five months' negotiations and brought wage increases to more than 16.600 men in the industry.

All records for equipment orders at an annual exhibition of the Canning Machinery and Supplies Association were broken this week, S. G. Gorsline of Battle Creek, Mich., secretary-treasurer, announced today as the 1937 show closed at the Hotel Stevens.

Heads of almost all the diplomatic missions to this country, together with government officials, army and navy officers and many members of Congress have accepted invitations to attend a dinner to be given here next Wednesday by Grover Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair 1939, Inc.

Governor Lehman telegraphed Governors Chandler of Kentucky, Townsend of Indiana and Davey of Ohio today that farmers in the western part of the State had informed him that they were ready to contribute several carloads of fruit and vegetables to the flood-stricken areas.

Going out with a brilliant, unfinished run of 73 points after Willie Hoppe had collected 98 straight, Jake Schaefer of Chicago tonight won the eighth block of the 2,500-point match for the world's 28,2 balkline billiard title, 250 to 201. The cumulative score is 2,000 for Schaefer to 1,546 for Hoppe.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Olga Tritt of 40 East Seventysecond Street of the marriage on Wednesday evening of her daughter, Miss Alva Skalmer, to Harold P. Davidson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice P. Davidson of 25 Central Park West.

George W. Mason, president, chairman of the board and general manager of the Kelvinator Corporation, was paid $193,128 by the company in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, 1936, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission's data on salaries made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
All Protestant pastors in Germany have received orders from their superiors to gather their parishioners tomorrow or Sunday to give thanks to God for granting Germany the Hitler regime.

Six thousand Buick employes will return to work on part-time jobs next week, Harlow H. Curtice, president of the Buick division of General Motors Corporation, announced today. With the 12,000 Chevrolet employes who returned to part-time work

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Cartier Gilbert Carter, daughter of George Carter of the St. Moritz and the late Mrs. Carter, to Hamilton Gates Ford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold' Stanley Ford of Ridgewood, N. J., has been announced by her father.

W. Clive Crosby, a leader in the warehouse industry in this city for the last thirty-five years, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in the Pennsylvania Station while on the way to his office from his home at 310 Shore Road, Douglas Manor, Queens. He was 65 years old.
Barney Ross of Chicago, world welterweight champion, won a ten-round decision from Al Manfredo of Fresno, Calif., in a non-title bout tonight. Ross weighed 142 1/2 and Manfredo 147.

The wheat market in Liverpool today reversed itself and advanced 1 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel on buying induced by reports that United Kingdom mills had purchased supplies of new Argentine grain now afloat.

Army engineers today ordered removal of livestock and household goods along the 150-mile stretch of Mississippi River front from Hickman, Ky., to the mouth of the White River in Arkansas in a precautionary move to assure orderly evacuation of residents in case of emergency.
Flashing spectacular long-range shooting, the Fordham University five overwhelmed St. Peter's College, 57-35, before a capacity crowd of 1,000 at Collins Memorial Gymnasium in Jersey City last night.

The Export-Import Bank disclosed today that it was prepared to extend credits up to nine months to exporters in an effort to increase cotton exports to Italy. Because of lack of foreign exchange, Italian spinners requested longer-term
Outbursts of party passion marked the Chamber of Deputies' debate on national defense today with a violence not seen for. several months.
Sir James M. Barrie's play, "The Boy David," written especially for Elisabeth Bergner, will be withdrawn tomorrow, after a disappointing London run which lasted only seven weeks.

Assessments that have been taken in official circles of the conversations held here earlier this week with Walter Runciman, President of the British Board of Trade, have served to strengthen the belief that' eventually Great Britain and the United States will arrive at a basis for negotiating a reciprocal trade agreement.

Senator McCarren of Nevada described the O'Mahoney Corporation Licensing Bill today as "power for the Federal Trade Commission to destroy corporations at will." Interrupting William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who approved the measure in testimony before a Senate judiciary subcommittee, the Senator said:

Funeral services for Miss Lila Agnew Stewart, organizer and director of pageants at charity entertainments in this city, were held yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Army Atlantic engineering contracts totaling $3,934,605 were awarded by the War Department today as follows: McCarthy Improvement Company, Davenport, iowa, for construction of dam, lock and Dam 13, Mississippi River, Rock Island, Ill., Dlstrict-$2,384,288.62.

The interior of the Magnolia Baths, a three-story frame and stucco building on the Boardwalk at the northeast corner of Magnolia Boulevard, was destroyed by fire tonight, with damage estimated unofficially at $25,000. The bathhouse was closed for the season.

A crowd of 18.864 fight fans paid $111,570 to see Joe Louis, Detroit's Brown Bomber, fight Bob Pastor, ex-collegian from Washington Heights, for ten rounds in Madison Square Garden last night. But they saw a foot race instead.

Drenching rains. sleet and sharp winds proved only casual hazards to the golf game of Jimmy Thomson today and the husky professional from Shawnee, Pa., charged home with a par-cracking 64 to win medal honors in the $5,000 San Francisco match play open.

Except for two events, both scheduled for Wednesday eveningthe debut of Lady Susanne Wilkins as a singer at the Mon Paris and the replacement by Emery Deutsch's orchestra of the Johnny Hamp crew at the Rainbow Grill-next week's cupboard appears to be completely bare of any fresh nocturnal excitement.

They sparred for several seconds before Louis threw a short left for the head. Louis toyed again with his left and drove a short right to the head. Pastor sent a straight left to the head and took a left and right to the face in the return. Pastor retreated continuously.

Miss Patricia Davidson of Nassau Boulevard gave a dance tonight at the Garden City Country Club. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Francis Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Gordon, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Jensen, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Conant, Mr. and Mrs. John Miller Jr.,

The Seward Park basketball team turned in an impressive performance yesterday as it defeated an interborough rival, Abraham Lincoln High of Brooklyn, 34 to 13, in a non-league test staged in the Seward gymnasium. Both teams are pace-setters in their respective sections of the P. S. A. L. with undefeated records in five starts.

A resolution protesting against the proposal of Commissioner of Markets Morgan to eliminate the farmers' market at Gansevoort and West Washingtor Markets in order to construct three wholesale meat buildings was passed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Central Mercantile Association at 65 Fifth Avenue.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has taken a $15,000,000 fifteenyear first mortgage on the properties of John Wanamaker, Philadelphia, it was learned tonight. The interest rate will be 4 1/4 per cent for the first five years and 4 per cent for the last ten.

The Bureau of changed to c Navigation released these orders today, dated Jan. 27: LIEUTENANTS. Bacon. B. E., Jr., the Argonaut, to Naval Air Station, San Diego, Calif., in May. Blanchard, J. W., Naval Academy, to the S-44, in May. Caldwell, R. 8., 8-31. to Naval Academy, In May or June. Copping, B. S., the S-28, to San Francisco, Calif., in May or June.

Six robbers toiled for nearly two hours early today in a futile attempt to blast open the safe of the Hamlin National Bank here while a neighbor watched from his bedroom window. Although a ten-inch hole was smashed through the heavy outer door, an auxiliary emergency lock and an inner door balked the robbers.

Climaxing several days of brilliant golf, Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, N. J., added another title to his collection when he defeated Joe Switzer of St. Louis, the medalist, in the 36-hole final of the annual Winter championship of Florida for the Ponce de Leon Cup today. permitted The score was 2 and 1.

A charge against Dr. Juljusz Szygowski, Polish Consul here, of operating an automobile without a driver's license was dismissed by Magistrate Dreyer in Traffic Court yesterday. Sidney Sussman, lawyer for the consul, contended that State courts have no jurisdiction over consular officers in cases of misdemeanor.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The celebration this week of the anniversary of the beginnings of basketball some forty-five years ago may render interesting vagrant recollections of one who, forty-one years ago, participated in the earliest college playing of the new game-at Yale in 1895-96--and continued active playing until 1902 (under more elastic eligibility rules
New bond financing this week amounted to only $29,800,000, the smallest volume for any comparable period since the week ended on Nov. 6, when $450,000 in new loans went on the market.

I STARTED off last Thursday morning for the meeting with some misgivings. The jury for the Book-of-the-Month Club Fellowship Awards was an unusually large one - about thirty members in all-and it was only natural to ask one's self whether nearly two and one-half dozen individual tastes could be brought into sufficient harmony and agreement to permit a reasonably speedy decision.
Miserable weather imposed quiet on the Madrid sector today after the Insurgents had tried in vain last night to reconquer the trenches they lost yesterday morning in West Park.

Retailers invested between $400,000,000 and $500,000,000 in advertising space last year, while national advertisers gave newspapers about $190,000,000, or approximately 45 cents of each advertising dollar spent in the principal media, William A. Thomson, director of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, told the Advertising and Marketing
KIPLING'S recollections, after the first two installments dealing with his early childhood, become inevitably a series of footnotes on his books.
Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne have returned to the Ambassador from their home in Columbia, S. C. Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Birge Jr. arrived from Ithaca, N. Y., and are at the Weylin.

With cotton-mill production declining at a period when a rise is seasonal, the adjusted index dropped more than 7 points last week. The figure now is 133.5 as against 140.9 (revised) for the preceding week and 109.4 for the week ended Jan. 25, 1936.

The unfortunate situation involving the shooting of many species of migratory birds in the West Indies, Central America and South America is disclosed in a report on international bird protection compiled by T. Gilbert Pearson, president emeritus of the National Association of Audubon Societies.
Charles E. (Gus) Dorais announced today that he had agreed to a three-year renewal of his contract as athletic director and football coach at the University of Detroit, which expires Monday.

Henri Duvernois, noted novelist, died tonight. He was 61. Henri Duvernois wrote "Guitar and Jazz Band," a comedy produced in Paris in 1924 and purchased by Ray Goetz for Broadway production. The play did not materialize on the American stage, however.
The commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "With floods and strikes, not to mention easier foreign wool markets, the wool trade here has been in a somewhat uncertain frame of mind.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, returned to New York last night after a secret conference at Washington with Secretary Perkins, at which they reviewed the deadlock between management and labor representatives in the automobile strike.
Matty Bell, ringmaster of the Southern Methodist University football aerial circus, was "more interested than I thought I would be" today in the football-coaching position at the University of Iowa.

A "voting strike" by 133 signal maintainers employed on the city's Independent Subway System was the sole discordant factor yesterday in the general election of workers' representatives, held under the auspices of the Board of Transportation, the Municipal Civil Service Commisison and a group of impartial inspectors and tellers.
Dallas and East Texas capitalists, bankers, lumbermen and timberland owners, meeting here yesterday, mapped plans for the construction of the first newsprint mill in the South.
The body of an unidentified man, shot through the heart, rolled out of the open door of a wrecked automobile as the car struck a building at 441 West Fourteenth Street just after last midnight.

Congress was asked today by a group of members of the American Bankers Association to amend the Postal Savings Act "to bring the administration of the system again within the purpose governing its establishment."

Milton Speiser, 54 years old, senior member of the law firm of Speiser Speiser at 29 Broadway, which had one of the largest negligence law practices in the country, and Thomas R. Hughes, one of his runners, were found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of attempting to tamper with witnesses in a Supreme Court accident suit last June.

Eric Herbert Coster of 445 Lawn Ridge Road, an engineer, died today in Fifth Avenue Hospital, New York, after a short illness. He was born seventy years ago in London, a son of Fredrik L. Coster, the Swedish vice consul there.

The Department of Commerce reported today a near balancing of exports and imports during 1936, attributable to the drought, which cut down exports, and to an increased industrial activity, which resulted in a need for raw materials.

This morning I wrote this about the forthcoming verdicts: "It is possible that two or three of the defendants would be spared in order to avoid extreme monolithism. The most important of the accused will in any case be condemned to death."

Mr. and Mrs. Michael Francis Hanson of 480 Park Avenue and Duluth, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Louise Hanson, to Robert Forster Wilson of Washington, son of Mrs. Clinton Gaylord Galway of Cincinnati and the late Harry Thomas Wilson.

The activities of the Maryland Casualty Company in mortgage bonds and guaranteed certificates were described yesterday morning at a public session of the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate the Guaranteed Mortgage Situation, in the State Building, 80 Center Street.

Owners of old-law tenements wishing to obtain exemption from criminal and civil liability as provided by an act recently passed by the Legislature must sign an agreement to comply with the Multiple Dwelling Law or vacate their buildings and must post a performance bond, Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post said yesterday.

Queen of South set Scottish football fans on edge today with a sensational 1-0 triumph over the Glasgow Rangers in the first round of the cup competition. The low-placed Dumfries entry played typical cup-tie football to explode the powerful Rangers' chances of duplicating last year's cup-winning feat.

The major track and field season, launched so successfully last night in Boston, will make its New York debut on Saturday when the Millrose A. A. presents its thirtieth annual indoor carnival at Madison Square Garden. The entry list looks to be the finest in the long history of the games.

Frank Goldmann Jr., 17 years old, of 10 Brookdale Avenue, Newark, who tried to climb the almost perpendicular face of Washington Rock this afternoon, sprained his ankle a little more than half way up the 200-foot eminence and was marooned on a narrow ledge for forty-five minutes until rescued by police and firemen.

The Rev. Bernard R. Hubbard, known as the "Glacier Priest," will present a travelogue on Alaska tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, for the benefit of the endowment fund of Anthonian Hall. The lecture will be illustrated by motion pictures.

The fourth Wagnerian work of the week was presented yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. On this occasion "Siegfried" was given for the second time in the current season, and, like the three other presentations, the work was witnessed by a highly responsive capacity audience.

New York University will present Dr. Hendrik Kraemer, Dutch authority on religions of the East, in the 1937 series of the Charles F. Deems lectureship in philosophy, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university.

THIS is one of the most readable and comprehensive books yet published an the subject of modern psychology and psychiatry. No other work has so successfully summed up the major characteristics of the leading schools of psychiatry and recent discoveries in relative sciences. or so skillfully dealt with controversial Issues.
Mrs. Christiana Burgess Royce, mother of former Assistant United States Attorney Alexander Burgess Royce, died Friday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Edith Royce Snyder, in Haverford, Pa.

Increased sales, better rentals and new construction augur well for the future of real estate in Westchester County. Building is the special harbinger of a brighter Spring outlook as large apartment houses again begin to cap the county's rolling hills.
One of the most popular features of St. Valentine's Kettledrum, which will be held on Saturday at the Plaza, will be the bridge and mah jong games, for which a special room has been reserved.

Exceeding even the high attendance figures forecast by officials before the market opened, registrations of furniture buyers at the trade showing here during the last two weeks reached 6,150. Officials had forecast a total attendance of 6,000 for the two weeks, which was 400 greater than any similar period in the forty-three years since the New York Furniture Exchange was established.

President Roosevelt has decided to base the administration's policies with respect to permanent neutrality legislation on the measures already introduced by Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and Representative Sam D. McReynolds of Tennessee, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, rather than on a separate measure introluced for the White House.

An all New York Athletic Club final in the New York State A. A. U. four-wall handball doubles championship was assured yesterday as two Winged Foot pairs survived the semi-final round at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A.

President Anastasio Somoza sent Rafael Huezo, assistant manager, and Alfred Gini, auditor of the Nicaraguan National Bank, to New York today by airplane to reorganize the directorate in New York. Both will serve as members of the new board.
Led by Frank Bowe, who tallied 19 points, the Loyola School basketball team turned back the Georgetown Prep quintet of Washington, D. C., on the former's court last night, 34 to 15.
Hebron Academy won an interesting basketball game from Exeter, 50 to 49, today. Exeter took a 4-to-0 lead at the start but thereafter trailed the entire distance.

Long Island University and Manhattan remained unbeaten in competition at the Hippodrome last night in the basketball doubleheader, but the Blackbirds were pressed before gaining their triumph. Washington and Jefferson gave Clair Bee's charges bitter opposition before bowing, 34-30, but Manhattan scored easily over St. John's of Annapolis, 48--26, before a crowd of 4,500.
A. W. A.--Julia Goldman, speaker on Persian art and literature, 8:30 P. M., at clubhouse. United Order of True Sisters (Junior League of Arista 36)-Installation, 2 P. M., 150 West Eightyfifth Street.

IN the early hours of June 20. 1937. the century which began with the accession of Queen Victoria to the throne will be completed. So long was her reign that the great majority of her subjects at her passing had never known another sovereign, and it Is hard to

IT is the Mediterranean cruise season. The landlocked sea, as many times in the past, is an International arena, with warships plying it and soldiers crossing it; but the cruise ships pass the zone of conflict and take their passengers to all those many places that concentrate their pleasures for the cruise visitors.
Funeral services for Joseph Sterzini, who was a member of the Metropolitan Opera Company chorus for thirty years, were held yesterday morning at the Church of Our Lady of Pompei, 25 Carmine Street.

IN the stricken flood areas of the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys last week the Boy Scouts played a notable role in rescue work. This is a traditional Scout service, as the record shows. As far back as 1913, when the organization had just about begun, its boys rendered aid to the public in flooded Ohio and Indiana.

The Committee for Economic Recovery reported to President Roosevelt yesterday that a thorough survey of the Resettlement Administration's much-criticized subsistence homestead project at Arthurdale, W. Va., had convinced the industrial leaders who make up the committee that "the Arthurdale experiment can, must and should become a pattern from which dozens of similar communities may be founded."

A committee of Congress today opened an inquiry into charges by Congressman Pedro Vergara that Congressman Paulo Martins acted in behalf of Argentine wheat interests in opposing legislation to encourage the growing of wheat in Brazil. Brazil now imports more than $20,000,000 worth of wheat annually from Argentina.

Germany was pictured yesterday as the sole threat to European peace by. three speakers who gave three opposed explanations of why that was so, at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association in the Hotel Astor. Unofficially representing Germany, England and France, the speakers admitted that the balance between war and peace in Europe rested in the actions of the Reich, but declared that the danger of conflict was not immediate.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt heads the list of patrons and patronesses for "Carnevale of 1937," to be presented by Brooklyn Camp Fire Girls, next Saturday night at Kismet Temple, Herkimer Street, Brooklyn.

Giving formal expression to National Socialist anger at the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Carl von Ossietzky, Chancellor Adolf Hitler issued today a decree signed only by himself forbidding Germans to accept any Nobel prize in the future and establishing rival prizes for Germans only. The decree reads:

Students and faculty members of Bryn Mawr College are placing increased emphasis this year on field work in connection with regular college courses and they plan to expand this activity even more in the future.
The Citizens Budget Commission warned yesterday that the city is facing a $29,000,000 increase in its running expenses in 1938 unless municipal spending is curtailed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Considering the vast sums spent on education in the United States, it is surprising how ignorant people in all walks of life, both public and private, are concerning some elementary truths of economics.

Jean J. Arens, Soviet Consul General in New York, recently received notice of his transfer to Moscow and will sail late this week. Members of the consulate staff said they did not know whether Mr., Arens had been shifted to a new post or whether his successor had been appointed.

Louis Boehm, counsel for the New York Joint Legislative Committee on the Guaranteed Mortgage Situation, issued yesterday the following statement: "My attention has been called to articles in Saturday morning's press with reference to the hearing conducted on Friday by the Joint Legislative Committee on the Guaranteed Mortgage Situation, of which Senator Lazarus Joseph is the chairman.

Showings of men's wear for Spring by retail stores will start in the last week of February, with some retailers holding off until the middle of March, reports in the local market indicated yesterday. The earlier openings this year have been made necessary by the fact that Faster falls on March 27.

So far as the Corn Belt farmer's mind is reflected in the midwinter meetings of agricultural societies there is a good deal of doubt in it over the sufficiency of the Soil Conservation Act to assure what he believes should be its major objective.

The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System today increased reserve requirements for member banks by 331-3 per cent, as follows: On demand deposits, at banks in central Reserve cities, from 19 1/2 to 26 per cent; at banks in Reserve cities, from 15 to 20 per cent; and at "country" banks, from 10 1/2 to 14 per cent; on time deposits, at all banks, from 4 1/2 to 6 per cent.

WINTER carnivals, which transform quiet mountain villages and distant college campuses into holiday resorts, are about to begin, for February with its customary crisp days and deep-drifted snow has become the traditional period of celebrating the delights of Winter sports.

The Hobart College basketball team scored its second victory of the season today, defeating Wagner College of Staten Island, 33-23. The New Yorkers were unable to penetrate the Hobart zone defense, scoring six of their eight baskets on long shots and missing twelve out of nineteen foul tries in their only opportunity to even the game.

The collection of eighteenth century French furniture, paintings, rugs, silver and decorations from the chateau of Mrs. Talbot J. Taylor near Versailles, brought $42,467.50 at auction yesterday and Friday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

MIAMI, Fla.--Interest of the vacation throng in the greater Miami area, mince late December centered upon events ashore, will turn seaward next Saturday when the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club's jubilee race is sailed over a thirty-mile ocean course.

Two men held up Abe Danziger, a butcher, in his shop at 1,965 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, late last night, shut him in his icebox and ran out with $51.50. Acting Lieutenant William McCoy of the Simpson Street station, on his way home, saw the robbery, and captured a suspect in a chase.

NEW YORK society has taken up bowling and at Rockefeller Center these Winter evenings matrons and debutantes, financiers and playboys are pitching sixteen-pound balls down the shiny surface of the alleys. The thrill.
Led by Rose with ten goals, Lawrenceville School's polo team barely defeated the Essex Troop trio today, 14 1/2 to 12, at the 112th Field Artillery armory.
Maritime union leaders called tonight for an end of the costly 93day West Coast shipping tie-up, ordering a settlement vote and recommending acceptance of tentative agreements.

BIG commercial land planes for Air France, the Gnome-Rhone powered Farman-224s, of which an interior picture appears on this page, will be put into service this Spring on the Paris-London run. Six are being built.

SOME time before the last war, there appeared in London a play called "An Englishman's Home." The author was Gerald du Maurier's brother, Major du Maurier, but the play appeared anonymously as having been written by "A Patriot."

AMERICAN HURLY-BURLY. By Ernest Sutherland Bates and Alan Williams. 12mo. New York: Robert M. McBride Co. $2.50. A review of 1936 events. MARIE TEMPEST. By Hector Bolitho. 12mo. Philadelphia, Pa.: J. B. Lippincott Company. $3.50.

The Manhattan-City College rivalry that has burned with undiminished ardor for many years will be renewed in all its flaming intensity at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday when Jaspers and Beavers clash in their annual meeting in the feature of the intercollegiate basketball double-header.

TRACK EVENTS 45-Yard High Hurdles--Won by John Donovan, Dartmouth; Ray McLaughlin, Boston, second; Bill Schmidt, Harvard, third; Sam Allen. Oklahoma Baptist University, fourth. Time--0:05.8. (Equals world record. Donovan also equalled that record in his trial heat and Allen in his semi-final.)

Led by Bobby Reinacher and Bill Conroy, who tallied 9 points each, the New York Athletic Club overwhelmed the Prudential Athletic Association, 51 to 23, in an Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League contest on the Winged Foot court last night.

The General Motors Corporation declared today that 123,724 of the 149,249 workers affected by labor troubles in its plants were supporting a "back to work" movement in several cities, and had shown their "satisfaction with current bargaining methods and opposition to strike activity."

The Rev. Gaston Septier, who was superior of the Fathers of Mercy in America, a French order, from 1898 until his retirement in 1933, died yesterday morning in the House of the Divine Providence, Old Town Road, Staten Island. His age was 85.

Robert J. Young, 16-year-old schoolboy, who disappeared Jan. 4, is alive and well in Miami, according to a postcard received today by his father, Bert J. Young, former director of public works in this city.

THE new line of 1937 commercial cars and trucks, redesigned in chassis and bodies, has been announced by the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Sales Corporation. All models have a new six-cylinder valve-in-head high compression engine of increased horsepower, placed rather forward in the chassis to make room for longer bodies on the commercial cars and improved load distribution on the 1 1/2-ton truck models.
THRITY-THREE years ago two daring men (both broke at the moment) joined forces for the conquest of Broadway. Fifteen years later they parted company. with their purpose achieved Now,

Mrs. Irving L. Cabot will be hostess in the Women's Opera Committee box on Tuesday night, when the Metropolitan Opera Association presents "Il Trovatore" as the third performance in its Brooklyn season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

"The problem now is one of finding the right people for the jobs, and not in getting the jobs," said Mrs. Marjorie P. Nield, Smith College vocational secretary. The number of positions filed with the Smith College vocational office has increased notably this year as compared with last.

Three separate and secret investigations by agents of the Federal Government sought today to determine the merits of accusations by the United Automobile Workers of America that the General Motors Corporation incited disorders here.
Mrs. John Anthony Hill of 41 Fifth Avenue gave a tea at her home yesterday for a group of women's sorority representatives from Manhattan, Bronx, Long Island, Brooklyn and Westchester.

Illiteracy is costing the United States $1,200,000,000 a year in decreased earning power, Dr. Louis R. Alderman, national director of the educational division of WPA, told 200 persons yesterday at a meeting of the Association of Educational Supervisors of WPA at the Russell Sage Foundation.

Because of the current fashion interest in the plaid motif, the Textile Color Card Association is issuing a broadcast to its members tomorrow, listing comparable colors on its recent cards to the shades in the more important tartans worn by the ancient Scottish clans.

The Rev. Martin G. Clayton, a retired Presbyterian clergyman, died at his home here on Thursday night in his seventy-sixth year after a long illness. He had been well known as an evangelist and had held pastorates in Ohio, Indiana, Kansas. Oklahoma and New Jersey, and at Romulus, N. J.
La Salle College won a hard-fought game from Providence College tonight, 47-36. The Explorers were hard pressed most of the way, leading at the half by only 21-14.

Mr. and Mrs. John Lewis Montgomery of 29 East Eighty-third Street have announced the marriage of Mrs. Montgomery'sdaughter, Miss Henrietta Wardwell, to Haley Fiske 2d, which took place on Jan. 23 at Pound Ridge, N. Y. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Y. Leming.
Members of the Brooklyn Colony, National Society of New England Women, will hold their annual philanthropic bridge on Wednesday afternoon in the ballroom of The Towers, Brooklyn.
The town of Harrison announced this week that it had finally discovered after more than half a century that Rye Lake belongs to the City of New York and should be on the town assessment rolls.
COMMENTING on surrealism in connection with the recent exhibition, "Fantastic Art, Dada and Surrealism," Charmion Van Wiegand, in the January number of Art Front, comes to this conclusion:

Edward Barnard Meyer, chief engineer of the electric engineering department of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, died here today at his home, 47 Crest Drive, after a month's illness. He was 54 years old.

Miss Jane Atherton, daughter of Mrs. Anne E. Atherton of 425 Riverside Drive, has chosen Feb. 20 for her marriage to Robert, Bulkeley Winslow of this city, son of Mrs. Lawrence Ewing of Greenfield, Mass., and the late Edward B. Winslow of Beverly, The ceremony will take place in the James Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary.

The Junior Service League of Scarsdale will give a tea dance and supper party with dancing next Saturday at the Scarsdale Golf Club for the benefit of the White Plains Hospital. If weather permits there will also be skating, skiing and tobogganing parties.

The Hutchinson River Parkway Extension, between Westchester Avenue in Harrison and King Street, at the Port Chester-Connecticut boundary, was opened to traffic today without ceremony. It- is 3.1 miles long and at the State boundary connects with the Merritt Highway, now under construction by Connecticut.
With the stock markets here closed, credit was plentiful today at one-half of 1 per cent for week-end loans. The three-month rate remained at nine-sixteenths of 1 per cent.

Dr. Ante Kosutitch, former Yugoslav Cabinet member and secretary general of Dr. Vladimir Matchek's Croat Peasant party, has returned to Zagreb from Vienna after four and one-half years' voluntary exile, spent chiefly in the United States, Great Britain and Austria. It is understood he returned in accordance with the wishes expressed by Prince Paul, the Chief Regent.
Creed has achieved a stunning collection, featuring suits having hip-length fitted jackets, straight skirts with broad shoulders and normal waistlines.
ONE would not have believed that there were so many monkeys in the world! For the layman, merely to look at the photographs in this English naturalist's book is to open the door upon amazement.

To augment their scholarship fund, member of the Mount Holyoke Club of New York have taken over the performance next Friday of the new Shubert operetta, "Frederika," which is to have its opening at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre the preceding evening.

The trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced that beginning Saturday, Feb. 13, the museum will be closed at 5 P. M. instead of 6 P. M. on Saturdays and legal holidays, except when public concerts are to be given in the evening.
Private hospitals which care for the indigent sick will receive $6,472,000 as a contribution from the city this year, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, said yesterday.

AN unusual cheerfulness, derived in part from the flurry of out-of-town sightseers now in New York, animates the narrow streets of Pell, Mott, Doyer and Bayard as Chinatown provisloners stock up with delicacies for the Chinese New Year on Feb. 11.
FOR complete proof that the Wagner music-dramas have become the bulwark of the repertoire at the Metropolitan Opera House, the bills last week and this are suggested for examination.

Consolidated net income of the Industrial Rayon Corporation for 1936 was $1,361,460 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, estimated Federal surtax on undistributed profits and other charges, according to an amended registration statement filed with the SEC.

An influx of real estate interests is one of the factors contributing to present occupancy of the building at 570 Sevrenth Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-first Street, according to Thomas M Graham, agent, who reports that within the past two years five suites have been leased to operating syndicates whose recent turnover of real eState has been the largest in the city.
With the crest of the flood yet to spill into it from the Ohio, the Mississippi River today rose to a higher stage than any level previously recorded.

Though blindness has shrouded his life with darkness, 65-year-old Peter Robertson moved unerringly about his 100-acre farm today, feeding the stock, cleaning stalls and finishing the odd chores. His step is slow but confident as he moves about, his only companion a collie pup.

A charge of attempted murder tonight faced 20-year-old Frances Finkle as the aftermath of what Police Inspector Harry Pierce declared was her unsuccessful effort "to end her mother's suffering, then commit suicide".
Two home-made bombs were thrown at the strike-troubled Titan Metal Company plant today, shattering several windows, but causing no serious damage.

In the vast spectacle planned for Flushing Meadows in 1939, attitudes and interests of women of this generation will be interpreted through the activities of the general advisory committee announced last week.

Mayor La Guardia, in a brief informal talk to 20,000 persons attending the twenty-third annual entertainment and reception of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association at Madison Square Garden, hailed the devotion to duty of the force and singled out Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine for praise.
The Federal Reserve Board announced today an increase of 331-3 per cent in reserve requirements for member banks, moving to prevent a possible "injurious credit situation" such as occurred in 1929.

A conference of persons interested in the home building industry will be held Tuesday afternoon at Essex House, Newark, N. J. The "Principle of Planning Small Homes" will be the subject of an address by Howard Leland Smith, chief architect of the Washington office of the FHA.

Miss Eugenia C. C. Gambee, daughter of Robert C. Gambee of MacDougall and the late Mrs. Gambee, was married here this afternoon in the Hobart College Chapel to Robert W. Sanders of Chicago, son of Harry A. Sanders of Greenville, Me., by the Rev. Irving McGrew, the college chaplain.

Army air manoeuvres under Winter conditions, aiming to test the functioning of the new airplanes with which the General Headquarters Air Force is equipped, will be conducted at Selfridge Field in Michigan, from Feb. 1 to 24, according to announcement by Brig. Gen. Henry C. Pratt, commanding the Second Wing of the G. H. Q. force at Langley Field, which will be responsible for conducting the tests.

Expanding business activity and industrial production resulted in internal revenue receipts of $1,864,400,781 in the first half of the government's 1937 fiscal year, ended on Dec. 31, the Treasury announced today. This was an increase of $267,127,679, or more than 16 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago.

Undamaged by the fire that started in her cotton cargo in No. 2 'tween deck hold early Friday morning, the Clyde-Mallory liner Shawnee lay at her Canal Street dock yesterday while stevedores unloaded the cargo and put on general merchandise for the return voyage to Florida.

Tommaso Tittoni, a great-nephew of the Italian statesman of the same name who died in 1931. and son-in-law of J. Arthur Nelson, president of the New Amsterdam Casualty Company, died in New York yesterday, it was learned here today.
A threegoal flurry in the third period helped the New York Americans to a 4-0 upset tonight over Montreal's crippled Canadiens in a National Hockey League contest before about 7,000 fans.

A cooperative scheme which has as its aim the improvement or modification of the present curriculum of required courses at the City College was started last week by a student council curriculum committee headed by Joel Weinberg, '37.

The thirteenth annual building management course of the Department of Business, Columbia University, will begin Wednesday evening and will continue until May 12, according to Charles F. Merritt, vice president of the management division, Real Estate Bpard of New York.

In place of the accolade annually given a group of women who have achieved distinction in their own field, the New York League of Business and Professional Women have decided to extend a modern equivalent of the laurel wreath, to men who have expedited the progress of women in the business world.
Former President Hoover expressed the opinion today that the Mississippi Valley had been prepared for the current high waters by the "costly but valuable lesson" of the great 1927 flood.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, vice chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, announced last night that grants by the committee in support of the child welfare program in Poland would enable two organizations there to feed 53,400 Jewish children daily.

Training of students for service in State and local government, particularly in Pennsylvania, will go forward at the Pennsylvania State College during the second semester as one of the functions of the new Institute of Local Government, Dean Charles W. Stoddart of the School of the Liberal Arts announced today.

About a third of the operas being presented this season at the Metropolitan have stabbing or dueling scenes; among them, "Carmen," "Faust," "Lucia," "Rigoletto," "Tosca," "Romeo and Juliet," "Die Walkuere," "Lohengrin," "Tristan and Isolde" and "Caponsacchi."

AFTER a seven and a half hour search for some of the answers to bad-weather flying, D. W. (Tommy) Tomlinson, assistant to Jack Frye, president of TWA, and his over-weather flying laboratory were forced to acknowledge defeat last Sunday.

During the first year that it has been open as a public art gallery, the Frick Collection, 1 East Seventieth Street, established by the will of the late Henry Clay Frick, was visited by a daily average of more than 460 persons, according to the first annual report of the institution, just issued.

In normal times the Mississippi and its great tributary, the Ohio, are bearers of prosperity to millions who live in the river towns and cities along their banks. On their sluggish yellow tides are borne annually--even in these days of railroad and truck transportation--more than 60,000,000 tons of coal and steel, sand and gravel, petroleum, cotton, tobacco, grain, and the finished products of thousands of factories.

The Savage School of Physical Education basketball team accounted for its fifth triumph in seven starts, repulsing the Arnold College five of New Haven, Conn., by a 50-to-27 score in the winner's gym yesterday.

FROM the great mass of scientific and theoretical papers and their discussion which occupied every minute of the three-day annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at Columbia University last week there emerged definite indications of trends in flying and the aids to flying contributed by sciences associated with aeronautics.

ALMOST twenty-two years have passed since that fateful day when the Russian Baltic fleet, led by Rozhdestvenskii, met Togo's ships at Tsushima. The decades that elapsed since the Battle of the Sea of Japan have witnessed momentous changes in the history of the so-called civilized nations.

With a hearing on a plea for Executive clemency scheduled in Albany for Monday for Alfred Volckman, 21 years old, who murdered 9-year-old Helen Glenn in Greenville, the Rev. Ernest Glenn, father of the slain child, announced today that he had been asked to help save Volckman from death on Feb. 11, but that he had declined to recommend mercy.

Recommendations that the Republican party support labor legisnation, governmental reorganization and other subjects of popular concern were adopted yesterday by the Young Men's Republican Club of Westchester County at their annual convention in the headquarters of the county committee.

The Cabinet of General Felicien SlawojSkladkowski, which enjoys the full confidence of Premier Ignaz Moscicki and Marshal Edward SmiglyRydz, the virtual dictator is menaced by a strong group headed by Colonel Prystor, Premier during Marshal Josef Pilsudski's dictatorship, and now President of the Senate.

The results of the election held by employes of the city's independent subway system on Friday, to choose seventy-nine representatives to conduct collective bargaining with the Board of Transportation, will be disclosed tomorrow, the board announced yesterday.

Vermont's unique covered bridges are gradually disappearing to-be replaced by more modern structure The flood of 1927 spelled doom for many of them, while the flood of last March, which swept through New England, accounted for others which survived the 1927 disaster.

The wide upturn in building during the past year is emphasized in a report made yesterday by E. M. Craig, executive secretary of the National Association of Building Trades Employers, with headquarters in Chicago.
Marc Aurele de Foy SuzorCote, noted French - Canadian painter and sculptor, died at his home here last night after suffering repeated strokes. His age was 66.
Purchase of the old Brinckerhoff homestead at Englewood, N. J., by the Englewood Woman's Club has been completed and the property prepared for occupancy by the organization.
FLOOD waters in the Midwest swept unrehearsed and unscheduled drama across the radio waves during the past ten days.

Governor Murphy was ready tonight to call again a joint conference of spokesmen for General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, if Federal authorities in Washington were willing to relinquish further intervention attempts in the month-old automobile strike.

Ceremonies for the unveiling of a statue of Thomas Paine in Paris, scheduled for last week, have been postponed until April, it is announced by the French headquarters of the committee celebrating the bicentennial of Paine's birth.

Real estate has taken a leading part in the New Jersey prosperity recovery for 1936, declares Thomas E. Colleton, FHA director for that State. He reports that more than 4,000 homes were erected in New Jersey during the year and of these 75 per cent were financed under the FHA single-mortgage system.
WASHINGTON. CABINET DAY at the White House. Members of the President's official family arrive singly, some by motor; others, whose offices are closer by. get their weekly constitutional this way.

AGAIN Francis Meynell has paused to observe his accomplishments. For six years ago, halfway to the completion of a century of books, he rendered an informal report of his stewardship of The Nonesuch Press, under the label of "Some Collectors Read."

Seventy-three baby pictures of members of the faculty of the College of New Rochelle will be used in a novel "beauty" contest during the week of Feb. 8 for the benefit of the library building fund of the institution, it was announced today.

DO not be misled by the title: this is not a funny book, nor one taken up with gossip and wisecracks. In spite of the conventional catchiness of the name they have chosen, and the sprightly style in which they write, the authors of this history of the year 1936 in the United States are deeply and passionately serious.

In proclaiming final abrogation of that part of the Versailles treaty "which denied our people equality of rights and degraded it to an inferior people" Chancellor Adolf Hitler announced today that to remove the last remnant of such inequality he proposed to "strip the German Reich Railways and Reichsbank of their present [semi-independent] character and put them completely under the sovereignty of the government of the German Reich."

The marriage of Miss Adele Baring-Gould of this city, daughter of Major Edward Sabine Baring-Gould of London and Devonshire, England, to Jean Baptiste Reboul took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, the rector, assisted by the Rev. Joseph E. Mills Jr. of St. James Church, St. James, L. I.

GENEVA.--The size of the world's butter and egg business can now be seen, thanks to the volume, "International Trade in Certain Raw Materials and Foodstuffs," just issued by the League of Nations Economic Intelligence Service.
THE revival of "Coq d'Or" this week at the Metropolitan is one of the musical events which signalize in this country the hundredth anniversary of the death of the mighty Pushkin.
Don Lash, the unpredictable one, forced the mighty Glenn Cunningham into one of the greatest mile races of his victory-studded career in the Boston Garden tonight.

Bob Pastor, on the record. yesterday stood out as the fifth boxer to lose and go the distance against Joe Louis, a distinction that doubtless will gain importance when the facts of his bout with the Bomber are forgotten. But he had an even greater distinction. He collected the highest sum ever paid the runner-up in a foot race.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico. THE fifteen-ton schooner yacht Vagabond stopped here recently, nearing the end of a cruise which started at Oslo last July with seven youths aboard. Six of the seven had graduated from Yale the previous June and one was "ex-35."

Home building has outgrown local enterprise and will become a nation-wide industry in the hands of a few large building companies within ten years, according to Irwin S. Chanin, head of the Chanin Organization, developer of Green Acres, the new 335-acre residential community on the Sunrise Highway at Valley Stream, L. I.

Commendation and criticism of women's organizations in a single field--that of development of good citizenship--will be voiced in a debate between the Women's Club of Maplewood and the Woman's Club of Orange on Friday at the latter clubhouse, on the topic, "Resolved, That women's clubs are using their power to develop good citizenship."
To George (Napoleon) Rucker, who retires as Mayor here next Monday, the political game is more like umpiring than pitching baseball.
Mrs. Belle K. Hughes, wife of Eugene E. Hughes, an executive of Armour Co., died here yesterday at the age of 66. She was born in Pittsburgh and came to Chicago with her husband nineteen years ago.
THE author of "The Well of English," Blanche Mary Kelly, is one of the most distinguished Catholic scholars in the field of English literature.

For two hours this afternoon Chancellor Adolf Hitler stood before the Reichstag, specially summoned in celebration of the fourth anniversary of the National Socialist attainment of power, and reviewed German policy and aspirations in the domestic and international fields.
Robert N. Stanforth of Mineola, L. I., has been elected president of the Student Council by the students of Teachers College, Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.
Several definite indications that the pursuit of scientific interests by college students in superseding that of the arts have been realized by Trinity College officials.

Inquiry into the Influences and the conditions surrounding dependent children in New Jersey was begun last week by members of the American Association of University Women, not in the nature of a crusade but to compile material which will be submitted in April to the State convention of the association for information and discussion.
A 7-month-old girl was killed and two women and two children were overcome sometime before last midnight by leaking gas in a tenement at 297 Columbia Street, Brooklyn.

Five thousand young persons are expected to converge on Washington on a four-day "pilgrimage" from Feb. 19 to 22, called by the American Youth Congress to symbolize the needs of young AmericaPresident Roosevelt will deliver a message to youth Feb. 20.

The Bolivian delegate to the Council in a note the League published today, recalls that the time limit for Paraguay's withdrawal from the League expires Feb. 24 and urges Paraguay to show its will for peace by remaining in the League.

THAT phrase about the iniquity of oblivion applies more emphatically to the plays of American writers than to almost any other product of the hand or brain of our forefathers. Of the thousands of plays written by Americans in the past two hundred years, by far the greater number have disappeared, many of them never to be recovered.

Edward J. Reilly, chief of the defense counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann in the Lindbergh kidnapping case, entered the Brooklyn State Hospital for the Insane, Clarkson and Albany Avenues, yesterday at 5:20 P. M., under an emergency commitment on a petition made by his mother, Mrs. Helen Reilly.

Jose R. Capablanca, former chess champion of the world, as representative of Cuba, and Reuben Fine of New York, invited to represent the United States, will be participants in the international tournament to be held at the third annual Easter Chess Congress of the Kent County Chess Association at Margate, England, from March 31 to April 9, according to advices received yesterday from abroad.

THE American Whist League, oldest of the national card players' organizations, decided at its directors' meeting last week to hold its contractbridge tournaments jointly with the United States Bridge Association. The decision was reached only after some debate, in which Sidney Lenz, dean of American bridge authorities, was among the directors opposing the motion.

The marriage of Miss Nathalie Beach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Beach, to John Ellis McLaury, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis B. McLaury of Ridgefield, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 207 East Seventeenth Street.

AS so aptly stated by a brother commissioner of mine, Charles A. Harnett of New York, the one black mark which seems to continue to resist the efforts of all those interested in highway safety is the death and accident rate on our rural State highways. The preponderance of these accidents and fatalities are occurring at night.

W. E. Weiss, general manager Sterling Products, Inc., packaged drug products, yesterday announced that the company through its representatives was surveying retail stocks damaged in the flooded areas and would replace such losses without charge.

The Supreme Court today decided the Swedish Government's dollar loan of 1924 was payable not in gold but in paper dollars, thus overruling the lower courts. The court also decided the current exchange rate from dollars to Swedish kroners should apply on Kreuger secured debentures.

Rocco Arema, 26 years old, of 1,645 Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, a professional boxer under the ring name of Rocco Martin, was shot and seriously wounded shortly after midnight while he was walking on West Fifty-seventh Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.
A shift to emphasis on socially applied religion has taken place this year in the program of the Smith College Association for Christian Work with a restatement of objective as follows:

SOUND is this poet's great delight. sound of word and of line. He restrains his use of alliteration and assonance by the use of the spondee of the wrenched accent to give sharpness to the line. Robert Penn Warren has originality of a kind.

The establishment of new health centers is important, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, told members of the Trade Union Institute yesterday at a meeting in the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street.
Jascha Heifetz, the violinist, said yesterday that he considered the New York World's Fair "the concurrence of every artistic impulse and achievement of which this age has been productive."

A determined fight to obtain a 25 per cent increase in the appropriation for the division of foreign trade statistics of the U. S. Department of Commerce will be waged in Washington thin week when a committee representing import and export groups and local merchants appears before the House Committee on Appropriations.

Except when dams and levees break, men and women die and let their children perish with them, not because flood waters rise too swiftly for their escape but because they leave their homes so slowly and reluctantly even after they have been warned that to tarry longer is to court disaster.

The plain inference of a series of amendments to the Missouri Old-Age Pension Act, offered in the General Assembly, is that the administration of this form of relief has resulted in political favoritism to such extent that it generally is termed a racket.
The eminent Russian composer IGOR STRAVINSKY recently directed a series of concerts in New York as guest conductor

An additional detachment of 100 uniformed Philadelphia policemen, six police sergeants and a captain, left for Louisville at 5:25 P. M. today in response to a new appeal from that city for aid in flood rehabilitation.

An official communique today announced the signing at Salamanca, Spain, on Jan. 28 of a trade agreement between Rome and the Burgos government. Details were not given, but they were generally supposed to provide for the payment of supplies shipped to General Francisco Franco by Italy by means of raw materials and agricultural products from the areas controlled by the Insurgents.

The annual luncheon of Colonial Daughters of the Seventeenth Century, to be held Feb. 9 at the Biltmore Hotel, will commemorate the anniversary of the advent of the Rev. Thomas Hooker at Hartford, Conn., in 1636.

SHANGHAI.--For the past six months Shanghai has been testing the biggest social insurance scheme ever devised in China. It is an insurance plan for ricksha pullers, and already has 41,000 satisfied members.

More than 10,000 persons attended the opening day of the New England Sportsmen's and Motor Boat Show at Mechanics Building today and, judging from the enthusiasm of the crowd and the fine show, it is expected that a new record for attendance will be established during the eight-day stay.
Colombia's coffee export trade established a new high record in 1936, the Department of Commerce reported today. It was 3,980,650 bags of 132 pounds each, against 3,876,675 in 1935.

John B. Packer, an insurance broker, died of a stroke Thursday at his home in Wynnewood. Born in Sunbury, Pa., he was a great-nephew of Senator Simon Cameron, Secretary of War in President Lincoln's first Cabinet.

OFFICIALS of major steamship lines last week endorsed a plan, to become effective tomorrow, which removes Quarantine as a compulsory way station for all ships entering New York Harbor that have touched foreign ports.

The Duke and Duchess of Sutherland, who had been at the WaldorfAstoria since their recent arrival from London, left yesterday for a visit with Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien in Palm Beach. Mrs. Miles Poindexter of The Pines, Lexington, Va., is at the Barbizon.
ALL of this diary, the earlier parts of which have for some time been extant in English, Is a striking document; but because of the intense

Accused of being one of the leading narcotic distributors in this city, Max Sprung and an alleged lieutenant, Henry Weinberg, were held in $3,000 ball each for the grand jury yesterday by United States Commits sioner Garrett W. Cotter. They were charged with selling heroin Friday night.

The annual ice carnival for the benefit of the Princeton Nursery School will be held in Baker Memorial Rink here on Feb. 20. This year the carnival will be called the "Cruise of the S. S. Washington," and the west end of the rink will be decorated to represent the boat.

Of the nearly 11,000,000 employed women in the United States more than a third carry the full responsibility for home-making in their families as well as holding a paid job, the Women's Bureau reports in a recent analysis of the 1930 census.

The army spokesman denied today that the military sought fascism or a dictatorship or intended to make extensive economic changes. He said the army wanted parliamentary government according to the Japanese Constitution and national principles and wished political reforms so the army could attend to its own business of national defense.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Jan. 28: Buzy. Lt. F. L., VO Squadron 1-B, to VP Squadron 12-F, the Langley. Fahy. Jr. Lt. J. S., the Waters, to the Goff. Greenlee, Jr. Lt. A. W., VO Squadron 1-B, to VS Squadron l-B, the Ranger.

AKNOWLEDGE of the Roman Catholic attitude toward the various schools and trends of present-day psychology should be of considerable interest both to the religious and non-religious elements of the general public.

TCHAIKOVSKY'S Fourth symphony (in F minor, Op. 36) is not new to the gramophone, but when played and recorded in the manner of other recent duplications by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Koussevitzky-Schubert's Unfinished and Mendelssohn's Italian, for example-it might just as well be.
The oldest event of its kind in American college life will be renewed when the twenty-seventh annual Winter Carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club is staged at Hanover, N. H., on Friday and Saturday.

Following a settlement of terms for barter with Germany announced on Friday, a $3,500,000 credit with Italy was reported yesterday and prospects of a better cotton export business strengthened the market materially.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Hamilton Salmon Jr. gave a dinner tonight at their home in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hixon of Short Hills, N. J. Their other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Birdsall, Mr. and Mrs. Frank de Mercado, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Patterson Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Caswell Stoddard, Mrs. Edmund Driggs, Mrs. Allan Hardie and Mrs. Alfred Bowman.
A centennial commemoration of the birth of Dwight L. Moody will be started next week in an effort to kindle a "spiritual awakening" in America.

A foul shot by Howard Schmidt in the closing seconds gave the New York Stock Exchange basketball team a 17-to-16 victory over the New York University jayvees yesterday. The N. Y. U. juniors led at half time, 11 to 9.

With suits prominent in the foreground of the current fashion picture, gloves to go with them are important, too. Some one with an eye to quiet dash designed a glove to be worn with suits by Creed, and it turns out to be a glove that one could pull on with any-tailored suit.

Leigh Harris, chairman of the local Red Cross chapter, protested today because reports had .gone around that the city was under water. It not only had not been touched by the flood, Mr. Harris declared, but it had been a refuge for flood sufferers.
After a spectacular uphill drive, Pennsylvania defeated Yale at the Palestra tonight, 33-30, to increase its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League with six victories in a row.
Stocks closed firm and generally higher, steel shares up 1 to 4 points; turnover, 1,194,730 shares. Federal loans lower, industrial bonds higher, other issues steady; transactions, $6,967,200.

City Collector William Reid announced yesterday that collections of the city's 2 per cent sales tax for 1936 stands at $44,349,113, with a considerable number of persons and concerns still to be heard from. It is expected that total receipts for the year will reach $45,000,000.

New York is preparing to entertain 50,000 visitors next month who will come to the city from all sections of the country to attend various types of conventions and business shows. John R. Young, manager of the convention bureau of the Merchants Association, said yesterday that from the standpoint of the number of visitors and the amount of business which they will produce, would undoubtedly be the best February in several Years.

Miss Ruth Marguerite McClelland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. McClelland of this city, was married to Kenneth C. Bert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Bert of Yonkers, N. Y., this afternoon in the Orange Methodist Episcopal Church. The Rev. Arthur H. Brown, the pastor, performed the ceremony.
The Lawrenceville quintet defeated the Yale freshmen today, 39 to 29. The Laurentians took the lead early in the first period and never relinquished it.

FROM dust-covered attics, long neglected trunks and yellowing business files, rare old stamps are still turning up at intervals in various parts of the country to reward the diligent search constantly being carried on by philatelic experts.

Richard T. Frankensteen, Detroit organizational director of the United Automobile Workers of America, said today that elections held in the past week by Chrysler employes had gan given the international union control of the plants' employeee representative system."
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross more than passed the half-way mark yesterday in its campaign to raise its flood relief fund quota of $1,500,000 in Manhattan and the Bronx.

EVER alert For duty when emergency summons them into action, the American raido amateurs, now numbering 46,000 in the United States quickly cast . aside their experiments, casual traffic and nonchalant talk and respond to the call of service.

With defaults playing a leading ro1e in moving almost half of the contestants up a notch, most of the second round in the M. M. Sterling1 Trophy squash tennis tournament at the New York A. C. was completed yesterday.
At 11 A. M., Jan. 30, 1933, Adolf Hitler was named Chancellor of Germany by the late President and Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg. Two days later the Nazi leader addressed the nation:
While Ohio counted its flood cost upward from $70,000,000 tonight, a representative of President Roosevelt said that the Federal Government would seek to curb future inundations of the valley.

America's first free port of modern times, opening on Staten Island tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock as a municipally operated project, will be turned over to private interests if a satisfactory basis for transferring its operation can be worked out, city officials conceded here yesterday.
