College notes include announcement by Miss Frances Froatz, director of women's athletics at New York University, that the ninth annual championship tournament of the Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association will be held on Saturday, April 10 in the East building of N. Y. U. at Washington Square.

The Greenwich committee of the Seeing Eye will hold a meeting at the Greenwich High School on Monday night when Mrs. Harrison Eustis, founder and president of the Seeing Eye, will tell of the work being done by that organization in educating dogs as guides for the blind.

More than 100 exhibitors will show their products at the Long Island National Home Show opening Tuesday evening at the Jamaica Armory, 168th Street, near Jamaica Avenue, continuing through Wednesday, Feb. 10. The show is being held under the joint sponsorship of the Federal Housing Administration, the Manufacturing Housing Council and the Long Island Real Estate Board.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday swore in Edward F. Breslin, Bronx Assistant District Attorney; Deputy Fire Commissioner Francis X. Giaccone, Assistant Corporation Counsel Alvin McK. Sylvester and Henri Schwob, secretary of the Purchase Department, as thirty-day magistrates.

Complete understanding between the interested parties is essential in building alteration, as a successful alteration always represents a work of collaboration, John S. Burrell, architect for the Union Dime Savings Bank, told members of the apartment house group of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York in a recent talk at the Town Hall Club.
Contrary to a prevalent belief, not all women with a large amount of leisure spend their time flipping cards across a bridge table or tipping up teacups during a gossip rest.
APPEL--Mr. and Mrs. John J. Appel announce the birth of a daughter. Joan, on Jan. 19, 1937, at Physicians Hospital, Jackson Heights. N. Y.

Jake Schaefer of Chicago won the world 28.2 balkline billiard championship tonight by 2,500 to 2,162, defeating Willie Hoppe of New York, 250 to 183, in the tenth and final block of their 2,500-point duel for the title and a $1,000 side wager.

The Senate received from its Appropriations Committee today a report favoring passage of the First Deficiency Bill, intended primarily to finance work relief through the fiscal year, in approximately the same form as it passed the House.

Lee Tracy, Mary Brian and Florence Lake, film stars, were among the passengers that were snowbound at the city airport here tonight. They were flying from Hollywood, Calif., to Cleveland, where they were scheduled to appear at the President's ball.

About 10 per cent of the young men and women attending colleges and universities this year are earning part of their expenses through employment in the student-aid program of the National Youth Administration, Administrator Aubrey Williams, the administrator, stated today.

Blair athletes triumphed in two of three meetings with Peddie today, winning the swimming and wrestling meets and losing the basketball match. Placing first in every event, the Blair natators scored by 58 to 17 for their twenty-fifth consecutive victory.

The Junior Service League of Short Hills, of which Miss Mary Irwin is president, will present "Ocean Daze," a musical revue, on Friday and Saturday nights at the Millburn High School. Many dinners will be given before the performances, and dancing at the Essex County Country Club, West Orange, will follow the second.
Further improvement In the prices of real estate bonds in 1937 is predicted by H. R. Amott, president of Amott, Baker Co., Inc.

Music has sufficient charm to lure students at Cornell University away from all other extra-curricular activities to a degree exceeded only by intercollegiate sport, according to a survey by Professor Paul J. Weaver, head of Cornell's Department of Music.
The Soviet public undoubtedly was surprisedas were foreign observers at the trial of seventeen for treason-by the fact that Karl Radek and Gregory Sokolnikoff escaped death sentences yesterday.
Substantial decreases in the number of new influenza and pneumonia cases for the twenty-fourhour period ended 10 A. M. yesterday were reported by the Department of Health.
Stockholders of the Gamewell Company have been summoned to act on March 8 on a plan to eliminate a consolidated deficit arising from operations of the company's

The sale of 104 properties for a total of $2,753,200 is reported by the realty firm of Hy. D. Agar of Brooklyn for the year 1936. The sales included fifteen one-family and seven two-family houses and sixty-five other residential properties in addition to fourteen stores and three vacant plots.

J. Hampton Leonard of Iona, for more than thirty years publisher of The Newfield Item and The Clayton Reporter, died at his home yesterday in his ninetieth year. Coming here from Kossuth, Iowa, in 1866, he operated a chain of small weekly newspapers throughout Southern New Jersey.

The body of a man, shot through the heart, that rolled out of an automobile in a crash against a building at 441 West Fourteenth Street shortly. after Friday midnight, was identified through fingerprints yesterday by the police as that of Ralph Clements, 36 years old, a longshoreman and an exconvict.

THE American premiere of Richard Hageman's opera, "Caponsacchi," sung in English; the revival of "Le Coq d'Or" and the debut of Gina Cigna and Gertrud Ruenger are some of the events scheduled for the seventh week of the Metropolitan Opera season. This week also marks the ending of the first half of the season.
The Senate Civil Liberties Committee, pressing its inquiry into the General Motors Company "sitdown" strikes, announced today that it had subpoenaed three law enforcement officers in Flint.

D. B. McElroy of the University Club, New York, will meet Murray Vernon of the Greenwich Country Club and B. N. Everett, Harvard Club, will play J. R. Ward of the Squash Club, New York, in the Class A semi-finals of the annual invitation squash racquets tournament on the courts of the Round Hill Club.

Brooklyn National Corporation--Liquidating value as of Dec. 31 was equal to $49.48 a share, based on market value of investments, without provision for Federal income tax or excess-profits tax or surtax on undistributed profits.

Engineering as a profession is the subject of a motion picture prepared by students and faculty members of the Department of Engineering in the University of Virginia which will soon be shown in a selected group of high schools and preparatory schools of this State and in Washington.

As was the case a year ago, the building of small homes today is setting the pace for realty recovery and probably will continue to do so for several years. Apparently suburban developers even in the busy metropolitan district still have a long way to go before they satisfy the backlog of demand which piled up during the slack construction period at the depths of the depression.
The House Rivers and Harbors Committee today set a hearing for next Tuesday on a plan to deepen Barnegat Inlet, N. J.

H. K. Brewer Co., stationery firm founded in 1835, has bought from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company the four-story business building at 22-24 East Forty-first Street for its permanent uptown headquarters. The building is on a plot 25 by 100 feet.

Mrs. Harlow Brooks of 47 West Ninth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Walker Brooks, to Kenneth Landers Hoffmann, a New York attorney. Miss Brooks, a portrait sculptor, is the daughter of the late Dr. Brooks, one of the foremost diagnosticians and consulting physicians of the country.
NEW YORK provisioners have become conscious of a reviving culinary interest in herbs They are carrying a wider variety than they have offered in several years.

Terror-stricken Kao Lomeng was dragged through the streets to public execution today for the slaying of his aged parents. Dressed in a red silk robe, ironically the emblem of joy and happiness, authorities ordered Kao executed in the most humiliating manner to avenge the transgression against the ancient Chinese teaching of filial piety.

This musty, walled-in city was being squeezed today between two mighty rivers, the Ohio on one side and the Mississippi on the other. These two threatening streams, which meet at the lower end of the city, have backed up the Cache River until it is only a little below the top of the levee.

The foreign exchange market here moved narrowly yesterday. The franc closed unchanged at 4.66 1/4 cents, as did the pound at $4.8913-16. Overnight news of the [Pound]40,000,000 London banking loan to the French railroads for ten months was received with satisfaction.

The Dunnigan-Steingut Social Security Bill, recommended by Governor Lehman, was endorsed by the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union, of which Walter Frank is chairman, in a statement issued yesterday.

This one-bladed propeller, invented by W. W. Everts, Baltimore engineer, was flown into Floyd Bennett Field last week. It looks like half of the conventional propeller--one blade set in a "hub" from which it is easily removable for inspection.

While across the Hudson, New Jersey's "co-educational" jury system has been monopolizing public interest and newspaper columns, a furiously energetic campaign for the same objective has been launched with a lack of fanfare but a great deal of determination, by the Woman's City Club.

Miss Mary Vail Andress of the Chase National Bank, one of the outstanding women in her profession since she was appointed assistant cashier at the main office of the bank, will assist in the organization of the firm's new office to be opened in London.

Explaining that cancer "cures" and preventivee" recently have been "boldly and subtly exploited," the Executive Committee of the American Society for the Control of Cancer issued a statement yesterday declaring that early and accurate diagnosis and prompt treatment by surgery, radium or X-ray offered "the only present hope of cure from cancer."
"A Point of Honor," by Jo Eisinger and Stephen Van Gluck, had its world premiere here tonight in the McCarter Theatre. Produced and staged by Luther Greene, the play was well received.

With every government agency working in harmony and the War Department ready to evacuate 500,000 persons between Cairo and New Orleans, if this should be necessary, the President's special flood relief committee prepared to leave tomorrow for Memphis, from which point northward they will make a complete survey of the entire situation.

Princeton Theological Seminary, the oldest theological school of the Presbyterian Church in this country, is observing the 125th anniversary of its founding. On Tuesday Dr. John Alexander Mackay, formerly of the Board of Foreign Missions of the church, will be inducted as fourth president of the seminary.

IT is the citizen in the long run who is responsible for the enforcement of motor vehicle regulations in any State, in the opinion of Chief Justice William M. Maltbie of the Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors. In an article in the current issue of Connecticut Safety, a publication of the Governor's Commission of Street and Highway Safety, Judge Maltbie particularly deplores the practice of "fixing" tickets.

A group of Western New York residents organized today to revive and preserve memories of the days when commerce plied the old Erie Canal between Buffalo and Albany. Topping the organization's agenda were plans for the first annual dinner of the "Society of the Erie Canal."

The best thing which has happened to the.West Side during the past year, in the opinion of William B. Hall, manager of the Parc Vendome, on Fifty-seventh Street, is the Rezoning Act, as it marks the beginning of a new era for that section.

A resolution calling upon Congress to reallocate funds set aside for military purposes for the relief of the unemployed and flood victims was adopted last night at the end of a two-day conference on peace conducted by the American League Against War and Fascism. The conference, attended by 431 delegates from more than 250 organizations, was held at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

THE government's unique venture in hotel building, Timberlin Lodge, recently opened on the slopes of Mount Hood, Oregon, marks the culmination of many years of effort on the part of local groups and the National Forest Service to provide adequate hotel and recreational facilities for an increasing number of tourists.

Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, retired, executive director of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, reported the following flood relief contributions received at the headquarters here yesterday:

MANHATTAN BROWN. JAMES (Dec. 6). Estate, less than $5,000. To Thomas Brown, brother, County Fermanagh, Ireland; Alice Corty, sister. 1,748 Hendrickson St., Brooklyn; Robert A. Brown, brother, executor, 49 Claremont Av., equal shares in residue.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Seymour G. Cole of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Louise Cole, to Gordon R. Carpenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Carpenter of New Rochelle.
Dr. Fred E. Hamlin an examining physician for the last forty-two years for the Prudential Insurance Company of America, died on Friday of a heart attack at his office, 682 Leonard Street, Brooklyn.
Paced by Harvey Jackson and Rookie Gordon Drillon, the Toronto Maple Leafs swarmed over the Montreal Maroons in a National Hockey League game tonight, winning 7-4.

The latest international repercussion resulting from the arrest of the former Iranian Minister to the United States, Ghaffer Djallal, in Elkton, Md., in November, 1935, came to light today when the American motor ship Wichita tied up at a Canton ore pier.
With 131 students ready to participate, Rutgers University will open on Tuesday a program of forty-six varsity and six freshman debates. This marks the 155th year of forensic activity at the college.

Because some residents along the flood route in Missouri and Arkansas did not understand the word "evacuate" as army and other agencies went into action to move them to higher ground considerable delay arose.
The tone of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday again was reflected in the action of the United States Government obligations, which turned definitely lower.
TODAY Music Hall of the Air presents a string orchestra directed by Mischa Violin; soloists are Viola. Philo, soprano; Lucille Lawrence, harpist, and Robert Weede, baritone; WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M.

The eventual disappearance in this country of Jewish institutions except in the religious field was predicted tonight by George Backer, chairman of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, in a combined appeal and prophecy voiced at the opening session of the 1937 general assembly of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds.

The Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company launched the new oceangoing tanker Mobilgas this afternoon, adding 15,500 deadweight tons to the fleet tonnage of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company. The 501-foot craft will be one of the two largest tankers in the oil company's fleet and will run with her sister ship, the Mobiloil, between Texas and Atlantic Coast ports north of Cape Hatteras.
The amateur theatrical efforts of Connecticut State Prison inmates have won praise from Eva Le Gallienne, who visited the prison to help produce "The First Legion," to be given there Feb. 4.

In the midst of a fight against an epidemic of influenza and the depredations of looters, a "limited" quarantine was established around the area within five miles of Louisville late tonight. It will be effective at sunrise tomorrow.

WITH a peak figure of 7,000 persons arriving in Florida resorts in two days, all modes of transportation are in use to bring the rising total of visitors to the State known--among other things--for its orange blossoms.

A special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States recommended today the curtailing of activities of the Federal Government in competition with private industries. These five recommendations were placed before the chamber membership.

From the way entries are flowing into the offices of Al Lattin, promoter, and Elmer Baumgarten, secretary of the American Bowling Congress, under whose auspices New York's first major bowling tournament is being staged at the 212th Coast Guard Artillery Armory from March 10 to April 30, all previous records for the pin classic seem likely to be exceeded.

It was miniature day yesterday in everything but crowds at the National Aviation Show in Grand Central Palace. Entitled Junior Birdman Day, with reduced admission for boys and girls, the aisles were jammed with young folk eager to see and to learn.
Approximately sixty - three new courses of study will be offered by New York University's degree-conferring schools and colleges during the Spring semester, which starts Wednesday.

More than 600 members of the Manhattan College Alumni Society, the oldest organized Catholic college alumni group in the United States, are expected to assemble at the Hotel Astor Saturday night for their sixty-eighth annual dinner.
FLOODS cost Pittsburgh about $2,000,000 annually and the 968-mile stretch of the Ohio from Pittsburgh to Cairo, Ill., some $10,000,000. These are only averages losses.

Army poloists rode down a fast and hard-fighting Yale trio in a game played before a large crowd in the West Point Riding Hall today. Triumphing, 12 to 9, the Cadets marked up their twenty-seventh consecutive victory.

Mr. Roosevelt likes knick-knacks and collects them assiduously, to the dismay of White House porters who are supposed to keep his desk clean. They have tried hard, but they have given up the task: it can't be done.

Members of the suburban Women's Republican Club of Essex, of which Mrs. E. Garfield Gifford of. this city is president, will give a benefit bridge party on Wednesday afternoon at the South Orange Community House. Proceeds will be turned over to the Red Cross chapter of the Oranges to aid the flood sufferers.

Cables have been received by John Robert Babcock of 25 East Eightysixth Street announcing the marriage of his daughter, Miss Dallas Babcock, to Antonin Thiollier, son of Mrs. Edouard Thiollier of Paris, which took place there yesterday in the Church of Notre Dame des Champs.

The Harmon realty organization, now headed by W. Burke Harmon, is celebrating this year its fiftieth anniversary. The firm dates back to a real estate concern organized by his father, William E. Harmon, in Cincinnati in 1887.
British Guiana cricketers left for Georgetown today. But the intercolonial cricket championship which they had held for the past year remained in Trinidad.
Customs authorities at Buffalo seized the hockey equipment belonging to the Yale hockey team and caused postponement of the International Intercollegiate League game today with the Toronto varsity.

The first intercollegiate basketball game to be held at the County Center, White Plains, N. Y., will be played under the auspices of the Intercollegiate Alumni Association of Westchester in cooperation with the County's Recreation Commission on Wednesday evening.
Even here in Madrid the overwhelming presence of war tends to obscure the fact that a community of nearly 1,000,000 persons cannot exist without a mechanism of government.

THIS, by the Attorney General in President Roosevelt's Cabinet, is the history of an evolution. That the evolution is an extraordinary one may be suggested by a single example: that the Department of Justice was not created until 1870, only sixty-seven years ago.

Willie Eley, Harlem welterweight, earned the decision over Joe Pennino of Brooklyn in the feature eight-round bout before 2,500 at the Rockland Palace last night. Eley weighed 144 1/4 pounds and Pennino 144 1/2.

The free-care service conducted by the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital in its twenty-four surgical and medical clinics will benefit from the eleventh annual midwinter polo tournament of the New York Athletic Club, which will be held on the night of Feb. 13 at the 105th Regiment Field Artillery Armory, Franklin Avenue, the Bronx.

Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Pell Lawrence of Loudonville, N. Y., formerly of Newark and Montclair, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Lawrence, to Duane E. Minard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Duane E. Minard of Wawonaissa Farm, Boonton, N. J.

That national characteristic of the French that will never permit them to admit that what is not perfect is any good at all is at work again just now trying to undermine Premier Leon Blum's government. Naturally, the attack is being directed at the weakest point in the armor of the Popular Front Government, its precarious financial position.

Imports of copper by the United States in December amounted to 19,459 tons, compared with 9,957 in November, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Exports by the United States in December were 17,427 tons, against 20,193 in November.

Members of the Alumnae Association of Packer Collegiate Institute, of which Mrs. Tremper Longman is president, will hold their second annual "amateur night" entertainment tomorrow in the assembly room of the institute, 170 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn.
Representative Fish said tonight that President Roosevelt had put forth a "revolutionary, unlawful and a monstrous" doctrine when he "lectured" the Supreme Court in his annual message to Congress.

Dr. Lawrence Donald McEvoy, retired army medical officer, died Friday in Mount Sinai Hospital at the age of 71. He lived at 339 East Eighty-eighth Street and had his office at 551 Fifth Avenue, where he practiced until falling ill a few weeks ago.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Juliet Bell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus Lafayette Bell of the Barclay, this city, and Rocklea, Collender's Point, Darien, Conn., to Allerton James Anthony McEwan, son of Mrs. Robert B. McEwan of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. McEwan, took place here yesterday in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

Closing of the retail fiscal year yesterday discloses an almost general adherence to the plan of avoiding speculation in merchandise by retail stores, despite the price rise which featured many of the wholesale markets during the Fall period.
ABOUT a year ago the interesting Bibliographia Series was further enlivened by a provocative work compiled by I. R. Brussel.
The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore in 1936 earned a net income of $6,394,688, after all charges, according to its statement issued yesterday.
UNCLE SAM -- Winter resort operator--has a report to make. The Virgin Islands in the Caribbean, he says, are enjoying peak tourist and vacation business.

Regardless of a difference of opinion among social agencies as to the most effective method of bringing the New York State policy on care of the blind into consonance with provisions of the Federal Social Security Act, there is a unanimity of belief among junior club women that the sightless are their special interest.

FLINT, MICH. THE essence of Flint is speed. The tempo of the production line, where the speed-up was one of the grievances of the sit-down strikers who tied up the mammoth General Motors automobile plant throughout the country, has spread to the entire life of the city.

Thousands of applicants for 1937 automobile license plates stormed the main office of the Motor Vehicle Bureau yesterday in the State Building, Worth and Center Streets, and its fifteen branches in various parts of the city.

One hundred absent-minded citizens of Bronxville may suddenly some day wonder what has become of their shoes, but if they ask Tony Wannantuono he will tell them the Red Cross is distributing them to flood sufferers in the Midwest.

Hailing the decision of Judge Julian W. Mack in New York that holding companies must register under the provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935, James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that Electrio Bond and Share Company and others which sought to avoid the provisions of the 1935 act "cut their own throats just for the pleasure of following their lawyers' advice."

Zevson, 5-year-old son of Zev, flying Mrs. E. H. Bartlett's silks, scored his fifth straight victory in taking the measure of six of the best horses in training at the Fair Grounds today in the mile and 70 yards of the Lake Pontchartrain Handicap.

Benny Gottesman, the waiter who fought off the efforts of racketeers led by Jules Martin to take over Waiters Union Local 1, gave the jury hearing the restaurant racket case yesterday its first testimony on acts of extortion.

Complete revision of the State's finance law in an effort to provide more detailed information for legislators and the public concerning how appropriations of the taxpayers' money are to be expended is sought in a bill to be introduced Monday night by Assemblyman Moffat, New York Republican.

THE rate of death from automobile accidents continues to mount faster in rural districts than in urban. In the ten years from 1923 to 1933, motor fatalities in cities increased by less than one-third, but in rural territories they increased by more than 100 per cent. Figures from the National Safety Council show that in 1935 the urban fatalities were 11,800; rural, 25,200.
DORFMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Dorfman Announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Mervyn, on Saturday, Feb. 6, 10 A. M., at Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, L. I.

WHEN I undertook to dance the Dance of the Flame in Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's production of "The Good Earth," I had an impression that the nature of the Oriental dance would make it peculiarly adaptable to screen treatment.

With a new roster of officers and several new member organizations, the Women's Joint Legislative Forum activities are well under way at Albany. This is the group established in 1932 to educate and enlighten its members in New York State government.

PALM BEACH, Fla.--This week residents may either play in or witness two important golf tournaments of the Palm Beach season. The contest of the Artists and Writers Association will be. held at the Palm Beach Golf Country Club and that of the South Florida championship will be held at the Palm Beach Golf Club.

Playing before a capacity audience, which was augmented by close to 300 standees, John Gielgud, the young English actor, closed his record-breaking run in "Hamlet" last night at the St. James Theatre with his 132d consecutive performance of the play on Broadway.

For years, to cite a case, Morris Green (of the former firm of Jones Green) and Morris Green (lieutenant to L. Lawrence Weber) have received each other's mail and telephone calls. Mr.
The Long Island University junior varsity basketball team defeated the Twenty-third Street Y. M. C. A. quintet, 50--36, at the losers' court yesterday. The victors led at half-time, 21-16.

A flood relief supper dance, entertainment and bazaar is to be given on Wednesday at the Warwick Hotel for the benefit of the American Red Cross. All wares for the bazaar and the entertainment have been donated, so that the entire proceeds will go directly for aid to flood sufferers.

The week's events in Japan are a priceless lesson in the first principle of Japanese politics, which is that things never are what they appear. The crisis began as a duel between the army and the politicians. With General Kazushigi Ugaki's entry on the soene it lost that character and became an issue with deep ramifications in the past feuds and the internal politics of the army.

WHILE many of us following Santayana and Marquand, delight in deriding "last" Puritans, a little band of Boston biographers--not "fictional" but documented to the eyebrows--are as delightedly rehabilitating the first Puritans.

Holding that the solution for the returns evil in the dress industry is the use of a "little NRA" label, Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers, in a letter to Philip Koven of the Coronet Costume Company, urges the trade to set up its own voluntary code.

Authors and stage stars will attend the third book and play luncheon, in a series conducted by Miss Emma Mills, to be held Thursday at the Biltmore, when the relation of "Literature and the Theatre to the World of Today" will be discussed.

A new industry, which started recently from study of the stars at Cornell University, is doing a national business here from a basement room. The workmen are two young scientists who are making mirrors of a new kind, of evaporated metal films, aluminum, chromium, gold, only one-millionth of an inch thick.

The Garden Club of Larchmont, the largest organization of its kind in New York State, having a membership of 400, will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary on Monday afternoon with the presentation of a play entitled "A Fantasy," written by Mrs. William J. Moran, a member of the club.
The executive committee of the New York Board of Trade appealed to all law enforcement agencies yesterday to put an end to sit-down strikes in this country.
Vitamins, proteins and minerals are going into the class rooms and playgrounds with 500 Altoona school children in a unique nutrition experiment announced here today.

Scoring a complete upset, the Tome School swimmers from Fort Deposit, Md., garnered 40 points to win the third Harvard interscholastic swimming meet and take the Arthur W. -Stevens cup from the favored Andover team in the indoor athletic building today.

The National Conference for Palestine, under sponsorship of forty national Jewish organizations and hundreds of Jewish communal societies, in association with the United Palestine Appeal, will be held at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington Saturday and Sunday, it was announced yesterday.
IN the Land-of-the-Eagle, remote and inaccessible, "where the snow lies heavy on the necks of the mountains," children have listened for many centuries to these tales.

The first weak SOS call from Jack Binns on the sinking liner Republic in 1909 has another historic radio achievement to stand beside it as a result of the flood here. This is a new record of radio calls for help-16,500 separate appeals in five days over station WHAS.

NOW LAUGHS: Former Mayor Walker, in his day a smooth and witty politician, had this to say last week: "From my seat 'way back in the bleachers, I watch the political parade. I read what the politicians say and I watch what they do. You would be surprised how my sleeves puff with the laughs that run up and down them."
J. A. Cope of the State College of Agriculture predicted today that New York's 4,000,000 acres of woodlots would develop into a "definite unit of the State's lumbering industry."

A new spirit of continental solidarity between the Americas, which should do much to keep the world from war, has resulted from the recent peace conference in Buenos Aires, Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, Special Ambassador from Brazil to the United States,. declared yesterday upon his arrival here from Washington.

Foreign Minister P. T. T. Spaak went to St. Quentin in France today for a conversation with Foreign Minister Julio Alvarez del Vayo of Spain in an effort to clear up differences between their nations over the death of Count Jacques de Borchgrave,

The annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club will be held tomorrow in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The feature of the event will be a program by several well-known entertainers.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Modern Sculpture," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 2 P. M.; "The Making of a Stained-Glass Window; Tapestries and How They Are Made," motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Design in Mural Decoration," (Gillender Lecture), Hildreth Melere, 3 P. M.; "Attic Grave Monuments," Clarence H. Young,. 4 P. M.

The marriage of Miss Edwina Warman, daughter of Mrs. Ethel M. Warman of this city, to William Ratner, also of Newark, took place this morning at the home of Mayor Ellenstein, who performed the ceremony in the presence of a few friends. The couple left on a wedding trip to Miami.

Miss Dorothy Mathilde Thebaud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gilbert Thebaud of this place, was married here this morning to Richard Earl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Earl of Kew Gardens, L. I., in St. John's Church, which was a gift of her great-grandmother, Mrs. Jules Reynal.
Officials of the Forest Hills-Kew Gardens Apartment Owners Assoclation are urging realty interests to protect standards as development stimulated by improvements affecting the area go forward.

The only known existent piece of taxidermy executed by the late Carl E. Akeley, famous explorer, as an amateur will leave Rochester for the Akeley Memorial Hall in the American Museum of Natural History, New York City, it was revealed today.

Piling up an early lead, the Essex Troop polo team defeated the Boulder Brook trio of Westchester, 6 to 5 1/2, tonight in the feature game of a flood relief benefit program at the Essex Troop armory. The entire proceeds were turned over to the Newark Chapter of the American Red Cross. A capacity crowd of 2,500 saw the matches.

By breaking 97 out of a possible 100 targets, O. Agathon led in a field of twenty-six gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. It gave him the High Scratch cup, the major prize of the day.

A "real Southern party" is forecast for the night of Feb. 19 when the annual Dixie dinner dance of the New York Southern Society will be held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. A large committee of patronesses, including many native Southerners, has been formed for the event, at which Phelan Beale, president of the society, will preside.

Construction of a group of ten bungalows has been started by Morrissey Walker, owners of Shark River Manor, near Asbury Park, N. J., who plan to build thirty more before June 1 to take care of the Spring demand.

Buyers are expected to arrive steadily in the New York market for the next few weeks, although the peak of the season has been passed, according to a special report prepared for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. The report continues:

With arrangements completed for the installation Wednesday of Dr. Henry Merritt Wriston, retiring head of Lawrence College in Appleton, Wis., as president of Brown University, Brown looks forward to the beginning of the eleventh presidential administration in its 172 years of history.
A luncheon under the auspices of the Lincoln Fellowship Society will be held on Feb. 12 in the Blue Room of the Hotel Lincoln to celebrate the birthday of Abraham Lincoln.

Leaders in education, religion and government will address the students of New Jersey College for Women during the coming semester, it was announced today by Dean Margaret T. Corwin. Among them will be:
The Westchester County Realty Board will give a lecture course at its headquarters, 32 Depot Plaza, White Plains, on alternate Monday evenings beginning tomorrow. Six lectures will be held. Albert W.

FOR its forty-sixth annual exhibition, current at the American Fine Arts Building, the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors has assembled almost 400 items. This large show, installed in the three main galleries and in the Academy Room, may be visited until Feb. 10.

THE jealous eye which dictatorships cast over the reading habits of their citizens becomes ever sharper. In Russia, Italy and Germany it has been accepted as fundamental that nothing may be printed which reflects adversely on the regime in power.

Two ex-convicts, accused of leisurely holding up two Jamaica haberdashery shops last yesterday afternoon, tying up three victims and assaulting one of them with the butt of a pistol, were captured after a chase by the teamwork of a patrolman and a detective, who cornered the fugitives on the westbound elevated platform of the Sutphin Avenue station of the B. M. T. line.
THIS book of the English countryside is not one of those chronicles which, in arousing the reader's interest, almost destroy his pleasure with futile envy, at the same time.

The immediate construction of two strategic railroad lines across the Carpathian Mountains to connect Transylvania with the old kingdom was decided on today at a conference attended. by Cabinet members, the chief of the general staff and the manager of the State railways.
Retiring after fifty-three years of active service in the Postoffice Department in this city, Frank C. Roehrig was honored last week by Postmaster Albert Goldman and his associates.

Carlos (Indian) Quintana, 119 1/4, Panama, gained the decision over Tony Marino, 118 1/2, Pittsburgh, in the feature eight-round bout of the Ridgewood Grove's weekly boxing show last night before a crowd of 2,500.

Connecticut couples desiring speedy marriage proved a profitable business for the town clerks and justices as well as the ministers in the towns of Carmel, Patterson and Southeast in Putnam. County during the past year.

A new charter for Westchester County, approval by the Legislature and a county referendum in November were probabilities foreseen last week by Bert C. McCulloch, member of the County Board of Supervisors from Mamaroneck.

The memory of William Holmes McGuffey and the hundredth anniversary of the first publication of the McGuffey Readers are being honored at the Wesleyan University Library with an exhibit of early American reading books.

Mark McCloskey, director of the National Youth Administration for this city, will be the guest speaker at the midwinter luncheon of the New York Council of the Girls Service League, to be held on Wednesday at the clubhouse, 138 East Nineteenth Street.

Miss Barbara Purdy, daughter of Mrs. E. Fairall Purdy of this city has selected March 29 for her marriage to Alexander C. Ironside of Toronto, Ont., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Ironside of Aberdeen, Scotland, and a nephew of Colonel and Mrs. George T. Chisholm of Toronto.

Mrs. Caroline Andrews Milligan, widow of Captain Frank J. Milligan of the United States Navy, died at the Hotel Hazelton today after a brief illness. She had been a resident of Stamford for the last ten years.

The Kosciuszko Foundation's fourth annual Night in Poland Ball, entitled "A Night in Old Krakow," will provide an actual as well as spiritual link between this country and Poland when it takes place on Wednesday night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Crippled Dorothea Antel, promising actress of former years and lately winner of the $500 Heroism Prize awarded by Kate Smith on her radio program, served as audience yesterday afternoon for a series of skits by policemen and firemen of Jersey City.

Arrangements are now being made for a benefit hockey match to aid the Community of St. Johnland at Kings Park, L. I., which consists of several cottages for aged men and women, as well as a kindergarten, school and cottages for orphaned boys and girls.

IT has long been rumored that Americans are great joiners, and in this compendium--the first of its kind, so far as one can recall--Mr. Ferguson confirms one's most extravagant suspicions He might have done it in the spirit of H. L. Mencken, who used to derive much amusement from the more spectacular of the American fraternal orders and secret societies.
ADELSDORF--At Baltimore, Md., Jan. 30, 1937. Monie Adelsdorf. Funeral from the residence of his sister, Mrs. Ansel Schoeneman, Emersonian Apartments, Monday, 10 A. M. Interment Baltimore, Md.
SINCE the outbreak of the Spanish rebellion, new stations have appeared on various short waves, sending music and speech from both Nationalist and Rebel headquarters.

Figures compiled by the Monmouth County Board of Taxation reveal that the total county valuation has dropped in the past year to an extent where assessments will be raised by more than $1,000,000 in 1937 in order to maintain a semblance of balance in a stable rate, according to the Monmouth County Real Estate Board.

With garden clubs and gardeners each Winter becoming a little more enamored of window gardening there appears in florists' windows and in- nurserymen's catalogues an increasing number of unusual plants that, with reasonable attention to their wants, may be grown indoors.

May I suggest that neutrality legislation is the opposite of the underlying purpose of the League of Nations, which is to help the innocent and punish the guilty? Cutting off commerce with the innocent violates that principle. The very knowledge that the United States will forbid the sending of supplies to the innocent will encourage the wouldbe aggressor, who will generally have prepared in advance.
George Wellington Tryon, 77-yearold painter who hasn't Lad a steady job for five years, started a spending spree today to test the efficacy of the Townsend old-age pension plan.

MILAN SECOND major novelty of Italy's lyric seasons was "Imelda, three-act opera by Adolfo Gandino, premiered by the Teatro Comunale of Bologna under the baton of Maestro Del Campo, as winner of the local Baruzzi contest.

The eleventh anniversary of Marymount School, 1,027 Fifth Avenue, will be celebrated Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. The Rev. Coleman Nevils, rector of St. Ignatius Church and former president of Georgetown University, will officiate at the exercises.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mayor La Guardia will head the list of after-dinner speakers when the Lower Primary Club of Teachers College holds its dinner meeting next Friday evening at International House, 500 Riverside Drive.

Asserting that Mayor LA Guardia, of whom he expected great things, had turned out to be just another "radical political opportunist," David Hirshfield, former Magistrate and Commissioner of Accounts, declined yesterday an invitation-to become a member of the Progressive City Committee in a letter to Maurice P. Davidson, its chairman.

David Lloyd George, wartime Prime Minister of England, who is occupying Appleton Hall at Montego Bay, with his wife, Dame Margaret Lloyd George, and his daughter, Miss Megan Lloyd George, M.P., will attend a reception and ball to be given in his honor on Wednesday by the Jamaica Imperial Association.

Temporary Assignments SERGEANT--Louis Ramirez. from 61st Precinct to 18th Division, duty In D. A. office, Kings County, for 1 day, from 4 P. M., Jan. 27. PATROLMEN--James F. Sullivan, from 30th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 2 days, from 8 A. M., Jan. 27.

Mrs. Frederick G. Harris of 224 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn, will open her home on Wednesday for a dessert-luncheon and meeting for members of the executive board of the Chaminade, of which society Mrs. William A. Phillips is president.

Speakers at the monthly meeting of the Industrial Real Estate Brokers Association of the New York metropolitan area last week at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, included H. Findlay French, director of the industrial bureau of the Baltimore Association of Commerce, and Louis B. Beardslee of Chicago, chairman of the industrial property division of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

WITH everything about his next picture completed except that he must go back to Hollywood, fall on a live wire, and be killed, Pat O'Brien was looking extremely cheerful during the tag-end of a brief Manhattan holiday last week.

WHEN an airplane hits the side of a mountain in thick weather or lands in the treetops, either killing all hands, or merely injuring a few people, the pilot is frequently blamed for an error in judgment or for careless flying.
All Hallows defeated Fordham Prep, 22-18, in overtime, in a Bronx-Westchester Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball tournament contest at the Fordham University gymnasium yesterday.

Experience through fifty years with voluntary university church and chapel services has proved this religious policy to be a definite success at Harvard, according to a report of the Rev. Willard L. Sperry, Dean of the Harvard Divinity School and chairman of the Harvard Board of Preachers, presented to President James B. Conant today.

Sponsors of the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra will inaugurate a fund-raising campaign at a luncheon on Thursday in the Biltmore to establish the orchestra on a permanent basis, it was announced yesterday.
The United States Export-Import Bank has agreed to aid in financing the sale. of between 50,000 and 500,000 bales of United States cotton to Italian cotton spinners on nine months' credit.

A grave crisis confronted the Moscow diplomatic corps tonight over the "boiled" shirt question. With the Winter social whirl at its height and with foreign diplomats called on to dine out nightly in formal attire, the lack of adequate laundry facilities has posed a serious problem for worried Ambassadors, Ministers and secretaries.

The great flood in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys has given impetus to study and plans by various governmental agencies and authorities for practical water control from the raindrop to the largest river.

The State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, acting for the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation, distributed 62,258,205 pounds of surplus foodstuffs to needy families in 1936, according to statistics made public yesterday.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 23 amounted to 670,376 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

A reception With music to mark the sixteenth anniversary of the founding of the Judson Health Center will be held Friday afternoon at the studio of Colonel A. A. Anderson, 80 West Fortieth Street. During the afternoon there will be a musical program by Miss Mary Moore, coloratura soprano.

REPORTING on television progress at a recent meeting of the Franklin Institute, Philadelphia, Albert F. Murray, television engineer of the Philco Radio and Television Corporation, outlined the development Plans for 1937.
HAMAILTON, Bermuda. BERMUDA's social season is in full swing, and every incoming ship brings hundreds of visitors. Many of the hotels are filled, and a number of guest houses have waiting lists.

Mrs. Beatrice Rogers of Great Neck, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jeanne Beatrice Rogers, to Robert William Watson, son of Mrs. John F. Watson of this city, and the late Mr. Watson.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles De Witt Bruyn of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Chandler Bruyn, .to Preston Ira Carnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Baldwin Carnes, also of Englewood.
Just when Townsendism was thought to be as extinct as the dinosaur, the spending tests now taking place in this region have revived it as a political force in the Pacific Northwest.

Germain Glidden, national titleholder and recent winner of the Atlantic City tournament, yesterday gained the semi-final round in the district's newest squash racquets competition, the Union Club's invitation tourney.

The marriage of Miss Kathleen Carpender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Bleecker Carpender of this city, to Arthur Lowe Connell, son of Mrs. Robert Morris Fish of Scranton, Pa., and Edward William Connell of New York, took place here tonight in Christ Church.
Fordham's hopes for a swimming victory over Rider College lingered until the final event, but the Rams were unequal to the task of capturing the relay and consequently suffered a 42-29 loss today.

The Adirondacks Mountain Club, at its annual meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday afternoon, adopted a resolution approving the provision of the State Constitution that the State forest preserve be maintained as wild forest land.

President Roosevelt's birthday was celebrated last night at a dinner dance held by the Association of Postal Supervisors of New York in the Hotel Astor. Postmaster General James A. Farley headed the list of postal officials, including representatives of sixteen employes' organizations.
In a spectacular last-quarter rally a fast Hill School quintet downed the Penn Charter five of Philadelphia, 31 to 25, on Gillison Memorial Court today.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Jan. 27, aggregated $9,168,000,000, or 9 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 20 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.
Tom Smith, Utica speed skater, won four out of five events today to capture men's honors in the Mohawk Valley skating championships.

Tom Stephen Rees, 20, a senior in the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce at the University of Pennsylvania, shot himself fatally today at his mother's Summer home at Crystal Lake, near Carbondale, less than twenty-four hours after he had passed his mid-year examinations.

Mr. and Mrs. Gaston Drake of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Harsell Drake, to James Lawson Karrick Jr., son of Mrs. James Lawson Karrick of Washington, D. C., and Stockbridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Karrick.
A goal after one minute of overtime gave Michigan Tech's outweighed hockey team a 1-to-O victory over Minnesota today.

HOLLYWOOD seems to have mislaid the happy ending. Where once every picture faded out ecstatically with the hero and heroine embracing, the trend more recently has been toward the complete frustration of the screen lovers.
ASKENASE -- GOLDMAN -- Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Goldman of 446 Kingston Av., Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter, Hilda, to Irving L. Askenase; son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Askenase.

The National Conference of Jews and Christians is seeking the signatures of 100,000 Protestant, Catholic and Jewish clergymen in the country to a pronouncement affirming the right of persons of different religious convictions and contrasting cultural traditions to live in the United States "in amity and mutual respect."

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Freya Beryl Kanter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kallman Kanter of 51 Riverside Drive, to Dr. Harold Solodar, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Solodar of this city, which took place Tuesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Over choppy waters, cruisers and runabouts here today rocked over one of the oldest racing courses in Florida before a large crowd celebrating the annual citrus jubilee. Captain Lynn S. Nichols, commodore of the Palm Beach Yacht Club and manager of the fifth district of the American Power Boat Association, was official timekeeper.

Members of the Vassar Club of New York held their annual luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The guests of honor, Michael MacWhite, Minister from the Irish Free State, and William B. Edwards, trustee of Vassar College, were introduced by Mrs. Arthur Butler Graham, president of the club.

ALTHOUGH Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina" is one of the four or five novels that have been made into moving pictures more often than any others, the sage of Yasnaya Polyana never had to go through the torture that is scenario writing in Hollywood. But Leo Tolstoy had his own troubles with the movies, nevertheless.

A government expert described the Midwest floods today as sixty billion tons of water trying to reach a lower level. J. B. Kincer, chief of the climate and crops division of the Weather Bureau, estimated that the water had fallen on the first twenty-five days of this month over an area of 100 miles wide and about 550 miles long.
The Legislature will be asked on Feb. 8 to pass an emergency bill amending the island's boxing rules to permit 15-round fights instead of 12-rounders so that the bout between Sixto Escobar, N. B. A.
Bulgaria celebrated the fortythird birthday of King Boris III today and the monarch's birthday gift to the nation-votes for mothers.

Twentythree foresters of the senior class at the University of Maine returned to the campus this week after a nine weeks' sojourn at the university's woodland Winter camp two and one-half miles from the little town of Princeton, in Indian Township.

The marriage of Miss Patrice Marie Delfoe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Delfoe of 255 Maple Street, Brooklyn, to George Douglas Webb, son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Webb, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday morning in St. Francis Assisi Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn. Mgr. F. X. Ludeke performed the ceremony.

Local offices of the large communication systems reported here yesterday that communication to and from the flooded areas in the Ohio River Valley was improving daily. At the same time the companies added that they were mobilizing their forces and making all possible preparations for floods threatened in the Mississippi Valley region.

Another series of record-breaking frosts in California and the devasstating floods in the Ohio-Mississi basin have combined to increase the prices of citrous fruit and Western vegetables In New York City.

The tendency of modern education to depreciate "good, honest work" was criticized yesterday by two of those attending the all-day conference on training for citizenship conducted at the Hotel Biltmore by the public service division of the Vocational Research Bureau.

Crashing through the iron picket fence around the Interborough Rapid Transit subway yards at 146th Street and Lenox Avenue, Leonardo Macca, 21 years old, a stationary engineer, of 1,165 Third Avenue, drove for a block along the tracks at 1 o'clock this morning in a taxicab he had taken for a "joyride" without the consent of the driver.

The Federal Reserve Board has postponed from Monday to May 1 the effective date of a regulation prohibiting member banks of the Reserve System from absorbing charges for check collection and services.

A series of four garden lectures at the New York Junior League clubhouse, arranged in cooperation with Country Life and The American Home, will be inaugurated on Tuesday with a talk by Professor Hugh Findlay, whose subject will be "Gardens to Live With."
Drew won its fifth basketball game in six starts when it defeated the New York Aggies, 35-20, tonight. Harry Stillwell was the high scorer with 14 points.

THOSE who like to use scissors and paste find in the sample books of last year's wallpaper the means to a decorative craft that affords an almost limitless creative outlet for leisure hours during the Winter.

The National Labor Relations Act does not restrain the free circulating of news nor does it impair the privilege of a news-gathering agency of discharging an employe for failure to live up to its standards of impartiality, government counsel declared in a brief filed today with the Supreme Court in behalf of the National Labor Relations Board.

THE worse the weather for the skiers, the happier are the sportsmen in the Carolinas. As they stride across billiard-green golf courses or amble through rust-colored woods they mutter happily that while last Winter was paradise for the snowbirds, this is their year to gloat.

White Cockade, owned by Ogden Phipps, won today at Hialeah Park a few minutes after two men who have been watching horses run for sixty years regretfully concluded that he probably could not score over the slow track that prevailed for the running of the $4,090 Miami Beach Handicap.

THE name of Francis Beeding has, in recent years, been associated with stories of international intrigue, in which gallant British Secret Service men and villainous foreign spies chased each other all over the map, affording, in the words of one of Beeding's admirers, "plenty of action and mileage."

An extremely modest New York City woman who, while stranded last week in flooded Louisville, pitched in and aided workers in caring for homeless families, told reluctantly yesterday afternoon of how she happened to be brought into the emergency work.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Celotex Corporation of Chicago had filed a registration statement covering $4,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent debentures, due on Feb. 1, 1947, with attached common - stock purchase warrants, and 40,000 shares of nopar-value common stock to be reserved for exercise of the warrants.
Into the torrent of flood news this week, Mayor Kelly of Chicago flung forty-five pages of proposals for solution of the city's long-nursed traction problem.

Architecturally, many of the new houses being built today follow Colonial or "modified Colonial" lines. Hence, the marked revival of interest in the Colonial garden. But with the garden-as with the house-it is essential that the design be Colonial in more than name alone; that certain basic ideas be carried out, even though they may be modified to suit modern conditions.
Walter W. Ramer Sr., of 189 Liberty Street, Bloomfield, N. J., former head of the Ramer Wholesale Typewriter Company of New York, dropped dead in the street here today of a heart attack.

Mopping up of Southern Indiana's Ohio Valley began in earnest today. Some places were still too watersoaked for efficacious efforts to" ward rehabilitation, but along the eastern boundary the citizens of Lawrenceburg, Aurora and Rising Sun followed the river as it retreated foot by foot, anxious to salvage what they could.

WHAT has the Occident to offer the Orient? One thing only, in the opinion of Elgin Groseclose, and that something which in its beginning belonged to the Orient, so that the West can merely share with the East what is in fact its own.

Members of the North Carolina Society of New York, of which Charles W. Lewis is president, will hold their annual dinner dance Friday at the St. Regis. Benjamin Duke Glenn is chairman of the arrangements committee. An entertainment program will be presented during the dinner.

Extension of the safety provisions now effective on passenger vessels to ships of the cargo carrier class is urged in a set of provisions which will be considered by the governing body of the International Labor Office when it meets Thursday in Geneva for its seventy-eighth session.

Walter Zimmerman of Oak Park, Ill., sculptor, died here tonight of pneumonia. Mr. Zimmerman was engaged by the Ililnois Daughters of the American Revolution to carve the episode of the migration in 1830 of Lncoln from Indiana to Illinois on the new Lincoln tablet on the Illinois end of the Wabash River bridge.
NOW for a long look ahead at the streets in Spring. There is no trickery about it. The fashions are already made, the fabrics spun and the color charts worked out.

The nation's only free port, at Stapleton, S. I., will start operations tomorrow, housed in four of the twelve two-decked piers the city built during the days of Mayor Hylan at a cost of about $20,000,000. There will be no formal ceremonies, the free port will merely be opened for business.

Performances of "And Now Goodbye," a play adapted by Philip Howard from James Hilton's novel, with Philip Merivale and Marguerite Churchill in the leading roles, have been taken over by charitable organizations for the purpose of raising funds to carry on their various projects.

THE traditional moralist has made a spoiled child of tolerance and undutifully neglected to understand and appreciate the many advantages of that opposite and more virile state of mind. "Reasons for Anger" is not only an intriguing title, but the germ of a much-needed theme.

Colonel Terence E. Murphy, a retired regular army officer, who fought in the War with Spain and the World War, and also served in the Philippines in 1899 and 1900, died here today at his home, 106 North Walnut Street, in his seventyfirst year.

College dramatic departments are taking the place of the old stock companies as a training ground for the new generation of actors, according to Theresa Helburn, director of the Bureau of New Plays. The bureau was organized last year by seven motion-picture companies to discover new play-writing talent.

NEW cultural by-products of motion pictures keep cropping up. The latest is in the department of research. In early days when a director produced a movie he shot it off the cuff-made it all up out of his own head as he went along.

Mrs. Florence C. Brockett of this city was married to Marion Hatch Fisher of Lakewood, N. Y., yesterday afternoon at the St. Regis by the Rev. William Pierson Merrill of the Brick Presbyterian Church. Only a few intimate friends were present at the ceremony and at the reception.
To the Drama Editor The untimely death of Richard Boleslawski, which the Monday papers reported, removed, I sincerely believe, the coming master genius among the newer film directors.

Unprecedented honors were planned today for Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, here on his way to the United States to attend a trade conference. Emperor Hirohita was to receive him in audience Monday after which a luncheon was to be tendered him in the State banquet hall of the Imperial Palace.

Millions of gallons of water are rolling over the spillway of the Cornell Dam, making a cataract 150 feet high and 1,200 feet wide, and all of the Croton River chain of reservoirs in New York City's water supply system are overflowing from the drainage of heavy rains.

After many years of comparative neglect the tuberose is once more arousing interest in northern gardens--in the South it had been more fortunate in retaining its popularity--and is probably due for a real "revival."
The most difficult thing, during this flood, in a lightless city, is to hold a flashlight under your chin while using both hands to manipulate a dial telephone.

Many dinner parties last night preceded the President's Birthday Ball, the hosts and hostesses bringing their guests to the Waldorf. Mr. and Mrs. James W. Gerard had as their guests at dinner at their home, 1,014 Fifth Avenue, Postmaster General and Mrs. James A. Farley, Mr. and Mrs. W. Forbes Morgan and Count Casa Grande.

Whether or not there is to be an Anglo-American trade agreement is a question that, in the last analysis, will be decided right here in London between now and May, when the imperial conference assembles.

The newspaper Nichi Nichi charged today that Soviet authorities are trying to compel withdrawal of the Japanese Consul General, Y. Sugishita, from Vladivostok by a campaign of "persecution" so he cannot watch development of that port as a formidable naval base.

The late Captain Hanson Gregory of Camden has been nominated for the Hall of Fame by the national doughnut committee. The citation declares that Captain Gregory, who died fourteen years ago, "not only discovered the hole in the first place, but invented the proper process for enclosing the hole in the doughnut."

A CAMPAIGN for additional members to raise $4,000 to finance the national awards in the Young Artists' contests which have their finals at the biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs in Louisville, April 23-29, has just been announced' by Mrs. John Alexander Jardine, national president of the federation. Mrs. George W. Langford, chairman of endowment and special memberships, is in charge.

Wallace Tiernan, Inc., manufacturers of chlorine apparatus and the Kooler-Keg, have assembled seven acres in Belleville, N. J., for major additions to their plant operations. Leo Flaster, broker, assembled the properties. The parcels include the Channel Lumber Company's holding of 203 feet on Main Street, 248 feet on Bayard Street and 228 feet on Schuyler Street.

A recommendation that the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad's operating agreement with the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad be rejected as burdensome has been approved by Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court.

Officials of the State Federation of Women's Clubs, in New York for their mid-Winter executive session, have accepted the invitation of Sorosis, repeated annually for the last quarter of a century, to be special guests tomorrow at the meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Enlistment of Canadians on either side in the Spanish civil war will be effectively stopped by legislation to be introduced by the Dominion Government shortly, according to a statement in Parliament by Minister of Justice Ernest Lapointe.
Four gardening lectures ending with a flower show will be given for members of the New York Junior League at their clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, on the mornings of Feb. 2, 9, 16 and 23.

The 5-story building at 95 Lenox Av. will be sold at auction on Tuesday by Henry Brady. On Thursday Mr. Brady will sell the 6-story building at 334-36 W. 53d St. Arthur Ponsonby, consultant of the National Real Estate Clearing House, is in England consulting with brokers there cn realty problems.
OUR FRONT?: "The British Empire and France constitute the first line of defense of North America."--Raymond Leslie Buell.

Since 1919 the unification of all rapid-transit lines, with public ownership and operation, has been the goal of successive city administrations. The La Guardia administration is in the midst of the most vigorous drive yet made to attain that goal. But those close to the situation believe that its efforts too are doomed to failure.

Brooklyn Prep continued to dominate the competition in the Private School Ice Hockey League by turning back St. John's Prep, 3 to 1, in the first contest of a doubleheader at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday. St. Francis Prep won, 4 to 3, from La Salle Military of Oakdale, L. I., in the other encounter.

ANOTHER group of sculptural work produced by artists working under the WPA Federal Art Project has put in an appearance at the Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-seventh Street. A previous exhibition was held there last April. The current show will remain until Feb. 15.

SOME of the newest effects in home decoration draw inspiration from surrealistic painting, adding an element of novelty and sophistication to old-time settings and antique furniture. The recent exhibition of surrealistic paintings at the Modern Museum emphasized this trend in art and its effect has already been noted in the color schemes of several decorated exhibit rooms.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan is expected to attend the eighty-seventh annual dinner of the Fordham University Alumni Association at the Commodore Hotel on Thursday evening. Tributes will be paid at the dinner to the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university.

HOLLYWOOD. ANNOUNCEMENT of a simplified three-color process which will materially cut the cost of tinted films was made this week by Carroll H. Dunning, head of Dunning Process, by which some of the screen's more baffling illusions have been created.
A blizzard in the high Sierras today isolated more than 5,000 persons in the mining communities of Grass Valley and Nevada City. Snow piled twelve feet in drifts.

To the Music Editor: In view of the fact that "Le Coq d'Or" of Rimsky-Korsakoff is to be given for the first time in its original form at the Metropolitan Opera House this season, your readers might be interested to learn some of the facts of its initial performance in Petrograd in 1909.

LOS ANGELES. THE first American performance of Ernest Bloch's composition for 'cello and orchestra, "The Voice of the Wilderness," was given by the Los Angeles Philharmonio Orchestra, Otto Klemperer conductor, on Jan.
Freddie Lindstrom, the one-time "boy wonder" of baseball back in 1924 when John McGraw managed the Giants, was wondering tonight what is to become of the boy.
Members of the Nurses Alumnae Association of the Yonkers General Hospital will hold a dance here on Feb. 13 at the Grassy Sprain Golf Club. Miss Lillian Moskowitz,

There doesn't seem to be a holdout in the entire Giant family. One by one the satisfied Terrymen have been forwarding their contracts to Secretary Eddie Brannick with such regularity that he has not missed a day in nearly three weeks in announcing another signer.

The Berkshire School basketball team lost to the Westminster quintet of Simsbury, Conn., 23 to 17, today. Westminster led all the way. Berkshire threatened in the seoond half. Trudeau for the winners and Hoysradt for the losers starred with six baskets each
SWIMS NO MORE: On Aug. 6, 1926--a day that began hot and calm and developed high winds, sudden squalls and choppy seas--Gertrude Ederle swam across the

The increasingly vital role of the consumer in current merchandising was given further recognition with the announcement yesterday that, with the cooperation of national consumer groups, plans for the fornation of a Consumers Council to function with its merchandising division are being put into effect by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Two valuable Rembrandt pen and ink sketches, part of a personal collection on display in the Fogg Art Museum of Harvard University, have been stolen, Harvard authorities disclosed today.

Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, will review the results of the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace at Buenos Aires at a dinner of the Peoples Mandate Committee Thursday at 8 P. M. at the Hotel Biltmore.

A reception will be given this afternoon at the Yacht House, Travers Island, for the officers of the yachting department of the New York Athletic Club who were elected at the annual meeting of the department last month.

Captain Harry Manning, master of the United States liner American Banker, has taken a leave of absence to prepare for a new adventure in transportation. He has been approached with a proposal to serve as navigator of an airplane which Amelia Earhart plans to fly around the world, and has left for California to train for the post.

Add to the Dickens calendar Jan. 21. On that day in 1837 CHARLES DICKENS, Esq., of Furnival's Inn, was elected a member of the Garrick Club, then a five-year-old. Somebody on The Times of London has been allowed to consult the club records.

Racing opened today at Oriental Park under auspices of the Havana Jockey Club, a cooperative organization of horse owners. A large crowd of local fans and visiting American tourists attended and brisk pari-mutuel betting prevailed throughout the seven events on the program.

Rhode Island State College is making preparations for the annual conclave of the New England Association of Women Student Governments, which will be held on its campus the latter part of February. Miss Martha McCormick of Rumford, R. I., president of the women's government group here, has been selected as general chairman of arrangements.
The thirteenth annual conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures will begin on Thursday morning and continue through Saturday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

AT midnight on Jan. 30. 1933, the Wilhelmstrasse, soberest and staidest of all Berlin's streets, was a madhouse of joyful enthusiasm. Its sidewalk, from Unter den Linden to Leipzigerstrasse, were jammed to suffocation by cheering crowds.

A luncheon and fashion show will be held on Tuesday at theAmbassador for the benefit of the Infants Welfare League, and in celebration of the birthday anniversary of the organization's founder and president, Mrs. Harry Marrits. The Rev. Dr. Stephen Wise will be the guest speaker.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, contradicted yesterday Secretary Perkins's assertion that he had agreed at his conference with her in Washington on Friday to renew negotiations for settlement of the automobile strike.

Among more than a million puplic school children who will begin the Spring term-tomorrow are 12,000 physically handicapped pupils in special classes which extend to them the privileges of other students.

The Federal Housing Administration said today that Eugene A. Shekan of Ridgewood, N. J., had been appointed assistant to the deputy administrator and director of savings and building and loan activities, with headquarters here.

Joseph Berger, 29 years old, of 643 Warwick Street, Brooklyn, and Gabriel Klar, 34, of 618 Chester Street, Brooklyn, who were indicted Friday for murder in the first degree in connection with the fatal stabbing of Frank Cicero, 33, of Stamford, Conn., at a dinner in the Manhattan Opera House two weeks ago, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Judge Cornelius F. Collins in the Court of General Sessions.

Opening a program of public discussion in five communities Monday night, Fairfield County Public Forums will become the first Eastern unit in a nation-wide movement to stimulate civic education and better understanding of domestic and world problems of the day.

Library sets of the works of English and American authors, first editions, and autograph material, including the library of the late Theodore A. Swan, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., Wednesday and Thursday afternoons.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Woods Bliss will be hosts tomorrow at a musical in their home, Dumbarton Oaks. Mr. and Mr. Dwight Davis, who are returning from the South this week will entertain at dinner on Feb. 6.

The collection of New England antiques formed by the late Frederick Wellington Ayer of Bangor, Me., for Marietta R. Ayer will be sold by her order at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

Miss Anne Marjorie Walsh, daugnter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Walsh of 1,111 East Second Street, Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to Arthur Robert Gallagher, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Eugene C. Gallagher of Rahway, N. J.

IN 1833 a certain Harvard undergraduate had the measles--an occurrence of such unimportance that it would have entirely escaped notice had it not led to the writing of a landmark in American literature.

Robert S. Stevens, a Professor of Law at Cornell University since 1921, was named dean of the law school by the university trustees today. He succeeds Charles K. Burdick, chairman of the State Law Revision Commission, who resigned Jan. 1 after ten years as dean.

Although a new Presidential term at Washington has barely begun, the line of action of the Republicans in the State Legislature will be determined largely by thoughts of 1940, when another national election will be held, and 1938, when the State will elect a Governor, a United States Senator and members of the House of Representatives of the State Legislature.

Newspaper reporters not members of the American Newspaper Guild were barred today from the Fisher Body Plant No. 1, owned by the General Motors Corporation, by the sitdown strikers who seized possession of the plant a month ago.
As a survey of the tastes and tendencies of the reading public, the book-publishing census compiled at the end of each year by The Publishers' Circular is necessarily inadeguate.

ZADKINE, the Russian sculptor, is attracting many visitors to the Brummer Gallery. Within an hour or so of the opening of this beautifully installed exhibition the gallery was an animated place. Other sculptors and artists were quick to respond, recognizing in Ossip Zadkine, as one could not fail to do, a poet and a craftsman whose work possesses real style.
Predicted flood crests for February in the lower Mississippi River Valley from Natchez to New Orleans were lowered about two feet today in a revised forecast by the New Orleans Weather Bureau.

DODGE CITY, KAN. THE Fort Zarah State Park, developed by the State Highway Commission in its plan to preserve historical spots in Kansas, will recall to present travelers on the motor highway the dangers which beset travelers over the old Santa Fe Trail.

To show present trends in foreign poster advertising and to emphasize the artistic value of these trends to American poster design, an international exposition of design in outdoor advertising, entitled "New Poster," will be held March 17 to May 2, inclusive, in Franklin Hall of The Franklin Institute.

NASSAU, Bahamas.--The Scorpion Club will hold a private shoot today, after which two teams will be picked for public competition during the season with the Bahamas Rifle Association, with a view eventually to entering a team for the annual West Indies shoot, conducted under the auspices of the National Rifle Association, Bisley Camp, England.

Denial has been made by the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York to the statements recently made at hearings before the Housing Authority that rentals have been raised in many old-law tenement houses because of the impending housing shortage.

A BOY was born in a farm cottage at Northfield, Mass., on Feb. 5, 1837, and was christened Dwight Lyman Ryther Moody. The home, a brick mason's, was humble and poor. Its nine children were early left fatherless.
The annual concert of the New York Junior League Glee Club, to be given Friday night at the league clubhouse, has received a large advance subscription.

Lawrenceville's swimming team defeated Erasmus Hall of Brooklyn, 38-28, today. The victors' five first places, including that gained in the medley relay, accounted for most of their points. Erasmus won two individual events and the freestyle relay.

Attacking modern educational methods which neglect the classics and liberal arts, Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, in an address yesterday urged a revival of the arts of language to help students understand the tradition in which they live.

Dr. George C. Diekman, since 1895 a member of the New York State Board of Pharmacy and a former Professor of Pharmacy at Columbia University, died yesterday at his home, 2,215 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn, after a month's illness.

In response to a demand manifested during the past two years for individual residential properties and apartment buildings in Queens and on the North Shore of Long Island, building programs have been greatly expanded for 1937, according to brokers and developers.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, was the guest of honor yesterday afternoon of the Women's Civic Organization, which celebrated its eleventh anniversary with a luncheon and bridge at the Hotel Commodore.
Curly-haired Vivian McGrath today won the Australian tennis championship, defeating 17-year old Jack Bromwich, 6-3, 1-6, 6-0. 2-6. 6-1. in the final.

Members of society in the North Shore colonies and incorporated villages and prospective new estate owners have been taking advantage of the mild weather to build new homes and additions to their country places.

Squadron A's indoor polo team clung to its second-place position in the Metropolitan League last night, but gave its supporters a bad scare before it came to life in the second half to score nine goals and defeat Governors Island, 11 1/2 to 5 1/2. In the first game of the evening the New York Athletic Club won a hard-fought league game from the 112th Field Artillery, 10 to 9.

Twenty-five years ago, as today, the country was agitated over industrial unionism. Then the idea was being promoted by the I. W. W. In 1912 that organization of Western laborers came East and staged a great textile strike at Lawrence, Mass. The strikers gained wage increases, but their industrial doctrine so alarmed employers that strikes in other cities were fought to a standstill.

Continued activity in the construction of homes and apartment houses in Brooklyn is predicted by Melville A. Kelsey, president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board, who bases his opinion on building records for the borough over the past two years.

A survey of loans made during the last six years by the Franklin Society for Home Building and Savings shows, points out Kenneth H.
