Zabriskie, vice president, that the average borrower today is under 44 years of age, or four years younger than in 1930. That shows that he carries more than twice as much life insurance.

Approximately three and one-half times as many apartment houses and dwellings were built in the Bronx in 1936 as in 1935, according to Herman A. Acker, head of the realty firm bearing his name and president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

Miss Olive Winifred Grimshaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Grimshaw of this city, was married this afternoon to Robert Henry Schmelzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Schmelzer, also of Passaic. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Donald Macadie, the rector, officiated.
The recent opening of Wheaton's new 25 by 60 foot pool has brought an increase in enthusiasm for swimming which promises to make it the most popular indoor Winter sport at the college.

A "King of v England, Scotland and Ireland" was proclaimed publicly today, but the monarch this time was not George VI. In a ceremony at Oxford University, where traditions die hard, a Jacobite faction among the students paid homage at the Martyrs Memorial to Prince Rupprecht of Bavaria--"King" by descent from Charles I of England. The ceremony marked the anniversary of the execution of that unfortunate monarch in 1649.

Under auspices of four of the leading organizations of Jewish women, the third annual assembly of the Women's Institute of Jewish Studies will be held at 1 P. M. tomorrow at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.
Pitt's Panthers strengthened their leadership of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball Conference tonight by defeating West Virginia, 44--36. The loss dropped the Mountaineers to last place.

Many of the better type of apartments in Harlem's Negro section are fully occupied, reports Fitzherbert Howell, who specializes in those properties. While rentals are still at a low ebb, he declares that rates must advance in the near future in view of the general housing shortage which is beginning to be seriously felt in some areas.
Montreal's Flying Frenchmen, the Canadiens of the National Hockey League, will be the New York Americans' rivals in tonight's game at Madison Square Garden.

Two sons of the late Joyce Kilmer, soldier-poet, one of whom is a junior clerk with the FHA in Washington, will each receive $25,602 from the estate of their grandfather, Dr. Frederick B. Kilmer, the final accounting of which was approved in Orphans Court yesterday by Judge Adrian Lyon.

Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, former Foreign Minister of Brazil, after a visit yesterday to the World's Fair site in Queens and an inspection of fair exhibits in the Empire State Building, expressed enthusiasm for the project and said he would use all his influence to have Brazil "worthily" represented at the exposition in 1939.

Twenty-one workers deemed to have shown outstanding skill in the erection of the addition to the American Radiator Building nearing completion at 46 East Fortieth Street, will be honored in ceremonies to be held on Thursday at 11:45 A. M. under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.

An estimated population of 1,253,400 is given for Queens borough at the present time by the statistical bureau of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce. The estimate was completed by Percival Mullikin, chairman of the bureau and it marks the twelfth year that the Commerce Chamber has compiled annual population figures for the borough.

This South Berkshire town of 569 inhabitants is attracting wide interest because of its financial position. Debtless, with $12,000 surplus and a tax rate of only $22 on each $1,000, the town officers at the annual town meeting on Monday will be able to give a good account of their stewardship.

Driving down the stretch in a heavy rain, Marshall Shea's Merry Maker won the $3,500 added San Vincente Handicap at Santa Anita today in a field of candidates for the coming $50,000 added Santa Anita Derby.

Dr. Niels Bohr of Copenhagen, Denmark, distinguished theoretical physicist, will come to Princeton the first week in February to give a series of lectures on theoretical physics, it is announced at the Institute for Advanced Study. Dr.
Mrs. Robert N. Turner of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Pamelia Turner, to Hugh Montell McNeill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis B. McNeill of Huntington, W. Va.

Temple University has put into operation, on the grounds of the Stella Elkins Tyler School of Fine Arts, in Elkins Park, a foundry in which art students may learn to translate their work in sculpture from clay to bronze. University officials say it is the first project of its kind in the country.

The "100 Per Cent Rented Club," composed of building superintendents of the Herman A. Acker Corporation, is credited by Mr. Acker with being in large part responsible for the buildings under his management having at present less than 8 per cent in vacancies.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William D. Ray of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine M. Ray, to Frank Bryant, son of Mrs. Frederick Bryant of Worcester, Mass., and New York, and the late Dr. Bryant.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler decreed today that Berlin, like Paris under the first and second Napoleons, should be replanned and rebuilt. A general architect for the city has been appointed-Professor Albert Speer, who started his career in 1932 and has constructed only Nazi party buildings.

John L. Eschrich, reporter for The Louisville Courier Journal, has won the title of the Derby city's Noah. On Sunday, when few persons believed the flood would be serious, Eschrich, after a trip to the Weather Bureau, telephoned his city editor, and shouted:

At the sixty-first annual all-breed bench show of the Westminster Kennel Club in Madison Square Garden Feb. 10, 11 and 12 there will be exhibited 3,144 dogs. This is the greatest entry ever received in the history of the organization.

Putnam Hill Chapter, D. A. R., will meet at the Putnam Hill Cottage on Thursday afternoon. The Rev. Daniel Bliss, pastor of the Second Congregational Church, Greenwich, will give an illustrated address, describing the earthquake and fire in Tokyo in 1923, which he witnessed.
Business in the Brooklyn and Queens real estate brokerage field in 1936 was the best for any year since 1928, according to George S. Horton, president of the Bulkley Horton Company.

Captain Johann Wagner, a retired master of the Hamburg American Line, arrived yesterday on the liner New York to visit relatives and friends. He said that it was the first time in his forty-six years of sea service that he had traveled as a passenger.

The New York Rovers downed the Hershey sextet, 4-2, in an Eastern Amateur League game tonight. The Rovers scored in the second period, Wareing crashing through on a pass from Macdonald. Desmarais tallied in the same period, aided by Collings's backhand pass.

Sixteen women pc ts will read their own compositions in a contest to be judged by John Hall Wheelock and Padraic Colum, both authors of books of verse, at a meeting of the Carroll Club's Literary Guild tomorrow afternoon.

Five persons were burned to death late today in a collision between two trucks about six miles west of Sterling. Two of the dead were identified as Julius Kaplan and Fred Porter, both employes of a Chicago concern in whose truck they were riding.

The College Entrance Examination Board, at the request of Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Columbia Universities, will set up a new examination system this April, to help these institutions choose the nation's ablest high school students for their scholarships, Dr. George W. Mullins, executive secretary of the board, announced yesterday.
Midyear examinations at Elmira College, which began yesterday, were preceded by two days known as "Reading Days," when no classes or laboratories are held.

The third annual luncheon of the Women's Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, of which Mrs. Irving L. Cabot is chairman, will be held on Wednesday at the Botanic Garden, 1,000 Washington Avenue. A reception and exhibition will precede the luncheon.
Navy teams scored a sweep of five varsity engagements at home today, turning in victories at basketball, wrestling, boxing, fencing and water polo.

The most important problem confronting the nation is to avoid involvement in the next world war, if it comes, Senator David I. Walsh of Massachusetts declared yesterday at a public forum meeting held in the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue.
There was music and gaiety aplenty--but no dancing feet--tonight among those for whom Americans made merry at Roosevelt Birthday Balls throughout the country.

Lord Gifford, a grandson of the noted early Georgian jurist, died today at Shrivenham House in Berkshire. He was 79 years old. Lieut. Commander Charles M. E. Gifford, R. N., retired, a nephew, succeeds to the title.

To thousands of East Arkansas lowlanders, Crowley's Ridge means safety. History repeated itself this week when thousands of dwellers along the Mississippi River's west banks left their homes and sought a haven on the ridge.
Honeymooning in a mountain cabin, 9-year-old Eunice Winstead Johns played happily today with her doll--a gift from her 22-year-old husband--while he made plans for their new farm home.

Paul Cormier of Lille, a scaler for a paper company in Caswell plantation, was walking along the tote road toward camp when, at a bend in the road, he suddenly came upon a mother bear and her two cubs.
Lehigh University seniors are to have a chance to learn how to land a job at a demonstration lecture Feb. 4, sponsored by the Electrical Engineering Society.

Some men, on certain festive occasions, distribute cigars, others, encores. Josef Hofmann added eighteen of these to the compositions announced on the program of his recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, when he played prodigiuosly to an audience which packed the auditorium.

Captain Larry Kelley today issued the call for the Yale baseball squad to report in the Coxe cage Monday for its first regular workout. He is still campaigning with the quintet, following a season with the football team, which he also captained.

THAT outspoken and able soldier, Major Gen. Hagood (retired), has given us the best summary of our own national military problem which has yet come from the pen of any member of our regular army. Every main point is sensibly approached and vigorously put. This reviewer is happy to welcome a book of such luminous common sense.

The most advanced forms of social dancing in all its varieties will be exhibited in a novel manner when, for the first time, members of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., will occupy the floor alone and in a body at the annual benefit ball of the society, in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt on the night of Feb. 21, the eve of Washington's Birthday.

THE Summer tourist season is in full swing in South Africa. From Cape Town on Table Bay, along the coast to Durban and Lourengo Marques, gardens are in bloom, orchards are bending under early ripening fruit, and beaches of white sand are crowded with sun-brown bathers.

By having a real leading lady and a feminine chorus, the management of the coming Columbia varsity show is setting a new style.for the college show business. Whether other colleges will follow Columbia's lead is debatable.

The practice of shaking hands, which has been forbidden to Italian Fascists on the ground that it is "unworthy of Fascism," has been attacked in Europe before this. Not long ago an AntiHandshaking Club was formed in Ljubljana (Yugoslavia).
The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Georges Enesco, guest conductor, last night was enthusiastically applauded at its concert at Carnegie Hall by a large audience.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Sarah Porter Hunsaker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Clarke Hunsaker of this city, to David Swope, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Swope of New York and Ossining, N. Y., which will take place here on the afternoon of Feb. 27 in King's Chapel.

Lawson Little, one-time amateur kingpin of two continents, found himself in his element today, and in two crushing victories moved into the semi-finals of the 72-hole $5,000 San Francisco match play open golf tournament.
Every person who files a Federal income tax return, with only few exceptions, is required also under the law to file with the return a copy thereof on the duplicate form (green paper).
Paced by Charles Barnett, England took the upper hand today in the fourth cricket test match against Australia. With eight wickets to fall,

FROM Harper Brothers comes word that this firm is to bring out, within the next few months, an encyclopedia of art bearing the Harpers imprint. The prospectus and a set of galley proofs at hand leave no doubt in one's mind that this will prove a publication of genuine importance.

A well-known musician is now in Italy in an effort to induce Arturo Toscanini to return to America this season. It is hoped that the Italian maestro will come here to conduct a series of radio broadcasts and possibly some public concerts.

BUNKIN--FRANK--Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bunkin announce marriage of their son, Leon, to Betty Frank of Philadelphia. CONAY--WOLPERT (nee Birkner)--Mrs. Augusta Blrkner announces the marriage of her daughter, Hattie Birkner Wolpert, to Jack Conay of New York City.
Mr. and Mrs. Percy M. Chandler gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Chandler.

With Billy Reber and Clarence (Buddy) Combs sharing the scorn ing spotlight, the Winmont Farms team remained close behind the pace-setting first division trio in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League competition by defeating the Gypsy Club, 12 to 7 1/2, at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night.

The alertness of Patrolman Lawrence Kerner of the Bath Beach station resulted yesterday in the recovery of women's dresses and coats valued at between $10,000 and $12,000 before they were reported stolen. Six men were arrested on charges of receiving stolen goods.

Russell Page, sales director of the "Easy-to-Own" Homes organization, reports that, through the cooperating brokers in Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau and Westchester, 183 one, two and three family homes were sold in 1936, having a total sales value of $1,227,137.

A new use for a vacuum cleaner was revealed today by the Rev. Eugene Bardwell, pastor of the Millport Methodist Church. In every Sunday service a vacuum cleaner is used, not for the usual purpose, but to furnish air for the church pipe organ, which, after a ten-year period of silence, is being heard again.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Taylor Parton of Yonkers, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Anna Parton, to the Rev. John Mosher Mulligan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Richardson Mulligan, also of Yonkers.
General Jose Millan Astray, oneeyed, one-armed founder of the Spanish Foreign Legion, asserted today the Fascist uprising would have been won if foreigners had kept out of Spain.

At least 100,000 families which have acquired new homes in America during the past two years are likely to retain ownership until the mortgage debt is paid off within eight to fifteen years, officials of the home building and home owning committee of the United States Building and Loan League point out. That view is based on the fact that this number of houses was built by the present owners and occupants.
Residents of the West Virginia flood zone north of Point Pleasant were rapidly cleaning up their streets and homes tonight while those south watched the high waters slowly recede.

Details of a new transport monoplane to be 30 miles an hour faster than any commercial plane now in use on the airlines are announced by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, whose factory is at Burbank, Calif.

An appeal for new labor legislation by Congress has now arisen as a result of sit-down strikes in the automobile industry, despite the fact that full advantage has not been taken of a law passed less than two years ago which, it was thought, offered a method of avoiding such a deadlock as now exists.

The first step toward affiliating Catholic student groups of the United States with Pax Romana, the international secretariat of Catholic students, was taken recently with the formation of an organization committee under the auspices of the Catholic Students Association.

LONDON. MUCH prominence has been given in the English papers recently to the failure of Julius Hagen's producing concerns and to the fact that other independent film producers here are likely to go under.

LAKE PLACID.--With a crowded Winter sports program, this Adirondack resort is ready to receive its February visitors. From now through the Washington's Birthday week-end it will be a round of activity, followed in the latter part of February and early March by the popular "shirt-sleeve" skiing.

Spring merchandising prospects in general will not be altered adversely by the flood, according to the consensus of producers and retailers' representatives here yesterday. While a clearer idea of the water damage and potential credit losses is anticipated this week, the view was taken in lines ranging from ready-to-wear and accessories to home furnishings that the effects would be temporary and will compel no major revision of production or distribution plans.

Thomas J. Scully, building contractor, who built the Newark School Stadium and Ruppert Stadium, the home of the Newark Bears Baseball Club of the International League, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness. He was 45 years old.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Jan. 29 unless specified: San Francisco to San Diego via San Pedro, Jan. 30: Bainbridge, Goff, Reuben James, Sturtevant. At San Diego: Brant, New York, Nttro, Utah. Asheville, at St. John's Island, Jan. 30.

The christening of the daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Kent will be held on Feb. 9 in the private chapel of Buckingham Palace with the King and Queen and Queen Mother Mary and other members of the royal family present. It is the custom at every royal christening for the child to wear a robe of old brussels lace and cream satin made for Queen Victoria.

DOGDOM is dressing up for the biggest event on its sports calendar, the annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which will be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 10, 11 and 12. And this 1937 version of an unbroken string of sixtyone exhibitions bids fair to outrank all its predecessors in number of entries, value of prizes and general interest.

All components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity declined for the week ended Jan. 23 and the combined number receded to 103.2. For the previous week the index was 105.2 (revised) and for the corresponding week last year 92.4.

Three Atlantic passenger steam ships arrived yesterday from Eu rope from one to two days late be cause of continuous head winds and high seas. The North German Lloyd liner Columbus, twenty-four hours late from the Channel ports, had her worst day last Sunday, when according to Captain Wilheln Daehne, the wind blew with hurri cane force. The ship, which brought ninety-five passengers, was undamaged.
Man can do nothing to prevent floods such as the one which has moved down the Ohio Valley, Dr. Charles P. Berkey, Professor of Geology at Columbia University, contends.
TOKYO. So much has been written of the modernization of Tokyo that a visitor who returns to it after a long absence has discounted his impressions in advance.

AUGURIES being harkened to with respect in this month of January, the sages, viewing "Champagne Waltz," have wagged their beards and uttered prophecy of a year to come of large spectacle. But this is all the great, perhaps, even if behind the arras are seen bulgings of "The Good Earth" and "Maid of Salem," whose advent can't be held back much longer.
James A. Patterson, manager of the Berkeley Hotel, has been elected president of the Hotel Executive Club; Frank Klabouch, restaurant manager of Essex House, vice president;
Strength in Liverpool and Winnipeg dominated the action of domestic wheat markets today. There was no material pressure, and liquidation by scattered longs appeared to have run its course.

In a lengthy decision handed down yesterday, Justice Paul Bonynge in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, raised the question as to whether the "serious public emergency" which caused the Legislature to enact Section 1,083-a of the Civil Practice Act, known as the Mortgage Moratorium Act, in 1933, still exists.
The absence of ice and snow from Niagara Falls Scenery was blamed today by tourist agencies for a decline in visitors this Winter.

For over a century levees have been the main, indeed the only, bulwark against the rising Mississippi. Time and time again they have given way. Yet they are not futile. Without them, cities like Cairo, Memphis, Vicksburg, New Orleans would hardly have grown to their present importance.

An invitation has been extended to the public to participate on Wednesday in a legislative clinic and luncheon under the aegis of the New Jersey League of Women Voters, at the Bamberger store in Newark, the first of the season.
Visitors to the Lafayette College campus this week might be surprised to see a number of bearded youths seated in the Colton Memorial Chapel, pensive and relaxed, listening to the organ.

Colonel and Mrs. William A. Mitchell of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margery Frances Mitchell, to Second Lieutenant James B. Lampert, Corps of Engineers, U. S. A., son of Mrs. Lloyd R. Brigham of Sheboygan, Wis., and the late Lieut. Col. James G. B. Lampert.

As a tribute to the memory of Alexander Pushkin, her countryman, the centennial of whose death is being celebrated this year, Maria Kurenko, soprano. gave a recital at the Town Hall last night devoted to songs and arias with texts derived from that greatest of Russian poets.

An American medical unit, headed by Dr. Edward H. Barsky of New York City, arrived today with a quantity of medical supplies and four ambulances to assist government forces in the civil war. The group, including six surgeons and six internes, announced that twenty-one other surgeons and four ambulances would arrive in Barcelona soon.

Paddling over snowless streets, Walter Young of the Happy Hearts Club, Montreal, won the ten-mile snowshoe championship of the world today at the International Snowshoe Convention. His time was 1 hour 6 minutes 23 seconds.

A tract of 125 acres opposite the Tamarack golf course, Greenwich, Conn., is being developed as a community of homes. The first unit consists of six Cape Cod Colonialtype houses now being built, containing seven and eight rooms and three baths on plots of two acres each.
The widespread strike situation in the United States makes a report of industrial conditions in Great Britain and the European Continent timely.
Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin gave a reception and tea yesterday at Sherry's in celebration of the thirty-sixth anniversary of their marriage.

Its first decade of existence, during which it has functioned particularly in the field of vocational guidance, will be celebrated by the Altrusa Club of New York with a dinner Tuesday evening at the A. W. A. clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Miss Grace Elsie Sloane, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane, heads a. group of young women who will take part in a Viennese waltz contest that will be a feature of the supper dance in behalf of the Virginia Day Nursery on Feb. 8 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Lynn Bogue Hunt, artist, author and sportsman, and Francis G. Russell, president of the Camera Club of New York, have consented to serve as judges in the Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest sponsored by The New York Times Wide World Photos, Inc., and the National Sportsmen's Show.

The great international debate now going on among the statesmen of Europe, which, according to their own assertions, will decide the fate of the Continent, seems to be turning to a surprising extent about such a comparatively minor and prosaic thing as butter.

Aviators' Post, 743, of the American Legion is completing arrangements for its annual supper dance to be held on Friday at the Pierre. Major Eugene F. Gillespie heads the arrangements committee and has appointed Colonel Harold E. Hartney chairman of a reception committee.

Escaping coal gas killed one man and overcame three other persons in the six-story apartment house at 501 Brightwater Court, near the Brighton Beach boardwalk, Brooklyn, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning and caused most of the 125 families living in the house to evacuate the building.

Manufacturing operations will be resumed Sunday at midnight in the B. F. Goodrich Manufacturing Company's factory here, where a sitdown strike has made 10,000 employes idle since Thursday midnight, the company said today at the end of a conference.

Miss Marjory Burt Brophy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Selwyn Brophy of this place, was married here this afternoon in the parlor of the Baptist Church of the Redeemer to Roger E. Davis, son of Harold W. Davis of Manhasset, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. H. Otheman Smith, in the presence of the two families and a few friends.

A serene start wound up in a Garrison finish of excitement in last week's large and extraordinary dinner meeting of the Marine Trades Association of New York at the Hotel Lexington. Motor boat folks are sitting on top and riding high, wide and handsome in this their most prosperous year in nearly a decade, but they mighty nearly led themselves into some international complications in their exuberance the other night.

New England States are spending $10,000,000 a year to eradicate an insect which a man brought into the country with the idea that he might breed silkworms that would survive the northern climate. "It was an impossibility biologically and some of the bugs got loose," said S. A. Rohwer of the Bureau of Entomology.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Levering Crane, daughter of Mrs. William C. Crane and the late Mr. Crane, to David Lee Royer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Burwell Royer of Richmond, Va., took place tonight in Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church.

Fourteen special lectures on the artistic, educational and social aspects of the motion picture, offered by the New York University School of Education in cooperation with the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, will be included in a second-semester course beginning on Feb. 4 at the university, Professor Frederic M. Thrasher announced yesterday. All lectures will be delivered on Thursday evenings during the course.

A preliminary digest of bills of interest to retailers issued yesterday by the American Retail Federation shows that approximately 150 measures have already been introduced in Congress which affect retail trade.
BOSTON and its Theatre Guild subscribers count themselves fortunate that Maxwell Anderson's third play of the Winter, "The Masque of Kings," has stopped here on its way to Manhattan.
FOR the second time in recent years the Austrian Air Line has transported thousands of migrating birds, frustrated by the cold Alps, into the mild climate of Italy.

Following similar action taken by the State Banking Advisory Board two weeks ago, the New Jersey Bankers Association has declared its opposition to proposals to impose Federal branch banking on the States without regard to State laws, it was announced yesterday by Garret A. Denise, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association and president of the Central National Bank of Freehold, N. J.

Opening of an exhibit at the Montclair Art Museum yesterday of the works of Rhys Bradley Jones, 11year-old son of Dr. and Mrs. W. Rhys Jones of 33 South Fullerton Avenue, who died suddenly of spinal meningitis Jan. 4, was followed today by tributes from Van Dearing Perrine of South Orange, noted artist and national academician, and Olympio Brindisi of New York, nationally known sculptor.
Mrs. Ella Murdock Pemberton, mother of Brock Pemberton, New York theatrical producer, and Murdock Pemberton, New York writer, died today at her home here.

Reviewing the Spring outlook for Greenwich and the surrounding section of Southern Connecticut, real estate brokers today expressed the belief that this area is on the verge of the heaviest activity since 1929.
The engineer, fireman and two soldiers were killed as the second section of the National Railways Laredo Express was wrecked near Rodriguez, Tamaulipas, early today.
The Players Club of Swarthmore will present O'Neill's "Ah Wilderness!" next week, from Tuesday until Saturday nights, inclusive. The play is directed by J. W. Simmons.

Younger members of society among the undergraduates at Smith College are taking an active interest in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "Die Meistersinger," with Lotte Lehmann in the leading role, the afternoon of Feb. 12 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to augment the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York.

Contending that the United States Supreme Court, when it held that the owner of a trade-marked product is entitled to protection on the resale price so long as the trademark is part of the product, did not go far enough, A. Wineburgh, president of the Carbona Products Company, Inc., said yesterday that the protection should cover the product regardless of the fact that the trade-mark had been removed.

The first foreign ship bringing delegates to the Thirty-third International Eucharistic Congress, the liner Potsdam, arrived at Manila today. Thirteen Catholic Bishops, of whom four were Chinese, arrived from China. The five-day congress will open next Wednesday.

Publication of The Lawrentonian, a new monthly magazine, was announced today at the Lawrenceville School. The first issue of the magazine, edited by members of the faculty, has been received from the printers and is being distributed to alumni, parents and friends of the school.

Behind the maze of conflicting statements, propaganda, charges and countercharges in the strike which has stopped the production of all General Motors automobiles one big issue is predominating. That is:

George Seabury of Boston led the Yale freshman hockey team to an easy 12-to-2 victory over Exeter today. Seabury registered three of the Eli cub goals and assisted on three others. Kite and Toland also were outstanding in the Blue attack, each contributing two markers.

An unusual event in behalf of philanthropy, the first in a series for the benefit of the sufferers in the stricken flood areas, will take place Tuesday during the luncheon hour in the Caprice Room of the Weylin when a beauty parade entitled "I've Got Youth Under My Skin" will be presented.

The War Department released the following orders today dated Jan. 29: Talbott, Col. S. G., Adjutant General's Dept., Philippines, to Headquarters, Fort Hayes, Ohio; previous orders amended. Hodgson, Lt. Col. P. A., Engrs.,
The Brooklyn Jewish Center quintet turned back the Crescent Athletic Club, 33 to 25, after leading by 20-6 at the termination of the half on the winners' floor last night.
Secretary Wallace will be one of a group of government leaders who will address the National Conference for Palestine to be held here next week Saturday and Sunday.

A new attitude on the part of the Sian rebels, who insist that General Chang Hsueh-liang come to Sian before they evacuate and who make other demands that the government cannot entertain seriously, renews the tension on the military fronts in Shensi Province.

Sales are booming at Manhattan newsstands which specialize in out-of-town papers. Dealers in the vicinity of Times Square, where the majority of out-oftown papers are sold, are besieged daily by metropolitan dwellers seeking papers from the "home town"--Cincinnati, Louisville, Memphis, New Orleans and other centers in the path of the floods.
Army's basketball team, with Monk Meyer in the leading role, outscored Colgate tonight, 34--31, in a game that was not decided until the last minute, although the visitors managed to lead throughout.

THE action of this brilliant psychological novel really begins with a murder which took place twentytwo years before. Dr. Georg Claasen, a wealthy young professor at the University of Munich, had gone for a day's walking trip into the mountains.

While most of the top-flight performers were up in Boston last night the so-called "lesser lights" of the foot-racing world, comparative unknowns, young men whose names may some day mean more than at present, displayed their talents in an A. A. U. development meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Miss Alice Gertrude Doherty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Augustine Doherty of Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to Dr. James Thomas Geddis, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Geddis of Manhattan. The Rev. Sylvester J. Higgins performed the ceremony in St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.

HITLER'S long, rambling, hazy discourse before the Reichstag yesterday on the occasion of the fourth anniversary of the Nazi regime, whatever its effect upon the Germans, must have been disappointing to EDEN and BLUM, anxious for constructive replies to their recent offers of economic and political cooperation.

A patient and two others were hurt shortly after 11 o'clock last night when an ambulance, en route to Kings County Hospital with a patient who had been injured in a boxing bout, was in collision with a street car at Park Circle, Brooklyn.
WHILE broadcasters along the Eastern seaboard are strengthening their shortwave transmitters and building new directional aerials that project programs to Europe and South America,

Dr. William Otis Hotchkiss, president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Insttiute, urged teachers of scientific and technical courses to lay more stress on cultural studies in their classes. He recommended the further development of character and personality.

THE desperate and romantic legend of Gauguin has never been more quietly told than in this book: It is a memoir by his youngest son, who scarcely saw his father at all. though he grew up in the flaring shadows of the legend.

Almost without exception, suburban communities within the New York district have been busier during the past year in the construction of homes than at any time within the past six years. A review of building permits and other construction figures gathered last week by correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in the metropolitan area gave tangible evidence of the extent of the rise last year.

Patrick Francis Murphy 2d, son of Gerald Murphy, president of the Mark Cross Company of New York, died here this morning at the family residence at the age of 16. Services will be held here Monday morning in the Church of St. Luke the Beloved Physician.

Five hundred additional troops were en route to Paducah tonight to assist in the evacuation, by force if necessary, of several thousand persons still marooned in their homes and in office buildings by the flooded Ohio River.

The January salaries of three Harrison employes who figure in an investigation of what a Supreme Court justice has called "the Harrison marriage mill" were withheld today by Town Supervisor Raymond J.

President Roosevelt observed his fiftyfifth birthday anniversary tonight, honored at birthday parties in more than 6,000 communities throughout the nation, by thanking the celebrants, whose contributions, he said, were hastening the day when infantile paralysis "is brought under control and proper aid has been rendered to all."

HIGH on the Alleghany ridges the January snowstorm has turned into rain, the whole region steams with moisture, trees and bushes drip and melting snowdrifts swell the rills and rivulets created by the steady downpour. Over all the hillsides and valleys there is the sound of running water.

SOUTHERN PINES, N. C.--The midwinter program of sports, now getting under way with quail shooting on near-by reserves, continues to attract many Easterners to Moore County. The week has brought John M. Seagle and A. Gordon of the Game Commission of Pennsylvania, who have hunted during the week with the game warden. Among others joining in this sport was Edward F. Spahr of Roscoe, Pa. The season for quail hunting will close Feb. 5.

The annual alumnae day at Barnard College will be held Friday, Feb. 12, at the college. The events of the day will begin with a tea in honor of Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve, which will be held in the college parlor. The class of '12 will present a special feature during the afternoon.

The "industrial production index" for December, published last Wednesday by the Federal Reserve, suggests some remarkable comparisons. It is a "weighted index "; that is to say, is adjusted according as the month's increase or decrease in production was greater or less than normal for the season.

IN 1911 Jamil Sudki Azza Khawy, a noted Baghdad poet, delivered a speech urging that the veil worn by Moslem women be torn away, and for his pains he was forthwith cast into prison on the charge of sedition.

Children will be invited to hear revelations of science's war on disease viruses when the Rochester chapter of Sigma Xi stages its annual science show on Washington's Birthday at the University of Rochester.
Yale University's swimming team defeated Dartmouth in the Spaulding Pool today, capturing eight of nine first places to win by the score of 57 to 18.

ONE of England's oldest and most tragic families, the Courtenays, has been hard hit by the death duties. The head of the family, the seventeenth Earl of Devon, has recently offered for sale the family seat, historic Ford House in Devonshire.

Real estate prospects are the brightest since 1929, according to Ray Hofford, executive vice president of the Real Estate Association of New York State, who has just completed a canvass of all boards in the State to get a composite picture of market trends. Although he found all types of property in good demand, Mr. Hofford said single-family dwellings led activity.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred V. Leaman entertained today with a large cocktail party at the Everglades Club. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman, Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr. and Mrs. Bertram E. Linde.
The weather changed today from the damp rains of last week to comparative brightness and the Pope's health improved. He passed a very good night, disturbed at infrequent intervals by pain.

IN order to acquaint the public with the section of the WPA Federal Art Project in New Jersey, which is not represented in the current Federal Art exhibition at the Newark Museum, easel paintings created under the project are shown at the Raymond-Commerce Building in Newark until Tuesday.

AND NOW GOODBYE--Tuesday evening at the John Golden Theatre. This is Ehilip Howard's dramatization of a James Hilton novel: the story of two days in the life of an English village clergyman. In the company. are Phillip Merivale, Marguerite Churchill, Richie Ling, Hilda Plowright, Horace Sinclair, Ruth Vivian, Eda Heinemann, Edgar Kent and Kathryn Collier.

THE majority of broadcasting stations maintain emergency current supply equipment, which at times seems useless, for throughout years it is never needed. Such disasters as the Midwest flood teach the value of such

In Washington this week close to a dozen government agencies have been gearing themselves up to meet what Rear Admiral Cary L. Grayson, national Red Cross head, describes as "the greatest emergency since the World War."
The gas man got a royal welcome today from Frankfort housewives, who had been without gas service for almost a week. Restoration of the gas service placed the city virtually back at normal.

New York University's basketball team, apparently none the worse for its two-week lay-off because of examinations, came back soundly to trounce Brooklyn College, 34 to 21, last night on the University Heights Gymnasium court before a capacity gathering of 1,500.

The Savage School women's basketball team defeated East Stroudsburg State Teachers College, 22 to 20, today. A basket by Miss Ruth Hill with less than a minute to play won for Savage, which led at the half, 16 to 11. Miss Willett Hill, with twelve points, was the victors' high scorer.
The University of Newark defeated the Cooper Union Institute of Technology basketball team tonight, 43 to 27. Newark led, 19 to 8, after the first eight minutes.

While the disastrous flood paralyzed trade and industry in the Ohio River Valley last week and threatened to cause further heavy losses in other areas, business moved at a faster pace in many sections of the country as more favorable weather had a stimulating effect on the demand for all types of Winter merchandise.
Joseph Szigeti offered the third and last of his three recitals, outlining "three centuries of violin music," at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

Lawyers in general were urged to outgrow their "individualistic attitude" and to modernize their economics, in a scheduled and prepared address delivered yesterday at the close of a three-day annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association, by Isidor Lazarus, chairman of the association's committee on professional economics.
Cincinnati police received a report late today that a man calling for help was floating down the flooded Ohio River in a small rowboat. The message was relayed to the Coast Guard here.

Means of preventing delays in the administration of the law and of stopping unlawful practice by laymen will be discussed in a luncheon meeting of representatives of twenty bar associations in the Hotel Pennsylvania on Monday.

The marriage of Miss Janice Wile, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar J. Wile, to Irving Herzenberg, son of Adolf Herzenberg of Koethen, Anhalt, Germany, and the late Mrs. Herzenberg, will take place Thursday noon at the Wile apartment, 1,130 Park Avenue.

Reports from the flood area showed that, while the upper Ohio River continued recession, waters were rising at the confluence with the Mississippi and along down the valley of the latter river. The situation by States and communities was as follows:
The Argentine soccer team defeated Brazil, 1-0, before a crowd of more than 50,000 at San Lorenzo de Almagro's Stadium today to gain a tie for first place in the South American soccer championships.

Offerings of new securities to the public this month included a greater variety of issues than in recent months. Bond flotations were in the aggregate smaller than in December but larger than in January, 1938, and stock issues were the largest since May, 1930.
YOU cannot find out beauty by the shortest way: only in the diverse richness of life can you come upon it; and when you thus discover beauty you have a treasure for memory.

Fixed State and Federal rewards large enough to be attractive to persons in a position to give information on kidnappers to authorities was recommended yesterday at the annual meeting of the New York State District Attorneys Association, a section of the New York State Bar Association.

The Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage and violations of the right of collective bargaining and of peaceful picketing is now in the midst of sensational disclosures. Its inquiry has been filled with echoes of violence and distrust in employer-employe relationships.

An influenza epidemic is raging here and in many other sections of Rumania. More than 5,000 school children have been stricken in Bucharest. All schools are closed for a fortnight and a number of factories and stores also have been shut.

ON the appearance a short time ago in Paris of Charles Plisnier's "Mariages" (Editions Correa), a novel written by a still youthful Belgian, a name no less than that of Balzac was evoked in some quarters.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Elizabeth Zicterman of this city, daughter of Mrs. Peter Zicterman of Chicago and the late Mr. Zicterman, to Donald Pastorius Wilson of Mount Vernon, N. Y., took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

A rapid upturn in coat and suit activity is reflected in the weekly sales of the consumer protection labels of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, F. Nathan Wolf, executive secretary, repoted yesterday. Label sales last week totaled 391,800, which is 48,800 in excess of the figure for the preceding week and 131,800 greater than that of the corresponding week last year.

Definite policies observed by the Real Estate Bureau of the State Banking Department contributed to the recent sale of the forty-twostory Broadway-Continental Building, 1,450 Broadway, at Forty-first Street, states Willard K. Denton, manager of the bureau.

Government lines to the west and northwest of this vital railroad and highway junction remain as they were before the Insurgents launched a heavy three-day attack this week. All idea that the Valencia road is being menaced from this quarter, about twenty-five miles southeast of Madrid, can be certainly dismissed for the present.

Mrs. I. Curtis Gary will give a tea on Friday in the Garden of the Ambassador for members of the Chi Kappa Club of the Stony Wold Sanatorium. A meeting of the organization will precede the tea. The club supports five young women at the sanatorium, as well as contributing clothing and knitted articles.

The Reserve Board's order raising reserve requirements was hailed as "wholly admirable" last night by Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank, according to The Associated Press.

Lou Gehrig's party to the press at the Hotel Commodore yesterday was for the purpose of making public the Iron Horse's ambition to top all the records in major league baseball, or at least a major portion of them.

Students of design and of Indian cultures of NorthandSouth America have a new aid at the Brooklyn Museum in a mural map depicting and locating decorative motifs and symbols, typical of each geographical area. The map in the work of two WPA artists, Guy Maccoy and Leonard S. Jenkins of the Federal Art Project.

Reviewing with considerable satisfaction the upturn which took place in real estate in the metropolitan district last year, brokers joined yesterday in predicting furtheir gains during the months just ahead.

Every year a greater number of gardeners avail themselves of the many lectures, "demonstrations" and short courses presented by garden clubs, horticulture societies, botanic gardens, experiment stations and similar organizations and institutions.

Election of officers during the morning session and installation of the new executives at an evening ceremony at the Hotel Astor will be the principal items of business before the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs on Friday.

A bridge tea will be held tomorrow at the Plaza under the auspices of the Women's Auxiliary of Congregation Emanu-El, of which Mrs. Belle Sessler is president, for the benefit of the philanthropic activities of the organization.

The fourth and last of the free symphony concerts for the month of January, under the direction of David Mannes, was presented last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. An audience of approximately 9,000 heard the program.
The Hispanic Art Center, founded on Pan-American Day, April 14, 1935, to promote cultural relations between the people of the Americas, has incorporated itself as the PanAmerican Center.
A series of weekly sailing races on Lake Conway, which will culminate on March 14 in a State-wide regatta, were begun here this week by the Orlando Yacht Club.
The new thirteen-million-dollar Interior Department Building, the latest polished expletive in mechanically equipped structures, has been finished.

EXCEPT for the areas affected by floods and strikes, retail trade turned in better figures last week and irregular conditions were less pronounced. On the Coast the prospective settlement of the maritime strike led to improvement. In the East sales regained a good lead over last year.

ALFRED EINSTEIN is a learned and authoritative musical student, having at his fingers' ends much of the accumulated wisdom of his science. This accumulation has been enlarged greatly in recent decades.

The parallel mirrored walls of the dining room of the Jansen suite at the Waldorf-Astoria reflected yesterday an infinite number of images of coats of arms, medals, flags, daffodils, sweet peas and members of the Order of Americans of Armorial Ancestry.

Forty sales totaling $448,000 were made during 1936 by the Wheeler Agency of Darien, Conn., Herbert Wheeler reports. The company sold nineteen houses at an average price of $18,750 and twenty-one parcels of land, the average price of which was $4,400; it rented 100 furnished and unfurnished listings for a total of $86,750.

More than 200 members of the Veterans Club of the New York Athletic Club assembled at the thirty-ninth annual dinner of the organization last night commemorating the 100th anniversary of the birth of the club's founder, the late William B. Curtis.
Perhaps the Vermont Legislature of 1937 will be immortalized in some of the literature of the coming year. For this group of 278 solons is being observed at their session by several writers.

The greatest amateur racquets player developed in this country, now past his prime, looked down from the balcony of the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday and saw his son carry on the family tradition by winning his first American title.

Members of the Jefferson County Independent Milk Producers Association, representing 2,000 dairymen, met here today to consider their program for presentation before the joint legislative committee hearing in Watertown Feb. 5.

As a result of continuing interest on the part of members of the Home Makers Forum in the development of the city markets, a meeting in the office of the commissioner of that municipal division last December was followed by a tour, two weeks ago, of the new enclosed market in Park Avenue, and of the proposed sites of the five new markets.

The final services of the Cornell Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church, 231 East Seventy-sixth Street, will be held today at 11 A. M. and 7:15 P. M. Earlier this month the building was sold, its financial burdens having become too heavy. It is to be razed to make way for an apartment house.
The town of Belleville, In Essex County, N. J., desires to dispose of a number of town-owned properties, both industrial and residential, according to William H. Williams, Mayor and Finance Director.

THE Nation's Number One Citizen, the President of the United States, 'is also its Number One movie fan. With an enthusiasm rivaling that which he gives to the job of running the nation, it is nothing for the Chief Executive to see four and five movies a week, a figure calculated to stop the casual moviegoer in his tracks and leave even the dyed-in-the-wool fan checking up on his laurels.
Continuance in 1937 of the improvement which was experienced by Bronx real estate in 1936 is foreseen by realty brokers in that borough.

A new era for the Austrian Nazis and their pronounced Nationalist backers has opened, as a recent visit to the Austrian provinces revealed to this correspondent, by the foundation in Graz Jan. 14 of the East Mark Volksverein.
More than 5,000 guests attended the fourth President's Birthday Ball given at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.
Sixty billion tons of water rolled relentlessly on yesterday toward , Cairo, Ill., crouched behind its flood wall, and the whole rich lower Mississippi Valley as new rains were predicted.

DETROIT. DESPITE strikes and floods which impair purchasing power, the automobile industry is optimistic about the outlook for the long pull. It is not letting its enthusiasm run away with its better judgment, but is basing its conclusions on firm facts.

George Ockner, a 19-year-old student at the Juilliard Graduate School of Music in New York, will be violin soloist at a youth concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra on the evening of Feb. 10 at the Academy of Music here. Eugene Ormandy will conduct.
Many luncheons will be given tomorrow at the Pierre after the lecture on "Democracy and Irresponsibility" which Louis K. Anspacher will give in the ballroom.
The United Automobile Workers headquarters reopened here today after Mayor Harry R. Baldwin said that union officials had accepted provisions under which police protection would be provided.

Extra-curricular music has become an important adjunct to the academic musical courses at Vassar College, and this semester there are six agencies outside of the classroom bringing music in various forms to the undergradaute community.
The beat of horses' hoofs on Pennsylvania turf, accompanied by the click of pari-mutuels, would be melodious music for many a Democratic politician.

SOMEWHERE in Editor Menke's All-Sports Record Book there is a notation that Bill Robinson, the genial tap dancer, ran 100 yards backward in 131-5 seconds. Unfortunately, Bob Pastor covered a zigzag course at Madison Square Garden the other evening and he wasn't clocked in the proper manner.

Professor Lawrence Bruner, distinguished entomologist, died here today. His age was 80. He was born at Catasauqua, Pa. He held a number of government positions, starting in 1880 as Assistant United States Entomology Commissioner. He spent a year in Argentina in research work.
The qualifying round of the open pair championship of the second annual Atlantic National Bridge Championship was held yesterday at the Hotel Edison.

However disappointed the British Ministers may have been by the negative nature of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech today, they are determined to push ahead in the next few weeks with their efforts to bring Germany into a general European settlement.

King George returned to London today preparatory to undertaking next week a heavy program of pre-coronation engagements. Traveling with His Majesty in the royal train from Sandringham, where the royal family has been since before Christmas, were Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother and the Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose.

Mrs. Annie Jamison Boone. widow of Dr. William Judson Boone, founder and president of the College of Idaho, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital of a fractured skull suffered in a fall Wednesday evening.
Harry F. Wolf, New York A. C. star, and Philip T. Moore of the Columbia University Club, gained the final of the fifteenth annual New Jersey squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club today.

Some time before the end of this congressional term it is predicted that the Air Mail Act will be amended drastically, changing the control now exercised by the government over the contractors and in some respects lessening the influence of the Bureau of Air Commerce and the Postoffice Department and increasing the powers of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WHILE Europe has war and rumors of war, the plow share and the pruning hook, given by Americans as symbols of world peace, stand largely forgotten in the Alabama Room of the Town Hall in Geneva, Switzerland. Only an occasional sightseer notices them.

Daniel S. Brassil, one of the oldest employing bookbinders in the city, who was head of the D. S. Brassil Bindery for many years until its liquidation, and since then had been vice president of J. J. Little Ives, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 415 West 144th Street.

Speakers at the annual mid-Winter meeting of the Princeton University Alumni Association, to be held here on Feb. 22, will be Dr. Wilder G. Penfield, '13, professor of neurology and neurosurgery at McGill University, and T. J. Edward Pulling, '20, headmaster of the Millbrook School, according to an announcement today by Bevis Longstreth, chairman of the program committee.
With marked increases shown by sales, building permits and marriage licenses, the outlook for real estate in the Oranges and Maplewood for 1937 is encouraging.

A tea will be given this afternoon by Mrs. George H. Bradford at her home, 308 West Eighty-first Street, for younger members of the dance committee for the St. Valentine's supper dance to be held at the Biltmore on Friday under the auspices of the New York State Chapter of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae.
BUIIDERS and developers on the North Shore of Nassau County are in the midst of an active program which has resulted in the transfer of a large number of homesites and acreage in recent weeks.

The two giant air masses that fight their battle over the United States each Winter are more evenly matched this year; and that fact, says the Weather Bureau, explains the record Winter warmth and rainfall in the Ohio Valley, the catastrophic floods from Pittsburgh to the Mississippi delta, the unseasonal cold on the Pacific Coast and the freak weather elsewhere.

ONE of the momentous questions before Congress--a question already widely debated--is the revision of the Neutrality Act, which expires in most of its provisions on May 1. The problem of protecting the rights of neutral nations under conditions of modern warfare makes difficult the task of enacting effective legislation.

Local quintets fared well in the basketball quadruple-header at the Hippodrome yesterday afternoon, capturing three of the contests before a crowd of 1,500. The Long Island University freshmen, Xavier High of Manhattan, St. Joseph's High of West New York, N. J., and Bayside High of Queens were the victors.
Dr. Charles E. Briggs, retired Cleveland surgeon, died of a stroke today in Lakeside Hospital, where for twenty-three years he had served as visiting surgeon. His age was 65.

A large group of members of the Artists and Writers Golf Association arrived today to participate in the tenth annual Winter championship of the organization. An eighteen-hole medal play handicap, which will serve as a prelude to the title event, will be held tomorrow.

In laying this "Key" before his readers the author warns them that it turns none too easily. To put it more plainly, this scientist-formerly Keeper of Minerals in the British Museum-rather brusquely disdains any facile "popularization" of his subject.

Winter's fiercest weather threatened today to push Europe's storm casualties into the hundreds. Cold and more snow were forecast for Britain in the next two days. When the gale abated slightly in the Shetland Islands mail was C flown there for the first time in history.

In their petition for a restraining order against the Essex County Gasoline Retailers Association, obtained tonight, James E. and George Haas, operators of a gasoline station at 428 Clinton Avenue, Newark, charged that four members of the association had set up a bridge table in front of their pumps last Wednesday afternoon and played bridge for hours, ruining the station's business for the time.

Sigmund Ruud, famous Norwegian ski jumper, arrived yesterday morning aboard the North German Lloyd liner Columbus from Bremen, Germany, to compete in a series of tournaments scheduled to be held in the East next month.

The remainder of Manhattan's varsity swimming schedule, as announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics, includes six dual meets and the Eastern Collegiate Swimming-Association championships at Franklin and Marshall, Lancaster, Pa., on March 13.

The names of the five judges for the prize-story contest sponsored by the New York Newspaper Women's Club were announced yesterday. The contest, in which three $100 cash prizes will be awarded, is to determine the best stories written and published by New York newspaper women between March 1, 1936. and March 1, 1937.
Father Charles E. Coughlin called upon owners of mass production industries today to "recognize that the only method of saving their private property is the paying of living, annual wages."

Several hundred tourists on the cruise liner Kungsholm from New York joined today in the opening of the annual carnival. This year's carnival was named after Ponce de Leon, discoverer of Florida in his search for the fountain of youth and Puerto Rico's first Governor.

Fraternal services were held last night for William Brunner, father of Aldermanic President William F. Brunner, at his home, 217 Beach Ninety-ninth Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens. Mr. Brunner died last Wednesday in Miami Beach,

Although it will not be published until Feb. 8, Conrad Richter's new novel, "The Sea of Grass," already has gone into its third printing, Alfred A. Knopf reports. Each of the printings is of 5,000 copies. Houghton Mifflin will publish the fifth novel of Dorothy Speare next month. The title is "The Road to Needles."

For many years sound corporate practice has called for sufficient reserves to draw upon in lean years, without which "backlog" many corporations could not have survived the recent depression. Some corporations, of course, built up an unnecessarily large reserve and instead of distributing their earnings in the form of cash they issued stock dividends.
Germain Glidden, national titleholder, carried off the honors in the Union Club's inaugural squash racquets invitation tournament yesterday.

William Bianco, 26 years old, of 768 East 224th Street, the Bronx, who according to the police had been involved in the policy racket, was shot and killed early yesterday morning at White Plains Avenue and 223d Street, the Bronx.

Grain future purchases on the Chicago Board of Trade last week were marked by losses, compared with the previous week, but were substantially larger than a year ago. Purchases of rye, however, were slightly larger than the previous week and about 4,000,000 bushels larger than a year ago.
Steve (Crusher) Casey, Irish grappler, who has become a big box-office attraction, will exchange holds with George Koverly in the feature wrestling bout at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory tonight.

Competing in a field of seventeen, Sergeant Joe, eight-year-old bay gelding belonging to N. Harry Wagner of Media, Pa., and shown by Joseph Meara of Philadelphia, captured the top honors in the Olympic Course Jumping Class, a feature of the Trenton Indoor Horse Show today.
Diners at the Cafe Loyale, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, decided to serve themselves last night when waiters walked out on strike at the height of the dinner hour.

Prayers were offered in Cincinnati churches today that no more rain might fall until the Ohio River had receded to its normal stage. The river continued to fall as preparations went forward for rehabilitation.

Two American Federation of Labor unions will represent most of the workers on the city's independent subway system in collective bargaining with the Board of Transportation, as a result of Friday's balloting.

Hardware retailers have regained a larger proportion of their depression loss in sales than the average for all lines of distribution, according to the National Retail Hardware Association. In 1936 sales were reported 62 per cent larger than in 1932 and 17 per cent above the figures for 1935. Dollar volume was only 19 per cent under the 1929 total.

British bankers, who are traditionally cautious when expressing their opinions upon the prospects in business and finance, offer, in view of that customary reserve, much' encouragement because they find exceptionally wide agreement in the optimism they voice in their annual reviews of the position of business and the prospects in Great Britain.

Discontented people were placed in two classes, those who are dissatisfied with what they are and those- who are discontented with what they have, by the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

The flood situation was discussed in sermons yesterday morning by several New York City clergymen, who largely agreed in repudiating the common belief that such disasters are visitations by Providence upon erring humanity. The Rev. Francis P. Lyons of the Paulist Mission Band, Chicago, Ill., criticized the failure of Federal and local authorities to foresee the necessity for. and provide adequate protection from floods.

Few anglers probably are aware of the fact that there is a Federal black bass law which prohibits the shipment of largemouth and smallmouth species from one State to another that have been taken, sold or transported contrary to the law of the State in which they were caught. The law was enacted in 1926.
Final approval of the 1937 automobile insurance rates was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.

The sudden raising of the official rate of the Bank of France to 4 per cent from 2 surprised everybody in financial circles, because it is considered contrary to the cheap-money policy so frequently advocated by the government. The decision of the Bank of France must certainly be taken as a symbolical gesture aimed at checking capital exports.
Two Americans committed suicide here last night within an hour of each other. Both shot themselves in the head with revolvers.
By a sudden decision, the British Government has abandoned its plans to house several departments, including aviation, in a single huge building by the Thames.

The fourth anniversary of Adolf Hitler's rise to power in Germany was marked here last night by a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall, at which 1,200 persons opposed to the Nazi Government heard speeches attacking it in all its phases. The meeting was under the auspices of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League for the Championship of Human Rights. William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, was the principal speaker.

Germany's coal output in 1936 amounted to 158,380,000 tons, against 143,030,000 in 1935. Of the increase, 2,000,000 was due to incorporation of the Saar into the Reich. Steel production in Decemberwas 1,469,700 tons. Last year's total was 19,157,500 tons, against 16,419,200 in 1935 and 5,750,000 in 1932.

" The firm and courageous stand of the German clergy against the cruel and unfair demands of a to. talitarian state and its powerful dictator stands high among the great evidence that God is winning the world to Himself." the Right Rev. John Thomas Dallas, Bishop of New Hampshire, declared in a sermon yesterday morning as guest preacher at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventythird Street.

Lawson Little, match-play wizard during his amateur championship days, proved invincible at this type of golf today when he defeated Neil Christian of Yakima, Wash., on the twentieth hole to win the $5,000 San Francisco match-play open tournament.

The American Jewish Physicians Committee last night gave a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in honor of Dr. Saul Adler, Professor of Parasitology at the Hebrew University in Palestine. Two hundred and fifty persons attended.

Two opposing lobbies, one made up of municipal officials and the other of public employes, are expected to be on hand when the Legislature reconvenes tomorrow night with one of the more important questions confronting it being that of continuing the law permitting suspension of mandatory salary schedules.

Donald Boyle, Amsterdam lawyer, today was elected president of the State Association of Young Republican Clubs by the unanimous vote of the board of governors. He had served as vice president for some time.
Action on slum clearance and bootleg coal legislation is scheduled for tomorrow night, when the Pennsylvania Legislature begins the fifth. week of its regular session.

Prices of hogs last week were on the decline until Friday, when both the extreme top and the average were steady with those of Thursday. The best price of the week, $10.45 a hundredweight, was made on Monday. This was unchanged from the previous week's top and compared with $10.25 a year ago.

Dr. Leon Cushing Prince died here this morning of a heart embolism. His age was 61. A Pennsylvania State Senator for eight years and Dickinson College Professor of Economics and History for nearly thirty, Dr. Prince was a Methodist minister, an attorney and an authority on international law.

E. A. Pierce, a senior partner in the firm of E. A. Pierce Co., disclosed yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange membership which he had bought last week from Stuyvesant Fish, a partner in Callaway, Fish Co., was for a relative of one of the partners in his firm. Mr.

Wheat markets of all the leading countries are in a position where extreme caution is needed, and traders are reluctant to take a pronounced stand from day to day. At the same time the world situation is being given more attention than usual.

After a month of moderate activity in the wake of the holidays, the floodgates of the exhibition field reopen this week. More than thirty galleries, offering a total of some forty exhibitions, are on the roster.
A clean conscience and a faith in God make for wholesome sleep, a Trenton clergyman said today, but observed that the church was not the place to indulge the habit.

The Rev. Dr. William Brown, pastor of the United Presbyterian Church here for nineteen years, resigned today to become synodical superintendent of missions for the Synod of New York, which includes all New England, the eastern part of New York, New Jersey and the Presbvterv of Philadelphia.

BERVILIO LAMATTINA, beer and ale, 104 West Moreland Av., White Plains, by Fldelio Brewery, Inc., on a claim for $1,000. Judge Bondy appointed Frank W. Ford receiver under a bond of $1,000. RELIABLE STEEL SHEET CORP., 160 W. 18th St., by Frank Surtshin. Inc., for $305; Max Pechman, $150; Herman Altenhaus, 587.

Ellsworth Vines stretched his barnstorming lead over Fred Perry to eight matches to five today, defeating the Englishman, 5--7, 7--5, 6--4. Perry opened strongly, but weakened under the rapid-fire delivery of Vines as the tennis exhibition progressed.

" Red tape" in the WPA was the business of the evening last night at the Adelphi Theatre, where some thirty-five actors mustered by the New Theatre League turned up in a revue called "Pink Slips on Parade."

A group of debutantes of this season and recent years will meet this afternoon at the home of Miss Mabel Poillon, 125 East Seventieth Street, to arrange details for a benefit entertainment to be held on Feb. 19 to raise funds for flood sufferers.

The possibility of an earlier, end to the civil war in Spain than is generally expected was suggested by the Spanish Foreign Minister, Juan Alvarez del Vayo, speaking informally here today on the eve of his return to Valencia.

Fritz Lang's "You Only Live Once," now at the Rivoli, is not the dynamic and powerful photoplay his "Fury" was, but, within the somewhat theatrical limits of its script, it is an intense, absorbing and relentlessly pursued tragedy which owes most of its dignity to the eloquence of its direction.

A special Saturday evening series of performances of Wagner's "Der Ring des Nibelungen" will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager.

The New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association ended its season today with the Montclair Athletic Club holding the championship. Defeating the Essex County C. C. team by 5-2 today, Montclair was the only team to go undefeated. Last year Montclair won in the Class B League when there were two Jersey circuits.
Spenser Wilkinson, military historian and one of the founders of the Navy League, who was Chichele Professor of Military History at Oxford from 1909 to 1923, died today at the age of 83.

Declaring it was the American Labor party's first step toward organizing for this year's Mayoralty campaign, Luigi Antonini, State chairman, announced yesterday the appointment of a legislative and public affairs committee.

Moriz Rosenthal, the venerable pianist, was the guest artist at last night's concert at the Metropolitan Opera House. He was heard in Chopin's concerto in E minor. Wilfred Pelletier conducted the opera orchestra for this performance, which was received warmly by the good-sized audience.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday its endorsement of the proposal to establish a bridge across the East River, between Old Ferry Point in the Bronx and Whitestone Landing in Queens, and another span across Flushing Creek at Willets Point Boulevard.

The pressure on the franc is creating no surprise here in view of the sharp and continued rise in the French retail price level and the consequent absence of improvement in the living conditions of the French laborer.

Buying continued active in the wholesale markets here last week, with retailers -making generous commitments for apparel, accessory and staple lines for Spring. Dress demand stressed costume-suit and redingote styles in all price ranges, with plain wool coats and contrasting print or solid-color dresses popular. New small-patterned prints on light backgrounds were well received, and Southern buyers were enthusiastic about the new sheer marquisette, net and chiffon afternoon dresses.

Retail trade sales in Great Britain in December were only 5.5 per cent larger than in December, 1935. This was the smallest increase from a year before since December, 1935. It is suggested here that business was unfavorably affected by the constitutional crisis that arose last month.

The official press continues to emphasize that industry, to provide for expansion under the four-year plan, must furnish its own capital, whether out of reserves or by borrowing, and manufacturers are thus warned not to depend on the Reich for financial help. It is implied that banks,
Recorder George B. Kellman committed two youths to the Camden County jail without bail today on a charge they robbed Mrs. Ellen A. Reader, 21 years old, of her pocketbook containing 9 cents.

The government will collect a movie admission tax of 10 per cent. The proceeds will be used to help maintain hospitals throughout the country. President Anastasio Somoza has announced a large hospital will be constructed in Managua to take care of army men, government employes and the general public.
A plea to American Jewry to help make democracy "continue to work in the United States in the future as it has in the past," a goal termed "as universally American as America itself,"

McGill University, with five victories in as many games, leads the International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League at the conclusion of the first half of the schedule, according to the standing announced tonight by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics at Princeton and American secretary of the league.

Plimpton Av., 1,530 (11-2874): Fanbes Holding Corp. to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; extends mtges. to Jan. 20, 1942, at 5 per cent; $107,800. Bronx Blvd., 3,534 (16-4641); Frances W. Davidson to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtge. to Jan. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $200,400.

Issac I. Kashdan, New York State champion, and Albert C. Simonson, runner-up in last year's national championships, won their final round games yesterday and finished in a tie for first place in the annual tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club.
A press campaign against the Austrian casino system has commenced as the result of a large number of suicides, mostly connected with the gambling casino in Baden, near Vienna.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's decision forbidding Germans to accept Nobel prizes in the future created a more unfavorable impression in Sweden than anything that has happened in Germany since the "purge" of June, 1934.

The Kosciuszko Foundation announced yesterday the winner of the second of the five scholarships open to art students submitting murals to decorate the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria next Wednesday for the foundation's fourth annual ball.

In his first list of honors King George VI has paid tribute to Queen Elizabeth by appointing her a Dame Grand Cross and Grand Master of the Royal Victorian Order. He appointed his brothers, the Dukes of Kent and Gloucester, his personal aides-decamp and created one Viscount, three Barons, two Privy Councilors, six Baronets and a large number of Knights.

Despite the constant fire of criticism that is leveled against them, probation and parole "are nevertheless advancing in usefulness." according to Rachel Hopper Powell, first director of the Women's Prison Association of New York and the Isaac T. Hopper Home, 110 Second Avenue.
Pierre Valdagne, French dramatist, died today after a long illness. He was in his eighty-third year.

Cranberry growers of New Jersey who distribute one inch of sand over their bogs will receive $15 an acre under the 1937 Agricultural Conservation Program, W. H. Allen, State executive officer for the program, announced here today. The sand, which must be free from stones and loam, will help prevent soil deterioration.

If ADOLF HITLER had a particle of the grim humor of BISMARCK, his description of the present Government of Germany as a beautiful democracy might be taken as sardonic. He innocently numbered it among the great achievements of his rule durig the past four years.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech to the German Reichstag yesterday seems in Geneva to leave the European situation virtually unchanged. That disappoints those Who had hoped for something either constructive or sufficiently conciliatory to encourage a constructive reply,

Probably the course of last week's financial markets, which was slowly downward, reflected the feeling, shared by all readers of the papers, that two or three months which had been marked predominantly by agreeable happenings have been followed by a succession of almost exclusively unpleasant news. No one can have escaped the change in atmosphere.

Governor Lehman has completed preparation ganof the 1937-38 executive budget and will transmit it to the Legislature tomorrow night. The budget for the next fiscal year is expected to be the largest in the State'shistory.

Robert Worth Bingham, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, who is arriving today on the Bremen, will be at the Plaza. Mrs. John Harper Bonnell will give a luncheon on Friday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for her niece, Miss Frances Boynton Dickinson, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Boynton Dickinson.
Learning to know Jesus would help all to do things better, the Rev. Dr. Bob Jones said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Rudolph Redlin, 43 years old, an unemployed wireless operator, jumped to his death early yesterday from the sixth floor to the courtyard of 243 West Ninety-eighth Street, where he had lived in a furnished room for the last week.
Members of the Stuyvesant Group of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization, will hold their annual "paid-up membership" card party this afternoon at the George Washington Hotel.

A picture of God with a plumbline maintaining standardss in a too-lax age was presented in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Theodore F. Savage, excutive secretary of the New York Presbytery. Dr. Savage preached at the Second Presbyterian Church, Ninety-sixth Street near Central Park West.
