Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 75 per cent of capacity, and the estimate for the preceding week was revised from 81 per cent to 80 per cent because restriction by the flood late in the week was found to have been greater than assumed.
The Provident Loan Society of New York announced yesterday that its interest rates would be reduced, beginning today, to threefourths of 1 per cent a month, or 9 per cent a year.

Catholics should read Catholic literature in order to attain "true pu: Christian culture, which is based on the revelations of God," the Right Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the New York Archdiocese, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

A "limited" quarantine today blocked highway entrance into flood-stricken Louisville, while an "absolute" quarantine was to be placed on the inundated West End areas of the city at 8:30 o'clock tomorrow morning. The number of dead in the flood mounted to 207 during the day.

Describing the proposed study as a waste of public funds, the housing section of the Welfare Council of New York City and United Neighborhood Houses have addressed to Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate a joint letter opposing the plan to conduct a new investigation of housing conditions in the city.

Tony Marino, Pittsburgh bantamweight, who was taken to the Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn Saturday night following injuries in a bout at Ridgewood Grove, had not regained consciousness late last night. It was announced at the hospital that the boxer's condition is critical.

Paraphrasing opinions expressed by Gouverneur Morris when he helped to write the United States Constitution 150 years ago, Brig. Gen. Louis W. Stotesbury severely criticized the General Motors strikers, who, he said, "have taken possession of other people's property."

Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte gave a dinner last might as the Westbury for Mr. and Mrs. S. Proctor Brady, Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Hiscoe, Mr. and Mrs. Townsend M. McAlpin, Mr. and Mrs. James C. Dailey, Miss Barbara Strebeigh, Alexandre Malakoff and Charles Stuart-Linton.

Harry Kutch, 55 years old, of Kingwood Township, committed suicide by hanging himself to his cell door in the county jail early this morning. Arrested by -State troopers last night on a disorderly conduct charge preferred by his wife, he received a ten days sentence in the county jail from Justice of the Peace George Webster.
Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the Red Cross, announced tonight that contributions to the flood relief fund now total $8,319,500. The appeal is for $10,000,000.

The marriage of Miss Anne Rebe Wertheim, daughter of Maurice Wertheim of 33 East Seventeenth Street, New York, and Cos Cob, and of Mrs. Paul L. Wiener of New York, to Dr. Louis Langman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Langman of Camden, Me., took place here this afternoon at Wyndygoul, the Summer place of the bride's father.

Cotton prices broke last week out of the narrow range to which they had held in the previous four or five weeks and recorded a substantial advance. On the New York Cotton Exchange active months showed net gains for the week of 9 to 36 points.
W. H. Carpenter of New York advanced to the final round in the Everglades men's golf championship today by defeating H. A. Bedford of New York, 2 up and 1 to play.
Stephen G. Weaver, who as a sergeant was one of the guard of eight on duty at the bier of Abraham Lincoln when his body lay in state in Washington, died at his home here early today.

The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America reports for 1936 a gain of $6,606,014 in assets, which stood at a new high record of $115,737,356 at the end of the year, the seventy-seventh in the company's history. Total income last year was $25,137,528, exceeding disbursements by $7,220,191.

The rifle ranges and other facilities at Camp Smith will be improved under a $40,000 building program recently authorized by division staff officers of the New York National Guard and work on the ranges already has started.

Gratefully recalling American assistance to China in times of flood and famine, a group of leading Chinese gathered at the suggestion of Finance Minister H. H. Kung at his home here this afternoon and decided to raise funds in a nation-wide campaign to assist the flood victims in the United States.

Henry W. Toll, executive director of the Council of State Governments, issued a call today for a conference of representatives of all flood-ridden States "to seek future ways to bridle the -Ohio River and forestall flood devastation."

The world today needs that which only Jesus Christ can give, Dr. Robert E. Speer, secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. The service was in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the founding of the board.

Most of the action was packed into a furious third period tonight as the Montreal Maroons defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 to 1, to take a firmer hold on second place in the National Hockey League's international group.

The Economist's index of business activity in Great Britain, based on 1935 as 100, is 109. This compares with 108 in November, 108 1/2 in October and 102 1/2 in March. In December, 1935, the index Number was 104 1/2; in December.
Mrs. John Warns Herbert, who will leave Feb. 16 for Salubrity Hall, her Winter place in Augusta, Ga., gave a farewell reception and musicale last night at her home, 25 Sutton Place.

Eightythree contracts amounting to $6,129,666 were let by ten government agencies under the Walsh-Healey Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Jan. 28, according to the Department of Labor. Orders for more than a third of the -amount went to concerns in New York.

Performing in the same skillful manner that has stamped him as America's premier skier, young Dick Durrance led Dartmouth's powerful squad to a sweeping victory in the invitation slalom race held today.

As in past years, government aid will be given to the development of the Canadian mining industry in the coming year. The chief assistance is the sending of geological exploration parties into improved areas. Periodic reports are published concerning the areas surveyed.

William Judson Eastham, 18-year-old Virginia Military Institute sophomore, of Washington, D. C., died in the V. M. I. Hospital today of a broken neck received in a boxing match last night with a member of the University of Maryland team.

Advertising in metropolitan newspapers is one of the surest ways for a mortgage firm to build a clientele of private investors and borrowers and to acquire prestige, according to T. A. Buenger, mortgage banker and president of Dovenmuehle, Inc., Chicago. A systematic campaign of regular, even if small, advertisements in the leading publications of a city produces much new business, his company has found, he said.

Looking more than ever like the original sitter for a portrait by Goya, Andres Segovia, the Spanish guitarist, dispensed his extraordinary art to a large and extremely enthusiastic audience at Town Tall yesterday afternoon.
The annual registration of school children, which has produced a bitter struggle during the last few weeks between the Catholic church and the Bavarian Nazis, -was held in Munich yesterday.

Economics Minister Hjalmar Schacht's press organ, the Deutscher Volkswirt, criticizes foreigners who are asking what became of the exchange funds obtained from Germany's large export surplus in 1936. The newspaper repeats that this exchange was absorbed entirely by various deductions and losses.

Declaring J. P. Morgan and Pierre du Pont were responsible for the stalemate in the automobile strike, John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, called upon them last night recede from what he termed their intransigent position and make possible the return of peace in the automobile industry.
An elderly widow's grateful tears today started Chelan's second month of experimentation with the Townsend $200 pension plan.

Labor and employers in the automobile strike were urged to listen to God, by the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, when he preached yesterday morning. The Rev. Mr. Shoemaker said:
Rain or snow by Monday afternoon or Monday night through most of the Ohio River Valley and Southern Illinois was forecast today by meteorologist J. R. Lloyd.

Assemblyman Moffat's bill proposing a bond issue of $100,000,000 for slum clearance is constitutional, in the opinion of John W. Davis and other prominent lawyers, according to a letter received by Mr. Moffat from Harold Riegelman, chairman of the legislative advisory committee of the New York Republican County Committee, the New York Assemblyman announced tonight.

Assure or virtually a free hand, without furother intervention by Secretary Perkins, Governor Murphy today threw himself into a series of whirlwind conferences with spokesmen for General Motors and the United Automobile Workers, in an effort to restore the shattered fragments of the truce which he arranged Jan. 315.

Frank C. Pequignot, an authority on pearls, died of a stroke yesterday in Jefferson Hospital. He was 56 years old. He spent thirty-six years in the jewelry business, having directed since 1909 the business established in 1854 by his father, Z. J. Pequignot.

John Golden, New York theatrical producer, won the eighteen-hole medal play handicap event of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Country Club today. He led a select field of famous authors and illustrators with a net score of 62. Golden turned in a card of 54, 48--102 and was aided by a liberal handicap of forty strokes.

The Northern New Jersey Federation of the American Student Union, meeting today at 34 Park Place, voted to hold a convention in Newark March 21 to discuss plans for the annual student strike against war.

This town, which was the first in any European country outside of Russia to put on Dimitri Shostakovich's sensational "Lady Macbeth of Mzensk" a year and a half ago, brought forward another unusual operatic work at the Municipal Theatre last night with the three-act lyric tragedy "Czar Kalojan."
Winter clamped a new icy grip on many sections of the Pacific Coast today, disrupting transportation and communication and isolating 5,000 residents in two California mountain towns.

Reorganization of the women's division of the Democratic National Committee for between-election activity began today. Miss Mary W. Dewson, vice chairman, announced the appointment of Mrs. Mary Thompson Evans of Raleigh, N. C., as assistant director of the division, effective March 1.

Although the raising of the official bank rate this week makes the carryover dearer at the next settlement on the Stock Exchange, the Bourse's tendency still is exceptionally favorable, except for renters.

The Opera Bouffe Company, which has been organized to produce in English Mozart operas and comic works of other composers, staged its first presentation at the Bayes Theatre last night. Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" was the inaugural work.

Spotting their foes a two-goal lead in the first period, the Canadiens of Montreal staged a strong rally to hand the New York Americans a 3-to-2 defeat in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Orders for rolling stock amounting to almost $20,000,000, were announced today by the Canadian National Railways. They were placed with concerns in the Maritime Provinces, Quebec, Ontario and Manitoba.

Two moves designed to help clear Leon Trotsky of the charges against him in the recent political trials in Moscow and expose the trials as "frame-ups" were announced yesterday by the American Committee for the Defense of Trotsky.

Four of the city's best-known cracksmen, whose records show thirty-three arrests and fifteen convictions over a quarter of a century, grumbled in cells at headquarters yesterday after detectives had thwarted a $50,000 "job" that took two months to plan and ten minutes to collapse.
Wallace Smith, novelist, magazine and screen writer and illustrator, died here tonight following a heart attack. His age was 48.

A resolution calling upon the Polish government immediately to restore to Jews the equal rights guaranteed them by the Treaty of Versailles was unanimously adopted yesterday afternoon by the 2,396 accredited delegates who crowded the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore to attend the emergency conference on Poland called by the American Jewish Congress.

The output of manufactures and minerals in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve District, after four years of upward movement, reached in December more than 98 per cent of the 1923-25 average, making the monthly level the highest since May. 1930.

Flying the papal flag, the liner Conte Rosso sailed into Manila Bay today bearing Dennis Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia, the Papal Legate to the International Eucharistic Congress here and the Papal Mission.

Declaring that a "Christian experience in many of our churches today would be a shock," the Rev. William C. Bennett, executive secretary of the Queens Federation of Churches, in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, 164th Street, near Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, reminded adults of their obligations to voting people.

Charging discrimination under the terms of the present law, the membership of the National Association of Credit Men is advocating, to Congress an amendment of the Revenue Act of 1936 which would provide an exemption from the corporate surtax for corporations which conduct their business under written agreement with creditors.

Joe Gould, manager of James J. Braddock, world's heavyweight champion, announced yesterday that he had accepted an offer of $500,000 from a Chicago syndicate, headed by Sheldon Clark, for a title bout between Braddock and Joe Louis in the Windy City next June.

The new 28.2 balkine billiard game will be seen for the first time in New York tonight when Willie Hoppe and Young Jake Schaefer play the opening block of a 3,000point match at the Strand Academy. The remaining eleven blocks, each at 250 points, will be contested each afternoon and evening thereafter.
French financial affairs again are occupying an unpleasantly prominent position in the financial markets here, but the best opinion in London is that no fresh crisis is threatened.

Beginning the second month of the strike in which they have seized and occupied two General Motors plants here, and on the eve of the injunction proceedings to be heard in court tomorrow afternoon, the sitdown strikers today asserted their intention of holding the factories until victory is assured.

Imports of American tobacco into Bremen, Germany, increased 4 per cent last year over 1935, but a sharp decline in imports was rioted in the closing months of the year, the Department of Commerce reported today. Imports for the year were 12,605,420 pounds.

William S. Morrison Jr. is in the municipal trading department of Granberry Co. The Chase National Bank, fiscal agent, has invited tenders of sufficient State of New South Wales (Australia) thirty-year 5 per cent bonds, due on Feb. 1, 1957, at prices not exceeding par and interest, to exhaust $154,146 in the sinking fund.

Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., teamed with Levan Richards of East Orange, N. J., today to win a mixed foursome warmup for the Miami Biltmore women's golf tourney. Miss Bauer, the winner here in 1935, and her partner turned in both the low gross of 38, 37-75 and the low net of 70, one below par, for the 6.640-yard layout.

Although efforts of Secretary of Labor Perkins to end the automobile strike appeared no nearer success tonight, it was learned that her conference here Friday with Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, had been brought about by a third party.

Twenty cadets of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy will receive their diplomas at the seventy-sixth graduation exercises at 2:30 P. M. today on the floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

The redeeming of bonds before maturity dates, which in 1936 reached record heights, shows no abatement, the total in January being the largest for any month since July, and the record for a January in more than eleven years. As was the case in every month back to April, 1936, public utility company retirements led the other five groups included in the tabulation.

The release yesterday of the 1937 roster of the Giants reveals that thirty-three players will report to Manager Bill Terry at the training base in Havana on Feb. 19. Of this number the pitching corps heads the list with a total of thirteen hurlers, most of them definitely established.

William W. Ferguson, retired New York architect, died here yesterday at his home, 23 Linden Place, of a heart attack. He was 73 years old. Mr. Ferguson was associated for more than twenty-five years with the architectural firm of the late H. J. Hardenburg as supervising architect.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., has subscribed for $250,000 of the New York World's Fair debentures, according to an announcement yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the committee distributing the $27,829,500 exposition financing issue.

Carl Gamble made himself something of a story-book hero yesterday afternoon. With twenty-five seconds left to play and the score knotted at 2-2 he plowed through a half-dozen Red Shirts and sent the rubber sailing into the cords to give the Atlantic City Sea Gulls a 3-to-2 triumph over the New York Rovers.

The need for a religion that will make people more socially responsible was emphasized by the Rev. Dr. Harold Cooke Phillips, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Cleveland, Ohio, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street. The Christian religion at its best achieves this, he said, adding:

Although hard pressed in both its games last week, Long Island University continued to set the pace in metropolitan basketball circles and annexed its nineteenth and twentieth victories. The Blackbirds received unexpectedly strong opposition from Tennessee, which played inspired basketball on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden, and were extended to the limit.

Cunningham the Magnificent is in the best condition of his career, The pre-season disposition to sell the Kansan short as a fading veteran who had seen his best days can be dismissed without a backward glance. Galloping Glenn is as good as he ever was-if not better.

A break in a secondary dike loosed flood waters of the Mississippi River into an area of Tennessee already covered by backwaters today, while reports to army engineers here said main levees were holding along the big stream.

A collection of Siamese coins of various sizes and shapes, some dated as early as 1200 A. D., has been presented to the Princeton University Library by the Rev. Dr. William Harris, a member of the class of 1892 and president of the Prince Royal's College, Chiengmai, Siam, it was announced today by Dr. James Thayer Gerould, university librarian.

Enforcement of the MultipleDwelling Law against the one-time mansion at 2 East Seventy-eighth Street, a six-story brownstone front building, which still retains the appointments that in the structure's heyday made it a palatial residence, is bringing about the eviction of thirty tenants, it became known last night.

Brooklyn properties sold by banks were acquired by investors. The Brooklyn Savings Bank sold to a client of Hy. D. Agar, brokers, the four-story walk-up apartment house at 650 East Twenty-first Street.
The board of directors of the National Council of Jewish Women, at the opening here tonight of its annual meeting, heard reports of Mrs. Arthur Brin of Minneapolis, president; Mrs.

A young woman Identified by a note in her handbag as Miss Sarah Rubin, 23 years old, of 1,541 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, was killed some time before 7:15 o'clock last night by a plunge from the roof of Butler Hall, a sixteen-story residence club at the southwest corner of Morningside Drive and West 119th Street.

Owners of 40,000 old-law tenement houses in which 300,000 families dwell will issue eviction orders effective March 1 rather than comply with- the Miltiple Dwellings Law, Joseph Goldsmith, president of the Taxpayers Union, declared yesterday. Mr. Goldsmith said the landlords could not afford to comply with the law and that recent emergency legislation offered no relief.

At the dinner of the State Bar Association Mr. ROBERT H. JACKSON, Assistant Attorney General of the United States, admonished and reproved the Supreme Court and members of his own profession guilty of being " guided by "precedents and boastfully regardless "of reason or wisdom."
When I ventured, last week, to differ with the conclusion of your editorial "Speed, Guns, Armor," I scarcely expected to draw immediate-or heavyfire from Waldemar Kaempffert, or from H. W. Bomser.

Clemency pleas by thirteen confessed conspiratoms against the Soviet Union were rejected today by the Presidium of the Communist Executive Committee, destroying the doomed men's last hope of escaping a firing squad.

The rise in security prices last year,enabled the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation to revalue at more than $11,000,000 investments which it had carried at the nominal price of $1 each since June 30, 1931, its report for 1936 discloses. Chief among the. revaluations was the trust's $9,497,704 investment in the United States and International Securities Corporation.

The influenza epidemic that has proved costly to the motion picture studios by delaying pictures in production has caused Paramount to announce that no new projects will go before the cameras until the epidemic end.

Dr. John R. Huffman of the New York A. C. won the national threeweapon fencing championship for the third successive year on the strips of the Fencers Club yesterday. Huffman, a member of the past three Olympic teams, came through a field of twenty-nine to conquer.

Allowing for handicaps caused by labor troubles in the automobile industry and the floods in the Ohio River basin, trade and industrial reports continue excellent, according to the February bulletin of the National City Bank of New York.

Falvey, Waddell Co., Inc., underwiters, will offer today to the public 40,000 shares of 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle Properties Corporation, a subsidiary of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, at the par value of $25 a share.
Nearly 5,000 gypsies attended the funeral at Graz yesterday of the Austrian gypsy King Ludwig Wadosch, a horse dealer. The late monarch's subjects passed the body to the wailing of violins.

Mr. and Mrs. John Hubert of this city have issued invitations to the wedding of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Ruth Hubert, and Charles Henry Hubbard, son of Mrs. Charles E. Hubbard of Hartford, which will take place on Feb. 20 in the First Congregational Church here.

James J. Wilson, president of the Wilson Stokes Lumber Company and a director of the Broad Street National Bank, died at Mercer Hospital today of a sinus infection that developed thirteen weeks ago. His age was 64.

The team of George Linde and M. B. Alfred of Hartford, Conn., won the Joseph E. Ridder Trophy for the open pair championship of the Second Annual Atlantic National Bridge Championship held last night at Crockford's Club, 14 East Sixty-second Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Rentner of 55 Central Park West, this city, and Larchmont Manor, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bernice Rentner, to Arthur Jablow, son of George Jablow of New York.
Organized labor itself today asked for National Guard rule at Anderson, where are located the General Motors Guide Lamp plant and General Motors Delco Remy factory.

The Pennsylvania Railroad yesterday resumed operation of passenger trains directly into its terminal at Fourteenth and Main Streets, Louisville, Ky. The terminal had been under water and operation of trains discontinued for several days. Sleeping car service is still suspended.

Military, civil and private agencies coordinated their forces tonight under City Manager L. V. Bean to speed the evacuation of flood-swept Paducah and control relief and health in the crowded western highlands.
The continued fall of gilt-edge securities is overshadowing the stock markets here generally. It contrasts curiously with the confident belief of bankers that cheap money will and must be maintained.

It will be "Now You've Done It," the Mary Coyle Chase comedy formerly called "Me Third," that next represents Brock Pemberton on Broadway. It enters rehearsal today under Antoinette Perry's direction and will open "cold," an event that should take place in the customary three or four weeks.

The indications are for partly cloudy and colder weather today and for cloudy weather with snow and continued cold tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

After a dull ever, opening during which, however, healt minor industrials were bought, this week's stock market turned firm under the influence of foreign bids, and the subsequent activity produced advances almost all along the line.

Miss Patsy McWhortel, a 12-yearold star representing the Newark Women's Athletic Club, captured the spotlight at the open A. A. U. meet held in the pool of the Women's Swimming Association yesterday. Five events were on the program, four of them being handicap affairs.
The Brahms program of the New Friends of Music's tenth concert at the Town Hall yesterday included two of that master's finest works--the "Vier Ernste Gesaenge" and the clarinet quintet.
A semi-official statement issued by the Vatican today described the Pope's condition as "stationary but displaying a distinct tendency toward improvement."

Mrs. John H. Morice, in 1,158 5th Av. from Mrs. Frederick Palen; Harry B. Hollines, in 320 E. 72d St.; George H. Lanier, in 7 Gracie Sq.; Evelyn Sladdin, in 321 E. 54th St.; Price Jordon, in 45 E. 60th St.: Pease Elliman, Inc., broker. Oliver N. Hobbs, in 45 Christopher St. from Bing Bing, Inc.

Nearly seven hours after sending out an S O S, the captain of the 6,061-ton American freighter Meanticut, rolling helplessly in a great swell in mid-Atlantic, indicated last night that he was considering abandoning the ship.

Murray Vernon of the Greenwich Country Club was the winner of the Class A final in the annual invitation squash racquets tournament on the courts of the Round Hill Club today. He conquered B. N. Everett of the Harvard Club in five games before a large society gallery.

The National Aviation Show at the Grand Central Palace was declared yesterday to be the most successful aviation exhibition in the history of the industry. The show has now been in progress for three days and a night.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had issued a complaint charging Primrose House, Inc., of New York, makers of cosmetics, with violation of the Robinson-Patman Act.

United States Senator A. Harry Moore of New Jersey has been elected president of the board of directore of the Betty Bacharach Home for Afflicted Children at Longport, near here, according to an announcement tonight. David C. Reed, Assistant City Finance Director, was re-elected chairman of the board;

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,849,334,000. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bill. The list follows:

An apartment house will be erected in the Inwood section of Manhattan as the result of the resale by Joseph K. Schwartz and Max the Rosenfeld of vacant property on the east side of Seaman Avenue, between 207th and Isham Streets, facing the playgrounds of Isham Park.

Persistent rain and mist continue to hold up military operations on the Madrid front. For an entire week not a plane of either side has been able to get off the ground, and for six days there has been no shelling of the center of Madrid.

Carl Hessler, a Chicago publicity man, arrived here tonight to handle press relations for the United Automobile Workers, and announced that he intended to "straighten out" difficulties arising from union discrimination against reporters who do not belong to the American Newspaper Guild.

Two of baseball's greatest veteran players will be signally honored by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America, when that organization stages its fourteenth annual dinner and show at the Hotel Commodore on Sunday night.

A struggle between the American Bar Association and the new National Lawyers Guild, similar to the contention between the old-time American Federation of Labor leaders and the Committee for Industrial Organization, was forecast yesterday when Frank P. Walsh, New York attorney and president of the Guild, outlined further the purposes of the new liberal organization.

Kenneth Kendall Koenig, 17-yearold son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Koenig of 87 Garden Street, Teaneck, was announced today as the winner of the James F. Minturn Scholarship, entitling him to two years' free tuition in the college department of John Marshall College of Law.
Mr. and Mrs. William L. Van Alen entertained tonight with a dinner a company of thirty at the Towers, where they are guests of Mrs. Van Alen's parents, Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent.

Last night was the fifth anniversary of the local Boys Brotherhood Republic, which started with eight boys in an unoccupied store and now has 450 and a five-story building of its own at 290 East Third Street.

Announcement was made yesterday by Dr. and Mrs. Clarence William Lieb of Blue Herons, Bedford Village, N. Y., of the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Elizabeth Reynolds Lieb, to George Douglas Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley B. Lawrence of Mount Kisco, N. Y.

Benny Gottesman, the waiter who told of racketeers under Jules Martin trying to take over Local 1 of the Waiters Union, will take the witness stand for cross-examination when the restaurant racket trial is resumed before Supreme Court Justice McCook and a jury today.
The winners of five fellowships and scholarships totaling $8,750 and one award of $500 were announced yesterday by the Bureau of New Plays at the end of its nation-wide search for new dramatists.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 90.4, which compares with 90.2 the week before, 90.7 two weeks before, 90.1 three weeks before and 88.8 four weeks before.

Expectations of a heavy increase well up in the millions of pounds in lard stocks at Chicago and Western points in January brought about liquidation and hedging pressure. This, combined with the sharp break in prices of hogs, made a most unsatisfactory market here last week for holders, with the close around the lowest of the week.

The new 28.2 balkine billiard game will be seen for the first time in New York tonight when Willie Hoppe and Young Jake Schaefer play the opening block of a 3,000-point match at the Strand Academy. The remaining eleven blocks, each at 250 points, will be contested each afternoon and evening thereafter.
BELOVED FRIEND: THE ROMANCE OF TCHAIKOVSKY AND NADEJDA VON MECK, by Catherine Drinker Bowen and Barbara von Meck. (Random House, $3.) The Book-of-the-Month Club choice for February.

Among those entertaining in boxes for the Perry-Vines tennis match today were Dr. and Mrs. George H. Opdyke, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Dennis, Mr. and Mrs. Carl G. Lueders, Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Braun, Mrs. H. D. Everett and George A. Brockway.

Removing the main obstacle to a complete industrial recovery in the United States, a substantial revival of residential building activity is in progress here that will soon reach the level of British activity and may, according to present indications, outstrip British construction, Alfred Braunthal declares in a study published in Social Research, released today.

ALTHOUGH most of the Giants have turned their signed contracts over to Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick and a few advance agents are already sunning themselves on the Southern sands, the Hot Stove League is still in unofficial session and the following communication from a New Jersey constituent is exposed to view:

A former member of the White Don Cossack Army during the Russian Re-iution has been made a member of the faculty of Princeton University, it is disclosed in the current issue of The Daily Princetonian. The new appointee is Professor Gregory P. Tschebotareff of the university's Engineering Department.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Federal Social Security Board, listed yesterday four don'ts" to guide employers in making monthly security tax returns, the first of which, covering January payrolls, must be made between today and Feb. 28. The list follows:

Consumptive demand for oats is heavy, with 500,000 bushels reported sold for shipment from Chicago at the end of last week. Country holders are not selling freely, and primary receipts are off sharply, while shipments have increased.

There are conductors who might be actors, manufacturers or elder statesmen, men who, perhaps, could have turned to one or another occupation and by virtue of cleverness, practicalness and adaptability made a success in any line.

A "sit-down" and "liedown" protest by Chinese on unemployment relief in Calgary was short-lived. Protesting relief grants of $1.12 a week, thirty jobless Chinese marched to the corner of Eighth Avenue and First Street, busy downtown intersection, Saturday.

Julius Liebman, general manager of The Milwaukee Sentinel, died today in a fall on the icy walks of Lake Park. Mr. Liebman was strolling with his dog on a leash, and apparently slipped while holding the dog in restraint. Death was due to skull fracture. He was 47 years old.

After twenty-four hours of reflection over Chancellor. Adolf Hitler's speech before the Reichstag the British- Government found itself tonight not an inch nearer a solution of its one overshadowing diplomatic problem.

Anatole de Monzie, former Education Minister, was seriously hurt in an automobile accident near Cabors today. At the hospital where he was taken it was said he had a fractured leg and contusions and that he was weakened by loss of blood.

Accepting as fully sincere Chancellor Adolf. Hitler's statement that there could be no humanly conceivable ground for a quarrel between France and Germany, France's Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos replied today to the Chancellor that that was not enough to secure world peace.
During Col. Gen. Goering's recent visit to Rome he might have encountered on the Tiber Bridge another distinguished Prussian, here also on an official mission.

The Senate faces a probable stiff fight over two phases of the Deficiency Relief Bill as Congress enters tomorrow the fourth week of the session. Neutrality legislation will be the chief topic for committee consideration in both houses.

William Atwood Shelton, a retired real estate dealer who was in usiness in Harlem for forty-seven years, died today at his home, 32 Oak Avenue, after a five weeks' illness, at the age of 81. His widow, Minnie Thurston Shelton, and a daughter, Nathalie, survive.

A heel mark in the ground in front of the home of Thorville Rude, 82 years old, of Mooney Pond Road, Holtsville, led to the arrest last night of Orlando Rizzuto, 17-yearold member of a CCC camp in Huntington, on a charge of holding up Rude Jan. 27.

A red kitten, retrieved some time ago from the White Plains animal pound by 12-year-old Harriet Ward of 130 North Street, White Plains, was one of the prize winners in the two-day cat show which ended to-' night at Junior Order Hall.
A still-life painting called "Vegetables for the Soup," by Jean Baptiste Simeon Chardin, has been acquired by the John Herron Art Instite of Indiananolis
In contrast with the record disbursement ordered in the two preceding months, dividends declared in January were smaller. They also were slightly less than those of the first month of last year.

Features of the eighth week of the Metropolitan Opera season will include the debut of Bidu Sayao, Brazilian soprano; the return of Karin Branzell and Gladys Swarthout, the opening of the matinee Wagner cycle and the Winter's first "Die Meistersinger."

Heavy industries and stable non-ferrous metals production are active, but light manufacturing is seasonally dull. In the mechanical and shipbuilding branches the boom is unabated. In December 70.9 per cent of all working places in industry were occupied, against 72.3 in November. Outdoor constructional activity almost ceased because of the cold.
The recent ruling of the United States Public Health Service to facilitate the landing of steamship passengers here by avoiding delay in the examination at Quarantine goes into effect today.

January ended in a gust of rain yesterday, thereby maintaining a consistent record. It was a month of five Sundays,- and every Sunday was rainy, as were ten other days during the month. Records at the Weather Bureau show a measurable amount of precipitation on fifteen days during the month and a quarter of an inch or more each Sunday.

Fear that diphtheria will be more prevalent this year than in recent years was expressed yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, in a statement pointing out that diphtheria immunization treatments had decreased by more than 34,000 in 1936, as compared with 1935.
The strike-paralyzed West Coast shipping industry stirred a little today under the stimulus of "back to work" preparations accompanying the union call for a vote to end the 94-day tie-up.
James Brady sticks to burglary, although it has been responsible for keeping him in prison fortyone out of his sixty-six years of existence, according to the police.

Strikes will be called today against a few of the 250 owners of loft and office buildings who failed to renew contracts with Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union when the contracts expired last night, according to James J. Bambrick, president of the union.
David Isenberg died of heart disease yesterday morning in his home, 178 Beach 135th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens. His age was 66. He was Republican leader of the Rockaways from 1918 until 1932.
Four thousand WPA laborers will be at work tomorrow in ten West Virginia border counties shoveling away debris left by the Ohio River flood.
A mongrel dog, faithful to a master stilled by death, stood guard beside the body a month.

A junior division of the United Palestine Appeal was organized yesterday afternoon at a meeting of delegates from more than twenty Jewish youth organizations, in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth. Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street.

The executive council of the Newspaper Guild of Philadelphia and Camden voted unanimously today to affiliate with the recently organized Philadelphia council of the John L. Lewis Committee for Industrial Organization.

The condition of Mgr. David J. Hickey, vicar general of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, who has been critically ill following a heart attack a week ago today, was reported yesterday as about the same.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:

Premier and Mrs. Leon Blum, Finance Minister Vincent Auriol and other Ministers and a large number of members of the Chamber of Deputies and Senate of all parties attended a reception given this afternoon by United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt in honor of the

Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador to Great Britain. is due to arrive today from London on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen on his way home to Louisville, Ky., accompanied by Mrs. Bingham and their daughter, Miss Henrietta W. Bingham.

Contributions ranging from $5,000 to two dimes pinned to a soiled home sheet of paper yesterday brought local cash donations for flood relief to $934,727.14. Besides this amount the Red Cross of Queens had reached a total of $23,000 last night, of which $16,200 was raised by the Central Queens Chapter of 89-31 161st Street, Jamaica, and $7,000 by the North Shore Chapter of 136-48 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing.

Miss Rosemary Phelps Dodge of Simsbury, daughter of Mrs. Guy Phelps Dodge of Essex Fells, N. J., will be married Wednesday afternoon in the apartment of Mrs. Arthur S. Runyon of 45 Park Avenue, New York, to Alexander Gregorieff Jr., son of Colonel and Mrs. Alexander Gregorieff of Hartford. Only relatives will be present.

Harriet Chapin Hughes assigned to the trustees for Harriet Chapin Hughes a mortgage for $15,000 on 1,748 Amsterdam Av. When the New York Savings Bank sold to the 562 W. 149th St. Corp., Bernard Cransman, president, the five-story flats at 562 W. 149th St. for $29,000 over the mortgage for $35,000, the bank took back a purchase money mortgage for the $29,000.

Only fourteen New York A. C. gunners braved the rain yesterday for the final shoot of the month at the Travers Island traps of the organization. As the number was so small, the competition was limited to one class. L. F. Sanman won the high scratch cup by breaking 94 targets. W. F.

The children who appeared from one of the public schools to congratulate WALTER DAMROSCH at his many-candled, birthday celebration may be said to have represented the millions of school children around the earth who have enjoyed his "wonderful broadcasts."

The marriage of Miss Jean Manley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Manley of New York, to Leonard A. Joseph, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Joseph, also of this city, took place yesterday afternoon in the apartment of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Herbert Salomon, in the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A large area of the Great Plains may have been afflicted by a major drought about 250 years ago, forcing farmers to abandon their corn and bean fields to the bison and creating a turning pint in aboriginal history which indirectly affected the nation's development.

The text of the new Constitution of the U.S.S.R., adopted last Dec. 5, contains several of the guarantees that have been considered the essential bases of democracy, according to the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
The flood in the Ohio Valley was gradually receding. All floood deaths were put at around 400 and the property loss at $400,000,000. The Red Cross estimated the homeless at 671,176.
With the nation's agencies struggling to save millions of acres and a million or more homes from destruction by water, the Public Works Administration tonight reviewed its water impounding projects.

An offer of aid from a floodthreatened city came to a floodstricken city today. A telegram from Cairo, which is fighting the Ohio River, to this city, where the river has cut off the water supply, said:

Beginning of a movement to "draft" Mayor La Guardia as a candidate for re-election and a sagging in the boom of Grover A. Whalen for the Democratic nomnation for Mayor were the most marked developments in the city's political situation last week.

Mayor Sam Beecher and his wife, Katharine, who is City Controller, were arrested late today after a Vigo County grand jury indicted them for misconduct and misfeasance in office. Mayor Beecher and Mrs. Beecher were released at once on bond of $2,500 each.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the largest since February, 1936. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 58,675,976 shares, compared with 48,605,047 in the preceding month and 67,211,035 in January, 1936.

The Kilres brothers enabled the pace-setting Red Wings to come from behind and nose out the Bruins, 2-1, in. a hard but cleanly fought National Hockey League game tonight before 15,000 at the Boston Garden.
A certain amount of reflection, with the recent utterances of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Great Britain and Premier Leon Blum of France in the background, is required to classify,

It now appears probable that a fundamental settlement of the Sian crisis is likely to be postponed until after the plenary session of the Kuomintang, the Nationalist party, which will open at Nanking on Feb. 15.

Three dance performances were on view in the Broadway sector yesterday, when Carola Goya gave her only recital of the season at the Guild Theatre in the afternoon, Elna Lillback and her group made their season's bow at the same theatre in the evening and Uday

The steel industry of the United States will spend more than $290, 000,000-this year for new constrution and equipment. or 45 per cent more than the $200,000,000 originally estimated for expenditures in 1936, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The combined Case load of the Works Progress Administration and the Emergency Relief Bureau in this city declined 10.7 per cent during 1936, Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the ERB, reported yesterday.

Several luncheons will be given before the first performance of the revival of Rimsky-Korsakoff's "La Coq d'Or," with Lily Pons and Eziq Pinza in the leading roles, Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over for the benefit of the maintenance fund of the Schola Cantorum.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Jan. 27 at 81, compared with 80.7 ?? fortnight before, 78.3 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

A situation exists in the corn market that is not relished by the trade. Uneasiness prevails as to the market's action in the future, as settlement of the seamen's strike, reported to be near, is expected to increase the movement of Argentine corn to the United States markets, which, it is feared, will create a lessened demand for our domestic corn.

One thing only stood fast through this welter. I was making money-much- more than four hundred rupees a nionthand when my bank book told me I had one thousand whole pounds saved the Strand was hardly wide enough for my triumph.

A 13-year-old schoolboy and a youth of 20 were arrested last night as the two burglars who escaped after ransacking the apartment of Harry Hanson. a building superintendent, at 169 East Sixty-ninth Street, by leaping from the roof of the four-story building to the roof of a two-story structure adjoining.

A test of what he termed the "fundamental right of every American citizen to be arrested" will be sought by Arthur Garfield Hays, attorney of the American Civil Liberties Union, in a civil suit to be filed in Federal court in Newark against Mayor Frank' Hague of Jersey City, other officials and a patrolman.

Dr. Robert J. Inglis, 69 years old, a dentist, ended his life this morning by inhaling illuminating gas at his home, 646 East Twenty-sixth Street. His wife, Mrs. Anna Inglis, told the police that her husband got out of bed early this morning to get a sleeping tablet.

Bleecker St., 200, 25x98.1; half interest; Peter Rinelli and wife to Stephen Guardino, 8,222 19th A.v., Brookiyn; mtg. $29,900 ($2). 3d Av., 349, 24.8x100: Sol Cohen and wife to Theresa Leventhal. 502 Park Av.; mtg. $16,000. 96th St., 206-208 E., 54.3x100.8 1/2; 206 96th St. Corp. to Entini Realty Corp., 206 E. 96th St.; mtgs. $51.500 ($6).
According to advance figures from the customs office, Peruvian cotton exports in 1936 amounted to 1,746,945 quintals, valued at 91,481,790 soles, an average of 52 soles to the quintal.

The Harper Oil Co., Inc., Long Island City, has. been appointed distributor for Richfield products in the metropolitan area here. The personnel of the new company will be men formerly employed directly by Richfield, under John Harper, who served as branch manager here.
Funds have been appropriated for a publicity campaign to stimulate the cultivation of quinoa, which grows wild in Peru to a height of six feet.

Batting cautiously, England had scored 217 runs for the loss of four wickets at lunch time today in the first innings of the fourth test cricket match of the series against Australia. The Antipodeans compiled 288 in their first innings.

Numerous large shipments of gold from Great Britain in January raised imports of the metal here to the highest total for any month since October, according to daily statements of the Federal Reserve Bank.
In his graceful speech of acknowledgment to the people attending the birthday ball in his honor on Saturday evening, President ROOSEVELT mingled some useful information with his cordial thanks.

The Rev. Alvin H. Bohls of Taylor, Texas, was installed as assistant pastor yesterday at the Fordham Lutheran Church, 2,430 Walton Avenue, Bronx. -The Rev. Dr. F. H. Meyer, pastor, officiated. The sermon was preached by the Rev. Dr. Walter E. Schuette of Sewickley, Pa., president of the Eastern Conference of the United Lutheran Church.

Criticizing the Roman Catholic Church for perpetuating, as dictatorships do, the philosophy that man is insignificant, the Rev. Frederick W. Cooper endorsed yesterday morning Christ's advocacy of man's sovereignty as the path to progress.
On July 14 last the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, acting under recent law, increased the reserve requirements of member banks by 50 per cent.

Mrs. Ella Morgan, 76, who died destitute with no known relatives in the charity ward of County Hospital from pneumonia on Friday was identified today as formerly a wealthy philanthropist who played a prominent part in the expansion of Los Angeles in the Nineties and early Nineteen Hundreds.

Frank L. Weil was re-elected president of the Ninety-second Street Young Men's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, yesterday at the sixtythird annual meeting of the organization.

George W. Green, former pubfisher of The Home Chat, Brooklyn weekly newspaper, died of pneumonia early yesterday at the New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 438 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn.
* * * the press as an international factor [should not] become an uncritical servant of bureaucratic diplomacy or its propaganda organ. Its mission is higher, its purpose should be loftier.

Hank Marino of Milwaukee retained his American match bowling championship by a margin of 20.36 points tonight in concluding his 120-game title series with Joe Miller of Buffalo, N. Y., holder of the crown in I934.

Bad, weather cut down the frostbite dinghy fleet to half a dozen boats in today's regular Manhasset Bay Y. C. weekly regatta. Jack Prokop, sailing 0. H. Chalkley's Popover, won three out of four races in Class B, while in Class D Robert Fraser Jr.

Mrs. Kate Melber cleaned the rooms of the Union College Administration Building yesterday just as she has done for fifty years. At 3 o'clock she changed her apron for a party dress and an hour later entered the same building as guest of honor at a tea given her in the president's office.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M., "Current Events," Frank Bohn. Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M., "The President," George E. Sokolsky. Hotel Pierre, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street, 11:30 A. M., "Democracy and Irresponsibility," Louis K. Anspacher.

With Madison Square Garden again transformed into a glamorous Winter setting the annual Silver Skates Derby, conducted by the Daily News A. A., will be presented tonight at the Eighth Avenue arena. More than 100 men, women, boys and girls will take part in the speed skating races.

Miss Mary Angela McDonnell, debutante daughter of Mrs. Robert Emmett McDonnell, has enlisted the aid of several young women in planning for the annual supper dance to assist the Barat Settlement, to be held on Feb. 8 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Dutch economic situation is improving gradually. Capital is constantly being repatriated, resulting in great strength in the guilder, checked by the control of guilder sales.

The fighting services won 80 per cent of their demands today in the dispute with General Senjuro Hayashi, Premier-designate. The navy nominated Vice Admiral Mitsumasa Yonai for the Naval Ministry, and General Hayashi accepted Lieut. Gen. Kotara Nakamura as War Minister.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:
The International Mercantile Marine Company has created a post of director of unlicensed personnel and appointed Paul E. Warfield, formerly second officer of the liner Leviathan, to fill it.

The net income of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1936 amounted to $3,699,000 after expenses, reserves for contingencies, special reserves for charge-offs on bank premises, prior-service contributions to retirement system and assessment for building for board of governors, it was announced yesterday. This income compares with one of $4,336,000 in 1935.
Labor unions should be incorporated and subject to regulations which would make them equally responsible with employers for their unlawful acts or violation of their contracts,

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, announced 'yesterday the receipt of $86,205.19 in fifty-three cash gifts and bequests made to the New York University Corporation during December and January.

The twenty-eighth annual Long Island Sound championship motor boat race to Block Island, the most exacting of any of the power cruiser events held on the Atlantic seaboard, was set down on the nautical calendar for Saturday, July 10, yesterday at a meeting of the yachting department of the New York Athletic Club.

The Federal Trade Commission today promulgated tentative rules for the wholesale jewelry industry as proposed by the National Wholesale Jewelers Association of Philadelphia and set Feb. 17 for the hearing of oral arguments on final adoption.

Polish-Americans of this city and New Yorkers without a Polish background joined yesterday to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the death of General Vladimir B. Krzyzanowski, Civil War hero, who rose from the rank of a common soldier to command a brigade composed mostly of Poles in a series of brave actions, for which the United States Government decorated him.
James G. Tremaine has been admitted as a general partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Gude, Winmill Co., it was anof Morris S. Tremaine, Controller of the State of New York.

Professor Robert S. Stevens of Cornell University, national authority on corporation law, has been named dean of the Cornell Law School by the Board of Trustees, succeeding Professor Charles K. Burdick, who resigned on Jan. 1 after ten years in the deanship.

The business volume of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, a finance company, for 1936 was $1,169,696,815, resulting in net profits of $21,181,020, equal to $6.07 on each of the 3,307,422 common shares outstanding at the year-end, following deduction of preferred dividends, according to the annual report made public yesterday.
It is believed here, despite the rumors that were circulated concerning the conversations in Washington, F that England is willing to stabilize the pound at this moment.

Opposition to cancellation by the Legislature this year of all the pay cuts imposed on teachers during the depression was expressed in a letter from the Citizens Budget Commission to Governor. Lehman and the legislative leaders, made public yesterday.

A heavy steel barge loaded with an undetermined number of WPA levee workers, estimates ranging from 60 to 250, sank in the icy waters of the Birds Point-New Madrid spillway last night and one occupant said tonight it was "impossible" to establish if any had drowned.
Frank B. Mecray, deputy sheriff of Cape May County and former Mayor of Cape May, died today at his home of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

Except for an increase in discount quotations for bankers' acceptances, money rates in January were stationary. The rumored rise in rates for collateral loans failed to materialize and charges remained at the level at which they had held throughout the previous seven months.

The bloc of tour Senators who have consistently opposed for the past two years the administration's desires for discretionary neutrality legislation plans to introduce tomorrow a bill to regulate foreign commerce in time of war abroad, it was learned today.
Three national records were bettered when a fast field opened competition today in the annual two-day North American indoor speed skating championships, a feature of St. Paul's Winter carnival.
Robert W. Bingham, Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived yesterday from London on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, hurrying to his home in Louisville to aid the floodstricken city.

The number of persons injured and the total of traffic fatalities and accidents rose sharply last week compared with the same period last year, it was announced yesterday by Acting Police Commissioner Harold Fowler. It was the third successive week against the corresponding period of .1936 that injuries and accidents increased.

Wheat futures advanced a cent a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today on buying induced by strength in Liverpool and Winnipeg, but the market weakened later with May wheat under pressure and the close was at the low point. The May declined 3/4 cent and the new crop months were 1/8 to 1/4 cent lower.

A move by counsel for Ellis H. Parker, chief of Burlington County detectives, and his son, Ellis H. Jr., to prevent their trial on a charge of conspiracy in the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton lawyer, failed today when Federal Judge Guy L. Fake overruled a special plea in abatement.

An offering to the public of the new issue of $29,000,000 of Kingdom of Norway twenty-six-year 4 per cent sinking fund external loan bonds, dated Feb. 1, and due on Feb. 1, 1963, is scheduled tomorrow, according to an announcement yesterday by Lazard Freres Co., Inc., who head the banking group making the offering.

The last Yorkville dinner dance for this season will be held tonight at the Ritz-Carlton. The dances, which have been conducted annually for twenty-three years, are given in behalf of the vocational and recreational projects of the Yorkville Community Association, which also conducts Summer camps for children.

B. Earl Puckett, president of the Allied Stores corporation, yesterday announced the resignation of Marvin D. Waters as assistant treasurer, effective today. Mr. Waters has been with the company since its inception in charge of tax matters, and is opening offices at 120 Wall Street to practice as a tax consultant.
George E. Roosevelt of Roosevelt Sons of New York, investment bankers, laid today before the Securities and Exchange Commission six rules for proper management of investment trusts.

Two seamen who had been arrested on assault charges growing out of the recent ship strike were acquitted yesterday - by Justices Salomon, Gresser and Walling in Special Sessions, although a patrolman had testified he witnessed the attack. James J. Wilson,

The fourth "Tristan and Isolde" was given last night In the Metropolitan. Opera House, which, as usual when this opera is performed, was sold out and had been sold out days in advance of the occasion.

Contracts on considerable amounts of cotton suiting and shirting for the Civilian Conservation Corps, on which bids were opened at the quartermaster depot here on Jan. 28 under Invitation 170, were awarded today, including the following: (1) Khaki shirting, oxford,

Dr. William P. MacCracken, father of William P. MacCracken Jr., who was Assistant Secretary of Commerce under President Hoover, died here yesterday in his home. Dr. MacCracken had been ill for several months. He was 73 years old.

Airplanes weighing 250,000 pounds and with cruising speeds up to 300 miles an hour were predicted last night at the Aviation Show in Grand Central Palace by T. P. Wright, chief engineer of the Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company.
Dr. John F. Hagerty, medical director of St. Michael's Hospital and a surgeon here for forty-three years, died today at his home here of pneumonia. He was 67 years old.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey have terminated their common ownership of important natural-gas transmission properties in the Eastern part of this country by taking over the respective minority interests owned by the other party and by making a cash adjustment of an undisclosed amount.

Pointing out that a small, mile and a half square district in Brooklyn has a population and buying power greater than many cities throughout the United States, Frank R. Coutant, research director of Pedler Ryan, Inc.,

Plans are under consideration for the merger of the subsidiaries of the J. G. Brill Company, Charles J. Hardly, president of the American Car and Foundry Company, which controls Brill, said yesterday.

The greatest gathering of bowlers' ever to assemble in one spot will try their skill in the thirty-seventh annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress which will be held at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory March 10 to April 30.

The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that the unit of trading in the Kings County Lighting Company's 7 per cent preferred B shares and 5 per cent preferred D had been changed from twenty-five to ten shares.

For the first time since the division was started five years ago, the air-conditioning department of the General Electric Company will launch a factory-controlled newspaper campaign this year, in addition to its cooperative newspaper advertising, J. J. Donovan, manager of the division,

Operations of the steel industry in the United States this week are estimated at 79.6 per cent of capacity, an increase of 1.7 point, or 2.2 per cent, over last week, when the estimated rate was 77.9 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Field goals by Eddie Loik and Joe Condict in the last two -minutes gave the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn a 30-27 victory over the John Marshall College quintet in the Edison High School gymnasium tonight. The victors,

By far the most stringent neutrality legislation yet proposed in Congress was introduced in the Senate today by Senators Bennett Champ Clark of Missouri and Homer T. Bone of Washington, Democrats, and Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan, and Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota, Republicans.

A group of eighty pickets paraded for an hour, from 5 to 6 o'clock, last night before the General Motors Building on the Fifty-seventh Street side between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. While they were marching back and forth Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors, entered his car unrecognized.

Operations last year of the F. W. Woolworth Company and subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $32,624,988 after amortization, depreciation, Federal income taxes and surtax of $300,000 on undistributed income.

Marching orders issued at midnight to troops mobilizing over the State will concentrate the full National Guard strength of 4,000 soldiers today in Flint where a regiment took over last night an area in which new rioting in the General Motors strike occurred in the afternoon.

Under French tutelage and with France supplying the greater part of the cost, Poland is about to build a "Maginot" defense line in her territory opposite the German border. France will supply not only money but also the engineers who are to supervise the construction.
Two steel companies are studying plans for new mills in this district which would cost $9,000,000.

A forecast of warmer temperature threatened floods in Western Oregon tonight as Portland dug out from under the heaviest twentyfour-hour snowstorm in history and Winter continued its grip on other Pacific Northwest areas.

Marquis Chokun Asano, last Japanese feudal lord, died at 8:25 o'clock last night. His age was 95. The death of the Marquis was not unexpected, for last week he was reported to be seriously ill with specialists in attendance.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it has issued a complaint charging unfair trade practices against Royal Revues, Inc., West Coast Discount Corporation, Ltd., and their officers, L. H. and W. C. Hyde, trading as Royal FiLm Studios of Hollywood.

Five South Amboy, N. J., commuters asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to investigate an increase in monthly commutation rates between Perth Amboy and South Amboy, N. J., and New York City.

Stanch batting by Captain Don BWadman and Stanley McCabe brought. the Australian cricketers' total to 157 runs for the loss of two wickets by lunch time today in the second innings of their fourth match of the current test series against England.
The response of the money market yesterday to the announcement by the Federal Reserve Board of a further increase of 331-3 per cent in member-bank reserve requirements was favorable.

On the eve of her departure for a European tour, Stell Andersen appeared in a piano recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. She played three pieces by Gluck, each by a different transcriber-Sgambati, Friedman and Saint-Saens.

A conference of Republican members of the House adopted a resolution tonight favoring Social Security Act amendments to eliminate the provision for reserves, delay increases in the payroll taxes and expand the classes of persons reached.

Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club, seeded No. 1, made his-first start in the M. M. Sterling Trophy squash tennis tournament at the New York A. C. a winning one at the' expense of L. B. Dailey, Princeton - Club representative, yesterday.

Noting a "definite upswing" in early enrollment figures for the Spring semester, Edward J. Grant, registrar of Columbia University, predicted yesterday that this session's total registration at Columbia would exceed that of last term by at least 4,000.

Blacksod, tireless 3-year-old daughter of Boot to Boot, ran six furlongs in 1:162-5 over the heavy Alamo Downs track to win the feature race today. Harry's Dream was two lengths back and Spey Fox a nose further back in third place. Blacksod paid $9.40 for $2.

Jolin F. Dailey Jr., former head of the criminal division of the United States Attorney's office, has been appointed Chief Assistant United States Attorney, and Gregory F. Noonan, a member of the staff, has been appointed head of the criminal division; Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, announced yesterday.

The Reconstruction Finance Corportion has been asked by a group of property owners in the garment district to turn down an application for a $2,000,000 loan for the construction of a twenty-seven-story office building on property owned by the Wendel estate at the southwest corner of Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street, it became known yesterday.

School relief funds are inadequate to permit distribution of shoes and clothing to needy pupils in the same number as in past years, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, informed principals in a circular, made pub-lic yesterday.

Thirty-eight years of judging the qualifications of applicants for city, teaching posts ended last night for Dr. George J. Smith, a member of the Board of Examiners since the original board was named in 1898. Retiring at the age of 70, Dr. Smith summed up his impressions in a mood alternately mellow and cause tic.

Stockholders of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois, when they meet on Feb. 23, will be asked to approve issuance of a new series of first-lien and refunding mortgage bonds not to exceed $80,000,000, it was announced today.

Enraged WPA women workers, all nonstrikers, holding a mass meeting this afternoon, drove from City Hall auditorium John Dean, an avowed Communist organizer and one of the leaders of the male WPA workers' strike here.
Willie % Smith, 24-year-old garage proprietor, grinned today and observed that he is free of one trouble that bothers several million other Smiths in America.

Representatives of 'twenty-two bar associations and lawyers' clubs in the metropolitan area, meeting jointly to discuss means of eliminating the law's delays and preventing its unlawful practice by laymen, voted yesterday to set up a pernmanent board to carry out their aims.
More than 15,000 WPA workers joined flood victims and relief workers today in an eager advance as the receding waters in the upper Ohio River Valley revealed a spectacular trail of wreckage.

The directors of the General Motors Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of 25 cents a share on the outstanding common stock, payable March 12 to stockholders of record Feb. 11, and the regular quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share on the $5 preferred stock, payable on May 1 to stockholders of record on April 5.

Sueo Ohe, Japanese polo vaulter. who finished in a tie for second place in his specialty in the Berlin Olympic Games, arrived here yesterday by train from Chicago. He was greeted at the Grand Central Terminal by a large group of American and Japanese newspaper men.
To be at all cheerful over the prospect that Congress will enact the Pittman bill, the McReynolds bill or the VandenbergClark-Nye-Bone amendments on Neutrality it is necessary to hold these beliefs:

A motion inviting Dr. Carlos Marquez Sterling, President of the House of Representatives, and other officers of that body to resign was approved by the House this afternoon by a vote of 96 to 22. A special meeting was called for tomorrow afternoon to raise the question of confidence in the presiding officers of the House unless today's suggestion is accepted.
Toronto's Harvey Jackson, who found his scoring eye somewhere along the National Hockey League trail the last few weeks, today was tied for first place in the individual scoring list.
Tony Lazzeri, veteran second baseman of the Yankees, rolled into town expeted and unannounced yesterday, accompanied by his wife and baby boy.

After being questioned about several fires and a series of thefts at Fort Totten, Bayside, Private Harry Venable, 21 years old, barricaded himself in a barrack's room last night, withstood an attempt by officers of the post and thirty policemen to dislodge him and then committed suicide when tear gas bombs were-hurled in the room.
The American Car and Foundry Company has received orders for 2,900 freight cars and twenty-eight passenger cars. The Clinchfield Railroad ordered 250 gondola and 500 hopper cars;

The sap that stirs the maple's heart Knows more than I shall ever learn; It tells the waiting buds to start, That never fail at Spring's return. The bulb that feeds the plodding mole Is master both of hue and shape, And would have formed a fairer bowl Than man can ever hope to ape.

The Senate today began debating the $934,000,000 deficiency bill, which carries $775,000,000 for relief, and devoted its time to wrangling over an appropriation of $15,000,000 for the Resettlement Administration, the alleged "carpet-bag policies" of the WPA in some of the States and $250,000 which the Committee on Appropriations eliminated from an item involving the contract air-mail service.

In his speech before the Reichstag, Herr HITLER spoke complacently of friendly agreements which Germany had made with other nations, and of her readiness to make others. There was not a word, however, about one agreement which she freely made since HITLER himself came to power

Mrs. Robert W. Winslow was reelected president of the Guild of Long Island College Hospital at a and meeting yesterday morning at the hotel hospital. Mrs. Theodore C. Streibert, first vice president, presided. Other officers re-elected were Mrs. Streibert, first vice president; Mrs. Maxwell Lester, second vice president; Mrs. Kenneth M. Reed, third vice president; Mrs. Albert G. Fuller, secretary, and Mrs. M. Herschel Parsons, treasurer.

Mrs. Thomas I. Morrow, vice president of the Associate Alumnae of the Packer Collegiate Institute, was elected a trustee of the institute last night at a board meeting held at the school, 170 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn.
The Rev. George F. Oley, one of three brothers in the Catholic priesthood in the Syracuse Diocese, died here today. His age was 52.
Any attempt to control child labor except through an amendment to the Federal Constitution would be unsound and impracticable, Governor Lehman said in a letter to Dr. Nicholas

Mr. and Mrs. Sam Seaton Spalding of Montclair, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Everett Spalding, to Dr. Cecil Collins Swann of Asheville, N. C., son of Mrs. Edward Swann of Marion, Ala., and the late Dr. Swann.

The residents of East Flatbush will have additional police protection as the result of a conference yesterday in the office of William F. X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, between borough police officials and the residents of the district.
" The Return of Hannibal," an elaborate historical drama in sixteen scenes by Amory Hare (Mrs. James P. HIutchinson of Philadelphia), had its first performance at the Geary Theatre here this evening.

General Motors, in declaring a 25cent disbursement on the common stock yesterday, evidently has adopted the du Pont policy of declaring interim dividends at periods through the year and a final dividend at the close of the period.

Charles H. C. Pearsall, president of the Colombian Steamship Company, urged yesterday that the twoyear course now offered by the New York State Merchant Marine Academy be extended a year to enable cadets to become acquainted with the shore problems of ship lines.

Charles Betts Hillhouse and Miss Sylvia Remsen Hillhouse of the Westbury and Newport have gone to Palm Beach. Count Alexandre de Pourtales will arrive today from Cambridge, Mass., to join his grandmother, Mrs. S. Milton Hitt, at 14 East Sixtieth Street.

The decision of the British Law Lords, constituting that country's highest court, that the 51/2 per cent United Kingdom dollar bonds, placed in the United States in 1917, are payable in United States dollars as devalued since 1933, was not unexpected. In July, 1933,

General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano's southern drive against Malaga thrust the spearhead of his Insurgent army within sight of the sea today, virtually isolating the important Mediterranean port from Leftist territory.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized Burton H. Sheffer today to hold positions of assistant secretary of the New York Central Railroad Company, the Lake Erie Pittsburgh Railway Company and the Zanesville Terminal Railroad Company.

Dropping a long putt for a birdie 3 on the concluding hole, Tommy Goodwin, New York State amateur champion, led a select field in the qualifying round for the annual South Florida golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

While there is a certain amount of uneasiness in the local wholesale markets over the strike, floods and unseasonable weather, retailers from sections not affected yesterday placed substantial orders on all types of Spring goods, reports indicated.

The twelve-story apartment house at 31 East Twelfth Street, northeast corner of University Place, in Greenwich Village, has been sold by the Guaranty Trust Company to a client of Gettner, Simon Asher. Duff Conger acted as brokers.
In connection with the sit-down strike it has been several times said that if it succeeds it would destroy

Tenders for about $50,000,000 of 273-day Treasury bills, dated Feb. 3 and maturing Nov. 3, 1937, which were offered on Jan. 29, amounted to $191,855,000, of which $50,385,000 was accepted, the Treasury announced tonight.

A 9 per cent increase in imports and exports of food products in 1936 over the previous year was shown in a report made. public today by the Department of Commerce. The figures for the respective years were $933,961,000 and $856,907,000.
W. C. Devereaux, meteorologist, offered today a chart showing how the Ohio River first exceeded flood stage near Cairo, and worked its way up the valley and down the Mississippi.
Andre Jessurun, Bronx welterweight, had an easy time last night hammering his way to a decision Over Jay Macedon, South Orange, N. J., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace.

Once more the number of persons slaughtered in automobile accidents reaches a "new high record." There were 38,500 people killed in that manner in 1936, 1,500 more than in 1935, the previous high mark.
Through air service between the United States and China will be started on March 24 or a few days later by Pan American Airways, Postmaster General Farley stated today.

A distribution at the rate of $23.13 on $1,000 of Kreuger Toll secured debentures deposited will be made on Feb. 18 to holders of deposit certificates issued by the protective committee, of which Grayson M.-P.

Mrs. Zillah Stix Cullman, mother of Howard S. Cullman, member of the Port of New York Authority, left a gross estate of $878,308 and a net of $859,680 when she died on March 12, 1935, the transfer tax appraisal showed yesterday.

William B. Joyce, veteran insurance broker, admitted yesterday, after a robbery in his office, that he was without burglary insurance. When he resigned four years ago as chairman of the board of Lhe National Surety Corporation,

With unspar ing criticism of last year's Republican-controlled Assembly for "wrecking" his financial program for the 1936-37 fiscal year and "substituting a plan of its own," Governor Lehman submitted to the Legislature at its session tonight

The women's emergency brigade, which took part in today's rioting at the Chevrolet plant, was organized by Mrs. Genora Johnson, wife of a General Motors worker. She took part in the battle at the Fisher Body Plant No. 2 three weeks ago when twenty-eight persons were hurt.

The Metal Tone Manufacturing Company of Jersey City failed in the Supreme Court today to win the right to manufacture dolls which cry "Mama." The tribunal refused to pass upon a judgment against the firm by the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals.

The Warren Brothers Company of Cambridge received permission today from Federal Judge. Elisha H. Brewster to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act. The company, organized in West Virginia in 1900, has, according to the petition, five domestic and two foreign subsidiaries and a controlling interest in six domestic and four foreign companies.
The newly organized Concert League began its career in the comfortable little hall at 846 Seventh Avenue last night with a recital of Russian songs by Sergei Radamsky, lyric tenor.

Dr. Hugh R. Leavell, city health director, raised the total of Louisville's known deaths to 221 today and predicted it would be "revised upward" when the flood receded further from its peak of 57.1 feet.

The Manufacturers Trust Company as depositary under an agreement dated June 1, 1927, between Prudence Bonds Corporation and the State Bank, as assigned to the Brooklyn Trust Company as trustee under a reorganization plan, a consolidated mortgage for $1,550,000 on 101-03 West 37th St.
Auction of a case of wine for a total of $14,000 was a feature of the flood sufferers' benefit last night in the Royal Palm Club, attended by scores from all parts of the Greater Miami area.
