Federal agents and the local police cooperated early yesterday and last night in three raids in Brooklyn, which they believed definitely "broke" the kidnapping case of Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr., seized in Albany and held for $250,000 ransom on July 10, 1933.

President Roosevelt sent to Congress a message asking legislation to permit the Federal Government to accept the gift of art treasures and a gallery offered by Andrew Mellon, and conferred with Donald Richberg on labor and hours legislation.

The Westchester trustees, who recently resigned following differences as to counsel fees and attacks upon their administration by Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme, defended and explained their accomplishments today through their executive secretary. Alfred D. Cole, who reviewed their work in a letter to certificate holders.

The third semi-annual Fashion Accessories Show opened yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker with a list of 116 exhibitors, almost twice as many as participated in the first show a year ago. Lines represented included handbags, scarfs, handkerchiefs, costume jewelry, flowers and other items. The show continues through Friday.

The fourth concert of the Bennington College Series was given by the Philharmonic - Symphony Chamber Orchestra last night in Town Hall. In the absence of Hans Lange, the official conductor of this organization, the concert was directed by Otto Luening, the composer and member of the music faculty of Bennington.
While this oity and the section near by today continued its practically- snowless record, areas to the north reported a- blanket of snow ranging from two to six inches and affording good skiing.

Louis F. Middlebrook, for fifty-two years with the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company and for forty years an officer of the company, died today at his home in West Hartford at the age of 70.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt attended Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's ninetysixth Musical Morning at the Mayflower today, entertaining in her box Mrs. Fulvio Suvich, wife of the Italian Ambassador; Mrs. Fernando de los Rios, wife of the Spanish Ambassador; Mrs. Cordell Hull, wife of the Secretary of State, and Miss Nancy Cook, who is her guest at the White House.

A card party, fashion show and tea under the auspices of the Alumnae Association of the Academy of St. Elizabeth at Convent Station, N. J., will be held Saturday at the Ritz Tower. Mrs. James Roosevelt will be the guest of honor.
Appointment of Merlin H. Aylesworth as a member of the ScrippsHoward newspapers executive staff was announced today at the annual business meeting of Scripps-Howard officials.

With John Crawford and Vic Berni heading a consistent attack, the Riverdale Country Day School basketball team routed the Collegiate School five, 45 to 17, on the winner's court yesterday. Crawford and Berni counted 16 and 12 points respectively.

Jeanne Behrend, who gave her first New York recital last night, chose to do it in a big way. Not only did she play in Carnegie Hall, where solo debuts by young artists have been rare in recent years, but she introduced an elaborate sonata of her own devising.

Frederic A. Muller, a consulting engineer with the Singer Manufacturning Company for thirty-five years, who invented many mechanical devices, died last night at his home here following a heart attack.

The champion Detroit Red Wings will invade the Garden ice tonight to oppose the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League contest, starting at 8:45 o'clock. The battle between the high-flying Westerners and the second-place Rangers is likely to have an important bearing on the outcome of the race in the American group.

If the crisis arising from the Spanish war can be weathered, the peace of Europe is safe for at least five or ten years. But until that conflict is resolved, in Premier Benito Mussolini's opinion, there can be no approach to a general settlement of other problems. The first task of Europe,

The Rev. Michael J. Earls, S. J., former vice president of Holy Cross College, author and poet, died suddenly in St. Vincent's Hospital Sunday night after suffering a heart attack in Grand Central Terminal. His age was 63.

Tony Marino, Pittsburgh bantamweight boxier, died at 2:30 A. M. yesterday in Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Brooklyn, a little more than twenty-four hours after he had been injured in an eight-round bout at the Ridgewood Grove in Queens. He was 25 years old.
General Francisco Franco, Spanish Insurgent commander, sent Chancellor Hitler his congratulations Saturday on his successful rounding out of four years in power. The message was as follows:

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday he had taken over for liquidation the Cremieux Benevolent Society, a cooperative assessment life insurance continuously in business here since its organization in 1851 by immigrants from AlsaceLorraine.

The Almoners will meet next Monday at the Plaza to formulate plans for their annual dinner dance in behalf of the New York Foundling Hospital, to be held late in April. A luncheon for officers of the organization and members of the benefit committee will precede the meetings.

Rumor flew around the Capitol today that ten Senators have been persuaded, for $1,000 each, to give testimonials for a tobacco company of how little its cigarettes affected the throat membranes of great orators like themselves.

Anna Kronenbitter sold three adjacent block-front apartment-house sites on the west side of Sixty-third Drive, between Alderton and Carlton Streets, Rego Park, to a client of Charles Friedman through George Lutz as broker.

Clarence A. Dykstra, City Manager of Cincinnati, appeared today to be a leading possibility for the presidency of the University of Wisconsin following a series of conferences conducted in Chicago yesterday by the committee of the board of regents empowered to seek a successor to Dr. Glenn Frank.

The first of the monthly index numbers for January was published today by Dun's Review. It showed a decline of 15/8 per cent for the month. This was the first decline since May, 1936, since which month the advance in the Dun average had been 20 per cent. As compared with Feb. 1, 1936, the Dun index number is 133/8 per cent higher.
The report of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company for the year ended Dec. 31, 1936, shows a net income of $12,761,667 after interest, amortization, Federal taxes and surtax on undistributed profits.

The annual convention of the Nationalist party at Caguas reelected as its President Pedro Albizu Campos, now in jail pending an appeal on his sedition sentence. A resolution was adopted to ask the Vatican to withdraw Bishop Byrne of San Juan and Bishop Willinger of Ponce because, the resolution says, they are persona non grata to the country for criticism of priests for pro-Nationalist activities.

W. Stapley Wonham begaff his quest for another Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, doubles championship yesterday when be. and D. Lee Norris swept aside Horatio K. Gray and Edward G. Benson in straight games as .the sixth annual tournament opened on the courts of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

Hog prices generally were 25 cents a hundredweight higher today than Saturday as the result of light receipts. Eleven markets received only 47,000 head, or 52,000 fewer than a week ago. The price was up 25 cents at $10.25, while the day's average advanced 25 cents to $10.05. Most sales were at $9.90 to $10.20.

Mrs. Robert McCurdy Marsh gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 960 Park Avenue, for members of the committee who are assisting her with the sale of tickets for the recital by Alexander Culbertson, violinist, on Friday night at Carnegie Hall.
Fred Perry, former British and: American amateur titleholder, defeated Ellsworth Vines, world's professional tennis champion, 2-6, 6-3, 9-7, at. the Everglades Club today.
The Supreme Court held invalid-today a Washington State law imposing a fee on railroads and other public utilities to be used In defraying expenses of regulating them. The decision was 5 to 4.

An investigation to identify and expel the school teachers of this city who may be spreading radical doctrines in the classroom and elsewhere was ordered by the Board of Education here today after Mayor John V. Hinchliffe told the board that "a professional agitator" and "vile, un-American methods" had been employed by school board employes in their fight for restoration of wages.

With the final step of filing a certificate of consolidation with the secretary of State undertaken, trading in securities of the new Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, which has been organized as a consolidation of the old Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its subsidiary, the Mohawk Hudson Power Corporation, started yesterday morning on the New York Curb Exchange.

Miss Edmee Roberta Reisinger, daughter of Mrs. Mary McKee Reisinger of Greenwich, Conn., and of Curt H. Reisinger of this city, will be married to Joseph Jenry Morsman Jr. of Chicago on Feb. 16 at the home of her grandfather, James Robert McKee,

It looked tonight as if Cairo might win its battle with the river. Higher than it had ever been before, the Ohio climbed still higher, but the ramparts held and showed no signs of yielding to the tons of water racing past the city's second-story windows.

Metro's film adaptation of Pearl S. Buck's "The Good Earth" will be ushered into the Astor Theatre tonight with all the fanfare of a Hollywood premiere. That means it will be a dress affair, that the festivities will be broadcast from the lobby of the theatre and that huge amber-colored lamps will flood the vicinity of Broadway and Fortyfifth Street. The film was directed,

Madison Square Garden rocked to the cheers of an overflow crowd of 16,197 persons who turned out for the fourteenth annual Silver Skates Derby last night. Thrills and spills were plentiful, and the program conducted under the auspices of the Daily News A. A., was one of the most successful of its kind.

An effort to return to work all employes of the Chevrolet Motor Company plant here was begun today, with seventy-five men resuming work, officials said. Thirty more men will be called back tomorrow, they said.

A combination of circumstances has forced Governor LEHMAN to submit to the Legislature the largest budget in the history of the State. Compared with last year's budget, it shows an increase of $68,000,000-the greater part of which can be explained by changes at three points.

Billy Gillespie, third seeded entrant from the Scarborough School, became a finalist in the eleventh annual De Witt Clinton High School interscholastic indoor tennis tournament at the 369th Infantry Armory courts in Manhattan yesterday by eliminating Arthur Dreyer of Boys High, 6-2, 6-1.
W. C. Devereaux, meteorologist, reported today that the Ohio River was falling from Pittsburgh to below Evansville, Ind. He reported these conditions at points on the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers.

Continued labor difficulties and the floods led to another decrease in automobile output last week and the adjusted index has declined to 79.0 from 87.1, comparing with 99.9 for the week ended Feb. 1, 1936.

Frank B. Hall Sr., founder of the Frank B. Hall Co. fire and marine insurance agency of 67 Wall Street, Manhattan, and chairman of its board of directors, died at his home in this village last night at the age of 73.

Admitted assets of the Jefferson Standard Life Insurance Company of Greensboro, N. C., were $67,626,350 at the end of last year, according to Julian Price, president, in the company's annual report. This is a gain of more than $5,000,000 for the year.
Four bills sponsored by Miss Todd, Westchester Republican, to permit women to serve as jurors were passed in the Assembly tonight, 112 to 18. Seventeen of the negative votes were by Republicans.

A new Cabinet, consisting, for the time being, of eight members instead of the usual thirteen, was installed by the Emperor this morning. General Senjuro Hayashi became Premier, and for the present is holding also the portfolios of Foreign Affairs and Education.

The matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday in aid of the Schola Cantorum will begin with "Cavalleria Rusticana" and end with "Coq d'Or." In the former the principals will include Rosa Ponselle, Sydney Rayner and Carlo Morelli; in the latter Lily Pons and Ezio Pinza. Gennaro Papi will conduct both.

Government payments to American ship lines under mail contracts were ordered suspended yesterday by the Federal Maritime Commission. A form letter conveying the information to the lines aroused widespread discussion in shipping circles and it was indicated that protest would be made.

The Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest offers a $100 grand prize and fifty honorable mention prizes of $5 each for the best photographs of outdoor life (except athletic contests and games) taken by amateurs.
The McNaboe committee to investigate communism in the schools died officially tonight, but Senator McNaboe forced through the Senate a resolution to "revive and extend" it until March 15.

Firmness in United States Government obligations and irregularly higher levels for the main body of domestic corporation issues was the bond market's response to the Federal Reserve Board's lifting of reserve requirements.

The Mayonnaise and Salad Dressing Manufacturers Association, which was disbanded after the demise of the NRA, has been reorganized, it was announced here yesterday by R. F. Wilson, assistant to the president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, and trade relations counsel to the new group.

President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the annual report of the Panama Railroad Company showing that the government-controlled agency realized a $1,127,340 net profit in the fiscal year ended on last June 30.

The influx of foreign skiers to these shores this Winter reached its beak yesterday when six members of the Swiss Universities' ski team, accompanied by Manager Karl Weber, arrived on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line.

Concentration camps for Haitian and Jamaican workers, estimated around 50,000, whom the government expects to deport in order to provide labor for Cubans during the present sugar harvesting, are being constructed at Santiago, on the south coast, and Antilla, on the north coast of Oriente Province, the Department of Labor announced today.
The Federal Power Commission told Congress in testimony made public today electricity rates in New York City should be lowered.

The White Motor Company announced today the largest single truck order for export since the close of the World War, a $500,000 purchase of 130 heavy-duty trucks by the Societe Anonyme Centrale, the government transportation monopoly at Teheran, Iran.
The United States men's table tennis team won three matches and the women's team won two today in the international round-robin competitions for the Swaythling and Corbillion Cups, respectively.

Three armed men held up a committee of the Bronx Veterans NonPartisan Political Organization at its hall at 411 East Tremont Avenue at 10:30 o'clock last night, obtained $572, mostly proceeds from the sale of tickets for an entertainment scheduled for Saturday night, and escaped.

The stock markets opened the new account today and, although conditions were quiet, a firmer tendency was noticed. Gilt-edged issues recovered somewhat, but all early rallies were not maintained. German bonds and certain Japanese issues, however, were better.

Miss Elizabeth Marie Gallagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Gallagher of Manhasset, L. I.. was married to Gerald J. McKernan of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John McKernan of Philadelphia, yesterday morning in the Church of St. Agnes, East Fortythird Street, by the Rev. John Toomey.

Indicated op Sept. 22 on charges of contempt of the Senate for their failure to appear before the La- Follette committee investigating labor- espionage, six officials and employes of the Railway Audit and Inspection Company, Inc., pleaded not guilty when arraigned before Justice O. R. Luhring in United States District Court today.

That the Original Celtics have done more for the development of basketball throughout the country than any other aggregation was the opinion voiced by John J. O'Brien, president of the American Professional Basketball League, at the Basketball Writers Association luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln.

Priests of the Spanish College in Rome asserted today, in an article in the newspaper Osservatore Romano, that 40 to 50 per cent of Spain's priests had been killed in "systematic slaughter" by "Reds" during the Spanish civil war.
Dr. Henry B. Savage of New York died tonight at the home of his son, Cornelius B. Savage, where he was visiting. He was 84 years beloved old.

Steve (Crusher) Casey of County Kerry, Ireland, was declared the winner on a foul over George Koverly of Hollywood, Calif., in the feature bout of the wrestling show last night at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.
Baron and Baroness Frederic Van Hogendorf have issued invitations to a marlners ball, a costume event to be held Friday night at the Biscay Bay Yacht Club in Coconut Grove.

Walter Neusel, German heavyweight, defeated Jack Petersen for the third time tonight when he scored a technical knockout over the Englishman in the tenth round of their fifteenround bout at the Haringway Arena.

Governor Murphy will not declare martial law in Flint for the present, it was reported last night during a recess in his conferences with aides on the situation created in Flint by the clash today at one of the Chevrolet plants.

To meet a shortage of middle-ranking officers. in the British Navy, the Admiralty is offering permanent commissions as lieutenants to mercantile marine officers who have reached that grade in the Royal Naval Reserve.

Complaints of harassed householders of Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, that vibrations from the nearby Independent subway caused their freshly baked cakes to fall, sent dishes slithering off shelves and generally disturbed their "domestic tranquillity and home life," found judicial corroboration yesterday.
The creation of a federal district for the capital of Colombia is authorized in one of thirty-six articles amending the Constitution passed by the Senate and referred to the House.

Net assets of the Continental Securities Corporation at the end of 1936 were $4,896,246, according to a statement issued yesterday. They were equal to $1,762.51 for each $1,000 debenture, $149.76 for each share of preferred stock and, after deducting $25 a share for unpaid accumulated dividends on the preferred, to $6.06 for each share of $5-par common stock.

A major letter has been awarded to Dick Hough, Princeton sophomore from Trenton, N. J., in recognition of the world record of 1:07.6 he set two weeks, ago in the 100-yard breast-stroke, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, Princeton graduate manager of athletics.

Mrs. Christine S. Trexler, wife of the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, was brutally beaten ten days ago by two thugs who followed her into the vestibule of their home, the parsonage of St. James Lutheran Church at Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, it became known yesterday.

The "Bearded Bishop of the Arctic" came back from the North to relate today how ten shipwrecked travelers were rescued by an airplane pilot who used the Northern Lights for landing flares to pierce the polar night.
Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden made it clear today that Great Britain had not abandoned hope of German cooperation in Europe, despite Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech Saturday.

Manager Red Dutton of the New York Americans announced yesterday the purchase of Alfie Moore, goalie, from the New Haven Eagles of the International-American League. Moore, considered a brilliant prospect, was acquired in exchange for Lloyd Jackson, a wing man, and an unannounced amount of cash.

The House today began consideration of the first regular appropriation bill for the fiscal year 1937-1938, a measure providing funds for about thirty bureaus, commissions and agencies not affiliated with any department.

After an early advance into new high ground for the season, prices on the Cotton Exchange reacted slightly yesterday to end with a loss of 2 to 6 points. The action of the market reflected a general disposition to await the result of the sale by the government of cotton held in loans.

Passage by the Assembly of a 1937 relief bill calling for expenditures. in the State of $12,667,000 was the only out action taken by the,Legislature tonight during a brief session. The bill was not reported in the Senate.

A Virtual demand that the Roosevelt administration appeal directly to the people for the strong central powers it requires to carry out its program, rather than try to accomplish the same result by "lecturing" or tampering with the courts, was made by Senator Borah in a radio speech broadcast from Washington tonight.

Alexander E. Duncan, chairman of the board of the Commercial Credit Company, said today that the directors had authorized a stockholders' meeting to consider a new issue of $35,000,000 convertible preferred stock.

A national committee of twenty-eight was designated today by the National Conference for Clarifying the Constitution by Amendment to meet in thirty days and examine the draft of a proposed amendment which will deal with the Improvement of working and living conditions of agriculture and labor.
New York City's free port on Staten Island was opened yesterday without public ceremony and with no ships standing by to unload cargo at the Stapleton piers.

Branch offices of the Motor Vehicle Bureau in the city closed last night, and belated motorists seeking 1937 license plates now will have to apply in person or by mail to the main office at 55 Center/Street. I. J. Brody,

A plea that the United States Government "will not discriminate between one group of its citizens and another" in reference to Palestine and that "it will turn a sympathetic ear to the voice of the Arabs of Palestine" was made to Secretary Hull today by a delegation representing the Arab National League.
A luncheon in behalf of St. Luke's Hospital in Tokyo, Japan, will be held on Feb. 9 at the Pierre by the Woman's Division of the American Council of St. Luke's International Medical Center of Tokyo.

Samuel Klaye, a restaurant keeper, told the jury hearing the restaurant racket case yesterday that he had been "shaken down" for $3,500 and forced to join an association for which he signed a statement denying that he had been coerced.

Wells K. Stanley, attorney for the Fisher Body Company, filed a petition in Common Pleas Court today for an injunction restraining striking employes from entering the company's property without its consent and from maintaining more than two pickets at each of the main entrances.
Introducing the game of 28.2 balkline billiards to New York, Jake Schaefer and Willie Hoppe played their first block of a 2,500-point match at the Strand Academy last night.
Collections for the Red Cross Relief Fund, as reported to headquarters today, reached $9,963,354.
The Rural Electrification Administration announced allotments totaling $335,000 today for New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Virginia.

The largest realty sale to be made in the old Horseshoe section of Jersey City for several years has just taken place in the sale by the Hohoken Land and Improvement Company to the Continental Can Company of the entire block bounded by Monmouth, Coles, Fourteenth and Fifteenth Streets.

Major General Markham, Chief of Army Engineers, here with President Roosevelt's Flood Relief Commission, expressed the belief today that the super-flood waters in sight on the Mississippi River would flow inside the government's billion-dollar bulwark of levees to the Gulf without bursting out of bounds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Robert Wilson, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, states that the thirty-hour week would entail "moral and economic retrogression." Moral retrogression would follow in the wake of increased leisure; economic decay would eventuate as a result of decreased demand that would follow in the path of increased

A book that has been kept continually in publication for more than 100 years, and that has been under the editorial management of members of the same family through all that time, has been reissued by Lippincott in its twentysecond edition. The book is "U. S.

After failing to finish closer than third in five previous starts this year, the 5-year-old Palasa scored a comparatively easy triumpr in the mileand-a-sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds card today.

Matty Bell, football coach at Southern Methodist University, only Southwest Conference mentor ever to take a team to the Rose Bowl, agreed to a new contract today, terminating the negotiations for the University of Iowa coaching position.
Another of the many parties in honor of Miss Sarah Jane Sanford and her fiance, Mario Pansa, was the dinner and dance Mrs. Dodge Sloane gave tonight at Concha Marina.

Secretary Perkins said today that James F. Dewey, a Federal conciliator, had been dispatched to Michigan to observe the General Motors strike situation, and added that she would continue her efforts to get corporation and labor leaders back into a peace conference.

The consolidated operating income bf the Marine Midland Corporation and its constituent banks, trust companies and affiliates for 1936 amounted to $4,361,193, according to the annual report submitted yesterday to stockholders by George F. Rand, president.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Jan. 27 shows decreases for the week of $30,000,000 in total loans and investments, $17,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, $34,000,000 in government deposits,

St. Peter's Prep, defending champion in the metropolitan Jesuit basketball tournament . sponsored by St. Peter's College, survived the first round at Collins Memorial Gymnasium in Jersey City yesterday by defeating Fordham Prep, 22-18.

After a rest of more than a week, the theatre tonight finds itself with an opening, that being "And Now Goodbye," or Philip Howard's derivative from the James Hilton novel. Philip Merivale has the part of the young English clergyman on whom the story is based, and others in the cast are Marguerite Churchill of the screen, Richie Ling, Hilda Plowright, Eda Heinemann and Edgar. Kent.

Abraham Fox and Raymond M. Miller, two of three men accused of robbing a bank messenger in Farmingdale, L. I., of $12,000 last Summer, were convicted of robbery by a jury before Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn last night. Neither offered a defense.

Marvin Swanson of Minneapolis and Miss Dorothy Franey of. St Paul, national outdoor speed-skating champions, added the North American indoor men's and- women's senior titles to their collections tonight.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday announced an advance of one-half-cent a gallon in all grades of gasoline throughout its territory with the exception of Delaware.

Acceptance by the government of Andrew W. Mellon's "magnificent gift" of his art collection and money to build a national museum in Washington was recommended by President Roosevelt in a special message sent to Congress today.
Dr. wilson G. Smillie of Harvard University has been chosen as Professor of Public Health and Preventive Medicine and head of that department in the Cornell University Medical College in New York.

Pacific Coast steamship lines yesterday. started to book passengers and accept cargo for sailing dates later this week in anticipation of an early end of the maritime strike that has been effective on the Coast since Oct. 29.

Two years after startling the basketball world by defeating Long Island University, little Geneva College of Beaver Falls, Pa., repeated the feat last night. The victory was a close one, 33-31, but was fully earned.

THE AVON FLOWS, by George Jean Nathan. (Knopf, $2.) An "orchestration" of three of Shakespeare's plays, with no phrase or line in the original texts altered, that answers in terms of the stage what might have happened to Romeo and Juliet had the lovers lived and married.

Salvatore Balbo, 185, Italy, finished Felix Zbysko, 188,: Poland,: with a flying mare and- body hold in the feature 'match at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 1,500 watched Balbo conquer his rival in 27:56.':
Mrs. Robert Parrish gave a farewell dinner last night in La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. T. Jefferson Penn of Reidsville, N. C., who will sail tonight on the Bremen.

THE NEW YORK TIMES received yesterday a resolution adopted on Jan. 21 by the board of managers of the State Charities Aid Association to express the board's appreciation of the aid to "many unfortunate children and mothers" rendered by the One Hundred Neediest Cases appeal. The resolution,
Miss Ebba C. Hartten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey F. Hartten of Cranford, will be married on April 10 to Rufus King Weeks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Weeks of Elizabeth.
Phillips B. Shaw, a retired business engineer formerly associated with Thomas A. Edison, died in St. Luke's and Childien's Hospital here yesterday in his ninetieth year.

Circuit Judge Paul V. Gadola tonight adjourned a hearing on-a petition for a mandatory injunction asked by the General Motors Corporation to compel sit-down strikers to evacuate its two Fisher Body lants here and to stop picketing the plants.

The Federal Trade Commission reported today to Congress that it had found unfair trade practices and "racketeering" in the distribution of fresh fruits and vegetables, and recommended the strengthening of the Perishable Agricultural Commodities and the Interstate Commerce Commission Acts.

The Rev. Dr. Lee William Beattie, superintendent of the Madison Square Church House for nearly forty years, died yesterday after a protracted illness at the Presbyterian Hospital. He was 78' years old.

AS for the first-class ironclad Oslyabya, 13,000 tons, she turned turtle, so that her keel became visible, and sank nose first. The Japanese had got her range early on the afternoon of May 15, 1905. The third shell fired had struck her on the port bow, carrying away the hawse-hole and releasing the anchor. Another had struck the port beam at the water-line, inundating the first and second compartments of the main deck.
Argentina scored twice in an extra period tonight to defeat Brazil, 2 to 0, and win the South American soccer championship. A huge crowd saw the game and contributed to a record gate of 67,000 pesos.
Marcel Rochas, in his new designs, lengthens shorts to the knees. He shows a group of play ensembles with tailored shorts and hip-length jackets and sports shirts in pin-striped flannel or shantung.

Industrial self-government is "unquestionably superior" to government conduct of a recovery plan, Alexander Printz, chairman of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board last night told members of the Infants' and Children's Coat Association at their third annual dinner meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

Donald Budge, the nation's topranking amateur, and Bryan M. Grant, the Atlanta giant killer, advanced toward a possible third meeting of the year by easily winning their opening matches in the Surf Club's tennis tournament today.
Captain Johnny Lenhart's field goal in an overtime period won a 28-26 basketball game for Colgate over Clarkson Tech tonight, after the teams ended the regular playing session deadlocked at 26--all.

A World's heavyweight championship fight between James J. Braddock, the titleholder, and his Negro challenger, Joe Louis, seemed definitely assured for Chicago today, with a million-dollar gate as a possibility.
F. W. Pirie, Minister of Lands and Mines of New Brunswick, Canada, announces a change of policy on non-resident angling licenses, intended to stimulate a greater influx of American sportsmen.
Bodies of five levee workers, drowned when a steel barge carrying more than 100 men sank Saturday night in a flood-prevention spillway, were recovered late today from the icy waters.
James C. Brogan of 685 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, a retired Battalion Chief of the New York Fire Department, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Brooklyn, of pneumonia, at the age of 85.

M. Preston Goodfellow, president of The Brooklyn Eagle, said last night that the shifting of The Brooklyn Times Union to the Eagle plant on Johnson Street, where the two Brooklyn afternoon papers began printing yesterday, was carried out very smoothly.

Mrs. Helen Jean Paddock, wife of the Right Rev. Robert Lewis Paddock, retired Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Eastern Oregon, died suddenly of a heart attack on Sunday at her home, 400 East Fiftyninth Street.

A four-day mock battle to test Singapore, Britain's $50,000,000 fortress and vital link in her Far Eastern "life line," began today. Early this morning a fleet of airplanes took off from the new air field in an effort to destroy the approaching enemy, consisting of warships, an aircraft carrier and transports carrying a small army, steaming from the southeast.

At 8:25 tonight this curt announcement, in regard to the thirteen men sentenced to die as conspirators against the State, was made by the government: "The sentence upon the convicted Trotskyists has been carried out."
Justin Adams, actor and playwright, died today at his home in Dorchester. His age was 75. He wrote more than 100 plays, many of which were produced professionally and by amateurs.

Colenel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh started another of their "mystery' flights this morning, and, as usual, all trace of them was quickly lost. Within a few hours after they had left Lympne Airfield in the Colonel's new Miles Mohawk two-seater

The list of the Grace Line motor ship Santa Maria, due today from Chile, Peru, Ecuador, Panama and Havana, includes Charles Cuthbert Concannon; Mr. and Mrs. William F. Heide Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Higson, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Van Dyke, Mr. and Mrs. Ramon Nadal and Mrs. W. N. Hinshaw.
The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today a move by Texas to limit production of natural gas in the Panhandle field and to allocate the amount among the various producers.

Miss Helen Cutting Wilmerding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Wilmerding, and Philip Bastedo, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Arthur Bastedo, have completed plans for their marriage, which will take place on Thursday afternoon in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square.

Benjamin J. Rabin, newly appointed chairman of the Mortgage Commission of New York State, took the oath of office yesterday before Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division in a ceremony attended by more than 100 friends and associates.

Arrest of a suspect in the bombing of rubber workers' homes brought several hundred General Tire and Rubber Company employes to the police station today and caused a suspension of work at the General's plant.

The Yale wrestling team tonight outscored Tufts, 24-6. Waldo Bird, who threw Carney in the 135-pound class, Captain Dick Stewart of Tufts, who, though injured, defeated Cutler in the 155-pound class, and Herb Pickett, who pinned Hermann in the heavyweight bout, featured the meet. Yale won in bouts, 6 to 2.

It seems next to incredible that Harry Watrous should have waited sixty years before deciding to have a one-man show. As a matter of fact Mr. Watrous has been-and now, at the age of 80, continues to be-one of the busiest men in New York. Perhaps there never was time to think much about a oneman show, or perhaps it was, as he puts it, "too much bother" to assemble pictures.

A Council of Laymen representing all Protestant denominations is being created by the board of directors of the Greater New York Federation of Churches. This was announced by the Rev. Dr. Robert Wyckoff Searle, the general secretary, at the annual meeting of the federation yesterday in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Sidney Howard, president of the Dramatists Guild, challenged yesterday the benefits in store for the winners of fellowships and scholarships announced on Sunday by the Bureau of New Plays, which is under the sponsorship of seven motion picture companies.

The property at the northwest corner of Eighty-third Street and Madison Avenue, known as 25-33 East Eighty-third Street and 1,118-20 Madison Avenue, has been purchased by the Lusk Oprating Company, represented by Gleason, McLanahan, Merritt Ingraham. The Joseph Milner Company negotiated the deal.

Joseph Weiner, the New York poultry racketeer, must serve the remaining eighteen months of his twoyear sentence in a Federal penitentiary, the Supreme Court unanimously held today in an opinion by Justice Sutherland.

Ten years ago George C. Diehl, one-time county highway, superintendent, built a bridge over dry land in suburban Cheektowaga. Mr. Diehl defended the expenditure by declaring: "The time will come when the bridge will be used."

A high official of the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, said today that he expected demands for a wage and working agreement to be laid before steel operators by April 1, which is the date on which contracts involving 450,000 soft coal miners expire.

Joseph E. Widener's Optic, one of the better juveniles of New York's 1936 season and a nominee for the $20,000 added Flamingo Stakes on Feb. 27, made his first start of the Winter today at Hialeah Park in the Orlando Purse, exclusively for 3-yearolds.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $8,520,000 of Fairfield County, Conn., no 1 3/4 per cent Merritt Parkway bonds Iv on a bid of 96.927. The bonds,

L. O. McGowan, director of the SinoAmerican Trading Company and a prominent American resident of Tientsin, died today of pneumonia. He formerly lived in New York. He is survived by his widow and family, who at present are in California.
Stockholders of the Detroit Edison Company, at the annual meeting yesterday, approved an increase of 500,000 shares of capital stock of the company.
Edward Frowde Seagram, noted Canadian race-horse owner and president of J. E, Seagram Sons, Ltd., distilling firm of Waterloo, Ont., died here today. He was 63 years old.

Charles H. Tibbits, whose longcontinued voluntary care of the park on the north side of Broadway caused the local authorities to name it Tibbits Park in his honor, died today in the White Plains Hospital after a month's illness, at the age of 93. A sister,

Mem bers of the House from flood areas started a drive today to expand government lending services to meet the demands for rehabilitation and a canvass was begun of the possibility of special taxation to support a comprehensive longrange program of flood control. It is proposed to lay the proposals on the President's desk.

Secretary Morgenthau and Mrs. Morgenthau will be in Sea Island, Ga., for the next week on a holiday. The Secretary, however, will be closely in touch with the Treasury Department and the White House, owing particularly to the activities of the stabilization fund. He is particularly concerned with the international monetary situation.

THE Rangers had to wait for the ice to harden before they could go through their practice session yesterday. M'sieu Lestairre Patrick stood impatiently on the runway. There wasn't any time to be wasted. The milk-fed Red Wings of Detroit, who had just conquered the Boston Bruins, were heading this way.
Mrs. T. A. Snow, 40, matron at the Boys' Industrial School, suffered a compound skull fracture today when attacked by a prisoner whom she identified as Charles George, 16, of Steubenville.

The Princeton Club team shut out the Short Hills combination on the Princeton courts, 5 to 0, yesterday to register its fifteenth straight triumph and clinch the title in the metropolitan Class B squash tennis race. The Columbia Club lost to the Harvard Club, 3 to 2, but held second place.

Charles Francis Coe, writer, topped the field today in the qualifying round for the tenth annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Country Club. He had a card of 41, 40-81.

The purchase of 4,800 shares of Chesapeake Corporation stock for $424,437 by the Alleghany Corporation, formerly the top company in the Van Sweringen holding structure, was disclosed yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Fifty business men from New Jersey discussed problems of government tonight with their State's Congressional delegation. Under the auspices of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, the dinner meeting was attended by the entire New Jersey group in Congress except Senator-elect Smathers, who, as a State Senator, was detained in Trenton;

Mrs. Eugene Southall gave a small reception yesterday afternoon in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for a group of women in charge of the arrangements for the luncheon and fashion show to be held at the hotel on March 9 for the benefit of the Longacre Nursing Center of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service.
The Ohio Legislature urged tonight immediate Congressional action on a proposed Ohio Valley authority for flood prevention, to be financed wholly by the Federal Government.

Francis B. Bracken, prominent attorney who was serving his second term as chancellor of the Philadelphia Bar Association, died of a heart attack tonight at his office here. He was in his sixty-ninth year.

Grover Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair of 1939. signed yesterday contracts for the design of four more buildings at the fair. The buildings, two of which will house food exhibits and two of which will be devoted to means of production, will cost about $1,475,000.

It is sad to think that the Young Republicans of New York are getting older every year, and still knocking at the door of the Old Guard mess and shouting for "recognition." At the meeting of the officers of the State association in Albany Sunday
A campaign to raise the equivalent of $60,000 to help victims of the United States flood was started today by Chinese leaders, hopeful of reciprocating American aid in Chinese disasters.

Pope Pius's condition had so far improved today that he resumed his audiences of Tabella, granted on fixed weekdays to the heads of Vatican congregations and other branches of the Vatican administration. With this he has returned to what is his ordinary routine when he is well.

The city of Antipolo, one of the many centers of the Roman Catholie Church in the Philippines, entertained today Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia, Papal Legate to the Thirty-third International Eucharistic Congress, which will be opened formally here tomorrow.

Several sales of housing properties to investors were included in the Manhattan realty transactions reported by brokers yesterday. The Red Top Realty Corporation, representing Herman King, bought the two four-story buildings on a plot 40 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and 121st Street from the 80 and 82 East 121st Street Corporation. Alfred H. King,

Dr. Gustave Gruenbaum, for twenty-six years Professor of Italian at Johns Hopkins University, died here today at the age of 52. Dr. Gruenbaum received a medal from the Italian Government three years ago for his work in promoting Italian culture.

Sanford Bates, former Federal b Director of Prisons, on assuming yesterday the executive directorship of the Boys Clubs of America, dedared that attacking crime at its source is a problem which we must face "from an economic as well as from a sociological and humanitarian viewpoint."

Samuel T. Brown of Setauket, N. Y., and the estates of Mary C. Brown and Elizabeth B. Davis sold six acres in the Bergen Point industrial section of Bayonne, N. J., to the Richfield Oil Corporation for a total of $242.499.
Queen's University had little trouble downing Yale in an International Intercollegiate Hockey League game tonight, 10-0. The visitors were seldom in the picture, although they never gave up.

Members of the committee of management of the Studio Club of the Young Women's Christian Association will act as hostesses at a reception this afternoon at the clubhouse, 210 East Seventy-seventh Street, for the judges of the annual art exhibition of the work of members of the club, which also opens this afternoon.

Flood relief contributions, reaching upward toward the $1,500,000 quota set for the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, had totaled $1,009,918.60 yesterday, General Robert C. Davis, retired, executive director, announced from headquarters at 315 Lexington Avenue.

Further liquidation caused a 10point loss in prices on the Cotton Exchange at one time yesterday. The setback of $1 a bale, however, brought some buying and late recover left the list with losses of 4 to 8 points. Profit-taking on straddles between cotton and cottonseed oil was reported and a reaction in Liverpool reduced buying support from that quarter.

Courtlandt Nicoll, president of the board of trustees of the Museum of the City of New York, reported yesterday that 339,748 public and private school children used the educational facilities of the museum in 1936, compared with 8,225 in 1933, the first year of the institution's educational activities.

The Rev. John H. Esquirol, former attorney and local Democratic leader, who was ordained a deacon of the Protestant Episcopal Church last Dec. 22, was assigned today to the post of assistant to the Very Rev. Arthur B. Kinsolving 2d, dean of the Cathedral of the Incarnation here.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Hallam Boyd gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. William E. Farnell, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Baker, Mr. and Mrs. Johnfritz Achelis, Mr. and Mrs. J. Berens Waters, Mrs. Samuel C. Hutcheson, Mrs. Eugene M. Thomasson of Chattanooga, Tenn.; F. Frazier Jelke, Captain Howard McCulley, Townsend Morgan and Lawrence M. Marks.

Assistant District Attorney James J. Conroy of Queens absolved all those connected with the boxing bout that resulted in the death of Tony Marino, Pittsburgh bantamweight, of any culpable or criminal negligence after an investigation yesterday.
Mrs. Charlotte Comstock Fowler Gray, 94, who was graduated from the University of Chicago at the age of 55, died today at her home here.

An issue of $10,000,000 of 4 per cent debentures of the Electric Auto-Lite Company will be offered today at 104 1/2 and interest by an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers and including Hemphill, Noyes Co. and Chas. D. Barney Co. They are due on Feb. 1, 1952.

Upholding the constitutionality of New Jersey's law providing that fourteen jurors be drawn for murder trials, the Court of Errors and Appeals affirmed today the conviction of Mrs. Marguerite Dolbow and Norman Driscoll for the killing of the woman's husband, Harry, on his Salem County farm.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,194,050 barrels, compared to 3,205,150 in the preceding week, a decline of 11,100, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 16,500 barrels in the daily average output of Oklahoma and a gain of 6,600 in Louisiana were the important changes.
A short scene ridiculing Chancellor Adolf Hitler resulted in heavy fines for a comedian and a theatre manager at a West London police court today.

Hofstra College, New York University's educational center in Hempstead, L. I., has purchased a ten-acre tract directly south of the original campus on East Fulton Avenue, Hempstead, Dr. P. T. Calkins, chairman of the college building committee, announced yesterday.

Descriptions of the two men who beat and robbed her ten days ago were furnished to the police yesterday by Mrs. Christine S. Trexler, wife of the Rev. Dr. Charles Trexler, pastor of St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.
The third annual fashion training course sponsored by the Fashion Group, Inc., will open next Tuesday, Feb. 9, at the Fashion Group offices, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

The return of fine weather permitted the government forces to strike hard and successfully yesterday and today in the Aranjuez sector, about twenty-five miles south of Madrid. Driving in a northwesterly direction, they have reached the town of Valdemoro and have forced the Insurgents back toward Pinto.

A national exhibition of lithographs, woodcuts and block prints, held under the auspices of the So ciety of American Etchers, will open to the public tomorrow in the gallery of the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park.

Plans for a six-story apartment house, a taxpayer and a 600seat theatre were announced yesterday by Max Rosenfeld and Joseph H. Schwartz, builders and operators, for the vacant plot on the southwest corner of Thirtyninth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, Astoria, Queens.

First Officer Douglas Nunan of the steamship Coamo was sent to a hospital on the ship's arrival here today. He suffered a fracture of the right leg near the knee, while Second Officer Otto Berggren had a sore head from a stitched scalp wound as a result of a 24-hour storm in the Gulf Stream last Friday.

The Financial Observer, a new weekly magazine of which the edi tor-in-chief will be Reginald Wright Kauffman, former associate editor of the Saturday Evening Post, will make its initial appearance on news stands this week. The Observer Publishing Company, Inc., the publisher.

The Board of Health, finding that many unscrupulous meat dealers have been giving the needle too generously to corned beef, beef tongues and other meats, announced yesterday that it had amended the sanitary code

John L. Lewis, labor leader and p chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, is following a policy which will lead ultimately to the sovietizingg" of every industrial plant in the United States, Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, warned more than 150 members and guests of the Queens Borough Chamber of Commerce yesterday.

Following is the text of the injunction granted by Circuit Judge Gadola: This cause came on to be heard upon the motion of application of the plaintiff for a temporary mandatory injunction, based upon the allegations of the plaintiff's amended bill of complaint on file herein.

The marriage of Miss Beulah Martha Belgard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Belgard of 21 West Eighty-sixth Street, to Dr. Richard E. Gluck, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Gluck of 18 West Eighty-eighth Street, took place yesterday afternoon in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. The Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise performed the ceremony.

Harold Pemberton, writer for The Daily Express and one of the bestknown journalists in Britain, is missing with three companions in an airplane in which they left Renfrew, Scotland, yesterday morning for Liverpool, a comparatively short flight over Solway Firth and the mountainous lake district in Northwest England.

Leon Trotsky, exiled Bolshevist leader, intends to speak to a New York City audience over the telephone Feb. 14. This was revealed today when Mr. Trotsky asserted he was already preparing a speech in which he would defend himself against "Stalin's" charges that he had conspired against the Soviet Union with "Hitler and Japan."
New buildings and alteration projects will result from several of 14 the sales of properties on the East Side of Manhattan, brokers revealed in their reports of deals in that section yesterday.

One of the outstanding musical events of the season was the recital given by Nathan Milstein last night at Carnegie Hall. Never before in this city has the Russian violinist played with the incandescence and glow which marked his performance on this occasion, or with such purity and opulence of tone. Mr.

Dr. Carlos Marquez Sterling, president of the House of Representatives, and Dr. Radio Cremata, its secretary, resigned tonight following approval by the House of a motion expressing lack of confidence in them by a vote of 101 to 28.
" Home and Beauty," Charles B. Cochran's coronation revue, was hailed tonight at the Adelphi Theatre as the best show the veteran impresario has sponsored in years.

Linford Castor, the "part-time prisoner" of Gloucester County jail here, not only is permitted by court order to commute from his cell to his job six days a week, but he gets one meal more than any of his companions behind the bars, it developed today.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Salvage of Rynwood, Glen Head, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Smith Salvage, to James Potter Polk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lyon Polk of this city and Syosset, L. I.

New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company sold to the Alport G Realty Company, Alvin Blau, president, the two four-story brick flats with stores, 421-425 Ocean Avenue, Jersey City. The price is reported as $61,000.

A card party, entertainment and tea in behalf of the Prosperity Shop will be held next Monday afternoon in the Chinese Lounge of the Polyclinic Hospital under auspices of the Social Service Auxiliary of the hospital. Mrs. Victor Harris is president of the auxiliary.

The Reading Company reported a net income of $6,515,071, or $2.65 a share on common stock, in a preliminary statement for 1936. This compared with a net income of $5,714,173, or $2.08 a share on common stock, in 1935.

The nine judges of General Sessions made public yesterday resolutions urging the Legislature to pass pending bills which would permit Controller Taylor to issue $15,000,000 in corporate stock to build a combination criminal courthouse and city prison to replace the present inadequate Criminal Courts Building and Tombs Prison.

Assemblyman Moffat, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, declared tonight that Governor Lehman's budget message was misleading in its statement that its huge total should be charged in large measure to the Assembly's refusal to adopt his plan for the present fiscal year.

After dropping the first two games to their opponents and being in a serious predicament in the fifth and deciding chapter, D. B. McElroy of the University Club and J. K. Weeks of the Princeton Club staged a great closing rally yesterday to gain a place in the quarter-final round of the sixth annual doubles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

Dr. RICE, the Health Commissioner of New York, attributes to immunizations the reduction in diphtheria deaths to "new record low marks" in the last two years. In 1936 there were only thirty-six such deaths, as compared with the annual average death toll from this dread disease for the tenyear period ending in 1929, which was about 750.

The Long Island National Home Show, sponsored by the Long Island Real Estate Board in cooperation with the Federal Housing Administration, opened last night in the Jamaica Armory, 168th Street near Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens. Several thousand attended.
Mrs. James Cox Brady was reelected commissioner of the Manhattan Girl Scout Council at its annual meeting at headquarters, 670 Lexington Avenue, yesterday morning.

The necessity for expanding health, sanitation and other municipal services is "bound to increase" the cost of this city's government in the future, Mayor La Guardia informed 300 women yesterday in the lecture group in the Hotel Plaza of the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

Continuing the brand of golf that won for him the qualifying medal yesterday, Tommy Goodwin. New York State amateur champion, came through successfully in the r first round of match play for the annual South Florida championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. f He repulsed John Cushman of e Greenville, Miss., in a closely con- i tested match by 3 and 1.

Injunctions against the sit-down strikers, prayed for by General Motors, have been granted by a Michigan circuit judge. The strikers have been occupying several of the plants of the automobile company and preventing it from operating them.
While eating a hurried meal at a lunch counter on her way to attend a radio audition, Mrs. Bernice Riggs Sells, 36 years old, an organist and pianist, died suddenly at 1:30 P. M. yesterday.

Thousands prayed throughout Manila early this morning, preparing to participate in ceremonies opening the thirty-third International Eucharistic Congress. Crowds of visiting Catholics thronged midnight masses and awaited the dawn and the exposure of the host, which is to remain in view on altars of adoration until the congress closes on the night of Feb. 7.

Capital Management CorporationFor 1936: Net investment income, $40,117; including $154,925 profit on sale of securities, the net profit amounted to $194,942. In 1935 net investment income was $41,183 and net profit totaled $49,052 after adding $7,869 profit on securities sales.

Domestic sales of household refrigerators in 1936 totaled 1,892,378 units, valued at $153,758,797, compared with 1,446,790 units, with a valuation of $112,703,414 in the previous year, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association. World sales,
Dr. J. C. B. Davis, 67-year-old physician, who disappeared a week ago, was taken off by a kidnapper for $5,000 ransom, authorities disclosed today.
Led by Captain Donald Curtin, Conway Cohalan and Paul Shea, Manhattan's swimming team defeated the Brooklyn College natators, 42 to 29, in a dual meet in the pool of the Park Central Hotel yesterday.
Replying to inquiries from many Moslems, Sheikh Abd el-Magid Salim, Grand Mufti of Egypt, issued today a statement generally approving birth control by married Moslems.
Twentythree Alpine soldiers were killed, government officials disclosed today, when they were buried under an avalanche of snow Saturday while reconnoitering in the Italian Alps.

The final Yorkville dinner dance of this season was given last night in the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton for the benefit of the vocational and recreational projects of the Yorkville Community Association, which maintains a community center in that district.

A banking group composed of Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Phelps, Fenn Co. and the WellsDickey Company won the award yesterday of a new issue of $825,000 of Minneapolis (Minn.) public relief and permanent improvement bonds on a bid of 100.075 for 2.10s.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott McPherson of 1,192 Park Avenue, formerly of Pasadena, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Anne McPherson, to Braman Blanchard Adams 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Robert Adams of Pelham Heights, N. Y.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization which precipitated the General Motors strike, moved his headquarters from Washington to Detroit tonight to take active command of the union forces.
A business building in the Times Square district and tenements on the West Side figured in the brisk trading reported by brokers yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange Committee on Stock List has authorized the listing of the following securities: Martin-Parry Corporation, 50,000 additional shares of capital stock, no par value; Greyhound Corporation, 95,090 shares of 5 1/2 per cent preferred, $10 par value;

Excitement ran high in metropolitan skiing circles last night as reports from the Northlands brought the glad tidings that the past Sunday's snowfall should permit the first good skiing of the Winter to be held this week-end in upper New York State, Vermont and New Hampshire.

Word that "business as usual" would be under way by Monday came today to Greater Cincinnati's 700,000 residents, who for nine days have had access downtown to only hotels, restaurants and drug stores.

For his seventh New York performance this season Uday Shankar, assisted by his admirable company of Hindu dancers and musicians, last night attracted another large audience which filled the Forty-sixth Street Theatre and exhibited few signs of any diminution of enthusiasm.

The beautiful Ohio let go its heaviest guns today on Cairo, a city under siege, but it made never a dent in the walls. The handful of citizens who remained on hand to watch the climax of the battle between the mighty river and puny man lost interest in the Ohio's infinitesimal rise.

The Argentine Republic filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $70,000,000 of sinking fund external conversion loan 4 per cent bonds due Feb. 15, 1972.

Chased around a subway pillar by an armed peddler with a persecution mania, a 27-year-old semi-professional football player gambled with his life yesterday after one shot missed him, and brought down his pursuer with one blow of an injured right hand.

Funeral services were held here today for Professor Moritz Heymann, 65-year-old painter, formerly director of one of the chief art schools in Munich, who was especially popular with Americans and Britons.

Only one contractor had submitted estimates on the construction of the second tube of the Hudson Midtown Tunnel when the Pert of New York Authority met yesterday to open bids, and as a result it was indicated that the contract would be awarded tomorrow and actual work started within a month.

Continuance of the Roosevelt-Hull foreign trade program for another three years, through an extension of the powers granted by Congress in 1934, was recommended to the House today by the eighteen Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee.
Using the entire varsity squad of eleven players, Villanova easily defeated the Ursinus five tonight, 39-14. The Wildcats led at the half, 13-9.

The Koppers Company of Pittsburgh announced today the completion here of a 99 per cent unburnable passenger ship. The vessel, the announcement said, "is the first to be rebuilt in compliance with the new regulations of the United States Department of Commerce to eliminate for the first time in history the hazard from fire at sea."

Announcement was made here today by Mrs. Charles Eugene Battle of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Rosemary Woodworth to Rene Robert Salembier Jr. Miss Woodworth is also the daughter of Chauncey Clark Woodworth m of New York and Palm Beach.

A three-day attempt to conduct a church trial of James E. Bennet, attorney and crusading Fundamentalist within the Presbyterian Church, ended abruptly yesterday amid scenes of disorder in the church house of the First Presbyterian Church, at Twelfth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Alone among 308 members of Parliament, George Buchanan, Scottish member of the Independent Labor Party, voted tonight against the second reading of the regency bill, which would make a "permanent understudy" for the Brititsh monarch.

The death knell was apparently sounded today for the McNaboe committee set up to investigate "communism in the schools." The committee's life officially expired last midnight, but Senator John J. McNaboe had forced through the Senate a resolution to "revive and extend" it until March 15.
Events in the affairs of Greater New York's major league ball clubs continued to move briskly yesterday but along rather divergent lines.

The Bayside Tennis Club last night joined the City A. C., which already had an unbreakable hold on first place in Group 2 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association, in doing some position clinching. By defeating invading Block Hall, 4-1.
The University of Toronto trounced Yale, 5 to 1, tonight and strengthened its grip on second place in the International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League. Hopelessly outclassed,

The three men trapped Monday by Federal and local-authorities in connection with the kidnapping of Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr. from Albany on July 10, 1933, were held in $100,000 bail each yesterday by United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn Federal Building.

The Royal Dutch Petroleum Company announced today it was prepared to pay coupons on its 4 per cent dollar loan still uncashed and which matured before devaluation of the guilder on Sept. 26, last, at their gold value ($1.693 to each $1 face value at the present parity of the dollar).

President Leon Cortes persists in refusing to accept a salary increase of 500 colones, or about $79 a month, voted to him by Congress over his veto. When he was paid his salary this month he turned the amount of the increase over to charity.

Arturo Godoy, South American heavyweight, who hopes for recognition as a title prospect, meets Otis Thomas of Chicago tonight in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Hippodrome. The contest will be the fourth in this country for Godoy, who is seeking his second victory.

A total decrease in December of 7,958 civil employes in the Executive departments and agencies of the Federal Government, leaving 831,095 persons on the payrolls, was reported today by the Civil Service Commission.
Alexander Troyanovsky, Ambassador to the United States from the Soviet Union, answered today questions regarding the recent trial of Trotskyists in Moscow.
The world's medicinal needs of morphine in 1937 are fixed at forty-five tons in the annual statement by the Narcotic Supervisory Body, issued by the League of Nations today.

Piling success on success, Premier Leon Blum's Cabinet followed up today the Chamber's recent unanimous approval of its French foreign policy with regard to Spain by obtaining a vote of 405 to 186 in favor of the government's national-defense program.

Out of James Hilton's novel they have conjured the sort of rueful and middle-aged romance that Philip Merivale underplays so affectingly, "And Now Good-Bye, "which was put on at the John Golden last evening. Once it was labeled "Cynara" when two other authors called the tune; -there was an echo of it in "Call It A Day" not so long ago.

Governor Lehman praised approval by the Senate, 38 to 12; of ratification of the proposed Federal Child Labor Amendment as "the happiest day of my life." He and Mrs. Lehman were hosts at the Executive Mansion at the annual reception to legislators and their wives.

A small-scale reproduction of last year's building service strike halted all the elevators in the forty-two story office building at 1,450 Broadway, at Forty-first Street, for four hours yesterday afternoon.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas Mitchell Chalmers, a clergyman of the United Presbyterian Church who was long engaged in Christian evangelization work among Jews, died of a heart attack in Tampa, Fla., last Friday. Dr. Chalmers, who lived at 2,654 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, was 78 years old and a native of Riverside, Ill.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Sinclair have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Shelby Sinclair, to Louis Wood Hoyle of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Hoyle of Pasadena, Calif. Miss Sinclair was introduced to society in New York at a dinner dance in the St. Regis in 1931 and was a member of the Junior League. She is a half-sister of Mrs.
The Alabama Legislature passed a modified prohibition repeal bill today. over the veto of Governor Bibb Graves, automatically enacting the measure into law.
Ernie Dusek of Nebraska last night pinned Hank Barber of Boston in 41 minutes 16 seconds of the feature wrestling event to a finish at the St. Nicholas Palace.
No "Jean Valjean" whose past includes escape from Granite Reformatory is safe today. Slowly Warden Fred Hunt is combing the nation to find illicit wanderers from the institution.
An indictment charging Mrs. Jean-. nette Trader with the murder of her estranged husband was returned today by the special grand jury investigating his fatal shooting in her home.

In an all-New York Athletic Club final, Edward Linz and Frank Coyle defeated Angelo Trulio and Robert Ford to win the New York State four-wall handball doubles championship at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night.
King headed George of Great Britain has sent to President Roosevelt the following message of sympathy over the flood in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys:
The Foreign Office has been asked to obtain evidence bearing on charges that a Brazilian Congressman acted in behalf of Argentine interests in opposing a bill to encourage wheat growing in Brazil.

Gloom entered the hearts of many "true believers" in the Candlemas Day legend yesterday as groundhogs in the Bronx and many other places scampered back to shelter, thereby predicting six weeks of cold weather because, as tradition has it, they were afraid of their own shadows.

Four firemen were plunged into four feet of water when a section of flooring collapsed beneath them in a fire in the five-story loft building at.222 Fifth Avenue, near Twenty-sixth. Street, early yesterday morning.

Unlimited establishment of branches by national banks was opposed in a resolution adopted today by the executive committee of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, which conferred here with officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance COrporation.

The plant of the Kelvinator Corporation closed today because of a sit-down called by the Mechanics Educational Society of America. Matthew Smith, national secretary of the M. E. S. A., said 400 men remained inside the plant.
Many parties were given in villas today. More than 100 colonists attended the housewarming party held by Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Vail Brokaw at their newly remodeled residence.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was only fair in most classes. Fresh pork cuts showed some strength and best heavyweight veal was in demand at strong prices.

The first example of Stone Age architecture, said to mark the earliest urban culture and to indicate a highly civilized life, has been discovered at Tepe Gawra, Mesopotamia, by the expedition sent out by the American Schools of Oriental Research in collaboration with the University of Pennsylvania Museum and Dropsie College.

The Senate voted down, late this afternoon, an amendment by Senator Bone, Democrat, of Washington, which would have increased from $789,000,000 to $1,200,000,000 the deficiency appropriation to finance Federal relief activities during the remainder of the fiscal year.

In a surprise move the Democratic-controlled Senate adopted by a vote of 38 to 12 this evening a concurrent resolution approving the Federal ChildLabor Amendment. A majority of the Republican Senators, including Perley A. Pitcher, floor leader, voted with all except one Democrat to ratify the amendment.

Using a twelve-inch ruler to trip the trigger of a large-caliber hunting rifle, Gustav Lange Jr., 57 years old, an authority on international law, shot and killed himself yesterday morning in his office at 17 John Street.

Due to floods, steel ingot production last week was lower, when the usual trend is upward, and the adjusted index has declined sharply to 112.5 from 122.5 and compares with 71.7 for the week ended Feb. 1, 1936.

L. C. Probert, vice president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, died in the Good Samaritan Hospital here tonight of pneumonia, which developed from influenza. His age was 53. He was stricken ill a week ago on his annual trip here,

The Executive Mansion was the scene at noon today of the wedding of Mrs. Mary Browder Lynch of Washington, sister of Mrs. George H. Earle 3d, wife of the Governor, to Thomas R. Wickersham, attorney of this city, and a former Republican State Assemblyman.

Baron Saye and Sele died tonight at Broughton Castle, near Banbury, which has been in the possession of the family since 1540. He was 78 years old. After a long army career, he served as Controller of the King's Household in 1912-15. Meantime, however, he had taken a job as a brewer's salesman, and worked up considerable business in the army canteens in Africa and the Mediterranean countries.
Detroit's high flying first forward line kept the Red Wings very much in the fight in their hockey game with the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross announced yesterday that it had received flood relief contributions totaling $1,129,891.52. General Robert C. Davis,
Regional conference on Social Hygiene under the auspices of the Social Hygiene Council of Greater New York, Hotel Pennsylvania, 10 A. M. Luncheon session 12:30 P. M. Address by Mayor La Guardia.

Fred R. Fairchild, Professor of Political Economy at Yale, said in an address to the Economics Club of the university today that an analysis of the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1938, as presented to Congress by President Roosevelt, appears destined to bring a recurrence of heavy deficits when the business cycle next takes a downward turn.

National Social Hygiene Day will be observed today in more than 200 communities throughout the United States with public meetings at which authoritative speakers will outline the campaign to stamp out syphilis and reduce the widespread prevalence of gonorrhea, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William F. Snow, general director of the American Social Hygiene Association.

The higher grade bonds showed further improvement yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with the trading volume slightly heavier. Sentiment in general continued to improve as the financial community expressed approval of the increase in reserve requirements, or at least relief that the uncertainty has passed.

A new award of $10,000 is offered by Dodd, Mead and Redbook Magazine for the best first novel submitted before Dec. 1, 1937. American and Canadian authors are eligible. Further particulars may be obtained from Dodd, Mead Co., 449 Fourth Avenue, New York City.

Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, and Tewfik Rushdu Aras, Turkish Foreign Minister, arrived in Milan this morningtfor a conference tomorrow from which Italian adherence to the Montreux accord is expected. to result.

The Washington air is thick these days with stories of a new NRA. Congress, it is said, will "re-define" interstate commerce, thus taking the interpretation of that phrase away from the Supreme Court:
Following is the text in part of the decision of Judge Gadola granting an injunction against the sitdown strikers in two General Motors plants here:

Fredric March, screen actor, 9-room duplex in 129 E. 69th St., through Frances Tllghman; Robert H. Strahan, 12 rooms in 447 E. 57th St., through J. Ralph Bloomer; Betty Brooks, duplex penthouse in 130 E. 37th St.: George B. Flanigan, in 135 E. 74th St.; George C. White, in 400 E. 59th St.; Hickernell-Romeyn, Inc., broker.

From his sickbed in Philadelphia, Henry L. Doherty made a compromise offer involving the payment to the Cities Service Company of $1,250,000 or 250,000 shares of that company's stock, it was disclosed yesterday, to settle a minority stockholders' suit demanding rescission of a $20,000,000 stock deal and an accounting of $80,000,000 alleged losses.

The average hourly wages of steel employes have increased 23 per cent since 1923, although the composite selling price of finished steel products has decreased 16 per cent in that time, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
The Guide Lamp and Delco-Remy divisions of General Motors Corporation were reopened today on a limited operations basis after being closed a month because of labor troubles here and elsewhere.
For the first seven months of the government's fiscal year, ended Jan. 30, the deficit, as shown by the Treasury's daily statement for that day, was $1,745,758,978, it was announced today.

Mayor La Guardia, after conferring for more than an hour yesterday with members of the Board of Higher Education; persuaded former Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to withdraw his resignation as a member of the board.

A writ of attachment in favor of the Pan American Securities Corporation of New York against the Fried, Krupp Aktiengesellschaft of Germany for $298,684 was issued yesterday by Gustav Back, County Clerk, at Jersey City.
The Blue Ridge Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $51,671,279 at the close of 1936, after provision for normal Federal income tax on unrealized appreciation of investments.

Only 460,000 of the 599,419 Class A shares of British Type Investors, Inc., required for a quorum were represented at a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., on last Saturday to vote on a proposal to reduce the stated par value of the issue from $1 to 25 cents a share, the company reported yesterday. Accordingly,

A total of 2,117,924 tons of merchant ships was launched throughout the world last year, representing an increase of 815,844 tons or about 60 per cent above the total launched the previous year, it was announced yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping. The report did not include Russian construction for which returns are not available.

The Rev. Dr. James Scarth Gale, formerly a missionary in Korea for the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, died at his home in Bath, England, on Sunday, according to word received here yesterday. He was 75 years old. He was noted as an Orientalist.
The threefurlong world record was equaled today by the Whiskaway filly, Sally Shall, shortly before two other fillies, Log and Lady Higloss, scored in Hialeah Park's principal races.

The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company, in its annual report to stockholders, yesterday reported net operating revenues for 1936 as $71,655,068, a gain of $3,867,719, or 5.7 per cent, over 1935.
President Roosevelt found an opportunity today to chaff the Weather Bureau about the rainstorm which swept the capital on Jan. 20, Inauguration Day.

As a climax to the drive of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department to stop car-watching and street entertainments by children in the theatrical district, Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation yesterday calling upon theatregoers to support the drive.

A great cold wave, whipped by a northwest gale that reached a top force of sixty miles an hour, spread freezing weather over the Eastern States yesterday and turned temperatures in the city downward toward an expected minimum of 12 or less.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Eleanore Card, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert N. Card of Berkeley, Calif., to John Gordon Ahlers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gordon Ahlers of Kew Gardens, Queens.

Two hundred persons sat in the main ballroom of the Hotel Commodore last night in semi-darkness and watched a woman acrobat, illuminated by a spotlight, perform atop an eighteen-foot pole balanced by her husband.
John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, is expected to convene the Automobile Workers Union board of strategy tomorrow soon after his arrival
Betty Shaw, away from the winners' circle since late December, came through today in the one-mile-andseventy-yard race for players at the Fair Grounds.

Funeral services were held on Sunday for Gaston Haardt, officer of the Legion of Honor. Burial took place in Pere Lachaise Cemetery. Gaston Haardt, private banker, traction financier and munitions manufacturer, died on Sunday in his Paris home of a heart attack, according to word received here.

W. M. Hughes, Federal Minister of Health, opening a conference being held under auspices of the National Health and Medical Research Council, declared Australia was in danger of becoming a stagnant community.

Business failures increased in the manufacturing and wholesale divisions last week, in comparison with the previous week, but there was a decline in the retail group, according to a compilation issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
