In due time, when he was building up what turned into the great firm of Doubleday, Page and Co., and later Doubleday, Doran and Co., I handed over the American side of my business to Frank Doubleday.

The 6,600-ton American freighter Meanticut, which had been pounded by heavy seas in a storm Sunday about 250 miles northwest of the Azores and sent out an S O S that her No. 1 hold was flooded, radioed at noon yesterday that she had been able to make repairs and was proceeding on her course to Liverpool.

Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Jack Garland, from 88th Precinct to 19th Division, duty in Raided Premises Squad, for 13 days. Bernard A. McGuigan, from Borough Headquarters Squad, Brooklyn and Richmond to Traffic Precinct G, assignment to duty in plain clothes discontinued. Additional compensation of $240 ($220) per annum revoked.

Among the real estate deals in the Bronx reported yesterday was a five-year lease on the two-story garage at 610 Bergen Avenue, taken by the Belber Garage, Inc., from the Dollar Savings Bank. The aggregate rental is said to be $46,800.

Sears, Roebuck Co. yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 75 cents a share, placing the stock on a $3 annual basis. Previously the company paid 50 cents quarterly. At the close of last year, the directors declared an extra dividend of $2.50, which was paid on Jan. 7.
The branch of the National Socialist party created to spread the National Socialist doctrine among Germans outside Germany became an official section of the Foreign Office today.

Under the spur of Governor Lehman, the Senate Judiciary Committee today reported several Democratic measures, including two proposed amendments to the Constitution. Amended to make them permissible instead of mandatory, the committee reported the Kleinfeld woman juror bills.

The Tennessee Valley Authority offered to the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation today an option to extend its arrangements with the corporation for thirty days if the corporation had reason to believe that a contract covering the sale and interchange of power could be agreed upon in that period.
President Roosevelt today issued an executive order permitting gifts of clothing, food and supplies for flood relief to enter the United States from foreign countries free of duty.

CHARLES W. FERGUSON has packed away enough dynamite in "Fifty Million Brothers" Farrar Rinehart, $3) to blow himself, sand Messrs. Farrar Rinehart, about ten miles high in the air. It is sobering to consider what might befall the author and his publishers should the fifty million brothers (and sisters) decide to make something of it.

Formal orders from the Hays office to delete all scenes of excessive or unnecessary drinking were received today by producers from Joseph I. Breen, Production Code Administrator, who announced that the purity seal under which all films must be released would be withheld from pictures in which liquor plays too prominent a part.

The adaptation of American production to Brazilian economic con- G editions was urged last night by Jose Carlos. de Macedo Soares, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, at a dinner given in his honor by the Pan American Society, Inc., and the American Brazilian Association at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, has left the Waldorf-Astoria for Louisville, Ky. His daughter, Miss Henrietta Bingham, is remaining at the hotel. Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann plan to leave today for Palm Beach.

Joseph Fishbach of De Witt Clinton High entered the final round of his school's eleventh annual interscholastic indoor tennis tournament when he turned back Don Buffington of the Scarborough School, 6-1, 6-3, yesterday on the courts of the 369th Infantry Armory.
Exports of iron and steel products by the United States last year reached the highest level since 1930, figures made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce indicated.

Frank Kane Sr. of this town died today in Princeton Hospital, after a long illness, at the age of 60. Closely identified with athletics at Princeton University for many years, he was known to hundreds of alumni of the university in all parts of the world. For more than a score of years he served as an official at football, swimming and track contests here.

Australia took a good lead today in the fourth match of the cricket test series with England. The Aussies completed their second innings with 433 runs and the Tourists, going in to bat for their second innings, needed 392 runs for a victory.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal for a municipal power plant to compete with private companies already in the field and serve as a "yardstick" on their rates and service to consumers would go on the scrap heap if a bill introduced last night by Assemblyman Phelps Phelps, erstwhile Republican and now a Democratic member of the Assembly from New York City, should become law.

Enjoying the distinction of being the only illustrator to win the title since the organization was formed, Fontaine Fox of Manhasset, L. I., renewed his bid for another crown by winning his first-round match today in the tenth annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association.

WITH college basketball about to break out again in the Garden, this would be a proper time to announce that the great whistleblowing debate has come to a quiet end. Ned Irish, the basketball impresario, has run up the white flag of surrender.

Plans for an eight-story and penthouse apartment building at 231-233 East Seventy-sixth Street, on the site now occupied by the Cornell Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church, were filed yesterday by Sugarman Berger, architects.
Sales of Brooklyn realty announced yesterday included the site for a large cold storage building, several private dwellings and several apartment buildings.

Public offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co., Inc., of a new issue of $29,000,000 of Kingdom of Norway twenty-six-year 4 per cent sinking fund external loan bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1937, and maturing Feb. 1, 1963. The bonds will be priced at 98 1/4 and accrued interest.

The Otis Steel Company has called for redemption on March 18 at 1011/2 and accrued interest its $10,827,500 first mortgage fifteen-year sinking fund bonds, Series A, due in 1941. Holders may obtain immediate payment at the City Bank Farmers Trust Company here or the National City Bank in Cleveland, Ohio.

Two barges laden with 800 tons of high explosive ammunition were out of control in the harbor for more than two hours yesterday while Coast Guard cutters, private tugs and a police launch battled against the forty-mile wind and a rough sea.
Behind the concurrent resolution looking to improvements of the Social Security Act, jointly sponsored in Congress by a Republican group, is the story of an interesting experiment.
Plans for four six-story apartment houses in Forest Hills, Queens, to cost $500,000, featured the projects filed with the Building Deapartments yesterday. The list follows:

Mrs. C. F. Van Inwegan, 83 years old, and Mrs. Susan Shimer, 70, of Port Jervis, were injured fatally at about 2:30 P. M. today, and Mrs. Helen Van Inwegan, 47, of Larchmont, was hurt so seriously that she may die, as the result of an automobile accident on the extension of Hutchinson River Parkway, which was opened to traffic on Saturday.

Charles Howard Warren, former M treasurer of the Mutual Life Insurance Company and once an associate of the late James J. Hill, left a net estate of $1,682,393, of which Yale University will ultimately receive $1,400,000 to set up a fund in memory of Mr. Warren's son and "the Anglo-Saxon race."

Francis Gerald Walthew, New York bond broker, died yesterday at the Rockefeller Institute Hospital, Sixty-sixth Street and York Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 40 years old and lived at 1,148 Fifth Avenue.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Colcord Bartlett, retired missionary for the American Board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions, the Congregational Foreign Missionary Society, who passed nearly half a century in Japan teaching Christian evangelism, died Monday at his home in Norwich, Vt., according to word received here yesterday. Dr. Bartlett, who was 71 years old, had lived in Norwich since his retirement in the Summer of 1935.

Nadia Reisenberg, pianist, of New York, appeared for the first time in Vienna at the small hall of the Musikverein tonight. Miss Reisenberg was warmly received by an audience of unusual size, which included United States Minister Messersmith.
In Mrs. MCCORMICK'S interview with MusSOLINI at Rome, published in yesterday's TIMES,

A committee to propose regulation of home work in the infants' and children's wear industry and control sanitary conditions under which this work is done was appointed yesterday at the annual meeting of the United Infants' and Children's Wear Manufacturers Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

Stephen C. Smith, former director of the Citizens Bank of this city for nearly thirty years, and a trustee of the Home Savings Bank here for more than twenty years, died last night at his home, 153 Fisher Avenue. He was 74 years old.

The St. Augustine's High School quintet, which is setting the pace in the Brooklyn division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association tournament with eight triumphs in as many contests, defeated Cathedral Boys High of Manhattan, 45-17, in a non-league test on the winner's court yesterday.

About 1,200 additional troops arrived here today and tonight to increase the guard around General Motors plants, bringing the total strength in the city to about 3,500 men. The new units included light artillery and cavalry detachments.
Davis Cup tennis battle lines for 1937 were drawn today, sending the United States against Japan and Australia against Mexico in first-round matches of the North American zone.

Out of the match-making muddle involving James J. Braddock and his worlds heavyweight title there Came one definite development yesterday. The heavyweight champion agreed to engage two men in sparring bouts in the Hippodrome on the night of Feb. 15.

Governor Cross in a letter to President Roosevelt made public today asserted that he favored abolition of child labor, but said that an amendment to the Federal Constitution seeking the end "should be an act of last resort."

Both Senate and Assembly passed today the Steingut bill validating the action of the Board of Estimate in New York City in voting $250,000 to the American Red Cross for relief in the flood-stricken areas.
Trouncing the vaunted Red Rain and three other candidates for the coming $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap, Donaldson Christmas's Accolade won the $1,500 added Durante Handicap at Santa Anita Park today.
The British have resurmed their discussions with Germany for a qualitative naval limitation pact on the lines of the 1936 London treaty.

Bernstein Bros. Hat Co., Inc., Wallis Hat Inc., in 49-53 W. 38th St., White Sportwear Co., in 683 Broadway, through Frederick Fox Co., Inc.: Spence-Bryson, Inc., linen Piece goods, handkerchiefs, Arshag M. Topalian, Oriental rugs, in 2-16 W. 33d St.; Brodsky and Ruisi, Sunday Dress and Shirt Co., in 25-49 W. 27th St.: Ad-Display Service, hand-painted articles, in 104-08 W.

Presentation of evidence in the patentinfringement suit of the Textile Patents Corporation and Julius Kayser Co. against the Rosedale Knitting Company ended before Judge Oliver B. Dickinson in Federal court today.

Predictiens flew thick and fast today when Dizzy Dean and a group of American Leaguers got together but the predictions were all Dizzy's. "The Cards will finish first next season, provided I sign. If I don't they'll finish seventh or eighth," was his first offering.
Earnings in 1936 of the First Bank Stock Corporation were equivalent to $1.01 a share on 3,035,258 capital shares, compared with 90 cents a share earned in the preceding year.

Speaking as the honor guest of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America at a luncheon meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, Major Gen. Oscar Westover, Chief of the Army Air Corps, asserted that the United States, by balancing its aviation program, could have the outstanding air force of the world.

L. E. Judd, public relations counsel for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, announced early today that the company's plant No. 2, employing 5,000 persons, was closed at midnight after a dispute in which C. C. Slusser, vice president in charge of production, was forcibly evicted by workers from the tire building, department.
Representatives of railroads serving the citrus fruit growers and shippers of Florida will meet representatives of those classes here on next Tuesday to discuss rates.

New building construction in Brooklyn last month was more than four times that of January last year, according to the monthly report made public yesterday by Edwin H. Thatcher, Brooklyn building commissioner. There was also an increase in the number of alterations sought.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave tonight the last state dinner on the season's official program, entertaining in honor of the Chief Justice and Associate Justices of the Supreme Court.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler restored today the independent status of Ministries of Transportation and Posts which had been operating in combined government departments under Baron Paul von Eltz-Ruebenach pending liberation of the German railway system from quasi-foreign control imposed under the reparations accord.
Deputy Zhivota Milanovitch informed the Yugoslav Parliament today that Germany was financing a Yugoslav Fascist movement, headed by former Minister Lyotitch.

Wage increases affecting nearly every member of the unlicensed personnel of forty-one ship operating from Atlantic and Gulf ports were granted yesterday at a conference of spokesmen of the American Steamship Owners Association and the International Seamen's Union.

Power Memorial strengthened its hold on first place in the Manhattan-Richmond Division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association tournament by conquering De La Salle, 32-27, on the loser's court yesterday.

A dinner dance called "A Night in Old St. Petersburg" will be given tomorrow in the Garden of the Ambassador under the direction of Mrs. Constantin Goodlet. Old-time Russian ceremonies, music and entertainment will be features.
A head cold bothered Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant today while he and Donald Budge moved nearer another meeting in the invitation tennis tournament at the Surf Club.
Encouraging reports brought optimism to the 1,200-mile Mississippi River flood front today while wind-lashed waters of the stream climbed by inches toward a crest.

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced yesterday that the District Attorneys of the four other boroughs of the city had joined him in endorsing a proposed ordinance before the Board of Aldermen to stop the bootlegging of stolen coal into this city.
Australia's gold production for 1936 was estimated today at 1,150,000 fine ounces, valued at about [Pound]10,000,000 in Australian currency.

Menaces of flood and disease hung over the snow-whitened Pacific Northwest today as the great blizzard of Jan. 31 began to release its paralyzing grasp. The death list stood at seven in Oregon and Southern Washington, with many communities isolated.
The Mitchel Field Aviators defeated the Fort Hamilton Regulars, 38-28, in the feature basketball contest of the military triple-header at the Hippodrome last night before a crowd of 2,000.

The United States men's table tennis team suffered its first setback in the Swaythling Cup international competition today, but recorded three victories to hold second place in the round-robin tourney among thirteen nations.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 30 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The United Engineering and Foundry Company has acquired a substantial interest in Davy and United Engineering Company, Ltd., of Sheffield, England, which was formed to acquire the assets and business of Davy Brothers, Ltd., manufacturers of rolling mill machinery in England since 1880.

Pope Pius was none the worse today from the exertion entailed by the resumption yesterday of his normal routine. In fact, Professor Aminta Milani, his physician, was able to state this evening that the Pontiff was as well as at any time since he was taken ill almost two months ago.
Burly Babe Siebert, former pet of the Boston top-balcony patrons, sent in a thirdperiod goal tonight to give the Canadiens a 1-0 victory over the Bruins before 15,000 at the Boston Garden.
Attacks on the National Labor Relations Act, the constitutionality of which will be argued before the Supreme Court next week, were made from three quarters in briefs filed today.

President Roosevelt officially turned thumbs down today on knee breeches, gold braid or other regalia in the diplomatic and consular service. An executive order made public by the State Department said:

When the administration discloses its stand on permanent neutrality legislation in hearings conducted by the Senate Foreign Relations and the House Foreign Affairs Committees it is expected to favor a combination of mandatory and discretionary authority for the President.

A Brooklyn ambulance-chasing inquiry that may exceed in scope the present Manhattan investigation, in which 13,000 witnesses have been subpoenaed and 150 prosecutions undertaken in the last six months, was projected yesterday during a conference in the office of District Attorney Geoghan.
The engagement of $2,521,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $1,696,000 in Canada, $710,000 in England and $115,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

New window drapes, probably red, and a new piano decorated with gold leaf soon will replace the hangings of golden yellow damask and the gold piano now in the East Room of the White House, Mrs. Roosevelt announced today.

At the close of the hearing on. whether the order continuing Utilities Power and Light Corporation temporarily in possession of its property should be made permanent, Federal Judge Holly took the matter under advisement today and continued the case until next Tuesday.

The Bank for International Settlements still lacks official confirmation or details regarding press reports of German abrogation of the law requiring that the Reichsbank president be a member of the World Bank zoard and denunciation of the German Railway Law.
George W. Mason, president of the Kelvinator Corporation of Detroit, received total remuneration of $193,128 during the corporation's fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, 1936.

With 12,000 informal applications already received for suites in Harlem River Houses, Langdon W. Post, as chairman of the New York City Housing authority, announced yesterday that formal application blanks were ready for distribution to prospective tenants.

The demonstration in General Motors shares, which started yesterday soon after 2 P. M. when Judge Gadola in Flint, Mich., commenced reading his decision on the injunction proceedings ordering the strikers to vacate the company's plants, was impressive to those watching the tape.
Joe Pollard vanquished George Haney, 100 to 92, in thirty innings of the national snooker tournament at McGirr's Academy last night. Pollard recorded a high run of 17 as against his opponent's 25.

The Right Rev. Mgr. David J. Hickey, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, died at 10 o'clock last night in the rectory of the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 225 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 84 years old.

The stock market here was generally quiet and firm today, but there was a small boom in oil shares. Rumors of a further rise in the price of oil in Great Britain as well as favorable reports from the United States caused some oil issues to reach new high levels.

William M. Scott has been appointed assistant cashier of the National City Bank. The Manufacturers Trust Company has been named paying agent for reparations refunding bonds of the Board of Levee Commissioners of the Orleans Levee District, Louisiana, due from March 1, 1942 to 1965;

Net income of the Continental Baking Corporation and subsidiaries for the year ended on Dec. 26, last, amounted to $3,502,486 after interest, amortization, depreciation, estimated Federal income taxes and other charges.

The solution of Japan's ten-day constitutional crisis, through the formation of the Hayashi Cabinet announced yesterday, is a threefold victory for the militarists. The Army has routed the political parties, warned the capitalists, and shown that even the wish of the Emperor is not sufficient to prevail against the will of the military high command.

Third - round victories were achieved in comparatively easy fashion by the seven remaining seeded contestants as play continued in the Monte Sterling Trophy squash tennis tournament on the New York A. C. courts yesterday.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Tyler Jr. of Baltimore of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Tyler, to John Archer son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Archer of Salem, Mass.

Figures on the Atlas Utilities and Investors Company, Ltd., wholly owned Canadian subsidiary of the Atlas Corporation, were released yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission and showed that the former company, for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1936,

Holland Williams received credit for a technical knockout over Walker Byrne when James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion, who was referee, stopped their bout in 1:45 of the first round at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

In his budget message to the Legislature Governor LEHMAN took occasion to remark that " few people realize the " growth that has come about in State"aid service since the war." This is obviously the case.

German military expenditures for the year 19361937 will reach the gigantic total of 12,600,000,000 marks, according to the February issue of The Banker, a monthly credited with special facilities for the correct analysis of conditions in Germany.

Through a bus and truck company which they control, the Union Pacific Railroad and the Chicago North Western applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to purchase the Burlington Transportation Company, operator of buses between Chicago and the Pacific Coast.

A sharp rally developed in the wheat market on the Board of Trade today following an early decline of around a cent a bushel. Closing trades showed net gains of 7/8 to 1 1/3 cents. Trading early in the session was extremely dull, with professional operators inclined to sell on the weakness in Liverpool, which closed 1 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel lower.

Death Announced Retired Chief of Battalion James c, Brogan, formerly assigned to the 22d Battalion, residing at 685 Nostrand Av., Brooklyn, died Feb. 1. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M., Thursday, Feb. 4. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

Friends of Postmaster General James A. Farley denied yesterday a published report that he was backing former Mayor James J. Walker for the Democratic nomination for that office. Mr. Farley, it was said,

Collective labor agreements, after the slowing down during the depression, are again advancing in the world, particularly in the United States, France and Belgium, according to a report on this subject to the International Labor Office, published today.

The Rev. Dr. John Alexander Mackay was inducted as president of the Princeton Theological Seminary at ceremonies today in the Princeton University chapel. In his address titled "The Restoration of Theology," Dr. Mackay said the churches "must return to theology or they will perish."

Solly Krieger, 162, Williamsburg, middleweight title contender, scored a knockout victory over Bob Turner, 155, of Richmond, Va., in the scheduled ten-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
Stocks closed irregularly higher with some issues strong; turnover, 2,428,500 shares. United States Government, Italian and convertible bonds higher, other groups steady; transactions, $13,703,400.

President Roosevelt indicated today that, in his studies of labor and business legislation, hours, wages and the prohibition of child labor were of primary concern and fair trade practices of separate and secondary importance.

Owing to a marked decrease in the number of deaths due to pneumonia and influenza, the general death rate for the city dropped to normal for the season during the week ended last Saturday, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday.

Declaring her age to be 18, Leona. Elizabeth Roshia, 12-year-old daughter of Joseph J. Roshia of Watertown, was married to Stanley S. Backus, 19, also of this city, on Jan. 15 at Carthage, by the Rev. William K. Bradshaw, in the Methodist Episcopal Church parsonage, under authority of a marriage license issued by Mrs. Phil Zecher, deputy clerk of Champion Township. The girl appears to be much older than 12.
Mrs. Virginia Asher of Winona Lake, Ind., wife of the Rev. William Asher and for almost half a century well known as an evangelist, died here today at their Winter residence. Her age was 67.

Pennsylvania sportsmen apparently are being won over to the idea that they must pay a higher license fee if they want better hunting. Dr. C. A. Mortimer, secretary of the Pennsylvania Federation of Sportsmen's Clubs, in a letter sent to members, emphasized that it was the sentiment of the federation's directors "that there is a need for

William Maxse Meredith, publisher and - younger son of George Meredith, the novelist and poet, died here today, at 72 years of age. Esteemed by authors and the trade generally, he was three times president of the Publishers Association. Besides editing his father's letters, he was a brilliant writer on country life.

Benjamin Rosenthal, formerly executive vice president and chairman of the executive committee of the United States Playing Card Company, was elected yesterday chairman of the board of the company, succeeding John Omwake, who resigned. Mr. Omwake will continue as a director. The announcement was made following a meeting of the directors.

With a total of 122,700,366 dozen pairs, shipments of hosiery established a new high record last year in the history of the industry, according to a report issued yesterday by the National -Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Earl Ferrers, head of the ancient historic family of Shirley, died at Staunton Harold Hall today at the age of 72. Lord Ferrers was the only British peer who practiced professionally as an architect. After the loss of his old pre-Norman home of Chartley he worked hard for the preservation of similar structures.

Resumption of active operations in the United States Government bond market, including guaranteed issues, Federal Land Bank, territorial and municipal obligations was announced yesterday by Harvey Fisk Sons, Inc., one of the oldest banking houses in the country. New offices have been taken at 40 Wall Street.

Frank Lyon, attorney for the Inter Coastal Steamship Freight Association, told the House Interstate Commerce Committee today that repeal of the "long-and-short-haul" clause of the Interstate Commerce Act would destroy steamship transporstation between the East and West Coasts. In opposing the Pettengill bill to repeal the clause, he said railroads, in urging repeal,

The $15 minimum wage for employes in work clothing plants selling goods to the government, established by Secretary of Labor Perkins under the Walsh-Healey act, threw a scare into business men yesterday, who felt the scale was high. They reasoned that,

Metropolitan rivalry of the most bristling kind will be on display in Madison Square Garden tonight when Manhattan and City College, arch-foemen for several decades, clash in the feature of the intercollegiate basketball double-header, while N. Y. U. and St. John's meet in the opener.

A link between the restaurant and bakery rackets was indicated yesterday in the testimony of one of two witnesses who told a Supreme Court Jury of being "shaken down" for a total of more than $18,500.
Complete evacuation of two General Motors plants here, seized and held by sitdown strikers, by 3 P. M. tomorrow, was ordered here today by Judge Paul V. Gadola.
Grimsby Town and Birmingham played a 1-1 draw in an English Football League match on the former's ground today.
President Roosevelt issued an executive order permitting entry to the United States, duty free, of gifts from other countries for flood sufferers.

Trouper of the Shandon Farm, showing much of last year's running form, was well ridden by Jockey Charley Parke today to win the fourth race, substituted for a canceled handicap feature, at Alamo Downs.

The Securities and Exchange Commission took under advisement today the application of the San Francisco Curb Exchange for the extension of unlisted trading privileges to seven security issues, most of which are listed on large Eastern exchanges.

Mayor La Guardia and Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, conferred at City Hall yesterday, after Park Commissioner Robert Moses and the heads of other city departments had complained that-an inadequate supply of materials was hampering the efficiency of WPA projects under their jurisdiction.

While the names of more than 20,000 entries for the thirty-seventh annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress to be held at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory March 10 to April 30 were being tabulated yesterday, it was found that practically all of the outstanding stars of the game were on the list.

Saverio Turiello, Italian welterweight, gained a decision over Phil Furr of Washington in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before a crowd of 10,000. The winner was impressive in taking seven of the eight sessions.

The Palestine Orchestra scored another success here tonight at its third subscription concert. Issay Dobrowen, internationally known conductor, who came to Palestine to be guest conductor, directed the orchestra.

The hope of the world lies in firm understanding and fellowship among the English-speaking peoples, Bishop William T. Manning declared last night at the fiftieth annual dinner of the Church Club of New York. The organization,

The long-looked-for release of loan cotton by the government commenced yesterday, but all indications are that the amounts actually released were comparatively small. The reaction of the cotton market here to the release was comparatively insignificant,
A departure in American labor tactics developed here today when members of the Mechanics Educational Society of America at the Spicer Manufacturing Corporation engaged in a "slow-down" strike.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Pierce of Milwaukee of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Charlotte Pierce, to Rogers Sanderson Hewlett, son of James Monroe Hewlett of Lawrence, L. I., and the late Mrs. Anna Willets Hewlett.

Richard Walther Darre, Minister of Agriculture, has found time to write a book entitled "The Pig Murder." The book deals with the killing of 9,000,000 pigs in 1915. Jews, according to Mr. Darre, were responsible.

Presenting a budget equivalent to $45,000,000 to the financial committee of Parliament today, the Yugoslav War Minister, General Lyubomir Maritch, warned the country that this sum covered only bare essentials. In the interests of economy, many real needs have been left unsatisfied, he said.

Sir Eric Phipps, British Ambassador to Germany, has been appointed Ambassador to France in- succession to Sir George Russell Clerk and will take up his new duties when Sir George retires in a few months. Sir Eric's successor in Berlin has not been named.

Seven of the eight men accused of conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government in a lumber transaction pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn. The court deferred sentence of all and continued them in $1,000 bail each until Feb. 10.

An uncommonly absorbing program of sacred music of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries was presented at the Town Hall last night by the Dessoff Choirs under the direction of their recently appointed conductor, Paul Boepple.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The efforts of advocates of the present child labor amendment to stir up the prejudices of people in Northern States which have not voted in favor of the amendment, are very apparent and are deeply resented in the South where humanitarian feelings are strong as those of the North.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered less than in the preceding week. However, the total was well above the correspond. ing week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

The Swedish American motorship Gripsholm, which was due to arrive yesterday from Gothenburg via Southampton, has been delayed by stormy weather and will dock at 9 o'clock this morning at the foot of West Fifty-seventh Street.
David S. Meister purchased a three-story apartment at 58-16 Forty-third Avenue, Woodside, Queens, from the Brooklyn Trust Company for cash over a mortgage of $20,000 at 4 per cent interest.

The Duke of Marlborough, Kathleen Viscountess Falmouth, Sir Charles Sykes, Sir Charles Hyde, and J. H. Jarrett, Colonial Secretary for the Bahamas, are among the passengers due to arrive today from England and France on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others are Marlene Dietrich,

Billiard records for 28.2, the newest balkline game, were made and broken yesterday with surprising swiftness in the match between Jake Schaefer of Chicago and Willie Hoppe of New York at the Strand Academy.

Continued light receipts of hogs were instrumental in causing an advance in price of 10 to 15 cents. Some sales were regarded as being as much as 25 cents higher. Demand was active, all interests being after supplies,

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Rose Ledeberg. daughter of Mrs. Nathan Ledeberg of this city and the lately Mr. Ledeberg, to Dr. Albert Whitken of Elizabeth, N. J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Saul Whitken.

The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross is making splendid progress toward meeting the quota which has mounted with the waters. Starting with an allocation of $300,000, it has advanced more than two-thirds of the way toward $1,500,000, which has now been estimated to be its fair share of the total national contribution.

Miss Mary Helen Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Duane Stevens of Darien, was married to George Whiting Harper, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Whitney Harper of Minneapolis, this afternoon at the Stevens home. Both bride and bridegroom were unattended.

The marriage of Miss Mollie Wells Barnes, daughter of Mrs. George H. Barnes of 138 East Thirty-sixth Street, and the late Mr. Barnes, to Colonel Maurice Eugene Gilmore, New York State engineerinspector of the Public Works Administration, will take place this afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. William F. Madden.
This evening's arrival is a play about a Nebraska farm just before the turn- of the century, "Thirsty Soil" being the name and Raymond Bond the author. In the company,

Statements made yesterday by William S. Knudsen, executive vice president, for General Motors, and John L. Lewis for the C. I. O., the former at Detroit and the latter at Baltimore on his way to Detroit, as quoted by The Associated Press, were as follows:

Sueo Ohe of Japan spent a mournful several hours yesterday attempting to find bamboo replacements for five choice poles. He carefully packed them before sailing from the Orient, but all were splintered in transit.

Once again Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has enriched the screen with a superb translation of a literary classic. Its film of Pearl Buck's "The Good Earth," which had its premiere at the Astor Theatre last night, is one of the finest things Hollywood has done this season or any other.

The compositions of Nicolai Berezowsky will be featured in the Composers' Forum-Laboratory tonight at the WPA Theatre of Music. Twelve young pianists will appear on the Radio City Music Hall stage beginning tomorrow in a musical spectacle created by Leon Leonidoff entitled "Illusion."

United States aircraft manufacturers will benefit from the establishment of the trans-Canada air service, for which an organization bill will be introduced in Parliament this week. C. D. Howe, Minister of Transport, who will have jurisdiction over the service, has stated that Canada must have airplanes which will compete with those operated by American air lines.

Among suggestions aimed to help flood sufferers received at Red Cross headquarters was one from a piano repair man in a small Pennsylvania town, who offered advice on how to save the family. piano if the home had to be abandoned.

With the first four scorers shooting sub-par golf, Miss Patty Berg, 18year-old Minneapolis star and defending titleholder, won the qualifying medal today in the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf championship.

H G. S. Noble has rented from Mrs. William L. Crow her residence on Pine Island, Rye, through Blakeman Quintard Meyer. The loft buildings at 513 Broadway and 264 Canal St. are fully rented, according to Thomas J. O'Reilly, broker.

A swift scoring spree midway in the second period enabled the Columbia five to defeat Pratt Institute, 45-33, last night, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. Up until the Blue started its strong drive, Pratt appeared to have the contest safely tucked away.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh landed safe and sound at the Rome airport in their little red two-seater monoplane at 5 o'clock this afternoon, apparently quite unaware of the strong apprehensions for their safety entertained last night.
The death of Marguerite Audoux, seamstress, who became an author and won the Femina Prize in 1910 for her novel "Marie Claire," was announced today.

The Guaranty Trust Company, as coil trustee for the issues, warned holders of about $77,000,000 of Alleghany Corporation bonds yesterday , that the value of the collateral behind the bonds was subject to diminution as a result of pending court actions. The Alleghany Corporation is controlled by the Midamerica par Corporation.

An educational campaign, designed to acquaint consumers with facts concerning production, distribution and advertising was rec ommended yesterday by Howard W. Dickinson, advertising and marketing counselor, speaking at a luncheon meeting of the New York chapter of the American Marketing Society at the Advertising Club of New York.

Arnold Bernstein, head of 'the Red Star and Arnold Bernstein Shipping Lines, and four directors of his companies were released today after a week's detention and questioning by German authorities at Hamburg.

William Edwin Davis, retired chairman of the board of directors and president of Denman Davis, a steel distributing firm in North Bergen, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home here. He was 73 years old.

One of the largest and most elaborately designed entertainments of the season will take place in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria tonight when the fourth annual Poland ball will be given under the auspices of the Kosciuszko Foundation. The event,

The Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday announced a transposition in next week's opera schedule. While the casts for the operas remain the same as previously announced, the eighth week's schedule will be as follows:

82d St., 313 W., 20x102.2; Margaret McDonnell and husband to Alexander J. McDonnell. Same property, Alexander J. McDonnell to Fergand Corp., 309 W. 82d St. ($20.50). 39th St., 36 W., 25x98.9: Eugene H. Paul to Lawrence M. Helfgott, 512 Avenue F, Brooklyn.
Customers of J. P. Morgan Co. were notified yesterday that six members of the firm's staff had been authorized to sign per pro J. P. Morgan Co."
The New York World's Fair of 1939 was introduced to society here tonight at an official debut party attended by practically all of the leading diplomats and a number of government officials.

The Schoctim Union 370 announced yesterday that 280 kosher poultry slaughterers who went on strike Tuesday had returned to work following a renewal of the Rosalsky agreement with dealers' associations in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

The Brodhaven Manufacturing Company, Inc., makers of toys, leased an entire floor of 19,000 feet in 594-96 Broadway through Berley Co., Inc., who also report renting space for the Malbern Construction Company in 150 Varick Street to Elite Jewelry Products, watchcase manufacturers, and the Seneca Art and Litho Company, offset lithographers;
The Rev. John J. Fitzgerald, cofounder and pastor of St. Rose's Catholic Church, Fairhaven, died today of a heart attack and complications after a long illness. He was stricken a week ago.

Voters of 109 municipalities located in 29 States, approved in January municipal bond issues aggregating $8,838,279, compared with $9,420,867 approved in December, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York.

WARREN, CHARLES HOWARD (Nov. 29, 1935). Gross assets, $1,789,533; net $1,682,393. To Lillian Baker Warren, widow, jewelry, personal effects, $155,455 and life estate in residue; Ruth Stiles Johnson, niece, $25,000; Elizabeth S. Merchant, Nancy T. Ragland, nieces, and Harold V.
President Roosevelt recommended a six-year program of public works in a special message to Congress and conferred with his flood relief committee.

The directors of Bonwit Teller Co. have approved a plan of recapitalization, involving a new issue of 200,000 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock of $10 par value and 320,000' shares of common stock of $1-par value, contrasted with the present authorized capital stock of $2,320,000.

Following hearings which have lasted intermittently since May, 1935, the Interstate Commerce Commission reaffirmed today its order of three years ago forbidding seven railroads using the Port of New York to permit interstate shippers over their lines to use warehousing and shipping facilities at rates below the actual cost of the service.

Savings banks will cooperate with the Tenement House Department in preventing a housing shortage, and probably will remodel many of their old tenements during the six-month period of "grace" permitted under the amendment to the Multiple Dwelling Law adopted a few days ago by the State Legislature, a spokesman for the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York said yesterday.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 2, unless specified: At Kahului: Cushing, Perkins, Tanager. At Honolulu: Lark, Quail. Asheville, at Amoy. Hatfield, at Bordeaux. Kane, Ville France to Marseilles, Fe. 3. Lamson, Buenos Aires to Bridgetown.

The 1937 American Association baseball campaign will get under way on April 16, with Toledo at Louisville, Columbus at Indianapolis, St. Paul at Milwaukee and Minneapolis at Kansas City, according to the official schedule announced yesterday by George M. Trautman, president of the league.

The Yale freshman five repulsed Collegiate School of New Haven, 30--20, today, leading throughout and closing the first half with a nine-point advantage. Edward Callan of New York, who registered ten points for the Eli cubs, was high scorer of the contest. De Blasio led Collegiate School with eight.

A pageant of medieval Poland was presented at the Kosciuszko Foundation's fourth annual Night in Poland Ball last night in the grand ballroom suite of the WaldorfAstoria in the presence of several thousand persons including distinguished guests of honor, among whom were Count Jerzy Potocki, the Polish Ambassador to the United States, and Countess Potocka.

Asserting that its Federal taxes increased 116 per cent in 1936, whereas there was a rise of only 22 per cent in its gross business, the Norfolk Western Railway stated today that "no railroad or other industry, however sound financially, can stay in business if taxes continue to soar at the present rate."

The Navy finally succeeded in buying some copper today after the Department of Labor had ruled that copper companies could fill Navy orders from stocks on hand, without complying with the WalshHealey Act.
Spurred by science and supported by G-men, police tonight pinned the kidnapping and killing of a 67-yearold country physician on a farm youth turned hoodlum.

Several Bronx apartment properties changed hands in deals reported by brokers yesterday. An investing client of Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., purchased a fivestory house at 2,764 Creston Avenue, corner of 197th Street, from the Resco Holding Corporation.
Electric power production registered a greater decline last week than was seasonal, and the adjusted index receded to 105.8 from 107.2. For the week ended Feb. 1, 1936, it was 99.0

Another strongly worded protest concerning Austro-German relations was published in tonight's Weltblatt, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's organ, this time directed at the interpretation given in the German press to the non-interference guarantees in July's Austro-German agreement.
Arturo Godoy, Chilean heavyweight, last night made Otis Thomas, Chicago battler, the victim of his second knockout conquest in an unblemished career in American rings.

Jean Patou, as in the pre-depression days, is showing 200 models in his collection. One-third of these are invitations to women to dress up in the afternoon and for the cocktail hour. This group, usually day-length, includes many navy-blue ribbed organdie dresses, some having a vest front and hip-length cape.

Settlement was reached late today in what union leaders termed the longest "sit-down" strike on record when the United Automobile Workers of America and executives of the Hercules Motors Corporation signed an agreement.
Robert Alfred Shaw of 343 Carlton Avenue, Brooklyn, gave a dinner last night at his home in honor of Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General at New York, and Lady Campbell.

Rider College had an easy time with Newark University tonight, swamping the up-State quintet, 63-35, as Howard Benyon's play excelled for the winners. Benyon scored 21 points and turned in a fine floor game.
Net income of the Commercial Credit Company from operations in 1936 was $12,159,887, compared with $7,800,133 in 1935, according to the consolidated annual report, issued yesterday.

Applications by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, and by claimants against the Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company for immediate use of portions of the $132,394 segregated funds of the company were denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

As Federal authorities and the police here found themselves in conflict yesterday over the three men arrested Tuesday in connection with the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell in Albany three years ago, it was disclosed last night that whoever brought about the arrest of the prisoners is in a position to collect a $15,000 reward.

Almost twenty years to a day since he delivered his last address here immediately before his departure for Russia to help organize the Bolshevik revolution, Leon Trotsky will be heard in New York next Tuesday. He will speak in both English and Russia.

Charging misrepresentation of the therapeutic value of certain medicinal preparations and appliances for use by women, the Federal Trade Commission issued today a complaint against the Bureau of Hygiene, Inc., the Gynex Corporation and the Preferred Industries Corporation and its president, Benjamin Lindner, all having places of busi-ness at 301 Madison avenue and 211 East Nineteenth Street, New York.

A pontifical mass of requiem for Mgr. David J. Hickey, who died Tuesday night, will be celebrated at 10 A. M. on Saturday in the Church of St. Francis Xavier by Bishop Thomas F. Molloy, assisted by the Rev. John J. Donlan of St.

Judge William P. James directed today that debenture subscription certificates and stock subscription certificates, provided in the plan of reorganization of the Richfield Oil Company of California and the PanAmerican Petroleum Company, be made available for distribution to bondholders and unsecured creditors of those companies on Feb. 20.

The arrest last night of two youths on charges of burglary in a five-story tenement house in Suffolk Street, between Stanton and Houston Streets, after several shots had been fired caused considerable excitement in the crowded neighborhood. The incident occurred about 6:30 o'clock, when congestion in the neighborhood is thickest.
The Swedish Supreme Court ruled today that Swedish dollar bonds, carrying a gold clause and payable in the United States, are not payable at the pre-devaluation rate of the dollar.

A bursting water main beneath Central Park West flooded the cellars of three blocks of buildings, including a private hospital and a thirty-two-story apartment house, from Eighty-eighth to Ninety-first Street last night, cutting off the water supply and in some cases heat.
An unintentional stowaway who left New York on Nov. 25 after a day of convivial celebration returned yesterday on the French liner Paris in a state of mind immune to surprise and disappointment.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress transmitting a report from the National Resources Committee:

The National Bond and Investment Company of Chicago today filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $7,500,000 of debentures due on Feb. 1, 1947, and an equal amount due on Feb, 1. 1952.

Colonel Robert Guggenheim, who arrived yesterday from Florida, and Mrs. Guggenheim gave a dinner tonight at their home in Woodland Drive for twenty-two guests, including the Minister of Finland and Mrs. Jarnefelt, Senator and Mrs. Copeland and General and Mrs. Dion Williams.
Continuing his spectacular play, Jake Schaefer of Chicago increased his lead over his famed rival, Willie Hoppe of New York, in their 28.2 balkline billiard match at the Strand Academy yesterday.

Thomas Moles, 66, managing editor of The Belfast Telegraph and Deputy Speaker of the Northern Ireland House of Commons, died today. Mr. Moles had directed editorial policies of The Belfast Telegraph and allied newspapers since 1901 and had written their leading editorials for fifteen years.
Increased costs of labor and materials promised today to delay construction of a second floating drydook for the Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, naval base.

A situation declared to be unique, at least in recent Wall Street history, was disclosed yesterday when it was announced that sales of nearly $7,080,000 of Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad 2 per cent equipment-trust certificates would have to be canceled as a result of uncertainty as to the title of the security behind the issue.

A new rule, designed to provide further safeguards against boxing fatalities such as overtook Tony Marino, young Pittsburgh bantamweight who died following a bout last Saturday night at the Ridgewood Grove S. C., will be framed by the State Athletic Commission, it was announced at yesterday's meeting.

The Westchester women's Class B squash racquets team clinched victory in metropolitan triangular sectional competition by defeating the New York team at the Junior League yesterday. Last week, in the first of the series of three matches, the seven Westchester players defeated both New York and New Jersey.
Stocks closed generally higher, steel shares strongest; turnover, 2,451,670 shares. United States Government bonds lower, Italian loans higher, other issues irregular; transactions, $14,248,800.
It is widely reported that Pope Pius may soon go to his Summer residence at Castel Gandolfo, hoping the change of air and the greater quiet there will help him overcome his various maladies.

Ontario's 12,500-bushel surplus of alfalfa seed has been bought for about $185,000 by the Soviet Government, the Dominion Seeds Branch here reported today. The last of twenty-five carloads now is on its way to the Atlantic Coast for trans shipment to Russia.

A fairly well sustained buying wave lifted United States Steel common to a new high of 99 7/3 yesterday, the highest price since 1931, but the movement was not quite strong enough to lift the price to 100.

The practice in the United States which limits treatment for venereal diseases in the free clinics to -the indigent can have only a "slight and insignificant effect upon the reduction of syphilis," the Regional Conference on Social Hygiene was told yesterday by Professor C.-E. A. Winslow, director of the Yale School of Public Health.

" Sit-down" technique was applied to romance here today as Harold Hulen, 30 years old, kept a seated vigil in the lobby of an apartment house, swearing that he would not budge until Miss Florence Hurlbut consented to marry him.

Members of the Brooklyn Colony, National Society of New England Women, held their annual philanthropic bridge yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of The Towers, Brooklyn. Mrs. John J. Feerich was chairman, assisted by Mrs. Frederick H. Burbank, Mrs. Sherman F. Worster, Mrs. George C. Taft, Mrs. Clifford R. Beardsley,

President Roosevelt received encouraging reports from his flood-relief committee on the flood situation in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys today, although it was realized that the danger had not passed and with heavy rains might again make coneditions acute.

Led by Wilbert Falk, who scored twenty-three points, the New York University freshman basketball team recorded its eleventh consecutive triumph yesterday when it defeated the St. John's yearlings, 48 to 43, at the University Heights gymnasium. The Violet trailed at half time, 19 to 18.

The Aunt and the Uncle had said to us: "Let the child that is coming to you be born in our house," and had effaced themselves till my son 'John arrived on a warm August night of '97, under what seemed every good omen. Meantime, we had rented by direct interposition of Fate that third house opposite the church on the green.

Commander Charles Semmes Stanworth, U. S. N., retired, regarded as largely responsible for the navy's retaining its base at Mare Island, Calif., died today at the residence of his niece, Miss Mabel Wing. He was 73 years old.
In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 397-The Henderson Co., applt., v. Ernest O. Thompson, C. V. Terrell et al. Argued for both.

The workers in his Broadway Kosher Inn were unionized and under contract, Phillip Samberg told a Supreme Court jury hearing testimony in the restaurant racket trial yesterday, but they went on strike peremptorily one Saturday night to force him into an association of employers, to which he "unhappily" paid $500.
Judge Richard J. Hennessey, who won attention through his many reconciliations of couples during a term on the Family Court bench, died today. He was 57 years old.
Powerful icebreakers fought today to free twenty-nine Soviet and foreign steamships trapped in ice that closed this Black Sea port for the, first time in more than a generation.
G. Parker Toms, a leader in Pacific Coast finance, director and member of the executive committee of American Trust Company, also Pacific Coast representative of Atlas Corporation, died here today.
The center of the Rome-Berlin axis is Vienna. In Rome it is said the balance in Austria is stabilized by a new alignment. To a certain extent this is true.
The Laclede Gas Light Company reported yesterday for 1936 a net income of $23,296 after taxes, depreciation, interest, amortization and other charges, compared with 73,003 in 1935.

SCHUPPS STORES, INC., women's apparel, 1,552 Broadway, 221 W. 82d St., 900 Flatbush Av., Brooklyn, and 1,102 Chestnut St., Phila.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 770 of the bankruptcy law listing liabilities of $34,132 and assets of $22,465 as of Jan. 31.

Representatives of seventeen Canadian railway workers' unions decided tonight to poll their 117,000 members as to whether a strike should be called in rejection of the majority recommendation of the MacLean Conciliation Commission for only partial restoration of wage cuts.

The major oil companies in Texas have increased the prce of all grades of gasoline a half a cent a gallon in that State. The new retail price is 18 1/2 cents a gallon for the regular grade, including taxes.
Bacon, consistent son of Epinard and Blushing Beauty, won his third straight race today by romping home a nose ahead of Dreel in the featured handicap at Alamo Downs today.

Miss Margaret Drummond, eldest' daughter of Sir Eric Drummond, British Ambassador to Rome, and John Walker 3d, son of Mrs. Leslie Morgan Johnston of Pittsburgh and the late Hay Walker, were married today in St. Andrew's Church.

The field for the ninety-ninth running of the Grand National steeplechase at Aintree, March 19, was reduced to forty-five today when the trainers of fourteen horses, two of them American - owned, refused the weights recently assigned.
Housing properties along the West Side from Washington Square to Washington Heights figured in contracts of purchase reported yesterday.

Three airplanes, believed to belong to the Spanish Government, flew high over the British battleship Royal Oak while she was cruising yesterday near Europa Point and apparently mistaking her for one of General Francisco Franco's cruisers dropped three bombs.

Drawings by John Russell Pope, architect of the art gallery which is to house the $50,000,000 collection of Andrew W. Mellon here, reveal that the building which Mr. Mellon plans to give the nation is one of great beauty.

Voicing opposition of the State Grange to ratification of the child labor amendment in its present form, Raymond Cooper, master of the State Grange, attacked the amendment today as a "stepping stone to the regimentation of the children of this country."

Salvator Valvo, 36 years old, a one-legged racketeer who used his crutch to terrorize competitors in attempting to gain a monopoly of the retail sawdust business in lower Manhattan, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions on a coercion charge.

Edward Stegemann Jr., president of the Globe Shipping Company, 11 Broadway, a custom-house brokerage firm, died of a heart attack yesterday at Pocono Summit, Pa. Mr. Stegemann, a native of Brooklyn, was 63 years old and a widower. He lived at 100-44 Stratford Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Rose Marie Lederberg, daughter of Mrs. Nathan Lederberg of 310 West Seventy-second Street, and the late Mr. Lederberg, to Dr. Albert Irving Whitken of Elizabeth, N. J., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Saul Whitken.
Three hundred ice men from a dozen Eastern States began their convention in icy weather today and predicted a less icy future for ice.

Northern University, which opened last Fall in a flush of enthusiasm, with. students and faculty pitching in with shovels, brushes, saws and hammers to renovate an enormous barn and picturesque, Colonial-style mansion in Rivervale, is a shattered hope today, four-fifths of its faculty having resigned.

While declaring the outlook for an expanding and profitable. credit business is brighter now "than it has been in the history of retail credit selling," Channing. Sweitzer in an address tonight before the Federated Council-of Retailers of this city "warned of pushing credit trade "to the limit," with "unbridled competition" on easier terms and on so-called soft goods."

Miss Melitta Brunner, one of the two European figure skaters who have been invited to take part in this year's charity carnival at Madison Square Garden, March 27, 29 and 31, arrived on the French liner Paris yesterday.

Resumption of steel making by mills in the Pittsburgh, Wheeling and Youngstown districts which were affected by the flood has resulted in ingot production for the country rising to 79 per cent of capacity, compared with 75 per cent a week ago, according to The Iron Age.

Miss Muriel Behrens, daughter of Mrs. Ernest Behrens of 171 West Fifty-seventh Street and the late Mr. Behrens, was married to Joseph Lester Freudenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Freudenthal of Chicago, yesterday at the home of her mother by the Rev. Dr. Solomon Lowenstein.

Mr. and Mrs. John Melville Shute of Wyckoff, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Shute, to Richard Hazen of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Allen Hazen.

The mutinous spirit spreading among the rebel troops within Sian, Shensi Province, brought about the assassination yesterday of General Wang I-cheh, commander of the Sixty-Seventh Army of former Manchurian troops.

Sheriff Thomas Wolcott of Genesee County asked the National Guard tonight to occupy the sector surrounding Fisher Body Plant 1, after thousands of sitdowners and pickets there had defied him to compel its evacuation and end picketing under the injunction issued yesterday.

A strong trend to limit the proposed convention guaranteeing workers the freedom of association to protecting them from the "yellow-dog" contract and company unions has developed in the International Labor Office committee dealing with this subject in preparation for the quarterly session of the governing body opening tomorrow.

While nearly 100 patrons dined and danced, unaware that a robbery was in progress, a young woman who carried a pistol in her handbag held up the cashier in the Chin Lee Chinese restaurant at 1,604 Broadway, at the southeast corner of Forty-ninth Street, at about 1 A. M. today.

Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, arrived here today with members of the President's flood relief commission to confer with Governor Henry Horner and local officials. They found the Ohio almost at the crest of its flood but still rising infinitesimally. The city remained dry, however, behind its sixty-three feet of walls and levees.

The Navy basketball team defeated the University of Maryland today, 53 to 37. It was the Navy's tenth game and its seventh victory of the season. With Captain Bob Ruge and Alan McFarland, the- forwards, leading the way with 18 and 12 points, respectively, the -Middies displayed some flashy passing and shooting.

Justice James Clark McReynolds, second member of the Supreme Court in point of service, was 75 years old today. Associates quoted the justice as saying that his birthday meant "just another day and I'm another year older."

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 2: Adams, Col. E. S., Adjt. Gen.'s Dept., Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., to Atlanta. Ga.; to sail for New York about June 12. Muhlenberg, Col. H. C. K., Air Corps, Baltimore, Md., to Langley Field, Hampton, Va.

James J. Braddock, world's heavyweight, will be one of the prominent boxers to appear at the Hippodrome next Monday night in a benefit boxing program arranged in the interest of flood sufferers under the direction of Jack Dempsey, former world's heavyweight champion.

Airline operators gathered here for the three-day air safety conference called by the Department of Commerce are to be shown by engineers of the Bureau of Air Commerce a new instrument called the "Flight Recorder."
Word of the death of Mrs. Charlotte Comstock Fowler Gray, 95 years old, in Cambridge, N. Y., was received here today. Mrs. Gray was graduated from the University of Chicago in 1897 at the age of 55.

The Victorias gained undisputed possession of first place in the TriCounty Hockey League as the result of a 2-1 triumph over the Astoria Americans at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Prior to the game the winners were tied for first place with Baldwin, each with 14 points in nine games.
Following is the text of Governor Lehman's letter to the Board of Estimate on pay restorations for city employes: Board of Estimate and Apportionment,

Construction on the 125-foot high steel slide that will be the scene of the ski competition of the Internaional Winter Sports Carnival, scheduled for Feb. 20-22 at the Polo Grounds, was started yesterday, when Mayor La Guardia tightened the first bolt of the tower.

To the Board of Estimate and Apportionment of the City of New York. Gentlemen: I am submitting herewith and request that your board go on record as approving an act for submission to the State Legislature which if enacted into law will make possible the complete restoration of salaries of city employes whose compensation was reduced in 1933 and has not since been restored.

Dr. Jacob Novikoff, a dentist, with offices at 2,112 Broadway, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 219 West Eighty-first Street, at the age of 49. Born in Smolensk, Russia, Dr. Novikoff came to New York at the age of 17.

After a dip of the mercury to a low of 13, a blustery cold snap held the city below freezing yesterday, except for one hour. At 3 P. M. a bright sun with a promise of Spring pulled the temperature above freezing to a high of 34, but then it dropped again.

Those who have kept in touch with the mood of organized labor, particularly John L. Lewis's wing, since the President's first election have not doubted that with the advent of recovery there would be deep struggle between employe and employer in the basic industries.
A State-wide vote on amendment of New Hampshire's Constitution to permit modernization of its government was urged today by Francis P. Murphy. Republican Governor.

While German shells rained on Rheims during the World War, French peasants insisted on tilling the soil not far from the town; and while the Ohio was steadily rising near New Madrid, farmers armed with shotguns had to be driven away from land about to be flooded by the release of a fuse plug.

Twenty-eight players from fourteen schools will start play today in the singles portion of the Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis championships, according to the draw announced yesterday by Clair F. Bee, director of athletics at Long Island University.

Mrs. G. Gilbert Brown of Newark, N. J., gave a luncheon at Pierre's yesterday for six Newark debutantes, including her daughter, Miss Sally Brown. Later the party attended a performance of "Tonight at Eight-thirty," starring Noel Coward.
Wagner's "Walkuere" was repeated last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. The novelty of the cast was the American debut of Gertrud Ruenger as Bruennhilde.

Prices of hogs continued on the upgrade here today as the result of light receipts. General sales were 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight higher and the top of $10.45 showed 5 cents above Tuesday and 45 cents above the outside figure at the close of last week. The day's average advanced 10 cents to $10.30.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday data showing that officers of the Electric Auto-Lite Company by Dec. 31 had exercised warrants to buy at $25 each 15,875 of the 25,000 common shares made available to them on March 9, 1936.

Placed by Captain Bud--Miles and the irrepressible Larry Kelley, a fast-moving Yale basketball team romped to a 35-26 victory over Colgate tonight before a near-capacity crowd of 3,500 persons at the Westchester County Center.

George Rosendale, a lawyer, was elected the new Potentate of Mecca Temple of the Mystic Shrine, succeeding Dr. S. Ormond Golden, at the annual election held at the mosque, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, last night.

Deadlocked on a demand by the Automobile Workers Union that it be the sole bargaining agency for all employee of General Motors Corporation, two conferences held here today failed to reach an accord, and an adjournment was taken until 10 o'clock tomorrow morning.

New Concern Seeks to Bring Econcomy to Business-on Public Projects To remove from the status of political plums" insurance controlled by city public and quasi-public bodies, the Broker Associations Public Projects Insurance Committee has been formed, it was announced yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. John J. McCall of 42 West Twelfth Street of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lynette Fowler, to Quentin R. Burke, son of Mrs. Walter A. Burke of 1,111 Park Avenue, and the late Mr. Burke.
Frank Dunne, a partner in Dunne Co., was elected president of the New York Security Dealers Association. at the annual meeting held yesterday. He succeeds Oliver J. Troster.
The United States women's table tennis team won the world's championship today, defeating Czechoslovakia, 3 to 1, for its eighth successive victory.

The Delaware Hudson Company has sold about one-third of the 10 per cent interest that it acquired in the New York Central Railroad for $11,065,000 in 1932, according to a report in Wall Street yesterday. No comment on the report could be had at the Delaware Hudson's office here.

The will of Martin Johnson, explorer, who was killed in an airplane accident on Jan. 13 when a transport crashed in the California hills near Los Angeles, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, bequeathes his residuary estate to his widow, Mrs. Osa Johnson, of 160 Central Park South. The estate was valued at $10.000.

An order permitting reclassification of the capital stock of the Northern States Power Company into 4,000,000 shares with an aggregate stated capital of $90,000,000, effective yesterday, was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The stock market here was generally cheerful today and most sections were stronger. One of the best features of the day's dealings was a further recovery in gilt-edge issues. In the market for foreign securities similar firmness prevailed, led by Japanese and Brazilian loans.
Among the deals in Long Island properties announced by brokers yesterday was the sale of the sixstory apartment at 85-42 Elmhurst Avenue, Jackson Heights, to Samuel Reznick, operator.

Manhattan's marksmanship was of the old wild West order at Madison Square Garden last night as the Jaspers, capitalizing fully on their sharpshooting at long range, conquered City College, 36 to 38, while New York University took the measure of St. John's, 29 to 21, before a gathering of 14,500 basketball fans.

Three New Yorkers advanced to the semi-final round in the annual South Florida championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. They were Tommy Goodwin, New York State amateur champion; T. Dennis Boardman, who last Summer competed in the British amateur championship, and Joseph Schenck

In an article published on Feb. 1 THE NEW YORK TIMES referred to Ernst Toller, the German play wright, who was one of the speakers, as a Communist leader. Mr. Toller writes THE NEW YORK TIMES, saying that he was never a Communist.

Supplementing his long tee shots with consistent putting, Charles Francis Coe of New York, medalist in the competition, today defeated Fontaine Fox of Manhasset, L. I., in the featured match of the second round in the tenth annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Country Club.

Vilhjalmur Stefansson was elected president of the Explorers Club at a directors' meeting held yesterday at the club headquarters, 10 West Seventy-second Street. Dr. Walter Granger, whom Dr. Stefansson succeeds as president, was elected first vice president.

Ernest A. Alcorn, Greenwich merchant for the last sixty years, died at his home here today at the age of 78. He was born in Brighton, England, coming to America in 1875. He took a position in Marshall's Market and worked his way up to a part ownership in the business.
Hastinola, fleet 5-year-old mare from Clyde Troutt's stable, lived up to her name again today when she ran through six furlongs of heavy going in 1:15 to win the feature race at the Fair Grounds.

Lieut. Gov. Victory A. Meyers, who campaigned unsuccessfully for Mayor on a platform advocating hostesses for street cars, said today that he would put three of them aboard Seattle's new trackless trolleys late this month.

Main line levees of the Mississippi River held fast today against the full load of the Ohio's destructive flood. From Cairo, Ill., to New Orleans dike workers stiffened defenses against the swelling burden which rolled through the $1,000,000 levee system thrown up for just such an emergency, and army engineers saw victory in the greatest battle against disaster on the Mississippi.

An issue of $60,000 of refunding nds of Fulton, N. Y., was awarded yesterday to Roosevelt Weigold, Iac., on their bid of 100.11 for 2.30 per cent securities. The bonds, which will be dated Feb. 15, 1937, and will mature from Feb. 15, 1938 to 1947, are being reoffered to the public at prices to yield from 1.20 per cent to 2.20 per cent.

The Cabinet of Premier Senjuro Hayashi, at its first meeting, decided today to ask both houses of the Diet to adjourn till Feb. 10. The budget and other bills will be re-examined and the government will prepare a declaration of policy, which it intends to publish before the Diet reconvenes.

The House Labor Committee today voted an unfavorable report on a resolution by Representative Clare E. Hoffman, a Republican, of Michigan, asking Secretary Perkins for detailed information about the automotive strike.

Joseph J. McNally, former newspaper man, died yesterday at his home at 531 West 187th Street, at the age of 60. Mr. McNally, originally a resident of Albany, was managing editor of the old Albany Argus for a number of years, prior to becoming associated with former Lieut. Gov. Thomas F. Conway

Hialeah's mile track mark was equaled today in another flashing speed performance similar to those which have marked the sport since the opening of the meeting. Finance, from the string of Mrs. Emil Denemark and under the handling of Charlie Kurtsinger, was timed in 1:35 1-5, to equal Steel Cutter's record.

Probably the plays about farm life should be written exclusively by poets. When the honest artisan puts one together the mechanical piling of woe upon woe has a fearful resemblance to the workaday theatre.

The Jamaica High School basketball team sustained its first setback of the campaign yesterday, dropping a 20-to-18 decision to the John Adams quintet in a Queens P. S. A. L. engagement on the Ozone Park squad's court. Despite the reverse the Red and Blue retainedfirst place in the tournament with six victories in seven starts.

Harry W. Colmery, National Commander of the American Legion, told 1,200 legionnaires at a luncheon in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, yesterday, that the nation expected the Legion henceforth to be "the stabilizing influence in American life."
The Southern New England Telephone Company, in its report for 1936, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $3,073,370 after depreciation, interest and Federal taxes.

The State Supreme Court today upheld the injunction issued in Huntington Circuit Court forbidding Mayor C. W. H. Bangs of Huntington from extending the Huntington street lighting utility into the commercial lighting field.

James T. Farrell's novel, "A World I Never Made," which has been attacked as obscene by John S. Sumner of the New York Socity for the Suppression of Vice, was defended yesterday in Yorkville Court by three witnesses testifying for the defense as literary experts.
The Assembly Judiciary Committee will hold a public hearing on Feb. 16 on the resolution for ratification of the proposed Child Labor Amendment to the Federal Constitution.

President Roosevelt urged upon Congress, in a special message today, the adoption of a six-year program of coordinated public works with a view to carrying out an orderly development of the nation's resources and providing "needed facilities for our people." His message accompanied a report of the National Resources Committee.

IN most of the books on Europe--"Zero Hour" (Oxford, $2.50), by Richard Freund, and "The Dangerous Sea" (Macmillan, $2.50), by George 'Slocombe, are among the most recent-talk of the net. world war is, of course, as common as is talk of the weather aboard a commuters' train. Questions and warnings set the writing styles.
Donald Budge and Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant won their quarterfinal matches in the Surf Club tennis tournament today, but a match that wasn't played commanded greater interest.

Sigmund Ruud and Sverre Kolterud of Norway, two of Europe's outstanding skiers, arrived tonight with the seven-man Swiss team from the Universities of Berne, Zurich and Geneva, which will compete against the representatives of nine American and Canadian colleges in the Dartmouth Winter Carnival. In all there will be fifty-seven skiers in the meet.
A bill introduced in the Legislature would change the date of the State election from September ot November, thus removing Maine from the role of "weather-vane" in national election years.

With the Giants moving serenely onward in the business of hustling their players into the fold for the 1937 campaign by signing two more, both rookie pitchers, it remained for the embattled Yankees to supply most of the fireworks yesterday in baseball's capital-labor struggle.

A recommendation that courts accept the evidence of psychological tests to help them determine whether consumers are confused by similar trade-marks in cases of trade-mark litigation is contained in a report published yesterday by the Bureau of Business Research of the Harvard Business School.

The Crescent Athletic Club quintet vanquished the Prudential A. A. basketball team, 50--36, at the Crescent court last night in-an Eastern Athletic Club League clash. At half-time the victors were ahead, 25-17. Willie Faas of the losers took high scoring honors with 14 points.

Robert A. Lewis of Standard Brands, Inc., has been elected president of the Tea Association of the United States of America. Other officers for the ensuing year are Henry P. Thomson, Anglo-American Direct Tea Trading Company, vice president; Reginald A. Mason, Carter, Macy Tea and Coffee Company, secretary, and George Hewlett, Hewlett Co., treasurer.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh tonight accepted, an invitation. to swap yarns on the edge of an African desert with another famous airman, General Italo Balbo.

West Farms Rd., 1,096 (10-2751), William Oberhardt to Irving Trust Co., five years at 4 to 5 per cent: $12,000. 147th St., 427 E. (9-2292). 427 E. 427 E. Corp. to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, due as per bond; $28,135. Mosholu Parkway S., 116 E. (12-3313). Mosholu Housing Corp. to North Side Savings Bank, due on demand, 5 per cent; $67.000.
On the arrival at Constanta Monday of the Spanish Government oil tanker Zampomores from Barcelona, the captain and four other officers landed and demanded protection as political fugitives.
In England a vaudeville performer and his manager have been fined by a magistrate for producing a sketch in which HITLER

Eudice Shapiro, young American violinist, gave her first Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon and revealed unmistakable evidence of talent. She played with the ease and security of a veteran, her tone was firm and sensuous and her intonation dependable.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area. Each of the following Reserve officers is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective Feb. 1. Each officer will proceed to Headquarters Schenectady district, CCC, Schenectady, N. Y., for assignment:

Suit for an accounting of more than $12,000,000 brought against the Consolidated Oil Company, Harry F. Sinclair and others by James W.
