Hyde, a holder of stock of Consolidated Oil, was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when various defendants moved to dismiss the action on the ground that it was barred by the statute of limitations.

Playing its fourth game of the season, the Peddie School sextet went down in defeat before the Hun School skaters, 6--1, today. Hun tallied three times in the first period, once in the second and twice in the last, with Reed making two of the team's scores. Peddie's lone goal was made by Goble in the middle frame.
Plans for a $300,000 Brooklyn apartment house, another multifamily building in Jackson Heights and several dwellings in various parts of Queens were filed yesterday. The list follows:
Lord and Lady Swinfen, whose marriage took place recently in London, arrived on the Pennland and are at the Waldorf-Astoria before leaving for the South.

Silicosis can be prevented, if not cured, members of the second National Silicosis Conference, appointed by Secretary Perkins, asserted today in a report embodying their recommendations for prevention and control of the disease and calling, also, for the inclusion of its victims in the benefits of Federal and State compensation laws.
Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, declared here last night that even the top of an industrial boom within the next two or three years would still leave perhaps 4,000,000 unemployed.

Pennsylvania's statesmen and a broad grouping of the Keystone and surrounding States' outstanding figures in professional and political life paid tribute here today at the funeral of Dr. Leon Cushing Prince of the Methodist New York East Conference.

American flags and Red Cross banners formed a background tonight for the flood relief supper dance in the ballroom of the Hotel Warwick. More than 500 persons attended. Proceeds went toward Red Cross relief in the stricken areas.

The market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $2,033,743,753 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price to the share of all listed stocks on Feb. 1 was $45.30, compared with $44.02 at the beginning of January.

An interesting sidelight on the great Soviet trials was once given me by a German Ambassador to Moscow, the late Count von Brockdorff-Rantzau, who was a firm advocate of German cooperation with the Soviet Union and a friend of the then Foreign Commissar, Georges V. Tchitcherin.

The education committee of the Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Children's Museum, of which Mrs. Dean C. Osborne is president, met yesterday morning at the museum. Mrs. Delia McCloskey, librarian of the museum, spoke. A luncheon followed at which Mrs. R. Edson Doolittle told of arts and architecture in New York, and Mrs. Thomas F.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In taking stock of my past four years in high school, I am ready to agree with Robert Maynard Hutchins's claim that the high school cannot make up its mind whether it prepares for college or for life-or for either, decently.
More organizations and realty leaders gave their support yesterday to the movement for prompt passage of the proposed new city building code as a means of stimulating building activity.
The Department of Justice received today "for .appropriate action" an Agriculture Department report regarding violation of a game law by Justice Willis Van Devanter of the Supreme Court.
A report of changes in equity holdings in various corporations in December was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Dartmouth's basketball team came back after the long lay-off period during examinations to crush Tufts tonight, 63--21, before a crowd of 1,000.

The Millrose A. A. yesterday completed the fields for some of the minor races on the program of its thirtieth annual indoor carnival at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, but Director Fred Sohmertz and--his fellow committeemen rested on their oars as far as the Wanamaker Mile and the Millrose 600 were concerned.
In his sixth year as president and treasurer of Albright College, Dr. J. Warren Klein submitted his resignation at today's annual meeting of the college trustees Ill health prompted the action.
It was announced in Angora today that the estimates for the Turkish budget represent an increase equivalent to $25,000,000 compared with last year.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was fair to slow. Wholesale prices showed signs of strengthening because of reduced supplies on Western livestock markets and cold, snappy weather locally. Pork loins were sharply higher and lamb sales moderately higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated veal to be stronger and other classes steady.
League for Political Education, the Town Hall, "The First Londoner," Henry Noble MacCracken, 11 A. M.; "Should the Federal Child Labor Amendment be Adopted?" Mayor La Guardia and Merwin K. Hart.

Calling American aviation thirteen times safer than that of the rest of the world and four times as safe as it was here five years ago, Colonel J. Munroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, expressed yesterday the enthusiastic backing of his department for the development of flying.

Members of the Seven O'Klockers Klub, Inc., a group of 125 Philadelphians who commute daily to New York, at their tenth annual election of officers, it was announced yesterday afternoon, chose for the tenth time Richard A. Wotowich, an executive of the Warner-Quinlan Co., 2 Park Avenue, as president.

Starting April 1 there will be no monthly charge for the use of telephone handsets on the bills of subscribers of the New York Telephone Company who have paid the additional monthly fee for at least two years, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday.

Temple University broke the winning streak of F. and M. by easily beating the Lancaster five tonight, 49-30. The diplomats, present leaders of the Eastern Pennsylvania Collegiate League, had four straight before coming here.

The House today passed by a voice vote the Independent Offices Appropriations Bill, carrying $1,046,757,143 in appropriations and authorizations for the fiscal year 1938 for almost forty independent agencies, bureaus and commissions.
Asa E. Kiefer, retired lace manufacturer of Scranton, died here last night at the home of his son-in-law, Dr. Ralph H. Spangler. He was 88 years old.

Although the whole 200 miles of country between Glasgow, Scotland, and Liverpool, England, was searched today by planes of the Royal Air Force and by civilian aircraft, no trace was found of the airplane in which Harold Pemberton of The Daily Express and three companions disappeared yesterday morning.

A step toward the socialization of shipping in Canada is made in a government bill introduced in the Senate to establish a board of transit commissioners to control transport by railways, ships, aircraft and motor vehicles.
Margaret Roberts, soprano, will appear as guest artist with C. Orestes Fiorenza and his ensemble tonight at the Hotel Astor.
Governor Lehman wrote a letter to the Board of Estimate of New York City today urging pay restorations for city employes. The Senate held only a routine session.

After easing early on selling by Bombay interests in undoing a straddle between the two markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered 15 points yesterday to end at the top with net gains of 3 to 6 points.

Sales in Yorkville were a feature of activity on the East Side yesterday. The Bank for Savings sold to William M. and Harold S. Baumgarten the five-story apartment house occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at 334, 336 and 338 East Seventy-first Street, 100 feet west of First Avenue.

Plans for erection of a $400,000 six-story elevator apartment house on a plot of 23,000 square feet on the north side of Sterling Place, 125 feet west of Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn, were announced yesterday by Shampan Shampan, architects.

The Harvard Club defeated the Yale Club, 3 to 2, on the latter's court yesterday to take premier honors as the Group I race of the Metropolitan Class C Squash Racquets Association came to a conclusion.
Orders booked by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in 1936 amounted to $182,521,304, an increase of 47 per cent over 1935, when orders received amounted to $123,629,333.

The Senate today passed the $948,735,000 Deficiency Bill, carrying $789,000,000 for relief, in the face of a warning by Senator Josiah W. Bailey of North Carolina that unless relief is returned to local responsibility there will be a steady increase in the national debt, inflation and ultimately "a national socialism that will repudiate the Republic."

Australia evened the current test cricket series against England today at two victories each, winning the fourth match by a margin of 148 runs. England was dismissed with a second innings' score of 243 today shortly after lunch. The fifth and deciding match opens at Melbourne Feb. 26.

In connection with the recently approved increase in the capital funds of the Public National Bank and Trust Company, a block of 4,000 shares of the bank's stock was sold yesterday at auction to C. E. Unterberg Co. at 53 5/8.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 1. Nichol, Lieut, B. B., Pensacola, Fla., to VB Squadron 8B, the Enterprise. Shaver, Jr. Lt. G. R., Dental Corps, the Rigel, to the Chicago.

Settlement of the Pacific Coast maritime strike, which was scheduled for yesterday, was postponed twenty-four hours because weather conditions delayed the transmission of ballots to 3,000 longshoremen in the Seattle area and prevented their voting on the terms offered by the shin lines.

Kirsten Flagstad, the current first lady of song, appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night. It was the sixth event of the hall's endowment series. Days ago all the seats were sold; every available spot on the stage was used to accommodate the overflow. Excitement ran high, and Miss Flagstad did not let down her expectant audience.

Philip Schick, a retired wholesale wine and liquor merchant of Staten Island and father of Alderman Frederick Schick of the Sixty-fourth Aldermanic District, died yesterday at the Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn after a brief illness.

The Dartmouth- hockey team defeated Middlebury tonight, scoring two goals late in the final period to triumph by 5-3. Dave Walsh, sophomore center, combined with Dick Lewis to give the Indians their winning margin.

Queen of the South, Dumfries soccer club, whose 1-0 victory over the Glasgow Rangers was the outstanding achievement of firstround matches in the Scottish Cup competition, will play Airdrieonians in the second stage Feb. 13. The draw for the second round was made today.

Brief service strikes were called yesterday in fifteen Manhattan buildings. The walkouts lasted from one minute to three hours, full service being restored after the building owners had signed temporary agreements or formal two-year contracts with Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union.

Dr. George L. Omwake, president of Ursinus College for twenty-four years until his retirement last June, died of heart disease today at his home-here. He was 65 years old. Ill health prompted his resignation in 1934, but he did not give up his post for two years.

Seton Hall College of. South Orange registered its second victory of the season over St. Peter's College at Collins Memorial Gymnasium in Jersey City last night, winning a hard-fought basketball game, 35--29. The victors held an advantage of 16-11 at half time.

After seven days of the first aeronautical exhibition in New York in seven years, Aviators Post 743, American Legion, and the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America announced last night their intention of making the National Air Show an annual event in this city.
Frederick W. Marks, former partner in the firm of David Marks Sons, wholesale clothing merchants, died yesterday afternoon at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was in his seventy-third year.

Acting promptly on a strong recommendation from Governor Lehman, the Board of Estimate moved late yesterday afternoon to assure the ending of pay cuts for city employes on July 1 and the restoration of the salaries of about 110,000 men and women to the old levels on that date.
Chanceview, top-weighted favorite, finished a neck in front of C. V. Whitney's Piccolo and won the $1,500 added Sierra Bonita Handicap at Santa Anita today.

Turpentine steady, 42C; no sales: receipts, 61 barrels: shipments, 129 barrels; stock, 29,717 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 149; receipts, 437; shipments, 861: stock, 71,495. Quote: B, $8.80; D, $9; E, $9.25; F, $9.50: G to N, $9.70; WG, $10; WW, X, $11.80.

The arrest of Stanley Backus, 19-year-old husband of a 12-year-old girl, was announced tonight by District Attorney Carl J. Hynes, who said the youth would be charged tomorrow with second degree rape.

Sir Raymond Unwin, British city planning authority, and Major J. H. Roberts are among the passengers sailing today for London via Plymouth on the Cunard White Star liner Antonia. Others sailing are Miss Pamela Dodwell, G. M. A. Davis, Mrs. John Flower, Mrs. W. Bonar Hall and Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Batson.

Walter Hammitt, senior vice president and secretary of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc., Brooklyn, will in the future devote the major portion of his activity with the store to the duties of executive vice president in charge of public relations, it was announced here yesterdaY.

Following his election last night as president of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers, A. S. Phillips, president of the Phillips-Jones Corporation, pledged the support of the organization to cooperate with the Federal government to stimulate business. The organization, he said.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

The National Resources Water Committee recommended today a program of reservoir construction on tributaries of the Ohio River as "the most practical means of controlling the floods of the Ohio and its larger branches."

Assets of the Standard Investing Corporation, at market value on Dec. 31 stood at $9,209,795, against Bank debt of $1,000,000 and debentures of $2,941,000, according to the company's annual report issued yesterday.

Surviving their semi-final games at Collins Memorial Gymnasium in Jersey City yesterday, St. Peter's Prep and Brooklyn Prep earned the right to play for the championship next Tuesday night in the third annual metropolitan Jesuit basketball tournament sponsored by St. Peter's College.
Thousands of Roman Catholic women from all parts of the world paid homage here today to Christ in the Blessed Sacrament on the second day of the thirty-third International Eucharistic Congress.

Miss Eliza MacDonald, 91 years of age, one of the leading clubwomen in Queens, organizer of the Flushing Equal Franchise Association, which did much in the early days of the fight for woman suffrage, died yesterday afternoon at her home, 43-62 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing.
J. J. (Uncle John) Allen, 112-year-old Confederate veteran, who reared forty-three orphans besides his own family of eight children, died at his home here today.
Mrs. A. N. Clarke of Hilton Hall gave a tea today at the Garden City Hotel. Mrs. Clarke's guests

With the expiration today of the contract between the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Commonwealth Southern Power Company, negotiations for a permanent agreement on operations in the Tennessee Valley have broken down.

By L LINCOLN SEIDE Sedgwick Av., 2,790-2,794; 2-story brick dwelling, 75.8X139.11; Empire City Savings Bank against Solomon J. Weinstein; due $26,790, taxes. , $49; to plaintiff for $23,000. By GEORGE J. KEARNS. Dwight PL. 1,528; 75x100; Edward E. Bashford. trustees, against Ida Kristenson. due $5,769, taxes, , $958; to plaintiff for $4,500.

Having lacked an operetta for some time, the theatre this evening can pile into the Imperial and have a look at "Frederika," music by Franz Lehar, book by Edward Eliscu. Singing the roles-the story is about the youthful Goethe-are Dennis King, Helen Gleason, Ernest Truex, George Trabert, Arthur Vinton, Doris Patston, Edith King and many more. The curtain is at 8:30 and the top price for the opening performance is $5.50 a ticket.

The French liner Paris docked yesterday, the first major transatlantic passenger liner to use the new system of "radio pratique," by which certain classes of liners may pass through Quarantine - after medical clearance by radio.

Sales of copper abroad were reported yesterday at 13 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports. Closing quotations on the London Metal Exchange, however, were equivalent to 13.08 cents. On Tuesday foreign sales were made between 12.75 and 12.925 cents.

The upward impetus given to the bond market by the announcement last week-end of the increase in reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System appeared yesterday to have spent itself.

Three more teams reached the quarter-final mark in the sixth annual doubles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday at Heights Casino, one of them being the seeded pair composed of W. S. Wonham and D. L. Norris of the Greenwich Field Club.
ZERO HOUR, by Richard Freund. (Oxford University Press, $2.50.) A picture of the present world crisis. DAY OF ESCAPE, by Louise Braden. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) A novel of suspense.
While complete data still are lacking, credit executives agreed yesterday that the merchandise losses caused by the floods in the Ohio and Mississippi valleys will be lower than earlier estimates.

Several new sources of revenue, among them a personal income tax and a levy on amusements, were suggested today by Governor Wilbur L. Cross. Bills containing the proposals were submitted to the General Assembly.

WHEN Mr. Y. Muraoka, who writes pieces for a Japanese newspaper, rambled in he was followed rather shyly by a slim young Japanese chap. Pointing to his young friend, Mr. Muraoka said with a genial smile: "He goes up. This is the pole vaulter, you know."

Miss Margaret C. Holly, for thirty years executive secretary of the Charity Organization Society here, died today in Muhlenberg Hospital after a short illness of pneumonia. She was born in New York, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John I. Holly, and was 62 years old.

Inducted into office today with traditional ceremony as the eleventh president of Brown University, Dr. Henry Merritt Wriston declared his administration would be free from the boundaries of some formal plan and would point toward the continuous development of the institution's individual personality.

The Foreign Ministers of Italy and TurkeyCount Galeazzo Ciano and Tewfik Rushdu Aras-had two long conferences this morning and this afternoon, in which, it is understood, the two statesmen found themselves in agreement on the principal questions pending between their countries.

For the first time since 1930, the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York reported for last year a gain in total insurance in force, the figure rising from $3,708,081,401 at the-:end of 1935 to $3,712,259,614 at the end of 1936, an advance of $4,178,213.

Miss Rosemary Phelps Dodge, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter Phelps Dodge of London, was married to Alexander Gregerieff Jr., son of Colonel and Mrs. Alexander Gregorieff of Hartford, Conn., yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Arthur S. Runyon, 45 Park Avenue, this city.

Tolls collected from 399 ocean vessels traversing the Panama Canal during January amounted to $1,598.323.51, and from ninety-seven local vessels the sum of $6,070.13 was received, the Governor of the Panama Canal reported to the War Department today.

The District Attorney's office and the Nassau County Police Department were a bit embarrassed today as the "phantom burglar of Nassau" auspiciously opened his 1937 robbery season by breaking into twelve houses in Williston Park and Mineola.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Forbes Parker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ransom J. Parker of 155 Lexington Avenue, to Dr. Charles A. Ragan Jr., son of Colonel Charles A. Ragan, Medical Corps, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Ragan of 445 Riverside Drive, took place yesterday in the Catholic Church of St. Stephen in East Twenty-eighth Street. The Rev. Christopher J.

Attacking the Wagner act "on constitutional grounds" William Randolph Hearst and the publications under his control asked the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today to enjoin the National Labor Relations Board from enforcing its orders in The Seattle Post-Intelligencer strike.

The provisional 5-cent postage stamp issued by the postmaster of Boscawen, N. H., in 1846 was sold yesterday for $5,100 at the dispersal of the stock of Frank Marquis, stamp dealer, who recently retired.

Two men arrested on the Yugoslav frontier today at Maribor told police officials that they were deserters from the German Army who escaped in order to avoid serving with General Francisco Franco's forces in Spain.

E. M. Delafield, whose latest book, "I Visit the Soviets," will be published by Harpers two weeks from now, will arrive here on the Europa on Feb. 8. She will go on a six-month lecture tour through the United States and Canada.

The increasing rate of fall of the Ohio River from Pittsburgh to Evansville brought the stream back within its banks in a region extending almost down to Portsmouth, Ohio, today. W. C. Devereaux, meteorologist, reported these conditions:
Among many luncheon parties at the Bath Club was that at which Mr. and Mrs. Hamlin Garland of Cape Cod were guests of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac R. Edmands of Brookline, Mass.

With many of the metropolitan district's leading players as well as several Philadelphia stars represented among the twenty pairs entered, the eighth annual invitation squash racquets doubles tourney for the Lockett Trophy started last night at the University Club as two preliminary-round matches were contested.

With only three more team matches remaining to wind up the season, the New York Athletic Club yesterday maintained its slender hold on first place in the Class A race of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League by scoring its thirteenth victory in as many starts. The Winged Foot representatives visited the Crescent A. C. courts for a 4-to-1 triumph.

The State of Georgia, defending the insurrection conviction of Angelo Herndon, Negro communist, told the Supreme Court today that "time has not dimmed or varied the evil of attempting to incite people to insurrection."
The Spanish Rebels' radio station in Seville, Spain, announced today that their southern army had reopened its drive against the Mediterranean city of Malaga.

In the midst of the civil war General Francisco Franco's adherents have repaired Spain's biggest railroad bridge, the Ormaiztegui Viaduct, which was blown up by the Leftists in their retreat from the Irun-San Sebastian sector early last September.

The address by Dr. JOHN A. MACKAY at his inauguration as president of the Princeton Theological Seminary gives evidence that a great thinker has come from the years of service in the field of missions into that of intellectual theological leadership.
The Yeshiva College quintet defeated Webb Institute, 29-18, on the victors' court last night. Irving Koslovsky made 10 points for the winners to take high scoring honors.

As a study of the constant love of a man and woman kept apart by circumstances and their own weaknesses, "Orchard Walls," by Merton Hodge, based on the Hungarian play of Ladislaus Fodor, was presented at St. James's Theatre tonight.

Blair defeated Trinity, 28--26, today to topple the losers from the lead in the Eastern Private Schools' Basketball League, Peddie taking the pace-setter's post. At half time the score was tied, 9-9, but Blair led at the close of the third period, 24-14. Trinity rallied in the last quarter and nearly caught the winners.

Frank B. York of 169 West Eightieth Street, a retired lawyer and formerly president of the Brooklyn National League Baseball Club, died- on Tuesday in the Misericordia Hospital of pneumonia after a week's illness. His age was 59.

President ROOSEVELT sent to Congress yesterday a report of the National Resources Committee, carrying a six-year program of public works. The period of six years has been chosen arbitrarily, and the President notes that it can, of course, be modified in accordance with future appropriations made by Congress.

Ivan Dobson, associate manager of the supervisory department of the Standard Statistics Company, Inc., was called yesterday to testify for C. C. Wright in the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearings on alleged manipulation of the Stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Company.
Diplomatic notes may be ignored or remain unanswered, but armament expansion by one Power is promptly countered by like or greater enlargement of fighting strength across the frontier.

Yugoslav economic organizations, including the National Bank, exporters and the Ministries of Commerce and Agriculture, advocated at a recent meeting the application of the National Bank proposal for limiting German purchases in Yugoslavia.

World grain markets were on the upgrade today from start to finish, with the close at the top levels. Reports that Germany had entered the market as a large buyer of Argentine wheat and corn, and an aggressive demand for cash grain in general from importing countries, brought in a rush of buying orders in futures.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and the Chase National Bank, in disposing in 1982 of their controlling interest in the $190,000,000 Federal Water Service Corporation, "unjustly enriched themselves" at the expense of the utility corporation and caused a direct loss of $900,000 and indirect losses of "many millions" to the utility, it was charged yesterday in a suit for an accounting brought in Supreme Court by a stockholder of Federal Water Service.

Defying an elevator starter and two operators, two robbers, one tall and the other short, with one pistol between them, held up Miss Estelle Mendelson, bookkeeper of the Goldworm Sportswear Company, in the lobby at 1,372 Broadway, near Thirty-eighth Street, at 3 P. M. yesterday and escaped with $2,233.

The marriage of Miss Sarah Jane Sanford, daughter of John Sanford of New York and Palm Beach, to Mario Pansa, son of Alberto Pansa, Senator of the Kingdom of Italy, and the Countess Maria Gigli Cervi, took place at 1 o'clock today at Villa Marina.

Government economists estimated today that the flood loss to business in stricken areas would total around $600,000,000. This estimate was based on loss of business property and equipment, crippled trade and weakened purchasing power. It did not inelude damages to homes and other losses of individuals.
47th St., 446 W., 5-story building, 25x100; State Mortgage Commission and Title Guarantee Trust Co. against Jennie F. Mulholland; due, $26,623; taxes, $2,925; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Frank Iannicelli of the New York A. C. scored a third-round triumph over W. R. Cameron of the Princeton Club, 15-4, 15-10, in the lone match contested yesterday in the Monte Sterling Trophy squash tennis tournament at the New York A.C.

Coming from behind in a whirlwind finish, Duke University won a closely fought game of basketball from the Army five today, 31 to 28. The Army set a fast pace throughout the first half and led at the intermission by 22 to 14. Duke had a difficult time getting started and was shooting with poor direction in the opening session.

Twentieth Century-Fox's "On the Avenue," for which Irving Berlin supplied the music and lyrics, will open today at the Radio City Music Hall. Dick Powell and Madeleine Carroll are the principals and the supporting company includes Alice Faye, the Ritz Brothers, George Barbier, Alan Mowbray, Cora Witherspoon, Walter Catlett and the slow-moving Stepin Fetchit.
Choate School defeated Loomis, 1--0, at hockey today. Although both teams have been handicapped by the lack of sufficient practice they put on a fast, hard-fought battle.
Consolidated operating revenue of the Beauharnois Power Corporation, Ltd., for 1936 was $1,645,429, compared with $2,872,881 in 1935, according to the annual report issued today.

The International Paper Company filed suit in the United States District Court today to enforce an award of the Interstate Commerce Commission for approximately $125,000 which was made last Nov. 9 against sixteen railroads that hauled shipments of clay from South Carolina and Georgia to the paper company's factories in New England in the two years ended with April, 1928.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following calendar was announced: .
Fiftyfive women from a WPA sewing project in Atlantic City, whose skill in the making of layettes had won her praise, were received at the White House this afternoon by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Policemen were summoned to the Federal Building at 45 Broad way yesterday morning when a clash threatened between employes of the United Fruit Company holding membership in the Cargo Handlers Association and former employes during a hearing of charges of the latter that the association was a company-controlled union.

Passage by the State Senate at Albany on Tuesday of the concurrent resolution ratifying the child labor amendment of the Federal Constitution doubtless portends similar action by the Assembly. Governor LEHMAN believes that it does.

Red Dutton's New York Americans will clash with the Toronto Maple Leafs on the ice tonight at Madison Square Garden in a game that will have an important bearing on the future of the Star-Spangled squad in the National Hockey League's pennant race.
The basketball teams of Fordham and St. Francis put together a game last night which easily surpassed any court struggle seen on Old Rose Hill in recent seasons.
Ray S. Trent, former instructor in economics at. Indiana University, died at his home here today. His age was 57. At one time he was dean of Crescent College, Eureka Springs, Ark.

Word was received here of the death yesterday at Ormond Beach, Fla., of Mrs. Susan Burchell Adams, widow of John Dunbar Adams, who was one of the founders and a former vice president of the American Chicle Company. The Adams home is here.

Proposed changes in capital stock have been reported to the New York Stock Exchange by the Grand Union Company, the Exchange announced yesterday. Each share of the 500,000 convertible preference shares, no-par value, will be exchanged for one and a half shares of $1-par value capital stock, with adjustment for accrued and unpaid dividends.
Led by Miss Patty Berg, 18-yearold Minneapolis sensation, all favorites came through successfully in the first round of match play of the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf championship today.

Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr. entertained with tea and cocktails today at their villa in honor of Mrs. Bertrand E. Linde. Mrs. Harold A. Braman, Mrs. Frank L. Cheek, Mrs. John H. Perry and Mrs. Lawrence A. Furlong presided at the tea table.
The Duke of Windsor made his bow to society as a private person tonight at a musical evening at the British Legation given by Sir Walford and Lady Selby. Among the other guests
John J. Levenson of White Plains comments interestingly on the necessity of protecting the black bass during the spawning season, a subject discussed in this column several days ago.

Representatives of coastal steamship operators told a Congressional committee today that modification of the long-and-short haul clause of the Interstate Commerce Act would lead to a "jungle battle" between rail and water lines.

Joachim von Ribbentrop, fresh from a protracted sojourn in Germany, came back to his Ambassadorial post this afternoon to meet the reaction from Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Reichstag speech and the tenser atmosphere it has created here. He had been absent since mid-December.
Adolph Lankering, former Mayor of Hoboken, who was one of the original "boomers" of Woodrow Wilson for Governor of New Jersey and later for President, died at Christ Hospital, Jersey City, yesterday.
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross came yesterday to within $250,000 of its goal of $1,500,000 for flood relief as gifts brought the total up to $1,250,804.35.

Alexander J. McDonnell sold to the Fergand Corp., Alice M. Ferguson, president, the dwelling at 313 W. 32d St., and took back a purchase-money mortgage for $19,000, due in five years at 5 per cent. An $8,000 mortgage on 225-227 E. 24th St. was assigned by Susannah Walther to Rudolph J. Fischer.
With Everett Spannert leading the attack with fourteen points, the Drew quintet halted Wagner, 47-22, tonight. The victors led by 22-7 at the intermission.

The Haverhill Country Club today announced adoption of the fourteenclub-limit plan of the United States Golf Association. Officials said they believed the club was the first in New England and the second in the country to adopt the rule.

A bill to outlaw "sit-down" strikes in Alabama was reported favorably today by the State Senate Finance and Taxation Committee. The committee provided that damages should be paid by strikers or unions encouraging "sit-down" strikes.

The executive committee of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks opposes the establishment of national bank branches beyond the confines of the State in which the parent organization is located.

Cash receipts of the Argentine Treasury in January were 79,567,950 pesos, or about $26,550,000, an increase of 3,261,096 pesos, or $1,090,000, over those for January last year, according to cabled advices received here yesterday by the Argentine Information Bureau.

Estimated production of coke pig iron in January, according to The Iron Age, totaled 3,212,135 gross tons, compared with 3,115,037 tons in December. The daily rate in January, at 103,617 tons, was 3.1 per cent over the 100,485 tons in December.

The engagement abroad for shipment here of $7,382,000 of gold was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gold included $4,100,000 taken in England, $1,695,000 in Canada, $1,150,000 in Bolivia and $437,000 in India.

On his own application: PATROLMAN-Joseph F. Kirsch, 66th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 1, 1896. Temporary Assignments Patrolmen-Daniel J. Hannon, from 14th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. Office, N. Y. County, for 5 days. William Friedman, from 15th Precinct to 18th Division, for 13 days.

Germany's banks have fulfilled their duty to facilitate Chancellor Hitler's first Four-Year Plan and their coming task is to provide long-term credits for Four-Year Plan No. 2. Thereby, however, the dictates of banking liquidity must be observed.
Among foreigners in the list of awards of the Legion of Honor, published by the Foreign Office today, were the following Americans resident in France: Charles Anthony Fulton

A plan of reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act, contingent on government benefits, by which the Munson Steamship Line hopes to regain "an important position in the United States Merchant Marine," was filed in Federal court yesterday.

Miss Rosemary Clark, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Vincent Clark and the late Mr. Clark of this city, became the bride this morning of John F. McDonough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. McDonough of New York.

The marriage of Miss Mary Wells Barnes, known to her friends as Mollie, daughter of Mrs. George H. Barnes of 138 East Thirty-sixth Street and the late Mr. Barnes, to Colonel Maurice Eugene Gilmore, New York State engineer-inspector of the Public Works Administration, took place yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A mother and her son were burned to death and five others narrowly escaped when flames destroyed their home on the Harvey H. Dey farm two miles east of here at 4 o'clock this morning. The dead were Mrs. Belle Davison, 60 years old, and her son, Elmer, 22.

Mr. and Mrs. John T. McMahon of Manhasset, L. I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. McMahon's sister, Miss Elizabeth Coster Hepburn, also of Manhasset, to Henry Noyes Gammack of Sea Cliff, son of the late Rev. and Mrs. John W. Gammack.

Scoring the largest weekly increase thus far this year, retail package deliveries for the week ended Jan. 30 in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban area increased 17 per cent over the comparative 1936 week, the United Parcel 'Service announced yesterday.

Manhattan SAGGALEY, LOUISE (Nov. 28). Estate, more than $10,000. To Helen P. McDowell, sister, Rye, N. Y., specific Jewelry and household furnishings; William Baggaley, husband, 2 Grace Church St., Rye, N. Y., executor.

An order is sued by army headquarters for the detention of Dr.- Carlos Marques Sterling, former president of the House of Representatives, was rescinded tonight when a group of Congressmen intervened on his behalf.

One of Nicholas Kozma's last official acts as Minister of the Interior before resigning today was to cancel the ban on the American film, "Born to Dance." The ban imposed by the Budapest censor was based on the allegation that the film was contrary to military discipline, therefore damaging to the prestige of the United States Navy.

William E. Coyle and Conway Hoffman of the Montclair A. C., favored entrants, reached the quarter-final round in the sixth annual doubles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Heights Casino last night. They defeated Sam Cochran and W. J. McQueeny of the Squash Club, 15-12, 15-12, 3-15, 15-11.

After decreasing decidedly for three consecutive weeks, business in the Pittsburgh district recovered sharply in the week ended Jan. 30, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Donald Budge, ranking national amateur, teamed with John Harris of Miami today to defeat J. Huntington Hartford of Palm Beach, Fla., and Cedric Major of New York, 6-3, 6-1, in the doubles quarter-finals of the Surf Club's tennis tournament.

Overruling a demurrer filed by Henry A. Jennings of Bridgeport, individually and as administrator, Judge Arthur F. Ells of the Superior Court has upheld the right of Ervin J. Friede of Minneapolis, receiver for the Southern Minnesota Joint Stock Land Bank of Minneapolis, to sue stockholders of the corporation in this State for unpaid stock assessments levied under an order of the United States District Court of Minnesota.

The difficulty with Dr. Stanley High's forecast of the leadership and direction of the Democratic party with which he has so recently affiliated is not that he was all wrong about everything he wrote. Most of the material in the article which provoked the President today to disavow the author as a "close adviser" has been so repeatedly published in Washington dispatches that no rewrite job could be all wrong.
His own Second Suite spoke most eloquently for Georges Enesco at Carnegie Hall last night when he began the second half of his fortnight as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.
The Toronto Globe and Mail reported today that "the largest producing oil well in the British Empire was brought in yesterday morning" at the Turner Valley field in Alberta.

Municipalities throughout New Jersey tonight were in open revolt against the Legislature's failure to defer operation of the new Budget Act and to re-enact a law making permissive suspension of mandatory salary schedules.

Net profit of the Connecticut Power Company and affiliated companies for 1936 was $1,741,418 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, interest and other charges, Compared with $1,539,998 in 1935. V. E. Bird, president, told stockholders the improvement in 1936 was not confined to any one division of the business.

Bank clearings of twenty-one Principal cities of the country for the week ended on Feb. 3 rose 14.5 per cent to $6,850,935,000, the highest total in six weeks. According to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., the figure also showed a gain of 16.3 per cent over the $5,888,448,000, reported for the corresponding week in 1936.

Klare F. Covert, secretary to Frank M. Hardiman, general manager of the Harrison radiator division of General Motors, announced this afternoon that as a result of layoffs last night and today the plant was "virtually shut down."

The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today by the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad Company for permission to exercise an option to acquire control of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company and the Erie Railroad Company.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today gave William Randolph Hearst and five of his subsidiary companies permission to appeal from an order of the National Labor Relations Board involving the reinstatement of two discharged Seattle Post-Intelligencer employes.

A special meeting of the stockholders of Carib Syndicate, Ltd., has been called for Feb. 16 to act on a proposal to sell all or any part of the company's holdings of 20,868 shares of the capital stock of the Colombian Petroleum Company at not less than $2,050,000.

Sponsors of the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra were indignant yesterday in contradicting a statement attributed to Jose Iturbi, Spanish pianist and conductor, that women can never into achieve greatness in music or sports.

A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $112,000, unchanged from the last previous transaction on Jan. 29. The Exchange.posted two proposed transfers of membership, representing the last two deals.

Stockholders subscribed for 28,446 shares of the 38,280 offered of the new $100-par 5 per cent cumulative convertible issue of the Bangor Aroostook Railroad Company, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Hugh Alessandroni of the Fencers Club, holder of the national foils title, early this morning added the metropolitan foils championship to his impressive list of conquests. He emerged victorious in the annual tournament held under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America at the Salle d'Armes Vince.

Mrs. Bessie Amelia Lawrence Gilman, member of an old Long Island family and mother of Lawrence Gilman, music critic of The New York Herald Tribune, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital of pneumonia. She was ill only a short time and was taken to the hospital from her home at 65 West Forty-fifth Street a few days ago.

Cotton prices were somewhat higher at the opening of'the Cotton Exchange yesterday but the market felt the first hedging pressure from releases of government cotton and a setback left the list unchanged to 5 points lower on the day.

The necessity for social security and economic justice so that political liberty may continue in this country was stressed last night by speakers at a testimonial dinner to United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, given by the American Jewish Congress in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

City officials began yesterday to work out. plans to restore pre. depression pay to 110,000 city employes on July 1, as the Board of Estimate voted to do on Wednesday at the pointed suggestion of Governor Lehman.

" The Bulgaro-Yugoslav pact is the greatest success of the present generation of Yugoslavs, who after three terrible wars have achieved sincere friendship between the two nations," said Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch today in a statement on foreign policy before Parliament.

Mr. and Mrs. Lester C. Haworth of Wallingford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Peyton Haworth, to Allen Thomas Bonnell of Erie, Pa. Miss Haworth, who passed last year studying in Europe, is a graduate of the John Burroughs School at St. Louis and attended Washington University and Oberlin College.

The Rev. Giles Buckner Cooke, last surviving officer of the immediate staff of General Robert E. Lee at the time of the Appomattox surrender, died at his home here today. He would have been 99 years years old on May 13.

" The old idea of science based on "belief in the supremacy of the intel"lect is finished," was one of the gems that sparkled in the address delivered by Herr BERNHARD RUST, HITLER'S Minister for Education, at the recent celebration of Heidelberg's 550th anniversary.

Niagara University's basketball team defeated State Teachers of Albany for the second time this season, 44 to 24, tonight. Four of the Albany players-Captain Jack Ryan, Tom Ryan, Tommy Harrington and George Bancroft-were shaken and slightly bruised when their automobile collided with a truck between Syracuse and Rochester on the way to the game.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler's failure to include Switzerland in his offer Saturday to respect the neutrality of Belgium and the Netherlands is causing some concern in League of Nations and Swiss circles.

The Italian liner Rex docked at the foot of West Eighteenth Street last night, delayed by storm for the first time in fifty-five voyages. Captain Francesco Tarabotto said it was one of the worst storms in his experience and that it lasted five days.

The New York Americans missed a good chance to make up valuable ground in the National Hockey League race when they lost to the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. Facing the team they hope to eliminate in their fight for a play-off berth in the International Group of the league,

A. B. Fletcher, vice president of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company, is with Hallgarten Co. in charge of the foreign department. H. H. Sharp, formerly assistant general manager of El Potosi Mining Company, has been appointed a vice president of the Howe Sound Company.

Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Sterling gave a dinner last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mr. and Mrs. S. Oakley Vander Poel, Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot, Miss Mary vail Andress and Bertram Lord.
Five thousand famished victims of the drought invaded the suburbs of Fortaleza, the capital of the State of Ceara, today and demanded shelter, food, clothing and medicines.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the Davega Stores Corporation's 5 per cent $25-par cumulative preferred stock will be admitted to its list today.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts will consider bids on Monday for a new issue of $3,000,000 of short-term notes. The notes will be dated Feb. 15, 1937, and will become payable on Feb. 8, 1938.

As a result of the Governor's letter, the prompt response in the City Controller's report and the action of the Board of Estimate, it seems practically assured that a full restoration of the salaries of city employes cut in 1932 will becomn effective on July 1 next. Governor LEHMAN points out that the city pay cuts have been in effect five years.

Robert J. McManamy of 275 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, a real estate operator, died on Wednesday in St. Peter's Hospital at the age of 78. He was a native of Canada and came to Brooklyn in his youth. He was at one time associated with the old firm of H. B. Claflin Co., before he opened a drygoods store of his own.

The constantly increasing pressure of the Nazis and so-called Pronounced Nationalists on the Schuschnigg government has resulted in the intensification of monarchist propaganda during the last two weeks not only in the press of the monarchist groups but also in the Weltblatt, which Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg now uses regularly to propagate his political aims.
A literary critic, of supposed authority, was testifying the other day in the case of a publisher charged

EvidentlyGubby Allen, captain of England's cricket team, has been delving into old test records. Hoping history might ret peat itself, he told Don Bradman, Aussie skipper, today not to be too optimistic about the result of the fifth and deciding match of the test series opening at Melbourne Feb. 26.

It is now evident that Mr. JOHN LEWIS from the first aimed to make, or force, a bargain with General Motors. By ordering a strike which would hit it at strategic points and at a critical time, he planned to exact from the company a promise to recognize his union as the only one entitled to speak for the whole body of automobile workers.
The most costly maritime strike in American history ended at 2:45 P. M. today on a call expected to send 40,000 men and 239 ships into a scramble for long-lost jobs and trade beginning tomorrow.

Willie Hoppe of New York yesterday established a new high-run mark for 28.2 balkline billiards when he clustered 154 shots in sensational fashion during the sixth block of his 2,500-point match against Jake Schaefer of Chicago at the Strand Academy.

John L. Baird, inventor and founder of Baird Television, had the greatest disappointment of his life tonight when the Postmaster General announced that the British Broadcasting Corporation would henceforth use solely the Marconi-Emi system when transmitting television programs.

Representative W. G. Andrews of Buffalo made public today a letter from President Roosevelt in which the President said he hoped the United States would soon be able to reach an understanding with Canada on the preservation of Niagara Falls.

A flying instructor and his novice pupil stared death in the face 3,000 feet above the earth and lived to congratulate each other today. George De Vorss, 27, the student, essayed a barrel roll during a flight yesterday with Louis Dale, 25, instructor.

With six inches of ice available, officials of the Middle Atlantic Speed Skating Association are confident that it will be possible to hold their championship meet tomorrow on Orange Lake, near Newburgh, N. Y.

After a hearing yesterday in proceedings for the reorganization of the Standard Textile Products Company of 320 Broadway under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act Judge Julian W. Mack adjourned the .case until April 12. In the meantime, he must serve a bench assignment in Florida.

Matching par on twelve of the fifteen holes played, Tommy Goodwin, New York State amateur champion, scored an easy victory in the semifinals of the annual South Florida golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

Government troops captured another trench today in Moncloa Park, on the northwestern border of Madrid, bringing them right up to the large building known as the Del Amo Foundation and further endangering the Rebel communications into the Clinical Hospital in University City.

Miss Virginia Frances Colwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lawrence Colwell of this city, was married to Eliot Winslow Todd, son of Mrs. Eleanor Todd of this city and James Todd of New York City, this afternoon at the home of her parents. The Rev. George L. Fitzgerald, rector of the Church of St. James. performed the ceremony.
International racing for Star lams sloops in the Spring championship in Bermuda will start on April 2? and run through May 3, it was announced yesterday.

A Supreme Court jury returned a verdict yesterday in favor of the brokerage concern of Eastman, Dillon Co. in a suit for $244,271 brought by William H. McGowan, receiver of the Penn National Bank and Trust Company of Reading, Pa.
A lawsuit in which the history of Greater New York's water supply is traced back for two and three-quarter centries was fought in the Supreme Court today.

General Oreste Mariotti, who commanded the Italian column which crossed the Danakil Desert in the advance on Makale in the Ethiopian campaign, died today at the age of 64. He led his troops in a pitched battle at Azbi in that advance.

Great Britain's task of maintaining her own neutrality in Spain is made considerably easier by the relatively small amount of British capital invested there and by its equal distribution between Rebel and government-controlled territories.

Miss Alice Anna Sunderland, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Leslie Ernest Sunderland of 265 Riverside Drive, was married yesterday afternoon in All Angels' Church to the Rev. Thomas Porter Simpson, son of Mrs. Wade H. Simpson of Knoxville, Tenn., and the late Mr. Simpson.

A crowd estimated at 125,000 men representing fifty-four nations gathered before the tall Eucharistic altar in Luneta Park last midnight to receive communion and acclaim the prophecy of Isaiah that all nations shall gather together to witness the glory of God.

The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 3, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,483,000,000, a decrease of $2,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $9,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1936.

A banking group headed by Edward B. Smith Co. will offer today a new issue of $18,000,000 of Atlantic City Electric Company general mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due in 1964, at 101 and accrued interest.
James J. Braddock, world heavyweight titleholder, and his Negro challenger, Bomber Joe Louis, will sign articles Monday for their fifteen-round championship battle to be fought here June 15.

THE first vigorous counter-attack on the strikers of the Yankee labor battalion in the diamond industry was Capitalist Ruppert's "Bawl Two" speech, aimed directly at Larruping Lou Gehrig and Don Vernon Gomez. It is reported that, in his righteous wrath, Capitalist Ruppert spoke loud enough for all to hear him, including Lou Gehrig, who was in a distant part of the city, and Don Vernon Gomez, who was in Bermuda.

Not since the time of De Witt Clinton has any man done for the public schools of New York State anything comparable to the service rendered by Alfred E. Smith when he was Governor, in the opinion of Guy W. Cheney, Assemblyman from Corning, who addressed the mid-year meeting of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

High-grade bonds resumed an upward course yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange under the leadership of United States Government issues. Day-to-day reversals in the trend of the better-grade investments are becoming a matter of some discussion in bond trading circles,
The Boston Bruins kept hot after second place in the American Division of the National Hockey League tonight by trampling the highly regarded Montreal Canadiens, 6 to 2, before 5,000 fans.
Edward H. B. Allen, 30, former gentleman jockey of Philadelphia, died in a hospital here today. a Injured when thrown from a horse five years ago, Allen had since been a semi-invalid.
Mrs.Joseph T. Ryerson, wife of the retired steel man, was robbed of jewelry valued at $7,000 last night by two gunmen who entered their automobile on the Near North Side.

Experiments leading to the establishing of an Italian airline between Rome and South America will be begun in a few weeks following negotiations just concluded by General Aldo Pellegrini, Director General of Italian Civil Aviation, in Argentina, Uruguay and Brazil.

Relic of a great air story that held the world's interest more than sixteen years ago, a weather-beaten old balloon was reported found today twenty miles north of Moosonee. It lay hidden a few yards from an Indian trail, not far from James Bay.

The estate of Prince Serge Mdivani has dwindled to $67,590, according to a petition filed in Probate Court today asking that the $1,500 a month allowance paid his widow, the former Louise Astor Van Alen of New York, be reduced or terminated.

The contract held by Madison Square Garden for James J. Braddock to meet Max Schmeling is causing the 'champion some concern as regards his exhibition appearances. Braddock is listed to appear in two short bouts that head a charity card at the New York Hippodrome on Feb. 15 and the Garden is seeking ways to prevent his so doing.

Mrs. Dorothy Lindner Kalman of 23 West Seventy-third Street, daughter of Mrs. Walter Lindner of this city and the late Mr. Lindner, was married to Jacob Omansky, also of New York, son of Mrs. Louis Omansky of Akron, Ohio, and the late Mr. Omansky, yesterday in the Marriage Chapel of the Municipal Building by Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines in the presence of the bride's mother and sister, Miss Marion Lindner.

Charles Francis Coe, New York writer who won the qualifying medal, defaulted his semi- final match in the tenth annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Country Club today and made possible an all-artist final for the first time in the history of the tournament. The title contenders tomorrow will be William DeBeck of New York and Frank Willard of Chicago.

Miss Mary Ellen Duggan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William George Duggan of this city, was married to Arthur W. Murphy, son of Mrs. Joseph Murphy, also of New York, and the late Mr. Murphy, yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Henry Hammer.

W. C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, received $125,000 as compensation from the company in its last fiscal year, the annual report filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed. W. S.

EIighteen-year-old Miss Patty Berg, Minneapolis sensation, and 17-yearold Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, Ga., met today in one of the feature matches in the second round of the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf championship and the Minnesota star emerged triumphant by 3 -and 2.

Police Chief Russell Hilbert, who recently received publicity far exceeding his position as the one-man force of Montville Township by his refusal to take a literacy test, was suspended from duty tonight pending a public hearing on Feb. 17.

A Townsend test "pension" cost Mrs. Retta Freeman her State old-age benefits today. Mrs. Freeman, an indigent former storekeeper and orchard owner, received $200 to spend in a test of the old-age pension plan.

More than 1,000 persons, including many firemen, attended a requiem mass in St. Gregory's Catholic Church, Brooklyn Avenue and St. John's Place, Brooklyn, yesterday for James C. Brogan of 685 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, formerly a battalion chief in the Fire Department. He was in the Fire Department forty-nine years.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."
Indignation again flared up in the House of Commons today over the intrusion of newspaper reporters into private griefs in search of interviews.

All four seeded players in the ninth annual Ardsley Country Club women's invitation squash racquets tournament followed form today and advanced to the quarter-final round as the competition got under way.

Although the total loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City continued to decline in the week ended on Wednesday, the drop in business loans was halted, the weekly statement of condition of the banks, published yesterday showed.

The M. I. T. hockey team won its first game -of the season tonight when it defeated Hamilton College, 2-0. Scoring early in the second period and late in the third, the Bostonians displayed superior skating and passing ability, coupled with an aggressive style of play.
Gregor Piatigorsky, Russian 'cellist, arrived here yesterday with his bride, the former Baroness Jacqueline de Rothschild of Paris. They were married on Jan. 26 in Ann Arbor. Mich.

In his annual report, made public today, Dr. James Rowland Angell, who will retire as president of Yale University in June, declared that the depression had taught that education, instead of belonging to the young or a privileged few, is at the heart of the sound social order.
time big league baseball player and manager of the New York Yankees, was found dead on a downtown street tonight, his head crushed. Police said that he apparently was the victim of a hit-run driver.

The United States liner Washing ton arrives today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. Hei passengers include Rear Admiral Walter S. Anderson. former naval attache at the United States Embassy in London; William Griffin, publisher of The New York Enquirer, and Kingsley Martin, London editor.

At the opening yesterday the stock market gave promise of extending the Wednesday advance. On initial transactions, United States Steel changed hands at par for the first time since 1931, General Motors showed an overnight gain of 3/8 point, and the market generally had a firm appearance.

Dr. George W. Russell died tonight at St. Mary's Hospital after a short illness of pneumonia. He was 64 years old. Born in this city, Dr. Russell was the son of the late James and Bridget Fahy Russell. He had his early schooling here and was graduated from Columbia University.

President Roosevelt repudiated alleged "close advisers," requested Senator Copeland to defer special flood legislation until his special committee completed its inspection trip and announced that he would withhold transmission to Congress of the report of the Great Plains Drought Committee until he could confer with Western Senators.

By an order issued yesterday General Francisco Franco, Insurgent chief, permits members of the Fascist militia not incorporated in the army to use the party salute of outstretched hand, like the Hitlerite greeting.

Nazism, which has elbowed monarchy into the background in Germany, brought itself prominently to the attention of British royalty in Buckingham Palace today to the consternation of assembled diplomacy, which was having a field day there.

On the opening day Mainbocher's showing was stampeded by buyers. He is solving every woman's dress problems in a tremendously varied collection consisting of 300 models. With twenty silhouettes he aims to correct all figure complaints.

But at the back of my head there was an uneasiness, based on things that men were telling me about affairs outside England. (The inhabitants of that country never looked further than their annual seaside resorts.)
The Spanish Government established the civic status of women on a basis of absolute equality with men by decree today, abolishing "the archaic privileges" of the husband.

Two famous transatlantic fliers, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and General Italo Balbo, Governor of Libya, exchanged tales of their experiences today in Rome-marking the American aviator's thirty-fifth birthday.
A. A. Baroni's Ann O'Ruley crashed into the winners' circle today, capturing the $1,500 added San Raphael Handicap for fillies and mares 4-yearolds and upward at Santa Anita Park.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight held the State reception for officials of departments not previously honored, including the Treasury, Postoffice, -Interior, Agriculture, Commerce and Labor, and other Federal agencies.

Trading in the Bronx yesterday in real estate was confined principally to deals involving apartment houses. Two were old-type, multifamily dwellings, which were taken over for alteration into small-unit modern apartments. The transactions reported follow:

That wondrous boy RUSH DEW HOLT has recovered from an unexpected attack of silence. Burlesquing Senator GUFFEY'S burlesque proposal to investigate anecdotes about the Supreme Court emitted by a pair of wellknown entertainers, Mr. HOLT offered a resolution to investigate statements made in a magazine about Mr. GUFFEY.

An intensive liquor price war, reminiscent of that of last May and continued spasmodically for several weeks, broke out here yesterday afternoon when retail quotations were cut sharply on outstanding brands of rye, Bourbon and Scotch whiskies, gin and vermouth.

A man believed by the police to be J. Raymond Riker, 60 years old, of 14 West Ninetieth Street, New York City, collapsed as he stepped off a train from Boston in the Union station this morning and died a short time later from a heart attack. Papers in his pocket led the police to notify New York authorities.
A huge replacement market for various types of consumers' merchandise, particularly home furnishings, as a result of the destructive effects of the flood, was forecast yesterday in the local market.
Joseph A. Broderick, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said tonight that monetary controls alone could not bring "a full utilization of our national resources" without "violent fluctuations."

George Kronengold of the home club recorded an upset when he conquered Jack Bieber, rated third, in the quarter-finals of the first invitation two-wall singles handball tournament at the City Athletic Club last night. Kronengold, who is unseeded, triumphed, 21-3, 19-21, 21-13.
The northerly winds which have chilled New Yorkers with subfreezing temperatures for the last three days shifted to milder southerly winds late yesterday afternoon.

Carnegie Metals Company common, $1 par value, has been listed on the Curb Exchange. Rights to subscribe to one share for each five shares held, expire on Feb. 23 and have been admitted to when issued dealings. The final date for trading in rights is Feb. 18.

The: thirty. persons in high places who in the opinion of David Lloyd George, deserve laudation for their part in the World War on the side of the Allies, are listed in the preface to the sixth and final volume of "war Memoirs of Lloyd George," published today by Little, Brown.

Hog prices declined 10 to 25 cents today as the result of larger receipts than expected, but the movement was regarded as due to some extent to the release of storm-bound stock. Other Western markets reported a reduced run.

Financing for the Iowa Public Service Company will be undertaken soon with the public offering, probably next week, of issues of $14,200,000 of first mortgage 3 3/4 per, cent bonds, due in 1967, and $2,200,000 of serial debentures maturing from 1938 to 1947. A. C. Allyn Co., Inc., and Bonbright Co., Inc., will be the principal underwriters.

Better airways aids and more spending by the government alone will not provide air line safety in this country, declared Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, this morning in opening the three-day safety conference of government officials, technicians and air-line operators, called as the result of recent fatal crashes on the nation's airways.

District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn will present to the Kings County grand jury today evidence purporting to link one of the three kidnappers of John J. O'Connell of Albany to the $427,000 armored truck robbery in Brooklyn in 1934.

Buildings in the area on Central Park West between Eighty-eighth and Ninety-first Streets, where waters from a main that burst Wednesday night, filling cellars and crippling elevator service, heating facilities and water supplies for a time, were going through the drying-out process yesterday.
The seven five-story tenement houses at 322-334 East Sixty-third Street have been sold by Private Garage, Inc., to a client of A. J. Bernstein, it was announced yesterday.

Irl Tubbs, genial little Miami (Fla.) University coach, tonight was named head football coach at the University of Iowa. The board in control of athletics announced its selection of the 49year-old Floridan after a long session following Personal

A moderate advance in wholesale prices occurred in the week ended on Jan. 30, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics in a report today. The index rose to 85.4 (based on the 1926 weekly average as 100) from 85.3 the preceding week. A year ago the level was 80.5.
Leases of commercial space reported yesterday by brokers included many lofts, floors and stores over a wide area of the city. The list follows:

Two seeded players met their masters and another came close to experiencing the sting of defeat as the Monte Sterling Trophy squash tennis tourney continued yesterday at the New York A. C. with seven men winning their way into the quarter-finals.

The projected official journey to Moscow of the Finnish Foreign Minister, Dr. Rudolf Holsti, is expected to materialize during this week-end because Maxim Litvinoff, the Soviet Foreign Commissar, has invited Dr. Holsti to visit him Monday.

Two measures designed to insure prevention of child marriages in New. York were offered in the Legislature today. They were inspired by the Johns case in Tennessee and by the disclosure that Leona Roshia Backus of Watertown was a 12-year-old bride.
WAR MEMOIRS OF DAVID LLOYD GEORGE, 1918. (Little, Brown, $3.) The sixth and final volume of the memoirs deals with the last year of the war and discusses the lessons taught by the four years.

Captain Thor Eckert, vice president and general manager of the Red Star-Arnold Bernstein Steamship Line, announced yesterday that he had been authorized by the line's American financial interests to state that its services would continue without interruption by reason of the seizure of several of the lines officials in Germany. He said there had been no intention of seizing the ships.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago filed today an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission, asking approval of acquisition of outstanding securities of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois as a part of a plan contemplating the simplification of the financial structure of the applicant's interests in the Chicago area.
Continuation of the cheerful atmosphere in the stock markets was reflected today in the large volume of business and fresh increases among the giltedged issues.

Miklas Szabo, Hungarian middledistant runner, yesterday withdrew his entry from the Wanamaker Mile, feature race of the thirtieth annual Millrose games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. A cold, which though not serious, would prevent him from doing his best against stiff opposition, caused the European star to cancel his first scheduled American appearance.

At the close of a conference with President Roosevelt today on flood-control measures, Senator Copeland of New York, chairman of the Commerce Committee, indicated that the President would submit a control program to Congress after the special committee, now in the Mississippi Valley, had made a report on conditions there and in the Ohio Valley.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York resolved yesterday without dissent to urge Federal and State legislation requiring unions to incorporate and submit to regulation, in return for the statutory privileges they already enjoy.

Commodity futures showed a mixed movement in trading on local commodity markets yesterday. Cocoa futures encountered more liquidation, while silk, hides and sugar also were lower. Coffee futures, after touching new high levels in active early trading, lost some ground.

The Soviet press today presents a most different picture from yesterday. The government organ, Izvestia, for instance, looks today like a newspaper, whereas yesterday the first three of its four pages were devoted wholly to the Soviet program for Spring planting-doubtless valuable but dull reading.

Having explored virtually all of the two-dimensional surface of the earth, and nearing the limit of our three-dimensional explorations beneath its surface, civilization's future hope rests on the "fourth dimension," a distinguished gathering of scientists at the Hotel St. Regis was told last night by Dr. Frank B. Jewett, president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

The Appeal Court today quashed the conviction of the managing editor of the Laborite paper, Het Volk, who was fined 150 guilders by a lower court because of an alleged insult to Chancellor Hitler, the "head of a friendly State."
Beating the New York A. C., 4-1, the City A. C. went into a tie for first place with the Jackson Heights Club yesterday in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group 1 competition.

The Mississippi River, absorbing devastating flood waters of the Ohio, carried its record load through the delta country tonight under the vigilance of river men who predicted a safe passage to the Gulf of Mexico.

Early approval of the city's application to the PWA for a loan and grant of $26,785,000 for construction of a mid-Manhattan underpass was new asked by the Fifth Avenue Association yesterday in letters sent to President Roosevelt and other government officials.

Henry F. Botts, 66 years old, was killed last night when he jumped from the westbound platform of the Jamaica elevated line at 139th Street and Jamaica Avenue, Queens, to the sidewalk fifty feet below.

The recent reversal by the Supreme Court of New York of a decision in the case of Walter P. Fickett against the HigginbothamBailey-Logan Company of Dallas, Texas, for charges in connection with sample cards supplied by converters to the company, was applauded here yesterday by Flint Garrison,

The rise of $1,000,000 in "other loans" reported this week by member banks of the Federal Reserve in this city is of negligible size, but it does seem to indicate that the seasonal drop in business loans is likely to end somewhat earlier than usual.

Stephen Morehouse Avery has sold "The Sound of Your Voice" to Columbia for Grace Moore. The story, which concerns an opera singer who is the object of a romantic kidnapping, will be prepared for the screen by its author. Production is scheduled for early April.

The really immoral feature of the motion picture, and one to which the official censors never object, is the completely false view of life it occasionally presents to the young, Pearl Buck, author, said yesterday at the opening luncheon of the thirteenth annual conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

An international advertising code, aimed to eliminate disputes and to standardize world practices, will be presented for adoption at the International Advertising Congress, July 5 to 10, in Paris, Andre Kaminker, member of the French delegation which has just completed a tour of the United States, revealed here yesterday.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley, who will retire from the Mount Holyoke College presidency in June, came out publicly here today in opposition to Dr. Roswell G. Ham of Yale, who has been chosen as the first male president of the college, in succession to herself.

Beans and not more fighting planes are apparently the war materials of which the Spanish Leftists are in the greatest need. The Spanish Ambassador, Gordon Ordas, was queried today in writing as to why the ship Mar Cantabrico, which has been in Vera Cruz Harbor for weeks, has not sailed for Spain.

Many persons, reading reports of the flood disaster, undoubtedly have speculated as to the effect on wildlife. The question is answered by Howard Zahniser of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, and it is a disconcerting picture he. paints.
Four million gas masks are to be stored in two regional warehouses in Manchester and London districts, and eleven more warehouses are soon to be built, it was revealed in the House of Commons today.
Mrs. Effie Zabriskie Corbin, wife of Philip Corbin of 122 East Seventy-sixth Street, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness.

A 19-year-old University of Alabama law student was charged today with attempting to extort $7,000 from a Tuscaloosa woman twelve hours after Federal and county officers frustrated an effort to collect the money.

The Port of New York Authority purchased from the William Pe?? Brewing Company for $195,000 the eight two-story brick dwellings as 625-639 Pleasant Avenue, southwest corner of Cantelo Street, and the two three-story brick flats, 109-11?? Cantelo Street, Union City.

The International Match Realization Company, Ltd., has been organized in Bermuda by the protective committees for International Match Corporation debentures to effect an orderly and gradual liquidation of the remaining assets recovered on behalf of the debenture holders and now held by the Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy.

Cathedral College downed the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy five last night at the latter's gym, 38-20. Jerry Nolan, diminutive Cathedral forward, ran rings around the Pharmacists to score nine field goals.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to dispense with the services of Willis J. Ballinger, chief of special studies, it was stated tonight by a spokesman for the commission.
For the second time in three nights the Detroit Red Wings and New York Rangers battled to an overtime tie tonight. The score was 2 to 2, with the game attracting a paid attendance of 13,140 fans.

Impeachment proceedings against a Sheriff and a special grand jury investigation were ordered today as Alabama moved to bring to justice members of a mob which Monday night lynched a 19-year-old Negro accused of attacking a white woman.

While trading in the wool goods markets was only moderately active this week, prices continued strong in all divisions, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service, Inc.

Purchases by investing groups and quick resales were among deals reported in Queens yesterday. David S. Meister sold the threestory apartment house at 58-16 Forty-third Avenue, Woodside, to an investor after an ownership of one day.

The United States is trying to travel in two opposite directions by enacting rigid wartime export restrictions and at the same time trying to develop foreign commerce through the Roosevelt-Hull reciprocal trade agreements, Bernard M. Baruch warned the House Military Affairs Committee today.

The two-and-a-half story bricK and timber residence on a plot 100 by 140 feet at 66 Greenhaven Road, Rye, was purchased by Mrs. Florence K. Tanzer from the New York State Teachers' Retirement System. Pease Elliman, Inc., and James J. McCann, Inc., were the brokers.
Now there is nothing to be seen from here But the unbroken sweep from barn to hill Of snow, unprinted, shadow-blue and clear, Where nothing moves, where everything wis still.

The New York Junior League Glee Club will hold its annual concert tonight in the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Members of the unit will be assisted by the Yale Semi-Chorus and by several husbands, brothers or fiances of the glee club members.
The United States men's table tennis team tied for the world's championship today and earned the right to a play-off with Hungary for the crown in the international competition.

The Mississippi River rushed toward the sea today at the fastest flow in history. The stage was 47.59 feet, 4.5 feet above flood level, but the water was moving even faster than it did in the 1927 flood year when the stage was ten feet higher.

Porter Elliott went back home for his dog today and returned to Tiptonville with six huddled in his skiff. "I looked for that dog of mine when we left last week," he said, "but he was not to be seen, and I figured he'd be able to take care of himself, as there was a plenty of dry land when I left.
At a conference held here today the Right Rev. Dr. Frank Whittington Creighton, now Suffragan Bishop of Long Island, N. Y., accepted the post of Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Michigan.
A 14-year-old girl was wounded last night by a shot fired by hold-up men as they were leaving a liquor store at 750 Columbus Avenue after taking $350, the day's receipts, from the cash drawer.

Under a blue sky, this New Hampshire village made its final preparations today for the twenty-seventh annual Winter carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club, which starts tomorrow with fifty-eight of the best college skiers of this continent and Europe, representing a total of ten colleges, entered.
