Notice A complaint has been received at these headquarters that salesmen are soliciting orders for uniforms for newly appointed firemen by visiting their respective company quarters. Attention is called Paragraph I, Special Order 182, Oct. 16, 1936.

The Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority awarded the contract yesterday for the construction of a second tube of the Hudson Midtown Tunnel to the Mason Hangar Company, Inc., for $8,764,003. Actual work probably will be started on the project within a month. it was said.

The Rev. Dr. Oliver Sherman Bake tel, believed here to be the oldest Methodist Episcopal Church clergy man in active service, died today in his Maplewood home at 3 Win throp Place after a short illness Ten days ago he suffered a stroke He was 88 years old.
A tense situation existed here tonight between the local police and the union forces, as Chief of Police James V. Wills continued to swear in special policemen.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Mellon will give a dinner tomorrow night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for their daughter, Miss Mary C. Mellon, before the second Knickerbocker Assembly at the Ritz-Carlton.

Mrs. Emma Lydia Benedict Transeau, recording and research secretary of the Scientific Temperance Federation of Boston for more than thirty years, died yesterday at the Pioneer Club of Boston. She was born in Clifton Park, N. Y., on Nov. 16, 1857.

President Frederick B. Robinson of City College welcomed yesterday the entering class of about 800 students in the first chapel meeting of the new semester held in the Great Hall during the noon hour. Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men, presided.
With three Minimum Wage Bills pending, of which only one can become law, conflict developed at a joint hearing on the measures before the Senate and Assembly Committees on Labor and Industry today.

Operations of the American Chicle Company in 1936 resulted in a profit of $3,681,271 after all expenses and charges, but before deductions for income taxes, it was announced yesterday. The profit in 1935 was $3,063,766.
Governor Charles F. Hurley, in an open letter to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, today opposed ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment as giving to Congress "a staggering grant of power."

Everything has been properly attended to in "Frederika," which was staged at the Imperial last evening. It is an operetta by Franz Lehar, who wrote "The Merry Widow" many years ago, and it is produced by the Messrs. Shubert, who are old hands at this sort of thing.
President Roosevelt expressed his appreciation to King George of Great Britain for the latter's message of sympathy over the Midwest floods in this telegram sent last night and made public today:

The Regional Labor Board ended yesterday a three-day hearing of charges of former employes of the United Fruit Company that the Cargo Handlers Association was a company-controlled union and discriminatory to the interests of the general employes.

Three important former Manchurian commanders besides General Wang I-cheh were slain during Tuesday's new revolt in Sian, according to reports received here. These were Colonels Chiang Pin, Hsu Fang and Sung Hsueh-li.

Returning to the ring after an absence of three months, Pedro Montanez, 140, Puerto Rico, knocked out Joe La Fauci, 1381/2, Astoria, L. I., in 2.34 of the second session at the Star Casino last night before 4,000 fans. The contest was scheduled for ten rounds.

Sixteen men were hurt, three severely enough to require hospital treatment, when pickets patrolling the Caloric Gas Stove Company's branch factory in Topton, twenty miles northeast of Reading, clashed with workers this morning.

Members of the Boy Scout Leaders Wild Life Conservation Patrol spent 6,126 hours on volunteer duty in the Palisades Interstate Park in 1936, Harold K. Whitford, director of the patrol, announced yesterday in its annual report.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a story dealing with the Moscow trials, published in THE TIMES of Feb. 1, it is stated that I am a member of the American Committee for the Defense of Leon Trotsky. I did join the committee when it was formed and it may be said, technically speaking at any rate, that I was still a member at the time your story was written.

Dissolution of the firm of Herrick, Berg Co. on Jan. 31 was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. A new concern of the same name has been formed with Charles F. Guild, Royal Little, Alden S. Blodget, Rensselaer W. Bartram Jr. and Archie B. Gwathmey 2d as partners and Walter R. Herrick as special partner.
Barring some unforeseen developments, The Pictorial Review magazine will acquire The Delineator in time for a combined May issue with a circulation of 3,000,000, it was learned yesterday.
" Attacks" against this fortress in Great Britain's Far Eastern manoeuvres are considered to have failed, and the attacking "Blue" fleet has withdrawn.

Almost 18,000,000 wage earners, or 80 per cent of the total of industrial and commercial employes expected to be covered by unemployment compensation laws, are now protected by such legislation in thirty-five States and the District of Columbia, the Social Security Board announced today.

Mgr. Michael J. Whalen, spiritual director of the Roman Catholic Immaculate Conception Seminary at Darlington, N. J., died Wednesday night at Good Samaritan Hospital at Suffern, N. Y. He was stricken with pneumonia ten days ago.

Banking in this city which on Jan. 6 offered $11,000,000 city of Chicago 3 per cent judgment bonds at 104 1/4 have been able to sell only $3,000,000 of them. Rather than cut the price 3 points, a reduction believed necessary to move the bonds,

Announcement yesterday by Eugene Garey, counsel for C. C. Wright in the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation of alleged manipulation of Kinner Airplane and Motor stock, that he would call three more witnesses, two from Stock Exchanges here and one from Los Angeles, forced extension of the hearings, which were expected to end this week. They will be resumed this morning.
The navy announced tonight that two new battleships to be built this year would be powered by steam turbines with mechanical reduction gears rather than by electric drive.

The marriage of Mrs. Trevania Dallas Blair-Smith, widow of Hugh Blair-Smith, former treasurer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, to Daniel E. Pomeroy of Englewood, N.J., leader in Republican politics and retired banker, took place yesterday afternoon in the bride's home at 25 Fifth Avenue. The Rev. Carl Hopkins Elmore, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood, performed the ceremony.

John Mecray Sr., president of the Merchants National Bank of Cape May, died here last night at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Frank B. Williams Jr. His age was seventy. He suffered a heart attack last week following a month's illness.

Stock-holders in the Riverside and Dan River cotton mills were notified today that on Feb. 18 at their annual meeting they will be asked to authorize the issuance of 300,000 shares of additional common stock of $25 par value to be offered first to holders of preferred stock after deferred dividends of $6 a share on the referred stock have been paid.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Nicholas Shriver of Baltimore have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Owings Shriver, to Rutherfurd Stuyvesant Pierrepont Jr. of Far Hills, N. J.

Baseball men converged on New York from all points yesterday for the Spring schedule meeting of the National League today and the fourteenth annual dinner and frolic of the baseball writers Sunday night.

Brown's hockey team had an easy time defeating Springfield, 12 to 2, tonight. Captain Jackson Skillings of Brown gave way to Herman Toof as goal-tender through half the game. Foster Davis scored three goals. Dye, Darling and Walsh registered two each.

Joseph Fishbach of De Witt Clinton High School turned back Bill Gillespie of Scarborough School yesterday to retain his singles championship in the eleventh annual De Witt Clinton interscholastic indoor tennis tournament at the 369th-Regiment Armory. The score was 4-6. 6-2. 6-1 7-5.

The Winter exodus of New Yorkers to their favorite "ski spots" in the North country will begin in earnest tonight. Some 600 passengers are expected to occupy the eighteen cars of the New Haven's Ski Meister which will take them to Jackson, Franconia and Plymouth, N. H., and Stowe and Woodstock, Vt.

Mrs. Abbie Kerrigan, 65 years old, of 2,502 Avenue D, Brooklyn, was killed at 8 o'clock last night when the automobile in which she was a passenger collided with another machine at Lenox Road and East Thirty-ninth Street, bumped across the sidewalk and crashed into a brick house.

American shipyards on Jan. 1 were building, or had under contract to build for private ship owners, exclusive of vessels previously launched, 212 vessels aggregating 247,713 tons, the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation of the Department of Commerce reported today.

As if to show that there is a stalemate in European diplomacy and no way to make progress at the moment, it was announced today that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden was leaving Saturday for a fortnight's rest at Monte Carlo.
Stocks eased slightly and closed irregular; turnover, 2,388,480 shares. United States Government issues generally higher, corporate and foreign bonds firm and mixed; transactions, $13,124,200.

Among the ten properties sold yesterday at auction in Manhattan were the Ageloff Tower Building, at 51-7 Avenue A, the eighteenstory apartment building at 1,175 Madison. Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street, and the Bender Court Apartments, at 377 1/2 West Fiftyfifth Street. The list follows:

Mrs. Adelaide Hitchcock Brown, widow of Archer Brown, philanthropist and author, whose father, the Rev. Dr. Luke Hitchcock, was a prominent figure in methodism in Chicago and Cincinnati, left a personal estate estimated at $250,000, according to a petition filed with the will, which was admitted to probate here today.

Rabbi Abraham N. Schwartz, one of the oldest orthodox rabbis in Baltimore, died at his home here today at the age of 65. For years prominent in Jewish educational activities, he was also noted for his charity work.

A course of illustrated lectures on the music of India by Sarat Lahairi will be given this afternoon. Because of illness, Gladys Swarthout will be unable to sing in "The Tales of Hoffmann" on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House. She will be replaced by Helen Jepson.

The American Federation of Hosiery Workers embarked today on a permanent program of workers' education and appropriated $10,000 for the first year's financing. Convention delegates wrote into the organization's constitution a provision for a department of education.
Louis Comisky, 44-year-old clothing worker of 890 Elsmere Place, the Bronx, was ordered excluded from the country yesterday after a hearing before a board of inquiry on Ellis Island.

Jockey Jimmy Lynch gave the Australian barrier a big boost in the featured Jupiter Purse at Hialeah today when he beat the gate so far with Patriotic that the horse was able to stagger home a length to the good at $24.60 for $2. Beating the gate means getting away from the gate before the other jockeys can get their horses started. .

An injunction restricting expansion of the Tennessee Valley Authority's power program has been modified by Judge J. Gore of the Middle Tennessee Federal District Court to allow the TVA to sell and transmit power from Norris Dam to the Aluminum Company of America at Alcoa, Tenn.

The Inter-American Conference at Buenos Aires "was signally successful in adopting practical methods of preserving the peace of this hemisphere," Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, said last night at a dinner of the Peoples Mandate to Governments to End War, at the Hotel Biltmore.

Gustav Eder of Germany outpointed Cleto Locatelli, Italian welterweight, in a twelve-round bout tonight. Eder's superior reach and boxing skill provided his winning margin. Locatelli carried the fight to Eder throughout in order to overcome the German's greater reach, but nevertheless dropped seven of the rounds. Ten thousand fans turned out for the bout.
Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during 1936, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with those in 1935 and 1934.

Alarmed by heavy losses from unfair returns of merchandise and other evils in the industry, members of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc., at a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker last night, adopted a program designed to eliminate unfair trade practices.
Defining in clear terms his conception of his task as Ambassador to the United States George Bonnet, at an American Club luncheon today, declared:

Engineering construction awards for the week showed a loss in every classification, compared with the same week a year ago, according to The Engineering News-Record. The total this year was $41,451,000, against $50,036,000 in 1936.

Because the required number of shares of preferred stock has not been deposited, the management of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company has not be able to carry out the plan of reorganization approved by stockholders on Oct. 8, 1935, according to a letter sent to stockholders by Roy B. Jones, president.

Cigars, cigarettes and other forms of tobacco yielded the government $536,102,850 in internal revenue collections during the calendar year 1936, the Treasury announced today. This compared with $478,367,718 in 1935 and the low of $387,271,269 in 1932.
Captain Thomas Hagen, who held one of the longest, sailing records in Great Lakes shipping, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

Miss Virginia Elizabeth Gallagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Walter Gallagher of this place, was mar. tried this morning to William Andrew Nugent, son of Mrs. William A. Nugent of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Nugent. The ceremony was performed in St. Joseph's Catholic Church, here, by the rector, the Rev. Edward C. McManus.
The question of "balancing" the National Football League by addition of a tenth club is due for decision Feb. 12 and 13 at the circuit's annual meeting in Chicago.

The wreckage of The Daily Express survey airplane Dragon Fly, which had been missing since it left Renfrew, Scotland, for Liverpool Tuesday morning, was found today by a shepherd on a hilltop near Newton Stewart, Wigtownshire, Scotland, its four occupants dead.

Huey Pierce Long Sr., father of the late Senator Long, died today. He was 84 years old. Although his son established a dictatorship in Louisiana and gained fame as a political strategist, the senior Long held only one public office during his lifetime, that of a Democratic Presidential Elector in the last general election.

W. W. Durbin, Register of the United States Treasury, died at his home here tonight. Ill only a few days, Mr. Durbin succumbed to a cerebral hemorrhage less than twenty-four hours after the death of his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Francis W. Durbin, at her home in Lima.

President Roosevelt intervened last night to end the deadlock in the automobile strike conference by sending word through Governor Murphy to both sides that the White House was expecting a settlement, it was reported after two conferences during the day had failed to result in any progress whatever.

Miss Irene Marie Friedl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Friedl of Gibbon, Minn., was married to Louis Alfred Sutter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin L. Sutter of this place, this morning in the Church of St. Augustine here.
Dr. Antonio Martinez Fraga, National Democrat from Santa Clara Province, was elected President of the House of Representatives today by a vote of 104 to 24.

Rimsky-Korsakoff's fantastic operatic satire, after Pushkin, "Coq d'Or," was revived yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House with the scenery and in greater part the stage properties of Willy Pogany, which were such an original and fascinating feature of the Metropolitan premiere of this work in 1918.

A threatened strike of 8,000 employes in the women's ready-to-wear industry in this city has been averted. Abraham Silver, executive director of the Philadelphia Waist and Dress Manufacturers Association, announced tonight that the association had reached a tentative agreement with the joint board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union.

A change in ownership for one of the "show places" in the Roslyn section of Long Island was announced yesterday. Clark T. Chambers sold for Frederick Brown the nineteenacre estate on Hempstead Harbor, formerly owned by Benjamin Stern.

Dry goods jobbers cut down their operations considerably in the primary markets this week, reports yesterday indicated. Practically all of those who had been in the market in the preceding week have returned home and are now engaged in the selling of goods, Underwear purchases have been practically completed but some buying of knitted outerwear continues, it was said.

About one of every seven government employes works in an agency set up primarily to help the farmer. Civil service lists showed today that bureaus to aid agriculture employ almost 120,000 of the 831,095 government workers.
A nonpartisan group of about twentyfive Representatives agreed informally today to assure President Roosevelt of their cooperation with possible plans to alter the power of the Supreme Court.

A grueling five-game match resulting in victory for Germain G. Glidden of the Harvard Club and Donald Grant of the Heights Casino featured last night's competition in the eighth annual invitation squash racquets doubles tourney for the Lockett Trophy at the University Club. They downed Ivy Lee and B. B. Adams of the home club, 15-12, 15-9, 3-15, 13-15, 18--15.

The Rev. vigor at Charles E. Coughlin will say tomorrow in an editorial in Social Justice that the "most immoral aspect" of the General Motors strike is "the pussyfooting of the Federal Government and of the State government.
The United States Army horse show team, which has been training diligently since its arrival, has announced it is in excellent condition for the international exhibition which will open Feb. 18.

The American Smelting and Refining Company has advanced the price of prime Western zinc 1/4-cent a pound at East St. Louis. The new price of 61/4 cents is the highest since November, 1929, when it was quoted at 61/2 cents.

GEORGE STEER, whose dispatches from the Italo-Ethiopian war appeared in this newspaper as well as in The Times of London, has summed up his impressions of the campaign in a sharp and fairly realistic book called "Caesar in Abyssinia" (Little, Brown, $3).

Because of the rising costs of contract materials and labor and the unwillingness of the State to defray the cost of several minor projects originally assigned to it, New York City must increase its own share of expenditures for the 1939 World's Fair from $7,000,000 to $8,000,000, Park Commissioner Robert Moses has informed the Board of Estimate.

Thirty players from fourteen colleges started swinging yesterday in the Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis tournament and at the end of the day only the eight seeded favorites remained in the play for the singles title.

Directors of the Gulf States Steel Company, the second largest steel company in the South, will meet today in the offices of Hallgarten Co. at 44 Pine Street, to consider an offer of the Republic Steel Corporation to acquire Gulf States' common stock on an indicated basis of $24,350,000.

It will not be a decade, at their present pace, before some one of the country's Portias takes her place among the "nine old men" on the Supreme Court bench, Miss Charl Williams of Washington predicted yesterday.

Bill Delancey, former catcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, today was appointed manager of the Albuquerque club of the reorganized Arizona-Texas League. A year ago he came here to recuperate from a serious ailment, being taken off the train on a stretcher.
Frank W. Wheaton, who in 1907 resigned as a Common Pleas judge of Luzerne County to return to private law practice, died tonight at his home in Kingston. He was 82 years old.

Insurance in force of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company at the end of 1936 represented the largest total ever recorded for a single company, and was more than one-fifth of the aggregate for all the life insurers in the United States, Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the board, and Leroy A. Lincoln, president, reported to the convention of the company's district managers at the Waldorf Astoria yesterday.
Because it is to be made a book club selection in May, the publication of "Hero Breed," a novel by Pat Mullen, has been postponed. Robert M. McBride is the publisher. Mullen wrote "Man of Aran."

The first regular appropriation bill of the new Congress--the Independent offices Bill--has been put through the House of Repesentatives in short order. It carries authorization for the expenditure of slightly more than a billion dollars,

The condition of Elihu Root, statesman-lawyer, was announced as being unchanged at 6:45 o'clock last night by Mrs. Elihu Root Jr. from her home at 1 Beekman Place. Mr. Root has been confined to his home, 998 Fifth Avenue, during the last two weeks suffering from a heavy cold.

Following is Bernard M. Baruch's formal statement made yesterday before the House Military Affairs Committee: The Bill S25 is to prevent profiteering in time of war and equalize the burdens of war and provide for the national defense and promote peace.

Acting Secretary of the Treasury Wayne Chatfield Taylor announced today that bids were invited for $50,000,000 in bills of 273-day maturity, dated Feb. 10, to meet a maturity of approximately the same amount in similar securities.

The West Side Elevated Highway, completed all along its four-and-ahalf-mile length from Canal Street to Seventy-second Street, will be formally opened to traffic Tuesday morning by Mayor La Guardia and Borough President Samuel Levy. The last link of the $16,000,000 elevated roadway, on the upper West Side. has just been completed.
Establishment of a station at Floyd Bennett Airport to serve as the main aviation base for the Coast Guard in the New York district is envisaged in government plans made public yesterday.
Arthur F. Danz, formerly manager of the industrial division of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, has been named vice president and general manager of Kirkman Son, Inc., soap manufacturers,

Counsel for the Consolidated Oil Corporation, Harry F. Sinclair and others asked Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan yesterday to dismiss two stockholders' accounting suits for more than $12,000,000 brought against the corporation, Mr. Sinclair and several other defendants. Justice Callahan reserved decision.

Herbert Courtney, New York state amateur pocket billiard champion, won the third block of his 250Point match with Ted Snyder, 61 to 23, at Jack Doyle's Broadway Academy last night. Courtney, who heads 185 to 148, had an unfinished un of 25, while Snyder's best effort was 19.
Final approval was given by the Federal District Court here today to the plan of the Baldwin Locomotive Works for reorganization of its financial structure under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

A comprehensive code of fair tradee practices which calls for "outright legal prohibition of the loss leader and of retail sales below cost" has been drafted and placed in the hands of President Roosevelt, it was stated yesterday by Siegfried F. Hartman, chairman of the legal advisory committee of Major Berry's Council for Industrial Cooperation.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday discharged a jury, which, after deliberating five hours, was unable to agree on the innocence or guilt of John McGill, former Surveyor of Customs for the Port of New York, and Paul P. Henderson, salesman of Valley Stream, L. I., who were accused of conspiracy to defraud the government.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Jan. 23 totaled 285,211,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

A charge of homicide against Julius Kowal, 26 years old, a bus driver, of 229 West Ninety-seventh Street, in connection with the death of Mrs. Anna Fishman, 45, of 102 East 105th Street, was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Anthony F. Burke,

Opposition to rapid-transit unification under public ownership and operation was voiced yesterday by the New York Board of Trade at a Transit Commission hearing on the $436,000,000 unification plan proposed by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr.

A service of thanksgiving was held yesterday morning in St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, Broadway, between Fulton and Vesey Streets, in commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the consecration to the episcopate of the Right Rev. Samuel Provoost as first Bishop of New York and of the Right Rev. William White as first Bishop of Pennsylvania.

After more than three years of disagreement over Bush Terminal matters, a plan of reorganization for the Bush Terminal Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Bush Terminal Buildings Company, that has been agreed upon by the most widely divergent interests in both companies was filed yesterday in -the Federal court in Brooklyn. Judge Inch signed an order setting March 10 as the date for a hearing on the plan.

John Henry Belden, chief clerk in the State Controller's office from 1902 until his retirement in 1933, died today of acute bronchitis. His age was 81. In 1899 Mr. Belden was elected to the House of Representatives and in 1911 he was again elected.

President Roosevelt was kept informed today of the progress of the automobile strike conference, chiefly through Secretary Perkins, who talked by telephone for about twenty minutes with Governor Murphy.

De Witt Clinton High School remains the undefeated pace-setter in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division of the P.S.A.L. basketball race as the result of a 44-23 triumph over Washington on the latter's court yesterday. The victory, which marked the start of action in the second half of the league drive, was the sixth in as many games for the invaders, who held a 25-12 lead at the half. Bill Gylen was outstanding, scoring 13 points.
In one of the longest wrestling encounters witnessed hereabouts in recent years, Robert Bruns of Germany downed Jim McMillen of Chicago last night before a gathering of 3.000 at. the Hippodrome.

America First won by a neck in the fifth and feature race, the Rainbow Terrace Purse, at Alamo Downs today. Solar Hawk outgamed Me O My for second money. Billy Neal ran his riding streak to thirty-eight triumphs for the year in piloting home the ChicleHail Columbia 3-year-old gelding, carrying the silks of H. E. Simpson.

Governor Lehman demanded tonight the waging of war against syphilis until the disease was conquered. The Governor spoke at a Syphilis Control Forum here at Chancellor's Hall and stressed his conviction that in view of the wide ravages of the disease an extensive eradication campaign was necessary.

The largest income from operations in the history of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. was shown yesterday in its annual report for 1936. The year's income from this source was $52,965,490 after $15,222,225 provision for depreciation and obsolescence, compared with $40,716,925, after $14,473,364 such reserves, for 1935. The highest record prior to 1935 was $34.212.150. in 1929.

Slant drilling of oil from beneath the graves of a cemetery does not constitute disrespect for the dead and does not offer grounds for a damage suit, Superior Judge Minor Moore ruled yesterday in dismissing a $226,000,000 damage action against the operators of the Sunnyside Cemetery, a group of oil companies and 107 individuals.

" On the Avenue," the latest musical comedy from the Twentieth Century-Fox studios, is a moderately amusing revue with no more of a plot than we can expect from these things, but with a pleasant Irving Berlin score and a disarming informality in its production to lure us into liking it.

A temporary truce prevailed yesterday in the series of strikes called this week by the Building Service Employes Union. James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32 B, which has been directing the strikes, said no additional walkouts would be called until Monday.
Some 15,000 railway men in blue Labor Front uniforms paraded before Chancellor Adolf Hitler today as an expression of the Reich Railways' gratitude for the "liberation from Versailles."

Importing countries were in the market early today for cash wheat and corn but the buying was not so spectacular as that of yesterday. The trade estimated that 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 bushels were bought, and this with removal of hedges in Liverpool advanced futures in the English market 2 3/4 to 3 1/8 cents a bushel.

Karl W. Corby, Washington banker, died at his Winter residence today after an illness of several months. His age was 43. He arrived here Monday. Mr. Corby was a director of the Riggs National Bank in Washington, president of the District of Columbia Bankers Association and partner in the brokerage firm of W. B. Hibbs Co.

Miss Helen Cutting Wilmerding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Wilmerding, was married yesterday afternoon to Philip Bastedo, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Arthur Bastedo, in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square. The Rev. Elmore McKee, the rector, performed the ceremony.

John B. Lewis, who retired as cashier of the Citizens National Bank and Trust Company here two years ago after serving in that capacity for eighteen years, died at his home today of pneumonia. He was 65 years old and had been associated with the bank for thirty years.

Mrs.Hobart Warren Thompson, social leader and clubwoman, died today at her home at the age of 67. She was the former Grace McLeod, the daughter of the late Charles A. and Harriet Rockwood McLeod. Her father was an officer of the Bussey-McLeod Stove Company and president of the Chicago Stove Works.

Italo-Turkish relations, for twentyfive years troubled by fear and suspicion or breached by war, are apparently about to be healed. The conference on Wednesday in Milan between the Foreign Ministers of Italy and Turkey-Count GALEAZZO CIANO and TEWFIK RUSHDU ARAS-suggest that MUSTAFA KEMAL ATATURK is at last convinced that Italy has renounced the ambition to extend its authority over Adalia, "the Southern California" of Turkey.
Premier Benito Mussolini, in the role of fond father, was host today at a reception honoring the 22-year-old girl who will marry his eldest son, Vittorio, Saturday.

The flood relief fund of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross mounted yesterday to a total of $1,376,722, according to an announcement by General Robert C. Davis, executive director, bringing the total close to the quota of $1,500,000, but national headquarters urged that the drive be continued past that figure because the original estimates of the needs have been far exceeded.

In an effort to aid the Mayor's campaign to abate noise in the streets, the League for Less Noise, Inc., of 580 Fifth Avenue, is supplying to its members a green card which may be handed to offending motorists. The Police Department announced that it would accept for distribution 100,000 of these slips, offered by the league.

Jean J. Arens, Soviet Consul General in New York, who has been recalled to Moscow, was honored at a farewell reception yesterday afternoon in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the American-Russian Chamber of Commerce and the American-Russian Institute. He is sailing on the Paris tomorrow.

The Nassau-Hofstra College of N. Y. U. quintet rallied to beat Princeton Seminary, 28-23, at the high school court tonight. Trailing by 13-8 at the intermission, the victors, with Donald Lay leading the attack, came back to win.
Joseph E. Widener entertained to night with a dinner at Il Palmetto in honor of Sir Bede E. H. Clifford Governor of the Bahamas, and Lady Clifford, his house guests.

Demands from Fernand Laurent, on the extreme right of the Chamber of Deputies, that there should be a change of government, and from Paul Reynaud, in the center, that the government should change its policy if France was to be saved from a new catastrophe, were made today during debate on the financial situation.
Although the strictest secrecy is being observed, it is understood that the government is confronted with a serious problem in connection with the provision of an income for the Duke of Windsor.

Mrs. Frank E. Gannett of Rochester, N. Y., wife of the publisher; Mrs. George Platt Brett of New York, Dr. Barbara Ring of Boston, Mrs. Clark Stearns, Mrs. Antonio De Almar, Mrs. Cleland Davis, Mrs. E. Ewing Chatten and other socially prominent women are members of the board of directors of the Pan-American League who assisted Mrs. Johnny Gruelle at the concert, given at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Gruelle tonight.
Lumber production increased last week when a decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index has advanced to 68.6 from 65.1, the previous week's figure. It was 82.9 for the week ended Feb. 1, 1936.
Cruising, a good second-place horse until he finished fifth in his previous race, got up in the final strides to take a head decision in the fiveand-a-half furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

In a telegram to Mayor La Guardia yesterday President Roosevelt reaffirmed his support of the Federal Child Labor Amendment and expressed the hope that it would be ratified by the New York Legislature, where it already has been approved by the Senate.

The Russian Eagle of the SherryNetherland was the setting last night for the annual dinner dance of the Association of Former Imperial Russian Naval Officers, given to augment the association's relief fund for dependents of former Russian naval officers.

Aviators Post 743, American Legion, sponsor of the current aviation show at Grand Central Palace, volunteered yesterday to provide funds for the rehabilitation for an entire family in the flood area. The unprecedented success of the show caused the members of the post to take this action.

Richard Hageman's "Caponsacchi," the text by Arthur Goodrich, after the play which has been made familiar in this city by Walter Hampden, was given its first American performance last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, the composer conducting.

Replying to charges that they had "unjustly enriched themselves" at the expense of the Federal Water Service Corporation when, in 1932, they disposed of holdings of that corporation's securities, the Chase National Bank and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company yesterday asserted that it was the utility that had had the advantage.

The St. James Theatre, which, until last Saturday was usy with Mr. Gielgud and Elsinore, this evening gets another revival of Shakespeare. The matter this time is the seldom produced "King Richard II," with Maurice Evans, late the Emperor of St. Helena, in the title role.

Manhattan's one and two-mile relay teams, which will seek to repeat their 1936 triumphs in the Millrose games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, were named yesterday by Coach Pete Waters. The Jasper mile quartet, slated to meet Holy Cross,
The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., today will advance the price of all grades of gasoline a half cent a gallon throughout New York and the New England States.

Demands for "teeth" in the State i Milk Control Law provided a common meeting ground today for opponents and proponents of the law, as they voiced their opinions before a fourteen-member joint legislative committee in a public hearing here.

Having lived in hopes for six weeks, the vast army of metropolitan skiers is looking forward to enjoying its first good week-end of running tomorrow and Sunday as conditions in general are reported to be good in the Upper Adirondacks of New York State and the Green and White Mountains of Vermont and New Hampshire.

President Roosevelt today repudiated any one who wrote as "one of the President's close advisers." A White House announcement said: "The President announced the death of the 'official spokesman' in March, 1933.

Jules Martin, who has been described to a Supreme Court jury as the arch conspirator in the restaurant racket, was revealed yesterday to have been a beer collector for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in 1932.

A Republican attacked Secretary Hull as a "mystic and a dreamer," and a Democrat defended the Secretary as a great man in a storm of debate in the House today on a resolution to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.
The Governing Body of the International Labor Office named a delegation of nine members today to represent it at the textile conference to be held in Washington early in April.

Blown by the gale that swept across Lake Musconetcong, at Netcong, N. J., on Wednesday, a streak of soft ice only ten feet wide opened yesterday and prevented the hoped-for sailing of the first ice boat match for the Rumson Country Club's new Eastern championship ice boat pennant.

Harold Hulen's "sitdown" antics got some new furbishings today, including a ball and chain and a radio broadcast. City officials called at the apartment house home of Florence Hulbert where Hulen is seated, chained to a radiator, in his quest for her hand, and asked him to desist in the interest of "civic pride."

Apartment and apartment house sites were among the properties sold in the Bronx yesterday. Irving W. Karpf, operator, bought a plot of about 12,000 square feet at 1,963 Ryer Avenue, facing Echo Park between 178th Street and Burnside Avenue.

Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, announced today the appointment of Richard S. Childs of New York City, as a member of the State Board of Housing. The appointment has the approval of Governor Lehman.

Povla Frisch made her fourth appearance of the season in Town Hall last night before a large audience that applauded and cheered her. She again demonstrated the many sideness of her interpretive talent.

John F. Burke, 13 rooms, 6 baths in 510 Park Av.; John C. Wilmerding, in 333 E. 68th St.; Dr. Abram Abeloff, in 19 E. 88th St.: Douglas L. Elliman , Inc., broker. Robert L. Zabriskie, in 563 Park Av.; William M. Collins Jr., in 42 E. 57th.; Miss Mary A. Magill, Miss Betty Hepburn, in 757 Madison Av.; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., broker.

A painting by August Renoir, "Tate de Femme," was sold for $2,400 last night at the Rains Galleries at an auction of modern paintings, drawings and water-colors. The buyer was an agent for a private collector.

THERE was a three-piston cornet on the dresser and Archie San Romani said it was strictly a standard cornet, no trick trumpet gadgets attached. He plays it. Not too well, according to his own confession. This was corroborated by his temporary room-mate, Chuck Fenske of Wisconsin.

Pennsylvania Airlines was exonerated of blame today in two $100,000 damage suits when Justice Joseph W. Cox in the District of Columbia Supreme Court declared that airplane passengers assume "the risks necessarily incident to traveling in the air, known as perils of the air."

As Lent begins next Wednesday sermons tomorrow in all the churches of the ritualistic communions will be on "How to Keep the Penitential Season." In the ecclesiastical calendar the day will be "Quinquagesima Sunday."

The President's Supreme Court proposal was discussed at the annual meeting of the Tenth Assembly District Republican Club, 6 West Twenty-eighth Street, last night. William S. Murray, new Republican State chairman, was the guest of honor.

The Capitol Greyhound Bus Lines will open its new $300,000 terminal at 245 West Fiftieth Street today for a public inspection period to continue through tomorrow. On Monday the Greyhound Lines and all buses of tenant companies will transfer operations from the adjacent hotel building to the new structure.

The first anniversary of the publication of George Santayana's "The Last Puritan" has just been marked by the eleventh large printing of the novel and its 165th thousand sale. "The Last Puritan" was the Book of the Month selection for. February, 1936.
The Duke of Windsor, like most men looking forward to marriage, is seeking means of financing such a step, a reliable informant disclosed today.

Ray Napolitano, 146, Williamsburg, outpointed Willie Hines, 142 1/2, Harlem, last night in the eightround feature boxing bout at the Flatbush Arena. Hines, a substitute for Irish Jimmy Brady, who was ill, was unable to solve Napolitano's two-fisted attack, which gained the winner six rounds. The crowd numbered 1,200 fans.

James S. Angus Mercer, former State architect of Cuba, died today at White Plains Hospital. He was 81 years old. Until several years ago Mr. Mercer resided at Albany, where he was designer for the State architect. After coming here he did work for the Board of Education in Brooklyn.
Transportation by water between Atlantic ports and California was resumed last night after a threemonth interruption during the strike of Pacific Coast maritime workers.

It will be Glenn Cunningham against the field tonight when America's finest and fastest milers line up for the Wanamaker Mile that will feature the thirtieth annual Millrose A. A. indoor carnival at. Madison Square Garden.

Threats of an attack on the constitutionality of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 appeared yesterday in the Security and Exchange Commission's hearings against C. C. Wright and others for alleged manipulation of the stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd.
Supreme Court Justices who are 70 years of age and have served ten years may resign at full pay of $20,000 a year, but Congress may alter their compensation later.

Operators figured yesterday in housing deals in the upper West Side and Washington Heights areas. Charles Walzer paid all cash over a first mortgage of $452,000 for the nine-story apartment house at 345 West Eighty-eighth Street, between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive. Assessed at $490,000,
Benjamin W. Moore, former judge of Children's Court in Yonkers, was elected president of the Westchester County Bar Association at the annual meeting tonight in the County Court House.
President Roosevelt's proposal to increase the membership of the Supreme Court is one of the most drastic moves affecting the tribunal ever made.

The 1,405 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $46,591,515,045 par value as of Feb. 1, had a total market value of $45,113,047,758, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday.

Luther M. Walter, trustee of the Chicago Great Western Railroad, said tonight five railroad unions posted notice today that their members on the Great Western system would go on strike Feb. 9 at 6 P. M. unless demands for a wage readjustment were met.

Bank exchanges of the principal cleaning houses of the country in January amounted to .$29,613,428,635, a decrease of 13 per cent from December, but an increase of 7 per cent over January, 1936. New York City clearings amounted to $17,523,317,216, a decrease of 14.4 per cent from December,

Rolling in heavy seas eighty miles off the Virginia Capes east of Norfolk, the Morgan line freighter El Occidente sent out a call for assistance at 12:50 o'clock this morning. Captain E. S. Campbell, master of the vessel, reported that the rudder was damaged and it could not be steered.

This year's effusion of tender sentiment attendant on St. Valentine's Day will be marked by a note of sophistication. The annual poetic transmission of heart throbs will feature just as many of the lush staples of St. Valentine's Day as were used in the Nineties but the versions also will have a note of modernity.

Miss. Helen W. Fox, daughter of Mrs. Charles N. Read of Elkins Park, was married this afternoon to Laurence J. Brengle Jr. of Bryn Mawr, son of Mrs. Laurence J. Brengle of Morristown, N. J., and of the late Mr. Brengle. The ceremony took place in St. Paul's Church, Elkins Park.

132d St., 43 W., 5-story tenement; Harlem Savings Bank against Weincome Realty Corp.; due, $17,463; to plaintiff for $1,000. By JAMES R. MURPHY Boynton Av., 1,108, n. e. cor. Watson Av., 150x100; Aaron Rabinowitz, trustee, against Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance; due, $211,841; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Folie Monvel, his new residence on Hi-Mount, was the setting for a large cocktail party and house warming given today by Bernard Boutet de Monvel. Mr. and Mrs. John M. L. Rutherfurd entertained more than a hundred guests with cocktails today at their home.
Six foilswomen earned the right to represent this district in the national junior championships as a result of qualifying tests conducted last night on the strips of the Fencers Club.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Rowland Ellis Lea of Devon of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Steuart Lea, to Henry Ross Watson, son of Mrs. George H. Stuart 3d. of Villanova and the late Robert C. Watson of New York.

The extent of British recovery is emphasized by the comparisons of corporation profits in the Jan. 16 issue of The London Economist. That journal's index had shown trade activity in Great Britain as a whole last year-to be about 6 per cent above 1935, 25 per cent above 1932 (the worst year of depression) and even 9 per cent above 1929.

The death by strangulation of Miss Lilian Ethel Drescher, a social worker in New York, was reported by the police today. Miss Drescher came to Paris recently from Nice. Declaring that she was tired of social work, she had been trying to get employment in American newspaper offices here.

While the automobile strike drags on, a major dispute has been settled on another labor front. The most costly maritime strike in American history, a ninety-eight-day walkout on the Pacific Coast, ended yesterday with the return of some 40,000 men to work.

Mrs. Ary J. Lamme 'Jr., recent winner of the metropolitan and New Jersey championships, was well on her way to another major squash racquets victory. today when she scored easily in quarter and semi-final matches to reach the final in the ninth annual invitation tournament of the Ardsley Country Club.

Several hundred younger members of society, including the majority of this Winter's debutantes and several of recent years, attended the third and last of the Junior Assemblies for this season, which took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. As usual the Assembly was preceded by several dinners and dinner dances, some of which served as coming-out parties.
A special "people's court" will sit in judgment on the Augustinian friars who dwelt in the Escorial monastery built by King Philip II nearly 400 years ago, the government announced today.
Henry G. Eisenhand, Associated Press staff photographer in the Denver Bureau, died tonight of pneumonia. He had been ill since Sunday. His age was 48.

Events of tonight in this area were featured by a mariner's costume party given by Baron and Baroness Frederik van Hogendorp of the Coconut Grove Colony in Miami, in the club house of the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club, and by a musical and punch party, at which Mrs. Nelson B. Warden of Philadelphia was hostess at White Haven, her estate on Belle Isle.
Columbia University recently has received new gifts totaling $92,625.76, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, disclosed yesterday.

The House completed ten hours of general debate today on the Doughton resolution to extend for three years from June 12 the tariff bargaining: powers under which President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull have negotiated fifteen reciprocal trade agreements with as many foreign countries.

Tomorrow is the fifteenth anniversary of the Pope's election to the pontifical throne and the Osservatore Romano seizes the occasion to print a brief bulletin on his present state of health, which, it says, is greatly improved.

Figures tending to show nearly a 20 per cent decline in the general mortality rate in the region served by the Judson Health Center as compared with the rest of the lower West Side were cited by Health Commissioner John L. Rice yesterday as proof of the effectiveness of public health agencies in the fight to curb. disease and death.
F. Godber of London was elected here yesterday chairman of the Shell Union Oil Corporation to succeed Sir Henri W. A. Deterding, who had resigned. Mr.
A family of fifteen persons so poor that the members have to go out in relays because they have not enough clothes to go around was found living on the East Side yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Horner of Danbury have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Louise Horner, to John C. Beer, managing editor of The Newark Call and president of the New Jersey Associated Press organization.

William S. MacDonald, a leading lawyer of Seneca County for more than half a century, died here yesterday at the age of 75. Mr. MacDonald was president of the Seneca County Trust Company here. Prominent in financial, civic.

Even with attendance cut somewhat by the inclement weather of yesterday, there were many visitors at the National Aviation Show at Grand Central Palace. Exhibitors were pleased at having less of a jam in the aisles, for they were better able to attend to visitors who seemed seriously interested in purchases. Many sales were reported.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Russia's Coming of Age," Maurice Hindus: Annual science luncheon of the Science Council, the Biltmore, 12:45 P. M. Dr. John Tildsley, guest of honor. "Science and Society," Waldemar Kaempffert. Sinclair Wilson, toastmaster.

The four-story apartment house, 160 by 100 feet, at 260 Gregory Avenue, Passaic, N. J., was resold by Charles Walzer for cash over a first mortgage of $315,000 at 3 per cent for five years. Harry Hoberman negotiated the deal.

The Commercial Bulletin will say of the wool market tomorrow: "The market continues quiet and is slightly easier, some few apprehensive holders having taken a smaller profit to keep wool moving but this is not considered symptomatic of the market which generally is regarded as fundamentally strong.

President Roosevelt's proposals for changes in the Federal judiciary came as a stunning surprise to the financial community yesterday. They evoked uncertainty and alarm among bankers and business men which found expression in a sweeping decline of stock prices.
Nine 2-month-old pedigreed bull calves were carried today from Lima to Cajamarca by plane. They were wrapped in burlap sacking for the journey.
John R. Dillon of Hayden, Stone Co. has been elected a director of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Charles Hayden.

After an absence of a decade, Alexander Culbertson, American violinist, returned to the local concert stage last night at Carnegie Hall in a program which was well attended and demonstratively received.
FERRERS was the name of an illustrious Anglo-Norman house that came in with the Conqueror, owned whole English counties, and whose head was sometimes called Earl of DERBY or of NOTTINGHAM.

The registration statement of the Texas Corporation, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the offer to its stockholders to buy 1,556,694 shares of its capital stock -at $40 a share, became effective yesterday. The stock closed at 57 1/2, off 1.
Recent reports in the public press concerning the presidency of Mount Holyoke College have attributed remarks to me which I have not made.

President Roosevelt nominated a Negro lawyer today to be Federal judge for the Virgin Islands. He is William H. Hastie, 32-yearold Assistant Solicitor in the Interior Department, an honor graduate of Amherst College and the Harvard Law School.

The Democratic majority in the Board of Estimate defeated one of Mayor La Guardia's pet projects yesterday, the construction of a group of buildings for meat wholesalers at a cost of $373,000 on Washington Street between Gansevoort. and Little West Twelfth Streets, the- development to be known as Gansevoort Square Meat Market.
Walter Runchiman, President of the Board of Trade, emphasized on his arrival at Southampton on the Aquitania today that no great importance was to be attached to his trip to the United States.

Four State Street department stores announced today a reduction in working hours for employes, and in two instances an increase in minimum starting wages. The stores are Marshall Field Co., Mandel Brothers, The Fair and Carson, Pirie, Scott Co.
The flood-relief fund of the Red Cross jumped today to a new total of $15,776,000 with the receipt of contributions totaling $1,657,000 in twenty-four hours.

The St. Augustine's quintet, unbeaten pace-setter, gained a firmer hold on first place in the Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. race by turning back Bishop Loughlin, 21-19, in an overtime game on the winner's court yesterday. The victory was the ninth in the tournament for the home forces.

New bond financing this week amounting to $71,605,000 was represented by a fairly well diversified list of new issues. Placements included one loan each in the foreign, public utility, industrial and railroad groups, and four tax-exempt issues.
The Ohio River fell throughout its 900-mile length today and was below flood stage from Pittsburgh to Cincinnati for the first time since Jan. 18. This table shows the situation:

Major Stephen Fowler Hart, retired real estate dealer and veteran of the Spanish and World Wars, died today at his home, 31 Oakland Avenue, here, of heart disease at the age of 76. He retired last April. Major Hart was born in Peekskill, N. Y., the son of Henry White and Esther James Fowler Hart.

The Neighborhood Music School will present a concert tomorrow afternoon at the Museum of the City of New York. The Mandolin Orchestra of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union will give its second annual concert at the Town Hall this afternoon.

Copper sales were made abroad yesterday at 13.20 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, a new high level for the current move and 20 points above the domestic quotation. -Most of the business, however, was done between 13.125 and 13.175 cents.
Savings deposits increased while current and call loans declined, according to the monthly statement of Canadian chartered banks for Dec. 30,. made public today at the Finance Department.

Public opinion throughout the State will uphold the Assembly in resisting concurrence in the Senate action for ratification of the proposed Child Labor Amendment, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared in a letter to Governor Lehman, made public yesterday.

The sit-down strike at present employed against General Motors Corporation by the United Automobile Workers of America "is manifestly a, dangerous weapon," the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America declared in a review of the General Motors strike made public yesterday.

Winter beset New York in earnest yesterday, bringing the city 1.8 inches of snow in the second snowstorm of the year and making the streets so slippery from slush and ice that many pedestrians and vehicle riddrs were hurt in accidents.

At the close of today's session of the Air Safety Conference sponsored by the Bureau of Air Commerce, Colonel Edward S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association, urged that Congress be asked to appropriate "enough dollars to make the airways safe."

An armed trio of thieves held up nine persons in a store 100 feet from police headquarters and escaped yesterday afternoon with a batch of worthless insurance papers while a traffic policeman stood in the street about sixty feet away assisting school children. The trio missed a $5,000 payroll.

The earliest ice floe blockade in many years has isolated St. Johns since Tuesday. Four steamers are held immovable. The Furness liner Newfoundland, bound for New York, is stuck in the narrows unable to go on or return.

With President Ford C. Frick in the chair, the National League club owners yesterday staged a sixhour conversational marathon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and emerged with only one matter definitely settled.

Chief Justice Hughes said nine years ago that 70 might well be considered too early an age for the compulsory retirement of Supreme Court Justices. Mr. Hughes, who was then 66 and not a member of the court, expressed this view in a lecture afterward incorporated in a book dealing with the court.

The new mortgage firm of Henry J. White J. Halperin, Inc., will open an office at 175 Main Street, White Plains, today. It will conduct a mortgage loan, appraisal and general real estate business. Henry J. White was until recently supervising residential appraiser for the Investors Syndicate in the metropolitan area and Mr. Halperin is president of J. Halperin Co.. Inc., of Jamaica, L. I., prominent in the Long Island mortgage field.

In the shifting European balance of power, the weight of Poland's influence is disproportionately large. The present Polish tendency to draw away from Germany toward France, illustrated this week by the announcement that a "Maginot" line of underground defenses along the German frontier would be built with French money and under the direction of French engineers, is therefore of world importance.

" On Your Toes," the musical comedy, has a good chance of repeating its New York success, judging by tonight's reception, with an English cast, at the Palace Theatre. Some American gags went over well and Jack Whiting got plenty of life into the show.

The marriage of Miss Helen Alvis MacAfee, daughter of Mrs. William Harrison MacAfee of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. MacAfee, to Oliver L. Smith, son of Mrs. Thomas W. Smith, also of that city, and the late Mr. Smith, took place here yesterday afternoon at 121 East Fifty-fourth Street,
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 30 amounted to 659,790 care, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The wedding of Miss Eleanor Minott Waller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tom T. Waller of this place, and Judge Harold L. Knapp of Greenwich, Conn., took place today at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Dr. Archibald Black officiated. A reception for relatives and friends was held after the ceremony.

More than 12,000 persons, including hundreds from near-by States and foreign countries, crowded the Coliseum tonight to pay tribute to Dwight L. Moody, evangelist, who died thirtyeight years ago. The service celebrated the centenary of the evangelist's birth.

Democratic Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan Introduced again today his resolution to amend the Constitution so as to permit use of pari-mutuel machines at the New York race tracks. He is riot overoptimistic about success in his drive, but will launch a campaign for approval even if only for its propaganda effect.

Capturing the opening hole and increasing his margin as the match progressed, Frank Willard of Chicago won the tenth annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Country Club today.
An estimated 60,000 children adored the Saviour in the Holy Sacrament of the Altar today as the y participated in a special program of the Thirty-third International Eucharistic. Congress.
George Jessel, who sacrificed a chance to earn big money by refusing to appear in the first sound picture, "The Jazz Singer," ten years later is joining the Warner forces.

Miss Gwen Leys, daughter of Vice Admiral James Farquharson Leys, Medical Corps, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Leys of Bryn Mawr, Pa., formerly of New York, was married to John Andrews Davenport, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Davenport

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Child of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Child, to Arthur Gilbart, son of Mrs. Louis F. Sailer of Ridgewood, N. J., and the late Arthur W. Gilbart.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5.--Supreme Court attaches said today that the tribunal was up to date in handling its business.

Lady Sybyl Colefax, Judge and Mrs. Samuel W. Greene, Baron Jean de L'Espee C. S. Macinnes, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Best, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Cabot and Judge Isaac Wolfe are among the passengers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex. Others sailing on the ship include: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Abraham Fox, 26 years old, of 731 East 147th Street, and Raymond Miller, 28, of 481 Wales Avenue, both of the Bronx, who were convicted last Monday evening of beating a bank messenger in Farmingdale, L. I., and robbing him of $12,500, were sentenced yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn Federal Court to serve a total term of twenty-two years each in a Federal prison.
A squadron of army bombers reached Miami today on a flight to test the practicality of rushing aerial aid if the Panama Canal should be threatened by an enemy.
Silas H. Strawn, former president of the American Bar Association, today said President Roosevelt's proposal for reorganizing the judiciary meant "a short cut to dictatorship."

Government scientists announced today a new process for shipping fresh flowers in near-zero weather. A package of roses, sweet peas, gardenias, carnations and buttercups, packed by the process, came to the Department of Agriculture from the West Coast by air.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Aumann of 21 West Eighty-sixth Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Aumann, to Frederick Falkenstein, son of Mrs. Frances Mugdan of San Salvador.
Floodweary Kentucky, leaning heavily on the Federal Government- for help, received assurance from Harry L. Hopkins today that the people would have that help as long as they needed it.

A great war industries region is to be created within the next four years in South Central Poland in the triangle having as its apex the confluence of the Rivers Vistula and San, the Premier told the Sejm today in introducing a 514,000,000 zloty investment plan for the coming year.

Not only six of the nine justices of the Supreme Court but half a dozen of the judges of the Federal Circuit Courts and an undisclosed number of the judges of the District Courts would be eligible for retirement as having reached the age of 70 after ten years of service on the bench, as urged by President Roosevelt.

Legislative regulation of motor carriers in New York, New Jersey and Delaware, the only three States where there is no provision for regulation of trucking, is the objective of a movement launched by members of the "Big 4" railroad brotherhoods at a meeting yesterday at the Pennsylvania branch of the Y. M. C. A. in Pennsylvania Station.

Justice Isidor Wasservogel ruled yesterday that the Hillside Housing Corporation, a limited-dividend organization, need not pay taxes on its. $5,000,000 group of low-rental apartment buildings on Boston Road at Seymour Avenue, in the Bronx.

Mrs. Evelyn Hall Warburton, widow of Barclay H. (Buzz) Warburton Jr., today asked the Bucks County Court here to restrain her parentsin-law, Mr. and Mrs. Barclay H. Warburton, from selling the late sportsman's "Saracen Farm" estate.

Dr. Henry B. Swartwout, first Mayor of Port Jervis, in 1907-08, and for half a century one of tile leading physicians of this part of the State, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 76 years old yesterday.

Orders with local wholesalers and manufacturers that may total $9,000,000 were reported today by the Chicago Association of Commerce, following a check of buying by Middle Western merchants here last week for the semi-annual convention and style shows of the Interstate Merchants Council.

Witholding any recommendation regarding continuation of present price-fixing features of the Milk Control Law, Peter J. Ten Eyck, Agriculture Commissioner, urged in his annual report to the Legislature today a simplification of administrative features of the present law.

Pressure against the French franc increased yesterday as financial markets here and abroad considered the implications of the latest evidence of French monetary troubles--the transfer of 3,000,000,000 francs gold from the Bank of France to the stabilization fund.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, and William S. Knudsen, vice president of General Motors Corporation, comprising a subcommittee designated at today's joint conference of spokesmen for both sides in the automobile strike dispute, sat down tonight with Governor Frank Murphy to formulate a report to go before the full committee tomorrow.

Disagreement of milk producers over means to end their price troubles was demonstrated today at a hearing before the joint legislative committee investigating dairying, headed by Senator George F. Rogers of Rochester. About 500 dairymen attended morning and afternoon sessions.
A sharp warning to other nations not to underrate Britain's naval rearmament was delivered tonight by Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, in a speech to the Bradford Chamber of Commerce.

Directors of the Gulf States Steel Company approved yesterday in substance the offer of the Republic Steel Corporation to acquire all the former's property and assets and instructed its counsel, in collaboration with counsel for Republic Steel, to prepare an agreement.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 906,000 bales, against 972,000 a week ago, 916,000 two weeks ago, 927,000 three weeks ago and 752,000 a year ago; of which American 396,000 bales, against 398,000 a week ago, 374,000 two weeks ago, 364,000 three weeks ago and 409,000 a year ago.
For the sons of Dartmouth there was nothing except perfection today. When the visitors to the twentyseventh annual Winter Carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club awoke this morning,

It is almost impossible to keep a major secret in the nation's capital, but President Roosevelt succeeded in doing it with his judiciary plan. The first clue that something highly important was about to "break" developed a short time before 10 o'clock this morning when a long line of black limousines drove into the White House grounds.

A spokesman for Japan's North China garrison said at Peiping today that if Nanking failed to suppress the Communists in the northwest provinces the Japanese military would be "faced with the necessity of taking independent measures."

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $18,445,489, one State and 116 municipalities being represented. This compares with the revised total of $21,113,797 for this week, and $51,397,233, the weekly average for the year.
The Appellate Court of the State of Rio de Janeiro will hold an extraordinary session tomorrow to act on issues of whether a Juvenile Court has power to bar minors from carnival festivities.

Gertrude Bary, pianist, and Jacques Gordon, violinist and leader of the string quartet which bears his name, last night presented a sonata recital before a highly enthusiastic audience at the Steinway Concert Hall.

Log, a filly and a five-time Florida winner, is likely to rule favorite at Hialeah Park tomorrow for the Bahama Handicap, a seven-furlong speed test for 3year-olds, some of which are eligible for the $20,000 added Flamingo Stakes later in the session. Perhaps the biggest crowd of the meeting, estimated by officials at 20,000, may turn out.

William M. Girden, who during the last month purchased two large apartment houses in Queens, extended his holdings there yesterday by buying the six-story house for fifty-eight families at 87-42 Elmhurst Avenue, Jackson Heights.
R. T. Stephens, City Attorney, filed a complaint today against Harold Hulen, 35-year-old sit-down suitor, charging him with "disturbing the peace and quiet of the neighborhood."

In the late editions of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 16, 1937, and in the early editions of Jan. 17, there appeared an item concerning the return of Eddie Schneider, aviator, from serving a month in the so-called Yankee Squadron with the Spanish Loyalists and Schneider's appearance at the Federal Building, where he was questioned by John F. Dailey Jr., Chief Assistant United States Attorney.

Representatives of shippers, manufacturers and farm groups in the inter-Rocky Mountain and Great Plains farm areas argued today that a bill to repeal the "long-andshort-haul" clause of the Interstate Commerce Act would bring economic ruin to their territories.

The most important requisite for progress in market and marketing research "is a more complete independence from bias," Paul T. Cherington of Cherington Roper said yesterday in addressing the advertising and marketing forum of the Advertising Club of New York.

Of all those whom the King, GEORGE VI, delighted to honor on his birthday, the intellectual world put H. A. L. FISHER first. His monumental work on "The History of Europe" would alone give him that place.

Tommy Goodwin, New York State amateur champion, regained the South Florida golf championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today by defeating Joseph Schenck Jr., also of New York, by 9 and 8 in the 36hole final.
The preliminary statement of the creased United Gas Improvement Company for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $27,953,755, an increase of $217,818 over 1935's figure.

Trade movements were steadier this week, with many of the key cities recording an upturn in retail sales of 3 to 8 per cent over the totals in the preceding week, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Herman J. Diekman, Albany lawyer, died today of a stroke at the age of 64. He was one of the few men who lived to read his own obituary. During the Spanish-American War he was reported as having died of yellow fever, but returned from Cuba in 1900, and although his health was shattered he continued his work.

While Governor Lehman remained silent tonight on President Roosevelt's recommendation to increase the number of United States Supreme Court justice, Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Republican-controlled Assembly was blunt in his criticism.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: When John Alexander turns his face toward the millennium and begins to preach collectivism in college football there is scarcely any answer that can be made.

Charles R. th Walgreen, president of the Wal- to green Company, disclosed today plans for a recapitalization of the company which call for retirement of the present preferred stock, the providing of $6,000,000 of new capital and the doubling of the common stock capitalization.

Henry Burden, business man and philanthropist, died at his home here today. He was born in Troy seventy years ago. He was president of the Cazenovia National Bank for thirty years and of the Novia Electric Company and Cazenovia Canning Company.

Dr. William R. Sitler died in the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital this morning. He was 84 years old and had been a practicing physician here for more than forty years. He was Health Commissioner of the town of Ramapo for the last twenty years.

Miss Helen Elizabeth Crosby of Rhinebeck, N. Y., daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Coolidge Onativia and the late Maunsell Schieffelin Crosby, was married to Lewis Bates McCabe of Garrison, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Resurreaction, Seventy-fourth Street, east of Park Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Gordon Wadhams.

Former Premier Frederic Francois-Marsal was sentenced to two years' imprisonment by a Paris police court today on charges of abuse of confidence and fraudulent distribution of dividends from the electric company with which he was connected.
The Women's City Club of New York has sold its former clubhouse property, at 22 Park Avenue, corner of Thirty-fifth Street, to the Windholm Realty Corporation.

Seward Park High's speedy basketball tossers continued on their way to an unbeaten season in the Lower Manhattan Division of the P. S. A. L. by topping Haaren, 23-12, on the winners' floor yesterday. The victory was the sixth in the league for Seward, which tightened its grasp on the lead.
The joint legislative committee to investigate --the guaranteed mortgage situation continued yesterday its examination of the Maryland
The Harvard Club and the New York A. C. still shared first place in the Class C competition of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League after they concluded their respective matches last night.

The volume of business of Sears, Roebuck Co. transacted in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 29 last exceeded all previous records, including the 1929 sales total of $443,000,000. For the fifty-two weeks sales aggregated $526,292,137, an increase of 26.2 per cent over the $417,080,465 reported-for the preceding year.

106th St., 239 E., 25x100.11; Misard Holding Corp. to Rosaria Sardo, 2,116 Strang Av.; purchase money: 6 per cent; $8,000. 39th St., 354 W., 19.7x74.1; 354 W. 39th St. Realty Corp. to East River Savings Bank; due Feb. 1, 1942, 4 per cent; $19,500.

Federal grand jury indicted six men today for altering and passing Treasury bonds which Arthur J. B. Cartier, Assistant Federal Attorney, said had been traced to the robbery of $1,500,000 from a Bank of Manhattan messenger in New York a few years ago.
The Commerce Department reported today that cotton cloth imports had doubled in volume during 1936.

Presidents of fourteen national organizations totaling more than ten million members have joined in an appeal to legislators of twenty-four States urging the enactment of uniform traffic laws with particular emphasis on standard drivers' licenses.
The second of six Mozart-Haydn concerts, under the sponsorship of the WPA Federal Music Project, was presented last night at the project's new Theatre of Music, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street.

Miss. Anne Dieffenbach, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Hagen Dieffenbach of this city, became the bride this evening of George Pettengill 3d, son of Rear Admiral and Mrs. George Pettengill of Washington.

However shabby and tarnished Vienna becomes in its progressive deterioration, it remains a metropolis. It remains a cosmopolis. By comparison with some vociferous capitals in this respect, its position even improves with time.

While 100 policemen patrolled the sidewalks and broke up several fist fights, more than 15,000 men and women in Madison Square Garden last night adopted a resolution urging Stalin to use "iron hands" to wipe out "Trotskyism and all other enemies of the Soviet Union."

Colder weather and firmness in the fresh pork market improved the demand for hogs today and prices were steady to 10 cents higher, with weights under 220 pounds showing the most strength. Top was 5 cents higher at $10.35 a hundredweight, with the day's average up a like amount at $10.20.
More than 500 Cornell alumni pald tribute to Jack Moakley, 73-year-old track coach of Cornell University, at a smoker given tonight at the Montclair Golf Club by the Cornell Club of Montclair.

IN these parlous times, when only novels extraordinarily extended and magazine articles extraordinarily contracted appeal to the American reader, it may seem impertinent to call attention to a volume of literary essays.

Colonel Earl McFarland, U.S.A., and Mrs. McFarland of Governors Island, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ann McFarland, to Lieutenant Hamilton Austin Twitchell, U.S.A., also of Governors Island.

With 744 dogs on the benches, the Maryland Kennel Club today opened its twenty-fourth annual all-breed show in the new Fifth Regiment Armory. Quality, higher than ever before, characterized the two-day exhibition, which will be concluded tomorrow evening when Anton A. Rost of Brooklyn selects the best dog in the show and awards the Hurst Trophy.

Three amendments to the rules of hunts racing which had been under consideration for some time were made effective at a meeting of the Board of Stewards of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, it was announced yesterday. These apply to trainers'

Frederick H. Stinchfield, president of the American Bar Association, criticized in a prepared statement tonight President Roosevelt's recommendations for revision of the Federal courts and said they were "out of line" with the Constitution's segregation of official powers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that round-lot transactions of members of the New York Stock Exchange, except those of specialists, initiated on the floor in the week ended on Jan. 9 amounted to 2,081,040 shares, or 7.23 per cent of the total transactions of 14,395,270 shares.

Charles O. Grim, retired lawyer, died Thursday at his home, 780 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 76 years old. Born in the old Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, Mr. Grim was admitted to the bar on Dec. 16, 1882, and entered the firm of Fisher, Hur?? Boltz.
The City College swimming team won seven of the eight events and the relay' team created a new Beaver record to overwhelm Manhattan College, 51 to 20, at the C. C. N. Y. pool last night.

The government announced today that Chilean oil wells in the Tres Puentes district were now out of danger of being reached by flames from surrounding mountain forest fires, which had threatened the wells.

Less urgent mill buying characterized trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices declined 3 to 7 points. While comparatively little hedging was done by spot, houses, indicating limited sales of loan cotton, scattered liquidation of long accounts supplied contracts.

While the liquor price war continued unabated here yesterday, with new low retail quotations reached on some items, one leading distiller moved to curb the outbreak by announcing no deliveries would be made to wholesalers and by the latter to retail distributors until next Tuesday.

Fred Perry of England defeated Ellsworth Vines of the United States, 6--3, 1--6, 9--7, tonight in the fifteenth match of their tennis series. The Briton's victory left Vines with an 8-7 lead in the exhibitions.

Trade movements were steadier this week, with many of the key cities recording an upturn in retail sales of 3 to 8 per cent over the totals in the preceding week, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Many leases for entire floors were reported in the commercial space contracted for yesterday. The State Committee of the American Labor Party took the entire fourteenth floor of 151 West Fortieth Street. Recovery Coat Company, Stanley Coat Company, Gladstone Bros.

Wheat prices advanced today to new high levels for the current movement as the result of a continued European demand for cash wheat and reports regarding the food situation in Germany and Spain. Both these countries were buyers of wheat today.
The bond market was abruptly disturbed about midday yesterday by the President's message on the Supreme Court. Prices generally and held steady to firm through the morning in routine trading.

An amendment to Rule JD 2 (a) to provide for routine notification by registered Exchanges in cases where securities are suspended from trading was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The text of the commission's statement follows in part:
