Coming through a sensational battle that required two extra periods to decide a victor, the St. Joseph's quintet turned back Long Island University, 46-44, before 5,000 wildly cheering fans at the Arena tonight.

The annual report of-the Central States Electric Corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net asset value of $40,220,364 at the year-end, compared to $37,364,239 at the close of 1935, including holdings in common stocks of affiliated investment companies at year-end market values and not liquidating values.

With one known dead, firemen aided by searchlights from fire trucks searched for other victims tonight in the smoldering debris of two three-story buildings razed this afternoon by two gas explosions and fire at Market and Floyd Streets, in the business district.

James A. Reed, Democrat and former Senator, met the news of President Roosevelt's message to Congress with an "I told you so." "This is just what I warned the people would occur if Roosevelt was re-elected," he said,

Asserting that good housing was basically one of the most important problems facing the country, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in an address here last night, held out a challenge to educators to learn slum conditions so that they might better prepare underprivileged children to become useful citizens.

A painting, "St. Francis," by El Greco, has been purchased by William Helis, newly appointed Greek Consul in New Orleans, La., according to announcement yesterday by the Newhouse Galleries, Inc., 5 East Fifty-seventh Street.

August Oppenheimer, prominent jewelry merchant who, until his retirement early last year, was believed to be the oldest active member of the business in the United States, died early yesterday at his home, 15 Central Park West. Mr. Oppenheimer, who was 90 years old, was a former bank director and president of several jewelers' organizations.

Dartmouth bowed before Harvard, 55-20, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet today, gaining only one first place in the nine events. Although 500 carnival guests cheered the Indians, not until the final event, the 400-yard relay, did Dartmouth manage to gain a victory.

Broadway, 325.327, 60.2x95.2; Suburban Brokerage Corp. to Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co.; mtg., $150,000, held by grantee. 101st St., 3-5, 50x100.11: Matthews Farrell Realty Co., to Bank for Savings; mtg., $32,000, held by grantee ($34).

Investigation by The Associated Press of published reports of open hostility in Russia to Joseph Stalin brought the following yesterday from its correspondent at Moscow. "Official quarters denied there was a parade yesterday in which War Commissar Voroshiloff was cheered and Stalin ignored.

Former Governor Joseph B. Ely, commenting tonight on President Roosevelt's proposal for the judiciary, said: "It would give the President, and by this I mean President Roosevelt as distinguished from the office,

With reference to a letter, "The Trotsky Controversy," written by Mauritz A. Hallgren and published in the Letters to the Editor columns in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, George Novack, secretary of the American Committee for the Defense of Leon Trotsky, made public yesterday a letter he had written to Mr.
Stocks closed lower; turnover, 3,321,850 shares, second heaviest and broadest trading of year. United States Government and foreign bonds irregular, corporate issues lower; transactions, $13,217,500.

Despite the cancellation of several snow trains because of insufficient snow, Winter sports enthusiasts will be able to don their skis and snowshoes over the week-end in various parts of New England, Pennsylvania, New York and Long Island.

In an interview on Feb. 3, Soviet Ambassador Troyanovsky attempted to make the recent Moscow trials of leading Bolsheviki appear just and plausible to a doubting world by referring to previous cases of counter-revolutionary activity. Unfortunately,

Yorke Stephens, veteran English actor, who also played several engagements in New York, died today. He was 74 years old. Yorke Stephens was born in London, Sept. 26, 1862 and educated at King's College, London.

The Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest offers a $100 grand prize and fifty honorable mention prizes of $5 each for the best photographs of outdoor life (except athletic contests and games) taken by amateurs. Open to amateurs anywhere. Deadline for mailing entries-midnight, Feb. 12.
Despite a grand rally by Willie Hoppe of New York, Jake Schaefer of Chicago maintained a lead of 133 points last night in their 28.2 balkline billiard match at the Strand Academy.

Arturo Toscanini, symphonic conductor, who resigned his post last year as director of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, will return to this country late this year for a series of radio broadcast concerts, it was announced yesterday by David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America and-chairman of the board of-NBC.

Loyalist columns in Southern Spain, driving toward the Malaga coastal front, captured the towns of Montoro and Villefrance de Cordoba in a sweeping advance against the Rebels, reports from Andujar said today. [Montoro is about twenty-five miles northeast of Cordoba and 150 miles northeast of Malaga.

President Roosevelt's proposals for a comprehensive reform of the Federal judiciary fell today like a bombshell upon a Congress which thought it already had experienced the ultimate in surprises when it heard his recent messages on reorganization of the executive branch.

The United Fruit Company and its subsidiaries earned $14,176,995 after expenses, interest, depreciation, loss on fixed assets sold or retired and $2,142,960 provision for United States and foreign taxes, including undistributed profits tax and other charges, according to the annual statement for 1936, made public today.

St. Valentine's Kettledrum, New York's oldest "charity fair," held annually to aid the Samaritan Home for the Aged, which this year celebrates the seventieth anniversary of its founding, will take place this afternoon in the ballroom suite of the Plaza.

Construction of a six-story apartment house at 168 Grand Street, White Plains, will begin as soon as the existing structure is demolished. The builders purchased the property, which measures 60 by 125 feet, from Mrs. Anna Rooney. Warren W. Maslen was the broker.

The consolidated-mortgage 5 per cent bonds of the Baldwin Locomotive Works due in 1938 jumped a maximum of 51 points on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, a gain which was without precedent, at least in recent years.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday formally requested Governor Lehman to issue the necessary emergency message to the Legislature for quick passage of the three acts needed to make possible the city's pay restoration plan, which was unanimously approved Wednesday by the Board of Estimate.

President Roosevelt sent to Congress a message and a draft of a bill to effect drastic reform of the Federal courts. The Senate received the Presidential message and draft of legislation for judicial reform, approved a resolution asking the Federal Reserve Board its reason for increasing reserve requirements, and adjourned at 12:45 P. M. until noon Monday.
Sir Harry Mallaby-Deeley died today at the Chateau des Fayeres of pneumonia. The Baronet was 73 years old.

President Roosevelt, with two new battleships to name, is considering the claims of thirty-three States not represented in the navy's battle line. His decision must be made before keels are laid in June for the two new $50,000,000 steamdriven dreadnoughts.

The ninety-seventh annual concert and charity ball of the Emerald Association of Brooklyn, held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of orphan asylums in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and Long Island, was one of the largest and most successful in the association's existence.

A $100,000 example was given to the Supreme Court jury hearing evidence in the restaurant racket trial yesterday by Hyman Gross, who had been one of the owners of the Gerard Cafeteria, on Broadway at Times Square, which was closed by a stench bombardment ten months after it opened.
Until the President's message to Congress recommending reorganization of the judicia?? became known at midday, the share market developed moderate strength yesterday.

Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop on his return from Germany is letting no grass grow under his feet before taking up here questions of foreign policy which interest the Reich. He has already sought an appointment at the Foreign Office, and in Anthony Eden's absence will probably see Viscount Halifax, who is sitting in as Acting Foreign Secretary.

Edward J. Fox, former justice of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania and president of the Easton Trust Company for the last twenty-three years, died at his home here tonight after suffering a stroke. His age was 78. Judge Fox,

The Federal Communications Commission recessed today until Feb. 15 its public investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company after hearing a contention that the utility acquired control of associated companies by forcing out minority stockholders.
Contracts on cotton cloth for the army clothing factory, on which bids were opened at the quartermaster depot a few days ago under Invitation 172, today were awarded as follows:

The problem of sanitation, mopping-up and emergency reconstruction in the wake of the OhioMississippi flood brought announcement yesterday from officials of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross that the campaign for contributions for flood relief would be continued here after the New York Chapter's quota of $1,500,000 had been reached.

Mr. and Mrs. William H. Davis will sail today on the Carinthia for Nassau, B. W. I., where they will remain until the end of the month. Mr. and Mrs. Ledyard Heckscher have come from Radnor, Pa., to the Gotham. Mrs. Alexander C. Barker and her daughter, Miss Frederica Barker, have gone to Canada for Winter sports in the Laurentian Mountains.

Representative George Holden Tinkham, Massachusetts Republican, won a directed verdict in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today in the $500,000 libel suit brought against him by Bishop James Cannon Jr. of the Methodist Episcopal Church South.
Following are the text of the President's message to Congress on the judiciary, the draft of his pro-. posed bill and the text of the letter of Attorney General Cummings to the President:

Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska, after expressing surprise over President Roosevelt's judiciary reform message, said that he thought a "much simpler plan" would be for Congress to require at least a twothirds majority in cases involving constitutional questions.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was generally only fair. The smaller independent killers were forced to take 50c-$1 off steer hinds and ribs in order to move accumulations. Some of the larger packers reduced prices 50c. Veal and calf cuts were steady. Other classes were strong to higher. All kosher markets opened higher.
Joe Gould, manager of heavyweight champion Jimmy Braddock, said last night he would not go to Chicago Monday to sign for a Braddock-Joe Louis fight as he had planned.

A 72-year-old great - grandmother joined union pickets today in front of Fisher Body Plant No. 1, held by sit-down strikers. She was Mrs. Rebecca Goddard of Clio, Mich., who said she had nine or ten relatives, including a son, inside the plant.
West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, of which the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin has been the pastor for thirty-two years, will open a School of Life tomorrow evening.

All this busy while the Committee of Ways and Means kept before them the hope of a house of their very own--a real House in which to settle down for keeps--and took trains on rails and horsed carriages of the age to seek it.

Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Beebe of Hill Top, Wallingford, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Beebe, to Leslie Q. Miller of Bronxville, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. S. Miller of Spokane, Wash.

Lucrezia Bori, former Metropolitan Opera soprano, yesterday received the yearly award of the Alumni Association of the Graduate School of Columbia University. At the last meeting of the association Miss Bori was chosen for the honor.
Frederick H. Rawson, Chicago banker and philanthropist, who had been living at Pasadena, Calit., since his retirement in 1933 because of ill health, died early today at his West Coast home.

When the Midwinter meeting of the National Baseball League opened yesterday morning a published report in a magazine stating that John L. Lewis might attempt to organize a baseball players' union lay on President Ford Frick's desk.

In a bit of a hurry so that he may enjoy a rest today, George Dunn took on one more opponent than required to by the tournament officials and became the first finalist in the Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis championship competition at the 369th Regiment Armory yesterday.

A special subcommittee recommended to the Ten-State Conference on Flood Control tonight the creation of a permanent interstate commission of the Ohio River Basin to coordinate flood prevention and allied projects.

The State Banking Department today announced that the Bank Clerks Cooperative Building and Loan Association of New York City had been converted into the Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association, pursuant to Section 497 of the Banking Law.

A concert for the benefit of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress will be given tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The concert was arranged to finance the promotion of better understanding between Jews and non-Jews. Mrs. Jacob M. Ross heads the concert committee.

Setting a fast pace. Konstantv Kempisty of Manual Training High finished first by fifteen yards in the 880-yard senior race, feature of the track and field meet sponsored by Lincoln High School at the New Jersey National Guard Armory in Jersey City last night.

President Roosevelt's message to Congress asking for authority to appoint Federal judges in addition to those more than 70 years old was characterized last night by Herbert Hoover, his predecessor in the White House, as a proposal for "packing" the Supreme Court to get through New Deal measures.

After winning considerable admiration during the past two years for his able acting in various parts, Maurice Evans now deserves a sort of reverence for his triumphant performance as King Richard II, which was put on at the St. James last evening.

The President suddenly, at noon today, cut through the tangle of proposals made by his Congressional leaders to "bring legislative and judicial action into closer harmony" with a broadaxe message to Congress recommending the passage of statutes to effect drastic Federal court reforms.

The discharge of Morris Watson, an editorial employee of The Associated Press, may result in a "major industrial conflagration," it was asserted today by the American Newspaper Guild, intervening in the fight of The Associated Press against the Wagner National Labor Relations Act in the Supreme Court.
The National Conference for Palestine, said to represent 2,000,000 American Jews, will meet here tomorrow evening to voice their concern for the future of the Jewish National Home in Palestine.

A furniture merchandising course for men and women now selling on the floors of retail establishments in the metropolitan area here, will be launched next Wednesday night at the Furniture World Educational Institute in the New York Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue.

A Department of Correction guard in pursuit of a convict escaping from a prison van parked outside Yorkville Court, 157 East Fifty-seventh Street, shot and seriously wounded a passer-by at 10:14 A. M. yesterday.
John H. Whelen Jr., a broker of Philadelphia, accompanied by his wife, left today on a trip in the Peruvian jungles to hunt jaguars.

While the storm slowed up retail trade activity here somewhat yesterday, sales earlier in the week were reported as good. Some department stores-here had increases ranging up to 10 per cent or mere over the comparative 1936 period, executives said. Consumer response to seasonal ready-to-wer clearances picked up with the fall in temperatures.

Alfred S. Rossin of 40 East Sixtyeighth Street has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Carol Rossin, to Charles S. Rosenthal of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max Rosenthal of Dixon, Ill.

Thursday evening of next week looks like the red-letter night of that hebdomadal session, what with it being a holiday eve (always as good as a Saturday night), and likewise the scheduled date for the opening of a brand new show at the Paradise Restaurant and the debut of Mitzi Mayfair at the Versailles.

The Russian reply, presented today to Lord Plymouth, chairman of the International Committee for Non-Intervention in Spain, throws out of gear the whole work of this body and may have far-reaching consequences for the European situation.

Archibald Barklie, sportsman and banker, died tonight in Bryn Mawr Hospital, just three weeks after the death of his wife, Mrs. Isabel Armstrong Barklie, society hostess. Mr. Barklie, who was 73, lived in Wayne with his sister. Mrs. Henry Darcy.

The appointment of Sir Neville Henderson, British Ambassador to Buenos Aires, to the Embassy in Berlin was officially confirmed tonight. He will succeed Sir Eric Phipps, who will go to Paris to become Ambassador there in place of Sir George Clerk.

A former Assistant United States Attorney General tonight asserted that President Roosevelt's proposal to permit enlarging the United States Supreme Court from nine to fifteen members would "intensify the controversy" between the executive and judicial branches of the government.

The government has issued a decree laying down regulations for more efficient control and expenditure of revenues accruing from unemployment taxation. In the future no work may be started from these funds without prior approval by the government.

The Bishop of London, the Rev. Arthur F. Winnington-Ingram, attacked all forms of pacifism in a speech today before a Church of England assembly, which then adopted a resolution approving the government's preparedness policy.

In the face of the warning by Park Commissioner Robert Moses that the proposed construction of a $1,200,000 spur track from the Queens Independent Subway System into the World's Fair site would be "extravagant and wastefil,". Mayor La Guardia called a committee meeting yesterday for Monday to consider the project.
Some time ago President ROOSEVELT announced that "the official spokesman" for his administration had

Millions of dollars in transfer taxes in this State will be an issue when Surrogate James A. Foley hears an appeal on March 3 from an order fixing the tax in the estate of Mrs. Alice Gwynne Vanderbilt.

Following is editorial comment from various parts of the country on President Roosevelt's proposal for reorganization of the Federal judiciary. The tone of many papers is critical and in some cases denunciatory.

The question whether the Board of Education should be permitted to hire special architects to expedite the preparation of school plans and school construction raised a storm yesterday at a Board of Estimate meeting at City Hall.

Germain Glidden, national singles champion of the Harvard Club and Donald Grant of the Heights Casino were eliminated from the invitation doubles squash racquets tournament for the Lockett Trophy last night at the University Club.

A strong demand for iron and steel products by the general industry, with an urgent call for raw materials by domestic steel mills, caused an increase of imports of semi-finished and finished iron and steel products into the United States last year, the Department of Commerce made known today.

The Five West Eighty-sixth Street Corporation, Irving Broff president, filed yesterday plans for a nineteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 5-11 West Eightysixth Street, near Central Park West. The building,

Francis La Monaca, Italian sculptor who arrived Tuesday evening from New York, was found dead in his bed at the Mayflower Hotel shortly before 11 o'clock this morning. According to the hotel physician, death was caused by a heart attack. His age was 49.
Stockholders of Anglo-Canadian Telephone have approved the redemption on May 1 of the company's outstanding $3,300,000 of 7 per cent $50-par preferred stock at $55 a share and accrued dividends.

Williams (Doc) Newton, for the last five years coach at Davidson College, signed a five-year contract today as head football coach at North Carolina State College. The announced salary was $6,000 a year.

Recommendations that the State Unemployment Insurance Law be amended to simplify its recordkeeping provisions and raise the weekly unemployment benefit payments from $5 to $7 were sent to Governor Lehman yesterday by the New York Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council, of which Herman A. Gray is chairman.

The United States liner Washington arrived yesterday thirty-six hours late as a result of freakish water conditions. Captain Giles Stedman said the vessel left Hamburg nearly two days late because of : unprecedented tidal conditions in the Elbe River keeping the water shallow.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, commended the press and the radio for a generally wholesome influence as factors in the formation of character, while deprecating motion pictures as "not so good," before the convention of the City Federation of Women's Clubs yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

Chief Justice Louis Wendel of the City Court swore in Frank A. Carlin as City Court justice yesterday morning, and in another ceremony in the afternoon was the recipient of a ten-piece bronze desk set presented by the City Court Attaches Benevolent Association.

The stock markets generally were cheerful today, although some irregularity deVeloped.in spots as the week's business was wound up. Gilt-edged issues stood out as one of the strongest features of the day's dealings and achieved fresh all-round improvement.

A short circuit in a heater under the seat in one of the cars of a B. M. T. West End line local train near the Myrtle Avenue station in Brooklyn caused a six-minute delay at 10:15 A. M. yesterday and some discomfort to passengers.

Memories of King George V's historic visit to Belfast. in 1921 were revived yesterday by an official announcement that George VI and Queen Elizabeth would pay a state visit to the capital of Northern Ireland July 28, as soon as the coronation festivities in London have ended.

The State Mortgage Commission announced yesterday that it had appointed as its General Attorney Professor Maurice Finkelstein, who will take the place of Benjamin J. Rabin, recently made chairman of the commission.
Four large State Street department stores announced today that their employes would be placed on a sixday, forty-hour work week basis starting Monday.

Statistically speaking, the Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest sponsored by the New York Times Wide World Photos, Inc., and the National Sportsmen's Show has assumed rather surprising proportions. So much so that the judges, all busy men, are envisaging the task before them with a bit of apprehension.

The Iranian Parliament today ratified the concession for vast oil developments recently given an American group sponsored by Seaboard Oil Company of. Delaware; Case, Pomeroy Co., banking firm, and Ogden Mills, former American Secretary of the Treasury.

Don G. Abel, State Works Progress Administration director, today announced dismissal of 1,700 "sitdown" strikers on twenty-five projects in this county. The strikes, called by the Workers Alliance of Washington, are part of a campaign for union wage scales.
Following are comments of members of Congress on the President's court proposals:

Winning six of the eight events, Fordham's swimming team decisively defeated the Brooklyn College natators, 53 to 18, in a dual meet in the Ram pool yesterday. It was the third triumph in seven starts this season for the Maroon mermen, who previously had dropped four meets in a row.

After making amiable plans to move on Monday to the Fortyfourth Street Theatre, "Tide Rising" decided yesterday that it wouldn't bother after all. It will close this evening at the Lyceum, at the end of sixteen performances, having the dubious honor of being the only departure of the current week.

The Broadway war which for months has raged around the Bureau of New Plays yesterday entered a new phase when Walter Prichard Eaton-formerly one of its sponsors-withdrew his name with a mutter of "commercial chicanery."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Albert Gallatin Wheeler, retired New York financier, died today at his Bonita Hills residence. His age was 61. His father was the late Albert Gallatin Wheeler Sr., president of the Automatic Telephone Company of Chicago and builder of the Chicago tube.

Commodity futures showed wide variations in moderately active trading on the local commodity markets yesterday. Cocoa futures fell 48 to 53 points on further liquidation, and silks, hides, sugar and lead futures also lost ground. Rubber futures advanced 9 to 12 points, with coffee and copper contracts also recording gains.

Max Strolowsky, 23 years old, of 801 Riverside Drive, who, admitted that he could not resist stealing automobiles to impress his female acquaintances, received a ten to twenty-year sentence in Sing Sing yesterday from Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions.

Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., the current New York State champion, and Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, runner-up for the national title in 1935, reached the final for the annual Miami Biltmore women's golf championship today.

Prison sentences of three to eight years each were imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Nott on A. Henry Ross, 28 years old, a lawyer, of 2,069 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, and Max D. Krone, 34, a former private detective of 255 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Herbert Wechaler of New York Qity was admitted to practice today and the following proceedmngs were had: 454-Jay B. Phelps, aplt., v. Board of Education of the Town of West New York et al.:

Mrs. Grace Anna Collier Hunt, a child pianist in England and Chicago in the Seventies, died yesterday in her home, 400 West 146th Street, after a long illness. Mrs. Hunt was the wife of Dr. Leigh Harrison Hunt, Emeritus Professor of Art at the College of the City of New York, etcher and art critic. Her age was 72.

The President, controlling the executive, legislative and judicial departments of government, would become a dictator under the program in today's message to Congress, William F. Bleakley declared tonight.

Eight foodless days of utter darkness while lost in the debris-choked passageways of an abandoned mine ended today for Robert Johnson, 36-year-old rural mail carrier. "I sure thought I was a goner," he said.

Thomas D. Flynn of the Bayside Tennis Club, seeded No. 8, led the field into the semi-final round of the Monte Sterling Trophy squash tennis tourney by defeating Franklin V. Brodil of the Columbia University Club, 15--13, 15--11, at the New York A. C. yesterday.
President ROOSEVELT surprised Congress and the country yesterday by a message, with an accompanying bill, urging sweeping reforms in the Federal judiciary. For some of them he argued plausibly.
Four consistent opponents of administration legislation are among the six Supreme Court members who could retire at full pay under the plan advocated today by President Roosevelt.

The American Export liner Excambion reached here today, delayed four days on its voyage from the Mediterranean by winds that reached 105 miles an hour and seas that ran 35 feet high. Smashed windows, twisted ventilators and other damage bore witness to the fury of the storm.
Dean Richard M. Gummerie of Harvard, on inspecting the flood army mobilized in Memphis, said: "The sight of this city organized to face disaster makes an American glow with national pride."

Circuit Court Judge Paul V. Gadola issued a writ of body attachment today commanding Sheriff Thomas Wolcott of Genesee County to arrest all the sit-down strikers in possession of Fisher Body plants Nos. 1 and 2, all the pickets in front of No. 1, and fifteen officers of the United Automobile Workers, including Homer S. Martin, president.

Opponents of appointment of Dr. Roswell G. Ham of Yale as the first male president of Mount Holyoke College refused to retreat from their stand tonight in the face of charges that they represented only a minority of the alumnae.

Presidential plans and messages which gave rise to serious alarm in banking circles have not been rare in recent years, but there was a different quality to yesterday's response of the banking community to the news of the President's plans for changes in the judicial system.
New paintings by Georgia O'Keeffe were placed on view yesterday at An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, directed by Alfred Stieglitz. This one-man show will be current until March 17.
A story of wrecked hopes and aspirations, "Because We Must," by a new dramatist, Ingaret Giffard, produced at Wyndham's Theatre tonight, preaches the stern necessities of compromise.

Admiral Arthur J. Hepburn, Commander-in-Chief of the United States fleet, asserted in a statement today that defense is the major objective of the joint ArmyNavy-Marine Corps war games about San Clemente Island.

Miss Virginia Marie Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Ward of 27 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to Frank Lee McGratty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McGratty, also of Brooklyn, in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.

Dr. William E. Grady, Associate Superintendent of Schools in charge of vocational education, was honored yesterday by the Vocational High and Continuation School Teachers Association and school officials in recognition of his "outstanding contribution to adult and vocational education."
Max Herzberg of Jackson Heights has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Alice Beatrice Herzberg, to Victor Robert Galea, son of Professor Robert V.. Galea of Malta and Mrs. Galea.

DESPITE the lengthening of daylight hours as the sun moves northward, recent afternoon tuning on the popular 49-meter wave band has been excellent for reception of lowpowered European stations. On three consecutive days the elusive short-wave transmitters in both Denmark and Yugoslavia were heard in the East with fair volume.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sidney Johnstone of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna Hill Johnstone, to Curville J. Robinson of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Curville C. Robinson of Richmond.
Miss Helen Elizabeth Member, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rolland Edgar Member of this place, was married this afternoon to John E. Hopkins, son of Mrs. Gerald Hopkins of Haddonfield.
CARLOS CHAVEZ, third and last in the series of Philharmonic-Symphony guest-condUctors, will take over the orchestra for two weeks beginning Thursday night.

National advertising campaigns, which have been seriously retarded by the floods, strikes and adverse weather conditions in many seetions of the country, will be resumed on a large scale by the end of this month, it was indicated in advertising circles yesterday, as some of the difficulties began to disappear.

Niagara Chapter, Daughters of the British Empire, of which Mrs. William D. Heaton is Regent, will give a bridge tea on Feb. 16 at the Roosevelt Hotel for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women, at Ossining, N. Y.
For a while things looked very bad yesterday for J. Norman Anderson Jr. of Dartmouth in his semifinal round singles match in the Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis championship tournament.

Clara Lang, soprano, was heard in a song recital at Town Hall last night. Miss Lang made her debut here several seasons ago, and before that had sung with the San Carlo Opera Company. Her program was composed of offerings in Italian, German, French and English.
SCULPTURE continues to play a prominent part in the local ex hibition realm, the week just concluded having added several interesting attractions to the list.
To acquaint students with various types of life work, and assist them in preparing for careers, Wilson College will observe vocational week from Tuesday to Saturday, with addresses and conferences.

Whirling up from fourth to first with an inexorable drive a lap from the finish, Glenn Cunningham, the old master, won the Wanamaker Mile at Madison Square Garden last night while a capacity gathering of 16,000 shrieked frantically at the thrill of the race and then groaned disappointedly at the time.
AILMENT: "The world today is not so much in need of skill as of character. We do not lack ability so much as we lack purpose."-Dr. Henry Merrit Wriston.

ONLY the records bear convincing testimony to the fact that Harry Watrous has attained the age of fourscore years. In conversation no clues are offered, nor does his painting-so fresh and firm and assured-indicate at any time the touch of a brushmanship grown venerable.
FASINATING photographs come to us, every now and then, of a great herd of an telope in swift passage across the jungle-girt plains of farthest Africa.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: The controversy over Mr. John Corbin's review of Mr. Morris Ernst's "The Ultimate Power" has reached the stage where some one ought to intervene with a further word about the book itself. Much of the actual material of the book has, I think, been rather neglected, in the review and elsewhere.

THE customers at a Queens cinema house were standing T six deep in the top and lower portions of the theatre last Wednesday night. Twenty persons out of 215,000 chances scattered throughout this and nineteen other houses-meaning that there would be "twenty sure winners" in twenty theatres-were slated to divide $1,500.
New York's first aviation show in seven years closed last night at Grand Central Palace with sales of planes and equipment estimated by G. A. Parsons, director, at more than $1,000,000.

Sixteen chapters will be represented at the annual convention of Eastern alumnae of Trinity College, Washington, to be held in the clubrooms of the New York Chapter at the Barbizon on Saturday and Sunday. A panel discussion on Catholic Action is planned for Saturday, under the direction of Miss Antonia McInnis of Boston, and with Miss Ellen Ganey and Miss M. Pauline Casey as speakers.

Connecticut Power The Connecticut Power Company for 1936 reports a net profit of $1,741,418 after depreciation, Federal taxes, interest, amortization, , equivalent to $2.63 a share on the 662,791 shares of common stock.

The Pomfret hockey team triumphed over Westminster by 2-0 in a fast and thrilling game today. Pomfret's defense held the Westminster forwards at bay while Feitner, center, and King, star left wing, accounted for the goals.
Jake Schaefer of Chicago won his match against Willie Hoppe of New York by 204 points in the newest type of billiard game, 28.2 balkline, as the competition ended at the Strand Academy yesterday.

The governing body of the International Labor Organization today authorized study of the question of just and equitable treatment of immigrants and the convoking of an international conference of experts to examine the possibility of financing immigration.

Miss Athalia Stearns Ogden, daughter of Mrs. Archibald Gracie Ogden of this place and the late Mr. Ogden, was married here this afternoon in St. John's Church to Dr. Robert Howard Barker of Boston, son of Mrs. Raymond Howard Barker of Cleveland and the late Mr. Barker.

ONE social problem at least Hollywood faces unafraid. It is the problem of great wealth. While tax experts, soapbox speakers, . moralists, rich men and poor men alike regard large riches with considerable
Stocks recovered half of Friday's losses and closed strong; steel and rail shares leaders; sales, 1,453,480 shares.

Trim in the blue and gold uniform of an admiral of the fleet, King George VI stood stiffly last Thursday in the Throne Room of Buckingham Palace. Around him were ranged the Ambassadors and Ministers from other countries, there for the ceremony of presenting their letters of credence.

Miss Marie Louise von Goldberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. H. G. von Goldberg of Bala, was married this afternoon to Dr. John Zenas Preston of Tryon, N. C., son of John Zenas Preston of Jacksonville, Fla, and the late Mrs. Preston.

Three New York fui dealers who received last week a shipment of Persian lambskins valued at $100,000 from British Southwest Africa agreed yesterday to ship the merchandise out of the country and also to pay $5,000 each as a penalty.

Last May a price war broke out among New York liquor dealers, whose sniping, attack and counter-attack demolished retail prices. The consumer, somewhere in an alcoholic No Man's Land, found the battle to his liking, for it leveled to humble purses the haughtiest of gin, vermouth, rye, bourbon and Scotch.

Colonel Adelno Gibson, U.S.A., and Mrs. Gibson of Governors Island have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Adele Gibson, to Robert Murray Field, son of Major Robert Baxter Field, U.S.A., and Mrs. Field.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Schenck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Corle Schenck of Metuchen, N. J., was married today to Raymond Einnon Thomas, son of Mrs. John Thomas and the late Mr. Thomas of Yonkers, N. Y. The ceremony
Movements of vessels follow, all dates being Feb. 5, unless specified: San Clemente Island to San Diego: Antares, Bridge, New York, Utah, Wyoming. At Kingston, Feb. 6: Bass, Bonita.

Reversing the result of the recent national championship final, E. M. (Ted) Edwards and Warren Ingersoll of Philadelphia defeated C. C. Pell Jr. and Robert Grant 3d of New York in the annual intercity racquets doubles at the Racquet Club today.

The success of Yale's undergraduate string orchestra, organized this year, has shown in its two concerts that there are among present-day students musicians of considerable skill and that undergraduate audiences are highly appreciative of their efforts.

Delegations from nine States set up a special Ohio Basin commission today to coordinate flood prevention work, after rejecting a proposal to ask the Federal Government to assume full responsibility for financing and directing an Ohio Valley flood control program.

Legacies were left to nine public organizations by Henry E. Gregory, a New York attorney, according to his will filed in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court today. Mr. Gregory resided in Scarsdale. He died Jan. 23.

Additional blanket prices for Fall delivery will be made tomorrow when lines are shown at the Linen and Domestics Show at the Hotel New Yorker. Little in the way of business can be placed, however, as most mills now cannot make delivery this side of September and October.

After an object lesson of seven lean years during which at times curtailed revenues could not keep step with expenditures, the State of New York now is preparing to spend $1,000,000 a day, Sundays and legal holidays included, during the next fiscal year, beginning July 1.

President Roosevelt has endorsed "Brotherhood Day," Feb. 20 and 21, under the auspices of the National Conference of Jews and Christians. "Brotherhood Day" will be observed in the synagogues Feb. 20 and in the churches Feb. 21.
Charles E. Stuart, a steel executive, died tonight at his home here at the age of 57. He suffered a stroke Wednesday. Born in Montreal, Mr. Stuart moved with his family to Buffalo, N. Y., as a boy.
A new loan of 180,000,000 schillings will be floated by the Austrian Government within the next few weeks for public works.

The Federal Child Labor Amendment, which would give Congress the power to regulate, limit and prohibit the labor of persons under 18 years, is increasingly debated Since President Roosevelt, at the beginning of the year, appealed to the States for ratification, two States, Kentucky and Nevada, have taken this step and in New York last week the Senate voted to ratify.

Circulation of library books among Middlebury College faculty and students has increased appreciably, according to Wyman Parker, acting librarian. The average student is borrowing two more books a month for home study than he did last year, while faculty members have increased their quota by three.

MIAMI, Fla.-Entries in the fourth annual Miami-Nassau race, which will be started here at noon on Tuesday, are expected to include Water Witch, owned by L. W. MacFarland, which was the winner of this event in 1936 and placed third in both the 1984 and 1935 races;
TODAY Music of the Theatre presents Margaret Daum, soprano; Ruth Carhart, contralto; William Perry, tenor, and Hubert Hendrie and Russell Dorr, baritones: WABC, 2-2:45 P. M.

The Weather Bureau forecast of partly cloudy skies and slightly, colder weather today instead of the snow predicted in an earlier report last night was gratefully received by the Sanitation Department, which still has 12,000 men clearing away the last snowfall.
One Girl Scout of the 16,000 troop members in the five boroughs will be proclaimed champion cookie baker in the Greater New York Federation, following a contest to be held on Friday.

Five officials of the Big Five railroad unions Were cited today by Federal Judge Charles E. Woodward to appear before him at 2 P. M. Monday on a contempt charge for calling a strike of 1,800 operating employes of the Chicago Great Western Railroad, effective at 6 A. M. Tuesday.

Six narcotics dealers were executed today in a sudden renewal of Peiping's anti-opium campaign. The executions brought to twelve the number of narcotics dealers who have died in public ceremonies since the drive began New Year's Day.

The Fordham University quintet turned back Army, 37-28, today in a fast-moving contest which was one of the highlights of a stellar sports program at the Military Academy. The Cadet poloists fared better, routing Harvard, 12-6, for their twenty-eighth consecutive triumph.
Net assets of the Plymouth Fund, Inc., according to the company's annual report, at the close of last year, stood at $239,630, without giving effect to $387 of appreciation in market value over cost.

The opportunity to participate in an old-fashioned Viennese waltz contest, as well as to-aid the maintenance of one of the oldest charitable institutions in the city, has led many members of society, to subscribe to the supper dance being held tomorrow night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery.

The School Settlement Association, 120 Jackson Street, Brooklyn, will be aided by an Eastern fashion show, to be held on the afternoon E of March 19 at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Mrs. Tremper Longman is chairman of the benefit, and Mrs. Walter Scott Robinson is president of the School Settlement Association.

Come what may of the Yankees' current difficulties in getting some of their outstanding stars to accept what they insist are adequate and reasonable salary terms, the world champions will inaugurate the 1937 American League pennant race on April 20 at the Stadium, according to the official schedule released for publication today.

The new technique of the sit-down strike was brought to a peak of perfection here. A few hundred men by sitting down in each of three plants which employ more than 20,000 workers stopped the wheels of production in this automobile city, where normally from 45,000 to 50,000 are employed at this time of year under current business coneditions.

Religious instructors in the public schools in the Province of Anhalt have received orders to suggest in their teaching that Christ could not have been Jewish, to emphasize that He fought the "Jewish spirit" and not to use the Old Testament any more than necessary except as a demonstation of the breakdown of a race that "refused to receive God."

The long and powerful legs of Richard Werner, who represents the Blue Bird S. C., carried him to a brilliant triumph and the men's title in the Middle Atlantic Association's outdoor skating championships held on Orange Lake, near here, today.
TRADE activity expanded in most sections of the country last week, with urban business registering the beat gains.
America's lone musher in the ninety-mile Laconia Dog Derby trailed four Canadians tonight at the close of the second day's run of the three-day contest.

A broader base for taxes and a maximum basic rate of $1.75 on real estate in New York City 'to assist in business recovery are urged by Ivor B. Clark, head of the realty and mortgage firm bearing his name.

Old and young associates gathered yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor at a testimonial luncheon for Miss Maude Simmons, chief hearing stenographer of the New York State Industrial Commission of the New York State Department of Labor, who will retire March 16, after being in the employ of the State since 1905.

The University Extension division of the Columbia School of Architecture will add courses in illumination of buildings, contemporary interior materials and color, specification writing, construction cost trends and housing development to its present curriculum during the Spring session.

Schiaparelli has an unusual collection dedicated to the things around us. She puts styles knee-deep in Spring, with lush flowers, bees, birds on branches and ripe pineapples printed on fresh, light-colored silks.
Miss Petra M. Aaroe of 1,120 Park Avenue, a nurse with the French and American armies during the World War, died yesterday in the Park East Hospital after an operation. She was 50 years old.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is transfer agent for 300,000 shares of the Pharis Tire Rubber Company capital stock. Lancaster Norvin Greene, Inc., has prepared an analysis of the General Alloys Company Class A cumulative 7 per cent preferred stock of $10 par value.

Sinking fund operations, calling for the retirement of parts of issues outstanding, raised last week the volume of notices of bonds called for redemption before maturity above the total of the preceding comparable period.

A good demand for Brooklyn real- client ty was indicated yesterday by investment buying of houses. The activity was featured by resales. Malibu Properties, Inc., which a year ago bought the six-story elevator apartment house at 8,000 Fourth Avenue, resold the property to the Granville Management Corportion, represented by Max Olester.

Price movements In commodity futures were irregular in trading on local markets last week. Coffee futures advanced to new highs for the season and rubber and copper futures also gained. Cocoa futures suffered a further severe break which established prices at new lows for the current move.

Miss Anne Virginia Wrightson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis German Wrightson, and Stephen Cook Thayer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Thayer of Cleveland, were married today at St. Matthew's Protestant Episcopal Church, in suburban Sparrows Point.

Another in the series of entertainments for the benefit of sufferers in the flood disaster will take place Tuesday during the luncheon hour in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. An elaborate fashion revue entitled "The Twenty and Forty Style Revue" will be presented.

The New York Rangers will seek to advance a step closer to the top of the heap in the American group of the National Hockey League when they skate against their old rivals, the Maroons of Montreal, at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Alarmed lest the settlement of the Arab Jewish question in Pales. tine involve a "parity," which theo hold prejudicial to Jewish interests, 257 Orthodox rabbis from this country and Canada announced a resolu. tion of protest yesterday through Rabbi Jacob Levinson of 832 East. ern Parkway, Brooklyn.
In one of the most thrilling games witnessed in the Morningside Heights gymnasium in several years Columbia gained a 50-48 victory over Navy last night.

THE two-acre hothouse of the New York Botanical Garden which rises up like a crystal temple in Bronx Park will be completely renovated within the next few months in order to repair damage done to the structure by the weathernot outer, but inner weather.

STREAMLINING has invaded the model railway field. Offering dramatic proof of this newest rail hobby development, a tiny scale-model Diesel-powered train will be featured at the ninth annual exhibit of the New York Society of Model Engineers, opening tomorrow at 152 West Fortysecond Street.

President Roosevelt's message to Congress, so far as it applies to the Supreme Court, was criticized yesterday by Frederic R. Coudert, constitutional and international lawyer. Mr. Coudert held that passage of the legislation suggested by the President would force the retirement of the justices over 70 or result in an enlargement of the court from nine to fifteen.
There is skiing on the Berkshire mountains, the first of the year. Residents of Mount Washington, Southern Berkshires, report ten inches of snow In the Guilder pond and Plantain. pond sections.
With his flight around South America in his "air yacht" almost completed, William K. Vanderbilt and his party landed here this afternoon after an uneventful trip from Lima, Peru.

The aim and method of a Mount Holyoke education, studied from the faculty, trustee and alumna viewpoints, will be the central theme of the annual alumnae council here March 5, 6 and 7. About 100 alumnae, representing some forty clubs throughout the country and groups in Hawaii, China, Japan and India, will take part in the program.

The Peddie School five today defeated Poly Prep, 40 to 17. This was Peddie's fourth league victory and strengthened its lead over Trinity for first place in the Eastern Private School Basketball League. Persons was high scorer for Peddie, totaling 13 points.
ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 6.-The marriage of Miss Mary Anne Arnott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Arnott of this city, to Robert MacDonald of Orange took place this evening at the Arnott home.

Scoring in each of the three periods, the Andover Academy hockey team defeated its ancient rival, Exeter, for the second straight year, squeezing out a 3-2 decision in the twentythird annual game between the two schools today at the Boston Arena.
C. H. Polley of Buffalo and Neil Sullivan of Philadelphia moved into the final round of the Canadian squash racquets championship today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William E. Sims of 103 East Seventy-fifth Street and Monroe, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Elizabeth Sims, to William Wheeler Bainbridge, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Seaman Bainbridge of 34 Gramercy Park and Bethel, Conn.

English and French furniture and other furnishings, diamond jewelry, Georgian silver and objects of art, comprising property of Mrs. Julia C. Lyle, contained in Springwood, her home at Tenafly, N. J., property of C. Ruxton Love Jr. and other owners, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

In Flint on Tuesday Circuit Judge Paul Vincent Gadola, 50 years old, war veteran, Republican, Exalted Ruler of the Flint Elks, Past President of the Flint Eagles, an enemy of communism, recently an investigator of the Black Legion, always a strict enforcer of the motor vehicle laws, and--so far as union agents could ascertain--not a stockholder of General Motors, granted the prayer of that corporation for an injunction.

George H. Worthington Jr.. formerly associated with Louis Trilsch of the Worthington Agency, Inc., has opened his own office at 163-05 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, under the name of Worthington Agency. He also maintains an office at 149-30 15th Av.. Whitestone.

The first touch of real Winter has reached the Cornell campus. For students engrossed in their midWinter final examinations the snow and ice are welcome harbingers for the success of Cornell's Junior Week which will begin at the end of examinations on Wednesday evening, and which will continue until the resumption of classes on Feb. 15.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-The seventh annual Atlantic Coast women's squash racquets championship will be held on the courts at ChalfonteHaddon Hall here on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia is the defending titleholder. Among the contenders will be a team of British stars.

A resolution urging Yale University to reappoint Jerome Davis, Professor of Practical Philanthropy in the Yale Divinity School, was adopted unanimously yesterday by more than 2,000 persons attending a twentieth anniversary celebration of the Teachers Union in the Hotel Astor.

The British Cabinet, assembling this week for the first time since Chancellor Adolf Hitler made his declaration to the German Reichstag, considered the European situation in the light of that speech but took no action thereon.

Senator Maximiano Errazuriz, head of a committee of Chilean business men who will make an industrial study in Japan next month, conferred today with Finance Minister Gustavo Ross and Foreign Minister Miguel Cruchaga Tocornal concerning the project.

The final selection of Port Chester's Spanish War Memorial, the subject of a long dispute, will be made tomorrow night in the sculpture studio and workshop of the sculpture division of the WPA Federal Art Project, 6 East Thirtyninth Street.
HAROLD STEARNS has been through many phases of which it may be predicted the one represented in this book is not the last. As a journalist he had a brilliant prewar career.

Payrolls in Rocky Mountain and Pacific Coast iron and steel plants last year rose 55 per cent over the 1935 total, according to a report by the American Iron and Steel Institute. Total disbursements for wages topped $17,000,000 in 1936, against $11,000,000 in the year before.

The seven years since the government in 1930 gathered the statistics on which the recent bulletin of the Women's Bureau regarding employed homemakers was based, have wrought considerable change, employment totals in New York City indicate.

Truth and Justice rest here in an old building next door to a once roaring hotel, waiting for Edward the Peacemaker. They have waited thirteen years and may wait in vain. Truth and Justice, ten feet tall, were brought here in 1924 from the Toronto studio of Walter S. Allward. creator of the Canadian memorial at Vimy Ridge, to form part of a great monument to Ed. ward VII, the Peacemaker."

Miss Alice Mary Eckman, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Whiley Eckman of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Mr. Eckman, has completed plans for her marriage to Richard Dean Mason of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall A. Mason of Lawton, Okla.
The La Salle College quintet, aided by the brilliant playing of Frank Hoerst, defeated St. Francis of Brooklyn today, 31-25, an extra Period being necessary.

Manhattan College's debaters will be active in the next few weeks. Seven contests have been arranged for the varsity team and eight for the newly organized freshman-sophomore group by Professor Nicholas P. Westhof, who coaches the speakars.

FOLLOWING the retrospective exhibition of work shown by resident New York artists at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, the eighteenth group exhibition has opened and will be current until Feb. 21.
The Nizam of Hyderabad-reputedly the world's richest man with an estimated annual income of $50,000,000-will celebrate his silver jubilee starting next Saturday.

Mr. and Mrs. John W. Falson of 43 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline G. Faison, to Joseph Dana Allen Jr., son of Dr. Joseph Dana Allen, headmaster of Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School.

The marriage of Miss Gertrude Anne Leddy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Leddy of Elmhurst, Queens, to Milton Edward Lacina, son of Mrs. Rose Petricek of Jackson Heights, and the late Dr. Anton M. Lacina, took place yesterday morning in St. Bartholomew's Church, Elmhurst.

Ordinarily February would be considered rather late for applying mulches, but in a Winter so unconventional as this one has been thus far, it is necessary to make some exceptions to general procedure.
Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey was attacked again yesterday by officers of Local 3, Electrical Workers Union, the books and records of which he subpoenaed several weeks ago.

A British battleship in Manila Harbor, which saluted the Presidential yacht Casiana with nineteen guns a few weeks ago, was surprised to find its salute replied to with nineteen revolver shots fired from the Casiana's deck. by the President's aide de camp. It sounds highly irregular, but assuming that the Casiana had no guns, it seems to have been correct.

Tens of thousands of Catholics from all parts of the world gathered in Luneta Park for the closing day of the 33rd International Eucharistic Congress, which began shortly after dawn today with a pontifical mass celebrated by Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia.
IN ancient Athens it was the custom to provide plays for the edification of the populace at the end of March during the festivals of the great Dionysia and of the Lenaea at the end of January.
Miss Mary A. Lewis, one of the first American interior decorators of her sex, died yesterday at her residence, 140 West Fifty-seventh Street, after a lingering illness.
A surprisingly stubborn battle waged by Donald J. Nightingale and Marshall M. MacLeod against the two metropolitan champions, William Coyle and Conway Hoffman of the Montclair Athletic Club;

The 146th anniversary of the birth of Peter Cooper, who founded. Cooper Union in 1859 to provide free instruction in science and art, will be celebrated by alumni, faculty and students Friday, Lincoln's Birthday.

The "remarkable ingenuity" of a resident who submitted a scheme whereby any resident in town could give a burglar alarm to its one police constable during the night was praised by Mayor S. J. Boyd to the Council this week.

S. J. Maddox, vice president or the Seas Shipping Company, which operates the Robin Line between New York and South Africa, announced yesterday that his company had filed application for a subsidy under the Shipping Act. Mr. Maddox said he believed that the United States Maritime Commission had "sufficient power to correct the chaotic conditions" which have caused a rate war between the Robin Line and members of the South African Freight Conference.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would name an as yet unselected member of the Court of Special Sessions to become presiding justice of the court to succeed the late Frederic Kernochan and that he would promote Magistrate George B. De Luca, a Bronx Democrat, to the Special Session bench to fill the resultant vacancy there.

NASSAU, Bahamas.-The MiamiNassau yacht race for the Bahamas Government Cup will start from Miami on Tuesday, to be followed in Nassau by an ocean race for a cup offered by Governor Clifford and the presentation of trophies at the Nassau Yacht Club.

IN northern countries, Winter games are the order of the day, but few nations have taken advantage of the advertising possibilities presented by the issuance of Winter sports postage stamps except in a few instances of international contests and the need of special revenue to finance the events.

Following publication of the story of the difficulties of the Spangler family, fourteen children and a widowed mother living at 705 East Sixth Street on $28.80 a week, gifts of all kinds poured into the sixthfloor tenement apartment yesterday.

Just at the time when a recovery movement, led by steel shares, appeared to be getting under way in the stock market as a result of the easing of the flood situation and the more hopeful outlook for early settlement of the General Motors strike, nervousness returned yesterday to the market because of the President's surprise move for power to. enlarge the United States Supreme Court. True,

MARIE HARRIMAN is showing in her Fifty-seventh Street gallery work by two Vienna painters, newcomers here: Robin Andersen and Josef Dobrowsky. They reveal, alike, ingratiating qualities; and while each is individual, the two artists have certain traits in common-traits that belong to the modern Austrian school.

The Vocational Service for Juniors, which for several years has promoted guidance for youths, will maintain quarters in the lobby of the Ritz Tower on Tuesday and Wednesday from 10 A. M. to 5 P. M.,. at which contributions of old gold and silver of every description will be received.

RENO. Looking back upon a year in which the number of divorces fell sharply and the number of marriages increased to a new high record, Reno is taking stock of its reputation as a center for marriage and divorce.

President Roosevelt's proposals for the reorganization of the Federal judiciary, as made on Friday, have been rightly interpreted as the most drastic that have been made by any President since the adoption of the Federal Constitution. Guarded, tactful and considerate though the language of the message to Congress was, its implications are clear.
Westminster Kennel Club will open its sixty-first annual all-breed dog show in Madison Square Garden Wednesday morning to continue through Friday evening.
To the Muato Editor: The article in Sunday's TIMES of Jan. 24, entitled "Lehmann and Flagstad," afforded me considerable amusement.
The annual all-star show and fashion revue of the Israel Orphan Asylum, of which Mrs. Gustave Hartman is president, will be held on March 20 in Madison Square Garden.

Authorization for the establishing of a bureau of information on the economic status of women was voted yesterday to the executive board of the Women's Professional Panhellenic Association at its eighth biennial convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

Dr. John C. Riggins, a physician specializing in tuberculosis and arthritis and a brother of Dr. H. McLeod Riggins, New York physician, is dead of pneumonia in Tucson, Ariz., after a brief illness. Dr. Riggins was associated with the Thomas Davis Clinic in Tucson.

Knitters on the lookout for the latest yarns will probably discover soon a new one made of silk ribbon about an eighth of an inch wide. It is used for dressy jackets for Spring and Summer. Crimson, yellow, straw-color, dull navy, green, blue green, raspberry and gray are its shades.

For three years, Winter and Summer, Charles Hill has avoided the rent problem by living in a small cave close by the thundering waters of the Horseshoe Falls. His quarters are far from elaborate, but his "front yard" view is magnificent.

Young students of today should be taught that "unselfishness is merely a higher form of selfishness," and that through a spirit of instinctive cooperation with society they can live more richly, Dr. John Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent of the High School Division of the Board of Education, declared yesterday.
The smuggling of narcotics into this country was greatly checked

Deadlocked for the fourth day on the union demand that it be recognized as the sole bargaining agency in those General Motors plants where its men have struck, peace conferences today were kept alive over the week-end by President Roosevelt's intervention for the second time in forty-eight hours.

With business improvement continuing, department stores this Spring will put forth strong efforts to regain some of-the business lost to specialty shops during recent years, close observers of the situation said here yesterday.

PERPETIUATION of the unique and world-famous collection of glass flowers and plants in the Botanical Museum of Harvard University is assured by the recent $300.000 bequest in the will of Miss Mary Lee Ware.

Amherst College undergraduates are rejoicing in an announcement, made by the Department of Physical Education, that the new natatorium will probably be completed by commencement next June and will be ready for use at the reopening of college in September.
Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Boyles of 1,165 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Farley Moody Boyles, to Dr. James Searcy Snow of Ann Arbor. Mich.

THE after-theatre supper, a long-neglected social ritual. has returned to New York this Winter. In the new version the dishes are modern both in their simplicity and in their restricted variety. They do not compare in lavishness with those of the Gay Nineties,

Officials of the Imperial School Children's Association of Tokyo have written to F. Earl Williams, high school principal, asking that a motion-picture film showing activities of the Connecticut Valley high schools be sent to Japan to educate Japanese children in the ways of American young people.
Navy returned to the upper tier of college boxing, after its sudden drop of last year, when it won from a veteran Syracuse team, 5-3, to night.

The old Steiner estate at Riverdale, comprising about three and one-half acres at 256th Street and Independence Avenue, has been sold by the Cross Brown Company to a syndicate which will develop the property with singlefamily residences.

SOME years have passed sinoe the Philharmonio- Symphony. Orchestra toured extensively One concert in Hartford has been about the extent of the out-oftown appearances in the past two years, except that Arturo Toacanini took the orchestra to Boston for two concerts at the end of last season.

In one of their fiercest attacks near Madrid since the beginning of the siege of the capital, Insurgents tonight forced Loyalist militiamen defending access to the Madrid-Valencia road to withdraw from Ciempozuelos and Maranosa.
OF the hundreds of volumes on the depression and its cures, this is by far the most thorough and authoritative written from the American point of view.

Miss Norma Marion Burtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Martin Burtis of 165 Maple Street, Brooklyn, and Bay Crest, Huntington, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to James Ryan O'Neill, son of Mrs. Dennis O'Neill of 223 Park Place, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. O'Neill.

Doubtful that a change in the Supreme Court's personnel would necessarily affect the nature of that body's future decisions, Osmond K. Fraenkel, constitutional expert and lawyer for the New York Civil Liberties Committee, advocates instead the "liberalization" of the amendment process as a step toward curbing the court's power.
Alarmed by a huge increase in imports of Japanese cotton goods, which, it is declared, are being finished in Lancashire and reshipped to the British dominions as British products.

Miss Nan Chase Goldschmidt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manfred M. Goldschmidt of this place, was married here this afternoon in St. John's Church to John Gordon 3d of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gordon Jr. of Santa Monica, Calif.
Behind closed doors a military court is now conducting the trial on charges of high treason, of a remarkable figure of the World War, Sigmund Kiss.
Frederick W. Rueckheim Jr., president f the Crackerjack Company here, died yesterday in his home at Tucson, Ariz. His age was 63. Mr. Rueckheim was born in Chicago.

The unexpected decision of Joe Gould manager of James J. Braddock, not to sign tomorrow in Chicago for the heavyweight champion to defend his title against Joe Louis there in June yesterday caused Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C. to abandon plans for a plane trip to the Windy City.
WILL 1937 see an American airship line started, carrying passengers in trans oceanic travel? The question suggests others: For example, of what use would such a line be to America?

HAVANA.-With the beginning of the traditional carnival today and the start of the Eleventh International Star Class Yacht Regatta on Thursday, seasonal activities will be at the peak this week in Havana.
In the first year of the Alderman Alumni Fund 1,977 of the University of Virginia have contributed $31,261.32 as a memorial to the university's first president, Dr. Edwin Anderson Alderman.

Sydney Barton Booth, veteran actor nephew of Edwin Booth and last of the male line of this famous American theatrical family, died yesterday in the Stamford Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered two days before at his home, 3 Saddlerock Road. His sixty-fourth birthday was on Jan. 29.

Renewed interest in cooperative apartments may follow increasing rentals, according to Roland F. Elliman, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co. Mr. Elliman maintains that cooperative apartments came through the difficult conditions of the past five years in a much better status than was generally expected and that comparatively few of the cooperative buildings completed and entirely sold prior to 1929 have experienced serious difficulties.

The arrival in Madrid on Wednesday of Wenceslao Carillo, Director General of Police, to inquire into prison conditions and the formation of a new emeragency court to speed up trials of political prisoners, has served to concentrate attention on the problem of the men and women de- Freixa. trained for offenses against the present regime.

WITH his historical novels Gudmunjur Kamban is now making a highly distinctive contribution and doing for his native Iceland what Sigrid Undset also brilliantly did for Norway in her early medieval trilogies.

Housing properties in Harlem and the Bronx changed hands in deals announced yesterday. The six five-story walk-up flats at 34 to 44 Moylan Place, near Broadway, were sold by the Central Savings Bank to a syndicate formed by Arthur Cutler.

Miss Leila Delano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Delano, and Arthur Willing Patterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Stuart Patterson of Philadelphia, will be marrie'd on March 5 in the Church of the Incarnation. A small reception will follow at the Delano home, 39 East Thirty-sixth Street.
Gordon Kingsley, the American aviator who became lost while searching for his brother, was brought to the east coast of Nicaragua today by members of the National Guard.
One by one, during the past eight days, the bodies of six men have been discovered floating or washed up on the Western Coast of France near the island of Noirmoutiers.
Hamlin F. McCormick, one of the leading figures of the Pacific Coast lumber and steamship industries, died today of influenza. His age was 62.

Miss Jean Underhill Price, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis V. Price of Watchung, was married this afternoon to Robert Griggs Williamson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Williamson of Franklin Park, in the First-Park Baptist Church here.

Although fifty Federal housing projects are almost ready for occupancy, millions of American families are still in need of decent housing, according to Loula D. Lasker, writing in the February issue of The Survey Graphic Magazine.

Miss Janet Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nixon Lee of Ivy Close, Forest Hills, Queens, was married to Harold E. Bickford yesterday at noon at the home of her parents. After the wedding breakfast at Sherry's, Mr. and Mrs. Bickford sailed for Bermuda.

The marriage of Miss Jane Anne Gobel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Gobel Jr., of this city, to John Patrick Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Barnes, took place here yesterday morning in St. Joseph's Church.

Moderate rallies in both the pound sterling and the French franc were features yesterday in the foreign exchange market, the tenor of which otherwise was quiet. Changes throughout the list generally were narrow.

THE languid woman in the dragon-lady pajamas, whose annual salary is within a paltry few thousands of the $374,505 that Alfred P. Sloan Jr. of the General Motors Corporation gets, was, of course, Marlene Dietrich,

Charles M. Rogerson of this city has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Martha Rogerson, to James M. Estabrook of New York. iss Rogerson is a daughter of the late Mrs. Rogerson, who was Miss Helen Campbell of Brooklyn.

The Children's Welfare Federation will be aided by another in the series of Clare Tree Major children's plays when a performance of "Little Women" will be presented Saturday morning at the Barbizon Plaza Theatre.

The garden lectures being held by the Junior League of New York in cooperation with Country Life and The American Home will be continued with the second in the series of four talks, which will take place on Tuesday morning at the league clubhouse.
Shooting sub-par golf and completely outclassing her rival, Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old red-haired Minneapolis girl, successfully defended her women's Miami Biltmore championship today.

Two boys, playing a game they called "bends," sliding over humps in the ice, were drowned yesterday afternoon at Clove Lake Park, West New Brighton, S. I., when the ice gave way. There was no trace of them when Park Department employes who heard their cries ran to the scene.

Enactment of Federal legislation to eliminate child labor from employment was urged upon Congress today by the National Association of Manufacturers through the endorsement in principle of the Clark-Connery bills now pending.

Persons interested in the charitable and educational activities of the New York Society for Ethical Culture are active in the sale of boxes and seats for the recital by Lotte Lehmann of the Metropolitan Opera on the afternoon of March 7 at the Town Hall for the benefit of the organization.

Postmaster General Farley, speaking at the dedication of a new postoffic here today, said that postal receipts in New York State for 1936, amounting to $116,985,821, increased more than 10 per cent beyond those for 1935.

The nine justices of the Supreme Court probably will be invited to express their views to Congressional committees on President Roosevelt's proposals for judicial reform before measures embodying the recommendations are presented to either House for definite action.
Dartmouth successfully defended its championship in the annual Winter carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club today, finishing the two-day skiing competition with a total of 486.3 points.

Consideration of the President's surprise proposal to reorganize the judicial branch of the Federal Government, primarily by increasing the number of Federal judges, including Justices of the Supreme Court, undoubtedly will lead, whether or not so intended, to a review of the attitude of the Supreme Court toward the New Deal.
The annual Kake Walk celebration at the University of Vermont returns once more to brighten spirits, after the two weeks' examination period.
ENGLAND, France, Germany and Mexico were all represented in the exhibitions which opened last week and continue through the present week or, in some cases, longer.

The "Faculty Follies," by the faculty of Barnard College, will be presented Friday and Saturday at Brinckerhoff Theatre for the benefit of the fiftieth anniversary fund. Barnard will celebrate its golden jubilee in 1939.

Four persons were stabbed, one seriously, and more than sixty-five others thrown into panic on a New York-bound B. M. T. Broadway-Jamaica elevated train between the Alabama Avenue and the Eastern Parkway stations at 2 o'clock this morning when a passenger suddenly started slashing about him with a pocketknife.

Influenced by the recovery in outside markets and absence of hedging pressure against releases of the government staple, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday to end with a gain of 2 points to a loss of one on the day.

Outingiclub cabins are replacing campus social halls as the hubs from which the Cokes of college week-end life radiate. Throughout the East college students of both sexes are turning to the out-ofdoors for their Saturday and Sunday recreation.
Morris Llewellyn Cooke, authority on power and conservation, resigned today as Rural Electrification Administrator, saying he wished to travel abroad.

The full text of the three articles on "How to Avoid a Slump," written by J. M. KEYNES and published in The London Times, is now available here, and has already provoked some comment. While the articles deal particularly with the situation in Great Britain, the general principles laid down are, of course, intended for universal application.

Leaders in the civic, business and political life of Brooklyn, together with high-ranking church dignitries, attended the funeral services for the Right Rev. Mgr. David J. Hickey, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and Prothonotary Apostolic, yesterday morning at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, Sixth Avenue and Carroll Street, Brooklyn.
The United States won the world men's team table tennis championship tonight, defeating the Hungarian trio, 5 1/2 matches to 3 1/2, in the play-off series for the title.

Above the conventional hum at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, as the twenty-second annual luncheon conference of the National Board of Review settled down to business, could be heard distinctly, and at frequent intervals, the ghostly clanking of the chains of the cinema's pet bugaboo-censorship.

Controversy still is raging over the sudden end of "The Boy David," Sir James M. Barrie's play with Elisabeth Bergner in the cast. Dramatist Robert Harcourt, in a letter to The Times of London, lays the death at the door of speculative ticket agencies.

In the current issue of "Bird Lore" Kermit Roosevelt, president of the National Association of Audubon Societies, poses some pertinent questions for consideration at the second annual wildlife conference to be held at St. Louis March 1-4.
Dr. Mark Omeara, Kingston surgeon and former president of the Ulster County Medical Society, died today after a year's illness. He was 63 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. William Rosenfeld of Larchmont, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Estelle Rosenfeld, to Lawrence Whitehead Kohlman, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kohlman of this city.

A girl from New York, a boy from Idaho, a millionaire from Philadelphia and the Governor General of Great Britain's nearest possession, the Bahamas, gathered before 20,000 persons and a battery of cameras at Hialeah Park today because another thoroughbred had won another American stake race. The horse was No Sir, owned and trained by Miss Mary Hirsch, the girl from New York.

Brooklyn Prep won a hard-fought game from the Poly Prep sextet in the first game of a Private School Ice Hockey League twin bill at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday. The score was 2 to 1. St. Francis Prep flashed its finest form of the season and blanked St. John's Prep, 5 to 0, in the second contest.

The wardens and vestrymen of Grace Episcopal Church of this city gave a reception this afternoon at the Field Club for their new rector, the Rev. Harold Hinrichs, and Mrs. Hinrichs. Ernest A. Bickell,

Revenue from documentary and playing card stamp taxes in 1936 increased $13,104,614, or more than 24 per cent. over 1935, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today. The total for 1936 was $68,975,663; for 1935 it was $55,871,049.
Trailing, 26-19, at the end of the third period, the fast Hill School quintet fought an uphill battle to. subdue the University of Pennsylvania's junior varsity, 32-28, today.
