The Lenten Sewing Class, under the auspices of the Cribside Social Service Committee of the Babies Hospital, will be resumed Thursday morning and will be held on subsequent Thursday mornings throughout the penitential :season.

An address at 6:15 P. M. on Friday, Lincoln's Birthday, by Senator Robert F. Wagner over station WJZ will bring to a close the nationwide campaign to enlist public sentiment against lynching and in support of anti-lynching legislation, it was annuonced yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

unidentified poison, which kills swiftly without leaving a trace of its presence, was held responsible for the deaths of two native bushmen when inquests were held in the inland mining town of Bartica, according to word reaching here today.

FILMGOERS, lying back in upholstered comfort in the cinemas today, are apt to take a film for granted. In rease they are right, for they are thee ,to be entertained and not to worry about how the film got there. C sometimes think, however, that if they but knew of some of our "headaches" and difficulties behind the scenes, theirs would be a greater appreciation when the film is finally unspooled before their aritioal eyes,.

The College of New Rochelle entered upon the second half of its thirty-fourth academic year on Feb. 1 with eight new courses and six new students, bringing the total registration to 754, according to a report by the Registrar's office today.

In his annual report to Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University, Henry G. Arnsdorf, secretary of the university, declared yesterday that the last academic year had seen sharp increases of enrollments in the adult education and graduate study divisions.

WHO is--or was--Vivian Lestrange? Did he, or she, ever exist? If so, what has become of him, or her? These are a few of the questions that Chief Inspector Warner and his colleagues of Scotland Yard are expected to answer.

The world can experience a long period of great prosperity if immediate steps are taken to encourage private enterprise in all directions and if confidence can be restored among nations, Sir George Paish, British economist, said in an address last night at the annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking, held at the Hotel Astor.
THE recently created Maritime Commission is now receiving bids from American shipyards for the construction of a large passenger liner to succeed the old Leviathan.

FEW cartoonists probably, would admit that they had any duty to the world except to throw a ripe tomato at it. But if in their more conscientious moments, perceiving how far signs and symbols constitute the mental

In bitterly cold weather, nationally known contestants met for honors today in the national and Michigan open amateur speed skating championships. The events featured the annual Michigan Winter carnival.

TODAY is the 125th anniversary of Dickens's birth, and all over the English-speaking world the faithful are gathering this week-end to honor the immortal memory by feasting and other merrymaking. Some of them are revisiting the birthplace at Portsmouth, which serves as the starting point of many a pilgrim's progress Except that it has been converted to a museum

Out of a total present membership of 95, the Senate, which must approve President Roosevelt's proposal to induce retirement of Federal judges at the age of 70, has only ten members who have reached that age. They are:

The Tydings-Miller. bill providing for resale price maintenance on a national scale, if enacted by Congress, will have as one of its major effects the "forcing"- of manufacturers, who have been reluctant to set retail prices on their products, to adopt resale price programs, according to views expressed here yesterday.

Railroads in the United States bought more steam locomotives in 1936 than in any year since 1929, according to a compilation by the Baldwin Locomotive Works. In 1929, the railroads moved more freight than in any other year.

All Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York may eat meat next Friday by dispensation of Cardinal Hayes. This is because Friday is Lincoln's Birthday. It is custom to excuse Catholics from abstinence on a Friday if that day is a civil holiday.

Members of the St. Francis College Auxiliary will give a reception this evening at the college, at 41 Butler Street, Brooklyn, for students and their mothers. Mrs. Frank G. Noonan, president of the auxiliary, heads a large committee in charge of arrangements.

King George VI has approved the appointment of the Earl of Ancaster as Lord Great Chamberlain of England. This office is 800 years old. The main duties are concerned with coronations and openings of Parliament.
AUGUSTA, Ga.-Two major social events and several golf tournaments, together with individual sports activities, compose the program here this week.

Backed by the irresistible force of reports from the flood regions, and with authorized available funds rapidly reaching the vanishing point, a deficiency appropriation to carry on relief and work relief until the end of the fiscal year was hurried through the House and Senate this week.

A HUMBLE cobbler of Parma, one Anacleto Fochi, suddenly found himself in the musical limelight a fortnight or so ago on unearthing an important unpublished manuscript work of Nicol? Paganini-the Fourth concerto, in D minor, for violin and orchestrathe existence of which was known, and its significance appraised, but which had been lost sight of during the past three decades.
Builders and developers in Queens and adjacent sections of Long Island are looking ahead to a year of steadily increasing buying and construction activity.
Pennsylvania College for Women will hold another Summer school in choral speaking, with correlated courses in the aesthetics of poetry, phonetics and rhythmics.

IN mid-February at St. Moritz, Switzerland, is held what is generally considered the world's most thrilling downhill ski race, the "Flying Kilometer," run solely for the purpose of learning the highest possible speed attainable on skis.

AntiSemitism, raised by Adolf Hitler in Germany to the status of a political religion, is rapidly spreading throughout Eastern Europe and is thereby turning the recurrent Jewish tragedy in that biggest Jewish center in the world into a final disaster of truly historic magnitude.
The Woodmere Academy basketball team defeated Collegiate School, 39-16, in the latter's gymnasium yesterday. At half time the victors led, 26 to 4.
Onrush, a rank outsider from Mrs. F. C. Dunn's Stable, scored an unexpected victory today in winning the six furlongs of the Rex Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

More than half a million families in the United States received considerably more than one billion dollars in 1936 from the savings, building and loan associations of the country for various forms of home financing. The total amount loaned for these purposes was S1,200,211,000, reports the United States Building and Loan League.
The engagement of Miss Kathryn Joyce Laird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Laird of 526 Ramapo Avenue, to Paul J. Ward of Butler has been announced.
Mrs. Mildred Shay Gardiner obtained a divorce today from Winthrop Gardiner Jr. of New York. Mrs. Gardiner came here by plane in October.
Inquiries inspired by the recent marriages of a 9-year-old Tennessee girl and a 12-year-old New York girl reveal that child marriages are more common in the United States than generally supposed.

A rough-riding Metropolitan Indoor League allstar trio that overcame a five-goal handicap defeated the crack Yale University polo team, 11 1/2 to 9 1/2, before a capacity crowd of 8,000 at the 124th Field Artillery Armory tonight.
Squadron C scored an unexpected 7-to-21/2 victory over the 112th Field Artillery of New Jersey in a Metropolitan Indoor Polo League game last night on its home tanbark in Brooklyn.

ROME.-It is just two years since Italian troops began to sail for East Africa for the conquest of Haile Selassie's domain, an event precipitated by the border clash at Ualual on Dec. 5, 1934. Premier Mussolini proclaimed Ethiopia's annexation to Italy on May 9, 1936, and since then consolidation of Italian power has proceeded rapidly.
The centenary of DWIGHT L. MOODY'S birth, which is being widely celebrated this week, brings freshly back the

President Roosevelt's plan to appoint six more justices of the Supreme Court was termed a "dangerous experiment" today by David M. Newbold, an attorney and president of the Welsbach Street Lighting Company.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn personally will conduct the prosecution of Murray Bleefeld, Martin Schloss-man and Harry Weiss, under in dictment for kidnapping Paul Wendel, former New Jersey lawyer.

Through the recent though belated act of Congressional beneficence by which a pension of $5,000 was voted for Mrs. Calvin Coolidge at the behest of Senator Carter Glass, that popular personality found herself once more the cynosure of the nation-a role she has consistently shunned, especially in the past few years.

The Family Adjustment Society of Queens Borough, of which Mrs. Alexander Graham is president, will give its annual benefit bridge party on the afternoon of Feb. 15 at Hotel Pennsylvania. Mrs. Julian Hartridge and Mrs. William B. Barry are general chairman of the bridge.

With twelve performances of "Cinderella" in Newark schools and institutions to its credit, the Newark Junior League will add to that number by again presenting the play on Thursday afternoon at the Elliott Street School.

While General Francisco Franco's Insurgent forces, now largely dominated by German officers and in a lesser degree by Italians, are pounding at the gates of Madrid and threatening Malaga, another important front has been maintained in the Aragon region since the first days of the insurrection by Catalan militia columns.
HAS contemporary art a rightful place in our museums? When is art living and when is it dead? What is art's true function in the social scheme?

PROBABLY those who live in the American atmosphere are not fully aware of its heady effect upon one who encounters it for the first time or after years of absence. It has been demonstrated scientifically that the American climate is exceedingly stimulating;
Miss Dechantal Brennan, daughter of Mrs. M. C. Brennan, will be married on Monday to Dr. James V. Nespeco of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick Nespeco of New Haven.

Mr. and Mrs. Huntington Hartford 2d entertained today with a luncheon at their residence for Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Kent Jr., Mrs. M. Dorland Doyle, Misses Mary and Frances Munn, Lesley Bobert, Eleanor Young, Katharine Barker, Elena Villa, Arielle Fraser and Prince Kyril Scherbatoff, Prince Georges Scherbatoff, Charles A. Munn Jr., Rodman De Heeren, Beverley Bogert and Vadim Maka??off.

IT is hard, almost impossible, for ex- monarchs and ex- movie queens to retire completely from the public eye. The light that beats upon a throne is not much fiercer than the hard magnesium glare which continues to burn sacrificially

Public schools are beginning to follow the lead of the colleges in exchanging professors and students. Dr. Elmer Scott Holbeck, principal of the Woodrow Wilson School in Passaic, N. J., recently complet a one-year exchange with George Hetzel, principal of a junior high school in Pasadena, Calif.
Flowered witch-hazels are a boon to Northern gardens. Blooming over the five-month Winter period when no other Northern woody plants are in flower, they are of exceptional importance.
The first of the official reports now coming through on both retail sales and profits give ample evidence of the improvement which developed in retail trade last year.

Miss Marjorie Rahmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Henry Rahmann of Summit, and Malcolm J. Odell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Odell of Winnetka, Ill., were married this afternoon in Calvary Episcopal Church by the Rev. J. Stuart Neill, Archdeacon of Hartford, assisted by the Rev. Walter 0. Kinsolving, the rector.
Thomas B. Griffin, "barge" driver and taxi man for Wellesley College since 1888, nine years after the founding of the college, died yesterday at his home here. He was 69 years old.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Anne Rainey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McCandless Rainey of Riverdale-on-Hudson, to William Braxton Pegram, son of Professor and Mrs. George Braxton Pegram of this city and Norwalk, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon in the Riverdale Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Duff.
Mr. and Mrs. James May of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lillian A. May, to Fergus S. Middleton, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. E. Middleton of Ramsey.

The cracked tones of an ancient school bell pealed out over the air waves at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon and ushered in a one-hour old-fashioned spelling bee between fifteen New York high school girls and fifteen Pittsburgh boys that showed that modern youngsters can stand right up and spell jawbreakers never even heard of in their grandparents' time.
The "seven wonders of modern medicine" were described by members of the American College of Surgeons at a community health meeting which closed their Southern section session.

John E. Edgerton, president of the Southern States Industrial Council, expressed the opinion today that President Roosevelt's "revolutionary proposal" for court reorganization "involves the very life of the Republic and of our Democratic ideals."
AFTER a brief interval, we have another ample volume--the sixth--of Mr. Lloyd George's inexhaustible memoirs.

The day of the "self-made" man is nearly over, in the opinion of Dr. Paul S. Burgess, president of the University of Arizona. Only for a little longer, he said in an address here, will men of eminence be able to point to success despite meager educational advantages.

Dr. Guillermo Sevilla Sacasa, President .of the Chamber of Deputies, submitted a bill whereby families with ten or more children would be exempt from taxation of all kinds and the children educated at the expense of the nation.

Citing the need for, additional safety measures in the building industry, Samuel R. Bishop of New York City, chairman of the committee on health and safety of the American Institute of Architects, declares that architects, contractors and workmen must act together not only to cut down the number of accidents but also to reduce building costs, conserve time and man power, and increase general efficiencv.

Mr. and Mrs. James O'Brien of 22 Stuyvesant Avenue, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rose Mary O'Brien, to Fred J. White Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. White, also of Brooklyn.

James Roosevelt, son of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, piloted his yacht, Half Moon, this afternoon in the Golden Jubilee race of the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club on an ocean course of thirty miles, off Miami Beach. Tonight Mr. Roosevelt was a dinner guest of the club at its house in Coconut Grove.

The Princess Royal, the Duke of Windsor's only sister and a close companion since childhood, left London today on the first visit to his Austrian retreat undertaken by any member of the royal family since his abdication in December.
Calais, Me., and St. Stephen, N. B., on opposite sides of the St. Croix River and connected by a long bridge, set a perfect example in amity for European nations that are such bad neighbors.
The Brown and White, semi-weekly newspaper of Lehigh University, will begin its forty-third year Tuesday under the direction of a new staff of officers.

Miss Kathleen Mary O'Brien, daughter of Thomas Edward O'Brien of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. O'Brien, was married yesterday morning to Martin James Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Newman, also of Brooklyn. Mgr.
Several Yale Law School professors today voiced approval of President Roosevelt's proposal affecting the judiciary. Professor Fred Rodell said, "I am definitely in favor of the proposal."
Miss Elizabeth Margaret Karins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Karins of this place, was married this afternoon to Gilbert Lawrence Wright, son of Ernest B. Wright of Montclair. The Rev.

AN exhibition of paintings, pieces of sculpture and drawings by Czech musicians was held recently in Prague. The show included seventy-seven works of art by sixteen composers, instrumentalists and singers.

THE Roth Quartet has become associated with the Westminster Choir School, Princeton, N. J. There Fred Roth's group will inaugurate the Westminster Academy of Chamber Music. Mr. Roth intends to form a symphonia from the student body, which will be similar to the Westminster Choir in its standards.

Hospital Commissioner S. S. Goldwater announced yesterday that the New York Academy of Medicine has endorsed his plan for using land available on Welfare Island to relieve the shortage of facilities for convalescents for persons unable to pay for care.

The Justice Department has on its hands a puzzle that is almost a hundred years old. Since the middle of the nineteenth century it has had an official motto, but even Attorney General Cummings cannot say exactly what it means.

The situation in Honduras indicates a possibility of a revolt against the Carias government. According to reports received here President Tiburcio Carias Andino has abandoned the presidential palace at Tegucigalpa and is occupying the residence of Julio Lozano, Honduran Minister to Washington on a hill north of the capital, refusing to receive visitors.

Courage and common sense were united in the remarks of Dr. JAMES H. KIMBALL, chief of the United States Weather Bureau in the North, before the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, when he opposed the suggested air race from New York to Paris to commemorate the epochal flight of Colonel CHARLES A. LINDBERGH on May 20-21, 1927.

Mr. and Mrs. Esdras L. Gruver of 1,220 Park Avenue gave a dinner-dance last night in the roof garden of the Pierre for their debutante daughter, Miss Vivette Gruver, and for Miss Anne Crewe Delafield Finch, debutante daughter of Judge and Mrs. Edward Ridley Finch. The dance served as Miss Gruver's coming-out party.
THE Golden Age of Russian Letters, the Age of Pushkin, is little known beyond the boundaries of Russia. It coincided with the Romantic period in Western Europe but was not Romantic in itself.

Herbert S. Duffy, State Attorney General, a Democrat, protested to the Ohio Congressional delegation in Washington today against President Roosevelt's proposed increase of the Supreme Court membership. saying the present system was a protection "against possible political dictatorship."

The Real Estate Association of the State of New York will hold its annual convention in Niagara Falls in September "to celebrate a third of a century of progress," Herman A. Acker, president, announced yesterday.

The present city administration, although an improvement on the preceding ones, lacks "a definite program" and is addicted to "oneman rule," Louis Waldman, Socialist leader and a State Committeeman of the American Labor Party, declared yesterday.

David Levinson, American lawyer who came here to defend Luis Carlos Prestes and Harry Berger, on trial for alleged connection with the revolt in November, 1935, cannot take charge of the defense, according to Judge Barros Barreto, president of the security tribunal that is trying the revolters.
The story of a man to whom "law of flight" apparently was applied and who lived to tell the tale reached here today.

Miss Mary Madeline Birmingham, daughter of Mrs. Howard Jerome Duncan of South Orange, N. J., was married here yesterday noon in the Church of the Incarnation to William Benjamin Grafton Kirk, son of Mrs. Edwin L. Kirk of Sharon, Conn., and the late Mr. Kirk.
OUTSIDE Rudyard Kipling's study in the gray-shingled house of Naulakha his wife sat with her sewing in the mornings and saw to it that the writer was never disturbed.

Tentative plans for the seventeenmile Ocean Highway, linking the Queens terminal of the new Queens Midtown Vehicular Tunnel with the Atlantic Beach Bridge crossing at the eastern approach to the Rockaways, were disclosed yesterday by John Howes Burton, one of the first to propose the construction of he East River tunnel.

The marriage of Miss Rita Kiernan, daughter of former Alderman and Mrs. James F. Kiernan of Brooklyn, to W. John Devine, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Devine of Ozone Park, Queens, took place yesterday morning at St. Mary Mother of Jesus Church, Brooklyn.

The New Jersey Bar Association, at its midwinter luncheon meeting here today, voted almost unanimously its opposition to President Roosevelt's plan to reform the Federal judicial system and add to the number of justices of the United States Supreme Court.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, received a shock of surprise when he opened his mail yesterday morning and out dropped a check for $1,000 on a Chicago bank signed "Alfred M. Landon."
SKIERS, skaters, hockey players and youngsters with new sleds are not the only lovers of Winter sports who have been impatiently waiting for durable ice and snow.
ON TRIAL: Born and bred as a youth in Chicago's South Side slums, James T. Farrell has become the exposer of that depressing environment.

Slum clearance and rehousing projects under governmental auspices are not competitive with private enterprise, declares Joseph Milner, head of the realty company bearing his name. Such operations, he adds, actually assist in bringing about stabilized conditions in the real estate business.

Hunter College will celebrate this week both its sixty-seventh year of educational activity as a city college for women and the completion of the first year of intensive campaigning for a new building to replace the one swept by fire on the college's sixty-sixth birthday, last Feb. 14.

A FADED entry on the books of the Supreme Court of Illinois, dated March 1, 1837, bears record that on that day Abraham Lincoln, Representative in the Illinois Legislature from Sangamon County, was admitted to the Illinois bar.

Off to a whirlwind start and keeping well in front, the New York A. C. defeated Winmont Farms, 14% to 9, at the Squadron A Armory last night and moved into a secondplace tie with Squadron A in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League.
Figures revealing a record volume, both in number and value, of aircraft exports from the United States in 1936 have been made public here by an official of the Department of Commerce.

President Roosevelt's judiciary proposal, regarded here as having in view "liberalization" of the Supreme Court, and a belief in Democratic quarters at the Capitol that Congress will fall in line, have radically changed the atmosphere at Albany as far as minimum wage and New Deal legislation generally are concerned.

GERMANY promises a gay climax to what is considered the merriest pre-Lenten season known since the war. Every community in the Reich, from Aachen to Zoppot, has organized its own celebration, so almost any visitor may step from his train, hotel or pension directly into the midst of a continuous carnival somewhere along the way.

Premier Benito Mussolini's eldest son, Vittorio, was married this morning to Miss Orsola Buvoli in the Church of St. Joseph on the Via Nomentana, only a stone's throw from the Villa Torlonia, the residence of the Mussolini family.

Miss Margaret Glavin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Glavin of Bloomfield, was married to Frederic K. Miller Wanner, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wanner of West Orange, today in Sacred Heart Church by Mgr. Timothy W. Donovan.

The thirtythird annual congress on medical education and licensure, which is held each year in Chicago under the auspices of the American Medical Association Council on Medical Education, will open Monday morning, Feb. 15.

Passage of the so-called "Demolition Bill" now before the State Legislature, designed to force the repair or razing of abandoned tenements, is being urged by Stanley P. Davies, general director of the Charity Organization Society.

Regarded chiefly as a guide to the minimum wages that will be suggested under any government revival of the NRA, the schedule set last week by the Department of Labor for work clothing plants under the Walsh-Healey Public Contract Act drew sharp criticism from some business men, while others were inclined to regard it as reasonable.

Scotland defeated Wales, holder of the international Rugby championship, 13-6, today, the winners' margin being two goals and a try to two tries. Wales Previously had lost to England.

Oilstocks, Ltd.--Liquidating value of capital stock as of Dec. 31, approximately $14.83 a share, based on market prices for securities owned and after allowing for Federal normal income taxes applicable to the unrealized appreciation, compared with $14.78 a share on Dec. 31, 1935. In a nation-wide WPA search for material for the Federal archives, many valuable historical documents have been rescued from oblivion during the past eighteen months. Investigators have worked under widely varying conditions.

Statistics showing that sixteen of the last twenty-seven accidents on the air lines of the United States have been attributed to errors by pilots precipitated a lively battle of words today at the final session of the threeday air safety conference sponsored by the Bureau of Air Commerce.

Members of Masque Triangle, the Colgate University dramatic club, will honor the memory of the late Lee Alexander of Drexel Hills, Pa., when the play, "The Royal Family of Broadway," is staged in Schine's State Theatre here at 2 P. M. Saturday as one of the events of the midwinter carnival.

THE widow of Pancho Villa-his last and only legal wife-is writing his biography for the American public just twenty years after an American expeditionary force pursued this extraordinary Mexican leader south of the border.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Frances Glavin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Glavin of this town, to Frederick Wanner, son of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Wanner of West Orange, took place this afternoon in Sacred Heart Church, Bloomfield.
THE special "Ring" cycle starts this week at the Metropolltan. It will be oversold. This Can be stated without inquiry of the Metropolitan box office.

Many parties will be given in conjunction with the luncheon in behalf of St. Luke's Hospital in Tokyo, to be held on Tuesday in the ballroom of the Pierre under the auspices of the Woman's Division of the American Council of St. Luke's International Medical Center, Tokyo.
In some respects it was like a scene in the adventurous North where men are men and ice is more than something to put in drinks.

A notable collection of chemical memorabilia assembled by the late Dr. Edgar Fahs Smith, provost and Professor of Chemistry at the University of Pennsylvania, is to be made more readily accessible to the growing numbers of students and research workers from this country and abroad that consult its source material.

Miss Anne Warren, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Dennis Warren of Marlboro Street and Rockyhill Farm, Essex, and the late Mr. Warren, was married this afternoon to Philip Saltonstall Weld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Weld, prominent New Yorkers, who have a Summer home at Wareham, Mass.

Members of the boys' work committee of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Y. M. C. A. will give their third annual Valentine bridge party on Saturday evening at the White Plains Y. M. C. A. The boys division is divided into an older group under the direction of Edwin E. Bond and a younger one under the leadership of George Goodfellow.

A suggested thirty-one-point legislative program for Philadelphia, including recommendations for citycounty consolidation and decreased authority for such independent bodies as the Board of Education, Board of City Trusts and Fairmount Park Commission, was made public today by Mayor S. Davis Wilson.

Mrs. Samuel Seabury, chairman of the New York chapter of the English-Speaking Union, will give a reception this afternoon at her home, 154 East Sixty-third Street, for Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Lady Hardwicke, and for Philip Merivale and Marguerite Churchill. Mr.
Theodore Bishop Sr., who celebrated his sixty-fifth wedding anniversary on Dec. 7, died late yesterday at his home here following a brief illness. He was 87 years old. Mrs. Bishop died on Dec. 29.

Once more the eyes and thoughts of millions of Americans turn to the lower valley of the Mississippi. The long drama of man's fight against this river's floods has been an American epic ever since the white man first settled the valley empire.

Now that the wasnington treaty has gone the way of previous attempts at armament limitation, the British Empire is again confronted with the same problem of sea power she faced on the eve of the World War.

Jack Brodie, his Irish face open and honest in spite of a decade as a fugitive from prison, sat in Oklahoma State penitentiary here and declared that in spite of his prison garb he felt he was a better man than at any moment since he fled a prison camp near Ardmore, Okla., in 1926.

THE new blond and bleached furniture woods have already created their own distinctive backgrounds of vivid clear colors in. contrasting shades or harmonizing hues. Their light tones are further enhanced by the diffused modern lighting, which brings out the delicate moldings and contours.

Senator J. Hamilton Lewis, Democrat, of Illinois, said today he believed consideration by the public and Congress would suggest "just compromise legislation" on the President's judiciary reorganization recommendations.
The marriage of Baroness Alexandra von Nagel zu Aichberg to Count Hubert Deym von Stritez, Knight of the Order of Malta, took place at St. Michael's Church here today.

N unexpected volume of sightseeing visitors to New York City is disturbing the hibernation of Broadway tour conductors, many of whom are accustomed to sleep more, eat less and earn little during the lean Winter months.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 4: CAPTAIN Foy. E. J., detached from command of the Raleigh in March or April and ordered to staff. Army War College. Fort Humphreys, D. C.

Modernization of buying and merchandising technique is essential for any retail store planning to do a good knitwear business this Spring, according to Tobe, style authority and merchandising consultant.
THIS longest of the Myron Bring novels is a story that takes hold of you and keeps you engrossed until you have finished it.

The American Merchant Line as operator of the service between New York, Plymouth and London has been abolished and the ships now operating under that banner will become part of the United States Lines, it was announced yesterday.

Higher standards in Pennsylvania for unemployment relief and for mothers' assistance or aid to dependent children were termed "obvious and imperative" by the Goodrich committee today in submitting to Governor Earle a series of estimates of the cost of a consolidated State relief and assistance program.
The second annual Carnation Show sponsored by the New England Carnation Growers Association will be held in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, Thursday, Friday and Saturday, Feb. 18, 19 and 20.

Miss Erika Loes, daughter of Mrs. Erna Loes of Freiburg, Germany, and the late Judge Franz Loes, was married here yesterday at noon in St. Peter's Lutheran Church to Dr. Hermann L. Witte of Trenton, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Witte of NienburgWeser, Germany, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Alfred B. Moldenke. Mrs.

Union College put up a good fight against C. C. N. Y., but lost, 53 to 34, tonight after leading through the first quarter. When Union's star guard, Johnny Schultz, was injured in the last half C. C. N. Y. set a scoring pace that Union was unable to match.

Miss Eleanor Kraft, daughter of Mrs. John George Kraft of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to Wheeler Lord Jr. of Germantown, Pa., which will take place here on Friday afternoon at St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church.

The marriage of Miss Mary Borden Turner, daughter of Mrs. Edward Louis Spears of London and of Colonel George Douglas Turner, also of that city, to Edward Hamilton Hall, took place yesterday morning at 439 East Fifty-first Street, the home of her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Zlatko Balokovic.
The New York Athletic Club five scored its sixth success in seven Eastern Athletic Club League games last night by downing the Seventh Regiment, 39 to 24, on the victors' court.

Without the knowledge of school officials, children at the Ontario School for the Blind here sometimes read in bed at night a book they have slipped in with them, Principal H. J. Vallentyne said today.

The engagement of Miss Edith Wakeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Wakeman of Quincy, to Donald Perry Spencer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rae MacCollum Spencer of Worcester, has been announced by her parents.
THE Autocar Company of Ardmore, Pa., has entered the light truck field with two new models, one of 13,000 pounds gross rating and the other of 16,000 pounds.

Appointments of new members to Pictra Mitra, the oldest student organization on the local campus of Georgian Court College and one of the most unusual secret societies in the country, were made today.

The busiest and richest year in the history of gold mining in Canada is expected by mining men for 1937. Based on records, especially those since 1930, the expectation is that production of gold will pass the 4,000,000-ounce mark this year.

THE curtains of the little theatre in Prague slid right and left disclosing orle of the oddest stages I have ever seen-shaped like a painter's palette and tilted from front to back at an angle of twenty-five, perhaps thirty, degrees.

RADIO'S invisible waves turned into rivulets of gold that have flowed into the Red Cross headquarters during the past two weeks in response to appeals for flood relief in the Ohio-Mississippi Valleys.

THE catastrophic eruption of the volcano San Vicente in El Salvador last month came as a shock to the world. But to the people who live along the volcanic line which extends through Central America such a happening exists as an ever-present menace.

The marriage of Miss Agnes Cloherty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Cloherty of 24 East Ninetyseventh Street, to William J. Campbell, son of Mrs. John Campbell of Chicago and the late Mr. Campbell, took place yesterday morning in the Church of St. Francis de Sales.

Mrs. M. Young Cowl, who is visiting here from her Canadian home, Youngland, at Shediac Cape, N. B., gave a dinner dance last night at the St. Regis to introduce to society her daughter, Miss de Lancey Cowl who will be presented at the Court of St. James in London in July.
Relief workers on projects of the Works Progress Administration are more than four-fifths men according to an analysis of the more than 2,000,000 workers so engaged which was made public today.
The George Washington High School has sent to the Red Cross a check for $815.27 to be used for flood sufferers. Teachers, pupils and a few parents sent donations.

Except in the market for United States Government obligations, where unsettlement continued as a carryover from Friday afternoon, bonds on the New York Stock Exchange recovered fairly well yesterday from the impact of the President's message on the Supreme Court and judicial system in general.

Net income of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company and subsidiaries in 1936 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and $11,500 provision for surtax on undistributed earnings amounted to $2,351,968, which was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.95 each on 611,712 no-par common shares. In 1935, net income was $1,699,400, or $1.70 a common share.
INCREASINGLY we are becoming a nation of dog lovers That fact is emphasized by the keen interest in the Westminster Kennel Club's show-the top indoor show-at Madison Square Garden this week.
The possibility of continued competition between the Swiss and American college skiers loomed today.

AN interesting addition to its collection of Civil War material has recently been acquired by Reis Library of Allegheny College through the gift of the Misses Agnes and Melrose Pitman, Cincinnati, Ohio. who presented a copy of "The Assassination of President Lincoln and the Trial of the Conspirators," arranged and compiled by their father, Benn Pitman. Staving off a desperate bid for victory in the waning minutes of the game, the City College junior varsity quintet topped St. Simon Stock High School team of the Bronx, 27 to 26, in the closing game of a basketball triple-header at the Hippodrome yesterday.

SEVERAL months ago the Society of American Etchers held. its annual, and now, as promised at that time by John Taylor Arms, the president, it comes forward to sponsor a national exhibition of work in mediums not included in the. society's own shows-lithography, woodcut and block-print.

In anticipation of the arrival of Miss Marguerite Wells, national president of the League of Women Voters, a report is in preparation on activities of both the city and the State league, with special emphasis on the work for ratification of the child labor amendment, which last week received the approval of the Senate.

The social whirl of baseball's rapidly fading off-season is scheduled to pass out with a loud blast tonight when more than 800 guests attend the fourteenth annual dinner and frolic of the New York Baseball Writers Chapter in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

The "schoolmaster of motordom," Ransom E. Olds, has retired once more. He plans a vacation in Australia. Mr. Olds, 72 years old, has left his name well impressed upon the automobile industry--first with the Olds Motor Vehicle Company, then with the Olds Motor Works, later with Oldsmobile and subsequently with the Reo Motor Car Works.

Two college presidents will be the guests of the council of the Wellesley Alumnae Association when it assembles Thursday afternoon for the annual midwinter meeting. Dr. Mildred H. McAfee, president of Wellesley, will give her "First Impressions of a First Presidency"

Miss Donita Ferguson, daughter of Mrs. Donna Beach Ferguson of 31 Sutton Place South, New York, and the late John Sherlock Ferguson, was married to Roy Van Auken Sheldon of New York here today at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Joseph Herben by Justice W. B. Lownes of Gladwyne.
ROME. NOTABLE among those who are playing important roles in the dramatic events at the Vatican is Cardinal Pacelli, Cardinal Secretary of State, long a close friend of Pope Pius XI.

One scarcely need follow statistics in the daily press to realize that a new era in home-building has opened in this country. Wherever the traveler goes, in suburban areas and even along concrete roads well out into rural sections, countless "developments," half - completed new buildings and foundation excavations are encountered.
High school students, thrilled about juvenile weddings, organized today the "Association Okehing Child Marriage All Over the United States."

The public reacted to the Trotskyist trial in a usual and an unusual way. I say usual because the newspapers were full of resolutions voted by factory and other organizations to demand condign punishment for the "Trotskyist dogs, blackguards, traitors, wreckers and firers-up of war."
The Turkish Grand National Assembly adopted yesterday three amendments to the Constitution which had been proposed by 150 members.

In a statement issued at the Russian Consulate General, 7 East Sixty-first Street, before he sailed yesterday on the Paris, Jean J. Arens, Soviet Consul General in New York, who has been recalled to Moscow, expressed his gratitude to "Americans, not misled by campaigns of prejudice and distortion from certain hostile quarters."

The note that Russia addressed to the London non-intervention committee disapproving the plan for naval control of the Spanish coast is unanimously denounced by the Italian press today as an attempt to sabotage non-intervention.

Judging from the large subscription for the supper dance in behalf of the Barat Settlement to be held tomorrow in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, the funds for carrying on the work of that organization will be augmented greatly.
Further reduction in the amount of vacant office space in the downtown financial district is shown by a survey of renting conditions in that section of Manhattan.

Reflecting the nation-wide growth of interest in housing and city planning, this year's program for Alumni Day at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, set for June 7, will comprise a many-sided conference on the "house of tomorrow."

The Republican party is hampered by leaders "who are still living among cobwebs and mothballs," Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey declared last night at his Annual birthday dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The year 1936 has gone into the record as one of the most peaceful and prosperous ever experienced in the republican history of Peru. Even to a greater extent than in 1935 unemployment was practically non-existent. The unemployment tax remains in force, but the funds are being administered not so much with a view to bringing relief as to carrying out public works.
Familiar echoes ring down the corridors of the Capitol these days as members of Congress, more or less wearily, prepare to get into what has become an annual battle on neutrality legislation.

Fear of imperiling work relief payrolls in many parts of the country next week spurred leaders of both houses of Congress today to plan postponement of all other business on Monday in an effort to pass the First Deficiency Bill, carrying $789,000,000 with relief expenditures among its other items.

Following upon the visit of King Gustaf of Sweden to Brussels land discussion of the development of the Oslo convention, the Netherlands Government has taken the initiative of inviting the three Scandinavian States and Belgium and Luxemburg to send experts here to attend an informal meeting this month-end.

HISTORY sometimes offers instances of men whose lives have been so calamitous that were their biographies the products of fiction the reader would cry out against them for their improbability. Such a life was that of Thomas Paine, whom Hesketh Pearson in a timely biography qualifies as the Friend of Mankind.

THIS new book about Mme. de Sevigne is not a biog raphy. It is modestly presented without any claim even to rounded portraiture. But the reader will lay it down, after finishing its. four scholarly and lucid chapters, with a deepened sense of acquaintance and with a feeling of real gratitude to this English author, not so much for his facts--in themselves not new--as for his emphases.

A committee representing the hundreds of employes of the Fisher and Chevrolet plants in Baltimore, who have been idle since the works were shut down because of the strikes in Michigan, today started a campaign for Congressional legislation to outlaw sit-down strikes.

A wide disparity in the supply and demand for librarians, with $1,800 to $3,000 a year jobs available and no qualified librarians to take them, is reported by Dean C. C. Williamson of the Columbia University School of Library Service.

The stock market rallied briskly yesterday and recovered about half of Friday's losses that resulted from the sudden announcement of the President's plan to reorganize the judiciary. The recovery was led by steel and railway issues with gains of fractions to 2 1/2 points on the short day.
An attempt to clarify the forward pass interference rule, source of woe in football, headed six recommendations framed today by the rules committee of the American Football Coaches Association.

George Thiel, 17, was arrested tonight by police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation when he gave the password designated in an extortion note to Frank J. Boehm, vice president of the Union Electric Light and Power Company, demanding $25,000.

William H. Canning of Clarksboro, five miles from here, a court crier of Gloucester Cbunty courts for the last twenty-six years and connected with the courts as Constable for the last forty-four years, died last night at his home of a heart attack. His age was 85.
Michael Dowery, 16 years old and homeless, was arrested last night on a charge of burglary after the flat he is alleged to have entered at 315 East Eighty-fourth Street caught fire.

Miss Margaret R. Deeks, daughter of Mrs. Robert E. Deeks of this place and the late Mr. Deeks, was married here tonight in the First Presbyterian Church to Robert P. Hahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Hahn, also of Rutherford, by the Rev. Fred M. Holloway.

Miss Marie Veronica Rogers, daughter of Joseph J. Rogers of 971 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to Thomas Howard McEachern Jr., of Medford, Mass. The Rev. John E. Ruppert performed the ceremony in St. Gregory's Catholic Church, Brooklyn.

The excessively collegiate youth of a few years ago is gradually disappearing, Professor Christian Gauss, dean of the college at Princeton University, declared today in revealing that the academic term which ended Tuesday was one of the best from the standpoint of discipline among the undergraduates that he has known.

Dr. Marion Edwards Park, president of Bryn Mawr College, will give a dinner on Tuesday at the deanery on the campus in recognition of Dr. Mary E. Woolley, who is retiring from the presidency of Mount Holyoke College.

Mrs. Maud Lanear, 20 years old, and her 2-year-old daughter of Nevada, Mo., were rescued today from a snow-bound automobile which they had occupied for fifteen days. In that time their only food was half a package of oatmeal mush and a can of mustard.

The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard University will give its ninety-second annual production, "Come Across," in the ballroom of the Bellevue Stratford Hotel on April 7, under the auspices of the Harvard Club of this city.
Miss Frances Dwyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Dwyer of Manchester, became the bride this morning of Peer Eiler Wedvick of New York City, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wedvick of Riverdale, N. Y.

While several hundred fearful spectators watched, two patrolmen dived through holes in the thin ice of the upper Central Park Lake at Seventy-second Street near Central Park West yesterday afternoon and rescued two small girls from the deep water.

Unless Congress extends the authority of the Federal Public Works Administration beyond June 1, 1937, the present expiration date, there is little chance that the city will receive the $12,000,000 grant it has sought to construct the proposed midtown Manhattan underpass under Thirty-eighth Street.

LEADERS in the aircraft industry, assembled last week to do honor to General Oscar Westover, Chief of Air Corps, at a luncheon given by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, expressed great satisfaction at one phase, in particular, of the general's remarks. This dealt with competitive procurement.

Of the record total of 2,631 bills so far introduced into the 1937 Legislature, one of the most interesting was that providing for a $100,000,000 superhighway project, which John A. Macdonald, State Highway Commissioner, has just presented.

With New York City as the hub of a world-wide celebration, Columbia University alumni clubs throughout the nation and in foreign countries will dedicate this year's alumni day on Friday to the School of Law, whose roots go back to 1773, when the first American Professorship of Law was established at Columbia, then King's College.

The British Government is emulating dictatorship countries in its effort to improve the national physique by means of physical training. It has issued proposals for developing and supplementing existing facilities at a cost during the next three years of more than [Pound]2,000,000.

Re-election of Mrs. Carleton M. Hommel of Syracuse as chairman of the New York branch of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom is forecast as one of the developments expected when the seventeenth annual State meeting is held here this week-end.

MEMBERS of Congress. as the New Deal enters its second lap, are acutely aware, regardless of their political affiliation. that the steady expansion of Federal activities which the past four years have witnessed means more work, and chiefly leg work. for Congressmen.
DEALERS in the products of General Motors who operate in the metropolitan area are increasingly feeling the pinch of idle assembly lines due to the strike.

The perennial campaign of teachers' organizations to bring about restoration of salary cuts ended in victory last week when the Board of Estimate, on Governor Lehman's recommendation, took favorable action toward restoration July 1.
The Stevens Tech quintet won their fifth game in seven starts yesterday, beating Drew University of Madison, N. J., 33-21, at the William Hall Walker gym, Castle Point, Hoboken.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Caldwell Manning of Greymont, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Anne Manning, to Richard Harvey Wood, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Clinton Tyler Wood of Philadelphia.

Bert Van Wie, accountant of the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, died today in Bath Hospital at the age of 61. He was graduated from Geneseo Normal School and later taught in public schools and at the Rochester Business Institute.
The touring Marylebone Cricket A Club team today opened a two-day match with Geelong, compiling a first innings score of 282. The home players made 50 for one wicket before the close of play.
Germany launched another 10,000-ton cruiser today amid the blare of bands and patriotic oratory.
Reports from all parts of Soviet Russia told today of the greatest Communist party purge since 1927.

WASHINGTON. NEXT Friday will mark the 128th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln. Except in the Southern States it is noted nationally, and increasingly Lincoln admirers seem to spend the day in Lincoln pilgrimages.

Police tonight examined a blood-stained pocket-knife and a thread of torn wool as clues to the slayer who attacked Mary Ellen Babcock, 18 years old, and left her body in a field last night.

Announcement was made yesterday of the committee for the junior promenade of the University Heights branch of New York University. The twenty-seven committee members appointed represent the University College of Arts and Pure Science and the College of Engineering.
President ROOSEVELT must have anticipated the strong protest made in many places against his proposal to increase the membership of the Supreme Court.

Leonard Hartman of New York and George Seewagon of Jackson Heights, seeded first and fourth, respectively, led the field into the third round of the second annual New Jersey State indoor tennis championship at Llewellyn Hall tonight.

Sharp increases in sales, shipments and unfilled orders were registered by the furniture industry in 1986, according to preliminary figures issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants and auditors.

Seven architects, including one Canadian, have been appointed to the advisory cooperating committee of the Syracuse University Department of Architecture, Dean Harold L. Butler of the College of Fine Arts announced today.

Straightening out the hitherto tangled- affairs of the Syracuse club, which had been their last source of worry, the club owners of the International League concluded their annual Spring meeting at the Hotel Commodore yesterday by ratifying their 1937 championship schedule and expressing the firm belief that the coming season would prove the most prosperous for the circuit in years.

The Montclair State Teachers College quintet turned back the Savage School of Physical Education team, 46-28, on the latter's court yesterday. The New Jersey squad, which was paced by Steve Mueller's 11 points, led at the half. 28-13.
PARIS.--The French Chamber has approved the government's defense program, which includes, among other things, the extension of the Maginot Line along the Swiss and Belgian frontiers.

The marriage of Miss Frances Margaret Wynne, daughter of Mrs. Charles W. Wynne of this city and the late Public Safety Commissioner Wynne, to Alfred J. Callahan, son of Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Joseph M. Callahan of New York, took place here this morning in the Church of St. Ursula.

Ernst Toller's generally well-handled statement, "The Function of Drama," which appeared in your columns on Sunday, Jan. 24, seemed to me to bring up a highly important matter, only to drop it again in a rather odd fashion.

Mr. and Mrs. Merl S. Learnard of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Learnard, to Victor Reid Rose of Bogota, Colombia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Rose of Bismarck, N. D.
Catholicism's emphatic defeat in the South German annual school registration must have stirred ghosts long laid to rest in centuries of German history. In Munich last Sunday practically 96 per cent

The past few days have brought a recurrence, both in military and diplomatic fields, of activity in the Spanish Civil WarWhile General Franco has launched fresh attacks against Malaga, the government forces have started to try to take Cordoba away from the Insurgent forces.
A MUSEUM of radio recordings is being collected by the Canadian Broadcasting System with the aim that the records of historic broadcasts may well be of "inestimable value to posterity."

WITHIN a few weeks, the "pardon" season will begin in Brittany, and it is estimated that 3,000,000 persons will witness or participate in these colorful folk festivals which are a strange combination of religious zeal, Breton legends, innocent revels, and the "Old Home Week" idea.

Lawyers in the Department of Justice said today that no member of Congress would be eligible for appointments during his present term to any of the additional judgeships which might be created under the President's reorganization plan.
Honorary degrees will be conferred upon seven persons. at the mid-year commencement exercises at Temple University on Feb. 15. A class of about 300 students will receive diplomas.
Scoring two falls and three decisions, the Columbia wrestlers defeated Pennsylvania, 19-11, today before several hundred fans at the Palestra.

Ethan Allen's traditional demand for the surrender of Fort Ticonderoga "in the name of the great Jehovah and the Continental Congress," documents recently published by the Fort Ticonderoga Museum suggest, may have been the work of two other men.

In a five-pound report, three inches thick, the Atlas Corporation recorded last week the numerous changes in its structure resulting from the merger with its former subsidiaries, the Pacific Eastern, Shenandoah and the Sterling Security Corporations.

IN the National Aviation Show at the Grand Central Palace, which closed last night, many aircraft accessories missed the scrutiny of the casual visitor. For the most part lay visitors evinced interest in standard airplanes and such displays as those of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, the Bureau of Air Commerce and the commercial air lines.
The problem of disease in the wake of the midcontinental flood grew more pressing today as crests of the swollen Mississippi smashed impotently at miles of unyielding levees.

PERSONAL piety is practically a non-existent quality in Hollywood and, as far as this contributor has been able to discover, the number of ministers of the gospel connected in any way with motion picture studios can be generously set at one. However,

A further Itep toward centralization of chain stores on South Ocean Avenue in his town has just been made in he signing for a long-term lease y the Great A. and P. Tea Com)any on the two-story brick buildng at 77 South Ocean Avenue, fornerly occupied by Hochheiser's Department Store.

With three of its components higher and four lower, THE TIMES weekly index of business activity receded to 101.7 for the week ended Jan. 30. The revised figure for the previous week was 103.4, while a year ago it stood at 92.5.

Following a custom established seven years ago, Antioch College is holding its annual Life's Meaning Conference next Saturday and Sunday. The speakers will be Arthur Braden, president of Transylvania College; Charles Spurgeon Johnson, Negro sociologist,

Miss Emma Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman D. Smith of 277 Park Avenue, was married to Paul Marcy White Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Marcy White of Rye, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Walter T. Kellenberg.

Miss Julia I. Conry, daughter ?? Mrs. John Noonan of Cleveland was married to Thomas Coughlin, also of that city, yesterday morns ing in the Church of St. Jerome at 138th Street and Alexander Avenue the Bronx.

BULTLETINS having been issued that the Theatre Guild plans to keep Katharine Hepburn on the road for the rest of the season, this column seized its musket and scurried off to Chicago, where "Jane Eyre" has been doing a land-office business.

three days after the Supreme Court had declared the NRA unconstitutional-President Roosevelt made his famous "horse-andbuggy" comment on that august tribunal. Facing a crowded press conference, he declared that the court had interpreted the interstate commerce clause of the Constitution in the light of the "horse-and-buggy days of 1789."
A winning streak that had swept through thirty-four straight meets was snapped here tonight when Lehigh's wrestling team crushed Indiana University under a 26-to-15 score.

THE evolution of a sordid tragedy of seventeenth century Rome, which found its most modern expression in a spectacle with words and music last Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera House, was briefly indicated in the program and, with more detail, in the all-English "Libretto."

Although the maritime strike is officially over, the bitter interunion dissension which started it last Fall flared up anew in New York yesterday on the eve of the American Federation of Labor's investigation into disputed union leadership.
JANUARY sales of automobiles to Consumers were larger than in the corresponding month of 1936, according to preliminary estimates.
The second of the season's Knickerbocker Assemblies took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The dance drew a large attendance of former debutantes and their friends.

With Spring needs well covered and early Easter purchases taken care of, the number of buyers in the market and the volume of orders received fell off considerably last week, according to a special report prepared for THE TIMES by Kirby, Blook Co.

Preliminary steps have been taken in Orphans Court to terminate a $150,000 trust fund for Ursinus College, on the ground that the institution has failed to teach and maintain Evangelical Reformed Church principles but has become non-sectarian.

The General Motors Corporation sought in court today to enjoin mass picketing at its strike-closed Fisher Body plant here, and the United Automobile Workers of America replied that the action was part of a "campaign of intimidation and effort to undermine the union."

Discussing the pushcart -market problem in New York City and the efforts being made by Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. of the Department of Markets to elimminate pushcarts from the public streets, I. Goldberg, a member of the Greater New York Taxpayers Association, takes the view that, despite the many objections which have been made, the commissioner's plan should be supported.

Canada's revenues soared more than $6,000,000 in January, compared with last year's figures, according to official figures released today. The National Revenue Department reported for January, 1937, $32,606,978; for January, 1936, $26,330,808.

Miss Anna Gleason of White Plains, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Gleason, was married to Francis M. Nealey of Pleasantville, N. Y., this morning in St. John's Roman Catholic Church here. Mgr. Joseph
Miss Mary Day Dewart, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William Herbert Dewart of Manchester, Mass., was married to Benjamin Allen Goodale of New York today in Trinity Church.

The New York State Association of Retail Liquor Package Stores and the Liquor Dealers Association, through their counsel, Arthur A. Kestler, former Assistant United States Attorney, urged the State Liquor Authority yesterday to put an end to the cut-price war.

Lowered tax rates in New York City are not in sight before 1941 or 1942, Mayor La Guardia told some 1,400 members of the Real Estate Board of New York at their fortyfirst annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore last night.

A collection of gold nuggets, discovered by a British explorer in a washed-out slope of the Llanganatis Mountains, was on display here today, hailed by government officials as an indication that Ecuador holds rich gold resources.

A nursery school program involving the training of deaf children, the training of teachers of the handicapped and extensive research in the needs of the handicapped is being started jointly by the Lexington School for the Deaf, 904 Lexington Avenue, and the Department of Education of the Handicapped, Teachers College.

How the motto on the seal of old Marshall College was designated "Lux et Lex," changed by the die maker to "Lex et Lux," and restored to its original order when Franklin College merged with Marshall in 1850, was revealed this week by Dr.

Michael A. Scudi of 995 Finley Avenue, Bronx, an insurance broker with offices at 154 Nassau Street, died suddenly at six o'clock last night while calling on a client at 428 West Forty-third Street. Mr.

Midwinter alumni day at Rutgers University, to be held on the campus on Feb. 22, will include a varied program of committee meetings, luncheon and dinner, intercollegiate athletics and lectures, Ernest E. McMahon, alumni secretary, announced today.
American veneration for the Supreme Court has puzzled the British people for so many years that there is much relief in this country today over what President Roosevelt has lust done.

Impressions on surrealist art, by means of which prospective exhibitors may rid themselves of real or fancied inhibitions through a "Ga Ga" exhibition of their own handiwork in the realm of surrealism, will be the motif of an exhibition to be held on Feb. 17, 18 and 19 at the Continental Restaurant for the benefit of the Girls' Vacation Fund.

Scholarships for advanced study, research and travel have been established by the American Institute of Architects, which has received $104,000 to promote higher education in architecture from the estate of Edward Langley, architect, of Scranton, Pa., according to announcement yesterday by Stephen F. Voorhees, president of the institute.
STE. MARGUERITE, P. Q. PEOPLE from the United States are finding a new Winter playground in the Laurentians. The range is neither very high nor very rugged.
John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared here tonight that the duty of the Republican party at the moment was to furnish an intelligent "opposition" in national affairs.
This week, for the first time, the New York hound show will be given in conjunction with the allbreed exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club.

Seniors at New Jersey College for Women who major in library service are spending two weeks in public and university libraries in three States, putting into practical application the theory which they have gained through lecture courses.

Contributions from merchants, theatrical and radio enterprises, schools and city employes yesterday continued to swell the fund being collected by the New York chapter of the American Red Cross for flood relief in the Ohio and Mississippi valleys.
Mrs. Melville R. Croll of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jean LoewenLhal, to Elliot Greene, son of Mrs. Max Greene, also of this city, and Lhe late Mr. Greene.
Real estate in New York City has a 1937 final valuation of $16,599,695,194, a total $79,070,354 less than the 1936 final figures, the Board of Taxes and Assessments announced yesterday.
The little red school house is going modern in five rural counties of Southwestern Michigan.

A group of one-family houses designed to permit addition of bedrooms and bath on the upper floor at a minimum cost and at such time as the need arises, is being constructed at Westport, Conn., by the Evergreen Park Company, Philip Sands Graham architect.
Tne war Lepartment released the following orders today, dated Feb. 5: Colonels Slaughter, H. H., Inf., General Staff Corps. 5 days' leave, Feb. 8.

The Manhattan College paid tribute to Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, '73, one of its oldest and most distinguished graduates, -at the sixtyeighth annual dinner of the alumni society at the Hotel Astor last night.

WHEN John Howard Lawson's "Marching Songg" opens at the Bayes Theatre on Wednesday eveunig, Feb. 17. the organisation preenuing it will be described as Theatre Union, and to the degree that it represents a continuity from "Peace on Earth," "Stevedore," "Sailors of Cattaro," "Black Pit," "Mother," "Let Freedom Ring" and "Bitter Stream," it is carrying on its widely known precepts of combining the entertaining and the instructive in drama.

With Rudolf Serkin as piano soloist, the National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, gave the first of its special series of five Mozart-Beethoven concerts at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The program, following the happy idea conceived by Mr. Barzin for each of the events vents series, contrained a Mozart and a Beethoven piano concerto and also an orchestral overture by each of these composers.

THE charm of "My Circus Animals" lies in its simplicity and unpretentiousness. The reader has the feeling that he has come upon this famous clown and animal trainer, Grandfather Durov, in a moment of leisure behind the scenes and has found him quite willing to answer questions and to describe in detail his method of animal training.

Arrangements for the annual ball of the Madison House Society on March 20 at the Plaza will be discussed today at a tea for the trustees of the organization and members of the dance committee at the Plaza.
A SYMPHONY of Tikhon Chrennikoff, young Rusian composer, will receive its first hearing here at the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra,under Eugene Ormandy on Feb. 16, in Carnegie Hall.

Millions of pounds of fresh and frozen fish are coming into the markets--the fresh chiefly from Southern waters, the remainder from the cold storage supply--to meet the demands of New Yorkers during the Lenten season, which begins on Wednesday.

Word was received here yesterday of the death from a heart attack in Rome, Italy, of Pier Adolfo Tir- b indelli, Italian violinist and composer, who was at one time head of the violin department of the Cincinnati Conservatory. He was born b in Conegliano, Italy, seventy-eight years ago. After a long residence and professional career in this country he returned to Italy fifteen years ago.

Mrmbers of the Supreme Court not only maintained silence today on President Roosevelt's proposal to revamp the court, but went into deeper seclusion than ever. Frank Key Green, the court marshal, issued orders barring newspaper men and others from the justices' section of the building, except by special appointment.

Enrollment in the Constitution Essay Contest, being conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES for secondary school students in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, reached a total of 826 schools last week with about 110,000 student participants.

A plea for scientific study and planning in retail structures and particularly in the construction of outlying business centers featured an address by T. C. Nichols of Kansas City, Mo., at the recent South Central regional convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in St. Louis. Mr. Nichols is a vice president of the association and a director of the American Planning and Civic Association.

One of the most misguided notions of this and past generations is that "society" is composed of a class of people known as the "idle rich." Few of the alleged four hundred are idle. Most of our debutantes and sub-debs, our socalled "playboys," are hard-working women and men in the business world. Some are clerks in department stores, some do secretarial work, some even do menial labor.

As 35,000 maritime workers go back to work after a strike that paralyzed Pacific Coast shipping for 100 days, all hands are asking how long peace will continue and what guarantee exists that it will not happen again.

Despite the number of adverse factors facing business in January and this month, first quarter industrial operations should run considerably ahead of the corresponding period of a year ago, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

Winning seven of the eight events, the star swimming team of Blair Academy defeated the Columbia freshmen, 49-17, yesterday in the Morningside Heights pool. Completing the afternoon's freshman sports program was the basketball victory of Raymond Riordon Prep over the Lions by 42-20 and the 6-3 triumph scored by the Stuyvesant High School fencers.

Five government departments will have exhibits at the World TwoWay Trade Fair to be held here from May 10 to 22, it was announced yesterday. They include the Tariff Commission, and the department of State, Commerce, Agriculture and Labor.
The Real Estate Association of the State of New York has organized a committee headed by J. Howard Johnson of Albany to offer an arbitration service to the public and to members of realty boards.

TELEVISION receivers have been installed and successfully operated on both sound and vision within a fiftymile radius of Alexandra Palace, where the British Broadcasting Company's ultra-short-wave television station is located.

Miss Florence Cavanaugh, daughter of Mrs. Emma Cavanaugh of this city and the late Harry Cavanaugh, was married to Carl Stavener, son of Charles Stavener of South Amboy and the late Mrs. Marie Stavener, this morning at the rectory of Holy Rosary Catholic Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Phillip McCabe.

Referee Burt Jay Humphrey, who retired from the Supreme Court bench the first of the year, was the guest of honor last night at the annual dinner of the Queens County Bar Association at the Hotel Biltmore.
After a month of unusually mild weather Bermuda today was whipped by a rain and wind storm that at one time reached a velocity of ninety-four miles an hour.
New York teams emerged triumphant in both halves of the basketball double-header at the Hippodrome last night before 3,000 spectators as St. John's scored

Mayor Harold Fisher Mason of Glen Cove and Miss Violet A. Jensen, daughter of Mrs. Emma Sandahl of Huntington and the late John Jensen, were married tonight at the home of the bride's brother in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Curran. The Rev. Frank B.
Daughters of Ohio-Tea dance, cards, 3 P. M., St. Regis Hotel. League of Girls' Clubs-Holiday House reunion, 4 P. M., League House.

Gina Cigna, recently of La Scala and also of leading opera houses in Europe and South America, made her debut in this country yesterday afternoon as Aida in the Metropolitan Opera House. She was very well received, and her appearance gave notice that the Metropolitan has in her a new soprano well equipped by the quality of her voice and the resources of her technique to do justice to this great role.

An alphabetical index of the program preferences of women's organizations in New Jersey, available through the compilation of a "great calendar" of topics under the direction of Mrs. Sherman L. Black of Orange, skips nimbly from culture to adventure, through legislation to recreation, from courts to sports and back again.

Apartment houses opened for renting in Brooklyn during 1936 are now 92 per cent occupied, according to a survey of new buildings conducted by the Brooklyn Real Estate Board. The survey covered seventy buildings of the seventy-seven apartment structures completed during the year.

More than 250 veterans of the 308th Infantry, among whom were many of those who make up the famous "Lost Battalion" during the World War, attended a reunion dinner of the regiment last night at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

To the Editor of The New York Timea: I read with great interest your editorial "Business Concentration," which discusses the study of the Twentieth Century Fund and the book which I wrote with Gardiner C. Means, "The Modern Corporation and Private Property." Since I am a member of the committee of the Twentieth Century Fund, it is perhaps appropriate to commnent on your editorial.

Good Counsel High School of Newark captured the two State group track and field championship for the fourth consecutive time tonight in the ninth annual meet of The Newark Sunday Call at the 113th Regiment Armory.

Members of the Alumnae Association of St. Elizabeth's Academy, Convent, N. J., gave a bridge tea and fashion show yesterday afternoon at the Ritz Tower to raise money for the establishment of two scholarships at St. Xavier's College for the academy students.

A radio address by President Roosevelt from the White House tomorrow will feature a week's celebration, beginning today, of the twenty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the Boy Scouts of America. Waiter W. Head,

New York's own little flood the other day at Central Park West, where a broken main flooded a private hospital and several apartment house cellars, directs attention to one of the engineering marvels of the age-the city's water supply system. Each day 913,100,000 gallons of water comes in from distant rural reservoirs; is distributed through 4,686.4 miles of mains under the city's streets.
Two hold-ups occurring in the Bronx between 6:30 and 7:30 o'clock last night were believed to have been committed by the same band of three robbers. The total loot taken was $759.

The debating society of the college of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, has announced a full program for the new semester. Trained by Gabriel Liegey, Assistant Professor of English, the teams will meet rivals from many local and distant colleges.

Frank E. Gannett, publisher of the Gannett group of sixteen newspapers, accused President Roosevelt today of having "cleverly camouflaged a most amazing and startling proposal for packing the Supreme Court."
A special grand jury directed by Governor Bibb Graves to investigate the lynching of Wes Johnson, 19-yearold Negro, failed today to return indictments.

In forming opinions as to the consistency and public authority of the President's plan to keep the courts of the country younger and more in tune with changing conditions, and to accelerate that judicial process which now keeps litigation the luxury of the few, it is desirable to bear three things in mind.

Junior metropolitan A. A. U. titles in the low board dive and the 220-yard free style for men will be decided in the A. A. U. swimming meet to be conducted under the auspices of the Park Central Athletic Association in the Park Central pool on Sunday, Feb. 28.
MORE than 15,000 letters a week are being received at the United States Office of Education in response to its educational radio projects.
Upsets marked play in both B and C divisions as the New Jersey individual squash racquets championships opened at the Plainfield Country Club today.

President Roosevelt's proposal to have Congress empower him to add a justice of the United States Supreme Court for each of the six justices over 70 years of age continued yesterday to meet opposition from leading lawyers In this city.

The University of New Hampshire is introducing a course on weather forecasting. Touched on in previous courses given by Dr. Donald Chapman, the weather now occupies for the first time a course by itself. It is on the "prescribed and recommended" list for the second semester, and is called "Elementary Meteorology."

In a surprising feat as a rank outsider, W. F. Flannigan's Chanceview ran away with the $5,000 added San Carlos Handicap today at Santa Anita Park and became a formidable threat for the- $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap three weeks hence.

The formal opening of the completed elevated express highway along the West Side between Canal and Seventy-second Streets Tuesday will be -the climax of a drive started in 1926 by Borough President Julius Miller of Manhattan and carried to conclusion by his successor, Borough -President Samuel Levy.

Gross revenues of manufactured and natural gas companies for the eleven months to Nov. 30, 1936, totaled $700,835,800, against $660,602,500 correspondingly in 1935, an increase of 6.1 per cent, according to the American Gas Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Park Logan of Belle Haven, Greenwich, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjory Logan, to Richard Davol Chapman, son of Mrs. John Davol Chapman of Round Island, Greenwich, and the late Mr. Chapman.

The program of refunding and redemption of the Argentine dollar debt in this market is definitely linked with the reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Argentina that- is expected to be negotiated this year, according to opinions expressed last week in foreign trade circles.

Mrs. Louise Weller Reges of East Orange, N. J., widow of Maximillan F. Reges, was married here yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Church, to Rudolph Euler of York, Pa., by the rector, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent.

Dr. Edward S. Robinson, Professor of Psychology at Yale University, has presented to the university a piano made in England about 1779, the gift being in memory of his wife, Mrs. Florence Richardson Robinson, who had been Professor of Psychology at Drake University and a member of the faculty of Chicago University.

Pie for breakfast has long been a good old New England custom, so the story goes. Some New Englanders hesitate to admit they eat pie for breakfast in these days, however. Not so with Charles S. Dana of this town, former Speaker of the House of Representatives and undisputed pie-eating champion of Vermont.

Sigmund Seiferheld, president of N. Erlanger, Blumgart Co., manufacturers of linings, of 354 Fourth Avenue, died on Friday at his home, 1,130 Park Avenue. He was 62 years old. Mr. Seiferheld was born in Germany and came to this country in 1892, joining the Erlanger firm two years later.
Three out of every four persons in the United States neither. brush their teeth nor consult a dentist, it was disclosed at a meeting of the Dental Institute of America.
Dick Neal of Kansas City drove his Class B outboard hydroplane to victory in the Southeastern championship regatta today and equaled the world record for the event.
Elihu Root, former Secretary of State and widely known for his service in many other posts and his efforts to promote world peace, died at his home, 998 Fifth Avenue, early today.
In an interview yesterday Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg fully confirmed what this correspondent reported two days ago regarding Italy's unchanged policy in respect to the independence of Austria.

ALTHOUGH it is far too early in the season to begin shouting hosannahs for 1937, there can be no great harm in whispering that the screen year is off to an encouraging start. In the brief span of five weeks we have had "The Eternal Mask," "The Plainsman," "Black Legion," "Camille," "You Only Live Once," "The Plough and the Stars" and "The Good Earth."
