WHILE those insured motorists who live in the socalled high-rate zone of Greater New York were doubtless gratified to learn last week that the rate for public liability insurance had been cut $5 to $90 a year and that the rate for property damage insurance had been cut $1, with the approval of the State Superintendent of Insurance. Louis H. Pink,

For thirty-five years the Bulgarian Women's Union has worked for the social, mental and moral elevation of women as well as for equal civil and political rights with men. Last year it was compelled formally to renounce any political aims.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Palmer of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Alling Palmer, to Joseph Michael Healy of San Pedro, Calif., son of Mrs. John Healy of Eyota, Minn., and the late Mr. Healy.

Pensioned On their own applications: PATROLMEN To take effect 12 midnight, Feb. 7: Patrick T. Powers, Traffic Precinct F,. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 3, 1908. To take effect 12 midnight, Feb. 8:

A concert by several members of the Metropolitan Opera Association will be given tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress to finance the educational activities of the organization in the promotion of better understanding between Jews and non-Jews.
Scoring three goals in the first period, the Montreal Maroons topped the New York Rangers, 4-2, tonight in a National Hockey League contest before a crowd of 6,000.

C. T. S. Keep of the National Real Estate Clearing House, in citing the improvement of large estate sales and homes in the higher price range, points out that while the lending policy of the FHA created the appearance of a trend toward low-price housing during the past year, the purchaser demand for properties in the higher brackets will undoubtedly assert itself more vigorously in 1937.

The requirements of a radio program and a twin-motored transport plane brought 20-year-old Florence Hurlbut here yesterday from Excelsior Springs, Mo., where on Tuesday Harold Hulen began a sit-down strike for her hand.
The annual dinner, dance and entertainment of the 307th Infantry Post of the American Legion will take place on Saturday night at the Capitol Hotel, Fifty-first Street and Eighth Avenue.

Mrs. Ary J. Lamme Jr. of Apawamis, who already this season has captured the metropolitan and New Jersey championships, today added another major squash racquets victory to her string by winning the ninth annual invitation tournament of the Ardsley Country Club.

Mr. and Mrs. William Marbury Beall of Washington, D. C., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Beall, to Thomas Wistar Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wistar of Germantown.

The drastic effect of strikes on production of the General Motors Company, which has seen its output decline from a peak of 53,000 units in the middle of December to barely 1,500 last week, was disclosed today in production figures since full operations on current models got under way in November.

Ambrose Hilliard Douglas, a Negro 92 years old and the father of thirty-seven children, told the Board of Social Welfare today that the thirty-eighth was on the way. The Welfare Board will give the baby, the thirteenth by Douglas's present wife, a complete layette.
PALM BEACH, Fla.-One of the outstanding musical events of the Palm Beach season will be held on Tuesday night, when the Romany Chorus presents its annual concert.

The Pennsylvania Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue $52,670,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/4 per cent convertible debenture bonds with which to finance completion of its electrification program between New York, Washington, Philadelphia and Harrisburg and to make other betterments and retire maturing obligations..

Miss Anne Heywood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson Heywood of this city, was married to Eugene Gordon Reid, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Reid, also of New York, and Old Greenwich, Conn., at noon yesterday in the parish house of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola by the Rev. Thomas J. Delihant.

Under the auspices of the board of directors of the Catholic Young Women's Club, the fourteenth annual luncheon, followed by bridge, will be held on Feb. 25 at the Ritz Carlton. Mrs. Paul T.'Kammerer Jr. heads the committee in charge.
WELCOME as more than just another indication of the extraordinary revival of interest in the gramophone, a second independent venture has entered the field.

Probably the most remarkable phenomenon of the Louisville flood, which as this is written still covers one-third of the city's area, is that despite the fact that 230,000 persons were obliged to flee from high waters, many into crowded quarters without water, sewerage and other services of comfort, there was little loss of life and no epidemic.

John C. Dolph, a pioneer in the manufacture of insulating varnishes for the electrical industry, died yesterday in his home at 569 Mount Prospect Avenue, here, after a long illness. He was 72 years old. He was president of the John C. Dolph Company of Newark, a business he founded here twenty-five years ago.

MR. ALEXANDER'S life of Aaron Burr is a notable and worthy contribution to American biography. It is unsentimental--and that term includes sentiment either for or against the colorful Colonel Burr. It is factual, interesting and virile.

A leisurely thudding of sneakered feet in slow motion and a soft plopping of half-dead tennis balls are getting to be familiar sounds around the Congressional gymnasium these days. They are the unique noises of "paddle ball," a game devised for Washington's statesmen and said to be the greatest and safest conditioner for Congressmen in the history of representative institutions.

A short life is predicted for the new Cabinet by many observers. The circumstances in which the administration was born obliged it to reject the political parties, and Premier Senjuro Hayashi's failure to make Lieut. Gen. Seishiro Itagaki as War Minister deprives him of the active support of the army's Right Wing.
Friends of the progressive education movement are encouraged by the showing made In public high schools by the graduates of the Little Red Schoolhouse.
Georgia Tech, with a winning streak of seven games, was stopped by Pennsylvania tonight at the Palestra, 31-30, after putting up a keen fight.

Howard Leland Smith, chief architect of the Federal Housing Administration discussed various phases of the government's housing program before a conference of builders, realtors and others at the Essex House, Newark, N. J., last week.
WITH the appearance of Mr. Winther's second novel, in which he continues the saga of the Grimsens, it seems clear that there is more still to follow.
The commercial agreement between Peru and Argentina has been signed at Buenos Aires. It will be in force for two years and may be prolonged by mutual agreement.
Dr. Gilson C. Engel, instructor in surgery at the University of Pennsylvania, said here that physical effects of the depression are yet to be felt by American men.

The indications are for partly cloudy and slightly colder weather today. Snow or rain is expected tomorrow with little change in the temperature, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

The city's proposed new building code will be the topic of a luncheon tern meeting of the- New York Building Congress on Wednesday at the Architectural League. The speakers will be Edward J. Sullivan, chairman of the- Aldermanic Committee on Buildings, and Bernard Gillroy,

Nearly 2,000 delegates at the first session here tonight of the National Conference for Palestine were told by the chairman, Dr. Stephen S. Wise of New York, that theirs was a "peace mobilization" to further the rebuilding of the Jewish homeland in the Holy Land.

ASTOR-The Good Earth: Paul Muni, Luise Rainer. BELMONT-Robber Symphony.* CAMEO-Spain in Flames, a documentary film.* CAPITOL-Camille: Greta Garbo, Robert Taylor.* CRITERION-Great Guy: James Cagney, Mae Clarke.* 55TH ST. PLAYHOUSE-Masquerade in Vienna: Paula Wessely.* FILMARTE-The Eternal Mask: Mathias Wieman.* GLOBE-Beloved Vagabond: Maurice Chevalier. MUSIC HALL-On the Avenue: Dick Powell, Madeleine Carroll. PALACE-Black Legiont agnd Off to the Races. PARAMOUNT--Champagne Waltz: Gladys Swarthout, Fred MacMurray.
The Sullivant moss herbarium, comprising some 20,000 specimens and constituting one of the most valuable collections of its kind in the world, is now in the custody of Duke Uniyersity.

The Apawamis Club here will celebrate Lincoln's Birthday with a buffet luncheon and musical. Next Saturday evening a dinner dance will be held. The Scarsdale Golf Club will be the scene next Sunday of a holiday tea dance and buffet supper.

THE center of interest shifts this week to Philadelphia where on Friday evening the Philadelphia Ballet Company will make the first American pres entation of Tchaikovsky's "The Sleephig Beauty" in its uncut form, lasting two hours and a half.

The engagement of Miss Winnifred Emily Scott, daughter of Mrs. Thomas B. Scott of this place, to Dr. John Lyon Caughey Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. John Lyon Caughey of Glens Falls, N. Y., has been announced by her mother.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 3 aggregated $10,672,000,000, or 16 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 16 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Concern over the fact that young people were not reading the works of Charles Dickens was expressed last night by speakers at the dinner celebrating the 125th anniversary of the author's birth, which was held by the Dickens Fellowship of New York at the Hotel Brevoort.

Miss Amy Burril Rainier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Rainier of the Plandome Colony here, was married at noon today in the rectory of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Roslyn, to John Berchman Cavanagh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Francis Cavanagh of Roslyn.
The New York Central Railroad became the third largest subscriber to New York World's Fair debentures yesterday with a subscription of S400,00.
With the exception of real estate, accounts receivable now constitute the largest single item on the average store's balance sheet, reflecting the effect of the sharp upswing in retail credit sales.

THEY seem to have settled that little matter of a London production of "You Can't Take It With You." When Washington Heights goes to the Thames it will be with Mr. Coward's John C. Wilson as manager and guide. And while he was about it, Mr. Wilson acquired also the English rights to "Reflected Glory."

Miss Jane Kershaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Kershaw of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to William Spence Harvey 3d, son of Mrs. Lefferts Leffert Downing of Chestnut Hill, and of William Spence Harvey 2d.
Dartmouth's basketball team rose to the occasion before a Winter carnival throng of 2,500 tonight by slapping a surprise defeat on Yale, 35-25, in an Eastern Intercollegiaite League game.
What breed will be represented by the best-in-show award in the Garden Friday night? The percentage is in favor of one of the twenty-one types of terriers.
Breaking a tie in the last minute of play, the Syracuse basketball team took a 39-35 decision over Colgate tonight in a game that kept 3,000 spectators in an uproar.

The annual theatre party of the Tiny Tim Society of the House of St. Giles the Cripple will be held on the night of March 1 at the Broadhurst Theatre, where the committee has taken over the orchestra seats for a performance of "Victoria Regina." The society,

A collection of Napoleonic relics recently given to Hamilton College by Mrs. Mary L. Miller of New York City in the name of her late husband, Roswell Miller, '69, former Midwestern railroad executive, is being exhibited in the college library.

The annual theatre party of the Tiny Tim Society of the House of St. Giles the Cripple will be held on the night of March 1 at the Broadhurst Theatre, where the committee has taken over the orchestra seats for a performance of "Victoria Regina." The society,

A collection of Napoleonic relics recently given to Hamilton College by Mrs. Mary L. Miller of New York City in the name of her late husband, Roswell Miller, '69, former Midwestern railroad executive, is being exhibited in the college library.
TWO distinct categories divide the miscellaneous collections which will be sold at Sotheby's in London on Feb. 15 and 16.

FLORIDA'S hospitality still extends to automobile trailers. But they have come here in such large numbers this season as to create several problems that are being studied with no little concern by permanent residents.
The Federal automotive tax bill for 1936 was $338,100,126, the largest since inception of the special taxes, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compared with $296,086,980 in 1935.
Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholio Diocese of Brooklyn has written an appeal for funds to pastors of the churches of the diocese to meet the annual budget for Catholic high schools.

Hearn Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday that it had purchased the Adams-Flanigan Store, 150th Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx. The store will be renovated and remodeled and known in the future as HearnsBronx.

The entry today of Allan Potts in the North American amateur outdoor skating championship made certain that all members of the 1936 United States Olympic skating team would compete. The threeday meet begins Friday.

Robert A. Taft, whose father was President and Chief Justice, said today the President's judiciary plan was an attempt to "secure personal control of the entire government." Mr. Taft was a "favorite son" candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination last Summer.

The Royal Mint announces that the King and Queen have given their approval to the designs for the coronation medals that have been executed by Langford Jones and Percy Metcalfe, to whom Their Majesties have given sittings.

The first in a series of buffet suppers with dancing, to be held on Sunday evenings this month in the Caprice Room of the Weylin, will take place tonight. Arranged by an invitation committee, of which Mrs. John L. Tonnele is chairman, the parties will be featured by dancing instruction, general dancing, bridge, backgammon and other indoor games..

For the first time in the history of figure skating in the United States the national championships, when they take place in the Chicago Arena next Friday and Saturday, will have left the Eastern seaboard.

The second effort to get a separate trial for 18-year-old Donald Wight-man of Bayonne, who, with his 17-year-old school chum, Gladys Mac Knight, is accused of murdering the latter's mother, Mrs. Helen Macknight, in Bayonne last July, failed today when Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the Supreme Court denied an application for a writ of certiorari.

The protection afforded by the Old Age Security Act depends very largely on what taxpayers twenty years hence think about it, in the opinion of Dr. William O. Hotchkiss, president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

Virtually on the eve of the trial of Major Green, 33-year-old Negro, for the murder of Mrs. Mary Harriet. Case on Jan. 11, counsel for the defendant charged yesterday that there has been an attempt to stir up class hatred against him. The charge was denied by District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens.

When the Japanese people survey the battlefield after the recent Cabinet crisis they are puzzled to say which side won. The encounter between the army and General Ugaki was fought on a limited 'issue, and the only decision registered was that the army's "Big Three" were strong enough to keep General Ugaki 'out of office.
HILLSDALE, Mich. - Dogs walk in honor in Michigan this centennial year, since historians report they were so valuable to Wolverine State pioneers that they became a medium of exchange.

Carlos Jolly, counsel for the General Motors Corporation in Detroit, conferred today with Judge Paul V. Gadola of the Circuit Court relative to filing an application for an injunction against the sit-down strikers now holding Chevrolet Plant No. 4.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that its total disbursements to Jan. 31 had been $11,897,986,417, which figure in cluded $882,469,031 to other governmental agencies and $1,799,984,733 for relief. Of the total disbursements, $6,387,619,095 went to activities other than advances to governmental agencies and for relief, and $4,395,891,427 of this sum had been repaid, according to the report.

Howard S. Palmer, Winthrop M. Daniels and James Lee Loomis, trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad system and the Hartford Connecticut Western Line, filed today in the Federal court here petitions requesting authority to apply to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to abandon fourteen separate segments of what is described as unprofitable railroad in New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts, totaling 204.34 miles.

Certain types of begonias have for centuries been satisfactory dwellers in window-gardens. It would be possible to select varieties that would produce blooms in every month of the year, but some of them would be difficult to obtain, and they would vary in cultural needs.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh and their son are now so much a part of the English rural scene that it is only on such rare occasions as this week, when Colonel Lindbergh bought a new airplane and started off on a "mysterious" flight, that they get any mention in the British press.

Interests connected with the use of automobiles and the consumption of gasoline are up in arms, it was disclosed yesterday, over the budget proposals of Governor Lehman, which provide only $33,000,000 for highways but urge an additional taxation on gasoline of 1 cent a gallon. The Automobile Club of America, the Automobile Club of New York and many motor clubs upState have scored the proposals.
The marriage of Miss Barbara Potter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Bertram Potter, to John Lawrence Milton, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gerald Milton of Jersey City, N. J., took place today.

Deep human sympathy, a profound emotional insight which laid bare the soul of each selection on an unusually lengthy program, informed the stirring interpretations put forth by George Enesco last night at Carnegie Hall in the course of his last students' concert of the season with the Philharmonic-Syminhnnv Orchestra.
McGill University strengthened its grip on first place in the International Intercollegiate -Hockey League today, overcoming the University of Toronto, 6-3, for its seventh successive victory.

The Ohio River fell 9 feet in 24 hours at Cincinnati, bringing it to 10 feet below the 52-foot flood stage which it passed on Jan. 18. Falling 5.5 feet at Louisville the river was within 8 feet of flood stages.
Breaking a national preparatory school record in the 150-yard medley, Mercersburg swimmers defeated the Penn State freshmen, 47-24, today for their fifth straight victory.
A new air speed record between Chicago and New York of 2 hours 53 minutes for large, two-engine transport planes was established yesterday by the American Air Lines ship, the Arrow.
Stimulated by more favorable developments, including an improvement in weather conditions, business expanded over a wide front last week, with retail trade leading in the general upturn.

NEW Year's Eve provoked singular musical combinations. In the Theatre on the Buelow Platz, according to a custom of several years' standing, Beethoven's Ninth symphony was performed, so that the New Year was ushered in with the Invocation to Joy.
History discloses that Presidents frequently cannot depend on their appointees to the Supreme Court to uphold the policies of the party to which they belong.

A new "fair trade practice" measure, designed to prevent price-cutting on widely advertised products, requires only the signature of Governor Jensen to make it effective July 1. South Dakota is the seventeenth State to pass such a law, modeled after a California statute held constitutional by the Supreme Court.

Bryan M. Grant, Atlanta's "giant killer," teamed with Wayne Sabin of Los Angeles today to win the Surf Club tennis doubles by defeating Charles Harris of Palm Beach and Dr. Eugene McCauliff of Chicago, 3-6, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4.

Field agents of the Building Service Employes International Union began yesterday to map a strike campaign designed to force the owners of between 1,500 and 2,000 buildings, who have never negotiated with the union,

President Roosevelt turned back today to study of his program for reorganization of the executive establishment of the Federal government, while most members of Congress still were discussing his dramatic action yesterday in recommending sweeping reorganization of the Fedeal courts, including the Supreme Court itself.
Tewfik Rushdu Aras, the Turkish Foreign Minister, spent most of yesterday in conference with Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch.

While Federal judges in the United States Courthouse in Foley Square declined to be quoted yesterday because they are "part of the system," there were expressed some private, guarded opinions concerning the President's projected bill for increasing and rejuvenating the judiciary.

The first formal dance to be sponsored by the men's student body of the College of William and Mary since the disbandment of the Cotillion Club will be. held on Feb. 19 in the George Preston Blow Memorial Gymnasium.

The Iona Prep quintet gained undisputed possession of first place in the Bronx-Westchester division of the C. H. S. A. A. by repulsing the Manhattan Prep team, 25 to 16, in the Manhattan College gym yesterday.
The Yale swimming team tonight gained its 157th consecutive victory by beating Rutgers, 43-32, in a meet marked by brilliant competition and close finishes.

Miss Elise S. Meyer will be married to M. Lawrence Maier this afternoon at the home of her stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. August Strauss, 310 West Seventyninth Street. The ceremony will be performed by Dr. Joseph S. Kornfeld, United States Minister to Persia under President Harding, and uncle of the prospective bridegroom. He will be assisted by Dr. Nathan Stern of this city.

Registration this week of forty-five Syracuse students for a course in broadcasting technique, which in the past three years has sent seventy graduates out into commercial radio work as announcers, continuity writers and program directors, is indicative of the increasing interest in "getting on the air."

An appeal for the cooperation of government and industry in projects of the Resettlement Administration, such as that at Arthurdale, one mile from Reedsville, W. Va., is stressed in a report of the Committee for Economic Recovery. After a careful study the committee concludes that the Arthurdale experiment should become a pattern upon which other communities may be modeled.

A charge that diplomas and college entrance ratings have been offered for sale directed attention again today upon Woodrow Wilson High School, whose principal, Winthrop M. Johnson, resigned recently following inquiry into his management of a students' savings fund.
A legislative committee investigating law enforcement in Hot Springs stated today it believed impeachment proceedings against officials here were "inevitable."

Mr. and Mrs. Howland S. Davis entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Cornelia R. Kellogg, debutante daughter of Mrs. Frederic R. Kellogg. The other guests were the Misses Jane Travers, Cecilia B. Drinker, Eulalie Pepper and Catherine L. Davis and Robert St. J. Borden, David L. Howe, Howland Davis and Piero Senni.

Pulp and paper interests in the United States have approached the Saskatchewan governmbnt seeking concessions in northern timber areas for a paper mill, it was learned today. The plan is said to involve construction of a mill on Dore Lake, 150 miles northwest of this city, a power project and a railway to connect with the Canadian National at Big River.

Champion Mistress Petticoats of Pastorale, a superb Old English sheepdog, owned by Mrs. Lewis Roesler of Great Barrington, Mass., and handled by George J. McKercher, tonight was awarded best in show at the closing session of the twentyfourth annual exhibition of the Maryland Kennel Club in the Fifth Regiment Armory.

Serious street fighting occurred again in Sian last night. The fighting was between Communists and the anti-Nanking faction on one side and the faction that stands for a peaceful withdrawal on the other.

DR. ALES HRDLICKA, curator of anthropology of the Smithsonian Institution, has been measuring the heads of old Americans (persons with at least three generations of American blood in them on both sides), the heads of members of the National Academy of Sciences and the heads of Indians.
Jimmy Lancaster, 129, Wilmington, Del., outpointed the Iavana Kid, 127, Havana, in the feature bout of six rounds at Ridgewood Grove last night. A crowd of 2,500 was present. Tony Marteliano, 139,

The Dionne quintuplets are to be copyrighted. That does not mean that any Canadian mother following the example of Mrs. Dionne would be exposed to prosecution for patent infringement. It does mean, however, that, even though fate should again deal out five of a kind to some Canadian and they should survive, they might be quintuplets, but could never be known as "the" quintuplets.
With New York's department and food. stores cooperating the Board of Education is proposing to give young people and adults more basic training in the distributive and food trades.
Prospects for new impetus in the movement to have February designated as a month for special tributes to American composers were reported yesterday by Baroness Katharine Evans Von Kienner.

The Toronto Maple Leafs tonight strengthened their hold on third place in the National Hockey League's international group as they gave the tailend New York Americans a 5-0 drubbing to further dim the playoff hopes of the Red Dutton team.

The marriage of Miss Emily Denton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Douglas Denton of Hollis, Queens, to Edward D. Tunis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Tunis of Boston, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Gabriel's Church, Hollis. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Frederick L. Barry.

Chet Withey, 50 years old, actor and pioneer motion-picture director, was critically injured early today, when struck by an automobile. Lawrence Nelson, driver of the car, stopped to give first aid. He said that Mr. Withey appeared suddenly from behind a trolley car.

MAXWELL ANDERSON'S third play of this season and his sixteenth to date is "The Masque of Kings," which the Theatre Guild will present tomorrow with Henry Hull, Margo, Dudley Digges and Pauline Frederick playing, respectively, the roles of Prince Rudolf of AustriaHungary, the Baroness Mary Vetzera, the Emperor Franz-Josef, and the Empress Elizabeth.
Charles (Bud) Wilkinson, quarter back star at Minnesota, has been appointed a member of the Syracuse University coaching staff for the coming season.

Miss Evelyn Soule Wurzburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Wurzburg of Bronxville, has chosen Feb. 26 as the date for her marriage to John Hampton-Barnes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs.- John Hampton Barnes of Devon, Pa. The ceremony will take place in the Church of the Resurrection, this city.

An attendance of several hundred persons, including members of the Lincoln Fellowship Society of New York and their friends, is expected at the Lincoln's Birthday luncheon to be given by the society on Friday in the Blue Room of the Hotel Lincoln.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Helen Gierding, daughter of Dr. Ernest A. Gierding of West Orange and the late Mrs. Gierding, to Stephen S. Fagerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley S. Hagerman of Maplewood.

The annual junior riding competition for private schools in Greenwich will be held at the indoor ring of the Round Hill Stables on Feb. 27. One of the principal events will be the team class for the Marguerite Noble Trophy, formerly presented by Miss Gertrude Ely.

The House Plan, the social activities center at City College, has been found to be a necessity and has executed its function with marked success, according to the semi-annual report of the director, Mortimer Karpn.

EASTER and pre-Easter holidays will see a lively exodus from New York and vicinity to various playgrounds. Since Lincoln's birthday falls on a Friday and Washington's on a Monday, many citizens have declared an extra vacation for themselves.
ROCKAWAY, N. J., Feb. 6.-Mr. and Mrs. Llewellyn Decker of Hill Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Gertrude Decker, to Charles W. Reilly of Hasbrouck Heights.

Announcement will be made at a tea tomorrow afternoon at the home of Miss Emma Lee of Newark of the engagement of her niece, Miss Harriet Jane Lee, daughter of Recorder and Mrs. Thomas E. Lee of Mount Arlington, to Stanton James MacIntosh, son of Mr. and Mrs. James G. MacIntosh of Passaic and Lake Hopatcong.

CARLOS CHAVEZ, the Mexican conductor, will be guest of honor at a reception of the League of Composers, Feb. 21, at the Cosmopolitan Club. A program of chamber works by Mr. Chavez will precede the reception.

All the circumstances are so different between the stay-in strikes that were epidemic in France last Summer and Fall and the sit-down strike in the automobile industry in the United States, that it is unwise to compare them in any way.

Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street, 11 A. M. "The Cult of Force." Professor Hans Kohn. "New and Old Japan," Burton Holmes, Martin Beck Theatre, 302 West Forty-fifth Street, 2:45 P. M. and 8:30 P. M.

Underwear buyers have placed such a large volume of advance business on heavyweight cotton ribbed numbers for Fall that the volume of reorderss usually appearing later will be cut down sharply this year, selling agents believed yesterday.

ONCE upon a time a recalcitrant child was hauled by a puzzled aunt away from profound contemplation of "The Rake" at the Soane Museum and commanded instead to bask in the "Age of Innocence" that reigned at the National Gallery. Auntie thought it disgraceful that such pictures as the "Rake's Progress" should be exposed to public view and started a letter to THE TIME.

Miss. Vera Felicity Story, daughter of Mrs. Julian Story of this city and of the late Mr. Story, has completed plans for her marriage on March 2 to Henry Latrobe Roosevelt Jr., son of Mrs. Henry Latrobe Roosevelt of Washington and of the late Mr; Roosevelt.

THE MASQUE OF HINGS-Tomorrow evening at the Shubert Theatre. The third of the season's Maxwell Anderson plays, this tells the story of the Crown Prince Rudolf and Madam Vetserj, whose deaths in the hunting lodge at Mayerling were never solved.

BOY SCOUT WEEK, marking the twenty-seventh anniversary of the Scout movement in this country, opens today. Throughout the land, in churches of every faith, there will be special "Scout Sunday" services, for more than half of the 33,707 Troops and 3,046 Cub Packs are sponsored by religious institutions.
A special economic good-will mission will be sent to the United States in April by the Japan Economic Federation, it was announced today.

MANY will recall with pleasure Miss Chapin's poem "Bright Mariner." with something of the note of "The Happy Warrior" about it. In "Time Has No Shadow" Miss Chapin in the main sounds again the same note of hope, serenity and encouragement. "Bright Mariner" is reprinted in the present collection.

The St. Johnland committee, which is sponsoring the hockey match between the New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs on the night of Feb. 23 at Madison Square Garden, has arranged an "after the game" party to be held in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

THE date line "Seattle, Wash.." is seldom missing from the front pages of the newspapers of America. The metropolis of the Pacific Northwest, with only a half-million population, is the mightiest headline-getter, for its size, in the known world.

New York University alumni will participate in about 120 college, class, fraternity and sorority reunions within the next five months, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin A. Ross, secretary of the New York University Alumni Federation.

The seventieth St. Valentine's Kettledrum, known as New York's oldest "charity fair," was held yesterday afternoon in the ballroom suite of the Plaza. The beneficiary of the fair, the Samaritan Home for the Aged, was founded and obtained a charter in 1867 and for fifty-four years maintained quarters in West Twenty-second Street.

AS MAINE GOES: That old and newly discredited political saw, "as Maine goes so goes the nation," is based on the fact that Maine holds its elections in September. Last week a bill was introduced in the State's Legislature which would move election day to the Tuesday after the first Monday in November.
J. D. Griggs of Jonesboro, who owns a farm near the recently dynamited Charleston (Mo.) fuse plug levee, has acquired a new four-room house under mysterious circumstances.

A collision involving the British- battleship Malaya and the Netherland steamer Kertosono off Leixoes, Portugal, was reported in a. message picked up late tonight by the Land's End wireless station and relayed to Llovd's.

One hundred and fifty persons picketed the offices of the General Motors Corporation at Broadway and Fifty-seventh Street for ninety minutes yesterday to indicate their opposition to any move to eject sitdown strikers from the company's plants.

The performance of "Tristan und Isolde," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchoir in the leading roles, on the afternoon of Feb. 25 at the Metropolitan Opera House has been taken over as a benefit for the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc.
A CORRESPONDENT wrote from Cincinnati, while the Ohio River was in its record flood stages, that the amount of bridge-playing rose with the river. "There is no electricity,

THE wonder is that the island fever did not sooner spread south. Ranking, for long years past, as favorite objectives of travelers and vacationists, large and small islands all along the New England coast, in the Sound and down Chesapeake Bay have sounded a recurrent call.
The national intercollegiate tennis championships return to the grass courts of the Merion Cricket Club at Haverford, Pa., in June.
The Drama League of New York will give a dinner tonight in the ballroom of the Pierre to mark the closing of activities of the seventh national drama week, which began last Monday.
Working in the ruins today of two buildings wrecked yesterday by explosion and fire, firemen recovered seven bodies and expressed a belief that at least three other victims would be found.

The tendency seems to be growing, points out Edward M. Bassett, counsel for the Zoning Committee, to establish certain business activities in many residential sections of the city contrary to the zoning regulations. Many of these cases are of such a nature that he admits difficulties are encountered in dealing with them and another difficulty is that Building Departments, as a rule, do not on their initiative ston these violations.

Chalmers Clifton, Professor of Music Conducting at Columbia University, will head the WPA Federal Music Project in New York City, it was disclosed yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator.

Formation of a provisional organization and establishing of temporary headquarters in the national capital marked the end of the first month since the Women's Charter was submitted by its authors to feminine organizations of the country.

The Boerse was weaker today, with the turnover small. Heavy industrials were quiet; Rheinstahl gained 1 1/2 points, with little trading. Potashes continued to fall, Aschesleben losing points and Westeregeln 2.
Although weather conditions interfered with Winter sports competition, undergraduates at Williams College opened their annual carnival here tonight with a dance in the Lasell gymnasium.

There has been as yet no lyrical outburst of happiness iN Congress over the new lifelong civil service status of postmasters, voted them last week in the House bill that is now awaiting action in the Senate.
The Archbishop of York asserted "it can be a Christian duty to kill" in approving today the Church of England assembly decision that "Christian citizens may fight in the service of their country."

Never was it so essential for the British Empire to be strong and for the Empire to know how best to use its strength. That declaration in- the address last Friday of Sir SAMUEL HOARE, First Lord of the Admiralty, will be reechoed in all the democracies of the world.

Coast Guard headquarters here announced tonight the cutter Modoc had reached the Norwegian motorship Rigel, listing dangerously 345 miles off Cape Fear, and was standing by awaiting favorable weather.

A highly regarded Squadron A team went down to defeat before the Ramapo Valley Polo Club trio of Carol Hipp, Wilbur Wood and William Vetter yesterday as the New York Athletic Club's eleventh annual low-goal polo tournament began at. the 105th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx. The score was 10 to 31/2.

During the past four years receipts from the sales of public documents have increased $140,193, the Public Printer, A. E. Giegengack, recently told Congress. For 1936 receipts totaled $680,725-and Uncle Sam's publications were never in greater demand than they are today.

While the Minister of Trade Treaties, Sir Henry Gullett, claims that the trade diversion policy promulgated against the United States last May has been a success, having stimulated Australian manufactures beyond expectations, a section of the Cabinet has suggested that the policy should be subjected to an early review.

Joseph H. Moss, owner of the Hollywood Restaurant, 1,600 Broadway, between Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets, told a Supreme Court jury yesterday that he signed a union contract and then joined an employers' association because Jules Martin suggested it.

The largest group of local welfare agencies to be united in a single appeal in the United States came into being yesterday with the joint announcement by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities that their fund-raising forces had merged for 1937.

Optimism tempered by caution sums up London's view of business conditions in the United States. The labor situation appears to be capable of precipitating a broad setback, and Wall Street's buoyancy is by no means fully share here.

The need for spiritual security and its importance in comparison with social security were emphasized by the Rev. Dr. John L. Davis in his sermon yesterday morning at the Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church, 133 West Fourth Street.
An increase of twenty new corporations last month from January, 1936, and a rise of 173 from the number for December was reported today by the division of corporations of the Department of State.

BORROW-Dr. and Mrs. Ben Albert Borkow (nee Althea Kleiger) announce the birth of a daughter on Feb. 7, 1937, at Beth Israel Hospital. FREIBERG - Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel J. Freiberg (Muller), announce the birth of a daughter on Feb. 2, 1937, at the LyingIn Hospital.
The Supreme Court will grapple this week with the thorny problem of deciding the constitutionality of two administration laws-the National Labor Relations Act and the Railway Labor Law.

The death of John Rille Jr., 22 years old, of Erlton, N. J., member of the CCC Camp on Saw Mill River Road, who was found lifeless in bed at 6:30 this morning, was attributed to a rupture of the aorta, the main trunk of the arterial system, in a tentative report by a board of inquiry of officers from other camps.

106th St., 227 E., 25x100.11; East End Funeral Home, Inc., to Mary La Piccolo, 231 E. 106th St.; prior mtg. $17,245, due Jan. 31, 1940, at 6 per cent; $5,000. Park Av., 1,026, 20x70; Aglo Realty Corp., to Franklin Savings Bank; 5 years, 4 percent purchase money; $50,000.

Stachmik, head of the Catholic Center party, yesterday was placed under "protective custody." All the leaders of the three major opposition parties have now been imprisoned by the Nazi government of the Free City.

The deepest impression has been made here by the fact that the equalization fund was obliged to take 3,000,000,000 francs of gold from the Bank of France. In fact, it had sold the bank 7,000,000,000 francs of gold in October, because of the capital repatriations which took place immediately after devaluation of the franc.

Male alligators are being made into feminine saurians by two scientists at the University of Rochester. How the transformation, which the scientists term "development of egg-laying organs," is accomplished, will be told when the Rochester chapter of Sigma Xi, honorary scientific fraternity, puts on its annual exhibition Feb. 22.

Protestantism, in order to survive, must help solve such social and economic problems as slums, venereal diseases, juvenile delinquency and that of the Negro, the Rev. Dr. Robert Wyckoff Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, declared yesterday.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh visited a noted Italian specialist, Senator Nicola Pende, at Polyclinic Hospital today to talk about the artificial heart the American aviator invented.

A rose by any other name might smell just as sweet and, whether the spelling is Ohe, Oye, Oe or Ohye, the fact remains that Sueo Ohe of Japan was the standout performer of the thirtieth annual Millrose A. A. games in Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

A call for blood donors more than 18 years old who have recovered recently from scarlet fever was issued yesterday by the Department of Health. The donors will receive $5 each time they furnish blood and can be used at intervals of two or three weeks over a period of four to five months.

Great indignation has been aroused in political circles here by publication of a book by Jan Seba, Czechoslovak Minister'to Rumania, entitled "The Little Entente and Russia," in which it is charged he has treated his country's ally in an offensive manner.

General Francisco Franco's third great drive for the capture of Madrid has been under way since yesterday afternoon in the Jarama River sector, southeast of here. Rain held up activity on that front today.
The tanker St. Anastasia advised the Coast Guard today it picked up the missing cabin boat Nancy and a fishing party of four in the Atlantic Ocean 200 miles northeast of Jacksonville.
The Scots-Americans defeated the Passon Phillies, 2 to 1, in the second round of the Challenge Cup competition of the United States Football Association at Clark's Field today.

Tributes to the memory of Elihu Root, former Secretary of State and former Secretary of War, were paid by leaders of the nation, State and city yesterday. At the same time it was announced that funeral services for Mr. Root would be held tomorrow morning in Clinton, N. Y., his birthplace, in the chapel of Hamilton College, Mr. Root's alma mater.

Through her program of rearmament and defensive preparedness Great Britain now has reached the stage where she is ready for any eventuality, and this policy of preparedness has actually brightened the outlook for peace in Europe, in the opinion of Sir Thomas Inskip and Alfred Duff Cooper.

The Genmar Holding Corporation, which bought the residence at 158 East Sixty-third Street from Peggy Hopkins Joyce last February, has resold it to an art dealer who intends to alter and occupy the house. The property adjoins the home of Samuel Seabury and was sol through Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc.
Governor Lehman issued a proclamation today setting Feb. 15 apart as "Susan B. Anthony Day," in honor of the pioneer in the fight for women's rights. He wrote:

Ten Federal agencies awarded 100 contracts valued at $18,152,969.61 under the Public Contracts Act during the week ended Feb. 4, the Labor Department announced yesterday. Contracts awarded to New York State concerns amounted to well over a third of the total.

The close of the first week-end in which there has been generally good skiing and other Winter sports conditions in Northern New England saw eleven Boston Maine snow trains moving back toward Boston, Worcester and New York tonight carrying a total of some 3,500 Winter sports enthusiasts who had spent the day or the week-end in the north country.
The Madrid defense junta dealt a severe blow to the POUM (Marxist Workers Union), the Trotskyist party, by confiscating its radio station and its newspaper and locking the party headquarters.

Making their first competitive appearances in American skiing circles since the 1932 Olympic Games at Lake Placid, Sverre Kolterud and Sigmund Ruud, Norwegian aces who rank among the world's best fliers, carried off the first two positions in the Norsemen Ski Club's sixteenth annual jump today.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 80 per cent of capacity, up 5 points from the preceding week, when the effect of the flood was greatest. Operation of some plants is not back to normal, time being required for cleaning and repairing.

Although the British credit of [pound]40,000,000 to France just raised in London provided the French exchange-equalization fund with substantial resources for fresh defense of the franc, capital again is flowing in from France,

Marvin Swanson of Minneapolis won his third straight senior men's title in the national amateur speed skating championships which closed today. He became the first to accomplish this feat since Bobby McLean, now a pro, won all four seasons from 1911 to 1914:

Popover, sailed by O. H. Chalkley and Jack Prokop, won the Class B One-Design racing of the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association by a wide margin today. There was a tie for first honors in the Class D fleet which turned out ten of the day's 14 boats.

Swinging along through midwinter, the art season continues its pace with more than thirty new exhibitions on the calendar of the present week. Two museums are among the exhibitors and the oneman shows include several by wellknown artists.

True charity is the love of God and not the sickly feeling that comes from giving grudgingly of one's money, the Right Rev. Robert E. Campbell, retired Bishop of Liberia, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy, 26 West Eighty-fourth Street.

Four games were played in the Metropolitan A. A. U. basketball tournament at the Hippodrome yesterday with the Ohrbach A. A. gaining a 27-to-25 victory over the Fort Jay Hawks in one of the feature tests. In the others,

Uday Shan-Kar and his company of Hindu dancers and musicians, who gave their tenth performance of the season last night at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre before another capacity audience, have extended their engagement for a second time and will give a further series of four performances over the coming week-end.
Liquor tax collections from all sources for the 1936 calendar year amounted to $569,081,879 as compared with $458,494,721 in the preceding twelve months, the Treasury announced today.

Trade in soy beans on the Board of Trade here was active a good part of last week. Advances in prices brought out profit-taking by holders, while shorts were the principal buyers. Processors bought fairly at times.
An official communique from the Aviation Department states the hydroplane TP-1B has been lost between Atalaya and Puerto Maldonaldo, on the River Ucayali while flying to Iquitos.

Debutantes of this season headed by Miss Damaris Lee are active in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "Die Meistersinger," with Lotte Lehmann in the leading roe, Friday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. It will aid the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York.

With the deadlock in the automobile strike reported still continuing on the question of recognition of the union as the sole collective bargaining agency for all employes in twenty struck plants, Governor Murphy conferred for two hours today with John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization.
The United Automobile Workers of America today issued new press cards, eliminating the notation which showed whether or not the holder was a member of the American Newspaper Guild.

Thom Cooper, 21, Kansa City, Mo., racing pilot, set a worl record for Class C outboard hydrc planes as the southeastern cham pionship regatta ended today. Sending his racing shell skim ming over the smooth waters of th speedway in the second five-mil heat at an average speed of 51.99 miles per hour, the Missourian.ex ceeded the old record by Frank Vir cent at Tulsa in 1935.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Seward Allen, who will sail soon for Europe, gave a dinner last night at the Pierre. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Warren, Mr. and Mrs. William Seward Allen Mrs. Arthur Ryle and Howard Hasbrouck.
Premier Leon Blum stood today in a beating rain to review 40,000 Leftist followers, marching in commemoration of counter-demonstrations after the riots of Feb. 6. 1934.

A warning that "newer youth movements" are designed as "short cuts to power or to change" was addressed yesterday by Walter A. Jessup in his annual report as president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, to its board of trustees, headed by Thomas W. Lamont.

James J. ?? president of the Greater New York Council of the Building Service Employes International Union, proposed last night that an impartial election be held in buildings operated by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company to determine whether the workers wished a closed shop.

Frank Craven, who made a special trip from Hollywood to stage "Glory For All," a political farce by Nat Perrin, has withdrawn as director. George Jessel and the author have taken over the direction of the play, which will begin a week's preBroadway engagement here tomorrow evening at the Erlanger Theatre. Billed as the producer, Mr.
The Air Commerce Bureau told today of plans for requiring additional safety devices on air liners as Edgar S. Gorrell asserted that lack of government safety aids caused some recent crashes.
An unusually large attendance marked tonight's semi-weekly dinner dance at the Everglades Club, at which Sheila Barrett gave impersonations.

Mrs. Anna Louise Soley, daughter of Bishop Edwin Holt Hughes of Washington, senior Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, died today after a week's illness at the University of California Hospital here.
Foreign Minister Rudolph Holsti of Finland arrived in Leningrad today en route to Moscow for an official visit, expected to presage improvement in Soviet-Finnish relations.

Hunter Lott and William Slack of the Philadelphia Cricket Club captured first prize in the annual Lockett Trophy invitation squash racquets doubles tournament by conquering William Coyle and Conway Hoffman of the Montclair Athletic Club, 15-7, 15-10, 11-15, 15-4, at the University Club yesterday.

Communal working of lands divided among Mexican peons is failing and workers in many localities are deserting the land donated by the government, Senator David Ayala claimed today in the lead article in the important newspaper Excelsior.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,849,619,000. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

A roadster, driven by George Smith, 36 years old, a former motor cycle policeman here, ran off the road this evening and turned over in a ditch, killing Smith instantly and slightly injuring his two passengers, Winthrop Gardiner Jr., 24, and Charles Hand, 25, both of this village.

Seeking special parking privileges at Westchester County parks which are intended only for local residents, several thousand Bronx and Manhattan residents have purchased new automobile license plates bearing Westchester letters of identification, it was said today by park and motor vehicle bureau officials.

Long John Sorrell, achieving hockey's rare feat of scoring on a penalty shot and firing home two, more goals from difficult angles, led the champion Detroit Red Wings to their sixth straight victory over the Boston Bruins, 8 to 0, tonight.

Enrico Venturi, lightweight cham pion of Europe, who has yet to meet defeat in an American ring, will oppose Jimmy McLeod, rough Tacoma battler, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight.

A message from President Roosevelt lauding "the vitality and vision of the Jewish pioneers in Palestine" was read to the National Conference for Palestine tonight. After setting $4,500,000 as the American quota for 1937 toward financing the Jewish colonization of the Holy Land, the meeting of nearly 2,000 representatives of American Jewry closed with a banquet.

The Radio Corporation of America in 1936 had a net profit of about $6,100,000 after costs, expenses, Federal income taxes, interest, depreciation and amortization of patents and good-will, according to David Sarnoff, president, in a letter to stockholders enclosing proxies for the annual meeting on April 6.

By the Jurisdictional Act of 1925 the discretionary jurisdiction of the Supreme Court on petitions for writs of certiorari was enlarged and its obligatory jurisdiction on appeal was restricted. Rule 12,

A prominent business man and his son, a clergyman, presented their views of what their attitudes would have been if their roles in life had been resersed, at a novel vesper service yesterday afternoon at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street.
Some $25,000 is required to "insure the financial honor of St. Patrick's Cathedral during 1937," Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, the rector, declared yesterday at solemn high mass.

Mayor La Guardia, criticizing the building bureau of the Department of Education for delay and accusing it of designing "mail order" school buildings, announced yesterday he would press for the employment of special architects to draw the plans for six modern schools.

" Easy Money," which Paramount has contemplated as a Carole Lombard vehicle for nearly two years, has been assigned to Jean Arthur. with the probability that Ray Milland and Adolphe Menjou will be named for the leading male roles.

Photographic prints and panels of related pictures in sequence, the work of amateurs throughout the country as well as examples if the work of professional photographers, are included in the third annual Zeiss-Ikon exhibition which will open to the public today in the gallery of Carl Zeiss, 485 Fifth Avenue.

A field office of the Federal Social Security Board will open today at 105 Court Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the board, announced that Herman J. Weber, an annuity expert, would superintend the office, which is designed to further understanding by employers and employes of all sections of the security act and to assist in the adjudication of claims for old-age benefits.

Miss Lea Falk, daughter of Mrs. Leon Falk of New York and the late Mr. Falk, was married here to Maurice W. Uhlmann of New York, son of Mrs. William Uhlmann and the late Mr. Uhlmann, this evening at the home of Mrs. Edwin M. Stroock, sister of the bride.
SOME alleged "insiders" were discussing the heavyweight situation, which is slightly muddled at the moment, when along came a genial Bostonian with a quaint tale.

The cotton market was without special feature last week. Price movements continued within a narrow range after the fairly substantial advance of the preceding week. On the New York Cotton Exchange, closing prices on Saturday were 11 to 13 points below those of a week earlier.

Word was received here yesterday of the death Thursday in St. Petersburg, Fla., of John J. Coakley, East River diver and life-saver, who lived for more than forty years in a shack on the rocks at the foot of Jackson Street and often received the title of "Mayor of Poverty Hollow."

Varying ability of counties to obtain tax funds makes State aid for public education essential if adequate educational opportunities are to be maintained, Dr. Francis G. Cornell, research assistant at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared in a survey made public yesterday.

The New York Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, defeated the German-Hungarians, New York State cup holders, by 6-2 yesterday, in the first round of the annual cup competition of the United States Football Association before a crowd of 2,000 fans at Starlight Park.

Judge and Mrs. Charles E. Hardies of Amsterdam, N. Y., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Ellen Ayres Hardies, to Malcolm Atterbury, son of Mrs. William Wallace Atterbury of Boudinot Farms, Radnor, Pa., and the late General Atterbury, former president of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Sir Hugo Cunliffe-Owen, chairman of the board of the British American Tobacco Company; Lady Cunliffe-Owen, Elizabeth, Countess of Abingdon, Sir Harold and Lady Wernher, Lady Henry Grosvenor and Captain Woolf Barnato are among the passengers due today from the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

Scientists said today the current outbreak of sunspots, blamed by some theoreticians for the extraodinary weather this Winter and magnetic storms that have crippled communication, probably would grow for two or three years.

The Federation of British Industries is unusually optimistic in its quarterly trade forecast. It suggests that the recovery in domestic trade is appreaching its peak, although it is too early to judge whether this will be reached this year or next.

A plan to enable the city to finance the rehabilitation of old-law tenements and to charge the cost against the owners as assessment liens was approved yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. The proposal was advanced by the New York City Housing Authority, and the Mayor,

The announcement by the Federal Reserve of an advance in member bank reserve requirements, which would reduce surplus reserves from $2,000,000,000 to $500,000,000, had little or no effect on markets. It is true,

Colonel Tryggve A. Siqueland, assistant vice president of the First National Bank and commander of the 317th Cavalry (reserve), died today at his home here. His death was caused by a heart ailment, following an attack of influenza. He was 48 years old.

It is expected that a scheduled strike Tuesday of 1,800 operating employes of the Chicago Great Western Railroad will be called off tomorrow when notice is received here that the President has appointed an emergency board to settle the dispute, Leo J. Hassenauer, attorney for the Big Five railroad unions, said today.

A Congressional investigation of discrimination by private employers against job-seekers who have passed the age of 35 was asked yesterday by the New York Council on Economics. In letters to Senator Hugo L. Black, chairman of the Senate Committee on Labor, and Representative William F. Connery, who heads the corresponding committee in the House, the council said:

For years a remembrancer and monument of so much of our history, he has now become formally a part of it. He kept undimmed in extreme old age an intellect not, perhaps, surpassed in power and lucidity by any American of his time or ours.

Members of the Goodyear local of the United Rubber Workers of America voted unanimously today to accept a proposal of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for settling a dispute at Plant No. 2 and return to work at midnight.
" Japan's Feet of Clay," a book in which Miss Freda Utley, correspondent of The' Manchester Guardian, discusses Japanese industries and general economics, today was banned from Japan.
The trend in the Reich's foreign trade, according to official and party sources, is toward increasing the export surplus.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, received the Erasmus Award of the Netherland-America Foundation at a small gathering last night in the River Club, 447 East Fifty-second Street.

Who invented gunpowder? BERTHOLD SCHWARZ, a monk, if history reports aright. Who invented the submarine? No bloodthirsty naval officer, but harmless BUSHNELL, artistic ROBERT FULTON and gentle HOLLAND.

Stanley T. Backus, 18, was free on $1,000 bail today while his bride, Leona Roshia Backus, said to be 12, was held in Mercy Hospital following a hearing on charges preferred against the young husband.

The Ministry of Education issued today a basic list of 120 books that all public schools are to obtain at once for their libraries. The books in the basic list, as well as others, are presented under the following classifications:

The Royal Bank of Canada, which is withdrawing from Costa Rica, today contracted with the Bank of Costa Rica to assume the former's local assets and liabilities, thereby assuring the Royal's depositors a continuity of service.
Prague sticks to the German custom of eating stale bread on Sunday, a sacrifice to the bakers' holiday, but it refuses to sacrifice to Moloch by eating it dry.

The return of the Bank of France for Jan. 29 shows large fluctuations in accounts. Bills discounted increased 1,344,000,000 francs, to which must be added an increase of 156,000,000 francs in agricultural items and popular bank bills. Advances against collateral and bonds increased 662,000,000 francs, and State advances rose 400,000,000 francs.

Five methods of procedure that will make one a "great" Christian were set forth yesterday morning in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.
Strong south winds whipped up battering waves on the flooded Mississippi River today, complicating the heroic fight of army engineers to keep important levee lines intact.

Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Cuban army chief of staff, today planned speedy extension of the army-taught rural school system over which he clashed with former President Miguel Mariano Gomez, leading to the impeachment and ouster of the President.

Announcing a subscription of $500,000 to New York's World Fair debentures by the New York Telephone Company, Richard Whitney, chairman of the committee for sales of the securities, disclosed yesterday that subscriptions or commitments to purchase them had risen to $18,325,000.

The New England Power Association has filed applications to list its preferred and common shares on the New York Curb Exchange, according to an announcement by Frank D. Comerford, chairman of the board of the association.

With the Detroit peace conference in the automobile strike reported here to be on the verge of collapse, the National Guard was ready tonight to respond to any orders which may come from Governor Murphy tomorrow.

Agitation among Mexican political groups with regard to the presence and activities here of Leon Trotsky increased today as the pro-Stalin Communist party warned it would prevent any public appearance by Mr. Trotsky here.

Maintaining his winning streak, which has kept him out in front since the start, Frank J. Marshall, former United States chess champion, gained an additional point in the championship tournament at the Marshall Club yesterday.
The venerable MARCUS CATO, to whom CICERO attributes his discourse on old age, citing for precedent SOLON,

Gregor Piatigorsky, the Russian 'cellist, at his recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon, opened his schedule with an anonymous sonata so remarkable in its content that it probably called up many questions in the minds of the large audience in attendance.

With Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden gone to Monte Carlo for a fortnight and the diplomatic situation in Europe more or less in quiescence, some attention is being paid to economic factors. There has been noted,
The members of the New York Society of Model Engineers will open their ninth annual exhibition today in the shop where most of their models were made, 152 West Forty-second Street.

The number of employed persons rose in December, but 8,917,000 were still without work, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, reported today. He again called for reduction in hours of labor as the remedy.
Governor Lehman's social security program, subject of sharp dispute last year, is scheduled for passage in the Republican-controlled Assembly this week.
President Roosevelt, in offering his proposals regarding the Supreme Court and for reform of the entire Federal judiciary, did "what he was elected to do," asserted General Hugh S. Johnson yesterday.

This column of General Francisco Franco's has reached Las Bolichas beach, about fifteen miles from Malaga. Relentlessly driving on in a determined effort to capture Malaga, the Insurgents tonight seemed to have beaten a starving, disorganized defending army into rout.

The 125th anniversary of the birth of Charles Dickens was celebrated today in a London "werry changed" from the city the novelist knew. Tabard Players marked the occasion by performing scenes from "The Tale of Two Cities" in the yard of the old George Inn, a Southwark hostelry Dickens knew.

The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has reversed its decision against granting a degree to Kenneth Arnold of Pawtucket because of his refusal to take compulsory military training, the Rev. James D. Dingwell of Central Falls Congregational Church stated yesterday.

Gusty winds, accompanied by Summer-like temperatures, brought the year's first dust storm to parts of the Southwest today. Visibility in the Texas Panhandle after the duster ranged from zero to one-eighth mile.

More than 1,500 persons jammed the streets around the Hotel Astor last night when police arrested twelve pickets, two of whom had chained themselves to a railing at the hotel florist shop. The pickets,

The dismissal of Professor Jerome Davis by Yale Divinity School was characterized as "discrimination founded on his political and economic views" in a letter to President Angell of Yale from the Committee on Academic Freedom of the American Civil Liberties Union, made public yesterday.

Receipt of four gifts, totaling $19,250, which have been made to the Isabella McCosh Infirmary of Princeton University, was announced today by Mrs. William F. Magie of Princeton, president of the ladies' auxiliary of the infirmary.

The Ministry of Agriculture approved construction of three new whaling depot ships today to spur Japanese competition with British, Norwegian and other companies in the Antarctic whaling industry. The new ships will increase the Japanese depot ships in the Antarctic to eight.
Some 8,000 racing fans turned out today for the first charity program of the current meeting at the Fair Grounds, a benefit for the Society for, the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

The Count of Covadonga, former heir to the Spanish throne, announced he was leaving at 7 o'clock tonight for New York by way of Miami to straighten out an attorney's controversy and to appear before New York courts in his annulment suit against his wife, the former Edelmira Sampedro.

Stocks recovered after heavy selling after the President's message on the courts; prices were irregular on the week; total sales, 14,401,250 shares. United States Government bonds higher, corporate and foreign issues irregular; total transactions, $72,815,800.

Temporary bonds of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company first and refunding 3 1/2 per cent series due on Sept. 1, 1966, may be exchanged for definitive bonds at the office of the J. Henry Schroder Trust Company, New York, and at the office of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago.
Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today that the sales of United States saving bonds, socalled "baby bonds," up to Feb. had reached $862,781,212 on a maturity-value basis.

A national quota for the United States and Canada of $4,650,000 was adopted today for the 1937 campaign of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee for aid to Jews overseas. The action was taken by the plan and scope committee of the campaign in an all-day session.

The Madison Square Boys Club hurled its annualpooh-pooh at the Westminster Kennel Club in the fifteenth annual pet show at 312 East Thirtieth Street last night. Whereas previous exhibitions in the brick-walled gymnasium with the roped-off sawdust "ring" have brought acclaim to rabbits, snakes, turtles and parrots, the 1937 array was overwhelmingly topped by a 4-year-old boy and a St. Bernard puppy three times his size.

With the death rate in New York State increased and the birth rate continuing downward in 1936, Dr. J. V. De Porte. director of the Division of Vital Statistics, declared today that "we are within sight of a demographic equinox, when the birth and death rates just balance."

John Langer, 68-year-old retired merchant, early today forced his way into the bungalow of Ludwig Mazzia, 63, and shot to death his estranged wife, Mrs. Emma Langer, 43, and Mr. Mazzia. Mr. Langer then drove across town to his own residence, telephoned for his lawyer, and when the lawyer arrived dictated a will. At the end he said:
William Howard Taft, who was both President and Chief Justice, favored the retirement of Federal judges at the age of 70 but vigorously opposed Congress expanding the Supreme Court.

The German Ski Club won the downhill meet for New York clubs today over the Ghost Trail in State Forest. Four leaders of the German team had a combined time for the halfmile run of 9 minutes 26 seconds.

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor will meet in Washington today in an effort to determine the authorized wage-bargaining agency for seamen in Atlantic and Gulf ports. The council is expected to hold a series of hearings, some of them in this city.,

Arthur Knapp and Alex Gest carried off top honors today in the sailing dinghy regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club. Under the old news gag of man bites dog, however, the outstanding fact was that Corny Shields, who won the first series of the Winter, wound up in. eleventh position on the day.

The recently organized Presbyterian Church of America, like the Thessalonian Church founded by St. Paul, faces "opposition, tribulation and persecution," according to the Rev. Edwin H. Rian, president of the board of trustees of Westminster Seminary, Philadelphia, who spoke yesterday morning in a classroom of the Master Institute of United Arts, 310 Riverside Drive.
The Black Hawks defeated the New York Americans, 5 to 1, tonight in a National Hockey League encounter before 9,000 fans, little Mush March leading the Chicago attack.

A trade conference out of which will probably come recommendations for legislation to govern the trade between the United States and the Philippine islands is to be called by President Roosevelt within a few months.

Addition of 250 members to the advisory council of the Progressive City Committee in preparation for support of the Fusion candidates at the coming city election was announced yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the committee.
The need for a greater faith in a supernatural Christ was emphasized yesterday morning by Bishop William T. Manning in his preLenten sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Glass, who are occupying Khaum Wood, the home of Mrs. Richards Taylor at Round Hill, entertained a party this afternoon in honor of Professor and Mrs. George Rawley of Princeton, N. J., their house guests, and Mrs. Lucy Colburn of Peiping, China, a guest of Mrs. E. Norman Scott of Greenwich.

The commercial department of the Pinches Pleasure Trailer Corporation has been amalgamated with Fischer Exhibits, Inc. The company says this phase in merchandising would progress more rapidly if it were possible to coordinate its efforts with those of a concern thoroughly trained in the art of effective merchandise display.
Neil J. Sullivan of Philadelphia won the Canadian squash racquets championship today by defeating the defending titleholder, C. H. Polley of Buffalo, N. Y., 10-15, 15-8, 18-13, 15-9 in the final.

Twenty-five hundred uniformed Catholic Boy Scouts from the ten counties of the New York Archdiocese marched into St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon to attend solemn vespers and benediction in celebration of Scout Sunday, which was part of a week's celebration of the twenty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the Boy Scouts of America.

The marriage of Miss Elise S. Meyer, daughter of Mrs. August Strauss, to M. Lawrence Maier of this city, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Strauss at 310 West Seventy-ninth Street. Dr. Joseph S. Kornfeld,

The Weehawken Board of Education called for proof today of charges, made by a Hudson County newspaper, that graduation certificates and university ratings of Woodrow Wilson High School had been sold for as high as $200 a set.
Eight of the nation's outstanding amateur pocket billiard players are to compete in the national championship tournament starting this afternoon at the Capitol Health Center, 1,680 Broadway.

The New York Rovers and the Baltimore Orioles spent seventy spirited minutes on the Madison Square Garden ice yesterday afternoon, pounded a total of eight goals into the nets and together drew a new high of fourteen penalties. But when it was all over the net result was not entirely satisfactory to either team, for they concluded hostilities with a 4-to-4 tie.

Accused of slashing two men and two women in a crowded B. M. T. elevated train on the Jamaica line in Brooklyn early yesterday morning, Fred Holmes, 22 years old, of 345 West Twenty-third Street, Manhattan, was held without bail yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court for a hearing Feb. 9 on a felonious assault charge.

Executives in the food and drug field have become somewhat discouraged by reports from Washington that the bill for revising the Food and Drug Act would probably be held up indefinitely. While they felt that the possibility for early action in the Senate was good, a fight over administration of the advertising provisions is again threatened in the House.

Delay by Congress in acting on President Roosevelt's recommendation for legislation to empower him to increase the number of justices on the United States Supreme Court was urged yesterday by Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn in a letter to Marcellus H. Evans, Representative from his district.

Jerbens, Inc., millinery, store at 15 E. 48th St.; Culver, Hollyday Co., Ine., brokers. L. K. Jobbing, Henry Kayser FilS, Inc. (additional), in 41 Union Sq.; Wadsworth Co., Inc., brokers. United Asbestos Pad Corp. and Max Gordon, shoe stylist, in 43 W. 34th St.:

A new set of champions was crowned in. the Eastern intercollegiate indoor tennis tournament yesterday. Columbia and Penn shared the honors as the competition, which was conducted by Long Island University, closed at the 369th Regiment Armory, Manhattan.

Several cases of "delayed - action" blindness, caused by exposure to mustard gas twenty years ago, are being treated at St. Dunstan's Home for Blinded Soldiers. The first sufferers began to appear about three years ago, since which time there have been twentyfour cases, fourteen of them during the past year.

The world still rejects Christ because it refuses to accept His standards of right and wrong, the Right Rev. Rocksborough R. Smith, Lord Bishop of Algoma, Canada, -declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.

Albert D. Phelps, chairman of the executive committee of the Prudence Bondholders Protective Association, sent yesterday a circular to holders of fifteen series of Prudence bonds urging them to stand against ratification of the recent reorganization plan.

Miss Ruth Hughes Aarons of New York lost the world's women's table tennis singles championship tonight when her final-round match with Trude Pritzi of Austria was ruled "no contest" and the title was declared vacant for 1937.

A general revision in the rates for burglary, robbery and theft insurance throughout New York State will become effective today, according to the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters. The revision will bring about a reduction in the State-wide rate level and specifically affects certain classifications and territories, it was stated.

In cleaning out an old pond which might have been an ancient marl-pit or mine-head, we dredged two intact Elizabethan "sealed quarts" that Christopher Sly affected, all pearly with the patina of centuries.

The Penn A. C. quintet came back stronglyy in the second half after trailing by 18-23 at the intermission to beat the Crescent A. C. five, 41-35, at the loser's court yesterday in an Eastern Athletic Club League battle.

Confirmation of the great improvement in Pope Pius's condition during the last six weeks was given today by the message and blessing he broadcast through the Vatican wireless station to participants in the International Eucharistic Congress in Manila.

The marriage of Miss Mildred Jeanette Kaye, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kaye of Riverview, Conn., to Joseph N. Barnett, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ira Barnett of Amsterdam, N. Y., took place here yesterday in the St. Moritz.
The security markets here this week have shown the first signs of decided revival since the year opened. Activity increased daily and, with minor reactions, prices advanced steadily.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had ordered Loft, Inc., of Long Island City, N. Y., to cease "disparaging the candy products of its competitors." The company was alleged to have directed radio advertising against the use of glucose by its competitors in making candy.

The Brooklyn Hispanos triumphed over Brookhattan by 3-2 in the second round of the national challenge cup competition at Hawthorne Field yesterday. Hispano led by 2-0 at half-time. on markers by Ruddy and Gianotti.

Domenico Borgia of 561 West 185th Street, a prominent member of the Italian-American colony in this city, died Saturday evening of a heart attack while at his desk in the offices of the Borgia Ecclesiastical Studios, 1,947 Broadway, which he established in 1892. Born sixty-seven years ago in Messina, Sicily, he had lived here since boyhood.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Raymond Medina Jr., whose marriage took place recently, gave the first in a series of Sunday afternoon receptions yesterday at their home, 155 East Ninety-third Street. Mrs. Medina is the former Miss Janet Brevoort Williams.

Venerable Brethren, Beloved Children: Although we have already, in letters given our legate a later, addressed ourselves to you who are celebrating the thirty-third International Eucharistic Congress, it is, none the less, a pleasure to speak to you now with the paternal accents of our own voice.

Major George L. Berry, president of labor's Nonpartisan League, announced today that the league had sent to all State chairmen copies of bills recommended for local enactment as a part of the legislative program of every State branch.

A. L. Burns enjoyed a successful day at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday.
