The Winged Foot gunner carried off the high scratch cup in the 100-target shoot with 98 clays to his credit, then took both scratch and handicap laurels in the contest at 155 targets with a card of 149-0-149.

One of the most magnificent collections of the season is Captain Molyneux's. This designer snubs daytime black for navy blue. To it he gives an unusual excitement with the Gauguin shades that he has adopted this season.

Mrs. Meredith P. Snyder, wife of a former Mayor of Los Angeles, died today of a heart attack at her home at the age of 75. Mrs. Snyder was born in Washington, D. C., where her father, the late W. W. Ross, was an adviser to President Lincoln.

In a thick volume appraising the results of the National Recovery Administration, Charles F. Roos, economist, held today that "economic planning, even of a mild 'fixing' type, must remain impracticable" as long as large gaps in statistical information exist.

Determined to force a showdown with Governor Hoffman over four ad interim judicial appointments in Bergen County, the Republicans of the State Senate have agreed to refuse confirmation of all new appointments except those absolutely necessary, according to Senator Winant Van Winkle of Bergen County.

For the second consecutive day competition for the new Eastern championship ice boat pennant of the Rumson Country Club was postponed and club races of the Musconetcong Ice Boat and Yacht Club for the Von Lengerke Trophy took its place.

New plans for legislation affecting business, labor and agriculture, and embodying some of the outstanding principles of the invalidated National Recovery and Agricultural Adjustment Acts, are expected to follow soon after President Roosevelt's Congressional leaders are able to assure him that his sweeping proposals for reform of the Federal judiciary will be enacted.

George Bonnet, new Ambassador to Washington, declared today he will seek United States cooperation with France in keeping the peace of Europe. The Ambassador, who will leave Wednesday to assume his duties, asserted his program had been drawn up in "very precise manner"

A plea to his congregation to resist the encroachment of propaganda in the field of education was offered yesterday morning by Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

An increase in the note circulation of the Bank of England normally occurs at this period, but the rise of [Pound]5,014,172 in the week ended on Wednesday was much greater than expected, even allowing for the more active state of trade, and part of the increase must be attributed to the resumption of French hoarding of British bank notes.

Secretary Ickes announced today that $615,500,000 lent to municipalities and railroads for work-creating construction would be almost entirely recovered, with interest, to the Public Works Administration.

Prices of hogs were active last week over a wide range. They declined early to $10.25 a hundredweight, rallied to $10.45 and closed at $10.35. The average price was $10.30, compared with $10 the previous week and $10.35 a year ago. The average weight was 234 pounds.

The three-room apartment of the Spangler family at 705 East Sixth Street resembled a well-stocked country general store yesterday afternoon. Voluntary contributions of all kinds continued to pour in to the family of fourteen children and a widowed mother who two days ago were on the verge of starvation.

Mrs. Sidney C. Borg will give a reception on the afternoon of Feb. 15 in the Adam Room of the Chatham for members of the Cooperative Committee of the Big Sisters, which is seeking funds to carry on the organization's work in aiding underprivileged girls. Mrs. Lowe Fiske heads the campaign committee.

With hearings on the SeaburyBerle plan for transit unification scheduled to end soon, the City Club made public yesterday a letter to the Transit Commission in which it contended that "opponents of the plan have failed dismally to show any good or sufficient reason for its being rejected."

Ponce de Leon, Puerto Rico's first Governor more than 400 years ago, returned today to receive posthumous honors from civil and church authorities on the occasion of the restoration of the de Leon coat of arms on the entrance to Casa Blanca de Jesus.

The State Insurance Department is considering the possibility of proposing an amendment to the insurance law which would permit life insurance companies to broaden their investment portfolios, Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, declares in his annual report to be submitted today to the State Legislature.

During his first term President ROOSEVELT had occasion to appoint quite a number of Federal district judges. The whole list was put together and "edited" with appropriate notes for the information of bar associatios and others deeply interested in the personnel of the courts.

John Allaire, who, as recently as September, 1935, was called "the oldest active fencer in the world," died yesterday at his home, 2,265 Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, of the heart ailment which had caused him to lay aside his foil forever. He was 80 years old.

Catapulted into the water when their iceboat struck an air pocket while speeding across thin ice at sixty miles an hour, a man and his wife were saved today after clinging to jagged ice for more than a half hour.

The Bacardi Company, announcing the seventy-fifth anniversary of its founding in Cuba as well as its recent establishment here, in full page advertisements in island newspapers announced that it would make no appeal to sex in attempting to exploit its rum and would eliminate from advertisements all pictures of women drinking.

Continuance of the labor difficulties of General Motors has been showing no effect on demand for steel and steel makers continue to wrestle with heavy backlogs while consumers seek more rapid delivseries, the magazine Steel says in its issue for today.

An official communique tonight declared Russia had no intention of stopping shipping between Vladivostok and Japanese ports or of impeding regular sailings of Japanese ships to Vladivostok, as was reported in the Japanese press.

Dr. WALTER A. JESSUP, president of the Carnegie Foundation for Teaching, reminds us in his annual report, published today, that America has not only had its youth problem from the beginning, but that it has been trying to solve it both by public enactments and private efforts ever since.

Secretary Wallace, addressing himself directly to Great Britain, warned today that a renewal of the traditional lending policy of the United States was "unlikely until the question of defaults is settled."

The Jesuit Missions for training young men for the missionary field will be aided by a Mi-Careme luncheon and card party March 9 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador under the auspices of the Loyola School. The Rev. Francis E. Garner is headmaster of the Loyola School.

Net income of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company, sole supplier of gas to Chicago, in 1936 was nearly double that of 1935 and the largest since 1932, according to the annual report issued tonight by George A. Ranney, chairman of the board.

The action of the lard market recently has been so erratic that both packers and speculators are puzzled. Aside from the hedging of lard futures on all strong spots, the trade is in an uncomfortable position, as stocks have been accumulating for several months, despite a moderate consumptive demand.

Liberal Protestantism "has been more and more throwing away the techniques, methods, and observances by which spiritual life is nurtured and disciplined," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Charles R. Crisp, former Representative and once Democratic member of the Tariff Commission, died at his home here today. He was 66 years old. Mr. Crisp came to his Georgia home a year ago after suffering a stroke in Washington.

A small cabin monoplane twisted slowly in the haze above Bolling Field this morning. Watching it from the ground were a group of veteran airline pilots. After some minutes of slow manoeuvres the plane dipped its nose suddenly and plunged straight toward the ground at a steep angle. The pilots watched with strained attention.
The Leftist Government announced today that United States and Canadian international workers' organizations had contributed $250,000 to assist the Loyalist forces in the Spanish civil war.

Although the Jim Braddock-Joe Louis title fight proposition can't seem to make progress without a daily squabble, things looked somewhat more hopeful for a settlement yesterday despite a new firecracker that had been tossed into the proceedings.

Beaten on the head and stabbed several times during a free-for-all fight about 3 o'clock this morning at Poppy's Place, a tavern near here, Howard C. Titus, 21 years old, of 303 Peach Street, Vineland, died soon afterward in Newton Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage.

Formation of a cooperative union of all church organizations in the city under the leadership of Bishop William T. Manning to "awaken the civic conscience" to the housing evil and the need for effective slum clearance was announced yesterday.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced today its list of nominations for the annual awards of merit for outstanding contributions to the screen during 1936. Ten pictures and thirtyseven personalities were named as those upon which the academy membership will ballot.

Lloyd B. Marsh, Passaic County Clerk and county Republican leader was put into the race for the New Jersey Republican Gubernatorial nomination today by the Passaic County Republican League. The league,

James E. Malley, Sheriff of Monroe County, died of pneumonia yesterday at the age of 55. He was the first Democrat to be elected to the Sheriff's office in fifty-seven years. He was a director of the State Sheriffs Association. Before his election he was head of an insurance agency.

Contributions ranging from $3.56 collected from members of the Kips Bay Boys Club to $4,449.18 given by employes of the United States Postoffice Department yesterday brought the flood relief fund raised by the New York chapter of the American Red Cross to $1,497,137.81.

NOT many novels since "Huckleberry Finn" have sprung from as deep in America as does Conrad Richter's "The Sea of Grass" (Knopf, $1.25). Underneath its melodrama it is the story of how one of the old cattle kings of the West was cut down to size by a woman and a flood of homesteaders, a story of an individualist warred on by the mass.

Declaring that a stalemate has been reached in recent efforts to provide housing for low-income groups, the Merchants Association is distributing this week several thousand copies of a report intended to aid in developing a plan for solving the housing problem by "private enterprise on an economic basis."
Yesterday the New York and Brooklyn Jewish Federations announced a constructive move of broad import which deserves the warm support of the whole community of the Greater City.

Fear that adoption of the Federal Child Labor Amendment might lead to abolition of Roman Catholic parochial schools was expressed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Brooklyn Diocesan Union of Holy Name Societies.

Fighting a wind which blew in so strongly from Lake Michigan that young riders were barred from competition on the towering 180-foot slide, Sverre Fredheim of Minneapolis won the Class A Central United States ski jumping championship before 57,000 spectators at Soldier Field. The meet was sponsored by The Chicago Times.

" Shall we have more fish and better fishing?" asks the Salt Water Anglers of America in a message to its members. In a pamphlet distributed by the organization some startling figures on the economic and recreation aspects of ocean fishing are brought out. A few of the highlights follow:

As Preparations for the Four-Year Plan progress the stock market becomes even more uncertain, and last week, despite occasional recoveries, trade ing activity was down almost to nothing, and the tone listless.

Clinton L. Bardo, trustee of then New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company, has filed a statement of income with the United States District Court here disclosing that the road had a deficit of $3,066,569 from operations in 1936.

Dispatches from Acapulco tonight reported Admiral Ernest J. King and eight other United States Navy men narrowly escaped drowning today as the plane in which they planned to fly to Panama crashed in Acapulco Harbor.

Mrs. Mary Sharpe and Mrs. Lizzetta Schimpfs were neighbors and life-long friends. When Mrs. Sharpe, 45 years old, was taken to Teaneck's Holy Name Hospital several months ago Mrs. Schimpfs assumed care of her friend's three children.

As Chinese Government troops massed today in a semicircle only twelve miles from rebellious Sian, capital of Shensi Province, Communist troops near Sanyuan, to the north, evidently feeling their position to be insecure, began retreating.

To the Editor of The New York Times: More than three months have gone by since the election, and while the 26,000,000 persons who voted for the President may still be confident that they did the right thing, nothing has yet happened to change the point of view of the 16,000,000 who voted against him.

Buying in the ready-to-wear and accessories markets maintained a steady pace last week, with all price ranges active. In dresses, prints still accounted for the bulk of purchasing, with the new shades of thistle, postman blue and beige coming well to the fore in solid colors.

Three Akron, Ohio, business men and a woman were killed in the crash of a privately owned cabin plane this afternoon twelve miles northeast of Louisburg, N. C., seat of Franklin County, about thirty miles north of Raleigh.
No failure marred the record of national banks in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1936, J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced in his annual report today.

Mrs. John Harris Orbison, retired member of the Punjab (India) Mission of the Presbyterian Church, died in India on Friday after a long illness, it was announced here yesterday by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church. She was in her seventy-ninth year.

Concerned over the failure of business men to hire persons from the relief rolls when they have jobs to fill, Mayor La Guardia has appointed a committee of twenty-five business leaders to speed the absorption of employable relief recipients into private industry.

Mrs. Pauline Grossman, 34 years old, of 118 Riverside Drive, was killed at 10:45 o'clock yesterday morning when she jumped or fell from her fifteenth-floor apartment and landed in an areaway at the rear of the building.

Young Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., won his second golf tournament of the California Winter series today when he posted a subpar 68 to capture the $3,000 Bing Crosby amateur-pro event at the Rancho Santa Fe Country Club.
Secretary Wallace will meet with fifty agrarian leaders tomorrow to draft "a better program" than the Agricultural Adjustment Act, invalidated by the Supreme Court a year ago.

Two seeded players were eliminated in the quarter-finals of the New Jersey Class B individual squash racquets championship at the Plainfield Country Club today. Herbert L. Hanschka, captain of the Montclair Athletic Club team and ranked third, lost a stirring five-game match to John H. Doeg, of the Essex Club, former national tennis chanmion.

Appointments of C. R. Johnson as technical director and Carl J. Minnig as general sales manager have been announced by the newlyorganized Witco Carbon Company, which recently erected a plant at Sunray, Texas, and plans to begin marketing its carbon black product shortly.

An electric alarm system installed by a grocer who had grown tired of repeated raids on his milk supply led to the capture and arrest early yesterday of two men in front of his store at 180 Thirty-first Street, near Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

The debut of John Brownlee, Australian baritone, in the title role of "Rigoletto" and the return to the repertoire of Bellini's "Norma" and Ponchielli's "La Gioconda" will mark the ninth week of the Metropolitan Opera season, beginning next Monday.

Beef prices are higher than at this time last year, principally because of the lighter supply of the better grades, it was reported yesterday by the weekly Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets. Veal is slightly cheaper and pork prices are slightly higher. Lamb is the most reasonably priced meat.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

Baseball went clear back to its infancy last night when a record crowd of 800 packed the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore to attend the fourteenth annual dinner and frolic of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association.

Princess Mary, the Princess Royal of Britain and sister of the Duke of Windsor, arrived today, with her husband, the Earl of Harewood, for the first visit to the former King by a member of his family since his abdication.

Report that the trawler Clinton was in need of "immediate assistance" 150 miles northwest of Cape Henry sent the Coast Guard cutter Sebago to sea again today as soon as she arrived at Hamptop Roads with the disabled Morgan Line freighter El Occidente in tow.

Mrs. Joseph Wright Graeme of this city and Washington, D. C., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alice Graeme, to Baron Serge Alexander Korff, son of Baroness Serge Alexander Korff of Washington, and the late Baron Korff.

To the Shubert Theatre tonight comes the Theatre Guild's fourth local production of the season and Maxwell Anderson's third play in eight weeks. It is "The Masque of Kings" telling in three acts and six scenes the tragic and mysterious story of Crown Prince Rudolph of Austria and Baroness Mary Vetsera.
Gradualness and moderation are to be the keynotes of Premier Senjuro Hayashi's policy. "The Cabinet's duty is to carry out the Emperor's administration in accordance with the times," he said today.

The Stock Exchange here was in a cheerful mood at the beginning of the week, French as well as foreign securities rising, but a reaction took place following the unfavorable impression caused by the report of the Bank of France.

Professor George Tilden Ragsdale, member of the faculty of Louisville Male High School and instructor in the Louisville Police School, died today in the office of Director of Safety Dunlap Wakefield in the City Hall. His age was 60.

The Most Rev. Augustine F. Schinner, Catholic Bishop, formerly of Superior, Wis., and of Spokane, Wash., the first native Wisconsin priest to become a Bishop, died today at St. Mary's Hospital. His age was 74.

Recognizing that "youth in the church is the hope of the world," the All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, dedicated its services yesterday morning to the young people of the congregation.

Taxes in this country are the highest in the nation's history, each man, woman and child paying an average of $100 a year, according to a report made public last night by the Twentieth Century Fund, Inc. If borrowing were ended and expenditures undiminished, the average tax would be increased an additional $15 to $20 a person, the report said.

Manhattan took first ranking in metropolitan intercollegiate basketball circles with two victories last week as Long Island University was upset twice. The Jaspers gave their finest performance on Wednesday when they outplayed C. C. N. Y. in a game which produced probably the best basketball of the season at Madison Square Garden.

" Measurable" progress in affording "greater security to millions of men and women" was reported to Congress today by the Social Security Board, which combined with its first annual report supplementary data for the period July 1 to Dec. 31, a novel feature.

Park Av.. s. w. cor. 35th St., 33x100; Women's City Club to Windholme Realty Corp., 515 Madison Av.; mtg., $100,000 ($30). Interior lot, begins 100 ft. n. of Broadway and 100.3 ft. e. of 207th St., runs east 50 x n. 26.10 x w. 50 x s. to beginning; Elael Corp., Helen L. Harpel, president, to Lillian Leale, 383 Park Av.

Manhattan College will build a $250,000 library this Spring. Plans for the erection of the building, which will mark the seventy-fifth anniversary of Manhattan's receiving a charter from the Regents of the University of the State of New York, were announced yesterday by Brother Patrick, president of the college.

An American opera, Ernest Carter's "The White Bird," received its first New York presentation at the Hudson Theatre last night. Mr. Carter himself conducted what amounted to a one-night stand, for this was the only performance scheduled.
Credit this week was plentiful here, day loans on Friday being at 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 per cent. The Gold Discount Bank in December increased its circulation of promissory notes by 300,000,000 marks.

The world's wheat markets developed spasmodic activity and price irregularity last week, and good advances followed sharp breaks. On the Board of Trade here futures had a range of 5 to 63/8 cents a bushel, the nearby deliveries leading, and they finished with a net advance of 65/8 cents on the May, with July up 51/4 and September up 4 3/2.

Recognizing that "youth in the church is the hope of the world," the All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, dedicated its services yesterday morning to the young people of the congregation.

Leo J. Ryan, for many years a newspaper reporter in Boston, New York, Chicago and Washington, died here tonight at the age of 41. He had been employed by The Boston Traveler for the last four years as a political and news writer.

Patrick F. Scanlan, editor of The Tablet, official publication of the Roman Catholio Diocese of Brooklyn, received last night the fifth annual Catholic Action Medal presented by the faculty of St. Bonaventure College. The ceremony was held at a dinner in the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

Continuing their part in the national drive of the Knights of Columbus against communism, more than 500 members of eleven councils in Hudson and Bergen Counties met tonight at the Columbia Club here to hear addresses on the subject.

" That the Presidential term should be six years with prohibition against re-election" will be argued by the senior-junior teams in an interclass debate at the College of New Rochelle tomorrow evening it was announced today by Miss Margaret Wilson of New York City, president of the Council of Debate.

Another long novel about life in the South during the Civil War, the result of a number of years of research and writing, is about to be published by Charles Scribner's Sons. Caroline Gordon, the wife of Allen Tate, poet and critic, is the author. The title is,

The annual ball of the Miami Junior League will be held Tuesday night at the Indian Creek Club. Mrs. Frank Smathers Jr. is general chairman and Mrs. Harrison S. Phelps her assistant. Mrs. Robert D. Patterson of Dayton, Ohio, was hostess at a luncheon at the Bath Club today for Sir Charles and Lady Higham of London.

Asserting that "every one agrees certain reforms are needed," Dr. Edward S. Corwin, Professor of Jurisprudence at Princeton University, said tonight that he "sympathizes on the whole with President Roosevelt's proposal to increase membership of the Supreme Court.".
The leading Liberal newspaper, Dagens Nyheter, editorially urges that those awarding the Nobel prizes be not influenced by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's ban on prizes for Germans.

The Governor's Horse Guards of Atlanta lost to the Camden Ramblers today, 9 to 5, in the first game of the Camden mid-South polo tournament for the Russell Memorial Trophy. A crowd of 3,500 witnessed the play.

Capably handled by James Hogan and performing well in the ring, Ch. Elyria Easter Parade, owned by Dr. O. M. Deems of Springfield, Mass., won the best-in-show award at the evening session of the Boston Terrier Club of New York's twenty-ninth annual specialty exhibition held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The real test of the validity of an idea is the persistence with which it clings to our minds, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday in his sermon in James Methodist Chapel, Claremont Avenue and 121st Street.
The motives of the National Association of Manufacturers in endorsing the Clark-Connery bill for the regulation of child labor were challenged last night by the National Child Labor Committee.
More farms were bought from Federal Land Banks in 1936 than in any previous year of their history, the Farm Credit Administration said today.

Producers have declared war on dialogue thieves. Secret sessions have been held in every studio in Hollywood during the last few days in an effort to devise some sort of unified plan whereby a clever group of sound stage eavesdroppers can be tracked down and brought to justice.

Steve (Crusher) Casey, the Irish wrestler who has developed into a great drawing card here, will exchange holds with Cliff Olsen, one of the many claimants to the world's heavyweight championship, in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The exhibition is slated to go to a finish.

The Jews' plight in Poland, which comprises all the problems of national minorities in the most aggravated form, is in the last analysis the result of a conscious effort by the government to make Poland a big Polish power by "Polonizing" whatever domains are still being held by minorities, especially by Jews.

The Canadian hockey teams moved closer to complete domination of the International Intercollegiate League last week as Queen's University passed Yale by splitting its two circuit contests to gain a fourth-place tie with Montreal, while the Elis dropped both their games to Canadian rivals.

Fifteen teams of Boy Scouts from Manhattan Council took part in the annual Winter jamboree at Kane's Open Camp, near here, over the week-end. Troop 799 won the high standard award, the first time this honor has been given to a Scout team in three years.

Russian scientists reported tonight the sudden appearance of a small island in the Black Sea off the Crimean coast near Balaklava. They believed the island to be the product of a rare geological phenomena.

Frank B. French, for twenty-four years a vice president of the Chatham and Phenix National Bank, now a part of the Manufacturers Trust Company, died at his home, 158 West Eighty-first Street, late Saturday night. He was 72 years old.
The carnival parade this afternoon was one of the largest in many years. During the wait the crowds were entertained by loud-speakers in every block which broadcast music.

Dr. and Mrs. Henry Larned Keith Shaw of Guilderland and Albany, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Keith Shaw, to Burton Francis Bossi, son of Mrs. Arnoldo Luigi Bossl of New York and of the late Dr. Bossi of this city and Milan.

Phil Watson gave the New York Rangers a one-goal advantage over the Montreal Maroons by scoring all alone in the first period of the teams' clash at Madison Square Garden last night. The Blue Shirts held this margin through the second period, but yielded a score to Baldy Northcott in the third.

The halting of power pool negotiations is regarded here by high government officials as one of President Roosevelt's moves to let a "Leftist" element in Congress talk itself out, giving him time to bring its members to his viewpoint that the public-private utility. question should be settled on a basis of fairness for all.

Mrs. Delia Downs Colgan of Jersey City, widow of Thomas J. Colgan, head of the former Colgan Marble Works, died Saturday in the St. Francis Hospital, Jersey City, after a three weeks' illness. Born in Ireland seventy-eight years ago, she came here about 1877.
The stock market here this week opened with a general decline, with the exception of some electrical and machinery issues, and continued to be inactive and undecided most of the time.
With form prevailing, the quarter-final brackets of the second annual New Jersey indoor tennis championships were filled today with the ranks of the eight seeded players still intact.

Redhaired Don Budge, the nation's topranking amateur tennis player, partially avenged two previous Florida Winter defeats at the hands of Bryan M. Grant by vanquishing his diminutive Atlanta rival today in the final of the Surf, Club tournament. The score was 6-3, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4.

Mrs. Georgianna Shafer Pollock, wife of Dr. Horatio M. Pollock of the Department of Mental Hygiene, died today at the age of 67. She was graduated from the Cobleskill High School and the Oneonta Normal School.

William Salvatori, who upon his graduation from the Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, N. J., in 1935, was elected to the all-America lacrosse team, died tonight at his home here at the age of 24. Death was due to a kidney ailment, aggravated by pneumonia.
Georges Enesco conducted his last concert of the present season with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, and a most impressive leaving-taking it was.

Mr. and Mrs. Cecil J. North of Hewlett, L. I., will give a small dinner tonight in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Sir Herbert Marler, the Canadian Minister to the United States, and Lady Marler.

While American musicians appeared with increasing frequency in Vienna this season, it was not until this afternoon that they numbered a symphonic conductor. Hans L. Heniot son of Heniot Levy of Chicago and brother-in-law of the Russo-American basso, Alexander Kipnis, conducted the Vienna Concert Orchestra in the Ehrbarsaal, winning an ovation from the capacity audience.

A steady rise in placements in private industry is shown in a report of the 1936 activities of the public employment offices in New York State. The report, made public today by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews, shows that a total of 177,917 jobs was filled in private industry for the year.
The domestic steel market was firm this week. To obtain speedy delivery from mills, buyers abroad are offering prices that are considerably in excess of the international cartel's rates.

Until Friday, when the President's unexpected proposal for reorganizing the Federal courts was given out, financial .markets had been moving upward. On receipt of this news, all of the week's previous gain in the "averages" was canceled by an abrupt decline in a 3,300,000-share stock market.

The Massachusetts Milk Control Board today prepared to go into court this week to prevent New England Dairies, Inc., a farmer cooperative, from acting as a dealer in the Boston market, and to halt six dealers from buying milk from the cooperative at lower prices than fixed by the board.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 90.4, which compares with 90.4 the week before, 90.2 two weeks before, 90.7 three weeks before and 90.1 four weeks before.
The estate of Serge Mdivani, killed in a polo accident last year, is valued at more than $1,000,000, attorneys informed Judge Craig today.
Brown's basketball team defeated Lowell Textile, 38-28, tonight. Lowell led at half time, 17-16, but Brown pulled steadily away in the second period.

George Fish Parsons, optician, president of Ga Nun-Parsons, Inc., 5 West Fifty-second Street, died yesterday at his home, 75 East Fifty-fifth Street, after a two-week illness. Mr. Parsons, whose firm, long called Ga Nun Parsons, fitted eyeglasses for some of New York's most prominent families, was 78 years old.

Wallace G. Garland, former honor student at Yale University, in one of whose ventures Professor Irving Fisher is said to have invested a large sum of money; Arnold C. Mason, also a Yale man, and eighteen others went on trial yesterday in Federal Court on a forty-threecount indictment alleging mail fraud and conspiracy.

Howard Chandler Christy, the artist, presented an original oil painting to Harold Fowler, Acting Police Commissioner, at police headquarters yesterday. The painting displays two children in the uniforms of the Police Athletic League, looking up trustingly at a uniformed policeman.
Jascha Heifetz, violinist, has been added to Fairfield County's roster of residents. He has purchased an estate in Sanford town district from Chester Burt Fentress, retired concert singer.

Stocks closed generally higher, with steel and rubber shares 1 to 3 points higher; turnover, 2,987,500 shares. United States Government bonds steady and slightly higher, other groups irregular; transactions, $11,585,500.

With the loss of only one encounter, and that by default, the Junior League combination routed the Ardsley C. C. representatives, 4 to 1, on the winner's courts yesterday in the play-off for the Class A intersectional team championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

In accordance with the government's intention to foster new cultural, economic and technical contacts with the Far East, especially Japan, a delegation of university students sailed on the liner Heiyo Maru today for Japan.

The efforts of a wealthy young undergraduate to live up to his ideals make "Great Possessions," produced at the "Q" Theatre tonight, a good play. Written by William Douglas-Home, the 22-year-old son of the Earl of Home, it tells of the Earl's son, converted by the Oxford group movement, who seeks to devote his wealth to philanthropy and leaves a luxurious university life for the squalid slums of the East End of London.
Most commodity futures showed a firmer trend in trading on the local markets yesterday. Cocoa, coffee, rubber, silk, copper, lead and cottonseed oil futures advanced.

Declaring that he favored a vehicular tunnel rather than a bridge as a link between Staten Island and New Jersey highways and the arterial system of Brooklyn, Manhattan and Long Island, Mayor La Guardia requested the New. York City Tunnel Authority yesterday to study such a project at once.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 6: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Gandy, C. L., Med. Corps, Ft. Banks, Mass., to the Philippines, to sail from New York about May 27.

Gaston Morawiecki, French Minister to Cuba; George Tait, United States Consul in Paris; Joseph Lewis, president of the Freethinkers of America, and Miss Helen Keller are among the passengers due today from Havre via Southampton on the French liner Champlain.

The exhibition of modern paintings that opened yesterday at the Durand-Ruel Galleries in Fiftyseventh Street is not a large one. It contains only thirteen catalogued pictures, but among them are items of considerable interest.

Colonel Jacob Ruppert's Yankee holdout brigade was reduced by one more yesterday when the signed contract of George Selkirk, the outfielder who inherited Babe Ruth's uniform, No. 3, was deposited on Business Manager Ed Barrow's desk.

President Roosevelt approved today the recommendations of a Marine Corps selection board providing for the promotion of sixty-five captains to the rank of major and of eighty-five first lieutenants to the rank of captain. The list of those selected for promotions follows:
As happy and carefree as the songs of his native city, Karl Schafer, world and Olympic figure skating champion, arrived with Mrs. Schafer from Vienna on the North German Lloyd liner Europa yesterday.

Miss Mary May White of Ridgefield, Conn., was married to George Doubleday, also of Ridgefield, yesterday afternoon in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, by the Rev. James A. Paul, the associate rector, in the presence of near relatives.

Brunswick High scored its third victory in as many starts in the Westchester County Interscholastic Hockey League by blanking Dobbs Ferry, 5-0, while Greenwich and Roosevelt of Yonkers, both unbeaten, played to a 2-2 tie in the other league game of the twin bill at the Playland rink tonight.
The British Government today showed once more that it had no sympathy with the effort of Nazi Germany to exclude Russia from European affairs.

I note that the city is about to restore cut salaries to 110,000 of its employes, at an estimated additional annual cost of $18,000,000. I note, further, that Governor Lehman has recommended to the Legislature the restoration of the additional 1 cent a gallon tax on gasoline, to yield an estimated $15,000,000.
Undefeated since coming to this country in quest of the world light-weight title, Enrico Venturi, Italian boxer, last night on his thirteenth straight American victory at the St. Nicholas Palace.

The newsprint industry is using up Canada's wealth of forests "at a prodigious rate" and getting little for it beyond wages for the industry's workers. Charles Vining, president of the Newsprint Association of Canada, said today to the Canadian Club.

A proposed law on internal security, which would give the executive virtually dictatorial powers in dealing with Communist or other domestic disorders, with authority to suppress publications, is now becoming a dividing line between Right and Left groups lining up for the forthcoming general elections.
The hog market here developed an easier undertone today after a steady opening, with final sales generally showing a decline of 10 cents a hundred-weight, compared with the close of last week.

A popular referendum on the Federal Child Labor Amendment at the general election this year prior to legislative action in this State is provided for in a bill introduced in the Assembly at tonight's session.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Van Schaick of Southport have announced that the marriage of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Van Schaick, to the Rev. Sewll Emerson of New Haven, son of Dr. and Mrs. Kendall Emerson of New York, will take place on April in Trinity Episcopal Church here.

A large group of stockholders of the Detroit Bankers Company appealed today to the United States Supreme Court in an effort to escape paying an assessment of 100 per cent upon their proportionate share of the stock of the First National BankDetroit.

President Roosevelt appointed today an emergency board of three, headed by Chief Justice John P. Devaney of the Minnesota Supreme Court, to investigate the dispute between the Chicago Great Western Railroad and union employes. He acted under provisions of the Railway Labor Act.

It was announced at the military headquarters here that two divisions of government troops had entered Sian, the provincial capital, at noon today, even though a considerable body of Communists and their sympathizers had not yet evacuated. No resistance was reported.

Retired Fireman Thomas J..Lee, formerly a member of H. L. 9, residing at 2,433 2d Av., Manhattan, died Feb. 7. Funeral will take place from W. B. Cooke's Funeral Parlor, 1,451 1st Av., Manhattan, at 9:15 A. M. Wednesday, Feb. 10. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Negotiations for prolongation of the standstill agreement under which Germany's foreign bank credits are bracketed will begin tomorrow at the Reichsbank, when an international committee representing foreign creditor banks will confer with the German debtor committee over procedure to be followed in the conversations.

The proposal advanced by the New York City Housing Authority and approved by Mayor La Guardia to have the city finance the remodeling of tenements to bring them up to the standards of the Multiple Dwelling Law was being studied by realty, men and bankers yesterday as the Housing Authority laid plans to hold a meeting of owners to discuss the plan.

The Supreme Court heard arguments today on the constitutionality of a 70year-old statute under which Angelo Herndon, Cincinnati Communist organizer, was sentenced to serve eighteen to twenty years in a Georgia chain gang.

Business failures in the United States showed another rise for the week ended Feb. 4, the total going to 184 from 178 in the previous week. They remained well under a year ago, when the number was 209.

ALLAIRE--John, Feb. 7. Services at his late residence, 2,265 84th St., Brooklyn, Tuesday evening, 8 o'clock. BAILEY-Robert Barnes, son of Mrs. Robert Otis Jones of White Plains, N. Y., in New York City Feb. 7, 1937. Services and interment private.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 8, unless specified: At San Diego: Ramapo, Feb. 7; Algorma. San Diego to San Clemente: Antares, Bridge, New York, Utah, Wyoming. Asheville, Amoy to Shanghai.

Trailing, two games to one, Germain G. Glidden, the national titleholder, staged a blazing rally to defeat F. D. Rogers of the Yale Club yesterday as the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's fifteenth annual Class A singles championship opened on the tenth-floor courts of the University Club.

Early this morning a truckload of gendarmes appeared at the home of J. S. Jordon, a Dane, employed by the Standard Oil Company of Yokohama, and removed him to prison on a charge of possessing a shortwave radio transmitter without an official permit.

At the request of Secretary Morgenthau the executive committee of the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve Bank will meet him tomorrow at the Treasury Department. Beyond saying that the conference concerned "financing," the Secretary would not comment on the matters that the conferees planned to discuss.

Senator Wagner of New York will introduce soon a new housing bill probably outlining for a four-year period expenditures in loans and grants of more than $1,000,000,000, he said after conferring with President Roosevelt today.
Mrs. Sarah Losee, who is 101 years old, was recovering in Peekskill Hospital today after a serious fall down a flight of stairs in an office building here last Friday.

Charging to the front at the halfway mark, Hueu, 7-year-old gelding racing in the silks of C. Troutt, easily led home a band of sprinters to capture first money in the featured fourth race at the Fair Grounds today.

A letter of congratulation from President Roosevelt to Brother Vincent, who has just celebrated his fiftieth anniversary as a Franciscan, was read last night at the annual dinner of the alumni of St. Francis College of Brooklyn in the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, where Brother Vincent was the guest of honor.

Alix surpasses herself in her new collection with truly great harmonies in color, line and drapery. Her showing of exotic beach clothes leads off with a knee-length, full circle skirt of navy and white grass cloth over a red swim suit.
Various methods of training salesmen were outlined by executives of leading companies yesterday at a symposium conducted by the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

A strike of 700 sandhogs that threatened to tie up construction on the city's new Sixth Avenue subway north of Thirty-fourth Street got off to a poor start yesterday afternoon because of the intervention of Sam Rosoff, subway contractor, who appeared as usual in a picturesque role.

The Insurgent attempt to cut the Valencia road has apparently failed. At 3 o'clock this afternoon automobiles were able to drive along the road through Arganda and Vallecas into Madrid without being fired upon.

Two Broadway restaurateurs, the owners of Lindy's and of Roth's Bar and Grill, gave a Supreme Court jury yesterday a complex picture of restaurant racket operations which cost them, together, more than $16,540 and threatened the life of one.
The Tariff Commission, in a detailed report on Philippine-American trade, said today that "general misconceptions" exist regarding Japanese gains in the islands.

The Rev. Gustav Theodore Fischer of 195 Nichols Avenue, Brooklyn, pastor of the Evangelical Church of Peace, Brooklyn, died in a Man-hattan Hospital yesterday after a two months' illness which included an operation.

The President and the supporters in Congress of his plan to overturn the present Supreme Court majority will not be dissuaded by the outcry-both sincere and political-which has greeted the sudden, unexpected revelation of Mr. Roosevelt's plan.
Dr. Philip Hammond, ear, brain, nose and throat specialist, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of several months. He was 65 years old.

Automobile traffic accidents and the -fatality rate rose last week compared with the corresponding week of 1936 despite the safety campaign of the Police Department, it was announced yesterday by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.
Seventeen new acquisitions of painting and sculpture will be placed on exhibition tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.
The Continental Bank and Trust Company is successor trustee of the Metropolitan Edison Corporation indenture dated Sept. 1, 1931. Irving L. Praet is in the trading department of W. F. Thompson Co.

The State Highway Survey Committee, in a report to the Legislature tonight, made the recommendation, among others, that all proceeds from motor vehicle license tax and from motor fuel revenues be used exclusively for construction, maintenance and repair of highways.

Miss Julia Jay Pierrepont, a member of one of the oldest families of Brooklyn, died last night after a brief illness, at her home, 1 Pierrepont Place, Brooklyn, where she lived with her sister, Miss Anna J. Pierrepont.

Unfavorable crop comments in the way of severe dust storms in parts of the Texas Panhandle and Western Oklahoma, Kansas and Nebraska were a factor in the market for wheat on the Board of Trade here today and more than offset a marked falling off in the European demand for the cash article.

Having won the recent international chess masters tournament in this city from a field of entries which included the cream of Swedish chess talent, Reuben Fine of New York, who did not lose a game, was again put to the test when friends of the second-prize winner, Gideon Stahlberg, likewise undefeated, rallied to his support and arranged for a set match of eight games between the two.

Mrs. Clara Jay Williams Keech of 4 East Seventy-ninth Street, former wife of Colonel Frank B. Keech, founder of the brokerage firm of F. B. Keech Co., died yesterday at her Winter residence in Boca Grande, Fla., according to an announcement made here last night.

Fearing disorders at tonight's meeting in the Hippodrome, called by the American Committee for the Defense of Leon Trotsky, the police made elaborate preparations yesterday to avert a possible repetition of the disturbances in Madison Square Garden in 1934, when Communists broke up a demonstration of Socialists in support of Austrian workers engaged in battle with Fascist forces.

Plans for compensating New York farmers for diverting up to 25 per cent of past average production of acres planted to tobacco were announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration. These payments would be in addition to allowances for other soil building practices.

In filing an answer yesterday to the complaint of the Federal Trade Commission that it has violated provisions of the Robinson-Patman law, the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company not only denied the charge but attacked the constitutionality of the law on a number of grounds and asked that the complaint be dismissed.

A warm welcome was extended in today's press to Foreign Minister Rudolf Holsti of Finland, who arrived in Moscow this morning on an official visit as a "guest of the Soviet Government" accompanied by his wife and the director of the Political Department of the Finnish Foreign Office.

Paul H. Wendel will tell in court today his story of being kidnapped and tortured into signing a false confession to the Lindbergh baby kidnapping in a plot alleged to have been engineered by Ellis H. Parker, the county detective and friend of Governor Hoffman of New Jersey.

The following statement was issued tonight simultaneously in Detroit, Washington and New York on behalf of the General Motors Corporation by William S. Knudsen, executive vice president; Donaldson Brown, chairman of the finance committee, and John Thomas Smith, chief counsel:

Elihu Root's death caused much regret in League of Nations quarters, where it was felt that international organization generally and the League and World Court particularly, had lost one of their best American friends.

The vanguard of General Francisco Franco's victorious forces, detachments approaching along the coast from Fuengirola to the west, entered the city at 7 o'clock this morning. These were followed quickly by sections from Loja and Antequera to the north.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today deplored what she termed a lack of knowledge of their own country on the part of some of its citizens.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced Feb. 4 as the effective date of the following declarations:
The stock market here generally was strong and cheerful today. Gilt-edge issues opened steady but closed lower. Among the foreign bonds, German loans improved.

Represenative Edith Nourse Rogers, a Republican, of Massachusetts, introduced a resolution today, calling for a special House committee of five to investigate the possibility of retiring members of Congress at the age of 70 1/2 years, six months beyond the limit suggested by President Roosevelt for members of the Federal judiciary.

Some of President Roosevelt's friends in Congress began pressure today for a compromise on his sweeping plan for judicial reform, one of their proposals involving the possible retirement of two or more of the present justices of the Supreme Court.

Steamship lines reported yesterday that the movement of mails between ships arriving in port and the New York Postoffice had been speeded up as much as two hours because of the new Federal regulation permitting vessels to omit the stop at Quarantine when permission is obtained by radio.

The 125th anniversary of St. George's Church at Stuyvesant Square was celebrated last night by 1,200 of its parishioners at a dinner at the Hotel McAlpin, Broadway and Sixth Avenue. Among the guests was Bishop William T. Manning of the Diocese of New York, who said.
The Assembly voted tonight, with the Senate concurring, to recess for one hour at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning during funeral services for Elihu Root.

The Ludlum Steel Company reported yesterday that its sales in 1936 were well above $10,500,000, the largest on record for itself and subsidiaries. Earnings were estimated, pending an audit, at $1,100,000, or 18 per cent more than the $919,531 earned in 1929, and 71 per cent more than the $636,729 cleared in 1935.

Only 13 per cent of eighty persons interviewed said they would prefer their newspapers and magazines without advertising of any sort, according to a report on a preliminary survey on "The Consumer Attitude Toward National Advertising," conducted by the George Burton Hotchkiss Chapter of Alpha Delta Sigma, national honorary advertising and marketing fraternity at New York University.

" If the worst comes to the worst I'll always pick up a living showing people around Schoenbrunn; I know it so well," was the double-edged remark made today by the former ruler of the British Empire, now the Duke of Windsor.

Lincoln R. Scafe, manager of the General Motors Corporation's strikeclosed Fisher Body plant here, testified today that he had "standing instructions to open the plant whenever I can." The plant, employing 7,000 men, has been closed since a sit-down strike started there Dec. 28.

Reports were current today that Hugh S. Gibson, Ambassador to Brazil, and Jefferson Caffery, Ambassador to Cuba, might be transferred to other posts. One was that Mr. Gibson might be appointed Ambassador to Germany and that William E. Dodd, now serving at Berlin as Ambassador, might be transferred to another capital.

A block front of four-story and five-story buildings with 105 feet in Third Avenue, 230 feet in Westchester Avenue and 260 feet in Bergen Avenue, in the Bronx, has been leased by the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., in connection with the sale of the assets of the Adams-Flanigan store assets to the Hearn interests.

The crest of the Mississippi River flood rolled past Memphis tonight while a high wind hurled waves against the elevee tops, causing anxiety but no serious damage. A levee slide was reported along the Reelfoot levee, between Hickman, Ky., and Tiptonville, Tenn., but workers quickly repaired the damage with sandbags.
The United States Secret Service announced yesterday that it had arrested three counterfeiters and seized $50,000 in counterfeit money they had printed, before a bill had got into circulation.

In addition to releasing its annual statement for 1936, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday the declaration of a dividend of 50 cents a share, resuming payments on the common stock.

THE MASQUE OF THE KINGS, a play in three acts and six scenes, by Maxwell Anderson. Staged by Philip Moeller; settings and costumes by Lee Simonson; presented by the Theatre Guild (production committee, Theresa Helburn, Lawrence Langner and Mr. Moeller). At the Shubert Theatre.

Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday directed a jury to acquit Louis Levine, 34 years old, of 69 East Fourth Street, and Morris Goldenberg, 34, of 218 Beach Seventy- fifth Street. Rockaway, Queens, on a first-degree murder indictment in the death of Isidore Lazarowitz, 61, on Jan. 3, 1936.

The second National Notion and Novelty Exhibit opened yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania with a list of 150 exhibitors, an increase of about 30 per cent over the number participating in the first show last February.
Ralph Greenleaf led Andrew Ponzi by 250-229 at the conclusion of the first two blocks of their pocket billiard match for 1,250 points at Ponzi's Academy yesterday.

Dr. Glenn Frank, deposed President of the University of Wisconsin, called last night for a national leadership "that plays favorites with no economic group" in a broadcast address before the Ohio Society of New York.

Opposition to President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Federal judiciary or any other plan to increase the number of justices of the Supreme Court or otherwise interfere with the independent action of the Federal tribunal was expressed yesterday in a resolution adopted by the Bishop and members of the standing committee of the Diocese of Long Island of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

The Riverside Choir, under the direction of Harold Vincent Milligan, will sing Mrs. H. H. A. Beach's "The Canticle of the Sun" at a music service of the American Guild of Organists at the Riverside Church tonight.

With the flood waters receding and rehabilitation begun, buyers arriving in the market yesterday were chiefly concerned about the automobile strike. Together with manufacturers, they felt that a prolonged deadlock would affect retail trade seriously in many sections. Current trade, they reported, is running slightly ahead of a year ago.

After nearly two years of discussion, the National Retail Dry Goods Association, in a letter to members signed by D. E. Moeser, presilent, and made public yesterday, announced its affiliation with the American Retail Federation, organized in April, 1935, to become the "spokesman for retail distribution."

In Leeds Police Court the other day one WILLIAM HENRY WOOD was charged with wearing a political uniform forbidden by the Public Order Act. A policeman had found him in a public street trying to sell Action and The Black Shirt, organs of the British Union of Fascists.

The National City Bank of New York, syndicate manager of the banking group that on Jan. 13 offered to the public $50,000,000 of New York City 3 per cent corporate stock due on Jan. 1, 1977, at 103 1/2, to yield about 2.85 per cent, reduced yesterday the offering price to par.
Pope Pius XI, slightly weakened by his broadcast blessing yesterday to the Manila Eucharistic Congress, suffered occasional pain today, but was able to receive a limited list of callers.

Holding their first public meeting since President Roosevelt expressed a desire to change the complexion of the tribunal, the justices of the Supreme Court heard arguments today on the first of six major cases challenging constitutionality of New Deal labor laws, especially the principle of collective bargaining.

Governor Lehman signed tonight the Dunnigan bill modifying the agreement between the bankers and the New York City administration so as to fix the reserve fund in the 1937 budget against tax delinquencies at $12,000,000.

A jurisdictional dispute involving ship crews and longshoremen today tied up five coastal freighters which previously had been halted for ninety-eight days in the maritime strike which was settled last week.

Senator John J. McNaboe charged today that Mayor La Guardia was responsible for the apparent killing of his move to "revive and extend" the life of his committee to investigate "communism in the schools."

Several apartment buildings and a garage changed hands in deals reported in the Bronx yesterday. The Bonay Realty Corporation sold a five-story house on a plot 80 by 106 feet at 2,497 Grand Avenue to an investing client of Armstrong Brothers.

Dr. Richard G. Wiener, who was a general practitioner of medicine in this city for forty-three years, until his retirement in 1921, died yesterday after a brief illness in his apartment in the Hotel Meurice, 145 West Fifty-eighth Street, at the age of 82.
The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to its lits the no-parvalue common stock of the Doehler Die Casting Company and the when-issued rights of the Industrial Rayon Corporation.
The North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy announced yesterday, a food collection drive for the support of the Spanish Loyalists, men, women and children.

Detroit's Larry Aurie, with a week's bag of five points, has forged into a tie with Harvey Jackson of Toronto for leadership of the National Hockey League's scorers. Official league figures released tonight show the Red Wing and Maple Leaf stars deadlocked at 34 points apiece.

Many parties were given last night before the supper dance held in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery, one of the oldest institutions of its kind in New York, which cares for children of unemployed mothers or those looking for employment.

Miss Mary G. Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Allen, was married to Charles N. Mellowes, son of Alfred W. Mellowes of Milwaukee, here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 15 Crest Acres. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph B. Nesbitt of the First Presbyterian Church of Summit.

The $1,500,000 quota assigned to the New York chapter of the American Red Cross for flood relief in the Ohio-Mississippi valleys was reached yesterday in record time, General Robert C. Davis, the chapter's executive director, announced last night.

A driver pulled out last night from a parking space at 275 Lincoln Place, Irvington, and had gone only a short distance when he looked in the mirror over his windshield and saw a darkened automobile following him at close range.

Presbyterian, Reformed, Congregational, Baptist and other denominations will join with the Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and Lutheran Churches in observance of Lent, beginning tomorrow, Ash Wednesday. The special services will culminate on Easter, which falls on March 28.

George Frederick Pelham, retired architect and a former resident here, died suddenly yesterday at Verbank, N. Y., where he had been residing. He was 70 years old. Mr. Pelham's father, the late George B. Pelham, designed the Dominion Parliament Building at Ottawa, Canada.

Solicitations of brokerage orders for the purchase of securities constitute a "sale" of such securities within the meaning of the Securities Act of 1933, in the opinion of Allen E. Throop, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Langston Hughes's play "Mulatto," which had a long run in New York, was prevented from opening in this city tonight under an order issued by Mayor S. Davis Wilson, who directed that policemen be stationed at the door of the Locust Street Theatre to circumvent "any attempt to ignore the order."

Mr. and Mrs. Warren T. Chandler of St. Louis gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Doris Havemeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Havemeyer of this city, and Dr. Daniel Catlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel K. Catlin of St. Louis, who will be married this afternoon in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

A group of school children in the path of a runaway horse was saved from possible injury in Brooklyn yesterday by Patrolman Louis Tuck, who got the children out of the street and stopped the horse after it had dragged him for 150 feet.

In the Court of Claims of the United States the following proceedings were had today: H-328-Hazen C. Pratt; findings of fact; plaintiff entitled to recover; entry of judgment reserved pending the taking of testimony by a commissioner of the court upon question of reasonable and entire compensation Opinion by Chief Justice Booth.

Dr. Julius Miltz, 45 years old, of 141 East Third Street, who has an office at 106 Rivington Street, was arrested yesterday in the new Accident Fraud Bureau on a charge that he conspired with Sam Bornstein, leader of a gang of fake accident indemnity claimants, to defraud an insurance company of $50 to settle an injury claim.

The Court of Errors and Appeals reserved decision today after hearing argument on the petition of Mrs. Mabel Eaton to have set aside a decree of the Court of Chancery awarding to her divorced husband custody of their two children on an advisory master's report that she was "a convert to communism and atheism" and "not a proper person to be entrusted with their upbringing."

In an effort to clarify the problems that have caused hundreds of persons to telephone for information, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, and James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second New York District, issued a joint statement yesterday on the method of filling out monthly tax return forms under the old age benefit title of the Social Security Act.

The Rev. Thomas A. Hyde, superintendent of Christ Hospital since 1918, died yesterday at the hospital at the age of 56. He had been ill ten days. Born in Brookdale, a section of Bloomfield, N. J., Mr. Hyde was graduated from the General Theological Seminary in New York in 1905.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh arrived at Bocco di Falco Airport at 3:10 P. M. today after having bucked storms that slowed their speed to an average of less than sixty miles an hour on a flight from Rome.
Ten thousand persons who turned out for today's special flood relief benefit program at Santa Anita saw Chartres win the mile and one-sixteenth feature.

Clicking off points with a consistency that was little short of amazing, Lewis Brooks, 21-year-old Philadelphian, created a new American amateur high-run record last night as he launched his defense of the national amateur pocket billiard championship at the Capital Health Center.

Returning today from a survey of the flood regions in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, outlined to President Roosevelt the following four-point rehabilitation program:

Jim McMillen, former University of Illinois football star, brought down Harry (Man Mountain) Jacobs, Los Angeles, with a flying tackle and body slam in the feature match at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 2,500. The time was 33:52.

The fifty spokesmen of national farm organizations who gathered in Washington yesterday to confer with Secretary WALLACE represent a constituency which has benefited greatly at the hands of the Roosevelt Administration.

Russia apparently has found a painful fashion of demonstrating to the Reich her displeasure with the Berlin government's worldwide anti-Soviet campaign. She is not delivering the raw materials Germany expected to receive through the 1936 trade agreement and a 200,000,000-mark credit in 1935.

The City Athletic Club went into a deadlock with the Columbia Club for second place in the metropolitan Class B squash tennis team tournament by topping the Lion players, 3-2, at the Columbia Club in one of three matches in the double round-robin competition last night.

In spite of the effect of strikes on operations by the General Motors Corporation, factory sales of autobiles in January were the second highest for that month on record, according to a report made public yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association, which includes major producers of motor vehicles except the Ford Motor Company.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading opened only fair to slow in the wholesale markets, Ash Wednesday, denoting the beginning of the Lenten season, probably affecting buying to some extent.
President Roosevelt today extended an invitation to the Boy Scouts of America to hold a "Jamboree" in the national capital next Summer, from June 30 to July 9.

The eighth week of the Metropolitan Opera fourteen-week season began last night with a performance of Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann." There were two changes in the principal roles from the first two presentations of the opera earlier this season.

The Savage women's basketball team halted the Brooklyn . College sextet, 24-21, at Savage last night after leading by 19-10 at the intermission. Miss Ruth Hill tallied twelve markers for the winners and Miss Agnes Donavan scored ten for Brooklyn.

The coronation durbar, one of the most colorful and elaborate ceremonies in connection with the proclaiming of a new British monarch as Emperor of India, will not be held in India next Autumn, it was officially made known tonight. In announcing the cancellation of the original plans an India Office statement said:

Three telephone operators who stuck to their posts until the usual exits were blocked were rescued, several firemen were overcome and damage of $150,000 was caused as fire swept through this college town's largest two-story business building block on Main Street early today.

On motion of Prosecutor Erwin E. Marshall, whose term expires Wednesday, Common Pleas Judge Adam O. Robbins nolle prossed today two indictments charging manslaughter against Dr. Guy W. Burns of New York.

The plight of the Jews in Poland was forcibly brought to the attention of the world with the startling report spread abroad that the Polish Government planned the immediate "evacuation" of all the 3,150,000 Jews in Poland, thereby confronting other nations with a migration problem of unprecedented dimensions.

Isaac Lincoln Merrill Jr. of Camden, former Maine State titleholder, spread-eagled the field in winning the medal in the qualifying round for the annual Ormond Beach golf championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.

Watertown's child-bride case developed new complications today when the girl's husband and her parents were arrested on charges of obstructing justice. Stanley Backus, 19, the husband, already faces a charge of rape in the second degree, which the State claims was a consequence of his marriage to Leona Elizabeth Roshia.

It is proposed to give the Executive six new and sure votes in the Supreme Court by the device of increasing its membership to fifteen. The reasons assigned for this startling proposal will not bear analysis. The chief one-relief for aging members-is patently baseless.

All ranks of official, diplomatic and resident society turned out today to welcome and applaud Miss Lotte Lehmann, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, and Gaspar Cassado, 'cellist, at Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's last Musical Morning of the season in the Mayflower Hotel.

On his own application: PATROLMAN-Harry C. Ernst, 80th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 17, 1908. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-John M. O'Shaughnessy, from 25th Precinct to 19th Division, office of the Chief Inspector, for 5 days.

The arrest of two men and the recovery of oil paintings valued by the artist at more than $12,000 were disclosed yesterday by the police of the West Forty-seventh Street station, who said the prisoners had confessed the thefts.

Leading by 18-11 at the close of the first half, the Manhattan College freshman five turned back the Brooklyn College cubs, 31-24, at the Lawrence gymnasium yesterday. Matt O'Rourke, left guard, was high scorer for the victors with 10 points, while Abe Gerchick led the Kingsmen with 7.
The State Insurance Department today won a verdict of $1,525,800 against eleven directors of the defunct Pennsylvania Surety Corporation, which failed in 1930 with heavy losses to investors.

Judgeships and mayoralty nominations go on the auction block in "Glory For All," new political farce by Nat Perrin, which George Jessel presented in its first performance at the Erlanger Theatre here tonight.

The Port of New York Authority has protested to Secretary of War Woodring against a bill submitted last week in Congress that would clear the way for the construction of a bridge over the Hudson River at a point between Fifty-seventh and Seventy-second Streets, it was announced yesterday.

Harry Luckman, who is serving a term of twenty years to life for the murder of Samuel Drukman, was brought from Auburn prison yesterday to Brooklyn to attend the funeral of his mother, Mrs. Sarah Luckman of 722 Montgomery Street, who died of a heart attack on Saturday.

More than the usual number of low-priced stocks scored substantial gains yesterday in heavy trading. The common stock of the American Zinc, Lead and Smelting Company headed the list with a rise of 4 points to 13 7/8 in a turnover of 93,700 shares.

Major L. L. B. Angas, author of "The Coming American Boom" and similar studies, in a new pamphlet called "Slump Ahead in Bonds," predicts a decline in bond values and a temporary sympathetic shock in the stock market as a result of administrative acts to prevent a wild price inflation.

Antonio Ratti purchased from Charles J. Schick the two one-story business buildings on Lewis Street, adjoining his present holding at the corner of Main Street, Eatontown , N. J. Ray H. Stillman was the broker.

Formation of a protective committee for $8,549,000 first-mortgage sinking-fund 4 per cent bonds of the Philippine Railway due on July 1 is to be discussed at a meeting called by the Bankers Trust Company, trustee for the securities, for Feb. 26 in the bank's offices at 14 Wall Street.

The Southwestern Light and Power Company of Tulsa, Okla., today filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $7,250,000 of firstmortgage bonds, series A, due on Feb. 1, 1967.

John L. Lewis, chairman of theCommittee for Industrial Organization, issued the following statement early today. "The proposals of the United Automobile Workers of America: "1. That General Motors Corporation in this conference recognizes the U. A. W. A. as the collective bargaining agency for the employes of the twenty plants closed by the existing strike (Plants to be identified and listed.)
Senator Winant Van Winkle of Bergen County, a Republican, bolted an executive session of the Senate shortly before midnight and prevented confirmation of pending nominations made by Governor Hoffman.

His sensational play in the recent Australian championships today earned a place for 17-year-old Jack Bromwich on Australia's 1937 Davis Cup tennis team. Bromwich was named to the team along with Jack Crawford, Adrian Quist and Vivian McGrath. He replaces Don Turnbull.

Recipient of a Federal charter from Congress in 1935, the American National Theatre and Academy announced yesterday that it had proposed an extensive theatre program for the World's Fair here in 1939.

Anti-religious violence at Orizaba gave fresh evidence tonight that Mexico's long-standing church problem remained unsolved. The police at Orizaba, in the State of Vera Cruz, raided yesterday a private home where, they alleged, a religious service was being held contrary to law.

TOWER MAN (RAILROAD)--Salary, 69 cents an hour; pension. Ages, 25 through 39 on Feb. 24. Applications received to 4 P. M. Wednesday, Feb. 24, Room 1400, Municipal Building, Manhattan. Vacancies, 15; others expected with the opening of new subway lines in 1937.

Harvey L. Winslow, architect and real estate developer, died yesterday of pneumonia at Bellevue Hospital, New York. He was 59 years old. Mr. Winslow had designed many bank buildings in Westchester County as a member of the former architectural firm of Holmes Winslow.
The Board of Supervisors voted this afternoon to ask the Westchester County Park Commission to devise some new method of identifying cars of Westchester residents.

Dashing young C. C. Combs Jr. more than justified his five-goal rating last night as he led the Allenhurst Polo Club to a convincing 15 1/2-to-7 1/2 triumph over the Squadron C first team in the New York A. C.'s eleventh annual lowgoal tournament at the 105th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx.

Those truants from Broadway, Victor Moore and Helen Broderick, return today by courtesy of RKO Radio in "We're On the Jury," which opens at the Rialto. The film is an adaptation of Fred Ballard's courtroom melodrama, "Ladies of the Jury," and features Philip Huston, Louise Latimer, Frank M. Thomas, Robert McWade and Vinton Haworth.

American terrier fanciers will gather today at Commerce Hall in the Port of New York Authority Building,. 111 Eighth Avenue, for the annual combined specialty shows of the Associated Terrier Clubs. It will be the twentieth exhibition, the organization having held its first event in 1917.
To complete and extend the musical information contained in "The Magic World of Music," Olga Samaroff Stokowski has prepared "A Music Manual," that W. W. Norton will publish on Thursday.
Declaring that a state of emergency existed because of the General Motors strike, the City Commission tonight adopted a resolution delegating all the city's police powers to Mayor Harold Bradshaw.

Jim Herbert of the Curb Exchange, the N. Y. U. freshman who has been one of the middle distance sensations of the present track and field season, yesterday filed his entry for the Buermeyer 500 that is to be one of the features of the New York A. C. carnival at Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday.

John Paul Laffey, retired general counsel and head of the legal department of the du Pont Company, who also had served as a director and vice president of the concern, died at his home here tonight from a stroke suffered three weeks ago.

The body of Elihu Root, former Secretary of State and former Secretary of War, was taken yesterday afternoon to Clinton, N. Y., his birthplace, for burial this morning. The funeral will be private. Mr.

Annual elections were held yesterday by the New York Curb Exchange and resulted in the choice of the regular slate of fourteen governors and two gratuity fund trustees designated by the nominating committee. The governors will meet tomorrow to select a president from among their number.

President Roosevelt was delighted when his plan for increasing the membership of the Supreme Court came as a complete surprise to the Washington newspaper men and "all anticipations were instantly transmuted into waste paper," Arthur Krock, Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said last night in a lecture on news reporting at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

The Federal Reserve Board in its monthly bulletin today called attention to the substantial increase in money in circulation. In the absence of any material hoarding of money, such as took place at the time of the bank holiday, the increase in the amount of cash outside the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Banks was regarded as indicating improvement in business conditions and greater national trading.
The fall of Malaga-next to Barcelona the most important port on the Mediterranean-is a hard blow to the Loyalist cause.
Exports of farm equipment last December were valued at $4,094,787, compared with $1,898,881 in December, 1935, the Department of Commerce said today. They were as follows:

Three navy fliers were killed here today in two service plane crashes. Cadet Ervin Kermitt Olsen of Freemont, Neb., drowned and Cadet Ray Albert Schmidt of Albion, Ill., narrowly escaped when the seaplane in which they were engaged in torpedo practice turned upside down and sank in Big Lagoon.

A sentence of thirty to sixty years in State's prison as a second offender was imposed by Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions yesterday on Michael Keller, 26 years old, of 1,157 Jackson Avenue, the Bronx. He had been convicted by a jury last Dec. 1 in the hold-up of a butcher shop at 11 Prince Street about a year ago in which the loot was $65 in cash and $480 in jewelry.

Joseph Triner, chairman of the Illinois Athletic Commission, scoffed tonight at reports that the city's centennial celebration committee was not solidly behind his efforts to bring the heavyweight title match between Champion James J. Braddock and Joe Louis to Chicago next June.

Ninety-seven maintenance and service employes began yesterday a sit-down strike in the Israel Zion Hospital at 4,802 Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn. They continued to serve and feed the 290 patients and ninety babies in the hospital and its maternity pavilion, but they refused to serve the thirty-two doctors and 250 nurses on the staff.

The annual report of the Electric Shareholdings Corporation for 1936, issued yesterday, showed net assets of $21,403,096 at the year end, compared to $19,970,263 the year before, equal to $218.35 a share of $6 preferred stock and to $6.14 a common share, against $196.76 and $4.82, respectively, at the end of 1935.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Jan. 31 showed that the gold reserve's ratio to notes in circulation had declined from 139.39 per cent on Jan. 15 to 137.04. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities changed from 92.72 to 92.43.

Counsel for the Stock Exchange firm of W. E. Hutton Co. sought today to quash a government order requiring the company to show cause why it should not be suspended or expelled from various national securities Exchanges for alleged market manipulation.

A recommendation for the dredging of nearly one-half of the Long Island intracoastal waterway, which extends from the East Rockaway Inlet to the Shinnecock Canal, has been filed by Colonel E. D. Peek, division army engineer, with the board of engineers for rivers and harbors in Washington, it was announced yesterday.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday a new issue of $3,000,000 of short-term notes to the Northern Trust Company of Chicago on a 0.50 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $10. The notees will be dated Feb. 15, 1937, and will become payable on Feb. 8, 1938.

In a leading editorial in The Times today the Englishman is scolded for his habitual inhospitality and is requested to outdo himself in welcoming the visitors from overseas expected here for the coronation in May.
