Announcement was made here last night of the death on Saturday at his home in Coudersport, Pa., of Nelson Edgar Barton, owner and editor of The Potter County (Pa.) Journal, who had been in the newspaper and printing business for sixty years. He was 78 years old.

Steve (Crusher) Casey of County Kerry, Ireland, threw Cliff Olsen of Minneapolis in 32:16 of a finish bout at the wrestling show staged last night before a crowd of 4,316 persons at Madison Square Garden.

John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight champion of the world, won from Al Ettore, Philadelphia heavyweight ace, tonight at Convention Hall, but by so slight a margin that many of the 12,000 who witmessed the frenzied fifteen rounds appeared to be unconvinced.

A refusal to identify by name secret operatives engaged by industries was made by the Pinkerton National Detective Agency today when the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage resumed hearings after a ten-day recess.

President Roosevelt received a report from Harry L. Hopkins on condition in the flood area; conferred with Senator Wagner on a housing program, discussed his judiciary program with Senator Ashurst and Representative Sumners and invited the Boy Scouts to hold their jamboree in Washington next Summer.

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at 13.275 cents a pound, c.i.f. European base ports. This is a new high level for the current movement and 27.5 points above the domestic level. Most sales, however, were between 13.15 and 13.20 cents, about the same as on Saturday.

A Philadelphia pair, Miss Charlotte Darling, runner-up in the recent singles championship, and Mrs. Edith Hahs Beatty, won the second annual women's New Jersey open squash racquets doubles championship at the Montclair Athletic Club today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted the application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the twenty-year 7 per cent sinkingfund debenture bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1945,

Mayor La Guardia was balked by the Democratic members of the Board of Estimate yesterday in his effort to speed up the school construction program by having private architects design the Central Needle Trades High School and five other new schools.

Special Sessions Justice William R. Bayes, who has been in that court since July, 1935, was sworn in as Chief Justice by Mayor La Guardia yesterday at City Hall. He fills the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Frederic Kernochan.

A joint resolution asking Congress to vote down President Roosevelt's recommendation to increase the number of justices in the Supreme Court was introduced in the State Senate here tonight by Senator Charles E. Loizeaux of Union County, Republican majority leader.

ONE of our prominent citizens was privately threatened two nights ago and an investigation was set on foot. The prominent citizen who was threatened was Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the New York Yankees.

Two hearings by the Interstate Commerce Commission today brought here about 700 witnesses, lawyers and observers. One was the reopening of the case covering freight charges on products shipped in refrigerator cars.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals Joseph Edward Well of New York was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 3726-Ex parte The Ric-Wil do. Opinion by Judge Graham. The decision of the Commissioner of Patents is affirmed.

The-War Department is making a study of outer clothing for the army to obtain a serviceable, comfortable and suitable uniform which will permit a soldier to perform best his duties under field conditions.

The marriage of Miss Louise Merriman Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Reed of 175 West Seventy-second Street, to Laurens Hamilton Rhinelander, also of New York, son of the Right Rev. and Mrs. Philip M. Rhinelander of Washington, took place yesterday afternoon in the West End Collegiate Church. The Rev.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Taylor Foster of Greenwich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Patterson Foster, to A. Oram Fulton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Oram Fulton of Boston and Oyster Harbors, Mass.

Five New York youths who tried to proclaim their maturity and freedom from parental supervision by staging a three-day "sit-down strike" in the Club Bali, 161 East Fifty-fourth Street, brought about a suspension of the club's cabaret license yesterday.

Imports of $5,304,500 gold here were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank. Of this amount, $2,754,600 was received from India on Saturday, and $2,549,900 arrived yesterday from England, consigned to the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

William L. Finley, field naturalist of the American Nature Association and a noted wildlife photographer, was chatting the other day about the excitement and hazards of taking close-up pictures of wild creatures.
The Rev. Hugo F. Sloctemeyer, S. J., former president of Xavier University, died at West Baden College, West Baden Springs, Ind., of a heart attack today. He was 52 years old.

The particularly interesting fact, emphasized in the Controller of the Currency's annual report, is the absence, during the twelve months ended last October, of any national bank suspension in the United States.

Frank A. Sieverman 3d of the New York Athletic Club and Walter D. Hoag of the Yale Club were triumphant yesterday as play opened in the Whitehall Club's third annual invitation squash tennis tournament. Twenty-three players, including several of the rankine stars. are entered in this event.
The Georgetown University quintet swamped West Virginia tonight in an Eastern Conference game, winning by a score of 51-23. The Mountaineers previously had defeated the Hoyas, 41-32.

With a half dozen mills announcing their 1937 prices yesterday at the semi-annual National Domestics and Linen Show at the Hotel New Yorker, all-wool blankets were definitely established on a basis about 12 to 15 per cent higher than a year ago.

Resuming his role as salesman, which he adopted last Thursday, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx yesterday sold the effects of thirteen factories in East 134th and 135th Streets, which are to be razed to make way for the westerly approach to the Triborough Bridge.
A score of sailing craft will hoist canvas tomorrow for the fourth annual Miami-to-Nassau race, with three of them carrying radio-direction finders an innovation in yacht racing.

With the express approval of President Roosevelt and in expectation of passage of the President's program for judicial reforms, Secretary Wallace proposed before a "historic meeting" of farm leaders and their Congressional spokesmen today that the administration's original farm program be revived in the form of his "ever-normal granary" plan, supplemented by commodity loans and "universal and positive production control."
Plans for Bermuda's fifth annual Rugby football week, in which American university teams will compete, were announced today by A. E. Nicholl, president of the Bermuda Athletic Association.

OVER the week-end 1 read two novels: Dorothy Speare's "The Road to Needles" (Houghton Mifflin, $2) and Wilma Pollock's "The Upps of Suffolk Street" (Dutton, $2.50). Neither one is any great shakes, but each will have its admirers--indeed, already has.

The Panzer College quintet scored its fifth triumph of the season in defeating Manhattan College of Staten Island tonight, 41-31. The winners led at the half 15-10. Eddie Mahoney of Manhattan tallied 15 points for individual honors.

The last of the jurors who will try Major Green, 33-year-old Negro porter, for the murder of Mrs. Mary Harriet Robinson Case on Jan. 11, was picked at 9:55 o'clock last night in the county court house in Long Island City, where ten years ago Ruth Snyder and Judd Gray were sent to the electric chair.

The New York Curb Exchange has approved an application for listing of 658,260 shares of New England Power Association preferred stock, $100 par value; 26,900 shares of $2 cumulative preferred, no par value, and 932,609 shares of common stock, no par value.

Jayee Realties, Inc., sold to O'Gorman-Halpin, Inc., builders, thirtyfive lots on the north and south sides of Voorhis Avenue, east of Knollwood Road, Rockville Center, L. I. Joseph T. Froehlich and Maurice W. Halpin were the brokers.

It seems as if this stage of the Spanish civil war is being fought on a movie lot. Favored with perfect subtropical weather, General Francisco Franco's Insurgent army has advanced among palms and pine and eucalyptus groves to capture trim-looking villages made up of whitewashed doll-sized houses somewhat like a real estate agent's cardboard toy city advertising some new Florida subdivision.
The weather gods, who gave Germany just one week's good snow last year for the Winter Olympics, seem to have turned thumbs down on the German ski championships scheduled to start today.

The prospect of exhaustion of Federal funds for work relief kept the Senate and the House in session until early evening. A compromise was reached between the two houses on the use of executive employes by Congressional committees, and the first Deficiency Appropriation Bill went to- the White House for executive approval when the conference report was adopted.

Rival thugs ended the criminal career last night of Henry (Knockout) Halperin, 37-year-old Brooklyn racketeer and extortionist with a long record of arrests, including several in connection with gang murders. He was shot and killed shortly after 6 o'clock at Boerum Place and State Street, in front of a church.
Leases of large space and expansion moves featured commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Mills Co. Real Estate, Inc., announced leases totaling approximately 150,000.

Herman D. Berndt, a pressman for THE NEW YORK TIMES for the last twenty-four years, died on Friday of a heart ailment at the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, after a week's illness. Mr. Berndt lived at 481 Dean Street, Brooklyn. His age was 67.

Owing to the lengthy examination to which Charles D. Lewis, defense counsel, subjected each of eighteen talesmen questioned today in an effort to obtain a jury for the trial of Chang Soo Lee, diminutive 36year-old Korean charged with attempting to kill two persons by feeding them poison, only four jurors were accepted.
The liquor cut price war begun last wek continued yesterday while Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, launched an investigation. Mr.
The thoughts of thousands who are detained at their occupations will affectionately join those who gather today at the grave

Harry R. Patten of New Rochelle, N. Y., was in front at the completion of the first group of matches played on St. Augustine Links today by members of the Daniel Boone Association, composed of New York professional and business men, in their inaugural Winter championship.

Approval was given by the War Department today to plans of the Triborough Bridge Authority of New York City for the construction of bridge from Old Ferry Point in the Bronx to Whitestone Point in Queens.

The final Coffee Dance in the Winter series was held last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. Many dinners were given in advance, the hosts and hostesses taking their guests later to the club for coffee and dancing.

World War veterans of fourteen nations will gather in Berlin between Feb. 15 and 18 in what promises to resolve itself into the most impressive gathering of former service men anywhere since the armistice.

Elisabeth Schumann, soprano; Gaspar Cassado, 'cellist, and Carl Friedberg, Coenraad V. Bos and Arpad Sandor, pianists, were the guest artists at the season's fourth concert of the Beethoven Association last night at Town Hall. The audience responded with prolonged applause to a series -of stirring, authoritative interpretations.

Richard Wheeler Baker, lawyer, police magistrate, World War veteran, and former Yale varsity football player, died this afternoon in the Princeton Hospital after a week's illness, at the age of 45. Mr. Baker was born in Cincinnati, a son of the Rev. Dr. Frank and Jennie Mills Baker.

ARGUIMBAU, ELISE C. (Jan. 22). Estate, not more than $1,200. To Marie H. Ramee, East Hampton, L. I. Joseph R. Ramee, nephew, executor, East Hampton, L. I. AVDOYAN, PEROOZ (Jan. 10). Estate, $2,500. To Setrak E. Evdoyan, husband, executor 615 W. 183d St., residue.

Two extremes in hockey will meet tonight in Madison Square Garden when the Detroit Red Wings, world champions, who are leading the American division of the National Hockey League, tackle the down-trodden Americans, tailenders in the International diision.
Two buildings in the Grand Central zone and several multi-family houses on the upper West Side figured in the realty transactions reported by brokers yesterday in Manhattan.

Professor Albert Johannsen of the University of Chicago is going to compile a bibliography of the dime novel. He has 4,500 of them in storage pending the start of his research soon after his retirement March 31 'from the Geological Department.

President William Green of the American Federation of Labor indicated tonight his organization had adopted a "hands off policy," amounting to endorsement of the General Motors strike, backed by the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Clarence A. Earl, formerly vice president of Willys-Overland, Inc., has been elected president of the Arcturus Radio Tube Company, Newark, N. J. The company will announce shortly the addition of several new lines allied to the radio tube business.
Unprecedented harmony prevailed at today's opening session of the Legislature when the Liberal minority members joined in the unanimous re-election of the coalition officers.

Producers of naval stores can profit, F. P. Veitch of the Department of Agriculture says, by the errors they have made if they will check up on changes that should be made in operation and equipment in the woods and at the still, correct unprofitable practices and substitute better methods.
Five years ago trailers were just so many overnight shelters. Now there are at least 300,000 which are real homes. Adversity is their father,

The Rev. William Francis Gagnieur, one of the best-known priests in Northern Ontario, died at the General Hospital here last night at the age of 79. He had celebrated on May 11 the golden jubilee of his ordination as a priest.

Substantial increases in the consumption of spiritous and malt beverages in 1936 over 1935 were indicated today by figures released by the Treasury Department showing the quantities of various commodities on which internal revenue stamps were affixed.

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 80.6 per cent of capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This is an increase of 1 point, or 1.3 per cent from last week, when the rate was 79.6 per cent of capacity.

Despite earlier indications that the negotiations for a settlement of the General Motors automobile strike would probably collapse at a conference which opened at 7 o'clock last night, the parley continued until 1:30 this morning and then Governor Murphy announced that it would be resumed at 8:30 o'clock tonight.

Mrs. Harrison Williams, who will leave tomorrow for New York, whence she will go to Capri, gave a dinner tonight for thirty at her residence. Her house party, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Shevlin, Captain and Mrs. Alastair Mackintosh, Mrs. Irene Branca and William Taylor, also will leave tomorrow.

Mrs. Alfred I. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., gave a luncheon on the clubhouse balcony at Hialeah Park this afternoon before the races. Her guests included Dr. Francis P. Gaines, president of Washington and Lee University, and Mrs. Gaines, and Ethan Allen Dennison of New York.
Production of steel ingots in January, at 4,736,697 gross tons, was the largest for any January in the history of the country, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Reorganization of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway, which is in bankruptcy, is not necessary, according to a letter sent yesterday to holders of the company's securities by Walter E. Meyer, chairman of a committee for its stockholders.

Frank Iannicelli of the New York Athletic Club and Vincent Furno of the Columbia University Club earned the right to meet in the final of the second annual Monte M. Sterling squash tennis tournament by capturing their semi-final tests on the Winged Foot courts yesterday.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Feb. 5: COMMANDERS Denfeld. L. E., Destroyer Division 11, to duty as aid to Chief of Naval Operations, Washington D. C. about May 31.

Dr. Edward S. Corwin, Princeton University Professor of Jurisprudence, said today that no Federal judiciary reform "could be better adopted than the requirement that no judge may hold office beyond his seventieth birthday."

The popularity of Jose Iturbi has not diminished since he entered the lists as an orchestral conductor, if the numerous and enthusiastic audience that gathered in Carnegie Hall last night is an indication, as no doubt it is, of the public attitude on the subject.
Edward G. Johns, editor of The Denville Herald, died of a heart attack at his home here last night. He was 68 years old. A native of Milford, Pa., Mr. Johns had long been engaged in newspaper work.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: Original-State of Texas, complainant, v. State of New York et al. This cause is set for argument on the rule to show cause and the returns thereto and is assigned for argument on Monday. March 8 next.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Feb. 3 shows decreases for the week of $48,000,000 in total loans and investments and $37,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, an increase of $25,000,000 in time deposits and decreases of $50,000,000 in government deposits, $41,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $25,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.
Fragmentary dispatches from London indicate that people there are surprised at the excitement caused here by the President's proposal to remake the Supreme Court.

The stock market closed generally higher yesterday, and the day's gains, together with those of Saturday, wiped out the losses on last Friday that resulted from the President's surprise message to Congress on reorganization of the Federal judiciary.

The time limit forced a draw between the touring Marylebone Cricket Club and a Geelong eleven today, with the Englishmen well ahead at the end of the two-day match. M. C. C. had 282 and 251, Geelong 161.
" Yes, My Darling Daughter," is this evening's-arrival at the Playhouse, this being a new comedy by Mark Reed, who provided some amusement two years ago with "Petticoat Fever."

Many State Legislatures are now in session, though they have necessarily been overshadowed by sensational public events during the past few weeks. The Western floods, the automobile strike, the President's court plans, have had first place not only in the news but in everybody's thoughts.

The Abraham Lincoln High School basketball team captured its seventh straight victory in Section Two of the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. race by staging an uphill battle to defeat Manual Training High School, 29-24, at the Prospect Y. M. C. A. yesterday.

The Grand Union Company sold the four-story warehouse on a plot 96 by 220 feet at 145 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, N. Y., to the Meralja Corporation, which intends to raze the building and erect a one-story business structure. John J. Reynolds negotiated the deal.
In a five-nose finish, Glastonbury, John McPherson's 9-year-old, gained a photographic victory in the sixth and feature race at Alamo Downs today. San Ardo gained second place and Show Boy third.

Plans for a $325,000 apartment house in upper Manhattan a multi.family structure to cost $165,000 on Kings Highway, Brooklyn, and two to cost $150,000 each, in Queens, were filed yesterday. Plans listed in the various boroughs were:

The 4-yearold filly Genie Palatine, one of Mrs. Emil Denemark's favorite thoroughbreds, won the featured Cocoa Purse at Hialeah Park today. Before the race Genie Palatine gave the big crowd a tip in a manner she had devised herself.
Every man must be his own law in his own work but it is a poor-spirited artist in any craft who does not know how the other man's work should be done or could be improved.

The heads of seventeen locals of the Building Service Employs International Union voted last night to join in a city-wide strike drive for closed shop agreements. The campaign, an extension of Local 32B's effort to obtain recognition in between 1,500 and 2,000 Manhattan buildings, which have no contracts with the union, will be directed against the owners of hundreds of apartment houses in Brooklyn, Bronx and Queens.

The pre-war idea of many Germans that war is a necessary element in the life of mankind has reappeared here in an article published by the Weekly Military Journal, a much-respected technical organ. The author, Captain von Waldeyer Harz, retired, says:

Continued strike difficulties caused automobile production to recede still further last week, but the decline was less than seasonal and the adjusted index has advanced to 80.8 from 79.0. It was 81.4 for the week ended Feb. 8, 1936.

ARLINSKY, THEODORE (Nov. 8, 1936). Gross assets, $25,500; net, $8,718. To sons, Jack and Reuben Arlinsky, daughter, Mary Savedoff, one-third of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $24,609; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $891. Wexler Sternberg, attorneys, 152 W. 42d St., Manhattan.

Tenders for approximately $50,000,000 of 273-day Treasury bills dated Feb. 10 and maturing on Nov. 10, 1937, amounted to $179,465,000, of which $50,025,000 was accepted, the Treasury announced tonight. The accepted bids ranged in price from 99.742, equivalent to about 0.340 per cent, to 99.707, or about 0.386 per cent.

Each of the following named Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC. is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: 1st Lt. Arthur A. Frambach, Inf-Res., Aug. 13. Captain Thomas M. Childs, MI-Res., Sept. 2.
Premier Senjuro Hayashi announced his program today in a brief statement of principles, some of which are so abstract that translation is difficult.

While price movements on the Cotton Exchange yesterday held within narrow limits, there was some liquidation of March against purchases of later months. Some holders sold at the opening and others at the close of the session and the list ended 5 points lower to 11 points higher.

Further gains in secondary and convertible domestic corporate issues were the feature of an otherwise dull trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market for the better-grade investments was extremely dull, with prices holding in a narrow range.

Miss Eleanor Shaler of this city, daughter of the late Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Charles Shaler, was married to Benjamin Abbott Dickson of Haverford, Pa., yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Smith, 109 East Sixty-fourth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Theodore C. Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church.
Madrid, formerly a non-industrial city, today has become the most active center for manufacturing munitions and other war supplies in Socialist-dominated areas of Spain.

While the fight on President Roosevelt's judicial reforms gets under way in the United States, approval of the President's proposals grows in this country, whose courts have been the envy of American lawyers and laymen.

E. K. Bryson's Calumet Dick, a beaten favorite in his last two starts, justified his backers' confidence today by capturing the major share of the $2,500 added Mardi Gras Handicap at the Fair Grounds at 9-5.

Carl L. Swenson of New York has purchased the fifty-eight-acre estate of Murray W. Dodge, known as Hocotia, at Mount Kisco, Westchester. A Colonial residence of twenty rooms, a cottage, garage and stable are among the buildings, and there is a swimming pool on the grounds.

Some 300 sandhogs employed on the Wards Island intercepting sewer units in Harlem walked out yesterday in a sympathy strike with the drillers who quit work Monday on the new Sixth Avenue subway. A skeleton crew, however, manned compressed air devices to prevent damage to the tunnel.

With a crash that was heard for miles, a United Air Lines transport plane manned by a crew of three, including a stewardess, and bearing eight passengers bound from Los Angeles to San Francisco Airport, plunged tonight like a plummet into San Francisco Bay, three miles off the village of South San Francisco, about ten miles from San Francisco proper.

The New Haven Railroad an nounced last night that it ha scheduled "snow trains" tomorrow and Friday nights to important ski points in the Green Mountains in Vermont and the White Mountains in New Hampshire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The American Revolution had its beginning in the theory that taxation without representation is tyranny. But how little this matters when compared with regimentation without representation.

The Seth Low quintet swamped NassauHofstra Memorial College, 45 to 25, in the Hempstead High gymnasium tonight. The victors, who showed the way by 19-7 at the half, were paced by Wally Levine with 22 points. The line-up:

Lieut. Gov. Francis E. Kelly was married this morning to Miss Marion G. McDonald of East Boston. They had been engaged for several months. The ceremony was performed privately at St. Peter's Church, Dorchester. Governor Hurley and Mrs.
Two seeded players were eliminated as the women's New Jersey Class B squash racquets championship advanced to the semi-finals at the Montclair Athletic Club today.

Dealings in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange showed a further slackening in the trading pace to the dullest session of the year. Prices in virtually all groups moved within a narrow range and drifted to moderately lower levels.

In all the discussion of the various bills proposed in Congress authorizing or requiring an embargo on American export trade with declared belligerents, surprisingly little attention has been given to what the result might be on the American community itself.

The violent and, in some quarters, confused assault on the President's scheme to get new Supreme Court justices at once without waiting for deaths or resignations has tended to divert attention from the immediate political consequences.

The visit of the Finnish Foreign Minister, RUDOLF HOLSTI, and the warm official welcome accorded him on his arrival in the Russian capital Monday would indicate that the two countries are anxious to improve commercial and political relations between them.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt held tonight the last State reception of the season, that in honor of the army and navy.

Tony Kozen of Bridgeport, Conn., and Dave Carter of Nevada, Mo., finished in a deadlock for first place in the qualifying round the twelfth annual Dixie golf championship at the Miami Country Club today.

AMERICA: A RE-APPRAISAL, by Harold E. Stearns. (Hillman-Curl, $3.) Reaffirming faith in American ideals and democracy. ANOTHER SUCH VICTORY, by Clifton Cuthbert. (Hillman-Curl, $2.50.) A portrayal in fiction form of life in a New England town during the general textile strike of September, 1934.

THE Millrose meet set a good pace in the opening track and field festivities in the Garden. Records were reasonably scarce, but the competition was unusually keen. If the New York A. C. games, the K. of C. carnival, the intercollegiates and the national championships furnish as much fun the track fans of this area are in for an enjoyable indoor campaign.

Unperturbed by the fact that firemen were fighting a stubborn blaze in a chimney flue between the top floor and the roof of the Graduate School of the Juilliard School of Music, some 180 students went about their routine of playing instruments and concentrating on the composition of music yesterday morning.

Declaring that the Wagner National Labor Relations Act was a government effort to force a nation-wide system of collective bargaining and make the closed shop compulsory, and violated the constitutional guarantee of freedom of the press, John W. Davis opened arguments in the Supreme Court today on the first test of the law.

While value of the estate of E. L. Doheny, oil, magnate, is now placed at $9,042,563, claims against it have reached $15,014,049, according to an account filed today in Superior Court by the executors, Mrs. Carrie Estella Doheny, the widow, Robert M. Sands and Olin Wellborn Jr.

Myron Fellows, justice of the peace, imposed a "life sentence" on Mason J. Halstead today for running a coupe carrying four persons past a "stop" sign. He married the defendant and Miss Ruth W. Alexander while deputy sheriffs looked on.

Andrew Ponzi increased his advantage over Ralph Greenleaf by taking the third and fourth blocks of their 1,250-point pocket billiard match at the Ponzi Academy yesterday. In the afternoon Ponzi triumphed, 157-33, in nine innings, while last night he scored by 11514, in two frames. High runs were:

Steel production regained its preflood level last week and the increase was more than seasonal, advancing the adjusted index to 113.3 from 112.5 in the previous week. The index stood at 71.7 for the week ended Feb. 1, 1936.

Allied International Investing Corporation--For 1936: Net assets, based on market value of securities owned at close of year, equal to $35.85 a share on 29,754 shares of $3 convertible preferred stock outstanding, compared with $27.42 a preferred share on Dec. 31, 1935.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We celebrate this week the anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln and in so doing it is well to recall the latter part of his Gettysburg speech: " * * * that we here highly resolve that these dead shall not have died in vain;
News of the discovery of hitherto unknown land in the Antarctic was received today by radio from Lars Christensen, Norwegian explorer.

The Chrysler Corporation announced a wage increase today of thirteen to fourteen million dollars annually covering all its employes. The average increase, on the basis of the increase made last May, is estimated at 10 per cent per employe.

Sir Samuel Kelly, shipowner, who had an interest in many Northern Ireland coal, traction and public service companies, died today. He was chairman of John Kelly, Ltd., coal importers, and of the executive council of the Shipping Federation.

Samuel Shipman, playwright and prominent figure in Broadway theatrical circles, died suddenly yesterday afternoon in his suite at the Hotel Alamac, Seventy-first Street and Broadway. He had been confined to his bed for only two days, suffering from an attack of angina pectoris, to which his death was attributed. His age was 53.

Thomas F. Troy, known on the stage as T. F. Thomas, who sixty years ago led a troupe of minstrels across the plains and mountains to California and back, died of pneumonia yesterday morning in French Hospital. Mr. Troy, who had been ill since Jan. 28, was 82 years old.

Trustees of the Gunnery School have decided to increase the number of forms to six and the institute will be divided into an upper and lower school, more or less separate. The two schools will be housed in separate dormitories.

Retailers must build the foundation for their sales structure this year by definite and careful planning, buying "toward the customer instead of from the manufacturer," Carl B. Drake, merchandise manager of Younker Brothers, Des Moines, Iowa, declared last night at the fourteenth annual dinner of the National Notion Association at the Hotel Astor.
Mrs. Reta Freeman, 68-year-old widow, spent all of her $200 old-age pension test fund in nine days. Today she pointed proudly to the results. "Just think, a real radio in my home!" she said.

A definite plan for amicably adjusting differences between retailers and manufacturers over merchandise returns has been developed by the venders' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and representatives of the apparel industries, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the retail organization.
Shielding his identity except to reveal that he is a former convict, city, State and Federal detectives questioned a man here tonight in connection with the Mattson kidnap slaying.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You see what you have done. By your championship of the New Deal you helped to bring about the Rooseveltian radical (not the Democratic) landslide of Nov. 3. What are some of the results?
The Yankees yesterday announced the signing of Vito Tamulis and Don Heffner, Leslie Powers came into the fold with the Giants .and Harry Lavagetto annd Tom Baker accepted terms with the Dodgers.

The Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company, which operates the traction lines in this city, announced today that by May 1 it would discontinue its trolley service on all local lines and substitute buses. The statement was issued by Walter Carr, vice president,

Events in Spain precipitated a freefor-all fight in the Chamber of Deputies today and foreshadowed a split in the Belgian Socialist party. The Rexists attempted to interpellate Camille Huysmans, the Socialist president of the Chamber, with regard to his recent visit to Spain and his conferences with leaders since.

Mayor La Guardia demonstrated the value of the West Side Elevated Highway yesterday morning in an automobile race from City Hall to West Fiftieth Street and the Hudson River, which he won against Borough President Samuel Levy.

Several dinners were given last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis in connection with the Mardi Gras festival held there. The walls of the room were draped with cellophane and decorated with clusters of balloons of different colors for the occasion.

For four hours yesterday in the Kings County Court Paul H. Wendel recounted in indignant accents his story of how he was kidnapped a year ago, half starved, beaten and burned until, in desperation, he signed his false confession that he kidnapped Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Practically no opposition has developed to any of the President's court proposals except to the retirement of Federal judges over 70, or the appointment of an additional judge for every judge past 70.

Announcement was made here today of the death on Saturday of Georges Calmann-Levy, head of the large publishing house which first published the works of Anatole France. He was 77 years old. Mr. Calmann-Levy was a member of one of the leading Jewish families in France.

Mr. and Mrs. G. Cleveland Cook today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Cameron Cook, to Hartwig N. Baruch Jr., son of Hartwig N. Baruch of New York and White Marsh Plantation in Gloucester County, and Mrs. Arline L. Baruch of New York, and a nephew of Bernard M. Baruch.

A warning against policies based on "boom" psychology and a plea for "continuing effort to consolidate the recovery" were voiced today by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in a speech to the Committee of One Hundred, an organization of business leaders wintering in Florida.

They call it their "convention," but what the Tin Can Tourists of the World actually are holding this week is a funfest and homecoming. Theoretically, every one of the 4,000 roamers is a delegate, but membership in the tourists requires no dues, no obligations, no wearing of badges or any other procedure except to own a trailer and be present.

Andrew Hagaman, retired Staten Island banker, died at his Winter home at Homestead, Fla., on Monday, according to word received here. He was 74 years old and resided at 46 Hatfield Place, Port Richmond, S. I.

Franklin D. Roosevelt, who started a style with his inauguration day cutaway, and Fred Astaire, movie star credited with taking the comedy out of the tailcoat, topped a list today of sixteen male fashion leaders.

The drug store of the future, radically different from the type known today, was described to more than 1,000 persons attending the twentyfifth anniversary dinner of the Fordham University College of Pharmacy last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania, by Dr. James H. Kidder, dean of the college.

The American Federation of Labor yesterday invited spokesmen of the group that sponsored the recent maritime strike in Atlantic and Gulf ports to submit proof of its claim to control of the three unions that compose the International Seamen's Union.

A program aiming to bring all national planning for control of floods and conservation of natural resources into one organization, based on eight regional boards, will be submitted to Congress by President Roosevelt with a recommendation that it be enacted into law at this session, the President said today.

A scheduled telephone speech from Mexico to New York by Leon Trotsky, in which the Russian exile offered to surrender to the Soviet Government if an impartial commission of inquiry should find him guilty of the crimes ascribed to him by Moscow courts, was prevented last night because the wire was cut somewhere south of Monterey, Mexico. according to Max Schachtman, Trotsky's personal representative.

The city of Holyoke, Mass., awarded yesterday a new issue of $500,000 of short-term notes to Leavitt Co. on a 0.715 per cent interest basis. The notes, to be dated yesterday, will become payable on Nov. 5, 1937. The city officials received six other tenders for the notes ranging from 0,737 to 0.78 Per cent interest rate.

The sit-down strike of ninetyseven maintenance employes of the Israel Zion Hospital at 4,802 Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn, was terminated last night by an agreement which gave the strikers the $15 a month living allowance they had demanded, and assurance that there would be no punitive action against any of them.

The electric light and power industry's output in 1936 exceeded 100,000,000,000 kilowatt-hours for the first time in history and its revenue from ultimate consumers passed $2,000,000,000, according to the annual Statistical Bulletin of the Edison Electric Institute.
Only two of the eight players in the national amateur pocket billiard championship tournament remained unbeaten at the Capitol Health Center last night.

The sum of $14,800 has been collected in the sale of seats for the grand concert on Saturday evening, Feb. 20, at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of flood sufferers, it was announced yesterday at a meeting at the home of Mrs. Alma Gluck Zimbalist, 227 East Forty-ninth Street.
In a resolution introduced in the Senate today the Earle administration proposed a joint legislative investigation of the State's criminal courts and the Municipal Court of Philadelphia.

The interesting question of how a thoroughgoing Nazi should greet a foreign monarch to whose court he is accredited arose again today when Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German Ambassador, who decided for himself last week that it ought to be done in Nazi fashion, met King George at a levee.
Simple funeral rites for Elihu Root were conducted today in the chapel of Hamilton College, within a stone's throw of the place where he was born nearly ninety-two years ago.

Mayor La Guardia swore in Magistrate George B. De Luca as a justice of the Court of Special Sessions yesterday and in doing so revealed that he had made the judicial promotion on the recommendation of District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx.

F. W. Sutherland has been elected vice president of the Sutherland Paper Company in addition to secretary. Edward Starr Jr. has been elected a director of Sharp Dohme, Inc., to succeed Thomas Newhall, resigned. He is a member of the firm of Drexel Co.
Commodity futures showed a mixed trend in trading on local markets yesterday. Cocoa and rubber futures met with heavy selling and hides, wool tops, copper and cottonseed oil futures also declined.
Alaskans peeped out of their homes on Main Street today with their sixshooters cocked to see if any more cold-crazed coyotes were chasing deer through town.

As part of a comprehensive plan to control the expenditures of local units of government in New York State, a bill was introduced yesterday in the State Legislature providing for a top limit on direct and overlapping debt on property of 20 per cent of the full value.

" Das Rheingold," first offering of the special Wagner matinee cycle, was performed yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance as a whole was exceptionally coordinated and poetical in mood. It was given before an audience which filled the theatre to overflowing.
Blaming "foreign armed intervention" as the cause of the fall of Malaga, the republican government in a statement issued tonight says:
Two men, armed with revolvers, held up Jacob Feuerstein, one of the owners of the Keystone Button Company at 251 West Thirty-sixth Street, and escaped with a $700 payroll yesterday morning.

While the near months on the Cotton Exchange made little progress in either direction yesterday, the new crop deliveries advanced again, which left the list unchanged to 6 points higher than on Monday.
A capacity audience filled the Paramount Theatre tonight for the ninth annual Romany Chorus production, a concert at which John Charles Thomas, one of its founders and sponsors, was guest artist.

Stanley H. Rolfe, acting superintendent of schools here since the death of Dr. John H. Logan on Nov. 16, was appointed superintendent by unanimous vote of the city Board of Education at a special meeting today.

Professor Oscar James Campbell of Columbia University and Mrs. Campbell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Fuller Campbell, to George W. Meyer Jr. of Ann Arbor, Mich., son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Meyer of Edwardsville, Ill.

Current reports that efforts were being made by some manufacturers to suppress the survey of window display as an advertising medium now being made by Dr. Miller McClintock for the Advertising Research Foundation, were vigorously denied yesterday at the offices of the Association of National Advertisers.

Opposition to a proposal to give the Tenement House Commissioner the right to make repairs to oldlaw tenements and to levy assessments against the property for the costs was expressed yesterday by savings-bank representatives at a public hearing before Langdon W. Post, chairman of the Housing Authority.

The National Hockey League's most persistent jinx was overcome tonight when Jerry Shannon teamed with Earl Robinson twice to provide the Maroons with a 2-0 victory over the Bruins before 10,000 fans at the Boston Garden.

The directors of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and of the Crown Willamette Paper Company today voted to submit to special meetings of stockholders a plan of reorganization which, if adopted, would result in the merging of Crown Willamette into Crown Zellerbach.

Britain's Christmas Princess was christened today --Alexandra Helen Elizabeth Olga Christabel. The ceremony for the baby daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Kent was held in the private chapel of Buckingham Palace, with the Archbishop of Canterbury officiating.

The Roan Antelope Copper Mines, Ltd., has called for redemption on May 11 its outstanding [Pound]1,441,800 of 6 per cent debenture stock at 107 1/2 per cent, according to cabled advices received from the company yesterday by the Irving Trust Company here.

By sweeping majorities, both houses of the Texas Legislature, which is overwhelmingly Democratic, went on record today as opposed to President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Federal judiciary.

Public offering of $70,000,000 of Argentine Republic sinking fund external conversion loan 4 per cent bonds will be made today at 91 and accrued interest, to yield 4.514 per cent, by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

The consumption of cotton, wool, silk and rayon in this country last year amounted to 4,233,400,000 pounds, the largest for any year since the World War, according to figures compiled by the Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

A keynote of optimism pervades the twenty-seventh semi-annual convention of the American Retailers Association, which opened a two weeks' meeting here yesterday. Manufacturers and buyers cited brighter business prospects for the coming year.

Proposed partnership changes in New York Stock Exchange firms include William J. Hall to become tomorrow a partner in W. D. Gradison Co., Alice O. Kay to become a special partner in Kay, Byfield Co., and Robert B. Almy to become a partner in Townsend, Anthony Tyson on March 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Only by reading between the lines of the Executive's January message to Congress can one discover the existence of Mr. Roosevelt's sartling intention to subjugate the judiciary to Presidential dictatorship. Even here the intention lacked clearness.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial "Tampering With the Court," you cannot deny that what the President has asked of Congress is constitutional, and surely you are for constitutional methods!

Two points removed from a twogame deficit, Beekman Pool of the Harvard Club, the defending titleholder, rallied to defeat F. Morgan Palmer of the Princeton Club yesterday in the metropolitan squash racquets championship on the courts of the University Club.
Dying winds, bright weather and falling water relieved anxiety of Mississippi Valley dwellers above Memphis today and cheered downriver levee workers preparing for approaching flood crests.

The elimination of "pernicious practices" in installment selling, through the cooperation of community interests, was urged today by J. Anton Hagios, manager of the Credit Management Group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association before a district conference of members of the organization at the Mayflower Hotel.
Leopold Stokowski signed with Universal today to appear with his orchestra in the forthcoming Deanna Durbin picture, "120 Men and One Girl," production of which will begin March 15.

President Roosevelt said at a press conference today that he had talked by telephone five or six days ago with the two principals of the General Motors Corporation strike negotiations, W. S. Knudsen, executive vice president of the corporation, and John L. Lewis, president of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The first day's activity in the city-wide strike drive of the Building Service Employes International Union was confined largely to field surveys, with a few scattered strike sorties reported in the Bronx.

Preliminary tabulations of factory employment and wages for the December-January period showed a decrease of 0.2 per cent in workers and 0.9 per cent in payrolls in the State, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, announced today.

William F. Garner, president and principal promoter of Sunset Gold Fields, Inc., a New Mexico company, yesterday admitted to wide discrepancies between the facts and the registration statement which his company had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The course of events in the United States within the last few years seem extraordinarily strange. This view is based on the apparent contradiction of three fundamental principles which are still supposed to underlie the structure of the government of the United States.
Albert Ganzert's "Borderline," a play set in the Berlin of today, was presented by Maurice Schwartz and the Yiddish Art Theatre Company at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre last night.

Columbia's basketball team won its twelfth game of the season last night by defeating Seton Hall, 4332, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. After leading by only 21-16 at the intermission the Lions spurted in the second-period and sewed up the victory six minutes from the final gun.

Trading was generally only fair to slow in most classes. Steer hinds and ribs were held at strong prices and an odd sale was 50c higher. Veal and calf hindsaddles were lower, lamb strong to slightly higher, fresh pork cuts steady to weak. Early trading in Kosher meats indicated beef and lamb to be steady with Monday's close, veal and calf weak.

Francis C. Gillespie, executive assistant manager of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, died on Monday night of a heart attack in his suite in the hotel. He was 67 years old. Connected with the Hotel St. George since 1925, he was previously engaged in hotel management in Albany, his birthplace.

It has been said by Lord BRYCE and others that public opinion is the true ruler of this country. This is one of those sayings which, however sound in principle, public authorities find it difficult to apply in detail.
Lord Lurgan, chairman of the Carlton and Ritz Hotel Companies and prominent in many other financial enterprises, died at the age of 79.

Trust officers were urged, in the opening address yesterday at the Midwinter Trust Conference of the American Bankers Association, to draw up a code of ethics so that the public might know that they have one.

The nineteenth annual seniors' championship of the Belleair Country Club was played today over the wind-swept No. 1 course. Eighteen golfers between the ages of 55 and 80-odd years took part in the combination 18-hole medal championship proper, with a blind bogey match on the side.
Members of the United States Senate have been asked by THE NEW YORK TIMES to express their views on President Roosevelt's proposals for remaking the Supreme Court.

Lewis J. Valentine, Police Commissioner of New York City, presented aprogram of reform for this city's Police Department to Mayor Fonville and police officials today. The report, given verbally, was the climax of a survey made on invitation of Mayor Fonville.

A curtainraiser to the Mayoralty campaign in New York City this Autumn was staged by Democrats in the Senate and Assembly today, incidental to the passage of three bills to prepare the way for restoration of pay cuts to New York City employes.

Continuing his Watson Chair lectures at the University of London on the United States as a colonial power, Theodore Roosevelt tonight dealt with the policy in the Philippines, where he was Governor General under President Herbert Hoover.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The late Melvin A. Traylor, as president of the First National Bank and Trust Company, was described today in a unanimous decision of the Illinois Appellate Court as "negligent" and "positively reckless" in managing the estate of Leonard A. Busby, traction man who died Sept. 9, 1930.
Counsel for Mrs. Susan A. Wooster, former Bridgeport school teacher, presented today to the Bridgeport Board of Education a bill for three years' back pay at the rate of her former salary, $2,100.

Dr. Frank Smithies, physician and authority on intestinal ailments, died in the Augustana Hospital today after a brief illness. He was 56 years old. Dr. Smithies was stricken with a cerebral hemorrhage while asleep in his home on Sunday.

Sit-down strikers occupying the Kelvinator Corporation factory here ejected thirty-five men sent into the plant as "fire insurance inspectors," and then welded shut the door of the administration building to prevent executives and office employes from entering today.

The National Retail Furniture Association, numbering approximately 5,300 home furnishings stores in the United States, yesterday announced that it had moved to become member of the American Retail Federation, bringing total membership in that group to approximately 180,000 stores of various types.

President Roosevelt announced at his press conference that he would ask for legislation creating eight regional planning boards to recommend flood control, drought prevention, power projects and other public works; said he had talked on the telephone several days ago with William S. Knudsen and John L. Lewis on the automobile strike;

The Spanish Insurgents' swift advance into Malaga was like a vacation joy ride, so rapidly had the opposition melted away. In the villages leading up to Malaga the most characteristic sight was presented by the churches.
All tne arguments in favor of including the "facts of life" in the school curriculum are paraded in "Come Out to Play," by John Sand and Tanny Jocelyn, staged at the Arts Theatre tonight.

G. Harry Rothberg; Howard E. Dodson and Marlo M. Manred, in 60 W. 68th St.; Bing Bing, broker. Samuel Goldberg, in 190 W. Burnside Av.; A. Palumbo, in 2,115 Washington Av.; Alexander S. Brown, in 716 W. 180th St.; M. Wallmann, in 213 Bennett Av.; R. Guyer, in 565 W. 188th St.;

Displaying the smooth passing attack of the good old days when the Cooks and Boucher were in command, the New York Rangers triumphed over the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5-1, to night in a National Hockey League battle.
The Supreme Court heard clashing arguments today as to the validity of the Railway Labor Act, which guarantees collective bargaining to rail employes.
Overcoming a one-goal lead hung up by their rivals in the first period, the New York Americans came through to defeat the world champion Detroit Red Wing sextet at Madison Square Garden last night.

A. L. Libman, insurance specialist and former newspaper insurance editor, has been appointed agency supervisor at the home office here of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company. Mr. Libman is former. chairman of the speakers' bureau of the American Red Cross.

Time Limit Entirely apart from any question as to the merit of the proposal, any such drastic change should be passed only with the limitation that it take effect after the expiration of the term of office of the person proposing it.

Although Mark Reed's "Petticoat Fever" was good enough, his "Yes, My Darling Daughter" is better. It is a light, summery comedy about the old fogies and the young imps, and it was buoyantly acted at the Playhouse last evening by a cast that knows the difference between gags and humor.

New Jersey's hard-talking Legislature continues to amuse or exasperate, according to the taste and fancy of the observer. Listening to no voices but its own, it is deaf to the pleas of perplexed and hard-up municipalities to permit them to keep up the cuts in the pay of their employes and to allow a month or more for the adoption of budgets. Economy is a curse.

Colder weather stimulated the demand for hogs today. While prices were steady to 10 cents lower, the greater part of the decline was wiped out before the close, and main sales were about in line with the previous day.

Fearing a life term as a fourth offender, George Burke, 29 years old, wept in Felony Court yesterday at his arraignment for the theft of a "lucky" quarter and a set of prayer beads from Patrolman John J. Mahoney of the Old Slip Station in a subway train several hours before.
Great Britain has over a million more women than men. In the Dominions the men are more numerous.

An issue of $5,000,000 Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad 1 1/8 and 2 1/8 per cent trustees' certificates will be offered today by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., and Bosworth, Chanute, Loughridge Co.
To the Editor of The New York Times: According to reports from Washington the President has asked Congress for power to retire all Federal justices over the age of 70.
The Prudential Insurance Company sold to the 620 Pavonia Avenue Corporation of New York the five-story, forty-family brick apartment house at 620-624 Pavonia Avenue, Jersey City.

Mrs. Sallie McLean Sehon Wright, widow of Colonel Moses H. Wright of the Confederate Army and mother of Colonel Edmund S. Wright, U.S.A., retired, died Monday at the age of 98 in the apartment in the Hotel Astor where she had been living with her son, the only survivor of her immediate family.
The thirty-eight-acre estate of A. Perry Osborn on Valentine Lane, Old Brookville, L. I., known as Valley House, has been purchased by Darwin R. James Jr. of Brooklyn for his own occupancy.

The Republic Natural Gas Company reported yesterday for the first six months ended on Dec. 31 a net profit of $356,653 after depreciation, depletion and interest charges, but before allowance for Federal income taxes.

An intensification of trade between Chile and Italy is expected soon following numerous conferences here between Finance Minister Gustavo Ross and Giovanni Malagodi, a representative of the Banca Commerciale Italiana,

Sixty-eight small panes of glass in the windows of twelve apartments at 1,235 Grand Concourse, at 167th Street, the Bronx, were shattered at 4:15 P. M. yesterday by a shower of small stones and pieces of wire mesh blown up by a dynamiter in an adjoining excavation.

Charles F. Noyes Co., Inc., has obtained for the Norchard Building Corp. (Abraham Silvermann, attorney) a loan of $172,500, at 5 per cent interest, on the new apartment house at 1,085 Anderson Av., the Bronx.

Yachtsmen starting in the fourth annual Miami-Nassau ocean sailing race here at noon today will be honored at social events on arrival at Nassau, including formal parties at the Royal Nassau Sailing Club, the Nassau Yacht Club and at the British Colonial Hotel.
St. Peter's College registered its seventh victory of the basketball season at Collins Memorial Gymnasium in Jersey City last night by overwhelming Wagner College's quintet of Staten Island, 50-16.

Offering will be made today by an underwriting group headed by the Lee Higginson Corporation and the First Boston Corporation of an issue of $16,000,000 of Dallas Power and Light Company first-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1967. The bonds will be priced at 102 3/4.

The marriage of Miss Jane Schuyler Nelson to Arthur McKinne Stires of New York, son of the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, and Mrs. Stires of Garden City, will take place on Friday in Boston at the home of Miss Nelson's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Humphrey.
Hilaire Belloc, British novelist, critic and historian, arrived last night to lecture as a member of the faculty of the Fordham University Graduate School during the Spring semester.

F. Barry Ryan Jr. of Short Hills, seeded No. 1 in the tourney, carried off a second-round match against Norman F. Torrance of the Crescent A. C. in the Whitehall Club's invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday. Ryan defeated Torrance, president of the National Squash Tennis Association, by 15-9, 17--15.

The House voted today to extend for three years from next June 12 the power which Congress delegated for a like period in 1934 to President Roosevelt to negotiate reciprocal trade agreements with foreign nations. The vote was 284 to 100.

The Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company had gross earnings of $5,760,215 in 1936, against $5,303,163 in 1935, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting in Philadelphia. Net earnings after operating expenses and taxes were $2,518,151, against $2,307,122.

Charles H. Ant, 32 years old, an attorney, who ran for Alderman on the Republican ticket in the Twenty-third Brooklyn District in 1935, was killed at 2 P. M. yesterday in a fall in front of a Brooklyn subway train.

Presilent Roosevelt today signed the $949,000,000 Deficiency Appropriation Bill, containing the $790,000,000 needed by the Works Progress Administration to finance its program until June 30, and extraordinary activities involving the employment of 150,000 workers in the flood regions.

A banking group composed of the Central Republic Company, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; Glore, Forgan Co., Dominick Dominick, and Piper, Jaffray Hopwood will offer today a new issue of $6,000,000 of Holly Sugar Corporation first mortgage bonds, due $500,000 annually on April 1, 1938 to 1942, inclusive, and the balance of $3,500,000 on April 1, 1947.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The fallacy in much of the objection to Mr. Roosevelt's proposal about the Supreme Court is perfectly expressed in the letter of William H. Chorosh, who says that the court is "our strongest fortification against the onslaughts of communism or fascism."

Martin W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, entered the road's subscription yesterday for $500,000 of New York State World's Fair 4 per cent debentures, placing his company second only to the Consolidated Edison Company of New York in the amount of its investment in the fair.

New York's Legislature recessed today as a final tribute to "a very great American-Elihu Root." Both houses adopted a resolution last night, offered by Republican Assembly Leader Irving M. Ives, terming the death of the former United States Senator "an irreparable loss to the whole world."

Twenty-four Supreme Court justices have resigned from the high bench during its history. Their average at the time of resignation was 66 years, and they lived another nine years, on the average. Many of the justices who quit the bench did so not for reasons of approaching old age but to take other places, either on the bench or in politics.
Representatives of Germany's foreign creditors, to whom 1,000,000,000 marks ($400,000,000) in private debts are owed, opened new negotiations with German officials today.

Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich refused today to grant a temporary injunction to restrain Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Cockburn from occupying the $20,000 English style house which they recently purchased on Fort Hills Road in Greenburgh, Westchester County.
Robert A. Barnet, executive vice president and secretary of the Irving Savings Bank, was elected president yesterday, to succeed Hampden E. Tener, who was elected chairman and a trustee.

National and Kuomintang (Nationalist party) flags are flying everywhere here as Sian, the provincial capital, again under government control, prepares to celebrate on Thursday the Chinese New Year, now called the Spring Festival.

The executors of the estate of Edgar L. Marston, a member of the original partnership of Blair Co., investment bankers, have begun suit in Supreme Court against John B. Dennis, another former partner, for an accounting of the proceeds of the original partnership, it was disclosed yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Stunzi gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Cornelia Shepard, daughter of Mrs. Frederic White Shepard of Woodmere, L. I., and Dr. John L. Riker, whose engagement has been announced. Other guests were Dr.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whole pages are given to comment by prominent people expressing their views and interpretations of the President's recent recommendations concerning Federal judiciary, but we seem to lose sight of the fact that there are many millions of obscure citizens who are vitally affected by whatever form the judicial department of our government may assume.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today. 324--The Virginian Railway Company, petr., v. System Federation No. 40, Railway Employes Department of the American Federation of Labor, , et al. Argument continued for respondents:

In his Summer collection Lucien Lelong features riotous colors. Fine handwork and embroideries are also evident. For his sports suits he uses woolens, in vivid patterns, and jerseys; they are accompanied by crisp white blouses. Flannel sports dresses are combined with tweed jackets.

The Greenebaum Sons Investment Company today filed a voluntary petition in the Federal Court for reorganization under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. It has approximately 3,500 stockholders.

Future sale of the site of the Church of All Hallows, in the heart of London's banking quarter, was approved today by the judicial committee of the Privy Council. The present church, attributed to Sir Christopher Wren, famed British architect, is valued at $1,250,000, including the site.

In Madison Square Garden this morning the Westminster Kennel Club will open the greatest allbreed dog show in the three generations of its notable existence. There will be no blare of trumptes to announce the beginning of the sixty-first annual exhibition, which is to continue for three days.
Encouraged by the fact that the post of League of Nations Commissioner for the Free City has been allowed to remain vacant, Danzig's Nazi government is continuing its drive against the Opposition.

The police began last night a campaign of mass arrests to halt the "organization" by racketeers of the baggage porters' "concessions" at the piers along the North River. Warfare by rival gangs for control of non-union porter jobs at passenger docks already has resulted in the shooting of four men, the police said.

An ordinance that would extend the existing control of firearms to air rifles and air pistols was introduced in the Board of Aldermen yesterday by Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley, Bronx Democrat, and was referred to the Aldermanic Public Welfare Committee for study.

The General Welfare Committee of the Board of Aldermen reported out for favorable action yesterday an ordinance designed to limit the number of taxicabs in the city to those now licensed and to maintain, as far as possible, the existing ratio between taxicab fleets and cabs individually owned.

HAROLD E. STEARNS'S heart is in the right place. American-born and Harvard-bred, he went away to France for a dozen years and became the most expatriatic of expatriates. Then about five years ago, he saw the light and came home. He has been celebrating his return ever since.
Danno O'Mahoney, Irish heavyweight, who formerly held the world title, last night threw Abe Coleman, Californian, in the feature of the wrestling card at St. Nicholas Palace before about 2,000 fans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The far-seeing men who fashioned our Constitution and established our government 150 years ago provided a system of checks and balances which should insure the perpetuity of the government thus established.
Mrs. Berniece Rickard and John Alexander Logan 3d were married today in the parish home of the Rev. Lelan H. Koewing, of Trinity Presbyterian Church.
Two six-story apartment houses, at 3,871-79 Sedgwick Avenue and 2,900 Morris Park Avenue, were among the properties sold at auction in the Bronx yesterday. The list follows:

Today is the 100th anniversary of the death of Alexander Pushkin, the famous Russian poet. The American Pushkin Committee announced yesterday that observances would continue this week and next. At 8:30 P. M. today the American Russian Institute will sponsor a symposium on Pushkin at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

A dramatic wireless appeal failed to prevent a shooting last night at remote Festvaag, a Norwegian fishing hamlet near Bodoe. Listeners heard at 11 P. M. a broadcast: "Hello, a warning for all listeners in Festvaag. A human life is at stake.

Opening its punitive campaign here against violators of the Motor Carrier Act of 1935, the Interstate Commerce Commission filed in Federal Court yesterday a 200-count information, four inches thick and containing 605 pages, against the Howard Trucking Corporation and three of its officers, of 550 West Twenty-fifth Street.
Talk that a state of insurrection here might be declared by Governor Murphy if present peace conferences fail, was current in some quarters tonight.

Three more men were reported missing in the snow-covered mountains today as searchers expressed grave fears for two Denver skiers. No word has been heard from the three since they left Jefferson on Saturday to inspect the Guyot Mine on Georgia Pass, near that city.

Income of the Tokyo Electric Light Company, Ltd., for the six months to Nov. 30 last, after operating and general expenses, was reported here yesterday as 44,902,813 yen, covering interest requirements almost 3.6 times.

A vague smile played about the lips of Major Green at his trial in Queens County Court yesterday as he heard an admission on his behalf that he "struck and killed" Mrs. Harriet Case in her apartment- at 37-06 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, on Jan. 11.

Name Change The name of Ununiformed Fireman Louis Esposito, Engine 154, is hereby changed to read: Louis Hanes. Resignation The resignation of Fireman First Grade Walker A. Redmond, H. L. 24, is accepted.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Article 3 Section 1 of the Constitution of the United States should be amended by adding after the words, "The Judicial Power of the United States shall be vested in one Supreme Court," words stating the number of justices who shall compose that court.

The Horace Mann School for Boys gained undisputed possession of second place in the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League as the result of a 32-28 triumph over Poly Prep on the former's court yesterday.

The Lehman social security program is due for passage in the Assembly tomorrow, and if the Senate concurs in minor amendments the measure, defeated three times last year, may be in the hands of Governor Lehman by nightfall.
The world's wheat markets developed a much easier undertone today as it became apparent that importing countries were not disposed to take large quantities of cash grain on bulges.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Roosevelt's brilliant message today anent the Supreme and lesser courts deserves careful and sincere study. The President follows duties laid down by the Constitution with reference to advising the Congress.

Three justices in Queens Special Sessions Court sentenced Walter Hitchcock, 36 years old, of 130-29 Van Wyck Boulevard, South Ozone Park, Queens, to four months in the workhouse yesterday for "relief chiseling."

Best Co. had a net profit of $1,281,458 for the year ended on Jan. 31, last, after depreciation, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings, according to the preliminary statement given out yesterday by Philip LeBoutillier, president and general manager.

The first move toward a compromise on the controversial part of President Roosevelt's judiciary reform program will be made tomorrow when House leaders attempt to shove through a voluntary retirement bill, under which Supreme Court justices with ten years of service might retire at the age of 70 with full and protected pay.

The general death rate for the city, continuing its decline, dropped to 10.9 for the week ended last Saturday, compared with 11.8 for the preceding week and 15.2 for the week ended Jan. 9, the peak of the influenza outbreak, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, said yesterday.

Total insurance in force of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston was $3,815,663,270 on Dec. 31, the highest on record for the company and a gain of $222,514,748 from 1935. Of the increase, $121,410,704 was in ordinary and group insurance. The weekly premium coverage was $101,104,044.

Completion of liquidation of twenty bank receiverships in January was announced today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency. This makes 571 receiverships closed since the bank holiday of March, 1938.

Charles C. Chappelle, for several years consulting engineer for the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company, died at his home at 10 Park Avenue yesterday after six months of illness. He was in his sixtysixth year.
Apartment properties and building sites continued to occupy attention in the Bronx real estate market yesterday.

William S. Twining, engineer, who supervised the construction of the Market Street subway-elevated and the Frankford elevated lines in this city and served as Philadelphia's first director of transit, died in Fort Myers, Fla., yesterday after a short illness. He was 71 years old.

There would probably be little controversy over President Roosevelt's proposals to reform the Federal judiciary if they did no more than remedy a number of "glaring defects" in the present system, says The Times of London this morning in an editorial which asserts that the "present state of uncertainty and delay is indeed almost incredible."
Thought Needed Much appreciation for your editorial "Tampering With the Court." The arguments you advance seem to me to be unanswerable.

After showing a decline in the three previous weeks, business failures in the retail group increased in the week ended Feb. 4, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total for the latest week was 101, against 90 in the previous week. The detailed report is as follows:

Governor Blanton Winship recommended immediate consideration of sterilization as a dependable means of improving the human race in an address today at the first regular session of the Fourteenth Puerto Rican Legislature.
Public utilities companies in Connecticut will spend more than $22,000,000 for plant and equipment improvement this year, compared with approximately $10,000,000 in 1936, according to estimates.
Pope Pius XI, hoping to regain use of his legs soon, made plans tonight to participate in Holy Week services of the Lenten season, which begins tomorrow.

The City Athletic Club combination, which clinched the title two weeks ago, concluded its campaign undefeated in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association Group II race by subduing the New York A. C., 5 to 0, on the Winged Foot courts yesterday. The victors finished with ten triumphs.

When all means of communication were silenced on the M-K-T railroad lines recently because of sleet and snow, Bill Bonnell, Fort Worth, Texas, amateur radio operator and American Airlines pilot, stepped in as a special "dispatcher" to broadcast from his radio station important train orders that helped keep freight and passenger trains operating nearly on schedules, says The M-K-T Magazine.

The German press, led by the Foreign Office's semi-official organ Diplomatische Korrespondenz, is indulging in unlimited jubilation over the fall of Malaga to the Spanish Rebels. Columns are filled with praise of the Rebels and mockery of the defeated Loyalist troops.

However hard-pressed it may be, the Jewish population of Poland is by no means resigned to the fate intended for it either by the violent anti-Semitism of the nationalists or by what it designates the "civilized anti-Semitism" of the Polish Government.

Mild weather and lack of snow have made this Winter a kind one for wildlife to date. There-has been little need for feeding activity on the part of sportsmen's clubs, the New York Conservation Department reports after a survey.

Paced by Joe Schief, who scored 15 points, Brooklyn Prep School captured the third annual metropolitan Jesuit basketball tournament sponsored by St. Peter's College at Collins Memorial Gymnaseum in Jersey City last night by crushing St. Peter's Prep, two-year defending champion, 24 to 12, in the final.

Nine army bombing planes arrived here late today after a non-stop flight from Panama. The wing and landing gear of a ship piloted by Lieutenant Eugene P. Mussett was damaged when it nosed over upon landing, but no one was injured. The pilot swung the plane from the runway to avoid striking spectators and parked automobiles.
Mrs. Osa Johnson, in a hospital with a leg broken in the plane crash fatal to her husband, Martin Johnson, said today she was planning a camera invasion of the Belgian Congo alone.

Chinatown will open its celebration of the Chinese New Year this afternoon. Families will hold reunions, dinners of ten to twenty-five courses will be eaten, old debts will be paid, and at midnight the year 4641 will be greeted with two parades through the narrow streets.

Two of the principal public-utility holding companies in the United States, the North American Company and the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., withdrew yesterday their suits to restrain the Securities and Exchange Commission from enforcing the Public Utility Act of 1935, and announced they would register under the statute.
Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, today had his first opportunity to tell the House of Commons that his recent talks in Washington were not conclusive but were worth while.

Dealers in house furnishings and furniture, home decoration and allied lines figured in many of the commercial leases reported by brokers yesterday. Several leases of large space to retail clothiers also were announced. The list follows:

Dr. Niels Bohr of Copenhagen, 1923 Nobel prize winner, talked in Convocation Hall on "Light and Life." Several hundred persons sat for two hours with knit brows, but today not a listener could be found who had understood a word.

Bobby Pacho, 147 1/4, of Los Angeles, overcame the greater height and reach of Bobby Wilson, 146 3/4, of Washington, to pound out a decision in the main ten-round boxing bout at the Broadway Arena last night. A crowd of 3,500 persons saw the program.

Almost 100 press agents in the stage, screen and radio fields, who now compose a unit of the American Advertising Guild and who may seek affiliation with the American Federation of Labor, discussed their problems last night at the offices of the Inter-Professional Association, 155 East Thirty-fourth Street.

General Francisco Franco's Insurgent troops announced tonight that they had severed Madrid's last important highway communication line, the road to Valencia, in a bloody conflict with Leftist forces today.
D. Spencer Berger's 71-foot Mandoo II sailed past Great Isaacs Light at 6:14 P. M., Eastern standard time, today in the lead of the Miami-Nassau Yacht Race.

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons today announced the appointment of Frank Keith Officer, Australian External Affairs representative in London, as Australian counselor at the British Embassy in Washington for a term of three and a half years.

A fight to the finish was in prospect in Westchester County today for control of the vote of certificate holders of $35,000,000 of mortgages for the election of trustees to succeed State Senator Pliny W. Williamson, Orie R. Kelly, New York banker, and Anthony J. Kerin of New Rochelle, who resigned. The three trustees, however, will not relinquish their offices until successors are elected by the certificate holders.

" Complete anarchy and disorder" reign in Barcelona and throughout Catalonia, according to a report made today to the Radical Socialist group in the Chamber of Deputies by four of their members who have just returned from a visit there.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just finished reading Arthur Krock's article on the judiciary reform measure in today's TIMES. It seems to me the only sane comment I have read.
F. B. Farik, Arctic flier, left Moscow today for a 20,000-mile flight to test his plane in severe weather and to take mail to northern colonists.

The merger of News Week, a weekly news magazine, and Today, a magazine of opinion and comment, was announced yesterday by Vincent Astor, who will be president of the combined publication, the first issue of which will appear soon.

An exhibition called "New York Realists" (1900-1914) opened yesterday afternoon at the Whitney Museum of American Art, to continue until March 5 The artists represented are Robert Henri, George Luks, John Sloan, William Glackens, Ernest Lawson, George Bellows, Everett Shinn, Glenn O. Coleman and Guy Pene duBois.

Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,220,750 barrels daily, a new high record, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represented a gain of 26,700 barrels over the average of 3,194,050 in the previous week.
