Facts regarding ownership of the Celotex Corporation were revealed yesterday through registration statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which were made public by the New York Stock Exchange.

Benno Rabinoff, a violinist of exceptional attributes, including a fluent and even spectacular technique, and a tone prevailingly warm and brilliant, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Rabinoff played Castelnuovo-Tedesco's "The Lark," Mozart's A major concerto;
Stocks closed irregular in less active trading; turnover, 2,592,970 shares. All classes of bonds fluctuated narrowly in slowest trading of year; transactions, $10,869,800.

In a battle of terrier giants, George S. West's imported Airedale dog, Flornell Straightaway, yesterday won the title of best in his breed at the twentieth annual exhibition of the Associated Terrier Clubs given in Commerce Hall of the Port of New York Authority Building.
This is the night they unfurl that old Cohan Harris banner at the Morosco, and from there Mr. Cohan will go on to act out his "way of telling the story of Parker Fennelly's 'Fulton of Oak Falls.'"
Russia began tonight nation-wide observance of the 100th anniversary of the death of her famed poet, Alexander Pushkin, who was killed in a duel.

Lou Ambers, the second ring champion to perform in the Hippodrome since Promoter Mike Jacobs converted the historic building into a fight arena, will seek to dissipate the championship aspirations of Davey Day of Chicago tonight.

De Witt Clinton's stellar quintet strengthened its hold on the leadership in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tourney by overwhelming Morris, 48 to 16, on the victors' court yesterday.

Three large shoe manufacturers today announced increases in wholesale prices ranging from 2 1/2 to 25 cents a pair. The International Shoe Company and the Brown Shoe Company price advances were from 5 to 25 cents a pair.
A radio comedian, John Rorke, set London agog tonight when he shouted into the microphone, "Mrs. Simpson!" as three men were singing a couplet:
Realty transactions reported in Manhattan yesterday involved several properties in Greenwich Village, apartment houses on the upper West Side and a group of dwellings in East Twenty-second Street.

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at 13.30 cents a pound c. i. f. the European base ports, a new high price for the movement. Closing quotations on the London Metal Exchange were the equivalent of 13.40 cents.
President Roosevelt asked detailed explanations today of the navy's inability to obtain sufficient supplies of steel.
The Hudson County Board of Freeholders, after a public hearing in the court house here today, adopted the 1937 budget, which was introduced two weeks ago.

An agreement was filed in the Registry of Deeds today for the sale before March 1 of Ashintully, the 800-acre Tyringham estate of Mrs. Lawrence Coolidge of Boston, to Real Properties, Inc., of Newton, Mass. She gets in exchange residential property at Cambridge.

By means of a newly evolved mathematical formula it is now possible to estimate each individual's requirements of the vitamins in a way which permits the planning of human nutrition with greater efficiency than ever before, Dr. George R. Cowgill, Associate Professor of Physiological Chemistry at Yale, reported last night.

Edward Valentine Shepard, one of the leading authorities on bridge during the days of "auction," died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 126 East Thirty-fourth Street. The only member of his immediate family surviving is a brother, C. W. Shepard of Salem, Mass.
Business ir the stock market here fell off today and enthusiasm was dampened by renewed weakness in gilt-edge issues. Movements in foreign bonds were small, although German securiwere better.
Fred Cooper, 36-year-old former convict who was wanted in New York as a parole violator, may attribute his arrest in Brooklyn late Monday night to curiosity.

Johnny Bonito, the Washington Heights lightweight, won a close decision from Charley Diaz of the West Side in the feature eightround bout at the New York Coliseum last night. The verdict met with the disapproval of many in the crowd of 9,000 who watched the contest.
Leon Trotsky's own exposition of the last ten years of Bolshevism will be published by Doubleday, Doran late next month. The title is "The Revolution Betrayed." Max Eastman translated the book.

Net earnings of the LibbeyOwens-Ford Glass Company for 1936 were announced yesterday as the largest for any year in the company's history. They amounted to $10,379,538 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, surtax on undistributed income and other charges, John D. Biggers, president, said.

Another conference in the effort to settle the General Motors strike ended ten minutes after midnight this morning with an announcement by Governor Frank Murphy that it would be resumed at 10 A. M. today.
Mrs. Carolyne Hyde Woodin was married to Melville Hanna Haskell of Tucson, Ariz., at noon today in the home of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Ard of Plainfield, N. J., at their Mountain Lake estate near here.

Alderman Joseph F. Mafera of the Fifty-ninth Aldermanic District in Queens said yesterday he would resign next Monday. Mr. Mafera, a member of the Democratic Executive Committee of Queens in the Sixth Assembly District, said he was giving up the position of Alderman to remain free to carry out his work as zone leader on the committee.

Miss Doris Havemeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Havemeyer of 960 Fifth Avenue and Olympic Point, Islip, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Daniel Catlin in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Current Events," Ida Wright Bowman. Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eighty-second Street and Fifth Avenue. "The Collection of Paintings," General Tour, 11 A. M.; "Introduction to the Language of Painting," Roberta M. Fansler, 4 P. M.;

Half a million celebrants tramped the streets from dawn to dusk today when New Orleans cast aside everyday cares to observe the century-old Mardi Gras. Parades and individual celebrations were the order of the day as thousands of masked, costumed celebrants took over the city.

Formation of a specialized unit in the Army Air Corps, to be called the Tenth Ordnance Service Company, was announced today by Major Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commander. It will be commanded by Lieut. Col. Russell L. Maxwell, ordnance officer of the G. H. Q. Air Force.

President Roosevelt took up today with men who fly the planes the question of what is needed to make flying safer. He received in a brief visit at noon five pilots from the country's major air lines, who were accompanied by Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, and Eugene Vidal, Director of the Bureau of Air Commerce.
A throng of Catholics, estimated to number from 5,000 to 15,000, seized and reopened long closed churches at Orizaba, Vera Cruz, late today, according to telephoned reports from that city.

The Mardi Gras Ball which took place here tonight in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel reflected the pageantry of the traditional New Orleans Shrove Tuesday festival. The guest list was limited to 200 persons, all of whom were requested to attend in costume.

A permanent farm relief policy, built around Secretary Wallace's evernormal" granary plan, designed to assure stabilized agricultural prices and production, was unanimously endorsed by national farm leaders today in resolutions calling for use of the Federal taxing power and the licensing of handlers of farm products, if necessary, to prevent a recurrence of price-depressing surpluses.

Johnny Bonito, the Washington Heights lightweight, won a close decision from Charley Diaz of the West Side in the feature eightround bout at the New York Coliseum last night. The verdict met with the disapproval of many in the crowd of 9,000 who watched the contest.
Leon Trotsky's own exposition of the last ten years of Bolshevism will be published by Doubleday, Doran late next month. The title is "The Revolution Betrayed." Max Eastman translated the book.

Net earnings of the LibbeyOwens-Ford Glass Company for 1936 were announced yesterday as the largest for any year in the company's history. They amounted to $10,379,538 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, surtax on undistributed income and other charges, John D. Biggers, president, said.

Another conference in the effort to settle the General Motors strike ended ten minutes after midnight this morning with an announcement by Governor Frank Murphy that it would be resumed at 10 A. M. today.
Mrs. Ellen Radbury Brittingham, who was active in club and church circles here, died yesterday of a heart attack while visiting relatives in Newport News, Va., according to word received here.

New York City will appropriate $250,000 for the American Red Cross for relief of flood sufferers, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. He received word from Reuben A. Lazarus, Assistant Corporation Counsel, who represents the city at Albany, that Governor Lehman had signed the bill permitting the city to make the contribution.

The day in stocks was one of irregularity. Although trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was somewhat less than on Monday2,592,000 shares, against 2,987,000many low-priced issues were active, although these did no better than close irregular.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 8: BRIGADIER GENERAL Abernethy, R. S., two months leave, May 15. COLONELS Bunker, P. D., C. A. C., Philippines, to Organized Reserves, Los Angleles, Calif. Rutherford, H. H., Med. Corps, Ft. Myer, Va., to retirement.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Baker of 555 Park Avenue will give a dinner on Friday in the ballroom suite of the Pierre in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the marriage of Mrs. Baker's brotherin-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Newberry.

Edwin Markham, the poet, who is best known for his work "The Man With the Hoe," was declared incompetent yesterday by a jury before Supreme Court Justice George E. Brower in Brooklyn. Mr. Markham is 85 years old.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why is it that every now and anon some male performer feels called upon to bring to the attention of humanity how well he, or some other man, can do a song or dance to the detriment of all women engaged in the same pursuit?
The sensational Seabiscuit added further luster today to the record he has built up since becoming attached to the racing stable of Mrs. Charles S. Howard of San Francisco.

Officers of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., announced shortly before 1 P. M. yesterday that "it is no longer deemed advisable to issue additional common stock, as contemplated, and the company has therefore discontinued negotiations for the underwriting of such stock."

An undertone of criticism of Washington's management of its side of the six-party gold accord marked talks here among the big European central bankers who have now all gone home after their monthly meeting as members of the board of the 8 Bank for International Settlements.
United States foreign trade gained in all geographical grand divisions in 1936, compared to 1935, the Department of Commerce disclosed today.

Dr. George J. Ryan, former president of the New York City Board of Education, was nominated by the Democrats in the Legislature today to fill the vacancy on the Board of Regents left by the death of Robert W. Higbie.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The President's latest action in proposing drastic reorganization of the Federal judiciary system, and the Supreme Court in particular, dispels all doubt as to the trend of his second term.

Estimating the year's volume at $5,600,000,000, the Engineering News-Record asserted yesterday, according to The Associated Press, that construction activity in 1986 "exceeded all advance predictions by a substantial margin."

129th St., n s, 176.8 ft w of Madison Av., 16.8x99.11; Mary C. Brady to John C. Brady, 17 E. 129th St., three-fourths interest ($7.50). 119th St., 354-362 W., s s. 125x100.11: J. H. C. Realty Corp., Henrietta Siegel. president, to Isidore Sturmak, 1,932 Loring Pl. ($1).

Preparations for transatlantic air service are so far advanced that the flying boat Caledonia, one of the type designed for ocean crossings, flew six hours today over the West Coast of Great Britain, across the Irish Sea and over Ireland to practice working with the new radio station in the Shannon estuary.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The political philosophy of our nation is democracy-government by the people through representation. But who represents the people, the Supreme Court or Congress? Despite invalidation of past New Deal laws, the people still think that Congress represents them and not nine men-if the last election means anything.

The seventeenth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York will be held this year at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club on Friday, June 4, it was announced yesterday by Percy M. Stewart of Kuhn, Loeb Co., chairman of the field day committee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Modern complexities" are, in the main, the effects of scientific research and invention operating through industrial processes on the economic texture of society.

Snark, the son of Boojum, was a speeding ghost at Hialeah today when he ran six and one-half furlongs in such time that the world's record he set probably will stand for years. The new mark, made in the Kendall Purse, is 1:15 4-5 and reduced by two-fifths of a second Gallant Knight's figure made at Churchill Downs in 1931.

The manoeuvres of Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador to London, and the success of the Italo-German interventionists at Malaga, Spain, have strengthened the conviction of the Soviet Union that it must depend on its own efforts to resist German and Japanese aggression, which is believed here to be inevitable and not far distant.

Herbert J. Adair of Washington, Philadelphia, New York, Massachusetts and "other addresses," was a witness today at the Securities and Exchange Commission hearing of charges that W. E. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange and many other Exchanges, had "rigged" the market in Atlas Tack Corporation stock in 1934 and 1935.

Transit unification by linking the city's Independent System with strategic lines to be recaptured from the B. M. T. and Interborough at an estimated cost of about $151,000,000 was advocated yesterday by Ezra E. Williamson, traffic and transportation expert, representing the Association of Long Island Commuters.

Holding their rivals to 4 field goals, the St. Francis Prep basketball forces trounced Cathedral Prep, 34 to 15, in a Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. contest on the latter's court yesterday. The triumph was the third in seven tournament games for the invaders, who were in the van by 14--8 at the half.

The "Twenty to Forty Style Revue" was held yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin during the luncheon hour. There were springtime decorations. A percentage of the luncheon receipts was given to the New York Chapter of hte Red Cross for the relief of the flood victims.

The marriage of Miss Grace Noble Green, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newman Law Green of this city and Gadsden, Ala., to Frederick Boyce Bryant, son of Judge and Mrs. Frederick Howard Bryant of Malone, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
The Squash Club's Class B squash racquets team earned the right to play for metropolitan district team honors by defeating the Westchester squad, the Bronxville Field Club, 4 to 1, last night.

I am in no way "psychic." Dealing as I have done with large, superficial areas of incident and occasion, one is bound to make a few lucky hits or happy deductions. But there is no need to drag in the "clairvoyance," or the rest of the modern jargon.

At the end of a week's conferences in Detroit, kept alive by the determination of Governor MURPHY to find some basis for a settlement of the automobile strike, the position of the two parties to the controversy, as it stood last night at midnight, may be summarized as follows:

The New Jersey Court of Pardons commuted today prison sentences of two to three years and fines of $1,000 imposed on William P. Walter and William J. Marren, former chief and sergeant, respectively, of the Trenton Police Department.

Novel designs worked out in fabrics ranging in color from the conventional to the unique, for day and evening wear for men, were shown here today at the opening of the fifty-seventh annual convention of the Merchant Tailor Designers' As sociatioin.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan, who recently criticized the city administration for delays in answering suits for reduction of tax assessments, set in motion yesterday legal machinery for clearing up the clogged court calendar of such suits.

The city-owned Tavern on the Green in Central Park was a $1,000 victim of the restaurant racket, a Supreme Court jury was told yesterday by Edward Levine, who operates it on concession, and who paid, he said, in an unsuccessful effort to keep the place from being unionized.

Dense fog that settled over the entrance of the New York harbor Monday afternoon and extended along the New Jersey coast as far as the Delaware River lasted until 1 P. M. yesterday and did not finally clear away until four hours later, when visibility at Sandy Hook was two miles. No accidents were reported.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson, after a public hearing today, left in the hands of a- special board of censors the decision whether the play, "Mulatto," which he banned from Philadelphia yesterday, would be permitted to open later this week.
Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, former British Consul General in New York, will sail today for England on the steamship Washington of the United States Lines, accompanied by Lady Armstrong.
Long Island University's basketball team returned to winning form last night with a 61-24 triumph over Youngstown College of Ohio at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

Chicago's prospective "million dollar gate" for a world heavyweight championship fight between Joe Louis and James J. Braddock, tentatively set for Soldier Field next June 15, struck an unexpected snag today.

Robert Daru, former Deputy Assistant District Attorney, defeated Reuben B. Shemitz for president of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association at the annual election in the Criminal Court Building yesterday. The vote was 41 to 29. Bernard Reiss, retiring president, presided.

Six American engineers will be honored, two of them receiving gold medals, during the 147th general meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers next Wednesday, it was announced yesterday. The awards will be presented at the annual dinner of the institute in the evening at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The elimination of Frank Strafaci of Brooklyn, N. Y., the 1935 national public links champion, and one of the comedalists marked the first round of match play in the annual Dixie golf championship at the Miami Country Club today. Tony Kozen of Bridgeport, Conn.,

Committees of hosts and hostesses have been organized for the "John and Priscilla Party" to be given by officers and members of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York tomorrow afternoon at Mayflower House, 120 East Seventy-first Street.

Mrs. Edna N. Greer James of this city, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Greer of Glendale, Calif., and the late Mr. Greer, was married to Harvey B. Newins of New York yesterday morning at the Roger Smith Hotel in Stamford, Conn., it was announced here.

S. Klein, Union Square clothing merchant, was asked to pay $50,000 for the removal of a picket line in front of an eating place in one of his store buildings, the Supreme Court jury hearing the restaurant racket trial was told yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday reduced the price of gasoline to dealers in Northeast New Jersey one-half cent a gallon. In Newark, the new price to dealers who sell Standard of New Jersey products exclusively is 8 cents a gallon, not including tax.

State laws are of equal importance to retailers as Federal legislation, the American Retail Federation pointed out here today in announcing publication-of a review of legislation in the States during l936.

The Blair Academy wrestlers trounced the Columbia University freshmen, 31 to 3, in the latter's gymnasium yesterday. Al Minervini registered the lone triumph for the Lion cubs, scoring over Heard in the 145-pound class.

President Roosevelt's judiciary reform program was put to the fore today in the Legislature and it was predicted that within a short time the issue would become one of sharp dispute on partisan lines in the Senate and Assembly.

ANDREWS, ALFRED CARPENTER (Jan. 20). Estate, less than $10,000. To Celeste A. Seton, daughter, 875 Park Av., two etchings and two scarf pins; Alfred C. Andrews, 310 E. 44th St., two etchings and residue of jewelry; Addle Clark Andrews, widow, executrix, 1,040 Park Av., residue.

Bishop William T. Manning, head of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared in his annual Ash Wednesday sermon, delivered at noon yesterday in Trinity Church, on lower Broadway, that "the nation faces a grave crisis" as a result of President Roosevelt's recent proposals dealing with the United States Supreme Court.

General Motors cars and trucks sold to dealers in the overseas markets last month numbered 26,990, an increase of 5.5 per cent from January, 1936. For the twelve months through January overseas sales aggregated 326,166 units, an increase of 12.2 per cent over the 290,696 cars and trucks sold in the preceding twelve months.

Counsel representing respondents in the Securities and Exchange Commission's action against promoters of the Sunset Gold Fields, Inc., for inclusion of alleged false information in a registration statement, indicated yesterday that they would consent today to issuance of a stop order prohibiting further sale of the company's stock to the public.

An open hearing on a proposal that the city lend money to tenement owners to finance the cost of removing fire hazards and installing toilet facilities was held yesterday by Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, with representatives of property owners and tenement residents in attendance.

Incredible as it may sound, the Giants, it was learned last night, actually have a holdout on their hands despite the fact that they have only three more regulars to bring into line. But one of this trio is likely to prove quite stubborn about it, for the recalcitrant signer again is Hank Leiber,
Bishop Edwin Dubose Mouzon of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, one of the most distinguished churchmen in America, died of a heart attack late this afternoon at his home here. His age was 68.

If current efforts to -stabilize prices succeed to the point where retailers can make a reasonable profit on national brands, stores will cease to push private labels, James J. Clark, .assistant to. the president of the Liggett Drug Com pany, yesterday told members of the New York chapter of the American Marketing. Society at a luncheon meeting at the Advertising Club of New York.

The signing ceremony which will bind James J. Braddock and Joe Louis to contracts for a heavyweight championship fight in Chicago next June will be held a week from tomorrow or the day after, Joe Triner, chairman of the Illinois State Athletic Commission, announced today.

The refusal of seamen to accept the continuous-discharge books which were made compulsory to American crews under the Copeland Safety-at-Sea Act resulted yesterday in the tie-up of the American Hawaiian Line freighter Columbian at her Brooklyn pier.
Postal officials chuckled today when advised that the South Carolina House of Representatives had protested against sale of stamps bearing likenesses of General William Tecumseh Sherman.
Ann Harding's eagerly awaited London debut in Shaw's "Candida," which opened at the Globe Theatre tonight, was praised for its dignity, authority and charm. The Times of London critic says:

State police said tonight that a man held here in connection with the kidnapping of Charles Mattson was arrested at a hotel, where he registered as "Tim Donovan," the same first name used in the crudely printed $28,000 ransom note left at the Mattson home by the kidnapper on Dec. 27.

Repeal of its rule exempting issuers of foreign securities from the necessity of filing annual reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission was announced today by that agency as new forms were issued on which information pertaining to such registered securities was to be supplied. The first report must be made by Sept. 30.

William Koch, active in political and real estate circles in Brooklyn and, with his four brothers, a founder of two amusement parks in that borough which were popular a generation ago, died on Monday at his home, 675 Sixty-sixth Street, at the age of 79.

Looking forward to a general up turn in business and better profits this year, the Textile Converters Association of America, Inc;, has launched a definite program to improve conditions in the industry and eliminate unfair trade practices, it was announced yesterday. Louis Lazare, president;
Twenty-one-year-old Arthur Cadogan of Muscatine, Iowa, is an authority today on how to travel around the world without spending a cent.

Kent School continued its winning streak today, defeating the Army plebes at hockey, 4 to 2. Eaton, Kent spare, opened the scoring in the first period with a solo dash. Rees added the second marker for the prep school boys in the same period and Brothwell counted in the second.

Another national amateur pocket billiard record fell by the wayside yesterday at the Capitol Health Center and once again it was the 21-year-old defending champion from Philadelphia, Lewis Brooks, who turned the trick. Having eclipsed the high-run mark earlier in the tournament with a string of 70, Brooks accounted for his third straight victory with a 125-to-11 rout of Ted Snyder, Brooklyn entrant, in fifteen innings.
After a slow and loosely played first half, which ended 17-9 in favor of Navy, the Middies hit their stride early in the second period to rout the William and Mary five, 42-21, today.

Paul Whiteman, orchestra leader, has "exploited me and practically sold me down the river as if I were a slave or some inanimate chattel," Ramona Davies, pianist and singer known as "Ramona," declared yesterday in Supreme Court in a petition submitted in an injunction suit.
The Governors of States that have not ratified the Child Labor Amendment were asked yesterday by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America to exert their influence for ratification.

Larger supplies of hogs depressed the market 5 to 10 cents, but there was a good demand on the recession despite the start of the Lenten season and its customary reduction in consumption of pork products.

Papenie, a 13-to-1 shot, overhauled Mr. Blaze to win the feature six furlong race for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita today. Lakeview was third and Gerald, the even money favorite, finished fifth in the sixhorse field.

Fordham's basketball team upset favored Canisius, 32-24, at the..Maroon gymnasium in the Bronx last night. It was the sixth victory in' a row for the Rams and the second defeat in nine games for their rivals, who had previously been beaten only by mighty Stanford and then only after a hard-fought encounter.

ABOUT a week ago M'sieu Lestairre Patrick said that the Detroit Red Wings probably were the best-balanced team on the hockey circuit. Since that time the Red Wings came to town and were tossed for a slight loss by the star-spangled Americans after going nine consecutive games without a defeat.

Solomon R. Guggenheim of New York, here in connection with a private view of his collection of "non-objective art" at the Art Alliance, said today that he was going to present the collection to the public "because I love it so much I want the public to get the benefit of it."

An extremely brilliant concert in aid of its. pension fund was given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, with Jascha Heifetz as assisting artist, last night in Carnegie Hall. This concert was not only for the benefit of the pension fund of the orchestra; it was also for the benefit of one Felix Mendelssohn and a great audience, numbers of which may have forgotten the aristocratic distinction and freshness of his art.

Count Francisco Matarazzo, said to be Brazil's richest man, died' this afternoon after a short illness. He was 86 years old. Count Matarazzo's life was colorful. Sixty years ago he landed in Rio de Janeiro as an immigrant from Italy.

Herbert B. Gill, hockey and tennis coach at Dartmouth since 1933, suddenly tendered his resignation tonight. It was accepted by the athletic council and will take effect at the close of the college year in June.

The New York Hippodrome Opera Company, under the direction of Alfredo Salmaggi, will present a series of three opera performances on Monday and Tuesday, Feb. 22 and 23, at the Hippodrome, it was announced yesterday.

By reporting gross earnings, net income, dividend' disbursements and production in 1936 at the highest levels in its history, and, of course, substantially ahead of 1935 totals, the Chrysler Corporation provided abundant evidence yesterday that prosperity has returned to the automobile industry.

A group of young women prominent in society, among whom will be debutantes of this and recent seasons, will sell flowers and programs at the performance at midnight tonight in the Radio City Music Hall for the benefit of the flood relief campaign of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

The Treasury has established a unique restaurant-where the talk is of billions and the food runs to less than 50 cents a plate. The sole patrons of this restaurant are Secretary Morgenthau's advisers, including Archie Lochhead, director of the stabilization fund; George C. Haas,

The Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., today offered cash awards totaling $500 for the best three articles relating to problems of investment banking and the securities business. Articles may be submitted on any of the following subjects:

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Halstead of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Margaret Halstead, to Anthony Mason, also of New York, which took place on Saturday in St. Matthew's Church, Bedford Hills, N. Y.

A plan to provide modern housing at $6 a room monthly for families with incomes of less than $1,200 a year was presented by Nathan Straus, member of the New York City Housing Authority, at a meeting in the City Club yesterday under the sponsorship of the club's committee on city plan.

After approving a $3,280,000 contract for dredging and bulkheading for the projected ship-to-rail terminal here today the City Commission heard a representative of the Pennsylvania Railroad oppose an operating agreement with Central Districts, Inc., on the ground it discriminated in favor of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.

Registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of $4,000,000 of bonds and preferred stock and additional common shares and scrip was asked in a statement filed with the agency today by the Pittsburgh Coke and Iron Company as a part of a plan for refunding more than $5,000,000 of bonds and debentures.

Selected American Shares, Inc., reported yesterday that its income in 1936 was $340,826 after management fees, running expenses and capital stock, stamp and franchise taxes but exclusive of gains and losses on securities.
The Board of Education has approved the following appointments and transfers of teachers and others in various branches of the school system:

Starting Feb. 23, the first day the traffic courts of the city will be open after the new traffic regulations become effective on Feb. 21, first offenders charged with cer tain traffic violations will not be required to appear in court in per son to pay their fines, it was revealed yesterday when Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurmap filed a proclamation concerning such cases with City Clerk Michael J. Cruise.

Severe measures for the control of prices in the hotels and restaurants of Paris during the coming season are being prepared by the French Government. These will probably not go so far as the Draconian measures taken in Italy for the protection of tourists from profiteering hotel proprietors, but it is understood a scale of prices will be fixed for all categories of hotels and restaurants before the international exhibition opens here May 1.

Dr. John McMullen, former Assistant Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, and Mrs. McMullen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Eleanor McMullen, to Otis Theodore Wingo, son of former Representative Effigene Wingo of Arkansas and the late Representative Otis Wingo.

The prosecuting attorney announced here today that the Arnold Bernstein and Red Star Lines, both controlled by the Jewish shipping man, Arnold Bernstein, were formally charged with breaches of the exchange laws and that a State trustee had been appointed to operate them pending the outcome of the trial.

A new series of mailed threats by a hooded band of night-riding floggers who pray over the prostrate forms of their victims prompted Sheriff J. A. Russ today to appeal for Federal aid in breaking up the secret order.

Leo Durocher, St. Douis Cards' shortstop, won his second-round match for the annual Ormond Beach golf championship today, defeating Joe Medwick, his teammate, 3 and 2. Medwick held a two-hole advantage at the turn.

More than 800 school children at St. John's Parochial School, Lewis and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn, were forced to flee from the instituition shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a fire broke out in the auditorium on the top floor of the four-story brick building.

Meyer D. Nitzburg, the Park Avenue liquor storekeeper who has a record of frustrating three holdups by hitting the would-be robbers over the head with bottles of champagne, did it again last night-but this time with a bottle of Scotch.

Miss Dorothy Louise Miller, blond, vivacious and 19, outdistanced five other Columbia girls yesterday and won the title of "ideal co-ed" by answering "correctly" every one of twenty-three questions designed by John Held Jr., the artist, and four Columbia campus leaders to determine the perfect woman student.

Fifteen thousand members of the Hitler Youth organization gathered here tonight to hear Dr. Robert Ley, chief of the German Labor Front, deliver the following "confession of faith," in which they joined by standing at attention. with arms raised in the Hitler salute.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation made public today the bids received on a list of 4 per cent county and municipal securities offered for sale recently. The issues, range of bids and highest bidder follow:
The New York Curb Exchange has approved listing applications for the following issues:

Department store sales showed about the usual seasonal decrease from December to January and the Federal Reserve Board's adjusted index continued at the level of the two preceding months, it was announced today.

Mrs. Katherine Evans of Short Hills won the women's New Jersey Class B squash racquets championship by defeating Mrs. George Dimock of Elizabeth in the final today after narrowly averting elimination in the semi-finals.

Fourteen men who were arrested on vagrancy charges Tuesday night as they reported at the French Line pier at West Forty-eighth Street to work as porters were in the police line-up yesterday morning and later were discharged by Magistrate Anthony Burke in West Side Court when they proved they had jobs.

Know how to judge a dog and see the world is the advice of Freeman Lloyd, who has officiated in shows of four continents in sixtyyears. His first important exhibition was that of the English Ken-: nel Club during the celebration ofthe Golden Jubilee of the reign ofQueen Victoria and only two weeks ago he judged in San Francisco.

Results of current furniture and rug promotions were described by retailers as "spotty" yesterday. In some sections, particularly Brook lyn. and Queens, the majority of retailers report sales well above estfmates and considerably ahead of the corresponding week last year.

Sharp debate marked discussion in the House today of President Roosevelt's plan for judiciary reform. Some of the most marked objections to the proposal, especially that section dealing with the personnel of the Supreme Court, arose on the Democratic side.

The fund which the New York Chapter of the Red Cross is collecting for flood relief in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys was increased yesterday by $47,988.41, making a grand total of $1,615,334.93, exclusive of the city's gift of $250,000, formally presented yesterday.

BISCHOFF, ERNST (April 19, 1935). Gross assets, $358,777; net, $168,906. To Edward T. Bischoff, son: Ilse Bischoff and Carola Terwilliger, daughters, one-third residue each. Chief assets. mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $178m815. Coster McGarey, attorneys, 51 Chambers St.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading in a general way was only fair to slow. A few miscellaneous cuts were in good demand, however.
A brilliant second-period drive which netted twenty su ??ssive points carried Manhattan's powerful basketball team to a 50 to 24 triumph over Cathedral College at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.

The service workers of Israel Zion Hospital, 4,802 Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn, were back at work yesterday, their "sit-down" strike having been terminated by a compromise on Tuesday at 7:25 P. M. The agreement gave the ninety-six strikers the $15-a-month-maintenance allowance nnthey had dehanded, and assurance there would be no punitive action.

In accordance with its plans for complete refinancing of outstanding obligations, the New England Power Association intends to file registration statements within two weeks covering the initial steps in its refunding program, it was announced yesterday by Frank D. Comerford, chairman of the board.
The touring Marylebone Cricket Club hit 381 runs in the first innings against New South Wales as a two-day match started today. Bad light forced an early adjournment after

Paul Moscou, who used to sell stock of the Public Service Holding Corporation, testified yesterday in Federal court that originally he had faith in the venture, backed in 1932 by two Yale graduates, but that later he changed his opinion.

Five officials of the Railway Audit and Inspection Company, Inc., an industrial detective concern, asked the Federal district court today to throw out indictments charging them with contempt of the Senate.

Karl Schafer, seven times world and twice Olympic figure skating champion, will skate from now on as a professional. The decision, which came so quickly after the great Austrian star's arrival here Monday afternoon that it was a surprise move even to him, was announced at the New York Skating Club yesterday.

Carlos Chavez, Mexican conductor and composer, will begin his fortnight leading the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra tonight at Carnegie Hall. His program includes a first performance of his concert suite "H. P." and his "Sinfonia de Antigona." The other works are Beethoven's "Coriolanus" Overture, Haydn's Symphony in C minor, Ravel's Daphnis et Chloe," and the Nocturnes, "Nuages" and "Fetes" of Debussy.

T. O. M. Sopwith's new motor yacht Philante, 1,612 tons, which will accompany the Endeavour II to the United States for the America's Cup series, was launched at Camper Nicholson's yard today. She is the biggest motor yacht thus far built in Britain, measuring 268 feet overall and 38 feet beam.
F. L. Flanders wanted to have his colors up in the $50,000 Widener, climactic feature of the racing here at Hialeah, so he purchased Mountainy Man, an eligible for that mile and a quarter special.

Representatives of the organizations affiliated with the Apparel Industries Inter-Trade Bureau decided yesterday to take steps to formulate procedure for the amicable adjustment of disputes arising over. returned merchandise with members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association as soon as the platform of the -venders' relations committee of that organization is approved in the current referendum of the store group.
A Chopin cycle, including the entire 169 works of the composer, will be presented for the first time in this city next season by Alexander Brailowskvy, pianist.

Miss Louise H. Tiffany, daughter of the late Charles L. Tiffany, who founded the New York jewelry house, died today at the home of A. E. Lugsdin, where she had been visiting since December. Her age was 82.

The members of the British women's squash racquets team have been accorded four places in the seeding for the national championship which will start Monday on the courts of the Junior League and the Cosmopolitan Club in this city.

In this age of comparative "index numbers" for industrial production, trade, employment and finance, the reader is sometimes bewildered by the multiplicity and varying trends of the different countries and of the different fields of activity.
The Legislature today elected Miss Susan Brandeis, a New York City lawyer, and George J. Ryan, former president of the New York City Board of Education, as members of the Board of Regents.

There is a story behind most of the wildlife pictures entered in the Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest, for the reason that these usually are taken under difficult conditions. It is regrettable that more contestants did not relate their experiences and the circumstances under which the photographs were obtained.
President Roosevelt transmitted a message to Congress on long-range drought relief, and conferred with members of the Congressional Judiciary Committees on his judicial-reform measures.

The field for the Lincolshire Handicap, to be run March 17, was reduced from fifty-two to forty-one today when a number of trainers declined to accept the weights assigned their entries. Weights for the remainder of the field were raised seven pounds.
The General Telephone Corporation reported yesterday that its subsidiaries made a gain of 1,810 telephones in service last month, compared with an increase of 1,029 in January, 1936.

Magistrate Frank Oliver in the Felony Court expressed regret yesterday to Georgette Hopkins, 26 years old, Negro owner of the restaurant at 2,246 Seventh Avenue, because the police had arrested her at 2 o'clock in the morning for shooting one of two hold-up suspects in her place with his own pistol.
Baron George Geymiller, Baron and Baroness Emmanuel Janssen, and Mrs. Helen Latini are among the passengers due to arrive today on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia from Mediterranean ports.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Buttenwieser of 885 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude C. Buttenwieser. to J. Warner Prins of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, son of Mrs. Maurits Prins and the late Mr. Prins.

Despite provisions of a Wisconsin law that espionage agents and detectives must first be registered before doing active work, an official of the Pinkerton National Detective Agency told the Senate subcommittee investigating labor

Members of the New York Stock Exchange were notified yesterday that the governing committee had adopted an amendment to the constitution clarifying and expanding the powers of the Committee on Quotations and Commissions with respect to persons proposed for partnership in member firms and with respect to partnership agreements. Ballots of the members on the question are to be returned by Feb. 24.
The Downtown Athletic Club and Cornell Club wound up the season last night deadlocked for honors among the Class C teams in Group 2 of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

N. Y. U. defeated Rutgers before 3,500 tonight, 39 to 38. It was the Scarlet's first defeat of the basketball season. Irving Terjesen, who started at forward and shifted to center, scored four points in the last minute for the Violets in one of the most stirring games played here in years.

Three years of labor trouble in local motion-picture theatres, marked by tear-gas bombings, violence, picketing and thousands of arrests, were believed ended yesterday when Local 306 of the Motion Picture Operators Union absorbed its chief rival, the Allied Motion Picture Operators Union.

The Rev. Charles E. Scudder, who was pastor of the Browne Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church in Jersey City for the last five years, died this morning at his home, 174 Carteret Avenue, of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and had been ill for two months.

Transatiantic ships were ordered to shift to the southern course yesterday to avoid icebergs which were reported adrift in the northerly Winter lane. This transfer generally takes place in March, but the unusual mildness of the Winter has caused Arctic ice to break up more quickly this year.

Governor Lehman's long fight for adoption of his social security program ended in victory today when the Assembly, with its Republican majority, passed by a vote of 115 to 20 the Dunnigan Social Security Bill, which had been sent to the Assembly for concurrence following passage by the Democratic-controlled Senate.

After protracted hearings before Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy on an application by the Rosoff Tunnel Corporation for an injunction against Local 102 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, officials of the union agreed late yesterday afternoon to put striking sandhogs back to work on the Sixth Avenue subway construction job, pending conferences in Washington to settle an inter-union jurisdictional dispute.

President Roosevelt won the first legislative move today on his judiciary reform proposals when, by personal Intervention, he stopped the splitting of the program in the House and prevented immediate consideration of the less controversial sections, as independent from his plan to remake the Supreme Court.
With unforeseen speed, three phases of the legal battle to test the constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Act were fought before the Supreme Court today.

Dr. Harriet Babcock entertained with a dinner last night at the National Arts Club, 15 Grameroy Park. Her guests included Colonel and Mrs. Storrs Bowen, Mr. and Mrs. Burton J. Hollister, Mr. and Mrs. Nevil Monroe Hopkins, Mrs. Herbert David Weiser,
The ponderous German helmet of World War "kamerad" poster memory is going to shrink. As a result, the men of Germany's new army will carry hundreds of tons less metal on their heads.

Assemblyman Moffat, New York Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, denied today on the floor of the Assembly that Mayor La Guardia had suggested that he kill the resolution extending the life of the committee created last year to investigate alleged teaching of communism in schools and colleges.

A proposed election to determine how many employes of General Motors' strike-bound Fisher Body plant want to return to their jobs received the approval of Lincoln R. Scafe, plant manager, today, but local union officials said they had no authority to make a decision on the proposal.

The Union Oil Company of California reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net income of $6,133,398 after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation and depletion, equal to $1.40 a share on the 4,386,070 common shares outstanding. This compares with $5,038,286,

The new French Ambassador to the United States, M. BONNET, is on his way to New York. There has been a good deal of mystery about his mission. That it will be special he himself has indicated by a statement that he does not expect to remain permanently, or even a long time, at Washington.

In the good old Colony times lawyers were scarce and generally disliked. Their conspicuous service on the popular side before the Revolution largely dispelled the prejudice against them. In some pioneer communities and States laymen might be judges.

The Gillette Safety Razor Company announced today it made profits of $4,975,888 in 1936, after all charges. After deducting dividends paid on prefernce stock the net profits were equivalent to $1.72 a share on the 1,998,769 shares of common stock outstanding.

The registration statement of the Colombian Bondholders Protective Committee for certificates of deposit, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Jan. 21 and scheduled to become effective today, has been delayed.
It is officially announced that Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, will come to Vienna Feb. 22 for a two-day visit and conferences with the Austrian Foreign Office.

While reports have reached the War Department that veterans' organizations are planning to protest the decision to award the decoration of the Purple Heart to military men for service with the Civilian Conservation Corps, no such protests have been received, it was said today.

Flying the old house flag of Cohan Harris, nnit is "George M. Cohan in his own way of telling the story of Parker Fennelly's Fulton of Oak Falls," and it was acted with a nice warm flow of sentiment at the Morosco last evening.

American Steel Foundries has notified the New York Stock Exchange that the company plans to increase its authorized common stock to 1,250,000, shares from 1,000,000 shares, of which 970,414 are outstanding.

Directors of the Eastman Kodak Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock, payable April 1 to stock of record March 5. This represents the highest basis for the company's common shares since 1922 when the common stock

The New York Life Insurance Company in 1936 had gains of $160,000,000 in assets and $40,000,000 in Insurance in force, Thomas A. Buckier, chairman, told the directors yesterday -at their monthly meeting. He said assets of the com'pany on. Dec. 31 were $2,404,236,413.

David Levinson, the American lawyer who came here to defend Harry Berger and Luis Carlos Prestes in the trial of the alleged leaders in the radical revolt of November, 1935, may be asked by the police to leave Rio de Janeiro.
Tests of Harriet Hoctor, currently in "Stepping Toes" at R-K-O, have intrigued Producer Pandro S. Berman sufficiently so that the dancer is to be made a featured player.

Displaying a powerful attack in the second half, during which they registered 20 points, the James Monroe High basketball forces vanquished George Washington, 32 to 19, on the former's court yesterday and advanced to a second-place tie with Evander Childs in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the P. S. A. L.

All Moscow was Pushkin-mad today on the hundredth anniversary of the poet's death. There were processions, mass meetings in public squares, gala performances of grand opera and special performances in theatres, movie houses and workers' clubs.
Ambassador Georges Bonnet accompanied by his wife and a small staff left Paris this morning for his post at Washington. He sailed later from Le Havre on the Isle de France.

The Crimson scored its seventeenth consecutive victory at the Garden tonight as nearly 5,000 fans watched Harvard lift itself into a second-place tie with Toronto in the International Intercollegiate Hockey League by a 5-2 triumph over Queen's University.

Edward G. Reimers, formerly a horticulturist in Louisville, Ky., died at his home here today after a long illness at the home of his son, Carl Reimers, with whom he had resided since retiring a few years ago. His age was 77. Two other sons,
The Spanish Insurgents claimed today the capture of Motril, a seaport city forty-five miles east of Malaga. Motril gives Granada direct communication with the coast.

The 'KfaftPhenix Cheese Corporation, Chicago, has announced plans for the most extensive advertising and merchandising- campaign in the company's history. Newspapers, magazines and radio will continue to be the chief media. John H.

Mrs. Mae Scheible, under a fouryear -sentence to a Federal prison for a Mann Act- violation, withdrew yesterday in District Attorney Dodge's office charges she made last December against Harold L. Kunstler, disbarred lawyer and former Municipal Court justice.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and the Texas Corporation have agreed for a term of fifty years to give to each other the opportunity to buy the other's interest in the South American Gulf Oil Company before selling to a third party, it was disclosed in a registration statement the Texas Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with its stock offering.

Frank M. Rooney, a former newspaper man and for thirty-five years a clerk in the Kings County Supreme Court, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at his home, 810 East Fortieth Street, Brooklyn. He was born in Newark, N, Y., sixty-nine years ago and was graduated from Syracuse University in 1890. He later received his LL. B.

The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday net income in 1936 of $62,110,543, a new record. This compared with $34,975,819 in 1935 and with $21,902,168 in 1929. The 1936 net income was equal to $14.25 a share on its $5-par common stock, against $8.07 in 1935.

Precautions were taken today by Sheriff Chauncey J. Williams to prevent any possible escape by two suspects in the O'Connell kidnapping case. Flood lights were installed to sweep the jail yard at night and extra guards were ordered on duty.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the marriage on Saturday night in Newburgh, N. Y., of Miss Patti Pickens, member of the Pickens Sisters trio of radio fame, to Robert Simmons of New York, tenor of the Revelers radio quartet.

Speaking as the head of a State frequently designated as the Belgium of the next war, President Eduard Benes expressed the conviction today that war in Europe not only could but, in his opinion, would be avoided.

The Peddle five swept to its eleventh straight victory today, routing Newman School, 33-16. The winners led from the start, being ahead at the half, 15-6. Jack Cronin, Person and R. Nolan each made seven markers for Peddle.

Plans to spend $30,554,553 for new power and rolling stock were revealed today in the applications of three Class I railroads for permission to issue equipment certificates filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. Increased demands from heavy industries necessitated immediate expansion in the roads' equipment facilities, they declared.

The Citizens Budget Commissionn, Inc., with offices at 51 East Fortysecond Street, elected Colonel Richard C. Patterson Jr. chairman of the board yesterday. He succeeds William Church Osborn, who was elected a vice president of the commission.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday withheld action on plans for a Max Baer-Bob Pastor heavyweight bout in Madison Square Garden pending application by Baer and his manager, Ancil Hoffman, for renewal of their licenses as boxer and manager.

The National Guard, which was ready for action last night on the basis of an expected proclamation of a state of insurrection existing in Flint, continued to stand by today awaiting orders from Governor Frank Murphy.

In an overtime game, a fast St. Francis College basketball team from Brooklyn registered a 38-to-36 victory over the Rider quintet tonight. The teams were deadlocked, 32all at the conclusion of the regular playing time.

An unprecedented first-day attendance responded to a recordbreaking entry in the sixty-first annual all-breed dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club yesterday in Madison Square Garden. The exhibitions continue through tomorrow evening.

Miss Dorothy Baird Turner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Turner of this place, has chosen April 16 as the date for her marriage to Beverly Wilson Robertson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Robertson of Orange.

The stock market here was brighter today, although business again was on an extremely small scale. Uncertainty continued to mark trading in miltedge issues, but after minor declines prices recovered slightly. Foreign bonds were quiet.

Stockholders of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company have subscribed for 436,668 of the 500,000 shares of new $4.50 cumulative preferred stock recently offered them, the company announced yesterday. It said no general public offering of the remaining 63,322 shares is expected.

The seventh annual Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship almost became an all-Philadelphia contest on the courts at Haddon Hall today as the members of the British team failed to get over their sea-legs in time to compete and the New Yorkers all defaulted, mostly because of slight attacks of grippe.
Housewives in-twenty-three Manhattan and Bronx apartment buildings felt radiators grow cold yesterday as the Building Service Employes International Union continued its strike drive.
Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday that on March 1 he would make what he believes will be the largest mass promotion in the history of the city's Fire Department.
Fred C. Moffatt yesterday began his third term as president of the New York Curb Exchange, following unanimous election by the board of governors.

A vague feeling that Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg is preparing another of his lightning counterstrokes against his enemies was strengthened this morning when the official gazette, the Wiener Zeitung, came out with a front-page editorial adopting monarchy as the principal plank of the present regime's program.

Total insurance in force for the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company at the end of 1936 was $1,874,060,619, or $22,615,000 more than a year before on a newbusiness volume of $141,410,115 in the year, the company said in its annual report yesterday. Fewer policies lapsed or were surrendered, and mortality was at 56.3 per cent of the expected rate.
Voters of this town will assemble in town meeting Tuesday night to remonstrate against the Supreme Court changes proposed by President Roosevelt.

There have been several indications that the House of Representatives is going to be more free to judge proposed legislation on its merits than was thought probable. Fifty or sixty Democrats voted against the bill to place all postmasters under the civil service rules.
Governor Lehman's $365,000,000 executive budget will be subjected to a joint public hearing of the fiscal committees of Senate and Assembly next Wednesday.

Georgetown's long-range guns carried the Hoyas to a 40-to-37 victory over Army in a hard-fought basketball battle today. The setback was Army's third in a row. At half-time the Cadets were leading by a margin of 3 points, 19-16.
Nicaragua's cotton crop which is now being sold is the largest in its history. United States cotton experts will plant the country's largest acreage this year on the flat plains near Leon.

Funeral services for Lewis Thompson Preston, sportsman, of Westbury, L. I., who died Tuesday in the Doctors Hospital, will be held at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow in the Church of the Advent, Westbury, L. I. The honorary pallbearers will be Thomas M. Carnegie, Rodman Wanamaker, Charles A. Clark,

The following film programs, which will be shown tomorrow through Sunday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

Syracuse, N. Y., has invited bankers to submit bids on Feb. 25 for a new issue of $4,260,000 of refunding, welfare and PWA project bonds The bonds will be dated March 15, 1937, and will mature in one to twenty years.

An anxious but confident watch upon the levees of the lower Mississippi River was redoubled tonight while the crest of the river's greatest flood crept past Memphis and on toward Helena, Vicksburg and New Orleans.

All told, the Scouts and their leaders in the Boy Scouts of America now number a million-a million in addition to the several millions who have been Scouts and still are; for, as President ROOSEVELT said in his address to his "fellow-Scouts" on the twenty-seventh anniversary of the organization, "once a Scout always a Scout."

Stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad will be asked to authorize an increase of $95,000,000 in the company's funded debt at the annual meeting to be held in Philadelphia on April 13. The funded debt now is $688,616,904.

Hamilton H. Durand, a lawyer, with offices at 68 William Street, died yesterday at his residence, 441 Park Avenue, in his seventy-first year. A sister, Miss Katharine Durand, of the same address, survives..
Burton C. Simon, a South Philadelphia builder active in Republican politics, died today after a short illness. His age was 60. One of the largest home builders in the city,
I have had miraculous escapes in technical matters, which make me blush still. Luckily the men of the seas and the engine-room do not write to the Press, and my worst slip is still underided.

Charles A. Webber of 172 Congress Street, Brooklyn, Brooklyn attorney, who was active in borough civic and Catholic organizations, died on Tuesday in St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn, of a heart ailment. He was 76 years of age.

After trailing by 13 points the Lafayette five came back to score a 33-32 victory over Upsala tonight. Upsala got off to a 12-0 lead and was ahead 19-6 when the Maroon started its rally, which brought the score to 19-16 at half time.

The public interest which exploded into being as soon as the contents of the President's message on judicial change were made known leads to the thought that it may be illuminating to review the development of Mr. Roosevelt's attitude

If President Roosevelt should obtain control of the Supreme Court it would mean "the death of our Republic," Alfred A. Cook, chairman of the judiciary committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, said yesterday at a luncheon of the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel New Yorker.
The field in the metropolitan squash racquets championship was reduced to five players at the University Club last night, with all four of the seeded contenders numbered among the survivors.

President Roosevelt's arguments for enlarging the Supreme Court will not hold water if impartially examined, A. Lawrence Lowell, presidentemeritus of Harvard University, maintained yesterday in a speech broadcast by the National Broadcasting Company.
The proper name for the West Side Elevated Highway is the Express Highway, and speed is no doubt its primary motive.

The city moved yesterday to have the 225-foot chimney adjacent to Floyd Bennett Flying Field removed because the Dock Department said it was a menace to aviation. The city is trying to have its own flying field at Barren Island, Jamaica Bay, designated as an eastern mail terminal instead of the present field at Newark.

Dartmouth's vastly improved basketball team handed Harvard a 44to-31 defeat before 1,200 spectators in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at the Harvard Indoor Athletic Building tonight. As a result of the Green victory, Harvard, Dartmouth and Yale are now in a three-cornered tie for third place in the league race.
Secretary Roper today announced ten recommendations worked out by the Bureau of Air Commerce since the air safety conference ended last Saturday.

In London last night George Bernard Shaw informed THE NEW YORK TIMES that for some months he had had an agreement with Milton Shubert whereby the latter would present "On the Rocks" in New York; that it was originally scheduled for this Winter; but was deferred to Fall for several reasons, including casting difficulties.
Bennett Ellison and Ernest Stauffen Jr. have been elected to the board of trustees of the Central Savings Bank. Jenks, Gwynne Co. have become members of the Montreal Curb Exchange.

A six-story apartment house for 185 families will be erected at 245263 West Twenty-third Street and 238-256 West Twenty-fourth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, according to plans filed yesterday by J. M. Felson, architect, who estimated the cost at $500,000.
A floodcontrol bill which would create seven river authorities was introduced in the Senate today by Senators Bulkley of Ohio and Barkley of Kentucky.

Lou Ambers, world's lightweight champion, added Davey Day of Chicago to his list of vanquished rivals last night in their ten-round non-title bout at the Hippodrome before a gathering of about 3,500 excited fans. But the Herkimer Hurricane, spotty in his fighting as compared with the consistent windmill puncher to whom local fans have become accustomed, had to step lively to gain the decision.

Two inquiries, one by officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company and another in Mexico, were under way yesterday to determine the reasons why Leon Trotsky, exiled Bolshevik leader, was unable to address an audience at the Hippodrome Tuesday evening, when telephone arrangements designed to carry his voice to listeners in New York broke down in Mexico City.

A joit resolution providing for acceptance by the government of Andrew W. Mellon's collection of work of art and the construction and maintenance of a National Gallery of Art, to house the treasures, was introduced in -the Senate today by Senator Connally, chairman of the Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds.
The effectiveness of the stay-in strikes as a method of drawing attention to grievances has been demonstrated anew by London's long-suffering subway passengers.

Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Donley of Plainfield have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Ruth Adams Donley, to James Alexander Malloy of New York and London. The ceremony was performed last night in the Bethesda-by-the-Sea Church, Palm Beach, Fla.

The first admission that Italians played a considerable role in the conquest of Malaga, Spain, was made today by the Rome press, which prints detailed reports from foreign newspapers attributing to Italian troops the chief credit for the unexpectedly rapid advance of General Francisco Franco's Insurgent troops in Southern Spain.
Governor Murphy announced at 2:45 o'clock this morning that an agreement had been reached to end the automobile strike which has crippled production in General Motors Corporation since late December.

Trends of commodity futures were mixed on the local commodity markets yesterday. Coffee, copper and rubber futures advanced while cocoa, hides and cottonseed oil futures declined. Sugar, silk, copper, lead and wool-top futures were steady.

Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin will give a dinner tonight in the Persian Room of the Plaza for her daughter, Miss Marjorie McAlpin, and Calvin W. Dail, whose marriage will take place tomorrow at the Colony Club.
The Valencia road is not cut and has not been cut despite the claims by the Insurgents that they had cut it.

The merger agreement between the McKeesport Tin Plate Company and its subsidiary, the National Can Company, provides that McKeesport Tin Plate be merged into National Can and the name be changed to the McKeesport Tin Plate Corporation, according to an announcement yesterday by G. V. Parkins, president of the parent company.
Forming a human chain,

Sir Reginald Henry Craddock, senior member of Parliament for the combined English universities, died here today at the age of 72. Entering Commons after a long and notable career in the Indian Civil Service,

A decision on the gold clause in the -redemption of foreign loans issued by France was postponed when the Senate today voted the disjunction of the provision inserted in the supplementary credits bill by the Chamber of Deputies.
A. W. Aldrich, a Vermont farmer who likes to climb mountains, adjusted his routine to city surroundings here yesterday by climbing to the top of the Empire State Building.

The common trust fund for the better investment and safety of small estates was pronounced "a sensible and natural development of trust service" in an address made here yesterday by Tom K. Smith, president of the American Sinkers Association.
An other 'anti-Italian purge, it is be lived, started here' today' with the dismissal of two Crown officials charged with acting against British interests.

Members of the Winter colony will attend "Governor's Day for Charity" at Hialeah Park on Friday. Arrangements are being made for the world premiere of "Lost Horizon," the motion picture which will be produced in Lincoln Theatre on Feb. 18, for the benefit of Shadows and Sunbeams, a local charity.

Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio gave a dinner tonight at their home for Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ittleson, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bayard Swope and Herbert Bayard Swope Jr., Mr. and Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart, Mr. and Mrs. William Randolph Hearst Jr., Mrs. Arthur Somers Roche, Miss Luriel Richards and Clyde Roche.

Part of the blame for the poisoning of Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves was attributed to a physician by defense counsel, as Chang Soo Lee, 36-year-old Korean house servant, went on trial today for the poisoning of the Reeves couple while employed in the home of Mrs. Ida L. Churchill, wealthy White Plains widow and aunt of Mrs. Reeves. The case is being heard in County Court here.

The Red Bank and the Gypsy Polo Clubs rode into the semi-finals of the New York Athletic Club's annual indoor polo tournament at the 105th F. A. Armory last night in two hard-fought games, both winning in the last period.

The Greco-Salle Santelli composite team defeated the Salle d'Armes Vince, 5 to 3, in the final round on the Salle Santelli strips last night to win the women's interclub foils competition staged under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America.

Albert George Effrat of 1,162 East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, was found dead here this morning in his room at the Hotel Tremont, where he had been recuperating from a recent operation for hernia. His death, at the age of 29, was presumably due to a heart attack. Mr.
With only two more matches to go, the New York Athletic Club and the Columbia University Club teams are running almost a dead heat for Class A honors in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association.
Madeleine Vionnet in her new collection features a daytime silhouette having very full circular skirts and slender bodices with coats in all lengths.

A "platform commission" of forty-nine retail merchants and five special committees to serve with it were appointed yesterday by David E. Moeser, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, to devise methods for carrying out those general principles of the "proposed voluntary platform" of the N. R. D. G. A. approved at the annual convention -in January.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday net income in 1936 of $8,933,175, or $1.79 a share, on the capital stock, the largest return since 1930. This compared with a net income of $115,046, or 2 cents a share, in 1935.

Led by the steel issues, and also by the motor, metal and rubber groups, and to a lesser extent by the railway shares, the stock market advanced on a fairly broad front yesterday. At the closing, many of the leading issues were up 1 to 4 points.

All sections of the bond market, except United States Government obligations, shook off yesterday the lethargy that has prevailed in recent trading and, on a quickened trading pace, moved upward with consderable enthusiasm.

Rallying strongly in the closing half, Stevens Tech won a thrilling 23-21 decision from Lehigh University's basketball team today. Overcoming Lehigh's first-half edge of 14-10 the New Jersey team jumped into the lead with seven minutes to play and was never again headed.

Using the argument that rising prices, if unchecked, would create social unrest and increase the cost of armament programs, Finance Minister Toyotaro Yuki has obtained the Cabinet's assent to a general reduc tion of the budget, including the army and navy estimates.

J. P. Morgan Co., the National City Bank and the First National Bank of Boston have been appointed fiscal agents of the loan for the payment of the $70,000,000 of Argentine Republic 4 per cent bonds, due on Feb. 15, 1972.
Mobile guards forcibly ejected sit-down strikers from a warehouse at La Madeleine, near Lille, which they had "occupied" this morning.

The Catalan Council of Ministers decreed early today a new mobilization to meet the threat of an Insurgent offensive. The Cabinet's action was taken after an Insurgent warship had bombarded this port for more than an hour early yesterday. More than forty shots were exchanged as shore batteries traded shells with the vessel, which kept far out at sea.

Dropping down several notches in the class ladder, Sir Michael, aged gelding owned by A. Gaignard Jr., barely eked out a nose decision over the Lone Star Stable's Dorothy B. in the six furlongs of the sixth race at the fair grounds today. Hueu was a disappointing third.

President Roosevelt's proposal to encourage retirement of Supreme Court justices at 70 does not touch the fundamental question of conflicts between executive, legislative and judicial branches of the government, Dean Charles E. Clark of the Yale Law School declared tonight at a meeting of the Yale Political Union.

The formation of a minority group, the "Democratic Parliamentary Bloc," in the House of Representatives to fight military domination of the government was announced by Representative Eduardo Suarez Rivas today.
Twenty-three more Senators replied yesterday to the request of THE NEW YORK TIMES for their views on President Roosevelt's proposal for reorganization of the Federal judiciary.

Samuel F. Irwin, a retired business man prominent as a Presbyterian layman, died at his home in Merion last night after a short illness. He was 79 years old. Mr. Irwin retired in 1935 as treasurer of the L. H. Parke Company, wholesale dealers in tea, coffee and spices.

A gigantic program designed to make over lands in ten States and help 4,000,000 persons to escape the scourge of duststorms, with their consequent ruin of the nation's granary lands, was urged on Congress today by President Roosevelt.

Miss Margaret H. Gens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul William Gens of Hollis, Queens, was married last night to John Drennen Hill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Arthur Hill of this city, in All Souls Unitarian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee and the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons.

Despite the short week caused by the Lincoln's Birthday holiday, engineering construction awards show a gain, as compared with the same week in 1936, the total this week being $33,010,000, against $31,445,000 last year, according to the Enginering News-Record.
Edward C. Johnson, trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today made a ruling on the admissibility of testimony in the manipulation case against W. E. Hutton Co.,

Representatives of tenants' groups and taxpayers' associations were heard yesterday on the proposal to give the Tenement House Commissioner the right to make repairs to old-law tenements and to levy assessments as first liens against the property for the costs at a public hearing before Langdon W. Post, chairman of the City Housing Authority.

A special board of six censors, which included three clergymen, sat in judgment on Langston Hughes's "Mulatto" at a rehearsal today and failed to agree on whether the play would be permitted to open in this city.

Raymond Holden, whose "Chance Has a Whip" was published by Scribner, has contracted with Henry Holt for a publication of his next two books, both to be brought out within the next year. One of the books will continue the life of Leda Putnam, leading character in "Chance Has a Whip." The other is a mystery story, set on the Mexican border.

Darkness closed in on this ancient fortified port tonight with most of the Miami-Nassau ocean racing fleet still at sea. Mandoo II, sailed by D. Spencer Berger of New Haven, Conn., was first to finish, covering the 184 nautical miles from the Florida city in 28 hours, 28 minutes.

An extensive alteration to cost about $75,000 was announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the five-story business building at 107 West Forty-eighth Street, near Sixth Avenue, by Henry Van Auken to Mont Levy of the Angelica Jacket Company of St. Louis, Mo.
Dr. Ernest W. Kelsey, widely known physician and one-time track star at the university of Pennsylvania, died at his home here Monday night after a long illness. He was 65.

A letter on this page yesterday from flood-stricken Carrollton, Ky., begins by saying that no words within the power of the writer to dictate could describe conditions in the little town. He then proceeds to tell in obviously unstudied language a story which many professional writers would be proud to claim:
Data from the Securities and Exchange Commission issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange included a report by Park Tilford, Inc., on the interests owning its shares.
The appointment of Chalmers Clifton as head of the WPA Music Project in New York City has been approved by WPA officials in Washington, it was announced yesterday.

Engineering contracts totaling $2,352 035.29 were awarded by the ?? Department today, as follows: Maxon Construction Company, Inc., Dayton, Ohio-For construction ?? Dam 17, Mississippi River, Rock Island, Ill., District, $2,281,042.79.

The text of Secretary Hull's letter to Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee on reciprocal trading agreements was as follows: My Dear Senator Harrison: May I supplement the statements which will be made before your committee by Assistant Secretary Sayre and others by offering brief comment on the joint resolution now pending, which extends, for another period of three years, the President's authority under the Trade Agreements Act of June 12, 1934?

The directors of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company have authorized the filing of a petition under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act in the United State District Court in Delaware, besides a plan of reorganization, according to a letter sent to stockholders by Roy B. Jones, president.

Six months to the day after he murdered his sweetheart, James J. McElroy of New Haven was the first victim of Connecticut's new electric chair tonight at the State prison, four miles south of this city in Wethersfield.

Bright printed materials will compete with plain colored fabrics in cotton dresses for sports and house wear during the Spring and Summer season, it was indicated at a style show staged by the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, Inc., at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night. Dresses of tailored linens of all types were among the outstanding features of the show, in which early American costumes were displayed as a prologue.

" Good clothes deserve good care" was the theme of a fashion show featuring the original designs of American dress creators, held last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania under the sponsorship of the I. B. Kleinert Rubber Company. Sports.
Alfred M. Krug of 782 North Broadway, lawyer, who had owned a music store here for forty-three years, died today in the Yonkers General Hospital of heart disease at the age of 66.
A collection of books, paintings, sculpture and historical items from the library of the late Speaker Henry T.
