Former Laborite admirers of Edward VIII voted today against giving him a special grant from public funds. At a meeting of all Labor members of Parliament it was agreed that the pension to the former King should come from the revenues of his brother, George VI.

DR. DIXON RYAN FOX, President of Union College and of the New York State Historical Association, has undertaken in an article in New York History to answer the question "What is a New Yorker?" The answer is made difficult by the fact that the city and the State have the same name.
Electric power production declined just seasonally last week, but adjustment for long-term trend caused the index to drop to 105.6 from 105.8. It was 98.9 for the week ended Feb. 8, 1936.

An extensive alteration to cost about $75,000 was announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the five-story business building at 107 West Forty-eighth Street, near Sixth Avenue, by Henry Van Auken to Mont Levy of the Angelica Jacket Company of St. Louis, Mo.
Dr. Ernest W. Kelsey, widely known physician and one-time track star at the university of Pennsylvania, died at his home here Monday night after a long illness. He was 65.

A letter on this page yesterday from flood-stricken Carrollton, Ky., begins by saying that no words within the power of the writer to dictate could describe conditions in the little town. He then proceeds to tell in obviously unstudied language a story which many professional writers would be proud to claim:
Data from the Securities and Exchange Commission issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange included a report by Park Tilford, Inc., on the interests owning its shares.
The appointment of Chalmers Clifton as head of the WPA Music Project in New York City has been approved by WPA officials in Washington, it was announced yesterday.

Engineering contracts totaling $2,352 035.29 were awarded by the ?? Department today, as follows: Maxon Construction Company, Inc., Dayton, Ohio-For construction ?? Dam 17, Mississippi River, Rock Island, Ill., District, $2,281,042.79.

Even if the United States should be able to escape actual military participation in any large-scale international war it would be certain to suffer heavily from the economic upheaval the war would cause, Secretary Hull told the Senate Finance Committee in a letter to its chairman, Senator Harrison, made public today.

Mrs. J. Wuertz Edwards gave a reception yesterday at Mayfair House for Lord Charles and Lady Swinfen of London, who were married in that city last month, and for V. C. Buckley, also of London. Lady Swinfen is the former Miss Mary Farmar, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Harold M. Farmar of London.

You cannot be a successful snob if you live in a trailer, according to the trailerites themselves here for the convention of Tin-Can Tourists of the World. They agree that they have no "400" and no keeping up with the Joneses.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday formation of a new brokerage house partnership, composed of Edward L. Cohen and Ira Streusand and bearing the name of Edward L. Cohen Co.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter signed "A. S. R." in THE TIMES on Feb. 8, states the Republican point of view with accuracy and moderation. "A. S. R." regrets that the President is not surrounded by practical men "experienced in active life,"
Leases of space in the midtown district featured the commercial rentals listed in brokers' reports yesterday. Several contracts for large office space, stores and for expanded quarters were noted.

For the first time in ten years the Mahmal started today in a procession toward Mecca from Cairo. The usual traditional elaborate ceremony accompanied the departure of this gorgeously decorated litter on camelback and with it the Kiswa [holy carpet] which was once woven here every year as Egypt's gift to cover the tomb of Mohammed at- the annual pilgrimage to the Moslem's holiest shrine in Mecca.

Irving Odessky, 35 years old, former manager of the Bensonhurst branch of the Public National Bank and Trust Company of New York, pleaded guilty yesterday before Commissioner Martin C. Epstein on a charge of embezzlement of $26,000 of the funds of the institution.
Attorney General Cummings said today that _the Supreme Court had "enough trouble" on its hands without worrying about possible legal action against a duck-hunting member.

Harry E. Sheldon, who rose from a laborer to a place of prominence in the steel industry, died today. He was 75 years old. Mr. Sheldon and his father-in-law, the late Colonel Alfred Hicks, founded the Allegheny Steel Company in 1900. Mr. Sheldon was president of the company at his death.
A brown Pomeranian valued at $150 was stolen about 7 o'clock last night from its cage in Madison Square Garden while the large hall was crowded with visitors to the Westminster Kennel Club's show.
The United Engineering and Foundry Company announced today it had received an order from the Rustless Iron and Steel Company of Baltimore for a new 12-inch merchant mill to roll stainless steel.
A Negro member of the Police Legion of Honor told the jury in Queens County Court yesterday what he swore was Major Green's voluntary account of the murder of Mrs. Mary Harriet Case.

An offer by the Stadium Theatres Corporation to purchase the Orpheum Circuit, Inc., for $700,000 cash, plus the cancellation or subordination of $2,880,686 in note claims, was approved yesterday by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy.

Unlawful trade practices involving the use of unfair methods of competition, exclusive dealing contracts and price discrimination are alleged in a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission against the Christmas Club,

Miss Ella M. Norton, life-long resident of Norwich, well known for her philanthropies, died of pneumonia last night at her home here. She gave to Norwich Free Academy the Norton Memorial Gymnasium and was a generous contributor to the Norwich Young Men's Christian Association,

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday held within unusually narrow limits with the list losing 2 to 5 points. Estimates from Southern sources placed the amount of loan-cotton released in the first ten days' operations at approximately 125,000 bales out of the 3,000,000 financed by the government.

International broadcasting of classroom lectures will be started at Harvard University this month as an experiment. If the undertaking proves successful this Spring, the broadcasts will be continued as a regular part of the university program.

The grand jury testimony of one of the accused kidnappers of Paul H. Wendel, introduced in Kings County Court yesterday by District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan, supplied complete corroboration of Wendel's own story of how he was tortured into signing a false confession that he kidnapped Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.
Church bells rang today in the State of Vera Cruz and eager people filled the churches after the State Legislature late last night repealed the law preventing religious ceremonies in the State.
Bids for $50,000,000 in Treasury bills, to replace approximately a similar amount in maturities of the same character, were asked today by Secretary Morgenthau.

Graduation from a law school is not the end but the beginning of the study of law,. the Very Rev. Edward J. Walsh, president of St. John's University Law School, told ninety-four graduates of the school and 500 relatives and friends last night at commencement exercises in the gymnasium of the institution at 96 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn.
Governor Lehman hailed the passage of the Social Security Bill by the Senate and Assembly today as a "great victory for ,Democratic government."

J. M. Kurn and John G. Lonsdale, trustees in bankruptcy of the St. Louis-San, Francisco Railway, announced yesterday that it was anticipated funds would be available by Feb. 23 for the purchase at face

Salvagers hoisted a wrecked airliner with its dead crew of three from the depths of San Francisco Bay today. Divers groping for the bodies of eight passengers recovered one while puzzled officials sought the cause of the spectacular plunge within sight of the destination of the transport.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Sunday at Beverly Hills, Calif., of William Roger Callaway of Minneapolis, Minn., former general passenger agent of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway,

Predicting that the standardization of sizes would lead to more aggressive promotion of infants' and children's merchandise by department stores, Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, last night called upon manufacturers to unite their efforts along these lines.

Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador, will call tomorrow by arrangement at the Foreign Office and will there discuss European matters with Viscount Halifax, Lord Privy Seal, who is acting for Anthony Eden during the British Foreign Secretanry's absence on a holiday.

Catherine Dale Owen, former stage and film actress, is planning to file suit within a few weeks for a divorce from her husband, Milton F. Davis Jr. of New York City, it was learned here today. Mrs. Davis is in seclusion at a mountain ranch.

Leading stocks closed strong, with steel, motor, metal and rubber Shares up 1 to 4 points; turnover, 2,919,520 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds irregular, South American issues strong; transactions, $13,467,300.

While the demand for wool goods was slower this week than it has been in some time, orders are expected to increase early in March when manufacturers start showing men's wear lines for the Fall season, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service, Inc.

James Fenner Lee, son of the late James and Mary Cornelia Read Lee, an old Maryland family, died last night at his estate, Lee Crest, Leonardtown. His age was 63. He was educated at Columbia University.

The settlement of the controversy between General Motors and the United Automobile Workers was hailed by Secretary Perkins today as an achievement creditable to both parties and the "finest example in labor history of cooperation between State and Federal officials" in the handling of a strike situation.

The police of the Fifth Avenue station, Brooklyn, arrested two young men late last night and charged them with assaulting Mrs. Mary Stewart, 57-year-old mother of three children, early Wednesday morning.

Mayor La Guardia assured Governor Lehman last night that the bills restoring full pay for city employes could not be construed retroactively, after the Governor had raised that question during the day by addressing an inquiry to Corportion Counsel Paul Windels.

The cost of living advanced 0.9 per cent from December, 1936, to January, 1937, according to the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board, a report on which was made public yesterday.

Walter C. Martin, architect for the Board of Education, filed plans yesterday for a new four-story school building costing $1,000,000 at 109 to 139 West 127th Street through to 114 to 150 West 128th Street.

The crest of the Mississippi River's flood neared Helena, Ark., tonight, the level there reaching 60.25 feet, but the levee line was reported holding along the entire front and no new danger was expected.

The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 10, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,485,000,000, an increase of $2,000,000, compared with the preceding week, and a decrease of $10,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1936.

The Squash Club retained its Class B metropolitan squash racquets team title by turning back the Montclair Athletic Club, 3 to 2, on the neutral courts of the Downtown Athletic Club yesterday. The victory of Sam Cochran Jr. over Robert Coyle in the No. 1

Representative John W. Flannagan, Bristol (Va.) Democrat, sought Congressional support today for Federal control of tobacco production because an alternative plan based on interstate compacts "apparently is doomed to fail." Two obstacles have developed, he said, which appear to make control through interstate compacts "hopeless." One, Mr. Flannagan said,

A bid of $2,500,000 was made yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in taking over at auction the twenty - five - story business building and two five-story buildings at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Charles H. Blaine, head of the Cobb, Bates Yerxa Company in Taunton for forty years and senior director of the corporation in Boston at the time it was sold to the S. S. Pierce Company, died today at his home here at the age of 79.

The first deep and heavy track of the meeting, and the smallest fielH and the rainiest day were on deck this afternoon at Hialeah, but all was forgiven by the form players when a favorite at last got home in front.

Two important paintings have been bought from New York galleries by the City Art Museum of St. Louis, it was revealed yesterday. One is a canvas by the American artist, John Steuart Curry, called "The Mississippi." It was acquired through the Walker Galleries, 108 East Fifty-seventh Street.
President Roosevelt conferred with Senators and agricultural leaders on agricultural problems; with Admiral Grayson, chairman of, the Red Cross; on the flood situation;
The 108-day-old labor dispute at the J. I. Case Company's three plants here ended today when members of the United Automobile Workers of America ratified a compromise plan on wage demands.
Here are the important dates and events in the dispute between the United Automobile Workers of America and the General Motors Corporation:

Miss Margaret Crozer Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Errington Martin of Elkins Park, has selected April 3 as the date for her marriage to Joseph Coleman Bright, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bright of Cedar Hill Farm, Reading.

Miss. Hazel Evarts Depew, daughter of Mrs. Frank Depew of this place, was married this evening to Roger Pierce Holden, son of Mrs. Leon C. Holden, also of Montclair. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church here by the Rev.

Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for her daughter, Miss Marjorie McAlpin, and Calvin Wright Dail, whose marriage will take place today at the Colony Club.

A payment of $25,000 to Sam Krantz, fugitive gangster, magically produced a union contract for William Lowenstein, cafeteria chain owner, after negotiations with officials of the A. F. of L. and other large union bodies had been unsuccessful, he testified yesterday at the restaurant racket trial.

The Yale Gallery of Fine Arts announced today the opening of an exhibition of paintings, water-colors and etchings by Reginald Marsh, modern artist, who graduated from Yale in 1920. The exhibition will continue to March 4.
Assembly plants of the Chevrolet Motor Company and the Fisher Body Corporation, here, cannot resume operation for several days, it was said today.
Coast Guardsmen, whose acquaintance with weather conditions is generally undisputed, predicted yesterday that the metropolitan area was due for a cold- wave that may come and stay some time.

Secretary Morgenthau will be among the government officials and business men who will take part in round-table discussions at the second annual Harvard-Yale-Princeton conference on public affairs here Feb. 26 and 27, according to Charles M. Storey Jr., president of The Harvard Crimson.
The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today by three railroads to authorize the issuance of obligations totaling $13,102,000 to be used toward the purchase of new rolling stock.

Television pictures "painted" by 441 lines, instead of 345 lines as heretofore, were demonstrated today by the Philco Radio and Television Corporation in a test across three miles of the city to the Germantown Cricket Club.

President Getulio Vargas today signed the Maritime Freight Bill regulating rates for all shipping lines plying between Brazil and foreign countries. By this law shippers and steamship companies can enter into individual agreements, provided regular service is maintained.

Award of a new issue of $800,000 Upper Darby (Pa.) School District bonds, dated March 1, 1937, and due serially from 1938 to 1966, was made yesterday to a banking group comprising Graham, Parsons Co., Dougherty, Corkran Co., C. C.

Rules governing trade practices in the tubular piping and trimming industry, submitted by the Associated Manufacturers of Tubular Pipings and Trimmings, Inc., were promulgated tentatively today by the Federal Trade Commisison and March 1 was set as the date on which a hearing would be held, before the rules are made final.

For almost four years the yen has been standing at ls 2d in relation to the pound sterling without governmental control and Japan is content with stabilization at the present rate, Shoji Arakawa, new Japanese Financial Commissioner for London, Paris and New York, said in an interview here yesterday.

All banks and security and commodity markets in this city will be closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. The New Orleans Cotton Exchange, the Boston wool market and the naval stores markets at Savannah and Jacksonville will remain open, as will most of the fruit, vegetable and livestock markets, including the Chicago Livestock Exchange.

Employe and management representatives of eighteen district plants of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation joined tonight in recommending that the company establish a $5-a-day wage minimum, give its workers a raise of 80 cents a day and put them on a forty-hour work week.
Robert R. Pointer; who once received his own People's Progressive party nomination for President, died here today at the age of 75.

The winners in the Wood, Field and Stream snapshot contest, sponsored jointly by the National Sportsmen's Show and Wide World Photos, will be announced in THE NEW YORK TIMES next Wednesday. Today is the final day for submitting pictures.

Praise for the efforts and the fairness" of Governor Murphy of Michigan in the settlement of the automobile strike was reiterated by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, in his statement here yesterday on the corporation's position in the strike agreement.

Black Rapids Glacier, on the loose again after several years of quiet recession, shook huge ice blocks from its 200-foot face today and crept steadily toward a roadhouse a mile and a half down the valley.

Mrs. Stephen S. Wise, president of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress, announced yesterday that the division had sent a telegram to Dr. Stewart W. McClelland, president of Lincoin Memorial University,

A suit by eight members against officers of the Printing Pressmen's Union was settled yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo, by consent of the parties, appointed General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA administrator;

Reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission which were made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange disclosed that, under an agreement signed Jan. 7 last, Consolidated Laundries Company is to pay Arthur S. Jenkins, president and a director, $25,000 in salary and 5 per cent of the consolidated net profit of the company in excess of $200,000 a year.
Following is the text of Secretary Wallace's statement to the Senate Finance Committee today in support of extension of the Reciprocal Trading Agreements Act:

A man who was tentatively identified by papers in his possession as William J. Cammett, 40 years old, a World War veteran, was killed yesterday when he fell or jumped in front of a southbound Seventh Avenue express at Intervale Avenue on the White Plains line- of the I. R. T. in the Bronx.

Negotiations for the new agreement covering Germany's private foreign bank debts reached the bargaining stage today, with parties to the current "standstill" agreement seemingly deadlocked on the proposal for reduction of the present credit lines or part capital repayment.

For the first time in thirty-three years the New York Athletic Club lost a dual swimming meet last night as the perfectly balanced national collegiate champion combination from the University of Michigan pushed the Winged Footers off the victory path and did it with undue emphasis, winning by 47 to 28, at the club's pool.

The sitdown strikers who stalled the General Motors production machine and paralyzed the economic life of this city of 165,000 persons evacuated the three occupied plants late this afternoon and tonight.

The final settlement terms reached in the General Motors strikes, as compared with original union demands and the corporation's expressed position on them, were as follows: 1. United Automobile Workers Union is recognized as the collective bargaining agency for its members. (G. M. also agrees to conditional sole recognition of the union in twenty struck plants for six months.)

Stocks closed irregularly higher after strong opening, steel and motor shares up 1 to 4 points; turnover, 2,929,390 shares. United States Government bonds lower, South American issues higher, corporate loans irregular; transactions, $14,966,600.

Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada decreased $34,300 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement of the bank, issued today. Deposits of chartered banks were reduced $460,905.

A warning that possession of the Philippineswas a necessary' part of Japan's plan to dominate Asia, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt today fired a broadside of criticism at the colonial policy- of the United States, especially in the Far East.

Plans for considerable military expansion were reported from South Africa and Egypt today. According to The Cape Argus, the South African Government has begun a survey to discover how industry can be mobilized for war production.

Prominence is given in today's newspapers to speeches delivered in various parts of the capital by Constantine Kotzion Governor of Athens, in which Premier John Metaxas is praised as the embodiment of the leadership principle.

By a three-to-two decision the Orphans Court of Philadelphia ruled today that trustees, when receiving discretionary powers in wills, may properly invest the funds of an estate in common or preferred stocks.

Fordham's varsity baseball team will open its 1937 campaign on April 3 against St. Peter's College of Jersey City at Fordham Field, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Jack Coffey, who released the Maroon schedule for the coming season.

A meeting, which a few years ago was nearly always followed by major revision in one of America's great sports, starts today at the Seaview Golf Club in Absecon, N. J., when the members of the Football Rules Committee gather for the annual. gathering of that body.

With a patrolman eating a meal at a table twenty-five feet away, a soft-spoken girl robber held up the cashier of an upper Broadway restaurant during the early hours of yesterday morning and escaped with $20, the contents of the cash drawer.

For some time His Majesty's Opposition has had hard work to find something to oppose. First the Liberals and then the Conservatives prigged the policies of social welfare. For straight Socialist measures the trade unions that control the Labor party have no enthusiasm. Motions of want of confidence have to be brought in periodically, but they are perfunctory.

A committee headed by.Ernest L. Nye of Freeman Co. for the Georgia, Florida Alabama Railroad's first mortgage and refunding 6 per cent series A bonds, due .in 1952, announced yesterday that its deposit agreement had been changed to extend to Feb. 27, 1940, the time within which the committee may approve a plan for recapitalization of the comnany.
Word was received today of the death of Louis H. Brinkman, Glen Ridge engineer and inventor, at the home of his daughter, Mrs. ??. Webb Cocke of Birmingham, Ala.

Mayor La Guardia received yesterday from A. T. McCormack, State Health Commissioner and State director of flood relief in Kentucky, a telegram expressing thanks for his action in sending a group of trained sanitary engineers and bacteriologists to Louisville to aid in flood relief.

The text of the agreement between the United Automobile Workers Union and the General Motors Corporation which ended the forty-four-day automotive strike was as follows: Agreement entered into on this 11th day of February, 1937, between the General Motors Corporation (hereinafter referred to as the "corporation"), and the International Union, United Automobile Workers of America (hereinafter referred to as the "union"):

The Hosiery Industry Conference, which opened yesterday a two-day session at the Waldorf-Astoria, under the auspices of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers and other groups in the industry, declared itself in favor of "reasonable and practical Federally enforced legislation regulating hours, wages and fair trade practices in the industry."

Broadway's latest war, the one that flared last week when Walter Prichard Eaton withdrew as a sponsor of the Bureau of New Plays with talk of "commercial chicanery," reached a partial truce yesterday. From New Haven,

Frank P. McGlone, former business manager of the local truck drivers' union, and Emanuel Romm, an attorney and former candidate for Congress, were indicted by a special Federal grand jury here today on charges of extorting $5,000 from a truck corporation at Milton, Pa.

Dr. A. L. Threlkeld, superintendent of schools in Denver, Col., nationally known figure in American education, has been appointed superintendent of schools here, it was announced today by Richard T. Greene, president of the Montclair Board of Education.

Joseph B. Kerr, representative of the Association of American Railroads, denied today that repeal of the "long-and-short-haul" clause of the Interstate -Commerce - Act would cause a rate war betwen rail and water transportation lines.

Miss. Hazel Evarts Depew, daughter of Mrs. Frank Depew of this place, was married this evening to Roger Pierce Holden, son of Mrs. Leon C. Holden, also of Montclair. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Dr. Robert C. Williamson, pastor of the Upper Montclair Presbyterian Church, assisted by the rector, the Rev. James T. Lodge.

A three-day suspension of the cabaret license of the Bali Restaurant Corporation, night club at 161-63 East Fifty-fourth Street, was ordered yesterday as the result of a police inquiry into a "sit-down strike" staged in the club by a group of college students. in protest against parental objections to late hours.

" Conquest of nature "-how often do we bandy the words and preen ourselves on our triumph over the wilderness. A careful reading of the report of the Great Plains Committee cannot but humble us. That admirably written document makes it all too evident that nature is not to be conquered.
A twelve-acre parcel of land adjoining the Manhattan Beach section of Long Island has been sold by the Long Island Railroad Company. The plot,

An early advance today of 1 cent a bushel in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here and of 1 1/2 cents in Winnipeg which carried prices up to the high levels of yesterday was followed by a gradual decline, due to pressure from houses with Eastern connections and to evening up for the holiday in United States markets tomorrow.

Mrs. Lawrence J. Mead and Mrs. Louis G. Smith, real estate, in 654 Madison Av.; Berman Braunstein, Inc., men's suits; Empire Textile Corp.. upholstery fabrics: B. Shackman Co., Inc., novelties; Buckmann Manufacturing Co., Inc., novelties, in 40 E. 21st St.; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker.
A meeting to plan for safeguarding of oil storage tanks in areas which might be subjected to flood was held here yesterday at the suggestion of the National Board of Fire .Underwriters.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, indicated yesterday that he would have something to say in the future about President Roosevelt's proposal to revamp the Federal judicial system, but for the time being he intends to remain silent.

Dr. William Dwight Tracy, noted dental surgeon, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack in his home, 1,170 Fifth Avenue. His age was 53. The New York State Dental Society had voted to present to Dr. Tracy next Spring the William Jarvie Gold Medal for conspicuous service to dentistry.

Eleven Columbia University graduates will receive medals for "conspicuous alumni service" when they return to Morningside Heights today to participate in Columbia's thirtieth annual Lincoln Day alumni celebration.

After heated debate, the Indiana Legislature today endorsed President Roosevelt's proposal regarding the Supreme Court when the House, on strictly party lines, approved, 74 to 19, a resolution adopted by the Senate yesterday. Copies were ordered sent to Indiana members of Congress.

A labor spy subpoenaed by the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage not only has been "contacted" in the committee room during the past week by Pinkerton detectives, but has been closeted in a hotel room for an hour with two Pinkerton officers in the hope of learning why he had been summoned, a Pinkerton officer testified at today's hearings.

This town with the complicated name situated twenty-five miles from Warsaw has acquired a certain if unenviable notoriety in Poland because it was the scene of one ot the bigger pogroms several months ago.
The Rev. Dr. John MacNeill, principal of the faculty of theology at McMaster University here, died yesterday at his home. He was 63 years old.

A State-wide investigation of National Guard affairs loomed today following disclosures of alleged discrepancies in the accounts of the Guard at the Brooklyn Arsenal, which now are being investigated by the United States authorities and which already have resulted in the indictment of one National Guard officer.

Joseph P. Dumesnil, vice president of the Carter Dry Goods Company, Louisville, for he last sixteen years, was yesterday elected president, succeeding his father, Harry Dumesnil, who died last week. He is also an officer of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute.

Chinatown ushered in yesterday the year 4641. Five thousand celebrants watched a four-hour parade through the narrow streets of the quarter and rejoiced in the passing of another year that has brought closer their dream of a unified China.

Major Green was convicted of first-degree murder in Queens County Court at 8:34 o'clock last night, barely more than an exact month since the body of Mrs. Mary Harriet Case was found in her apartment at 37-06 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose in the last week from 138.1 (revised) to 140.2 on Tuesday, a level last touched on Jan. 7, 1930. The rise was led by wheat, steers and the petroleum group. Losses included hogs and hams.
Archie Munro Pickup, head of a printing business well known in New York for many years, died yesterday morning in Veterans Facility Hospital, the Bronx. He was 63 years old.

Larry Kelley, Yale's All-America end and the nemesis of several Princeton athletic teams, intends to invade the halls of Old Nassau next Fall to do graduate work, it was revealed today in an interview which appeared in The Daily Princetonian.

Robert M. McTeigue of 16 East Ninetyeighth Street, New York, was designated by the War Department today from the Seventeenth Congressional District for the Military Academy entrance examination March 2.
The strike in the automobile industry was a struggle of more than forty days, marked by more apprehension than violence, more threats than action, and a multitude of conferences.

Isabel Hermoso, Venezuelan soprano, made her local debut in a song recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. An audience of good size, made up largely of her compatriots, responded warmly to the typically Iberian singing. Many flowers were passed over the footlights to her at the conclusion of the first half of her program.

Consolidation of the two committees representing landlords of the United Cigar Stores Company of America was announced yesterday. The committee headed by Peter Grimm added to its membership the members of the other committee, who were Edward Wise of J. S. Bache Co., John Sloan of Sloan Robertson and Jakob Goldschmidt.

Moved by protests in Parliament against "intrusions by certain newspapers upon the privacy of individuals in gathering news," the Newspaper Society and the boards of the Press Association and the Reuters News Agency have adopted resolutions in similar terms expressing disapproval of methods that "violate the

The trial of the three men accused of kidnapping Paul H. Wendel took an unexpected turn yesterday, apparently equally distressing to both the prosecution and the defense. County Judge Fitzgerald in Brooklyn dismissed the minor count of assault, on which the defendants had based hopes for leniency, and ruled that the trial must continue on the much more serious charge of kidnapping.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be -at the lowest point of the year to date. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."
Insurgen cavalry tonight swept across the Jarama River toward an important junction of supply roads southeast of Madrid.

Four of the standout two-milers of the country-the Rideout twins of Texas, Wayne and Blaine, and the racing twins from Indiana, Don Lash and Tommy Deckard-yesterday entered their specialty at the New York Athletic Club's annual track and field carnival in Madison Square Garden a week from tomorrow night.

Young Frank Iannicelli of the New York A. C., a freshman at New York University, recorded one of the principal triumphs of his squash tennis career yesterday, defeating Vincent Furno of the Columbia University Club in the fivegame final of the Monte Sterling Trophy tourney' at the New' York A. C.
This civil war with its international complications is so vast that it overwhelms the individuals taking part in it. But here is one of the innumerable personal tragedies of life in Spain today:

A new set of standards to enable investors of saving and trust funds to distinguish good railroad bonds from bad, was reported yesterday at the closing session of the midwinter trust conference ot the American Bankers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and was received with such interest by an attendance of 400 that the mimeograph department of the association suffered a run for immediate copies which it was not able to supply.

Malaga has changed its face. Now it looks like any other Insurgent city; bill posters have caused the metamorphosis. An army of these workers has managed to cover up most of the Leftist bills with the Insurgent product, even washing out some of those repainted proletarian slogans that adorned most houses and factory walls hereabouts when the army came in on Monday.

Mrs. Louis Reeves, frail and wan for her 56 years, was wheeled into County Court this afternoon and faced Chang Soo Lee, Korean house servant charged with feeding her poison. Her husband, 60, a tall man, who hunted gold in the 1898 rush to Alaska, hobbled in on a crutch and spent the afternoon on the witness stand describing how he, too, suffered from poison. Mrs. Reeves will testify Monday.

Retail prices recorded the greatest monthly advance in January since September, 1933, according to the Fairchild Index issued yesterday. Quotations on Feb. 1 averaged 1.4 per cent higher than on Jan. 2 and were also 5.3 per cent higher than on Feb. 1 a year ago.

RUDYARD KIPLING; in Wednesday's section of his autobiography, laid down the strict law of conduct, "Take "nothing for granted if you can check "it." He tells the story of how he and his friend, a distinguished scientist, raided the Kipling chicken yard.
The Treasury's ledgers showed today that if the nation's 129,000,000 inhabitants united to wipe out the Federal debt it would cost them $267.36 each.
Yesterday our Mr. MATTHRWS was in a position to report that the highway from Madrid to Valencia is still passable.

The human brain, in spite of the fact that it has been evolving for millions of years, is still far from a finished product, and its future development holds out the bright promise of vastly increased brain power with which mankind may assail its difficulties, Dr. Frederick Tilney, one of the foremost authorities on the evolution of the brain, declared last night in a paper presented before 1,000 persons at the Academy of Medicine.

Lumber production last week was sharply lower when an increase is seasonal and the adjusted index has dropped to 59.1 from 68.6 in the previous week, comparing with 79.8 for the week ended Feb. 8. 1936.

The Gross-Morton Corporation, builders, who have been active in developments in Laurelton and Bayside Hills, have purchased the twenty-seven-acre Klein farm, between Fresh Meadow Road and the Fresh Meadow Country Club, on the south side of Black Stump Road, Jamaica-Hillcrest, Queens.

Organization of the Manhattan chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards was perfected yesterday at a meeting of real estate men, formerly individual members of the national body, held yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore.
The water-driven grist mill where Abraham Lincoln once worked and the dam which caused his first visit to the village of New Salem are to be restored to actual working conditions.

A claim for forty yards of velvet as a "fee" from King George VI was gravely allowed to the Earl of Ancaster, Britain's Lord Great Chamberlain, by the commissioners of the Court of Coronation Claims today.

The Thomas Cadmus Home at 233 Ashland Avenue, Bloomfield, N. J., known by old residents of Bloomfield as Washington's headquarters, has been purchased by Melvin D. Greer from the Howard Savings Institution.

Approximately 66,000 more men were employed in the steel industry at the close of 1936 than were at work during 1929, according to estimates made by the American Iron and Steel Institute based on reports from companies employing approximately 95 per cent of the industry's workers.

The Alleghany Corporation, formerly the top company in the Van Sweringen railway-holding structure, issued 2,533 of its $2.50 prior preferred cumulative convertible preferred shares between Dec. 31, 1935, and Jan. 31 last in settlement of $126,650 of debts, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday.

The committee of industrial legislation of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association recommended today the creation of a government agency which would enforce agreements voluntarily made by various industrial groups.

Thirty-one meets, beginning March 18 at Pinehurst, N. C., and ending at Montpelier, Va., Nov. 20, and covering sesslons throughout the Atlantic States, have been scheduled by the hunts committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, it was made known yesterday.

An optimistic communique has been issued by the Soviet Foreign Office, stating that after an exchange of views on Finnish-Soviet relations and the international situation by Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff and Dr. Rudolf Holsti, Finnish Foreign Minister, it is felt:

Two men high in the ranks of Soviet leadership were mentioned prominently today as reported subjects of GPU (secret police) investigation, while informed Russians and foreign residents discussed renewed police activity in the wake of the recent Trotskyist conspiracy trial.

Governor Lehman signed the House bill extending the life of the Mastick Tax Law Revision Commission until April 15. In the Senate, Thomas C. Desmond, Orange Republican, introduced his resolution calling upon the Legislature to memorialize Congress to reject President Roosevelt's judiciary reform program.

Miss Mary C. Webster, daughter of Mrs. Anselm Webster of 165 Bard Avenue, Staten Island, and the late Mr. Webster, was married last night to Herbert Lloyd Schuttler, son of Frederick Schuttler of Hempstead, L. I., and the late Mrs. Schuttler. The ceremony was performed in the Chelsea Presbyterian
Commodity futures advanced sharply on a broad front yesterday. Settlement of the General Motors strike enabled the industrial staples to make substantial gains with other commodities.

Louis E. Felix of Goldsmith Felix, counsel for Sunset Gold Fields, Inc., consented yesterday to issuance of a stop order by the Securities, and Exchange Commission to prevent further sale of the company's stock to the public. His action brought to a close a threeday hearing before William V. Holohan as trial examiner in which the SEC has: charged that the mining company mad false statements in its application for registration.
Fighting for a play-off berth, the Chicago Black Hawks gained on the idle Boston Bruins tonight by upsetting the New Ybrk Rangers, 5 to 2, in a fast National Hockey League battle before 7,500 fans.

Julia Laird, former film actress, has arrived here to establish residence for divorce action against John Kirkland, playwright, co-author of "Tobacco Road. She retained counsel and will file in six weeks.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a proposal to transfer a membership from Alan L. Corey to Henry Arden, who will become a general partner in the firm of Granberry Co. The consideration was $110,000. Mr. Corey,
Johnny Cabello, 129 3/4, Puerto Rican lightweight, won on points from Dominick Barone,1301/2, East Sider, in the feature eight-round bout at the Star Casino last night before 2,500 spectators.

Having tasted good running last week-end, metropolitan skiers will have to live in memories this holiday week-end unless the much-desired snow arrives today or tomorrow as skiing conditions in general in the East are poor at present.

Amelia Earhart announced yesterday her intention of flying around the world within the next month. Miss Earhart, who is Mrs. George Palmer Putnam in private life, said that on the first lap of the 27,000mile air journey she wou be accompanied by Captain Harry Manning, veteran merchant marine officer of the United States Lines, who will be her navigator as far as Sydney. Australia.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Warland Wight of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Wight, to Charles Beaman Lakin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C Lakin of Greenwich, Conn.

The New York University swimming team yesterday triumphed over the Fordham mermen, 39 to 32, in the Maroon pool to win their seventh dual meet against the Rams in twelve starts since the two Bronx rivals began their rivalry.

The assets of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company last year rose to $375,000,000, a gain of $32,000,000 over 1935, according to the annual report presented at the annual meeting at Boston on Wednesday by George Willard

The fortieth anniversary of the graduation of the class of 1897 from the Naval Academy will be observed in May. by the unveiling of a memorial to the class, which will take the form of a limestone exedra.

Mrs. D. Buchanan Merryman of Washington, aunt of Mrs. Wallis Simpson, returned on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia yesterday after a visit with her niece at the Cannes villa of Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Rogers. Mrs. Merryman's name was not on the Savoia's list and officers of the ship denied for a while that she was on board.

The engagement of Miss Virginia Moore, 22-year-old former Bennettsville girl whose brunette beauty won her a job as a New York model, to McClelland Barclay, the magazine-cover illustrator, was announced here tonight by her parents.
Dr. Louis Leroy returned to his practice last night after directing the rescue of 13,500 flood-marooned farmers with his "mosquito fleet."

The Brooklyn Edison Company, Inc., in its annual report for 1936, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $10,416,734, equivalent to $8.34 a share on the outstanding capital stock of the companY, exeluding shares in its treasury. This compared with a net income for 1935 of $10.708,475, or $8.57 a share on the outstanding stock at that time.

The Federal Mining and Smelting Company, a subsidiary of the American Smelting and Refining Company, last year wrote down property account by $1,797,265 and charged that amount to surplus, according to a statement filed by the parent company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The first of a series of three volumes on big corporations and their place in American life will be published on Monday by the Twentieth Century Fund under the title, "Big Business: Its Growth and Its Place."
Scoring double victories, Frank Allan of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and Pete Harris of Miami advanced to the final of the annual Dixie golf championship at the Miami Country Club today.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Ludington of Philadelphia, among those entertraining at the Bath Club today, had as luncheon guests Mrs. Coleman Brown and Mrs. Mortimer Wilson of Philadelphia and W. C. Johnson of New York.

The Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest offers a $100 grand prize and fifty honorable mention prizes of $5 each for the best photographs of outdoor life (except athletic contests and games) taken by amateurs.

As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house the vacant plot at the southwest corner of the Grand Concourse and 182d Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by Reliance Equities, Inc., Leo Silver, president. The property fronts 154.9 feet on the Concourse and 84.6 feet on the street and was acquired through Darling McDonald, brokers. Joseph Howard Katz,
In the course of a press conference this afternoon on the agreement with the United Automobile Workers of America, William S. Knudsen, executive- vice president of General Motors, said:

Gus Poulis, 34 years old, who surrendered to the Department of Justice last week, pleaded guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe to an indictment charging him with conspiracy, possession and transportation of twelve stolen government treasury notes worth $70,000 across State lines.

The Rev. Bartholomew Hartwell, well known in Catholic circles for his many articles in Catholic publications and a former teacher of church history in St. Mary's Theological Seminary, died today at the rectory of St. Mary's Church at Govans, near here, where he had been pastor since 1915.

Former Governor Alf M. Landon, Republican standard-bearer in the 1936 Presidential campaign, arrived in New York yesterday morning, accompanied by Mrs. Landon. He will speak tonight at the annual Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Scientists examined an overcoat tonight for bloodstains, while detectives questioned a girl and a youth in connection with the slaying of Mary Ellen Babcock, 18. Police were spurred in their hunt for the girl's slayer by reports of new attacks on two women and a girl.

Both branches of Congress today rushed through a bill setting up the Disaster Loan Corporation, as a subsidiary of the Renconstruction Finance Corporation, charged with lending up to $20,000,000 to victims of disasters during 1937 for their rehabilitation.

Imports of gold in January were $121,336,253, more than double those for the same month a year ago. The Department of Commerce said today the total compared with $57,069,644 in December and $45,980,918 in January, 1936. Gold exports last month were $11,218, compared with $99,188 in December and $337,997 in January, 1936.
Representatives of General Motors signed today's strike peace pact with a fountain pen borrowed from the first vice president of the United Automobile Workers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me there have been too many broad statements made by socalled air officials, aviation experts and old-time pilots who are not connected with air lines or air line flying.

Evidence that death overtook them as they struggled in the submerged wreckage of a skyliner came tonight from autopsy examinations of four of the eleven persons who died when a transport plane plunged into the waters of San Francisco Bay Tuesday night.

A bill imposing a 5 per cent tax on all wagers at the New York tracks was introduced today by Assemblyman Harold P. Herman, Nassau Republican. Mr. Herman estimated that the proposed levy would net the State as much as $3,000,000 a year.

The New Mexico Legislature ratified the proposed child labor amendment to the Federal Constitution today, the twenty-seventh State to take such action. The Senate voted 14 to 10 and the House 27 to 17. Ratification came after a stormy, two-hour Senate session.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is moulding its regulations into a barrier against the use of "local pressure" in procuring charters for State banks.

Livingston Gifford, New York patent lawyer and senior partner of the firm of Gifford, Scull Burgess, 141 Broadway, died here today at the Marlborough-Blenheim Hotel after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived at 290 Park Avenue in New York.

Mr. and Mrs. Remsen-Johnson of The Towers, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Remsen Johnson, to Roland von Goeben, son of Mrs. Herman Behr of 445 Riverside Drive and the late Carl K. von Goeben.
Augustus S. May, retired treasurer of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, died of a heart ailment this afternoon at his home after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

The Arnold Bernstein liner Ilsenstein will arrive today from Antwerp. Her passengers include Dr. and Mrs. Ernst Blumenthal, Dr. Paul Caspari, Erwin Dallmann, Emil Hamberger, the Rev. Josef Lanz, Mr. and Mrs. Simon Moseslio, Mrs. Gwen Robertson, Eugene Stauder and Mrs. Louise Werberbauer.

Six persons died today when a tri-motored army plane, cut off from a near-by landing field by a curtain of driving snow, crashed into a crowded Berlin market place, caromed off a trolley car and burst into flames near a cage of circus lions.
Captain Thor Eckert, director and United States manager of the Arnold Bernstein and Red Star steamship lines, yesterday issued the following statement:

Prevailing minimum wages in the men's underwear industry, including both knit and woolen garments, were discussed at a hearing today before the Public Contracts Board of the Department of Labor, which reserved decision.

Excited dealings in transatlantics following on news of the settlement of the automobile strike were the feature of an otherwise hesitant stock market session today. General Motors and Chrysler both advanced sharply, and United States Steel touched a new high.

Crown Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard arrived here this evening and took a suite of rooms in the Hotel Bristol. The couple came from Budapest in a small sports car, the Prince and Princess alternately driving.
Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, issued the following statement today on the granting of a pay rise to all company workers:

The nation's first major labor dispute in the automobile industry ended at noon today when representatives of General Motors Corporation and the International Union, United Automobile Workers of America, signed an agreement terminating the forty-four-day strike which had crippled the production of automobiles by the corporation.

A Currier Ives large folio colored lithograph, "Home to Thanksgiving," brought $950 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction of lithographs and paintings. The buyer was the Michaelsen Galleries.

Senator Ellender of Louisiana said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission had informed him that the recent sale of an $85,000,000 Canadian Government bond issue in this country did not violate the Johnson Act forbidding defaulting debtor nations to float loans here.

Welcoming the enactment by the New York Legislature of the Social Security Bill, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, declared yesterday that the measure would make effectual in this State all the provisions of the Federal Social Security Act. This foreshadows,

Temporary Assignments For 13 days, from 8 A. M., Feb. 16: LIEUTENANTS--Frederick P. Bayer, from 34th Precinct to 5th Division, assigned to duty as supervisor of patrol in uniform. Frank Fristensky Jr., from 109th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad, Queens, assigned to duty in Traffic Court.

" Our home-breds are up to Hiuropean breeding in most instances and, I believe, we have surpaased them in Welsh terriers," is the opinion of Oliver C. Harriman, international judge who is officiating at the Westminster. He is a cousin of E. Roland Harriman who has helped make the American trotting horse the best in the world.

The crew of the American Hawaiian Line freighter Columbian yesterday awaited permission of officials of the Sailors Union of the Pacific to accept the continuous discharge books which a new Federal law provides crews must have before their ships can depart from port.

Governor LEHMAN has won a complete victory for his State social security program. The only cause for regret is that the victory was so long in coming. A handful of the Republicans who had opposed his program a year ago made a brave show of consistency by voting against it again, but their arguments were singularly hollow.

With many Democratic members of both the State Senate and Assembly not in accord with President Roosevelt's plan to reform the Federal judiciary, the Senate witnessed today the first move from the Republican side of the house to have the Legislature of President's home State go on record in protest against the proposal.

John Edward Mullins of New York has been divorced at Grasse by his wife, Silvia Marietta Jose of Villa Notre Dame, Cap Antibes, for desertion. He is a son of Mrs. John Henry Mullins of New York and London.

Albert Weber, Conrad Frisch and Emil Winter believe they have made some sort of record for picketing. They paused in their perambulations today to say they had been pacing up and down the sidewalk in front of a North Side hotel for about three years.

The proposed amendment to the Multiple Dwelling Law giving the Tenement House Commissioner the right to repair old-law tenements and levy assessments as first liens against the property for the costs and to provide a revolving fund for this purpose through the sale of bonds received the approval of Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, at a hearing yesterday before the City Housing Authority.
There are 296 "millionaires" in Great Britain, according to "the Statistical Abstract for the United Kingdom" just issued. This class officially includes persons with incomes exceeding [Pound]50,000.
Germany, engrossed in her own great rearmament, received today from Great Britain a significant warning, of what an aggression, should it affect British rights and possessions, would have to meet.

What looked at first sight like a startling announcement appeared in today's Izvestia toward the end of a long article by Vassily Bluecher, generalissimo of the Far Eastern Red Army, commemorating the fifteenth anniversary of the Volochaievsk victory.

Three seeded players scored second-round victories yesterday to enter the quarter-finals of the Whitehall Club invitation squash tennis tourney. They were Frank A. Sieverman 3d and Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A. C. and Franklin V. Brodil of the Columbia University Club, who are rated Nos. 2, 3 and 8 respectively in the seeded list.

The following from the President's message to Congress accompanying the judiciary bill discloses, but only in part, a long-standing abuse, and evidence of the urgent need for revolutionary reforms affecting jurisdiction and procedure of the Supreme Court.

The Dutch Reformed Church has formed a committee to repatriate Argentine Boersthe body of Boers who left South Africa after the Anglo-Boer War and settled in Argentina. They have not prospered, and about sixty families wish to return.
A new chapter in the history of figure skating will be opened when the national championships start officially at the Chicago Arena tomorrow morning.

General Motors Corporation agrees: To recognize the United Automobile Workers as bargaining agent for its members. Not to bargain on "matters of general corporate policy" with any other group from twenty struck plants without Governor Murphy's sanction. Not to discriminate against members of the union or the union in favor of any other group. To drop court proceedings in the sit-down strikes.

The dominant fact which emerges from the automobile strike settlement is that Mr. LEWIS has failed to establish his union as the " sole " bargaining agency in the plants of the General Motors Corporation. To be sure,

Stockholders of the Interlake Iron Corporation approved yesterday a plan for reduction of capital, paving the way for an issue of $10,000,000 of convertible debentures, the proceeds of which are to be used to retire underlying debt on May 1.

THE belligerents are throwing fast ones in the holdout alley now. The Yankee situation is baffling. First Colonel Ruppert pitches and Lou Gehrig catches. Then Gehrig pitches and the doughty colonel catches. Without getting into the direct line of fire, it might be pointed out that Colonel Ruppert rather has Columbia Lou in a neat hole fashioned by the first baseman himself.

Dartmouth's hockey team lost a thrilling 2-1 game to Queen's University of Ontario tonight, but the Green showed a marked reversal of form, playing one of its best games of-the year against the highly favored Canadians.

Construction of the permanent Edison Memorial Tower, a 135-foot shaft on the site where the inventor developed the first incandescent lamp at Menlo Park, N. J., will begin "as soon as the earth thaws," it was announced yesterday at a luncheon of 200 members- of the Edison Pioneers at the Hotel Astor in celebration of the ninetieth birthday anniversary of Thomas Alva Edison.
The ninth annual entertainment and reception of Strykers Lane Community Center will be held to night at the American Women's Association Clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Devastating bowling. by W. H. Copson, Derbyshire pro, 'featured the touring Marylebone Cricket Club's victory over a New South Wales eleven by an innings andl140 runs today The visiting team miiade 380riuns yesterday In the two-say match, their opponents being dismissed today for 162 and 78.

A group of Italian journalists who were expelled from a meeting of the League of Nations Assembly in 1936 for a demonstration against the Emperor of Ethiopia declined today to accept a monetary prize for their act.

Investigation of the importation of foreign capital, regarded as dangerous from the point of view of inflation of credit in this country, has reached a point where Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau today called a meeting for Monday at 10 A. M. with Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which may lead to Executive action.
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh came to this North African city today from Sicily for a visit with Marshal Italo Balbo, Governor of Libya.

Abraham Lincoln High School's basketball team tightened its grip at the top- in Section 2 of the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. championship race and remained the only unbeaten outfit in the borough by top ping James Madison High, 27-21,1 at Madison yesterday. The victory was the eighth in a row in the tournament for Lincoln.

A wooded tract of twenty-five acres near Sheldon Avenue, in Tarrytown, Westchester, has been sold by the Gracemere Holding Corporation to Dr. Leo Price of New York. There are three bungalows on the land, which Dr. Price proposes to develop for his own occupancy. George Howe, Inc., was the broker.
Postmaster General Farley was sworn in for his second term as Postmaster General today, .in a brief ceremony in his office, attended largely by members of the Postoffice Department.

Michael J. O'Neill, senior at Fordham College, won the annual prize of the Mimes and Mummers undergraduate playwriting contest for the second successive year with the presentation last night of his one-act drama of the Black and Tan rebellion in Ireland, "The Faith of Our Fathers."

Public hearings on the $436,000,000 transit unification plan sponscored by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr., were unofficially closed yesterday by the Transit Commisssion. The hearings began Sept. 10, 1936.

The Duke of Windsor keeps Vienna guessing as to his social and political views. When here in 1935 as Prince of Wales, he insisted, to the discomfiture of Clerical and Fascist circles, in visiting Karl Marx Hof, the three-quarter-mile-long block of ultramodern workingmen's dwellings built by the former Socialist regime and shattered by Fascist and Heimwehr shells in the counter-revolution of 1934 that overthrew the Socialist regime.

The Philippines' foreign trade last year made substantial gains, the Department of Commerce reported today. Exports were valued at $136,450,000, an increase of 45 per cent over 1935, and imports amounted to $101,125,000, an advance of 18 per cent.

Mock alarm lest six Maine Republican legislators bearing a protest to Congress- against President Roosevelt's proposed court reform be held in Washington as "undesirable aliens" was raised in the Maine Legislature today.

Champions tumbled during the second day of the Westminster Kennel Club's annual exhibition in Madison Square Garden yesterday. Defeats of veterans and the appearance of youngsters characterized the early sessions.

In a drive to reduce the rapidly mounting calendars in Special Sessions, the justices of that court unanimously voted at a meeting yesterday to increase the court sessions in Manhattan ten and onehalf hours weekly.

The Rev. Herbert Cookman Withey, a pioneer Methodist Episcopal missionary in Angola, Portuguese West Africa, and a philologist who was an authority on the Kimbundu language, died on Tuesday in Malange, Angola, according to word received here yesterday.

James J. Braddock's return to Hell's Kitchen to make a speech to the youngsters in the district where he lived as a boy ended yesterday afternoon with the heavyweight boxing champion having to use literally all of his fistic prowess to defend himself from the admiring throng.
James Torr Harmer, retired railroad executive, formerly with the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, died last night at the Winchester Hospital. He was in his eighty-first year.

Although production in Canada has been somewhat handicapped in recent weeks by climatic conditions, many economic factors show a definite improvement over a year ago and give rise to a conservative optimism for this year, according to A. E. Arscott, genoral manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

Steel and motor shares were buoyant in a sharply selective stock market yesterday, in which trading at times outdistanced the stock tickers, with a favorable reaction from the settlement of the General Motors strike the principal influence on the day's trading.

Winning the first heat and placing second in the second for an aggregate time of 5 minutes 8.5 seconds, Great Britain's team today captured the world four-man bobsled championships as American entries finished third and fifth.

Daisy Hill Farm, the secluded little "kingdom" on Cleveland's outskirts from which the late Van Sweringen brothers, O. P. and M. J., commanded a railroad empire in the quiet atmosphere that they cherished, had a "for sale" sign on it today.

James J. McEntee, acting director of. emergency conservation work, rejected today a proposal to transfer the old Civilian Conservation Corps camp at Smiths Mills, N. J., to Passaic County for a health camp.

Weakness in the underlying bonds of domestic corporations as well as in United States Government loans more than offset the sharp gains recorded in a few convertible and secondary issues in the corporate section in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Two fires broke out in this section of Long Island tonight, one here and the other in Merrick. Little damage was caused by either. Captain Howard Almedo of the local department was injured when he fell through a skylight, but after receiving treatment from a physician continued on duty.
Kelvinator Corporation officials disclosed today that $8,500,000 worth of collateral paper, cash and irreplaceable documents were in its main office building, which is held by "stay-in" strikers.

Premier Leon Blum, addressing the assembled workers of the National Building Trades Union today, associated the prompt opening of the International Exposition here May 1 with the honor of the Popular Front itself.

A falling off in receipts of hogs more than offset further weakness in the fresh pork market and prices generally were 5 to 10 cents higher than yesterday. The best hogs sold at $10.35 a hundredweight. The day's average was up 5 cents at $10.15.

Public health officers who conferred at City Hall yesterday with Mayor La Guardia set up a board of five members to pass upon the qualifications of public health officers and report them to the United States Conference of Mayors.

The special committee appointed by President Roosevelt to study farm tenancy completed its labors today after adopting a report calling his attention to the fact that fewer than half of the farmers of the nation own the land they operate and that "rural civilization is threatened with decadence."

More than 20,000 Catholics today took possession of eleven churches in the town of Orizaba in the State of Veracruz after Governor Miguel Aleman had ordered them closed at 8 A. M. under pressure from Leftists.

Ice on Lake Musconetcong, at Netcong, N. J., finally reached a condition yesterday that was about perfect for boating, and preparations were made to hold the North American Class B championship there tomorrow and Sunday. Even the weather report was favorable for a change, the prediction of snow being dropped and that of.a slowly rising temperature not being held to affect the altitude lake.

Among those who will have boxes for the performance of "Die Meistersinger" this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York are Dr. William Allan Neilson, president of the college, and Mrs. Neilson:

Among the apartment rentals reported yesterday was one of eighteeen rooms and seven baths in 630 Park Avenue to Harry Ittleson Jr., vice president of the Commercial Investment Trust Company. Pease Elliman, Inc., negotiated the lease through the Carpenter Realty Company. Other apartment leases were:
Al Casimini, Corona lightweight, knocked out Jack Stanley, Bay Ridge welterweight, in 2:56 of the first session in the feature bout scheduled for ten rounds at Henderson's Flatbush Arena last night.

Contributions to the flood-relief fund being raised by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross reached a total of $1,632,822, it was announced yesterday by General Robert C. Davis, executive director. The gifts received yesterday aggregated $17,488.
With that facility in recovery that Chinese cities have achieved from years of repeated civil wars, Sian has quickly achieved almost normal conditions following its surrender by rebellious forces.

The world's greatest copper smelter, according to A. P. Serebrovsky, Vice Commissar of Heavy Industry, will begin operation before the end of March. It is on the northern shore of Lake Ballkhash in Western Kazakstan, Siberia.

Engineers fought a 20-mile-anhour current in the Niagara River today to extend the cribwork for a weir, which they said would help to halt erosion of Niagara Falls. The obstruction will extend 750 feet into the stream from the Canadian shore, opposite Goat Island.

President Roosevelt moved with greater vigor today to head off an incipient Congressional revolt against his judiciary reform proposals, particularly the one permitting him to remake the Supreme Court with more "liberal" personnel.

Opposing views toward the Dickstein bill to limit the appearance of foreign musicians in this country were expressed here yesterday. Declaring that the proposed bill would "throttle a great art," the Concerts Association of America, a recently formed organization of managers, announced it would send a representative to oppose the bill at a hearing Wednesday in Washington.

Pope Pius XI, reported in good spirits despite damp weather which brought intermittent pain to his legs, celebrated today the eighth anniversary of the Lateran Accord and rejoiced over the Spanish Fascist capture of Malaga.
Settlement of the automobile strike was a factor in the trading in cotton yesterday and, in sympathy with the upturn in outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 7 points.

With the Giants moving serenely toward their Havana sailing date and even the Dodgers coming up with a contract signer and otherwise showing no great concern for the future, it remained for the Yankees yesterday to capture the spotlight once more in baseball's waning off-season.

Bank clearings for the twentytwo leading cities throughout the nation totaled $5,620,866,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This repsentss an increase of 29.4 per cent over the $4,345,145,000 in the corresponding week last year, which included only five days.

The glee clubs of Elmira and Union Colleges will give a joint concert on Feb. 19 at the WaldorfAstoria. Kirsten Flagstad, Metropolitan Opera soprano, will give a recital tomorrow evening at McMillin Theatre, Columbia University.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick McEwan of this city and Convent, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Vreeland McEwan, to Lewin B. Barringer, son of Mrs. Daniel Moreau Barringer of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Barringer.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson announced this afternoon that he had decided definitely to ban the showing of the play "Mulatto" in this city. "Mulatto" was to have opened Monday night at the Locust Street Theatre.
A day spent in typically German towns on this side of the Czech border illuminates the situation that stands out today, as Austria did yesterday, as the focal point of irritation in Central Europe.

Transfer of a regular New York Curb Exchange membership from William M. Carson Jr. to Linsly R. Williams Jr. of Blair S. Williams Co. has been approved. Chester A. Braman of Delafield Delafield has been elected an associate member of the Curb Exchange.
The stock market reflected yesterday gratification but not necessarily exultance over the news of the signing of peace terms in the General Motors strike.
John A. Kelly, State political figure and an early campaigner against the prohibition amendment, died in Fitkin Memorial Hospital here last night. He was 65 years of age. His home was in Belmar.

The annual report for 1936 of the McCrory Stores Corporation, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $2,436,168 after depreciation, amortization, interest, ordinary taxes and provision of $154,284 for flood loss last year.
All bond issue measures pending before the Assembly Will be discussed at a public hearing conducted by the Ways and Means Committee Feb. 24, it was announced today by Chairman Moffat.
The government program for Poland's political reorganization, long-heralded and long-delayed, is now to be outlined before a committee of the Sejm tomorrow.

The Fascist and anti-Semitic Iron Guard today exploited the return to Rumania of the bodies of two of its members, Dr. John Motza and Dr. Basil Marin, killed with the Spanish Rebel forces, for big political demonstrations.

Trade in chain stores in January was the best for that month in any year since the start of the depression, according to the compilation released yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc. The first twenty-five chains to report did an aggregate business of $167,300,394, compared with $145,334,179 in the corresponding month last year.

The Securities and Exchange Commission amended today, effective immediately, its "Form E-1" by permitting the financial statements required from bank subsidiaries and banks to be issued in the form used by these institutions to report to the Federal or State authorities.

A legislative program calling for an augmented plan of State assistance for the treatment of cancer was announced today by the Republican State Committee. The program would call for construction of three new cancer hospitals.

Alfred E. Volckman, 21-year-old choir violinist, who attacked and stabbed to death Helen Glenn, 9, daughter of a Greenville (N. Y.) minister, was put to death at Sing Sing prison tonight. He entered the chair at 11 o'clock and was dead at 11:03. The youth walked into the death chamber with the Protestant chaplain, the Rev. Anthony Petersen.
The operation of the Panama Canal twenty-four hours daily starts at 7 A. M. tomorrow and probably will continue until May 31.

A further rise in industrial production and a substantial gain in freight shipments boosted the index of business activity in the Pittsburgh district nearly 2 points last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, Uniyersity of Pittsburgh.

Miss Jane Watson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson, will give a dinner tonight in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Hope Noyes and James Townsend, who will be married tomorrow in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Total loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City showed a further decline in the week ended on Wednesday. The decrease was $25,000,000, bringing the total contraction in the banks' credit since Dec. 23 to $312,000,000.

Sitting in West Side Court yesterday Magistrate Anthony F. Burke scolded eight women representing the League of Women Shoppers who were arrested shortly before noon for picketing a beauty shop operated by Rocco Brothers at 152 West Forty-fourth Street, where a strike is in progress.

A telegram to this column from Detroit, sent by one who, in a wholly disinterested position, has been closer to the strike peace negotiations than any person except the conferees themselves, reads as follows: "No praise too great for Frank Murphy." That,

Secretary Wallace told the Senate Finance Committee today he believed the best insurance of foreign outlets for such crops as wheat, cotton and corn lay in President Roosevelt's tariff bargaining powers.
Having betrayed his country some time ago, Benedict Arnold has returned to betray the theatre in a futile play entitled "A Point of Honor," which was put on at the Fulton last evening.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading again was only fair to slow on most classes. Veal and calf were lower, lamb strong and other classes mostly unchanged. The kosher slaughter was confined mostly to a moderate supply of lambs and kosher business to lamb at stronger prices.
Miss Anne Page of the Merion Cricket Club, defending her Atlantio Coast women's squash racquets championship, moved two steps nearer the final round with viatories on the Haddon Hall courts today.

Echoes of the General Motors strike rang through the Supreme Court chamber today just before three days of arguments on the five Wagner Labor Relations Act test cases ended and the cases were taken under advisement by the justices.

Almost a complete lapse of memory by Hay Petrie, playing the chief comic part, made an unfortunate beginning for tonight's revival of Thomas Holcroft's comedy "The Road to Ruin," at the Ambassadors Theatre.

Death Announced Retired Captain John R. O'Brien, formerly assigned to Engine 55, residing at 47-18 46th St., Woodside, died Feb. 7. Bowling Members of this department who desire to enter a bowling tournament shall forward applications to this office on Tuesday, Feb. 23, 1937.

The declared intention of the Cuban Government to repatriate the 40,000 to 50,000 Jamaicans resident in Cuba is causing grave concern here. If the plan is put into effect it will add to the local unemployment problem and also cause difficulty in maintaining those repatriated. The Jamaica Government is in communication with the British authorities on the question.

Two teams from New Jersey rode into the final round of the low-goal division of the New York Athletic Club's indoor polo tournament at the 105th Field Artillery Armory last night when Red Bank and Allenhurst won their semi-final matches.

Yale overwhelmed Georgetown, 48 to 26, tonight in a surprise basketball victory. The Elis, showing a powerful attack, ended the first half with a .24-13 advantage and steadily drew away from the invaders in the final.
Lady Clifford and Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener 2d were hostesses this afternoon at the Society of the Four Arts salon for the tea and preview of water-colors by Frederick Soldwedel.

Ruling that a whole novel should not be condemned because of objections to its parts, Magistrate Henry H. Curran in Homicide Court yesterday dismissed a complaint seeking the suppression of "A World I Never Made," by James T. Farrell, as "obscene, lewd and lascivious."

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Helen Murray Dutcher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hamilton Dutcher of this city, to Edward W. Swinburne, also of New York, son of Edward D. Swinburne of Millburn, N. J., which took place here on Feb. 3 in the Fourth Presbyterian Church.

The resumption of operations in General Motors Corporation automotive units following today's strike settlement affects the following cities and plants ("x" indicates those where strikes have occurred) listed with the number of employes who are or have been idle because of strike effects:

New records were made last year by air line operators, it was announced today by Eugene'L. Vidal, Director of Air Commerce. The lines carried 1,020,931 passengers in 1936, an increase of 73 per cent over 1935, in which year 746,946 passengers were carried.

Funeral services were held yesterday morning for Miss Julia Jay Pierrepont in Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Grace Court and Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights. She died in her eightieth year on Monday after being ill with pneumonia one week.

A campaign to raise $100,000 to buy food and clothing for the needy women and children of Spain was undertaken yesterday by the Committee on Spain of the American Friends Service Committee, at a meeting called by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America at the Parkside Hotel, 18 Gramercy Park.
Pierce E. Benedict, first Mayor of Beverly Hills, which he helped found, died today at the age of 80. Born in Booneville, Mo., Mr. Benedict sailed from the Eastern seaboard in 1862,

Tonight brings .to the Longacre Theatre the fifth and last opening of the week. "Call Me Ziggy" is the name and it is announced as Dan Goldberg's comedy about show business in its most frenzied, or shoestring side. The company includes Joseph Buloff, Ralph Theadore, June Webster, William Valentine, Lucille Sears and a good many more; the curtain is scheduled for 8:40 P. M.

E. W. Butler, formerly manager of the Pittsburgh district, has been placed in charge of phonograph sales, under Paul C. Richardson of the RCA Victor organization, it was announced yesterday by Vance C. Woodcox, sales manager of field operations.
