Ending of the automobile strike in the General Motors plants was good news for the company's agencies and media such as newspapers and magazines yesterday. The suspension of newspaper copy and the curtailing of magazine space wherever possible were responsible for substantial linage losses to these media.

An investor represented by Max Frank, attorney, bought from Samuel Horwitz, operator, the sixstory elevator apartment house for thirty-eight families at 562 West 164th Street, southeast corner of Broadway. The building,

Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan reserved decision yesterday on new motions by defendants to dismiss a suit brought by Francis K. Gundlach, a stockholder, to compel return of $610,000 paid in bonuses to officers of the Consolidated Edison Company and others

Two attorneys, Samuel Ellis Levine and Edward J. O'Connor, were disbarred yesterday by the Appellate Division. Levine pleaded guilty on Jan. 13 in General Sessions to a charge of forgery in the second degree.

The Warners' screen transcription of Lloyd C. Douglas's "Green Light" will be presented this morning at the Strand. Among those featured are Errol Flynn, Anita Louise, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Margaret Lindsay, Walter Abel, Spring Byington, Henry O'Neill and Erin O'Brien-Moore.

Following months of differences between the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation concerning the definition of "interest," an agreement was reached today and a statement was issued by both agencies declaring that "any payment to or for the account of any depositor as compensation for the use of funds constituting a deposit shall be considered interest."

Sailed by Roderick Stephens Jr., the yawl Stormy-Weather, fifty-four feet long on deck, which was the winner of the transatlantic race to Nodrway, today was determined to have captured the first of the Winter season's ocean yacht races in Southern waters, that of 184 miles from Miami, Fla., across the Gulf Stream to Nassau.
Progress is being made in plans to offer to holders of Paramount Pictures, Inc., $24,998,182 twenty-year 6 per cent debentures due in 1955, a new issue of 3 per cent

No difference is to be made in the Third Reich between mothers of illegitimate children and mothers of legitimate children, Dr. Robert Ley, German Labor Front leader, informed an. audience of twenty thousand members of the "Many Children League" here tonight.
Hugh M. Freer of Basking Ridge, N. J., vice president of Standard Brands, Inc., died yesterday in the Hotel Fourteen East Sixtieth Street of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

Verdi's "II Trovatore" was performed for the second time this season at the Metropolitan last night. The house was sold out, a fact attesting both to the enduring popularity of the work and to the interest aroused by Gina Cigna, the Leonora of the cast, as a result of the favorable impression she had made at her debut last Saturday afternoon as Aida.

Hugh R. Monro Jr., president of the Montclair Printing Company, died of meningitis last night at Mountainside Hospital. He had suffered a fractured skull last Friday night when he fell down several stairs in the Montclair Y. M. C. A.

Emperor Hirohito discarded his customary modern dress today for a dazzling medieval court costume to receive the congratulations of his people on the 2,597th anniversary of the founding of his royal dynasty and the Japanese Empire.

Dry goods jobbers, in general, continued to withhold orders from the primary dry goods markets, they reported here yesterday. The ending of the motor strike, however, was expected to release a fair volume of business, which distributers in the affected areas had been holding up.

The Small Claims Court, the division of the Municipal Court that looks after litigants whose claims do not exceed $50, handled 24,958 such actions last year, compared with only 16,280 in 1935. The court was set up late. in 1934 under the authority of a legislative act which Governor Lehman strongly supported.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and. pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

With Jack Schmitt and Al Van Hove scoring more than half of their team's total, the St. Augustin High quintet chalked up its tenth victory in the Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. drive by downing Brooklyn Prep, 32-12, on the league-leader's floor yesterday.

The United Automobile Workers have gained nothing and the whole labor movement has been "injured" by the General Motors strike and the settlement represents a "complete surrender" of all major demands made by the workers, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today.
Polling for provincial assemblies in British India has ended in seven provinces and is proceeding in two, leaving only Bombay and Madras to start their elections.

With champion Lewis Brooks enjoying a holiday in the national amateur pocket billiard tourney at the Capitol Health Center, his three strongest challengers yesterday turned in victories to go into a tie for second place.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in poundss sterling:

A challenge to Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, to stop what they termed his campaign of misrepresentation against their organization or proceed at once with indictments and trial was issued by officers of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, at its meeting last night in the Central Opera House, 205 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Governor Murphy, as tired as he was happy, received today the congratulations of President Roosevelt, Secretary Perkins, Senator La Follette and a host of men and women from all parts of the country for his success in negotiating a settlement of the automobile strike.

Dr. T. Wingate Andrews, one of North Carolina's leading educators, for ten years a director of the National Education Association and superintendent of schools here since 1924, died this morning in a High Point hospital. He had been ill for ten days. His age was 54.

George H. Howard, president of the United Corporation, has advised holders of preference and common stock who did not send in proxies for the annual meeting on Feb. 2 that an adjourned meeting will be held on March 2 for which additional proxies will be necessary if the proposed cancellation of the authorized but unissued first preferred stock is to be approved.

Taking the lead at the outset and never relinquishing it, Long Island University's basketball team handed Canisius College of Buffalo its second defeat in two days at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night before an overflow crowd of 1,100.
Judge Leonard J. Nickerson, former Speaker of the State House of Representatives and for many years a leader of the Connecticut bar, died tonight at his home in West Cornwall. He was 79 years old.
A $5,000 jewel robbery in the apartments of Mr. and Mrs. Allan A. Ryan Jr. of 59 East Fifty-sixth Street, was reported to the police of the East Fifty-first Street station last night.
By a law decreed today the Reichsbank was stripped of its technically independent character and placed under Chancellor Adolf Hitler's direct authority as an organ of the German Government.

The Federal Trade Commission took under advisement today the motion of Bird Son, Inc., its sales company and Montgomery Ward Co. to dismiss a complaint-the first brought under the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act--charging preferential discounts to the mail-order house.

Douglas Arthur Reid, secretary general of the British Council of Foreign Bondholders, who arrived in this country on Jan. 20 with Sir Otto Niemeyer to discuss financial problems with holders of defaulted German and South American bonds, died on Thursday at the Biltmore Hotel of pneumonia. His age was 51.

At the end of the Lincoln's Birthday regatta of the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association today only half a point separated the first two boats in the Class D standing. Golly, skippered by her owner, Edward Stiles, scored 25 points.

The stock markets generally were unsettled today, with securities of the armament companies, oils and aircraft the strongest features in dealings. Giltedges, affected by the new defense loan statement, were irregular and, although there was some recovery from early weakness, these securities, as a group, closed lower.
With each team moving along at top speed, Notre Dame and New York University will meet at Madison Square Garden tonight in the feature game of the local basketball season.

With the exception of Buel Hollister, third-seeded star from Yale, favorites filled the semi-final bracket of the national intercollegiate squash racquets championship which opened at the Merion Cricket Club today.

Fred A. Cauchois won the first shoot for the Ralph L. Spotts Memorial Trophy at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The new prize takes the place of the Show Boat Trophy which was won outright last year. Thirty gunners participated.

An editorial which appeared tonight in the undergraduate weekly, The Mount Holyoke News, expressed deep and firm admiration for President Mary E. Woolley, "who stands for principle and not for prejudice," but urged that.an end be put to the controversy concerning the presidency,

Captain Herbert M. Knowles, one of the best known life-savers in the country, who retired in 1920.as superintendent of the Third District of the United States Coast Guard after forty-four years in the service, died today at his home in Wakefield. His age was 81.

President Roosevelt today stood bareheaded at the foot of the steps to the Lincoln Memorial while his military and naval aides opened services on the 128th anniversary of President Lincoln's birth by laying a wreath at the foot of the statue inside the edifice.

Professor Raymond Moley, an original and at one time the leading member of the Roosevelt "brain trust," last night opposed the President's proposal to enlarge the United States Supreme Court as undemocratic and asked why the President did not put the issue frankly to the country and propose a constitutional amendment. Dr. Moley spoke from radio. station WEAF.

The Benjamin Franklin High School quintet took a firmer hold on second place in the Lower Manhattan division of the P. S. A. L. race as the result of a 37-to-19 triumph over Commerce at the James Monroe High gym yesterday. The victory, the ninth in succession, was the sixth in seven tourney starts. Claude Philips paced the attack.

The arrest yesterday of three boys accounted for more than fifty house robberies in Flatbush, West Flatbush and Parkville in the last year, according to the Brooklyn police, who also took into custody two men on charges of receiving stolen goods.

Texas has decided to have a paper mill-the first in the South. There are bigger paper mills than this; for its initial capacity is to be only 150 tons a day. There are more expensive ones too; for this one will cost only $5,000,000.

Before attending the Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club, Alf M. Landon, last Republican nominee for President, attended a reception at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth F. Simpson 109 East Ninety-first Street. Mr. Simpson is chairman of the New York County Republican Committee.

Electric rate reductions aggregating $354,040 a year have been agreed upon in negotiations between two New Jersey utility companies and the State Public Utility Commission, it was announced today by the commission.
Wheeler W. Abbott, former superintendent of the New York division of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, died this morning at his home here after an illness of two months. He retired on Jan. 1, 1932.
Frank Campbell with his new sailing dinghy Felix won the holiday regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club today. He led in two races to four for Arthur Knapp in his Four Deuces.

The Senate Committee on Commerce voted today to report favorably the Copeland bill to prevent the adulteration, misbranding and false advertisement of foods, drugs, devices and cosmetics in interstate and foreign commerce.

Opposing factions in the strike of employes of the Kelvinator Corporation sought today to arrange a peaceful settlement before Monday's scheduled hearing on a petition for an injunction against the strike.

President Roosevelt will start work next week on the final form of a message to Congress transmitting recommendations for a bill to provide for the distribution of power from the Bonneville Dam on the Columbia River in Oregon, which is approaching completion.

Nine new pastors were announced yesterday by Bishop Thomas E. Moiloy for parishes of the Roman Catholic Diocese of. Brooklyn. Three assistants were transferred. Bishop Molloy also announced the appointment of the Rev. Francis Froehlich, pastor of All Saints Church, Brooklyn,

Many people who cannot write plays cannot resist the temptation to write plays about plays. Dan Goldberg, a news litterateur, belongs to the clan, and his "Call Me Ziggy," a cartoon of show business, opened at the Longacre last evening.

There was a decided lull yesterday on the Yankees' capital-labor battlefront. Herr Lou Gehrig, for one, seemed to' feel no crying need for issuing another public proclamation and Colonel Jacob. Ruppert seemed to feel he already had said the last word the first time when he broadcast an emphatic no, and so likewise maintained a dignified silence.

Secretary Hull said today he had heard nothing in official channels or otherwise that would support reports that Great Britain was contemplating a plan for the economic relief of Germany that would involve a loan by the United States to Germany.

Several deals in Brooklyn and the Manhattan Beach section were reported yesterday by Friedberg Co., brokers. The one-family dwelling at 1,013 East Seventh Street, on a plot 40x 120, was sold by Mrs. M. Hertzig to M. Pearlmutter.
Sixto Escobar, world bantamweight champion, and his challonger, Lou Salica of New York, engaged in their first workouts today for their title bout on Feb. 21.

The marriage of Miss Shirley Muriel Miller, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Miller of this city and the late Mr. Miller, to William Lehmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Lehmann, also of this city, took place yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador. The ceremony Do was performed by Dr. Stephen S. Wise.
The world's richest but pennywise ruler, Nizam of Hyderabad, was so happy tonight that he dug up two more automobiles, 1907 vintage, to add to the splendor of his golden jubilee procession tomorrow.

St. John's University of Brooklyn battled its way to a 39-38 victory over St. Joseph's five at the Arena tonight, winning in the second extra period before 5,000 fans. In the second game of the college double-header, Temple University turned back Penn State, 42-23.

Lieutenant Thomas J. Sands of the West Point Fencers Club regained the metropolitan individual epee championship yesterday by deeating Jose de Capriles, University Fencers Club ace, in a fence-off at the Salle d'Armes Vince, 3 to 1.

Miss Jane Schuyler Nelson, daughter of Mrs. Humphrey Nelson of Wyncote, Pa., and of Richard M. Nelson of Larchmont, N. Y., was married here at noon today at the home of her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Humphrey,

The largst field of juveniles ever to be named for a Winter stake, in the opinion of Racing Secretary Charles McLennan, is the twenty available for tomorrow's running of the Nursery Stakes No. 1 at Hialeah Park.
The government news service reports that the German Ambassador in Warsaw has been instructed to protest a speech delivered in Polish Upper Silesia by the Vice Governor of Bialystok.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market is distinctly quiet. This is true both in the East and the West. Heavy arrivals of foreign wool are affecting the price at which business can be done in domestic wools, which has been at a premium for several months.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the death of Frederick Keppel will be observed by the Keppel Galleries with an exhibition, during March, of the favorite engravings of the founder of the house, many of which were reproduced in his book, "The Golden Age of Engraving," published in 1910.

George M. Robinson, personal friend of Mark Twain, nephew of the late Governor Lucius Robinson of New York and a descendant of Isaac Robinson, who arrived at Plymouth, Mass., in 1631, died yesterday at his home, 264 Lexington Avenue. He was 91 years old.
The Automobile Club of New York, a member of the American Automobile Association, made public here yesterday a list of State bills that it is supporting, and another of those it opposes.
The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals took under consideration tonight the first test case to come before it of the old-age pensoin section of the Social Securitv Act.

The ten best-dressed men in the metropolitan area, and the five best-dressed men-tailored women in New York City, as selected by the Tailors Guild of America, were announced yesterday at the close of its annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

It is no reflection on the Warners to observe that "Green Light" made a better novel than it has a motion picture. While the film version opening at the Strand yesterday is an interesting one, representing a sincere and largely successful attempt to maintain the quietly philosophic quality of Lloyd Douglas's best-seller, it is unable to disguise (as the novel did) the author's weakness as a story-teller.

Best-in-show honors at the sixtyfirst annual exhibition of the Westniinster Kennel Club were awarded last night to the pure white wirehaired- fox terrier Flornell Spicypiece of Halleston, owned by the Halleston Kennels of Stanley J. Halle, Chappaqua, N. Y.

Traffic policemen watched warily and astonished Bermudians ran out of their shops and offices and lined sidewalks today when what appeared to be a two-seater "baby" motor car appeared in Hamilton, gliding through the principal streets.
Grenville Howland Norcross, Boston attorney since 1879 and president emeritus of the Bostonian Society, died today at his home here at the age of 83.

Abraham Cohen, on trial as a lawyer for the restaurant racket, got "inside information which cost a lot of money from a policeman or some-one" in the office of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, a witness testified yesterday.

The current sculpture exhibition at the WPA Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-ninth Street, has been continued through Feb. 18. This necessitates the postponement of the succeeding show, consisting of easel paintings done under the project, until the following week, when the exhibition will open on Feb.. 24.

Loud boos and prolonged hooting echoed loudly from the galleries to provide a unique conclusion for the annual New York Hound Show yesterday in Madison Square Garden in conjunction with the final day of the Westminster all-breed exhibition.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

New Mexico's Senate passed a joint resolution, 19 to 4, today, urging Congress to enact laws recommended by President Roosevelt "relating to the Federal judiciary." Three Democrats joined the one Republican member to vote against it.

Tennessee's "Press Gag" Bill has met the death its author predicted for it. Following a public hearing, held last night. the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives tabled and killed the measure that the Senate had passed, 29 to 1. No one appeared in its behalf.

Chairman Wheeler of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee said to day that he would introduce a bill to bar newspapers from owning radio broadcasting stations. He said the purpose was to prevent monopoly of the channels of public information.
Hog prices were 5 to 15 cents higher during the early trading today but the market weakened later and most of the late sales were steady to 5 cents higher compared to yesterday's average.

By the end of February it is expected that more than 2,000,000 tax returns under the old-age features of the Social Security Act will be filed, Guy T. Helvering, commissioner of the Internal Revenue Bureau, said today.

Miss Jane Watson gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Hope Noyes and James Mulford Townsend Jr., who will be married today in the Madison Avenue' Presbyterian Church. The other guests,

The dean's list of Sweet Briar College for the second semester year has been announced by Dean Emily H. Dutton. Forty-four students have received this honor, which is awarded on the basis of dependability, ability and achievement, and which carries with it the privilege of voluntary attendance at classes.

Called back to New York by the illness of his daughter, Rexford G. Tugwell, former Under-Secretary of Agriculture, left Bridgetown today by chartered airplane for Trinidad. There he expects to board one of the Jamaica-Miami Clipper planes.

Harvard's swimming team defeated Columbia, 53-22, yesterday in the Morningside Heights pool in an athletic feature of the Lions' Alumni Day ceremonies. The Crimson won seven of the nine events. Willie Roveto, 1935 Eastern intercollegiate champion, won the fancy dive, with 102.36 points, and Columbia's other victory was scored by the 400-yard relay team.

The Ruberoid Company for 1936 reports a consolidated net profit of $812,930 after all deductions, including the surtax on undistributed profits. This showing is equal to $6.13 a share on 132.602 common shares and compares with $505,747, or $3.81 a share, earned in 1935.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Jan. 30 totaled 285,384,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

The newspaper owned and edited in Cremona by Deputy Roberto Farinacci, whose outspokenness is at once his chief virtue and his chief fault, prints the following illuminating comment on recent events in Spain which reflects the viewpoint of a very large part of Italian public opinion:

The marriage of Miss Ruth Leonard Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Leonard of this place, to Paul McElroy Underwood of Millburn, formerly of Lebanon, Ky., took place here this afternoon in the chapel of Prospect Presbyterian Church. The pastor, the Rev.

Mrs. Phebe Elena Cary of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street died at her home yesterday in her 101st year. Mrs. Cary was born in New York and lived her early life in Brooklyn. Her husband, Benjamin H. Cary, was in the leather business here for fifty years until his death in 1917. A son, Edwin, of the Sixty-eighth Street address, survives.

Miss Anne Page, Merion's national champion, won the Atlantic Coast Women's Squash Racquets championship for the fourth time in a row with a 15-4, 15-11, 15-10 triumph over Miss Cecile Bowes, Cynwyd star, in the final of the seventh annual tournament on the Haddon Hall courts this afternoon.

To overcome the scarcity of scrap metal, British steel manufacturers have agreed to place control of the national supplies in the hands of two of the largest scrap-metal concerns in the country, it was revealed today.

This city of 165,000 population, paralyzed economically by the six-week automobile strike that ended with the evacuation of three Flint factories by sit-down strikers yesterday, began to work back toward normal today as General Motors officials announced that 26,500 workers would be on the job Monday and more than 36,000 during next week.

Thousands gathered at the tomb of Abraham Lincoln and heard his work and ideals extolled today on the 128th anniversary of his birth. The city put all else aside to pay tribute with parades, speeches and prayers in memory of the assassinated President. Heading the observance was the American Legion pilgrimage to Lincoln's tomb. There Harry W. Colmery, national commander. of the Legion, said:

Manufacturers of furs, embroidery and millinery were the principals in a number of the contracts for commercial space reported by real estate brokers yesterday. Activity for the day was centered in the midtown district and largely involved space above the street floors. The list follows:

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $6,504,079, to be represented by forty-nine municipalities. This is the smallest weekly total so far this year, and compares with the revised total of $20,445,489 for this week.
The Bureau of the Census said today that orders booked for commercial steel castings for December totaled 159,430 short tons, the highest monthly figure, with one exception, since 1920.
Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Lake Hopatcong, N. J., and Joseph Schenck Jr. of New York advanced to the final in the Everglades mixed foursome golf tournament today.

There is an association of the name of COOPER with that of LINCOLN because of LINCOLN'S speech in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, a speech by which LINCOLN introduced himself to the people of this city so favorably that his nomination to the Presidency and his election received an unexpected support. Moreover,

Mr. and Mrs. George Trotter Van Antwerp of this place and Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Van Antwerp, to Lucius Beebe, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Russell Beebe of Weston.

In one of the most surprising upsets of the basketball season, Fordham downed C. C. N. Y. before 3,000 spectators at the Maroon's gymnasium last night, 31-17. It was the tenth victory in thirteen starts for the Rams, their seventh in a row and their first over the Lavender since the 1930-31 season.

Sverre Kolterud of Norway left little to be desired as he triumphed easily in the annual Bear Mountain jumping competition today. Almost 4,000 looked on with amazement as this dynamic invader turned in two leaps virtually perfect in every detail of form as well as excellent in distance.

A short-lived sit-down strike of WPA workers in a Park Department garage in Central Park yesterday morning apparently left every one except Park Commissioner Robert Moses in confusion as to what the consequences would be.

Depositors caught in the crash of the State Bank of Binghamton in 1930 will recover $438,225 and interest of $188,055 from J. S. Bache Co., New York, under a decision handed down today by Supreme Court Justice Ely W. Personius of Elmira.

Another threat to disrupt Pacifia and intercoastal shipping developed yesterday when three-maritime unioni on the Pacific Coast carried to the Federal Court their protest against the continuous discharge books required for seamen under the Coopeland Safety-at-Sea Act.

Lewis Brooks, defending national amateur pocket billiard champion, today still led the field in the title tourney under way at the Capitol Health Centre by virtue of a hardwon triumph over Herb Courtney, New York State titleholder, last night.

Chartered Investors, Inc-For 1938: Gross income from dividends received and interest earned totaled $418,279; net income amounted to $355,891, against $282,115 in 1935. After $85,000 dividend payment on common, balance of net income, totaling $39,892 was credited to unappropriated dividend and interest income.

Featuring the twenty-seventh running of the famous Hunter Mile, with Glenn Cunningham heading a four-man field of international character, the Boston Athletic Association's fortyeighth annual indoor games will be witnessed by a capacity crowd tomorrow night.

President Roosevelt's proposal to name additional justices of the United States Supreme Court was attacked last night as an outrage and an attempt to tear down the very foundations of American freedom by Senator H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire. Senator Bridges spoke at the annual Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club at the Waldorf-Astoria.

" Booboo," one of twin black bear cubs born in a zoo here and kept in an incubator for several weeks, died today. The cub, mauled by its father, was rescued by keepers and put in an incubator at the home of Alex McLerie, a keeper.

Race Relations Sunday will be observed tomorrow as is the annual custom on a Sunday between the birthdays of Abraham Lincoln and George Washington Tomorrow being the first Sunday of Lent many clergymen will begin a special series of sermons that will continue through Easter, March 28.

Upsetting expectations, Norway won from Finland in the 40-kilometer cross-country relay race of the International Ski Federation here today. The Norwegian quartet did the forty kilometers in a total of 3 hours 6 minutes 7 seconds,

German engineers in metal industries receiving less than 1,000 marks monthly, a relatively high German salary, were forbidden by a decree issued today to change their places of employment without government permission.
Degrees in course will be awarded to 229 graduates of the University of Pennsylvania at the midyear convocation of the university council to be held tomorrow in Irvine Auditorium.

3d Av., 1,500, 25.6x75; Bergfirst Realty Corp., Louis Firstenberg, president, to Paul Wilson, 196 Ridgewood Av., Glen Ridge, N. J.; purchase money, 5 years, 5 per cent; $25,500. 56th St., 33 W., 25x100.5; Mattie H. Donahue to Teachers Insurance Annuity Assn. of America, 522 5th Av.; due Feb. 10, lQdn 4 per cent $11,000.

Is there a possibility of organizing an anti-war bloc among the Baltic and Scandinavian countries? The suggestion that there is, in the dispatch from Moscow yesterday on the results of the Finnish-Russian conversations just concluded in the Soviet capital, is extraordinarily interesting and promising.

The Rev. John J. McCreary, Catholic priest, died in a hospital here tonight at the age of 51. He was an outstanding speaker, being well known in this part of the State for his attacks on communism and warnings against threats to the Constitution.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission contended today that Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the board of the Chrysler Corporation, had received $1,000 for each hour he attended meetings of the directors of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation. Mr.

Honoring Governor Fred P. Cone of Florida and Mrs. Cone on "Governor's Day for Charity," Joseph E. Widener, president of the Miami Jockey Club, entertained a large group at lunch eon in the club board room at Hialeah Park this afternoon and later in the president's box in Hialeah Club for the races.

The show of early German pictures that opened yesterday at the Schaeffer Galleries, 61 East Fiftyseventh Street, interestingly supplements the current "Five Centuries of German Painting" at the Brooklyn Museum.

The 20,000 Catholics who forcibly opened the churches in the town of Orizaba, State of Veracruz, yesterday have won their battle for freedom of worship temporarily and perhaps permanently with the support of President Lazaro Cardenas.

Warnings that hosiery prices would have to be advanced soon because of the marked increase in the costs of materials were sounded yesterday at the conclusion of the twoday hosiery industry conference, according to a statement last night by Earl Constantine, managing director of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

The British Government's projected $2,000,000,000 defense loan has aroused definite criticism and a certain amount of opposition in Liberal and Labor newspapers, but on the whole it is having what is called a "good Dress."
Three Akron rubber companies employing 22,000 workers announced wage increases of 5 to 8 cents an hour today, and a fourth company, employing 15,000, announced it "undoubtedly will follow suit."

Announcement that TOSCANINI has been engaged to give a series of orchestral concerts in this country over the radio next year aroused mixed emotions. His eminence as a conductor is everywhere recognized.

The cotton market here today was ar extremely dull affair because other markets throughout the country were closed for the Lincoln Birth day holiday. With prices in Liver pool easier, the opening here was 2 to 3 points down on the near months and unchanged to 1 point down on the later positions.
The New York Aggies turned back the Moravian quintet, 30 to 28, tonight. Harold Proct paced the attack for the victors with eight points. Farney of the invaders led the scoring with twelve tallies.

The establishment at Barnard College of the Annie Nathan Meyer Drama Library, made possible through gifts amounting to $5,000, was announced last night by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve, speaking at the alumnae reunion dinner in the dining room of Brooks Hall at Barnard College.

Governor Murphy of Michigan remained in bed all day on the order of his physician, as he was exhausted by his labors in connection with settlement of the General Motors strike, but arose this evening to take a train for New York at 7:49 P. M.

The troubled conscience of a former prosecuting attorney won a parole today for Hans Hansen, 29, who had served six years of a twenty-five-year sentence for the murder of James Stephens, Union Pacific yardmaster. Hansen is 6 feet, 6 inches tall.

The Federal Trade Commission issued a complaint today charging the Morris White Manufacturing Company, handbags, New York and Bridgeport, Conn., and the Style Craft Leather Goods Company, New York and Scranton, Pa., with alleged unfair trade practices. The companies.

Peter Cooper, founder of Cooper Union, was extolled as a pioneer in the distribution of wealth by Henry D. Williams, president of the Cooper Union Alumni Federation, at exercises celebrating the 146th anniversary of his birth, at New York University's Hall of Fame, University Heights.

Because his terms of office have a distinct parallel in these times and because he voiced a definite opinion on the duties of the Supreme Court, Lincoln's Birthday should carry a special significance today, declared Dr. James L. McConaughy, president of Wesleyan University, in a luncheon address at the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, yesterday.
Last night the sixty-first consecutive holding of the Westminster Kennel Club show, which has come to be the criterion of all indoor competition among dogs, closed at Madison Square Garden.

Capturing six of the eight first places, the St. Francis College swimming team defeated Manhattan, 39 to 29, in a dual meet in the Park Central Hotel pool yesterday. It was the fourth victory in eight starts for the Franciscans this season and the third setback in four meets for the Jaspers.

The Board of Examiners reports thau there have -been placed, as of Feb. 11, 1937, upon the eligible list of holders. of licenses as teachers of open air and tubercular classes in day elementary schools, the names of the following teachers, who have been granted said license:

RKO embraced the brighter side of life today with the purchase of two comedies. "Love Below Freezing," a musical with a Winter sports background, was acquired from Dana Burnett as a tentative Ginger Rogers vehicle, and Victor Mapes, who wrote "The Boomerang" and "The Hottentot," sold the studio "The Kangaroos" for Robert Woolsey and Bert Wheeler.

The National Football League became a ten-club circuit again today for the first time since 1934 when Cleveland was taken back into the fold. Club owners, sitting in the first session of their annual two-day meeting,
The Harvard Club and the New York A. C. again found themselves tied for first place in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League as the result of yesterday's play.

The 1,100 officers and men of-the 107th Infantry, the former Seventh Regiment, New York National Guard, participated in a formal review last night in honor of Fulvio Suvich, Italian Ambassador .to the United States, and Mrs. Suvich, at the regimental armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
Halleston Kennels' wire fox terrier Flornell Spicypiece of Halleston. BEST BRACE IN SHOW R. F. Maloney's pointers Ch. Herewithem Moscow's Ghost and Herewithem War Cloud.

A New York City record for contributions to a disaster relief fund was established yesterday when the donations to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross for flood relief in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys reached $1,858,807.65.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, signalized the concert it gave last night in Carnegie Hall by a delectable performance of a delectable symphony of Mozart and by a very painstaking performance of essentially worthless and fatiguing music-that is to say, Mahler's "Lied von der Erde."

Ernest Crawford of this city thinks that the snagging of striped bass in Toms River, N. J., during the past few days is the strongest sort of argument for a sane system of administering fish and game resources, and, by the same token, an indictment of sportsmen generally for their failure to protect those resources.

A wage increase of 5 cents an hour for Packard Motor Car Company employes became known today. Company officials said the decision to grant the wage increase was made Wednesday and that notices announcing it were posted in the plant yesterday.
Arthur K. Ohmes, consulting engineer, died Thursday at his home, 260 Washington Place, Hasbrouck Heights, N. J. He was 62 years old and had been ill only a short time of Pneumonia.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy M. DeLacy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. DeLacy of this city, to Richard E. Winans of Newark took place here today in the Prospect Street Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. William Thomson Hanszche performed the ceremony.

A rift is rapidly developing between the American schools and the public, Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday at the second annual conference on educational policies, called by Dr. Paul R. Mort, director of the Advanced School of Education.

The Franklin and Marshall College swimming team hung up its third victory, decisively beating City College of New York tonight, 59-11. Coach Olivia (Whitey) Sola's natators swept all eight first places.

With an entry list of almost 200 athletes, including members of the United States Olympic team, the three-day competition for the North American outdoor speed skating championships began on Municipal Field today.

Eddie Shore, famous defense man of the Bruins since the horse-and-buggy days of professional hockey in Boston, was placed officially on the retired list today. The action was taken by Manager Arthur Ross, and means the team plans to get along without the injured player for the rest of the season.
Social Security old-age benefits cover only approximately 50 per cent of the total working population of the United States, the National Industrial Conference Board estimated yesterday.

Ambassador Myron T. Herrick's memory was perpetuated today when a bronze bust mounted on a granite pedestal was unveiled in the Place des Etats Unis by President RaymondLaurent in the name of the Municipal Council.
The Hayashi Cabinet's revised national budget totals 2,769,000,000 yen. (The yen was quoted yesterday at 28.56 cents.)
Rallying on the closing holes to win four of the last five, David A. Perkins of Whiteley, Ky., annexed the Ormond Beach golf championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.

Friends and foes of the administration's foreign trade policy appeared before the Senate Finance Committee today to testify regarding extension of President Roosevelt's tariff bargaining powers for another three years.

The strange story of how every member of the crew of thirtythree, except the captain, sawed wood daily with only three- hours rest in every twenty-four since Feb. 5, was told today when the British freighter Lindenbank reached St. Georges after an amazing Atlantic crossing.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, was cheered enthusiastically last night by some 1,500 members of the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York and vicinity, when he attacked the settlement of the General Motors strike.

There is a Prohibition Emergency Committee in Kansas. Its efforts will be watched hopefully by all the friends of that unequaled and uncorrupted Sunflower virtue, so long the glory of that Commonwealth The hour is critical.

After twelve hours' deliberation a Kings County jury was still deadlocked early this morning concerning the guilt of the two accused kidnappers of Paul H. Wendel who elected to take their chances on the jury's verdict, after the third defendant pleaded guilty.

The Princeton freshmen sextet today defeated St. Mark's School, 2-0, in a game played on melting ice. At one period of the game the St. Mark's net and the goalie, Hall, broke through, and three other players also fell into the waist-deep water.
A fierce struggle for the Valencia road is raging today, but from the latest information available the situation remains unchanged. The Insurgents are near the road, but have not cut it.

The coming week looms upon the nocturnal horizon like a freighted caravel from the East, considering the surprising number of events which it holds. Not for some little time has such a loaded calendar topped this column. In order-and without discriminationhere is the list:

Funeral services were held yesterday at Holy Rosary Church, Chauncey Street, between Reid and Stuyvesant Avenues, Brooklyn, for Thomas F. Troy, known on the stage as T. X. Thomas, who died of pneumonia Tuesday in French Hospital, Manhattan. He was 82 years old.
Finland remains the central topic of Moscow conversation, with much argument as to the precise significance of the visit of the Finnish Foreign Minister, Dr. Rudolf Holsti.

W. S. Alexander, Federal Alcohol Administrator, warned distillers today to make no vain boasts for their whiskies. The penalty for extravagant advertising claims or other violations of the administration's advertising rules, he said, will be "proceedings for the suspension and revocation of permits."

Governor Earle of Pennsylvania declared tonight that "the cause of human welfare has been advanced beyond calculation by President Roosevelt's proposal to break the conservative majority on the Supreme Court."

The Oswego Falls Corporation of Fulton, N. Y., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $2,500,000 first-mortgage 41/2 per cent sinking fund bonds due in 1952, with common stoc- delivery warrants attached.

Official figures revealed tonight that work on six new destroyers and three submarines had been halted by the navy's critical steel shortage. These vessels embrace half of the current warship building program.

Gene Venzke yesterday filed his entry for the Baxter mile, one of the features of the annual New York Athletic Club track meet at Madison Square Garden a week from tonight. This will be his eighth start in the oldest indoor eight-furlong test of them all.

George M. Wallace, editor of The Windsor Locks Journal, died at St. Francis Hospital in this city today. He was 67 years old. He was the son of Finton and Mary Wallace and had passed all his life here.

Thin ice on Prospect Park lake, Brooklyn, broke shortly after noon yesterday under the weight of three 12-year-old boys who had eluded patrolmen, but its shaky surface held while a rescuer made his way to the place where they had broken through and pulled them out.
The elimination of all Spanish leather from the market and the high price of wool, preventing the slaughter of sheep, have caused an acute shortage of glove leather and skins,

Content to be welcomed as another Republican woman rather than as a party personage, Mrs. Alfred M. Landon was the axis yesterday of a double line of members at the annual Lincoln Day tea at the Women's National Republican Club.

Governor Lehman signed today the three bills for restoration of pay cuts to New York City teachers and other employes of the city amounting to $9,000,000 for the last half of the current year. The restorations will be effective as of June 30.
Mayor La Guardia endorsed yesterday the observance of "Brotherhood Day" in the city next Saturday by Jews and on the following Sunday by Christians.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, sent a telegram today to Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the New York Assembly, urging ratification of the child labor amendment.

Mrs. Clarence J. Hines, home on Boston Post Road, Rye. from Mrs. Imogene M. Oler; Blakeman Quintard Meyer, broker. A. G. Hatzman of Tarrytown. Mrs. Irene McElrath of Scarborough, Earl Temple of Tarrytown, cottages on the Albany Post Road. Scarborough-on-Hudson, from James Speyer; I. C. Totaling, broker.

The Tribune today quoted an unnamed aviation expert as declaring he was positive the eleven persons aboard the Los Angeles-San Francisco plane were alive after the craft crashed into the bay Tuesday night and made futile efforts to reach shore.
Mrs. Wallis Simpson made her 1937 debut in Riviera society tonight when she dined and danced at a Cannes restaurant as guest of honor at a dinner given by Henry Clews Jr. of New York.

Samuel Shinkman, a leading figure of the Jewish theatre and a well-known restaurateur on the lower East Side, died Thursday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Ruth Phillips, 332 Rogers Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 83 years old.
The second special Wagner matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House presented yesterday "Die Meistersinger" for the benefit of the Smith College Club Scholarship Fund. The cast was of unusual interest.

Employable workers in relief roll families numbered 6,402,000 on Jan. 15, 1936, according to-an occupational census of their condition, circumstances and abilities made public today by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, as a "report to the American people of the way in which our operations have been guided by definite facts."
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 6 amounted to 675,026 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Three engaged couples were honored by dinners tonight. Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Beebe of Media gave a dinner at their home tonight for their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Beebe, and her fiance, Leslie Q. Miller of Bronxville, N. Y.

The great strides that the game of badminton has made in the past few years were quite in evidence yesterday as play in the Eastern New York open amateur badminton tournament started on the court of the 165th Regiment Armory and produced an entry list of more than 200 for the singles and doubles.

With a Suffield Academy Winter carnival crowd looking on, Suffield lost its first game of the season, 37-34, to a strong Deerfield quintet today. Reed played brilliantly for Deerfield to capture the scoring honors with 15 points.

TOWARDS THE CHRISTIAN REVOLUTION, edited by R. B. Y. Scott and Gregory Vlastos. (Willett, Clark Co., $2.) The contributors to this symposium argue that Christianity provides basis for, and justification of, a revolutionary ethic more vigorous than communism, indeed that Christianity is essentially-and intentionallyrevolutionary,

Fred Palmer Chapman, president of the Franklin Yarn Company here since its incorporation in 1900, died today at his home at the age of 71. Mr. Chapman was graduated from Dean Academy and Tufts College. His first employment was with the Gulf, Colorado Santa Fe Railroad as a civil engineer.

Harry Jacobs has been named asdistant Eastern regional manager for the House of Schenley, J. L. Leban, Eastern regional manager, announced yesterday. A style show of lighting fixtures, lamps and accessories for members of the trade only will be held at the Decorators Club, 745 Fifth Avenue, starting Monday.

With more than 100,000 employes of the General Motors Corporation called back to work by Tuesday, corporation executives worked strenuously today to "clear the decks" for as fast a resumption of peak production of motor cars as possible.

Large pre-publication sales figures are again being announced by book publishers. Although John Steinbeck's "Of. Mice and Men" will not be published until Feb. 25, orders in the last two days amounted to 12,000 copies.. Total copies printed so far have been 117,000, including those for Book-of-theMonth Club distribution in March,

Ben H. (Uncle Ben) Butcher of Parkersburg, member of the House of Delegates, died today of pneumonia. The 79-year-old dean of the Legislature had been ill a week. He began his legislative career as a youth in 1879, when Wheeling was the State capital, as the youngest member of the fourteenth session. He was the oldest member of the present, the forty-third, session.

Joseph B. Kerr, representative of the Association of American Railroads, said today to the House Interstate Commerce Committee that the industrial development of interior America was retarded by the "longand-short-haul" clause of the Interstate Commerce Act.
Miss Eleanore A. Minor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. J. Minor of this place, became the bride tonight of Ralph Menke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Menke of East Orange.

Three youths landed in the county jail today on charges of arson because, it was said, they thought a fire would attract some girls. Lawrence Wilkins, 18, and Arthur Miller, 17, of Lodi, and Rex Hess, 17, of Interlaken, were arrested by Under-Sheriff John G. Crisfield.

The scheduled appearance of James J. Braddock, world's heavyweight champion, in two four-round bouts Monday night at the Hippodrome in the interest of the Catholic Writers Guild yesterday was postponed.
Edwin Ekoff, 45 years old, of 1 Bevy Court, Brooklyn, was accidentally killed yesterday morning in a dumbwaiter shaft at St. John's Hospital, Atlantic and Albany Avenues, Brooklyn. Ekoff,

Dr. H. Louis Fuerstman, in charge of giving the Schick test for the Newark Board of Education for the last twenty years, died today at his home, 570 High Street, after suffering a heart attack on Wednesday. He was 52 years old.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired its first painting by the eighteenth-century English artist William Hogarth. It portrays "The Wedding of Stephen Beckingham and Mary Cox," and is among the earliest known canvases from the brush of Hogarth, who was 32 years old at the time he painted it.

Attorneys defending Major Green, Negro porter convicted of murder in the first degree for the slaying of Mrs. Mary Harriet Case in her Jackson Heights apartment on Jan. 11, planned yesterday to ask a stay of execution immediately after sentence is pronounced by Judge Charles S. Colden next Friday in Queens County Court.

Pope Pius and Chancellor Adolf Hitler exchanged cordial telegrams today, causing Vatican circles to hope for an improvement in the relations between Berlin and the Holy See, strained by conflict between the Nazi regime and the Catholic church in Germany.

The Pittsburgh Yellow Jackets ended a prolonged slump in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight with a 2-1 victory over the New York Rovers in an exciting game that included a last-minute fight. Paul Kowel, Rover wing, and Jack Thompson exchanged blows and nffinialR banished both.

A 15-year-old Boston girl, Miss Jane Tozzer, assured the East of another national figure skating crown by winning the junior title today. In the flag-draped Chicago arena, over the specially tinted robin's egg blue ice,
Two of the three players to gain the semi-finals of the second annual New Jersey indoor tennis championship today were extended by their opponents.
The Princess of Piedmont, Crown Princess Marie Jose, at 2:30 P. M. today gave birth to a strong, healthy boy who may one day sit on the Italian throne with the name of Victor Emmanuel IV.

Four mem bers of Joven Cuba, outlawed revolutionary organization, who are serving long sentences in the Prin cipe Fortress jail for terrorism, were injured today in a fight among themselves, according to a state ment by the authorities.
The racial specialist of the Hitler Elite Guard, Dr. Schmidt-Klevenow, proposes a law forbidding Germans capable of having children to marry persons incapacitated for begetting or bearing them.

Throughout last night and today many special trains brought members of the Fascist Iron Guard from all parts of Rumania. Already more than 150,000 have paraded before the bodies of Dr. John Motza and Dr. Basil Marin, who were killed in Spain while fighting with the Rebels.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Andrew Kirsch, assistant secretary of the Board of American Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America, with headquarters in the Lutheran Church House, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street, has been placed in charge of Lutheran work for Southern mountaineers.

Creation of committees of arbitration to intervene and settle. disputes between landlords and tenants "for the protection of the interests of both classes" and "to promote better relationships" was recommended to President Roosevelt in the report of his Special Committee on Farm Tenancy, which yesterday concluded its work with far-reaching proposals for financing present tenants in eventual farm ownership.

Competitive designs for a mural painting for the auditorium of the new Interior Department Building were asked today. The successful artist will receive an award of $5,500. Designs must be submitted on or before April 30 to Edward B. Rowan, superintendent of the Treasury Department's section of painting and sculpture,
George P. Hahn, Federal Judge of the Northern District of Ohio, died today of paralysis after a brief attack of influenza. He was appointed by President Coolidge in 1928.

Hunter College at its annual birthday breakfast, given yesterday afternoon by the associate alumnae in the Hotel Astor, celebrated both its sixty-seventh anniversary - and the completion of a year's successful campaigning for a- new college building to replace the one swept by fire on the college's sixty-sixth birthday last Feb. 14.

Walter W. Schneckenburger, vice president of the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo, has been elected president of the Trust Companies Association of the State of New York. Vice presidents elected were William A. Read, vice president of Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, and Lewis G. Harriman, president of Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo.

The speed with which the government is driving its rearmament program is shown by the announcement within three weeks of the abandonment of the proposal to erect an aircraft factory in the Thames Valley, that the construction of a 100-acre works will begin Monday at Speke, near Liverpool.

All the bankers in Sian gathered today at General Ku Chutung's headquarters to discuss the financial crisis brought about by the fact that when General Yang FU-cheng evacuated the city he took from the banks here 9,000,000 Chinese dollars, leaving merely personal receipts.

The $1,045.59 which David Lang, paperhanger, had on deposit in the Chelsea Second National Bank here when it closed four years ago, has been sold at auction for $25, Robert E. Steedle Federal Referee in Bankruptcy, disclosed today.

The Board of Tax Appeals ruled today that unpaid alimony claims were not deductible as worthless debts in computing income tax liability. The board's ruling was made in the case of Pearl A. Long of Hermosa Beach, Calif.

A charter has been sought here for "biological explorations," a nonprofit corporation to back the New Guinea expeditions of Richard Archbold of New York. Mr. Archbold now is financed by the American Museum of Natural History, which receives the specimens, maps and charts brought back by the expeditions.

Today is the third anniversary of the start of the fighting that culminated in the destruction of the Austrian Socialist movement by the Heimwehr Fascist counter - revolution, but though many thousands of Socialists have been arrested in the last three years, the underground movement has proved its vitality.

A rebirth of faith in the Christian Church to strengthen the individual's foundations to meet the challenge of the present time was urged yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning at a noon Lenten service in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street.

Miss Ruth K. Doehrmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J, Doehrmann of this city, and Paul Peter, son of Michael Peter of Washington and the late Mrs. Peter, were married last night at the home of the bride's brother-inlaw and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Harry O. Eckert of Westfield.

A court battle between the Ottawa Valley Power Company and the Ontario HydroElectric Commission has ended with agreement on a new contract between the parties, Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn announced today.

Stephen T. Early, a Presidential secretary, told reporters today that President Roosevelt arose slightly indisposed this morning, but upon reading that the Union League Club of New York had adopted a resolution opposing his judicial reform plan "he immediately began to feel better."
MARK TWAIN was one of the earliest sit-down strikers. The circumstance is recalled by a London commuter revolt

Robert A. Pinkerton, president of the Pinkerton National Detective Agency, which has been under investigation by the Senate subcommittee authorized to study labor espionage, refused twice today to produce records which would reveal the names of secret operatives in the General Motors Corporation plants during the sit-down strike. He contended that to do so would endanger the lives of the men.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I see that the humble athlete of the revered Amateur Athletic Union is to be given a little (sotto) voice in the affairs of that body. It is amazing to me to be informed that suggestions were solicited from competing athletes.

A four-story apartment at 237 Franklin Avenue, Cliffside Park, N. J., was sold by the Hudson Trust Company to the 237 Franklin Avenue Corporation, J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, announced. The building is on a plot 75 by 100 feet, contains twenty-eight apartments and produces a rental of approximately $12.500.

J. Teller Schoolcraft, who defeated George R. Lunn, Socialist Mayor of this city, in 1913, died last night. He was 81 years old. Republicans and Democrats supported Mr. Schoolcraft as a Fusion candidate, but failed to reunite in 1915 and Mr. Lunn, who now is a State Public Service Commissioner, returned to office as Mayor.
Mrs. Lillian E. Ward, a prominent member of the Daughters of the American Revolution and a descendant of two Presidents of the United States, died last night at her home here.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Speed to Spare won the $1,500-added Abraham Lincoln Handicap at Santa Anita today, nosing out Accolade and Appealing in a photo finish in the six-furlong race before 15,000 fans.

The women's auxiliary of the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital is sponsoring the eleventh annual midwinter polo tournament of the New York Athletic Club tonight at the 105th Regiment Field Artillery Armory, Franklin Avenue, the Bronx, as a benefit for the freecare service conducted by the hospital in its twenty-four surgical and medical clinics.
Francisco Bergamin, former Cabinet Minister and President of the Cortes under the monarchy, died here today. He was once president of the Spanish Academy of Jurisprudence.

" Let's hang him, but let's try him first," the famous dictum of a Far West judge trying a horse thief, seems to be the guiding principle of Insurgent military tribunals now working overtime to hear the cases of Malagans accused of crimes and rebellion.

Broad: expansion of WPA work to repair flood damage in nine States was ordered by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, in a conference with State administrators here today. "We are taking the lid off," Mr. Hopkiris announced.

While opinions appear to be divided as to whether contests are declining or gaining, they form the basis of two competitive merchandising fights which are attracting considerable interest in the advertising field.

The General American Life Insurance Company of St. Louis reported yesterday total resources of $123,046,148 as of Dec. 31; policy reserve of $115,477,962, and surplus of $1,915,745. Holdings of United States Government and other bonds were carried at $34,075,175, or more than $2,500,000 less than their market value.

Although cotton mill activity increased last week, the rise was less than seasonal and the adjusted index fell back two points. The figure now is 137.4, as against 139.4 in the preceding week and 108.9 for the week ended Feb. 8, 1936.

Miss Ruth Lammerding, daughter of Mrs. Mary Lammerding of this city and the late John H. Lammerding, became the bride of William J. McCrea, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph McCrea, also of Elizabeth, at All Souls Unitarian Church here this morning.
New York's legislative milk committee completed the second week of public hearings tonight admittedly no nearer a solution of the milk control problem than when the committee was created.

An all-Republican committee from the Maine Legislature presented to Vice President Garner today a resolution protesting President Roosevelt's court proposals. The Vice President gave assurance that the resolution would be read in the Senate Monday. Speaker Bankhead, asked if he would receive the delegation, replied:
President Roosevelt will confer with Secretary Hull soon on transfers and changes in the diplomatic service, he indicated at his press conference today.

The United States is using up its oil reserves faster than any other nation in the world, and unless action to conserve this national resource is taken soon, there will be a shortage of oil here "long before there is a shortage in the rest of the world,"

The Cardinal Newman award for 1936 will be conferred upon Dr. Alexis Carrel, surgeon and scientist of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research in New York City, it was announced today by the Rev. Dr. John A. O'Brien, director of the Newman Foundation here.

Relinquishing only one hole of the twenty-six contested, Frank Allan of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., overwhelmed Pete Harris of Miami, 11 and 10, in the 36-hole final for the annual Dixie golf championship at the Miami Country Club today.

New Yorkers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia include: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Barrett, Mr. and Mrs. R. S. Dodge, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Beggs, Charles Bloom, Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Cowles, Randolph Santini, Mr. and Mrs.

Dr. Patrick Thompson Campbell, superintendent of Boston schools, died today of a heart attack at the age of 65. Born in Jersey City, N. J., he attended public schools here, the Boston Latin School and Harvard College, where he received his degree magna cum laude in 1893.

Miss Mary Stuart Dayton, debutante daughter of Mrs. George S. G. Cavendish of Cedar Hill Farm, Media, was honored tonight at a red and white ball given at the home of her grandmother, Mrs. Charles Stuart Wurts. The ball,

THE firm of Random House has just published, in collaboration with Jonathan Cape of London, a new and handsome edition of C. M. Doughty's "Travels in Arabia Deserta" (2 vols., $15). The text is complete and unabridged and includes Doughty's maps and sketches as well as T. E. Lawrence's now-famous introductory essay.

An attack on President Roosevelt's proposal to remake the Supreme Court was cheered by prominent jurists and lawyers yesterday at the annual luncheon of Columbia University alumni in John Jay Hall, Morningside Heights.

Charging that President Roosevelt was seeking to pack the United States Supreme Court under the "camouflage" of dealing with calendar congestion, Federal District Judge Merrill E. Otis exhibited a chart today in an attempt to show that the business of the Federal courts had strikingly decreased in the last four years.
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh landed today for an overnight stay at Mersa Matrouh, a tiny fishing village two hours by air from Cairo, the possible destination of their aerial jaunt.

The Springfield College basketball team made difficult work of winning what should have been an easy game tonight. Trailing at the end of the first half, 15-13, the future gymnasts rallied in the final period to triumph over Brooklyn Poly, 41-20. Brooklyn was held to one floor basket for eighteen minutes of the last half. Nuttall and Lawler featured.

Victor Chenkin, character song interpreter, tomorrow night at the Alvin Theatre will give his first Broadway concert in two years. The Sunday night concert at the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow night will be for the benefit of the Israel Zion Hospital of Brooklyn.
Announcement has been made here by Mrs. Ruth Swaine of Taos, N. M., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margery Swaine, to J. Prentice Sanger 2d of this city and Rowe, N. M.

Though today's business-or the lack of it-may add to the number, only two Broadway attractions have decided definitely to fold their tents after this evening's performance. One is "The Country Wife," which will leave Henry Miller's after playing eighty-eight times. The physical. production: costumes.
The marriage of Miss Mary Frances O'Connell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. O'Connell of Woodside, Queens, and Roxbury, Conn., to Angus Shaw McCabe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank McCabe of Brooklyn,
The unauthorized first flight to Moyobamba from Trujillo has caused the government to suspend the service, grounding the airplanes of the Peruvian Condor Aviation Company.

Several railroads and ninety-four trucking companies opposed today at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing the application of the Philadelphia-Detroit Lines, Inc., of Butler, Pa., for permission to continue as a common carrier in twelve States.

A new method for the permanent elimination of the painful sensitiveness resulting from the exposure of the "necks" of teeth by receding gums was announced yesterday before the dental alumni of Columbia University at a symposium at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center as part of the Columbia Alumni Day program.
Ward's Reports, Inc., estimated today that this week's output by automobile plants would total 74,145 assemblies against 79,143 in the comparable week of 1936 and 72.010 last week.
Congress today passed a law authorizing the President of the Republic to spend 100,000,000 pesos for new planes for the air force.

A false burglary alarm, accidentally touched off by a night watchman in the Chemical Bank anrd Trust Company branch on the second floor of the Paramount Building, on Times Square at Forty-third Street, caused an excited crowd of 1,000 pedestrians to gather outside the building at 8:55 o'clock last night.

Nationalism and social radicalism were the keynotes of a speech that Colonel Miedzinski, vice president of the Sejm, and known as Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz's political adviser, delivered tonight at a private meeting of Deputies and Senators.

Indoor polo faces the most active evening of its season tonight, with fast triple bills scheduled for three centers of the game. In addition to important Metropolitan League contests at both Squadron A and Squadron C Armories, there are the first appearance of the Yale varsity against a strong 15-goal team and the finals in the 105th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx of the interesting New York Athletic Club invitation tournament.

Mrs. Wiley Post, widowed when her flier husband crashed with Will Rogers in Arctic Alaska, has enrolled in a business school here to prepare for a career. "I'm interested in secretarial work-and getting a job," she said today after her identity became known to fellow students.

Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 16 amounted to 19,715,840 shares in round-lot sales, compared with 14,395,270 shares the week before, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The Illinois Supreme Court, in a unanimous opinion .today, held unconstitutional the law imposing the 3 per cent occupational (sales) tax on electricity, gas and water sold by public utility companies.

Six new marks were established and one record was tied as the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High athletes carried off the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association senior team championship for the third straight year at the tenth annual track and field games at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn yesterday.
Approval was given by the War Department today to plans of the Board of the Supervisors of Suffolk County, New York, for the construction of a bridge across Great South Bay at Brookhaven, L. I.

Johannah O'Reilly, a domestic, who went on a sit-down strike in her employer's home and manhandled two law officers 'when they were called into the situation as mediators, began serving twenty-five days in the Riverhead jail today for disorderly conduct.

Mayor La Guardia, accompanied by Mrs. La Guardia and their two children, Jean and Eric, made an inspection tour yesterday afternoon of- the Harlem River- Houses, -the $4,500,000 PWA low-rental housing project now nearing completion at the northern end of Harlem.

W. C. Bewley, manager of the Georgia Peach Growers Exchange, said today that bud-damaging frost which followed unseasonably warm weather in the South might simply be helping peach-orchard men with Spring chores.

The volume of trading on the industrial floor of the Toronto Stock Exchange today was only about half of that of yesterday, traders preferring to stay out of the market in the absence of New York leadership. Ford A,
Informal conversations between Germany and Belgium over the Reich's proposed recognition of Belgian neutrality have been initiated by the Belgian Minister here, it was learned today.

Leading all the way, the Providence College basketball team outed Pratt Institute, 50 to 31, in he latter's gym in Brooklyn last light. The victors, who were paced y Captain Leo Davin's 15 points, showed the way by 26--13 at the inermission.

With the many instances noted of the counterfeiting of notes, bonds and stamps through the process of photoengraving, would it not be advisable to have all photo-engraving supply or equipment firms furnish the government with names of all prospective buyers of such equipment?

Mr. and Mrs. George Stevenson Fenton gave a cocktail party today in honor of their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Huntley, at their home. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps gave a dinner tonight at Heamaw for their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davis.

Joseph T. Dolan, formerly chief clerk for the United States railway mail service in District No. 3, which covers some of the principal railroad terminals in the metropolitan area, died today at his home here. He was 73 years old.

Transcontinental airline pilots scouted Wyoming plains for cattle thieves today, latest in the modern range war against rustlers. Under an agreement between the Wyoming Stock Growers Association and United Air Lines, crews of the speedy transport planes racing daily above the Wyoming cattle country will report by short-wave radio to Cheyenne headquarters all movements of cattle.

The death of a Czechoslovak stowaway from injuries he received when he was buried under tons of shifting coal in the bunkers of the liner Ilsenstein was related yesterday when the vessel docked in Hoboken after a passage from Antwerp. The ship's master,

Benjamin Janicki, veteran of the World War and long prominent in Polish circles and veterans' affairs in this township, died here today in his home at the age of 43. Mr. Janicki was born in Poland and came to the United States in 1913. In 1917,

Brazil's coffee bourse went through a hectic afternoon with coffee type seven, March delivery, attaining 113 milreis a bag, the highest level in several years. Speculators were heavy sellers at the start of business, counting upon National Coffee Department destroying more trees in order to reduce the crop surplus.

Public utility borrowing assumed the lead in new bond financing this week, accounting for more than half of the $172,761,000 in new issues put onto the market. This steels, week's volume was the second largest for the year to date, being exceded only by the $192,514,000 offered in the week ended on Jan. 22, and comparing with $71,605,00 in new loans marketed last week.

Miss Marjorie McAlpin, daughter of Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin of Madison, N. J., and the late Rev. Dr. McAlpin, was married to Calvin Wright Dail of this city yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club.

' America's first 4,000dog kennel show may come at Morris and Essex this May, it was indicated at Madison Square Garden yesterday by McClure Halley. Plans to house that many dogs are being made at Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge's estate at Madison, N. J., where the great outdoor exhibition is held. An international array of judges is being invited.

Under the auspices of an independent national committee composed of Catholics, Jews and Protestants a memorial dinner meeting to honor the late Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman will be held Tuesday--evening in the Hotel Astor.

The United States Supreme Court was charged yesterday by Mayor La Guardia with responsibility for bringing on the Civil War, "the bloodiest war in our history," -but was warned that it would not now be permitted to block a satisfactory solution of our present-day problems.

THE Notre Dame basketball squad was praoticing for its game with N. Y. U. at the Garden this evening. Elmer Layden, the Thin Man, had come to town with the sharpshooters of the hard floor, but the gridiron chief slipped out of the way to give the basketball heroes the floor.
The first public performance in this country of Tchaikovsky's famous ballet, "The Sleeping Beauty," was given here tonight at the Academy of Music by the Philadelphia Ballet Company.

Scattered deals in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday featured realty activity, which was moderated by the holiday. The modern five-story dwelling with elevator at 9 Sutton Place was leased furnished by Mrs. Joseph E. Willard

Sven Hedin, Swedish explorer, believes that the return of the colonies to the Reich would probably prevent a world catastrophe. In a long article published here he writes that colonies would be for overpopulated Germany what a safety valve would be for an over-heated kettle.

Registrations with the Securities and Exchange Commission today included that of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Corporation of Kansas City, Mo., covering $24,000,000 of 4 per cent first-mortgage and first-lien bonds, due March 1. 1952.

Senator E. P. Donohue, Republican, rose in the Senate today and told the chamber that "for some reason or other the picture of Abraham Lincoln which traditionally had a place at the right of the President's desk, has been supplanted by one of Henry Wallace."

The intimate atmosphere which sometimes pervades the House of Commons was illustrated by a homely incident there today. Joseph Bates, Labor member from Durham, who was to move the second reading of the Mines Nationalization Bill, speaks a broad dialect of the North country. When the Speaker called on him this afternoon he said:

In one of the finest racquets matches of this or any other year, J. Richard Leonard, former national doubles champion, defeated Rex Fincke of New York today in the gold racquet tournament at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club.

All statesmen have at times to yield something of what they desire. Standing by essentials, they may give up other points. This was characteristic of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, whose birthday is again reminding his countrymen of the qualities of a great character.

The Lawrenceville basketball team defeated Tome School tonight, 250. Lawrenceville jumped into a ix-point lead before the Tome quinet could find the basket and the core at half-time was 15 to 12. Throughout the second half Lawenceville held a slim lead and linchedd the game in the closing minutes of play with two field goals In succession:

The Lutheran Education Society, which has sponsored the Concordia Collegiate Institute in Bronxville and other outstanding educational programs within the Lutheran Church, celebrated its thirtieth anniversary last night with a dinner at the Hotel Commodore. Nearly 1,000 persons attended.

Responding to the stimulus provided by more seasonable weather, retail distribution expanded sharply this week, with some merchants reporting the best volume for the period since 1929 and others running slightly ahead of that mark, according to the review issued

The third in the series of HaydnMozart concerts under the sponsorship-of the Federal Music Project was given last night at the WPA Theatre of Music, 254 West Fiftyfourth Street. The concert attracted a near-capacity house, which greeted the program with warm applause.

Officials of the Louisville Nashville Railroad announced here today the appointment of John E. Tilford, for nine years chairman of the Southern Freight Association as assistant vice president, a new post. Mr. Tilford's office will be in Louisville, Ky.

Play-off dates for the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class C team championship were announced yesterday by J. N. Trainer Jr. of the tournament committee. The Cornell University Club and the Downtown Athletic Club will meet Tuesday at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, to determine the New York Division, Group II, winner.

As developments today showed a definite split among Senate liberals over President Roosevelt's proposal for judicial reforms, there were indications that the President himself would move to call upon the country to help put down the incipient legislative revolt.
Max Schmeling Will Sail next Friday for the United States and an exhibition tour of twenty-two American cities starting March 1.
-President Federico Paez today sailed on the United Fruit yacht White Shadow for Manta, where he will inaugurate a waterworks system in that rainless town.

Lighthorse Harry Cobper of Chicago cut three strokes from River Oak's rugged par, 35, 36-71, today to lead the field in the first eighteen holes of the $3,000 Houston open golf tournament. Cooper slipped one over par going out, but bagged an eagle 3. on the tenth and came home with a 32, four under par.
David Levinson, American lawyer, was asked today by Police Chief Filinto Muller of Rio de Janeiro to leave Brazil on the next boat for New York.

Four thousand men and women at the Hippodrome last night listened to speeches in German, Russian, Italian and English, denouncing communism, bolshevism, antifascism, the Loyalist Government of Spain and the anti-Nazi boycott. Flags of Nazi Germany, Italy and the stars and stripes were displayed on the platform together with those of old Imperial Russia and the colors of the former Spanish monarchy.
A passenger in a bus bound from Buffalo to Toronto today reported that he had overheard two "foreign appearing" fellow-passengers discussing a plan to kidnap two of the Dionne quintuplets.

William B. Armstrong of Glen Allen was found guilty of stealing two cows by Judge Frederick W. Coleman today and sentenced to ten years in the State penitentiary. Armstrong elected to be tried by Judge Coleman instead of a trial. jury.

Approached from the east or the south via Vienna, Budapest, Prague or Rome, Germany offers a different picture than is seen from the west. To countries poorer, less developed and less resourceful, the political power of the Reich seems stronger and its economic plight less serious than they appear from Britain, France and the United States.

President Agustin P. Justo signed a decree today ordering reconstruction of a seventy-seven-mile gap in the famous Trans-Andean Railway, washed out by glacial floods in 1934, to re-forge the rail link with Chile across the towering mountain chain of the Andes.
