The German Government formally announced today that its legation credited to the Spanish Insurgent junta of Generalissimo Francisco Franco had been raised to the status of an embassy.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Baker of 555 Park Avenue gave a dinner dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the marriage of Mrs. Baker's brother-inlaw and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Newberry of Shadowbrook, Irvington-on-Hudson, who are at the Pierre for the Winter.

Penn's furious finish nipped CoJumbia right at the tape last night to bring to a rousing conclusion a basketball game jammed with thrills. Four successive points in the last two minutes of play gave the Quakers a 4240 victory at the Morningside Heights gymnasium, continued Penn unbeaten in the Eastern Intercollegiate League and moved the circuit pace-setters to the threshold of the championship.

Through mud so deep that the hoofs of walking horses sank out of sight, the colt Bigey ran today to win the Nursery Stakes No. 1 by three lengths in a field of sixteen 2-yearolds which jammed and smashed each other as they fought for footing on the treacherous Hialeah Park strip.

Favorites smashed their way into the third round of the Scottish Football Cup today. Celtic triumphed, 5-2, over Albion Rovers at Coatbridge and Aberdeen downed Third Lanark, 4-2. Hearts scored fifteen goals against King's Park, low-placed second division squad, which failed to reply.

THE early years of Mirabeau, before the French Revolution broke out and gave a fit outlet to his tempestuous genius, were filled with strange adventures, revealing the irrepressible ebulliency of a fiery temper.
Within the next month Dartmouth fraternities will vie with one another in presenting plays in Robinson Hall on the occasion of the annual' contest between the Greek chapters.

PRAGUE.-Czechoslovakia offers a picture of busy bourgeois activity in the working hours and stolid bourgeois tranquillity in the intervals of leisure. A man from Mars would vainly search the country for a sign of "bolshevization."
Fifteen per cent of the undergraduate body at Hamilton will receive unlimited cuts and other privileges during the second semester for excellence in scholarship in the first semester.

The University of Louisville is picking up the pieces after a flood that turned its quiet academic life topsy-turvy. After two weeks of complete closure, its doors are once again open, though many students are unable to return. One-third of its 2,500 students are drawn from the West End of the city, where homes and shops were damaged by the deepest water and swiftest current of the flood.

The second "Faust" of the season was offered last night at the Metropolitan Opera House and attracted a near-capacity assemblage. Unlike the first production, this presentation was marked by the appearance of new principals in the cast. The opera was well received.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is distressing to find that in your issue of Feb. 6, "Topics of The Times" supports a view of the limits of possible achievement by women in literature, science and art which rests upon the crudest kind of fallacious reasoning.

When the appointment of Georges Bonnet as Ambassador to the United States was first rumored it was generally thought it was because he had been Minister of Finance and one of the foremost negotiators for France in recent years at international financial and economic conferences.

BASEBALL weather--and they could have played two games at any of the local ball parks yesterday-led to musing on diamond prospects. Discount the holdouts. They will all be in when the band strikes up.

Up and Up, Mrs. E. I. Wade's 5-year-old gelding, won the sixth and feature race at Alamo Downs today, running the mile in 1:382-5, only one second slower than the track record established last year by Wise Player. The winner went to the post an even-money favorite. Impeach, an outsider, beat out Prince Fox for place.

A new dramatic link with Broadway is being forged at Cornell University as the result of a cooperative plan recently entered into between the Dramatists Guild of New York and the Cornell Dramatic Club.

Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday that he is hopeful that the city's college system can be reorganized so that one of the free higher educational institutions will become a school of technology and another, or at least part of another, a school of government.

Preliminary reports by ninety-one Class I railroads for January show total operating revenues of $272,881,592, compared with $249,210,826 in January last year, a gain of 9.5 per cent, according to the Association of American Railroads.
Through the generosity of Mrs. A. C. Dietrich, Mrs. Sophy Gayton and Miss Mary Reese, several manuscripts of Miss Lizette Woodworth Reese have been given to Goucher College.

Undergraduates from many colleges will counsel girl high school students and answer their questions pertaining to college life and studies at the fourth annual PreCollege Guidance Conference, to be held here April 22 to 25.
MAN rushes through the air in passenger planes at speeds of over 150 miles an hour and dreams of rocket ships that will whisk him across the Atlantic between breakfast and luncheon.

The 210-acre tract known as the Silver property, on Route 22, in Armonk, Westchester County, has been sold to an investing client by Raymond R. Beatty as broker. The property fronts about 1,000 feet on the Armonk Bedford Road and 3,000 feet on the Byram Lake Road.

Ninetyseven of more than 100 stolen books, valued at more than $1,000 but purchased by the owner of a secondhand store for 50 cents at an auction, have been turned over to the Newark Public Library to await identification by their owners, including several libraries in the East.

Charles W. B. Hurd, who has covered the White House and President Roosevelt for THE NEW YORK TIMES ever since the President's first inauguration, was the guest of honor at a dinner given by a group of newspaper men tonight. Mr. Hurd will sail from New York on the President Roosevelt Wednesday to join the London bureau of THE TIMES.
The continued absence of William H. Smathers, New Jersey's Senator, has created a problem for the Capitol postmaster.
Four members of Kappa Sigma Fraternity kept a reunion date Thursday which they made at Penn State College twenty-five years ago.

Squadron A's polo Dream, going at a faster pace than it had revealed previously this season, galloped to a 17 1/2-11 1/2 Metropolita a League victory over its old rival from Brooklyn, Squadron C, at the winner's armory last night before a crowd which jammed the drill shed.

When th e Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary leaves Southampton next Wednesday for New York $500,000 will have been spent for alterations to eliminate the vibration and minimize the rolling which injured several passengers on four of her voyages, including the last one, Dec. 22, when the ship was thirteen hours late reaching Cherbourg after a stormy crossing.

Miss Mary Wilder Howland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Silas W. Howland of Poco Sabo Plantation, this place, and Rye, N. Y., was married at the home of her parents here at noon today to William Creighton Reed, son of Mrs. William B. Reed of 157 East Seventy-second Street, New York.
With the midterm examinations over and much of the tension eased, the student body at the College of William and Mary now can turn its attention to normal studies and some entertainment.

On the eve of the conferences opening in New York between the soft-coal operators and representatives of the United Mine Workers on renewal of the wage and hours contract which expires April 1, there is speculation anew, in view of the direct relation between coal and steel production, over whether the position of the miners will be used to further John L. Lewis's campaign for organization of the steel workers of the United States.

I had suspected-indeed, I had hoped-that the Theatre Guild was keeping Katharine Hepburn in "Jane Eyre" out on the road this year in order that the play might enjoy a longer life than would be permitted it by the infamous New York critics were it brought in after only a week or two.

When depreciation or devaluation of currencies became the fashion, after 1928 or 1931, a good deal was heard of the beneficial influence on the foreign trade of a country which had marked down its currency's gold value. The process was bound to stimulate exports, because foreigners could now buy that country's goods at a lower exchange price.

In Sweden the falling birth-rate, a problem commanding more and more attention in Western Europe, has been well before the public for more than two years. The work there of Professor Gunnar Myrdal, and of Professor Carr-Saunders in England, has made it generally realized that if the present drift is unchecked populations will begin to fall, and the decline become catastrophic without far-reaching reforms.

Lighthorse Harry Cooper of Chicago stood alone at the halfway mark of the $3,000 Houston open golf tournament tonight-five shots ahead of the field and four strokes better than par. Cooper tacked a subpar 70 to his opening 68 for a 138 total-far ahead of the two youngsters tied for second place with 143s.

The sonorous voice of the court crierintoned the traditional announcement in the marble-pillared court room of America's $11,500,000 palace of justice last Monday, the velvet curtains behind the high mahogany bench parted, and the nine most-talked-about men in the United States made their first public appearance since President Roosevelt called on Congress for legislation that would drastically rearrange the Supreme Court's personnel.

In the noisy political confusion of the current crisis in Japan, the warble and twitter of 40,000 poets have passed unheard by the outside world. The Imperial New Year poetry contest was held at the Emperor's Palace in Tokyo recently, and 41,496 poems, all on the same subject, were entered.

A statement received by the Spanish Embassy from the Loyalist government has been made public in behalf of Dr. Leopoldo Alas, president of Oviedo University in Spain, who is reported under sentence of death by the Rebel forces at Burgos.

PROFESSOR CALLAHAN'S book is a contribution of first order to American diplomatic history. With the principal episodes in the relations between the United States and Canada most readers will probably be more or less familiar, since even an elementary acquaintance with American history will include some knowledge of the peace treaty of 1783, the Jay treaty and the Treaty of Ghent.

With dancing now included as an elective part of the Bryn Mawr College athletic program, scores of students are showing a keen interest in it, both as an art and as an avocation, and the campus social calendar includes far more dances than in former years.

Place-Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue, between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets. Dates-Feb. 18-27. Exhibition Hours--Feb. 18, preview 2 P. M. to 11 P. M.; Feb. 21, noon to 10:30 P. M.; Feb. 19, 20, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26 and 27, 11 A. M. to 11 P. M.

The Department of Agriculture reported today that exports of farm products for the first half of the present marketing season were $57,092,000 below the first half of 19351936, while imports increased $88,511,000.

The Irish-Americans of this city defeated the Philadelphia Germans by 1-0 at Clark's Field today to qualify for the third round of the National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Football Association. The match was a replay of the 1-1 tie in the second round at Philadelphia.

Twenty-four chapters of the Daughters of the American Revolution in the metropolitan area will be represented, for the most part by their regents, at the observance on Tuesday of the eighteenth anniversary of the Ellen Hardin Walworth Chapter at the George Washington Hotel.
For the first time since the early Summer of 1935 there is a lull in the storm that has buffeted European diplomacy ever since the Nazi regime came into power in Germany.

BOY and girl members of the American Youth Hostels are renewing acquaintances formed while cycling during vacation days. The same ivydraped New England farmhouses and barns that served as shelters to cyclists in the Summer are now serving as 'headquarters for skiing hostelers during week-ends.

Recession in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity, which has been consistent for a month, was less pronounced for the week ended Feb. 6 but worked out as a loss of half a point. The number stands at 101.2 as against 101.7 in the previous week and 91.6 for the corresponding week last year.

In these days of frigid February, when motor boat folks have their own hot-stove league, just like the baseballers and other sportsmen, it is no wonder that heads are getting together and chins are wagging in speculation about the racing season that has already started in Florida and California and in another few weeks will open on northern waterways.

The complicated state of relations between the Vatican and Spain is shown by the pontifical year book for 1937, which lists diplomatic representatives accredited to the Holy See both from Valencia and from Burgos and Holy See representatives accredited to both of these governments.
MIMOSA blooms are again spreading their golden splendor along the French Riviera as a singna for carnival preparations to get under way. The season when the blue

Leading citizens from twenty-eight towns of Washington County, attending the first banquet of the newly formed Lincoln Club, at Perry, heard Representative Ralph Brewster denounce the proposal to alter the present constituency of the Supreme Court as suicidal and the result of impatience with the orderly process of law.

Indian Broom, Major Austin C. Taylor's outstanding candidate for the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap, came from behind today to win the Glendora Handicap at Santa Anita from four other crack entries in the approaching rich classic.

Wayne C. Robinette, formerly with Alexander Summer, Inc., has joined the Floyd H. Farrant Co. in Teaneck, N. J. The apartment building at 940 Grand Concourse, corner of 163d St., in the Bronx containing 105 suites, is fully rented, according to Port Burke, Inc., agents.
Sheriff Walter Jeffries defended this week the purchases of filet mignon, capons, fruit cocktails, anchovies and other delicacies for the Atlantic County jail last year.
The Bureau of Mines demonstrated today a new gadget to abate the smoke nuisance. It is a shrill whistle which precipitates smoke in snowlike flakes.

When the service employes, which means mostly elevator operators and janitors to the public, announced and began their strike last week, it recalled to many tenants of apartments and office buildings the time last Spring when they climbed stairs to the discomfort of unaccustomed muscles and lungs.

Shooting a sub-par round, Morton McCarthy of Norfolk, Va., who recently paced the amateur contingent in the Nassau open, went into the lead for low-gross honors in the thirty-six-hole medal-play handicap golf competition on St. Augustine links today.
BISMARCK, N. D.-After July 1, for the first time in sixteen years, the citizens of North Dakota can smoke in public eating places and public carriers without breaking the law.

Howard Leland Smith, chief architect of the FHA technical division, speaking before the Small Home Planning Conference of Jamaica, L. I., last week pointed out that the most important factor in planning a square or rectangularshaped house is a simple floor plan with an arrangement of rooms asduring privacy and livability. Adequate closet space, he added, must be provided;

Great excitement prevails throughout Finland over the Presidential election Monday. Though less than two days remain until the electoral college of 300 meets in the Hall of Parliament to choose the new President, the fourth since Finland became independent, there is still much doubt as to who will be elected.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

Miss Veronica Lucelle Keefe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael E. Keefe of Long Hill, has selected Easter Monday for her wedding to William 0. Hadlock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar A. Hadlock of Schenectady, N. Y.
Many parties will be given at the dinner dance for the English squash team to be held on Thursday at the New York Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

THE sudden and dramatic announcement, recently made, of the engagement of Arturo Toscanini to conduct concerts by the orchestra of the National Broadcasting Company next season is significant of many things, but of none more than the potency of the radio as a factor in modern musical life.

Members of the Girls Service League will give a St. Valentine's tea today at their clubhouse, 138 East Nineteenth Street, to mark the midwinter reunion of girls who have attended the organization's Hillcrest Camp in Salisbury, Conn., for the last four years.
Building activity in Queens during January was double that of the same month a year ago, according to John J. Halleran, Commissioner of Public Works.

Optimistic reports from all of the leading districts of the country last week indicated rising trade and industrial activity and gave further evidence of a satisfactory Spring season for business throughout the country.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Marie Dorsey Smith of Brooklyn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Martine Dorsey, to Horatio King Gray, son of Mrs. Percy R. Gray of 12 Clark Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Gray.

High-grade bonds continued to drift to moderately lower levels yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government obligations, as well as many of the underlying railroad and industrial issues, reflected the effect of current uncertainty over the immediate trend of money rates. The absence of near-by bids at prevailing levels rather than any heavy selling pressure directed the decline in the better-grade issues.

Continuing his series c.f upsets, Jack Taylor of the Mont clair Athletic Club, an unranked player, eliminated Ralph DeMoltt of the same club, the top-seeded ace, in a semi-final of the New Jersey Class B squash racquets championship at the Plainfield Country Club today. The score was 2-15, 15--7, 15-8, 12-15 15-12.

With a 4-0 defeat of State Island at Walker Park, Livingston, the soccer players of the Crescent Athletic Club yesterday gained the championship of the Field Club Soccer League of New York and New Jersey for the fourth year in succession and earned the right to meet the team of the Philadelphia Cricket Club in the annual intercity cup match.

Provision for an earlier start and a continuing concentration of graduate study to enable young scholars to receive their doctorate degrees and begin their teaching careers sooner by at least five years was suggested today by Dean George H. Chase of the Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.

TO thousands of young shop and office employes in New York-if I may approach you with a dull truth-the coming of Spring promises countless pleasant outdoor diversions. There are week-end trips to the country for the advantaged.

Miss Hope Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winchester Noyes of 45 East Sixty-second Street and Huntington, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to James Mulford Townsend Jr. in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. George A. Buttrick, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Charlotte Milburn Cheesborough, niece of Devereux Milburn, polo player, won an uncontested divorce today from Thomas P. Cheesborough Jr., prominent socially in Washington. She charged cruelty. Cheesborough was divorced here Sept. 24, 1935, by Eleanor Davies Cheesborough, daughter of Joseph E. Davies, Ambassador to Russia.

ALTHOUGH the President's recommendation that the Supreme Court be enlarged to fifteen members is part and parcel of a general plan for the reform of the Federal judiciary, and is cogently supported by his message as a measure for dealing with superannuation on the bench, it has already drawn fire as an "adroit" way of "packing the court" with a membership favorable to the New Deal.
A four-year term for Connecticut Governors and establishment of a Governor's Cabinet were among the proposals made for the executive branch by the State Commission on Reorganization issued today.

Three freighters were prevented from sailing from here yesterday because the crews would not accept the system of continuous discharge books required under the recently passed Copeland act. The controversy had been started by three maritime unions on the Pacific Coast on Friday.

Dr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Previtali gave a reception last night at their home at 1,107 Park Avenue for Mrs. Olivia Rossetti Agresti, which was attended by many members of the Italian Historical Society, of which the host is chairman of the board.
Milton Dwight Purdy, former Judge of the United States court at Shanghai, China, and former Federal judge in Minnesota, died here Thursday night of a heart ailment. He was 70 years old.
Albert Thomas, 28, who escaped from a London, Ohio, prison camp in July and married a Taunton girl five months later, was held here today on a plea of guilty to being a fugitive from justice.

Jascha Heifetz, whose last appearance with the Philadelphia Orchestra was in 1930, will be the soloist in the concerts Friday and Saturday when the Sibelius Concerto in D minor for violin and orchestra will be played.

Jack Deblois, a Piscataquis County guide and trapper, says the deer is the vainest creature in the forests. He declares that many a time, from a secluded spot, he has watched the graceful animals stop at some quiet pool which mirrored them plainly.

THE WINGLESS VICTORY" was six months finished and the hands of Katharine Cornell waiting the end of her "Saint Joan" engagement."The Masque of Kings" had been delivered to the Theatre Guild by the previous day's post or messenger. Maxwell Anderson with his son and the latter's companion set out on a tramp to High Tor, five miles distant from the Anderson farm up Rockland County way by the Hudson River. It was a Spring day.

FICTION "A CARDINAL OF THE MEDICI." Susan Hicks Beach. (Macmillan.) March. "BUCKSKIN BREECHES." Phil Stong. (Farrar Rinehart.) March/ "TODAY IS FOREVER." Ramona Herdman. (Harper.) March. "ALL GOOD AMERICANS." Jerome Bahr. (Scribner's) March.

Signing of the peace treaty in the General Motors strike was by all odds the most important news of the holiday week just completed. Activity in steel shares was the feature of the market, with the optimism at home helped along materially by heavy buying of our securities by European investors.
Three days next week will be given over by the Johns Hopkins University to a celebration of the twenty-first anniversary of its School of Engineering and of the sixty-first year of its own history.
A "smokeless chimney" is being devised in the Lake Forest University laboratory of Dr. Roscoe E. Harris, physicist, who has done much research work with the photoelectric cell.

In the role of silent listeners the nine Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States last week heard dissertations by more than a dozen attorneys on many aspects of constitutional law, with particular reference to the powers of Congress.

Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, offered today to appear before the New York Public Service Commission in support of his assertions at a House Appropriations subcommittee hearing Dec. 10 that "certain power rate schedules in New York City were out of line and too high."

There is a great diversity of opinion among the weather-wise as to whether we are likely to have a very early or a very late Spring, after the abnormal Winter which the Weather Bureau so far has served us. Gardeners soon learn, however, that the safest general rule to follow, so far as the weather is concerned, is to plan for the normal.

A report from Wuchow says that Chinese soldiers and students at Kweilin have seized American mission premises embracing the Baptist mission compound and school and the Baptist Hospital. It appears that the troops, accompanied by 200 students, forcibly entered the premises and took possession. No further details were given.

Ernest Schelling continued his musical itinerary yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall. On this occasion with the aid of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, the conductor took his near-capacity assemblage of youngsters-also a large sprinkling of adults-on a Mediterranean cruise.

As a result or the trena toward greater reliance on responsible apparel resources by retailers, the average span of life of a "capably conducted coat and suit house" will be lengthened from six years, as at present, to a considerably longer period, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, will say in his report to be made at the annual meeting of the membership on Tuesday.
SEA ISLAND, Ga. - Stirring rhythms and swaying bodies will characterize the spirituals by the St. Simons Negro Singers .to be given in the Cloister Spanish lounge at Sea Island this Sunday evening.

Colgate University students who spent the first semester in Washington studying government and its operations as laboratory work in a course in political science have returned. Dr. Paul S. Jacobsen of the politics department, who was in charge of the delegation. said:
DAYS TO COME. By Lillian Hellman. 105 pages. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $2. Text of a three-act drama about a strike in a small Middle Western community; it was produced in New York on Dec. 15, 1936.

The faculty of Barnard College entertained the students last night in Brinckerhoff Theatre on the campus with a farce, "The Faculty Follies," which had been requested by the undergraduates. The performance was for the benefit of the college's Fiftieth Anniversary Fund.

The array of selections brought forward by Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, the English duo-pianists, at their recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon was as exceptional, in its way, as the playing of it by the talented couple.
Officers and members of the New York Southern Society have subscribed en masse to "a real Southern party" which will be held on Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Lower interest rates and a longer period of amortization are regarded by Paul E. Stark, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, as absolutely essential to bring the number of home owners in the United States to the volume which he considers ought to be attrained.

One by one basic foods are going up in price, and the higher living costs forecast by the government at the beginning of the year are gradually becoming a reality. During the last two weeks the dearer brands of coffee have gone up 1 cent and the cheaper brands between 2 and 3 cents a pound.

Mrs. Eliot James gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 520 East Eighty-seventh Street, for Miss Cornelia Van Rensselaer Strong, daughter of Mrs. Theodore Strong of Stronghold, New Brunswick,

Relying more on a beautifully balanced program rather than attempting to carry the entire meet on the Baxter Mile alone, the New York Athletic Club will stage its annual indoor track and field carnival at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. It gives promise of being one of the best of the campaign.
School Health Day for the Spring term will be observed on Feb. 25 and teachers have been directed to make an inventory of their pupils' health for the month to be reported on that date.

The marriage of Miss Irene Rudy, daughter of Mrs. James Henry Rudy of ?? Ky., and the late Mr. ?? to Robert M. Henry, son of ?? and Mrs. Frank Hamilton ?? of Rye, took place here tonight in the Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by ?? Rev. Carl B. Bare, the pastor.
Aunt Sally Gardner observed her 101st birthday this week. She celebrated the event by defending the young people of today in a talk given from a comfortable rocker in her cozy home.

Three championships were taken by United States players today as the English table tennis tournament ended. Miss Ruth Hughes Aarons of New York won the women's singles title and teamed with Bud Blattner of St. Louis to take the mixed doubles honors. The New York combination of Sol Schiff and Abe Berenbaum won in men's doubles.
That the girls of today are just as sentimental as those of years gone by is drawn as a conclusion from the observance of St. Valentine's Day by Skidmore College students.

Fifteen Bucknell University women students chosen in competitive eliminations as the best co-ed spellers on the campus are brushing up on particularly difficult words in preparation for an intercollegiate spelling match next Saturday afternoon with fifteen men from Columbia University.

THE Japanese call their combination of propaganda and censorship "thought control." It is an expression that throws a great deal of light on what has been happening to the Germans since the arrival of the totalitarian State. Totalitarianism has taken time to establish itself. The nation-wide organization known as the Propaganda Ministry, with thirty-one subordinate offices in all corners of the Reich, is just beginning to appear in proper perspective.

THE first comprehensive announcement of the plans for the coming coronation opera season at Covent Garden in London discloses one bit of news that should interest followers of the lyric stage on this side of the Atlantic. That is the tidings that Lawrence Tibbett will appear in London.
The persistent ringing of an alarm clock concealed behind an organ interrupted Dr. Albert C. Wieand of Chicago as he addressed a chapel assembly of Bluffton College students yesterday.

The Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue, opened its annual exhibition of water-colors by its artist members yesterday afternoon. The show, which contains 130 paintings, will continue until Feb. 26 and will be open to the public in the afternoons.

The Muhlenberg College basketball team defeated Lehigh in Taylor gym tonight by 31 to 25. Lehigh took an early 7-to-4 lead, but Muhlenberg knotted the score at 9-all, then went into the lead and was never headed.

THE question of "master points" has again aroused controversy among different factions interested in the conduct of contract bridge tournaments. Master points are given by several national and sectional bridge associations as evidence of success in competition; a player finishing in first or second place is credited by the association sponsoring the tournament with a number of master points considered commensurate with the importance of the tournament.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helen Creighton Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight R. G. Palmer of South Orange, to John E. Currier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Currier of Montclair.

Another day of the unusually warm weather which has characterized this Winter was recorded by the Weather Bureau yesterday. At 2:50 P. M., the temperature went to within less than two degrees of the high record for the date, with a reading of just above 56 degrees.

Mrs. George H. Earle 3d, wife of the Governor, will head the list of patronesses for the presentation here on April 7 by the Harvard University Hasty Pudding Club of "Come Across" at the Bellevue-Stratford.

IN what amounts to a series of lyrics, sometimes catching the rhythms of Archibald MacLeish, sometimes written in shorter lines, Frances Frost now traces, from 1500 down, the history of the conquest of America.

WITH quail, duck and turkey hunting and trap shooting in full swing; with golf, polo and tennis tournaments, horse shows and cross-country rides scheduled to reach a climax in March, and with red, pink and white camellias, roses, azaleas and pansies beginning to bloom, Georgia is ready to greet the Winter visitor seeking balmy air. and warm sunshine.

Only one member of the Cabinet would have to retire if the President's proposed age limit of 70 for members of the Supreme Court were applied to his official family. Secretary Swanson is 74; he was born on March 31, 1862 Secretary Roper will be 70 on April 1.
Jean Burke, 25 years old, once a companion of the late John Dillinger, was seized with two men today for questioning about a robbery gang which has preyed on Gold Coast residents.

President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court has caused Dean Robert S. Stevens of the Cornell Law School to comment that "I think it's unfortunate that a power to alter the court exists, and I think it's fortunate that the power has not been used until the present time."

Sweeping six first places, the Princeton gymnastic team beat Dartmouth, 41-13, today. Jacobs starred for the Tigers with two firsts and a second to match the entire team total of Dartmouth. Gucker, intercollegiate rope climbing champion, lost to his team-mate Houston in his specialty, but took first in the side horse event.

Trotskyists abroad, in their attacks on the Soviet regime following the recent trial and sentencing here of alleged Trotskyists charged with treason and other crimes, have drawn a red herring across the trail in the form of a story about a "new and ruthless purge of the Communist party from top to bottom."
Five guards instead of the usual three watched over the Dionne quintuplets tonight as police investigated stories of a plot to kidnap two of the famous little girls.

REALISM has become a some what moot term. It has been employed in contexts often so widely at variance as to convey at length a general as opposed to a specific meaning. One factor involved is an indiscriminate substitution of the term "realism" for the term "naturalism."

Army's indoor polo team rode to its twenty-ninth straight victory today, turning back Yale, 10-9, in the feature of an attractive sports program at the academy. The Cadet basketball team halted Providence College, 48-34, while the boxers conquered Bucknell, 6-2, and the fincers lost to Columbia University, 14-13. in other varsity contests.

Andrew F. Derr Jr. has purchased from Daniel A. Heald thirteen acres of land on Blue Mill Road, in the New Vernon section of Morristown, N. J. The property adjoins the estate of Marcellus. Hartley Dodge. Eugene V. Welsh acted as broker.

Georges Bonnet, new French Ambassador to Washington, sailed last week for this country. As successor to Andre de Laboulaye, he is equipped with "precise" plans, drawn up but not disclosed by the Blum Cabinet. On the eve of his departure Mr. Bonnet said:

The Philadelphia Eagles and the Pittsburgh Pirates will offer the first display of 1937 National Football League technique at Pittsburgh on Sept. 5. the earliest opening date in the professional circuit's history.

AFTER fifty-seven months as President of the French Republic, Albert Lebrun has become godfather to no fewer than 1,363 boys and girls. At this rate, when he retires from the Elysee Palace in May, 1939.

Senator Pliny W. Williamson's bill for a reapportionment of the Congressional districts in this State received yesterday the approval of the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union. The bill, drafted by Professor Wallace Sayre of New York University, gives New York City twenty-five Representatives out of forty-five and increases the representation of Queens, the Bronx and Brooklyn, while decreasing that of Manhattan.

A demand for high quality building materials is reported by manufacturers and dealers operating in and around New York City, according to Thomas G. Grace, State Director of the Federal Housing Administration. Residential construction in that area will hereafter be on a higher standard so far as materials, he predicts.

LONG before they were actually discovered, the physicists knew that there were what we now call radio waves which were nothing but invisible light waves. When Hertz began his classic experiments fifty years ago and Marconi telegraphed through space there were great arguments about the distance to which the waves could be sent.

Thanks to their superior firefighting facilities, city folk have fifteen times as good a chance of saving their property in a fire as those in rural areas, according to Dr. David J. Price, fire and explosion specialist of the Federal Bureau of Chemistry and Solls.

A MONG the innovations which the National Socialist regime brought to Germany was the concentration camp for political prisoners. The Nazis did not invent it, but took it over bodily from the rivals from whom they have undertaken to save Europe, namely the Bolsheviks. Thus, in Germany, men and women are again being imprisoned for their political and religious beliefs.
AFTER twenty years of operating a gallery in Berlin, to gether with the publication of works on art, Karl Nierendorf has opened a New York gallery at 20 East Fifty-third Street.

Room sales of thirty transient hotels here in January, amounting to $2,199,551, showed a gain of 12.76 per cent over the total in the corresponding period last year, due to increases of 5.74 per cent in occupancy and 6.58 per cent in the average daily rate, according to the monthly statistics issued yesterday by Harris, Kerr, Forster Co., accountants.

THE Metropolitan Opera, now midway in its sawn is maintaining its tradition of lavish and impresive stage scenes; in that tradition the supernumerary, as well as the star, has a share But the super is often called the forgotten man of the opera.

Doubt is expressed in a report recently made by the special committee on housing of the Merchants Association of New York of any authority in the Federal Government giving the power to construct housing facilities to be sold or rented to private persons. Even if such a policy should be held legal by the courts, experience, it is held,

Stockholders of the Granby Consolidated Mining, Smelting and Power Company, Ltd., approved last Thursday issuance of $750,000 five-year 5 per cent convertible debentures and also authorized an increase of 100,000 shares in the common stock.

The United States is more heterogeneous and decentralized in its tax system than any other major nation in the Western World, according to a report, made public yesterday, which has been submitted to the special committee on taxation of the Twentieth Century Fund by a staff of fifteen tax specialists.

Another attempted attack on a woman today stirred this city where two other women and a girl have had encounters with men in the eight days since Mary Ellen Babcock was slain. Miss Virginia Skolyn, 29-year-old waitress, collapsed in a field at 4 A. M. today, after repulsing the attentions of a man in an automobile.
The United States may, if it wishes, have preference in Filipino trade, President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Islands said. on arrival here today.
IT is not an infrequent decorative practice to derive from a painting the color scheme of an interior or to choose a picture for a particular room because it "picks up" the colors already in it.

The settlement of the General Motors strike leaves organized labor with a foothold among the "Big Three" of the automobile industry. For the first time a union has won recognition on a company-wide basis from the corporation which produces 45 per cent of all American automobiles.

After a weak opening, the stock market drifted irregularly lower during yesterday's abbreviated session. Motor and steel shares bore the brunt of the selling, with the copper issues also showing signs of weakness.

Captain John W. Conover, who commanded the yacht of the late United States Senator Boise Penrose of Pennsylvania, died at his home here yesterday after a stroke. His age was 75. He was born in Conovertown, near here, and came to Atlantic City sixty-one years ago.
Three gifts to Amherst College are announced by President King.

Under the direction of the junior class of Goucher College, Baltimore, Md., a united campaign fund will be started Monday. This annual drive in the past has been primarily for purpose of perpetuating a scholarship at the Isabella Thorburn College, Lucknow, India, by which a student will be sent to Goucher, but this year the students expect to do other things when the goal is attrained.

TRACK EVENTS Briggs 50-Yard Dash-Won by Sam Stoller. Michigan; second, Ben Johnson, Columbia; third, Kenneth Clapp, Brown. Time-0:05.5. Samuel Richardson, Toronto: Herbert Weast, Columbia, and Martin Glickman, Syracuse, also ran. 45-Yard High Hurdles-Won by John Donovan, Dartmouth: second, Sam Allen, Bristow, Okla.; third, John Gowell, Maine; fourth, James S. McCarthy, Boston. Time--0:05.8. (Equals old world record.)

Judging from the large subscription for the annual Mi-Careme luncheon and bridge for the benefit of the Jesuit Seminaries to be held on March 9 in the Embassy Suite of the Ambassador, the fund for maintaining the various Houses of Study of the Jesuit Missions will be augmented greatly.
THIS having been a dullish week along Broadway, with nary an epic among the new films, we pause-more in desperation than in anger-to inquire what has become of comedy.

Intrastate control of the products of child labor as a substitute for the Child Labor Amendment will be upheld by Dr. E. Stagg Whitin, executive chairman of the National Committee on Prisons and Prison Labor, at a meeting of the Woman's Forum Friday morning at the Hotal Roosovolt.
Nineteen sophomore students of the School of Nursing of Russell Sage College entered the Albany Hospital Feb. 1 to begin their two-year period of clinical instruction and experience.
The New York A. C. trio overcame a two-goal handicap to win in the high-goal division and the Allenhurst Polo Club triumphed in the final of the low-goal tournament as the N. Y. A. C. eleventh annual
THE slow process of making America social-security conscious goes on in every corner of the land. New York sees posters in crosstown ?? uses which promise boldly.

Paced by Earl Robinson and Cy Wentworth, each with two goals, the Montreal Maroons tonight defeated their intracity rivals, the Canadiens, 5-1, in a National Hockey League clash before a jammed house of close to 11,000 fans.

The associate members of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies hold their annual meeting tomorrow at the Hotel Pierre, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street. Miss Jane M. Hoey, director of the Bureau of Public Assistance of the Social Security Board, will speak on "Social Security."
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 12:

A course in how the arts, including the moving pictures and the radio, portray social problems, arranged by the Social Work Publicity Council, will begin Feb. 24, at 4:30 P. M., in the Russell Sage Foundation Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street, it was announced yesterday.

Victory over Ireland, snatched in the closing minutes of play, today put England in a position to capture the international rugby tournament. Before an enthusiastic crowd of 60,000, the Englishmen staged a rousing finish to win, 9-8, after fighting an uphill battle from the start.
President William Green and the council of the American Federation of Labor today wrote to General Hugh S. Johnson saying that "we are amazed" at his newspaper column references,

After more than twenty hours' deliberation the jury in the case of Martin Schlossman and Harry Weiss charged with kidnapping Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton lawyer, reported yesterday morning to Judge John J. Fitzgerald, in the Kings County Court, that it was unable to agree on a verdict.

Further reduction in vacancies in low-rent houses on the East Side, in Harlem, the Bronx and Brooklyn were reported by Charles Abrams, counsel to the New York City Housing Authority, which is investigating the housing shortage.

The Design Laboratory, a school of industrial design directed by the WPA Federal Art Project at 10 East Thirty-ninth Street, announced yesterday that nine guest lecturers would participate in its "Design Analysis Lecture Schedule."

Activities on San Francisco's waterfront are back in high gear as a result of the settlement of the costly three months' maritime strike. First sign of revitalized action was the posting of eleven charters on the board at the Marine Exchange here.

Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's newspaper declared tonight, on the eve of a meeting of 1,500 leaders of the Government party, that restoration of the Hapsburg monarchy in Austria must be considered a possibility.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh has applied for permission to fly over Iran (Persia) and may extend the tour he and Mrs. Lindbergh are making as far as India, an authoritative source said today.

Mr. and Mrs. O. Fred Arthur of Albuquerque, N. M., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Lettiece Arthur, to Henry Dike Bixby Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. H. D. Bixby, of Huntington. The wedding is expected to take place in April. The couple will reside in South America.

Prices on the Boerse were slightly stronger today in a small turnover. Heavy industrials were quiet; Bruderus, Mannesmann, Rheinstahl and Vereinigtestahl each gained 1/2 point. Potashes fell, Aschesleben losing 1 point and Westeregeln 1 1/4. Machines were mixed. Electricals were quiet, but Siemens Halske gained 2 1/2 points.

Many American gardeners do not sufficiently utilize the native vines. There is an abundance of them. Each' has a distinctive charm. Certain types are suitable for banks, rookeries or stone or brick structures; others are effective on trellises, fences or arbors. They may be conspicuous for handsome foliage, brilliant flowers or showy fruit.

There may be fewer boyish pranks around New York if the bill to outlaw air rifles introduced last week by Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley is voted by the City Fathers. Technological improvements, it seems, have made .the onceharmless toys a dangerous weapon.

Leaders of Jewish organizations have invited rabbis and leaders of synagogues throughout Greater New York to participate in a conference today at the Hotel Astor to further American Jewish effort in behalf of the rebuilding of Palestine through the United Palestine Appeal, it was announced yesterday.

Calls from employers to the Vocational Service for Juniors increased from 799 in 1934 to 1,147 in 1936, while applications for work dropped from 25,132 to 9,840 in the same period, according to a three-year report issued yesterday by Mrs. Edward C. Henderson, president of the organization.
Dr. Evan J. Smith, a practicing physician for years in this village and vicinity, died last night at his home. He was 70 years old.

The Works Progress Administration workers who staged a sit-down strike in the Park Department garage on the Eighty-sixth Street transverse road through Central Park early Friday morning in protest against reclassification of skilled workers as common laborers will not attempt to return to work tomorrow, it was said yesterday at Workers Alliance headquarters.

Costa Rica probably has the highest percentage of landowners of any country in the world, undoubtedly the highest in the Americas. The government reports that 84 per cent of the heads of families at the close of 1936 were landowners, an increase of 3 per cent over the figure for 1935.

The National Socialist State's attempt to govern gently the Protestant church in Germany ended today in a public breach with the government's own Reich Church Administrative Commission. The orthodox but compromiseseeking Protestant churchmen appointed to control the church for the government have resigned in a body, and the press announced this afternoon that a further decree providing for the government of German Protestantism would be issued by the State Monday.

FISH is the traditional Lenten food, and this season its consumption is expected to reach a new high. Several forces are at work--the abundant supply of fish, its quality and its low price in terms of food value.

A high degree of intelligence is a handicap in certain jobs, according to Professor M. R. Trabue of the University of North Carolina. He makes the statement in a preliminary report to the American Youth Commission on the Occupational Adjustment of American Youth.
Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Abelow of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hadassah Abelow, to Charles Feit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Felt, also of Brooklyn.

"Let us have peace and make automobiles," said William S. Knudsen, vice president in charge of production of General Motors, last Thursday as he added his signature to the agreement which ended a six-week sit-down strike against his company-the first major shutdown of General Motors and the first major effort of the young international union, United Automobile Workers of America.

The volume of bonds called before maturity last week was less than half that of the preceding week, owing in part to the Lincoln's Birthday holiday. Among the calls, which were mostly for future months and principally for small lots of municipal bonds, were two large refundings,
WHEN Mohammed was asked what was the greatest act of charity, Mr. Ludwig tells us, he replied: "To bring water to men."

THIS book is the straightforward record of a British journalist's visit to the disturbed and disturbing land of Palestine in the Summer of 1936. As such, it is timely, objective, informative, and probably as nearly impartial as it is humanly possible to be. Mr. Farago has written an admirable report, and, needless to say, a very interesting one.

TROTSKY'S telephone speech from Mexico encountered wire trouble because most of the Mexican telephone company's technicians belong to a proStalin union. This is one more useful reminder for good people who hate politicians and want a world ruled by technicians.

The senior class of the New York Medical College, affiliated with the Flower Hospital, will hold its annual supper dance next Saturday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. In charge of the arrangements are Peter V. O. Bisconti, chairman; John Edward Annitto, H. Roland Chinigo, Douglas Giorgio, Mortimer Mann, Joseph Presti, Irving Shiner, Anthony Noto, Frank Prisco, Charles Stack and Charles B. Tramont.

HARVARD UNIVERSITY plans to inaugurate regular broad casting of classroom lectures for the short-wave audience starting this week over Station WIXAL, Boston. The university authorities announce that if the undertaking proves successful this Spring the broadcasts will be continued indefinitely as a regular part of the university program.

The man who sold information obtained in Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's office to Abraham Cohen, lawyer-defendant on trial in the restaurant racket, was one of the "hand-picked" policemen assigned to the investigation, it was made known yesterday.

Brevity, winner in wtrld-record time of the last Florida Derby and beaten favorite in the 1936 Kentucky Derby, is at the top of the list for the $50,00 added Widener Challenge Cup on March 6 at Hialeah Park, according to the announcement of weights by Handicapper Charles McLennan today. Brevity, assigned 124 pounds, is owned by Joseph E. Widener.

MR. NATHAN'S play contains 190 pages of the most exquisite poetry, the moat romantic and appealing characters and the most engaging scenes in the English-speaking drama. It has better poetry and better drama than the collected works of Eugene O'Neill, Bernard Shaw, Henrik Ibsen, W. B. Yeats, T. S. Eliot, Maxwell Anderson, and any one else at the moment out of mind.

Sails While Would.-Be Voyagers Are Searching for Passports Two passengers were left behind on the pier at West Eighteenth Street yesterday when the Italian liner Conte di Savoia sailed at noon for Mediterranean port. They were Mr. and Mrs. Daniel F. Rice, who had been stopping at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The engagement of Miss Maude Beatrice Pfalzgraf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Pfalzgraf of this city, to Horace Darlington of Brookline, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hart Darlington, also of Maplewood, has been announced by her parents.

A 68-year-old veteran of the Belgian Army is nearing this town after a sixteen-year-walking tour of Europe, Asia and Canada that covered more than 46,000 miles. Jean de Vaudreuil, who lost an arm and a leg in battle, landed at Borden, P. E. L Thursday.

THE special interest of Mr. Charles Landstone's "Behind Your Back" is that it is a purely commercial play. Most plays, alas, are commercial in purpose, but few are openly and unashamedly that and nothing else.

Fifty-one delegates from fourteen countries, including three Americans, will arrive here Monday for a four-day Congress which it is hoped will culminate in the creation of an international body of World War veterans.

Columbia's freshman basketball team defeated Trinity School, 33 to 25, yesterday in the Lions' gymnasium. The Blue had an 18-7 advantage at half time. Naylor, with 9 points, starred for Columbia, while Hartog and Rector each had eight points for Trinity.

William E. Sands, for forty years well known in the circus business, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 76. He had been advance publicity man for Barnum Bailey Circus, for Ringling Brothers and for Hagenbach Wallace shows.

Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Lustig of 211 Central Park West have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Florence Lustig, to Jack Poust, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Poust of 9 East Ninety-sixth Street. The wedding will take place next Sunday.

A delegation of British churchmen representing the Anglican Church, free churches and the Society of Friends has just completed its mission of investigating the republican government's attitude toward religious tolerance.

Miss Katherine Elizabeth Crane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Torrey Crane, and Richard Francis Burdett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Burdett, were married here today at the Crane residence by the Rev. Dr. John Curry Walker, pastor of the Second Congregational Church.

Leaders of all departments of British sport are included among the thirty-one members of the National Advisory Council for England and Wales appointed by the government in connection with its plans for improving the national physique.
THE most recent air line crash in San Francisco Bay throws into the spotlight again the conference just concluded between air line operators and the Department of Commerce.

THE Petershams have a way of lifting the common facts of living far above the commonplace. To their series of informational books, which have removed much of the onerous implication of that term, they have added a fourth book, a story book of the basic foods from the large and diversified grass family:

Chinaware that takes some of its charm from its early American ancestry as to decorative motif and color, and yet is as up-to-date looking as a 1937 automobile, is arriving in the household-goods departments of some of the stores. Its designer went back to china used by Americans of other centuries for inspiration for colors and decorative patterns.
A warning against promises by correspondence schools of training looking to sure positions with the Social Security Board was issued today by the board and the Civil Service Commission.

Streamlining made the Yankee clippers the fastest ships afloat a century ago. One of the first such experiments has come to light in the historic American merchant marine survey of the Smithsonian Institution.

Miss Julia Schairer of Bronxville, N. Y., will lead the Mount Holyoke College group of thirtysix official delegates at the New England Model League of Nations Assembly to take place on March 12 and 13 at Harvard University and Radcliffe College.

The jewelry, silver, tapestries and period furniture sold at the threeday auction ending yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries realized $51,580, the final session bringing more than half this sum, or $26,087.50.

The American actress Mary Morris will be seen on the London stage next week with a dramatic part in "Suspect," by Reginald Denham, a play and film producer, and Edward Percy. With her in the cast are Jean Cadell, David Horne and Campbell Gullan.

In a home ceremony this afternoon, Miss Pauline Seipp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Seipp of Lincoln Park West, became the bride of William Brown Goltra, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Goltra of St. Louis.

The Pure Oil Company's stockholders will be asked to approve capital structure readjustments that may clear the way for declaration of common stock dividends, Henry M. Dawes, president, announced today.
An interesting illustration of the business improvement in most of the residential centers of Westchester County is presented in a survey recently made by Thomas J. O'Reilly in New Rochelle.

The newspaper La Nacion said today that Argentina had killed a United States project to make the Monroe Doctrine a multilateral American declaration prior to the Inter-American. Peace Conference last December.

The Delaware State Bar Association, by a vote of 72 to 5, adopted a resolution today protesting against President Roosevelt's proposal for an increase in the Supreme Court membership. Nine in attendance did not vote. The bar of the whole State was represented.
A late attack enabled Penn to gain a 33-to29 triumph over Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game today.

Robert Page, president of the Student Council of the New York University Law School, was elected chairman and Miss Martha Reed of Barnard College co-chairman of the New York City division of the Intercollegiate Democratic League at a meeting yesterday at 1,440 Broadway.

Crack troops marshaled by the Spanish Government drove Insurgents back tonight with a fierce assault on entrenchments in heights dominating the Madrid-Valencia highway. An almost ceaseless battle has been under way for three days near Arganda about fifteen miles southeast of Madrid.
SKI patrols are being organized in districts where snow trains pour hundreds of skiers into local trails. Newest of the patrols is that of the Mount Greylock Ski Club of Pittsfield, Mass.

LONDON. IN the past when Christmas drew near, the thoughts of opera lovers turned to fortunate cities where Christmas Eve marked the opening of important events. This year, by the second week of January not one but four London organizations are engaged in the production of opera.

A. resumption of the international exchange of students, particularly On the part of Germany and the nations of Central Europe, for the advancement of social and intellectual intercourse and the strengthening of peace, was urged yesterday by Miss Erin Sampson, director of the Paris study group of the Catholic women's colleges of the United States.

The controversy stirred up by the President's proposals for reform of the judiciary system gets its bite from the belief that Mr. Roosevelt mainly wishes to eliminate Supreme Court opposition to his legislative program.
THIS year will witness in the Midsouth the climax of the most successful season of a rapidly. spreading new sport-running bird dogs in cross-country competition on points.

This bulletin is posted by special order of Alexander Woollcott, towncrier and party whip. Sixteen years ago he wept politely over a performance of "Aucassin and Nicolete," which was played by children-actors under Dorothy Coit's direction, and he published his affectionate grief in these venerable columns.

THE industry received a rude shock the other day when one of the broadcast chains refused to allow a studio to alter characterizations, plot and mood in adapting a radio serial to the screen. Negotiations of several months' duration between Paramount and National Broadcasting Company were terminated by the radio concern when the studio insisted on a too liberal interpretation of the "One Man's Family"

The Middlebury College Glee Club will make two concert tours this Spring, according to Manager Arthur Wilson of Hackensack, N. J. On Feb. 24 it will open its New England tour at Keene, N. H. Just before the Spring vacation it will. give seven concerts in New York and New Jersey.

Donald B. Carpenter of Burlington has been elected editor-in-chief of the student newspaper The Cynic at the University of Vermont. Other staff members elected include Marie Catania of Garfield, N. J., managing editor;

The solution of the motor truck and railway problem is much more complicated than appears on the surface and requires more than half-hearted attempts at rate regulation, according to S. W. Fairweather, director of the Bureau of Economics, Canadian National Railways.

Chicago again is the grain capital of the world, a position which it held for many. decades until Minneapolis took the lead in 1935. Statistics from the fifteen leading markets in this country disclose that last year American

A peek into the political teacup for prognostications on the future of women in public office-based on the past-brings the International Federation of Business and Professional Women to the chastening admission that progress depends upon abolishing apathy toward the franchise, in many instances.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Neil of New York and St. Petersburg entertained at dinner at the Soreno tonight in honor of their niece, Mrs. Victor L. Mitchell of New York, who is spending a month with them here.

Association of Jewish Youth, Marcus Loew Auditorium, 7 West Eightythird Street, 10:15 A. M. "Jewish Youth and the Present," Mark McCloskey, I. Edwin Goldwasser and Samuel Paul Puner. Annual convention luncheon of Trinity College Alumnae, Hotel Barbizon, Sixty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, 1 P. M. "Today's Interracial Problems." the Rev. John La Farge.

Although favorite lakes and other fishing spots of the Northeastern portion of the continent are frozen, and despite bitter winds that whistle through woods of Maine and Canadian Provinces promising snow and ice for-the remaining period of the'Winter, there will be a reminder Thursday that Summer is not far off.

During the Lenten season there will be four meetings of the sewing class which works for the Fresh Air Association of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The association conducts a home at Tompkins Cove, N. Y. The first meeting will be held Tuesday morning at the home of Mrs. Stephen C. Clark, 46 East Seventieth Street. Mrs. Joseph Burden will give readings.
The Dartmouth hockey team won its first game in International Intercollegiate League competition by defeating Yale, 4-1, tonight in a rough and exciting game.

Recorder volume improved in the wholesale market here last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Retailers requested that prompt deliveries be made on orders already placed, due to good consumer response to early presentations of Spring merchandise. The report continues:

Returning to early season form, Harvard's varsity basketball team remained in the running for a first division berth in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by routing Princeton, 36-22, tonight before 1,000 Crimson rooters.

This Winter's unusually mild weather has affected the "egg market," the New York Mercantile Exchange, Hudson and Harrison Streets. The egg news "broke" yesterday while the temperature was reminiscent of Easter and Easter eggs.
Most farmers would give almost anything to keep raccoons out of their poultry houses, but Bert Morang, who lives up Pleasant Valley way, has been offered all kinds of fancy prices for his pet coon.

Home building in Florida has progressed to such an extent, dedares Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, that it is possible to get some definite idea as to what the houses of the coming period will look like.
More than 400 guests are expected at the annual luncheon bridge of the Catholic Young Women's Club, on Feb. 25, in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Paul T. Kammerer Jr. is in charge.

A new chapter in the history of the American farm relief movement was written this week. It was the work of fifty-odd representative farm leaders, who met in conference here at the call of Secretary Wallace to formulate a permanent agricultural policy.

A list of thirty-three army-produced motion-picture films depicting numerous parade and combat evolutions and manoeuvres of expert troops, has been made available for use as aids to the training of military personnel, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the Second Corps Area at Governors Island.

As the crest of the Mississippi flood rolls down on the lower valley past Memphis, all levees are holding and their tops are further above the expected high mark than in 1927, when so many of these earthworks crumbled under the assault of the river.

Baby' Prince Victor Emmanuel, who one day may be King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia, received preliminary baptism today while joy spread through prisons in, the land as thousands of political prisoners learned of a grant of amnesty by the King on the occasion of the birth of his grandson.

As it aims to destroy the existing political parties by repeated election campaigns, the Japanese Army is also striving mightily to build up a new party, based on the extreme Right Wing of thought in Japan, drawing into its fold as many of the old-line party men as possible.

Henry Hesse, retired importer and former president of Henry Hesse Realty Company of 961 Lexington Avenue, died of a heart attack at his home, 164 East Seventysecond Street, on Friday. He was 75 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Cantor of the St. Moritz and Woodmere, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gladys Muriel Cantor, to Joseph Weckstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Weckstein of Lawrence, L. I.

THE first of the series of crimes with which this novel deals dates from about twelve years before the story opens It is our old friend Reggie Fortune who discovers the evidence of the earlier crime and who starts an investigation in which he is opposed not only by the local authorities but also by causes which go back to prehistoric times.

Paavo Nurmi's twelve-year-old standard for two miles indoors fell before the flying feet of Don Lash tonight at the Boston Garden where, in the presence of 14,000 wildly excited spectators, the Indiana iron man ran a formidable group of rivals into the ground with the fastest two-mile race the world has ever witnessed.

Just before leaving New York last week for her home in San Francisco-being now more than halfway across the continent-Miss Louise Boyd admitted that she will shortly head her own expedition into the Arctio again.

THE approach of Spring is now being observed on the short waves. Each Winter, as the sun turns northward from its journey below the Equator and daylight hours begin to lengthen, international radio experiences a change in conditions, sometimes seldom apparent until after it has happened.

By the sweeping nature of his proposals for remaking the judicial system of the country, particularly those relating to the Supreme Court, President Roosevelt has set the stage for perhaps his greatest and most significant test with Congress.
A process of boring from within the Mexican Government to effect the silencing and if possible the deportation of the exile Leon Trotsky from his Mexican refuge has got under way in full force.
Stephen D. Hurlbut gave a dance last night at his home, 10 Gracie Square, for his debutante stepdaughter, Miss Diana Kissel. The party was in celebration of Miss Kissel's birthday.

Former Police Lieutenant Abraham Cohen, a member of the New York City Police Department for nearly forty years, died of pneumonia on Friday at the Community Hospital, 150th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. He was in his sixtythird year.

The Student Council of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance of New York University announced yesterday the appointment of thirtyseven undergraduates to the junior promenade committee. The promenade will be held at the Colonnades, Essex House on March 13. Those appointed were:

Evidence that-the steamship Alabama, blockade runner in Civil War times, was built by Great Britain chiefly for warlike operations against the United States has been found in a letter unearthed by the Survey of Federal Archives in the files of the Federal District Court of New York, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Richard B. Morris, New York director of the survey.
The Girls Branch of the Public Schools Athletic League will be the beneficiary of a card party to be held the afternoon of March 6 in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria.

WILLIAM BREWSTER, who was born in 1851 and died in 1919, is known as one of the greatest of American ornithologists. But when he enriched the Harvard Museum of Comparative Zoology with his bequest of the finest collection of North American birds in existence, he left another valuable legacy as well.

Al Reid, the Bronx, outpointed Nickey Jerome, Greenpoint, in the feature eight-round boxing contest before 3,000 at the Ridgewood Grove last night. The victor scaled 126 3/4, two pounds more than his opponent. Joe Wach, 126 1/4, East Side, defeated Willie Felice, 125 1/2, Ridgewood, in the six-round semi-final. Jackie Aldare of Williamsburg, 173, scored over Leo Finnegan of Albany, 169 1/2, in six rounds.

Among the four houses in the row at 5 to 11 West Eighty-sixth Street now being torn down for a tall apartment structure, the dwelling at West Eighty-sixth Street was famous twenty and more years ago as the home of the "bon vivant" and successful steel salesman, James Buchanan, better known as 'Diamond Jim" Brady.

The high level of demand in the coat and suit manufacturing market was reflected in the distribution of the "consumers' protection labels" of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board last week, according to J. Louis Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, Inc., and chairman of the board's label committee.

The 400 delegates to the first convention of the Pratt Institute Art Alumni Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday were urged to fight against design stealing. "Design piracy," said Richard Bach, director of industrial relations for the Metropolitan Museum of Art, "is the ugliest thing that exists in design today.

Celebration of the 150th anniversary of the founding of the University of Pittsburgh will start-Feb. 25 with a sesquicentennial convocation of students in Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Hall and a "Charter Day" banquet of alumni.
"Don't have anything to do with averages," advised Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for the Coordination of Defense, in a speech in London tonight when he told this story:

A warrant charging extortion was issued today against John Robert Lynch, 35, who was arrested late yesterday at the postoffice in Athens by Department of Justice agents. It was turned over to a marshal to be served tonight at the Athens County jail, where Lynch is held.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN had an article of much interest in a recent issue of the magazine section of the Sunday TIMES. His thesis was that the public gets just the kind of pictures it wants and that this is the major reason the so-called "fine" pictures are made so rarely.

Carnations, in addition to greenhouse varieties such as will be exhibited at the second annual Carnation Show in Horticultural, Hall, Rockefeller Center, next Friday, Saturday and Sunday, come in a number of species that will thrive and bloom handsomely in the flower plots of amateur gardeners.
HERE is a novel which will make friends for itself. One would say at a venture that its appeal will not be very wide. It is rather too subtle in treatment to command a large audience.

Check clearings of the Westchester County Clearing House Association for the week ending on Thursday amounted to $2,407,600, compared with $3,807,778 for the previous week. Clearings for the corresponding period last month

Declaring that American citizens who commit extraditable offenses in France, even murder, and flee to this country, will go unpunished, the committee on international law of the New York County Lawyers Association has recommended as a remedy treaties with France and other countries giving the President discretionary power to extradite citizens of this country.

MIAMI, Fla.-The Helen Lee Doherty Milk Fund Ball will be held at the Miami Biltmore Country Club on Saturday night. Sponsored by Mrs. Theodore William Wessel, the former Helen Lee Doherty, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Henry L.

The government at Bangkok, Siam, has decided to send a student to Springfield College to learn American ways of training officials for recreation work and to start modern sports among young people of that country.

ALEXANDER KORDA made his first film, a private version of Freud's dream theory, in a rickety barn in Budapest in a day and a half, cranked the camera and cut and measured the footage himself. His latest, H. G. Wells's "The Man Who Could Work Miracles," was made on elaborate and complex stages at Worton Hall.

About to leave Brazil at the request of the police, David Levinson, the American lawyer who came here to defend two Leftists now on trial in connection with the Radical revolt of November, 1935, issued a long statement asserting

Plans for the fourth annual engineering conference for boys, to be held at Lafayette College from June 20 through July 3, have been approved. Professor William B. Plank of the Department of Mining Engineering and Metallurgy, will direct the conference, with Professor Lawrence Conover of the Electrical Engineering Department as assistant.
Pope Pius was freed from the annoyance of hypodermic injections today, removing one of the last visible reminders of his grave illness.

The marriage of Miss Sybil Kane Jay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Delancey Kane Jay of Westbury, to Francis P. Kinnicutt, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Hermann Kinnicutt of 65 East Eighty-second Street, New York,

NOTHING daunted by the late devastating flood, Cincinnati already has resumed its concert and operatic activities. The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, under Eugene Goossens, gave its first after-flood concerts last night and the previous afternoon.

The Misses Ann R. Foster, Isabel Gardiner, Nancy Vane, Lynette Fowler, Edith M. Hartshorn and Anna Lodge Minot, members of prominent New York, Boston and Philadelphia families, will be among the brides of the early Spring, their engagements having been announced recently.

BOOTBLACKS who ply their trade along the fringes of the city parks, particularly in Madison Square, have their own idea of elegance. Innovations in their equipment indicate not only an appreciation of the ornamental but a keen spirit
AN impish sort of fellow, no bigger than your thumb or thereabout and still in pa jamas and lounging robe at 5:30 P. M., Lorenz Hart, who writes the lyrics, started of by telling us a Goldwyn story.

Sixteen chapters of Trinity College alumnae from Eastern States are participating in a two-day convention at the club headquarters in the Hotel Barbizon, Sixty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, where the climaxing event will be a luncheon at 1 P. M. today,
Sir James MacBrien, Commissioner of Royal Canadian Mounted Police, disclosed today that a firm of Edinburgh lawyers had advised him that a woman in England had bequeathed to the force about $75,000.

The American Association of Social Workers will sponsor a conference on welfare, relief and security in Washington, D. C., for three days, beginning next Friday. Seventy-seven local chapters and State councils will be represented by 250 delegates.
Dr. Norman Henry Haviland, the oldest practitioner of medicine in Oswego County, died at his home here today at the age of 92. He first hung out his shingle in Fulton in 1878.

Bulgaria's exports to the United States last year increased threefold over the previous year, being valued at $1,150,000. the Department of Commerce reported today. Bulgarian imports from the United States were about $1,500,000, including $720,000 in cotton.
Announcement has been made by Charles Gehlhaus of this place of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Dorothy Gehlhaus, to Matthew J. Murphy of New York, formerly of Atlantic Highlands.

Three principal arguments have been advanced in behalf of the President's plan to alter the personnel of the Supreme Court by act of Congress. First, it is said that the present court is obstructing orderly social progress by its practice of invalidating necessary measures enacted by the Administration.

Building officials of Stamford and real estate men here are looking for increased activity in Stamford this year. Estimated cost of new building and alterations here in 1936 was $1,013,904, the best year since 1931 in this respect. January, 1937, was off to a good start, the first twentyfour days showing city building estimates of $53,713 as against $46,220 for the similar period in 1936.

In periods of depression and stress, revenue from the income tax is increased by the government in two basic ways: 1, by increasing the rates of tax, and 2, by increasing the income subject to tax. In connection with the latter, obviously the government cannot increase the normal income.

The Countess of Suffolk, who visited in Tucson last year, returned early in the Autumn to supervise the building of a mountain ranch home in the Santa Catalinas where she expects to pass the Winter each year. With her is her younger son, the Honorable Cecil Howard. Her older son, the Earl of Suffolk, resides in England.
Union labor leaders asked the Labor Department today for a conference to discuss the law setting up work standards for government contractors.

REVIVALS of Ponchielli's "La Gioconda" and Bellini's "Norma," the debut of John Brownlee, Australian baritone, and the first performance of the evening Wagner cycle Saturday night will mark the ninth week of the Metropolitan Opera season.

THE vogue for coin collecting has spread considerably in this country during the last year. One of the major reasons has been the generous policy of the Federal Government recently in the coinage of commemorative half-dollars.

The impending shortage of power admitted cautiously by private utility executives and hinted at broadly by government authorities-is expected eventually to bring about a pooling of public and private power. President Roosevelt is represented as believing that the final solution of the problem of many ramifications will come when the private utilities come to a realization-and admit it -that they are behind $2,000,000,000 in normal replacements since 1929.

The Shakespeare Fortnight Hostelry in Stratford-on-Avon, England, which was founded two years ago to encourage a more widespread interest in Shakespeare, will benefit by a program of monologues to be presented by Miss Cornelia Otis Skinner on the night of March 2 in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixtyfifth Street.

Edward F. Rothschild, Assistant Professor of the History of Art at the University of Chicago, died of a heart ailment last night in the Albert Merritt Billings Hosiptal, after an illness of five months. His age was 33.
