Taking the lead at the start of the contest, the Pennsylvania freshman quintet downed the Hill School five, 35 to 23, today on the Gillison basketball court. The visitors' clever defense kept Hill's forwards from erasing a slight margin attained during the first half.

Nazi Germany, striving to build up reserve supplies of bread grains, appealed today to farmers who have already delivered their quotas of rye to turn over to the government any surplus they might possess.

IN the course of its travels about the country the exhibition of German art organized under the auspices of the Oberlaender Trust of the Carl Schurz Memorial Foundation, Inc., has reached Brooklyn. It opened with a private view in the Brooklyn Museum Friday evening, Feb. 5, and will be current there until March 7.

The introduction of a greater sense of public responsibility into the management and control of endowments and foundations is the only way that political control over them can be forestalled, Raymond Moley declares in an article on "Private Funds in the Public Interest," in the current issue of Today.
Premier Leon Blum, in a personal radio appeal to State employes tonight, asked them to be patient and assist the government by not pressing their claims for increased pay at present.

A competition open to all American artists for a mural for the auditorium of the Interior Department Building in Washington, D. C., has been announced by the procurement division of the Treasury Department.

Alaska continues to yield more than 500,000 fine ounces of gold a year, or nearly a seventh of the total United States production. Last year the value, according to the Geological Survey, was $18,146,000, a new high record since the prolific days of 1909, when double the quantity brought at the old price only around $25,000,000.

Acclaimed by the Insurgent conquerors of Malaga as "saviors of hundreds of lives," Mr. and Mrs. Edward Norton of Memphis, Tenn., held open house today for grateful Malagans. The Nortons, who live in Villa los Pinos, overlooking the Mediterranean, admitted they had sheltered "lots of friends and friends of friends" during Leftist control of the city.

Mrs. Margaret Ross Babcock, for many years a member of the board of managers and treasurer of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery in New York, died at Greenwich Lodge this morning at the age of 65, after a long illness. She was the wife of Joseph Noyes Babcock, retired vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York.
Columbia's freshman class will ?? its first formal dance of the ?? in John Jay Dining Hall, ?? Heights, on April 3, ?? D. Steele, class president, announced yesterday.

A 70-year-old woman physician has forced into the open an issue which has been debated bitterly for years. Through the efforts of Dr. Inez Celia Philbrick, retired University of Nebraska faculty member, Nebraska's unicameral Legislature will consider a bill to legalize euthanasia or, "mercy death."

With a cast headed by Lily Pons, the Metropolitan Opera Association will present Leo Delibes's "Lakme" at the Academy of Music Tuesday evening as the fourth event in its Philadelphia series of six operas. Miss Pons last appeared in opera here in "Lucia" three years ago.

An exhibition of the writings of Princeton University alumni over a period of nearly 175 years has been assembled in the treasure room of the university library as a feature of the midwinter meeting of the national alumni association here on Washington's Birthday.

WITH the recent announcement by the Pennsylvania Railroad of plans for electrifying its main line from outside Philadelphia to Harrisburg, Pa., attention is again drawn to a subject of unfailing interest in travel circles.

Miss Anita Rockwell Farrington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Farrington of Kew Gardens, Queens, has chosen April 3 for her marriage to Philip Earl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Earl, also of Kew Gardens. The ceremony will take place in the Church of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Forest Hills.

Two men were held today for Grand Jury action on charges of grand larceny in connection with the looting of a dead man's gold hoard. They were Orland Laware and Raymond Dominy, both 25. They are accused of unearthing $700 in gold and silver buried in three jars in the cellar of the late Hiram Carter's home.

The Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross yesterday ended its campaign for the relief of flood sufferers in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys. C. R. Beardsley, chairman of the chapter, announced that the $200,000 quota assigned to Brooklyn had been oversubscribed by $6,027.92.

PRACTICALLY everything about the current production of "King Richard II" at the St. James Theatre is almost beyond belief. Here, for instance, is an ancient play which has been catching dust on the shelves for more than sixty years while managers yammered for scripts- and suddenly it becomes a hit! And here.

Holyoke High School's senior class honor roll contains the name of a student who did not attend any classes. James Daniel Clark, 19, stricken with infantile paralysis during his grade school years, continued his studies at home.

AND now Granville Fortescut is listed among those foreign correspondents who write personal history as they please inside Europe or on the transgressors' way where they have found no peace. He is not in a class with Duranty or Gunther or Sheean.
Spokesmen for Secretary Wallace said today he advocated re-enactment of a processing tax on sugar, suggesting a levy of 1 or 1/2 cent a pound.

SELDOM has a biographer encountered such well-nigh insuperable difficulties as those that beset Hector Bolitho when striving, through eight years and at some fifty different times to get Marie Tempest to unload herself of reminiscences which might have been expected to go back for more than half a century.

WE have read so much in recent years of atolls and coral strands, of waving palms, of Paradise generally in the South Seas, we forget that at our very doors is the same sort of paradise in the West Indies.

THE old theory that radio drama must accept limitations far more rigid than those that apply to the stage and screen no longer holds, according to the Radio Times, official program journal of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee took under consideration today the various proposals for neutrality legislation intended to replace the existing law which expires on April 30. All of the various bills and resolutions were discussed.

The marriage of Miss Mary Farley Moody Boyles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Boyles of 1,165 Fifth Avenue, to Dr. James Searcy Snow of Ann Arbor, Mich., son of Mrs. Henry Adams Snow of Tuscaloosa, Ala.,
Floodlighted waters of South San Francisco Bay early today gave up the coatless body of Myron Lorge, aged 27, of Los Angeles, one of eleven victims of Tuesday night's crash of a United airliner.

With the head of the Economics Department playing opposite a sophomore girl in the leading parts the Little Theatre Club of Swarthmore College will present the Kaufman-Connelly play. "Beggar on Horseback," on March 20, in Clothier Memorial.

The engagement of Miss Louise St. Leger Vance to Laurence Stallings of New York, writer and newsreel editor, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William McClellan Vance of 410 East Fifty-seventh Street, formerly of Princeton, N. J. The wedding will take place next month in this city.

Prominent young women of the Winter colony in this district, who represent many sections of the country, will participate in the lace pageant and fashion show which will be features of the Helen Lee Doherty Milk Fund ball, to be held at the Miami Biltmore Country Club on Saturday.
The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net income of $13,223,242 after expenses, taxes, charges and provisions for retirements and depletion.

After inviting Sian bankers, who were the losers of at least 19,000,000 Chinese dollars in cash taken by General Yang Fu-cheng when he evacuated the city, not counting many more millions lost through pillaging and looting, General Ku Chu-tung failed to make an appearance today and sent a subordinate instead.

Charles P. Taft, Cincinnati attorney and son of the former President, told Republicans at a Lincoln Club banquet tonight that if President Roosevelt is not satisfied with the Supreme Court he had "the same remedy that you and I havea constitutional amendment."
James E. Dever, newspaper man here for more than forty years, died yesterday at his home, 38 Central Avenue, St. George, Staten Island. He was 73 years old. A heart attack was the cause of death.

Although they did not see action yesterday, Brooklyn Prep's skaters clinched the Private School Ice Hockey League championship as Polp Prep upset St. Francis Prep, 1 to 0, in the second game of a doubleheader at the Brooklyn Ice Palace.
Representatives of fifteen branches of the New York State Nurses Association will convene tomorrow in Albany for conferences on their bill for control of their profession, now before the Legislature.

A NEW line of commercial cars has been announced by the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation. It includes the Commercial Pick-up, Commercial Sedan and the Westchester Suburban, a station wagon. All ?odels have a wheelbase of 116 inches and are powered by the Plymouth L-head engine.

Real estate salesmen working on a commission basis come under both the old-age and unemployment regulations of the Social Security Act, according to a ruling of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue made to the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.
NASSAU, Bahamas.-The most important racing event of the week will be held on Friday, when a string of Kentucky thoroughbreds will compete for the Norman Seagram Cup.

Three hundred persons, most of them women and children, were reported today to have been forced by Spanish Insurgents to cross the "No Man's Land" between Insurgent and Loyalist armies on foot. Mass expulsion of families with Government sympathies was said to be continuing in Insurgent territory in the Bay of Biscay region in Northern Spain.

THROUGH the rich bituminous coal fields of the nation, lying roughly in a triangle with its points in the States of Pennsylvania, Alabama and Illinois, voices are being raised in debate as the hour approaches for the expiration of the contract between mine operators and the United Mine Workers of America.

Columbia and Oxford Universities will discuss the question of government control over armament production in a transatlantic radio debate on April 17, George Freimarck III, Columbia debate manager, disclosed yesterday.

Patricia Maguire, 31, entered today her sixth year of coma, her affliction still a puzzle to physicians. Five years ago today she left her home to mail a valentine. She has never been out since. The pretty stenographer had complained of feeling "very tired and sleepy" several days before her coma, resulting from epidemic encaphalitis lethargic.

The marriage of Miss Jane Ermina Johnson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. E. Randall Johnson of Buffalo, to Richard Bancroft Knowles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Knowles of Lowell, Mass., took place here yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by Dr. Elmore McKee of St. George's Episcopal Church.

With Westminster added to canine annals, dog show folks will have a brief rest before moving eastward this week-end. The first stop will be New Haven, where the annual exhibition of the Elm City Kennel Club will be given on Saturday in the State armory.
COMMISSIONED by the League of Composers, Lazare Saminsky's "Pueblo, a Moon Epic," and Leo Ornstein's "Nocturne and Dance," will have their world premieres this month.

The welcome hum of machinery replaced the strident voice of disorder in Flint tonight as giant presses pounded and cranes screeched overhead under the eerie glow of violet are lights in Fisher Body No. 1plant, scene of armed occupation during the forty-four days of industrial paralysis caused by the General Motors strike.

Although she is well into her second administration as president of the National League of Women Voters, Miss Marguerite Wells of Minneapolis is making her first visit to New York in that capacity, to confer with the State and city units.

Six of the yachts which took part in the 184-mile race from Miami sailed today in the third annual twentymile ocean test for the Governor's Cup, with Victory going to H. M. Matheson's cutter Babe on corrected time.

One of America's outstanding educators and scientists, Dr. Edward Curtis Franklin, died at Palo Alto today. His age was 74. An internationally known authority on ammonia gases and liquid air, he was a former president of the American Chemical Society and holder of the Nicholas medal.

The makings of a shortage of skilled workers was found today by the Labor Department in an analysis of employment trends. The study, by Dr. W. H. Stead of the Division of Standards and Research, covered the work of the employment service in the last two years.

The Rutgers high-scoring basketball combination gained an easy 44-27 triumph over Lafayette on the Memorial Howard Gymnasium floor tonight. Forging to the front early the Mile Scarlet five got off to a 29-8 lead at half time and then coasted to victory. Jerebek, Lepine and Buttle were high-scorers for Rutgers.
YOUTH IN THE COURT: Sixtythree-year-old John W. Davis, former Democratic candidate for President, arguing in Supreme Court last week

Hans Strand, popular home club star who has ranked among the leading ski jumpers in the East during the past four years, was badly hurt today while practicing on the tricky Bear Mountain slide for tomorrow's exhibition program.

Judith Sidorsky, pianist, gave a recital last night in Town Hall, the first since her debut here last season in a similar event accorded her as winner of a Naumburg award. The award was not the first of her prizes, for when only 14 she reaped that of the "piano playing contest" of Detroit, her native city, and three years later won a Juilliard scholarship.

The Louisiana Boxing Commission today suspended three men and fined them $300 each, following an investigation of an alleged conspiracy to "throw" a scheduled fight between Jack Torrance and Jack Willis.

GERMANY'S much publicized new road system, the Reichsautobahn, is the railroad man's idea of the way highways should be built. The Reich railways received orders to build them. They are being built according to railroad ideas of construction. Any completed stretch of Reichsautobahn is essentially a broadened and paved double track railway line.

Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican lightweight, scored one of the quickest knockouts of his career last night at Rockland Palace. A crowd of about 4,000 fight fans, all the club could accommodate, saw Montanez stop Al Dunbar of Brooklyn in the first round of what was to have been a 10-round bout.
Tonight marked the fourth in a series of Piccadilly dances being given in the Rose Garden of the BellevueStratford Hotel for the benefit of the social service department of the Orthopaedic Hospital.

Today Catholic Young Women's Club-Valentine tea dance, auspices social committee, 4 P. M., clubhouse. Junior Hadassah-Meeting, discussion of Zionism, 2:30 P. M., Hotel Astor. Wheaton College Club-Meeting and tea. Dr. J. Edgar Park, speaker, Barbizon Hotel.

The Federal Housing Administration announces that the New York Life Insurance Company has made a loan of $725,000 to finance the construction of a new unit to Colonial Village, Clarendon, Va., the first large-scale housing project completed under terms of the insured mortgage system.
The St. Paul's sextet beat the Yale freshman today, 3-2, for a second straight victory over college opposition. The game was played onsoft ice covered by a quarter of an inch of water.

Viewed as one of the most constructive steps ever taken to curb merchandise returns in the apparel industries, the proposed program of retailer-manufacturer collaboration announced last week will be promptly put into effect after it has been approved by the membership of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was stated here yesterday.

When first the Federal Judiciary Bill was introduced, a few Republican leaders were disposed to pounce upon it in order to make political capital out of it. They were preparing to exclaim with ex-Senator REED of Missouri: "I told you so." But soon a sounder view, even from the standpoint of party expediency, set in.

The junior class at Vassar College gave its promenade tonight in Students' Building. Patrons received the guests in Main Hall at 5:30 o'clock in the afternoon and dinner was served there before dancing began later in the evening. The patrons were Dr. and Mrs. Henry N. MacCracken, Miss Eleanor Dodge, Miss Christine F. Ramsev, Miss Margarita de Mayo, Dr.

J. Howard Shoemaker, nineteen times national amateur pocket billiard champion, last night saw his chance for a twentieth crown fade when he went down to defeat before Herbert Courtney in a night game of the title tournament at the Capitol Health Center.

Colgate freshmen collected funds in a tag day today to aid a harassed classmate who had telephoned to a girl at an art school in Belgium. Their aim was to pay the telephone. bill rendered to Donald Richon of Hempstead, L. I., and variously reported at $17.50 to $44.50.

A warning that "strong qualities of intellectual leadership must be more generally developed by our universities, if modern democracies are to survive," was voiced by Dr. Detlev W. Bronk today in an address before 229 mid-year graduates of the University of Pennsylvania.
About 500 persons were routed by flames that for a time threatened to destroy the Mount St. Joseph Academy, a short distance west of Cincinnati, early this morning.

As at its concert of the previous night in the same surroundings, the Boston Symphony Orchestra's program performed at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, under Serge Koussevitzky, comprised Mahler's "Lied von der Erde" prefaced by a Mozart symphony.

Settlement this week of the strikes at General Motors plants, affecting more than 100,000 employes, leaves the country without a major strike of any kind. But there are two dark clouds on the labor horizon-coal and steel.
Penn State's Eastern boxing champions outfought Syracuse today before a crowd of 6,000, scoring by 5 1/2 to 2 1/2. The Nittany Lions won two of their bouts on technical knockouts.

France exported approximately 20 per cent more goods to the United States last year than in 1935, according to estimates by American consulates and made public today by the Department of Commerce. Merchandise shipments to this country amounted to $67,586,860, compared with $56,455,279.

The Neighborhood Councils, cooperating with the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department, will hold their first annual joint meeting and dinner next Tuesday night at the Hotel Commodore, it was announced yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, the chairman.

The annual report of the American Can Company, issued yesterday, showed for 1936 a net income of $17,226,845 after depreciation, $1,840,000 allotment to employes' annuity fund, $3,300,000 Federal income taxes and other charges. The income is equivalent to $5.80 a common share.
Six white-aproned young women worked industriously today to turn out the pie that will send one of them to the national finals at Chicago as New York State's champion cherry pie baker.

The modern New York City college girl is taking inspiration from the fact that she is in the midst of a great cultural art center, it was revealed in a survey made this week at Hunter College, which showed that almost half of the student body registered in fine arts courses for the past semester.

Government authorities disclosed today that almost all of the commodities acquired through operations of the Hoover administration's Farm Board have been liquidated. Commitments still on the books of the Farm Credit Administration, the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation and the- Commodity Credit Corporation were also shown to be relatively small.

Credit and collection conditions in Latin America at the close of last year showed little change from those of the third quarter, according to the survey released yesterday by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men.

The annual concert of the Pius X School of Liturgical Music, College of the Sacred Heart, will be given in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, on Tuesday night. Sixty students will be directed in the porgram by Miss Julia Sampson, Professor of Gregorian Chant.

A SIDE from having had to sing a number about "Those great big eyes, ooh-wooh," Miss Whitney Bourne's sojourn at the Gaumont British studios at Shepherd's Bush for the Jessie Matthews picture "Head Over Heels in Love" was pleasant enough, she says, although it was dreadfully uneventful.

Miss Olivia Edgerly FricK, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Edgeworth Frick of this place, whose marriage to William Champlain Robinson Jr., son of Mrs. William Champlain Robinson of Baltimore and Green Spring Valley, Md., and the late Mr. Robinson,

A distinguished group of patrons and patronesses has been organized for the annual International Skating Carnival, which will be held on the nights of March 27, 29 and 31 in Madison Square Garden as a benefit for the convalescent relief division of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service Bureau and for the Carroll Club of New York and its vacation camp.

TAXCO, Mexico. WINTER moves on slowly toward Spring in Mexico. Fiesta firecrackers explode constantly in the smaller towns, creating an atmosphere of gayety as colorful as the landscape. The plateau country around the capital glows with marigolds and geraniums and the sun arches higher in a cloudless sky.
Marshal A. I. Yegoroff, chief of staff of the Soviet Army, accepted today invitations to visit the capitals of the Soviet Union's Baltic neighbors, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia.

J. S. Bache Co., New York brokerage firm, will appeal as soon as possible against a court decision orduring the firm to pay to the depositors of the defunct State Bank of Binghamton the sum of $626,281.36. Supreme Court Justice Ely W. Personius of Elmira ordered the payment in handing down his final decision in the $1,250,000 recovery action brought by the bank against the brokerage firm, whose lawyers today announced the appeal plan.

Bids for 150 steel passenger cars for use on the city's Independent Subway system will be received on March 5 at 11 A. M., the Board of Transportation announces. The board recently rejected all bids for the manufacture and delivery of 250 steel cars, after one of the bidders offered to make a substantial reduction of price and sought an opportunity to revise its bid.

For the fourth straight time A Harvard player captured the national intercollegiate squash racquets championship today when Richard Dorson defeated Bernie Ridder of Princeton in the final round at the Merion Cricket Club, 15-5, 12-5, 8-15, 15-7, 18-17.

IN recent years it has become increasingly apparent that America has a folklore and mythology of a very original kind. If we do not have an Olympus or Valhalla resident with titanic gods and goddesses,

For the first time in history, Pennsylvania defeated Yale in boxing today, 4 1/2 to 3 1/2. With the meet deadlocked, Captain Sol Maksik, Red and Blue heavyweight, gained a three-round decision over Deering Danielson.

The city's quote in the $4,650,000 national drive of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, now under way, has been set at $1,860,000, it was announced yesterday by George Backer, chairman of the Greater New York campaign.

Visions of Ohio as an "American Monte Carlo," with the State acting as croupier, rose today as the Buckeye Legislature studied four bills which would put gambling in all forms on a "wide open" basis. One measure would increase the State's "take" from horse racing and make the pari-mutuel betting system compulsory at every track.

Petitions for allowances for fees and disbursements in connection with the reorganization of Botany Consolidated Mills, Inc., under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, will be heard at 2:30 P. M. on Monday in the County Court House in Paterson by Referee John Grimshaw Jr., special master.

SEVERAL one-man shows by American artists prove events of uncommon interest in the panorama of the week. Prints and drawings by Howard Cook have been placed on view at Weyhe's, current until Feb. 27. And new paintings by Georgia O'Keeffe have been installed at An American Place.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Visitors to Atlantic City over the Washington Birthday holiday week-end will have an opportunity to see some of the leading figure skaters of the United States and Canada in the annual Atlantic City Ice Carnival in the Municipal Convention Hall,. Sunday night, Feb. 21.

The George-Deen act recently passed by Congress to provide funds for vocational training draws attention to a similar system of education carried on here by the high schools in cooperation with business firms.

THREE days out of New York on our six-months' motor tour of the United States and Mexico and we walk the streets of Wilson, N. C., a pretty tobacco town, delighted by the sight of blooming forsythia, bridal wreath and other Spring shrubs. Feel we're one lap ahead of Winter already.

Navajo coin buttons have appeared in the tills of the Indian country-a sure sign of something amiss on the reservation. The buttons-dimes, quarters and half dollars with soldered copper eyes-provide an unfailing economic barometer of the Navajo tribe.

The Town Hall will open its books for the 1937-1938 season tomorrow, Kenneth Klein, booking manager: of the hall, announced yesterdays Mr. Klein made known that many requests already on file indicate one: of the busiest years in the existence of the auditorium.

Of the 470,000 fires in the United States in 1935, the latest period for which estimates are available, 55 per cent occurred in dwellings and caused 33.8 per cent of the $249,000,000 fire loss, reports the Continental and the Fidelity-Phenix Fire Insurance Companies.
The basketball team of the Riverdale Country School staged a fine rally in the last few minutes of the game today to defeat Morristown School, 27 to 26.
WHEN John Barbirolli, returning from America, arrived at Glasgow to conduct the Scottish Orchestra, he was greeted at the station by the playing of "See, the Conquering Hero Comes."

LIKE all Steve Passeur's plays, "Le Chateau de Cartes" is a study of passion, and, like most of them, its passion is hatred-not hatred between man and man or between woman and woman, but the hatred between man and woman, which is so near akin to love that it has followed love and will be followed by love once more.

EVER since television was first envisaged, predictions have been heard relative to telecasting a Presidential inaugural in the United States and coronation of a British King. The year 1937 offered both events but science, having missed the President at the radio cameras in January, now aims to make good on May 12 in London.

Showing a 1 per cent gain over 1935, 334,018 Indians are now registered on Federal rolls, according to the Indian Bureau. As defined by the Federal authorities, an Indian is a person of Indian blood who acquires certain rights through wardship, treaty or inheritance.

To avoid the tremendous wastes of soil deposits, as well as to diminish human suffering and property damage, the great rivers of this country should be given all the room they need for expansion in flood times.

Strike calls, effective tomorrow and Tuesday, have been issued to service workers in six of the city's largest hotels, Chris Houlihan, president of Local 32-C of the Building Service Employes International Union, announced last night.

The Cathedral College of New York defeated the Manhattan College, Staten Island branch, quintet, 44-30, yesterday at the loser's court. Ed Mahoney of the home team collected 13 points for high scoring honors.

Passengers sailing today for Antwerp on the Ilsenstein of the Arnold Bernstein Line include: V. O. Boone, Harrison L. Dick, Jules Monk, Alexander Nathan, Mr. and Mrs. Harold de Ronde, Henri de Ronde and William Whitener.

The International Symposium on Early Man, to be held at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, March 17-20 in observance of the 125th anniversary of the academy's founding, will have discussions participated in by 120 scientists from all parts of the world, according to Dr. Edgar B. Howard, the symposium's secretary.

The tuberculosis committee of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association is campaigning to awaken the public's interest in the need for 2,500 additional beds for tuberculosis patients in New York City, it was made known yesterday.

French leaders admitted tonight that the effort to obtain or impose a non-intervention policy on Spain had failed and that it was about to be abandoned. Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos made today a full report of the situation to the Cabinet, and although it is officially asserted France will continue to try to secure the establishment of effective control, it is privately admitted the whole scheme is no longer practicable.

Fares collected at the Twentythird Street subway and elevated lines for the year ending June 30, 1936, totaled 38,510,732, an increase of 1,103,360 over the previous twelve months, according to an analysis made by the Twenty-third Street Association of figures compiled by the Transit Commission. An increase in fares taken by the City Independent System and a decrease in elevated fares were among the features noted.

The State Liquor Authority began today a campaign to ban employment of "hostesses" in licensed drinking places "for the obvious purpose of inducing male patrons to buy drinks." John B. Judson, chief executive officer, said that the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law was broad enough to enable the Authority to declare such places disorderly.

How consoling are the words of the Archbishop of York, pronounced in the Church of England Assembly on Feb. 5. "It can be a Christian duty to kill," said he, and was sustained in his brotherly sentiments by the Bishop of London, who declared that pacifists are the real danger to peace. It seems that we have been wasting our opportunities.

Of the 176 firms which have answered a questionnaire circulated by the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., in a nation-wide survey, 78 per cent of the coat houses reported that they secure a premium for "specials."

Federal Theatre Projects in New York City played to 5,500,000 persons at 9,280 performances by relief actors and other relief workers, the Works Progress Administration said today. These figures are an advance except from the first annual report of the project, which will be made public next week.
Donald A. Hobart of Bronxville, N. Y., was re-elected national commander of the American Veterans Association at the close of the group's fifth annual conference here today.

King Carol, who has always shown a great desire to raise the cultural level of the Rumanians, has Just satisfied one of his special ambitions, that of becoming a publisher and bookseller, by opening a bookshop in the Calea Victoriel opposite the royal palace.
A bill which would more than double New York City's share of gasoline tax allocations has been introduced in the Legislature by Assemblyman Fitzgerald, Democrat, of Queens.

Dean A. Wellington Taylor of the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration declared in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase yesterday that theoretical economists and practical business men must be brought closer together in the common cause of social progress.

Forty students of the Yale Divinity School picketed Woodbridge Hall this morning and members of the Yale Corporation were forced to walk through the picket lines to hold the meeting at which they chose Professor Charles Seymour as the new president.
SOFIA.- The construction of bombproof shelters in the basements of all large tenement buildings here has been ordered by the Engineering Department of the Sofia City Council.

Members of the music club and poetry society of Marymount College will debate Thursday at the college on the proposition that "music is a more powerful expression of a nation's greatness than poetry." The affirmative music team is composed of Miss Sally Rodgers of San Mateo, Calif., and Miss Margaret Brown of Spokane, wash.,
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 11: Captain Shamer, G. P., Washington, D. C., to Asiatic Station, in February.
Resignations of 135 midshipmen, found deficient in studies at the Naval Academy, were announced by the authorities today.
AFTER the long Winter of Vardis Fisher's disturbing, even revolting, but powerful autobiographical tetralogy beginning with "In Tragic
UDAY SHAN-KAR, who is scheduled to give his third farewell performance of the season at the Majestic Theatre tonight, has every reason to be satisfied' with his New York reception.
THE "Fifty Books of the Year" will be on view at. the New York Public Library for four weeks beginning next Tuesday. Here are books judged for excellence in bookmaking.
The most effective relief to workingmen in Maine, and also the most extensive, is provided this year by the pulp and paper manufacturers in their pulpwood cutting operations.

Sluggish flood waters of the Mississippi River jettied into the lap of a winding course to the Gulf today, with their chief threat direacted against weak spots in closely guarded levees. Sand boils-suddenly developing openings in earthen banks beneath levees--commanded the major attention of United States engineers.

Mechanics who have shown outstanding skill in the construction work of the new thirty-six-story building at 14-20 West Forty-ninth Street, latest of the Rockefeller Center group, will receive certificates and gold-button awards in the building Wednesday under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.

New York's rivals in the National Hockey League, the Americans and the Rangers, will meet each other for the fifth time this season when they collide on the ice at Madison Square Garden tonight. These foes in the past have always waged savage battle against each other, and tonight's game promises to be no exception.

Members of the Artists and Teachers Benevolent Society will give their annual card party tomorrow afternoon at the Park Lane. Proceeds will be used to provide a monthly stipend for the care and maintenance of aged and needy teachers, artists and musicians.
Johnny McHale, Brooklyn welterweight, scored a surprising victory over Johnny Horstmann in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Mecca Sports Arena last night.
The St. Paul's School basketball team of Garden City, L. I., yesterday defeated an ancient rival, Brooklyn Poly Prep, in their annual game played on the Poly court. The final score was 23 to 21.

Graduates of Wellesley from every class from 1879 down to 1936 have responded to the invitations issued for the first event at which alumnae of this area will have an opportunity to greet Miss Mildred H. McAfee,

The Junior League of the Oranges presented the sixth and last performance of Charlotte Chorpenning's adaptation of "Cinderella" this afternoon at the Woman's Club of Orange. More than 6,000 children have been entertained in Cranford, Maplewood, Millburn, Madison, Westfield and the Oranges by the league.
Residential construction in andd around New York City this year will reach a total of $56,000,000, according to Thomas G. Grace, State director of the FHA.

A flight to Bombay by a flotilla of four or more light planes is planned for next Summer by Major Merrill K. Riddick, Dansville aviator. Accompanied by Edward Coon of Hamburg, N. Y., student pilot, and at least two other aviators, each flying solo, Major Riddick said they would fly by way of Los Angeles.

The annual book sale under the auspices of Everybody's Thrift Shop will be held Tuesday at the headquarters of the shop, 112 East Fiftyninth Street, for the benefit of the various charitable organizations aided by the organization.

Alpha Sigma Rho, a local fraternity at Rutgers University, became today the twentieth chapter of Alpha Chi Rho, national society, at the close of Hell Week activities here which involved the initiation of 145 undergraduates into sixteen fraternities and clubs.

The annual bridge, tea and fashion show of the Greater New York and Long Island Chapter of the Alumnae Association of the College of New Rochelle will be held the afternoon of March 6 at the Plaza Hotel. Miss Kathryn Ryan, president of the chapter, is honorary chairman.

Homer Folks, secretary of the State Charities Aid Association since 1893, will celebrate his seventieth birthday at a dinner given by several hundred friends at the Hotel Biltmore Thursday night, it was announced yesterday.

The United Textile Workers of America announced today it would demand another 10 per cent increase in wages immediately on the ground that figures from governmental and industrial sources showed a "prosperous condition" of the textile industry generally and particularly of the woolen and worsted and cotton branches.

THE two new transpacific airmail stamps recently announced by the Postoffice Department will go on sale at the Philatelic Agency here tomorrow. They will accord with the new schedule of reduced postage rates for the transpacific air-mail service which go into effect when the present route is extended beyond Manila to Macao and Hongkong.

A new and broader plan of intramural athletics, having as its aim the development of personality, a fraternity of feeling and contacts among the students, will be instituted early this semester at City College.
Charles W. Haight, railroad engineer who thirty-two years ago won the Congressional Medal of Honor for rescuing a child from the path of his locomotive, died here yesterday at the age of 69.

Unusual Technique Employed in 'Language and Thought' Class A course in "Language and Thought" is being offered this year as an experiment in the department of anthropology at Barnard College. Dr. Gladys Reichard, Assistant Professor of Anthropology, teaches the course, using a method similar to that she used in teaching herself the Navajo Indian language.
Arrivals at the Kirkwood include Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. E. on of Cedarhurst, L. I. At Hobkirk Inn are Mrs. Alfred Shriver and her daughter, Nancy, of Staten Island;
LONDON. LORD NUFFIELD, British automobile maker extraordinary, bobs up in the limelight again. With his rugged independence he is never out of public night for long.

The basketball team of St. Joseph's College for Women defeated the New York University girls, 43 to 15, yesterday on the victors' court in Brooklyn. The triumph was the fourth in as many starts for St. Joseph's.

On Tuesday King George VI made the first State drive since accession when he went to St. James Palace to hold the first levee of his reign. Ambassadors, Ministers and other members of the diplomatic corps were introduced in the order of precedence.

INCREASINGnation-wide participation in outdoor life and the sports of woods, fields and streams is reflected in the interest shown in the National Sportsmen's Show, which comes again to the Grand Central Palace for a tenday stand, beginning on Thursday. Last year some 230,000 attended this display for the hunter, camper and angler;
THERE is a story to the effect that Sir Thomas Beecham, billed to conduct his opera company in some English provincial town, arrived by the last possible train and entered the theatre "on the dot."

It is apparent in the Summer openings that fashion is not tampering with basic silhouette and that the Paris dressmakers have foraged far afield for their new styles. Aside from Alix's skin-tight line or her voluminous Egyptian front flares, Schiaparelli's stocking-fitted evening line and Vionnet's Near East drapery for evening, there is little tinkering with silhouettes.

More than 100,000 bags of coffee changed hands in yesterday's short trading period on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange as heavy profit-taking entered the market after an uninterrupted advance of 115 points since Jan. 25. Santos ended 34 to 39 points lower, with sales 67,750 bags, and new Rios were 32 to 57 points lower, on a turnover of 37,000 bags.

ARO, one of the foxes, could sing; and the young Wolfie made friends with a lamb, though he loved the house dog better than any other creature; and all the birds and beasts among whom Dr. Schmid lived and whom he writes about in this book, were interesting. But Guapo the Howler Monkey was in some ways the most interesting of all.

Blond-haired, 17-year-old Robin Lee of Minneapolis, representing the Skating Club of New York, continued his reign as men's national figure skating champion when he won the title tonight at the Chicago Arena for the third year in succession.

Air Investors, Inc.-Net asset value of 27,800 shares of convertible preference stock on Dec. 31, last, was $61,81 a share, compared with $46,76 for each of 30,615 shares at end of 1935. After allowing $40 liquidation value for the preference, net assets behind each share of common at end of 1936 were $2.98.

Adoption by private industry of a large-scale housing program to meet the present shortage is suggested in a report prepared by the Committee on Economic Recovery, which advocates cooperation by the Federal Government in the plan, but warns against governmental invasion of the housing field in competition with private business. The survey urges however,

St. Benedict's Prep of Newark gave out-of-town schools an even break against local fives with a 3225 triumph over St. Augustine's High of Brooklyn in the final contest of the scholastic quadrupleheader held yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden before 5,000 persons, the largest schoolboy crowd of the season.
Harry Kluger, silk manufacturer and converter, of Paterson, died today of a heart attack in Perth Amboy at the age of 68. He was returning from Lakewood in a car driven by his son, Benjamin.

The first in a series of Lenten needlework periods will be held Thursday by the newly established Sewing Guild of the Mothers' Auxiliary Association of Marymount School at the school, 1,027-28 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. William Fitz Gibbon, Mrs. Louis Soresi and Mrs. John White head the committee in charge of the sewing guild. Mrs.
May wheat soared 3 1/8 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today to $1.38 1/2, the highest price for the season and also the highest reached by any delivery since December, 1929.

The University of Toronto hockey team met defeat for the second time in less than twenty-four hours, when the Universilty of Montreal overcame an early lead to win, 5-4, today. McGill downed the Toronto team, 7-3, here yesterday.
The Japanese freighter Odaru Maru, with a crew of forty-one, today was feared to have foundered after having been caught in a blizzard last night off the Pacific coast of Aomori Prefecture.

LAKE PLACID - The highlight of the Winter sports program at Lake Placid will be the Washington's Birthday three-day holiday next week-end. All kinds of-preparations are under way for what will be the busiest period at this mountain resort since the Christmas holidays.

Leaders who have been called upon to push President Roosevelt's judiciary reform proposals through an obstreperous Senate were put on effective notice today that one of their strongest adversaries would be Senator Glass of Virginia. Already listed as an opponent of what he previously characterized as an "outrageous plan."

THE Theatre throughout the ages has invited composers to write special music for its plays, and many a popular tune has been projected from the films to be whistled and hummed throughout the land. Yet radio, which depends more upon music than the stage or screen, has been content to use the tunes first heard in the orchestra pits and from the screen's "talkie" apparatus.

A bridge party that will include ?? afternoon and evening session will be given by the Brooklyn ?? Club, of which Mrs. Thomas Henry McClintock is president, on Feb. 25 at the clubhouse, 14 Pierrepont Street. Mrs. ?? J. Baldwin Jr. is chairman of ?? bridge, which will aid the Red Cross Fund for Flood Victims.

AFTER a delay of some four years which Mr. Newman does not explain but says was owing to causes beyond his control, his elaborate life of Wagner is continued in this second volume. This is an even bigger book than the first, containing over a hundred pages more.

THREE of the prime impediments to retail trade expansion were removed last week in the passing of the flood crisis, the ending of the automobile strike and the appearance of more favorable weather in many sections of the country.
A new method of treating whooping cough will be demonstrated Monday at the exhibit of Sigma XI, honorary science fraternity of the University of Rochester.

Jose Benito Ramirez, Minister of Finance, announced today that 190 illicit stills had been seized and destroyed so far this month, forty in the Department of Carazo alone, Nicaragua's coffee-growing district.

Consolidated Has Net Equal to $4.52 on Common for 1936-Was $4.41 in 1935 The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore reported yesterday a net income of $6,394,688 for 1936. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $4.52 a share on the common stock. It compared with $6,288,204, or $4.41 a common share, earned in 1935.

ARRIVING Tuesday on the Ile de France, Dwight Deere Wiman must be thinking chiefly about seeing "Babes in Arms" to a stage. And the stage, it now appears, might be that of the distinguished Music Box. "Stage Door" occupies it now, and will continue there through March 20, if not longer.
IT is 800 years since Eleanor of Guyenne, Duchess of Aquitaine, Countess of Anjou, richest feudatory in France, took her great possessions to the French crown in her marriage to Louis VII.

THE gasoline tax always has been regarded as a "benefit" levy. It was imposed originally, and generally has been accepted, as a tax which enables the highway user to pay his fair share of the costs of the highways he uses.

The annual farm-and-home week at Cornell University will open tomorrow morning and continue until Friday afternoon. A special program has been prepared for those interested particularly in gardening. A few of the many subjects to be covered in these lectures, which will be given in the Plant Science Building at the university, include:

Princess Dorothy Caracciolo heads a group of women interested in the work of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association that is sponsoring the performance of "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse" with Sir Cedric Hardwicke in the leading role, the night of March 4 at the Hudson Theatre for the benefit of the organization.

The Mechanics Educational Society of America withdrew its picket line from one plant of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation this afternoon and food was sent inside the plant to a dozen company guards for the first time since Friday.

Senior Vernon Gomez, left-handed problem child extraordinary of the world champion Yankees, arrived in New York yesterday from a vacation trip to Bermuda and lost practically no time at all in getting down to the serious business of adjusting his 1937 salary affairs.

In Connecticut, at least, the fastest motor vehicle drivers have more accidents, according to a six-months' study of the Committee on Transportation of Yale University here. During the study, in which the license number and the speed of individual vehicles were recorded, the investigators were able to establish two groups of drivers-moderate and fast.

The abdication of King Edward VIII was a surgical operation that solved a major problem. It is now clear that minor complications have arisen. Edward's sister, the Princess Royal, accompanied by her husband, the Earl of Harewood, has been visiting the former king at Enzesfeld near Vienna.

Germany's war consciousness has become even more acute with the warning of Colonel Georg Thomas, chief of the economic defense branch of the general staff, that the next struggle will be a ruthless fight to the finish, with every man, woman and child mobilized. It will be a "totalitarian war."

Chicago's first industrial sit-down strike ended today after 150 young men and women, employes of the WahlEversharp Pen Company, spent a hilarious night in possession of the company's plant. The strikers surrendered the premises on an agreement that negotiations would begin Monday on wage increase demands.

Notre Dame, as mighty on the basketball court as it ever was on the gridiron, crushed N. Y. U., 52 to 26, in their annual game at Madison Square Garden last night with such a superb exhibition that the Ramblers looked as good as any college team ever to display its wares in the arena.

Mrs. N. Bronson Williams heads a junior committee which has been formed to aid the sale of boxes for the matinee performance of "Tristan und Isolde" on Feb. 25 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund.

The Williams quintet tonight snapped back into the winning column, defeating Tufts by a secondhalf rally, 33-25, on the Lasell court. The Purple led a slow first Half, 11-7, and increased it into their third victory of the season, losing the advantage only once during the evening. Pete Seay, with 13 points led the scoring.

A party of 100 American tourists, it was learned today, were stranded over night among the wild beasts of South Africa's Kruger National Park. The tourists, from the liner Franconia, were prevented by floods from reaching White River Camp, their destination.

The phrase will be remembered as the one with which Lord BEACONSFIELD summed up the results of the Berlin Congress, which fixed the final terms of settlement after the war between Russia and Turkey. The words might be applied to the ending of the automobile strike.

ALTHOUGH this department's first night review of "King Richard II" was fervent and joyous, it was still too guarded. In place of "one of the most thorough, illuminating and vivid productions of Shakespeare in recent memory," substitute "the most, "

With over $420,000 in Federal funds earmarked for talking-book machines, about 11,000 of these devices soon will be available for loan to needy adult blind in the United States, Director Martin A. Roberts of the Library of Congress Project recently reported.
James J. Braddock, world's heavyweight champion, and his challenger, Joe Louis, were ordered today to sign for their title fight, in Chicago next June, without further delay.
BALTIMORE. AT a sharp curve in Falls Road, Baltimore, motorists are confronted with a new traffic signal that compels them to reduce speed before negotiating the bend.
German and British sailors crowded the streets and cafes here tonight after the arrival of the German battleship Deutschland, the flagship of Admiral Hermann von Fischel, for a three-day visit.

The importance of religious instruction in the home and the school was stressed today by Dr. Endicott Peabody at the forty-fifth annual meeting of the Head Masters Association, held at the Westchester Country Club.

Warren Chivers, Dartmouth College junior, outclassed the field to win the national cross-country ski running championship at near-by Bush Lake today and set himself up in good position to take the national combined title when he competes in the ski jumping tomorrow.

The League of Composers has arranged to present two concerts on the nights of March 7 and April 4 at the Town Hall for the benefit jointly of the Composers Fund of the league and the Scholarship Fund of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre.

ONE of the paintings by Henri Matisse in the group of "moderns" at the Durand-Ruel Galleries is unusual in that it sponsors much more "finish" than we are prepared to encounter in the work of this artist. The picture referred to is "Deux jeunes filles a la fenetre."

PINEHURST, N. C.-Washington's birthday will be celebrated here with a combined social and sports program. A fox hunt, in which fifteen couples of the Carolina hounds. will run, will be held next Sunday morningthese informal hunts always attract a large number of hotel guests and cottage residents.

The Imperial Airways flying boat, Cavalier, probably will begin trial flights next week in preparation for the starting of the New York-Bermuda air service early April, M. Stuart Shaw, station superintendent of the Bermuda Airport at Darrels Island, announced today.

The newspaper Asahi reported today that more than 300 women and children had died in a moving-picture theatre fire in Antung, Manchukuo. Japanese troops were called out, the paper said, and distinguished themselves by saving many lives.

The death of William Forbes Fisher, after a brief illness, was announced today in a cablegram from Tangier, Morocco. His age was 74. Mr. Fisher was the son of the late Professor George P. Fisher, historian and theologian, who once was dean of the Yale Divinity School.

In line with Mayor La Guardia's desire to speed up the construction of new school buildings, the Board of Education has approved the naming of fifty-five additional draftsmen to its architectural office.

Announcement was made yesterday from headquarters of the Catholic Young Women's Club, at 641 Lexington Avenue. that a physician, a counselor of men, a dean of women and a leader in social service work will complete the lectures to the members in a series on "Personality Development From a Catholic Point of View."

With the spectacular sale of 431,500 bags of coffee at Santos yesterday against the normal average daily turnover of about 20,000 bags, at prices beyond all market expectations, and with prices still soaring at Santos, the National Coffee Department, through its president, Luiz Piza Sobrinho, conferred today on the situation with Arthur de Souza Costa, Minister of Finance.

The army, navy and marines have mobilized a force off Southern California to test one of the joint plans for defense of the frontiers and overseas possessions of the United States. Known as United States Fleet landing exercise No. 3, the secret operations will be held at the private shooting grounds of the fleet. San Clemente Island, sixty miles offshore.

National advertisers must realize the growing necessity of paying more attention to State legislation which may be inimical to their interests and confuse the pattern of merchandising and advertising, A. T. Falk, director of research of the Advertising Federation of America, pointed out here yesterday.

A choice lot of United States and foreign coins, including several old Colonials, among them a Massachusetts Pine Tree shilling of 1652 and an Oak Tree twopence of 1662, will be sold under the auspices of Wayte Raymond and J. G. Macallister in the Morgenthau Galleries, 1 West Forty-seventh Street, on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons.

13.-Norton Pritchett, University of Virginia athletic director, announced today that Frank J. Murray, head football coach at Marquette University since 1922, had accepted a similar post at Virginia. Murray will succeed Augustus G. Tebell, former Wisconsin end, who was head coach at Virginia for three seasons, before which he was a back-field assistant for four years.

John L. Lewis, leader of the recent automobile strike, declared today that in eight short weeks the international union, United Automobile Workers of America, had caused the General Motors Corporation to change what he said was its anti-union policy, to recognize the union and to make a contract with it for the first time.

BURKE, CHARLES FELIX (Jan. 21). Estate, more than $10,000. To Lorena Woodrow Burke, widow, executrix, 375 Riverside Dr., one-half estate, up to $350.000; Edmund G. Burke, brother, 270 Park Av., $50,000; Orvilleita B. Johnson, Oakdale, L. I.. $50,000; Earl Albert White, Oakdale, $1,000; Caroline W. Deckman,

The problem of farm tenancy is not only formidable in size but many-sided. That is why no blanket judgment is possible regarding the recommendations now made by the special committee appointed by President ROOSEVELT to study the subject.

Simultaneously with other units throughout the nation, the Hollins College Club of New York will hold a Founder's Day luncheon and program on Saturday at the University Women's Club, commemorating Charles Lewis Cocke, originator of the Virginia institution which is the oldest college for women in the South and one of the oldest in the country.

In the not too distant future, New York City will achieve municipal ownership and operation of the "essential services" of transportation, power and housing similar to its present operation of the water supply, City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr. predicted yesterday afternoon.

WHEN a country stops issuing stamps, interest in the old adhesives generally dies down quickly. The fact that no more specimens can be obtained from that country seldom increases the value of the old issues.
A series of lectures and discussions on marriage and kindred subjects will be given in the second semester at Vassar College.

Mrs. F. Leona Bonotaux of Woodstock Tower, 320 East Forty-second Street, formerly of Glen Rock, N. J., has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Lois B. Bonotaux, to Robert W. Drummond, son of Dr. and Mrs. Winslow Drummond of Philadelphia.

Two months of negotiations between the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and the clothing manufacturers resulted yesterday in an agreement to be made public today. The conferences revolved around the union's demand for a 15 per cent increase in the wages of 200,000 workers.

Miss Patience Radford of Boston, seeded first on the out-of-town list, and Miss Grace Carolan of the Central Badminton Club became finalists in the women's singles division of the second annual Eastern New York open amateur badminton tournament by scoring semi-final victories on the courts of the 165th Regiment Armory last night. At the end of the long day's play the final brackets of all five groups were filled.

THE student of international affairs who feels in duty bound to keep up with the rapidly mounting flood of publications on world politics may well reflect with the Gilbert and Sullivan policeman that his lot is not a happy one.

A clash in which ten persons were injured, following several weeks of tension caused by the General Motorts strike, led to the establishment of martial law today in this city and county. Under orders issued by Governor Townsend, 1,000 National Guardsmen took over control of the entire area.

Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, reported yesterday that the percentage of Negroes obtaining private jobs in the seven months ended Dec. 31 was about one-half the percentage of other home relief recipients who found outside work in the same period.
Stocks heavy, closed irregularly lower; turnover, 1,371,060 shares. United States Government bonds lower, corporate and foreign issues irregular; transactions, $8,568,100.

Shoe production during January was estimated yesterday to have slightly exceeded the figure for the corresponding month of 1936 by authorities in the local market. Output for last month was put at about 38,000,000 pairs, as against an actual figure of 82,420,000 pairs for the corresponding period last year.

Cottonseed crushed in the six months from Aug. 1 to Jan. 31 have been reported by the Bureau of the Census to have totaled 3,362,666 tons, compared with 2,935,861 in the corresponding period a year before.

St. John's University of Brooklyn captured the team honors and took possession of the Quentin Roosevelt Memorial Trophy last night in the twentieth annual indoor track meet of the Yorkville Athletic League at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

The Tufts Placement Service, which was organized by the Tufts Alumni Council last March to assist alumni and students in obtaining jobs, has proved of great value in its less than a year of operation.
A VISIT to old Jamestown and Yorktown, in Virginia, is like the opening of an enchanting history book, well illustrated.

Private holders of the 49 per cent class B shares of the Compania Petroleos de Mexico, S. A., have been ordered to deposit their shares with the secretary in anticipation of a meeting of the governors on March 1 to reorganize the concern.

Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, former President of Cuba and a leader in the Cuban Revolutionary party, was declared expelled from the party today in a statement from the executive committee, which maintains headquarters here.

Toward the end of a week in which lawyers and the more articulate laymen followed the bulk of the metropolitan press in a hot assault on the President's plan for the Supreme Court, the voices began to be heard of those who voted for him with the wish and expectation that he would alter the viewpoint of the present court majority by personal changes or otherwise.

Miss ?? McGregor Bremer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Long Bremer of Milton, was married today to Frederick Russell Moseley Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Russell Moseley of Charles River.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Guttridge of 1,780 Woodland Avenue, this city, have announced the betrothal of their daughter, Miss Alta Grace Guttridge, to Harold Herman Shincel of Westfield, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Shincel of New Haven. Conn.
Members of the faculty of Dickinson College are adding a new impetus to the study and appreciation of art by all students, regardless of the vocation they intend to follow in later life.

John Ogborne, who became known as the most famous plowman in the United Kingdom, is dead here at the age of 90. Left an orphan, he was brought up by friends and at the age of 6 was earning his keep by scaring rooks from neighboring farmlands.

Mr. and Mrs. Leslie G. Weldon entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Edmee Roberta Reisinger and Joseph Jenry Morsman Jr., whose marriage will take place on Tuesday in Greenwich, Conn.

Two men plunged to their deaths through the thin ice of Nuttings Lake here late today in almost simultaneous accidents, and two children were rescued by four Billerica youths who raced nearly a quarter of a mile across the ice to pull them from the water, where one of the men had dropped through:

Mrs. Susan Dayton Bonar, foster mother of Leon Fraser, president of the First National Bank of New York, and former president of the Bank for International Settlements in Basle, Switzerland, died yesterday of heart disease at her home in North Granville. Her age was 81.

Miss Sonja Henie, the 1936 Winter Olympics women's figure-skating champion, will make her New York debut as a professional skater tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden before what is expected to be a capacity crowd.

Close to a thousand requests from Federal agencies for decisions were received by the United States Board on Geographic Names during the past year, a recent report reveals. The Coast and Geodetic Survey heads the list with 253 requests.

Ducks Unlimited is setting up in business to provide more ducks fo men to shoot at. The More Game Birds Foundation is backing Ducks Unlimited. The general idea is to improve Canadian duck breeding grounds.

The collection of historical blue Staffordshire china formed by the late Eugene Tompkins and examples from the collection of the late Mrs. John E. Alexandre, as well as American furniture and decorations belonging to Mrs. George Farish and other owners, will be dispersed at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.
Christopher Miller, a material witness in the O'Connell kidnapping case, hanged himself in the Albany County jail late today.

Housing authorities must look to State and Federal Treasuries for funds to solve local problems, and the solution of slum and housing questions is too large and complicated for one State or one city to handle alone, states Carl Feiss, instructor in town planning in the Columbia University School of Architecture.

The Republic of Guatemala was the first nation to accept officially the invitation of the United States to participate in the New York World's Fair of 1939, it was announced yesterday at fair headquarters in the Empire State Building.

Charles Seymour, provost and history professor at Yale University, friend of Woodrow Wilson and Colonel Edward M. House, was elected president of Yale this afternoon. The Corporation, which for several months had deliberated the choice of a successor to James Rowland Angell on his retirement next June, announced after the meeting that the choice was unanimous.
Mr. and Mrs. S. Hinman Bird' of New York are visiting Mr. and Mrs. George Arthur Cluett of Williamstown, Mass.

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, A. Mullhaupt took the high scratch cup in the shoot of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island yesterday. In Class A? the handicap prize was annexed by J. Mercadante, who had a full card. W. S? Pate, C. T. Green, J. L. Meyer and E. J. Schaeffler tied in Class B? the first-named gunner winning the shoot-off.

A Federal grand jury indicted nineteen more Kansas City election officials and workers today on votetheft charges, swelling to seventyfive the number accused since an inquiry was begun into the Nov. 3 election.

EDVARD MUNCH, considered by many to be Norway's greatest artist, was recently persuaded. with great difficulty, to exhibit his work in London. Never before had Mr. Munch shown his pictures abroad and for many years he had refused to exhibit or sell even in Norway. He is now 73 years old and lives the life of a recluse near Oslo.

The Bureaus of adjustment of the Children's Courts have more than demonstrated their worth since their establishment last year, Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Domestic Relations Court told the Cooperative Committee of the Big Sisters last week at a meeting at the Federation Building, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

When His Excellency President Roosevelt addressed himself, just a year ago, to the heads of all the States of the New World, to suggest a special Inter-American Conference to unify the continent's will to peace, I had the pleasure of accepting without reserve so lofty a suggestion as a legitimate interpreter of the feel-. ings of the Dominican people, which all through its history has kept a fervid cult of peace and justice.

A Harlem resale and scattered transactions in Brooklyn were reported yesterday. After a week's ownership the five five-story double tenement houses at 354 to 362 West 119th Street were resold by a syndicate headed by Hyman Sturmak, attorney, to the Model Tenement Corporation.

Analyzing its sales by localities during 1936, the National Real Estate Clearing House of this city reports that transactions closed in Connecticut represented 19 per cent of the total number of listed properties, and sales in New Jersey represented 17.4 per cent of the properties listed in that State.

The Misses Charlotte Pidgeon, Miriam Osterhout and Katherine Gordon of Garden City gave a dinner tonight at the Cherry Valley Club before the junior dance there. Their guests included the Misses Adelaide Anderson, Alice Atwood, Barbara de Mercado, Nancy Halstead, Martha Hubbell, Betsey Hubbell, Deborah Jones, Susan Littleton, Betty McLean, Jean Stone, Mary Taylor, Susanna Townsend, Sealy Hiltz, Dorothy Ayers, Virginia Shaw, Jane Snyder;
Connecticut Dates Shifted

Despite a late rally by their rivals, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Lake Hopatcong, N. J., and Joseph Schenck Jr. of New York won the Everglades invitation mixed foursome golf final today. They defeated Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, the South Carolina champion, and J. W. Madden of Omaha, 2 up, in the eighteen-hole battle.

In President Roosevelt's project of remodeling the Federal judiciary, how much of Congress's traditional antagonism to the Federal Supreme Court can he tap? The question automatically projects itself as having a high strategic importance.

Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Spanish Foreign Minister, again accused Germany and Italy in a broadcast tonight of supporting the Insurgents. He said the capture of Malaga, southern seaport, by the Insurgents had been effected through the use of heavy detachments of foreign troops.

Mrs. Frank S. Hackett, a founder of the Riverdale Country School for Boys, Riverdale, and wife of the headmaster, died on Friday night at the New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 56 years old. With her husband she founded the school in 1907.

Princess Mary, sister of the Duke of Windsor,left Vienna this atfernoon by the Orient Express with her husband, the Earl of Harewood. Windsor brought them to the station after entertaining them at luncheon in the Hotel Bristol.

Raised by $40,000,000 this week, the steadily growing payroll of the automobile industry stood today at the highest point in history. Increases coincident with steadily expanding production volume in the last four years have increased

Wesleyan defeated Connecticut State College at swimming today, 51 to 26. Wesleyan won every event except the 150-yard breast-stroke and the 440-yard relay. Frantz of the Statemen swam the breast-stroke in 1:53.5, barely beating Lehninger of Vesleyan.

In view of frequent references made recently in the United States to English and Scottish investment trust practices, a firm of investment bankers identified with several investment companies in the United States decided to have a comprehensive survey made of the field.

Miss Katherine Christian Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Taylor of this place, was married this evening at the home of her parents to Lieutenant (Junior Grade) Allen Bond Adams Jr., U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Bond Adams of Moundsville, W. Va.
"Cruise Night" will be a feature of a dinner dance to be held next Saturday at the Westchester Country Club here by the factotums of the Scarsdale Woman's Club.

VIENNA. THE "Blue Danube" will be seventy years old in a few weeks and Vienna will make a real birthday celebration of it. For the Viennese really love the immortal waltz with an abiding affection and regard it as their true civic anthem.

Miss Cecilia Daly, 15 years old, of 676 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx, who confessed she had made cookies only a dozen times in her life, won the first prize in the Greater New York Girl Scout cookie baking contest, conducted by Schrafft's, it was announced yesterday.

The discovery that monkeys having had dog distemper are more resistant to poliomyelitis, commonly known as infantile paralysis, than monkeys which had not been infected, has been made by a group of scientists
The first division team turned back the Governors Island combination, 13 1/2 to 9 1/2, at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night to continue unbeaten in the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League.

Improved means of transportation and the general use of the automobile have radically changed the attitude of the majority of city workers as to the advantage of living near the municipal business areas, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, in commeeting upon the results of a survey recently completed

Archie M. Andrews, who made a sensational rise to fortune and has had a hectic career in the world of finance since he lost the chairmanship of the Hupp Motor Corporation, was accused yesterday of improper deals to outwit creditors in a bankruptcy petition filed against him in Federal court.

PALM BEACH, Fla.-For several days color and fragrance have filled the Royal Poinciana conservatories, where gardens have been planted in preparation for the ninth annual flower show, an event of next Friday, Saturday and Sunday.
Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Scandrett will give a dinner on Feb. 23 in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Mary Osborn Polak and her fiance, Donald Mitchell Oenslager.

Betsy floss House on Arch Street in Philadelphia, now to be restored as "the birthplace of the American flag," will be subjected to study and research by the assigned architect, R. Brognard Okie, with the cooperation of the American Institute of Architects.

Cornell's wrestling team gained its first victory today, defeating Columbia, 17-13, before 2,000 spectators. Cornell gained an 11-0 lead but the Lions retaliated with two falls. Then John Manning won the decision in the last bout to give the Ithacans the meet.

Executives of the New York State branch of the Shut-In Society, devoted to the companionship and assistance of the physically handicapped who must spend their days within their own homes, yesterday issued an invitation to the general public to attend the monthly meeting of the organization on Friday at the Hotel McAlpin.
A bridge and style show will be given under the auspices of the Faith Home for Incurables Auxiliary on April 6, at the Hotel Plaza. Mrs. William A. Winant Jr. is chairman of the bridge.

Lady Wilkins, weary of tending the home fires alone while her husband, Sir Hubert, periodically dashes off to the polar regions in submarines and annexes all the glory for the family, has decided to accompany the explorer on his next trip to the Arctic in June. 1938.

Curtis W. Pierce, vice president of the Continental Insurance Company, points out that a considerable proportion of the $53,000,000 fire loss estimated to have been incurred by churches in the United States in the past ten years, may be attributed to hazardous types of building, in which fire-resistance frequently is sacrificed or overlooked in the desire to enhance beauty.

Miss Florence Belding Wells, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wells of this place, became the bride of Charles Carroll Mulliken, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Mulliken, also of this place, last night at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by Rev. Herbert C. Lyttle, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church.

George Sellmayer, president of Baltimore's City Council, and Miss C. Marie Grau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Grau, were married today. The ceremony was performed at St. Gregory's Catholic Church by the Rev. Joseph Garvey.

BEAUMEL, DAVID W. (Oct. 1 1936). Gross assets, $30,403; net, $28,844. To daughters, Eva A. Beaumel, Julia F. Kalsch, sons, Walter D. and William R. Beaumel, one-fourth of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $700; stocks and bonds, $170; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance. $29,533. Wingate and Cullen, attorneys, 142 Pierrepont St.

More than 2,000 members of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers will participate in the 147th meeting of this organization, which opens its sessions tomorrow morning at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, and continues through Friday.
The Governor Lehman and Lithgow Osborne bobsled trophy races, scheduled for tomorrow, were indefinitely postponed tonight because of lack of snow and ice.

BOAT models in a variety of designs ranging from obsolete windjammers to modern power-driven speedboats are on view at the ninth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Model Engineers, 152 West Fortysecond Street.

ONE of the most frequent temptations to early eighteenth century printers was the inordinately popular "The Life and Strange Surprizing Adventures of Robinson Crusoe.". The work was pirated, abridged, and still further abridged.
Trailing, 18-6, midway in the first half, Yale rallied to subdue Dartmouth, 40-37, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League battle before 2,400 persons tonight.

Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, and Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, pioneer conservationist and chairman of the Senate Wildlife Committee, will be among the principal speakers at the second North American Wildlife Conference in St. Louis, March 1-4, it was announced here last night by Henry P. Davis, secretary of the American Wildlife Institute, sponsoring organization.
Dr. and Mrs. Winfred Morgan Hartshorn of 830 Park Avenue gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter,

George Foster Peabody of Saratoga Springs, N. Y., philanthropist, is ill at his home on the Georgia Warm Springs Foundation. Dr. J. A. Johnson of Manchester, Mr. Peabody's physician, said today the patient has had a heart ailment for some time. A month ago he contracted a severe case of influenza.

A $40,000 decrease this year in loans made by Columbia University to its students was accepted yesterday by W. Emerson Gentzler, bursar, as an indication that "the financial condition of the students' families has undergone marked improvement."

Two New Jersey youths were instantly killed this morning, a third received serious injuries and three others escaped unhurt when a sedan which they were demonstrating crashed into a tree near Central Valley owing to the driver being unfamiliar with the highway.

The Rev. Thomas F. Rudden, for ten years pastor of the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel, at Moorestown, N. J., died in St. Agnes Hospital here today after an illness of a week. He was 62 years old.

The growing sentiment against the ten and three-second rules in basketball and the consequent spread of the zone defense was reflected at a basketball clinic held in the auditorium of The New York Herald Tribune yesterday under the joint auspices of the City College Athletic Association and the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association.

The midwinter conference of the American Savings and Loan Institute will be held in Boston next Friday and Saturday. About 200 savings and loan executives from more than twenty-four States are expected to attend. Arthur W. Hanson, Harvard University accounting professor;

It has been a good many years since a player coming up in racquets has won the acclaim that has been showered upon Robert Grant 3d. Today the young Eton-trained New Yorker gave further evidence of a great future in gaining the final round of the thirty-first annual Tuxedo gold racquet tournament with J. Richard Leonard.
Dr. Keiki Nagatsuka, former Professor of Medicine at the University of Maryland, died last night at his farm in Ocean View, three miles from here. His age was 63.

A bequest of $200,000 to the trustees of Hamilton College at Clinton, N. Y., for the endowment fund of that institution was the largest gift made in the will of Elihu Root, former Secretary of State, which was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
A student movement to establish a cooperative bookstore to deal primarily in used textbooks is under way at the downtown center of New York University at Washington Square East.

Completed plans are announced by Williams College for the midwinter homecoming program, which will include addresses by Governor Herbert H. Lehman, '99, and Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College. The round of varied activities will begin Feb. 20 and end on Washington's birthday.

A period of intensive building activity has started in Chicago, according to John O. Merrill, president of the Chicago Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. Largely through the program of the Federal Housing Administration, the home mortgage has been re-established as a sound investment for private capital, he says,
