An alleged remark, "Let's go play railroad" figured today in District Attorney Dan F. Conway's investigation of the wreck of the Southern Pacific's "Owl" passenger train which killed two trainmen.

Georgetown University handed Syracuse its first home defeat of the season tonight, winning by 45 to 36 before a capacity crowd of 3,400. The Hoyas, coached by Fred Mesmer, native of Syracuse, had a 19 to 18 lead at half-time. Syracuse managed to tie the score on three eccasions in the second half, but the visitors put on a scoring burst in the closing minutes that Syracuse could not halt.

Resumption of active importations of goods from Germany by using raw cotton as the medium of payment is possible in the light of recent regulations issued by the German Government and transmitted to the Board of Trade for German American Commerce by cable yesterday.

Alignments in the increasingly 'bitter battle over President Roosevelt's proposal for court reform were more sharply drawn today as both sides intensified their campaigns to swing public opinion to their views. A suggestion of compromise was reiterated, but it gathered little emphasis. Senator King, an avowed opponent of the plan as it pertains to the Supreme Court, suggested after a visit to the White
Wesleyan continued its victorious march tonight, winning the opening "Little Three" basketball game from a highly touted Amherst five, 33-26. It was the eighth straight victcry for the Cardinals.

Bowlers held the whip hand in the opening day's play of the match between New South Wales and the touring Marylebone Cricket Club today. Batting in a strong wind, the home team was dismissed for 231 runs, and when stumps were drawn the M. C. C. had lost two wickets for 23.

Young matrons and debutantes will act as manikins in the fashion revue to be known as the "Park Avenue Parade" to be held on Tuesday in conjunction with a luncheon in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Ride A Wee Home for Animals.

A delightful performance of Massenet's "Manon" was given yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, with a new, young and gifted singer in the'title part, who looked the character, and interpreted the music with warm sentiment, grace and style. She was Bidu Sayao.

The Works Progress Administration today envisaged the return of 600,000 WPA workers to private employment within four and a half months. Administrator Harry-L. Hopkins told State WPA chieftains at a national meeting he believed that number would find jobs in various industries and on farms by the end of the fiscal year next June 30.

Mrs. Emilia Merlo de Hernandez of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Evelyn Hernandez, to Earl Cholmondoly Williams, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Williams, also of this city.

PARIS. WHEN the Paris Opera reopens in February the spectators will find the building completely transformed. Redecorated and relighted throughout, there will be little to recall the Opera of a year ago before the great hall was closed for renovations.

Fifteen children whose expenses in high school they are underwriting this term send as bright a gleam into the eyes of members of the Foster Mothers Association of America as did the single protege they financed during their first year in 1914.

THE houses people live in at any period are at once the frame and the reflection of the contemporary manner of living. Thus they become landmarks of history, poignant records of perished generations. On this page are shown emples--a few among many hundreds--of American homes spread over 200 years and distributed from Maryland to Florida.

Henry Cameron Eldert died yesterday at his home, 70 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, in his fiftyeighth year. He was a member of the law firm of Mitchell, Taylor, Capron Marsh, 20 Exchange Place, Manhattan. Surviving are his widow, the former Marion Macmillin; a daughter, Miss Elizabeth T. Eldert, and a son, Cornelius Eldert II.

THE Diesel motor in German aeronautics seems to have come in, during the past year, for more rapid advancement than ever before. The success of the Junkers Jumo 205, a product of many years of research by the technicians of the plant at Deseau, has attracted world-wide attention.
Thousands of Mohammedans bowed down to earth today to thank Allah for the life of the world's richest man-the Nizam of Hyderabad.

IN one way or another, all the good stories last week concerned the gala benefit show at the Music Hall on Thursday midnight for the nation's flood sufferers. The angle we found specially tempting and that drew us irresistibly into the vast labyrinth of rehearsal halls, broadcast and ballet studios, dormitories, Rocketterookeries, ,

THERE is a man who states, with the very best authority, that nothing in the world is more monotonous than the rehearsals of the sketches for a musical revue. Granted that these spicy little numbers eventually fus carry the burden of the comedy in the show, the business of putting them together is as dull as the inside of a hat.

The National Bank of Nicaragua has sent $70,000 in newly mined gold to the Federal Reserve Bank in New York by- airplane. Earmarked for the Government of Nicaragua, the gold will be used as a currency reserve.

Miss Ginbar accounted for her fourth victory in her last six starts in taking the six-furlong handicap, feature of the Fair Grounds card today. In her two other starts the 4-year-old daughter of Zev finished third.

The former Phineas Jones plant, adjacent to Route 29 on Florence Avenue, Hillside, N. J., has been leased, with an option to purchase, to the Jiffy Manufacturing Company of Boston. The property contains about five acres.

MRS. BERTITA HARDING retells the story of Emperor-King Franz Joseph I and of his wife, Elisabeth, with dramatic effect and a wealth of detail Here is a book that will be read by lovers of royal romance. It is written with verve, wit, paradox and pathos.

WITH the opening last week of the full stretch of the West Side Express Highway from Canal Street to Seventy-second Street, a practical by-pass of New York's congested traffic is provided for the many motorists traveling between New Jersey and Westchester and the wide range of country to the north and south for which these areas are the portals.

Questions relating to grants for scientific research will be discussed here next Friday and Saturday at a meeting to be held jointly by the American Philosophical Society with representatives of foundations, societies, universities and institutions administering research funds.

Young matrons and debutantes will act as manikins in the fashion revue to be known as the "Park Avenue Parade" to be held on Tuesday in conjunction with a luncheon in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Ride A Wee Home for Animals.

Hopkins told State WPA chieftains at a national meeting he believed that number would find jobs in various industries and on farms by the end of the fiscal year next June 30.

The National Bank of Nicaragua has sent $70,000 in newly mined gold to the Federal Reserve Bank in New York by- airplane. Earmarked for the Government of Nicaragua, the gold will be used as a currency reserve.

Miss Ginbar accounted for her fourth victory in her last six starts in taking the six-furlong handicap, feature of the Fair Grounds card today. In her two other starts the 4-year-old daughter of Zev finished third.

Joyce McGee, consort of gangsters, pleaded guilty today to a Federal extortion charge growing out of a letter threatening a second kidnapping of Miss Mary McElroy, daughter of City Manager H. F. McElroy. She was sentenced to seven years in prison.

The annual "Bassinet Dinner Dance" in aid of the.Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, 444 West Twentysecond Street, is being arranged by members of the Junior Committee for April 2 in the Embassy Room and garden of the Ambassador Hotel.

Poetry and patriotism will be served at one and the same time tomorrow night by the New York branch of the National League of American Pen Women, when Joseph Auslander and other literary figures will be honored with a dinner at the George Washington Hotel. Mrs. Elydia Shipman, president of the New York League, will be in charge.

Operations of the Childs Company and all subsidiaries last year resulted in a net profit of $291,138 after interest, provision for Federal taxes and surtax on undistributed profits of subsidiaries, depreciation, amortization and other deductions, it was announced yesterday.

Salvador de Madariaga, former Spanish Ambassador to the United States, will be one of the guests of honor at the annual mid-season luncheon of the League for Political Education on Wednesday at the Astor, Mr. de Madariaga is chairman of the organization committee of the World Foundation.

NEW YORK dog ownerstheir number is legionare renewing licenses for their pets these days. The city has an estimated dog population of 30O,000. By April 30, some 250,000 dogs will have received their 1937 licenses; the remainder will roam the streets without an identification tag.

Commencement stage honors for members of the senior class at the Mercersburg Academy have been announced here this morning by Head Master Boyd Edwards. Those so honored on basis of scholastic distinction were:

BRITISH publishers are not commonly regarded, at any rate by authors, as easy marks, but, if we may believe a correspondent of The Times, they have allowed themselves to be fleeced, during the last quarter of a century,

Townspeople, aware of the temperamental tendencies of musicians, declined at the town meeting this week for the second year to take upon themselves the "ticklish" decision whether the Ware brass band or the St. Mary's Drum Corps should give the official town concerts next Summer.

The battle for political power in Japan will be resumed Monday, when the Diet (Parliament) reconvenes after three weeks' suspension caused by conflict between the army and its civilian critics. Authoritative indications tonight were that all the contending forces, which clashed bitterly in the Diet on Jan. 21

Eight striking chauffeurs were shot today, two perhaps fatally, in a clash with the police at a demonstation against a decree requiring chauffeurs to wear uniforms. After the demonstration, in which thousands participated, Mayor Jorge Eliecer Gaitan,

Replying to a National Socialist member of the upper house regarding Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Jan. 30 offer to guarantee Netherland neutrality, Foreign Minister A. C. de Graeff said today he had notified Germany that, while appreciating such good intentions, the Netherlands was not prepared to enter an agreement with any power regarding the inviolability.

A gain of more than 20 per cent in construction during January over December, 1936, is reported by the F. W. Dodge Corporation. The January, 1937, total likewise was about 13 per cent wetter than the figure for January, 1936.

All Vienna will celebrate tomorrow and Monday the seventieth birthday of its civic anthem, "The Blue Danube Waltz." The festivities, which for some weeks have been casting their shadow before, range from speeches, wreath layings, unveilings of memorial tablets, special observances by the Vienna State Empera Philharmonic Orchestra to radio broadcasts over most of Europe and America and the playing of Johann Strauss's immortal melody in practically every nook and cranny of the Austrian capital.
A HANDSOME and historic clock in the Supreme Court Building has just attained its centenary. A gift to the court from a skilled clockmaker of Colnnecticut who was 85 years of age when he made it,
Preparations continue for the International Horse Show opening on Monday with delegations from the United States, Cuba, Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia and Chile.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan arrived here yesterday morning, happy that the General Motors strike had been settled without sacrifice of civil liberties and insistent that some formula be found for non-coercive governmental action to guard against future periods of industrial paralysis.
ONCE BURNT: "If there is anything that we of the Stock Exchange do not want, it is another great boom."Charles R. Gay.

Unbeaten Harvard won its sixth straight game in the International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League before 2,000 at Baker Rink tonight, defeating Princeton, 8 to 4, and strengthening its position as runner-up to McGill.

A "magic" portrait, with which Henry Adams, author and diplomat, held "conversation," adorns one of the rooms at Ashintully, Tyringham's great marble palace, which is soon to be transferred by Mrs. Lawrence Coolidge of Boston to real estate promoters.

These are grim days for Madrid and the Spanish Government-days that call for stout hearts and an unyielding determination. Malaga has fallen, the Loyalists have suffered reverses in the Valencia road sector, 12,000 more Italians have been landed at Cadiz, and all in less than a week.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will donate one of her inaugural gowns to the State College of Home Economics as part of a permanent exhibit, officials in charge of Farm and Home Week said today. The "first lady" will be one of the speakers for the 30th annual event, scheduled to take place from Monday through Saturday.

A COMPLETE section of republican and imperial Rome has been discovered during the course of excavations near the Capitol Hill. These remains, which are of high archaeological value because they will enable historians to reconstruct a hitherto unknown quarter of Rome.

Mrs. Robert C. Ream, president of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work, has announced the recent election to the board of directors of Mrs. Joseph Wilshire, one-time president of the Madison Avenue Woman's Exchange, and Mrs. Feank E. West, who also has served as an officer in the latter exchange.

AN ENEMY OF THE PEOPLE--Tomorrow evening at the Hudson Theatre. Mr. Hampden-he played it 127 times in 1927 and 16 times the next year-is again reviving the Ibsen comedy. He has the part of Dr. Stockmann and others in the company include Albert Van Dekker, C. Norman Hammond, Edwin Cushman, Hannam Clark, Mabel Moore, Dodson Mitchell, Marjorie Jarecki, Constance Pelissier and Elizabeth Farrar.

SEAL-IN STRIKE: Strikers occupying the Kelvinator Corporation factory in Detroit last week contributed a new wrinkle to labor's new stay-in technique. To prevent executives and office employes from entering they welded up the door.

Although two years will elapse before the opening of the New York World's Fair, retail executives in this area have started to plan for substantial increases in space, equipment and inventories, in order to supply the needs of the "greatest stream of out-of-town visitors this city has ever seen," according to a report yesterday by the bond sales committee of the fair.
Pierre L. Barbey Jr., gave a dinner tonight at his home for Miss Barbara Richards and Clifford Michel, whose marriage will take place on Monday.

Renaissance Quintet offers a program of seventeenth and eighteenth century music. Members of the quintet are Rudolph Bocho, dessus de viol; Jacques Malkin, viola d?amour; Youry Bilstin, viola da gamba; Benjamin Feinbloom, bass viol, and Leo Small, harpischord:

Frank Bowden, the Eastern association's fourth ranking netman, opened his 1937 campaign for titular honors in impressive fashion by conquering Charles Masterson, Long Island University captain, 7-5, 6-3, in the first round of the Brooklyn indoor tennis singles championship at the 106th Infantry Regiment Armory yesterday.

Search for Helen Moyer, a high school student of 16, who is believed to have been run down by a hit-and-run driver who carried off her body, was pressed by airplane today while officials considered asking Federal agents to enter the case.
Rescue crews worked at top speed today in four widely separated Western areas to free more than 100 persons in two snowbound communities and to locate seven missing men.
Mervyn T. Winglefoot, the peripatetic Mincing Lane tea taster, arrived in New York yesterday accompanied by his bosom pal; "Dogfaced" Jones of the Rangoon Rangers, and his Bengali servant, Choti Lal.

The Domestic Relations Court is prevented from properly discharging its duties of protecting children and preserving the family because of its lack of facilities, plant and personnel, according to a report adopted last Tuesday by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

While churches will be officially open for prayers tomorrow in the town of Orizaba, State of Veracruz, the scene of religious disturbances this week when Catholics forcibly opened the churches, masses will not be permitted in the State, Governor Miguel Aleman reported

ETHEL HUESTON chooses the old homestead of a once well-tdo family in a small Iowa town as the scene for the Merediths' battle with hard times. Mom, the stouthearted head of the family, spends every penny she has to provide food for her children and their youngsters, who have all returned to the old home, where they will have at least a roof over their heads.
Miss Betsy Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Ross of this place has selected Feb. 18 for her marriage to William Reed Jr. of Chappaqua. N. Y.

Albert Morris Bagby has enlisted the aid of several members of the Metropolitan Opera Association for the concert to be given under his direction on March 15 at the Waldorf-Astoria to aid the work of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., in giving pensions to aged musicians and lending assistance to dependent members of their families.
A State Labor Relations Board to "balance bargaining power" between employer and worker may become a reality in Pennsylvania before the end of 1937.

Additional indications of an active building season on Long Island this year have been presented in the announcement of two important transactions in the Bayside section. One involved the Bayside Gables tract opened in 1926 by the Cord Meyer Corporation and which has now been taken over by Anthony Villett, president of Villett Homes, for improvement with high-class homes.

Racing through a blinding snowstorm today, Emile Allais of France became the world's . champion downhill skier and Miss Christel Cranz of Germany took the same title for women. The titles for national teams went to the Frenchmen and the German women.

Chiropean, of which Mrs. John Weinstein is president, will celebrate its forty-first birthday at the annual breakfast on Feb. 25 at The Towers, Brooklyn. The reception and breakfast will be followed by a program. Miss Ethel R. Peyser will speak on "Travel," Mrs. Amelia Gray-Clarke, club musical director, will present a male quartet.

Collections on open credit accounts receivable at department stores were higher last December than a year ago, but were slightly under the November, 1936, figure, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Mr. and Mrs. Barry Wright of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Anne Phelan Wright, to William Carl Lohmeyer, son of Mrs. Carl Lohmeyer of Baltimore and the late Mr. Lohmeyer.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Agnes Elizabeth Cockerill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Cockerill of Scarsdale, N. Y., to C. Oliver Morfit, son of Mrs. Clarence Oliver Morfit, also of Scarsdale, and the late Mr. Morfit.

Five hundred persons, many of them members of the medical profession, attended a brief funeral service yesterday afternoon for Dr. William Dwight Tracy, dental surgeon, in the Fifth Avenue Chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East Ninetieth Street.

ONE of the season's most important events out of town is the large exhibition of bronzes, selected from American museum and private collections, which will be current at the Albright Art Gallery in Buffalo until the end of the month.

Miss Lucille Lyle Thorsen became the bride of Allen Tilden Chase here this afternoon at the home of her mother, Mrs. Arthur Clarence Thorsen. The bride was gowned in ivory satin, and attended by Mrs. Thomas J. Sullivan of Chicago as matron of honor and Miss Valerie Schmidt as maid of honor.

Knox College, the Old Siwash of the George Fitch tales and one of America's first prairie colleges, is 100 years old. The centennial anniversary of the granting of its charter was marked this week-end in Galesburg, Ill., by a two-day celebration. It will be further commemorated in June with a week of festivities, including the inauguration of Knox's eleventh president, Dr. Carter Davidson.

Three hundred and twelve years ago, when San Juan was a city more than 100 years old, General Boudewijn Hendrickez, Burgomaster of Edam, at the head of Dutch troops, burned the city after a twenty-one-day siege had failed to dislodge the Spanish troops in El Morro, commanded by Don Juan de Haro, Captain of Galleons and Governor of Puerto Rico.

IN the program of the Boy Scouts there is an important place for physically handicapped youth. Scout activities are adapted and often broadened to meet the capacities of such unfortunate boys. As a result a new and compensatory world of enjoyments has been opened to them.

Mrs. Charles D. Lanier of Greenwich will entertain the William Alexander Jr. Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy at a birthday reception and tea at her home Feb. 21. Mrs. Lanier is president of the Greenwich chapter and also president of the Robert E. Lee Foundation.

Announcement has been-made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Wait Lord of 238 East Sixty-eighth Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Kirkham Lord, to Wolcott Erskine Andrews of Wiscasset, Me., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Martin Andrews of Chicago and Wiscasset.

In his seventy-eighth annual report the State Superintendent of Insurance reviews the work of the real estate division since its creation in July, 1935, the study showing that up to Dec. 31, 1936, liquidation sales had been made of 513 parcels of real estate and mortgages aggregating $9,008,441.

Committees have been formed for the card party of the Ladies' Auxiliary of St. Peter's Hospital to be held Feb. 27 at the Hotel Plaza. Mrs. John J. McManus is president of the auxiliary. Mrs. John J. Hauff is chairman, assisted by Mrs. A. Sydney Barritt as co-chairman.

New York City is planning to fight school retardation and delinquency on a new front in the next few months. It will seek to discover how far intellectual and moral maladjustments of one sector of the city's children may be ameliorated by the simple means of giving them individual help in learning to read.

DETROTT. INCREASING sales of trucks powered by Diesel engines have given rise to considerable discussion lately of the future of this type of power plant in the automobile industry. Speculation has centered chiefly around the possibilities for the use of Diesel engines in light-duty trucks and in passenger cars. Growth thus far has been confined almost entirely to heavy trucks, operating on long hauls.

Representative Zimmerman of Kennett, Mo., said today he would ask further investigation of the sinking on Jan. 30 of a barge in the Birds Point-New Madrid Floodway with a loss of at least twenty-four lives. Zimmerman said the Works Progress Administration had advised him that all the victims are presumed to have been government employes coming under the Compensation Laws.
Skill in detecting the first of social maladjustment in girls ?? the contribution of spiritual ?? moral guidance before actual delinquency results, are the objective of the Big Sister movement.

An informed diplomatic source said tonight that the German Ambassador to London, Joachim von Ribbentrop, was rebuffed when he presented Chancellor Adolf Hitler's demand for the return of Germany's colonies to Viscount Halifax, the Lord Privy Seal, in London Thursday.

Plans to honor Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, at a reception and tea Tuesday at the Grover Cleveland- Democratic Club were announced yesterday by Miss Abbie Sheehan, heading the woman's auxiliary, which will be in charge.

ASTOR-The Good Earth: Paul Muni, Luise Rainer.* BELMONT-The Girl From Poltava: Thalia Sabineeva. CAMEO-Spain in Flames;* Prisoners, Thursday night. CAPITOL-Camille: Greta Garbo, Robert Taylor.* CRITERION-Great Guy;* Man of Affairs, Thursday night. 55TH ST. PLAYHOUSE-Masquerade in Vienna: Paula Wessely.* FILMARTE-The Eternal Mask: Mathias Wieman.* GLOBE--Devil's Playground: Richard Dix. MUSIC HALL-On the Avenue: Dick Powell, Madeleine Carroll.* PARAMOUNT-Champagne Waltz;* John Meade's Woman, Wednesday.

D.R. JOHNSON remarked to Boswell that "some people have a foolish way of not minding, or pretending not to mind, what they eat," and he went on to say that he minded his stomach very carefully, for he felt that if a person did not mind his. stomach he would not mind anything.

With Congressional legislation providing minimum wages and maximum hours for industrial employes as the topic of discussion, the varsity debating teams of Manhattan College and Fordham University will meet tonight at the parish auditorium of St. John's

Stimulation of a national spirit and wider participation by individuals in everyday politics were urge?? last night by former Governor David Sholtz of Florida at a dinner held in the Hotel Commodore to celebrate the sixty-ninth anniversary of New York Lodge 1 of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks.

A Washington's Birthday tea will be given next Saturday at Meadow Garden, the historic home of George Walton, signer of the Declaration of Independence, by the Augusta Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution.
Public whippings of persons found looting flooded homes were advocated today by Police Judge Joseph P. Goodenough.
The police announced tonight that they had discovered the existence of an arms-smuggling ring running German arms into France.

Three Germans met death at dawn today at the Nazi chopping block. Three times the top-hatted headsman swung his axe to execute one man for high treason and two others for "non-political" murders. At least six more remain in Reich jail cells waiting a similar fate.

Uncle Robert, sponsor of entertainments for children, and lecturer on safety, will present gold star emblems at his tenth annual Parents Day celebration to the couple from each of the five boroughs who have been married longest and who lost a son in the World War, he announced yesterday.

Reporting on the construction progress in New Jersey during the past year, Thomas E. Colleton, FHA State director, pays a high tribute to the building and loan associations of that State which in 1936, he states, made 1,536 loans aggregating $7,637,640 which were accepted for insurance during the year.

Extortionists have kept Federal agents on the jump this year. Almost once a week since Jan. 1 they have trapped extortion note writers. The intended victims have included at least one well-known public official, the wife of a prosperous manufacturer and two persons previously kidnapped-Miss Mary McElroy and Edward G. Bremer.

A report that the Bendix Aviation Corporation plans to develop a plant costing millions of dollars here was confirmed in several quarters today. However, Vincent Bendix, president of the corporation, said in New York that he would not make a definite statement until Wednesday.

An organization of young lawyers, to be known as a "Committee of Safety," has been formed to oppose any legislation by Congress the effect of which will be to destroy the independence of the judiciary, give personal control of the Supreme Court or other courts of the United States to the President or any other agency or tamper with the constitutional balance of powers and structure of the American Government.
Delegates representing fifty-six classes and the seventy-four Smith Clubs throughout the country will attend the. annual mid-Winter meeting of the Smith College Alumnae Council here Feb. 25-26-27.

The American boat Ace, sailed by Adrian Iselin 2d, and the Western Long Island Sound fleet representative, took the first race of the eleventh international Star class series for the Bacardi Cup today, while another American yacht, Jack Rabbit, handled by Paul Shields of Peconic Bay, won first place in the second contest.

An income tax lien for $210,916.74 was filed in Federal court yesterday against John Barry Ryan of 18 West Tenth Street, son of Thomas Fortune Ryan, the financier, who left an estate valued at $300,000,000.

Twenty-five rookie firemen saw their first action fire about 6 o'clock last night at a two-alarm blaze at 52 Lispenard Street. The heavy Canal Street traffic was tied up for about twenty minutes. Dense columns of smoke filled the entire block, from Broadway to Church Street, compelling the firemen to use searchlights.

A definite indication or returning prosperity and increased consumer purchasing power was seen last week in the action of leading woolblanket mills, which discontinued a considerable number of their lowend constructions. The number of styles in the lines of several mills was said to be the lowest in seven or eight years.

All the adverse developments affecting business since the start of the year failed to reduce materially the sales gains which were registered by dry goods wholesalers over the corresponding period of 1936, according to reports yesterday. Volume increases have been steadily maintained at about 25 per cent in most sections of the country, it was said.

MAXWELL, N. M. THE State of New Mexico has started serious preparation for its Coronado Cuarto Centennial (the Spanish form is official), which is to distinguish the entire year of 1940, with special emphasis upon the period between April 1 and Nov. 1 of that year.

DISCUSSING war debts in the House of Commons Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer-with less than the usual tact shown by Ministers of the Crown--once remarked that the British arguments against payment of these obligations "may not appeal to the Middle West,

After six years of operation in Sydney, the Royal Military College will reopen in Duntroon, near Canberra, Monday. Including New Zealanders, fortynine cadets will resume their studies and twenty-five new ones will be added on March 1, making the largest roll in many years.

Mortgage foreclosures in 1936 were the lowest in six years, according to the index of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, made up from the records of forced sales in seventy-eight counties in which are located cities with more than 100,000 population.
FORMOSA reports the discovery by Japanese fishermen of the largest piece of coral on record. weighing more than 350 pounds but worth only about $3.000.

Two things stood out after the conclusion on Friday night of the most successful Westminster Kennel Club show in the sixty-one years it has been conducted. Foremost was the attendance for the three days, which a Westminster official summed up yesterday as "much better than ever before" and was estimated unofficially at 55,000.

WHILE there are now 689 broadcasting stations in the United States, further grants are expected to lift the total to beyond 733 in 1937, according to the Year Book of Broadcasting Magazine. Fifty-seven new transmitters were added to the radio roster in 1936.

A divorce was granted today to D. W. Tomlinson, airline executive, from Mrs. Virginia S. Tomlinson. Judge Bird, in granting the decree on the grounds of incompatibility, put the child of the couple in care of the Sisters of Notre.Dame de Sion here.

A revival of plans for erection on Philadelphia's Parkway of a "Temple of the Arts," to become the home of the Philadelphia Orchestra and the site for operas, lectures and other events of civic interest, was announced today by Mayor S. Davis Wilson. The project would represent an outlay of about $5,100,000.

About 70,000 workers are scheduled to return to General Motors factories tomorrow, the first large section of 100,000 recalled after the six weeks of strikes. The company expects to have a total force of 215,000 at work early this week. This total is within 20,000 of the maximum.
The American boat Jack Rabbit, sailed by Paul Shields of Peconic Bay, this morning won the third and final race for the Bacardi Cup in the eleventh International Star Class regatta.
A revised book of rules and regulations and an "Official Action Guide" will be distributed to the members of the Fire Department today, Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday.

The markets here are full of rumors of impending changes in the political and financial direction of French affairs. Further foreign credits for France are reported as highly probable, while it is rumored that the French treasury is contemplating action which will bring about considerable return of gold to France and encourage people to stop hoarding.
So great is the demand from foreign countries for parrots, monkeys, macaws, snakes, small lions, tigers, wild cats and animals of various other types that the highest prices on record are being paid.

Although the Honduran Minister here has published an official telegram from Jose Albir, Nicaraguan private secretary to President Tiburcio Carias of Honduras, saying that the country is tranquil, Opposition leaders here report new uprisings in various places.

Carlos Chavez, Mexican conductor and composer, completed his' first week as guest director of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. Cherubini's "Anacreon" overture and Beethoven's Seventh symphony were added to the program.

Finishing with an aggregate of 144, Al Ulmer of Jacksonville won the low gross award in the 36-hole medal play golf tournament today. Trailing by a single stroke at the completion of the first half yesterday with 70, Ulmer added 40, 34-74.

The Foreign Policy Association said today that a survey of sixty nations had showed that the world expenditure for military purposes had doubled in the last two years. The armament bill was $5,000,000,000 in 1934 and almost $11,000,000,000 in 1936, a report prepared by W. T. Stone and H. Fisher said.

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch, accompanied by the Rumanian Foreign Minister Victor Antonescu, who arrived yesterday from Bucharest, left today on the Simplon Express for Athens to attend the conference of the Balkan Entente powers opening there tomorrow.

Warren Howland Jones of 51 Sycamore Avenue, secretary of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, with an office at 150 Broadway, Manhattan, died this afternoon in the Mount Vernon Hospital, after a week's illness of pneumonia, at the age of 61. His widow, the former Agnes Wetten, survives.

President Roosevelt's proposal for reorganizing the Supreme Court will hold the center of the legislative stage this week unless Republican State Chairman William S. Murray convinces the Republican leaders at a conference tomorrow afternoon that attempts to put New York State on record against the President's plan should be held in abeyance.

Opening performances of religious plays to be presented during the Lenten season by two Roman Catholic parishes of this city were held today. The afternoon and evening performances of "Veronica's Veil,"

Rebuking those who "view with alarm" the state of the theatre, Alexander Woollcott declared last night, at a dinner given in his honor at the Lotos Club, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street, that it is not the theatre that is decaying but the theatre critics.

The first meeting of the North Jersey Council for Industrial Organization was held at 83 Academy Street, here, tonight. The group, comprising representatives of electrical, radio, rubber, shipyard and steel workers, announced their intention to "challenge capital" in this area by a program of mass meetings, the first of which will be held next week.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 83 per cent of capacity, up 3 points from the preceding week, tonnage being above any monthly average except those for the five months through July, 1929.
Nearl 28,000 miles of wire now carry electricity to 75,000 New York farms, 42.5 per cent of the total number in the State, the Public Service Commission disclosed tonight in its annual report.

James:Sirmp son, chairman of the Commonwealth Edison Company, reported today that the company had in 1936 the largest earnings of the last five years. Marked improvement in income from investments and a decrease in interest charges more than offset a reduction in earnings from utility operations, he said.

" The Blue Danube Waltz," which yesterday turned 70, had a rousing birthday party today beginning this morning in the open air and reaching its climax in a grand concert in the large Musikverein Hall tonight.

The success of the first national championship figure-skating meet to be held here leaves the officials of the United States Figure Skating Association with several problems that are likely to affect the future growth of the sport.

One hundred and thirty-five, thousand members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America will receive a wage increase of 12 per cent, or $30,000,000 annually, under the terms of a three-year contract approved yesterday by the Amalgamated and by a committee of men's clothing manufacturers, representing 85 per cent of the national industry, with a retail production volume of more than $1,000,000,000.

To productive industry, termination of the defiant "sit-down strike" called by a minority union in the General Motors plants was the event of the week. It did not affect the markets in the degree that had perhaps been expected; indeed,

Cardinal von Faulhaber, in a sermon before 8,000 in St. Michael's Church here today, declared in bitter terms that the National Socialists had repeatedly violated the concordat signed with the Vatican in July, 1933, and for the first time he discussed the possibility of its denunciation as impracticable.

Record supplies of lard in cold storage, combined with selling by packers against the output of their houses, resulted in a sharp lowering of prices here last week. At times, hedging sales alone were sufficient to supply all regular consumptive and speculative requirements.
The Scots-Americans defeated the Paterson Caledonians, 4 to 2, in an American Soccer League match at Clark's Field today. At half-time the victors were leading by 3-1.

A special committee of mill men will present a report on tariff matters affecting the domestic wool textile situation at the annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Wednesday of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

Speculative interest in oats here has waned. It is said that leading cash interests have turned over their hedges while new commission-house business is less noticeable. Prices on futures had a range of 3/4 cent to 1 1/3 cents, the latter on July. The close, last week,

Historic Tanglewood on the north shore of Mahkeenac Lake has been offered as a gift by its owners, Mrs. Gorham Brooks and her aunt, Miss Mary Aspinwall Tappan of Boston, to the Boston Symphony Orchestra for Summer headquarters and for development by the Berkshire Music Festival Corporation.

C. N. Daniels, manager of the Fisher Body plant here, said that he was informed today a secret poll of the plant's employee had shown a majority opposed to joining the United Automobile Workers Union.

Social security rates eventually should be assessed against different employers according to merit, Samuel W. Reyburn, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, suggested last night over radio station WOR in a symposium on social security.

President Roosevelt's proposal to increase the membership of the United States Supreme Court is an "insult to the justices," Horace Dutton Taft, whose brother was President and Chief Justice, declared today.

At last the slow movement toward religious peace in Mexico seems to be accelerating. The popular and the official reactions to the recent tragedy in the State of Veracruz indicate that President CARDENAS may now feel able to proceed more vigorously in his efforts to end the war against the Catholic Church.

Mrs. Henrietta Solinger Hershfield, widow of Mitchell Hershfield, lawyer, died Saturday morning of a heart attack at her residence, the Hotel Narragansett, Broadway and Ninety-fourth Street, at the age of 72.
The Hunter River team of Australia, with the American star, Earl Hopping, playing No. 3, won the Philippine national open polo championship today, defeating Los Tamaraos, 13--6.

In his report, published this morning, Dean SMITH of the Columbia School of Law recurs to a familiar theme. Into the overcrowded bar new crowds are pushing every year. Average earnings are low. Nearly 10 per cent of the New York County bar has attained the status of paupers.

A steady downpour of rain today forced cancellation of the North American speed skating championships, leaving the 1937 titles unsettled. Charles H. Goldsmith, director of the meet, in announcing the cancellation, said medals and trophies were awarded the winners of the events completed on the opening day, Friday.

Patrolman Thomas Ennis was shot dead early this morning as he exchanged shots at close quarters with a hold-up man in the inside doorway of an all-night restaurant at 519 Main Street, in the heart of the business district here.

The unfortunate results for Yugoslavia that have followed her acquiescence to the plans of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister, for acquiring raw materials without cash payments were enumerated in today's newspaper Politika.
Dapper Harry Cooper, the man to catch from the start, today won the $3,000 Houston open golf tournament with a four-under-per total of 280 for 72 holes.

Defeat of President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the United States Supreme Court to prevent the destruction of democracy and the substitution of personal government was urged yesterday by Amos R. E. Pinchot in a message addressed to all members of Congress and sent from his law office at 101 Park Avenue.

Penn's two victories in the Eastern league and Notre Dame's onesided triumph over N. Y. U. were outstanding, while the performances of Fordham and St. John's also were noteworthy in a busy week of intercollegiate basketball.
Warren Chlvers of Dartmouth College won the United States combination cross-country and skijumping title today, holding a 24point advantage after completion of the two-day competition.

An unidentified hen of mixed breed belonging to Mrs. John Levi joined the prophets of disaster today by producing perfectly formed egg on which- witnesses. declared was plainly inscribed the message: "War-1937-Jure 20."

The Committee for the Relief of Home Owners will meet at 4 o'clock this afternoon in the Board of Estimate Chamber, City Hall. Joseph M. Duffy, for many years in charge of the management of the real estate of the Interborough Rapid Transit Co., has been appointed real estate agent for the receiver, Thomas E. Murray Jr. Charles A. Davis is now with the David Jaret Organization, 375 Fulton St., Brooklyn.

A. P. Palmer captured the high scratch trophy at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He scored by breaking 97 out of 100 targets. In the handicap competition the leader in Class A was L. F. Sanman, who had a total of 99. W. F. Adler prevailed in Class B with a full card.

As artists' models, chess teachers and window washers-along with a variety of other part-time jobs--a thousand Harvard College students last year earned about $204,000. The college employment office tonight reported the students' earnings represented a substantial improvement over last year, when 928 students earned $190,000. Waiters, the employment office said, fared better than others, 229 earning $32,000.
Dick Neal of Kansas City annexed two major victories in the annual New Smyrna speed boat regatta today, emerging with the $25,000 Sir Thomas Lipton trophy and the Governor Dave Sholtz trophy.

Increases in the maintenance cost of property in this city, especially East Side apartment houses, is threatening the upward trend of real estate recovery, according to a statement issued yesterday by Leslie H. Moore, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co.. Inc.,

Seven persons were burned to death near here early today in a flaming automobile which had struck a slow-moving produce truck. Four were identified as Clarence May, 39, farmer; Flora May, 28, his wife; Margaret May, 10,

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbet's, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:

All the scattered testimony of "shakedowns" in the restaurant racket are to be tied together in the testimony of one witness when Louis Beitcher, gangster collector, takes the witness stand before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook today.
Mr. and Mrs. William W. Hewitt of Hilton Avenue entertained at a large tea at their home this afternoon. Their auests included:

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt left yesterday to join Brig. Gen. Vanderbilt on their yacht, Winchester, at Miami, Fla. Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Pettinos of the Savoy-Plaza are returning this week from Sea Island, Ga. Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus H. Adams and Miss Mary Adams of Chicago are at the St. Regis.

Harvard University's unbeaten hockey team moved into second place in the International Intercollegiate League last week, according to the standings released today by Asa S. Bushnell, the league's secretary.
Thomas F. Brennan, pioneer Western New York railroad man and assistant to the vice president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, died here today. His age was 77.

A 20-year-old youth, who was paroled from Elmira Reformatory only two weeks ago, staged a race yesterday morning with the police radio system while fleeing from a hold-up of a photographer's studio at 165 East 116th Street. He lost.

The New York Rovers gave their fans a test of faith yesterday and, in the end, rewarded them handsomely for their patience. For in a game which was scoreless in the first period and tied at 1-1 in the second, the Red Shirts made an eleventh-hour stand which could not be denied. It yielded five goals and a 6-to-3 triumph over Hershey.
To destroy the "minding the children" excuse mothers give for staying away from church, a nursery has been established at the First Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Alfred J. Penney, rector.

Mrs. Clifton Downing Butler of Flushing, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Irma Patricia Butler, to Delmont Locke Bogart, son of Mrs. E. Locke Bogart of Scarsdale, N. Y. The announcement was made yesterday afternoon at a tea given by Mrs. Butler at her home.

The text of Attorney General Cummings's radio address tonight on President Roosevelt's court reform proposals was as follows. Only nine short days have passed since the President sent to the Congress recommendations for the reorganization of the Federal judiciary.
A warning against ratification in this State of the Federal Child Labor Amendment, signed by 143 physicians, was made public yesterday by the New York State Economic Council.

Public relief never can replace religious welfare work, the Rev. John J Donovan, recently appointed Moderator of Particular Council of the St. Vincent de Paul Society, declared yesterday morning at the quarterly meeting of the group in the auditorium of Cathedral High School, Fiftieth Street and Lexington Avenue.
Settlement of the General Motors strike and consequent releases of steel have given the steel market a fillip and tended to increase confidence according to the magazine Steel in its issue of today.
Don Budge caught Bryan Grant in his own back yard today and administered his second straight defeat to the little Atlantan, with whom he is feuding in Winter competition.
Dr. Henry K. Seelaus, Assistant Professor of Surgery at Jefferson Medical College, died of pneumonia today at his home here after a short illness. He was 41 years old.

The Madrigal Singers, directed by Lehman Engel, gave the second in its series of programs at the WPA Theatre of Music yesterday afternoon. The program was devoted to music of France and the Netherlands. The only composers of modern times represented were Darius Milhaud and Claude Debussy.
The world's wheat markets became more bullish last week, and professional traders moved more to the buying side, especially on breaks. The disposition in all markets is to look for higher prices.

Stubbornly refusing to be counted out of the picture, the New York Americans handed their favored local rivals, the Rangers, a 5-to-4 setback at Madison Square Garden last night. Red Dutton's skaters, aided by an early lead, just managed to survive a furious closing burst on the part of the Blue Shirts to register their second straight victory.

A campaign to unionize the 5,000 or more employes of the Smith Carpet Works here was launched this afternoon by Local 2,449, a recently organized unit of the United Textile Workers of America, an affiliate of John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization.

Announcement has been made by Colonel and Mrs. Augustus F. Dannemiller of Fort Hamilton of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Dannemiller, to Captain William A. Todd Jr., Medical Corps, U.S.A., of Fort Monmouth, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Todd of Augusta, Ga.

Arthur Greenleaf, 14-year-old Negro of East Orange, was shot in the abdomen here early today by Patrolman William Monroe when, it is alleged, the boy was attempting to escape after being caught attempting to break into a garage.
The formation of a development trust fund of more than $500,000 from which loans and grants would be made for social, agricultural and industrial purposes was officially announced here yesterday.

An analysis of the nation's financing activities appearing in the 1936 volume of "American Underwriting Houses and Their Issues," now-ready for distribution, reveals that Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., led the list of underwriting houses in the year by heading syndicates for new issues amounting to $1,126,183,900. Kuhn, Loeb Co.,

George A. D. Ogilvie-Forbes, who has been the representative of the British Government at Madrid and Valencia since the start of the civil war, has been promoted to counselor of the British Embassy at Berlin.

No anxiety is reported in Bourse circles on the score of dearer money. In any case, it is pointed out, when the tendency is to a hardening, speculators do not hesitate to pay exceptionally high premiums to maintain their commitments from which they expect large profits.

John W. Taylor of the Montclair A. C. and George W. Fraker Jr. of the local club won the New Jersey individual championships at squash racquets in Classes B and C, respectively, at the Plainfield C. C. today.

The settlement of the General Motors strike last week was hailed last evening by the Rev. Dr. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of the Broadway Temple Methodist Episcopal Church, 174th Street and Broadway, as a sign that sentiment is not dead.

Extolling Abraham Lincoln for his "moral and intellectual genius," Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson pointed out yesterday morning that. hi talents might have been restricted had he been deprived of the "open forum" that democratic America afforded him. Dr. Goldenson spoke at the Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, where he is rabbi.

Greater efforts by Catholic laymen to end the "prejudice and colossal indifference" of the American people to the Negro, and particularly of Catholics, so that more Negroes may be converted to the Catholic faith was urged yesterday by the Rev. John La Farge, founder of the Inter-racial Council and associate editor of America.
George Oliver's Augusta team won the Camden Mid-South polo tournamient for the Russell Memorial Trophy today, beating the Camden Yellow Jackets, 7-5.
The number of unemployed persons in Germany in January increased by 374,000 to 1,853,000, against 2,520,000 in the same month in 1936.
In an exhibition soccer game at Recreation Park in Long Island City yesterday the Brooklyn Hispanos defeated the New York Shamrocks, 2 to 0.

After a large increase in the preceding two weeks, the note circulation of the Bank of England declined [Pound]2,317,252 in the week ended on Wednesday. This was a much heavier decline than occurred in the corresponding week last year,

Manton Metcalf of New York, sailing Captain Kidd, which he owns jointly with Nelson Odman of Sweden, today won the Sir Frederick Williams Taylor Cup in the opening event of the Royal Nassau Sailing Club's season.
Daniel Chase, executive director of the Sportsmanship Brotherhood of New York was injured severely at Darien, Conn. today when he attempted to board a moving train.

The birth certificate for little Prince Victor Emmanuel was made out with elaborate ceremony in the Royal Palace today, with Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister and son-in-law of Premier Benito Mussolini, and Luigi Feder. zoni, President of the Senate, rep. resenting the government.

Three Brazilian engineers, who said that they struggled through uncharted jungles, swamps and mountains in a 15,000-mile journey during the last nine years to blaze a possible route for a Pan-American highway linking North and South America, told of their experiences here today.

Lamb and poultry are the best meat values with prices well below those of a year ago, it was reported yesterday by the weekly Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets. Pork and veal cost about as much as at this time. last year.

Prominent Equity members now under suspension for failing to Join the Screen Actors Guild are sharply warned in the February issue of Equity Magazine, published today, that their reinstatement will be "neither as simple, as easy nor as inexpensive as they mistakenly believe."

Thundering Black Rapids glacier crept toward the Revells' roadhouse home today, but the plucky family stayed with their packed possessions in hopes that the crushing ice giant would stop its slow advance.

The wine of Grinzing seems to please the taste of Vienna's royal visitors from the Netherlands. Crown Princess Juliana and her husband, Prince Bernhard, remained at Hengl's Heuriger Wine Garden in Grinzing until 5 o'clock this morning.

The advance in communism is "partly the result of our unfulfilled Christian duties," the Right Rev. Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America, Washington, D. C., declared. yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Peter Visconti, 46 years old, was seized early yesterday by two detectives at his home, 3,569 Broadway, near 146th Street. He was wanted in Brooklyn on a grand larceny indictment charging that he swindled Mrs. Annette Savine, a widow, of the Hotel St. George, of $950.

The engagement of Miss Virginia Ruth Paxton, daughter of Mrs. Edithe Edwards Paxtot, of this city, to Charles Smith Adams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Smith Adams of Macon, Ga., was announced this afternoon at a tea given for a company of 100 at the Paxton home.

Miss Sonja Henie, Olympic figureskating ruler, will perform on the ice of Madison Square Garden tonight in her initial appearance in New York as a professional. A capacity crowd is expected to be on hand to view the Norwegian star's program.
Death as the maximum penalty for those guilty of espionage against the Spanish Republic was established today by a Ministry of Justice decree.

If Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, likes 4 o'clock tea he will be out of luck during his forthcoming stay in Puerto Rico, because 4 o'clock coffee will be offered him instead at Carlota Matienz Hall, girls' dormitory at the University of Puerto Rico.

Bill Hewitt, star end, was traded today by the Chicago Bears of the National Football League to the Philadelphia Eagles for the draft rights to Sam Francis, University of Nebraska fullback and Olympic shotputter.

At this end of the Rome-Berlin axis it does not seem altogether certain that Berlin is the business end. Not yet, at least. Whether Italy and Germany are competing or cooperating, their common front in Spain serves Italian interests rather than German.

New York motor vehicle officials considered tonight a new highway-safety measure. which would require a special license for operators of trucks of more than two tons and buses carrying more than seven passengers.

Jerome (Dizzy) Dean, ace of the Cardinals' pitching staff, and Rogers Hornsby, manager of the Browns, disagreed today over the holdout question. Dizzy said: "I am dead certain I will not pitch for the Cardinals this year for less than $50,000."

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Feb. 10 at 81.5, compared with 81 a fortnight before, 80.7 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931. just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Bearing tidings of another of former King Edward VIII's "irrevocable" decisions-that he still intends to marry Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson at the first opportunity-the Princess Royal returned to London from Vienna today with her husband, the Earl of Harewood.

Mrs. Flora Spiegelberg, who recently celebrated her eightieth birthday,- yesterday witnessed the first New. York showing of her favorite creation, "Princess Goldenhair and the Wonderful Flower," presented as a play by the girls' department of the Educational Alliance in the Straus Auditorium, 197 East Broadway.

The universality of the Gospel of Christ and its inclusion of every human soul was stressed in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. John Timothy Stone, president of the Presbyterian Theological Seminary of Chicago, yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
David Pepper, a pioneer in the electrification of municipal transit systems in New Jersey, New England and Philadelphia, died at his home in Germantown yesterday at the age of 69. Mr. Pepper,

Heart-shaped bargains that had dotted lace-trimmed store-windows these last few weeks yesterday gladdened girl-friends, sweethearts, fiancoes and wives throughout a romance-conscious city. St. Valentine's Day had come.
Birger Ruud, the Norwegian phenomenon, retained his title today as the world's champion ski jumper n a "special jump" of the International Ski Federation meet, triumphing by a narrow margin.

The strength of new-crop deliveries, compared with the old-crop months, was the chief development in the cotton futures market last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange new-crop contracts showed advances of 9 to 13 points, while the old-crop- months declined 5 to 10 points.

Speaking on "The Value of Tradition," Dr. Fred Pierce Corson, president of Dickinson College, at the seventy-first founders' day exercises of the Peddie School here this morning, said that "tradition is a great thing if a challenge to progress, but if it binds one to the past it is a liability and not an asset.

Form held fast in the Brooklyn indoor tennis singles championship as the favorites advanced in an unbroken line at the 106th Regiment Armory yesterday. Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok, seeded fifth, and David Geller, rated eighth, gained the quarter-final, while George Seewagen, third on the seeded list, entered the third round.

Contributions for 1937 made thus far by employers under the New York State Unemployment Insurance Law exceeded by more than $300,000 the estimate of such contributions made in 1935 and early 1936, Glenn A. Bowers, Executive Director of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the New York State Department of Labor, stated today in a report to Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.

Edmund Moffett, 40 years old, a lawyer, of 192 Kerr Avenue, Newark, N. J., has been unable to explain how he fell to the bottom of an elevator shaft in the Midtown Hotel, 10 West Sixty-first Street, late Saturday. He is in Bellevue in a critical condition.

W. H. Frederick gained the honors for the first fifty targets in the shoot at the traps of the North Jersey Gun Club today. The high handicap gunner was F. B. Case with L. S. Rothwell finishing in the runner-up place.

Despite snow and Winter rains, the pro gram for unemployed women's camps was doubled during January the director, Miss Dorothea de Schweinitz, reported today to Aubrey Williams, National Youth Administrator.

" High Courts of the World and Their Powers" is the title of a table comparing high courts of the world with the Supreme Court of the United States in relation to the power to pass upon the constitutionality of legislative acts, issued by the United States Constitution Sesquicentennial Commission.

John L. Hartnett, secretary of the New York State Allied Printing Trades Council, died of heart disease Saturday night at the Manhattan Opera House during the Lincoln Day celebration of the New York Central Trades and Labor Council. He was 64 years old.

Dean Young B. Smith of the Columbia Law School urged stricter law school requirements in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, as a step toward alleviating the "appalling conditions" which exist in New York City's legal profession. He drew a dismal picture of an overcrowded and poorly paid profession. The report was made public yesterday.
The Penn A. C. quintet scored its ninth straight Eastern Athletic Club League victory and the seventeenth of the season by defeating the Uniyersity Club of Stamford today, 41--31.

Robers 0. Nilson, 28 years old, of 527 Center Place, Teaneck, saved himself from drowning in the Hackensack River here today by crawling through the window of his car, which had broken through the guard rail on the Anderson Avenue bridge overhead.

After seventy-two days of illness, during which the Pope had been either in bed or reclining in a special wheel chair, he was permitted today for the first time to rise to his feet and walk a few steps in his bedroom.

Six men, all charged with seconddegree manslaughter, will go on trial today in Bronx County Court as the result of a building collapse last June in which eighteen workmen were killed. The indictments were based on allegations of criminal negligence in the construction of the building at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's arrival here today after a prolonged stay at his home town, Fenghua, and in Shanghai caused a flutter of excitement among government officials, who had been anxiously awaiting his plans for the country's future.

The Continental Can Company, Inc., last year earned $9,038,788, equal to $3.17 on each of the common shares outstanding on Dec. 31, after all charges and Federal taxes on income and undistributed profits. Earnings compared with $11,223,578 in 1935, equal to $4.21 on each of the 2,665,191 shares outstanding at the end of that year.

Although Portugal's refusal to permit the establishment of a non-intervention control system along her frontiers has virtually wrecked the whole scheme, an urgent demand is being made here for the British government and the non-intervention subcommittee in London to make one more attempt.

Dr. Franz Sarga is up and about his dueling business again, because of a little conversation on a bus. The fiery. doctor, who challenged nine and fought three of the men he said slandered his ife last November, won a distinct victory in a ninety-minute duel today but failed to effect a reconciliation with his opponent.

Captain Marjorie Luella Weeks, who has a pilot's license to operate power craft in Long Island Sound, was married here today to another pilot, Captain Rayfield Ludwig Snyder of Springfield. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Weeks, is a native of Westhampton and attended school in East Hampton and Blanford.
The Rev. Dr William Tracy, rector emeritus of Christ Memorial Reformed Episcopal Church, West Philadelphia, died of pneumonia yesterday in his apartment in Drexel Hill. He was 91 years old.

The third act of "La Traviata" given in -costume was the most elaborate offering on last night's opera concert program at the Metropolitan. The bill also contained three other "scenes intimes," in addition to a duet from "Aida" and the usual round of vocal solos and orchestral numbers, all under the direction of Wilfred Pelletier.

Robert J. Kirk of 212-12 Thirtythird Avenue, Bayside, Queens, a veteran theatrical man who had been associated with John Golden since 1930, lately as manager of "And Now Good-Bye," died suddenly early yesterday of a heart attack while on his way home on an Interborough subway train.

President Roosevelt's plan for reorganization of the Supreme Court was praised and condemned in sermons preached yesterday in New York City churches. The Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, 263 West Eightysixth Street, said the proposed change Would leave the United States no longer a democracy.

Speculation as to Don Lash's potentialities as a miler, following his amazing two-mile achievement in the Boston A. A. meet last Saturday night, served as the chief topic of conversation yesterday for a group of athletes, officials and newspaper men on the train back to New York.

The storm blowing about the President's proposals for Supreme Court and judiciary changes has caused Congressional leaders to pause before bringing out other important measures for consideration. The program for this week, therefore, will mainly concern relatively unimportant legislation.

Graham, Parsons Co., Dougherty, Corkran Co., the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation and C. C. Collings Co. will offer today $800,000 Upper Darby Township, Pa., School District 23/4 per cent bonds. Dated March 1, the bonds will mature $25,000 each year from 1938 to 1952, inclusive, $30,000 each year from 1953 to 1965, inclusive, and $35,000 in 1966.

Our national difficulties are due to the fact that "we believe one thing and do another," the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Aveoue at Eightieth Street, said yesterday in his sermon there.

Miss Marjorie Lawrence, Australian dramatic soprano, who has been singing Wagnerian roles with the Metropolitan Opera Association for two seasons, sailed yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Hansa, to accompanied by her brother, Percy Lawrence. The prima donna said.

Acting on what they believe is authentic information that Mayor La Guardia will run for re-election, independent and civic groups supporting him increased their activity last week. In the same period Republican leaders have been suggesting that some other candidate be selected to run for Mayor without much hope of preventing Mayor La Guardia from getting the Republican nomination.

Members of Branch 10 of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers voted tonight to call a strike of all hosiery workers in Berks County in sympathy with the strike at the Berkshire Knitting Mills in Wyomissing, which began last Oct. 1.
The Toronto Maple Leafs lost a threegoal lead tonight, settling for a 3-3 tie with the champion Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game before 13,982 spectators.

Cimarosa's "The Clandestine Marriage" ("Il Matrimonio Segreto") will be the feature of the tenth week of the Metropolitan opera season next week. It is slated for Thursday night in an English version by Reginald Gatty and Albert Stoessel, with new recitatives by the latter.
Miss Elise Minshall Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wilson Robinson of Overbrook, will be married April 9 to Leighton Howe McIlvaine, son of Charles Lee McIlvaine of Bryn Mawr.

Leonard Hartman of New York won the second annual New Jersey indoor tennis championship when he defeated Herbert Bowman of New Rochelle in the final today, 1-6, 6-3, 6-4, 7-5. Hartman, who headed the draw, succeeds Donald Hawley of Orange, who was forced out of the tournament by illness.

General Jorge Ubico today began his second term as President of Guatemala as the result of a plebiscite called by a constitutional convention which provided for his continuation in office without the necessity of an election.
In expectation of the new Reichsbank and Reich railroad laws, the week's stock markets were exceptionally dull.

Traveling by ferry and bus from their homes on Eleventh Avenue, New York City', Elizabeth Burich, 8 years old, and Raymond Paul Martinez, 5, arrived here this afternoon looking for an uncle of Elizabeth's who lives "somewhere in Jersey."

" Let's Go Fishin'" is the provocative title of a new pamphlet on angling in the sailfish sector of the Gulf Stream just received from the West Palm Beach Fishing Club. Most literature of this sort may be classified as of the blurb variety, with exaggeration running rampant.

A survey of banks and trust companies in various sections of the country disclosed that 40 per cent of the institutions are increasing their expenditures for advertising campaigns in 1937, according to a report presented at a meeting of the officers and directors of the Financial Advertisers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last week.

The Associated Railroads of New .York State, an organization which voices the legislative aims of railroads in this State, issued yesterday a statement attacking the McElroy-Canney. bill, now pending in the Legislature, which provides that steam railroads must use five men in all switching or transfer operations.

The marriage of Miss Annabel Howell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Howell of South Orange, to Duncan Stevens Vanderbilt, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. S. Vanderbilt of East Orange, took place this evening in Christ Episcopal Church, Short Hills.

Choice of Professor CHARLES SEYMOUR to succeed President ANGELL at Yale when he retires-at the end of the college year will be popular within the university itself. There it will be regarded as a return to the old Yale tradition, whereby a son of Yale is sought for the presidency.

Direct government action is expected within twenty-four hours tending to normalize the coffee market, unsettled when a sudden rise in the market precipitated chaos and near-panic here yesterday, while on the Santos market there developed feverish buying out of all normal proportion.
Army engineers watched flood waters of the Mississippi-Ohio watersheds flow southward today, more confident that their man-made levees would see the extra waters safely to the gulf.

The resemblance between a man seen in a lunch counter here early yesterday and a photograph of Howard Dinger, a fugitive from an insane asylum wanted for questioning in the murder of Mary Ellen Babcock, 18-year-old Buffalo girl, started a search today in New Jersey, New York and PennsylL vania.

The American Merchant Marine Library Association, which last year distributed 261,000 books and 150,000 magazines among American merchant seamen, Coast Guard men and lighthouse keepers, yesterday announced plans for the expansion of its service.

Three early compositions of Beethoven made up the program of the twelfth concert in the New Friends of Music series given before an enthusiastic audience yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The works comprised the string quartet in D major, Op. 18. No. 3; the trio in C, for two oboes and English horn, and the septet, Op. 20.

Optimism continues here in financial circles on the economic situation in the United States. Nevertheless, it is realized that Wall Street's rise cannot continue indefinitely and the government at Washington is justified in desiring to avoid an unsound boom, which inevitably would lead to a crash. But the rise. it is felt.

Secretary WALLACE made an effective witness before the Senate committee which is now considering the Administration's foreign trade policy. He was asked to testify concerning the merits of a bill, already approved by the House of Representatives, which would continue for three more years the Government's power to negotiate reciprocal trade agreements.

Double victories by both Donald C. Vaughan Jr. of the Garden City Casino and Miss Patience Radford of Boston featured the finals of the second annual Eastern New York amateur badminton tournament at the 165th Infantry Armory courts yesterday.

The following are the Board of Trade's foreign trade figures for January: Total imports, [Pound]75,580,000; exports of British products, [Pound]39,100,000; reexports, [Pound]5,070,000; total exports. [Pound]44,170,000; excess of imports, [Pound]31,410,000.

Further reports from Kweilin, Kwangsi Province, explain that the seizure of the American Baptist mission property there followed recent negotiations for the sale of part of the property for use as Kwangsi government offices after the transfer of the provincial capital from Nanning to Kweilin.
The annual Junior League party in aid of the Children's Heart Hospital and other charities of the league will be in the form of a dinner dance in the ballroom of the Bellevue-Stratford on April 9.

Dr. Thomas O. Menees, roentgenologist on the staff of Blodgett Hospital, died suddenly tonight of a heart attack. He was a native of Nashville, Tenn., and was graduated from Vanderbilt University in 1912.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposed $722,000,000 Nicaragua Canal, as an auxiliary to the $547,000,000 Panama Canal, has aroused considerable controversy.

The Sleepy Hollow Country Club squash racquets team defeated the Apawamis Club squad, 6-1, on the losers' courts yesterday in the Westchester Division of the Metropolitan League. The Bronxville Field Club team won by default from the Greenwich Country Club.
Frank E. Gannett, publisher of the Gannett newspapers and a supporter of some Roosevelt policies, announced today the organization of a "National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government,"...

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at her home in Bethesda, Md., of Mrs. Lillian Stevens Lake, wife of Chester H. Lake, field engineer of the Rural Electrification Administration in Washington. Mrs. Lake,

The Jamaica Local Board will discuss the question of relocating the New York City-Nassau County boundary line in the Rockawaysection at a meeting Thursday night in Jamaica Town Hall. A representative gathering of Queens and Nassau property owners is expected.

Opening a fortnight's revival this evening is Ibsen's "An Enemy of the People," which returns Walter Hampden to Broadway and restores the Hudson Theatre to the legitimate field. The play is, 'of course, a favorite in Mr. Hampden's repertory, though he has not acted it here since November, 1928.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Robinson Darling of Chestnut Hill gave a tea this afternoon at their home at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Upton McNab Darling, to John B. Prizer of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Tower Prizer of Lancaster.

A five-point program for improvement of wages and working conditions of operating employes on the city's Independent Subway system will be submitted tonight, at a meeting to be held in the Times Square Hotel, to the board of seventy-nine men recently elected to represent the employes in collective bargaining with the Board of Transportation.

OME light may be thrown on what might be called the Major Experiment on ice when the Rovers of this district meet the Boston Olympics in an amateur hockey game at the Garden this evening. The Major Experiment is named after Major Fred McLaughlin, who owns the Chicago Black Hawks of the professional circuit.

Mrs. George F. Williams entertained at a large dinner tonight at the Everglades Club. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. Grover Whalen, Mr. and Mrs. William R. Sweatt, Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Sweatt, Mr. and Mrs. Chester Milton Williams, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Haven Windsor Jr.,

The German wholesale price index on Feb. 3 stood at 105.5, against 105.3 on Jan. 27. The index last year averaged 104.1, compared with 101.8 in 1935. Prices of agricultural products recovered to 77 per cent of the predepression level.

The "religion" of communism gained a foothold in Russia and is spreading elsewhere because of Christians' indifference and lack of self-discipline, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Tagart Steele Jr. declared yesterday in his first Sunday sermon as vicar of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, Broadway at 155th Street.

In a book to be published tomorrow in New York, entitled "Reciprocity: A National Policy for Foreign Trade," William S. Culbertson, former American Ambassador to Chile, strongly endorses the trade agreements program now being developed and applied by Secretary Hull.

Former Police Lieutenant David J. Sheahan, who retired from the force in 1924 after thirty-eight years' service, died yesterday morning at his home, 57 West Seventyfifth Street, at the age of 63. His widow, the former Margaret Quinn; a daughter,

Frank Coutant, president of the American Marketing Association, will become vice president and marketing counsel of Brown Tarcher, Inc., advertising agency, on March 1. He is a director of the National Federation of Sales Executives, a member of the Market Research Council and a member of the research committee of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

Encouraged by the reception of its quasi - historical products, "The Plainsman" and "Maid of Salem" at the box offices of the country, Paramount has authorized its director-producer, Frank Lloyd, to make "Wells-Fargo" next for the studio, replacing "I, James Lewis," which had been next on Lloyd's schedule.

The support of the international officers of the Building Service Employes International Union was thrown behind the threat of a hotel strike yesterday as the police posted guards outside three of the six large hotels on the union's strike list.
Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg indicated emphatically today that any decision on restoration of the monarchy rested with him.

Entertainments in honor oF British visitors aboard the Duchess of Richmond were given here yesterday afternoon, last night and today. Others aboard the ship included J. H. Thomas, former member of the British Cabinet;

Personal subscriptions for $10,000 of World's Fair Corporation debentures by Grover A. Whalen, president, for members of his family were announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the bond sales committee.
Dr. F. L. Whipple of the Harvard Observatory announced tonight the discovery of a new small comet in the constellation Canes Venatici (the hunting dogs).

Dr. Earl B. McKinley of George Washington University expressed confidence today that "we have isolated the true germ of leprosy." [Announcement was made in June, 1935, that experiments by Dr. McKinley and others had isolated this germ.]

Mrs. Mollie Luster Greenstein, widow of Leon Greenstein, New York merchant, died yesterday at her home, 300 Central Park West. A member of nearly thirty Jewish philanthropic organizations, Mrs. Greenstein had devoted much of her time since girlhood to benevolent enterprises.

Coming from behind to take the lead in the last few minutes, the New York A. C. basketball team turned back the Crescent A. C., 41-39, in an Eastern Athletic Club League game on the Brooklyn team's court yesterday.

Allan Clark and O. H. Chalkley were the winners in the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association's races off here today. Clark, sailing Penguin in Class D, won three races and took one second place for a point total of 19, seven more than his nearest opponent in a fleet of five boats.
Speculative trading in soy beans here last week was only fair and fluctuations were narrow. Consumptive demand was 111 fair.
