Prices of hogs here were unusually erratic last week. The week's average of all hogs was $10.15 a hundred weight, a drop of 15 cents from the previous week and 60 cents less than a year ago. The average weight of hogs was 237 pounds, compared with 234 the week before and 234 a year ago.

An unidentified cruiser lying well off the coast shelled this city, seat of the republican government, for about fifteen minutes tonight. It is estimated thirty shells fell in or around the city before shore batteries, assisted by the government gunboat Laya, forced the cruiser to withdraw.

Organized groups of motorists in the automobile clubs of the State, retailers of gasoline, the State Highway Survey Committee. and others interested in road building and road safety unite in opposing the provisions of the 1937 budget submitted by Governor LEHMAN in so far as they relate to gasoline taxes and appropriations for highways.
Of the eight present partners in E. W. Clark Co., which today will celebrate the hundredth anniversary of its establishment, three are grandsons and four are great-grandsons of the founder.

Three American delegates to the first international conference of war veterans opening here tomorrow arrived tonight. They are Dr. James Sparks of Indianapolis, Bernhard Ragner of McKeesport, Pa., and James McCann of Tuscaloosa, Ala.

The total number of unemployed workers in December was 8,399,000, a decrease of 477,000 from the total for November and a drop of 1,844,000 from the total for December, 1935, according to estimates made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The Alumni Association of Regis High School, founded in 1932, last night held the first of what is planned to be a series of cultural meetings at the school auditorium, 60 East Eighty-fifth Street. The Rev. James J. Rohan of the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 30 West Sixteenth Street, spoke on Lenin and Loyola. Nicholas P.

In defense of the national amateur championship, won by them last year, the soccer players of the first German Sport Club of Brooklyn yesterday defeated the Gjoa eleven, 2 to 1, in the fifth round of the U. S. F. A. cup competition at Bay Ridge Oval.

The exhibition season in the local art galleries continues to hold its pace with thirty or more exhibitions a week as an average. Work by French nineteenth century masters, American academicians and modernists, group and one-man shows, newcomers and old-timers, sculpture, oil, water-colors and graphics, are all on the roster of the present week.
Little comment has been made here upon the Federal Reserve Board's action in increasing the member banks' reserve requirements by 331-3 per cent.

MOST of Emil Ludwig's forty-odd books have been written about men he could adore as great. Even when they were not exactly im posing in themselves they were, like Kaiser Wilhelm, great in power. Napoleon, Lincoln, Bismarck, were among his heroes. Everything about them fascinated him.

Two modern destroyers, it is reported, will be built by Germany for the Venezuelan Navy, which has only two armed vessels. The flagship Mariscal Sucre, built in 1886 as the Isla de Cuba, was captured from Spain by the United States in 1898 and sold to Venezuela in 1912.

Alice Marian Hewitt, 14 years old, became the bride Friday of the Rev. Frederick Thomas Steel, 29, pastor of the Pentecostal Church, Matewan, W. Va. The couple went to Elizabeth City, N. C., where the ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Leo P. Louis. Virginia law forbids the marriage of persons under 15.

The National Public Housing Conference announced yesterday that it had sent to Mayor La Guardia and to the Mayors of 200 other leading cities an open letter appealing for support of the conference's 1937 drive for slum clearance and rehousing.

Mrs. M. Reis's Beau Bon, consistent7-year-old gelding, scored his third victory in four starts at the. Fair Grounds. today, capturing the featured sixth race on a charity program. Chatterfol finished second and Risibility third.

Unpleasant though the government's announcement that it proposes to use the power to borrow up to [Pound]400,000,000 may be as a reminder of the burden the country must bear in order to put its defenses on a basis comparable with those of other countries, it is possible to find some ground for satisfaction in this grim fact.

The general wholesale price index on Feb. 6 stood at 512, against 513 on Jan. 30 and 512 on Jan. 23. The index for domestic products was at 541, compared with 540 and 537, respectively, and other indices, with corresponding comparisons, were as follows: Imported products, 459, 464, 468; food, 521, 528, 527; industrial materials, 504, 501, 500.
Dr. Francisco Maria Fernandez y Hernandez, former Cuban Secretary of State, died today after a brief illness. His age was 50. Dr. Fernandez came here two years ago from New York.

Christian life is both a life .of peace and a life of struggle, the Very Rev. Joseph Vincent Ducattillon, assistant prior of the Dominican Convent of Paris, declared yesterday.morning in the first-of his series of Lenten sermons, which he will deliver on Sundays and.Wednesdays during the next. six weeks, at St. Vincent de Paul's Roman Catholic Church, 123 West Twenty-third Street. The sermon was in French.
Word was received here today of the death of Baron Godefroy de Blonay, fornier president of the International Olympic Committee, at Biskra during an African trip.

When business benefits it makes little complaint over the "principle" involved in the "interference of government in business," John E. Dalton, former head of the sugar section of the AAA and before that a member of the faculty of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, asserts in a book, "Sugar,"
A snow and wind storm that raged over the Northwest yesterday has caused three deaths, with at least four other persons injured in automobile accidents caused by the blinding snow.
Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 90.7, which compares with 90.4 a week before, 90.4 two weeks before,

The possibility of the division of the country into "semi-Fascist capitalism" and "semi-Communist labor" with a resultant civil war was foreseen yesterday by the Rev, Charles Francis Potter in an address before the First Humanist Society of New. York at 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The year has not commenced promisingly in regard to British railway receipts, which for the five weeks to date show a decline of [Pound]31,000 from a year ago. The country's business revival is reflected in the increase of [Pound]162,500 in general freight and passenger receipts, but the mild Winter has reduced coal-carrying receipts by [Pound]193,500.

Miss Raghild Hveger, the swimmer from the Netherlands, who already holds a couple of world's free style records, smashed Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett's 200-meter back-stroke mark by more than seven seconds today.

Natie Brown, 200-pound Washington fighter who meets Joe Louis in a ten-round bout here next Wednesday night, bounced through his first Kansas City workout today. When it was over his manager, the veteran Billy McCarney, announced Brown was "about set."
Army, navy and marine corps units with fighting equipment will move out of the harbors here and at San Diego before dawn tomorrow with all the secrecy required in time of war.
Thomas Augustus Mason, since 1927 secretary of the Thirty-fourth Street-Midtown Association, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 260 West Eleventh Street, at the age of 58.
Even as we the people of the United States are getting hot and bothered about farm tenancy, an aggravating message comes from Costa Rica.

The Merchants Association yesterday protested to Congressional leaders against legislation introduced during the present session which is intended to increase the personnel of American railroads and regulate the length of trains under certain circumstances.

The demand for dresses in the wholesale market here declined last week, although there was some call for the newer sheers, bolero styles, costume suits and sportsclothes. The Spring pastel shades gained in importance, with thistle coming well to the fore among the popular new colors.

The Union Central Life Insurance Company reported yesterday that in 1936 its assets rose $16,265,105 to a record high figure of $343,035,516, while capital, surplus and special reserves amounted to $12,526,496 at the year-end.

Daniel Carter Beard, National Boy Scout Commissioner, announced yesterday the award of two gold honor medals and seven certificates for heroism to nine Boy Scouts in. various sections of the country. The awards are made by the National Court of Honor, of which Mr. Beard is chairman.

Motion pictures depicting the activities of G-men are favored over all other types by the 10,000 boys and girls of elementary and high school age who attend the children's centers of the Children's Aid Society, it was announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Vasa K. Bracher of Tree Top, Dongan Hills, S. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Mande ville Bracher, to Robert C. Vincent of this city, son of Mrs. Clarence C. Vincent of Moscow, Idaho, and the late Dr. Vincent.

The Triborough Bridge Authority announced yesterday it has completed preliminary studies of the proposed Bronx-Whitestone bridge, which has been approved by the War Department, and will proceed with plans to finance the $18,000,000 project with a bond issue.

A campaign being conducted by the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., to standardize the teaching of ballroom dancing received impetus yesterday when a committee reported a standardization formula at the February meeting of the society in the Hotel Astor headquarters.

Government and private plans for slum clearance here "will not conceivably within this generation" reach 400,000 families now occupying 66,000 old-law tenements that "violate minimum standards of decency," according to a report prepared by the tenement house committee of the Charity Organization Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

The economic and cultural distress of Jews in Poland and Germany was described yesterday afternoon at a conference of representatives of 530 orthodox, conservative and reform synagogues and congregations in the Hotel Astor.

The body of Lieutenant I. Q. Forbes, United States Navy, was found in the wreckage of his plane today on a snow-covered mountain top sixty miles east of here. He took off from Yuma, Ariz., yesterday on the last leg of a flight from Norfolk, Va., to the Naval Air Station here in a single-seat highspeed plane.

A people should not be judged in the light of their wars and revolutions, but "by the hidden life that God works in the hearts of men," the Rev. Edgar Tilton Jr., pastor of the East Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church, between Park and Madison Avenues, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

Frederick D. Backus, treasurer of the Cord Meyer Development Company and one of the largest landowners in the Forest Hills section of Queens, died yesterday at his home, Queens Boulevard and Sixty-ninth Road, Forest Hills. He was born near this intersection on May 2, 1850.

A resolution opposing President Roosevelt's proposal for reform of the Federal judiciary, particularly as it applies to the change or enlargement of the United States Supreme Court, was adopted at a mass meeting today in the junior high school.

A severe dust storm, reported at most points "as bad as last Sunday's big duster," swept into the Oklahoma Panhandle early today but subsided somewhat by nightfall. Dust was reported all over Western Oklahoma.

Opening a barrage for another week of counter-attack by the administration against a Congressional revolt at President Roosevelt's judiciary reform program, Attorney General Homer S. Cummings, co-author of the plan, appealed directly to the people of the country tonight to disregard the "hysteria" and "irresponsible talk" of the last few days and turn their minds to "realities."

The Federal Trade Commission has dismissed its complaint against Sterling Products, Inc., 170 Varick Street, New York, manufacturing and selling, among other things, Phillips's Dental Magnesia and Danderine hair dressing.

The marriage of Miss Edna Roberta Giesy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marshall Giesy of Columbus, Ohio, to Thomas F. Frawley Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Frawley of Boston, took place here yesterday afternoon at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

Dividend distribution by Canadian mining companies in 1936 reached a highrecord of $80,950,000, according to official figures made public today. Of this total, Ontario companies distributed $53,870,000; those in British Columbia, $15.869,000; in Quebec, $8,112,000, and in Manitoba. S3.082.000.

The maintenance of democracy depends on greater enthusiasm and devotion than would be necessary for the establishment of fascism or a dictatorship, Canon James Stanley Bezzant, Chancellor of the Cathedral, Liverpool, England, declared yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

A son, their second, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Norman J. Marsh of New York and Mount Kisco, N. Y., on Wednesday at the Harbor Hospital. Mrs. Marsh is the former Miss Cornelia Van Rensselaer King, daughter of Mrs. James Gore King of 128 East Sixty-fifth Street and the late Mr. King.

The election of ninety-three new members and associates was announced today by the Yale Chapter of Sigma XI, the members having shown ability to carry on independent investigation of a high order, and the associates promising such capacity.

Marshal A. I. Yegoroff, Soviet Chief of the General Staff, left Moscow tonight with four aides for a tour of the capitals of the Baltic States--Kaunas, capital of Lithuania; Riga, capital of Latvia, and Tallinn, capital of Estonia.
Mrs. Fanny B. Russell, widow of Dr. William G. Russell and a resdent of Huntington for the last eighteen years, died at her home in the West Neck Apartments this morning at the age of 64.

Invitations to China and the Soviet Union to enter more harmonious relations with Japan were voiced this morning by Premier Senjuro Hayashi in an address to Parliament when it assembled for the first time since the fall of the Hirota Cabinet three weeks ago.

France's currency-equalization fund having taken 3,000,000,000 francs of gold from the Bank of France last week, with [pound]40,000,000 placed at its disposal through the French railway loan from London, any further withdrawal of gold from the central bank's holdings was out of the question.
" An attempt in Congress to pass a law which is contrary to the Constitution is not an act of Congress, but is an effort of less than 532 men to usurp powers never given them by the people."

Two elevator operators and a houseman staged a sitdown building service strike in a Bronx apartment house yesterday by chaining themselves to an iron girder leading down from the basement into the boiler room.
A name that apparently is destined to be headlined for years to come in the blinding-fast game of racquets was added to the distinguished list of winners of the Tuxedo Gold Racquet today.

After the clearing from the rain this afternoon, nine sailing dinghies competed in five races off the Larchmont Yacht Club and Ben Harrison, with his boat Blubber, led the others over a triangular course out in the harbor.

J. Augustus Keogh and his Irish Repertory Players, who had been going along in a quiet, semi-professional way these two seasons and a half, got around to a bill of three one-act plays last night at the Ninety-second Street Y.M.H.A., this time with the New Theatre League standing sponsor.

The Cadet Chapel Choir of the United States Military Academy, West Point, yesterday afternoon paid its tenth annual visit to St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. IThere it augmented the regular choir and sang three West Point songs.
" Joe College," the raccoon-coated, baggy-trousered, garterless college- student and his female counterpart, short - skirted, highly painted and slang-slinging "Betty Co-ed," have disappeared.

Three freighters, the Columbian and the Nevadan of the American Hawaiian Line, at Pier 6, Bush Docks, and the F. J. Luckenbach at the foot of Thirty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, which were to have sailed Saturday but were held up by the refusal of the crews to accept continuous discharge books, were still at their piers last night.

Edward Charles Rogers of Glen Cove, L. I., who won the national amateur pocket billiard title in last year's tourney, only to lose it to Lewis Brooks of Philadelphia in a challenge match, served notice last night that he intended regaining his crown.

President Kenneth C. M. Sills of Bowdoin College said tonight that nearly 1,000 Maine school teachers received wages of $10 a week. He spoke before the Woodfords Forum in a plea for support of an educational bill, carrying an appropriation of $1,750,000, now before the Legislature. Under this bill,

One half of the world's middleweight championship goes to the post tomorrow night when the aging Marcel Thil, recognized in Europe as titleholder among the 160-pounders, tries to make it three victories in a row over Lou Brouillard of Worcester, Mass.

The bodies of 658 celebrants of the Chinese new year were recovered in the ruins of a theatre at Antung, Manchukuo, destroyed last night by fire, said dispatches to the Domei (Japanese) News Agency today.

Leon Trotsky, in a telegram sent to a mass meeting of Socialists and Trotskyites today, offered again to surrender to the Russian secret police if an impartial commission found him guilty of the "monstrous crimes" imputed in the recent Moscow conspiracy trials.

What he termed the modern tendency of many children to "consider the home old-fashioned" and "just a place to sleep in" was the subject yesterday of Judge Matthew J. Troy of the Brooklyn Felony Court before 300 members of the Holy Name Society of the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament at a communion breakfast at the Embassy Hotel, Broadway and Seventieth Street.

The fate of President Roosevelt's judiciary reform program in Congresswhether it will be passed, modified or defeated-was seen tonight as reposing in the hands of thirty-four Senators, all Democrats but two, who as yet have not given sufficient indication of where they stand to be listed in the many informal polls of that body.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Herold Humbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Humbert of this place, to Joseph Stephen Straka Jr., son of Mrs. Joseph S. Straka of New York. The announcement was made yesterday at a tea given at the Humbert home.
A. Edward Santasiere, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, and Fred Reinfeld, a former champion, two of the leaders in the current tournament for the title, met yes terday in the seventh round.

In opposition to the "social role" intended for it by the Founding Fathers, the American public school system has supported the status quo, nine nationally known educators, members. of the John Dewey Society of Education and Culture, maintained in a section of that body's annual findings made public yesterday.
It is a fact well recognized by all investors, whether individual or fiduciary, that the present investment situation is surrounded with much more than the usual perplexity.

Leading figures of the legitimate stage projected last night a new American theatre, similar to London's "Old.Vic," which besides giving- young actors and actresses a chance to develop among thoroughly professional surroundings, would renew and perpetuate American contact with the greatest dramatic masterpieces.

In spite of the general let-down in business in the flood areas, commodity movement by truck increased 2.2 per cent in January over the monthly average for last year, according to the American Trucking Associations, Inc.

Six Milanese skiers were killed today in a snowslide. Two others were rescued. BETHESDA, Carnarvonshire, Wales, Feb. 14-(Canadian Press)-Two roped climbers fell 900 feet to their death today on the slopes of Llynidwall, part of the Snowden Mountain Range.

Deploring the lack of religious teaching for the youth of America, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, addressing the Protestant Teachers Association at the annual meeting yesterday in Riverside Church, advocated that the New York City schools be permitted to release their children one period a week for religious instruction.

Donald W. Howe, 35 years old, a civil engineer, was found dead today in the garage behind his home at 99 Washington Avenue. Dr. Amos 0. Squire, ' Westchester County Medical Examiner, listed the case as a suicide and said death had been caused by carbon monoxide fumes.

The railroads and the Pullman Company had 8,078 air-conditioned passenger cars in operation on Jan. 1, according to J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads. Since April 1, last, more than 1,300 passenger cars have been equipped with air-conditioning mechanisms.

Not only Catholics but Protestants as well prayed today in the churches of Orizaba and many other towns in the State of Veracruz. With police and troops withdrawn from the streets the devout were permitted at last to worship at ease and without fear of police breaking up their devotions.

A 17-year-old girl was killed, her cousin, the same age, critically injured and five others were taken to Fitkin Memorial Hospital suffering lesser hurts after a head-on collision between two cars on Route 34, in Wall Township, near here, shortly after 1 A. M. today.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of the Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in his sermon there yesterday morning called for a religious renaissance as well as a religious revival.

Sir William Soulsby, for fifty-five years (18751930) private secretary to successive Lord Mayors of London, died today at the age of 85. Often described as the "permanent Lord Mayor," he was largely responsible for the success of various Mansion House funds raised to relieve the suffering after disasters.
The Museum of the City of New York has sought to buy a pipe organ given by Queen Anne more than two centuries ago to a New York City church.

Predicting a decline in Federal expenditures in each of the next four years, a group of tax experts of the Twentieth Century Fund declares that expenditures by State and local governments "are almost certain" to increase in the same period.
Transactions on all registered securities Exchanges in 1936 amounted to $27,284,158,816, an increase of 42.7 per cent over the total for 1935, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

For a Christian to sin after acceptance of the faith is to show ingratitude to God, the Rev. John H. McComb said yesterday in his morning sermon at the Broadway Presbyterian Church, 114th. Street and Broadway.

A trend toward "more accurate, confidence-building advertising, fair not only to consumers but also to competitors," developed more clearly in 1936 than for several years previously, according to the annual report of the merchandise section of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc., issued yesterday.
The recital given by Alexander Brailowsky last night in Carnegie Hall brought back to this city a pianist of exceptional gifts, whose art has consistently developed with his experience.
Mr. and Mrs. William Van Cortlandt Brandt of Germantown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Weakley Brandt, to Lieutenant James Charles Dempsey, U.S.N.

Former Governor Alf M. Landon, recently Republican nominee for President, who came here to speak at the Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club last Friday evening, left yesterday with Mrs. Landon for Topeka.
Savage defeated the Brooklyn Pharmacy five last night on the Pharmacy court, 34-24. In the preliminary game the Thomas Jefferson jayvees downed the Pharmacy junior varsity, 19 to 12.
Dr. Sarah M. Crawford, one of the pioneer members of her sex to seek a career in the medical profession, died at her home today at the age of 92. She was the widow of Oscar Crawford.

The crisis in German Protestantism took a sensational turn today through the personal intervention of Chancellor Adolf Hitler, who issued a decree ordering writs of election for a new General Synod of the German Evangelical Church.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding at the end of January was $387,227,280, an increase of $14,410,317 over the end of December and a gain of $3,080,406 compared with the end of January, 1936, according to the monthly acceptance report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.
Despite small receipts of hogs here, prices dropped 10 to 15 cents today.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Arnoux Eskridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Webb Eskridge of this city, to Cadet William Perry Baldwin, son of Major Perry L. Baldwin, U.S.A., of Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Baldwin, has been announced.

The Soviet Government appears to be losing patience quite considerably with Japan, and unpleasant surprises may be in store for the Japanese unless they cease the protection of "White Guards" in Manchukuo, and halt irritating frontier incidents.

In the first twelve months of operation of eight provisions of the Social Security Act an increased measure of security has accrued to persons in all parts of the country, as well as in Alaska and the Hawaiian Islands, according to Miss Jane M. Hoey, director of the Bureau of Public Assistance of the Social Security Board.
Joe Dickson, a Uniontown newspaper reporter, testified today that he heard Frank C. Monaghan plead "give me a chance" in the Fayette County detectives' Bertillon room the morning of Sept. 12.

The current asset value of Adams Express Company common stock is $25.19 a share, based on market prices of last Saturday, Steele Mitchell, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders. On Dec. 31 the comparative figure was $22.84.

The Prudence Bondholders Protective Association voted yesterday full approval of the revised plan for reorganization for the Hotel Taft, certificates of which are outstanding in the amount of $4,088,300.

A check-up convinced hotel executives yesterday that the Building Service Employes International Union was almost completely without strength among the staffs of the six large hotels in which the union has threatened strikes.
The British Government again made it plain today that it had not budged an inch in its refusal to hand back any colony or mandated territory to Germany.

Norma Parker had an appointment in the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning that she failed to keep. At the time that she was to appear on a felonious assault charge involving a stabbing in November, she stood chewing gum and answering questions in the line-up glare at police headquarters.

Sales of two New York Stock Exchange memberships have been reported at $112,000 and $119,000. The last previous sale was at $110,000. The Exchange yesterday announced a proposal to transfer the membership of the late William B. Hibbs to William W. Spaid, who will continue as a general partner in W. R. Hibbs Co.
Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Heide of 210 Riverside Drive and Monmouth Beach, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Genevieve Heide, to Edward J. McCrossin Jr. of Brooklyn.

One point seems now to be fixed in the preparations for the election of a Mayor of New York this year. It is that the Republicans will not venture to name a candidate of their own. This has been made clear by Mr. SIMPSON, Chairman of the Republican Committee of Manhattan.

Georges Bonnet, newly appointed French Ambassador to the United States, is due to arrive tonight on the French liner Ile de France accompanied by Mrs. Bonnet and his chef de cabinet, Paul Charpentier. and Mrs. Charpentier.

About sixty-five WPA workers staged a sit-down strike yesterday in the WPA office at 40 Varick Street in protest against their reclassification from automobile mechanics and chauffeurs to laborers. The demonstrators arrived about 3 P. M. and at 6 o'clock announced their intention of remaining until they received a hearing from ,Mayor La Guardia or one of his representatives.

Adolf Hitler, Austrian-born Fuehrer and Chancellor who fought with the German Army during the World War, will mingle with old comrades and former enemies Wednesday when he greets fifty-one veterans from fourteen nations in his mountain retreat at Berchtesgaden.

Julian Louis Reynolds, a member of the Reynolds tobacco family, revealed yesterday through his attorneys that his wife, the former Helene Fortescue, whom he married in Washington last July, had left him. He declared in a public notice that he "will not be responsible for her debts."

President Roosevelt made an address at a testimonial dinner in honor of Postmaster General Farley, discussed the Judicial Retirement Bill with Senator McCarran, and appointed John M. Carmody to be Rural Electrification Administrator.
Colonel Alfred J. Booth of the Adjutant General's Department in the War Department died today of a heart attack in his home. He was 61 years old.

Apparently the Chinese Communists have agreed to abandon their party designation, relinquish at least a portion of their radical programs concerning property and wealth and consent to nominal merging of their armed forces into the Central Government armies.

Dr. Edmund LeRoy Dow gave a dinner, followed by bridge, for thirty-two tonight at Casa Pequena. Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Cheek entertained with a dinner at their villa for Mr. and Mrs. Edgar W. Garbisch of New York, their house guests.

The forty-eighth annual exhibition of the New York Water Color Club has opened in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until the end of the month. Besides 388 water-colors, nine pieces of sculpture are shown, furnished by the National Sculpture Society.

A five-room dwelling in Gramercy Park, the new residential development in Glen Rock, N. J., has been sold by Model Home Builders, Inc., to Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Ashton. The Realty Exchange of Ridgewood negotiated the sale.

Herbert Y. Hazelton, formerly with Brooks Harvey Co., has joined Wm. A. White Sons. The corner building at 481 Manhattan Av., recently purchased from Sarah See and modernized by N. Richard Hyman, broker, is 100 per cent rented and its income increased, according to the 860 Hunts Point Av. Corp., owner.

The Japanese military, having won a victory over the political parties and industrialists in the recent constitutional crisis, is now evidently striving to avoid sharp political controversies at home and to allay uneasiness abroad. The new Prime Minister, General SENJURO HAYASHI, in his address at the reopening of the Diet, was vague and soft spoken.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Feb. 10 shows a decrease of $24,000,000 in total loans and investments, increases of $59,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $18,000,000 in time deposits, decreases of $42,000,000 in government deposits, $35,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $10,000,000 in deposits credited to foreign banks, and an increase of $21,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Major Raymond G. Moses of the Mississippi River Commission said today that the fight to get the Ohio River's flood water safely down the Mississippi before dangerous rises of other tributaries had been won.
The House of Peers today heard Kishichi Kokubo, an elected peer, give a graphic description of the "third degree" methods that the Japanese police use against political suspects.

At Mayor La Guardia's direction, Deputy Police Commissioner John J. Sullivan suspended the license of the Queen Mary night club at 40 East Fifty-eighth Street yesterday after the club had falsely announced that it had hired armed guards for protection of its patrons.

A big increase in volume featured trading in synthetic gray goods last week with settlement of the motor strike, recession of the flood waters and more seasonal weather curbing the lull noted since midJanuary, according to the market report issued yesterday by Nickel Barrett, Lieberman Quinn, Inc., textile brokers. Trade was the largest since the week of Dec. 28.

Bya vote of 109 to 26, the House voted today to repeal the law which was passed four years ago legalizing pari-mutuel betting on horse races. It is indicated that the Senate will also vote for its repeal.

Mayor La Guardia submitted his capital outlay budget of $278,394,140 to the Board of Estimate yesterday with a message explaining his recommendations for largescale construction projects for the year ending on March 31, 1938.

Four passengers were riding in the last car of an eight-car B. M. T. express train bound for Brighton Beach at 11 A. M. yesterday when suddenly, just after the train had left the Newkirk Avenue station, one of the men displayed a pistol and gruffly ordered the others into the rear of the car.

Mrs. Suzanne Sheets Brandstetter, 18 years old, of this city, obtained an annulment this afternoon from Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich when she testified she was ill and intoxicated when she was married early in January in Northern Westchester and did not know what she was doing.

Thanks to words like "embarrassment," phthisiss" and "oscitancy," Coach Edward Hodnett had little difficulty in picking a fifteen-man starting line-up from the twentysix boys and one girl who tried out in McMillin Theatre yesterday for a place on Columbia College's intercollegiate spelling team.

Leonard Hartman, runner-up for the national indoor title and holder of the metropolitan and New Jersey indoor crowns, launched the defense of his Brooklyn championship by crushing Raymond Groden, Brooklyn College freshman, at 6-0, 6-1, in a second-round encounter at the 106th Regiment Armory yesterday.

The Wadsworth bill to require annual financial accounting by labor unions will be among labor measures considered tomorrow at a public hearing by the Senate and Assembly Labor and Industry Committees.

Coffee futures declined sharply yesterday on the local commodity market on news that the authorities in Brazil would take steps to end the chaotic market conditions in that country, which have been featured by sensational advances in prices.

In a further effort to establish that W. E. Hutton Co., New York members of the Stock Exchange and other Exchanges, made a business of acquiring stocks, "building them up" and then disposing of them, Jacob Gruber, counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission,

By a vote of two to one, the United States Circuit Court affirmed yesterday the decision of Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum dismissing a petition to reorganize the National Public Service Corporation, one of the old Insull holding companies.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to listing Brown-Forman Distillery Company $6 cumulative preferred stock, no par value; Simmons Hardware and Paint Corporation common stock, no par value; Soss Manufacturing Company common stock, $1 par value;

The Georgia House of Representatives adopted today a bill to investigate the administration of former Governor Eugene Talmadge, but fixed the appropriation to finance the inquiry at $10,000, or $240,000 less than was first proposed.

Paul Glass, chairman of the employes council at the National Tube Corporation, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, announced today that the council had recommended a general increase of 80 cents a day in wages and a minimum wage of $5.12 per day. The recommendation,

The spirit of give and take is essential among nations if peace is to be maintained in the world, John L. Merrill, president of All America Cables, Inc., declared yesterday in an address before the Pan American Society, celebrating its twentyfifth anniversary meeting at India House, 1 Hanover Square.

A clash between Representatives Fish of New York and McReynolds of Tennessee, who is chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, appeared today to jeopardize a bill appropriating $5,000,000 for the 1939 world's fair in New York City.

Minister of Finance Arthur SouzaCosta announced today that the government is prepared to take all necessary measures, even to legal prosecution, to prevent the speculative depression of coffee prices below normal levels.

Miss Madeline Dalton of the Salle d'Armes Vince, 23-year-old school teacher, won the women's national junior foils championship on the strips of the Fencers Club last night. She lost only one of nine bouts.
Major Gen. Robert Napier Harvey, one of the leading engineer officers of the British Army, died at Pyrford today. He was 68 years old.
The international stock market indices for Feb. 13, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927;
Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Meyer celebrated their fiftieth wedding anniversary yesterday afternoon with a reception held at the Women's Faculty Club in Columbia University. Annie Nathan Meyer,

Two British destroyers fired on an airplane "believed to be an Insurgent Spanish plane," which attempted to bomb them off the coast of Algeria, official London circles disclosed today. The plane flew off toward the Balearic Islands.

A query by the Socialist Opposition as to whether the Canadian Government was bargaining with Britain for economic concessions "with a blank check, which might be filled in with the lives of young Canadians," was met in the Dominion Commons today by Prime Minister Mackenzie King.

The Utica Club Curlers gained the final of the Gordon Grand National Medal tournament today, along with a Schenectady rink skipped by Charles L. Hequembourg. Utica, defending the medal, had Dan Burke as skip.

The New York City Chapter of the newly organized National Lawyers Guild adopted resolutions last night approving President Roosevelt's proposed changes in the membership of the Supreme Court and also urging three revolutionary constitutional amendments.

Ninety-four Columbia College students will receive either gold or silver crowns for outstanding achievement in extra-curricular activities, Benjamin A. Hubbard, director of King's Crown, the supervising body of activities at Columbia, announced yesterday.
Three methods of reducing milk delivery costs in New York City were outlined to visitors today as Cornell University opened its thirtieth

After nearly three hours of discussion, the New York Young Republican Club adopted last night resolutions opposing President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the United States Supreme Court and urging the Assembly to vote to ratify the proposed Child Labor Amendment.

Disability and death benefits of $1,171,661 were paid last year to employes of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and their dependents, according to the report of the trustees of the Bethlehem Relief Plan at their annual meeting in Bethlehem, Pa., yesterday.

For a long time now Mr. DEWEY had been exploring the ways and works of racketeers in this city. Appointed special counsel by the Governor, he has had the aid of skilled assistants. He knew from the first that it would be a long quest. Two or three years was the time he spoke of as necessary to pursue the matter to the end.

Night baseball will not be played by the Cardinals and Browns at home this year. Engineers said installation of a lighting system could not be completed before the season opened in April and the club owners did not desire construction work in progress during the playing of games. Sam Breadon.

Colonel Herbert H. Spender-Clay, Conservative Member of Parliament for the Tonbridge Division of Kent for the last twenty-six years, died at his home in London today after a twoweek illness of influenza.

John L. Liggett of Detroit died in a hospital today after a week's illness. He was 67 years old. Mr. Liggett, one of the founders of the General Baking Company in the Middle West, established his first bakery forty years ago in Canton, Ohio. He retired in 1927.

A House bloc of thirty members attacked tonight the Pettengill bill, which would repeal the long-andshort-haul clause of the Interstate Commerce Act. This clause forbids the charging of lower rates for a long haul than for a shorter one on the same route in the same direction.

Governor Lehman signed today the Social Security Bill which, in its amended form, was passed by the Senate and Assembly last week. He pointed out in a memorandum that enactment of the law rounds out an eight-point social security program he submitted to the Legislature last year.

The Legislature adjourned tonight until a week from Wednesday after members of the Democratic minority in the Senate joined with Republicans in confirming Governor Hoffman's nomination of Police Judge Andrew J. Duch of Trenton to be Mercer County prosecutor.
The stock market here was generally firm and more hopeful today as the new account opened. Gilt-edge issues continued weak, but foreign bonds mostly were at higher levels.

Ellery Sedgwick Jr., 28 years old, whose automobile crashed into a safety stanchion early yesterday morning, remained in a serious condition at Charity Hospital here tonight. The son of the editor of The Atlantic Monthly, who is an analyst at the Central National Bank, has a skull injury, a fracture of the left knee and deep lacerations of the jaw.

A research chemistry student of the University of Rochester cast goldfish for the "guinea pig" role today in his search for a soluble form of novocaine that would retain its present pain-deadening qualities.

Battle-scarred Marcel Thil of France retained his equally battle-scarred claim to the world middleweight championship tonight by turning back the third challenge of Lou Brouillard of Worcester, Mass., in a bout that almost duplicated their second meeting a year ago.

Francis H. Norris, a member of the Stock Exchange firm of Munn Norris, 30- Broad Street, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his office. He was 42 years old and lived at 111 Willowbrook Road, Staten Island.

Employment increased 10 per cent and payrolls 27 per cent in the wool textile industry during December, bringing both indices to a point above those for 1929, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers reported here yesterday.

Members of the faculties of Columbia University, New York University and Smith College sent cable messages of protest yesterday to General Miguel Cabanellas, presiding officer of the Burgos Junta, urging him to revoke the death sentence imposed upon Dr. Leopold Alas, president of Oviedo University, for Loyalist sympathies.
General business activity is nearly 20 per cent above levels of a year ago, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, said today in his monthly business bulletin.

To celebrate the conclusion of the pact between Japan and Germany the silk association of the town of Chichibu, northwest of Tokyo, today presented to Chancellor Adolf Hitler a set of Japanese clothes.

A drop of 8.9 per cent last year in major crimes as compared with 1935 was reported tonight after a statistical survey made by the State Department of Correction. The number of such crimes reported last year was 41,646: in 1935 the number was 45,717.

The navy got its beans, 1,030,000 pounds of them, but the Rochester shippers will have to pay the regular tariff for shipping them from New York to California, Supreme Court Justice John C. Wheeler ruled today.

Dr. Duncan Eve Sr., prominent Nashville surgeon, died today after a long illness. His age was 84. Dr. Eve served as Professor of Surgery at both the University of Tennessee and Vanderbilt University, later becoming connected with the Louisville Nashville Railroad and the N. C. St. L. Railway.

Leon Trotsky offered to THE NEW YORK TIMES last night his proof that he did not meet Vladimir Romm, Russian journalist, in Paris in July, 1933. According to testimony at the recent sensational trial of conspirators in Moscow, Romm was the go-between who carried letters to Mr. Trotsky from the plotters in Soviet Russia.
The twelve-story Hotel Colonial at 441-49 Columbus Avenue was bid in at auction yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the plaintiff, for $375,000.

The sale in Kansas of any beverage containing any alcohol would be prohibited under a bill passed today by the State House of Representatives, 84 to 37. The bill makes illegal "all beverages which contain any per cent or fraction of a per cent of alcohol by weight or volume."
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh arrived in Cairo late this afternoon, flying their private plane on a leisurely trip from England.

The House Appropriations Committee reported today a record Treasury and Postoffice Appropriations Bill, carrying $1,500,955,151. Of this, $718,485,790 is for the Treasury and $782,469,361 for the Postoffice Department for the fiscal year 1938.

Offering will be made today by Newkirk Co., Inc., of 6,000 shares of $1 par capital stock of Lessings, Inc., operator of ten restaurants in the downtown district of this city. The price will be $4 a share. The shares have been bought privately by the bankers and the offering does not represent new financing.

Despite a pair of 6s and an erratic 8,'Mrs. Leon Solomon of Memphis. former Southern champion, led the field in the qualifying round of the women's Palm Beach golf championship today with 39, 39-78. Second, only two shots behind, was Miss Patty Berg, 18-year-old Minneapolis girl, who came in with 42, 38-80 after a poor start.

A new type of fog-horn, which offers possibilities for clearing fogs over airports and over the ocean by literally screaming them out of existence with intense sound-waves, was demonstrated yesterday before the annual Winter meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

The report of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois and its subsidiaries for 1936 shows a consolidated net income of $3,739,330 after depreciation, interest, Federal income tax and payment of $212,900 surtax on' undistributed profits.

Ralph T. Crane, vice president of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and former president of the Investment Bankers Association of America and the Bond Club of New York, will address the Bond Club of New Jersey at a luncheon meeting on Feb. 24 at the Newark Athletic Club.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed registrar for 500,000 shares of $1-par common stock of Allen Industries, Inc. The bank is also registrar for 40,000 shares of $1.50 cumulative convertible $20-par preferred stock and 700,000 shares of $1-par common stock of the Eason Oil Company.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced tonight that the tenders for approximately $50,000,000 of 273-day Treasury bills, dated Feb. 17 and maturing on Nov. 17, 1937, which were offered on Feb. 11, amounted to $154,486,000, of which $50,027,000 was accepted.

Mrs. Mary Woodsmall Watkins, former school teacher and writer, who went to Europe on the Ford Peace Ship, died of a stroke on Sunday at her home, 3,223 Netherland Avenue, the Bronx. She was 75 years old.

ABERT-Benjamin, at his residence, 40 East 83d St., beloved brother of Annie Cohen, Florence Mendel and Isaac Abert. Body reposing at Park West Chapel, 115 West 79th St. Funeral notice later. Kindly omit flowers.

Mrs. Frank Dwyer, returning from church yesterday, found her house ransacked and awakened her sleeping husband, Policeman Frank Dwyer. After a joint check-up they listed as missing two purses, a $23 wrist watch and the policeman's blackjack.

Governor Lehman sent to the Legislature at its session tonight a report he had received from a commission appointed by him to study the educational problems of penal institutions for youths. The commission,

Joseph J. O'Brien, former patent attorney, who lost his license in 1927 but continued to solicit business from inventors, advertising in newspapers and periodicals, received a prison sentence of two years yesterday from Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe following his conviction on a six-count mail-fraud indictment.

The Kings County Criminal Bar Association, meeting last night at 482 Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, approved the proposed retirement age of 70 years for United States Supreme Court justices but opposed the recommendation of President Roosevelt that the number of justices be increased from nine to fifteen.

Labor espionage has been "wiped out" at the General Motors Corporation plants as a result of the investigation by the La Follette Senate subcommittee, Harry W. Anderson, labor relations director for the corporation, indicated at the hearing today.

More than 3,000 boys and girls from all parts of the United States will begin a three-day "Pilgrimage of Youth" in Washington on Friday, William W. Hinckley, chairman of the American Youth Congress, with national offices at 55 West Forty-second Street, announced yesterday.
Mrs. Nan du Page gave a dinner last night in the Iridium- Room of the St. Regis for Miss Sara Jane Phillips and Frank Begrisch Jr., who will be married on Thursday at the Ambassador.

Two Watermill couples will jointly observe tomorrow the golden anniversary of their double wedding, held fifty years ago here at the home of the late Mr. and Mrs. Luther D. Burnett, parents of the brides, who were Rose M. and Elsie S. Burnett.

Jules de Kahma-Kauffman, selfstyled Russian baron who has mingled freely with society in this city, was sentenced to from three to six years in Sing Sing yesterday on a guilty plea to a fraud charge growing out of the proposed operation of a vast scheme for the promotion of foreign trade.

Spurred by the 5-4 beating they gave the Rangers on Sunday night, the New York Americans will take to the ice at Madison Square Garden tonight in a determined bid to down the Canadiens, leaders of the International Group, in a National Hockey League match.

The international officers of the United Mine Workers of America were empowered today to take steps to expel from that union William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and since 1890 a member of the coal diggers' organization.
Offering will be made today by Riter Co. of $500,000 of 4 1/4 per cent convertible debentures due in 1947, and 65,000 shares of common stock of $5 par value of the Tokheim Oil Tank and Pump Company.

Prince Erik of Denmark and his wealthy Canadian-born wife were legally separated today by King Christian's order. Divorce proceedings, begun more than two years ago, culminated in an annulment by the monarch, a first cousin of the Prince.

Both the Tri-County Hockey League games at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night resulted in ties, the Astoria Americans and the Baldwin Hockey Club battling to a 1-1 deadlock in one contest and the New York State Insurance Hockey Club and the Crown Heights Hockey Club playing a scoreless draw in the other.
The Treasury plans to establish a silver depository similar to the one created for the nation's huge gold supply at Fort Knox, Ky.

Don A. Davis, chairman of the board of the Western Auto Supply Company, on Jan. 7 controlled 70.44 per cent of the voting power of that company, according to data of the Security and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
Aides of Pope Pius, thankful for the restored use of his legs, said tonight they expected he would perform the blessing of the Golden Rose, on March 7, one of the most beautiful papal ceremonies.
ON HIS OWN APPLICATION PATROLMAN Hugo Mayer, 25th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 11, 1911.

Lindsay H. Crawford, president of Wilson Brothers, has resigned, effective March 1, and will return to his former work as an industrial management and merchandising counsel. He will become associated with S. D. Leidesdorf Co., making his headquarters in the Chicago office of the company at 1 North La Salle Street.

Circuit Court Judge Thomas Brown signed today a rule to show cause on March 12 why the $298,684 writ of attachment served on banks in Hudson County as agents of four corporations should not be quashed.
Optimistic predictions for Pittsburgh real estate, based on a survey of the business prospects of that city, were made yesterday by Eli T. Watson Co., Inc., investment bankers of New York.
A resolution urging Congress to reject President Roosevelt's court reform measure was adopted by the Boston Bar Association in a special meeting today.

A class of thirty-three students will be graduated Wednesday from the Advanced Flying School of the Army at Kelly Field, Texas. It includes three officers from other branches of the military service and thirty flying cadets. They will be assigned to Air Corps Tactical units for active duty.
The Rev. Dr. Robert Healy Pitt, editor of The Religious Herald and for more than half a century a leader in the Baptist ministry in Virginia, died today at his home here. He was 83 years old.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Saturday at Lausanne, Switzerland, of Julia Elizabeth Delafield, widow of Maturin Livingston Delafield, former resident of New York. She was a daughter of Admiral Count- Daniel de Pernay of the French Navy.
C. Herbert Davison of Princeton, N. J., today announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaret S. Davison, to John Paul Chubet 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. A. Chubet of Boston.

The American boat Jack Rabbit, skippered by Paul Shields of Peconio Bay, won the first race of the eleventh International Star Class series for the Cup of Cuba this morning with a time of 2:16:08. Nutmeg, sailed by Paul Smart of the Central Long Island Sound fleet, captured the second contest this afternoon with a time of 1:33:12.

The economic progress made by Panama last year is reflected by increased imports compared with 1935, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from the American commercial attache in Panama City.

SUGAR, by John E. Dalton. (Macmillan, $3.) A.case study in government control. SILVER STAMPEDE: THE CARDER OF DEATH VALLTY'S HELL-CAMP, OLD PANAMINT, by Neill C. Wilson. (Macmillan, $3.) Early days in a mining settlement.

Copper Tube, an inconsistent plater from Mrs. M. Eckman's Stable, came through with one of his infrequent victories today when he took the measure of six rivals in a mileand-a-sixteenth race at the Fair Grounds.

Andre de Laboulaye, retiring French Ambassador, and Mrs. de Laboulaye with members of their family are expected to arrive today at the Pierre, where they will be I until they sail for Paris Saturday on the Ile de France.

Two men were killed and a third was overcome yesterday morning by fumes which spread through a twenty-family tenement at 69 Norfolk Street, between Grand and Broome Streets, following a fire in the cellar which had been put out with little trouble. .

Dr. Henry Merritt Wriston, new president of Brown University, declared last night at the sixty-ninth annual New York alumni dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt that the demands of education are changing and predicted that they would change even more in the next twenty years. Warning them never to turn their backs on change, he said.
Information available today regarding developments in Spain and in diplomatic quarters here seems to indicate a speedier end to the Spanish conflict than was envisaged a few days ago.
The sale of 41,400 shares of its common stock at an indicated profit of more than $1,000,000 was disclosed by the Lima Locomotive Works in a report which it issued yesterday on operations in 1936.
Captain Thor Eckert, vice president and general manager of the Arnold Bernstein and Red Star Lines, sailed for Europe Sunday on the liner Hansa, it was announced yesterday.

Traffic accidents, fatalities and the number of persons injured rose sharply last week and over the week-end, official tabulations by the Police Department showed yesterday. Compared with the figures for the corresponding week of 1935 the deaths in traffic increased 333 per cent.

Senator Royal S. Copeland removed himself from the Mayoralty situation yesterday by saying in Washington that he was not interested in the nomination for that office. There has been considerable talk of the possibility of his becoming a candidate, which would have been welcomed in Tammany but never obtained the approval of Postmaster General James A. Farley, Frank V. Kelly, Brooklyn leader;
Automobile production increased slightly last week, but less than seasonally, and the adjusted index declined to 79.4 from 80.8. It was 87.5 for the week ended Feb. 15, 1936.
Mrs. Roosevelt is hearing from the women of the country on the Presldent's proposed court reform, and her mail, she said today, reflects the national division of opinion on the new judiciary program.

The Communist Hammer and Sickle, clearly drawn in smoke against a clear blue sky, floated over Vienna for more than a half-hour this morning. Unsuccessful pursuit of the mysterious plane by six Austrian military planes followed.

Firing a variety bf bewildering angle shots, Germain G. Glidden, 23-year-old national squash racquets champion, easily vanquished Murray Vernon of the Downtown A. C. in the only match played in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class A tournament yesterday on the courts of the Universitv Club.
In the Supreme Court of the United States, John F. X. Sheridan and Max Rothenberg of New York were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

The most important assembly that statesmen of this capital have witnessed since the signing of the Balkan Pact, in February, 1934, occurred today when members of the permanent council of the Balkan Entente met to discuss problems affecting the four nations.
Monetary officials of the government considered today the possibility of levying a tax to retard a swift, sustained inflow of foreign capital.

BERLINER, FERIST (July 12, 1933). Gross assets, $34,455; net, $16,947. To Hattie Berliner, sister-in-law, life estate in $10,000; Jacob S., and Irwin M. Berliner, nephews, one-half residue each; Birdie B. Kessler, niece, succeeding estate in $10,000; six specific and twelve contingent bequests. Chief assets, real estate, $18,000.

Democratic leaders in both Houses of Congress intensified their search today for a compromise on President Roosevelt's judicial reform program as the unyielding attitude of the President and the evidence of strong opposition gave warning of the possibility of one of the most spectacular legislative battles of recent years.

The American Service Company of Illinois has filed a declaration with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Act in relation to its organization as a subsidiary service company for the holding company system, the American Utilities Service Corporation.

Franklin A. Banker died today at the age of 57. Mr. Banker, who had lived here for thirty-five years, had been associated for twentyseven years with Maher Brothers Corporation, coal and lumber dealers.

The University of Montreal's fleet French squad withstood a desperate thirdperiod rally by Dartmouth at the Forum tonight in an International Intercollegiate Hockey League fixture to score a hard-earned 6-4 victory and gain a third-place tie with Toronto in the standings.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, took under advisement yesterday a proposal to restrict homework in the men's neckwear industry. The proposal was made at a public hearing in the State Office Building, at which Miss Frieda S. Miller, director of the division of women in industry and minimum wage, Department of Labor, said an investigation disclosed cuts in piece-work rates and earnings.
The New Jersey Press Association at its midwinter dinner meeting here tonight announced the award to Mortimer Cornin of Jersey City of its annual scholarship.
A serious crisis between King Carol and the government occurred tonight which resulted in Premier George Tatarescu's tendering his resignation, although this is not admitted.

Jack Doyle, the Irish heavyweight who recently made North American tour, trounced Harry Stall, champion of the Netherlands, in a boxing contest at Earls Court tonight. Staal's seconds threw a towel into the ring during the sixth round.

Mrs. J. Hunter Barton of Philadelphia and Miami Beach entertained at the Surf Club today at one in the series of luncheons for Mrs. William P. Allen, Mrs. Seavey Battelle, Mrs. George W. Berger, Mrs. E. G. Biechler, Mrs. Louise Barlow Heikes, Mrs. Nelson R.

After having remained in the same ownerships for two generations, two Manhattan properties have just passed into new hands. The Bowery landmark at 264 Bowery, near Houston Street, a four-story business building on a plot 17 by 100 feet, has been sold by the Friedlander estate,

John Wallace Maxwell, who was an Indian scout under "Buffalo Bill" Cody and was in the regular army during the later Indian uprisings, died today at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. His age was 77. Mr.

Mrs. Sidney C. Borg gave a reception yesterday afternoon in the Adam Room of the Chatham for members of the Cooperative Committee of the Big Sisters, which is aiding the campaign for funds to further the work of the organization for under-privileged girls. Mrs.

Nearly 40,000 General Motors employes in Detroit, 30,000 in Flint and another 30,000 in other plants throughout the country returned to their jobs on assembly lines and benches today as production of automobiles was resumed following settlement of the long strike.

Twelve properties were sold at auction in foreclosure proceedings in the Bronx yesterday. Results were as follows: By GEORGE J. KEARNS Home St., 880, 2-story dwelling, 16x74, irregular, and rear lot, 24x14, irregular; Newburgh Savings Bank against Elsie M. Maynes: due, $2,8351 taxes, , $688: to plaintiff for $2,000.

Amos Northrup, 48, credited with originating the modern streamlined styling of automobiles, died in a hospital here today of injuries suffered Sunday when he fell on the ice. Mr. Northrup, born in Bellevue, Ohio, was said by automotive styling engineers to have been the leader in his field.

The sale of a substantial portion of the controlling interest in the Kansas City Southern Railway held by Paine, Webber Co., brokers for the Van Sweringen interests, to Harvey Couch, chairman of the Louisiana Arkansas Railway, was disclosed in Wall Street yesterday.

Assembly Democrats tonight blocked passage of the Brownell bill, which would authorize New York City to issue $15,000,000 in serial bonds to finance the construction of a new Criminal Courts building on the present site.

Valentine A. Ely led the eight seeded players into the third round yesterday as the Union League Club's invitation Class B squash racquets tournament got fully under way with the completion of the second round.

The Judiciary Committee of the Tennessee House of Representatives did a good day's work when it pigeonholed an extraordinary bill approved by the State Senate a fortnight ago. This bill proposed to fine, and to expel permanently from the ranks of Tennessee journalism, editors and publishers who permitted the publication in their editorial columns of "any untruth of any kind or character" about any person.

Three hundred representatives of taxpayers' organizations throughout the city, meeting at the Hotel Commodore last night, joined in a demand for "direct action" to force the city administration to reduce at once the emergency 10 per cent penalty on real estate tax arrears and to repeal the emergency 50 per cent increase in water rates.

Operations of the steel industry this week, according to the estimate of the American Iron and Steel Institute, are at the rate of 81.6 per cent of capacity, the highest since the institute began reporting weekly operating rates in 1933.

J. Howard Shoemaker, nineteen times champion, shot his way back into a contending position in the national amateur pocket billiard tourney at the Capitol Health Center last night by scoring a decisive victory over Arthur Cranfield of Syracuse, youngest player of the group.

Announced in a special insertion in the McBride Spring catalogue is a murder story in which the victim is a WPA administrator. The title is "Murder in the WPA" and Alexander Williams is the author. The setting is a WPA office of a large city, where 250,000 men and women are facing a cut in the relief rolls.
A colorful, parade headed by horsemen from the United States, Cuba, Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador and Chile officially opened the International Horse Show in El Tranque Stadium today.

The Westchester County Board of Supervisors approved today three non-partisan bills which would have the State take over maintenance of the county's four major parkways and provide $1,425,000 of State funds for the construction of two cross-county parkway connections made necessary by the recent opening of the Hendrick Hudson Parkway in New York.

Stockholders of the Pierce Petroleum Corporation approved yesterday a reduction in company's stated capital to $625,000 from $19, 134,519 as another step in the distribution of its assets, consisting mainly of 637,334 shares of common stock of the Consolidated Oil Corporation.

At a moment when Geneva reports the impending appointment of Professor Charles Burckhardt of Switzerland as the League of Nations High Commissioner for Danzig, the German press is up in arms about what it calls "a new French lie campaign" charging Germany with the intention of annexing Danzig through a coup d'etat.

Paroles were granted today to Henry H. Henley and Wilbur B. Foshay of Minneapolis, who are serving fifteen-year sentences in Leavenworth penitentiary for using the mails to dispose of worthless securities. The paroles are effective May 6.
Dr. William Hirsch, retired psychiatrist and neurologist, died on Sunday at his home, 150 Riverside Drive, after a brief illness, in his seventy ninth year.

One hundred and forty-seventh meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers begins, at 29 West Thirty-ninth Street. and continues through Friday. Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eighty-Second Street and Fifth Avenue. "Oriental Art: The Far East,"

New York City Traffic Courts had the busiest day in their history yesterday, with more than 6,300 violators appearing in response to summonses. The Lincoln's Birthday holiday, followed by a week-end in which no court was held, accounted for the congestion, according to Frederick W. Wright, clerk of the Bronx court.
Tai Shuang-chiu, college professor here who divorced two wives -because they would not wear cotton dresses, has found the girl of his dreams.

Miss Barbara Richards, youngest daughter of Mrs. Frederick Beckman and Frederick L. Richards of New York, was married to Clifford William Michel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence W. Michel of Bellrose, L. I., this afternoon in the Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea.

Angling isn't permitted in tne streams meandering through the Miami Biltmore golf course-but the playful mullet won't feel safe there hereafter. James Sinclair of the Knollwood Country Club, New York, halftopped a shot on the seventh hole.

Justice McReynolds, most frequent dissenter of the Supreme Court, appeared in that role again today when, opposing his eight associates in the only written opinion handed down, he asserted that taxation must be based upon realities and not upon imaginary assets.

THE Giants will leave for Havana tomorrow, but the advance guard, consisting of Senor Secretario Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick, will be off by noon today with his duffle bag slung over his shoulder and a Spanish grammar in his pocket. When Senor Secretario is off, it may be said that the season is on.

The Electoral College today chose Premier Kyosti Kallio of the Agrarian party as President of the Finnish republic for six years, in succession to President Pehr Evind Svinhufvud, Conservative, who was defeated on the second ballot.
Topping off a double-header which attracted more than 6,000 tonight, Notre Dame's basketball team scored a 40-36 victory over Canisius College.
A hundred eventful years were commemorated at Knox College today, when alumni from all parts of the country joined in celebrating Founder's Day.
The Columbia University Symphonic Band Harwood Simmons conductor, will present a program at the McMillin Academic Theatre tonight, with Lester Salomon and David Weber as horn and clarinet soloists.

Hans Kohn of the Smith College faculty does not altogether despair of the future. He ees Force and Unreason threatening to become dominant and the unexpected fruit of a century's imperialism about co mature.

Domestic stocks of refined copper, excluding consumers' stocks at their plans or warehouses, on Jan. 31 were 142,374 tons, compared to 161,068 on Dec. 31, a decrease of 18,694 tons, according to the Copper Institute.

Mrs. Frank P. Coltiletti's 4-year-old gelding Sandy Boot, saddled by her husband, survived a hard drive to win the featured Hollywood Claiming Handicap as another week of racing opened at Hialeah Park today.

John Trent, the former transport pilot whom Paramount is converting into a movie star, will make his debut today at the Rialto in "A Doctor's Diary." In support are George Bancroft, Helen Burgess, Sidney Blackmer, Molly Lamont and Ruth Coleman.

Although suffering from a broken collar bone and a shaking-up received in an automobile accident last week-end, Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink returned to the bench yesterday to conduct his court as usual.

A reported criminal attack upon a naval lieutenant's wife sent the police hunting tonight for an unidentified white man who dropped an initialed handkerchief in the garage where she said she was assaulted. A doctor who examined slight 24-year-old Mrs. Bennett S. Copping said he could not testify she had been attacked.

Fifteen Negro families were driven from their homes yesterday afternoon when a smoky but trifling fire spread through four tenement houses on Seventh Avenue between 127th and 128th Streets, twenty pieces of fire apparatus and a large reserve of police responded to the alarm. A second alarm brought Mayor La Guardia to the scene.

Howard P. Allen of 1,670 East Fifty-third Street, Brooklyn, and eight other citizen soldiers will receive from Secretary Woodring on Thursday John J. Pershing Gold Medals for Distinguished Attainment in Military Education, as the leading trainees of the Citizens Military Training Camps of 1936.

The Census Bureau reported today that domestic consumption of 678,064 bales of cotton in January set an all-time record for the month. The previous high was 668,286 bales in January, 1929. The new January peak was slightly smaller than the previous month.

Transatlantic air mail on regular schedule appeared to be a step nearer today with the reporting in the House of an item of $750,000 in the Postoffice Appropriation Bill to be set aside for an ocean mail contract.

National lumber stocks on Jan. 1 totaled 7,400,000,000 feet or 2 per cent over those a year ago, the special lumber survey committee of the United States Department of Commerce pointed out yesterday in its quarterly report on lumber consumption, stocks and anticipated consumption.
Charles H. Bond Jr., assistant selling agent of the Ludlow Sales Manufacturing Company of New York, died suddenly on the steamship Oriente on Thursday, while on a vacation trip to Cuba with his wife.

There was little change in the character of the bond market yesterday from last week, except that the convertible and secondary corporate loans drifted with the higher grade investments to lower levels. The trend, over a broad front, was definitely lower,

Five men were chosen from a special panel of twenty-five yesterday for the trial of six men indicted for manslaughter in the second degree in the collapse of the apartment building at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, in which eighteen men were killed last June 19. Seven more jurors and two alternates are to be picked before Judge Lester W. Patterson in the Bronx County Court.

Employment applications for participation in the Federal old-age benefits program under the Social Security Act now total 23,647,461, of which 3,564,652 were received from New York State, including an estimated total of 1,941,800 from New York City, the Social Security Board announced today.

The Federal Reserve Board sent to the Senate today a long statement, accompanied by charts, in which it set forth the reasons for its recent order increasing the reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System the full 100 per cent permitted by law.
Mr. ROOSEVELT thinks the members of the Supreme Court are too old. Just the same, the President might not like it if the

Apparently prompted by "A. S. R.'s" regret that the President is not surrounded by practical men experienced in active life, a situation which he concedes would be helpful to the administration, Herbert C. Pell laments in his letter to THE TIMES that "such men usually refuse to cooperate in any attempted reform * * * if the proposed
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Feb. 12:

Dust storms, ranging from a "black blizzard" here to a red-brown haze in North Texas, whipped over parts of four Southwestern States tonight. The storms spread in the old "dust bowl" sectors of Colorado, Texas and Oklahoma and in Northwest Kansas.
Restoration of full pay to all city employes on July 1 was voted unanimously yesterday by the Board of Estimate at a special meeting in Mayor La Guardia's office in City Hall.

A total of $6,100 contributed over the week-end, raised the amount raised by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross for flood relief to $1,878,477.24, General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the chapter, announced last night. The chapter's quota was $1,500,000, which was exceeded several days ago.
Groaning, booming and thundering on a rough thirty-mile mountain moraine bed, Black Rapids glacier presents one of the most spectacular sights of modern times by its sudden "rebirth."

Vincenzo Lancia, one of Italy's leading automobile manufacturers, died suddenly today. He was 56 years old. Mr. Lancia built up a large organization after starting his business with a small amount of capital.

Two men were shot, one of them fatally, by a hold-up man who Invaded the West Eleventh Street Association Club at 2,380 Eightieth Street, at the corner of Stillwell Avenue,. Brooklyn, shortly before .10:30 o'clock last night. The robber, after opening fire when one of the victims resisted him, escaped with loot of $10.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 13: COLONELS Tefft, W. H., Med. Corps, one month and 18 days' leave, Feb. 13.

MANHATTAN DOUGLAS, MARIA LOUISE (July 25). Estate, less than $10,000. To Marjorie Jane Douglas, daughter, executrix, 25 Prospect Pl. HARTELL, JOHN (Feb. 9). Estate, $3,500. To Madeline D. Hartell, widow, executrix, 155 E. 3d St.. residue.
City Treasurer Dorsey of Boston, Mass., will receive tenders at noon tomorrow for a temporary loan of $7,000,000. The notes will be dated Feb. 26 and will become payable on Nov. 3 next.
Major Gen. Sir Frederick O. W. Loomis, who commanded the Third Division, Canadian Corps, at the capture of Mons in 1918, died tonight at his home here at the age of 67.

William J. Lauck of Washington, an economist, will head the commission which is to investigate the bootleg coal situation in Pennsylvania's lower anthracite fields and recommend a solution of the problems to the present Legislature.

Colonel George A. Lynch, commander of the Fifteenth Infantry at Tientsin, China, and during NRA days an assistant to General Hugh Johnson, was appointed by President Roosevelt today as chief of infantry in the War Department with the temporary rank of major general.

Asserting that department stores today represent the highest degree of merchandizing technique, A. E. Allen, vice president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, said yesterday that such stores have become one of the major factors in the distribution of electrical merchandise.

The Regional Plan Association announced yesterday that it had protested to Secretary of War Woodring against the proposed construction of a bridge across the Hudson River near West Fifty-seventh Street.

Former Mayor Gaitan's order requiring chauffeurs to wear uniforms has resulted in a vacancy in the Cabinet, as Finance Minister Gonzalo Restrepo has resigned to accept appointment as Mayor of this city.

Offering will be made today by Alison Co., Detroit, of 150,000 shares of $1-par common stock of the Simplicity Pattern Company, Inc. The price will be $8 a share. Of the 150,000 shares, 100,000 will be marketed for the account of the company and 50,000 issued and outstanding shares are to be offered for the account of Joseph M. Shapiro. sole stockholder.

The Department of Parks has decided to padlock playgrounds throughout the city at night, it was disclosed yesterday. Park Commissioner Robert Moses explained the need for padlocks after park defenders had looked askance at the first of the iron picket fences that will enclose eighteen playgrounds around the edges of Central Park.

More than fifty socially prominent women of New York, Boston and Philadelphia attended a dinner given at the Weylin last night by the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association in honor of the visiting English women's team, and members of the national association.

The All-Purpose Gold Corporation, manufacturer of imitation gold and colors, for several years a tenant in the building at 107-111 Myrtle Avenue, through to Bridge and Lawrence Streets, Brooklyn, has bought the property from the Wilcox family.
Paul Mellon's Drinmore Lad ruled a second choice in today's betting for the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree March 19.

Football, so far as the rules of play are concerned, will remain very much the same this year-as it has been during the past. This became certain yesterday with the announcement here by William S. Langford, secretary of the rules committee, of the results of that body's meeting, held over the weekend in Absecon, N. J.

The Crucible Steel Company of America reports a net profit of $3,120,356 for 1936, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.49 a share on 550,000 common shares, compared to $1,268,176, or $5.07 a share earned on 250,000 preferred shares, in 1935. Net income was the largest reported since 1930, deficits having been recorded from 1931 to 1933 inclusive.

175th St. (11-2899), s. s., 54 ft. e. of Webster Av., 26x75; 406 Realty Corp. to Dollar Savings Bank; due as per bond; $9,500. Whitlock Av., 316 to 336 (10-2599); Wamkill Realty Corp. to Seamen's Savings Bank; extends mtgs. to Dec. 27, 1946, at 4 to 4 1/2 per cent; $300,000.

President Roosevelt led a chorus of acclaim of Postmaster General Farley at a testimonial dinner given tonight in recognition of the Democratic victory of November. Some 1,700 Democratic chieftains cheered the President's praise of Mr. Farley.

Thomas James Thompson, former director and Chicago general sales manager of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, died today at his home here after a brief illness. He was 73 years old. Mr. Thompson is survived by four children.
