A new offer to renew its truce agreement with the Tennessee Valley Authority has been made by the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, through its president, Wendell L. Willkie, is was understood today.
Robert Nilson, 28 years old, of 527 Center Place, Teaneck, drove his brother's automobile off the Anderson Street bridge into the Hackensack River at Teaneck yesterday.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, inspected today the School of Tropical Medicine, which Columbia with the University of Puerto Rico has maintained here for the last ten years.

Professor Charles Seymour, president-elect of Yale University, will leave with Mrs. Seymour this week for a European trip. He plans to spend some time completing historical investigations in which he has been engaged.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced today that C. B. Henderson and Emil Schram, members of the board of directors, had been appointed joint managers of the Disaster Loan Corporation and that it was hoped to be in a position to begin making flood loans within a week or ten days.

Prices of wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner on the Board of Trade here today, declining about 1 cent a bushel early, but the new crop months were affected later by reports of dust storms in the West and Southwest and rallied to close 1/4, cent a bushel higher while the May, which within a fraction of the bottom with a loss of 7/8 cent.

The share market could muster little enthusiasm yesterday except in the case of a few stocks which advanced for special reasons. Whether or not foreign selling cut much figure in proceedings, can only be conjectured. At any rate,

Fred Grubmeier, 205, Germany, threw George Decker, 195, New York, in the feature match at the New York Coliseum last night before 1,500 spectators. The German wrestler scored in 27:33 with a body scissors.

Playing to a capacity gallery of 16,221 persons, many of whom were countrymen from her native Norway, Miss Sonja Henie last night made her only New York appearance of the season at Madison Square Garden.

Marshall S. Morgan, former assistant to William P. Gest, chairman of the board of the Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company, was elected president of the company today, succeeding Henry G. Brengle, who was retired on pension. Mr. Morgan recently was elected to the directorate.

The city's accumulated deficits under the dual subway contracts with the Interborough and the B. M. T. totaled nearly $340,000,000 as of June 30, 1936, the Transit Commission revealed yesterday in making public its annual report to the Legislature.
The Committee for Industrial Organization was warned today by Governor Hoffman that New Jersey would not tolerate "the lawless methods and practices" used in Michigan and Indiana.

F. Barry Ryan of Short Hills. seeded first, led the way into the semi-finals of the Whitehall Club squash tennis tournament yesterday by defeating William J. Hall of the Crescent A. C., 11-15, 15-3, 15-8.

King George's town house at 145 Piccadilly--the "palace with a number"--is a royal home no more. Tonight the King and Queen took up residence in Buckingham Palace and a condition unique in Britain's history is ended.

Members of Congress who have been talking over the President's Supreme Court plan with him at the White House have come away persuaded that tactically he holds some very strong cards against the time when he decides to play them.

Anglo-German naval conversations have made such progress in the past few days that a bilateral "qualitative" agreement is now being drafted on the lines of the Lbndon Naval Treaty of 1936 between the United states, France and the British Empire.
Loyalist Madrid is fighting for its existence today as it has not fought since General Francisco Franco's forces first reached the gates of the capital Nov. 7.

American exporters with funds tied up in Spain have dropped negotiations to free the money for the time being and will await the outcome of the civil war there before any definite moves toward liberating the money are made, according to information obtained here yesterday.
A flying "eye" to see what the sky looks like twenty miles up has been developed at the University of Rochester Institute of Optics. It is sent far into the stratosphere attached to a balloon.

The six-story elevator apartment house at 145 Audubon Avenue, covering a plot 100 by 100 and containing 200 rooms laid out in suites of two, three and four, has been sold to a client of William L. Rosen, attorney.

The committee of seventy-nine recently elected to represent the employes of the city's Independent Subway System in collective bargaining with the Board of Transportation adopted last night the five-point program proposed for improving wages and working conditions.

Creditors and other claimants against the estate of the National Surety Company, now in liquidation, have been notified that application for approval of an agreement allowing certain claims has been scheduled for hearing before Justice Levy of the New York Supreme Court on March 15.

After announcing their possession of a confession from Harry Simmons, a 26-year-old Newark ex-convict, the police here today charged Simmons and a companion, Albert Faria, 29, another Newark ex-convict, with the murder of Thomas Ennis, an East Orange patrolman. He was shot yesterday following the hold-up of the Hi-Hat Restaurant, at 517 Main Street here.

Substantial subscriptions by three railroads place transportation companies in the lead among trades and industries in the purchase of New York Fair 4 per cent financing debentures, it was announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, chairman of the exposition's bond sales committee.

An offering of $4,650,000 of Great Northern Railway series E 2 per cent equipment trust certificates, maturing annually from March 1, 1938, to March 1, 1947, inclusive, will be made today by Evans, Stillman Co., Clark, Dodge Co. and Harris, Hall Co., Inc.
Emile Allais is the new world's all-around ski master and France's idol. His rise this year in skiing has been as spectacular as it was some years ago in tennis.
A demand for store and groundfloor space was indicated in commercial rentals yesterday. A number of leases were made on Fifth and Sixth Avenues and Broadway. The list follows:
Studebaker's contribution to the progress of the nation's automotive industry was acclaimed today at a civic luncheon here, held in observance of the company's eightyfifth anniversary. Alfred Reeves,

Mrs. Margaret Maher-Howell, first woman to cross the Ohio River on a bridge here, died at her home today at the age of 84. Her father, John Molloy, was superintendent of construction of the suspension bridge, the first bridge over the Ohio at Cincinnati.

Thomas C. Slattery, former United States District Attorney for the Eastern District of Kentucky and County Attorney of Mason County, Ky., died at Good Samaritan Hospital at Lexington today after a day's illness. He was 61 years old. Mr.

Testimony that Chang Soo Lee purchased under an assumed name enough cyanide mixture Sept. 10 to kill about 500 persons, and that the illness of Chang's alleged poison victims was diagnosed as four different ailments prior to the poisoning theory, was added today to the complex problem facing twelve jurors in Westchester County Court.

While stating that he will vote for the Tydings-Miller Price Maintenance Bill, "primarily because it outlaws loss leaders," Congressman Emanuel Celler, at a press conference here yesterday, announced his intention of "unmasking the hidden dangers of the bill" in a minority report he will submit.

Mrs. Helen V. Locke, principal of Lincoln Grammar School of this borough since 1918, died today in West Hudson Hospital, Kearny, after a long illness. Mrs. Locke, who was a teacher for forty-five years, was a member of the Kingsland family, pioneer residents of Bergen County. Mrs.
Business men here see a trend toward general recovery in the distinct improvement in the diamond industry indicated in the annual report of the Diamond Exchange, published today.

Two of the ominous but now familiar scarlet placards pasted on Berlin billposts amid advertisements of theatrical and other amusements announced today that three more heads had rolled in the sand this morning.
Maude Ellet Chambers, retired aerialist of Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Circus, died yesterday at her home, 133-09 Eightysixth Street, Ozone Park.

Uncle Sam would like to find reliable buyers for about 29,000 farms. W. I. Myers, Governor of the Federal Land Banks, told a House Appropriations subcommittee that the farms, carried at a value of about $100,000,000, had been taken over by the land banks.
Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, announced today that he would sell tomorrow an issue of $100,000,000 New York State short-term notes to meet current expenses.

Billy Beauhold, promising Jersey City lightweight, maintained his record as an unbeaten fighter last night at the St. Nicholas Palace, where, before an overflow crowd of more than 4,000, he held Aldo Spoldi of Italy to a draw in an exciting eight-round battle.

Another series of wage increases seems in prospect on top of those granted last Autumn. Some of the recent advances have come as the result of strikes, some of amicable agreements. The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation have increased wages; so have most of the units in the rubber tire industry.

The National Hockey League in its weekly statistics tonight placed Larry Aurie of Detroit at the head of its scoring column with 38 points. The Red Wing star, according to the official figures, picked up 4 points during the week to step ahead of Toronto's Harvey Jackson,

The engagement of Mrs. Genevieve Garvan Brady, widow of Nicholas F. Brady and a leader of the Catholic laity in this country, to William J. B. Macaulay, Minister to the Vatican from the Irish Free State, was announced last night.

Although it would be stretching the truth to imply that Ibsen's "An Enemy of the People" is not somewhat wrinkled and gray-headed, its spirit is still young and valiant. For it was written out of personal indignation by a man who knew his trade,

New York railroads joined today in attacking a legislative proposal for five-man crews on switching and transfer operations as "dangerous and contrary to the best interests of the railroads, their employes and the public."
Cuba commemorated the thirty-ninth anniversary of the sinking of the United States battleship Maine in Havana Harbor with official services this morning at the Maine Monument on Malecon Drive.

That vacation saga called "Having Wonderful Time" will not be starting this evening, after all. Mr. Connelly and his associates, baffled by the mechanics of some six heavy settings, decided yesterday to put the whole thing over until Friday. Same place: the Lyceum; same cast: headed by Katherine Locke and Jules Garfield.

Failures in the United States for the week ended Feb. 11 totaled 172, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 184 the week before and with 194 for the corresponding week last year.

The Supreme Court refused today to grant the petition of the city of Paterson that either the 145-yearold charter of the Society for Useful Manufactures be revoked or the organization's tax immunity be rescinded.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court here extended hearings today in connection with reorganization activities involving the New york, Westchester Boston Railway and the Old Colony Railroad.

Affairs in the ranks of the Yankee holdouts took a fresh and, for the holdouts, perhaps, a most alarming turn last night, when Colonel Jacob Ruppert let it be known in unmistakable terms that, instead of relenting, he planned to make the going even tougher for his unsigned players as time wears on.

Miss Doris Ann Gardner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hamilton Gardner of Orange, was married to James Fuller Chamberlain, son of Dr. and Mrs. Aims R. Chamberlain of Maplewood this evening in the Hotel Suburban, East Orange, by the bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. J. Holmes McGuinness of Chester, N. Y. A reception for relatives and close friends followed the ceremony.

A strong endorsement of Secretary Hull's reciprocal trade policy was given today by Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Budget, in testimony before a subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee, which is considering the bill for three years to negotiate reciprocal unconditional most-favored-nation trade agreements.

The first harbinger of Spring was detected on Old Rose Hill yesterday afternoon. While gusty winds whistled around the gray ramparts of the Fordham gymnasium, a squad of battery candidates for the 1937 Maroon baseball team drilled within its walls in comparative comfort.

Brig. Gen. James Robb, New York National Guard, retired, and a former vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died yesterday at his home, 75 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, after a four-month illness. His age .was 66.

Net profit of the United Carbon Company and subsidiaries in 1936 amounted to $2,202,850 after depreciation, depletion, minority interests, Federal and State income taxes and $53,000 surtax on undistributed earnings. The profit is equivalent to $5.54 each on 397,885 shares of no-par common stock outstanding. In 1935 the net profit amounted to $1,872,405, or $4.70 a common share.

Plans for a new six-story apartment building on the West Side, and for extensive remodeling of business properties on Fifth Avenue and in West Thirty-fourth Street, were filed by architects yesterday.

The necessity for commercial banking to supplement earnings from traditional classes of loans and investments with income from other forms of financial services is pointed out in a report of the economic policy commission of the American Bankers Association, which was issued yesterday.

President Roosevelt today sent to the Senate the nomination of John M. Carmody of New York to succeed Morris L. Cooke as Administrator of the Rural Electrification Administration. Mr. Carmody has been Deputy Administrator.

Only a big second innings recovery can save the Marylebone Cricket Club from defeat in its match with New South Wales. Replying to the home team's first innings, which netted 231 runs, the English players collapsed for 73. Going in a second time, New South Wales had made 205 for 6 wickets at the close of play today.

The Netherlands guilder rallied strongly yesterday from its slump of last week as a result of reports from Amsterdam that the Bank of the Netherlands had announced a gold-buying price reflecting a value for the exchange much higher than its recent levels.
The defeat of two seeded players featured the opening day of play in the individual championship tournament of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association, Group 2, at the City Athletic Club yesterday.
Thirty-seven Harvard seniors have been nominated for the offices of class marshals, treasurer, orator, poet, chorister and odist, with the election to be held Feb. 23 and 24. They are:

A group headed by E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and, including A. C. Allyn Co., Inc., and G. L. Ohrstrom Co., Inc., will offer today an issue of $1,500,000 of New Mexico Gas Company (formerly Albuquerque Natural Gas Company) first mortgage series A,

William Henry Tarbox, once famous as the "Dahlia King" of Tarbox Corners, died today in his ninety-sixth year. Born in the homestead in which he died and in which he spent his life, Tarbox and his brother, Daniel Webster Tarbox, developed the homestead surroundings into a place of beauty that became a mecca of flower lovers.

Wage increases were announced today by two tire and rubber companies, Goodyear and Firestone. Goodyear announced "wage increases for all factory employes in its rubber and textile mills amounting to approximately $300,000 increase in earnings for 1937."

A new schedule of reduced roundtrip fares between Westchester County points and New York City was announced today by the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad Company. The rates, which went into effect today, apply solely to single round trips, the commutation and one-way fares remaining the same.

Glenn Cunningham, pushed out of the headlines for the first time in nearly five years by the two-mile exploits of Don Lash, yesterday entered the Baxter Mile along with Archie San Romani with the distinct intention of making this old reliable test the feature event of the New York A. C. carnival at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

The 1937 advertising budget of the Apex Company, Cleveland, manufacturers of refrigerators, washing machines and other electrical appliances, has been doubled, J. W. Walters, metropolitan sales manager, announced yesterday, at the conclusion of a three-day sales meeting at the Hotel Granada, Brooklyn.

Mrs. Irene Machuga, 18, wife of a WPA worker and the mother of a boy 7 months old, broke down after her arrest here today, and confessed that she was the "phantom" burglar who had baffled the Police Department of Nanticoke for weeks and terrorized that city in the lower Wyoming Valley.

Two bandits yesterday held up twelve employes of the Jenrae Milk and Cream Company, at 540 Watkins Street, in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, according to police of the Canarsie precinct station, and escaped in an automobile with $1,100 in cash and checks.

The Panama Pacific liner California was held at her pier at San Pedro yesterday when members of the Pacific Coast Firemen's Union refused to work with fourteen men who had been sent from New York by airplane as crew replacements.

Sedkwick Av. (12-3249), s. e. cor. of 197th St.. 100x103; Madison Properties, Inc., to Irving Syndicate, Inc., 17 E. 42d St. Belmont Av. (11-3088), s.e. cor. of Creston Av., 47x77; also Crescent Av., s. e. s., 77 ft e. of Belmont Av., 51x128; Baldassare Caputo to Pietro Guarino, 1,956 Haight Av.
Lawyers for the government and public utilities defended and attacked in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today the right of the Public Works Administration to finance municipal power plans.

The Brooklyn Tech quintet advanced from a second-place deadlock to a tie for the lead with Thomas Jefferson, co-holder of the city title, as the result of a 25-21 success against Boys High in a Section 1 Brooklyn P. S. A. L. engagement on the Central Methodist Episcopal Church court yesterday.

The shortage of scrap steel and pig iron has become so acute in the United Kingdom that a number of steel furnaces in Western Wales have had to close down and others also may cease production. The tin-plate industry, too,

Election of twenty members to the board of directors for the ensuing year was the only action announced last night at the annual meeting of the Distilled Spirits Institute at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The board of directors of the B. M. T., after a meeting yesterday, requested representatives of the Transport Workers Lodge of the International Association of Machinists, who were responsible for a sit-down strike in Kent Avenue power plant on Jan. 25 and 26, to submit a collective bargaining plan to the B. M. T.

Nathan Wolfman, a lawyer here who said he was the second largest stockholder, charged today that stock in the Warren Brothers Company of Cambridge, a holding company for general contractors, had been manipulated shortly before the company applied for permission to reorganize under the amended Federal bankruptcy laws.

When the price of wheat was rising 24 cents a bushel in 1935 and 30 cents more in 1936, along with substantial decrease of world-production and fall in the yearly "carry-over" to the smallest in twelve years, it was not an infrequent prediction that the result would be such increased planting and harvesting as should again bring production well above consumption and turn prices downward.

The political parties, giving the new Cabinet of Premier Senjuro Hayashi no time for a honeymoon, opened fire upon it yesterday in the House of Representatives immediately after the Premier had completed his first address.

John De Witt, an investment banker here and in Chicago, who organized and financed the United Stockyards Corporation last year to acquire the stockyards holdings of Swift Co., has purchased from the Armour interests a controlling interest in the $4,000,000 General Stockyards Corporation.

Deaths Announced Fireman 2d Grade Edward T. Feyk of H. L. 20 died Feb. 13. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 130-08 120th St., Ozone Park, at 2 P. M. Tuesday, Feb. 16. Interment at Linden Hill Cemetery.

The Hotchkiss School hockey team today defeated South Kent, 1-0, on Lakeville ice. The goal was made late in the first period when McLennan and G. Young went down the ice together and the latter flicked a backhand shot into the net behind the goalie at 13:30.

Demand for knitted underwear was reported yesterday- to be somewhat spotty, with modified classic types accounting for a large share of the available business. In promotional merchandise, knitted cotton chenilles in pastel shades have enjoyed satisfactory reorder business, and there has been some call for classic sweaters for wear with suits.

An offering of 50,000 shares of $1.25 cumulative, no-par preferred stock and 150,000 shares of $5-par common stock of Kennedy's, Inc., will be made today by a banking group headed by E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and including Munds, Winslow Potter, Riter Co.,
Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, 53-year-old physi- Co cian to the Dionne quintuplets, entered Toronto General Hospital today suffering from influenza.
Federal Judge Luther B?? Way today ordered receivers of the Seaboard Air Line Railway to draft and submit to the court "a comprehensive plan" for reorganizing the road's financial affairs.
The text of Lewis W. Douglas's statement today before the Senate Finance Committee urging extension of the Trade Agreements Act was as follows:...

James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney, who has been investigating the so-called garnishee racket, reported to District Attorney Dodge yesterday that there were 1,802 garnishee executions on file with Controller Taylor against 699 members of the police force.

The forthcoming World's Fair and' the approaching extension of the municipal subway service of Jamaica continue to exert a major influence on realty trading in Queens. Several transactions involving properties within the zone of influence of these two major projects were reported yesterday.

Perfect weather conditions greeted the participants in the annual Belleair Country Club golf championship today, but as is sometimes the case the scores, with few exceptions, zoomed to almost unreasonable heights in the qualifying round. Douglas W. Hill, the defending champion and one-time reigning golfer of the Cincinnati district, carded a splendid 72, one over par, to lead the field.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area: 1st Lt. Joseph R. Mascaro, Med.-Res., now on active duty with the CCC, is relieved from further active duty and will proceed to his home, 141 Rockaway Av., Brooklyn, N. Y., to arrive threat not later than midnight. March 24.
Stocks heavy, closed lower in slowest trading of the month; turnover, 1,959,640 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds lower, foreign issues irregular; transactions, $13,508,000.

The Giants' pending trip to Havana, scheduled to start from New York on the liner Oriente tomorrow afternoon, had to undergo a hurried shift in plans yesterday when and President Horace Stoneham received word from Memphis that Manager Bill Terry was suffering from a heavy cold which would delay his arrival at the Cuban training camp for about a week.

A plot of about 21,800 square feet at the northeast corner of Eleventh Avenue and Twentyfourth Street, 100 by 218 feet, has been assembled by the Cross Brown Company and Edward A. Arnold, as associate brokers, for Francis H. Leggett Co., wholesale grocers.

Louis Singer, active for many years in Jewish charities, died on Sunday in Miami, Fla., after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday. He was 54 years old and lived at 609 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

Germany creator of vest-pocket battleships, turned her attention today to "vest-pocket sheep." To augment the nation's wool supply, small landowners are being encouraged by the government to raise Angora rabbits.
Miss Ottille Schillig, who appeared here in recital in 1919, 1920 and 1921 and was acclaimed as one of the most promising of young American singers, attempted a comeback at the Town Hall last night.

The City Athletic Club took undisputed possession of second place in the metropolitan Class B Squash Tennis League by blanking the Harvard Club, 5-0, in one of three matches in the double round-robin last night.

The estate left by James B. Clews, senior partner in the Stock Exchange firm of Henry Clews Co., was fixed at a net value of $1,690,064 in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The gross estate was $3,046,013, but it was reduced by debts of $1,271,128 and expenses of $84,820. Mr. Clews died on Dec. 17, 1934.

The ninth week of the Metropolitan Opera season began last night with a performance of "Carmen." In the principal roles were Rosa Ponselle as Carmen, Hilda Burke as Micaela, Rene Maison as Don Jose and Ezio Pinza as Escamillo. Gennaro Papi conducted.

Mail order and buyer activity in the wholesale markets here yesterday were described as fair. Some Spring trade is developing at retail, but it is still too early for reorders to develop in volume, buying offices said.

Louis Beitcher, a fifty-dollar-aweek gangster, collected more than $100,000 for the restaurant racketeers and part of it went to four of the union officials on trial in Supreme Court, he testified yesterday. His extortion list brought to about $400,000 the total of "shakedowns" on which evidence has been offered.

Carl M. Dann Jr. of Orlando, twice winner, and William Holt of Syracuse, making his first bid for the Walter J. Travis Memorial Trophy, deadlocked for medal honors today in the qualifying round of the tenth annual national championship of golf club champions. Each clipped two strokes from par, with 70, to lead by one stroke in the record field of nearly sixty.

Prison officials said tonight that seven convicts who escaped early today from the Caledonia prison farm with two attaches and a youth, abducted later, as hostages, released the trio unharmed in Moore County after several hours of wild riding over State highways.

The tenth annual championship of the Women's United States Squash Racquets Association progressed through the first round on the Junior League courts yesterday, with no upsets and few notable matches developing in the all-day session.
Stocks heavy, closed lower in slowest trading of the month; turnover, 1,959,640 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds lower, foreign issues irregular; transactions, $13,508,000.

The Giants' pending trip to Havana, scheduled to start from New York on the liner Oriente tomorrow afternoon, had to undergo a hurried shift in plans yesterday when and President Horace Stoneham received word from Memphis that Manager Bill Terry was suffering from a heavy cold which would delay his arrival at the Cuban training camp for about a week.

A plot of about 21,800 square feet at the northeast corner of Eleventh Avenue and Twentyfourth Street, 100 by 218 feet, has been assembled by the Cross Brown Company and Edward A. Arnold, as associate brokers, for Francis H. Leggett Co., wholesale grocers.

The judges in the Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest, sponsored by The New York Times Wide World Photos, Inc., and the National Sportsmen's Show, yesterday tackled the formidable task of selecting the best pictures out of an array of more than 2,500 that had come in from thirty States, ranging from Maine to California.

Marlboro hailed Mrs. Catherine Farley, 42, as a heroine today after she had rescued her 9-month-old granddaughter, Maureen, from flames that took the life of Maureen's father, James F. Farley, 23. Firemen found Farley's body behind a locked bathroom door.

Republican legislative leaders made a new move today in the hope of obtaining Democratic support in their campaigns of opposition to President Roosevelt's proposals relating to the Supreme Court of the United States.
January copper statistics generally were better than had been expected. Instead of a sharp increase in refined stocks abroad, which had been forecast, there was a decline of 5,669 tons.

Benny Rubano of the Maris Stella K. of C. provided the feature of the New York Athletic Club's amateur boxing show last night by knocking out both his opponents in the fourman 126-pound class. After halting John Toomey, unattached, in the first round, Rubano stopped Morris Wolitzky, Catholic Youth Association, in the third round. A crowd of 1,000 attended.

Preston Gibson, who played on the Yale varsity football and baseball teams and won the Croix de Guerre in the World War, died yesterday in Veterans Hospital 81, at 130 Kingsbridge Road, Bronx, after a month's illness of heart disease complicated- by uremia. He was 57 years old.

John S. Farnsworth, former naval officer, withdrew his plea of innocence today to a charge of conspiring to communicate naval secrets to Japan and threw himself upon the mercy of a Federal court. Judge James M. Proctor said he wanted to study the case before imposing sentence.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Bradshaw of the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. A. Bradshaw Nichols, to John Livingston Hopkins of New York.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday for i936 a net income of $2,250,813 after all deductions, including surtax on undistributed profits. This was equal to $3.02 a share on 745,364 no par capital shares, compared with $2,709,380, or $3.64 a share on 744,300 average number of shares outstanding in 1935.

Amid flurries of snow and a Wintry sting that sort of gave the work additional zest, the Giants completed arrangements yesterday for their sea voyage to Cuba, where before the week is out the National League champions will launch their 1937 training campaign.

Dwight L. Hoopingarner, associate director of the PWA Housing Division, with headquarters in New York, has given up his Federal post and will devote himself privately to slum clearance and low-rent housing in Manhattan, it was learned yesterday.
Full powers permitting temporary lowering or raising of tariff rates and immediate reprisals against dumping were voted by the Chamber of Deputies today.
A new symphony by Tikhon Khrennikoff, a Soviet composer not yet 24 years old, was revealed to New York by the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy at Carnegie Hall last night.

Ellis Jungman, 53 years old, of 2,125 Ellis Avenue, the Bronx, the last chairman of the Municipal Board of Examining Plumbers before it recently was abolished by Mayor La Guardia because of grafting, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to second-degree perjury.

Henry M. Briggs, 48 years old, for more than twenty-four years a carrier in the Sheepshead Bay section of the Brooklyn Postoffice, pleaded guilty yesterday before Commissioner Martin C. Epstein to a charge of "delaying the United States mail."

The Columbia basketball team advanced to second place in the Eastern League tonight by piling on the points in the closing minutes of play to send the Princeton quintet one notch nearer last place with a 35-28 defeat.

The trial of two former honor students at Yale University, accused of heading a group that swindled the public of more than $3,000,000 in 1932 and 1933 through the sale of stock of the Public Service Holding Corporation, assumed intercollegiate proportions yesterday when the government called a former Oxford man as its principal witness.
Governors of the New York Stook Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange took action yesterday against the trading practice know. as "free riding."

In countries for which statistics are available and which have populations aggregating 200,000,000, some 200,000 die every year of cancer. By analyzing this rich material for the second International Cancer Congress, Dr. W. CRAMER of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund (London) has shown how much the mathematician can contribute to an understanding of one dread menace.

The Vollrath Company, Sheboygan, Wis., will launch a newspaper advertising campaign early in April. Advertising is scheduled for one newspaper magazine supplement and newspapers of metropolitan markets. Dealer cooperation will be the deciding factor in determining the number of markets.
Political and diplomatic circles here hope that out of the agreement of the International Committee for Non-Intervention in Spain may come soon a concerted effort to end the civil war.
Mayor La Guardia pledged last night that the city will somehow provide funds to staff its playgrounds and recreation centers if and when no more WPA funds for this purpose are available.

By a margin of more than eight to one the Philadelphia Bar Association endorsed a resolution today condemning President Roosevelt's Federal court recommendations as "a menace to the independence of the judiciary."
The trend for short-term money rates is definitely upward, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, said last night at the monthly meeting of the Savings Banks Officers Forum in the Hotel Astor.

Unbeaten since the new year, Manhattan encounters a formidable foe and a persistent jinx tonight when the Jasper quintet faces St. John's in the feature of the basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. In the opening game a veteran Temple team will attempt to catch successfully on the rebound N. Y. U., which still is smarting under the crushing setback administered by Notre Dame.

Reflecting the further strength in copper prices abroad, the leading copper-producing companies yesterday advanced the domestic price of the metal I cent a pound to 14 cents, the highest since April 24, 1930.
Mrs. Edwin S. Stackhouse of New York was hostess today at a luncheon in the patio of the Surf Club honoring Mrs. Stuart Jamison of St. Louis.

Gross assets, $178,000; net, $59,219. To Rosa L. Barzaghi, widow, life estate in residue; Gabrielle M. Kenedy and Arthur J. Barzaghi, children, remainders in three-fifths and two-fifths residue respectively. Chief assets, real estate, $178,000. Casper B. Ughetta, attorney, 2 W. 45th St. Casper B. Ughetta attorney, 2 W. 45th st.

The following candidates for promotion to the rank of lieutenant of this department shall be directed to report to the Municipal Civil Service Commission at Room 1401, Municipal Building, Manhattan, at 9 A. M., on dates specified for medical examination. Candidates shall bring their notice of the result of mental examination with them.

Appleton - Century are hurrying into print with a new book by David Lawrence, "Supreme Court or Political Puppets?" Mr. Lawrence has been alarmed by the President's recommendations concerning the Supreme Court.

A severe storm, accompanied by high winds and causing the disruption of wire services in the South, was moving up the South Atlantic coast yesterday, but reports last night indicated that it was veering out to sea as it approached the Virginia Capes.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday in a preliminary statement that its net income in 1936 was $38,742,092, or $2.94 a share on its capital stock. This, the largest income earned since 1930, is compared to $23,849,798, or $1.81 a share, earned in 1935.

The directors of Paramount Pictures, Inc., have authorized the creation of an issue of $15,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent convertible debentures, which will be offered to holders of the present 20-year 6 per cent debentures on March 1 in a par-forpar exchange. The right to exchange will expire on March 9.

The marriage of Miss Violet Margot Catty, elder daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Douglass Catty of Stamford, Conn., to Brian Hutton Dulanty, elder son of John Whelan Dulanty, Irish Free State High Commissioner in London, and Mrs. Dulanty may be held in New York this Summer.

Richard W. Dodge has Joined the sales and renting staff of Leonard J. Winston, specializing in Greenwich Village real estate. A first mortgage of $160,000 was placed by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co. through Harry G. Gebhard, Inc., on a six-story apartment at 45-42 41st St., Long Island City. The owner is the L. R.

The murder of Abe Borson, union official, in 1933, was injected into the restaurant racket trial yesterday as suggesting the fate of labor leaders in the food industry who refused to accept the domination of Jules Martin and Sam Krantz, gangsters.

Declaring that a shortage of lowcost housing was imminent, the New York City Housing Authority asked Mayor La Guardia yesterday to support new legislation protecting low-income tenants from unreasonable rises in rent, as well as legislation giving the Tenement House Department power to assess the cost of required repairs against multiple dwellings as a prior- lien.

Sale of nine properties in various parts of the city and metropolitan area for title companies is reported by the Title and Mortgage Rehabilitation and Liquidation Bureau of the State Department of Insurance through ts real estate division.

The advisability of enacting any sort of neutrality or war-profits legislation to prescribe in advance this country's course in time of war was called into question today by General Hugh S. Johnson, former National Recovery Administrator and head of the Draft Board during the World War.
Mary Morris, making her London debut tonight, builds up in "Suspect" one of those hard sinister characters which are known in New York. At St. Martin's Theatre she is a woman with a mysterious past.

Frank Ahearn, described by the police as one of the principal lieutenants of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in the days when he was the beer-running czar of the Bronx, and Marty Powell, 34 years old, of 435 West 259th Street, were arrested at 1 A. M. yesterday at Eighth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street by Detectives of the West Forty-seventh Street police station.

Plans for the demolition of its old nine-story building at 375 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and the erection of a new bank edifice there were announced yesterday by the Fulton Savings -Bank through Richard J. Wulff, president.

In the speech which Attorney General CUMMINGS made last week, misquoting Chief Justice HUGHES and misunderstanding Chief Justice TAFT, he spoke of the " attacks of hysteria " to which the President's Supreme Court plan has been subjected.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard yesterday granted an application by the Federal Trade Commission for a writ of mandamus to compel the National Biscuit Company to answer certain questions concerning the salaries of its officers, purchases and sales and chain-store customers. He said in part:
The Alabama House today accepted Senate changes in a 2 per cent general sales tax bill and the measure went to Governor Graves. The law is to go. into effect March 1 and expire Oct. 31, 1939.

Labor's Nonpartisan League, of which Major George L. Berry is chairman, decided today to open a national campaign to obtain passage of the bills embodying President Roosevelt's plan for reform of the judiciary.

Supreme Court Justice Lockwood in Brooklyn authorized the city yesterday to tear down a 225-foot brick chimney located on a refuse disposal plant on Barren Island, near Floyd Bennett Field. The chimney is said to be a menace to aviators.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Rosenman reserved decision yesterday on motions by defendants to dismiss a stockholder's accounting suit brought by Bella Gallup against the Federal Water Service Corporation, the Chase National Bank, the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and others.

The food situation in the Malaga district of Spain, now under Rebel domination, remains most acute and is aggravated further by the fact that thousands of refugees are thronging the roads to the city.

ABERT--Benjamin, at his residence, 40 East 83d St., beloved brother of Annie Cohen, Florence Mendel and Isaac Abert. Funeral service Park West Chapel, 115 West 79th St., Thursday, Feb. 18, at 2 P. M. Kindly omit flowers. Interment private. ABERT--Kurnik. Benevolent Association sorrowfully announces the death of its esteemed life member, Benjamin Abert. Members are requested to attend funeral Thursday, 2 P. M., Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West 79th St.
Canada's newsprint production. last month increased 59,736 tons to 287,691 over January, 1936, the News Print Service Bureau reported today.
George A. Sloan war elected yesterday a director of the Bankers Trust Company, it was announced by S. Sloan Colt, president of the bank.

Resignation of Rabbi Isaac Landman as editor of The American Hebrew was announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by Louis Rittenberg, associated with the weekly for fifteen years and managing editor since 1928.

Dr. Ralph E. Heilman, dean of the Northwestern University School of Commerce, died in the Evanston Hospital today after an illness of a year. Dr. Heilman, who resided at 731 Clinton Place, Evanston, was 50 years old.

Salvador de Madariaga, former Spanish diplomat, said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Plaza that the world realized that it needed a certain amount of international administration and that for this purpose he was organizing World Foundation, an international body to foster world citizenship.
Governor Lehman signed the Rapp bill permitting the placing of "New York World's Fair 1939" on automobile license plates for 1938 and 1939. He also signed several minor measures.
New life insurance written last month was 1.6 per cent less than in January, 1936, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reported yesterday to the United States Department of Commerce.

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of the following securities: J. C. Penney Company-75,000 additional shares of common, no par value. Minneapolls-Honeywell Regulatory Company--5,700 additional shares of 4 per cent convertible preferred, Series B, $100 par value, and 4,750 additional shares of common, no par value.

Grace Av. (17-4885), w s, 426 ft of Boston Rd., 75x95: Louise Riggs to Madeline Rudershausen, 3,206 Rawlins Av. Stratford Av. (14-3744), e s, 616 ft s of Westchester Av., 100x100: Bessie Handier to Ezra Holding Corp., 152 W. 42d St.: mtg. $93,000.

Agreeing that it was a difficult task to determine the winner from such a fine assortment, the three judges of the snapshot contest last night expressed the opinion that amateur camera activity in hunting, conservation and outdoor life generally will be stimulated as a result of the competition.

The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress transmitting a report from his special committee on farm tenancy was as follows: I transmit herewith for the information of the Congress the report of the special committee on farm tenancy.

Dr. Robert B. Greenough, nationally known cancer specialist and former president of the American College of Surgeons, died today of a heart attack. His age was 65. Born in Cambridge, Mass., Dr. Greenough was graduated from Harvard College in 1892 and from Harvard Medical School in 1896.

While business failures showed an increase of four to 105 in the week ended Feb. 11, in comparison with the previous week, they were about on a par with the average for the past six weeks, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

Early last night, after a laborious day spent in his office in the Empire State Building, where he acts as technical adviser in this country for the Nakajima Aircraft Company of Tokyo, Seiichi Akabane was informed that he had won the snapshot contest.

The Reserve Board's formal explanation to the Senate of the reasons for utilizing its full power of a 50 per cent increase in member bank reserve requirements goes over much the same ground as its statement of Jan. 30, when the second and final increase was announced. It declares somewhat more explicitly, however, its ideas as to how a future need for control of credit would be met.

Holders of Rhine-Westphalia Electric Power Corporation capital stock have been notified by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company that, unless they enter their objections by March 17, net dividends of 5.40 reichsmark a year paid in 1935 and 1936 and now deposited in the Konversionskasse fuer Deutsche Auslandsschulden will be converted into Konversionskasse 3 per cent reichsmark bonds, Series A and B, due July 1, 1946, and July 1, 1947.
Dr. Albert L. Brown, director of the New York State Fair, announced today that two prize harness-horse stakes on the 1937 Grand Circuit had been awarded to the fair.

Men and women of 40 are still "growing up" and the growing process continues into the fifth and sometimes the sixth decade, according to Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, Curator of Physical Anthropology of the Smithsonian Institution.

Senator Glass has accused the Social Security Board of abolishing a branch office in his home town "out of spite" for him. This was disclosed today by the publication of proceedings at a Senate hearing on the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill.
King Leopold will lead thousands of Belgians on a pilgrimage tomorrow to Marche-les-Dames where King Albert was killed three years ago in a fall from a mountain.

More than 450 friends and admirers of the late Dr. S. Parkes Cadman assembled at the Hotel Astor last night to attend a memorial dinner sponsored by the Church Federations of Metropolitan New York and the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

Confident that he has attained the form that brought him the Olympic 1,500-meter championship in 1932, Luigi Beccali of Italy yesterday filed his entry for the two-mile joust with Don Lash Co. in the feature event of the New York A. C. track and field carnival at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

Miss Eleonora Sears of Boston was elected president of the United States Women's -Squash Racquets Association for the third time in succession at its annual meeting at the Junior League Club yesterday, The Associated Press reports.

Hilaire Belloc, prominent layman in the Roman Catholic Church and outstanding literary figure, delivered the first of a series of lectures yesterday in the Graduate School of Fordham University, as a "Visiting Professor of History."

Playing on its home court yesterday, the powerful St. Augustine's basketball team captured its eleventh straight league game by defeating Cathedral Prep, 24--15, and strengthened its grip on first place in the Brooklyn division of the C. H. S. A. A. race.
George Banks McGinty, for the last twenty-four years secretary of the Interstate Commerce Commission, died this morning of pneumonia at his home here. He was 58 years old.

Honus Wagner, high commissioner of semi-pro baseball, announced yesterday the appointment of Bill Hinchman, Pittsburgh Pirate scout, as a member of the all-American board to select the official allstar team at the national semi-pro baseball tournament at Wichita,

Testimony that subordinate company officials went through the files of Alfred P. Sloan, president of General Motors Corporation; William S. Knudsen, executive vice president, and C. E. Wilson, vice president, and removed papers relating to labor conditions a few weeks before Senate investigators subpoenaed records relating to labor espionage, was heard by the special Senate subcommittee today.

Clyde Proctor, 27 years old, was held here on a second degree murder charge today after District Attorney Joseph Molinari quoted him as confessing he "shook to death" a 15-month-old baby "because it bit me." The baby was a son of Mrs.

The Massachusetts House of Representatives today voted 124 to 92 to adopt a resolution criticizing President Roosevelt's proposal to add six members to the Supreme Court if justices over 70 do not retire.

Joseph Rose, 61 years old, of 2,547 East Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, retired diamond dealer who charged that he had been robbed of $250,000 in gems, was arrested yesterday on a charge of violating Section 148 of the Public Welfare Law, dealing with the acceptance of relief payments by persons with other means of support.

Frank A. Sieverman 3d of the New York A. C. advanced to the semi-finals in the Whitehall Club squash tennis tournament as the quarter-final round was completed yesterday. Sieverman, who is rated second, turned back William P. Hoffman of Bayside, 18-16, 15-4.

If it is still good legal doctrine that falsehood in one thing is falsehood in everything, then LEON TROTSKY in our pages yesterday disposed of the case built up against him in the recent Moscow treason trial. It was there testified by VLADIMIR ROMM, the Soviet newspaper man in whose behalf

A conference of the nation's religious leaders, to be addressed by President Roosevelt in Washington to dramatize the importance of religion in government, was suggested yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas.

Members in this city of the Noroton alumnae of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Noroton, Conn., of which Mrs. William Gatheral is president, have organized a lenten sewing group, which held its first meeting yesterday at the home of Mrs. Cal J. McCarthy Jr., 115 East Ninety-second Street.

With well-known guides and conservation officials drifting into the city, carpenters, electricians and decorators labored from early yesterday morning until late at night in the Grand Central Palace setting the stage for the National Sportsmen's Show, which opens tomorrow.

A concert of the most unusual interest was given by the choir of the Pius X School of Liturgical Music last night in Town Hall. The program offered nothing less than a survey of early developments of plain-chant and forms of contrapuntal composition, including works known to date from the eleventh to the sixteenth century.

Under a supplementary agreement between Loft, Inc., and the Phoenix Securities Corporation on Jan. 30, made public yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, Phoenix Securities may buy 300,000 shares of Loft capital stock by June 9, 1940. Until June 9, 1938, the price will be $3 a share, until June 9, 1939, $4, and until June 9, 1940, $5.

Now quartered at the Bayes, the Theatre Union tonight gets around to its first production since it took the trail uptown from Fourteenth Street. John Howard Lawson's "Marching Song" is the matter at hand: a play about an automobile strike, but coincidentally so, the manuscript having been completed last Summer. (And, by the way,
Demand far exceeded supply, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, said today at his sale of $100,000,000 of shortterm notes of the State of New York.

A restful picture of a mist-enshrouded trout stream taken with a vest-pocket camera by Seiichi Akabane of 5 Manning Circle, Pelham, N. Y., yesterday was adjudged winner of the Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES Wide World Photos, Inc., and the National Sportsmen's Show.
Premier Benito Mussolini swung a pick into the pavement of Piazzo Bocca della Verita today to inaugurate construction of Italy's first subway.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College urged the sophomores to take up careers, although not necessarily paid jobs, in her annual address to the class yesterday afternoon in Brinckerhoff Theatre.
Crown Princess Juliana of the Netherlands and her husband, Prince Bernhard, left Vienna this morning, concluding a five-day visit.

Fifth Avenue space was in demand, reports from brokers indicated yesterday. The national headquarters of the English-Speaking Union will move late in March from 19 West Forty-fourth Street to newly leased quarters on the fifteenth floor of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

Visiting buyers reported in town during the week ended yesterday numbered less than in the preceding week. The total, however, was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Negotiations for a- new agreement between the United Mine Workers and the bituminous coal operators of the Appalachian fields, extending from Pennsylvania to Northern Tennessee, will begin at a conference of representatives of both sides at the Hotel Biltmore this morning. About 400,000 miners are involved. The agreement now in force expires April 1.

Lewis Brooks, defending champion, defeated the veteran J. Howard Shoemaker, 125 to 63, in the national amateur pocket billiard tournament last night. The setback eliminated Shoemaker as a contender for the title.

The divorce obtained by David Wark Griffith, motion picture producer and director, in Kentucky in 1935 was illegally granted without notification to her, the producer's first wife, Mrs. Linda A. Griffith, declared in papers filed in Supreme Court yesterday in connection with her motion to compel him to file an amended answer to her motion for nullification of the divorce.

Chandler Hovey of Boston yesterday purchased the America's Cup defender Rainbow from Harold S. Vanderbilt and will race her against Mr. Vanderbilt's new yacht Ranger for defense of the historic trophy off Newport the coming Summer against T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II, or perhaps the first Endeayour.
Investors who have been congratulating themselves on the acumen that they displayed during 1936 may draw slight comfort from the current issue of the New York Stock Exchange Bulletin.

Dr. Charles Page Perin, consulting engineer, who did extensive development work in Asia, Africa, Europe and the United States, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 755 Park Avenue, after five days of illness. Dr. Perin was president of the Perin Engineering Company, 535 Fifth Avenue. His age was 75. He was notable for his work in iron and steel.

The value of organization to meet the "vital questions of industrial legislation likely to come up within the next three to four months" was stressed yesterday by G. H. Conze, president of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., at its sixty-fourth annual meeting in the National Republican Club.
Tommy Goodwin, New York State amateur golf champion, annexed qualifying honors in the annual Everglades invitation tournament today with a card of 38, 36-74.

Two young Harvard graduates, one the national champion and the other twice a winner of the crown, gained the final of the Metropolitan squash racquets championship last night on the courts of the University Club.
The total of open-market commercial paper outstanding on Jan. 31 was $243,800,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The Hollins Alumnae Advisory Council will hold its seventh annual meeting on Saturday and Sunday preceding Founder's Day, Feb. 22. The founding of the council seven years ago was inspired by Mrs. Henry Lane Schmelz of New York City.

A two-minute sit-down strike on Monday afternoon by twenty-two first year German language students at Lincoln School, 425 West 123d Street, against a German examination brought temporary triumph for the youthful strikers, but yesterday Frederick Rex, the teacher, ended a one-day truce and compelled them to take the examination.
This was a day of disaster for favorites in the first round of match play in the tenth annual National Championship of Golf Club Champions for the Walter J. Travis Memorial Trophy.
WILLIAM GREEN will probably go on being president of the American Federation of Labor after he has been expelled
Onatdnnat Street Railway Company--January: Net profit $12,865 after all deductions, including $72,160 transferred from contingent reserves, compared with $23,352 a year before.

Witnesses told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that the names of the Fisher Body and Chrysler Corporations were used without authority to boost the price of Atlas Tack Corporation shares.

National advertisers are apparently becoming converted to the theory that this is a nation of installment buyers and are following the tactics of the credit houses in their copy, according to comment here yesterday.

Led by Joe Reiser and Artie Mueller, who accounted for 19 and 17 points, respectively, the New York Stock Exchange quintet defeated the Crescent A. C. team, 42 to 39, on the latter's court last night.

The United States liner President Roosevelt, leaving today for the Channel ports, will have among her passengers Commander B. M. Thompson, Charles B. Hurd, Robert F. Dibble, Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Fawcett, Mrs. C. K. Woodbridge, Mr. and Mrs. S. S. Shepard, Captain and Mrs. Nils Leknes, Mr. and Mrs. Dana Bennett, Mrs. Barbara Marshall and F. B. Ash.

Of the 2,000 shirt makers here who stopped work yesterday, more than 1,500 will return to work today, as more than 80 per cent of the manufacturers have signed contracts for the 7 1/2 per cent pay increase demanded by the union.

The House Banking Committee heard Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, testify today that the Federal Reserve System might be responsible for starting a "disastrous deflationary development" unless it were authorized to continue to use government obligations as collateral security for Federal Reserve notes.

Herbert Fitzpatrick, president of the Midamerica Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railway holding structure, has been elected chairman of the boards of the Chesapeake Ohio and Pere Marquette Railways. He is a vice president of both railways.
Sitdown" strikers occupied seven service stores of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company today, demanding higher pay and a shorter week.

Reports that the better grades of cotton in the collateral for government loans were being released in the East and resulting hedging operations carried prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday into the lowest ground of the month.

Residential property featured deals reported in Brooklyn yesterday. Esther Shenkman bought a three-story brick building on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 428-30 Atkins Avenue from the Estate of Max Eisman through Walter Samuels, Inc., and A. Granatstein and R. Weissman. The building contains twelve apartments and rents for approximately $4,000.

Conditios in Congress and the country, and on the Supreme Court bench, were very different from present times in 1869, when the House passed the judicial reform measure which the President now resubmits. The differences somewhat impair analogies and conclusions, although the motive of the proposals was the same--to change the majority viewpoint of the Supreme Court.

Decelring that with the progress of the recovery movement, American men were becoming "more clothes conscious," Raymond G. Twyeffort of New York, president of the National Association of Merchant Tailors. predicted at its convention today that tailors will be "virtually swamped with increased trade this year."

Dr. H. Harlow Brooks, diagnostician and consulting physician, left an estate of $442,466 gross and $388,451 net when he died on April 13, 1936, the victim of a bacillus he had helped to discover. This was disclosed yesterday when the transfer tax appraisal of his estate was filed.

Brokers operating today on the Santos Coffee Exchange continued their strike,: begun -yesterday, against what they described as the recent "unwarranted. boost" in prices. Not a transaction was recorded.
Architects and developers yesterday gave the Queens Department of Buildings one of the busiest days in its history.

Gale Blocki corporation lawyer, died today in his home here of a heart ailment complicated by bronchial pneumonia. His age was 67. Mr. Blocki's father, William F., was a partner in the drug firm of Gale Blocki, which was established in Chicago in 1847.

The three lower classes of the Mercersburg Academy have elected officers as follows: Upper MiddlerPresident, Richard Greene of St. David, Pa.; secretary, Joseph L. Jamison of Greensburg, Pa., and historian, Frederick G. Grimshaw Jr. of Altoona, Pa. Lower MiddlerPresident, Richard P. Klopp of Sheridan, Pa.; secretary, John J.

President Roosevelt told Congress today that fewer than half of the farmers of the country owned the farms they operated, that about 40,000 farmers were being added each year to this tenant class, and that prompt action was necessary to correct the "evils from which this large section suffers."

Leonard Hartman, defending titleholder, maintained a blistering pace in his bid for a grand slam of the 1937 senior indoor tennis laurels in this area when he ran through Robert Keefe, Brooklyn College captain, 6-0, 6-2, in a third-round match of the Brooklyn tennis championship tournament at the 106th Regiment Armory yesterday.

The residence at the southwest corner of Stewart and Washington Avenues, Garden City, L. I., formerly owned by Walter B. Smith, was purchased by Anne K. Holliday from the State Mortgage Commission, George A. Bowman, Inc., broker, reports.
Although the Senate Civil Liberties Committee room was full of private detectives called as witnesses today, not one had a magnifying glass.

Investment trusts of the management type in the United States showed an average gain of 35 per sent in asset value during 1936, compared to a gain of 25.4 per cent in the Dow-Jones seventy-stock average for the period, according to a survey of fifty-three companies by Distributors Group, Inc.
One of those utterly unexpected things that give sport competition its fascination happened in the women's national squash racquets championship at the Junior League yesterday.

W. Forbes Morgan, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, was elected president of the Distilled Spirits Institute yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria. Mr. Morgan will resign his

The seeming indifference of Norma Parker since her arrest before dawn last Monday in a Columbus Avenue restaurant hold-up vanished suddenly yesterday and she wept softly in the office of Louis J. Capizzoli, Assistant District Attorney, after being identified by her grandmother. her father and other relatives.

The Panama Railroad Company's ship Guayquil sailed late yesterday afternoon from Pier 65, North River, for Haiti, all members of her crew in possession of continuous discharge books as provided by the new Copeland Safetyat-Sea Act.

A basic forty-eight-hour working week, without reduction in weekly 'wages, has been adopted for the 219 building service workers employed at Teachers College, Columbia University, Dr. H. H. Linn, business manager of the college, announced yesterday.

Approval of the 1937 budget was held up here today because Mayor George B. Goodrich was busy making clam chowder. A hearing on the budget was set for 10 A. M. in the Borough Hall, but the Mayor did not show up.

As the first installment of its f1,500,000,000 rearmament program, the British Government tonight announced that it would embark almost immediately on the greatest and costli?st program of naval construction ever undertaken in time of peace.

Nine striking service-workers took possession of the furnace room of one of the largest apartment buildings in the Bronx yesterday. They sealed the cellar doors and windows of the building at 721 Walton Avenue, built a barricade of ashcans and turned a cold ear to the shouted complaints of tenants, already chilled by the lack of heat and hot water.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 15: COLONELS Wildrick, E. W. (F.A), General Staff Corps, Headquarters, Baltimore, Md., relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps.

With the selection of the jury completed yesterday afternoon, Judge Lester W. Patterson in the Bronx County Court put off the trial of six men for manslaughter in the second degree, arising from the building collapse in which eight een men were killed last June 19, until next Tuesday.
Nurses seeking the consecutive eight-hour day in all hospitals clashed today with representatives of hospitals at a public hearing by the Senate and Assembly Labor and Industry Committees.

The Senate passed today a series of Kleinfeld bills recommended by the Law Revision Commission, which would eliminate all special types of juries, leaving only the petit jury picked at random from a general panel.

Ignatius M. Wilkinson, dean of the Fordham University Law School, and former State Senator Thomas I. Sheridan of New York City have joined the opponents of President Roosevelt's plan for reorganizing the Supreme Court. Both are Democrats.
Regulation of the big jibs on the six-meter sloops reached a virtual mutual agreement stage yesterday for the international races to be held in Bermuda in April.

Everett Bacon, former winner of the Mid-Ocean golf tournament, today took a preliminary event for this year's tourney, which begins Thursday. Bacon turned in the low gross of 72 and the low net of 68 in a special handicap event.
Using two full teams, the St. Benedict's prep quintet of Newark overwhelmed St. Michael's High at Union City, N. J., last night, 45 to 21. The visitors held an advantage of 17-9 at half time.

Anthony J. Pugliese of 411 East 239th Street, Bronx, who retired Jan. 1 as Assistant Superintendent of Public Schools in the Bronx, died yesterday afternoon in the Mount Vernon Hospital, where he had been ill since November. He was 60 years old.

Dr. Albert W. Page, a medical practitioner of many years' standing in this city, who is accused by the defense in the poison trial of Chang Soo Lee as being partially responsible for the crippled condition of Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves, volunteered to "take his own medicine" in county court here today.

Mrs. Stephanie Robison, widow of the Rev. Dr. A. G. Robison, fell or leaped to her death this morning from the roof of the six-story apartment house at 15 Goldsmith Avenue, here, where she lived with her daughter, Hope, 15, according to police. She was 45 years old.

An unusually important meeting of the Fascist Grand Council will be held in Rome on the night of March 1 to examine among other things the Italian military situation in relation to the present troubled and dangerous phase of European politics.

The De Witt Clinton quintet clinched the Upper ManhattanBronx P. S. A. L. championship by halting James Monroe, 35 to 29, before a capacity crowd of 1,300 in the former's gymnasium yesterday. The triumph was the ninth in as many league engagements.

In the first six weeks of the year the death rate for the city was 12.9 per 1,000 population, as compared with 11.9 and 11.7 for the correspending periods of 1936 and 1935, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday in his weekly survey.
Solly Krieger, Brooklyn's candidate for the world's middleweight title, tonight at the Hippodrome starts the climb back to a position where he will merit consideration as a contender for the title.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won the award yesterday of a new issue of $750,000 of refunding bonds of Portland, Me., on a bid of 100.80 for the securities as 2 3/4s. The bonds will be dated March 1, 1937, and will mature on March 1, 1952. The bankers are reoffering the bonds today, at a price to yield 2.60 per cent for the issue to maturity.

John Barrymore, actor, filed in Federal court today a debtor's petition of bankruptcy under Section 74 of the National Bankruptcy Act. He stated that he was unable to meet his debts as they matured and desired to effect "composition or extension of time" to liquidate them.
Walton O. Wright, who rose from office boy to passenger traffic manager of the Boston Maine Railroad, died last night. He was 46 years old.

A public offering of $4,500,000 ten-year 3 1/2 per cent collateral trust notes of the Kresge Foundation is expected to be made tomorrow. or Friday by an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers, with whom are associated the. Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, Kidder, Peabody Co. and Watling, Lerchen Hayes of Detroit.

Bronislaw Huberman, the violinist and founder of the Palestine Symphony Orchestra, received a rousing tribute at a concert here tonight with the Concertgebouw, under the auspices of the Society for Art for All. The house was sold out last week.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, today received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from the University of Santo Domingo, whose rector, Dr. Manuel de Jesus Troncoso de la Concha, told Dr. Butler it was the oldest institution of learning in the New World. Dr. Butler, responding in cap and gown, acknowledged the honor conferred on him.

Any plan of slum clearance and housing construction for low income groups must be on the basis of outright Federal grant, speakers agreed last night at a meeting of the City-Wide Tenants Council at the Washington Irving High School.

President ROOSEVELT'S message to Congress yesterday will be of special interest to many readers in the light of the present controversy over the Supreme Court. The message deals with one of this country's larger economic problems: the evil of farm tenancy. As the President observes, we have reached a point at which two farmers in every five are tenants.

Former Adjt. Gen. Percy Haly, a prominent figure in Kentucky politics since the Beckham administration in 1900 and deputy provost marshal of the Louisville military district in the recent flood emergency, died here tonight. He was 65 years old.
Crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 3,286,050 barrels daily, a new high record, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
A tradition whereby the member introducing the 100th bill must pay the cost of a dinner for the entire group blocked the flow of new legislation in the State Senate today.

Stocks sluggish, closed mixed in heavier trading with copper shares strongest; turnover, 2,221,110 shares. United States Government issues lower, corporate and foreign bonds irregular; transactions, $15,023,100.

New York City's "expense" budget, calling for the expenditure of $637,000,000 in the present calendar year, went into effect last December. There is still to be considered the "capital outlay" budget. This is an innovation in New York's fiscal history. Last year the Mayor submitted the first capital outlay budget.

A story of how President Roosevelt invoked the aid of the Pan American Airways to get Rexford G. Tugwell, stranded in the Barbados Islands, to the bedside of his daughter, Miss Tanis Tugwell, ill of double pneumonia in the Medical Center, was revealed at the White House today.
Continued record small receipts of hogs here-the 18,000 of today being. the second smallest for a Tuesday since last October-turned the hog market upward to the extent of 5 cents a hundredweight.
Edwin Cruise, Mayor of this city, died of heart disease in New London Lodge of Elks tonight. He had just made a speech before the lodge, which was celebrating its fortieth anniversary.

Whether brain or brawn is the most desirable attribute of a fireman puzzled the Municipal Civil Service Commission so much yesterday that it called a public hearing for'2:30 o'clock next Tuesday afternoon to settle the whole thing.

Wells Olmsted, 78 years old, a retired wholesale cotton merchant who lived in his family homestead at 216 North Broadway, here, died last night of a fractured skull in Yonkers Professional Hospital several hours after being struck by a trolley car, according to police, while crossing the street. at Broadway and 251st Street,. the Bronx.
Two sales of properties in the Time Square district for cash featured a group of realty transactions reported for the midtown business section of Manhattan yesterday.

The Rev. Joseph R. Laird died of a heart attack last night at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Leona R. Passmore. He had been pastor of the Twenty-second Street Methodist Episcopal Church for the last year.

Plans for the expenditure of $1,000,000 to improve and expand the quarters of the New York Historical Society on Central Park West from Seventy-sixth to Seventy-seventh Street were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Department of Buildings.
President Roosevelt today signed an order putting the personnel of the Federal prison system, with the exception of four positions, under civil service.

Re-establishment of an international gold standard in the immediate future is doubtful, O. M. W. Sprague, former financial adviser to the Treasury Department and the Bank of England, said today in a speech on "Monetary Stabilization" before the Harvard Business School Alumni at the Harvard Club.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 13: COMMANDER Judy, A. S., Med. Corps, Philadelphia, Pa., to the Chaumont. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Baugh, H. V., Philadelphia, Pa., to home, relieved of all active duty June 29.

The Westchester County Bar Association went on record at a meeting tonight at the Roger Smith Hotel here in opposition to the President's Supreme Court plan and also against the bill now before the Legislature at Albany which would permit women to sit on juries in this State.

Several apartment house sales in the Bronx were reported yesterday. The five-story ninety-five-room new law walk-up at 790 East 158th Street, on a plot 50 by 100, was sold within a week after purchase by Max Rosenfeld to an investing client of Winick Barnett.

Liquidation by holders of wheat contracts developed today on the Board of Trade here and prices declined sharply, the May delivery leading. Closing trades were at net losses of 3/4 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel, the former on September, which was bought by commission houses on the continued dry weather in parts of the Winter Wheat Belt.

Long Island University defeated Catholic University, 51-36, at basketball last night but Hermie Schmarr of the Cardinals stole the show. He tallied 22 points, 18 of them in the second half and all on field goals.

John E. Sullivan of 559 Fiftyninth Street, Brooklyn, real estate developer of the Bay Ridge district, died yesterday in Victory Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of five weeks. He was 72 years old.
Mrs. A. Ramsey Wallace of Flushing, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy E. Wallace, to Richard Dudgeon Kohler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Kohler of Glen Cove, L. I.

Several deals in the Scarsdale section of Westchester were reported yesterday. Seven plots on Mount Joy Avenue were sold for Earl and Mildred Yaple to the Waare Construction Corporation, which plans to build seven houses there.

Columbia's fencing team won its fourth meet of the year last night by defeating Yale, 14-13, in the Lion gymnasium. The Light Blue built an 8-1 lead with the foils and won the epee tests, 5 to 4. Leading, 13 to 5, and needing only one saber bout to clinch victory, Columbia turned the trick when Bruce Wallis defeated Jerry Steinberg, 5-3.

Hitting his fifth century of the Marylebone Cricket Club's Australian 'tour, Charles Barnett staged a great effort for victory to his team in the third day's play of the match with New South Wales. At the close of play the Englishmen needed 125 runs to win with three wickets to fall.

Sixteen baseball games, two less than last year, will be played by the University of Pennsylvania this season, according to an announcement today. Twelve of the contests are with teams in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

The agreement framed yesterday providing the essentials for assurance of effective non-intervention in the Spanish situation was adopted today by the full international committee comprising, among others, Great Britain, France, Portugal, Germany, Italy and Russia.

The Federal court in Minneapolis has ordered that all income, rent, issues and profits, after expenses, of the Duluth, South Shore Atlantic Railway be impounded for the benefit of the company's mortgage trustees, the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday.

Further contributions have raised the total gifts to the flood relief fund of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross to $1,888,989, it was announced yesterday by General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the chapter.

The National Labor Relations Board's attempt to force the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation into a hearing to answer charges of unfair labor practices today met another defeat, this time at the hands of the Federal Circuit Court.

Dr. H. W. Oppice insists it is mostly imagination working in people when the dentist goes to work. To overcome it, Dr. Oppice, teacher in the dental department of Loyola University, said today at the Chicago Dental Society convention, that dentists were using 70 per cent psychology and 30 per cent technique.

EVEN those who have never had much interest in Mexico should enjoy reading two books published today. One is Gregorio Lopez y Fuentes's "El Indio" (Bobbs-Merrill, $2.50), a translation by Anita Brenner of the novel that won Mexico's first National Prize of Literature.

Bond prices continued to move irregularly lower in somewhat more active dealings on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. United States Government issues were uniformly weak and closed with losses of from 1-32 to 11-32 point, the largest decline being in the Treasury 4s of 1954-44.

Fresh from the farm, and strong with the air of an outdoor-trained horse, Light Moment led from end to end in the feature at Hialeah Park today to add another victory to the growing list of Miss Mary Hirsch. Mrs.

An offering of 18,946 shares of capital stock of the Union Wire Rope Corporation, Kansas City, Mo., priced at $15 a share, will be made today by P. W. Brooks Co., Inc. The stock is part of a total of 104,000 shares registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Reports of continued improvement in retail business along Fifth Avenue were received at the thirtieth annual meeting of the Fifth Avenue Association yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore.

All railroads serving the southern territory were notified today by the Interstate Commerce Commission that a public hearing would be held to investigate complaints of shippers, State and local commissions and traffic associations that the present rates are "unjust and unreasonable."

Miss Edmee Roberta Reisinger, daughter of Mrs. M. McKee Reisinger of this place, and of Curt H. Reisinger of New York, was married to Joseph Jenry Morsman Jr. of Chicago at noon today at the home of her grandfather, James Robert McKee on North Street.
Pope Pius walked with faltering steps today the half-dozen paces from his bed to his private chapel while watchful prelates beamed.

EL INDIO, by Gregorio Lopez y Fuentes. (Bobbs-Merrill, $2.50.) A prize-winning Mexican novel, illustrated by Diego Rivera. I WILL NOT REST, by Romain Rolland. (Liveright, $2.25.) Essays on a variety of subjects.

The Sumners bill to allow Supreme Court justices to retire at 70 at full pay was recommended for early passage by a Senate subcommittee today in the hope of its members, as well as many other Congress members, that it would lead to a solution of the controversy raised by President Roosevelt's plan to reform the Federal judiciary.

Mrs. Happie Bedford Ladew of 180 East Seventy-ninth Street and Bruce S. Lachlan Jr. of Brooklyn obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building. They will be married on Friday in the apartment at the Hotel Pierre of Mrs. Ladew's father, Charles E. Bedford.

Agreeing with President Roosevelt that "the judiciary is coming more and more to constitute a third house of the national Legislature," Walter F. Willcox, Cornell economist and statistician and professor emeritus, said today:
