The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:
Mrs. Mary T. Faleck Wister, daughter of Frederick McQ. Falck of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and of the late Mrs. Falck, will be married to George Harrison Frazier Jr. of Plymouth Meeting on Feb. 23.

Amelia Earhart received Mayor La Guardia's best wishes yesterday for a successful round-the-world flight when she called at City Hall to say good-bye before leaving on Thursday for the West Coast to complete her preparations.
The 1937 lake shipping season unofficially opened here today when the steamer E. E. Pope left for Dearborn, Mich., with a load of 3,200 tons of coal.

After trailing by four holes, coming off the fifth green, Miss Patty Berg, red-haired Minneapolis sensation, rallied to win her first-round match in the women's golf championship of Palm Beach at the Palm Beach Country Club today.

Gerald, Mrs. W. H. Furst's candidate for the $50,000 added Santa Anita Derby next Monday, won the $1,500 added Derby Trial today with Clingendaal second and Papenie third. Jockey Basil James, chalking up a double, booted Gerald to the front in a driving finish down the stretch.

Serious consequences continue as a result of King Carol's demand for the recall of foreign diplomats who participated Saturday in the Fascist Iron Guard's demonstration on the occasion of the funeral of two of its members who were killed while serving with General Francisco Franco's Insurgent forces in Spain.

Sir Rodmond Pelan Roblin. who for fifteen years headed a Conservative government in Manitoba, died suddenly tonight of a heart ailment in Hot Springs, Ark., where he had been vacationing. He observed his eighty-fourth birthday yesterday.
Steel ingot production advanced more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index rose to 113.8 from 113.3. It was 73.0 for the week ended Feb. 15, 1936.

Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin of Glen Head, L. I., and Providence, R. I., who has been at the Ambassador, will sail today on the Aquitania for a South American cruise. Her daughter, Mrs. Archer Jones Jr. is remaining at the hotel.
The Harvard Club gained the final of the Class C championship play-off in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League yesterday by routing the Montclair A. C., 4 to 1, at the Squash Club courts.

Maxie Berger, Bronx lightweight, who seems to improve with each succeeding contest, outpointed Phil Baker of Norwalk, Conn., last night in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx.

A settlement ending the sit-down strike of 130 employes of the Cotton Products Company was reached tonight. The company manufactures seat stuffing for General Motors. The strike began Dec. 30, the same day that strikers began occupation of two Fisher Body plants here. The plant will resume operations Thursday.

New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. "Books in 1937: Young Biographies," Lewis Gannett, 11 A. M.; "Russia in European Politics," Hans Simons, 4 P. M.; "Soviet Education," Goodwin Watson, 8:20 P. M.

An American Episcopal rector-the Rev. James De Wolf Perry Jr. of Norfolk, Va.-will serve as a chaplain at King George's coronation as a "gesture of friendliness" between Great Britain and the United States.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 15 unless specified: At San Clemente: Antares, Bridge, Holland. Houston, New York, Utah, Wyoming. At La Haina: Breese, Gamble, Montgomery, Ramsay. San Diego to Mare Island Yard: Bushnell, Ramapo.

George F. Vreeland, former postmaster of Far Rockaway, died Monday night at the Rockaway Beach Hospital after a lingering illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 230 Beach Eighty-fifth Street, Rockaway Beach.
The Legislature cleared the way today for obtaining the public's view on a proposal to legalize betting on horse races, a bill that may have the support of Governor Earle.
A special meeting of the stockholders of A. M. Castle Co. has been called for March 9 to approve an increase in the authorized common stock to 300,000 shares, from 120,000 shares of $10 par value.

President Roosevelt's plan to enlarge the Supreme Court was condemned tonight by voters of New Canaan, assembled in special town meeting. Embattled individualists-most of them commuters-met in the auditorium of the Junior High School, listened to speeches accusing the President of seeking dictatorial powers and then, without a dissenting vote, adopted a resolution of remonstrancee" against any tampering with the Supreme Court.

Rapidly advancing forest fires in the southern provinces of Chile have caused the government to adopt strict control measures in view of the danger to near-by towns. Thousands of tourists are leaving the towns on account of the intense heat and dense smoke, which completely covers the landscape in many regions.

In an answer filed yesterday in Federal court, Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers asked dismissal of the triple-damage suit for $1,350,000 brought against it by ten large manufacturers of electrical equipment who charged violation of the anti-trust law.

President Roosevelt sent to Congress the report of his Farm Tenancy Committee, issued an executive order putting the entire personnel of the Federal Prison System under Civil Service, discussed with Representative Mitchell the expulsion of Joseph Lee Johnson, a Negro, from the Naval Academy, and conferred, separately, with former Governor McNutt of Indiana and Fred I. Kent, New York banker.

The first man-made meteorite, containing within itself a reproduction of the "cosmic code" found in all natural meteorites, was described yesterday at the annual Winter meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirtyninth Street.
Fifteen. auction sales. of Manhattan real estate were held yesterday, of which thirteen were foreclosures and two for purposes of partition. The list follows:

Secretary Morgenthau announced today that bids are being sought for approximately $50,000,000 in Treasury bills to be sold on a discount basis to the highest bidder. The bills are for a period of' 273 days.

At the annual meeting of the American Gas and Electric Company yesterday stockholders ratified the re-election of five directors of the company and voted approval of all acts of the board of directors.

An entire floor, consisting of twelve rooms and five baths, has been leased in the cooperative apartment building at 2 East Eighty-eighth Street to George W. Whitaker, vice president of of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company. Pease Elliman, Inc., negotiated the lease through Douglas Gibbons Co.

The Intercoastal Steamship Freight Association announced yesterday that the rate on shingles shipped from the Northwest to Atlantic Coast terminals had been set at 70 cents for 100 pounds, an increase of 2 1/2 cents. This is the first move to strengthen the intercoastal rates and other increases are expected to be announced soon.

The Police Department ended one relief sit-down strike yesterday, but permitted another to continue without interference after an Emergency Relief Bureau administrator had declared that Mayor La Guardia had given instructions to permit the demonstrators to remain so long as they committed no overt act.

Net surplus of the Fire Association of Philadelphia rose $1,014,342 during 1936 and at the year-end stood at $9,800,058, the gain contrasting with $2,873,995 during 1935, according to a report made public yesterday.

A conditional gift of $275,000 to the University of Chicago by the Rosenwald Family Association was announced today by President Hutchins. To receive the money, the university must raise additionally not less than twice that amount.

Mrs. Sarah Althea Hill Terry, once the toast of San Francisco, may be buried in a plot at the Stockton State Hospital. Mrs. Terry, 87 years old and widow of David S. Terry, survivor of the famous Terry-Broderick duel, died of pneumonia on Sunday at the hospital, where she had been a patient for forty-five years.

The trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra today announced the acceptance of Tanglewood, the 210-acre LenoxStockbridge estate once occupied by Nathaniel Hawthorne, as a permanent site for the orchestra's annual Berkshire symphony festival. The site, off West Street, Lenox, is the gift of Mrs. Gorham Brooks and her aunt, Miss Mary Aspinwall Tappan, of Brookline.

Estate, less than $1,000. To Isabel V. Cook, widow, executrix, 35 Morton St., residue. DE BARGE, LILLIAN A. (Dec. 16). Estate, less than $5,000. To Herbert De Barge, son, executor, 555 E. 27th St., residue; one specific beauest.

The German press today acclaims Chancellor Adolf Hitler's decree for a new Protestant church election-overruling the plan for a new Stateimposed church government which Hanns Kerrl, Reich Minister for Church Affairs, announced last week-as a new contribution by the Fuehrer toward both domestic and world peace and as a gift of the highest magnanimity of which the church must now prove itself worthy.
Rudy Dusek, veteran from Omaha, last night threw Gino Garibaldi, Italian grappler, in 29 minutes 44 seconds of the feature finish event on the wrestling card at the St. Nicholas Palace.

The American boat, Twin Stars, sailed by L. M. Pirie of the Lake Michigan fleet, today won the Cup of Cuba in the eleventh International Star Class yacht series with a total of 23 points. She crossed the finish line in second place in the final race of three this morning.

Although generally quiet, the stock- market here today was firmer than it has been In the last few days. Gilt-edge issues continued to act uncertainly, but closed slightly higher. Among the foreign bonds, German and Japanese securities showed to advantage.

The pamphlet report of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $1,071,828, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.76 each on 548,679 common shares of $3 par value. compared with $419,043, or $3.60 each on 96,883 outstanding no-par common shares after annual preferred dividend requirements, earned in 1935.
Two sales of apartment houses on the upper West Side of Manhattan were announced yesterday. Property on the lower East Side also figured in several deals. Banks figured as sellers of several parcels.

Net profit of the B. F. Goodrich Company for 1936 amounted to $7,319,507 after depreciation, interest, provision for Federal income and undistributed-profits taxes and all other charges. The profit is equal to $4.03 a common share after provision for preferred-stock dividends and it compares with $3,429,781, or $1.18 a common share, earned in 1935. Consolidated net sales of $141,097,136 were 17.6 per cent larger than those of 1935.

The defeat of Pehr Evind Svinhufvud as Presiident of Finland in yesterday's Electoral College vote and the election of Premier Kyosti Kallio as President were received with gratification here. The newspaper Izvestia, organ of the Soviet Government, writes:
The new King is learning. It might even be said that he is patterning himself on the ways whereby the former Edward VIII, his brother, achieved popularity.

Seven of the eight seeded players in the Union League Club's third annual invitation Class B squash racquets tournament came safely through their third-round tests yesterday to gain the quarter-finals.

Trade statistics for the first six months of the fiscal year are expected to show a profound change in commerce with the United States. It is believed the balance, hitherto heavily adverse, will favor Australia.

A verbal whirlwind stirred the Senate today as its members heard what was probably the last of Senator McNaboe's committee to investigate the alleged spread of communism in public schools and colleges.

President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge -the Supreme Court is attacked in the current issue of America, a Catholic weekly, both in an editorial and in an article by the Rev. Paul L. Blakely, S. J., as destroying the independence of the judiciary and tending toward the establishment of a dictatorship.

The latest attempt to allow Bermuda women to take some part in the government of this colony was defeated today when the House of Assembly, by 15 votes to 13, refused to pass the Parochial Woman's Franchise Bill on the second reading.

A plan to raise at least $1,000,000, in memory of the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, Presbyterian Fundamentalist leader, for buildings and endowment for Westminster Theological Seminary in this city was announced today following an organization meeting of the Machen memorial fund committee.

Lord Davies, British banker, former member of Parliament and founder of the New Commonwealth and International Society and Institute which advocates the maintenance of peace through an international tribunal backed up by military force, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

Mme. Barbara von Meck and Mrs. Catherine Drinker Bowen, authors of the book "Beloved Friend," the story of Tchaikovsky and Nadejda von Meck, will be guests of honor tonight at the home of Mr. and Mrs. S. L. M. Barlow.

Rolling up thirty-nine points in the second half, Bishop Loughlin's basketball team routed the Dwight School five, 57 to 18, on the court of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday. John Flanagan led the onslaught of the Brooklynites with 14 points.

Dr. Duncan Starr Johnson, Professor of Botany and director of the botany laboratory at Johns Hopkins University, died today. He was 69 years old. He had been a member of the Johns Hopkins faculty since 1898.

Benjamin O. Eggleston, portrait and landscape painter, formerly president of the Brooklyn Society of Artists, died yesterday at his home, 164 East Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn, in his seventyfirst year. A sister, Anna C. Eggleston, survives.

SERGEANT-Francis X. Wilde, from 104th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Queens County, for 1 day. PATROLMEN--Fred H. Winkelman, from 28th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 5 days. Walter A. Samwells, from 60th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Kings County, for 2 days.

A concerted effort to break up the American Committee for the Defense of Leon Trotsky by those who oppose the committee's program for an impartial investigation of the recent Moscow trials, involving Trotsky in treasonable and counter-revolutionary activities, was disclosed yesterday by Professor John Dewey and a group of other prominent liberals associated with the committee.
Final solution of the church question in the State of Veracruz, where Catholics forcibly opened the churches in many towns last week, is expected within a few days.

Bridge enthusiasts prepared today for two successive week-ends of competition, with announcement that Midwest national championships of the United States Bridge Association would be held here on Feb. 20 and 21, and on Feb. 26, 27 and 28.
With the arrest of five youths after a hold-up in the Bronx last night, the police believed they had the band that had committed about sixty robberies in the East Bronx in the last six weeks.

Beach Av., 536, 25x100: Dorothy A. Baker against Dorothy A. Stoedter; due $5,837; taxes, ,. $167; to plaintiff for $500. Hunts Point Av,, 867, 4-story tenement, 39x100; Dollar Savings Bank against 819 Hunts Point Av. Co.; due, $19,892; taxes, , $369: to plaintiff for $16,500.

Joe Louis, suffering from loss of prestige as the result of his failure to knock out Bob Pastor, will fight Natie Brown in a scheduled tenround bout tomorrow night. Louis is a prohibitive favorite to stop his rival, although Brown stayed ten rounds with the Brown Bomber in 1935.

Some 28,500 airplanes and nearly $1,000,000,000 worth of aircraft and equipment will be built and purchased by the countries of the world in 1937, according to an estimate made public by Vincent Bendix, American automotive manufacturer.

A revision of the wage scales of officers of Colombian Line ships was announced last night after a conference between officials of the line and the United Licensed Officers Association. Increases ranging from $4 to $35 a month are provided, effective immediately.

The report of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries for 1936 shows a net income of $20,240,020 after all deductions, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $8.49 a share earned on 1,806,000 common shares compared to $16,744,874, or $6.55 a share, in 1935.

A suit for recovery of $215,730, allegedly lost by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in publishing The Engineering Index, was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday when the plaintiffs moved for appointment of a temporary receiver for The Engineering Index, Inc., a separate corporation which has published the index since 1934.
Even men who sought to assassinate Premier Benito Mussolini enjoyed the benefits tonight of an amnesty act in celebration of the birth of a prospective heir to the Italian throne.

Eleven persons were slightly injured last night on the Cross Bay Boulevard near Howard Beach, Queens, in two collisions, the first involving two cars and the second four. The two automobiles that figured in the first crash also were struck in the second.

Saverio Turiello, 140 1/2, Italy, defeated Joe Pennino, 146, South Brooklyn, in the main ten-round bout before 3,000 persons at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Left hooks and effective rights to the jaw and body earned the decision.

The Boston Bruins overcame their home ice jinx and pulled into a second-place tie with the New York Rangers in the American group of the National Hockey League by defeating Lester Patrick's speedy stickmen, 3-2, tonight before a crowd of 12,000 at the Garden.

By an overwhelming vote today sit-down strikers in the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation's plants agreed to evacuate. The agreement stated that all employes would return to their usual work tomorrow morning and there would be no discrimination against any employes for membership in any labor organization.

Directors of the Utah-Apex Mining Company yesterday called a special meeting of stockholders for March 12 to consider consolidation of that company with the UtahDelaware Mining Company, a subsidiary of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company.

A brisk wind blowing in from the Gulf made things difficult for the contestants in the first round of the Belleair Country Club golf championship, but the three low scorers in yesterday's qualifying round continued to play well today.
Robert A. Duncan is with Cartwright Parmelee. Arthur I. Korn Co. have been elected to associate membership on the Real Estate Board of New York.

Because of the city's policy in limiting pushcart licenses, which was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Hallinan in Brooklyn, a family in that borough that has managed for some years to eke out a precarious living is now faced with the necessity of seeking home relief, it was said.

Schenectady's two curling rinks won the finals in the Gordon National and Emmet Medal tournaments today. Utica, defending the Gordon Medal, lost to Schenectady, skipped by Charles L. Hequembourg, 23 to 7. Another Utica team led by 16 to 10 in the seventeenth and final end for the Emmet Medal when James C. Parker, skip for Schenectady, made a brilliant toss to give his curlers an 18-to-16 victory.
Robert A. Duncan is with Cartwright Parmelee. Arthur I. Korn Co. have been elected to associate membership on the Real Estate Board of New York.

Because of the city's policy in limiting pushcart licenses, which was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Hallinan in Brooklyn, a family in that borough that has managed for some years to eke out a precarious living is now faced with the necessity of seeking home relief, it was said.

Schenectady's two curling rinks won the finals in the Gordon National and Emmet Medal tournaments today. Utica, defending the Gordon Medal, lost to Schenectady, skipped by Charles L. Hequembourg, 23 to 7. Another Utica team led by 16 to 10 in the seventeenth and final end for the Emmet Medal when James C. Parker, skip for Schenectady, made a brilliant toss to give his curlers an 18-to-16 victory.

Retail executives here, commenting yesterday on the statement issued on Monday by Congressman Emanuel Celler on the Miller-Tydings Resale Price Maintenance Bill, declared "his attack on resale price fixing was well founded," but that he had not given sufficient weight to the difference between "loss leaders and the fixing of retailers' margins by manufacturers."

James T. Costigan, in his letter printed in your issue of Feb. 9, raises a very natural question in regard to the element of chance under proportional representation. The answer is, first, that the element of chance is much less than is commonly supposed, and second, that it corresponds to a much more serious arbitrary element in the Aldermanic district system, which the "P. R." plan has replaced.

Ramona Davies, pianist and concert singer, whose stage name is simply Ramona, lost yesterday her application in Supreme Court to prevent Paul Whiteman, orchestra leader, from enforcing a contract for her exclusive services.

Mrs. Robert Morris Phillips gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Charles X. Cordier, Mrs. Charles Pfizer, Mrs. Hamilton Lamar, Mrs. Howard Chandler Christy, Mrs. Flora Terry, Mrs. Richard H. Swartwout, Mrs. Joseph B. Long and Miss Carolyn Riley.

There was deposited on Jan. 31 25.1 per cent of the $4,400,000 outstanding Ogdensburg Lake Champlain Railway first 4 per cent bonds due in 1948, under a plan proposed by the Rutland Railroad for a reduction in its interest payments, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia and other city officials endorsed yesterday the United Parents Association appeal for public support in a campaign for $18,000 to expand its services. The message of the Mayor and others urging public cooperation were read at a luncheon in the Town Hall Club, where campaign plans were outlined. Mrs. Henry S.

Two one-man shows sharply divrergent with respect to what may be termed the painter's philosophy have just become current in New York. Walt Kuhn, the well-known American artist, is making his first solo appearance in three years at the Marie harriman Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street,

20th St., 332 W., 18.7x92; Edward B. O'Hara to himself and wife, .332 W. 20th St. 20th St., 239 W., 26.8x74.3; John Hughes to Chelsea Apartments, Inc., 39 W. 19th St.: consideration. $5,000, foreclosure. 76th St. 171 W., 20x102.2; Savings Banks Trust Co. to Amherst Studios, Inc., 2,880 Broadway; consideration, $22,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Beaver Strassburger gave a dinner tonight at Seven Oaks in celebration of the birthday of Mrs. John Dewar of London. Other guests included Lady Burney, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Grafton Mortimer, Mr. and Mrs. Winston Guest,

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading was fair to slow. A light supply of strictly choice and prime steer hinds and ribs was held at firm prices but short-feds grading only good were lower.

The Joint Congressional Committee on Governmental Reorganization took its first definite action on President Roosevelt's reorganization plan today when it eliminated the proposal to increase the salaries of Cabinet officers and bureau heads.
Mrs. Roosevelt stole the show at the President's press conference today and brought laughter from the President and the assembled reporters.

The realization of scientists that "the proper study of mankind is man," after centuries of preoccupation with the physical world, marks a turning point in human history, Dr. Max Mason of Pasadena, former president of the University of Chicago, told several hundred doctors here today.
The Public Service Commission reported today an elimination of--$100,000,000 of fixed capital through mergers of New York State utilities in the last eighteen months.

The Georgia Senate adopted unanimously today a bill which would prohibitcourts from forcing a newspaper reporter or editor to divulge the source of confidential information. Efforts to stop transmission of the measure to the House failed.

The Georgia Senate adopted unanimously today a bill which would prohibitcourts from forcing a newspaper reporter or editor to divulge the source of confidential information. Efforts to stop transmission of the measure to the House failed.
Governor Lehman commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentences of Henry H. Stevens, 19, and Charles A. Waterbury, 20, convicted murderers slated to die Thursday night in Sing Sing prison.

Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, German War Minister, receiving fifty-one former service men from fourteen nations at a luncheon today, hailed with enthusiasm the formation of the International Veterans' Congress and greeted the delegates as "comrades."

A plan to reorganize the Prudence Company, Inc., was filed yesterday in the office of the clerk of the United States District Court in Brooklyn. Its submission was approved by the board of directors of the debtor company at a meeting held on Feb. 8.

The capture of the capital of the Department of Yoro is claimed by Honduran rebels. Government troops were said to have been defeated by revolutionaries under Colonel David Tablada, long an opponent of President Tiburcio Carias Andino. The government wounded were flown to Tegucigalpa.

Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, arrived here this morning, accompanied by several officials and German secret police. He was met at the station by the German Ambassador, Hans Adolf von Moltke, and Polish Foreign Office officials.
Stars of yesteryear, together with some of those that still twinkle in the squash tennis world, cavorted on the Yale Club courts yesterday as the national veterans championship got under way.

A gain of 60 per cent in the sales of champagne, both domestic and imported, was registered in this State in the last seven months compared to the corresponding period the year before, according to an announcement yesterday by Judge J. Howard Proper, general counsel, and W. Z. Fuller, secretary of the American Champagne Guild.

Francine Larrimore, who is not unknown to theatregoers, makes her screen debut this morning at the Paramount as Edward Arnold's leading lady in "John Meade's Woman." Others in the film are Gail Patrick, George Bancroft, Sidney Blackmer and Aileen Pringle.
THIS must be middleweight week in the boxing almanac. Marcel Thil and Lou Brouillard had their little meeting in Paris the other evening.

The Packard Motor Car Company shipped 52,186 cars from Sept. 1, 1936, when the 1937 models were started, to Feb. 1. last. against 27,906 in the same period a year before, an increase of 87 per cent, M. M. Gilman, vice president and general manager, announced yesterday.

The Coast Guard cutter Tallapoosa late today rescued seven passengers and most of the crew of twenty of the motorship Zapora, marooned at Angoon, an Indian village on Admiralty Island, when the ship grounded and foundered in a snowstorm Sunday.

George F. Swezey, East Patchogue's mail messenger for the last forty years and widely known because of the tricycle he rode in his work, died early today at Community Hospital, Patchogue, of injuries suffered last night when he was run down by a hit-run driver.

St. Joseph's College, after trailing for most of the game, defeated the La Salle five at the Palestra tonight, 28 to 25, in an extra period. A crowd of 3,500 saw the Hawks down the Explorers for the second time this season.
On a money basis French trade showed a marked rise during January, according to official figures published today, but the increase for the most part resulted from imports.
After a day of interpellations in which the army had been insidiously and effectively grilled, General Gen Sugiyama, the War Minister, conferred with his advisers at the War Office yesterday evening.

The Public Service Commission has authorized the Philadelphia Electric Company to borrow $37,000,000 from banks and trust companies in Pennsylvania and New York on notes dated March 31, 1937, maturing on April 1,- 1938, and bearing interest at 1 1/2 per cent a year.

Abraham Rosenthal, Greater New York representative of several knitwear firms and treasurer of the Daniel Webster Lodge of the Free Sons of Israel, died on Monday night. Mr. Rosenthal, who was 58 years old, suffered a heart attack while waiting for a train in the Hudson Terminal in Jersey City.
Three places in the quarter-final bracket of the. singles championship of Group 2 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association were filled at the City Athletic Club yesterday.

Once again the Insurgents appear to have been stopped in their effort to cut the road to Valencia. This correspondent has just returned from another trip to the Arganda and Jarama River front, where the situation was found much as it had been a week ago.

Mrs. Mary Louise Fake, mother of Federal Court Judge Guy L. Fake, died here today at her home. She was 80 years old. Born in Middleburg, N. Y., Mrs. Fake was a descendant of Pilgrim Cook, who came to this country on the Mayflower.

Three leading distilling companies subscribed yesterday to a total of $750,000 of the 4 per cent debentures of the New York World's Fair for 1939, according to an announcement by Richard Whitney, chairman of the sales committee for the debentures.

Directors of the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1.75 a share for the first quarter of 1937. In 1936 the company paid three dividends of $1.50 each and a year-end dividend of $2 a share.

By the narrow margin of four votes, the Board of Aldermen defeated an ordinance yesterday which would have limited taxicab licenses to the number now outstanding. Eleven Aldermen were recorded as not voting on the ordinance while seven voted against it.

The United Automobile Workers of America prepared tonight to submit to General Motors officials a plan for arbitration boards to settle grievances of union employes in the corporation's automotive plants.

President Roosevelt has ordered an investigation of the circumstances surrounding the forced resignation from the Naval Academy Saturday of James. L. Johnson Jr. of Washington, the only Negro to enter the academy in sixty-two years.

The Bide-a-Wee Home for Animals, of which Mrs. Harry Ulysses Kibbe is president and founder, was the beneficiary of a fashion shown known as the "Park Avenue Parade," held yesterday during the luncheon hour in the Caprice Room at the Weylin.

JUNIOR BILLING-BOOKKEEPING MACRINE OPERATOR, $1,440 a Year-Appltcations must be on file not later than March 8 if received from States other than those named below; March 11 if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming. Competitors will be rated on the following subjects: Clerical tests 30,

Paul F. Williams, leader in S. P. C. A. work, died at his home here today after a long illness, at the age of 67. He had been engaged in the real estate business for many years. He had served as president of the local chapter of the S. P. C. A. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Etta Manning Plumley Williams;
Herbert Wellington, treasurer of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, died on Sunday in the Germantown Hospital, Philadelphia, after a short illness. He was in his sixtysixth year.

Warned that the Canadian Western Provinces of Manitoba and Saskatchewan were ready to follow the example of Alberta and cut the interest rate on their obligations, the Dominion Government announced today that it would come to their rescue.
Foreign exchanges were uniformly firm against the dollar yesterday, although there was no further sharp rise like that of the Netherlands guilder on Monday.

The United Automobile Workers of America prepared tonight to submit to General Motors officials a plan for arbitration boards to settle grievances of union employes in the corporation's automotive plants.

President Roosevelt has ordered an investigation of the circumstances surrounding the forced resignation from the Naval Academy Saturday of James. L. Johnson Jr. of Washington, the only Negro to enter the academy in sixty-two years.

L. Earle Rowe, director of the Museuni of the Rhode Island School of Design, and nationally known for his work in art education and archaeology, died today. He was 54, years old. He had been associated with the school for twentyfour years.
Three Utica rinks were victorious today in Allen Cup and Mitchell Medal matches as the Grand National Curling Club opened its three-day competition at the Utica Curling Club.

Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, said today that an agreement reached between the United States and Japanese textile industries made unnecessary Congressional action for furtheir restriction of Japanese cotton piece goods exports to this country.

The life of the Desmond resolution, calling upon the State's members of Congress to oppose President Roosevelt's judiciary reform proposal, has been prolonged beyond what appeared likely twenty-four hours ago, but there is no probability that the death sentence passed upon the resolution by the Democrats in the Senate will be revoked.

Dr. Norman Bethune of Montreal tonight described the flight of 150,000 men, women and children from Malaga as "the most terrible evacnation of a city in modern times." [Malaga, southern Spanish seaport, was captured Feb. 8 by the Insurgents in the Spanish civil war.]
Members of the Supreme Court of Nicaragua must work regular hours, the same as other government employes, it was announced today by Dr. Jeronimo Ramirez Brown, Minister of Government.

A banking group composed of Salomon Bros. Hutzler, Dick Merle-Smith and Stroud Co., Inc., will offer today two new issues of railway equipment-trust certificates. An issue of $2,330,000 New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad

Offering of 93,000 shares of common stock of $5 par value of the Carpenter Steel Company wil! be made today by a banking group headed by F. S. Moseley Co., and including White, Weld Co., Goldman, Sacks Co., Hemphill, Noyes Co., Kidder, Peabody Co., and H. M. Byllesby Co., Inc.
A school for poets has been started by the League of American Writers, 125 East Twenty-fourth Street, with Genevieve Taggard and Rolfe Humphries in charge of instruction.
Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday the transfer of eight assistants from and to various churches as follows:

Army took a close game from Syracuse today, winning, 38 to 37, in one of the most exciting basketball games played here this season. It was the final home game for the Cadets, who will meet Navy in Annapolis on Saturday.
A sandstorm forced the flying Lindberghs, Charles and Anne, to an emergency landing today at a Syrian desert oasis, tardy but safe on their jaunt to the Near East from Cairo, Egypt.
The Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute basketball team downed Cathedral College, 46-25, at the winner's court last night. Poly led at the half by 16-10.

Paul Graetz, German film actor, died at his home here yesterday after suffering a stroke Sunday afternoon. He had been in ill health for several months. His age was 47. Mr. Graetz came to Hollywood from New York a year ago to play minor roles. He previously had
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, accompanied by Mrs. Henry Morgenthau, arrived tonight by motor to participate in tomorrow's program at Cornell University's thirtieth annual farm and home week.
Rumors of a shift in the Blum Cabinet that spread from Parliament today and even affected trading on the Bourse were squelched tonight by a bulletin from the Ministry of the Interior.

Milton Speiser, 48 years old, of 300 Central Park West, senior member of the firm of Speiser Speiser at 29 Broadway, which had the largest accident law practice in the country, was sentenced to six months in the work house yesterday by Justices Salomon, Bayes and Kozicke in the Extraordinary Term of Special Sessions.

GUYMON, Okla., Feb. 17.--Swirling dust clouds, bringing threats to crops and health, turned day into night in parts of Oklahoma today, while wind-blown top soil spread its haze over parts of Kansas, Texas and Colorado.

Mr. JOHN L. LEWIS came to town yesterday to state his views on another important labor question. This time his own union, the United Mine Workers, is directly involved. Its present contract with the bituminous coal operators expires on March 31.

Blair Academy routed Poly Prep, 35-17, on the loser's court in Brooklyn yesterday and moved into third place in the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League with a record of five victories and three defeats. It was the seventh straight setback for Poly Prep in the circuit.

A high authority reported today that Japanese interests have opened a drive for at least a $1,000,000 share in the Cuban textile market. Cuba at present is the market for $8,000,000 worth of United States textiles a year.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee reached virtual agreement today on a form of neutrality bill to present to the Senate to replace the existing law, which expires on April 30, it was indicated by Chairman Key Pittman of Nevada after the committee's ,executive session.

The Was Department released the following orders today, dated Feb. 16: COLONELS Ramsey, N. F., Ordnance Dept., Washington, D. C., to Rock Island Arsenal, Ill., June 28. Dent. E. J., Engrs., Baltimore, Md., orders to Panama revoked.
Plans for an addition to the New Rochelle Hospital costing $400,000 were approved by the intitution's building committee and medical board at a dinner tonight at the Westchester Biltmore Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--Two resolutions proposing constitutional amendments for limitations on the Supreme Court, one providing a formula for the overriding by Congress of adverse decisions and the other requiring retirement of justices at the age of 75 years, were introduced in the Senate today in the new general search for a way out of the controversy over President Roosevelt's demands for a change in the nation's tribunal of last resort.

Mrs. William Fellowes Morgan of 510 Park Avenue will give a tea at her home this afternoon for Mrs. William Henry Hays, chairman of the 1937 campaign committee of the Y. W. C. A. of the City of New York, and women who served as campaign team captains and majors. They include:

Officers and directors were reelected and routine business transacted yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Kennel Club held at the club offices. A number of amendments to the by-laws met with approval, while proposed amendments to the rules never came before the meeting.

Harper Sibley, president of the United States Chamberof Commerce, said labor leaders should be "held responsible for their acts as fully as management is today." Mr. Sibley, in an address to the Milwaukee Association of Commerce last night, characterized the sit-down strike as an adaptation of the forceful methods used in Europe for political ends.
In such a debate as that beginning over the President's judiciary reform proposals it is inevitable that the official ancestors of public men of today will be copiously invoked and quoted.

The home of the late George de Gumoens, on Moriches Bay, Basket Neck, Remsenburg, L. I., a halftimbered stucco dwelling and several outbuildings have been sold to a purchaser for occupancy. The property adjoins the homes of Dr. John J. Westerman, Dr. Louis L. Licht, Louis Dean Speir and Mrs. Charles Remsen.

Harry Joe Gregory, who was born in England and served his country in the Boer War, learned yesterday that he is to be one of the first recipients in the New York area of a lump-sum payment under the Social Security Act.
Yale's swimming team continued on its winning way today, the Elis scoring their 158th straight voctory by defeating the Army mermen, 44 to 31.

The press announces today that the height standards for conscripts are to be reduced in order to increase the number available for active service. The standard for the first class will be reduced from 5 feet 4 inches to 5 feet 2 1/2 inches, and the minimum from 5 feet 1/2 inch to 4 feet 10 1/2 inches.

Edward Arnold, the screen's best known lumber tycoon, plays fast and loose with the honest love of a little country girl-Francine Larrimore is the guilty person-and pays for it by being shot, fatally we trust, by a drought-stricken farmer, thereby bringing to a welcome halt one of the most fantqstic melodramas of the season.
Fanny Todd Mitchell Leonidoff, playwright and scenario writer, is back in Reno for another divorce suit against Leon Leonidoff, ballet master, of New York City.
A sigh was B. B. Gardner's reaction today to the news that once again he is acclaimed the country's biggest policeman. He has been trying hard not to be.

ACADEMY AWNING AND BLIND CO., 3,602 Park Av., by the Astrup Co., for $2,523; Abraham Goldberg, $41; Denemark Morris, Inc., S95. LIONEL FROCKS, Inc., 264 W. 35th St., by Textile Banking Co., Inc., for $200; Crompton-Richmond Co., Inc., $200; Mendelson, Fiering Horowitz, $200.

Apartments, business properties and apartment sites figured in deals reported in the Bronx yesterday. A house at 2,174 Davidson Avenue, corner of Clinton Place, was sold by the Clinton Molding Corporation to the Sam Ber Properties, Inc. The house is on a plot 100 by 60 feet and accommodates thirty families.
Harvard, never in any danger, defeated Boston University at the Garden tonight for its nineteenth consecutive victory and its twelfth this season, winning, 9-3.

BY WILLIAM KENNELLY. 109th St., 226-26 W;,6-story flat, 50x 100.11:: Broadway Savings Bank against Rose Fallek; due, $95,595; to plaintiff for $25,000. BY HENRY BRADY 4th St., 376 E., 6-story tenement and store, 28x96; Dry Dock savings Institution against Jo holding Corp.: due, $28,535, taxes, , $193; to plaintiff for $1,000.

The effect of the expiration of the emergency freight surcharges at the end of 1936 on railroad earnings, as reflected in reports issued yesterday, was obscured by other factors. While the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad reported increased returns, the Chesapeake Ohio's earnings were adversely affected by the Ohio River floods.

Good Omen from Miss L. C. White's stable showed an unusual burst of speed in the stretch today with the result that she created something of a surprise in winning the fiveand-a-half furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

Ten workmen on the huge Golden Gate Bridge plunged 200 feet to their deaths in the waters below today in a spectacular accident resulting from the collapse of a scaffolding previously declared unsafe.

Henry Richard Woebse of 187 Montague Place, a master in chancery in the New Jersey Court of Chancery and an examiner for the New Jersey Supreme Court, died of a heart attack yesterday in Union Township, N. J. He was seated at the wheel of his parked automobile when stricken. Mr.

The United States Government is expected to permit the Texas Corporation to transfer $37,117,532 of excess depreciation reserves to earned surplus account, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Of this sum $1,173,328 was recorded in 1935 and $35,944,204 in 1936.
A "Ga Ga," exhibition for the benefit of the Girls Vacation Fund was opened yesterday afternoon at Cafe Continental, 10 East Fifty-second Street, where it will continue today and tomorrow.

The publicity accorded the diplomatic conflict between the Rumanian Government and the envoys of Germany, Italy, Portugal and Japan has greatly distressed Germanophile circles here which seek to minimize the incident.

The Navy Ministry invited reserves and retired naval officers tonight to serve as shipping inspectors for the international "hands-off-Spain" committee in its efforts to localize the Spanish civil war.

Whoel sale trade in the United States for the year 1936 reached a value of $52,070,000,000, as compared with $44,463,000,000 for the preceding year, Secretary Roper announced today. This was an increase of 17 per cent.

St. Paul's Congregational Church, Sterling Place and New York Avenue, Brooklyn, established by the late Dr. S. Parkes Cadman more than thirty years ago, is negotiating for a merger with its mother parish, Central Congregational Church, Hancock Place near Franklin Avenue, it was learned yesterday.

The Mississippi's flood crest curled around river bends just above Natchez today and engineers reported preparations to keep' it moving "satisfactorily." R. T. Lindley, weather forecaster, said there was a fall of a tenth of a foot here, and expressed belief that the crest had definitely passed here and had practically reached Natchez, high bluff city secure from overflow.

Retirement of Supreme and Circuit judges of Wisconsin at the age of 70 was proposed to the State Legislature today by Governor La Follette in an administration bill. The judges specified would have to retire at 70 to become eligible for pensions of half-pay for life.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS -- Francis X. Murphy, from 42d Precinct to 19th Division, Office of the Chief Inspector, assignment to desk duty discontinued. Peter J. Kelly, from 19th Division, Office of the Chief Inspector, to 16th Division, assigned to desk duty.
Crippled by the lose of Captain Kennedy, Brown University bowed to Yale at basketball, 66--25, tonight. Yale's total was its highest in several years.

With Captain Don Curtin and Paul Shea showing the way, Manhattan's varsity swimming team downed the Lafayette natators, 44-25, in the Park Central Pool last night. The Jaspers took six of the eight first places in registering their second victory in five starts this season.

An improved flock of Black Hawks, Chicago's representatives in the National Hockey League, will skate in Madison Square Garden tonight against the blue-shirted New York Rangers, fighting to hold their place in the American Division.

These orders were issued on the Second Corps Area: 1st Lt. Abraham S. Zucker, Dent.-Res., 295 E. 7th St., New York, N. Y., General Hospital 205 (RAI), is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective Feb. 17. He will proceed to Headquarters Binghamton District, CCC, Binghamton, N. Y., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Lieutenant Zucker will rank from Feb. 17 1937.

Coach Pete Waters has selected Captain Matt Carey, Val Riordan, Dick Lundell and Howard Borck to defend Manhattan's metropolitan one-mile relay crown against N. Y. U., Columbia, Fordham and St. John's at the New York A. C. meet in Madison Square Garden Saturday.
Clarence R. Strohm, vice president of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company, died last night of a heart attack in his office on the twelfth floor of 1 Park Avenue. He was 46 years old.

Roswell Magill, who was named Under-Secretary of the Treasury by President Roosevelt on Jan. 22 to succeed Thomas Jefferson Coolidge, has received a special leave of absence from Columbia University, where he is a Professor of Law, for the academic year 1937-38.

The Finanoe Ministry denied tonight that it was responsible for the chaotic condition of the Santos Coffee Exchange which forced it to close for forty-eight hours. It placed all responsibility on the Sao Paulo Coffee Institute.

A few days ago there was unveiled on the outer wall of a museum at Hancock, England, on the Great North Road, immediately after leaving Newcastle, a tablet in tribute to the memory of Lord GREY, as he is known to us in America. It bears the inscription:

William H. O'Dell Jr. is with Lord, Abbett Co., Inc. James C. Whelen is with Morris Mather Co., Inc. Norbert W. Smith is with F. J. Rabe Co. August J. Schneider has been made assistant cashier of Roosevelt Savings Bank.

Officers of the United Automobile Workers of America must appear before Circuit Judge Paul V. Gadola and "apologize for their contemptuous actions" before he will dismiss the writs of attachment against them and the former Fisher sit-down strikers, he declared today.

George Hassell, former figure in Broadway operettas, died today en route to a motion picture location. In a car with several other players, he left the Twentieth Century Fox lot apparently in good health.

The decline in average middling spot quotations a point below 12.75 cents a pound, the theoretical figure for releasing collateral held in government loans, stimulated buying by mills on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices at one time were 10 points higher.

The Hon. Caryl Baring, brother of Lord Ashburton, has left the Pierre, accompanied by his daughter, Miss Leonora Baring, for Mexico City, D. F. They will return here on March 15 to join Lord and Lady Ashburton, who are now in La Quinta, Calif.
Stevens Institute won its fifth straight basketball game tonight, scoring a 29-26 victory over Haverford. Long shots by Dimasi and Verdee proved decisive.

Colonel Raymond F. Metcalfe, chief of the Surgical Service at Walter Reed General Hospital, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be assistant surgeon general of the army with the rank of brigadier general for a four-year period, beginning March 1.

With only one more match to be played, the New York Athletic Club yesterday maintained its place at the head of the list of teams competing for honors in Class A of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association.
Once more the great outdoors will be moved indoors for the benefit of observing city folk when the National Sportsmen's Show opens at Grand Central Palace today.

Twelve of the country's largest corporations keep acquainted with each other's problems through monthly meetings of a special conference committee, composed of employment managers, personnel directors and other officers who deal with labor conditions, the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage and the right of collective bargaining was told today by General Motors Corporation witnesses.

Detective Dominick Pape of the East Twenty-second Street station was acquitted by a General Sessions jury yesterday at his trial on a charge he and two other men, fugitives, stole $750 in jewelry on Feb. 18, 1936, from Max D. Federbush, a loose-leaf manufacturer at 91 Seventh Avenue. The jury deliberated on the evidence three hours.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Tasha Burgess, daughter of Mrs. Rosamond Tudor Burgess of this city and W. Starling Burgess of Wiscasset, Me., to Thomas Leighton McCready Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Leighton McCready of New York and Redding, Conn.
Dr. Meyer Jacobstein died yesterday at his residence, 901 Walton Avenue, Bronx, of heart disease after an illness of five days, at the age of 65.

Members of the National Coat and suit Industrial Recovery Board will be asked to forward samples of new materials for testing in conjunction with the "product improvement" program of the organization, J. Louis Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association and chairman of the special

The publication of the [Pound]1,500,000,000 British rearmament program, coming on the heels of the Non-Intervention Committee's embargo on volunteers for Spain, has created a profound impression in Germany.

Coming to life in grand style in the second half, Manhattan vanquished St. John's, 30 to 24, at Madison Square Garden last night, scored its fourteenth victory of the season in fifteen starts and routed that persistent Redman jinx that had hovered over the series from its very beginning.

A proposal to place a producerdealer milk price fixing plan on the statute books, in place of present price fixing by the State alone, was called "unconstitutional" at a legislative committee's hearing into dairymen's price problems today.

Speaking at the Hunter College birthday chapel yesterday morning at the Central Synagogue, Fiftyfifth Street and Lexington Avenue, Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of the college, referred to the Constitution as a "document whose genius transends human thought" and challenged "those who demand radical change."

178th St., 219 E. (11-2811): Rose Apartments, Inc., to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 1 Madison Av., extends mortgage to Dec. 1, 1941, at 5 per cent: Adams St. (15-4018), e s, 296 ft s of Van Nest Av., 18x95 by irregular feet; 1,600 Adams St. Corp. to Bronx Sash and Door Co., 1,069 Clay Av., installments, 5 per cent; $13,000.

Two ranking metropolitan golfers, Mark J. Stuart of the Winged Foot Golf Club at Mamaroneck, N. Y., and Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, N. J., continued winning in the second match round of the tenth annual national championship of club champions on St. Augustine Links today. Each squeezed out victory by 2 and 1.

A trade practice conference will be held under the auspices of the Federal Trade Commission by the Hotel Astor, New York, March 9, at 10 A. M., to adopt trade practice rules concerning the proper designations and representations to be used in describing the shrinkage properties or the pre-shrunk character of

William James Clinton Stuart, successful playwright a generation ago, author and newspaper man, who was said to be a grandson of Governor De Witt Clinton of New York, died here yesterday in obscurity at the age of 84 in a hall room that had been his home for more than fifteen years. A bachelor,
The Senate used less than ten minutes of its four-hour session today to pass the $971,000,000 Independent Offices Appropriation Bill. There was no debate and no roll-call.

The toll of beaten odds-on choices at Hialeah continued today when Warren Wright's Count Morse went down to a stunning defeat in a field of seven which ran for the purse in the featured Class A handicap. Mrs. Emil Denemark's Higher Cloud was the winner over the seven furlongs in fifth of a second of the track record set earlier in the meeting by Sweeplike.

Hampshire House, the thirtyeight story apartment hotel at 150 Central Park South, will be completed for occupancy about Oct. 1, according to plans filed yesterday by A. Rollin Caughey, architect of the original structure.

Senator Thomas suggested today that sit-down strikes originated in the shaven head of Mahatma Gandhi. The one-time college professor remarked during a Senate Civil Liberties Committee hearing that the recent General Motors. strike was "based on Gandhi's non-assertion doctrine."

The Ford Motor Company announced today that two 300-foot canal motor ships, described as the largest of their kind ever built for use between the Great Lakes and the Atlantic Coast, will be added to its fleet in June.

The Philadelphia Electric Company yesterday called for redemption on April 1 all of its outstanding $32,453,000 first mortgage 4 per cent bonds at 110 and accrued interest and all the outstanding $1,497,300 first mortgage 5 per cent bonds at 105 and accrued interest.

The Minister of Economy today signed a contract with a representative of the Krupp firm for the construction in Germany of ten cargo and passenger steamers, three of 1,600, four of 2,400 and three of 5,000 tons gross, and four ferry boats, at a total cost of about 10,000,000 Turkish pounds.

THE winner of the Baxter Mile at the New York A. C. games in the Garden on Saturday evening probably will have the silver cup handed to him by the donor of the trophy, the same being Hugh Baxter, the Winged Foot veteran hale and hearty at 75.

Electric power production declined last week when seasonal and long-term trends indicated an increase, and the adjusted index slumped to 101.6 from 105.6. It was 99.1 for the week ended Feb. 15, 1936.

A reuiem mass will be celebrated at 9:30 A.M. today in Holy Cross Church, Church and Rogers Avenues, Brooklyn, for Andrew P. Griffin, a boxing referee, who died on Sunday of pneumonia, at the age of 60.

A poll of newspapers which supported President Roosevelt for re-election, showing that more than two-thirds of those responding were withholding support of his plan to revise the Supreme Court, was reported today by The Christian Science Monitor.

ABERT-Benjamin, at his residence. 40 East 83d St., beloved brother of Annie Cohen, Florence Mendel and Isaac Abert. Funeral. service Park West Chapel, 115 West 79th St., Thursday, Feb. 18. at 2 P. M. Kindly omit flowers. Interment private.

Stamford, Conn., petitioned the House Roads Committee today for a Federal-controlled toll highway from Boston to New York. The town's petition proposes a "toll express motor way with oneway traffic lanes free of grade crossings." Under the proposal the

Mrs. Henry Martyn Alexander, president of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, will give a tea this afternoon at her home. 15 East Thirty-sixth Street, for the recently elected directors of the organization.

Miss Andree Vilas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Nathan Vilas of Chicago and Sarasota, became the bride this afternoon of William Edward Graham, son of Mrs. Ernest Robert Graham of Chicago, in the Music Room of Whitehall.

In a letter to the Federal Trade Commission yesterday the Morris White Manufacturing Company, Inc., leather goods manufacturers, protested the recent service of a complaint in a dispute which arose two years ago and has been dormant since that time.

The engagement of $9,385,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount $6,840,000 was obtained in England at some previous date and $2,545,000 was taken in Canada yesterday.

Waddill Catchings, who for several years has been an executive and director in several amusement and investment companies with which Harrison Williams is identified, has opened offices in the Chrysler Building to engage in private banking.

The Provident Loan Society in its forty-second annual report says fewer new loans were made in 1936 than in 1935, but that theoaggregate amount was 6 per cent larger. Loans made last year numbered 656,388, against 658,099 in 1935, and the amount loaned, $32,328,741, against $30,815,673.

The list of the Cunard-White Star liner Alaunia, sailing today for London via Havre, includes: Commander Alfred Jones, Mr. and Mrs. J. C. Chalmers, Miss C. E. Jones, Harry R. Rogers, Edward L. Luce, A. G. Meyers and Mrs. A. V. Conroy.
The Princeton freshman hockey team scored its eighth victory of the season today by turning back the Hun School skaters, 12-2, at Hobey Baker rink.

After including gold worth [Pound]2,500,000 in exports to the-United States, Australia has a favorable trade balance for the first semester of the financial year of nearly [Pound]1,000,000, compared with an adverse balance of [Pound]9,400,000 for the corresponding period in 1935. Wool exports of [Pound]3,003,000 compared with [Pound]424,000 in 1935.

The text of the letter written by John Bassett Moore to Representative Hamilton Fish of New York, ranking Republican member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, on the subject of discretionary power to be vested in the President by neutrality legislation follows:

Mr. and Mrs. Ronald T. Lyman of 39 Beacon Street, Boston, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Elizabeth Lyman Harrower of 136 East Sixtyseventh Street, this city, to Frederick Frelinghuysen of Elberon, N. J.

Exhibits designed to exonerate W. E. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange and other Exchanges, of charges of stock manipulation were introduced at today's hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

On the last day of the last session of Congress, the Senate, without debate and without a record vote, passed the Walsh-Healey act. It provided that any contractor bidding on any Government contract of more than $10,000 must pay the "prevailing wages" in his locality (as determined by the Secretary of Labor); must not work

Another warning to would-be troublemakers in Europe or Asia-the third of its kind within a week-was delivered by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the House of Commons today, although he mentioned no names and pretended that his government had no one nation or group of nations in mind.
Lanny Ross's song recital in Carnegie Hall last night was not a brilliant occasion, even though it brought him a large audience and copious applause.

A group of stage stars, musicians and other figures of the metropolitan amusement world came from New York today to testify before the House Immigration Committee on the Dickstein bill which aims "to protect the artistic and earning opportunities in the United States for American actors, vocal musicians, operatic singers, solo dancers, solo instrumentalists and orchestral conductors."

Eleven-year-old Gwennie Griffiths of Warren, fifty miles from Sudbury, will mush her fivedog team here Saturday to compete in the annual dog derby. She has trained her dogs as a team and individually for the derby.

A training test for individual riders competing in the International Horse Show was held today at the Valparaiso Sporting Club. The public was not invited to attend in view of the fact that the event was more of a technical display of horsemanship than a real contest. But a number of experts were on hand to witness the exhibition.

A record total of 4,000 five-man teams will take part in New York City's first bowling championships, the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress, which gets under way next month. The tournament, originally slated to end on April 19, has been moved back a second time because of the overwhelming entry list.
Mrs. John F. Wilkins announced the marriage of her sister, Mrs. Kate Harris Skipwith, to Berkeley Williams, which took place today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Wilkins in Washington.

The National Committee for Clarifying the Constitution by Amendment will meet in Washington Monday, Feb. 22, to consider: the draft of an amendment, select introducers in Congress and complete the membership of the committee.

The National Railways of Mexico contemplate substantial purchase of freight cars and locomotives in this country, Ingeniero Antonio Madrazo, president of the system, said yesterday on his arrival in New York. He plans to make a survey

Georges Bonnet, dynamic former French Minister for Finance and Commerce, who has been appointed Ambassador to the United States to succeed Andre de Laboulaye, arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France and departed for Washington without clarifying the mystery of his mission here.
Pierrepont B. Noyes, president of Oneida, Ltd., announced today a $167,000 bonus payable at once to all employes in service more than one year.
Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer gav a dinner tonight at the Everglades for Colonel and Mrs. Francis L.V. Hoppin, guests of Mrs. Thodore Frelinghuysen at Southways.

The New York State outdoor speed skating championships, which will be held at Sackett Lake, Monticello, N. Y., next Sunday, are expected to attract an entry exceeding 150. The leading Eastern speedsters will be among the starters.
Rutgers' brilliant basketball team had little trouble defeating Lehigh tonight, 50 to 23. The Scarlet, defeated only by N. Y. U. this season, won as it pleased, being superior in every department.

Baron Johann von Leidersdorff, art dealer of Harrison and New York City, recently voted one of the ten best-dressed men in New York City by the Tailors Guild of America, was named in a contempt of court motion today by an attorney who wants to examine him in connection with an unpaid bill of $82.71 for clothing.

If you are planning to take the youngsters to the National Sportsmen's Show this week-end and want to give them an extra thrill or two, try to get one of the New Brunswick guides over to a quiet corner and have him spin some yarns about bears for wide-eyed Johnny and Jim. Some of them will do it, too.
While 200 of their fellow-workmen applauded, twenty-nine mechanics received certificates and gold buttons yesterday for excellent work on the partly completed 9 Rockefeller Plaza Building. Thomas S.
Representative E. Harold Cluett of Troy, N. Y., introduced a bill today to create the "Saratoga National Park" at the Saratoga Battlefield in up-State New York.

Mr. and Mrs. James E. Pearman of Bermuda today captured the Don M. Parker golf trophy when they rounded the difficult MidOcean course in 88 strokes in the two-ball mixed foursome tournament, held as a curtain-raiser to the fourth annual Mid-Ocean invitation tournament, which starts tomorrow.
Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, will be 75 years old today.

A new type of mining drill which, theoretically, could bore a five-foot hole clear through the earth was described yesterday before the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building, 25-33 West Thirtyninth Street.

Arthur Cranfield, young cue wizard from Syracuse, last night threw the national amateur pocket billiard title tourney into a triple tie when he defeated Lewis Brooks, the defending champion, 125 to 83, in twenty-four innings.

A three-year ban on the issuance of-licenses for new taverns or other establishments selling liquor for consumption on the premises was urged in a recommendation adopted yesterday at an organization meeting of the newly formed United Retail Liquor Dealers of Manhattan at the Hotel McAlpin.
Constitutionality of the Social Security Act was upheld here today by the Circuit Court of Appeals. The opinion affirmed the judgment by Judge David J. Davis in Birmingham.

Meeting Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I., for the third time within a year, Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis registered her third triumph over her rival in the second round of the women's annual golf championship of Palm Beach today. The Minnesota girl overwhelmed the New York State titleholder, 6 and 4.

In an unexpected and possibly unprecedented statement read in open court, Burton B. Turkus, defense counsel in the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping case, charged District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn yesterday virtually with repudiating an "arrangement" made by him in behalf of the accused kidnappers.

When the New York Savings Bank sold the house at 154 W. 64th St. to the Mesemvria Corp., Stefanos Damascus, president, for $20,000 the bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $16,000. A mortgage for $9,000 on 116 Perry St., held by Josephine May Wise, as trustee of the will of Moses Stern, from the Algor Realty Corp., Alan B. Ansbacher,
Five new pictures are scheduled to open here today, one of the most congested Thursdays, excepting the annual Thanksgiving Day program, that Broadway has witnessed in recent times.
Pictures taken immediately after a fatal automobile collision are relied upon by Milton A. Abrams, 21, a Milwaukee newspaper photographer, to win him freedom. from a manslaughter charge.

" Who's Who in the Zoo," a guide book to New York City's zoological parks and at the same time a scientific handbook on mammals, has been completed by the Federal Writers Project of the WPA. The book will be published soon, bids having been submitted on the work.

New York public school students, teachers and staffs have contributed $72,818.92 to the flood-relief fund of the American Red Cross, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday. The money was forwarded to the borough chapters of the Red Cross.
The undefeated New York University freshman basketball team added the Manhattan freshman five to its string yesterday, downing the Jaspers, 47 to 20, on the University Heights gymnasium court.

Great Britain is determined not again to be caught unprepared. The White Paper, issued Tuesday by the British Government, estimating an expenditure of approximately $7,500,000,000 in the next five years to enlarge and modernize its land, sea and air forces, is more telling than any statement of a Prime Minister or Secretary of Foreign Affairs. Its repercussions will be felt

Exports of paper base stocks in 1936 aggregated $11,984,251, against $9,890,499 for 1935, an increase of 21.2 per cent, the Department of Commerce reported today. Sulphite pulp, bleached and unbleached, gained 26.6 per cent. In 1936 119,528 tons

A decline in the national intelligence of civilized countries was pictured by Dr. Earnest A. Hooton, Harvard Professor of Anthropology and president of the American Association of Physical Anthropologists, in a lecture tonight before the Harvard Club.
RIDE ON THE WIND, by Francis Chichester. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50.) A record of flight over the South Pacific.

Samuel M. Bomzon. a banker whom Jules Martin addressed familiarly as "old man," took the stand at the restaurant racket trial yesterday to show that four days before Martin was murdered $21,000 was withdrawn from the Metropolitan Restaurant and Cafeteria Association's account.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works reported yesterday that its net loss in 1936 was $2,163,949, against a net loss of $2,119,738 in 1935. Consolidated sales in 1936, exclusive of inter-company transactions, were $20,877,735, against $19,462,746.
Indians' dreams of complete independence were jolted unexpectedly today when the extremist congress party won outright control of only three of eight legislatures in provincial elections.

If the special, and uncut, performance of Wagner's "Walkuere" yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House had been of the prevailingly high level which has characterized most Wagner performances in this lyric theatre of late seasons, it could fittingly be dismissed with a brief retailing of the facts and the general character of an interpretation by a cast which in all its important respects is familiar to operagoers of the city.

While the House of Commons was debating today addition of another [Pound]400,000,000 to the British defense budget, a little group of ultra-Liberal members of the House of Lords, who have risen to the peerage by reason of the needs of successive Labor governments, staged a debate there on the colonial question.
Clear indications that the Navy Department would recommend matching Britain in new battleship construction were given today by Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations.

A net profit of $7,753,251 after all cnarges, including taxes, is reported by the National Distillers Products Corporation in its annual report for 1936, to be distributed to stockholders today by Seton Porter, president.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum in the United States at the close of the week ended on Feb. 6 amounted to 286,116,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with a week before, this was an increase of 732,000 barrels, comprising a rise of 805,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude petroleum and a decrease of 73,000 barrels in stocks of foreign crude petroleum.

Several concessionaries, direct from Coney Island, are to be on hand to lend "local color" to the Coney Island gala dinner dance of- Saturday night at the Surf Club. An entire carnival, complete with ferris wheel and merry-go-rounds, will be set up in the club.

Mayor La Guardia appeared yesterday in the role of guest lecturer on civics in the Brooklyn Technical High School, where he delivered a twenty-minute radio talk on city planning to 500,000 school children listening in.

There are increasing indications that the Nasi movement in the Netherlands is no longer progressing. Soon after the movement's inception it was asserted there were now 50,000 Netherland Nazis and that soon there would be 100,000. The prophecy has not come true.
Charles Tank, a mountain lion hunter, told today a stirring account of imprisonment in a snowbound cave for six weeks with his hounds after he slipped and fell on the ice.

Dr. Albert W. Page, medical practitioner of many years standing in this city who is accused by Charles D. Lewis, attorney for Chang Soo Lee, with having been partly responsible for the poisoning of Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves for which Chang is now being tried, testified under cross-examination today that he had been neglectful in his treatment of Mr. Reeves.

Some of the myths surrounding the trailer industry were exploded yesterday by Rufus S. Cole, president of Brennan-Cole Corporation, metropolitan distributors for Covered Wagon Trailers, who expressed the opinion that less than 200,000 are now in use.
Frank C. Manley, civil engineer with the New York office of the American Bridge Company since 1904, died here today at his home, 264 Third Avenue East, after a week's illness of pneumonia.

Whitlock Av. (10-2731), s. e. cor. of Tiffany St., 275x40; Bronx County Trust Co. to Tifflock Realty Corp., 535 5th Av. Bryant Av. (10-2756), e. s.. 150 ft s of 165th St., 40xlO0; Central Savings Bank to Richsol Realty Co., Inc., 15 Marcy Place. Johnson Av. (13-3409C), s. e. cor. of 235th St., 300x200: Barca Realty Corp. to A. C. H. M. Hall Realty Co., 143 W. 72d St.; mtg., $70,000.
Five members of the "Let Us Die League" attempted conspicuous but careful hara-kiri at various public places today.

The Long Island Lighting Company filed with the Public Service Commission yesterday a schedule of new electric rates, under which an estimated annual saving of $1,194,000 will accrue to the company's customers.

A two-story business structure will be erected on the site at 32-3436 East Fifty-third Street, where demolition was started yesterday of the three five-story buildings no? on the plot, according to Benjamin Winter, operator, who recently bought the property.

The following film programs, which will be shown tomorrow, Saturday, Sunday and Monday unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools:

The Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners has adopted a resolution asking all members of the Board of Estimate who promised repeal of the emergency 50 per cent increase in water rates and reduction of the emergency 10 per cent penalty on delinquent real estate taxes "to keep their campaign promises."

Stocks closed irregular, with rail shares strongest; turnover, 2,578,690 shares. Receivership rail issues strong, other bonds irregular in largest turnover since January, 1936; transactions, $22,332,200.

They will be reviving the Dion Boucicault "London Assurance" this evening at the Vanderbilt, the first local revival since the boys of the Yale Drama Association put it on in 1910. In the cast will be
The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 15 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

A bill to write into State law the requirement that if a boxer is knocked down three times in one round or if he appears unable to continue, the referee must order a physical examination was introduced today by Senator PeterFarrell, Queens Democrat.

The crew of the Dollar liner President Harrison, which is scheduled to sail from Jersey City today at 6 P. M. on a trip around the world, refused yesterday to accept continuous discharge books as provided by the new Copeland Safetyat-Sea Act.

Japan's liberal leadership came out today for a Russo-Japanese pact of peace, expressed amazement that "Japan can shake hands with a country like Germany" and attacked the army for trying to "guide" the nation.

Snatched from the storm-buffeted waters by rescue ships, all fortyfour crew members of the Italian motorship Feltre were saved today after their vessel was in collision with the American freighter Edward Luckenbach and sank to the bottom of the Columbia River.

Elliot Ambrose, a tuxedo-clad Negro, who seized a policeman's gun and shot the officer and two other men, mumbled in his cell today that he was a "religious messenger." The two victims, Albert Argens, the policeman, and Clifton Darblay, an express truck driver, were critically wounded.

Steel mill backlogs again are rising on expanding demand, as new business has been exceeding shipments and has forced further extension of deliveries on many products and higher operating rates, The Iron Age finds. The periodical estimates ingot production at 82 1/2 per cent of capacity, a gain of 1 1/2 per cent over last week.

More than 150 firemen from six municipal departments fought a fire here this morning on the top story of the northeast wing of the Chatsworth Gardens Apartments. The blaze caused more than $150,000 damage and slight injury to seven firemen. Traffic through the north side of Larchmont was tied up for more than four hours.
Dr. ALLAN DAFOE will no doubt soon be recovered from his flu. The real news will come approximately fifteen years from now when Dr.

The annual report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and its subsidiaries for 1936 released yesterday shows earnings of $2.68 a share on the common stock, compared with $2.53 in 1935. Gross operating revenues were $122,843,047, an increase of $3,616,619.

Harvard's basketball team fought a valiant battle tonight, but succumbed to a driving Dartmouth combination. The score was 40--29. The defeat dropped the Crimson to fourth place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.
The trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday developed a marked increase in activity, and prices, on the average, showed improvement on the day.

Alaska, once called "Seward's Folly," enjoyed commerce last year valued at $115,963,586, 108 times more than the United States paid for it sixty-nine years ago, J. J. Connors, Collector of Customs, said today.
Edward P. Frost, a member of the New York Curb Exchange since 1921, and William Brown, formerly with Andrews, Posner Rothschild, have formed Frost Brown, with offices at 11 Wall Street.

Strike movements in the building service field were halted yesterday. The long-heralded deadline for walkouts in six large hotels passed, with new threats from union offidials and no activity. The effort to negotiate contracts with office, loft and apartment building owners, who now have no agreements with the union, proceeded without strikes.

The New York Water-Color Club, whose annual exhibition opened last Saturday at the American Fine Arts Building, has announced the award of the Adolph and Clara Obrig Prize to Henry Jay Lee for his picture, "Storage Track."

Governor CRoss is one of the most multifarious personages now anywhere on view. He is capable of knowing and doing anything well. New honors rain upon him as if he didn't have enough, professional, literary, critical, editorial, political; and who shall count up his vocations and avocations.

Although it ended with the flavor of a wrestling match, Joe Louis, Detroit's boxing man, was credited with a four-round knockout tonight in his scheduled ten-round duel with Natie Brown, Washington heavyweight.
The New York Athletic Club basketball team registered its fourth straight Eastern Athletic Club League victory by routing Seventh Regiment, 38 to 22, on the loser's floor last night.

Mrs. Cornelia Clark Seymour, mother of Dr. Nan Gilbert Seymour, medical director of Booth Memorial Hospital, 314 East Fifteenth Street, died on Tuesday at her home, 134 East Nineteenth Street. She was 94 years old.
Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 12 per cent for the week ended Feb. 13, it was announced yesterday by the United Parcel Service.
