The three principal leaders of the American Labor party united yesterday in a pledge that their party would have a Mayoralty candidate in the field this Fall. The statement was made by Luigi Antonini, State chairman; Alex Rose, State secretary, and Gustave Strebel, executive director of the party.

Following a conference at the White House, Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury, chairman of the special committee appointed by President Roosevelt to make a study of the influx of foreign capital into the United States, said late today that the "matter is still in the study stage."

Wheat fluctuated erratically today within a range of about 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade here. There was an advance of a cent early in sympathy with Liverpool and on reports that Germany had re-entered the market as a buyer of cash wheat.

Over the protests of the managers of two rival contenders for the world's lightweight title, the State Athletic Commission yesterday approved the application of Madison Square Garden for another championship bout between Lou Ambers, current titleholder, and Tony Canzoneri, former champion.
It was reported to the Mexican Government today that 2,000,000 Mexicans in the United States, or 80 per cent of the 2,500,000 there, were out of work.

Governor Lehman's $365,000,000 budget for the fiscal year 1937-1938 was attacked by three critics today at a joint public hearing on the measure held by the Senate Finance and the Assembly Ways and Means Committees.

Representative Emanuel Celler "challenged" Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, and Q. F. Walker, economist for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., yesterday to sponsor legislation "specifically banning loss-leader selling," following their criticism of his stand on the Tydings-Miller bill to legalize price maintenance of trade-marked merchandise.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note that Senator McNaboe is considerably perturbed about the teaching of radical doctrine in the public schools and colleges. May I call the Senator's attention to a few general principles which have some bearing on the issue? My views are, of course, offered not to defend un-American doctrines or groups, but to confirm true democracy as I interpret it.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: Flood waters have receded from con. siderable areas of the Ohio Valley, and general conditions have improved. While many fields are badly erroded, previously inundated wheat in most places appears alive and is reviving.

IN Francis Chichester's accounts. of flights, "Solo to Sydney," "Seaplane Solo," and now "Ride on the Wind" (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50), the element of suspense is particularly prominent, not because of forced writing but because of the facts. Chichester has spent years attempting the

Stanley L. Orr, president of the Cleveland Bar Association, announced today that the executive committee had adopted a report of its Committee on Federal Procedure condemning the President's proposal to increase the number of Supreme Court and other Federal judges, in that it was unnecessary and would create a dangerous precedent for the domination over the judicial branch of the government by the other two branches.
Investment buying of housing properties from Greenwich Village to Washington Heights featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.
Fourteenth annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association begins at 9:30 A. M. at the Hotel Roosevelt and continues Friday and Saturday.

Miss Gladys B. Smythe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Richardson Smythe of 1,900 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, has selected April 16 for the date of her marriage to John Colegrove Sims, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Sims of New Haven. Conn.
Military rule of Anderson loosened tonight, permitting citizens additional liberties, but close watch was kept to forestall further strife between union and non-union automotive workers.
Showing new vigor, an alert Princeton hockey team scored its first victory in eight starts by turning back the Boston College sextet, 5-3, before 1,000 persons tonight in Baker Rink.

Representatives of shipping interests and port authorities involved asked the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee today to extend for one year the June 29 deadline for sale or charter of government-owned shipping lines.
Lawrenceville bowed to Trenton High School five, 29-19, today. The visitors' attack, led by the stellar All-State center, Ernie Young, who scored 15 points, reached its peak in the last half.

Germain Glidden of the Harvard Club, national amateur squash racquets champion, added another conquest to his string for the season last night preparatory to leaving for Cleveland to defend his title.

MANHATTAN BROWN, INEZ E. (Dec. 10). Estate, about $19,000. To Betty Lou Brown and Robert Y. Brown Jr., Millhill Rd., Southport, Conn., one-fourth residue each; Mildred A. Flottman, stepdaughter, 128 Main St., Petaluma, Calif., specific personal property and one-half residue; several specific bequests. Robert Y. Brown, stepson, executor. Millhill Rd. Southport, Conn.

A banking group composed of the First Boston Corporation, Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Stone . Webster and Blodget, Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $7,000,000 of city of Boston temporary loan notes on a 1.50 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $300. The notes, dated

A bill to provide for licensing and regulating practitioners in beauty parlors and teachers in beauty-culture schools was introduced today by Senator A. Spencer Feld, New York Democrat, and Jane Todd, Republican, in the Assembly.
Federal Judge Edward J. Moinet dismissed yesterday a patent infringement suit brought by William S. Ferguson of Cleveland and four co-plaintiffs against the Ford Motor Company.

In the rush of renewed production of automobiles and re-employment of well over. 100,000 workers since General Motors and the union reached a truce Thursday orders for materials for factories have totaled more than $100,000,000.

Reclassification of the stock of Educational Pictures, Inc., has been approved by the Chancellor of the State of Delaware, it was announced here yesterday. The plan 1 was approved by stockholders on Feb. 8 last.

James J. Braddock will defend his heavyweight championship in a fifteenround bout against Challenger Joe Louis at Comiskey Park on June 22, it was announced today by Joe Foley, matchmaker of the Sporting Club of Illinois, under whose auspices the match will be held.

Continuing the brilliant play which has stamped him as a threat for the title, Frank Bowden of the Seventh Regiment Tennis Club routed Lincoln Halberstadt, 6-3, 6-0, in the quarter-finals of the Brooklyn indoor tennis championship at the 106th Regiment Armory yesterday. .
dozen dummies at the convention of the National Association of Merchant Tailors of America displayed today outfits designed to. place men in rivalry with women in brightness of dress.
John J. McCann Jr., city court clerk, has decided that indebtedness is not hereditary and thereby cleared the name of a grandfather.

Plans to install automatic radio S O S signal devices on all American cargo ships will be discussed at a conference of radio manufacturers, telegraph companies and steamship companies called for Friday by the Federal Communications Commission.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers will offer today a new issue of $4,500,000 of the Kresge Foundation ten-year 3 1/2 per cent collateral trust notes, due Feb. 1, 1947, at 103 and accrued interest. Associated in the offering will be Bancamerica - Blair Corporation, Kidder, Peabody Co. and Watling, Lerchen Hayes.

Gold bullion valued at $1,250,000 was unloaded today from the Taronga at Commonwealth pier, placed in an armored truck and started over the road for New York. The shipment, comprising twenty-two boxes of bullion, weighing about two tons, was consigned to the Federal Reserve Bank here. It came from Australia.
Ecuador's budget for 1937 amounts to 79,000,000 sucres, or about $7,950,000, the largest in a number of years-made possible by returning prosperity.

Plans for the opening of a new store about July 1 to serve Brooklyn and Long Island were announced yesterday by Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc. The store will be at the northwest corner of Fulton and Bridge Streets, in the center of the Brooklyn shopping district.

Eleven hundred young people from New York City will form onefourth of a national assembly of about 4,000 American Youth Congress members who will converge on Washington to urge passage of the American Youth Act upon President Roosevelt and Congress during a four-day "pilgrimage" lasting from tomorrow to Monday.

Henry Rump Jr., Henry Beretta, Charles G. Johnson, in 378 Central Park West: BenJamin Levy, Sol Garfunkel, Abraham J. Charney, in 945 West End Av.; Pearce Mayer, broker. Morris Weinberg, in 244 Riverside Dr.; Curt Derog, in 276 Riverside Dr.: Charles M. Bingham, in 380 Riverside Dr.;

Something new in the houseselling field appeared in an advertisement in local newspapers, when the owner of a farm property in Lyndonville, Vt., offered a cash bonus for each baby born to whatever couple buys the farm.
Charles Laite, a New York actor understudying for roles in "In a Nutshell," collapsed and died of a heart attack today as he entered the stage door of the Hanna Theatre for a matinee. His age was 53.

McGill's Red Raiders trounced Dartmouth by 16-1 tonight in an International Intercollegiate Hockey League game. The Canadians staged a continual bombardment of the Green goal-keeper Goding, scoring almost at will.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 15: CAPTAIN Hall, W. A., the Oklahoma, to duty as Inspector of Ordnance in charge, Naval Torpedo Station, Keyport, Wash.

The regular meeting of the board of governors of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx will be held tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. In the board rooms, 391 East 149th St. Shampan Sbampan, architects, have been commissioned to prepare plans for a six-story apartment house to be erected on the southwest corner of Wetherole St. and

To avoid hurting the feelings of Roman Catholics, who form a large proportion of the population of Canada and Australia, and some other denominations, the coronation oath has been redrafted where it deals with the maintenance of the Protestant reformed religion and the establishment of the Church of England.

Continued weakness in British Government issues dampened the enthusiasm in the stock market here today, but armament issues did well, and oil shares were well supported. Some of the gilt-edge issues touched new low levels, influenced by the new defense loan that is contemplated by the government. Among the foreign bonds, the German ones were strong.

The three-story brick store and apartment building at 1,152 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, on a plot 30 by 97 feet, has been sold by Murray Hill Equities, Inc., to Bella Caren. The property is said to be fully rented and is assessed at $12,000. The buyer paid cash above

KINGS CAMPBELL, JOHN (April 20. 1936). Gross assets, $13,775; net, $11,908. To sons, John W. and Paul Campbell; daughter, Cora C. Gillies, one-third of residuary estate each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $3,837; miscellaneous property, $9,869. Watson, Kristeller Swift, attorneys. 68 William St., Manhattan.

Because an old North Country settler told him about an Indian cave when he was 12 years old, Riley Rickett has spent seven months digging a thirty-five-foot shaft through solid rock in a hunt for the cave and the treasure supposed to be in it.
Steel offices and plants buzzed today with a report that the larger companies were preparing to announce establishment of a forty-hour week for their thousands of employes.
This capital is in mourning today because of the sudden death here of General Chu Pei-teh from blood poisoning.
William Faversham, matinee idol of another day, is a guest at the Percy Williams Home at East Islip, L. I., it was learned yesterday.
Mrs. Harold Fowler of Middlebrook, Far Hills, N. J., and 1 East End Avenue, this city, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Molly Flagg, to Robert P. Gibb.

At 5 o'clock this morning government troops launched an offensive in the Jarama sector, southeast of Madrid, where since Feb. 6 the Insurgents have been trying to cut the road to Valencia. The drive got off to a

There were more unexpected developments as the national squash racquets championship moved into the quarter-final stage at the Junior League yesterday. Chief among them was Miss Elizabeth Pearson's surprise elimination of Miss Betty Cooke, fourth ranking player of the English team, which is here to defend the Wolfe-Noel international trophy next week.

Major Helen Purviance, known to World War fighting forces in France as the Salvation Army's "doughnut girl," and Major Agnes McKernan, women's prison secretary of the Eastern territory, have been promoted to the rank of brigadier, according to the first official promotion order gazette for 1937 issued last night from the offices of Commissioner Alexander M. Damon, Eastern Territorial Commander of the Salvation Army.

Mrs. August Belmont of New York City has given to the Naval Academy a massive silver platter which was presented to Commodore Matthew Perry by the General Assembly of Rhode Island, of which State Commodore Perry was a native, in commemoration of the treaty with Japan which was negotiated after his visit to that country.

Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant reserved decision yesterday on a motion for a mistrial made by counsel for Jacob J. Lesser, New York lawyer, and ten other defendants accused with him of concealing assets in the bankruptcy of the Aetna Sportswear Company of Boston. The motion was made

Commencing on March 1, New York Stock Exchange houses will be required to keep day-to-day records of every margin call, giving the name of the customer, the date, the amount, the date the call is met and whether it is met by cash, by additional collateral or by the sale of existing collateral in the account.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported today the addition of about $600 last year to its conscience fund. A man in Pittsburgh, who signed his name, sent $300, the year's largest payment. "I withheld money and materials as near as I can figure to about this amount," railroad officials from his letter.
Louis Dwight Ray, founder and former headmaster. of the Irving School and later headmaster of the Berkeley-Irving School for Boys, died here yesterday after a long illness. His age was 76.

Joseph Edward Peirson, assistant treasurer of the Berkshire Life Insurance Company for thirteen years, and prominent in the literary life of Pittsfield, died this afternoon at House of Mercy Hospital after an illness of two months.' He was 75 years old.
Princess Beatrice, the youngest daughter of the late Queen Victoria, has decided to sell her copy of "Alice in Wonderland" which Lewis Carroll sent her in 1866.

President Roosevelt conferred with Representatives on his judiciary proposals, appointed former Governor Paul V. McNutt of Indiana as High Commissioner to the Philippines, received a preliminary report from Secretary Morgenthau on controlling foreign investments in this country, and discussed foreign affairs with Secretary Hull.

In final tune-up races for the $50,000 added Santa Anita Derby Monday, Case Ace, Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's great 3-year-old, rang up a threelength victory in a six-furlong event and W. W. Taylor's Sir Oracle turned back the favored Tedious in a one-mile race at Santa Anita Park today.

Nearly 100 American department store buyers and fashion authorities returned from the Spring showings in Paris yesterday, arriving on the French liner Ile de France with expressions of enthusiasm for the coming styles in women's wear.

Reporting on a survey of relief administration in twenty-four States yesterday, the American Association of Social Workers described conditions as "chaotic," and recommended an investigation by a non-partisan Federal commission to devise "an integrated program for the future."
Two Cunard White Star liners sailed on cruises yesterday from Pier 90, North River, foot of West Fiftieth Street, with 1,290 tourists bound for the West Indies and South America.

Garret A. Hobart of the Arcola Country Club, Paterson, N. J., furnished the only upset today in the second round of the annual Belleair Country Club golf championship. He defeated Douglas W. Hill, Cincinnati star, who was defending the title he won in 1936, by 1 up. Hill won the medal on Monday.
Associates Investment Company common stock, no-par value, and 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, with warrants for common stock attached, were admitted to the list yesterday.
Charles Kilbourn is an ardent fox hunter, but when a little reid fox comes sniffing around the backyard like a tame dog, he holds his fire.

General Chang Hsuehliang, who kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and held him prisoner for a fortnight in Sian, Shensi Province, last December, now has complete forgiveness and seems destined to regain the high position in political affairs that he occupied before the recent revolt.
Berghof, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's highland home here, was the scene today of a picturesque reception by the Fuehrer of war veterans of fourteen nations, chiefly former enemy countries.

Canal St., 332, and 39 Lispenard St.; Supt. of Insurance, as liquidator of Lawyers Title and Guaranty Co., to Samuel A. Wander, 1,193 E. 24th St., Brooklyn; consideration, $13,000. Same property, Samuel A. Wander to Edroan Realty Corp., 332 Canal St.

A reduction in the assessed valuation of property owned by the Socony Vacuum Oil Company in Queens, on the East River opposite Forty-second Street, Manhattan, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Wenzel.

A motion to appoint a receiver for William V. (Big Bill) Dwyer, sports promoter, was granted yesterday by Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey on the plea of Augustine F. Meeker, a judgment creditor claiming $7,689.

At a reorganization hearing yesterday of the Consolidated Textile Corporation before Peter B. Olney, referee in bankruptcy, it was indicated that earnings for January would show an improvement over the net profit of $2,306 in the five weeks ended on Dec. 26 last.

Miss Mary Franklin Jones, daughter of the late De Witt Clinton Jones and a great-granddaughter of De Witt Clinton, Governor of New York, 1817-22, died here this morning at her home, 37 Aberdeen Road, after a long illness.

There was a marked contrast on the two New York baseball fronts yesterday. While President Horace C. Stoneham of the Giants, without a holdout on his mind, headed a happy and carefree party of some three dozen which sailed for Havana on the steamship Oriente at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, the embattled Yankees burst out with an announcement that seemed to indicate the fighting had just begun.

Elek John Ludvigh, a lawyer who had been closely associated with several of the leaders of the motion picture industry and had been their legal adviser in some of the industry's most important developments, died Tuesday night at his residence, 300 Park Avenue, after an illness of five months. He was 63 years old.

High Federal Income taxes are exerting pressure on investors to avoid many risky ventures which may sometimes be of considerable public importance, declares a comprehensive survey by a group of tax experts retained by the Twentieth Century Fund. Dr. Carl Shoup of Columbia University headed the group making the study, which will be published soon in a 600-page book.

The Commonwealth Edison Company, in its annual report to stockholders for 1936, showed a net income of $10,943,741, equivalent, after all charges, to $6.79 a share on 1,162,630 shares of outstanding capital stock.
The Public Service Commission reported today that New York utilities had issued "little or no" new stocks and bonds in 1936 for the third successive year.
The Supreme Military Tribunal granted today a habeas corpus writ to Major Benjamin Ribeiro Costa, a prisoner, so he would be free to defend himself.

A one-story motor truck terminal to be erected by the 603 West Twenty-third Street Corporation on a plot of 30,000 square feet, located seventy-five feet west of Eleventh Avenue and running through from Twenty-third to Twenty-fourth Street, has been leased to Consolidated Motor Lines, Inc., of Hartford, Conn.

Charges of inconsistency, exaggeration and unfairness are leveled at the recently issued annual report of the Tennessee Valley Authority in a sixty-page discussion of the report given out by the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation under the signature of Wendell L. Willkie, president of- the corporation, which is a. holding company for several Southeastern operating power companies.

An agreement for cooperation between British and American foreign bondholders' protective organizations has been reached at converstations held here in recent weeks between Sir Otto Niemeyer, representing the British Council of Foreign Bondholders, and officials of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., it was indicated yesterday in a statement issued by the latter organization.

Although the discussions in Washington relative to what action should be taken concerning American securities held by aliens have resulted in a moderate decline in the buying of securities here by Europeans in the last few days, it is understood that so far they have not resulted in heavy sales by the foreign holders.

In a message carried by radio to millions of Methodists gathered in their churches and homes throughout the country, John D. Rockefeller Jr., a Baptist, decried last night the rise of individualism in the world and urged a united church of all sects as the only means to stem the tide of materialism and crumbling moral standards.

An innovation in musical presenstation will be introduced Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall when the American Guild of Musical Artists, Inc., will present a concert for the benefit of flood sufferers. The proceeds of the concert will be given to the American Red Cross for flood relief.

A committee of representatives of insurance companies and savings banks headed by Carrol M. Shanks, associate general solicitor of the Prudential Insurance Company, announced yesterday the reaching of an agreement with the interests in control of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway for a reorganization of the -railroad company.

The latest official information from Mozambique (Portuguese East Africa) tonight showed less than one hundred dead had been accounted for in the severe floods but unofficial estimates still ran as high as 2,000 drowned.

Establishments in the thirteen largest cities transacted more than half of the nation's wholesale business in 1935, it was announced today by Acting Director. Vergil D. Reed of the Bureau of the Census in another of the series of final 1935 reports.
The government spent 576,652 colones, or about $230,660, on the- construction of El Salvador's section of the inter-American highway in 1936, according to an official report.

Declaring that the Duke of Windsor had been the most satisfactory Prince of Wales in centuries, David Lloyd George today explained for the first time how he came to send the Duke a Christmas message deploring the "shabby, stupid treatment accorded you," and the "mean, unchivalrous attacks upon you."

Members of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers were warned yesterday by the group's executive committee that continuation of the practice of lengthening hours by a few mills "will tempt others in the industry to do likewise."

At a tea at their Beacon Street home today Mr. and Mrs. Carl Pullen Dennett announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Alden Dennett, to John Wallace Goodrich Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Goodrich of this city and Manchester.
Amelia Earhart left New York yesterday for Cleveland for the final conditioning of her plane in preparation for her projected flight around the world at the equator.

The marriage of Mrs. Suzanne Armstrong Crocker, daughter of Mrs. Frederick S. Armstrong, to Orus J. Matthews of Philadelphia, took place yesterday afternoon in the apartment of the bride's mother at 1,040 Fifth Avenue.

Virgin Islands rum which has been manufactured for two years by a WPA corporation in the islands will be placed on sale soon in this country. It is understood that the distributor selected by Secretary Ickes is the W. A. Taylor Company of New York. An official announcement to this effect is soon to be made.

Conferring behind barricades, negotiators ended a new sit-down strike at a plant of the Briggs Manufacturing Company just before dawn today. Representatives of the United Automobile Workers said that the strike was in protest against notice of a speed-up in operations along with a pay increase.

Irked at the impassable condition of roads in this section, L. I. Gregg of Dickerson, who with other residents has been protesting, blew up his automobile with dynamite Sunday night when it became mired in a mud-hole.

A stir was made in Riviera society by an announcement today that Lord Auckland had filed suit in a local court for slander against Mrs. Arthur Woolley-Hart. Both principals are American-born British subjects.

Edouard Jonas, Paris art dealer and member of the House of di Deputies, arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France to consult here on American participation in the French Exposition, which will open in Paris in May.
Victor Chenkin, character song interpreter, will give his first major concert in two years next Sunday night at the Alvin Theatre.

The Nebraska nonpartisan unicameral Legislature adopted today, by a vote of 26 to 17, a resolution criticizing proposals for Federal court revision. The only Senator voting against it was Dr. A. L. Miller. who; criticized the legislators for spending an hour and a half in debate on a matter "which is none of our business."
A happy old Negro whose memory recalls his slave days sat in the White House study today and chatted with President Roosevelt for nearly an hour.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday its willingness to hold public hearings at which Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, can present "legal proof" of his recent assertion that electric rates in New York City are excessive.

The ground he lost as a middleweight title threat in his debut here a short time back was regained by Fred Apostoli, Coast Italian, at the Hippodrome last night as he hammered out a victory over stout- hearted Solly Krieger of Brooklyn, in the feature bout of ten rounds.
This town will have only half its representation in the Legislature this year because Romeo Lavelle is missing and his fellow-townsmen do not want to spend $100.

For the second day in succession trading in copper futures on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., yesterday attained record proportions. Transactions amounted to 4,425 tons, compared with 4,175 on Tuesday, which was the previous high record.

Fordham University's greatly improved basketball team rolled up its largest score of the season deeating Wagner College of Staten Island, 51 to 23, last night on the Ram floor before a crowd of 1,000.
More than 12,000 English and American carnations will be exhibited in the carnation show, opening in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, at 2 P. M. today and continuing through Saturday night.

The outstanding cause of a "very large majority" of fatal automobile accidents in the United States is high speed, coupled with inadequate lighting, Secretary Roper was told today in a report of a subcommittee of the Accident Prevention Conference, whose. studies are sponsored by the Department of Commerce.

Emmet J. McCormack, vice president of Moore McCormack, steamship operators, urged cooperative effort of executives and employes in the development of industrial safety at a meeting of the marine section of the National Safety Council yesterday noon.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in an address at the University of Puerto Rico this afternoon after he had received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws, said that the university was the oldest continuing institution that might have any guiding direction and force in the present world situation.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
An aftermath of the General Motors sitdown strike has upset the calm of historic Alexandria, five miles from Washington on the Virginia side of the Potomac and home town of General George Washington.

Net income of the Armstrong Cork Company for 1936 after interest, depreciation and allowance for Federal income tax and surtax on undistributed profits was $5,277,534, equal to $4.36 a share of outstanding common stock, against $3,434,912, or $2.84 a share, in 1935, according to the annual statement of the company issued today.

A permanent five-man tribunal to decide disputes in General Motors plants that could not be settled by union shop committees and local plant managers was proposed today by the United Automobile Workers of America in the second day of collective bargaining negotiations between the corporation and the union.

What is in effect a guaranteed minimum wage of $1,200 a year was demanded yesterday by the United Mine Workers of America for 400,000 soft-coal miners when representatives of the union met in the Appalachian Joint Wage Conference with spokesmen for bituominous operators from eight States at the Hotel Biltmore to begin negotiations of a new collective agreement. The present contract expires March 31.
The 250-acre farm estate of Mrs. William J. Jamison of New York, on the Holmdel-Red Bank Highway, adjoining Brookdale Farm, in Holmdel Township, N. J., has been sold to Percy D. Bewster of Newark.

One man was wounded slightly, a second was shot in the thigh in what the police listed, pending investigation, as "an unknown manner" and scores of persons were drawn to Thirty-third Street and Eighth Avenue shortly before 9:30 o'clock last night when a detective fired at a man wanted for questioning.

In his first public discussion of President Roosevelt's judiciary reform program, Secretary Wallace said today that it raised the question whether the government of the United States was to continue functioning through democratic processes for the general welfare or whether the Federal power to work toward this end was to be blocked "by a group in possession of autocratic power."

Following conferences with several New York life insurance companies, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that he had submitted to the Legislature bills slightly modifying the requirements governing investments by life insurance companies.

The five-story building at 48 East Fifty-second Street has been purchased by Maurice Epstein, treasurer of Hattan Estates, Ino., from Dr. George Gray Ward. The strueture occupies a lot 19 by 100 feet, between Madison and Park Avenues, and will be altered for business and apartments.

The trial of Russell Hilbert, the most sensational event in this township since the first contingent of recruits marched off for the World War, began today with the prospect that fists would be flying before the Township Committee decides whether the suspended police chief should be ousted.

Mrs. Anna Sheehan, 27 years old, of 445 West Forty-eighth Street, was indicted yesterday in Queens in connection with the fatal stabbing of her husband, Joseph Sheehan, an elevator operator, at a New Year's Eve party. The indictment charges her with first-degree manslaughter.

Governor Hoffman's statement that sit-down strikes will not be tolerated in New Jersey has drawn attention to a prohibition in the State's Unemployment Compensation Act against payment of benefits to workers who are idle because of labor disputes in which they are directly interested.

Securities with estimated gross proceeds of $5,064,737,000 became fully effective under the Securities Act of 1933 in the calendar year 1936, compared with $2,677,693,000 in 1935, and the portion of these proceeds intended for use by the nation's corporations for working capital and plant and equipment was nearly five times as great, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Hogs weighing more than 180 pounds were in good demand today with prices steady to 5 cents higher than yesterday, but lighter weights were weak to 25 cents lower.
There were elements of an interesting situation in Stephen Powys's comedy, '"Wise Tomorrow," shown at the Lyric Theatre tonight. There is a clash

Three upsets marked the quarterfinal round of the Union League Club's third annual invitation Class B squash racquets tournament last night with Ivy Lee Jr. of the University Club eliminating Valentine A. Ely, Union League, seeded first, in an exciting five-game struggle.
Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederick Talcott last night celebrated the twentieth anniversary of their marriage with "an evening of music and magic" at their home, 16 East Sixty-sixth Street.
Governor Lehman devoted himself to routine Work, preparatory to departing tomorrow afternoon for Ithaca for "Farm and Home Week" at Cornell University.

Oscar Sutermeister, pole vaulter, yesterday was added to the brilliant array of field-event performers who will compete in the annual games of the New York Athletic Club at Madison Square Garden Saturday night. The pole vault is a focal point of track followers' interest this year.
After a long period of rest and meditation, the Theatre Union, which once inhabited the Civic Repertory Playhouse, has moved uptown and upstairs to the Bayes Theatre. Take the elevators just
Mr. and Mrs. William A. Tucker entertained with a dinner last night at their home, 875 Park Avenue, later taking their guests to the Persian Room of the Plaza for supper and dancing.

The first eight elections of new trustees in the 472 mortgage series of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company and Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company were held today under the supervision of the president and secretary of the Westchester County Bar Association.
Peter Bethel, sailing Joanna, beat Anthony Drexel Jr. in Long John Silver by two and a half minutes today in the first of three races of the Royal Nassau Sailing Club for the King's Cup.
Miss Sarah Cleghorn, author and poet, has joined the faculty of Wellesley College for an indefinite period.

Fur and garment leases featured yesterday's commercial renting, with sportswear, - millinery, dress and shoe businesses and some allied specialties prominent among the lessees. In all, a good demand was shown in reports from brokers. The day's list follows:

The first eight elections of new trustees in the 472 mortgage series of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company and Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company were held today under the supervision of the president and secretary of the Westchester County Bar Association.
Peter Bethel, sailing Joanna, beat Anthony Drexel Jr. in Long John Silver by two and a half minutes today in the first of three races of the Royal Nassau Sailing Club for the King's Cup.

The first meeting in the training course in occupational therapy, under the auspices of the hospital committee of the New York Junior League, will be held this morning at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.
Still showing the effect of its four consecutive over-the-limit games, the St. Francis College five fell before a fighting Seth Low team, 35-34, on the losers court last night.

The city police will aid in the ejection and arrest of sit-down strikers in buildings, industrial establishments and relief offices in which a formal complaint is made by the owner or his representative, or a responsible relief official, Chief Inspector John J. Seery disclosed last night.

Edward P. Mulrooney, Correction Commissioner, said today that hardened criminals could deceive lie-detector machines. He was here to address a crime conference. "I know a lot of criminals who would get a kick out of submitting to a lie-detector examination," he said. "I don't

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--Paul V. McNutt of Indianapolis, who was Governor of Indiana from 1933 until Jan. 6, was nominated today by President Roosevelt to be High Commissioner to the Philippines. He will succeed Frank Murphy, now Governor of Michigan.
Detained in jail here today after suffering terrifying hallucinations, Mrs. John Smuts of Boston (the former May Yohe), scoffed at the reputed curse of the Hope diamond which she twice wore.

The Glidden Company's reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission on salaries and other remuneration paid during the fiscal year, which ended on Oct. 31 last, were made public by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

Eight New York and New Jersey students at the University of Maine have been named on the Dean's List. They are: Nathan W. Fellows Jr., '38, of Scarsdale, N. Y.; Howard J. Stagg, '37, of Syracuse; Edna L.
With the Mount Van Hoevenberg bobrun in racing condition for the first time this Winter, officials tonight decided to hold the first championship events of the season tomorrow morning.

Dmitri Mitropolous, who two weeks ago was guest conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, will be conductor of the orchestra the next two seasons. Engagement of Mitropoulous was announced at tonight's symphony concert by E. L. Carpenter, president of the Orchestral Association.
The heads of fourteen governments, including President Roosevelt, were informed by cable today of the official formation of a permanent international committee of war veterans in the Reich capital.

A report that former President Hoover plans to make an extended attack upon President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court in an address at the Union League Club Saturday night is current here.

Apartment property was the cen ter of attention in Bronx trading reported yesterday. The 900 Rogers Place Corporation, represented by, Sidney Anthony, sold the five-storY house at 900 Rogers Place, southeast corner of 163d Street, to an investing client of Abraham Sobil Low Gross, Inc., broker, announces.

Emerson Pitt Harris, pioneer publisher of trade publications, writer and former broker in publishing properties, died on Wednesday of pneumonia at his home in Franklinville, N. Y. Long active here and in Jersey City, N. J., and Montclair, N. J., he had been in ill health for several years. His age was 83.
The lower house of the States General today passed almost unanimously the budget for the Netherland East Indies for 1937, including 95,500,000 guilders for defense against 88,900,000 in 1936.

Because of the increase in demand for distillate fuel oil, gasoline stocks may reach the 78,000,000barrel level by the end of March, Fred Van Covern, director- of the department of statistics of the American Petroleum Institute, yesterday told the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at their annual meeting here.

Plowing through a maze of complicated financial details, humor, repartee and frequent bitter exchanges between counsel, Jacob Gruber, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, continued today his effort to prove the SEC's charges of stock manipulation against W. E. Hutton Co. of New York, which, if substantiated, might lead to the suspension or expulsion of the brokerage firm from the various exchanges of the country.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. R. Reynolds of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rhoda Reynolds, to Arthur Edward Sutton, son of Mrs. Walter J. Sutton and the late Mr. Sutton of Port Chester, N. Y.

The presentation of the prizes to the winners of cash awards in the Wood, Field and Stream Snapshot Contest sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES Wide World Photos, Inc., and the National Sportsmen's Show will take place at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon in the special photographic salon on the third floor at Grand Central Palace.

Negotiators for General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached an understanding today which they expected would end issues such as caused a new strike at the Fisher Body-Chevrolet plants in St. Louis.

A new theory fundamentally altering accepted views of the structure of the universe and the nature of time will be published here tomorrow by Professor Paul A. M. Dirac, brilliant young Cambridge physicist who revolutionized the quantum theory a few years ago and won the Nobel Prize.

More than 200 members of the Supreme Court Post of the American Legion attended the annual dinner of the organization held last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Luke Higgins, secretary to City Court Justice Thomas F. Noonan, was installed as the new commander of the post.

David Levinson, American lawyer who came here in an unsuccessful attempt to defend Harry Berger and Luis Carlos Prestes, accused of having taken part in the revolt of November, 1935, sailed today for New York aboard the steamship Southern Prince.

Oscar J. Smith, lawyer, former Assemblyman and active opponent of prohibition, died yesterday of pneumonia in Knickebocker Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 930 St. Nicholas Avenue. His office was at 101 Beekman Street.

J. Halperin Co., Inc.. arranged a firstmortgage loan of $160,000 on a new sixstory apartment house at 45-42 41st St., Long Island City, for the L. R. Development Corp., Simon Lipoff president, for ten years at 5 per cent. A first-mortgage loan of $60,000 at 4 1/2 per cent on the one-story business building at 108-10 North Main St., Port Chester.

Dr. Lamartine G. Hardman, former Governor of Georgia, died of a heart ailment today at Emory University Hospital. He was 80 years old. The Commerce (Ga.) physician, business man and politician was elected Governor in 1926 after two unsuccessful campaigns. He served two terms of two years each.

The Right Rev. Valentine Kohlbeck, Mitred Abbot of the Bohemian Benedictine Order of priests and one of the foremost churchmen and editors of Czech ancestry in the United States, died last night at St. Anthony's Hospital. Yesterday was his seventy-third birthday anniversary.
The Yale golf team will invade Scotland and England this Summer and play twelve matches, it was announced tonight by Malcolm Farmer, chairman of the Yale Athletic Association.

The world consumption of petroleum, its products and related fuels in 1936 made a new high record at 1,757,778,000 barrels, an increase of 143,000,000 barrels over 1935, according to an estimate made by V. R. Garfias and R. V. Whetsel of the Cities Service Company.

A young automobile worker who has been an operative for the Pinkerton National Detective Agency in the Lansing, Mich., plant of the Fisher Body division of General Motors Corporation since October, 1935, told the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage today that all five officers of the Lansing local of the United Automobile Workers of America had been undercover operatives for Pinkerton, while ostensibly serving the union.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Feb. 16: COMMANDER Awtrey, R. K., the Charleston, to continue treatment at the Naval Hospital, Charleston, S. c.

Four manhole covers in East Thirty-first Street, between Second and Third Avenues, blew off with loud explosions about 7:45 o'clock last night. The blasts were followed 'by bursts of fire and smoke and caused the cessation of electric light service in nine houses and the Chinese church in the block.

Meeting yesterday at the Commodore for the first time since teachers' salaries were restored, the board of delegates of the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations of New York City adopted a constitution placing the organization on a permanent basis.

President Roosevelt today recommended to Congress legislation which would set up a system of governmentally managed crop insurance for the 1938 wheat crop, designed as the first step to a system of "all risk" crop insurance as "a part of the foundation of agricultural policy we are building."

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, said tonight he had telegraphed President Roosevelt an assurance "of the support of our organization in your program for the reform of the United States Supreme Court."

While the share values of Britain's leading armament companies have been rising at a rate of ??128,000 per hour since the government's ??400,000,000 arms loan was announced last Thursday, the fall in government securities has been almost as substantial.

There was cheering and dancing in the streets around the Town Hall here tonight for "good ol' Russ" Hilbert, suspended one-man police force in the township, who was reinstated by a 2 to 1 vote of the Township Committee, effective immediately.

A definite move was made by President Roosevelt today to break the deadlock on naval construction, which has resulted from operation of the Walsh-Healey act, through a conference with Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, designed, it was announced, to find ways for speeding naval construction.

The police will not be "too strict" in their enforcement of the new traffic code, which goes into effect on Sunday, Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday. He declared, however, that this policy would not apply to "dangerous driving" as defined by the new rules.
William C. Proctor, former vice president and treasurer of the Magnolia Petroleum Company, died at his home here today. He was 70 years old. He retired in 1932.

F. V. S. Hyde, four-time holder of the national title, yesterday advanced one step nearer his objective when he defeated M. C. Markham of the Princeton Club, 15-8, 15-10, in the second round of the national veterans' squash tennis championship on the Yale Club courts.

LAGE, WILLIAM A. (May 11, 1936). Gross assets, $11,872; net, $3,496. To daughter, Veronica Kratzer; son, William S. J. Lage, one-half of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $8,000; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $2,398; miscel laneous property, $1,474. William J. Trenkle, attorney, 44 Court St.

A "substantial" increase in Works Progress costs and employment as a result of the devastation in the flood area, from which he recently returned, was predicted today by Harry L. Hopkins, administrator.

The American Metal Company, Ltd., has given the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation an option, subject to approval of stockholders, to acquire 60,000 shares of American Metal's common stock in exchange for Consolidated Coppermines stock.

SERGEANT-Clinton D. Townsend, from 5th Precinct to Office of the Second Deputy Police Commissioner, Division of Licenses, assigned to clerical duty. PATROLMEN-Walter G. Haslam, from 1st Precinct to 120th Precinct. John F. Wade, 9th Precinct, assigned to duty as attendant.

The semi-final matches of the Belleair amateur golf championship turned out as was generally expected today as Garret A. Hobart, steady shotmaker from Paterson, N. J., stroked his way to a 4-and-3 victory over David Howard, Buffalo, and Vincent K. Hilton, Dayton, Ohio, by virtue of better putting, eliminated the long-hitting Boston Red Sox hurler, Jack Russell, by 2 up.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By DOROTHY J. CERVANTES, housewife. 248 South 3d Av., Mount Vernon.--Liabilities $1,255: no assets. NICHOLAS DARATSAKIS, unemployed, 1,39S 2d Av.--Liabilities $1,402; no assets.

The following Coast Guard orders for the week ended Feb. 17 were announced today: Lt. Comdr. D. C. McNeil, the Galate, effective upon arrival of that vessel at navy yard. Charleston, S. C.; assigned Charleston Navy Yard to duty in connection with construction and outfitting the George M.
Lumber promotion registered a greater than seasonal increase last week and the index advanced to 69.3 from 59.1. It was 73.1 for the week ended Feb. 15, 1936.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 11 per cent for the first twelve shopping days of February as compared with the same period last year, it was reported yesterday by the New York Federal Reserve Bank.
Joy W. Dow, who severed his connection with the old New York Mining Exchange to become an architect, died here today at the age of 77.

With Sylvanus Apps playing his best game of the season, the Maple Leafs defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 1, tonight for their first National Hockey League victory of the campaign over the defending champions.

Increased receipts of hogs here today gave buyers the advantage and prices declined 10c to 25c a hundredweight, bringing hogs more in line with the price of fresh pork. The top price was 10 cents lower than yesterday at $10.30, while the day's average declined 15 cents to $10.05.
The Social Welfare Committee of the House of Representatives has approved a series of restrictions for Tennessee marriage laws proposed as a result of the recent marriage of a 9-year-old girl.

Two resolutions proposing constitutional amendments have been offered by opponents of President ROOSEVELT'S Supreme Court plan. One would provide for the compulsory retirement of justices at the age of 75. The other would give Congress power in certain circumstances to override adverse decisions of the court by a two-thirds vote of both branches.
Winston Churchill expressed hope tonight that the United States would build up its navy to keep pace with Great Britain keel for keel.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday proposed transfers of memberships from the estate of the late William Carroll Wilson to Stephen A. Tanburn, who has offices with Emanuel Co., and from Curtis W. Hutton to Maxwell M. Bilofsky, who has offices with Hedberg Koppisch.
The Union Steam Pump company announced today that its plant, where a strike has been in progress for five weeks, would be "wholly shut down and closed indefinitely."
The twenty-sixth annuel convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America will be held in the Greenbrier Hotel, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., Nov. 5 to 7.
Leases of office space featured yesterday's report of commercial space taken, and the demand cenered in the financial district and the midtown section of the city. The list follows:
Fighting on the Jarama River front, southeast of this city, has been exceptionally heavy today. Counter-attack followed attack as both sides strained for a few hundred yards of territory.

In a farewell message on his departure for New York today, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, called attention to the fact that 52 per cent of the island's population was under 14 years old and said, "This tells its own story."

Although skiing conditions in general are poor throughout the East, the New Haven and New York Central Railroads have discovered several sections where snow is available, and are making preparations to accommodate capacity crowds on week-end "snow trains" tonight.

Freddie Steele, the Tacoma (Wash.) fighter who is generally regarded as the world middleweight champion, will risk his title against Eddie (Babe) Risko, Syracuse exchampion, in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. With the recent revival of interest in the 160-pound division, the fight seems to have caught the interest of local fans, and Promoter James J. Johnston is confident of a turnout of 10.000 spectators.

The annual birthday party of Mary Alexander Field Chapter, Children of the Confederacy, was held at the cottage on Lake Avenue, Greenwich, this afternoon. It was the birthday of the late Mrs. Mary Alexander Field, mother of Mrs. Charles D. Lanier, and the fourth birthday of the chapter.

Andre de Laboulaye, retiring French Ambassador, stressed yesterday the importance of the bond of amity between France and the United States and expressed the hope that a similar amicable relationship would be extended among all the nations of the world.

BARTOCCI, MARIA (Feb. 5). Estate, $1,350. To Laura Labate, 390 Allerton Av., Bronx; Cira Verna, 761 E. 211th St., and Rosa Tardone, 219 Highlawn Av., Brooklyn, daughters, executrices, $125 each; two specific bequests. HURLEY, JOSEPH (Dec. 31). Estate, $700. To Rita Ryan, executrix, 457 W. 155th St., residue; five specific bequests.

Braman B. Adams of the University Club and John B. Wilkinson of the Harvard Club became the finalists yesterday in the Union League Club's third annual invitation Class B squash racquets tournament. They will meet to decide the title this afternoon at 5:30.

Veneers of urban life wear thin in one section of New York this week. The patinas of brick and stone and steel give way to healthier and, perhaps, more fundamental things; the smell of balsam and fir, the bright eyes of deer and other forest folk; the swish of a delicately balanced rod in the back cast;

The improvement in bond prices, although modest, was extended yesterday over a fairly broad front in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace slowed down somewhat, but the market generally reflected a return of confidence, particularly among the higher grade loans.

George Reid Richardson, a boat builder known to many American yachtsmen, died at the age of 57 last night in his home. He suffered a heart attack a week ago. He was president and general manager of the Richardson Boat Company, which he founded twenty-eight years ago. He built standardized cruisers and other pleasure craft.

Opposition was voiced yesterday to the plan for reorganizing the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation by a Class A stockholder who asserted that that type of stock had been converted improperly into common shares when the corporation was recapitalized in 1931.

Mr. and Mrs. George H. Schroder of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Schroder, to Alexander J. Geiges Jr., son of Alexander Geiges, also of East Orange, and the late Mrs. Geiges.

Governor Sir Edward Denham, who returned from Miami this afternoon, heard at Cienfuegos, Cuba, that there was no immediate prospect of the Cuban Government's repatriating most of the Jamaican laborers in Cuba. Nor were Jamaicans being taken to concentration camps, he was told.

Miss Cecile Claude Verron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Verron of Paris, was married yesterday morning to Edmund L. Palmieri, son of former City Court Justice and Mrs. John Palmieri of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed

Playing the last thirteen holes of the Mid-Ocean course in only one stroke over par figures, despite a stiff north wind which made control difficult, T. Suffern Tailer of New York today gained possession of the medal in the qualifying round of the fourth annual MidOcean invitation golf tournament.
The Farm Credit Administration announced today that the $50,000,000 provided by Congress for 1937 emergency crop and feed loans would be available to farmers this week in all parts of the country.

Joseph F. Lamorelle, president judge of the Orphans' Court of Philadelphia, died at his home in Overbrook tonight after an illness of more than a year. His age was 81. Long known as a leader of the Philadelphia bar, he had served on the bench more than thirty years.

TODAY-New England: Generally cloudy, probably snow flurries in the north and warmer, with thawing temperatures over south and central portions. New York State: Generally cloudy, probably snow flurries over the north and warmer, with thawing temperatures over south and central portions. Pennsylvania:

The political prisoners in Sofia, including Colonel Damian Veltcheff, who is serving a life sentence as the leader of the abortive plot against King Boris in October, 1935, and his comrades, will be sent to Sliven Monday.

The New York Board of Trade announced yesterday that it had written to the representatives in Congress from New York objecting to legislation which would-transfer from the War Department jurisdictional powers over the proposal to build a Hudson River bridge near Fifty-seventh Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Maddox Rumbough of the Waldorf-Astoria and Elstan Oaks, Lloyd Neck, Huntington, L. I., are leaving today for Palm Beach. Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw will give a dinner on Monday at her home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street.

Miss Wanda Michalis Constable of this city, daughter of Mrs. John Pierpont Constable of Constableville, N. Y., and the late Mr. Constable, was married last night to Warren Cady Crane 2d in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

German interest in Swedish factories was revealed by a strange offer to advise industrialists on antiair raid measures. By some the offer was taken as a pretext to obtain vital information about Swedish industrial undertakings.

Representative Florence Thurston, Democrat, of Bethel, sponsor of a bill which would set Maine's biennial State election date in November, holds it would prevent "national campaign workers coming into Maine buying our electorate."

Objecting strenuously to the use of cages for trapping of stray cats along the waterfront, Mrs. Martha J. Atkins, self-appointed guardian of the several hundred which roam this town, threatened tonight to have Walter R. Nickerson, agent of the Animal Rescue League, and his cat trapping assistant, Policeman William E. Carlos, prosecuted on the charge of "cruelty to animals."
The Stock Exchange admitted yesterday to dealing the "when issued" rights of the American Smelting and Refining Company and the Johns-Manville Corporation.

Mrs. Edith Chamberlain ?? daughter of Mrs. Selah Chamber lain of Woodside, Calif., and ? late Mr. Chamberlain, was married to Frederick Vanderbilt Field of this city yesterday in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building by Deputy City Clerk Thomas J. Barry.

A participating dividend of 66 3/4 cents a share has been declared on the 5% per cent participating preference stock of James Talcott, Inc., representing 18 per cent of net earnings for 1936, less the fixed dividend charge.

The marriage of Miss Cornelia Shepard, daughter of Frederia White Shepard of Woodmere, L. I., and the late Mrs. Shepard, to Dr. John Lawrence Riker, son of Mrs. Henry Ingersoll Riker of 7 East Seventy-second Street, and the late Mr. Riker, took place yesterday afternoon at 136 East Seventyninth Street, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Bruton Strange.

A banking group composed of E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and including MacBride, Miller Co. and Colyer, Robinson Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $450,000 of improvement and hospital bonds of Middlesex County, N. J., on a bid of 100.08 for $350,000 as 3s and $100,000 as 3 1/4s.
Francis A. Staten, an accountant for the Federal Communications Commission, testified today that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had tried to dominate the motion picture industry.

The National Biscuit Company and subsidiaries, in the annual report for 1936, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $12,640,077 after depreciation, Federal and foreign income taxes and other charges. After preferred dividend requirements, the income is equivalent to $1.73 each on 6,289,448 shares of $10-par common stock.
Dust clouds blew in thinning billows over parts of the Southwest tonight as Oklahoma officials mobilized for war on a four-State front against the menace to crops.

Playing in his best form, Edward Charles Rogers of Glen Cove, L. I., last night won the national amateur pocket billiard championship at the Capitol Health Center by subjecting the defending champion, Lewis Brooks of Philadelphia, to a decisive defeat.

The Actors Equity Association modified its support of the Dickstein bill to limit the entry of foreign stage, screen and musical artists into this country in testimony given today before the HouseImmigration Committee by its president, Frank Gillmore.

Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Philippine Islands, will arrive at 2:30 P. M. today at Pennsylvania Station, where he and his party will be received by Mayor La Guardia and escorted to the Hotel Ambassador.

Leonard Hartman, defending titleholder, and Morris Adelsberg, seeded first and fourth, respectively, joined Frank Bowden in the semi-final round of the Brooklyn indoor tennis championship at the 106th Regiment Armory yesterday. Bowden gained the next to the last round on Wednesday.
Building projects submitted yesterday to the Manhattan Department of Buildings included plans for a dwelling in East Fifty-fourth Street and alterations to a variety of structures.

Wedgwood Benn, who as Secretary of State for India was one of the outstanding figures in the last Labor government, was returned to Parliament tonight in a by-election in the Gorton division of Manchester.

A drive to crystallize opinion on President Roosevelt's proposal for the enlargement of the Supreme Court was opened yesterday by six leaders of the Voluntary Committee of Lawyers, which took a prominent part in the nation-wide campaign for repeal of the prohibition amendment.

Walter Merrill Hall, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for the last three years; Walter L. Pate, Davis Cup team captain the last two seasons, and Julian S. Myrick, former president and Davis Cup chairman, form a new big three that will direct the international play of the association in 1937.

The engagement of Miss Helen Mayna Shannon of this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John J. Shannon of Boston, to the Rev. Harry Bertram Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Taylor of Linn, W. Va., has been announced by her sister, Miss Marie E. Shannon of Boston.
Members of the United States Army horse show team scored an overwhelming victory over seventy competitors in the highly important contest for the Minister of National Defense Trophy today.

In response to queries that have reached the Senate Foreign Relations Committee concerning certain aspects of the Neutrality Bill that it is expected to report favorably on Saturday, Chairman Key Pittman of Nevada explained today that the bill under consideration did nothing to alter existing neutrality relations with the Latin-American republics.
Miss Betsy Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip L. Ross of this place was married to WilliamReed Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Reed of Chappaqua, this evening at the Scarsdale Golf Club here.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order directing Dart Co. of Detroit, a brokerage concern, to show cause why it should not be suspended or expelled from the Detroit Stock Exchange and the Chicago Stock Exchange for alleged manipulative activities in the common stock of the Lakey Foundry and Machine Company, a security registered on the Detroit Stock Exchange and admitted to unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange.

Announcement of gifts totaling $300,000 for the building of two dormitories at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, which will be the first step in the creation of an enlarged campus, was made last night by Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of the institute, at the thirty-seventh annual alumni dinner, held at the Hotel Astor.
Clarence C. Pell, winner of the title twelve times since 1915, was eliminated from the national amateur racquets championship yesterday as play started at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

President Manuel Luis Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth said today he did not believe Japan presented a "menace" to the Philippines or that a "Japanese situation" would arise when the islands obtain their independence nine years hence.

Recommendation that suit be filed to recover more than $100,000,000 of assets for the Standard Gas and Electric Company was made to Judge John P. Nields in the United States District Court here today by William G. Mahaffey of Wilmington and William H. Button of New York, special counsel appointed by the judge.

WELL, young man, now that you've read Dorothy L. Sayers's "Busman's Honeymoon" (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50), are you prepared to eat your sulky words of a couple of months ago about mystery novels? So you were one of those who kept urging, "Read Dorothy Sayers and see the light!" No, I haven't changed my mind.
Prank C. Manley, a former member of the Board of Education and the Roselle Borough Council, died last night at his home following a long illness.
Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would sign the Burke bill providing a working day of eight consecutive hours for nurses in city hospitals when the measure came to him.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, drove the first nail yesterday initiating a construction program of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, which will place 1,000 small houses in communities throughout the country this year.
The New York University junior varsity basketball team yesterday defeated the Manhattan jayvees, 34-33, on the Violet court. The victors' attack was led by Leo Feingold, who tallied 8 points.

The Triborough Bridge Authority received the last installment of a $35,000,000 Federal loan for the bridge yesterday in a $5,000,000 check delivered by Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director. A small part of the $9,000,000 outright Federal grant is still to be paid.

A special grand jury returned a true bill today indicting John Palm, 25, of Mount Vernon, N. Y., on a charge of first-degree murder in connection with the slaying of Deputy Sheriff Pete J. Kaminski in Milford Oct. 3.

The Globe Rutgers Fire Insurance Company reported yesterday a policyholders' surplus of $12,092,385 at the close of 1936, after establishing a voluntary reserve of $2,500,000 available to absorb declines in security values, retirements of stocks and other items, comparing with a policyholders' surplus of $10,641,237 at the end of 1935, when there was no voluntary reserve, and a surplus of $5,132,347 at the end of 1934.

Secret Service agents, detectives, uniformed patrolmen and soldiers comprised the convoy last night when the government started its second shipment of gold from New York to the Federal treasure house at Fort Knox, Ky.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy granted a temporary injunction late yesterday afternoon restraining striking sandhogs from continuing their walkout on the Rosoff Tunnel Corporation job on the Wards Island intercepting sewer, but strikers who attended the hearing refused to go back to work. About 100 of the men were in the court house for the hearing.

General Sir Herbert Lawrence, 76-year-old chairman of Vickers, Ltd., who as a champion of private arms manufacture has aroused the wrath of pacifists with every speech, announced tonight his forthcoming resignation.
The special committee appointed by President Roosevelt to study the problem of the influx of foreign capital into the United States met again today but reached no conclusions.

A flood relief contribution of $1,530.07 was received yesterday afternoon at the New York offices of the Red Cross from the Chinese Consolidated and Benevolent Associtation, representing forty-two local Chinese organizations.
" Having Wonderful Time" will not have its premiere tonight at the Lyceum Theatre. That event now is scheduled for tomorrow evening at the same house.

Germany's exports declined 9 per cent in January compared with the record month of December, but by throttling imports to the lowest point in a year she was able to maintain an export surplus of 79,000,000 marks, or only slightly less than in the preceding month.

Senator Horatio Clarence Hocken died tonight in Toronto General Hospital. He was 79 years old. With the late W. M. MacLean he founded The Toronto Star and became business manager. He was Grand Master of the Grand Orange Lodge of Ontario West and Grand Master for British North America.
Persons of 70 years of age or over have been increasing about twice as fast as the total population, the Census Bureau reported today.

With only two trading days remaining before the circulation of notices on next Tuesday evening up of outstanding March contracts was under way on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Factors were so evenly balanced that fluctuations held within unusually narrow limits to end with a loss of a point to a gain of 3 points on the day.

Tne executive committee of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission chose a site in the south side of the Tidal Basin today for the $3,000,000 memorial to the second President, for which funds were appropriated by Congress. The committee also approved the design submitted by John Russell Pope of New York and engaged him as the architect to supervise construction.
With exhibits representing outdoor life from sunny lands to arctic regions, the National Sportsmen's Show opened yesterday at the Grand Central Palace.

Her vocal cords and one arm partly paralyzed, apparently by a frightening experience last night, Miss Sophie Fleisher, 26 years old, of 503 South Seventeenth Street, rested at her home today, showing signs of recovery, but still unable to talk enough to tell what had happened.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins was chosen grand marshall for the annual St. Patrick's Day parade by the St. Patrick's Day committee at a meeting last night at the Hotel Astor which was attended by more than 500 representatives of various Irish societies of New York City.

Senator A. Harry Moore of New Jersey has renewed efforts in the Senate to secure payment of $109,088 to the Passaic Valley Sewage Commission for damage done to a sewer outlet in the Hudson River in 1923.

Don Lash, who established a new record for two miles at Boston last Saturday, will confine his efforts to the same distance at the N. Y. A. C. games here tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden. Lash had been entered in both the one and twomile events, but will stick to the longer distance.

A mortgage for $40,000 on 116 E. 83d St., held by the Bank for Savings from the 116 E. Eighty-third Street Corp., Jeanette L. Windegger president, was extended to March 4, 1940, the interest being reduced from 5 to 41/2 per cent. Two mortgages held by the Emigrant Bank from the Redrock Realty Corp.,

An unusual operation has just been performed on the pet of Cologne zoo visitors, the 5-yearold female orang-utan Lotte. An X-ray examination had established the presence of several iron splinters in the animal's appendix.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Ruth Adams Donley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Donley of Plainfield, N. J., and Oyster Bay, L. I., to James Alexander Malloy of this city and London on Feb. 9 in the Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea, Palm Beach, Fla.

Dr. Enrique Olaya Herrera, former President of Colombia and Minister to the Vatican since 1935, died today at Quissa Sana Clinic. He was 56 years old. The wife of the former Colombian envoy to Washington was at his bedside when he died after receiving a final benediction went by Pope Pius XI.
When people say that man is in danger of being devoured by his own machines, they have in mind machine guns, bombing

Governor Lehman recommended today in a special - message submission to the voters of a proposal for a bond issue of $60,000,000 for permanent State improvements such as hospitals, other State institutions, bridges and highways.

Harry Greenspan of 1,219 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, motorist whose fourteen summonses for illegal parking since 1934 caused his case to require a hearing of several hours in Downtown Traffic Court on Tuesday, pleaded guilty yesterday on all counts before Magistrate Burke in the same court.

The alleged failure of Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissidner Valentine and Chief City Magistrate Schurman to evince more than passing interest in the investigation the New York Criminal Courts Bar Association ordered a committee to make of the conduct of Magistrate Overton Harris on the bench led to a telegram of protest yesterday to Mr. La Guardia.

Federal officials said tonight that customs patrolmen and Mexican liquor smugglers staged a gunfight on the Rio Grande in which one Mexican was killed, two were wounded, one was captured and four escaped. Several sacks of liquor were confiscated.

United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City: General Conditions Veal continued to move very slowly at weak prices. Other classes were In fair to good demand. Steer hinds and ribs sold lower to the wholesale trade while retail sales were steady. The lamb market continued to advance. Fresh pork cuts sold steady to slightly lower. Kosher business was confined largely to lamb at somewhat stronger prices.

Following is the text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature asking a new bond issue: To the Legislature: New and reasonable demands for construction and permanent improvements are insistent and. urgent. We would be remiss in the performance of our duties if we ignored them or postponed action as was customary fifteen or more years ago.

The three-acre estate of Olivia G. and John D. Sullivan on Glendale Road in New Castle has been sold to Joseph H. Ream of the Columbia Broadcasting studios. A recently remodeled Colonial house is situated on the property. George Howe, Inc., negotiated the deal.

Members of both the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., and the Children's Coat Association will be asked to give their views on the reduction of coat terms from the present 8 per cent to a net basis, as favored by the Merchants Ladies Garment Association.

Alvin Griesedieck of the Falstaff Brewing Corporation, St. Louis, has been elected president of the Brewing Industry, Inc., to succeed Paul Esselborn, who has resigned as head of the organization. Jules R.

Ordinarily the time of Winter when wooded trails and open slopes in the "Northlands" re-echo with the clarion cry of "track" of enthusiastic skiers, the Washington Birthday holiday period this weekend offers little consolation for the snow zealots.
Legal action to prevent James J. Braddock from fighting Joe Louis in Chicago next June for the world heavyweight championship was threatened today.

Thrift House, said to be one of the largest rummage shops in the world, contributed more than $106,000 in three years to the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, according to an announcement made yesterday at the annual meeting by Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, who was re-elected chairman.
The newspaper Intransigeant today quoted Marcel Thil, the International Boxing Union's middleweight champion, as saying he had abandoned his claim to the title and would retire from the ring.

With his main budget bill still pending, Governor Lehman today sent a special message to the Legislature, urging that a $60,000,000 issue of serial longterm bonds be authorized, the proceeds to be used for permanent public improvements at the State's hospitals for the insane, at penal, charitable and educational institutions of the State, and for highways, parkways and some other purposes.

The April selection of the Book of the Month Club will be "Bread and Wine," a new novel by Ignazio Silone, author of "Fontamara." The book will be issued jointly by Harper and the Story Press on April 2. The author is an Italian and his book is decidedly anti-Fascist in point of view. It was picked by a book club in Switzerland and one in Holland.

Carlos Chavez's second Thursday night concert with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall strengthened the impression he made at his first appearance there as a musician and conductor of very exceptional knowledge and experience with the baton; also an interpreter

Burton B. Turkus, former defense counsel in the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping case, tried in Brooklyn last week, renewed his attack yesterday on District Attorney Geoghan by charging that the prosecutor had promised suspended sentences to the defendants in return for their "cooperation,"

Since control of the Western Pacific is Japan's strategic policy, the navy, according to the newspaper Nichi Nichi, is concerned about indications that the United States will follow the British example in naval building.

Bearish sentimenrt predominated among traders in wheat in the early part of the session on the Board of Trade here today and the market developed an easy undertone. However, there was rather persistent buying on scale orders by commission houses on the way down, especially in the new-crop months.

Rodney Fuller Co. were the highest bidders for underwriting the $750,000 of 5 per cent five-year convertible bonds of the Granby Consolidated Mining, Smelting and Power Company, Ltd., it was stated yesterday.

Miss Ruth Wiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Wiss of South Orange, N. J., gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the WaldorfAstoria for Miss Sylvianne Kendall Blanchard, whose marriage to'Carl Gunther Triest will take place tomorrow in the Church of the Resurrection. Among those present were

At last the French Government seems to mean business regarding Spanish affairs. It apparently is determined either to bring to an end the growing influx of Italians into the peninsula or resume its freedom of movement.

The New York Rangers had to go into overtime last night to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. In the extra session Ott Heller lifted a high shot over Goalie Mike Karakas's left shoulder to break a tie that had existed since the second period, and the Blue Shirts were victonrious by the score of 2 to 1.

Dr. Archibald Henderson, biographer of George Bernard Shaw, announced tonight that he has just given Yale University his entire collection of Shaviana. It covers a period of thirty-five years and is regarded as the most nearly complete in the world.

Vincent Bendix, head of the largest corporation making accessories for both the automotive and aeronautical industries, announced yesterday that he planned to build the aviation center of the United States at Hasbrouck Heights, N. J.

Continuing her brilliant golf, Miss Patty Berg, Minneapolis star, won her semi-final match in the women's annual championship of Palm Beach Conutry Club today. She scored a notable victory over Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., the trans-Mississippi cham pion, by 3 and 1, rallies at two stages aiding in her triumph.

NOBODY should waste much sympathy on the apparent victims of chicanery or skullduggery in the very odd business of boxing. If they had their way, the temporary sufferers would be giving the current triumphant parties the worst of it in similar hearty fashion.

The new flying boat Caledonia, which is equipped for experimental transatlantic flights, flew non-stop from Southampton, England, to Alexandria today in 13 hours 35 minutes, at an average speed of 184 miles an hour.
Designations were made by the War Department today from Brooklyn, New York City and other New York areas for West Point entrance examination on March 2.

A strike conducted jointly by the Retail Cigar Salesmen's Union, Local 906, and the Pharmacists Union resulted yesterday in the closing of fourteen Silver Rod Drug Stores in New York, Westchester County, Long Island and New Jersey.

Mrs. Howard Metcalfe Taylor of 1,037 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, and Bay Crest, Huntington, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Taylor, to Joseph Walter Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Walter'Miller of Princeton, N. J.

Mrs. Raymond V. Ingersoll, wife of the Borough President of Brooklyn, will leave Monday for Guatemala, Central America, where she will spend several weeks searching for the sacred quetzal, a crested member of the parrot family.
