An ardent ornithologist, she explained yesterday that her object was to observe birds in their Winter tropical home.

Nearly 2,000 employes of five shirt factories here who quit work Tuesday in a general "stoppage" called by Local 126 of the shirt workers division of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America returned to their machines this afternoon

A jury predominantly non-professional was confronted this afternoon in the poison trial of Chang Soo Lee with the problem of whether trivalent or pentavalent arsenic was the more dangerous for human consumption, a question which the defense regards as decisive.
Theology professors and clergymen, many his former students, honored Dr. Douglas C. MacIntosh of the Yale Divinity School at a dinner on his sixtieth birthday tonight.

Reversing a custom under which Nobel Prize winners go to the Swedish court to receive their honors, representatives of King Gustav V brought the literature award to Eugene O'Neill in a hospital here. The playwright had an

In about five years Dion Boucicault's "London Assurance" will be a centurion. On the whole, that is the most remarkable thing about this period piece and quondam favorite which was revived at the Vanderbilt last evening. All through the latter half of

The United States Treasury notified yesterday depositary banks in e this Federal Reserve District that it had called for repayment on next Tuesday and Wednesday of $27,068,900, or $13,534,450 on each day.

Bank clearings of the leading cities throughout the nation in the week ended on Wednesday, last, declined 1.2 per cent from the total in the corresponding week of 1936. Only five business days this year were included in the report of some sections, as compared with the full week last year, it was pointed out.

Apartment house deals in which banks figured as sellers comprised the bulk of realty trading in Manhattan yesterday. Several of the transactions were resales. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold the five-story apartment house on a lot 21 by 100.5 feet at 135 East Sixtieth Street in a deal negotiated by Brett Wyckoff,

Engagement of $1,650,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which also noted receipt here of $6,120,500 in gold, the largest single day's arrival in two weeks. The total included $2,545,200 from Canada, $2,005,100 from Switzerland, $1,461,500 from Australia and $108,700 from India.

Fears that the State emergency taxes, introduced to keep the State's finances on a sound basis and to provide for the victims of the depression, "may become a permanent part of the State tax system" were expressed in a report on Governor Lehman's budget approved yesterday by the board of directors of the Merchants' Association.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Feb. 17: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Grant, D. N. W., Med. Corps, Maxwell Field, Ala., to Barksdale Field, La. Magruder, M. (F.A.), General Staff Corps, Hawaii, relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps, and ordered to 68th F. A.. Ft. Knox, Ky.
The Massachusetts Senate today adopted, by a party vote of 22 to 9, an order protesting to Congress against President Roosevelt's plan for -revision of the Federal court system.

The Rev. Dr. Frank Burrows Reazor, rector emeritus of St. Mark's Episcopal Church of West Orange, died yesterday at his home in Morristown, it was learned here today. He was 80 years old. He resigned the West Orange post in 1924 and at that time he was made rector emeritus.

F. Barry Ryan of Short Hills, seeded first, and Joseph J. Lord of the New York Athletic Club advanced to the final round of the Whitehall Club's squash tennis tournament yesterday. The will meet this afternoon at 12:30 o'clock.
Life flowed smoothly onward today in the well-ordered farm household of Mr. and Mrs. James Masse-the be birth of their twenty-first child caused scarcely a ripple.

The team race between four American and four Cuban yachts, all participants in the eleventh international Star Class series for the Cuba and Bacardi Trophies, was won today by the American group with a total of 23 points, to 12 for the Cuban quartet.
Requefort cheese, American style, is coming out of coal and limestone mines in Pennsylvania, it was announced today at Pennsylvania State College.

The House Merchant Marine Committee was told at a hearing today that serious loss might be caused to the Port of New York from a consolidation of the America-France Line with the American Hampton RoadsYankee Line.
Producers of steel and dealers in scrap steel agreed today to establish "an economic price" for scrap metal, ending competitive bidding caused by scant supplies. The deal, arranged through the

Fees and disbursements totaling $146,044 were recommended today for lawyers and others for services rendered in connection with the reorganization of the Botany Consolidated Mills. Inc., of Passaic under
Ponchielli's "La Gioconda," which was absent from the Metropolitan Opera's repertoire last season, was presented last night and the performance was termed a revival.
Women should not be permitted to drink at bars, Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, said last night at the annual dinner of the Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association at the Hotel Astor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The annual report of Dean Smith of Columbia Law School points out the "appalling conditions" prevailing in the legal profession. There can be no quarrel with this report. The subject has been periodically called to the attention of the public and the bar. The quarrel, rather, is with the passiveness with which this condition is accepted and permitted to grow worse.

Although modern science has contributed its inventiveness to make possible all the Talking Books issued for sightless "readers" by the American Foundation for the Blind, it has brought more than its usual ingenuity to the latest book, that on the wild birds of America. This book not only talks but sings. On its disks, side by side with
Leslie C. Garnett, Federal Attorney, has thrown up his hands and cried "kamerad" in his battle of erudition with Attorney General Homer S. Cummings.

The preliminary report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for I936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $12,016,947 after taxes, depreciation, interest, subsidiary dividends and other deductions.

Italy's anti-aircraft precautions today were extended to cover Vatican City. Residents of the city, where Pope Plus XI is recovering from his long illness, were ordered to obey the same regulations as citizens of Rome during forthcoming air manoeuvres.

Several hundred persons attended the skating tea which Mrs. William Belden gave at the weekly dancing session of the Skating Club of New York at the Ice Club last night. The reason was the appearance of Karl Schafer, world and Olympic champion, and Miss Melitta Brunner, Viennese-born professional ice

Determined to put an end to the sit-down strike tactics of employes who believe they have grievances, the Works Progress Administration announced yesterday the dismissal of twenty-six additional workers who participated in recent sit-down demonstrations.
Charles Talbot Johnston, retired builder and former Pelham Village Trustee and Pelham School Board member, died yesterday at his home here. He was 71 years old.

The prosecution rested in the restaurant racket trial yesterday after showing how police laboratory methods were used to find the bank account from which Jules Martin drew the $21,000 he took up-State to Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer on a trip that ended with Martin's murder.

Among those entertaining friends tonight at the anniversary dinner dance marking the tenth anniversary of the Bath Club, Miami Beach, were Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Dallas Thayer, Gwynedd Valley, Pa.; Mr. and Mrs. Norman B. Woolworth, Mr. and Mrs. Hubert E. Rogers, all of New York; Mr. and

Furthering plans for an association in the metropolitan area, furniture salesmen in the wholesale field, at a meeting last night in the Advertising Club, elected as temporary president Charles Bolte, treasurer of the New York Furniture Exchange Election of permanent

A full program has been arranged for Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, who will arrive here for a two-day visit Monday. He will be accompanied by two officials of the Foreign Office and the Austrian Minister to Berlin.

A final decision on the status of the Catholic Church in the State of Veracruz was discussed by President Lazaro Cardenas in a series of conferences here with the State Governor, Miguel Aleman, and the commander of the Federal military zone of Veracruz, General Heriberto Jara.

About 2,000 young men and women, applicants for 200 jobs as camp counselors and youth leaders, converged upon the Mount Eden Center, 1,660 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, at 9 o'clock last night in answer to a newspaper advertisement and demanded admittance.

Stockholders of the Riverside and Dan River Cotton Mills approved today issuance of 300,000 new shares of common stock in what is conceded to be the first step toward retirement of the $7,500,000 of preferred stock. The new issue will be offered to preferred shareholders in a ratio of 4 to 1, then to existing common shareholders.

When Chandler Hovey of Boston purchased the America's Cup defender Rainbow from Harold S. Vanderbilt on Tuesday, he virtually purchased only her bones. Mr. Vanderbilt reserved the privilege to strip the defender of 1934 of all her rigging and usable sails, her winches and even her chain plates.

Robert Bruns of Germany pinned Big Chief Sanooke of North Carolina last night in the feature match of the weekly wrestling show at the New York Hippodrome. After weakening the Indian giant with a series. of flying mares and tackles, Bruns won in 17 minutes, 19 seconds, the finishing hold being a double armlock.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Baroness Anna M. von Zedlitz, eldest of eight children of the late George Ehret, New York brewer, lied yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a month's illness. She was in her sixty-ninth year. The Baroness had been living at 1,165 Park Avenue since 1927.
Vice Admiral Yashutaro Iwashita, chief of staff of the combined Japanese fleet and a delegate to the London naval conference, died of jaundice today. He was 51 years old.

Arthur H. Eddy, inventor of electrical machinery and founder of the Eddy Electric Manufacturing Company, died today at his home in Windsor at the age of 79. He. invented the Eddy dynamo, and at the World's Fair in Chicago in 1893 products of the Eddy Electric Manufacturing Company formed one of the outstanding exhibits.

Provocative in theme and containing much material of extraordinary interest, an exhibition called "The Dark Ages" will open with a private showing tonight at the Worcester Art Museum, Worcester, Mass. It opens to the public tomorrow and is scheduled to continue through March 21.

The success of marriage-aid loans as a first aid to increase the population is attested by the Reich Statistical Office, which reveals that between August, 1933, and the end of 1936 the government financed with such loans no less than 694,367 marriages, of which a total of 485,285 children were born so far.

Oxford and Cambredge drew, 5-5, at lacrosse today in the first drawn intervarsity game since 1924. The Dark Blues were superior during the first period and were leading, 4-1, at half-time. Cambridge rallied, however, in the second session, scoring five straight goals, and Oxford was hard put finally to draw.

The curious adventures of a youth from Staten Island were narrated yesterday by police from a station as remote from that quiet isle as that on Wadsworth Avenue, at 182d Street. Their story that he had stolen a taxicab, driven it up to Inwood Park and nearly over
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, flying from an overnight stay at an oasis in the Syrian desert, landed here at 1:30 P. M. Greenwich mean time [8:30 A. M. Eastern standard time] today.

The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 17, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,482,000,000, a decrease of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $22,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1936.

Long Island University will open its baseball season against George Washington University at Washington, D. C., on March 29, it was announced yesterday by Clair F. Bee, director of athletics. The Blackbirds will leave for Washington the day before the game.

Westy Egmont Ruschke, who claimed descent from the ancient Count Egmont of Flanders last Dec. 31, when he was arrested for soliciting Red Cross funds under alleged forged authorization of Henry Morgenthau Jr., was committed to Bellevue Hospital

The upward trend of economic activity throughout the world continued without check during January, according to the monthly review in the current issue of The Annalist. Industrial activity expanded further and international trade increased somewhat.
The Yale freshman sextet today defeated Choate School, 9-2, as Fred Burr, who scored four goals, led the attack. George Seabury played an excellent game. Neal and Nearing scored the Choate goals.

Dr. John Nolen, Internationally known landscape architect and pioneer in modern city and regional planning, died today at his home here. His age was 67. During his life he was engaged on more than 400 public planning projects.

A new concept of the baffling and problem of self-destruction, which gives modern psychology a hope for reducing the present total of more than 40,000 suicides a year in this country, was offered yesterday by Dr. Gregory Zilboorg, research director of the Committee for the Study of Suicide, which was organsized a year ago to make a worldwide study of self-destruction as "a preventable disease."

The last two members of the visiting English squash racquets team went down to defeat before their American opponents as the semifinal round of the national championship was reached at the Junior League yesterday.

Manhattan's varsity baseball team, a claimant to the metropolitan collegiate diamond championship last year on the basis of its record of fourteen victories in sixteen starts, will play seventeen games this Spring, according to the schedule announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics.

A simple method of increasing physical capacity and endurance between 30 and 100 per cent was outlined before the Berlin Medical Society yesterday by Professor Helmut Dennig, noted director of the fourth medical university-clinic of Robert Koch Hospital in Berlin.

The Arkansas House of Representatives defeated today, 46 to 19, a bill to prohibit the teaching of communism or any foreign doctrines intended to start a movement to overthrow the State or national government. It was said to have been aimed at Commonwealth College, a cooperative labor institution near Mena.

The following Marine Corps orders for the week ended Feb. 18 were announced today: COLONELS Vandegrift, A. A., Peiping, China, to headquarters, Washington, D. C., with permission to delay in reporting until June 15. Kincade, G. M., Quantico, Va., to Marine Barracks, Washington, and to continue

The most encouraging aspect of current consumer agitation for accurate fiber identification is to be seen in the diminishing number of errors made by retail stores, according to H. J. Kenner, president of the New York Better Business Bureau, who spoke yesterday at a meeting of the ready-to-wear and fabric divisions of The Fashion Group, Inc., held at the Town Hall Club. Mr. Kenner pointed out that

These orders were Issued in the Second Corps Area: 1st Lt. Mark L. Herman, Med.-Res., 2,009 Cruger Av., Bronx, N. Y., unassigned, is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective Feb. 19. He will proceed to Headquarters Binghamton District, CCC, Binghamton, N. Y., duty in connection with CCC activities. Lieutenant Herman will rank from Feb. 19.
Making fingers out of toes was successfully accomplished for a young worker named Baskoff by Professor M. I. Kuslik of the Central Traumotological Institute in Leningrad.

Representative Emanuel Celler announced here yesterday that he would seek an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission of the possible effects of the Tydings-Miller Resale Price Maintenance Bill, before it was acted on by Congress.

The United States liner Manhattan arrives today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh. On board are Rod La Rocque, actor, and his wife, Vilma Banky; J. Butler Wright, Otto Wadsted, Viscount Tarbat, General Jay Johnson Morrow, Mrs. Mada Brown, Timothy Eaton, Captain and Mrs. J. E. Crockett, Robert Cass and J. A. Tench.

Some 12,000 carnations, representing most of the 300 recognized varieties and including several new varieties, were displayed yesterday in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center. The exhibit, arranged by the New England Carnation Growers Association, will continue today and tomorrow.

Record crowds thronged Cornell's campus today, attracted by the presence of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. Bailey Hall was jammed at noon by 2,500 as the President's wife modeled her inaugural gowns at a fashion show. Later she spoke informally of "a day at the White House," asserting that
Engineering construction awards for private and Federal work reported for the week showed gains this year as compared with the same period in 1936, but the total of all awards was lower.

Winning four of his bouts in the final round robin, Norman C. Armitage, national saber champion, annexed the metropolitan championship with that blade at the seventh annual competition on the strips of the Salle d'Armes Vince last night.

An order requiring Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, to show cause why he should not be directed to return books and records of the Furniture, Flour, Grocery and Bakery Teamsters Union, Local 138, of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church.
By a vote of 385 to 195 the Chamber of Deputies today passed a bill abrogating the gold clause in international contracts on the French market. It now becomes operative.
The stock markets were dull and uncertain today, with British Government securities again losing ground. German bonds, among the foreign, maintained their gains of yesterday.

In the last two days the 8 per cent non-cumulative stock of the United States Rubber Company has played an unusual role on the New York Stock Exchange, advancing 17 points. Yesterday it touched 118, which price it has exceeded only three times since it was admitted to trading. In 1909 it touched 123 1/2,

The Philadelphia Electric Company of Philadelphia filed a registration statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $130,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 1967. The interest rate is to be announced later.
With the satisfied Giants temporarily out of the picture, the Yankees and Dodgers yesterday ran a dead heat in the contract-signing derby, each club announcing receipt of two attested documents.

Utica curlers won the Allen and Mitchell medals in the grand national competition tonight, defeating Schenectady rivals. The Brookline rink took the Country Club Cup with a 16-to-8 victory over Saranac Lake No. 2.

The Boston Bruins ran their National Hockey League winning streak to four games tonight and remained tied for second place in the American division by beating the Maroons, 2 to 1. The defeat ended the Maroons' string of six victories.
A government communique early today announced the death of Gregory K. Ordjonikidze, Commissar of Heavy Industry and one of the most influential leaders of the Soviet Government.

Apart from a rise of $52,000,000 in holdings of "other securities," reflecting presumably subscriptions to this week's issue of $100,000,000 of New York State four-month notes, the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City reported few changes in their condition statement for the week ended on Wednesday, issued yesterday.

In asking the press today to consider the dinner which he is giving Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop as a "purely private affair," the Earl of Derby, one of Britain's most influential leaders outside the government, is held to have committed one of the first blunders of his long career.

Japan is prepared to ship gold abroad at least within the limits of her domestic production, which is roughly 100,000,000 yen a year, Finance Minister Toyotaro Yuki told the House of Representatives today.

The Statehouse was the scene of tumult today when supporters of the Federal Child Labor amendment, angered by the procedure at a Legislative hearing on a ratification measure, burst from the committee room and picketed the Statehouse.

Federick E. Blaser, assistant to Vice President C. W. Galloway in charge of operations and maintenance of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and for many years prominent in railroad circles, died at his home here last night at the age of 79. He was born in Tomah, Wis., and entered

Liquor which rum-runners dumped overboard near here eight years ago has done wonders for Mayor W. Thomas Elliott's oyster business. The Mayor said he was puzzled by the large number of boats that showed up for duty, with a consequent increase in oyster production, until he discovered his oyster bars were, in a sense, whisky bars.

The right of the city of Yonkers to ?ecapture certain street railway Franchises given the Yonkers Railroad Company in 1911 and acquire property and equipment under the terms was upheld today by Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close. He dismissed applications for an injunction filed by the Bank?rs Trust Company of New York, ?ortgagee, and Charles I. McCar?agher, Yonkers taxpayer.

Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada in the week ending on Feb. 17 showed a decrease of $1,986,725 from the previous week, according to the weekly statement of the bank, issued today. At the same time, deposits by chartered banks were down $880,186.

Charles A. Munn gave a dinner tonight at Amado for Lady Sybil Stanley, the Countess of Abingdon Prince and Princess Hoheniche Schillingsfurst, Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien, Captain and Mrs. Alastair Mackintosh, Countess Edith in Zoppolo, Mrs. James P. Donahue Mrs. J. Philip Benkhard, Mrs. M Dorland Doyle, Misses Mary and Frances Munn, Douglas Williams, James Bush, Captain Charles Winn, Reginald Boardman, George F Baker Jr., Noel Munn and James P. Donahue.

The thirty-third annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America will be held on June 20 to 23 in the Hotel Pennsylvania, E. H. McReynolds, president, announced yesterday following a survey of various cities under consideration by a special committee of the board, of which C. C. Younggreen. Chicago, was chairman.

Bonita Granville, who gained screen recognition by her performances in "These Three" and "Maid of Salem" and who is in the forthcoming "Call It a Day," was placed under contract today by the Warners. Her first role will be that of Violet Vizetelly in Paul Muni's "The Life of Emile Zola."

Further indication that the decline in revenue resulting from the ending of the emergency freight surcharges on Jan. 1 might be offset by increased traffic was afforded by the statement for January issued by the Erie Railroad yetserday.

The body of Mrs. Caroline Post, 48 years old, of 11 Tarboro Road here, was found in a garage back of her home shortly after 10 A. M. today. Death was caused by burns which apparently were self-inflicted, according to Assistant District Attorney Seward G. Spoor, who made an investigation.

The surprise introduction by President Eamon de Valera in the Dail Eireann of a bill under which volunteering to fight with either side in Spain would become illegal has made the Spanish war a burning political issue here.

A political-economic alliance between the agricultural South and West, a union long contemplated by certain administration spokesmen but never openly advocated, was in the making here tonight on the eve of opening sessions of the National Farm Institute, a discussion group personally sponsored by Secretary Wallace and endorsed by former Governor Frank O. Lowden of Illinois.

A score of persons, members of families of Cadillac-Fleetwood employes who had received welfare aid during the General Motors strike, "sat down" tonight in the welfare station here in protest against their removal from the relief rolls.

Two New York district stars and two Florida contenders won their quarter-final matches today in the tenth annual national championship of golf club champions on the St. Augustine links. Competing for the title and the Walter J. Travis Trophy, the Northern survivors were Mark J. Stuart of Winged Foot Golf Club, former metropolitan champion, and Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, the 1936 New Jersey State amateur ruler.

Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the military head of the Chinese Government, will make a radio address in English from Nanking on Sunday morning for American listeners, which will be heard in New York from 7 to 7:15 o'clock Saturday night.

Action restoring a part of the heavily cut salaries of the officers and staff at the headquarters of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church, 281 Fourth Avenue, was taken by the council at a three-day session which closed there yesterday noon.

The existence in Northern Alberta, Canada, of a tremendous oil reserve of between 100 billion and 250 billion barrels, which offers assurance that the world is safe from possible early exhaustion of its oil supply, was reported yesterday at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Six five-story flats, at 20-25 Columbus Avenue and 103-05 West Sixtieth Street, were sold in one block today to John J. Meenan, trustee, who was plaintiff in an action to recover $189,916 and $18,826 taxes and other liens against the Elemco Realty Company. Inc.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The citation for the citizen of "the Oranges and Maplewood who has given outstanding service to humanity," the annual award of the Chamber of Commerce and Civics of the Oranges and Maplewood, was presented tonight to Oscar Schoenherr of Orange, managing director of the Welfare Federation of the Oranges and Maplewood.
National Guard troops enforcing martial law in this automobile-accessory city, a battleground of union and non-union labor, prepared tonight to remain at least through the week-end.
Jock McGovern, Laborite, from Glasgow, was suspended from the House of Commons tonight after he refused to withdraw remarks made in the heat of the debate on defense.

A proposed constitutional amendment under which a Governor would take office on the Dec. 1 following his election instead of Jan. 1 of the next year was prepared today by Irwin Steingut, Democratic leader of the Assembly.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York has been appointed sole distributor for all General Electric heating and air-conditioning products using gas fuel in the territory in which the Edison companies operate.

H. M. Byllesby Co., investment bankers, reported today a net profit of $391,244 for 1936, compared with $228,816 for 1935. At the end of last year $1,899,788 was added to the surplus account, making it $3,700,000.

William Faehndrich, his son, Rudolph, and their cheese importing corporation, William Faehndrich Co., at 13 Harrison Street were found guilty in Special Sessions yesterday of violating the State trademark law in misbranding and misrepresenting one of their products. Justices Brady, McDonald and Renaud will impose sentences next Friday.

The building at 2,840-2,842 Boulevard, Jersey City, used as headquarters of the Hudson County Boulevard Police since 1910, has been sold to the Lexington-Jersey Holding Company by Police Chief William F. Clossey, owner.

67th St., 242-246 W., 75x100.5; Metropolis Holding Corp. to Louise H. Archibald, 42 Perry St.; mtgs., $27,000. Madison Av., 1,520, 1,524 and 1,528, each 25 feet front: estate of George Fennell. Inc., to Vermont Realty Corp., 2,931 3d Av., Bronx (50 cents).
William G. Bramham, president of the National Association of Professional Basketball Leagues, said today the organization would hold its annual convention next December in Milwaukee, Wis.

H. B. Loxterman has been elected vice president and Albert L. Cuff secretary of the Blaw-Knox Company. Harold A. Meriam has been made assistant vice president of the Public National Bank and Trust Company. Branch E. Messick has been

Homer Folks, secretary of the New York State Charities Aid Association for forty-one years, was Mi the guest of some 300 of his friends last night on his seventieth birthday at a dinner in the Hotel Biltmore.
The latest arrival in the Hippodrome's long line of musical comedies, "Big Business," which opened tonight, cheerfully dispenses with the dignity of a plot or settled satirical purpose.

Mr. and Mrs. John W. Skelton of 110 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Fay Skelton, to Andrew McLean, son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. McLean of Eatontown, N. J., formerly of Brooklyn.

The prospect of a State securities commission to require the registration of all issues sold in New York, in addition to the registration now required by the Securities and Exchange Commission for sale throughout the nation, was revealed here yesterday.

Resumption of negotiations for a new agreement by the Appalachian Joint Wage Conference yesterday found the United Mine Workers, speaking for some 400,000 miners, and soft-coal operators of eight States as far apart as they appeared to be at the opening of the conference on Wednesday.
The board of governors of the American Bar Association voted tonight to poll its membership of 29,000 lawyers on President Roosevelt's proposals to reorganize the Supreme Court.

One of the few applications to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authorization to form a protective committee since these bodies were placed under the commission's jurisdiction was filed yesterday in the St. Louis Southwestern Railway's bankruptcy proceedings, it was announced here.

If the $436,000,000 transit unification plan advocated by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr. had been in effect in 1936 it would have resulted in a reduction of $9,130,000 in the revenue derived by the city from rapid transit operation, according to estimates prepared by the Transit Commission's bureau of valuations and transit readjustment.
Colonel Edward B. Underwood, Salvation Army executive, revealed today that his organization had received a $400,000 bequest from a New York manes estate because of a chance remark of a "Bowery bum."
Rufus Gibson, tenor, will be heard tonight at Roerich Hall. The Washington Heights Town Club will hold its regular monthly musical tonight at its club rooms.

H. M. Byllesby Co., investment bankers, reported today a net profit of $391,244 for 1936, compared with $228,816 for 1935. At the end of last year $1,899,788 was added to the surplus account, making it $3,700,000.

William Faehndrich, his son, Rudolph, and their cheese importing corporation, William Faehndrich Co., at 13 Harrison Street were found guilty in Special Sessions yesterday of violating the State trademark law in misbranding and misrepresenting one of their products. Justices Brady, McDonald and Renaud will impose sentences next Friday.

The building at 2,840-2,842 Boulevard, Jersey City, used as headquarters of the Hudson County Boulevard Police since 1910, has been sold to the Lexington-Jersey Holding Company by Police Chief William F. Clossey, owner.

67th St., 242-246 W., 75x100.5; Metropolis Holding Corp. to Louise H. Archibald, 42 Perry St.; mtgs., $27,000. Madison Av., 1,520, 1,524 and 1,528, each 25 feet front: estate of George Fennell. Inc., to Vermont Realty Corp., 2,931 3d Av., Bronx (50 cents).
William G. Bramham, president of the National Association of Professional Basketball Leagues, said today the organization would hold its annual convention next December in Milwaukee, Wis.

Declaring that a promise that no publicity would attend his plea of "nole contender" had been violated, John S. Farnsworth. former navy lieutenant commander, charged in United States District Court with conspiracy to commit espionage, today asked for permission to change his plea to one of not guilty.

Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, announced at the annual meeting of the directors yesterday a gain of $168,278,628 in the total assets, the largest increase in the company's history. Total assets were $1,984,449,584 at the year end.

Marriner S. Eccles, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today that the Federal Reserve Board had acted to raise the margin requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve Systern partly because of fear that institutional investors might, if interest Sates on long-term investments went lower, turn to speculative securities.

I VISIT THE SOVIETS, by E. M. Delafield. (Harper. $2.50.) More adventures of the "Provincial Lady," who recently has spent four months in Russia. NONE SHALL LOOK BACK, by Caroline Gordon. (Scribner, $2.75.) A novel of life in the South during the Civil War.

On the showing of informal polls that the administration's judiciary reform program may eventually hang on the decision of less than a dozen Senators, President Roosevelt and the forces identified with him, particularly organized labor, intensified their efforts today to insure its passage as a prerequisite to further New Deal legislation.

The first prospect of a mass execution of opium addicts and narcotics dealers has arisen in the small city of Mantungchow, on the north bank of the Yangtse River, in Kiangsu Province, where, after clean-up raids, seventy persons have been sentenced to death by shooting.

The Brooklyn Tech quintet took undisputed possession of first place in Section 1 of the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. tourney by vanquishing Franklin K. Lane, 27 to 21, at the Central Methodist Episcopal Church court yesterday. Tech led by 12-11 at the close of the second quarter in registering its eighth success in ten circuit starts.
Postmaster General Farley waved a weary hand today at crowds that dogged his steps at the Surf Club.

The former plant of the Indestructo Glass Works on Amityville Road, Farmingdale, L. I., has been sold to the Kirkham Engineering and Manufacturing Company. The plant consists of fifteen acres, with a one-story factory building containing about 50,000 square feet.

Ernest Obermeyer, retired officer and director of the Liebmann Breweries, Inc., of Brooklyn, died yesterday morning in Palm Beach, Fla., according to word received here yesterday. He had passed three months in Florida for his health, and had planned to return to New York in April.
Principally on account of the rising prices of farm products, the general level of wholesale prices advanced fractionally in the week ended on Feb. 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
Two sons of Reigh Count covered themselves and their owners with glory at Hialeah today as one of the biggest week-day crowds of the season turned out for an eight-race card.
Four daughters of Nanking officials broke bottles of wine on eighteen American-made pursuit planes today, dedicating them to the cause of "Chinese national salvation."

The drama library recently established at Barnard College and named in honor of Mrs. Annie Nathan Meyer, author and playwright, will be formally presented to- Mrs. Meyer today at her home, 1,225 Park Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date while total gold holdings reached a new low for 1937.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Sobriety, a candidate for the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap, today won the one-mile Los Angeles Handicap for a $1.500 added purse, edging out Sir Emerson and Grand Manitou in a blanket finish.

President Roosevelt sent to Congress a special message on crop insurance, discussed naval matters with Assistant Secretary of the Navy Edison, conferred with four Senators on his judiciary reform proposals and discussed power policies with a group of Senators and Representatives from Western States.

The Dollar liner President Harrison, scheduled to sail yesterday at 6 P. M. from Jersey City for California on the first leg of a trip around the world, was tied up last night when clearance papers were refused her by Shipping Commissioner John J. Daly.

Princeton staged a powerful second-half drive to outdistance Cornell and gain its second Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League victory, 4034, tonight. With Bud Sauter and Johnny Vruwlnk sharing 25 points between them the Tigers broke a 20-all deadlock early in the second period and never were headed.

Miss Sara Jane Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Phillips of Bartlesville, Okla., was married here yesterday afternoon in their suite at the Ambassador to Frank William Begrisch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Begrisch of 1,035 Fifth Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. Edgar Tilton Jr. of the Reformed Church of Harlem.

Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin told the House of Commons tonight that the British Government would push ahead "in the immediate future" toward pacification of Europe, with a regional pact in the west as its first objective.

Fourteen operating companies of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation system serving Central, Northern and Eastern New York, filed with the Public Service Commission yesterday a petition for consolidation, marking an additional step in simplification of the system.
Germany made "serious" representations to the Soviet Government today in a new and apparently unsuccessful effort to intervene for two score Germans held amid strict secrecy in Soviet jails.

Applications for listing the following issues are pending before the Stock Exchange's Committee on stock list: Sellanee Manufacturing Company-250,000 shares of common stock, $10 par value. Electric Auto-Lite Company-S10,000.000 of 4 per cent debentures, due in 1952.
Mary Astor, film actress, and Manuel Martinez del Campo, young Mexican, agreed tonight that they were man and wife. Miss Astor, in Hollywood, said they were.

In order to obtain a sufficient number of motor and pump operators for duty in the companies in the 1st, 3d, 8th, 10th and 12th Divisions upon the installation of the two-platoon and three platoon-ten group systems, commanding officers of companies in those divisions shall forward reports on Feb. 23 containing a list of the
Bachelors over 30 years old would be taxed $50 annually, under a bill introduced today in the Delaware House of the General Assembly.

The Annalist reports that prices of commodities rose last week after the strike settlement, but lost their gains afterward and its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined 0.2- point to 140.0 on Tuesday from 140.2 the Tuesday previous.

Stockholders of Russek's Fifth Avenue, Inc., approved yesterday resolutions to split the outstanding $5 par value common shares into $2.50 par value common shares, on the basis of two new shares for each old share, increasing the number of shares from 200.000 to 400.000.
A thousand river men dropped tons of sand against a thirty-five-mile stretch of low embankment below Deerpark, La., today to hem in the Mississippi's swelling flood crest.

Five marines and their commanding officer were killed and ten others injured today in the explosion of a five-inch shell as it was being loaded into the breech of a gun on the demilitarized battleship Wyoming during war games near San Clemente Island, in the Pacific.

The City Athletic Club won the Group 1 team championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association for the second year in a row with a 3-2 triumph over the Jackson Heights Squash Club yesterday at the losers' courts. The title was not decided until the final match of the day.

The President has transmitted to Congress, with a message endorsing them, the recommendations of his special committee on crop insurance. The report, which was made public last December, was more conservative than it was widely expected to be. It proposed that crop insurance be restricted at the beginning to wheat, and that it apply to the 1938 crop.
President Roosevelt discussed with a group of Senators and Representatives from the Northwestern States today the policies to be pursued in the distribution of power from the Bonneville Dam.
The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor authorized President William Green today to arrange for and supervise an election by members of the Eastern and Gulf Sailors' Association.

Dr. Geoffrey M. James, former Assistant Professor of Chemistry at the University of Pennsylvania, died in Women's Homeopathic Hospital here last night of injuries received in an automobile accident on Feb. 10. He was 45 years old.

Woman's Forum, Hotel Roosevelt, 10:45 A. M. "Europe on the Brink," Mrs. Samuel P. Orth. Address by Dr. E. Stagg Within. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Current Events," H. V. Kaltenborn.

Reflecting higher prices abroad, the price of lead in the domestic market was advanced 25 points yesterday. The new price is 6.25 cents a pound here and 6.10 cents at St. Louis. The price of zinc also was increased 20 points to 6.60 cents a pound at East St. Louis. The price of lead now is the highest since January, 1930, while that for zinc is the best since April, 1929.

Moscow is a city of mourning today. Blackdraped red flags hang limply from windows, and long lines of people, waiting to pay their last respects to Gregory K. Ordjonikidze, straggle from the doors of the House of Columns-where his body lies in state, as did Lenin's-across Theatre Square and Hunters Row.
Prof. Edward S. Erb, member of Pennsylvania State College faculty for twenty-eight years, died today of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.
Cram's Reports, Inc., today estimated this week's automobile production at 95,698 units, compared with 69,813 in the corresponding week of 1936 and 72,492 last week.

One Canadian and thirty-four Britishers told their Insurgent captors today they came to Spain to work, not to fight. The group was captured in the Madrigueras sector on Feb. 12 and brought here. They said they were attached to a battalion originally composed of 550 foreigners but reduced to 200.

Michael Krusky, 23 years old, of 308 Cherry Street, one of the five gunmen who held up Barney's clothing establishment at 111 Seventh Avenue last Jan. 2, smiled yesterday in General Sessions when he pleaded guilty to second-degree murder. He shot a confederate an hour after the robbery.

Patrolman Thomas Hogan, 35 years old, attached to the White Plains Avenue station, was killed instantly when his automobile crashed into an elevated pillar in Jerome Avenue near 202d Street, the the Bronx, at 4:15 o'clock yesterday morning.
Ellen McAdoo de Onate, daughter of Senator McAdoo and granddaughter of the late President Wilson, today filed suit for divorce from Rafel Lopez de Onate, charging non-supprt.

Mrs. Henry R. Rea, honorary vice president of the Garden Club of Palm Beach, entertained today with a luncheon for 200 at Lagomar, including its members and visitors from the Garden Clubs of Miami Beach, Fort Lauderdale, Mountain Lake, Boca Raton and Boca Grande.

The Bronx, of course, is New York's Borough Miraculous. It is there that the signs and portents multiply and the marvelous is almost taken for granted. If this city were ancient Rome, it is in the Bronx that the augurs would gather.

The engagement of $1,000,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Reserve Bank announced the arrival here of $583,800 gold from Australia.
For those who have grown weary of a strange and unexciting Winter it may be encouraging to know that the approach of Spring is being Confidently anticipated in the night spots.
Operators figured yesterday as the sellers of housing properties in the Harlem, Yorkville and West Side areas.
The fourth "Tristan und Isolde" of the current season was offered last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Like the previous presentations, it was attended by a capacity assemblage.

The buildings at 568-74 and 576-78 Broadway recently purchased by the Princeway Realty Corporation, Elias A. Cohen, president. are 100 per cent rented, according to Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc. Louis O. Trilsch has opened a real estate and mortgage loan office at 150-54 Northern Boulevard. Flushing, Queens, under the name L. D. Trilsch Agency, Inc. E. Linwood Dashiell is secretary.

E. H. Everson, president of the National Farmers Union, declared today he would not attempt to say what stand his organization might take on the proposed reorganization of the United States Supreme Court, but said he, personally, would oppose the move.

Flashing down the flag-patterned course under almost perfect control in both of her efforts, blond-haired Miss Kay Larocque of the Ottawa Ski Club defeated a strong international field of women skiers in winning the tricky slalom race today.

Braman B. Adams of the University Club captured the Union League Club's third annual invitation Class B squash racquets tournament by vanquishing John B. Wilkinson of the Harvard Club, 15-11, 14-17, 17-16, 15-8, in the final yesterday.

The Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra will give its first concert of the Winter series tomorrow afternoon at the County Center, White Plains. Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff director of the Federal Music Project, will attend.

The marriage of Mrs. Happie Bedford Ladew of 180 East Seventy-ninth Street to Bruce Lachlan Jr., son of Mrs. Bruce Lachlan of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Lach- C lan, took place yesterday at the Hotel Pierre, in the apartment of Y the bride's father, Charles E. Bedford.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 13 amounted to 691,618 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,592 cars, or 2.5 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 60,523 cars, or 9.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 109,949 cars, or 18.9 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric company and internationally known financier, is to be married tomorrow at 5 P. M. to Mrs. Louise Clark of New York City and St. Augustine, at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Walter Van Rennsselaer Powis in St. Augustine.
Vincent K. Hilton of Dayton, Ohio, won the thirty-six-hole final for the Belleair amateur golf championship today. He defeated Garret A. Hobart of Paterson, N. J., 6 and 5.

With the unqualified declaration, "the President wants you to join the union," in bold type across the top of its circulars, the Steel Workers Organizing Committee of the Committee for Industrial Organization has undertaken to 'recruit employes of three large Trenton companies as members of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers of North America.

Hank Johnson's long field goal in the last fifty seconds of play enabled the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute quintet to down its borough rival, Pratt. Institute, 27 to 2,. on the loser's floor last night.

With private and residential building taking the lead, building in general in the New York area during January of this year showed a marked increase over the same month last year, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

Thomas Jefferson High, co-city champion, and Eastern District moved back into a three-way deadlock with Brooklyn Tech for the Section 1 lead in the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. basketball race by scoring victories yesterday.

The February promenade at Briarcliff Junior College will be held here tomorrow, Miss Sally Heedy, the chairman, announced today. A tea dance will be held at the Briar Hills Country Club at 4 P. M. Dancing will take place at night in the Junior College main hall. Miss Doris Laura Flick,

The fourth annual Brotherhood Day will be observed today in synagogues and tomorrow in churches under the auspices of the National Conference of Jews and Christians. The day, which has been endorsed by President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia, is "to foster justice, amity,

Twenty members of the Giants now in Havana as the advance guard of the contingent which will participate in a series of exhibition games here with local teams and the St. Louis Cardinals appeared in uniform at Tropical Stadium today and went through a two-hour workout under the direction of Coach Frank Snyder, who is in command in the absence of Manager Bill Terry.

The tie-up of Pacific Coast ships in this port, which had extended to five intercoastal vessels, was halted yesterday when three seamen obtained an injunction againstFederal Shipping Commissioner John J. Daly, who had refused to grant clearance papers to the ship's masters.

The Duke and Duchess of Kent, it is expected, will be the next members of the royal family to visit the Duke of Windsor. The former King's brother and his wife are leaving London by plane today for a three weeks' vacation to stay with the Duchess's sister, the Countess of Toerring-Jettenbach, near Munich, and while there may make an excursion to Enzesfeld Castle.
The resignation of John G. Winant, former Governor of New Hampshire, as chairman of the Social Security Board was accepted for the second time, and finally, by President Roosevelt today.
The New York A. C. conquered the Prudential A. A., 45 to 27, tonight before a capacity crowd in an Eastern Amateur Athletic Club Basketball League fray.

Two months of intermittent street fighting between rival factions of the Greek Fur Workers Union, Local 70, flared yesterday into a brawl involving nearly 100 furriers, in which three persons were stabbed and several others were injured.

Premier Leon Blum and Pierre-Etienne Flandin manoeuvred for position today in preparation for the debate before the Chamber of Deputies next week dn the latter's interpellation on the government's general policy.
Frank Burnham Ogilvie, president of the J. S. Ogilvie Publishing Company, died yesterday in his home at 966 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, after an illness of two weeks. He was 62 years of age.

Henry C. Stuart, Assistant Collector of the Port, will retire from the Customs on Feb. 28 after fortysix years' service. He has worked under fourteen collectors and has had pleasant relations with them all, he said yesterday.

The Board of Tax Appeals ruled today that General Motors Corporation was not liable for a 1926 income tax deficiency of $15,342,369. The deficiency was assessed as the result of a transaction in which General Motors acquired all the assets of the Fisher Body Corporation.

A tablet memorial to John Frelinghysen Chambers, who died Sept. 9, last, will be unveiled tomorrow morning in the primary room of the Sunday school of the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, where he was superintendent and taught for forty years "the truths of the Christian religion" in such a way that they were not easily forgotten."

A special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today that the stand taken last year by the chamber that the corporate surtax is wrong in principle and destructive in results had been justified by developments, and urged that if this method of raising revenue were not to be abandoned major imperfections should be remedied.

Governor LEHMAN has sent a special message to the Legislature urging that a $60,000,000 bond issue be authorized for the purpose of financing permanent improvements in various State institutions. He says that the State's.

Thomas R. Coward of the Yale Club, former national squash tennis champion, and his club-mate, W. D. Hoag, advanced into the quarter-final round of the annual veterans' national championship yesterday. Coward won by default from C. M. Rushmore of the Harvard Club, while Hoag defeated O. C. Stanton, another Harvard
Henry P. Powers, dean of Orange County newspaper reporters and a veteran of sixty-four years in the business, died at his home here today. At the time of his death, Mr.

A charge that Cardinal O'Connell "cracked the whip" over the Massachusetts Legislature enlivened a meeting on Boston Common late today of persons favoring this State's ratification of the Federal Child Labor Amendment.
T. Suffern Tailer, two-time winner of the Metropolitan amateur golf crown, almost fell victim to the medalist jinx today in the opening round of the fourth annual MidOcean invitation tournament.

Donald Aitchison of the Bayside Tennis Club and Howard Stern of the City Athletic Club advanced to the semi-final round of the singles championship of Group 2 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association at the City A. C. yesterday.

Bond prices continued their improvement yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, under the leadership of a spirited demand for second-grade railroad issues. The trading pace slackened somewhat with total transactions reaching $17,510,200, compared with $18,459,100 on Thursday. The market for higher grade loans continued firm to slightly better as sentiment in trading circles grew brighter.

Grocery chain store sales for last January averaged a 4 1/2 per cent increase over the same month of 1936, and were 7 per cent above the corresponding months of 1935, the Department of Commerce reported today. Sales decreased about 4 per
Charles L. Dewick, the retired sea captain who served on Union transports in the Civil War, died at the Mather Memorial Hospital here yesterday at the age of 91.
An order for examination of L. Parker McKinley, head of the investment firm of McKinley Co., was sought yesterday in Supreme Court in a suit for $63,801 brought by James N. B. Hill, a former partner.
The State Banking Department today announced it had approved a change in the name of the J. Henry Schroder Trust Company of New York to the Schroder Trust Company.

Robert Grant 3d lost his first game of the racquets season yesterday as Philadelphia and New York each qualified two semi-finalists in the national amateur championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Russia's aged warships were a worry tonight for diplomats trying to weld a blockade of all Spain. Neutrality negotiators assigned to Russia, with Portugal, the patrol of the Basque coast along the Bay of Biscay.
The Manhattanville College women's basketball team, undefeated in five years, accounted for a 24-17 victory over the New College team on the winner's court yesterday.

County Judge Charles C. Mathis Jr. said today he married Miss Suzanne Couton of Paris and Howard C. Hirsch of New York here yesterday. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Auguste Couton of Paris. The bridegroom is the son of Charles S. Hirsch, banker, and Mrs. Hirsch of 300 Park Avenue, New York.

At the close of business today all banks and security and commodity markets will enjoy an extended holiday until the opening of business on Tuesday, Monday being set aside for observance of Washington's Birthday. However, all the

As he drove up to his home in Teaneck, N. J., at 7:30 o'clock last night, Norman Redwood, 52 years old, business manager for the Compressed Air, Tunnel and Subway Workers Local 102, was killed instantly by four bullets fired from an automobile.

The marriage of Miss Elaine M. Toors, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Earle Toors of Brooklyn, to Walter E. Warner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Warner, also of Brooklyn, took place last night at the Kings Highway Congregational Church, Brooklyn. The Rev.

Little change was shown in the hog market today. Receipts were small and the demand rather slow. The top was 5 cents lower than yesterday at $10.25 a hundred weight with the day's average unchanged at $10.05. Most sales were at $9.90 to' $10.20: light

Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight that the tenders for $50,000,000 of 273-day Treasury. bills, dated Feb. 24, maturing on Nov. 24, and offered on Feb. 17, amounted to $134,519,000, of which $50,024,000 was accepted.
The battle on the Jarama River front, southeast of Madrid, which has already developed into the most sanguinary and bitterly fought of the entire war, is gradually reaching a decisive phase.

In the hope that Andrew W. Mellon, now in his eighty-second year, will to see the completion of the National Gallery of Art which will house his $50,000,000 collection of art treasures, Congress is expected to expedite the passage of the bill accepting the gift for the nation.

Awards were made today by the American trustees of the Charles and Julia Henry Fund of the Henry Fellowships of 500 pounds sterling each to seven students for study at Oxford and Cambridge Universities.

The elimination of staleness in bread, the improvement of mass-production shoes and dental fillings that last are among the new scientific discoveries described in the annual report of the Department of 'Scientific. and Industrial Research.

Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Nazidom's oratorical advocate of more and better babies, became the beaming father today of his fourth child in a little more than five years. The fact that Mrs. Goebbels had given birth to her third daughter was published modestly, however, in conformity with German newspaper policy in such matters.

Miss Frederica Barker and Richard Rossbach, finding two Bowery residents with hearts tattooed on their arms instead of one, won first prize last night in a scavenger hunt arranged by a committee of debutantes to raise funds for donation to the Red Cross for flood relief.

A northwest gale, attaining a velocity of sixty miles an hour off Cape Race, blocked the port of St. John's with Arctic ice today for the second time within two weeks. The steamer Newfoundland, from Halifax and New England ports, fought the gale 200 miles out at sea. It was expected

Shareholders in Hathaway Bakeries, Inc., have been summoned to a special meeting at Cambridge, Mass., on March 23 to ratify assumption of the liabilities of the Hathaway Bakery Company on Oct. 3, last, as well as to conduct business which ordinarily would come before the regular annual meeting.

The final of the national squash racquets championship at the Junior League Club at 3 o'clock this afternoon will find the players of last year's final again facing each other for the title. Miss Anna Page of Philadelphia will try to repeat her straight-game victory over Miss Cecile Bowes of Philadelphia.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In a letter in last Saturday's TIMES, Hardrock Simpson takes umbrage at my assertion that a horse is superior to a foot-racer at any distance. He also claims to have available $10,000 to prove that he is right.

Wholesale deportation of Haitian and Jamaican laborers to make jobs for native Cuban labor during the sugar crop grinding began today. Four hundred and fifty Haitians left Santiago for Port au Prince after being rounded up by the army.

Mrs. Blanche Kennedy of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, won a verdict for 6 cents yesterday from a Supreme Court jury in her $200,000 alienation of affections suit against Mrs. R. C. Jones of 555 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

On motion of Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, the State executive committee of the American Labor party adopted a resolution yesterday supporting President Roosevelt's proposal for enlargement of the Supreme Court.

Announcement was made tonight of the engagement of Miss Barbara Anthony, daughter of Mrs. Roy Foster Anthony of this city and the late Mr. Anthony, to Walter H. Kline, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Walter Kline of Glen Ridge.

Shot in the back and the head as he stood at a bar playing a dice game with three other men, one of whom also was wounded, Frank Sacco, 28-year-old garage employee and truck driver of 225 East 111th Street, died almost instantly a few minutes before 2 P. M. yesterday.

The executive council of -the American Federation of Labor ordered an investigation today of the sitdown type of strike., Pending the study, the council declined to take a stand on the legality or desirablity of the procedure.
Canada and England tonight paced the eight teams that advanced into the second round of the world hockey championship.

Stocks closed generally higher with steel and copper shares up 1 to 6 points on rearmament news; turnover, 2,725,330 shares. U. S. Government and foreign bonds irregular, second grade rail issues higher; transactions, $17,510,200.
Because he answered the salute "Heil Hitler!" with "Heil London!" a Cologne resident has been sentenced to prison charged with a gross misdemeanor.

Several houses on the upper West Side were taken yesterday in leasing deals. The five-story flat at 118 West Eighty-third Street was leased by the Schwebel Realty Corporation, Louis Schwebel, president, to L. Trepel.
Armament shares continued today to be the only really bright spot in an uncertain and generally hesitant stock market. The session also marked the end of the account.

Joseph J. Lordi, seeded third, of the New York Athletic Club, turned in a brilliant performance yesterday to defeat F. Barry Ryan, ranked first, of the Short Hills Club in the final match of the Whitehall Club's squash tennis tournament. The score was 15-9, 15-10, 15-3.
Mrs. Elizabeth Kerr Shippey, whose childhood was linked closely with historic episodes in the South during Civil War days, died here yesterday. She was 85 years old.

Mrs. William Henry Blauvelt Cooper of 361 Carlton Avenue, Brooklyn, at a dinner last night at the Plaza announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lorraine Cooper, to Warren Allen King, son of Mrs. Warren C. Strugnell of Bloomfield, N. J., and the late George Garrett Hallock King.
The defense in the restaurant racket case will begin putting in its testimony today. One of its chief efforts will be to prove that Jules Martin was a gangster with a Jekyll and Hyde personality.

The information that the British-Cuban trade treaty signed this morning permits British firms established here freely to employ their own nationals as the sole exception to Cuba's highly nationalistic labor laws is causing much agitation among American business men.

The Perseverancia sugar mill in Santa Clara Province, which is owned by the Atlantic Gulf Sugar Company, an American concern, was forced to suspend grinding today when cane planters refused to deliver more cane in protest against the quota granted to the mill by the National Sugar Institute under the restriction plan.

For the fellow who has the time to stroll leisurely around the corridors of the Grand Central Palace and carefully observe the exhibits at the current National Sportsmen's Show, there are numerous articles to interest and amuse him, some of which he may or may not want.
Sports competition is expected to be a feature of today's calendar at the National Sportsmen's Show in the Grand Central Palace.

Putting on a powerful scoring drive in the last quarter after holding a two-point margin at the end of the third period, the Horace Mann School for Boys quintet downed Peekskill Academy, 37 to 24, on the winners' floor yesterday. Don Kubie, with eleven markers, starred for Horace Mann.
President Roosevelt indicated that steps must be taken to break the deadlock over the provisions of the Walsh-Healey act, which is said to be threatening naval construction.

The $60,000,000 long-term bond issue recommended by Governor Lehman for capital construction and improvements was assailed today by Chairman Moffat of the Ways and Means Committee as the "most expensive method possible of financing improvements."
Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., had notified the Stock Exchange that Chinton s. Lutkins has succeeded the late A. W. Erickson as a director.

The German and Italian Governments today presented separate notes replying to the Rumanian Government's protest at the participation of their Ministers in the demonstrations at the funeral of two Iron Guards killed in Spain while serving with General Francisco Franco.

On the eve of the opening of what the Berlin press hails as the "world's biggest automobile show," to be inaugurated by Chancellor Adolf Hitler tomorrow, come two announcements of considerable interest in connection with the Reich's automotive industry.

A reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and El Salvador was signed in San Salvador today by Frank P. Corrigan, the American Minister, and officials of the Salvadoran Foreign Office under which drastic reductions are granted to American exports.
A hint from the White House led informed observers to believe today that the nation's $26,000,000,000 railroad industry was nearing an agreement with its employes on the question of pensions.

William Watson, 24 years old, a plumber, who lived at the Y. M. C. A., Thirty-fourth Street and Ninth Avenue, was arrested yesterday and charged with grand larceny on the complaint of Leon Margulies, a laundry owner, of 2,394 Eighth Avenue, who alleged that Watson, posing as an employee of THE NEW YORK TIMES, obtained $150 from him on a promise to get a position on the paper for Harry Margulies, 19, his son.

Amoassacor Joachim von Ribbentrop, whose ill luck in his public relations here is becoming almost proverbial, went to Manchester yesterday at the invitation of the Earl of Derby to meet a number of Lancashire and Yorkshire business men who are interested in Anglo-German trade and to hear their views.

The German Government tomorrow will publish the text of a law carrying out the international agreement concerning the recruiting of volunteers for Spain. The decree, which was signed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler at Berchtesgaden today, conforms in principle to that which France has adopted.

President Roosevelt's intention to build a navy as strong, ton for ton, as Great Britain's prompts Virginio Gayda to print a rather sarcastic editorial in the Giornale d'Italia this evening, developing the theme that democracies which assert they are the principal enemies of war are setting the pace in the armaments race.
Eve Curie has cabled her publishers, Doubleday, Doran, that she has now completed the manuscript of her biography of her mother, which will be published under the title, "Madame Curie."
Attorney General HOMER S. CUMMINGS has emerged victor from a battle of tongues with a legal colleague.
The celebration of the seventieth anniversary of the birth of HOMER FOLKS was planned to give expression to the esteem in which he is held by this city and State and even by the nation at large.

Delay in the arrival of .the United States liner Manhattan on her regular transatlantic crossing, due to heavy weather, caused her owners to cancel a three-and-a-half day cruise to Bermuda which was to have started last night.

In a defense of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, the Federation's executive council today absolved him of charges of disloyalty to his own union. the miners. The charges had been made by the policy committee of the United Mine Workers of America.
The Charles A. Lindberghs paused tonight at one of the least-visited spots on the globe in their air tour of the Near and Middle East.

A dark blue Staffordshire platter decorated with the arms of Pennsylvania brought $1,600 yesterday afternoon at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. It was bought by F. S. Gaillard, who also gave $800 for another Staffordshire platter with the arms of New Jersey. The session, which

The ten-game winning streak of Manhattan's basketball team was abruptly ended tonight by a driving Temple quintet. The Owls' victory by 39 to 27 made the intercity double header at the Arena a Philadelphia success, for Villanova vanquished C. C. N. Y., 33 to 32, in the opening contest, which went into overtime.

Astronomers today catalogued a new "neighbor" of the earth. Dr. Willem J. Luyten of the University of Minnesota announced the discovery, one of the faintest stars ever seen by man, in the constellation Aquarius, six or seven light years away.

George Seewagen, third seeded entrant, conquered John Nogrady, former St. John's University netman, in two sets in the quarterfinal round of the Brooklyn indoor tennis championship at the 106th Regiment Armory yesterday.

Six major countries, Japan, Denmark, Chile, Great Britain, Norway and Germany experienced greater industrial activity and had greater industrial output in 1936 than in 1929, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

William Leverich Brower, 90 years old, of 17 East Seventyseventh Street, since 1918 president of the board of direction of the corportion of the Reformed Church ri in America, will be reinstalled tomorrow evening as an elder of the Collegiate Reformed Protestant Dutch Church in the City of New

A committee of the Amsterdam Bourse has just sent to the government in Washington a cable dispatch drawing attention to alarming press reports concerning the imminence of its taxation of foreign investments and stating that these reports have caused considerable apprehension here.

Witnesses in the trial of Chang Soo Lee for the alleged poisoning of Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves testified in county court here today that the defendant stalked physicians, eavesdropped on their conversations and made statements indicating his hostility toward the persons he is accused of poisoning.
A field goal by Louis Walloch: with two minutes of play remaining gave the New York Boys Club five a 35-33 victory over the St. John's University junior varsity in the De Gray Gymnasium last night.

Interest remained at a high pitch in the Class C race of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Tennis League as the Harvard Club and the New York Athletic Club registered triumphs yesterday to keep in a tie for first place. Harvard defeated Bayside, 3 to 2, on the former's courts, while the Winged Foot team conquered Columbia, 4 to 1, at the Columbia Club.
The Federal Music Project gave its fourth of the series of MozartHaydn concerts last night at the Theatre of Music, 254 West Fiftyfourth Street,. before another nearcapacity audience.
New York City's basic tax on real estate for 1937 will be $2.64 for each $100 of assessed valuation, a drop of one point from the 1936 rate, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.

Washington St., 141, 18.11x54.3x irregular; Stanley F. Hemlin to trustees will of Christian Liebers, 32 E. 169th St.; consideration, $3,000, foreclosure. 9th St., 426 E., 25x93.11; Annie and Max Feinberg to Emigrant Bank; mtg.. $17,000, held by bank.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 920,000 bales, against 906,000 a week ago, 906,000 two weeks ago, 972,000 three weeks ago and 716,000 a year ago, of which American 415,000 bales, against 399,000 a week ago, 396,000 two weeks ago, 398,000 three weeks ago and 391,000 a year ago.

Business leases reported yesterday by brokers involved space principally on the West Side, above Fourteenth Street, and firms in the garment, textile, millinery, shoe and allied lines were represented among the lessees. The list follows:

More than 500 couples attended the junior promenade of Rutgers University in the college gymnasium this evening, opening festivities in the first social week-end of the second semester. House parties will be given tomorrow night by nineteen campus fraternities and the Scarlet Barbs, local non-fraternity organization.

For the second day in succession the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage today heard a member of the United Automobile Workers testify that he supplied Pinkerton detectives with information about union and plant activities, but duped the detectives because he was "smart enough to outwit them." Continuation of the hearings was assured today when the Senate unanimously appropriated $40,000. More will be asked.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany has signed a contract to buy the vacant land at the northwest corner of York Avenue and East Seventy-fourth Street from the Union Dime Savings Bank as the site for a new church edifice.
Elisha Slocum, a descendant of Robert Morris, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence, died here today in Monmouth Memorial Hospital.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn upheld yesterday the decision of Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau of Suffolk County, L. I., in denying Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers's petition to set aside her waiver of rights in the will of her husband, the late Colonel Henry H. Rogers Jr.

A new non-surgical treatment for sinus trouble, which, it was asserted, has afforded permanent relief to 80 per cent of the sufferers treated, including cases of forty years' standing,' was reported last night at a staff meeting of the Harlem Eye and Ear Hospital, Lexington Avenue at 127th Street, by Dr. I. Daniel Shorell, staff surgeon at the institution.

Bound for a cruise in Southern 'Pacific waters to seek museum specimens, the yacht Nourmahal will leave Miami early next week with Vincent Astor and a party of six friends on board. At the owner's office it was said yesterday

Sharp differences of opinion were aired today over the merits of two automatic alarm devices for cargo ships when the Federal Communication Commission held a public hearing on a report which its engineers made recently favoring these devices as "the most effective and practicable automatic distress alarms which it is possible for American engineering skill to produce at this time."

The cotton spinning industry set a new all-time record for activity during January. The Census Bureau reported today that the industry operated at 137.7 per cent of "capacity"-100 per cent being figured on an arbitrary operating schedule.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today issuance of an order against Robert Holmes, Inc., and Albert Goodman of Jersey City, requiring them to modify representations in connection with the sale of home study psychology health courses.

President Roosevelt, in the eyes of psychiatrists, is a truly great leader, for his leadership is born from a rare human virtue, "the love impulse," rather than the "destructive" desire of self-aggrandizement which is the characteristic of most persons in places of power and authority.

Hearings to determine whether the Securities and Exchange Commission shall issue a stop order prohibiting the Bainbridge Colby bondholders' committee from soliciting further deposits of Kreuger Toll 5 per cent secured debentures are scheduled to start here on Tuesday.

The Edwin Howard Clark Machine Gunners' Trophy for the infantry machine gun company which makes the highest average score per man in the regular season's target practice was awarded by the War Deapartment today to Company H of the Thirty-first Infantry at Manila for a score of 931.32 in 1936.

Thirteen persons died as a wave of killings swept over Moroland, advices from Jolo disclosed today. The killings were the result of three separate incidents, including Attempted robbery, religious differences and a reported marital triangle, the information reaching here said.

Non-ferrous metals staged yesterday their most spectacular advance in several years. Reflecting the further strength of prices on the London Metal Exchange, sales of copper in the export market were made at 15.175 cents a pound, the highest since early in 1930 and more than 1 cent above the domestic price of 14 cents, which was unchanged.
Members of the American Legion joined the Veterans Association tonight to form a "vigilante" patrol against "curb-cruisers" who annoy women on Buffalo streets.

Youngwomen of the Winter colony will serve as manikins in the fashion show featuring the Helen Lee Doherty lace benefit ball of tomorrow night at the Miami Biltmore Country Club in behalf of undernourished children of the area.

John Pelenyi, the Hungarian Minister, is at the Ritz-Carlton from Washington. Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Vere-Smith have left the Waldorf-Astoria to pass some time at the Beverly Wilshire, Beverly Hills, Calif., before going to Palm Springs and Tucson, Ariz. Their daughter, Miss Shirley Vere-Smith, is on a South American cruise.

A study by the Twentieth Century Fund reveals the fact that there are 175,000 different tax collecting units in the United States. The problem of overlapping taxation and double taxation as a result of this system is a serious and baffling one.

The Rev. J. George Kerschner, a retired minister of the Reformed Church, died in Germantown Hospital Wednesday night at the age of. 81. He was active in the ministry for forty years, serving churches at Pottstown, Mahanoy City, Palmington and Spring City.

Governor Lehman, speaking here today at Cornell University's annual of Farm and Home Week, told the dairymen of the State that he was anxious to restore price-making in the milk industry to the industry itself just as soon as the dairymen ble and milk companies were able and willing to accept the responsibility.

Hurling acid and metal missiles through a teargas barrage, about 100 "sit-down" strikers in the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation plant in North Chicago, south of Waukegan, repulsed 125 policemen and deputy sheriffs today in a two-hour battle.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Dahlen of South Orange, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Caroline Dahlen, to the Rev. Albert Louis Neibacher, pastor of St. Luke's Lutheran Church. 316 West Forty-sixth los, Street.

Representatives of American foundations and institutions with aggregate endowments, of probably. $1,000,000,000 were called upon tonight by.Dr. Frederick P.' Keppel, president of the Carnegie Corporation' of New York, to cooperate in a nation-wide clearing house plan for the popular diffusion of scientific knowledge through adult education.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred E. Fuller scratched their heads tonight and tried to remember just exactly what the King, the Queen and Queen Mother Mary had said to them, so they could tell it back home in Flatbush.

Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City: General Conditions Trading continued very slow on veal Other classes were in fair demand. Some sales steer hinds and ribs were 50c lower The lamb market was stronger and other classes unchanged.

Turpentine steady, 42c; no sales; receipts, 32 barrels; no shipments; stock, 26.268 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 169; receipts, 326; no shipments; stock, 59,830. Quote-B. $8.65; D, $9; E, $9.45; F to N. $10: WG, $10.25: WW. X. $12.

The separate nationhood of every dominion will be recognized by King George VI when he takes the solemn coronation oath in Westminster Abbey next May. The text of the oath issued tonight shows slight but significant changes compared with the pledge which George V took in 1911.
Directors of the Pierce Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that the corporation would distribute to stockholders 500,000 shares of the common stock of the Consolidated Oil Corporation.
