The number of persons holding assignments as WPA employes totals 187,798, or 60,676 fewer than a year ago, when the number of WPA ble assignments were at their peak, it was announced yesterday at WPA headquarters. On Feb. 19, 1936, the

Fred Titzell, veteran middle distance runner of the Millrose A. A., last night captured the one-mile handicap which featured the eightyseventh annual indoor games of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association at the Park Avenue armory.

Miss Frances Hohlt Eggers, daughter of Mrs. Herman Hans Eggers of 227 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Eggers, was married yesterday to Walter Scott Newhouse Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott Newhouse, also of Brooklyn.
The Alleghany Corporation, next to the top company in the Van Sweringen railway holding structure, bought 6,400 shares of Chesapeake Corporation common stock for $558,600 in the period from Feb.

A continuing program of public works, based upon the findings and approval of a national planning agency, and supplemented by aprogram of general assistance financed through Federal grants in aid to the States, was proposed here today.

The government's "trust-busting" division began a fight yesterday in Federal Court to smash an alleged conspiracy that was charged with virtually controlling the price of gasoline throughout the nation.

The undulating greens and fairways of Glen Arven's sporty golf course succumbed today to a concerted attack on par in the first round of Thomasville's $3,000 open tournament, with the eighteen-hole lead resting in a three-way tie.
Transfers of many high officers of the Navy, as approved by President Roosevelt, were announced today. Admiral Arthur Japy Hepburn, commander-in-chief of the fleet, is not affected.

Capturing six first and second places in nine events, the Princeton swimmers scored their fourth victory of the season by downing a weakened team from the United States Naval Academy, 49-26, in Brokaw Pool tonight.

A list of donors to the Annie Nathan Meyer drama library, which was established in her honor at Barnard College last week, was presented to Mrs. Meyer yesterday afternoon at her home, 1,225 Park Avenue, by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that it would send a representative to Albany at once to urge defeat of the Piper bill, which recently was reported favorably by the Judiciary Committee of the Assembly and which would require certain corporations to keep monthly statements and permit their inspection by stockholders on demand.

Twice postponed, Arthur Kober's comedy, "HavingWonderful Time," was still scheduled last night to open this evening at the Lyceum Theatre. Marc Connelly producing and directing, Katherine Locke and Jules Garfield heading the cast. Curtain at 8:30 o'clock.

While a board of inquest convened today on the demilitarized battleship Wyoming, the toll of yesterday's gun explosion aboard her rose to seven dead, thirteen injured. The seventh to die was Private Sidney Ensley of the Marine Corps, whose home was in Atlantic City, N. J.

Educational institutions of the nation are facing a new challenge to offset a drift toward paganism in the philosophy of the individual and anarchy in government, Dr. Wilbur Fleck declared today as he was installed as president of Wyoming Seminary, Methodist Episcopal school. He succeeds Dr. Levi L. Sprague, who died in 1936 after 54 years of service.

Mrs. Eleanor Barry Ryan, through Pease Elliman, in 114 E. 56th st.; Wm. A. White Sons. broker. Dr. Thomas J. Ryan, in 270 Park Av.' Mrs. E. Cannon, through Byrne Bowman,in 1,225 Park Av.; Ray Miller, in 346 E. 52d St.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., broker.

Kieffer, P. V., F. A., Hartford, Conn., to Boston, Mass., for duty in connection with National Guard affairs at headquarters. Edmunds, K. B., Cav., Salt Lake City. Utah, to the Command and General Staff school, Fort Leavenworth, Kan., as instructor about Aug. 1.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals-only $13,117,393, one State and forty-eight municipalities being represented. The revised total for this week is $18,260,730, and the weekly average of new offerings for the year to date $42,241,769.

Generally favorable comments by coffee merchants followed on the decided action taken by the government last night to straighten out the chaotic situation in the commodity precipitated by speculators at Santos. Although the move was expected, the surprise was in how the government handled the situation.
Energetic, incisive renditions of the selections on an unconventional program were heard from Ruth Posselt, American violinist, at her recital last night in Town Hall.
Pope Pius walked more faltering steps today with the aid of crutches and rested in the sunshine of his glass-enclosed loggia for several hours.

Intensifying their efforts to counter the opposition to President Roosevelt's judiciary reform proposals, administration forces raised the issue in the Senate today while the President continued his personal work among the uncommitted in Congress.

Police Claptain Jacob Usenga was exonerated of a charge of stealing bread on several occasions from a bakery truck and reinstated at a hearing tonight before Mayor Henry Sluyter and the Borough Council, but he was publicly reprimanded for conduct unbecoming an officer.

The Yale Club C team triumphed over the Bridgeport University Club of Bridgeport, Conn., 4 to 0, at the Yale Club yesterday in an exhibition squash racquets encounter. John Thompson of the losers put up a stubborn battle before succumbing to S. W. Mears, 15-6, 15-18, 10-15, 15-10, 15-6, in the feature match.

The Domei News Agency reported today from Harbin, Manchukuo, that twenty-four Japanese had been kidnapped when about sixty mounted Manchurian bandits plundered a Japanese-owned motor truck convov east of Harbin.

Liquidation yesterday of March contracts in advance of notices on Tuesday was offset by mill pricefixing and prices on the Cotton Exchange ended unchanged to 3 points lower than on Thursday under unusually limited fluctuations.
William Warfield Ross, a prominent member of the bar here, died yesterday in Emergency Hospital. His age 50. Mr. Ross, a native

Manual Training High School and St. John's Prep scored triumphs in non-league scholastic hockey games at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Manual blanked Brooklyn Tech, 5-0, and St. John's topped Boys High. 2-1.

Dr. Frank W. Jewett, vice president of the American Telegraph and Telephone Company and president of the Bell Telephone Laborstories, Inc., said in an address before the Bond Club of New York yesterday that industry should be alert in utilizing all available resources at its command in scientific research.

John Sanford entertained tonight with a dinner at Villa Marina for his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Legendre, who recently returned from a big-game hunt in Africa to their plantation in Medway, S. C. Other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Mario Pansa, Mr. and Mrs. James D. Altemus, the Countess of Abingdon, Countess Edith di Zoppola, the Hon. Mrs.

Leslie Ames and R. W. V. Robins came to the rescue of the Marylebone Cricket Club touring team today in its second match against Victoria. At the close of the first day's play the M. C. C. had scored 169 runs for eight wickets, the English pair preventing a collapse by putting on 56 for the seventh wicket.

Joe N. Kirk, at 164 Central Av., Madison, N. J., from Mrs. Ida M. Otz; Lewis D. Silsby, at 12 Keep St., Madison, for Wm. F. Keefe; W. Kelton Evans, broker. The Rev. Joseph H. Dodshon, renewal on home on Circle Av., Larchmont; Houghton Co., broker.
Max Glauberg, former president and a founder of the Association of United Auctioneers, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital.

Craven, T. T., detached as commandant 13th Naval District about May 8 and ordered home, relieved from all active duty. Holmes, R. S., staff of the commander of Battle Force, to duty as director of Naval Intelligence, Navy Department, Washington, D. C.

It is not surprising that the President's "special committee," appointed to-examine the question of controlling or restricting foreign purchases of American securities, should announce that the matter is "still in the study stage." It is not easy, even for

Administration hopes of bringing about a political-economic alliance between farming interests of the South and the West were brought into the open today when W. W. Alexander, Resettlement Administrator, told the first session of the National Agricultural Institute that "we must break up this traditional economic alliance between the South and the Atlantic seaboard and replace it with one that will make easier the enactment of national agricultural programs."
Yale junior fraternities held their annual midwinter calcium light parade tonight when eighty-two members of the class of '39 were elected to six societies.

A family holding corporation, in which Albert H. Wiggin of New York City has an interest, the extent of which was not disclosed in the reports, liquidated in December its holdings of equity securities in four corporations, according to a summary of transactions by officers, directors and principal stockholders in equity securities which was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Esquirol bill setting up two main classifications of nurses in New York State, registered professional nurses and nurse aides, was attacked last night as "discriminatory and unjust" by speakers at a meeting of the National Nurses Association at Town Hall.

More than 900 persons paid fines totaling $991 as the result of the four-day drive conducted recently against persons who expectorate or smoke in the subways, surface and elevated lines and other public places, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. The campaign was conducted on Jan. 21 and 22 and Feb. 1 and 2 during the morning and afternoon rush hours.

Transformed into "enchantment land," the gallery of fine arts of the Yale Art School was tonight filled with guests at the biennial ball of the art students, who were costumed as characters from fairy tales and folklore.

The Lawrenceville polo team defeated the Princeton junior varsity at the 112th Armory today, 10-6. Behind four goals at the beginning of the fourth period, the Laurentians rallied with eight goals to win.
Frederick A. Leslie, president of Leslie Co., a chemist shop at 20 East Fifty-third Street, died of pneumonia Wednesday at his home, 1,781 Riverside Drive. He was 50 years old.
Five Detroit factories were held today by more than 2,000 "stay-in" strikers, most of them women, who demand wage increases.

Retail trade continued ac' ve here during the week, and showed a somewhat better rate of improvement than the 8.9 per cent increase noted for New York and Brooklyn stores during the first twelve shopping days of this month.

Trustees of the New York. New Haven Hartford and Connecticut Western Railroads today received permission from the United States District Court to apply to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to abandon fourteen segments of unprofitable railroad, totaling 204.34 nukes, in which Charles F. Caley. transportation analyst, testified that the expense of operation is greater than the revenue. The line are being operated only or freight.

The consolidated net income for 1936 of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company was $3,838,704 after providing for depreciation, taxes, reserves and all other charges, according to a statement issued yesterday.

Coach Jack Crenny's powerful St. Augustine's five clinched the Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. championship last night as a result of its victory over St. John's Prep and the upset triumph by St. Francis Prep over the second-place Bishop Loughlin Memorial tossers.

The emplacement of American anti-aircraft guns, "85 per cent accurate," on the Bay of Biscay front by Basque supporters of the Spanish Government was described today in semi-official Basque dispatches from Bilbao.

The Bronxville Field Club team, Westchester champion, gained the final round in Class C of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League by defeating the Cornell Club, Group 2 title-winner, 3-2, at the University Club yesterday. Harvard will oppose Bronxville in the final at the Yale Club next Friday.

Horses which later will be running in the $20,000 added Flamingo Stakes and the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup, richest events of the meeting, tomorrow will be seen in action in the Tamiami Purse and the McLennan Memorial Handicap, Hialeah Park's features.

Henry Ford today advised all workers to "stay out, of labor organizations" and charged "international financiers are behind the'labor unions." The Detroit automobile manufacturer, in an authorized interview, also criticized the proposal to increase the number of Supreme Court Justices.
Mrs. Caroline Gerard, widow of William B. Gerard and a resident of Huntington for the last fifty years, died here last night in her home at the age of 86. Her father,

In the very limited circle in which it is known, great disappointment is felt here in the result of last week's conversations between Joachim von Ribbentrop and representatives of the British Government.

Over the objection of David W. Peck, representing W. E. Hutton Co. of New York, brokers accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of having manipulated stocks, Edward C. Johnson, trial examiner, today permitted the introduction of checks relating to the purchase and sale of Atlas Tack Corporation stock between Nov. 1, 1935, and Aug. 1, 1936.

Major Green, Negro porter, was sentenced by Judge Charles S. Colden in the Queens County Court yesterday to be put to death in the week of April 4 for the killing of Mrs. Mary Harriet Case in her apartment at 37-06 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, on Jan. 11.
Commenting that the shipping articles under which the Dollar Steamship Line employed Chinese seamen "amount to peonage," Federal Judge William Clark today ordered Nai Tam, third cook on the

A patrolman attached to the East Twenty-second Street police station and two other men were arrested last night on charges of attempted extortion and taken to police headquarters after a chase by detectives of the main office division.

Total round-lot volume and member trading decreased in the week ended on Jan. 23, compared with the previous week, on the New York stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange, according to the weekly summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Carscale len entertained with a dinner last night at the Plaza. Among their guests were Dr. and Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Duff, Dr. and Mrs. Frederick N. Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Clif ford Bucknam, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Wright, Dr. and Mrs. Theodorus

Representative William B. Barry of Queens County, N. Y., asked President Roosevelt today to advise him whether the Brooklyn Navy Yard was likely to get a contract to build one of the new battleships recently authorized.
Acceptance of office by members of the Congress party in the Provincial Assemblies is now likely. The nationalist press is discussing the formation of Congress party ministries in six provinces.

Park Avenue's pedigreed pooches, scorned by apartment-house and hotel doormen in the Forties and Fifties and forded to walk near the treeless curb in accordance with the city's sanitation drive, received a pleasant surprise yesterday afternoon During their daily stroll they encountered eight Sanitation Department inspectors busily directing dog owners to a "canine rest room" in the form of a small tree.

One hundred and fifty miles northwest of St. John's, America's first transatlantic air terminal is rising out of the wilderness of Newfoundland not far from the spot where the first flight across the Atlantic started eighteen years ago.

The limit of the American people's capacity to pay tapes is not a fixed sum such as public speakers have estimated during the last year; rather it depends on how the government spends tax money, according to a report of the tax research staff of the Twentieth Century Fund made public yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Jeremiah Zimmerman, one of the oldest clergymen in Central New York, founder and pastor emeritus of the First English Lutheran Church, an author, educator, archaeologist and numismatics authority of note, died here today at Crouse Irving Hospital. His age was 88.

Commonwealth Securities, Inc.For 1936: Net profit, $33,185 before $176,411 loss on security transactions charged to deficit, contrasted with net loss of $36,197 for 1935, excluding $571,362 loss on security transactions.
Now are the tides of the restless waters Green through the serpentine grasses blowing, Black over furrow and clod and boulder Bitterly flowing.

Benedict M. Holden, Connecticut lawyer and during the World War quartermaster of the largest home base for accoutering the United States Army in France, died at 10 o'clock last night after suffering a heart attack in the dining room of the Roosevelt Hotel. He was 63 years old.
The Bank of the Manhattan Company has been appointed transfer agent for the common stock of Allen Industries, Inc.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Warner of 350 East Fiftysecond Street yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion, Medical Celter. Mrs. Warner is the former Miss Anne Homer, one of the twin daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Homer (the latter, Mme. Louise Homer, noted singer).
Bernard M. Baruch, financier and practical economist, who was chairman of the War Industries Board during the World War, has been appointed honorary chancellor of. Union College for 1937.

The gift of a $200,000 chapel for the new campus of Colby College from George Horace Lorimer, '98, former editor of The Saturday Evening Post, was announced by President Franklin Winslow Johnson at a dinner meeting of the Colby alumni of Eastern Massachusetts at the University Club this evening.
Several hundred members of the New York Southern Society and their friends attended the society's annual Dixie Dinner Dance last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The committee,

Gross assets, $153,899; net $71,023. To Ida McC. Wilson, sister, $5.000 and life estate in residue; Jessie Porteous, housekeeper, $2,000. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $78,617. Emmet, Marvin Marvin. attorneys. 48 Wall St.

The long-awaited Estonian national assembly, consisting of two chambers, elected solely for the purpose of framing a new constitution, met today at Tallinn. President Konstantin Paets made a speech in which he enumerated the principles which the Cabinet considers the most suitable basis for the new constitution.

Ruling that a sit-down strike which tends to interfere with the ordinary workings of the place occupied by the strikers constitutes a menace to the public peace, Magistrate William Klapp in the Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday found the seven men arrested Wednesday in the apartment building at 721 Walton Avenue guilty of disorderly conduct.

The Central Illinois Public Service Company, controlled by the Middle West Corporation, in its report for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $1,542,506 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Andre de Laboulaye, retiring French Ambassador to the United States, sails today for Paris on the French liner Ile de France with Mrs. Laboulaye and his family. Others sailing on the ship for Havre via Plymouth include: Pierre Barrillot, Governor of St. Pierre et Miquelon Islands; Leon Baum,
The Atlantic City Sea Gulls defeated the New York Rovers, 3 to 2, tonight in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game.

Mrs. Harry Oakes's Tumbling Glass won the Seagram Cup horse race in a blanket finish with the Hon. R. Collins's Blue Cloud and the Bahamian Club Stables' Star Marie at Montagu Park today, all three finfishing noses apart in the one-mile event. It was the first cup race of the season.

An attempt by a city marshal and two aides to evict John Cicarelli and his family of five from their apartment at 213 East 114th Street yesterday resulted in injury to four persons, including two policemen, and the arrest of two others. The disturbance lasted more than half an hour and involved about 500 persons.

Marcel Rosenberg, Soviet Ambassador to Spain, has been replaced by Leon Y. Gaikis, hitherto counselor of the embassy in Spain. The announcement stated Mr. Rosenberg "has been freed in connection with his appointment to another job."
A Bronx resale involved the building for sixty-two families at 2,512-18 Tratman Avenue, a five-and-a-halfstory walk-up on a plot 150 by 160 feet. The property was sold by

The body of Howard Smith, 65 years old, a member of a pioneer family here, was found today at 9 A. M. beside a houseboat on the shore of Manhasset Bay. According to the police, Mr. Smith was drowned when he went to board the boat, probably slipping and falling into the water. He had been a painting .contractor in the village for years.
With Miss Dorothy Lawlor tallying twenty points the Rider College girls' basketball team trounced the New York University combination, 41 to 14, on the Evangeline House court yesterday.

Several new directors and vice presidents were named by the Tide Water Associated Oil Company yesterday. The additions, however, were former directors and officers of the Tide Water Oil Company and the Associated Oil Company, both of which were merged recently into the Tide Water Associated Oil Company.

Transportation services reported "unprecedented" traffic yesterday as thousands of New Yorkers, taking advantage of the three-day holiday and the prevailing mild weather; started to stream out of the city last night to celebrate the 205th anniversary of the birthday of George Washington in their home towns or out-of-town resorts.

Declaring that Canada could no longer rely on the Monroe Doctrine for protection against foreign attack unless she were prepared to consult and cooperate with the United States, Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King told the Canadian House of Commons today that the Dominion must defend her own coasts.

Protesting to the last, Harry Greenspan of 1,219 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, motorist who accumulated fourteen summonses for parking violations during the last three years, paid $17 in fines yesterday for nine of the violations. While he was declaring hotly in Downtown Traffic Court that he "would not pay" and would "fight the case to the highest courts," Joseph Goldstein, his attorney, handed in the money.

By a unanimous vote the Board of Estimate appropriated $50,000 yesterday for the use of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Kings County to meet the costs of criminal investigations into racketeering and accident frauds by the additional grand jury empaneled for the January term of Kings County Court.

Led by Junius Calitri, the unbeaten New York University swimming team subdued City College, 38-31, in the Beavers' pool last night. It was the visitors' fourth victory. A 3-yard triumph in the closing relay decided.

The executive committee of the State Bar Association will meet at the Fort Orange Club here tomorrow to consider President Roosevelt's judiciary reform program. It is expected that the plan will be condemned.

Cosmic ray particles bombarding India have properties different from those found elsewhere in the world and may prove clues to the origin of the mysterious radiation, according to Dr. H. Victor Neher, physicist at the California Institute of Technology.

Attempting to stop an outbreak by nearly 500 persons protesting at the Emergency Relief Bureau station at 325 East 103d Street a reduction in relief, Policeman Martin Pendergrass, of' the East 104th Street station, was pushed down' the steps in front of the building yesterday afternoon.
The Woodlawn Building and Loan Association has sold to George Boss two brick store and dwelling properties at 143-145 Thirty-eighth Street, Union City. J. I. Kislak, Inc.. negotiated the sale.

Freddie Steele, Tacoma (Wash.) boxer, successfully defended his world middleweight title against Babe Risko, Syracuse husky who formerly held the crown, in fifteen unexciting rounds before a slim gathering in Madison Square Garden last night. With the victory,

The decline in cotton-mill activity last week was slightly greater than seasonal, with the result that the adjusted index fell back fractionally. The figure dropped to 136.5 from 137.4 the preceding week. It was 107.4 for the week ended Feb. 15, 1936.

WILLIAM ORTON'S "The Last Romantic" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50) is a curious and fascinating book, as baffling as it is memorable. Despite the torrent of recent autobiographies, there has been of late nothing else quite like it-nothing else at once so personal. and impersonal, so positive and negative, so illuminating and puzzling.

The New York A. C., which has been running indoor track and field meets since 1868 and which therefore must be considered quite an old hand at the art, will unfold the finest and best balanced set of games in its history in Madison Square Garden tonight.

Flood relief contributions totaling $17,566.96 were received yesterday at the offices of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, bringing the total received to date by the chapter to $1,952,825.69, it was announced by General Robert C. Davis, executive director.

Frieda Hempel, former opera singer, returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday from a month's vacation abroad that started two years ago. She went over at that time to visit relatives in Germany and to tour other countries, and she had such a good time she extended the visit until a week ago. While abroad she sang

More than 4,000 youngsters from the poorer sections of the city will enjoy a two-week vacation this Sum. mer at city expense under plans announced by Mayor La Guardia. yesterday for a city Summer camp on Hoffmans Island in the lower bay off Staten Island.
Albert J. Buttling, chief clerk of the Supreme Court Trial Term in Brooklyn, died yesterday of heart disease at his home, 404 Sterling Place, Brooklyn. His age was 61.

John Brion, 58 years old, an electrical engineer for forty years with the Central Railroad of New Jersey, hanged himself today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Bertha Carew, at 120 Hutton Street here, according to the police.

SERGEANTS-Siegel Goldstein, 6th Precinct, assigned to tours 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and from 4 P. M. to 12 midnight, for 30 days; Burton L. Royce, 76th Precinct, assigned telephone switchboard duty, tour 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and from 4 P. M. to 12 midnight, for 30 days; Walter P. Mitchell, from 88th Precinct to 18th Division, duty D. A. office, Kings County, for 1 day.

After hearing numerous arguments yesterday against a proposed local law requiring the fingerprinting and police registration of certain building service employes, the Local Laws Committee of the Board of Aldermen voted to table the measure and thus prevented it from coming before the Board of Aldermen.

Announcement was made yesterday of the formation of a new limited partnership under the name of Hayden, Stone Co., made necessary by the recent death of Charles Hayden, with Feb. 19 the effective date. The estate of Charles Hayden will be a limited partner in the new investment, brokerage and underwriting concern.

The New York Dock Company, which owns a $37,000,000 wharf, warehouse and railway development covering two and one-half miles of the Brooklyn waterfront, announced yesterday that it would ask holders of $4,386,000 of its notes, due on April 1, 1938, to exchange them for new notes to mature in 1947.

The Federal Trade Commission today issued complaints against the Mells Manufacturing Company, Brooklyn, N. Y., and the Maryland Baking Company, Baltimore, charging them with unfair methods of competition in the sale of their products by means of lotteries.

The Chase National Bank, as plaintiff, made yesterday a bid of $466,000 in taking over at auction the nine-story apartment house at 952 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of Seventy-sixth Street. The foreclosure action was

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, wealthy young horseman, chalked up another victory today when his Speed to Spare, piloted by Lloyd Knapp, won the $1,500 added National Orange Show Handicap, at Santa Anita Park.

A concert for the benefit of flood sufferers will be given tonight at Carnegie Hall. The proceeds of the concert, held under the auspices of the American Guild of Musical Artists, Inc., will be turned over to the American Red Cross for flood relief.

The Spanish steamer Mar Cantabrico sailed tonight for Barcelona, Spain, with a cargo of war materials and airplanes, made in the United States and Mexico, for the Spanish Republican Government. The shipment was the third Mexico had sent to the MadridValencia administration.

Echoes of the crash of the Insull utilities empire in 1932 were heard today with the disclosure that creditors of Martin J. Insull, brother of Samuel Insull, had agreed to a compromise settlement which might yield them between $1,000,000 and $2,000,000 on total claims of $9,000,000.

General Motors Corporation's automotive plants rapidly neared capacity production tonight as its negotiators ended four days of conferences with union representatives on issues remaining from recent strikes.

Once credited with having accumulated a modest fortune, Marie Prevost, film actress, left only personal effects worth some $300 when she died a month ago, according to a petition for the probate of her will, filed today.

The dealers' license of the Borden Company will be revoked in ten days unless the company opens its books and records to the Milk Control Authorities, Peter G. Ten Eyck, State Commissioner of Agriculture, announced today.

Appointments to Yale-in-China from the senior class of Yale College, announced today, include Edward V. Gulick of Andover, Mass., and John F. B. Runnalls of Syracuse, who, with Burton B. Rogers, '30, will sail for China this Summer. Mr. Rogers has been
The New York Giants announced yesterday that. the Polo Grounds would not be available for the Winter sports carnival sponsored by Armand Vincent, Canadian promoter, The Associated Press reported.

The government obtained its first convictions today in its warfare on what Federal Judge Merrill E. Otis termed "election thievery." A jury convicted Edson M. Walker, Democratic precinct judge, and John H. Drummond, Democratic precinct captain, of conspiring to deprive voters of their rights in the general election of Nov. 3.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, who was absent from Friday's plenary sessions of the Kuomintang (Nationalist party), the governing body of China, again submitted blanket resignations from all his official posts today but the party rejected them.

A large part of the noted collection of French eighteenth century art formed by David David-Weill of Paris, regent de la Banque de France and president du Conseil des Musies Nationaux, will come to this country and, presumably, enter American public and private collections.
Charles L. Preston, insurance executive and investment banker, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Preston, who was 44 years old, lived at 14 Chesterfield Road, Scarsdale.
Miss Helen P. McCormick, president of the Catholic Big Sisters of Brooklyn, underwent a blood transfusion yesterday at Brooklyn Hospital, following an abdominal operation.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Zolnay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Julian Zolnay, to John Churchill Newcomb of this city, formerely of Louisville, Ky., will take place on Thursday afternoon at the home of Miss Zolnay's parents, 137 East Nineteenth Street.

Colgate's five scored a 63-26 victory over the University of Buffalo tonight. The losers furnished unexpected opposition in the first half to hold the Red Raiders on fairly even terms but were unable to follow the fast pace in the second.

A variety of properties were reported sold in the Long Island area yesterday. A tract in Williston Park was purchased by Dr. Maurice A. M. Edkiss and is under development as a home community to be known as Wyndham Williston Estates. Sixteen houses, each of individual design, are under construction already and erection of 300 homes in all is planned.
Ethel Barrymore's daughter, whom the theatre welcomed in 1930 as Ethel Barrymore Colt, will be known on the stage hereafter as Ethel Colt.

Building plans were featured yesterday by projects for altering numerous structures in Manhattan. Architects also filed for a $250,000 tenement in the Bronx and for a group of homes in Brooklyn to cost $40,000. Details of the plans follow:

Three bills designed to insure a five-cent fare on city subways and provide for a referendum by the city voters on any transit-unification plan were introduced today by Assemblyman Moran, Democrat, of Brooklyn.
President Roosevelt today looked up from his office desk, saw bright sunlight and soft skies outside, and suddenly decided to go for a short drive.

Edward J. Phelan, a discharged fireman, brought suit today in a move for reinstatement. In mandamus papers served on Dr. Arthur J. Leonard, Commissioner of Public Safety, Phelan said he was dismissed "without cause" last November after Thomas Bonny, Assistant Fire Chief, accused him of taking two cigarettes from a package while he was on watch duty and supposed to guard all property in the firehouse. Phelan denied the charge.

Presideni Roosevelt accepted the resignation of John G. Winant as chairman of the Social Security Board and appointed Murray W. Board, promoted A. J. Altmeyer to the chairmanship and appointed Murray W. Latimer, chairman of the Railroad Retirement Board, to the Security Board vacancy.

Movementl or vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 18, unless specified: At San Pedro: Algorma, Thrush, Feb. 19; Antares, Bridge, Holland, New York,Saratoga, Utah, Wyoming, Grebe. At Philadelphia Yard: Bass, Bonita. At San Diego: Gannet, Houston, Pennsylvania.

China's governing organ, the Kuomintang (Nationalist party), decided at a plenary session yesterday to bury the hatchet with its long-standing enemy, the Chinese Communist party, if agreement is possible.

The Madison County grand jury, moving swiftly in an effort to fix the blame for the outbreak of a labor feud that brought military rule to Anderson, indicted nineteen men today for rout and riot soon after the military had given their custody to civil authorities.
The embargo on American apples was lifted today after Austrian supplies had become entirely exhausted. Apples from other European countries cost four times as much as the American product.

Extension of President Roosevelt's powers to negotiate reciprocal trade agreements with foreign nations, granted for three years in 1934, was recommended to the Senate today by its Finance Committee. Theproposal, which already has passed the House, would prolong the present system until 1940.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have on my desk a copy of a report by the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society, entitled "Why Abandoned Buildings Should Be Demolished."

Southern Blvd. (10-2732), e. s., 175 n. of Longwood Av., 100x100; Sigreen Operating Corp. to Fanyer Realty Corp., 175 Main St., White Plains. N. Y.; mtg., $116,600. 198th St., 369 e. (12-3284): Edna M. Casey to Charles Tinnelly, 244 E. 198th St. Palling Av. (15-4067), s. e. cor. of Poplar St., 33x100; Saveri Astorino to Adelaide Puleo, 1,516 Paulding Av.; mtg., $10,000.

Tiberias, one of the towns of Palestine known for its friendly relations between Arabs and Jews, was the scene of disorder today. Thirty Jews, thirty Arabs and two British policemen were slightly injured and two Jews were seriously hurt before order was restored.
H. Charles Ehrenfels, a retired Standard Oil Company official, died here yesterday at the age of 65.
Sir Charles Edward Ellis, one of Great Britain's munitions advisers and director of John Brown Co., Ltd.,

School Art League lecture, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 9:30 A. M. "Behind the Scenes in the Museum," Stuart M. Shaw. American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West. "Stories of a Camera Hunter," Howard Cleaves, 10:30 A. M.; "George Washington," Motion Picture, 2 P. M.

Estate, more than $5,000. To James Paul Herr, nephew, 1,000 Walnut St., North Wales, Pa., $1,000 annuity, principal at 21; Margaret M. Sinnott, half-sister, petitioner, 5.618 Baltimore Av., Philadelphia, Pa., $5,000 and household effects; Helen Murphy Kerr, half-sister, petitioner, 1,000 Walnut St., North Wales, Pa., household effects, specific real property and interest in residue.

James J. Brown, Rockland County Supervisor for twenty-five years, was sentenced to- nine months in the county jail today after he had pleaded guilty to a charge of misappropriating $728 received by the county from the State as a home relief installment.

Madrid sent eighty-three captured Insurgents back to the trenches tonight to fight their former comrades. The captives, now clad in government military uniforms, filed into the floodlighted Palace of Justice court room to hear themselves solemnly declared "free men going back into the trenches, not as prisoners, but as comrades."

Railway statements for operations in January, issued yesterday, continued to provide indication that, despite the ending of the emergency freight surcharges on Jan. 1, the gross revenues of railroads unaffected by floods or strikes continued to gain. These statements follow:

Trustees of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad have awarded an issue of $2,655,000 of equipment-trust certificates to the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company on a high bid of 100.067, equal to a yield of 3.24 per cent. The award is subject to

Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn pressed yesterday for immediate action on the reform of county government by introducing four bills in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly, but the board voted to send them to committee.
" The Man Who Could Work Miracles," a fanciful comedy written by H. G. Wells and produced by Alexander Korda's London Films, will have its Broadway premiere this morning at the Rivoli.

PROBABLY Don Lash will win the two-mile event in the New York A. C. festivities at Madison Square Garden this evening. Possibly Galloping Glenn Cunningham will take the Baxter Mile from a real Olympian field. But who will win that half-mile contest?

Another signed Yankee contract dropped on Business Manager Ed Barrow's desk yesterday, but after one glance at the signature Colonel Ruppert's right-hand man settled back in his easy chair with his calm unruffled.

The New York University women's fencing team gained its second straight victory by downing the Brooklyn College squad, 5-4, in a foils match on the strips of the East Building at Washington Square last night.
After quitting in the stretch in many of his recent starts, A. G. Tarn's Epernay carried his speed for the full five and a half furlongs today to win the feature race at the Fair Grounds.
James Neilson, philanthropist and oldest living alumnus of Rutgers University, died today at Woodlawn, the house in which he was born ninety-two years ago. He had been ill for less than ten days.

One hundred couples attended the annual Junior Promenade of Barnard College which was held last night at the Hotel Pierre. Miss Ruth Inscho was the chairman of the dance and her committee included the Misses Christina Boardman, Emily Chadbourne, Shirley Hageman, Alice Krbecek, Elizabeth Pratt, Adi-Kent Thomas, Mary Rhodin and Miriam Spencer.

James J. Braddock and Bomber Joe Louis signed today for their heavyweight championship fight, making it official for Chicago next June unless legal blows threatened by Madison Square Garden knock it out before that time.
Mrs. Anna Hauptmann came here today to claim a note for $200 given to her husband before his arrest for the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby and subsequently seized by State Police as evidence.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market has been exceedingly quiet. Transactions have been so few as to make it difficult to quote with certainty, but with the foreign market falling and domestic prices relatively dear the tendency for prices is lower and some wools held at country points are being offered at concessions to clean up in advance of the new clip.

Edward G. Lowry Jr., vice President and general counsel of the Maryland Casualty Company, was questioned at length yesterday morning at a public hearing in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, regarding a campaign to bring holders of mortgage certificates into a reorganization plan.

Hackley won a Triangular League basketball game from Storm King, 39-25, today. The second and third Hackley teams also won, by the scores of 27-24 and 16-13, respectively, giving the Gray and Black a total of 24 points for the league trophy. Riverdale is the third member of the group.

Beirne Gordon Jr., executive vice president and general manager of the Skenandoa Rayon Corporation since 1925, died this morning in Faxton Hospital here after an operation for removal of gallstones. His age was 52.
An exhibition of Turkish, Balkan, Caucasian and North African arms and armor, part of the George C. Stone bequest, will open to the public tomorrow in Gallery E-15 at the Metropolitan Museum.
The Spanish civil war occupied most of the Congressional attention that was devoted to the subject of neutrality legislation today.

Winning by similar scores in the thirty-six-hole semi-final battles today, Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, N. J., representing the Forsgate Country Club, and W. D. Stark Jr. of Jacksonville, Fla., advanced to the concluding round in the tenth annual national championship of golf club champions on the St. Augustine links.

Despite prevailing opinion to the contrary, it is perhaps not fantastic to suggest that at last-after seven months - of intervention in Spain-the end of the " Little World War " may be in sight. There is some basis for hope

It was officially announced today that negotiations between the government and the German Activist party had reached a successful conclusion. The results will be published tomorrow. The Prager Tageblatt understands that five of the seven demands the Activists presented to the government have been conceded, the remaining two to be settled in Parliament.

Bert Acosta, who recently faced a Federal inquiry for enlisting in the Spanish Loyalist air force, was rehanded to the Nassau Couny jail here this afternoon pending the posting of a $500 bond to insure his appearance in Children's Court next Friday morning.

American business men should unite to spend at least $10,000,000 a year in a collective advertising campaign to show what capital contributes to the country's welfare, Sir Charles Higham, head of one of England's leading advertising agencies, declared here yesterday.
Mrs. Goldie Balaban Levin, mother of seven sons who built the $20,000,000 motion-picture enterprises bearing the Balaban name, died at Miami, Fla., today after a brief illness.

A sitdown strike of union members among its press operators caused delay of several editions of The Detroit News, an evening newspaper of more than 300,000 daily circulation, here today. An agreement was reached and the presses began rolling again about 2:15 P. M.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

A $20,000 mortgage on 951 Madison Av., held by the Bowery Savings Bank from Seth M. Milliken, was extended to Feb. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent. Two mortgages aggregating $500,000 and held by the Bowery Savings Bank from 535 Park Av., Howard Mansfield, president, were consolidated to form one first lien for that amount and extended to Aug. 1, 1939, at 3 to 4 per cent.
The week-end holiday will be marred by rain, if the Weather Bureau forecast is correct. It was for partly cloudy and slightly warmer weather today and for rain tonight. Rain and moderate
MEXICO, D. F. Feb. 19.--Powerful anti-religious forces threatened tonight to disrupt conciliation of Mexico's stormy church-State controversy.

The government of the Soviet Union has agreed to adhere to the provisions of the 1930 London naval treaty governing the wartime action of submarines against merchant vessels. Thus all the great powers have formally accepted the terms of international law in humanizing submarine warfare, for which Great Britan and the United States have striven for eighteen years.
Nicholas Czechalenka of Brooklyn was convicted by a county jury of manslaughter in connection with the death of a fellowinmate of Woodbourne Medium Security prison.

Bullish news had relatively little effect on the wheat market today, except for a brief period early, when there was fair buying on the Board of Trade here based on strength in Liverpool and new reports of dust storms in the Southwest. The outside trade,

An accounting of the estate of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, filed in Surrogate's Court here today, showed a shrinkage in the estate of about $85,000 for a six-year period ending last Oct. 6.

Mayor La Guardia and several thousand men and women welcomed Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, when he arrived yesterday afternoon at Pennsylvania Station. It was his first visit to New York sinea 135, when he came here as Presidentelect.

Miss Patty Berg, 19-year-old red-haired Minneapolis sensation, gained her first victory toward the new challenge cup by winning the women's annual golf championship of Palm Beach at the Palm Beach Country Club today.

The marriage of Miss Mary Louise Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mills Wheeler of Unquowa Hill, to Frank Carley Hunt Jr., of Frank Carley Hunt of Brooklawn Park and Mrs. Herbert D. Smith of New Canaan, will take place on March 5 in St. George's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Delmar S. Markle and the Rev. Henry S. Kelly will officiate.

A very large audience attended the performance of Bellini' "Norma" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House This audience was cold after the first act, but uproarious after thesecond and third, when Gina Cigna who appeared for the first, time, here in the title part, was repeatsedly called before the curtain.

AT the moment, Mr. Stanley Baldwin ranks among the supermen. He is a Prime Minister who has made history. He defeated a general strike. He surrendered free trade. He is re-arming the nation. He has even presided over the abdication of a monarch--this Cromwell, the regicide--this Warwick, the king-maker.

James P. Gillies, formerly vice president and general manager of the Mssonite Company, Chicago, has joined the L. E. Waterman Company, manufacturer of fountain pens and ink, as executive vice president and general manager. F.

A debate will be held at Pennsylvania State College Thursday on whether bridge playing does more harm than good. Seton Hill College will send two women debaters to join with two members of the Penn State male squad in presenting a split-team debate on the bridge topic.

News dispatches from Europe state that Miss Audrey Peppe, the lone American entry in the European figure skating championship who has been training in Vienna all Winter, placed eleventh out of a field of fourteen in the contest at Prague.

A reception and card party will be given for the benefit of the Committee for Queens of the New York City Visiting Committee on Friday at the nurses' home of the Queens General Hospital. Mrs. Warren S. Schoonmaker is in charge of ticket sales.

The twelfth annual conference of the Secondary Education Board will be held at the Hotel Commodore on Friday and Saturday. Founded in 1924, this organization includes in its membership 144 of the leading independent schools. Dr. Samuel S. Drury, rector of St. Paul's School, will speak.

A dinner dance, to be known as "A Night in Bagdad," will be given for the benefit of the Red Cross Relief Fund on March 4 in the Garden of the Ambassador Hotel. An Oriental pageant and other divertissements will be presented during the evening.

EMBERS of the Forty-first Division Aviation, Felts Field, Spokane, Wash., have seen another one of their wishes come true. For many years they were active, the air corps disclosed last week, in the promotion of the northern transcontinental airway. now a reality. During recent months they have been equally interested in the development of the so-called "inside airway" between Spokane and Alaska.

The second in a series of tees was held by the Master fashion show committee of the School Settlement Association yesterday in the restaurant of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn. Mrs. Tremper Longman is chairman of the committee for the fashion show to be held on March 19 in the grand ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

New York University's College of Arts and Pure Science at University Heights will start this Fall a "new and unique" four-year curriculum of business and liberal arts studies, Dean Irving H. Berg announced yesterday.

A rapidly growing danger to American higher education through the encroachment of State Legislatures into the administrative affairs of universities and through the acceptance of Federal subsidies by these institutions was described by speakers today at a joint meeting of the American Philosophical Society with representatives of organizations administering research funds.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bertrand Wright of 1,120 Fifth Avenue last night gave a theatre party and afterward a supper with dancing in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for their daughter, Miss Phyllis Bertrand Wright, who is returning to Bennington College after the holiday. The host and hostess took their guests to the performance of "King Richard II" attheSt.James Theatre.

Williams dropped its opening Little Three basketball battle to Amherst at the Lasell gymnasium today by a 26-21 count. About 1,000 alumni saw the Caldwell-coached five beaten by its inability to drop penalty shots.
Four years after National Socialism's overwhelming triumph in the Protestant church elections of 1933, Chancellor Adolf Hitler has decreed that the whole thing will have to be done over again.

Illustration of the fact that contributions to science can be made by students who have not yet won their bachelor's degree was given at Yale University this week when for the first time in many years two undergraduates were elected to full membership in the Yale chapter of Sigma Xi. In receiving this honor,

Governor Horner was striving tonight to-get the opposing interests in the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation sitdown strike at North Chicago to agree to attend a conference in Springfield tomorrow morning.

Prosecutor John J. Breslin issued a statement here today saying he had "testimony" that Samuel Rosoff, subway builder, had twice threatened Norman Redwood, "sandhog" union leader who was shot and killed Friday night outside his home in Teaneck, N. J., in efforts to persuade Redwood to end a strike on a Rosoff Tunnel Corporation job on the Wards Island intercepting sewer.
WITH the conquest of the Sahara, immense new areas of equatorial Africa are being opened up to tourists at an astonishing rate.

Representatives of six colleges will take part in the annual Inter-Faith Conference to be held tomorrow afternoon and evening at Connecticut College. A panel discussion will be held in Knowlton Salon in the afternoon on the general topic "Common Tasks for Inter-Faith Cooperation on the Basis of JewishChristian Idealism."
President Roosevelt was quoted today as saying that if he went to Germany under the present regime there he would be arrested ten times in one day.
A campaign to unionize a million oil industry workers, including filling station attendants, took form today.

Three one-act plays will be presented by the Lakeview Players, formerly known as the Junior Branch Players, on the night of March 11 and the afternoon of March 13 at the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street, for the benefit of the New York Women's League for Animals.

An all-American program including three interesting novelties was offered at the fifth Young People's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Ernest Schelling, yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall. Helen Jepson, the Metropolitan soprano, was the assisting artist.

Wielding a sledge hammer, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx started- the demolition yesterday of several hundred "old-law" tenement buildings to make way for the westerly approach to-the Bronx end of the Triborough Bridge.

Willie Eley, young Harlem welterweight, last night won the decision from Jay Macedon of South Orange, N. J., in the featured tenround bout before 1,500 at Rockland Palace. Eley weighed 144 1/2 pounds and Macedon 148.

By order of the County Commis sioners, Harry W. Heaphy is drawing a new map of Berkshire Coun ty, which comprises the cities of Pittsfield and North Adams and thirty towns within an area of 959 square miles. The most irregular town is Lenox, with twenty-three corners.
The Elgin, Joliet Eastern Railroad has ordered six oil-electric locomotives from the Electro-Motive Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, according to Railway Age.

With Archie M. Andrews and his wife still unfound by process servers, creditors to another step in Federal Court yesterday to uncover the background of the former chairman of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, who is charged with putting a barrier of corporations, "dummies" and relatives between his creditors and "many millions of dollars."

Sturdy, 17-year-old Irwin Goodman, a senior at Abraham Lincoln High School, last night captured the New York State A. A. U. 300-yard medley swimming title at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. pool. Off to a fine start, Goodman won by 20 yards -from Eugene Beuschel of the Central Queens Y. M. C. A. in 3:56.

With the announcement that $300,000 has been donated for the building of two new dormitories, the Stevens Institute of Technology enters upon a new era of its existence. Plans are under way which will double the present enrollment of 500 within the next decade, and will accordingly increase the faculty and the number of courses offered to both graduates and undergraduates.

Dr. Thor Christian Rothstein, Professor Emeritus of Neurology of Rush Medical College, died yesterday at the Presbyterian Hospital. He was 71 years old. Born in Sweden, Dr. Rothstein was a graduate of the Royal Medico-Surgical Institute of Stockholm.

Announcement has been made or the engagement of Miss Charlotte Mills Parry, daughter of Mrs. Edwin Parry and the late Mr. Parry of Riverton, near here, to William P. Mulford, son of Dr. and Mrs. E. R. Mulford of this city.

Formation of the Lower West. Side Tenants League, with headquarters at 243 Thompson Street, is announced by the Lower West Side Federation on Health Housing and Unemployment. The league has affiliated with the City-Wide Tenants Council, composed of similar organizations in Harlem and on the East Side.

George, F. Getz, millionaire coal operator and member of the Illinois State Athletic Commission, today, expressed wholehearted approval of the closing of the James J. Braddock Joe Louis heavyweight championship fight in Chicago next June.

THE Spring season, usually a time when all young dancers with the price of a debut recital blossom forth irrespective of qualifications, is apparently preparing a change of pattern this year, for already on its schedule are two events in the debut category which promise to be of genuine interest.

There was some slowing down of wholesale buying activity last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Manufacturers made every effort to expedite deliveries. Buyers in the market were chiefly interested in fashion goods for quick delivery. The report continues:

Miss Margaret Leslie King, daughter of Dr. Morland King of Lafayette College and Mrs. King, was married here this afternoon in the Colton Memorial Chapel to Henry Wheeler Felker of New York and Denver by the college chaplain, the Rev. Charles Harris.

Despite the rapidly growing requirements for petroleum products, the perfection of apparatus for deeper drilling and advances being made in petroleum geology and geophysical science virtually assure an adequate future supply of gasoline for the increasing number of automobiles, J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company, states in the annual report for 1936.

The place of the home in the community is to be the theme of the annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, to be held in Richmond, Va., May 3-7, Mrs. B. F. Langworthy, national president, has announced. Delegates representing a membership of nearly 2,000,000 in more than 25,000 associations are expected to attend the convention.
LONDON.--By order of the Earl Marshal regulations regarding the type of jewels to be worn by women at the coronation season court functions. have been changed and published.

IT was in the incongruous setting of an expensive London restaurant, one of those strongholds of capitalism where caviar and champagne add greatly to the logical force and persuasiveness of any argument, that the suggestion of spending six months on a Soviet collective farm and of writing "a funny book about it" was first made to Miss Delafield.

The fourth program in its series of evolutionary German and French films will be presented for the first time by the Museum of Modern Art Film Library at 8:30 o'clock tonight in the auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

Two years through which the National League of Women Voters have waged a tenacious and consistent drive against the "spoils system" in civil service are ending. As an appropriate punctuation to the period that has focused on the group and its strategy the attention of numerous other organizations, an almost unique assembly has been scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday in Chicago, at the Palmer House.

WANDERING through the sixth circle of Hell, beyond Phlegethon and below the City of Dis. Dante, guided by his companion Virgil noted a whole bitter landscape filled "even as at Aries, where stagnant grows the Rhone, Even as at Pola near to the Quarnero" with burning sepulchers, and asked the classic poet what they contained.

Charles B. Eliot, an official of the Works Progress Administration, was committed to jail today to await action of the Federal grand jury after pleading guilty to collecting an extra salary by payroll padding.

Fifteen out of thirty-seven divisions of local department stores had advertising increases during January, according to the "breakdown" issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc. Total linage of these stores for the month was 2,895,532, against 2,791,238 in the same month a year ago.

AUERBACH-Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Auer-bach announce the arrival of a son on Feb. 19, 1937. BELI-A son to Mr. and Mrs. John Bell on Feb. 14, 1937, at Park East Hospital. BERNSTEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Max ("Bunny") (nee Ruth Reckselt) announce arrival of David's sister, Feb. 13. French Hospital.

Miss June Bruce of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. B. Bruce of Syracuse, N. Y., has chosen April 1 as the date for her marriage to Robert Goddard Jr., son of Mrs. Robert Goddard and the late Mr. Goddard.
The visit next Monday of the German Foreign Minister, Baron von Neurath, will afford an opportunity for testing the strength of Chancellor Schuschnigg's position in Austria.
IT would seem almost axiomatic that the children of great men rarely succeed to greatness And Hartley Coleridge, eldest son of that strange genius who composed The Ancient Mariner."

Formation of a Nonpartisan Social Security Commission to appraise "sympathetically" the Federal Social Security Act and related State measures and to suggest amendments, revisions and modifications was announced yesterday by Merryle Stanley Rukeyser, financial commentator. The commission is sponsored by the Hearst newspapers.

A woman tentatively identified as Mrs. Caroline Lyons, 50 years old, of 410 West 110th Street, fell or jumped to her death about 9 o'clock last night from the Mount Eden Avenue station of the Jerome Avenue elevated, the Bronx.

Confronted with the stubbornest opposition he has encountered on any New Deal proposal since he entered the White House, but resolutely rejecting all proposals for a compromise, President Roosevelt last week threw his shock troops into the campaign to drive through Congress his plan to change the complexion of the Supreme Court by adding a justice for every present member past 70 who refuses to retire.

To the Music Editor: Judging by the applause which Mr. Chavez received after his debut with the. Philharmonic, I am glad to feel that I was one of many who were completely delighted with his conducting.

In financial security, government enterprise, and as potentially a great trade center, the Philippines were pictured yesterday by Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Commonwealth, as holding an enviable position among the worlds Com monwealths.
LIKE the heroine in the movie serials, the Theatre Guild has been saved again. Every time we do an unsuccessful play the wailing and the chastisement begin. The old howl goes up:

Harold T. Williamson, United States Consul in Bermuda, has sent out more than 600 invitations for a Washington's Birthday tea dance to be held at the Princess Hotel on Monday in honor of the officers of the new destroyer U. S. S. Reid, which arrives in Hamilton tomorrow.

The Student Council of City College has invited representatives of sixteen colleges and universities in the metropolitan area to a conference on March 6 to discuss organization, work, purposes and common problems of student government.

THE opening of the AngloEgyptian Sudan to colonization by Egyptian citizens under the recent Anglo-Egyptian-treaty has aroused widespread interest. As a result an increasing number of people are seeking information about the 3,000-mile journey up the Nile Valley to Central Africa, British East Africa and the Congo.

The marquess of Huntly, premier marquess of Scotland, called "the father of the House of Lords" and a friend of many eminent Victorians, died at his home, Orton Hall, Peterborough, today. He would have been 90 years old on March 5.
Party strife within the Popular Front, especially among Communists, now is the most serious menace to the Spanish Government's cause, neutral observers said today.

MR. MORELAND, a new poet from the Southwest, can turn, occasionally, a striking line. For the most part he is still a little too literary, but the scene of his own country and the. people who live there do, almost despite him, walk into his ballad-like, simple lyrics, and the time may come when this poet will write more authentically of what he knows.

Dr. Augustus Warren Crane, radiologist and roentgenologist, died suddenly today at his home here while dressing. He was 68 rears old. Dr. Crane was made an honorary member of the London Roentgen Society in 1899 in recognition of his work in radiology. He was president of the American Roentgen Ray Society in 1916.

Rutgers College announces a oneweek course in flower gardening to be held at the College Farm, New Brunswick, N. J., March 1-6. The only. requirement for enrollment is that the applicant shall be at least 16 years of age and be able to speak, read and write English. Students not residents of New Jersey must pay a fee of $3. Board and room near by will be available at $10 to $12.

Mrs. Rachel Crawford Beith Day, widow of the Rev. Warren Finney Day and mother of the Rev. Dr. William Horace Day, pastor of the United Congregational Church, died yesterday at her son's home here at the age of 94. Mrs. Day came to Bridgeport shortly after her son was appointed pastor of the United Church, which this week honored him on his twentieth anniversary here. She received her B. A.

Staging a one-man sit-down strike against sitdown strikers, Walter L. Fry, president, general manager and chief salesman for the Fry Products Company, declared his position tonight as "if they won't work I won't, and unless I work and sell, they won't have any work to do."

AT the heart of San Francisco's "Flowery Kingdom" a tile inlay in the corner side walk reads "Grant Avenue, formerly Dupont Street," which may or may not symbolize the new order of things in the largest, wealthiest, most influential bit of China outside of Old Cathay. Chinatown is divided against itself:

Miss Dorothy V. Masters heads a group of young women who will sell flowers and cigarettes at the performance of "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse" the night of March 4 at the Hudson Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for carrying on the hospital work of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

More than 44,000 new garments were distributed last year to nearly 200 local charitable institutions by the New York City branch of the Needlework Guild of America, according to the annual report of the Secretary, Miss Maude B. Mowry.
A crowd of several thousand, singing, weeping and cheering, greeted Crown Prince Michael, recovered from a serious illness, when he returned to Bucharest early today from Florence, Italy.

To reduce the large number of injuries among Sanitation Department employes, William F. Carey. Sanitation Commissioner, has directed his engineers to devise a mechanical means for loading the deapartment's collection trucks.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is trustee and registrar under an indenture providing for the issuance of $13,000,000 Mississippi River Fuel Corporation first mortgage pipe line 4 per cent bonds due in 1952.

Three firemen were crushed to death today by the collapse of a wall of a burning building. Five other firemen, trapped near an entrance, were dug out of the tangled mass of bricks and timbers and two more suffered injuries while working outside. None of the injured was seriously hurt.

MR. FORD has found a new way to continue his inexhaustible autobiography. He has invented a history and philosophy of travel into whose universal truths his own intricate and peculiar wanderings may precisely fit. Once again we have the delight of Mr. Ford's reminiscences, which is neverfailing;

The College of Mount St. Vincent women's basketball team defeated the Notre Dame College of Staten Island sextet, 16 to 14, on the court of the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium on the victors' Riverdale campus yesterday.

Many visitors from New York will attend a tea dance in the Roney Plaza palm garden tomorrow for the benefit of the Greater Miami Milk Fund for under-privileged children. The event will be a sequel to the annual Helen Lee Doherty Lace Ball given for the same charity tonight at the Miami Biltmore Country Club.

Two hundred and fifty Bennington College students will return from the college's annual two months' Winter field and reading period over the week-end. The college reopens officially on Thursday, when an evening community meeting will be devoted to accounts of work which have carried the students into widely varied fields of activity.
THE forgotten hero of history who gives this book its title is Haym Salomon, the Jewish banker who pledged his whole fortune to the new nation in its time of need.

From foreign lands and from the far corners of the United States theme will gather in Madison, N. J., on Saturday, May 29, a notable company numbering some three score. They will constitute the board of judges officiating at the eleventh annual all-breed dog-show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, which once more will be held at Giralda Farms, the country estate of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge.

The National Geographic Society and the United States Navy are planning to send a joint expedition to one of the tiny Phoenix Islands in the Pacific to take pictures of the total eclipse of the sun on June 8, Dr. Gilbert Grosvenor, president of the society, said today.

The complete pine paneling for a large Colonial room was sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries to Paul J. Baumgarten for $950. It was part of the collection of early American furniture and.decorations that realized $15,762.
Despite blood transfusions from several fellow-students, Gertrude W. Chapman, 20, of Plattsburg, N. Y., a Smith College senior, died today of pneumonia in the college infirmary.

Professor Edgar S. Furniss, dean of the Graduate School, has been appointed provost of Yale University to succeed Professor Charles Seymour, president-elect. His selection headed several administrative adjustments announced today by Dr. James Rowland Angell, president.

A new sort of "Alumni Homecoming," to bring together liberal, progressive and radical college graduates of the last forty years, is scheduled by the American Student Union for March 21 in New York City. A dinner at the American Woman's Association will be marked by a series of dramatizations of historic liberal events on the campus, ranging from a Vassar students' suffrage meeting in 1907 to a forecast of the student movements of the future.

NORTHEDRN visitors to the Winter playlands of Cuba, South America, Mexico and Florida tell of their glowing reaction to jai alai, a sport long followed by Spanish-Americans with an enthusiasm equal to that of the wildest Americai baseball fan.

Miss Helen Preston Ellis, whose engagement to Dr. Lewis Thorne was announced recently, will be among the brides of the late Spring. The prospective bride is the daughter of Mrs. Howard Baker of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Reuben M. Ellis of this city.

ST. JOHN ERVINE made his journey to Jerusalem in the most conventional fashion, and-as any one will guess with a completely unconventional mind. And the book, which records his conducted tour under the auspices of the Hellenic Club, is completely unconventional on two counts. First, Mr. Ervine says exactly what he thinks about everybody and everything,

A flood control conference arranged by the Council of State Governments voted today to seek President Roosevelt's support for an $85,000,000 dam project designed to check any future rampage of the Ohio River. Nine States were represented.

In announcing its opposition to the Child Labor Amendment, the Merchants' Association of New York characterized the measure in a statement yesterday as an unwarranted interference with State's rights for which no "overwhelming necessity" exists.
AMONG the Winter visitors to Arizona-and this Winter has been something of a banner season-are many garden enthusiasts finding keen delight in fashioning cactus gardens.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, in its campaign to raise $4,650,000 this year for relief and reconstruction work among European Jews, will seek the assistance of 3,000 Jewish benevolent "landsmannschaften" organizations in the United States and Canada, it was announced yesterday.
Syracuse snapped Pennsylvania's winning streak of five straight games by coming through tonight, 39--35, before 7,000 wildly cheering basketball fans at the Palestra.
Word was received yesterday that a new attempt to prevent a recurrence of the slaughter of striped bass in Toms River will be made tomorrow night in the New Jersey Legislature.

The Finnish naval training ship Suomen Joutsen will visit this city during the first week of March, it was announced yesterday by the Third Naval District Public Relations Bureau here. Formerly the Oldenburg, the Suomen Joutsen is a full-rigged ship of 2,275 gross tons.

The visit of the Soviet Chief of Staff, Marshal A. I. Yegoroff, to the Baltic States draws further attention to the present Soviet policy of trying to build up the Baltic States, Finland and Scandinavia, into an anti-war bloc. Theoretically, Marshal Yegoroff is only returning the courtesy visits to the U.S.S.R.

Foster M. Follett, artist and cartoonist, died in a hospital in Richmond, Va., yesterday, according to word received here today. Mr. Follett was in an automobile accident in South Hill, near Richmond, last Monday while on his way to Florida on a vacation, and died of a heart attack. His wife, Mrs. Nettie Bell Follett, who was injured in the accident, is still in the Richmond Hospital.

Asserting that the Child. Labor Amendment was "falsely labeled," Mrs. Edward B. Huling of Larchmonth, chairman of the National Defense Committee of the D. A. R. and eleven other organizations, formally opposed the passing of the amendment yesterday before the members of the Women's Democratic Forum of New York, in an address at the Hotel Astor.

Members of the Woman's Club of Montclair, N. J. on Friday adopted without discussion a resolution pledging themselves not to purchase groceries after 6 o'clock at night in order to aid the employes of the chain- and independent grocery stores. The resolution had previously been passed by the board of directors after introduction by Mrs. Frank R. Pentlarge, chairman of the civics department.

Orchestra conductors in general and "Jose Iturbi in particular" are temperamentally unsuited to judge woman's temperamental fitness for careers in music and sports, according to the girls of Elmira College. In addition,
Union Temple's basketball team overwhelmed the Fort Jay Hawks, 59 to 31, on the. victor's court in Brooklyn last night. It was the seventeenth victory in twenty starts this season for Union Temple.

A slight increase in exports of raw tobacco and tobacco manufactures from the United States was shown in 1936 over the previous year, the Department of Commerce reported today. Exports amounted to $156,526,025 in 1936, compared with $150,828,881 in 1935.

President Roosevelt has named a committee headed by Secretary Ickes to survey the space needs of governmental agencies at Washington, and prepare a long-range building program. Despite the expenditure of millions of dollars for new government buildings in the capital since the Coolidge administration, the current expansion in Federal activity has created a serious space problem.

Back in the familiar confines of its home gymnasium for the first time in two months, the C. C. N. Y. basketball team rolled up an easy 50-36 victory over the Franklin and Marshall five of Lancaster. Pa., last night.

NEW DEAL ENGINEER: The recent resignation of Morris L. Cooke as Rural Electrification Administrator resulted in a promotion to that position last week for John Michael Carmody, who had been Deputy Administrator.

West Point's Art and Hobby Show committee has announced that the third annual exhibition will be held in the new gymnasium during the week of March 13 to afford to the members of the garrison an opportunity to exhibit their many diversified, leisure-hour creations.

During the campaign last Fall Missouri Republicans made the bossismm", of Tom Pendergast, head of the Democratic machine in Kansas 'City, virtually the only State issue. Particularly outspoken were the Republicans against Lloyd C. Stark, Democratic candidate for Governor, whose endorsement by Mr. Pendergast had assured him the nomination.
SINCE his re-election President Roosevelt, in state papers and addresses both here and in South America, has spoken much of "making democracy work" rather than of recovery and reform.
A suit attacking the constitutionality of election of City Councilmen by proportional representation, as provided in the new charter, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday.

CREDO: "Most Americans believe that our form of government does not prohibit action on behalf of those who need help."--President Roosevelt. * * * ANALYSIS: "In labor disputes strikes are always a clash of two different rights. You fight for the privilege of talking about how you are going to go on after it is over."Senator Thomas.
SUN spots were to blame for the recent floods in the Midwest, according to a theory of Dr. Charles G. Abbot, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

Virginia State Bar Association, after an afternoon of debate, today passed a resolution expressing "unalterable opposition" to President Roosevelt's proposal for the United States Supreme Court. The vote was 230 to 51.
QUITE as notable, the present season has proved, for outof-town special museum events as for similar developments at home.

President Roosevelt called two Senatorial groups-one the administration stalwarts and the other representing the progressive point of viewto conferences at the White House late this afternoon to discuss his proposal for reorganization of the judiciary and expansion of the personnel of the Sunreme Court.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their Sources, the names of authors, de., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.
Dr. George Todd, 69 years old, a general practitioner, was found dead in the bathroom of his apartment at 110 West Ninety-fourth Street about 7:30 P. M. yesterday by his wife, Mrs. Mabel Todd.

Justice Ed Winn failed to appear in court today to answer an order to show why a permanent injunction should not be issued to restrain him from soliciting marriages in the Yuma court house. He said that he could not afford to contest the suit.

BUSINESS IN THE MIDDLE AGES. By Summerfield Baldwin. 12mo. New York: Henry Holt Co. $1. A volume in the Berkshire Studies in European History. THAT WAS A TIME. By Harriet Gift Castien. 12mo. New York: E. P. Dutton Co. $2.50.

The Montreal Maroons strengthened their hold on second place in the National Hockey League's International Group tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 to 1. The victory was the Maroons' sixth straight over the Hawks this season.

In student elections at Sweet Briar College Janice Wiley of Maplewood, N. J., has been elected president of student government for next year. She has been prominent in student activities, has been on the dean's list both semesters this year, and is reading for honors in English.

Movements of foreign exchanges yesterday again were mixed on limited transactions. The pound sterling reacted 3-16 cent to close at $4.893/8 while the franc advanced 1-16 cent to 4.65 9-16 cents. Guilders added another point and closed at 54.72, a gain of 27 points on the week.

President Roosevelt informed the Twenty-third Street Association, in a letter dated Feb. 10, that action on the application for allotment of funds by the PWA for construction of the proposed midtown Manhattan underpass depended upon Congressional approval of a continuation of the PWA program.

Eight exhausted, sun-blistered convicts tonight told the story of their sixteen-day ocean voyage in an Indian dugout after escaping from the French penal colony at Cayenne, French Guiana. They drifted ashore last night after sailing 750 miles by a roundabout route. Their tattered shirts,
William McElwee, 40, was killed and his wife. Dorothy, 23, was wounded today, and State police said a gaunt hunter and trapper admitted he shot them because "they injected poison in my big toe."
