The marriage of Miss Rosamond Blanchard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Blanchard of Boston and Nahant, to George S. Weld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Coffin Weld of Boston and Beverly Farms, took place at noon today in Trinity Church.

Midget Doyle of Jersey City, surviving two early knockdowns, came back to gain the decision over Frankie Terranova of Harlem in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Mecca Sports Arena last night. Doyle substituted for George Zengaras, who suffered an ankle injury.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated, Feb. 18: COMMANDER Bryant, C. F., Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corp., Quincy, Mass., to command the Charleston. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS
Amherst won a Little Three swimming meet from Wesleyan today, 61-16. The only home natator to triumph was Don Davis, who established new Wesleyan records

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 19 unless specified: At San Diego: Holland, Partridge, Utah. Feb. 20: Brant, Rail, Thrush. At Pearl Harbor: Breese, Gamble. Lark, I Montgomery, Quail, Ramsay, Tanager. At San Francisco: Indianapolis, Mtnneapolls, Northampton, Pensacola, Portland. Salt Lake Citv.

Mrs. William J. Baldwin Jr. is chairman of the benefit bridge of the Brooklyn Woman's Club to be held for the Red Cross Fund for Relief for Flood Victims on Thursday afternoon and night at the Brooklyn Woman's Club.

The directors of Ulen Co. have recommended to the holders of the company's securities adoption of an agreement worked out with a delegation from the Polish Ministry of Finance providing for the postponement, over a period of years, of the amount which the company expects to receive eventually on its holdings of $8,134,000 of National Economic Bank of I.oland 8 per cent bonds, and reduction of interest to 3 per cent annually.

LORD BADEN-POWELL, founder of the Boy Scouts and Chief Scout of the World, will be 80 years old tomorrow. The farflung ranks of the khaki-clad boys--now 2,592,832 strong in seventythree different. lands-will render him homage and send their greetings by cable, wireless and Post.

THE next important tournament to be held in New York is the Eastern, which begins at the Hotel Commodore on March 1. Although regional in scope, as its title indicates, the Eastern has always attracted players from all sections of the country.

Great Britain held out a gun in one hand last week and an olive branch in the other and, in effect, called upon Western Europe to choose. Both gestures came in the course of the House of Commons debate over the proposal to spend [pound]1,500,000,000 in the next five years for rearmament.

The executive and subcommittees for the fashion congress to be held for the benefit of the Reed Street Neighborhood House and Summer Camp for Children at the Bellevue-Stratford on April 21 and 22 are now meeting every Monday morning in the board rooms of Charlton Yarnall's offices.

EITHER because its history brims over with adaptable glamour or because there is some strange, sturdy effluvium in roast beef gravy a I'anglais that gets into the blood, the United British Kingdom has flourished as a sort of fulcrum for the movie literature of all nations.

A meeting to celebrate recent signs of business progress on Sixth Avenue and to plan for further improvements along that thoroughfare will be held on Wednesday at 4 P. M. under the auspices of the Sixth Avenue Association.

Because the European situation is tense, and a world war may yet embroil the nations in another conflict, the New York City schools are placing increasing emphasis upon a program of education for peace. Members of the Board of Education, Superintendent of Schools Harold G. Campbell and administrative officials in the school system are unanimous in their contention that students should be taught the ideals of peace.

The University of Toronto sextet defeated Queen's University, Kingston, 2-1, in the last local scheduled game of the International Intercollegiate League at Varsity Arena today. The game had no bearing on the league championship, which now rests between Harvard and McGill of Montreal. Two early goals by Sweeney gave Toronto a lead Queen's could not overcome.

Changes in the Tydings-Miller resale Price Maintenance Bill were seen as a possibility here yesterday, with the announcement that Congressman Celler, second ranking member of the House Judiciary Committee, will seek to have the measure limited to outlawing loss leaders, or split into two parts, one dealing with loss leaders- and- the other with its so-called "fair trade" features.

When the North American figure skating championships, a biennial contest between picked teams of American and Canadian skaters, take place in the Boston Arena next Friday and Saturday the United States will be lacking its champion in the men's singles division.
FARMERS of the American Southwest are turning to goat-raising in a region where millions of acres will support no other livestock or will support cattle and sheep most precariously.

Lawrence Lee will lecture and give a reading from his poems at Randolph-Macon Woman's College on Friday evening. Mr. Lee, a member of the faculty at the University of Virginia, comes under the sponsorship of the students' poetry clubs.

Men do not like to marry girls who "warm up and serve over to them in conversation" the remnants of their college courses in psychology, Dr. Eugene H. Lehman of the Highland Manor School for Girls here declared tonight.

Criminal tendencies in boys were traced to the influence of aggressive, masculine mothers and "submissive" fathers, in a paper read yesterday by Dr. Martha Wilson MacDonald of Michael Reese Hospital, Chicago, at the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman of the State Mortgage Commission, told the members of the management division of the New York Real Estate Board at their meeting last week that the chief task remaining for the commission is to rehabilitate the large number of poor mortgages in its control, many of which are on properties which are returning no payment at all.

Differing in outcome from the original trial of Carlyle Harris, medical student, originally held in 1893 in New York City, the re-enacement of the case this afternoon by the Thomas Swan Barristers Union of the Yale Law School resulted in a disagreement of the jury.

Past and present national champions and other leading figure skaters from the East combined to make a success of the fifth annual ice carnival tonight in Baker Rink. There were performances by members of the New York, Princeton, Philadelphia and Boston skating clubs.

This week witnessed activities by the Committee for Industrial Organination on three fronts--coal, automobiles and steel. In New York the United Mine Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, on behalf of 400,000 bituminous miners, met spokesmen for operators from eight States in the Appalachian area for the purpose of negotiating a basic agreement that would apply to virtually all the nation's coal operators and miners.

Two more victims were added today .to the crash of an army bomb ing plane near Front Royal, Va., on Jan. 28. Sergeant J. Edison Harvey of Hampton, Va., and Private John W. Anderson of Greenville, Pa., died at Walter'Reed Hospital.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Ellington Dallis of this city have announced the enengagement of their daughter, Miss Epsie Phelan Dallis, to Harry William Buice, also of Atlanta, youngest son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Young Cleveland Buice of Greensboro, N. C.

General liquidation developed today in wheat and other grains on the Board of Trade as the result of rain and snow in parts of the dry areas in the southwestern Winter Wheat Belt and, with stop-loss orders uncovered, prices declined rapidly, the close being at the lowest level of the day.

Next week the world will observe the 130th anniversary of the birth of the poet of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, a graduate of Bowdoin College in the class of 1825. While Longfellow's poems are well known few realize that hundreds of noted composers have set his verse to music. In the college library is a collection of this music, one of the few of its kind in existence.

The first performance of the Saturday evening series of the operas of Wagner's "Ring of the Nibelungs," given at special prices, took place last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, which had been sold out long in advance for the performance of "Das Rheingold."

Captain Albert C. Wescoat, owner of a tugboat fleet here for many years and long an active civic worker in maritime affairs, died today at his home of a heart ailment. He was 59 years old. He was a leader in many movements to preserve historical landmarks associated with the sea history of Atlantic City.

A method of putting ancestral portraiture on maps -to illustrate family lineage, and of relating genealogy to history and geography will be discussed by its originator, Mrs. George T. Tunnell of Yonkers, at a meeting of the Eastern. Federation of Delphian Chapters at the Hotel Barclay on Wednesday at 3 P. M.

The New York Water Color Club announced yesterday the selection of eight artists for active membership. They are Joseph Villani, Syd Browne, Francis William Martens and James Sanford Hulme of New York City; W. Russell Flint,

SELECTING Washington's Birthday as the appropriate date to introduce a new weekly series of broadcasts entitled, "Let Freedom Ring," the Office of Education will go on the air tomorrow at 10:30 P. M., with the opening presentation. These educational programs, dramatizing the historic struggles of Americans to win civil liberties, will be heard on Monday nights through WABC's hook-up.

Thumbnail sketches of personalities important in the history of Mount Holyoke College will be presented to the undergraduates throughout the semester as a part of the educational program sponsored by the Student Centennial Committee.

Hugh L. Willoughby of Philadelphia won the Everglades Invitation Golf Tournament today, defeating William B. Langford, veteran Chicago golfer, 1 up. In the consolation class Elmer Rich of Chicago vanquished C. L. Turner of New York, also by 1 up.

Wesleyan defeated Brown in basketball, 46 to 43, in an overtime game Bloom, tonight. The teams were 41-all at Juenge the end of the regulation time, but Black, Richards's field goal and Morning- Tots Star's foul throw broke the, deadlock at 43-all and game the game to Wesleyan. Brown led, 22-19, at half time.
Beatrice A. Roth, 20-year-old daughter of a former real estate operator, was shot and killed tonight as she sat in an automobile awaiting her escort.

In her letter of dedication to three friends, Dorothy Sayers cals this book a sentimental comedy, and that is a very apt description of the story of the honeymoon of Lord Peter Wimsey and his bride, Harriet Vane that was.

Alfred David Petersqn, a student at the University of Pennsylvania, died on Friday in the Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 22 years old and lived at 1 Plaza Street, Brooklyn. He was manager of the 1936 football team at the university and was an associate editor of The Daily Pennsylvanian.
By an emergency act of the Legislature, the first so far passed and approved by Governor Winship, prize fights may go fifteen instead of twelve rounds in Puerto Rico.

Paced by George Seewagen, who accounted for 19 points, the Seventh Regiment basketball team defeated the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A., 37 to 34, last night in an Eastern Amateur Athletic League game on the losers' court.

The second Teachers Institute on International Problems, sponscored by the Foreign Policy Association, will be held at the Hotel Astor on Saturday, it was announced yesterday. Several hundred high school and college instructors are expected to attend.
Dartmouth's basketball team coasted to a 51-37 victory over Cornell tonight in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.
Charles (Buddy) Rogers, orchestra leader and motion-picture actor sailed yesterday on the French liner Ile de France to work in an English film, "Radio Parade of 1937."

Wholesale trade in the United States took a 17 per cent spurt last year over 1935, the Department of Commerce reported today. The volume was $52,070,000,000, compared with $44,463,000,000 in the previous year. The figure for 1936 was the largest since 1930, but was under the peak established in 1929, when sales were $68,950,000,000. This upward trend started in 1934.

WITH the Metropolitan Opera season under way, philatelists are taking special interest in their operatic stamps. Just as a Wagner work opened this season's program, so also did his "Ring of the Nibelung" initiate the issue of operatic stamps.

If it were necessary to further demonstrate that the ebb and flow of security prices are controlled in large, measure by the complexion of the news from the nations capital, last week's performances of share and bond prices afforded additional proof. Early in the week, prices were adversely affected by the conferences in Washington on plans to arrest the influx of foreign funds.

Title to about 220,000 square feet of land with buildings of one and two stories containing 100,000 square feet of space at Seventyfourth Street and Grand Avenue, Maspeth, L. I., has been taken by the Finco Dye Works from the Klein Liquidating Corporation.

The government announced today that Nicaragua could not be used as an asylum for emigres who fomented revolutions in sister republics. President Anastasio Somoza ordered the National Guard to watch the frontiers to prevent mobilization of armed grounds.

The Rev. Brother Cantidius Thomas, F. S. C., former president of Manhattan College, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital, Brook Avenue and 142d Street, the Bronx, He would have celebrated his sixtyeigehth birthday next Friday.

Committee chairmen have been selected for the St. Patrick's Day party to be given by the St. Angela Hall Auxiliary at the Hotel Biltmore. Mrs. Francis A. Young is general chairman and Mrs. Franklin Dunham is co-chairman.

A survey of' mortgage conditions to study the source of home financing money and the type of institutions from which it should come in future years is about to be made under the auspices of the American Savings and Loan Institute. Judge Fred G. Stickel of- Newark, N. J., recently appointed chairman of the committee on trends of the United States Building and Loan League, will be in charge of the proposed survey.

MOSCOW.--The traveler in modern Russia, whether he likes it or not, is impressed above all things by a new vigor and integrity in the people. He passes from city to city, from landscape to landscape, with a gathering feeling that the revolution which began in 1917 is as yet only in its early stages.

Alfred Hanby Jones, for many years prominent in Republican politics in Illinois, died at his home here last night at the age of 86. He was the first State Food Commissioner of Illinois, being appointed by Governor Tanner in 1898 to organize that office.

The new Fine Arts Building at the College of William and Mary will be officially opened on Friday. More than a thousand persons have been invited, and elaborate plans for a week-end of events to celebrate the opening have been made under the supervision of Leslie Cheek Jr., head of the Fine Arts Department.

Communal farmers in San Pedro municipality "struck" today in protest because their candidates for municipal offices had been declared losers in recent elections. They insisted they would plow no more ground and sow no more seed until "justice" was done.

A campaign to maintain high standards in building and to eliminate poor construction, popularly known as "jerry" building throughout New Jersey, has been launched by the FHA office there headed by Thomas E. Colleton. While there is comparatively little poor construction in new home operations at the present time, Mr. Colleton declares that the aim of the FHA officials is to wipe it out entirely.

The skies are scanned so closely these days by so many astronomers, amateur and professional, that new comets are discovered with almost monotonous frequency. Explorers with telescope and camera bag them long before they are visible to the naked eye, and that is the way Dr. F. L. Whipple last week discovered in the heavens an unexpected bright spot-a small comet, tail and all.

The hosts of prohibition, once beaten and demoralized but again resurgent, will rally at St. Petersburg, Fla., eight days hence to plan their strategy for the next two years in their drive toward their ultimate goal of a dry nation. The occasion will be the biennial convention of the Anti-Saloon League of Amer- C ica.

IT was just three years ago-Feb. 23, 1934-that Leopold III was crowned King of the Belgians. His short reign has been a singularly eventful one. especially in the field of foreign affairs; for a speech by the King, and the recently adopted Defense Bill which resuited. marked the emergence of a new policy of neutrality to take the place of the Treaty of Locarno, destroyed by the German occupation of the Rhineland.

Without solving any of the eternal mysteries, delegates to the 107th semi-annual convention of the National Puzzlers League at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday devoted themselves not unsuccessfullyto a series of minor perplexities.

Practically 93 per cent of all mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration since the beginning of its program have been on single-family houses. A study of insured mortgages by the administration revealed that more than half, or 52 per cent, of. these, homes are valued at less than $5,000 and 33 per cent of the total are valued at less than $4,000.

Mounting interest in amateur photography has led students and faculty members at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to branch out from the technical field of classroom and laboratory to individual venturing with landscape and portrait.

WHAT is the job of a justice of the United States Supreme Court? How much work does a justice do? These questions are raised by President Roosevelt's message to Congress on reorganization of the judiciary, in which he pointed out that the Supreme Court "is laboring under a heavy burden" and last year declined to hear 87 per cent of the cases presented to by private litigants.

Rioting strikers, protesting drastic increases in food prices, smashed windows, disrupted utilities and beat dissenters in Guadalajara, dispatches reported today, after disturbances yesterday had gripped the city in a twenty-four-hour general strike.

Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, speaking on "Academic Freedom" at the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, has told the City College section of the Teachers Union that it was necessary to band together to resist "subversive pressure" on colleges.

These orders were issued at Headquarters, Northern New York Reserve Area, Syracuse, N. Y. Each of the following Corps of Engineers Reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to organization indicated. 21ST ENGINEERS (General Service) RAI. 2d Lieut. Donald E. Craig, Engr-Reg. 154 Sacondaga Road, Scotia, N. Y> 24 Lieut. peter F. Egan, Engr-Res, R. D., Elizaville N. Y.

Forty-one public and private educational institutions and thirteen social service agencies have notified the University of Pennsylvania that they will participate in all or part of the "cultural Olympics" this year.
Senator COPELAND has had printed in the Congressional Record the resolution voted at the annual meeting of the Empire State Potato Club in Syracuse.

The Boerse here was dull today, but the general tone was rather buoyant, although price changes stayed within narrow limits. Heavy industrials 'were mixed; Harpener lost 11/4 points. Automobile shares,
The Florida West Coast tennis title will go to California for the first time when Walter Senior and Wayne Sabin, both of Los Angeles, meet in the singles final tomorrow.

John Allyn Oakley, business manager of Architectural Record, a trade journal, for the past fifteen years, died of a heart ailment today at Pinehurst, N. C., where he had been recuperating from a heart attack suffered last October.

During the next five months Mills College, second oldest college for women in America and oldest west of the Mississippi River, will celebrate the eighty-fifth anniversary of--its founding. The School of Science will be in charge of the program for the month of March, while the various other schools of the college will plan the commemorative events for the other months.

Opposition to housing legislation that will "penalize owners without benefiting the low-income tenant" and a plea for consideration of special conditions in Brooklyn are voiced by Joseph H. Fink, secretary of the housing committee of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities.

Corlies Adams, 15 years old, a relative of James Truslow Adams, the historian, has been missing from the home of his stepfather and his mother, Mr. and Mrs. C. C. East, at 517 West 113th Street since Wednesday, the police revealed yesterday.

Dawn was approaching and, as Southern yachtsmen would say, the sun was fixing to rise when one of the longest meetings on record of the National Council of the American Power Boat Association came to its adjournment the other night at the Hotel Lexington. These speed boat moguls stand for a deal of punishment in the countless hours they devote during the offseason laying plans for the Summer.

Mrs. Seneca D. Eldredge will give a reception Thursday afternoon at her home, 106 East Seventy-eighth Street, for Mme. Povla Frijsh, who will be guest soloist at the concert the night of March 7 at the Town Hall for the joint benefit of the Composers Fund of the League of

Mr. and Mrs. L. Logan Lewis of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Huber Lewis, to Craig Hutchinson Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Morrow Smith, also of Plainfield. The announcement was made at a bridge tea given at the Lewis home this afternoon.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation is now engaged in returning to the thousands of home-owner applicants whose applications were rejected the various deeds, insurance policies, abstracts, surveys and other title documents delivered to the corporation.
The sloop Leith departed today with a Fiji Government wireless officer and complete radio plant for Christmas Island, 2,000 miles northeast of here in the North Pacific Ocean.

Major Gen. Sir Percy Zachariah Cox, one of the ablest administrators who ever served Great Britain in Near Eastern lands, died of a heart attack today while hunting with the Makley foxhounds at Melchbourne, Bedfordshire. He was 72 years old.

The Esquirol-McCall-Schwartz bill to establish a State labor relations commission in the State Department of Labor was approved yesterday by the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union. The commission would consist of three members appointed by the Governor,

Comparisons of current industrial production with the pre-depression period are becoming interesting. The country's steel production in each of the three past months was the largest on record for the month. October's output had been exceeded by no monthly achievement except in the periodMarch-August, 1929, and by October, 1928.

Mount Holyoke's oldest living alumna, Miss Emily Wilson, who was handed her diploma in 1861 on the same day that the Battle of Bull Run war being fought, has made a reservation for the first of the farewell series of tributes to Dr. Mary E. Woolley, retiring president.

For the past fifteen years the guiding principle of tile naval policy of the United States has been parity with Great Britain, both in total tonnage and in classifications. This policy was agreed upon with Britain at the Washington Naval Conference of 1921-22, was reaffirmed at the London Naval Conference of 1930

MIAMI BEACH, Fla.-More than one hundred sail and motor boats are expected to compete in the sixth annual Roney Plaza regatta scheduled for next Saturday. From the juvenile point of view this regatta so closely by the senior yachtsmen of the Winter colony.

John J. McNaboe, State Senator from Manhattan, has been the stanchest legislative foe of Red activities. Last year he sponsored a bill to compel the display of American flags, three feet by four, in all classrooms; it was defeated. As the session drew to its close he scurried through the Capitol's corridors and washrooms, searching for colleagues to push through his Red Inquiry Bill.

Arthur Souza-Costa, Minister of Finance, reiterated today his statement that the government will maintain a firm hand in controlling the coffee situation so that recent happenings in Santos will not be repeated.

A change in Japan's China policy under which a cultural and economic method of approach will be emphasized and a political solution postponed until better relations are established has been decided on by the present Cabinet, according to the newspaper Asahi.
Savage School's women's basketball team maintained its undefeated record by vanquishing the Harrisburg State Teachers College sextet, 10 to 8, today for its eighth straight triumph.
Vernon Rasmussen, 25 years old, of East Salt Lake, Utah, a George Washington University student, suffeared burns on his arms and legs tonight when he came in contact with a 13,000 volt power line.

LONDON will now have one type of television instead of two, as in the past, from the Alexandra Palace Station. The British Broadcasting Corporation, when it instituted daily telecasts last November, alternated in the teats with the Baird system and the Electrical Musical Industries system, which is similar to that being tested in New York.

Ernest Marshall, London correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIME for sixteen years, from 1908 to 1924, died early this morning in the German Hospital here of a heart attack following a severe bronchial illness from which he had been suffering for many months.

IN the early nineteenth century, at a blessed spot behind Nice called Notre Dame de Laghet, the Virgin performed a miracle. Floating like an apsara below him, she broke the fall of a peasant climbing a precipice.

A modernized version of the shogunate of medieval Japan is the objective toward which the "younger element" in the Japanese Army is driving with all its energy, as it carries on its campaign to wipe out the political parties and parliamentary government.

The high schools of America, for the most part, are handing out bookish pap to a generation that is vigorously demanding to know the facts of life. The youngsters are being taught science, literature and trades. But of an understanding of themselves and of their relationship to others they are getting little.

Charges attributed to Frederick L. Redefer, secretary of the Progressive Education Association, printed in New Orleans papers this afternoon, that Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, is forcing the retirement this year of Professor William Heard Kilpatrick, Professor of Education, aroused wide comment among educators arriving for the convention of- the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association.

In an effort to preserve the wild life of the country, especially species threatened with extinction, the National Association of Audubon Societies has embarked upon a broader range of activities than any hitherto undertaken by the organization.
Stocks closed irregular, steel and copper shares up 1 to 3 points; turnover, 1,484,730 shares. United States Government, corporate and foreign bonds mixed; transactions, $8,096,400.

Furniture, Chinese porcelains and carvings, Georgian silver and other appointments for interiors, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson' Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons. The sale will comprise property of the residuary legatees under the will of Jessie R. Doremus, together with property consigned by other owners.

The War Deartment released the following orders toay, dated Feb. 19: BRIGADIER GENERAL ?ratt, H. C., Langley Field, Va., to duty as commandant of the Air Corps Tactical School, Maxwell Field, Ala.; to proceed to Washington, D. C., and report to the adjutant general about March 10 for temporary duty in connection with air corps matters, thence to Maxwell Field about March 15.

Miss Florence Adelaide Burgess, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Y. Burgess of Englewood, N. J., was married to William Herbold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Herbold of New Brunswick, N. J., here yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

OATS and bicycles, dry flies and live ??awks, rods and guns, rabbits and pheasants, black bear and white porcupines, skis and squirrels, live fish and growing flowers, tents and trees--all under one roof in the National Sportsmen's Show at the.Grand Central Palace.

Several features of entertainment have been arranged in connection with the hockey match on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden between the New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs, which will be played as a benefit for the Community of St. Johnland.

Three steamship companies sent out vessels yesterday that had been held in port by the refusal of the United. States Shipping Commissioner to clear them as long as seamen balked at accepting-the disputed continuous discharge books.

Mrs. Benjamin Harrison, widow of the former President, and Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser, who will celebrate her 101st birthday in March, will be guests of honor at the annual Winter breakfast of L. I. F. E., to be held at noon, on Wednesday, at the Towers in Brooklyn.

PARIS--France will this year build in Paris a special government palace to lodge and receive visiting sovereigns and the other foreign guests of the State. Hitherto the government has had no official accommodations to offer to important foreign visitors with the exception, occasionally, of certain rooms in the Quai d'Orsay residence of the Foreign Minister.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to recommend to the Senate the adoption of the Pittman resolution amending and extending the existing Neutrality Law into a permanent statute. Senator Hiram W. Johnson of California was the only member to vote against the proposal, but Senator William E. Borah of Idaho, who is understood to oppose it, did not attend the meeting and was not recorded.

The quill pen used by President Woodrow Wilson to sign the measure which put the United States into the World War brought $30 at an auction of books and other effects of the late Henry T. Rainey, former Speaker of the House of Representatives.

The marriage of Miss Emily Burchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Henry Burchell of this city, to Alexander Leslie Black, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Leslie Black of New Orleans, took place yesterday noon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, rector, performed the ceremony.

Rosemont, the Foxcatcher Farm's great 5-year-old, conquered a brilliant field of candidates for next Saturday's $100,000 classic before a crowd of 40,000 in the San Antonio Handicap at Santa Anita today.

After apparently losing the game in the first period, which ended with them on the short end of a 7 to 1 score, Squadron A's riders came from behind to hand the First Division its first defeat this season, at 151/2 to 7, last night in the victors' armory.

Patriotic, social and religious organizations throughout the city will pay tribute today and tomorrow to the 205th anmversary of the birth of George Washington. Transportation services to and from the city continued to be taxed to capacity yesterday as thousands of New Yorkers and out-of-town visitors, taking advantage of the three-day holiday, entered or left the city for the week-end.

To the Drama Bditor: May I be allowed, in the interests of a certain sizable section of theatregoers, to raise a mild protest against a very general affectation on the part of critics-that of ridiculing certain perfectly legitimate types of production as being unworthy of their serious consideration? As a case in point,

If any one doubts the Bolshevik hold on the Russian people -the mourning for Gregory Ordjonikidze should be an object lesson. In the Russian mind there are four outstanding leaders who have made their country great.

Miss Alice Mary Eckman, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Whiley Eckman of 10 Greenway Terrace, Forest Hills Gardens, L. I., and the late Mr. Eckman, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Dean Mason of Chicago, formerly of this city. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David G. Latshaw in the Church in the Gardens, Forest Hills.

Charles A. Jones, general manager, disclosed today that the Home Owners Loan Corporation has ordered a broad new policy which will result in a drastic scaling down of $4,059,821 in deficiency judgments and claims now held against debtors.

THOMAS ATTERBURY M'GINLEY, Pittsburgh industrialist and president of a large manufacturing concern, will be at the console of his $100,000 organ when a series of recitals originating from the music room of his home in Sewickly Heights, Pittsburgh suburb, are inaugurated Feb. 26.
Snow blanketed the high plains of the Southwest today, ending the week's scourge of dust storms and buoying the spirits of wheat farmers.

One of the "slowest" legislative sessions on record has now run almost half of its allotted course without a serious partisan clash on the floor of the Senate, where the Democrats have an ample majority, or the Assembly, where the Republicans have at least nominal control, to indicate that there is an opposition party in the Legislature this year.
This statement on the President's proposal for reorganization of the judiciary by Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, appears in the Chamber's Washington Review:
The engagement of Miss Kathleen Barry Quinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Quinn of this place, to Louis A. Fleck of Brooklyn, N. Y., son of the late Dr. Louis A. Fleck, has been announced.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lynn Closser Chamberlin of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Jewitt Chamberlain, to Brewster Huntington Gere, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Gere of Syracause, N. Y.
THE new Imperial Airways flying-boat Cavalier, which is to open the New York-Bermuds air service this Spring, embodies many major improvements and modifications in British flying-boat construction.

An investor purchased yesterday from Norman-Lila Estates, Inc., operators, the four-end-a-half-story apartment house at 274 East 172d Street, southeast corner of Morris Avenue, in the West Bronx. The buildingg accommodates twenty families and is on a plot 47 by 95 feet.

The resignation of Samuel Becker as special counsel for the Federal Communications Commission in its investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was accepted today by President Roosevelt.

Thomas G. Grace, State Direc-. tor of the Federal Housing Administration, announced yesterday that the Metropolitan Title Guaranty Company was taking over from Realty Associates, Inc., 100 mortgages representing a value of $750,000 under a contract making the FHA insurance obligatory in each case. The latter is processing the properties and expects to complete the work in about ten days.

Hand grenades, thrown at the conclusion of a distribution of gifts to the poor in Addis Ababa, East Africa, yesterday, wounded Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, the Viceroy; the Abuna Kyrillos, head of the Coptic Christian Church; General Aurelio Liotta, head of the aviation force in East Africa, and several natives.

BY way of a gesture to the Father of His Country, an alert delegate attending the National Puzzlers League Convention at the Hotel New Yorker looked at the phrase "Washington Crossing the Delaware" and quickly turned out a couple of perfeet anagrams: "He saw his ragged Continentals row" and "A wet crew gain Hessian stronghold."
An American farmer, Melvin J. Dunn, father of four children, tonight claimed the distinction of paying tax bills to more taxing bodies than any other citizen of the United States.

Mrs. Frances X. Reilly, daughter of Connie Mack, manager of the Athletics, was seriously injured in an accident tonight when her automobile skidded and crashed into another car. Miss Marie Dever and Miss Catherine Smith were also injured in the crash.

Notre Dame squared all accounts in the defeat column for the basketball season by defeating Pittsburgh, 29-18, before 5,500 fans tonight. Pitt was the only team to hold an edge on the Ramblers in this campaign.

NOBODY ever suspected that George Abbott was a music molder, something for which he never received proper credit-not even from the musicians' local. It now comes out that he has been molding music for years, giving it a loving embrace and a kindly thought, blending strange tunes among strange instrumentation in such places as an upper box, behind scenery and occasionally in the orchestra pit.

The long and in many quarters very anxiously awaited announcement of the Department of Agriculture concerning possible changes in the status of existing plant quarantines as applied to flower bulbs, was made this week.

Mr. and Mrs. James J. Lister of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred E. Lister, to W. Selden Steiger of 61 Park Av., New York, and Montclair, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Steiger of Montclair.

Somers Harrison Ingersoll, for fourteen years principal of Public School 77 of Jersey City, died today at his home here of a heart ailment at the age of 59. He had been stricken on Wednesday. Mr. Ingersoll had been a teacher for forty-three years, having begun his career at the age of 16 as a tutor in a small country school.

Robert Bruce McEwan, president of the R. B. McEwan Son paper mill at Whippany, died yesterday at his home here. Mr. McEwan had been an invalid for five years. Born in Windsor Locks, Conn., Mr. McEwan established the paper mill business in Whippany with seven brothers more than a half a century ago.
Four-year-old Jean Oxford, participating in a pageant at Albert Hall today, was informed that Queen Mary had arrived.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Josephine Alden Gibbs, daughter of Arthur S. Gibbs of Upper Montclair and the late Mrs. Gibbs, to Joseph John Du Bois of West Orange, son of Mrs. Hattie Du Bois of South Orange.

Designed to bridge the gap between the standards and techniques of high school and college academic life, an orientation course forfreshmen is being initiated this term as part of the new curriculum at Hunter College, it was announced yesterday by Professor Marie K. Gallagher, chairman of the Bureau of Educational Guidance at the college.

Elaborate preparations have been made for the Yale Junior promenade, the outstanding. social event of the year for undergraduates, to be held Frliday in Woolsey Hall. The fraternity houses are planning parties for Friday and also Saturday night.
EXHIBITIONS of work by women artists made up nearly half of the roster of new shows last week. Some of them are already widely known to gallery goers; others are newcomers to the local field.

HOLLIAND is to have national opera, if the plans which have been carried on for some time materialize. At a recent meeting in Rotterdam held for the purpose of discussing the founding of the opera it was decided to employ only Dutch singers and musicians.

From the high crescendo of the last few days, the most intense and portentous in its brief history, offices of the Joint Committee for Ratification of the Child Labor Amendment spiraled down last night to silence and emptiness. The boiler factory atmosphere had vanished, the buzzing telephones were stilled. But the executives beamed their gratification and their anticipation of the morrow.

Stark Young, Martha Ostenso ana Hendrik van Loon will be among the honor guests at the annual authors' luncheon to be given tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria by the Southern Women's National Democratic Organization.

AS the Civilian Conservation Corps marches toward its fourth birthday next month it bids fair to achieve a secure place as a training school for American youth and a peacetime force for the husbandry of national resources Director Robert Fechner,

Problems surrounding school peace education will be considered by the Public Education Association at its luncheon to be held at the Hotel Commodore next Saturday. Dr. Frank Aydelotte, president of Swarthmore College and a trustee of the World Peace Foundation, will deliver the principal address on "The School Child and His Education for Peace."

While President Roosevelt's suggestions for judicial reform have undoubtedly overshadowed all other legislative topics in interest here, Congressional attention has tended to return this week to the topic of neutrality legislation and the longrange implications it may have for this country's foreign relations.

Three local authors will be guests of Contemporary of Newark at a tea to be given by the fine arts department on Tuesday. One of the authors, Agnes Sligh Turnbull, who wrote "The Rolling Years," will hear her book reviewed and see it Illustrated in tableaux by members of the art division.

Leonard Hartman, defending champion and top-seeded player, was forced to come from behind to gain the final round of the annual Brooklyn indoor tennis singles championship at the 106th Regi ment Armory yesterday. Frank Bowden, second seeded, was the other contestant to qualify for the title round.

Samuel Rosoff has built several fortunes out of transactions involving subways, beer, sand, gravel, garbage, race horses, buses, railroads and ships. He is a stout, hearty man in his fifties and can be easily heard when he is in an expansive mood.

The new $139,000 museum building in Morristown National Historical Park, a vital unit of the reservation, will be dedicated Monday, Washington's Birthday, by the National Park Service at the annual meeting of the Washington Association of New Jersey.
Harvard captured its twentieth consecutive hockey game today when it sent the University of Montreal down to a 3-1 defeat in a furious International Intercollegiate League contest.

The Adrienne Cosmetics group of packages used by the United Drug Company, and designed by Gustave Jensen, took first honors in the 1936-37 Irwin D. Wolf Awards Competition for distinctive merit in packaging, it was announced yesterday by the American Management Association, sponsor of the competition.

IN Mexico. where glorious mountains, bright skies, flaming flowers and soft air lull many men into quiet contemplation, Leon Trotsky, revolutionary and former Soviet leader, works tirelessly, endlessly. writing, dictating, issuing statements.

The marriage of Miss Marie Louise Hanson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Francis Hanson of 480 Park Avenue and Duluth, Minn. to Robert Forster Wilson of Washington took place yesterday afternoon at the New York home of her parents.
Following a fire which destroyed the $75,000 government hospital here more than 2,000 Eskimos and whites along the northern Alaska coast were without adequate medical and surgical supplies today.
The University of Rochester basketball team ran into the Colgate tornado tonight and lost by 34 to 17. The invaders outclassed the home forces all the way.

Fred Coburn, 8 years old, was found dead in an attic closet tonight shot through the head with a highpowered rifle. The police, believing that the boy was shot in a game of "cowboy and Indians," 'said: that they were looking for one of his playmates in whose home the body was found by the other lad's father.

Vividly underlining its pronouncement that women have not gone as high in official life of their respective nations as their potentialities permit, the International Federation of Business and Professional Women is prepared to thrust its highest ranking executives into the limelight in twenty-four countries.

Government planes flew to Mount Aconcagua, the highest American peak, today to search for explorers who have been missing since a recent attempt to climb the mountain, on the border between Chile and Argentina.
The Lawrenceville School hockey team battled to a 1-1 tie with the Nichols School sextet today in Baker Rink, a five-minute overtime period failing to break the deadlock.

You should get a haircut only when the moon is growing. That is the conclusion of a Viennese writer, who cites clinical evidence to support it. The reason given is that periodic rhythms govern certain bodily functions, and that hair grows best when the moon is growing.

The immediate extension of the Mexican Government's activities in the rich sphere of petroleum production and the gradual elimination of all foreign oil companies is provided for in the official draft of a law which would create an entirely government-owned petroleum company.

Denying all the charges against them, Thomas Gentles, 28 years old, a suspended patrolman, of 409 East Thirty-fourth Street; John Levy, 25, who gave a hotel address, and Maurice Rue, 25, of 249 East Thirty-third Street, appeared in the line-up at police headquarters

Salt water fishing is receiving a bigger play at the National Sportsmen's Show this year than last. More exhibits, more tackle displays and a greater representation of clubs exclusively interested in ocean angling testify to the unusual development of the sport on the Atlantic seaboard.

A large home development on the North Shore of Long Island is about to be started by the Parmoor Corporation, which has just purchased for improvement the thirty-three-acre estate in Huntington of the late Henry W. Cannon, a former president of the Chase National Bank.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark.-Racing will hold the spotlight of the sports program here for the Spring season, with the opening of Oaklawn Jockey Club on March 1, for a thirty-day meet. With stable space all taken and larger purses, the Oaklawn event promises to surpass all former attendance records, horsemen predict.

Congressmen now burning the mid night oil studying New D?? problems may be able to stu?? in physical comfort at least, it is hoped that by the time months come around the newly air conditioned offices in which they labor will be just another taken for-granted part of the backgro?? against which national politics staged.

Miss Phoebe Knapp, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Knapp, chairman of the committee for the midwinter junior riding competition of next Saturday at the Round Hill Stables here, has completed arrangements for fifteen classes.

The International ban on foreign volunteers for service on either side in the Spanish conflict came into force at midnight. The ban is complete, including even Portugal, which has gone further than the other powers by ordering her nationals already in Spain to return within a month.

The Rutgers swimming team snapped the four-straight New York University winning streak today, triumphing by 48 to 21. Fritz Faulkner, Scarlet diving ace, scored 110.54 in his specialty to win easily, while Junius Calitri of the Violet won the 100-yard free style in 55.7. Rutgers won six of the eight events.
ONE of the headliners on the Spring list of G. P. Putnam's Sons will be "Desert Encounter," by Knud Holmboe, a young Dane who turned Moslem and lived among the Arabs.
If old man Winter thinks he is going to stop the Eastern ski championship races at Gilford and Laconia, N. H., next week-end, he may have to do more than keep snow from falling.

A united Christian world can alone "stem the tide of materialism, of self "ishness, of shaken traditions, of "crumbling moral standards."This is a voice not from the pulpit but from the pew, and from one whose name is known in all lands--one who in a sense has gained the whole world but whose highest concern is the saving of the souls of men. And his hope is that

The engagement of Miss Florence T. Sisson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Sisson of this place, to George F. Richards, son of Mrs. F. St. John Richards, also of Cranford, and the late Mr. Richards, has been announced by her parents.
Dr. Henry Martyn Chance, mining engineer and geologist, died at' his home in West Philadelphia yesterday. His age was 81. He had been active as a consulting engineer.

The city's new traffic code, in its entirety, goes into effect today. The provisions that became operative last Dec. 22 are supplemented now by a long list of regulations, including the much-advertised ban on a right or a left turn against a red light. They include also the severe penalties against "dangerous driving" as defined in the new ordinance.

EXERCISING an understandable caution in dealing with famous names, but treating the period with an eye to fact rather than to fiction, RKO-Radio is entering its third month of production of Edward Arnold's starring vehicle, "The Toast of New York," adapted from Bouck White's "The Book of Daniel Drew" and from Matthew Josephson's "Robber Barons."
Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Minigter, has arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington. Mrs. W. Schuyler Beekman of 1,060 Park Avenue sailed yesterday for Nassau.

Miss Victoria Smith of Baltimore, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. A. R. C. Smith, was married here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration to Howard A. Stone, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Stone of Le Grange, Ill., by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray. Miss Ruth Smith was her sister's maid of honor and James Croft was the best man.

With nearly $1,000,000 in private building work carried out here during the past year, requests totaling nearly half that sum probably will be made for the erection of municipal projects alone in the near future.

Executive approval of the Wagner Act was invoked yesterday by E. J. Lever, field director of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee of John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization, as justifying ,the use of the President's authority in its recruiting drive in the Trenton, N. J., area.

Savage's basketball team turned back the Princeton Theological Seminary, 49 to 32, on the victor's court yesterday. John Gaynor, with 12 points, led Savage to its seventh triumph in ten starts this season. At the half Savage was in front, 24 to 12.

To the hundreds of thousands who have lost their all along the Ohio and who must wait until Spring before water, sewerage and gas systems are restored in their home towns it will be small comfort to learn that the worst is over. In the Mississippi the flood has not fully run its course.

Mrs. Louise Powis Clark, widow of Horace Clark and daughter of Mrs. Walter Van Rensselaer Powis, was married to Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company and internationally known financier, this afternoon in Trinity Parish Episcopal Church, Old St. Augustine Square, this place.

A report s on a survey of the steel industry, made in a "big business" setting recently, has been hailed by John L. Lewis's Committee on Industrial Organization as being manna from heaven for its steel worker organization campaign.

Vivienne Butler gave her annual dance recital at the Town Hall last night, presenting among her ten. numbers four items which had not been seen before. These were"Metronome" (Beethoven), "Water Lily" (MacDowell), "Pi Ouit" (Har old) and "Shawl" (Lara).

Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's defense of Great Britain's armament program is accepted here as a logical declaration as far as it seeks to strews the requirements of national security. But its implications regarding Britain's obligations under colelective security appear less convincing.

Eighteen years ago a malaria epidemic raged in Palestine. Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis, there on a visit, gazed about him at the victims, and soon after the dull thunder of guns had ceased to reverberate in Europe signed a check that established the first research stations, under the direction of Hadassah.

WORKS of Johann Sebastian Bach and his sons, Philipp Emanuel, Johann Christian and Wilhelm Friedemann, will be offered at the final concert of the season of the Philharmonic - Symphony Chamber Orchestra at Town Hall, Monday night, March 1.

Stirring English football cup contests saw six teams pass into the sixth round of the competition today, while four others will replay drawn games next week. The matches attracted crowds aggregating 352,000.

WALT KUHN (whose first oneman show in three years opened last Tuesday at the Marie Harriman, to continue for four Weeks) seems to feel that he has worked out in painting some sort of analogy with modern music.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Edith Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Williams of this place, to Henry Horace Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Henry Davis of East Orange.

The Studio Arts Club of Skidmore College gave its an nual Beaux Arts Ball in the Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs last night. Since the plan for having an Oriental ball had been dropped and a Mardi Gras theme adopted instead, the students who attended wore all types of colorful costumes.
Temple made a second-half rally to defeat Penn State, 28-26, tonight and keep second place in the Eastern Basketball Conference. More than 6,500 witnessed the contest.
MALVINE BREE, who died in Vienna on Feb. 3 at the age of 86, is perhaps best known to Americans by her book "Die Grundlage der Methode Leschetizky" ("The Groundwork of the Leschetizky Method").

When Middlebury College students return from Spring vacation, the new astronomical observatory on College Hall will be ready for use. The building will have a revolving dome designed by A. R. Ibarguen of West Farmington, Me., a Guatamalan amateur astronomer, and will house a ten-foot telescope with a 121/2-inch lens given to the college by Professor John F. Haller of the Chemistry Department.

After an investigation of more than ten months, the Pennsylvania Museum of Art has assembled the extant works of William Rush, known as the first successful American sculptor, and will place them on exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum on the Parkway beginning March 6.

The series of garden lectures which have been conducted this month by the Junior League of New York, with the cooperation of Country Life and The American Home, will be concluded on Tuesday morning at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, with a talk by Mrs. Helen Page Wodeli of Short Hills, N. J., on "Flower A rangements for Modern Homes."

When the Cunard White Star liner Carinthia sailed at 3 P. M. yesterday -for Nassau, in the Banramas, she had an old anchor coverea with barnacles and coral on the forward deck. It was brought to the surface last Weednesaay morning in the harbor of Nassau.

Miss Anne Page defeated her fellow-Philadelphian, Miss Cecile nei Bowes, 15-13, 15-13, 15-4, to re- still tain her national squash racquets eig championship at the Junior League car yesterday. But there was more the significance to the repeat victory shi than even that concise score and me the half-hour of playing indicate.

Operations at a plant of the Continental Tin Company here were suspended today when about 600 employes left their posts. Algernon L. Smith, president, said that the plant was closed because of differences over a contract. and that "some of the men did not want to strike."

So far as the President is concerned, at the end of a week in which his friends in Congress who object to packing the Supreme Court strove to find a compromise acceptable to Mr. Roosevelt, he has been offered no substitute that meets his requirements. That is a simple statement of the fact--unchanged by the deluge of letters and telegrams, unaffected by millions of words uttered in Congress, on the air and in the newspapers.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Local hotel and business men see the near-capacity Washington's Birthday week-end crowd as heralding a fine Spring season for this resort. Also, the fact that Palm Sunday and Easter

Philip W. Kniskern, president of the First Mortgage Company of Philadelphia, warns builders to study their price field very carefully before undertaking large operations. Too much construction activity with the idea of relieving the shortage of medium-priced homes without a careful survey of market conditions, he says, will probably be detrimental both to the builders and to financial interests.

ENGLANDER-ROSENTHATL Mr. and Mrs. Max Rosenthal announce the marriage of their daughter. Miriam, to Henry Englander, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Englander, Feb. 19. GILBERT-ALEXANDER-Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Alexander of 515 West End Av. announce the marriage of their daughter, Louise M., to Mr. Gustave Gilbert of Los Angeles, Calif., on Friday, Feb. 19, 1937.

Preparations are under way for a new Students Building at Elmira College. A spacious sixteen-room house at one corner of the campus, formerly used for dormitory purposes, is being remodeled, and will be redecorated and refurnished under the supervision of the senior class.

There were 1,260 athletes competing in the Manual Training interscholastic track meet yesterday, but the 3,000 spectators came away with one name burned into their memory. Only 16 years old, Leslie MacMitchell stole the spotlight at the games in the Fourteenth Regiment Armory, and followers of running are likely to hear much more of him in the seasons ahead.
Thirty gunners opened a three day carnival at the Travers ?? traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. In the ?? shoot at 100 targets, the best work was done by A. Mullhaupt, whe had 98.

Mrs. Matilda Boudinot Edwards Vezin of Elizabeth, N. J., was married at noon today to Lawrence Warburton White of Milton in the First Parish Church in Chestnut Hill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Abbot Peterson of Brookline.

Plans for the 1937 North American Homes Exposition, to be held in Madison Square Garden with the cooperation of the Federal Housing Administration, builders, developers and building material manufacturers, were announced yesterday by L. Porter Moore and Captain R. L. Purdon, co-directors of the show.
President Roosevelt today signed a bill extending the guarantee by the government of the debentures of the Federal Housing Administration for two years, or until July 1, 1939.
Thirty-three employers in the wholesale dry goods field have declared a "strike" against their employes in defense of the employers' right to collective bargaining.

The Department of Hospitals needs greater control over its own funds to meet the increased demand for service which confronts it, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, told members of the Trade Union Institute of the Rand School yesterday at a meeting of that organization at 7 East Fifteenth Street.

The main task of the French Government today is, to sheck the rising prices of foodstuffs and manufactured goods, according to Charles Spinasse, French Minister of Economics. In an exclusive interview, he stressed that the French Cabinet had assigned first place to this article on its program.

JOINT RESOLUTION. Providing for the prohibition of the export of arms, ammunition, and implements of war to belligerent countries; the prohibition of the transportation of arms, ammunition, and implements of war by vessels of the United States for the use of belligerent States;
Mr. and Mrs. Merrill Anderson of this city have announced the engagement of Mr. Anderson's sister, Miss Helen Anderson of 229 East Seventy-ninth Street, to W. Gordon Dean of Sanford. Fla.

A dinner dance this evening opened the festivities being held at the Westchester Country Club here in celebration of Washington's Birthday. Tomorrow there will be trapshooting, a tea dance and benefit supper and dancing. On Monday the clubhouse will be the scene of another dinner dance.

Those who take pleasure in wild gardens have noted with sympathetic interest the clause in the recently published will of the late Elihu Root leaving a trust fund of $100,000, the income of which is to be used for the maintenance of his wild garden.

Police arrested thirty-four self-described relief roll "sit-down strikers" when they refused to leave City Hall today. The strikers had occupied the corridor-outside of the Emergency Relief- Bureau, on the twenty-fifth floor of the City Hall, since yesterday.

Miss Frances Louise Story, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford M. Story of this place, was married here tonight in the Second Reformed Church to Frederick Hadden Howell, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hadden Howell also of Hackensack, by the pastor, the Rev. John Charles Rauscher.

GRACE MOON writes of things that she has seen and known. and so to the children who read her books the Southwest, with its wide spaces, its smell of sage brush, its tang of mesquite smoke from the camp fires, its deep blueness of sky behind the buttes and hills becomes real and familiar.

The Marquis Players, Lafayette College's dramatic organization, is rehearsing "Men in White," Sidney Kingsley's Pulitzer Prize play, which will be given in the Little Theatre on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

Despite seasonal declines in business activity, placements of workers in private jobs during January were 131.1 per cent above a year ago, the United States Employment Service reported today. The number of placements was 142,981.

Four contests in the Eastern Intercollegate Debating League and four non-league debates comprise the Bates College schedule for the remainder of February and for March as announced today by Professor Brooks Quimby, debating coach.

Mrs. Warren Smith, daughter of the late Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage, pastor of the Brooklyn-Tabernacle for many years, died on Friday at her home, 50 East Fiftyeighth Street. She was a former resident of Brooklyn and East Harmptonn L. I.
Hopes of New York Americans entering the National Hockey League play-offs received a rude jolt tonight as they took a 4-3 beating from the Toronto Maple Leafs.
A FIRST FOLIO of Shake speare is not a scarce book any more, as the number of known copies must have mounted to something over two hundred.

Slender Henry Picard of Hershey, Pa., one of the game's consistent money winners of recent years, cracked par again today with a 71 to break a three-way opening-round deadlock and assume command of the $3,000 Thomasville open golf tournament with a thirty-six-hole tntal of 140.

The number of employable men and women receiving home relief in this city was put at 120,260 yes-terday by Leo Arnstein, chairman of the Mayor's committee on reemployment, which is seeking to cut the relief rolls through placements in private industry.

LAKE PLACID.-A five - inch snowfall early in this week transformed this Winter sports center into a glistening white fairyland. It has encouraged the community to proceed with extensive sports plans for this three-day Washington's Birthday week-end.

Certain classes of corporations are not subject to the income tax because they are exempted by law. Business corporations are not exempt, although they are not required to pay an income tax unless they have derived taxable income.

Seven persons, aboard a missing airliner, are believed to have died. One was an American. It was feared the plane, carryngfive passengers and two pilots, was lost at sea- in a flight along the southern Pacific coastline of Australia between- here and Brisbane, 475 miles north.

The annual "bickering" period for the election of sophomores to the upperclass eating clubs at Princeton University is under way, with formal calling between 9 and 11. During the formal calling upperclass representatives of the eating clubs visit sophomores in their dormitory rooms.

TO the antique collector's satisfaction, the figurines of pottery, porcelain and glass which he has been bent on acquiring have now come back as decorations. It is quite the thing to have little objects, modern-made as well as antique, to adorn one's mantel. table top or desk. Birds. animals-even our barnyard friends-are in the lead as favorites.

Young women in the gay native costumes of various European countries will preside at colorful booths for the display of beverages and foods indigenous to the respective nations at the "Taste Tour of Europe" in connection with the annual Madison House Ball on March 20 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

The end of the semi-annual period of independent study at Wells College has emphasized once more to the student body how much the program of the entire college depends upon the organization and contents of the Frances Folsom Cleveland Library, which was given in 1910 by Andrew Carnegie, and named in honor of Mrs. Cleveland.

Team racing between the Class B one-design and Class X sailing dinghies was held today for the first time as the three-day holiday regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club opened. The B boats defeated the X's two contests to one.

Three thousand' persons are expected to attend a testimonial dinner Thursday evening at the Hotel Astor to Charles Poletti, counsel to Governor Lehman, arranged by the New York Young Democratic Club. The. Governor and Frank C.

At a recent meeting of the board of managers of the Orphan Asylum Society of the city of Brooklyn, Kingston and Atlantic Avenues, plans were discussed for a bridge to be held under the joint auspices of the Junior Auxiliary and the welfare committee on April 8 at the home. Mrs. Waldo McCutcheon McKee was appointed chairman of publicity.
A crew of twenty-two, their schooner safe in the haven of Lunenburg Harbor, rested today after a battle of more than forty-eight hours with wind and sea ninety miles .off the Nova Scotia coast.

A story of how high labor officials adopted a hands-off policy when informed that gangsters from "the Dutchman's mob" were trying to take over Local 302 of the Cafeteria Workers Union was told at the restaurant racket trial yesterday by Irving Epstein, a defendant, who said he had been threatened with the loss of his ears.

NOW YOU'VE DONE IT-Thursday evening at Henry Miller's Theatre. The week's solitary Broadway opening is a comedy about a political campaign, the author being Mary Coyle Chase. In it are John Alexander, Evelyn Varden, Margaret Perry, Barbara Robbins, Ruth Gates and Mary Howes.

Dr. William Lyon Phelps, Professor of English Literature at Yale University, will deliver the annual Stone Foundation lectures at the Princeton Theological Seminary this week. The general theme of the lectures will be "The Christian Religion as Expressed in English Literature," and will be given in Miller Chapel on the seminary campus each afternoon at 5 o'clock from Monday to Friday.

Few, if any, of the sweeping changes which were foreseen from the original Patman proposal to ban manufacturers from retailing, and vice versa, were seen yesterday as likely to follow the enactment of the bill on this question which Representative Patman introduced into the House last week.

The preliminary report of the Federal Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for 1936 shows a net profit of $1,634,139 after interest, depreciation, Federal income and undistributed profits taxes, preferred dividends of subsidiaries, , equal to $2.61 a share on the common stock after dividend payments on the $6 preferred stock.

The Columbia University Medial School will spend $500,000, obtainedd through gifts, to enlarge its laboratory facilities, Dean Willard C. Rappleye announced yesterday. Eight floors will be added to the west wing of the School of Medicine Building at the Medical Center, Broadway and 168th St.
MARCH CALENDER

Ten accountants began a survey on returns in the popular price dress field last week, and the first report they have made covering 250 manufacturers shows returns by retailers last year ranged from a minimum of 10 per cent to a maximum of 18 per cent, it was announced yesterday by Louis Rubin, executive of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group and the Dress Returns Control Bureau.

Mankind needs a "biological purge" and "a sit-down reproductive strike of the busy breeders among the morons, criminals and social ineffectuals of our population," according to Professor Earnest A. Hooton, Harvard anthropologist and president of the American Association of Physical Anthropologists.

The executive committee of the New York State Bar Association unqualifiedlyy" disapproves of President Roosevelt's program to reorganize the Supreme Court. Gathering in a special meeting on call of George H. Bond of Syracuse, the State president, the committee adopted a resolution sharply condemning the plan and ordered a

While even the most daring of weather prophets would scarcely presume to forecast, as yet, that we will be favored with an extra early Spring this year, experienced gardeners, recalling certain seasons in the past, will be prepared for such an eventuality.

MORE than four hundred years ago Vasco Nunez de Balboa fought his way for twenty-six days through the trackless jungles of Panama on his historic trip to discover the Pacific Ocean. Today one can fly comfortably over the same jungles and the Panama Canal in less than twentysix minutes by regular airplane service.

Lord Auckland, who recently announced that he had begun. a defamation suit against Mrs. Arthur WoolleyHart, was summoned to court today for an alleged public, threat. against Henry Russell, former di rector of the Boston Opera.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary will carry joint pursers for the first time in the history of the combined lines when she arrives tomorrow after a lay-up of six weeks in Southampton. Harold Bennett and Lionel Carine have been appointed to the posts, and Ronald Wadeson has been named staff purser. Mr. Wadeson was chief tourist purser of the ship last season.

Repercussions of the unanimous vote of remonstrance against President Roosevelt's proposed changes in the Supreme Court at a special town meeting here this week continue to rock the community. Democratic support of the President, none of which was voiced at the time, is now coming forth in full blast, and with it charges that the meeting was merely a "Republican rally."

Lawrenceville School's basketball team routed the Poly Prep five, 26 to 12, on the Brooklyn team's court yesterday. Led by their two guards, Ellis and Bartlett, who tallied 9 and 7 points, respectively, the New Jerseyites amassed a 15-to-8 lead at the half and coasted to an easy triumph.
Edson Henry Mattice of Penacook, superintendent and director of Stratton Co., flour millers, and for fifty years in the service of the company, died at his home today at the age of 78.

PROFESSIONAL women have a long way to go before they can take their careers for granted. The fault is not theirs. Made selfconscious by opposition, they remain self-conscious in victory. Few women have as much cause to be proud of their achievements as Dr. Rosalie Slaughter Morton. well-known physician and surgeon.

President Roosevelt has endorsed the aims of the Women's League of the United Synagogue, the nineteenth annual convention of which will be held in the Hotel Schenley, Pittsburgh, opening Feb. 28 and continuing through March 2.

Samuel R. Rosoff, wealthy. sub-way building contractor, and one of his trusted employes were arrested yesterday as material witnesses in connection with the murder of R. Norman Redwood, business agent for the striking sandhogs' union, at Teaneck, N. J.

A day of solemnity was proclaimed in the Reich for tomorrow while Germans, at home and abroad, honor the nation's war dead. Dancing and gay music were forbidden during the memorial day and moving-picture theatres were ordered to show only serious dramas.

A NEW line of three-quarter ton commercial cars, known as the "Big Boy" line and designed to serve in the field between present types of commercial cars and the larger trucks, has been added to the Hudson Motor Car Company's 1937 lines of Terraplane models.

The eleventh annual luncheon of the United Neighborhood Houses will be held on March 13 at the Pennsylvania. Further plans for the event will be discussed by members of the committee at a tea to be given by the chairman, Mrs. George L. Shearer at her home, 63 East Sixty-sixth Street on Wednesday.

Nearly 700 graduates of Wellesley, representing graduating classes ranging from 1879 to 1936, attended the annual luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday by the Wellesley Club of New York in honor of Miss Mildred H. McAfee, newly appointed president of the college.

Miss Berta Mitlacher of Vienna will be married here next Saturday to Baron Jean du Boisberranger. The bride-elect will be the guest of Miss Katherine Weld and her aunt, Miss Rosa Howard, while here. The baron is French consul at Bogota, Colombia.

With gains in four of its components and losses in three, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended Feb. 13 moved forward to 102.3 from 101.2. It was 91.9 for the week ended Feb. 15, 1936.

Siege or no siege, the Madrilenos must have their movies. Madrid papers recently received in America carried advertisements for nineteen theatres that were open for afternoon performances and were showing American and Russian films. Bombs and shells might be dropping in the streets outside,

Woman's contribution to better human relations is the topic of a talk which Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, will deliver at a meeting of the women's committee of the National Conference of Jews and Christians at 11 A. M. Friday.

Pitching down the snow-packed highway at a terrific speed, Sverre Kolterud, Norwegian skiing ace, scored a convincing victory over a crack array of international runners today in the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds downhill race.

With the completion of plans for Rutgers University's annual midwinter alumni day program Monday, Bryce I. McDonald, '14, of Westfield, chairman of the alumni council, announced today appointments to the nine standing committees of the council.

The three factory buildings, being one, two and four stories in height respectively at 71-73 Richmond Street, Newark, N. J., have been purchased by the Richmond Hat Company from the West End Building and Loan Association through David Cronheim, as broker.

The American public has declared a political blizzard season over the Supreme Court renovation issue. As a result, Congress is trying to dig itself out from under storm drifts of mail. Although it is only fifteen days since President

Combining a speed attack with uncanny accuracy in shooting baskets, the St. Benedict's Prep School quintet moved a step nearer retaining its Group 4 State Preparatory School championship by scoring a 38-to-28 victory over Pennington School today.

"Cooperative school life" has been selected as the theme of this year's program for the convention of Student Government Officers, June 29 to July 3. Four general sessions and many conferences and sectional meetings are scheduled which are expected to attract students from all parts of the nation.

For a clarification for its members of the present situation under the Soviet, the A. W. A. will present Bruce Hopper, Associate Professor of Government and International Relations at Harvard, at the clubhouse Wednesday night at 8:30 o'clock. The recent treason trials.

J. Tate, 69 years old, of Springfield, Mass., formerly co-owner of the Eastern Dairies Corporation in New England, died in a hospital tonight of heart disease. Mr. Tate, chairman of the board of the Jersey Ice Cream Company of Miami, came here this week to attend the company's annual meeting.

The second in a series of Wednesday afternoon book talks to be given at private homes by Miss Louise Maunsell Field during the Lenten season will take place Wednesday at the home of Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin, 61 East Eightysecond Street.

Steady absorption of office space in nearly all parts of the country, with a consequent sharp reduction in what was at one time an alarming percentage of vacancies, is shown in the January survey of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

Dr. Helen Schutz, 35 years old, a former member of the faculty of the University of Michigan, who had been a patient since Dec. 31 at the Neurological Institute of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 168th Street and Broadway, was found dead there yesterday, a suicide by hanging, according to the police.

Mrs. George Messersmith, wife of the United States Minister, opened yesterday an exhibition of designs for theatre costumes, fantasy costumes and materials by a young Austro-American. artist. Sissi Viditz-Ward.
Premier Leon Blum went to St. Nazaire tonight without giving any indication of what sort of pronouncement he will make on policy in his speeches there and at Nantes tomorrow.

A registration statement covering the issuance of $2,500,000 of fifteenyear 4 1/2 per cent debentures has been filed by the Memphis Commercial Appeal Company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In entering deals with Americans for raw cotton, Germany is ready to barter any goods she can freely spare, can produce from her own raw materials or which require only a small percentage of imported material in their manufacture, according to authorities who received a long list of eligible German products from that country last week.

An operating'deficit of $70,759.79 for the Children's Aid Society for 1936, the lowest since 1929, was reported last week by Edwin G. Merrill, treasurer of the society, at its annual meeting yesterday in the board room of the Bank of New York and Trust Company, 48 Wall Street. The trustees of the society voted to adopt a budget calling for the expenditure of $813,600 for 1937.
The recall from Spain of the Russian Ambassador, Marcel Rosenberg, some observers said tonight, may indicate the Soviet Government feels an Insurgent victory in the Spanish civil war is inevitable.

Navy beat Army at basketball today in the type of a battle that has come to be expected in service academy meetings, one fought with the utmost of spirit on both sides and with more or less loose play that the intensity of the contest engendered.

We are fined for using unofficial posters or stickers on our automobiles. But what constitutes an unofficial poster or sticker? Our license plates may be too low. But how high should they be? There are always various degrees of dirt on a license plate-but try argue

A State commission which has been working for three years on the problems of re-educating inmates of penal institutions for youth has just reported to Governor Lehman. Its findings indicate that the proper type of education can reduce the tendency to habitual criminality.

General Motors employes went back to work last week after a six-week sitdown strike, but their return did not bring an end to the sit-down problem. In various industries in many parts of the country sporadic sit-downs took place or were threatened, and authorities picked different methods of dealing with them.

An almost furious concentration on women's work, hours and wages characterized study after study of the subject during 1936, according to a review of the year made for the Women's Bureau at Washington. No corresponding interval, it was said, has ever been marked by such vigorous attention to the situation.

A card party will be given the evening of March 16 at the Commodore to aid the mission work of the Rev. Francis Powers in Hanyang, China. The benefit has been arranged by a group of friends of the missionary, who is a native of this city.
