A procession of prominent artists appeared in a concert at Carriegie Hall last night for the benefit of flood sufferers. The program,under the auspices of the American Guild of Musical Artists, Inc., attracted an assemblage that overflowed the hall.
A dinner dance at the Field Club tonight was attended by more than 100. The ballroom was transformed into a Colonial setting in keeping with Washington's Birthday.

Tan-colored snow fell in the Corn Belt the other day. Nobody needed an explanation of the phenomenon. What had happened was perfectly plain to all. The snowstorm had got mixed up with a dust storm on the way here, and this was the result.

Miss Gene Sonsire is chairman of the annual bridge of the Junior Auxiliary of the Flatbush Boys Club to be held March 13 at the Brooklyn Edison Biiliding. Among the subscribers for the benefit are Mrs. George S. Edwards, Mrs. Edmund H. Driggs,

Ten years ago Rainer Marta Rilke--alone and far from home-died "his private death." He was a poet, filled with the sense of his lofty mission, and gifted. But he had to struggle greatly for this gift of poetry. Often his soul remained silent for years, and this emptiness of exhaustion caused him untold suffering. But then the divine spirit returned to him, and he worked as under compulslon.
ONE of the younger generation of American artists whose work entitles him to serious attention is having his second one-man show (through March 1) at Macbeth's. Horace Day,

The gray stone walls Of the Fordham gymnasium reverberated the cheers of 3,100 voices as another chapter in the battle of the Bronx was written last night. In a typical struggle between Fordham and New York University for borough supremacy the Maroon basketball team emerged triumphant by a 31-to-19 score.
A luncheon and dance will be given in the roof garden of the Pierre tomorrow by the Veterans Corps Artillery of New York in observance of the 205th anniversary of the birth of George Washington.

BY far the most ambitious of Caroline Gordon's novels. "None Shall Look Back" is a story of the Civil War which at first gives promise of outdistancing its numerous competitors. Miss Gordon, it is obvious at once, has many assets in her favor.

The marriage of Miss Charlotte R. Quig, daughter of Charles J. Quig and the late Mrs. Quig of Delaware, N. J., to Charles G. Hartung, also of that town, took place today at the home of the bride's sister, Miss Emily Hart Quig.

On behalf of the Garden Club of America, Mrs. Joseph C. Grew, wife of the United States Ambassador to Japan, today presented 4,650 American trees to the Japanese nation. Formal ceremonies in which Mrs. Grew and Mayor Torataro Ushizuka of Tokyo will participate are to be held next Thursday.

Philip H. Showers, Virginia farmer who claimed to have lived through twenty-eight Presidential inaugurations, died at his home here last night at the age of 116 years. His family records show he was born at Oxford, Pa., on June 24, 1820.

Two field goals by Miss Miriam Serrick, Wagner -College captain, in the last two minutes of play gave the Staten Island sextet an 18-14 victory over New York University's girls' basketball team last night on the Wagner court.

ALTHOUGH E. F. Benson, versatile and indefatigable as an author, with almost 100 books to his credit, has excelled in every form of writing, including fiction, he is at his best in historical biography.

THE problem of Elisabeth Bergner is still unsolved. This girl-woman, who has proved herself such a great little artist on stage and screen in one part and its variations that she has been widely acclaimed as a great actress, still gives us no proof of the versatility that any actress meriting the adjective great must possess.

TALES of the fabulous wealth and beauty of the East, as well as hundreds of photographs of sacred temples and places rarely seen by Occidental eyes, have just been brought out of the least accessible provinces of Persia, now called Iran, by Dr. Arthur Upham Pope, director of the American Institute for Persian Art and Archaeology, who is now in London.

Without any increase in automobile taxes the State of New York should show an increased revenue from this source of $200,000,000 in the next decade, Robert L. Graham Jr., secretary of the New York Petroleum---Industries Committee, said yesterday. By the year 1946, he added, the State should be colelecting about $50,000,000 more annually than it did last year, when in excess of $100,000,000 was derived from automotive taxes.

Nine operas will be given by the Metropolitan Opera Company when it returns to Cleveland's Public Hall April 12 to 17 for the first time since 1932, This will be Cleveland's tenth Metropolitan Opera season and the seventh season sponsored by the Northern Ohio Opera Association.

Mrs. Allan Ryan Jr., who heads the reservations committee, has announced that all of the boxes and many of the seats have been purchased for the performance of "Tristan und Isolde," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles, Thursday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc. Miss Katherine Blake is aiding the benefit as a member of the junior committee.
New Hampshire's eighteen women legislators serving in the 1937 General Court have given the State the greatest representation for their sex in any State law-making body.

MANHATTAN HOLDEN, WARD A. (Jan. 24). Estate, more than $10,000. To Elizabeth Holden Canda, sister, Cambridge, Mass., residue: Mrs. Anna Marcus, 943 Lexington Av., $1,000. Empire Trust Co., 120 Broadway, executors. LEE, ANNA C. (Feb. 9). Estate, more than $10,000. To Henry T. Lee, husband, eexcutor, 1,185 Park Av., residue.

PLANS for a twenty-four-cylinder, 1,000-horsepower, in-line air-cooled engine of the "H" type, made public last week by Sherman M. Fairchild, indicate the first entrance of the United States into the high power development of power plants of the type.

Aroused at the spread of irreligion, the National Catholic Alumni Federation, in a statement made public yesterday, appealed to the 300,000 American Catholic college graduates and interested non-Catholics to join forces and assume the lead in fighting this "product of communism, fascism and materialistic capitalism."

Several dinners were given last night before the Red Cross Mlood Relief Concert at Carnegiee Hall under the auspices of the American Guild of: Musical Artists. Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, was the guest of rs. Alma Clayburgh at the Ritz Tower.

The Crescent A. C. of Brooklyn defeated the University Club of Stamford tonight, 34--31, in an Eastern Athletic League basketball game in the State armory. Crescent led, 23-13, at half time. Then University Club spurted and tied the score with a few minutes to play. Crescent's superiority from the foul line accounted for its victory.

LICE DUER MILLER writes Light fiction with a light and expert hand. She makes even a flimsy story take on a sparkling texture. In "The Rising Star" she writes a Hollywood romance with the emphasis not on life in the cinema city but on the reactions of her main characters to a chance at fame and glory in the movies.

A young Harvard graduate whose appearance in a racquets court prior to this year would have been of no more than passing interest went into the championship east court at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday and electrified a large gallery with one of the greatest exhibitions ever seen there.

Members of various national sororities composing the New York Panhellenic Society will hold their annual scholarship ball next Saturday at the Ritz-Carlton. A part of the proceeds will be used for a $500 scholarship to be awarded in April to a Panhellenic member who received the degree of Bachelor of Arts last June, that she may continue her studies.

Among the patrons and patronesses for the Columbia College Junior Promenade, which will be held on Friday in the Oval Room and ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, are Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas McKnight, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hubbard, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Carman, Mr. and Mrs. James Gutmann, Mr. and. Mrs. C. Pierpont Ladd, Chaplain and Mrs. Raymond C. Knox, the Rev. and Mrs. Robert G. Andrus and George Rath.

THE world's hidden treasure, it is computed, amounts to a rough total of eleven billion dollars. But Harold T. Wilkins, who may be accepted as an authority on that romantic subject, is careful to hold out no tempting hope of finding it.

"The best landlord in New York State" is Harry Z. Suchin, according to the tenants of the Rosalind Gardens Apartments here, so the fifty-four families gave their ninth annual party, for him and his family tonight.
WILLA CATHER'S famous plea for "the novel demeuble" is more than answered in this uncommonly interesting story of Indian life in Mexico.

THE ingenuity of the newsreel editors will be put to test some three. months hence. And already they are devising ways and means of outwitting one another in the mad race which will begin when George VI leaves Buckingham Palace on the morning of May 12 for the coronation ceremonies in ancient Westminster Abbey.

The theatre has an old ida of having scouts mingle with the crowd in the lobby during intermission and at the end of the show to eavesdrop on what the audience says about the performance. So it is also illuminating in television at the finale of a demonstration to listen to what the spectators in natural conversation sav among themselves.

Willam H. Smathers of Atlantic City finds himself in the unusual and, no doubt, unhappy predicament of having to keep a $500-a-year job when a $10,000 one is available the moment he is free to take it. Mr. Smathers is a Democrat and he is at once the Atlantic County member of the State Senate and United States Senator-elect.

The Edward M. Morgan Foundation of the New York Post Office, Inc., last year provided ward bed care for 554 postal employes at a cost of $18,706.72, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman, the president.

Plans for a variety of promotional and sales campaigns aimed at building up millions of dollars' worth of new business from neglected or partially developed sources, were perfected here last week by the business development committee of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

The new Traffic Code is mainly a summary and codification of ordinances and regulations already in effect, but it contains several important new provisions. The following are the principal new features effective today:

B. A. Hjorth, Swedish industrialist maker of wickless kerosene stoves familiar to thousands of war veterans, died today. Mr; Hjorth's stoves were used by several of the World War armies and in Arctic and Antarctic expeditions, but their outstanding recommendation came in 1930, when the remains of the Swedish polar explorer, S. A. Andree, were found on White Island, near Spitzbergen.

BRITISH television experts believe they have solved the riddle why the images broadcast on ultra-short waves have on several occasions been seen fifty miles from London when, according to theory, twenty-five miles was expected to be the limit. Three electrified regions, between five and forty miles above the earth, have been discovered by the National Physical Laboratory,

There has been an increase in the demand for industrial space in Westchester County during the past six months, with indications that this demand will be followed by considerable new industrial building during 1937,' according to Harold E. Snow, manager of the industrial division of Prince Ripley.

Paul O'Brien, last year's winner in Class C, scored a first-round victory today as the fourth annual championship of the Westchester division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association got under way at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

Benjamin P. Morris, former Mayor and an attorney here for fifty-three years, died today at his home of a heart attack. His age was 79. Mr. Morris was born in this city, a son of the late Jacob W. and Elizabeth Pearce Morris, pioneer settlers. Jacob Morris erected the first large hotel and Summer boarding house on the beachfront.

Mexico's religious agitations, which centered last week-end in the State of Veracruz, extended tonight in the northern States of Coahuila and Chihuahua. Catholics there demonstrated to enforce demands for punishment of the persons who last week killed a Jesuit priest in Chihuahua.

Friends and relatives here have received word of the engagement of Miss Jacqueline de-Neuflize, daughter of Baron and Baroness Andre de Neuflize of Paris and Neuilly, France, to Baron Jean de Watteville-Berckheim of Paris. It is understood that the marriage will take place early next month in Paris.

Max W. Amberg, one of the leading figures of the millinery industry in the United States and prominent in the affairs of millinery associations, died yesterday of heart disease at his residence, 1,112 Park Avenue, after an illness o several weeks. His age was 54.

America's first transatlantic air terminal, one of the largest airdromes in the world, is rising out of the virgin wilderness of Newfoundland not far from the spot where the first flight across the Atlantic was started eighteen years ago.

WESTERN civilization is doomed if religion. on which it is founded. should fail. With that thought, expressed in a notable inaugural address, the Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay assumed, this month, the presidency of Princeton Theological Seminary.
A DEFINITE trend in shortwave broadcasting which grows more and more pronounced each month is the transmission by South and Central American countries of special programs for American listeners.

Representatives of youth organizations from all over the country held a "sit-down" practically at the door of the White House today as part of their demonstration in favor of the Lundeen bill, providing $500,000,000 for-jobs, scholarship assistance, and vocational training for all persons between 16 and 25 years of age.

Encouraged by the successful records made by holders of the John McMullen Regional Scholarships in Engineering, Cornell University is offering thirty additional scholarships carrying a stipend of $1,200 at the rate of $300 annually to graduates of high schools and preparatory schools in fifteen districts of the United States.
The coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth of England will be celebrated here by a "Coronation Ball" the night of May 12 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixtysixth Street.
Andre de Laboulaye, who has just retired as French Ambassador to the United States after being four years in Washington, sailed with his family yesterday for Paris on the French liner Ile de France.

William H. (Lone Star) Dietz, freshman football mentor at Temple University, was named head football coach at Albright College today, succeeding Clarence Munn, who resigned recently to become line coach at Svracuse.

A musical will be given this afternoon at the clubhouse of the Girls Service League, 138 East Nineteenth Street, for members of the Dowfin Club, a group of boys from the Institute for the Blind. Acting as hostesses during the afternoon will be Mrs. Francis Rogers and Miss Rosemary Baltz.

DAVIS-Mr. and Mrs. Paul (nee Juliette Holzman) of 156 Beach 134th, Belle Harbor, announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Richard Sidney. at Temple Beth-El. Saturday, Feb. 27. At home Sunday, 3 to 6. GOLDBERG-Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Goldberg of 670 West End Av. announce the bar mitzvah of their son. Jacob, at Congregation Shaare Zedek, 212 West 93d St., on Feb. 27, 1937, at 9:30 A. M. Reception at home.

The Ridgewood Polo Club rallied to conquer the Kilkare Farms trio of Red Bank, 13 1/2 to 10 1/2, tonight at Essex Troop Armory. The game followed the machine gun troop's fourth annual military horse show.

Mrs. Erastus Ketcham, who has been a widow for many years, celebrated here tonight her ninety-sixth birthday in the house where she has lived since she was married eighty years ago. Mrs. Ketcham is as active as women half her age. She was born near here.
Four veterans of the Erie Railroad, partners for many years in daily card games, counted up their score in the rooms of the Erie Veterans Association in the station here.

THE settlement of the automobile strike, putting more than 100,000 men back at work and resuming production on all General Motors cars after six weeks in which the wheels had stopped turning, was a great triumph for Frank Murphy, Governor of Michigan.

Virginia's boxing team ended its season tonight by defeating Harvard, 6 1/2 to 1 1/2. The bantamweight bout between Bill Siegel of Harvard and Ben Jacobs of Virginia was declared a draw after three spirited rounds. The Crimson's lone winner was Dwight Ellis, who scored a technical knockout over Page Claggett in the first round.

While Southern Michigan is returning rapidly to its normal task of building automobiles, it would be an untruth to say that the period of strife which prevailed during the 44-day General Motors strike had already been succeeded by an era of good feeling.

Yale swam away from Columbia University tonight for its 159th consecutive victory, winning by 52 to 24, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League competition. The visitors were exceptionally versatile in the dive and breast-stroke, in which Captain Roveto and Justin Callahan scored. The Elis captured the other seven events.

The international "standstill" conference which has been considering further liquidation of more than 1,000,000,000 marks of frozen short-term credits extended to Germany by the banks of eight nations, including the United States, ended today with a new agreement prolonging these credits for the seventh time and for another year until Feb. 28, 1938.

Bond prices moved irregularly higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading, however, was dull. Secondary railroad Issues continued to hold the center of interest in the corporate division, although the pace of the advance was somewhat subdued, with gains, in most instances, restricted to fractions.

Members of the Bryn Mawr College Alumnae Council will assemble in Washington Thursday for their annual three-day session. Among the speakers will be Miss Marion Edwards Park, president of the college, whose topic will be "1937 and What Lies Ahead for Bryn Mawr."

THE international significance of the Berlin automobile show is increasing, as is evidenced by the fact that the motor-car industries of every nation except Russia and Japan are represented. From the attendance figures it may be said to be 'the largest automobile show in the world.

Realty men of Danbury, Conn., have decided to form a real estate board, to be a part of the Connecticut Association of Real Estate Boards and of the National Association of Real Estate Boards. The organization meeting was arranged by G. LeRoy Kemp, president of the Connecticut organization.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College left yesterday for Tucson, Ariz, where she will remain for a week before leaving for Los Angeles. Dean Gildersleeve will address the Barnard Club in that city and will visit Occidental College in Pasadena.

A spectacular shot-making performance by Clarence (Buddy) Combs carried the Winmont Farms indoor polo-trio to a 15 1/2-to-12 triumph over Governors Island last night at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn.

Dr. Katharine F. Woodward of this city, daughter of Rufus S. Woodward, was married yesterday to Bradford Buttrick Holmes, also of New York, in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building after they had obtained a marriage license at the bureau. Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines performed the ceremony.

A Japanese amateur astronomer reports having located the "missing" Daniel comet. The astronomer, Shinichi Shimizu, has informed the Central Meteorological .Observatory of his rediscovery of the comet, named for the Princeton University professor who discovered it first.

St. Peter's College of Jersey City opened its three game invasion of Western New York against Canisius College tonight, losing, 44--26. The second game, against Niagara University, will be played Sunday afternoon, and Monday night the Jerseyites tackle St. Bonaventure College.

A number of informal receptions were held in connection with the dance given by the Young Republiban Recruits tonight at the Garden City Hotel. Henry Munson of Hilton Hall entertained at tea at the hotel for Mr. and Mrs. Thurston Smith, Mr.

The marriage of Miss Jane Atherton, daughter of Mrs. Anne E. Atherton of 425 Riverside Drive, to Robert Bulkeley Winslow of this city, son of Mrs. Lawrence Ewing of Greenfield, Mass., and the late Edward B. Winslow of Beverly, took place here yesterday afternoon in the James Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary.

String beans and peas are bringing the highest prices of the year in the produce markets due to asteady advance in the last week, it was reported yesterday by the Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets.

AMBERG-Max W., on lFeb. 20, in his fiftyfifth year, dearly beloved husband of Irma Hiller, devoted father of Richard, Jane and Constance. Services Monday, private. Kindly omit flowers. New Orleans papers please copy. AMBERG-Max W. With profound grief we record the passing of our dear friend and past president, Max W. Amberg, an inspiring influence at our councils and one deeply esteemed for his unselfish and untiring efforts in behalf of the Millinery Industry.

Tomorrow the nation celebrates the birth of the Father of His Country. After earnest study of his views and the views of two other great Virginians, I am more than ever impressed that a great fundamental principle is involved in the President's proposals.

Judge Eugene O'Dunne fined fifteen striking taxicab drivers $1,000 each today and suspended jail terms of one year on their convictions of assaults, riots and other disturbances. A sixteenth man was fine $200.
Exports of leaf tobacco from Cuba declined from 30,901,174 pounds, valued at $11,604,000, in 1935, to 22,728,398 pounds, valued at $9,153,504, in 1936, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The Misses Ethel and Margaret Grimmer, daughters of Otto Grimmer of this city, entertained with a tea dance yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador Hotel. In the party were classmates of Miss Ethel Grimmer at Wellesley College, and those of Miss Margaret Grimmer from the Gardner School.

Jake Schaefer successfully defended his 28.2 balkline billiard championship today when he turned back a final challenge from Willie Hoppe and ran out with a cluster of 71 to end their 1,500-point match.
Japan's ragpickers have taken such advantage of the shortage of metals for battleship construction and other purposes that one's doorknob and plumbing are scarcely safe.

Syracuse University dramatic students have taken their textbook theories and dogmas behind the footlights and put them to the test in the first production of "Daughters of Atreus" away from Broadway, which closed a three-day run here last night.

Education has continued from the schoolroom into cellars and lofts in a striking experiment f the WPA Adult Education Program of the New York City Board of Education. Six months' progress is now reported by the Youth Service Division, which is already reaching upward of 7,000 young people. The experiment is known as the Youth Club Work program directed toward the thousands of young people banded in private "social clubs" in the metropolitan area.

FROM every standpoint trailer life and trailer living have all the advantages." remarks the author of this book, with the serious inclusiveness of perfect satisfaction. But if his happy attitude of mind seems ingenuous, it is not, for all that, uninformed or inexperienced.

The familiar scene of overstuffed automobiles on country roads leading to fishing and hunting grounds may soon become a thing of the past. Streamlined, moderately priced utility trailers are being produced by manufacturers to change the complexion of these expeditions and relieve the burden of racks and running boards.

Benjamin Franklin gained ground on Seward Park in the race for the lower Manhattan division title in Public Schools Athletic League basketball yesterday by defeating Haaren, 37 to 22, on the neutral court of public school 99.

Lloyd W. Bleeker, 28 years old, of 417 Marrow Field Avenue, Elmira, N. Y., a member of the CCC camp at Goldens Bridge, N. Y., was fatolly injured and five other persons hurt in a three-car collision on Crompond Road here early today.

Two hundred and fifty natives of St. Lawrence County now living in the metropolitan area gathered yesterday at the Commodore Hotel to renew acquaintance, swap tales of the broad valleys and deep rivers of up-State New York and in general enjoy themselves at the thirtysecond annual meeting of the St. Lawrence County Society.

A very witty member of the diplomatic corps in Rome, referring to the heterogeneous mixture of races and nationalities engaged on either side of the Spanish civil war, remarked recently that one of General Francisco Franco's chief difficulties is a lack of enough interpreters to act as intermediaries between himself and his troops.

Mrs. Catherine A. Jenkins Heuisler, widow of Dr. Joseph Gregory Heuisler, died yesterday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Lawrence Miller, at the age of 73. Mrs. Heuisler was the daughter of the late Captain and Mrs. William H. Jenkins.

The Department of Labor has asked the United States Steel Corporation, of which the Crnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation is an affiliate, to set aside two plants to furnish navy steel on the basis of a forty-hour week with overtime, under the terms of the Walsh-Healey Act, in order to speed the navy's battleship program.

The Naval Institute announced today that Lieutenant Henri H. Smith-Hutton had won its fifty-ninth annual prize essay contest with a paper entitled "Naval Limitations." Lieutenant Smith-Hutton is serving on the Augusta.

Holders of mortgage certificates in Series A-2, issued by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, have been notified of the filing of the account for the year ending Dec. 31, 1936, by Cornelius J. Smyth, trustee of the issue, which he took over from the State Mortgage Commission on Dec. 1, 1935.
C. E. Horn, 73 years old, of Cleveland, needed a shave. Henry Schuler, 72, a barber, began to lather Horn's face. "Well, I'm a son of a gun," said Schuler, stopping suddenly.

Princess Daria (Dolly) Obolensky, daughter of Prince and Princess Alexis Obolensky of 147 East Fiftieth Street, has chosen March 12 as the date for her marriage to Hans George Spitzer. The wedding will take place in the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour Madison Avenue and 121st Street.

A $30,000,000 junior high school building program to continue over a period of six years starting in 1938 will be recommended to the New York City Board of Education within the next three months by the Board of Superintendents. This further extension of the junior high school system, it is expected, will cut the number of high school failures as well as school construction and administration costs.

Joseph E. Manning, formerly with the Eugene J. Busher Co., has joined Hugh A. McGorry, Inc. He will have charge of the sales department. Nathan Ossip. Samuel Costuma, Harold Frank and William Allen have formed a new realty company known as Boulevard Associates, with offices at 117-14 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

A four-foot stretch of track has been completed and locomotives placed under test for a unique railroad, the Chautauqua Valley line. It is the property of the Chautauqua County Model Engineers Society, the members of which are laboriously whittling hundreds of miniature ties.

Admiral R. R. Belknap and Mrs. Belknap will be guests of honor of the Lyric Art Society's luncheon in celebration of Washington's birthday tomorrow at the Plaza Hotel. Other guests will include the Rev.

President Roosevelt's proposal for increasing the personnel of the Supreme Court was called an attempt to destroy "the independence of the judicial department" last night by James A. Emery, general counsel of the National Association of Manufacturers, in an address made at a banquet of the Traffic Club of New York.

the development of the United States the printing press has played a master role. It was the hardy Colonial printers generally newspaper editors, too) who helped to lash public opinion into the frenzy that gave birth to our country:

Albert R. Brand of the department of orthinology at Cornell University, has announced the completion of "talking books" on birds for the American Foundation for the Blind. The "books" are phonographic recordings of the calls and songs of thirty- wild birds, together with descriptive comment by Mr. Brand.

By dint of strong effort all around, the International Committee for Non-Intervention in Spain has been saved from wreck at the eleventh hour, and the prospects for continuing European peace are correspondingly higher. This has been one of two weighty factors this week, each tending toward the same end.

Cor nell's track men, I. C. A. A. A. A outdoor champions, opened then 1937 campaign indoors tonight by defeating Yale, 751-3 to 37 2-3. It was Cornell's fourth straight tory over the Elis since 1932 and ?? tenth in the thirteen-meet series.

Two pool records were broken today as Exeter defeated Worcester Academy, 42 to 24, in swimming. Carl Rohman took the 100-yard backstroke in 1 minute and 7 seconds to clip eight-tenths of a second from the mark set by Captain Bosworth in 1936.

Shampion Wolvey Noel of Claireale, Sealyham terrier owned by the lairedale Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. V. O. Penney of Riverhead, L. I., his evening was proclaimed the est of 444 dogs entered in the eigheenth annual exhibition of the Elm ity Kennel Club in the State rmory.
North Carolina's Prohibition Law, which held sway for twenty-eight years in the greater part of the State, went to the scrap heap today, displaced by a county-optionmonopoly system of package sales.

Miss Sylvianne Kendall Blanchard, daughter of Mrs. Walter James Herzfeld of 50 East Seventyseventh Street and of Dr. William H. Blanchard of Boston, was married to Carl Gunther Triest, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Gustav Triest of 1,100 Park Avenue, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Resurrection by the Rev. Gordon Wadhams, the rector.

Mrs. Russell S. Hume will be hostess in the Women's Opera Committee box on Tuesday night, when the Metropolitan Opera Association will present "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacc at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

LAST week the American Institute of Mining and, Metallurgical Engineers met at New York. H. W. St. Clair, Bureau of Mines metallurgist, demonstrated a new way of clearing the air of fog, smoke and soot, by whistling it down.

The national A. A. U. track and field championships, which have been increasing in stature every year until they now have become the blue-ribbon event of the indoor season, will be staged in Madison Square Garden on Saturday before a capacity crowd of 16,000.

Thirty-three members of the Giants went through a three-hour workout at Tropical Stadium today under the watchful eye of-Coach Frank (Pancho) Snyder. Johnny McCarthy, slated to replace Manager Bill Terry at first base, again was the center of attraction as he fielded his position sensationally and put pep in the fielding workout.

A gradual decline in the average interest rate for first mortgage loans on new medium-priced homes is reported by the National Association of Real Estate Boards as the result of its twenty-eighth semiannual survey of the realty market throughout the country. Replies were received from 250 cities regarding the first mortgage interest rate and slightly more than 91 per cent cited the -common rate as within the 5 to 6 per cent range.

The annual report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1936 shows a consolidated net income of $13,223,242, which, after payment of preferred dividends of $6,942,122, was equivalent to 53 cents a share on the outstanding common stock. This compares with a consolidated net income of $11,944,326 in 1935, equivalent, after preferred dividends at that time, to 43 cents a share.

United States curlers failed in their attempt to retain possession of the Gordon International Medal, emblematic of curling supremacy on the continent, when they bowed to representatives of the Canadian branch of the Royal Caledonian Curling Club today by thirty-five shots, 211 to 176, in a sixteen-game match.

About $20,000,000 worth of debentures of New York City's World's Fair- of 1939 have been sold or spoken for, according to a statement issued yesterday from the offices of the World's Fair bond sales committee, 41 Broad Street.

The Jewish Consumptives Relief Society, with headquarters here at 31 Union Square West, will hold its annual dinner, with places at $100 a couple, at the Hotel Astor on Sunday night, March 14, it was announced yesterday by Charles Miller, manager of the city office.

Since organizations in which consumer interest is of paramount concern may not agree on vital questlons the new Consumers' Emergency Council will explore, it has been agreed that instead of a sort of super-organization, this council will be a clearing house for all independent bona fide consumer groups.

A luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Longacre Center of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service will be held March 9 at the Weylin. Younger members of society will act as manikins in the fashion revue of the latest Spring costumes.
This afternoon's session of the International Horse Show gave the United States team still another viotory in the presence of thousands of onlookers drawn from every city in Chile.

A resolution condemning President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the -Supreme Court was adopted yesterday by the Women's National Committee for "Hands Off the Supreme Court" at a meeting at the Biltmore Hotel. Miss Catherine Curtis, acting chairman, presided, and plans were made for a mass meeting to be held shortly in this city.

The Hershey Bears defeated the New York Rovers, 2 to 1, in a fast, but peaceful Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight. Morris inadvertently gave the Rovers their tally. Skating backward to help cover the net, he backed into the puck which Collings had just shot from behind the Hershey net and the rubber dribbled into the goal.

Retrievers (Golden)-John K. Wallace's Bingo of Yelme. Retrievers (Labrador)-Mrs. Morgan Belmont's Echo of Arden. Spaniels (English Springer)-Reinhold J. Logue's Rexos Inveresk Bunte. Norwegian Elkhounds-A. Wells Peck's Westview Tapper. German Shepherd Dogs-Grenfair Kennels' Lucie V. D. Dreikronen. Great Danes-R. G. Gladen's Rhona of Kittyglade.

Winning four of the five games the Central Badminton Club easily defeated the Hartford Badminton Club on Rip's courts in the Seventyfirst Regiment Armory yesterday to capture the Metropolitan League Class B team title for the fourth straight year.

Dr. F. D. Patterson, president of Tuskegee Institute, today credited a 90 per cent decrease in lynchings in the United States since 1887 to "growth in the humanitarian attitude of the American people."

Now that he has "The Eternal Road" actually. running in New York, Max Reinhardt has accepted a long-standing invitation to produce "Die Fledermaus" in London. Rehearsals will begin soon after his presentation of Goethe's "Faust" at Salzburg. A. P. Herbert and Reginald Arkell will prepare a new version of the "Fledermaus" libretto.

Realty conditions in Westfield, N. J., as presented in the thirteenth annual building and vacancy survey just completed by the Westfield Board of Realtors showed more improvement last year than in any previous year since 1928. A total of 149 new homes were erected, equaling the aggregate number of new dwellings built in the four preceding years and existing homes in the town are 97.7 per cent occupied.

Comprehensive plans are being evolved by the toilet' goods industry to seek removal of the Federal nuisance tax on toiletries. Industry-wide action will get under way here this Tuesday, when a meeting will be held under the auspices of the Toilet Goods Association.
The agreement concluded between the government and the German Activists was published today. It follows the lines cabled yesterday in giving satisfaction to certain demands of the German minority.
ELSA RESPIGHI is engaged in a minute revision of the many manuscripts left by her late husband. All of them

Heartly W. (Hunk) Anderson, who helped Knute Rockne mold a crushing football machine at Notre Dame a decade ago, joined the University of Michigan staff as line coach tonight. "Good line play is good line play in any system or in any ball game," said Fielding H. Yost, Michigan athletic director, "and Hunk Anderson has the reputation of being one of the best line coaches."

ABOVE the ticket window at the Scala Opera House in Milan on Saturday afternoons, a small, lop-sides sign announces boldly--"2 Lire" (10c anywhere in the house.) Five dollar orchestra seats--they'll sell for that at the evening performance--for the Italian equivalent of a dime. The programs are the same, both afternoon and evening; and Gigli may be singing.

RETAIL trade improved on its gains last week with the average for the country running about 11 per cent over a year ago. Women's apparel buying has increased, but the most general comment comes on sustained high volume in home furnishings departments. The Middle West continues to furnish reports of exceptional increases over last year.

Next to robins, the surest harbinger of Spring is the arrival of golf schedules. Yesterday the Metropolitan Golf Association announced its tournament dates, the two principal fixtures being awarded to the Westchester and New Jersey districts in accordance with the group's rotation plan.

IT is hard to believe that the partita for violin and piano contained in the current Columbia Masterworks Album No. 275 is actually the first recording from the compositions of Charles Martin Loeffler. There was a time, nearer ten than five years ago, when Loeffler's partisans became almost threatening about the manner in which the record people were neglecting him, but in the years of the slump their ardor evaporated.

ASSISTANT COMMUNICATIONS OPERATOR (air navigation), $1,620 a year (for filling the position designated junior radio operator)-Applicatins must be on file with the manager, Second United States Civil Service District, Federal Building, Christopher St., New York, N. Y., not later than March 16. Competitors will not be required to report for examination

Students of Wellesley College are preparing for a "big push" in a drive to attain for their college an indoor swimming pool and. recreation center. Dormitory teams are organizing for the opening of a threeday campaign Monday, March 1.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Van Pelt, daughter of Mrs. Oris Jacob Van Pelt of this city, to Ridgeway A. Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross K. Cook, also of East Orange, took place this afternoon at the First Reformed Church here.

Honor rating was obtained by 257 students at Manhattan College during the first semester, according to the list made public yesterday by Alfred D. Donovan, registrar. This number represents more than one fifth of Manhattan's undergraduate body of 1,250.

The housewife who wields a can opener instead of a paring knife is keeping close track of prices for goods For this is the season when marketmen are either running short of last Summer's stock of canned fruits and vegetables or are trying to unload a surplus before the fresh products come in the Spring.

Although only a few industries have established the policy they will pursue when the expected Federal legislation for control of hours, wages and trade practices appears, sentiment .has been. crystallized in the last few weeks among business men as to what they will accept, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

Forty-four vocations which women students have decided to follow after graduation will be the subject of a conference at Syracuse University on Thursday and Friday, in which authorities in each field will participate. Based on a survey made of student ambitions, the program will cover aviation, banking, dentistry, political service, hotel management, beauty culture and real estate, as well as the older careers of teaching, secretarial work, social service and advertising.

With the congestion of air traffic which has developed at Newark Airport, the busiest landing field in the world, the enlarged and fully modernized airport which Vincent Bendix will develop at Teterboro, N. J., in connection with the $3,000,000 aeronautic accessory t plant he is to build there, is expected to prove a welcome haven for transport planes in bad weather.

The Regional Plan Association is opposing the proposed construction of a bridge across the Hudson River at Fifty-seventh Street and has asked Secretary of War Woodring to refuse a permit for the project, which is being sponsored by the North River Bridge Companv.

Cold figures are now cast into the heated controversy over whether a constitutional amendment should supplant the Roosevelt program for reconstructing the Supreme Court. Statistical challenges are offered to refute arguments by Attorney General Cummings and other Roosevelt lieutenants that delay surrounding thirty-six States' approval of a constitutional change precludes such a proposal.
Tempers and combustible materials flared up today, the fifth day of a heat wave that has sent temperatures up to 96 in some parts of Brazil.
THE 162d annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts is current, until the end of the month, in Philadelphia.
Production at the Conklin Pen Company stopped today, the result of a sitdown strike called by the United Automobile Workers Union, although the plant is not connected with automotive Production.

HAVING concluded his work with the WPA Federal Music Project, Lee Pattison has taken up his duties as director of the Spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Plans and personnel, which were not whipped into final shape, awaited his arrival.
WINTER visitors from all the world these days explore New York on recreation and business bent. Give them a week and they know and feel the metropolis as though seasoned New Yorkers.

DURING the coronation opera season, from April 19 to June 30, at Covent Garden, London, twenty operas will be performed, including two complete cycles of Wagner's "Ring." The cast of the first cycle will practically duplicate that of the last Baireuth festival.

AUTHORS do not, as a rule, object to publicity, provided it is of the right sort. But they naturally complain when such reports are circulated about them as those of which Margaret Mitchell has been the victim. These have been so baseless and mischievous that the London publishers of "Gone With the Wimd" have thought it desirable to issue a public protest.

TRAVELERS in foreign lands will find March days starred with festivals and religious pageants, with fairs and racing meets. Among these pre-Easter events are the ski races at Trondhjem, Norway, on March 11, the agricultural exhibition in Budapest, Hungary, and the St. Patrick's Day festivities in Ireland on March 17.

Business in the flooded area of the Ohio Valley, except for those relatively few establishments in which plants and machinery were utterly ruined, is making a rapid recovery. This is especially true of all lines of wholesale and retail consumers' goods, illustrating the resiliency of the populace and the depth of the public cash and credit reserve.

Supper conversation at Hobart and William Smith Colleges has turned from literature, basketball scores and junior proms to heated political discussion, with the students and faculties of both colleges dissecting and criticizing President Roosevelt's proposed changes in the Supreme Court.

In an anteroom of the Family Court chambers on the fifth floor of the court house in Milwaukee sits a fair sampling of humanity-a motorman, a druggist, a reporter, a mother of six, a society matron and a WPA worker. Domestic trouble has brought them together.

A warning to American colleges to restore their system of "selective admission" to insure the worth of the college degree was sounded by Frank H. Bowles, acting Director of Admissions, in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University. The report was made public yesterday by university officials.
Thanks to the assistance of three radio amateurs, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Houseman received a postcard message from St. Petersburg, Fla., less than twenty-four hours after it was sent.
The New York Americans will find out tonight whether they still can hope for a play-off berth or whether they will have to look ahead to building up an organization that will do better next Winter.

A celebration of the thirty-fourth anniversary of the founding of the Catholic Young Women's Club will be held in connection with the annual bridge luncheon of the organization on Thursday at the RitzCarlton. A birthday cake with thirty-four candles will be presented to Mrs. De Lancey A. Kane, a founder and honorary president, by Mrs. Cornelius Tiers, a member of the arrangements committee.

The tremendous proportions of the new rearmament program of Great Britain can be gauged from the fact that she purposes to spend annually in the next five years a sum which is four times what she spent during the last year before the World War when she was preparing for a conflict with Germany, and more than twice what she spent last year.

Men died with a joke on their lips, and others "though fearfully maimed, concerned themselves with their shipmates," Navy Chaplain H. P. Trump said today of the explosion aboard the U. S. S. Wyoming Thursday.

In a whipping drive from the head of the stretch to the wire, Finance, a son of Bull Dog, defeated Maerlel, a son of Ariel, before 20,000 persons in the McLennan Memorial Handicap at Hialeah Park today. It was a finish that further scrambled the outlook for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup, for back of Mrs. Emil Denemark's racer were many of the favored candidates for the climactic test of this meeting.

In French eyes the Italian Government has acted in the Spanish war, as in the attack against Ethiopia, with such cold indifference to any kind of morality or obligation that that mistrust of fascism which has simmered here for the last ten years has been converted into an active sense of danger.

D. Aitchison and E. Lee, the former a member of the Bayside Tennis Club and the latter a representative of Block Hall, will meet Tuesday to decide the Group 2 singles championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association.

Bike stars from the United States, Italy, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Germany and Canada have been signed to compete in the six-day bicycle race which gets under. way in Madison Square Garden next Sunday night.

Mrs. Stanley Baldwin, wife of the Prime Minister, is holding weekly at homes at 10 Downing Street until March 18. Among her guests Thursday were the Belgian Ambassador, Speaker Fitzroy of the House of Commons and Mrs. Fitzroy, Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Sandys, Brig Gen. and Mrs. E. L. Spears, Viscountess Deerhurst and Lord and Lady Leigh.

THIS short novel by the author of "Early Americana and Other Stories" should easily find for itself a wide circle of readers. It has charm, and, in a special sense, power. The charm is pervasive; the power rests in Mr. Richter's ability to evoke atmosphere.

Citing the prospective benefits or a central mortgage bank which would be created following favorable action on the Wagner-Pepper bill, now before Congress, Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, states that the value back of the central mortgage system and its securities would be the actual permanent use value of the nation's urban homes, commercial buildings and office buildings.

Scouting the claim that a battle between private brands and nationally advertised food products has developed in the wake of enforcement of the Robinson-Patman act, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., said Yesterday that nationally known brands are becoming more firmly entrenched with distributors than ever before.

With special emphasis on the increasing use of marijuana in the United States' the World Narcotic Defense .Association all this week will observe the eleventh annual Narcotio Educational Week, appealing to the public through the press and radio as well as through religious, fraternal and educational institutions.
A musicale was given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman at the Evergrades Club, and nearly 300 were invited to hear Luerezia-- Bor of the Metropolitan Opera Company. A buffet -supper followed.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of.Miss Sylvia Silk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Silk of 310 West Eighty-fifth Street, to Martin Binder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan J. Binder of 308 East Seventy-ninth Street.
Canada will have no team in 1937 Davis Cup competition as a result of a poll of members of the Canadian Lawn Tennis Association, Secretary J. De N. Kennedy told the annual meeting today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. G. Howard Bright of Princeton, N. J., now here for the Winter, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Bright, to Rodman Morgan, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Rowland Morgan of Chestnut Hill. Pa.

H. G. Wells has been tinkering with the universe again - with the universe and with man's place in it. He was doing the same thing last Spring when he looked ahead a century or so and called his predictions "Things to Come." This time he has abandoned the role of prophet (he was too impractical for it, anyway) and has begun to conlecture what would happen if some average chap received virtually limitless power.

Capital and labor in the motorcar industry having decided for the time being at least to compose differences of opinion around the conference table, automobile factories are steadily heading a record level of
Secretary Wallace will be among the speakers at the annual North American Wild Life Conference in St. Louis March 1-4. Among other speakers will be Senators Clark and Pittman.

CAME off our course to see Charleston, S. C. Worth it, too. Hired rickety old sedan with wheezy old native guide. He had a rich dialect and shifting plate, but with help of guidebook we got a good idea of the antiquity of Charleston.
There were not any bass lurking under lily pads in the tank at the ' Grand Central Palace yesterday, but nevertheless Anthony J. Pilar Jr. of East Orange did not take any chances with his casts.

A strange sea creature thirty feet long, which raced a steamer off the Shetland Islands, was seen from the inter-island vessel Earl of Zetland, according to passengers and members of the crew who arrived at Lermick.

Brig. Gen. Henry C. Pratt has been transferred from command of the Second Wing, General Headquarters Air Force, at Langley Field, Va., to the command of the Air Corps Tactical School, Maxwell Feld, Ala., the War Department announced today.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler today warned Germn automobile manufacturers in no uncertain terms that the country's automotive industry must be made completely independent of the "insecurity" of imports and must be placed on its own firm basis.

With a city election of more than usual importance coming next Nomember, both Mayor La Guardia, who is expected to be the Fusion nominee for re-election, and the leaders of the regular Democratic organizations, who will oppose him, are stalling for time.

Police Commissioner Valentine dismissed seven more men yesterday from the department, bringing the total dropped under his jurisdiction to 161. Two of the men were sergeants and six of the seven were charged with intoxication or offenses connected with drinking while on duty. They were:

WHEN "London Calling--1600" is broadcast from Daventry, England, Feb. 25, listeners should imagine themselves living 300 years ago and hearing the sort of programs that might have been on the air in the reign of Queen Elizabeth.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- Next week will witness several major sporting activities in Nassau. The finals of the Bahamas Country Club's annual golf tournament for the championship of the Bahamas will be an event of Washington's Birthday. Sixteen qualified in the preliminary rounds, playing over an eighteen-hole course.

NOW it is the skirt that is articulate. This Spring it is going to have something to say for itself in a modest way. For while it is attracting attention because of interest in detail it in no way is detracting from the suavity of the new silhouette.

Mrs. Charles D. Lanier will entertain members of the William Alexander Jr. Chapter, United Daughters of the Confederacy at Her home in Rock Ridge tomorrow afternoon at a reception and tea. Lanier is president of the Greenwich branch and also president of the Robert E. Lee Foundation.

WASHINGTON'S birthday, less than two decades ago, meant rather desultory public exercises in a few more or less mud-bound Virginia communities associated with the career of the Father of His Country and a school holiday. Today it means unofficially, if not quite formally, the opening of the Washington region's annual tourist season.

A committee of twenty-five members of the faculty at City College, formed to aid the Loyalist forces in Spain, have begun activity on a program to increase their membership. The committee is headed by Lewis Mumford of the Board of Higher Education as honorary chairman, and Professor Harry Allen Overstreet of the Department of Philosophy as chairman.

Layton F. Smith, for years prominent as a civil engineer and twice president of the Engineers Club, died here last night at the age 66. He was a veteran of the Spanish-American and World Wars. As an engineer he superintended construction of viaducts and bridges about Baltimore.

For his "outstanding contribution to the development and protection of the nation's outdoor resources," President Roosevelt has been seelected as the recipient of the 1937 Conservation Award of the New York Rod and Gun Editors Association.

Taking first place in all six events the New York University women's swimming team defeated Hunter College, 35 to 18, yesterday in the Evangeline House pool. Miss Constance Hanf and Miss Constance Diemling scored twice for the winners.

The story of Oliver Twist, in which Charles Dickens used a vocabulary of 5,000 words, has been retold with 900 words of "easy English" in a marionette show prepared by the WPA Federal Theatre Project for foreigners and semi-illiterates.

ATINY Georgian library, with books, furniture and rugs--the whole no A bigger than a good-sized hatbox will be carried across the Atlantic soon to join the collections in London's Kensington Museum. This miniature room is now on exhibition at the Chicago Historical Society. where adults and children alike marvel at the amazing precision. the taste and the beauty that have gone into its making.

Many persons have the erroneous idea, states the Federal Housing Administration, that the National Housing Act will soon expire. The act is permanent and the Federal Housing Administration is a permanent governmental agency.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eighty-second Street and Fifth Avenue: "Wall Decoration in Medieval Italy" (survey of collections), Margaret B. Freeman, 2 P. M.; "Yorktown; Firearms of Our Forefathers" (Yale photoplay), 2:30 P. M.; "Color Contrasts," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Old Solutions for Modern Problems," Walter Pach, 4 P. M.

Hearings are now being held in Washington on a measure, known as the Dickstein bill, the declared object of which is " to protect the artistic and " earning opportunities in the United "States for American actors, vocal "musicians, operatic singers, solo "dancers, solo instrumentalists, and "orchestral conductors."

Mrs. Edith Mackinney Mackie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Baldwin Mackinney of Providence, R. I., was married here today at the Winter home of her parents to Edwin C. Laird Jr., son of Mrs. Edwin C. Laird of Richmond, Va., and the late Mr. Laird. There were no attendants.

The marriagt of Miss Virginia Ijams, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. George E. Ijams, and Tracey Coleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Coleman of Washington, took place this evening at the Starr Methodist Church.

A powerful Lehigh wrestling team crushed Cornell, 36 to 0, before more than 2,000 spectators in Taylor Gymnasium tonight. The Engineers, undefeated in six starts this season, crashed through for six falls in the eight bouts.

Carlos (Indian) Quintana of Panama stopped Jimmy English of the West Side in 1:58 of the fifth in the eight-round feature contest at the Ridgewood Grove last night. The program was for the benefit of the family of Tony Marino, the boxer who died after fighting at the Grove three weeks ago, and a purse of $1,212 was realized with 3,500 attending.

Times Square's Saturday matinee traffic was disrupted yesterday afternoon when spilled grease set fire to the flue of the Cadillac Restaurant, between Forty-third and Fortyfourth Street on Broadway. Seven fire companies responded to the alarm, attracting a crowd estimated by police at 8,000.

WPA officials of Chicopee have. found that a surprisingly large number of boys, who are just as. handy with their fists as any normal youngster, at the same time are genuinely interested in the correct method of cross-stitching, embroidering, knitting, crocheting and sewing.
New York teams emerged triumphant in both halves of the basketball double-header at the Hippodrome last night before 4,000 spectators.

Stockholders of the Walgreen Company approved today the company's recapitalization plan, involving retirement of preferred stock, raising $5,000,000 of new capital, doubling the present common stock capitalization and payment of a 50 per cent stock dividend to the present common stockholders.

Mrs. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Chinese generalissimo, made an address last night on behalf of her husband for American radio listeners. It was delivered from her home in Nanking and was broadcast by Station WEAF of the National Broadcasting Company at 7 P. M. It was sent by short wave from Shanghai to San Francisco for rebroadcast in the United States.

Properties chiefly in demand by investors in the New York City area at the present time, according to I. Jerome Riker, president of the realty company bearing his name, are choice industrial and business locations and modern, well-rented apartment houses.

O an ever increasing extent trailers are in the public eye. Trailer manufacturers, although working at top speed in many cities, are said to fear, when the heavy season of the open road arrives, a shortage such as complicated their delivery problems last season.

In the forty-hour period ended at midnight yesterday the pier staff of the Hapag Lloyd Line handled four arrivals and four departures, involving 99,213 tons of shipping and 2,032 passengers. Rough weather that delayed the arrival of ships combined with a movement in the company's cruise schedule and the arrival of a freighter on an infrequent visit provided the unusual volume.

A steady increase in the number of investors seeking good real estate properties- is one of the encouraging features of the present realty market, declares Herman A. Acker, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.. Another helpful factor,

With a holiday tomorrow and March notices expected on Tuesday, outstanding obligations in the near month were reduced substantially on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. With trading more active than the limited fluctuations indicated, the list closed with a gain of 5 to a loss of a point on the day.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gilchrist of Jeffrey, N. H., today announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Caroline Gilchrist, to Roswell Delmege Trimble Jr., son of Major and Mrs. Roswell Delmege Trimble of this city.

THE mild weather which New' York has enjoyed this Winter belies the regular schedule of the Army Air Corps in raining pursuit, observation, scoutng and bombing pilots for operaions under the most severe condidons offered by the elements.
For the first time the manoeuvres of the British Home and Mediterranean Fleets are to be made the subject of a film which, it is understood, will eventually be released to the public.

How can Loyalist Spain win the civil war? This is a good time to ask this question now that everybody abroad seems to think that all is over but the shouting. It is human nature to believe a winner is going to keep on winning and a loser losing.
Mrs. George E. Nelson gave a buffet supper tonight at her home, 104 Woodland Avenue, for Roman Verhovskoy, architect and sculptor, a brother of Princess Cyril Toumansky of Englewood.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Feb. 17, which included only five business days in many of the reporting centers, aggregated $8,835,000,000, or 3 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 3 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

NOW that the Theatre Guild has produced "The Masque of Kings," three plays by Maxwell Anderson are simultaneously visible in this neighborhood. Although that is not a numerical record, it is an artistic triumph, for Mr. Anderson's plays have high aspirations.

More than 650 persons attended the annual supper dances of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance and Washington Square College last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. About 350 were present at the School of Commerce senior ball in the Starlight Roof and some 300 persons attended the Washington Square College Prom in the Astor Galleries.

The annual report of the Jewish Social Service Association was presented last week at a meeting of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies at 71 West Forty-seventh Street. It showed that of the $890,000 expended by the organization during 1936, $472,818, or 53 per cent, went for direct material relief of families in need.

Spurred by the heavy volume of retail distribution, which in some sections of the country reached the highest level so far this year, all of the major branches of business forged ahead at a fast pace last week. Gains were especially impressive in the South, retail sales figures in some areas rising 25 per cent ahead of those in the corresponding period last year, with the demand for Spring merchandise the heaviest since 1930.
The Most Rev. John Aloysius Duffy, who will be installed April 14 as Bishop of Buffalo, aligned himself today with opponents to ratification of the child labor amendment.

The advisory council of the Associted Alumni of Brown University will meet in Providence this weekend to nominate new officers of the alumni, alumni trustees, candidates for alumni district officers, hear addresses by members of the faculty and administration, and weigh a variety of alumni and university problems.

Pleas for more medical supplies and nurses went out today from this lieve dust-plagued town of 1,500 in Southwestern Kansas after two more course, deaths brought to fourteen the number of victims of influenza pneumonia.

That the annual registration of thoroughbred dogs in the United States will exceed 100,000 within the next few years is indicated by the figures for the first month of 1937, released yesterday by the American Kennel Club. During January there were entered in the stud book a total of 7,500 pure-bred individuals.

Suites All- Rented Practically all the apartments in the building at 292 Monroe Street have been rented at a 50 per cent increase in rental following alterations completed- under the supervision of N. Richard Hyman, the Tentye Realty Corporation, owner, announces.

Germain G. Glidden, New York, opened the defense of his national squash racquets championship today with with a second-round victory over Bogue Cummings of Baltimore. Glidden will meet J. L. Ware of Boston tomorrow in the quarterfinals.
THIS is new deal week for New York City's cavalcade of more than 1,250,000 motor vehicle drivers At midnight last night the city's first new traffic code in nearly twenty years became effective.

12-Pound Shot-Put-Won by Sammy Taylor, New Utrecht (51 feet 101/2 inches); Herman Rupelli. New Utrecht (49 feet 11/2 inches). second: Vincent Barrett, St. Francis Prep (48 feet 91/2 inches), third; Michael Motto, Manual (48 feet 13/4 inches), fourth; George Matthews, St. Michael's (48 feet I inch) fifth.
THE report of the State Highway Survey Committee of New York, recently submitted to the Legislaturei envisages a long-term road building and improvement program for the entire State.
Before a crowd of 6,500, one of ?? largest to witness an intercollegiat?? boxing meet, Penn State's und?? feated boxing team defeated Navy tonight, 71/2 to 1/2.
Miss Kathryn Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rogers of this city, was married this afternoon to Edgar C. Jones Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar C. Jones, also of this city.
The first phase of the Jarama River battle has ended. Neither side can advance against the other or force the enemy back, so both are digging in and hanging on.
A wildcat bit off more than it could chew this week when it leaped off a country highway near the center of the town of Hardwick and sprang on to.a car driven by Joseph Reidy of Hardwick Road.

For the first time in its history Union College will celebrate Founder's Day next Saturday and pay tribute to General Philip Schuyler, who brought it into legal existence in 1795 and was the chief patron of the college.

The junior committee of the Little Italy Neighborhood Association, of which Mrs. John O. Zimmerman is chairman, will give a "Spring Fiesta" as their annual entertainment on May T at The Towers, Brooklyn. Mrs. Charles B. Singleton is chairman of the party and Mrs. James K. Kent will serve as treasurer.

The Public Service Coordinated Transport, a subsidiary of the Publie Service Corporation of New Jersey, has ordered forty additional light-weight twenty-one-passenger trolley-buses from the General Motors Corporation. The new vehicles are to be of the same type as those purchased last year for use on traffic lines handling the lighter volumes of business.

WILFRED PELLETIER, the conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, who listens to between fifty and sixty singers each week in connection with the opera auditions of the air, broadcast over WEAF's network Sunday afternoons at 3 o'clock, asserts that while vocal talent among the applicants is plentiful, personality is rarely encountered.

The twenty-nine organizations cooperating with the Joint Committee for Ratification of the Child Labor Amendment will send representatives to Albany tomorrow morning to participate in the Assembly hearing on the amendment at 1 P. M. The delegates will leave here at 8:30 A. M.

UNLESS the records are holding out, Guthrie McClintic and Sam H. Harris have never ventured on a show together. Nor is it certain now that they are going to. But good authority admits that Mr. McClintic is more than interested in joining Mr. Harris next season as coproducer and director of "Bright Rebel."
Handbags promise to be one of the more spectacular accessories this Spring, if the collection of one of the pace setters among the bag manufacturers is any indication. Big bags, severely simple,

Mrs. John H. Lippincott of Chestnut Hill Has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Deborah Lippincott, to Guy Currier, son of Mrs. Guy W. Currier of Boston and of Peterboro, N. H., and of the late Mr. Currier.

THE short-necked, sad-eyed hair seal is making his periodic pilgrimage from northern waters to New York's shores, undismayed by the dangers involved in crossing busy steamship lanes. Coast Guards at Fire Island sighted a small seal herd recently tossing along through the inlet into Great South Bay.

Approximately half the home mortgages insured by the FHA are for amounts between 76 and 80 per cent of the appraised valuation of the properties, and the public shows preference for the long-term mortgage, particularly when the loan is for new construction, according to the Federal Housing Administration.

Earnings of the Commercial Solvents Corporation for 1936 were $2,232,135 after allowing $405,949 for depreciation and $360,940 for estimated normal Federal income taxes, according to the company's annual report issued yesterday. In 1935 net profit was $2,702,092, and the decline last year was attributed in part by the company to the lack

The jury to select the prize-winning designs in the ninth students' bridge-design competition of the American Institute of Steel Construction will consist of Dr. D. B. Steinman and Jay Downer, consulting engineers;

An infant traveler who has journeyed a thousand miles for every month of her life, arrived yesterday on the Anchor liner Caledonia en route to California. The baby, Clunies Anne Denholm, the daughter of David Denholm, a horticulturist of El Monte, Calif., was accompanied by her mother.

Helen Moyer, 15, a high school girl for whom search had been conducted since her disappearance nine days ago, was found dead today at the bottom of a fifty-foot stone well on an abandoned farm near Downingtown.

Mrs. Walter Kobbe heads a group of women in charge of the arrangements for a card party in behalf of the Humane Society of New York on the afternoon of March 5 in the Perroquet Suite of the WaldorfAstoria.

Ground for three small homes, designed according to the composite wishes of more than 11,000 consumers of electric power, will be broken next month in Syracuse, Albany and Buffalo by the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation.

A story that George Washington threatened to resign from the Alexandria Jockey Club because of an unfair decision in a horse race was recalled today by historians. Items from Washing?on's diary and stories handed down from one generation of Alexandrians to another tell of his interest and participation in all sports popular in his day.

Army's swimmers vanquished Dartmouth, 39-36, in a closely contested meet today, while the Cadet gymnastic team subdued the Green's representatives, 45-9. West Point gained its third varsity victory of the day at boxing, halting the Citadel glove-swingers, 5-3. However, the academy's fencers did not fare so well, dropping a 1512 verdict to New York University in a threeweapon match.

Mrs. Robert 0. Hayward of 426 Park Avenue and Kent, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Hayward, to T. Dixon Walker of Kent, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Edgar Walker of Short Hills, N. J. Miss Hayward is a daughter of the late Mr. Hayward and a granddaughter of the late Dr. and Mrs.

The subject of foreign investments in this country came to the fore in financial discussions last week as a result of the conferences held in Washington by government monetary experts to consider means of checking the flow of "hot money" from Europe.

According to present plans, the nation-wide election for a new General or National Synod of the German Protestant Church, which, by ChancellorAdolf Hitler's will, is to draft a new church constitution and organize a new church regime, will be held either the first or second Sunday after Easter, that is. either April 4 or 11.

Cathedral College's basketball team made a strong drive in the last period to defeat Columbia lead Pharmacy, 52-43, at the Morningside Heights court last night. At the end of the first half the rivals were tied. 22-22.
EARLY German paintings have been placed on view at the Schaeffer Gallery, there to remain until March 13. It isn't often that we are privileged to see as many as nine Cranachs in one group.

Henry G. Arnsdorf, registrar of New York University, announced yesterday that 28,m students had enrolled for the second semester in the fifteen divisions of the university, compared with 25,886 at the same time last year.

Miss Priscilla J. Sharpless, daughter of Mrs. Albert Wayne Sharpless of West Chester and of the late Mr. Sharpless, was married at noon today to William Knapp Hathaway 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Hathaway, also of West Chester.

Miss Arline Elizabeth Parsells, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Parsells of this city, was married this evening to Lieutenant Warren Wentzel of the 112th Infantry, East Orange, National Guard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Wentzel of Newark. The ceremony was performed in St. Thomas Episcopal Church here by the rector, the Rev. John H. Keene.

This book tell us.

The University of Pennsylvania announced today its varsity eightoared, shell would not compete in the annual Poughkeepsie regatta on the Hudson River this year because "for the present, at least, the university does not contemplate participation in long-distance rowing."
THE American production of "White Horse Inn" marks the twelfth country in which the play has been presented since its original launching at the Grosse Schauspielhaus, Berlin, in November, 1930.

The fact that for some years financial difficulties have compelled about 200 members of every class at Temple University to drop out at some time during the four-year course led the university to announce today the establishment of a scholarship loan fund.
A formidable team representing Penn Hall yesterday defeated the Savage School girls' swimming team at the American Women's Association pool, the score being 41-18.

The engagement of Miss Sonya Altmark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Z. Harry Altmark of 1,192 Park Avenue, to Dr. Robert A. Ullman, son of Dr. Julius Ullman of Buffalo and the late Mrs. Ullman, has been announced by her parents.

The objectives, scope and technique of social work as a professional function were discussed today before the Conference of the American Association of Social Workers, in addresses by Wayne McMillen of the University of Chicago, Miss Virginia Robinson of Philadelphia and Miss Grace F. Marcus of New York City.

The New York Credit Men's Association is advising its members here to check with local groups in the flood areas before extending credit on a large scale to any accounts in those districts, W. W. Orr, secretary, announced here yesterday. The local association will send out a letter this week to all members, reporting on conditions in the stricken districts, based on surveys by credit groups along the Ohio Valley.

Harvard's basketball team went into fourth place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League tonight by beating Columbia, 37-30, in a rough game. The Lions dropped to fifth place. Harvard's play was featured by d accurate and uncanny passing.

Luke Appling, American League batting champion, signed a one-year contract for $18,500 today, the White Sox management announced. The star shortstop had asked $20,000 and been offered $17,500. A compromise was reached today.

Four buses purchased by the Chilean Government will leave Paris for Madrid on Monday to begin the evacuation of 750 Spanish women and children who have lived in the Chilean Embassy since the start of the civil war, it was announced today.
The 30-year-old daughter of a former Indian Ocean island queen who gave up her kingdom for a policeman was married today to a French engineer twice her age. The wedding announcement said:

Branch Rickey, general manager of the Cardinals, said the National League club today received the unsigned contract of its ace pitcher, Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean.
