James Roosevelt, son of the President, plunged tonight into Massachusetts's controversy over the child labor amendment with an assertion that ratification had been made necessary by the Supreme Court's invalidation of the National Recovery Act.

To the Screen Edftor: AS a reader, and a fairly consistent one at that; of the Sunday TIMES film news, might I ask why you are allowing your columns to deteriorate into a sparring ground for the battle of the film giant's? If this keeps up,
Paraguay "completely and definitely" severed its connection with the League of Nations today. The move, begun two years ago while the League was attempting to negotiate a settlement of the Chaco

Business advisers of the Roosevelt administration have drawn up a new formula for curing "sweatshop" ills and. improving trade practices. Informed officials said today that President Roosevelt is favorably disposed toward the proposed legislation, which would provide mandatory minimum labor standards for industries operating in interstate commerce.

Charles G. Sonntag, a member of the brave band of men who volunteered, under the leadership of Dr. Walter Reed, to submit themselves to the bite of the yellow fever-bearing mosquito, died last night. Mr. Sonntag, who was 64, died at his home in the Sandy Run section of Calhoun County. Interment will be in Arlington Cemetery, near Washington, D. C., Monday with full military honors.

Miss Lorraine Gomer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Comer of Stratford, will be married on June 26 to A. Edwin Crockett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Edwin Crockett of Rochester, N. Y., in the First Congregational Church of Stratford, by the Rev. Stanley Sellick.

Behind the energetic speech of Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria last Sunday before the leaders of his Fatherland Front lies a personal tragedy and act of selfsacrifice of which few Austrians outside the ranks of the aristocracy are aware because of the discreet silence of the Austrian press.

GARRICK," opera in three acts, libretto by Robert A. Simon, music by Albert Stoessel, will be-given its first performances this week by the student singers and orchestral players of the Juilliard School of Music. The stage settings have been designed by students in the Juilliard School's class in stagecraft conducted by Frederick Kiesler.

Joseph P. Daly, retired woolen merchant, died suddenly today at the home of his son, Herbert W. Daly, in Yonkers, N. Y. He was in his seventy-ninth year. Mr. Daly was born in Brooklyn, the son of John and Marion Daly. Upon leaving school he entered the woolen business and remained in it until he retired, fifteen years ago.
APART from the Far East." Dr. Sehacher points out in the first sentence of his book. "Central Europe has become the most dangerous center of crisis in the world."

Seventeen-year-old Alejandro, Pistolesi Manzoni, identified by the government as former secretary to the Italian air attach, was accused in a court trial today of spying against the Spanish Government.

Collapsible articles and accessories, designed to conserve space in automobiles, trailers, trunks and at camp, are all the rage in camping equipment. A survey of store show cases and exhibits at the National Sportsmen's Show reveals the development of numerous lightweight contraptions which require little room and are easily handled.

New York's current public-works program includes about eighty projects, on which a total of $142,881,396 is being spent, a summary prepared by Controller Frank J. Taylor shows. Of the total cost, $49,351,987 is covered by outright grants made by the Federal Government.
Professor Sir Augustus Bartolo died today at the age of 53. He was a member of the Malta Parliament from 1921 to 1933, had been a member of several administrations and since 1934 a judge of Malta.

A Proposal that the Federal Government should first instruct farmers in the proper use of their land and then, if necessary, compel them to abide by such instructions was voiced here today at the final session of the National Farm Institute by Harry L. Brown, recently appointed Assistant Secretary of Agriculture.

Quick-acting. jailers halted an attempted break by eight men at the Mahoning County jail today, shooting to death Frank Bonk, 22year-old robbery suspect, and wounding three other prisoners. The four other prisoners rushed back to their cell block to escape the gunfire.

WITH the same snow that brings the influx of Winter sportsmen to New Hampshire comes the challenge to the State Highway Department to make good its boast that it keeps the roads open throughout the Winter, even during the worst storms.

Bail bonds totaling $9,000' were provided today for nineteen members of the United Automobile Workers of America and their sympathizers arrested in disorders attending a strike here which resuited in a declaration of martial law.

AUGUSTA, Ga.-Polo, the annual field day of the CrossCountry Riding Club and golf comprise the sports calendar of this week here, while a number of Augustans and Winter visitors are taking advantage of the last days of the quail season for hunting.

Mrs. Agnes Fairchild Moley, mother of Raymond Moley, former "braintruster" in President Roosevelt's official family, died today at her. home in suburban Berea. She had been an invalid for several years. She was 82 years old.

If Governor Hoffman's statement, issued on Monday, warning the Committee for Industrial Organization that New Jersey would not tolerate sitdown strikes, even if bloodshed should be necessary, was prompted by an urge for front-page publicity he accomplished his purpose.

Miss Hildreth Meiere, president of the National Society of Mural Painters, will be the guest of honor of the Catholic Young Women's Club this afternoon at the second in a series of teas given for outstanding American women. Mrs. William C. Hammer, member of the board of directors. will be hostess.

CRITERION-Man of Affairs: George Arliss. 55TH ST. PLAYHOUSE-Masquerade in Vienna.* FILMARTE-Eternal Mask: Mathias Wieman. GLOBE-Devil's Playground*: House closes Wednesday night. MUSIC HALL-When You're in Love: Grace Moore.

The filing of duplicate bids in an office in the Grand Central Terminal was disclosed last Wednesday as being one of the provisions of the recently signed voluntary code of fair competition for the heating, piping and air-conditioning industry in New York, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Andover's relay quartet clipped 3 3/5 seconds from the 1,200-yard track mark in their race with the Yale Freshmen today, winning in 2:16 2/5.

Harvey R. Halsey of 158 East Fifty-fifth Street, senior assistant secretary of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company, died yesterday in Metropolitan Hospital after suffering injuries when he was struck by an automobile on Fifty-seventh Street on Friday. He was 72 years of age.

The Yankees may be world champions, but they are well below the Dodgers in the contract-signing league. Yesterday Ed Barrow could produce no new dotted-line penswingers, while John Gorman rushed forward with a full quartet of athletes, all of whom have written in complete harmony on the papers that will put them on the Brooklyn payroll April 20.

Veteran anglers are of the opinion that artificial lures are best for catching bass, walleyes and the great northern pike. For smaller fish, such as sunfish, bluegills and rockbass, bait is more affective.

About 200 men, identified by authorities as Italian civilians and sailors from an Italian warship at anchor here, stormed a motion picture theatre today and routed the audience with gunfire. ammonia bombs and clubs.
Eric P. Monroe, 33, secretary to the headmaster of the Westminster School in Simsbury, plunged to his death today beneath the wheels of a ii passing freight train at Union Station.

William Watson, 24 years old, who has a-police record of six arrests and was once sentenced to six months in the workhouse for driving while intoxicated, was arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of grand larceny.
Professor BEARD does not want to deprive the Supreme Court of the right to pass on acts of Congress.

Seven religious, civic and peace organizations are cooperating in plans for an all-day forum on peace and world affairs to be held on Tuesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Dr. Stanley High will discuss the foreign policy of the United States, and Miss Dorothy Detzer, Washington representative of the' Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, will speak on women In world politics.
Wider and tighter bandages were applied today to Pope Pius's crippled legs and physicians reported the Pontiff, in walking a few steps again, had reopened an ulcer on the left leg.

More than thirty women headed by Mrs. Roosevelt and including wives of high officials and others of achievement in many fields will be the honor guests of the Women's National Press Club at its annual dinner on Monday night, March 1, at the Willard Hotel.

With prices on lumber, steel, leather and other materials rising steadily, additional price advances on sporting goods are expected before May 15, according to-manufacturers here yesterday. The scheduled increases have brought in to manufacturers. a larger amount of business than would otherwise develop, it was said.
Winning all eight bouts, Columbia's varsity wrestlers defeated Rutgers, 32 to 0, yesterday in the Morningside Heights Gymnasium. Bob Taylor, Lenox Muldoon and Captain Ken Elmes threw their opponents.

The gala concert to be given under the direction of Albert Morris Bagby on the afternoon of March 15 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria is receiving the support of many men and women of prominence in society and the musical world who are actively interested in the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., beneficiary of the concert.

The Journalism Department of the College of New Rochelle now numbers 147 students, representing 20 per cent of the total enrollment at the college, according to a report submitted by Miss Margaret V. Cosse, head of the department. Of the seven courses presented to train the students for actual newspaper work, increased registration is most noted in propaganda, advanced news writing and book and play review.
Alas! should you ever be urged to endeavor To map for young Siegfried a fam-i-ly tree, Be advised now to ponder the verses down yonder, And not be becalmed on the Nibelung sea.

Where can I go? What will it cost me? What kind of fishing is there? What of the food, lodging and conveniences? How can I get there? These and other similar questions are being asked more and more these days by many thousands of Americans eager to spend vacations hunting, fishing or camping.

Miss Catherine Bigelow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Carl Bigelow of this place, was married to Charles M. Wilgus, son of Mrs. Helen Wilgus of Ocean Grove, N. J., today at the Bigelow home by the Rev. Thomas D. James of Berkshire Valley.

New Hampshire, Dartmouth and Middlebury finished in that order at the close of the Middlebury Winter Carnival tonight. All events scheduled for the two-day meet were run off with few delays in spite of the handicap of almost no snow and mild weather. New Hampshire won first place with a total of 485.78 points.

Evergold, stanch 8-year-old gelded son of Ladkin out of Golden Lassie II, carried the Shandon Farm Stable colors to a nose victory in the mile and 70-yard feature at Alamo Downs today, beating the mighty challenge of Up and Up, 4-to-5 favorite. Corum was third, a half length away.

TWENTY YEARS or more of study and labor have gone into the writing of Dr. Oberholtzer's history which with this present volume is completed. Five long. solid volumes have been required to tell the story of thirty-six years, a generation, of national life. but now the story is finished and on the manner of its telling must depend the authors place among the ten or twelve major writers of American history.
ARTUR RODZINSKI, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, begins his engage meant as director of the Philharmonic-Symphony Thursday night, remaining until the end of the season, April 18.

The Japanese Army's continental expansion drive, having run a broad course for five and one-half years, appears suddenly to have suffered a decisive check. That important fact was marked last week in the appeal for cooperation and friendship that the new Premier, General Senjuro Hayashi, in his first address to the Tokyo Diet, made to China and Russia.

Mrs. Oliver Harriman heads the reception committee for the annual Elisabeth Marbury Authors' luncheon, which will be given tomorrow in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Many women of prominence in social and literary circles are sponsoring the luncheon,

The beginning of the new term at Princeton University has brought a transition in the management of both major undergraduate publications, as the senior boards have followed the traditional policy of Landing over control to their 1938 successors with the start of the second semester.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wonder if the solution of our economic problem suggested by James Truslow Adams, in his recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, is so entirely "up to" the capitalist as he seems to think.

Clyde Troutt, owner and trainer, sent out two of his consistent horses, Hueu and Hastinola, to run one, three in the six furlongs of the National Education Association's Handicap at the Fair Grounds today. Hueu, 7-year-old gelded son of Rodgers, led the way home, finishing a length in front of Butsy Hernandez's Marcabala.

A $1,000 prize will be awarded by the Conference on J wish Relations, Inc., to the person writing the best essay on the subject of "The Occupational Distribution of the Jews in the United States," it is announced by Professor Morris R. Cohen, president of the conference.

Sale of twenty-two one and two family homes in the New York City area during the past month is reported by Russell Page, sales director of the Easy-to-Own Homes organization, representing a large insurance company. Six dwellings were. sold 'in Queens through William M. Smith as broker, being respectively at 159-01 Twenty-eighth Avenue, Flushing, to Cell Robbin, with Thomas Smith as co-broker;

TOURING thousands spending the cold months along the Mississippi Gulf Coast again are getting a thrill from Pascagoula's "singing river," a phenomenon that never fails to intrigue and which thus far has not been solved.

Frederick M. Babcock, chief of the underwriting section of the Federal Housing Administration, points out that one of the greatest sources of grief that could result from a building boom would be the overbuilding of localities, not only in a quantitative sense but also in regard to the distribution of dwellings in various price ranges.

Eastbound intercoastal traffic from this port-was under way again for the first time since November, when the harbor strike tied up traffic, as the Grace Line's flagship, Santa Rosa, bedecked in flags, with all of her passenger accommodations filled and her freight' holds laden to capacity, sailed yesterday for New York, via Mexico, Guatemala, El Salvador and the Panama Canal.

THE new season, long delayed, is at last in full swing. After weeks in which evening after evening has been vacant, there are now two and sometimes three or four new productions on a single night, and all the office boys are being called in to the aid of dramatic criticism.

With the 1937 championship already clinched, the Brooklyn Prep sextet registered its seventh straight victory by halting St. Francis Prep in the opening contest of a Private School Hockey League twin bill at the Brooklyn Ice Palace yesterday. Tallying in every period, the Blue and White skaters won, 5 to 1.

Government cashiers the country over are playing the merriest tune heard by Uncle Sam in many a year. The 1936 income tax returns are pouring in on the sixty-five collection districts into which the country is divided for income tax purposes, accompanied by checks and cash.

Miss Helen Keller will sail for Japan on April 1, according to her secretary, Miss Polly Thomson. It will be Miss Keller's first trip to the Orient and in every community she visits she will make public appearances on behalf of the blind and the handicapped.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is an honorary chairman of the luncheon committee for the luncheon and discussion to be held on Saturday at the Commodore under the auspices of the trustees of the Public Education Association.

Members of the Junior League of the House of Calvary have arranged their annual card party and fashion show in aid of that organization for the night of March 12 at the Concourse Plaza Hotel. Young women, members of the league, will act as manikins in the fashion revue.

Princeton University's alumni will convene in the historic faculty room of Nassau Hall on Monday for the annual midwinter meeting of the National Alumni Association. The meeting will be the main event of an alumni week-end program. Laurence G. Payson, '16, of New York, president of the association, will preside at the meeting, which will begin at 11:15 A. M.t

Power Memorial Academy's powerful quintet assured itself of at least a tie for the Manhattan Richmond division C. H. S. A. A. championship yesterday afternoon when it routed- Cathedral Boys High, 41-27, in the final game of the scholastic quadruple-header at the Hippodrome. A crowd of 2,000 saw the four -games.

TWO hundred and five years ago to morrow was born on the banks of the Potomac River the man whose name still stands at the head of the honor roll of the nation which his generation of Americans created out of a baker's dozen of English colonies strung along the Western coast of the North Atlantic.

Nineteen scholarships carrying a cash value of $7,600 were awarded to these students at the Harvard Law School today: Robert Heller of New York City. Floyd V. Amoresano of Paterson, N.J. Israel W. Auerbach of New York City.

Derby day will come to Santa Anita on Washington's Birthday with the third running of the mile and a sixteenth event for an added purse of $50,000. Overshadowed to some extent by the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap which will follow next Saturday, the Derby nevertheless will attract a brilliant field of 3-year-olds.

The mid-year dance at Rosemary Hill School, Greenwich, tonight, was attended by Rosemarians and students from several colleges. Prior to the dance, Miss Anne Turner, daughter of Mrs. Terrill Van Ingen of Round Hill Road, entertained fellow-members of her: committee in charge of the dance and their guests, at her home for dinner.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ceora Jennings Hufnagel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Bernhard Hufnagel of Greenwich, Conn., formerly of Sewickley, Pa., to Walter Ware Slocum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stepnhen Slocum of Ardmore. Pa.
A charity ball will be held by the Elizabeth Junior League at the Elizabeth Town and Country Club on April 3 under the auspices of the ways and means committee headed by Mrs. Houston E. Landis Jr.

Virginia Military Institute, at Lexington, Va., looking forward two years, soon will begin plans for the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the founding of the institution, which has had an unusual and colorful history.
Gene Gisburne, Penn's star free-style swimmer, helped the Red and Blue to gain a 41-34 victory over the Navy in the Eastern Intercollegiate League match at Hutchinson pool today before a large crowd.
PALM BEACH, Fla.-Six major events of this week plus numerous smaller ones are expected to leave few unoccupied hours for those here who attempt to keep step with the midseason rush.
Hands off the Supreme Court" was the watchword offered tonight to those opposed to President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge it, by Herbert Hoover in a speech before the Union League Club here..

Eight students of Fordham College will deliver original speeches on topics of contemporary interest at the Annual Varsity Oratorical Contest of that institution to be held in Collins Auditorium on the campus Thursday evening.

The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday characterized Mayor La Guardia's announced intention to sign the bill providing an eighthour day for city hospital employes as "deplorable" and in direct contradiction of his previous position.
Sidney Goldwyn, 32, of New York City died today of injuries received when the automobile in which he was riding skidded off the highway near here and crashed into a tree.

Asking protection for New York's labor and industry from "viciously unfair competition of States in which the labor of children is exploited," the labor committee of the Progressive City Committee yesterday at a special meeting called upon the Assembly for immediate ratification of the Child Labor Amendment.

A large audience was on hand for the annual benefit of the Treasurers Club of America held last evening at the New Amsterdam Theatre. It marked the forty-sixth in the series of such entertainments sponsored by the organization,

Following an autopsy performed yesterday on the body of Dr. George Todd, 69 years old, of 110 West Ninety-fourth Street, Dr. Benjamin M. Vance, assistant medical examiner, said that Dr. Todd's death on Saturday night was caused by acute gastritis. Dr. Vance said, however.

A 10-year-old boy sobbed out the story to police today of how ne killed 8-year-old Frederick S. Coburn with his father's rifle while playing "cowboys and Indians." District Attorney Carl J. Hynes said Frederick C. Miller Jr. admitted to him he shot his chum while playing in the Miller house alone last night.

Mrs. Hay Battaile Clayton, member of a Colonial Virginia family, died here today; She was a daughter of the late Dr. Benjamin Robinson Battaile, a surgeon in the Confederate Army, and a great-granddaughter of Christopher Robinson, a royal secretary of the Colonial Virginia colony.

Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, Minister of War and head of Germany's newly re-created military machine, told a distinguished memorial day gathering today the Reich had strengthened the world conception of morality by "tearing up the iniquitous Versailles treaty."

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary will arrive this afternoon after two months' absence from this port with a new staff captain on board, R. J. Finlow. He was formerly staff captain of the Georgic and is making his first voyage as executive officer of the Queen Mary.

Major Joseph Eustace Chilton, for more than a half-century a leader in the development of the Kanawha Valley, died today at his St. Albans home at the age of 81. Major Chilton was a brother of for mer United States Senator W. E. Chilton and a law partner of former Governor William A. McCorkle.

Declaring that "time is pressing," Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh, in a statement today said that tomorrow night "would not be too early for a favorable vote" on his resolution urging Congress to defeat President Roosevelt's court reform program.

Since he accepted the call to head a nation-wide movement against President' Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court, Frank E. Gannett, Rochester newspaper publisher, has received hundreds of letters from all parts of the country and nearly as many contributions, Mr. 'Gannett said yesterday over a WABC-Columbia Broadcasting network.

A group of members of the Penn Athletic Club arrivedd today to participate in the first annual Winter golf tournamentt of the organization on the St. Augustine links. The championship will commence tomorrow with the playing of the qualifying round. Match play will continue through Wednesday.
Bill Terry's worries concerning a suitable understudy for his iron - man catcher, Gus* Mancuso, which at times became more than mildly acute last Summer, may be considerably lightened this year.

Fortunately for seven students sleeping on the third and fourth floors of the fourth entry in Patton Dormitory at Princeton University, Kirkland B. Alexander Jr., a senior of Detroit, stayed late at a dance and did not return to his dormitory until about 7 o'clock this morning.

To dramatize peace time heroism, Mrs. J. Sergeant Cram, for twenty years an ardent leader of this country's peace movement, announced yesterday plans to award six residents of this city with silver cups, suitably engraved, for acts which have saved the lives of their fellow-citizens.

The shoot at the Westchester Country Club today attracted a field of eight. In the singles the scratch cup went to C. H. Goudiss, who had 40 out of 50 targets. The handicap prize was won by S. Johnson, who had 46. Johnson also annexed the handicap honor at doubles with 42.

President Roosevelt, by permitting a vacancy in the local Federal courts to exist for more than a year, added to the congestion in the calendars, which since has been relieved, David Steckler, chairman of a special committee of the League Opposed to Remaking the Supreme Court, asserted yesterday in a report, copies of which will be sent to the President, the Attorney General and all members of Congress.
Dr. J. V. De Porte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Health Department, reported today there were 632 deaths in the up-State area from gas poisoning in the period 1931-1935.

Loud-speakers in central streets and squares of Warsaw and other towns, posters all over the country and leaflets distributed on long-distance trains announced tonight to the Polish nation the creation of the new government party by Colonel Adam Koc, commander of the Pilsudski Legionnaires, who appealed by radio to all Polish citizens to join the new organization.

Political tension continues here over the government's attitude toward the Fascist Iron Guard. A Cabinet meeting held yesterday at the home of Constantine Bratianu, Liberal, was attended by Premier George Tatarescu and by the presidents of the Chamber and Senate.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Stratford Johnston of Scarsdale, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Johnston, to Penn Harvey Holsapple, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle Taylor Holsapple, also of Scarsdale.
Spokesmen for fifteen standard railway labor unions conferred here today on a program which will call for a wage increase to be demanded of the nation's railways soon.
Mystery surrounds report that a train carrying Europe-bound passengers for the transsiberian express was wrecked west of Harbin and twenty-four foreign passengers were kidnapped.

A Westchester County park police captain and fourteen patrolmen heard the Federal Music Project's Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra play Beethoven's Seventh symphony at the County Center this afternoon while awaiting an expected "sit-down" strike of discharged WPA choral singers.
The Rev. Newman L. Heroy of Accord, N. Y., member of the first graduating class of Cornell University, in 1872, died on Friday in Benedictine Hospital in Kingston at the age of 87.

Lawrence Gilbert, 25 years old, a writer, son of Mrs. Adelia B. Gilbert of this city and the late Clinton W. Gilbert, former Washington newspaper correspondent, died today in Muhlenberg Hospital of a skull fracture received when he was struck down by an automobile said to have been driven by William Dafcik, 20, of Plainfield.
The vote by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in Congress last week:

Because of his alleged reliance on force for the settlement of labor disputes in Indiana, former Governor Paul McNutt is "definitely not the type of man to represent the United. States during this formative period of the Philippine Republic,"

Kirsten Flagstad, the Norwegian dramatic soprano, will sing leading Wagnerian roles on three successive days at the Metropolitan Opera House next week. In the season's first performance of "Goetterdaemmerung" on that Tuesday afternoon she will be the Bruennhilde.

Jenny, skippered by Leonard Romagna, and Dampants, sailed by Everett and Buddy Morris, tied for first place today in the Class D races that featured the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's rain-swept dinghy regatta.

Williams College trustees today announced the appointment of Dr. Elliot M. Grant of Smith College as Professor of Romanic Languages, and Dr. Peyton Hurt, assistant librarian of the University of California, as librarian.

Proffessor John Dewey, Columbia University authority on education, addressing the John Dewey Society here today, urged that the freedom of schools-be maintained in order that they may "give direction to social change."
If Our present civilization is to survive, man as a whole must be understood by science, Dr. Alexis Carrel of the Rockefeller Institute of New York told a University of Illinois audience today.

Reiterating his opposition to President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court, Senator Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana, declared in an address on the radio tonight that "we had better have no Supreme Court at all than to have a Supreme Court which is subservient to any one man."

The Dayton Rubber Company of Dayton, Ohio, has bought the plant and equipment of the McClaren Rubber Company of Charlotte, original producers of McClaren tires, according to A. L. Freelander, president of the Ohio concern.

The wholesale price index on Feb. 10 was 105.6, against 105.5 on Feb. 3. Import goods, particularly non-ferrous metals, rubber and colonial wares, showed sharp rises, while home agricultural and industrial products were unchanged.

Dan Topping, sportsman and official of the Brooklyn Baseball Club, and Pat di Cicco, actors' agent, exchanged blows in a night club here early today, but "both missed so often it got dull," to quote W. S. Van Dyke, screen director.
If the baseball player is a holdout, the club owner might be considered a hold-in. At least, that's the way some of the reluctant signers of Yankee contracts view the strained situation.
Pete Morneau of St. Pamphile, Que., drove his mixed team of dogs to victory in the annual ninety-mile Quebec international dogsled derby today.

Liberal selling of lard by packers and tired speculative holders, combined with only a. moderate demand, lowered prices here last week, with the March and July deliveries off 40 cents a hundredweight at the close, while May declined 42 1/2 cents compared with the previous week's finish. March closed at $12.20;
Professor Wallace M. Lindsay, one of the foremost classical scholars of Great Britain, died today of injuries suffered in an automobile accident. He was 79 years old.
The thirty-third annual mid-Winter festivities of Choate School, just ended, were attended by 110 girls as guests.

The new elastic decree of the foreign exchange- board is viewed here as foreshadowing a more stringent control of trading in securities. As was expected, not only has the decree been extended to the class of transactions in foreign securities, for which official permits may be required, but it vaguely added that similar restrictions might be imposed on any kind of securities whatever.

Prices of hogs were easier last week, with the top of $10.40 a hundredweight made on Wednesday. This was the same as the previous week, while a year ago $10.50 was the best. Friday's average of $10.05 compared with $10.20 the week before and of $10.25 a year ago.
Wild fowlers in sixteen States already have organized State committees to carry on the "Ducks Unlimited" program, it was announced yesterday by More Game Birds Foundation.
With two bullet wounds and with marks of a beating evident, the body of Mrs. Louise Adair, 24, who disappeared last Monday night, was recovered today from the Delaware River.

A 1937 soil-conservation program designed to enable the farmer to outguess the weather and protect himself against droughts and dust storms or make the most of bumper conditions was announced today by H. R. Tolley, Agricultural Adjustment Administrator.

Miss Ethel du Pont, fiance of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., was operated on at Emergency Hospital today for acute appendicitis. The operation was successful and Miss du Pont is resting comfortably, Dr. Ross T. McIntire, White House physician, said.

The British authorities here were aware that the international ban intended to prevent any more foreign volunteers from entering Spain was supposed to become effective last midnight, but they said they received no new orders or instructions for enforcing this ban.

The British Board of Trade's index of industrial production for the last quarter of 1936, based on the average of 1930 as 100, was 132.1, compared with 122.4 in the preceding quarter and 120.7 for the last quarter of 1935.
Four persons, three of them unconscious, were carried down ladders by firemen early yesterday morning from the top floor of the four-story building at 751 President street, Brooklyn.

At Albany today a public hearing will be held before the Judiciary Committee of the Assembly on the question of ratifying the Federal child labor amendment. A number of delegations will appear before the committee to argue for or against such action. But the argument on both sides has been stated on so many occasions and at such length that all members of the Assembly must be thoroughly familiar with it.

Dr. Gregorio Maranon, Spanish biologist and Liberal leader, one of the founders of the Spanish Republic, in an Jna terview with the Petit Parilien, expressed his disillusionment in Republican Spain and his remorse for his part in creating it.

Thirty-one nationally known educators sent a telegram to President Roosevelt tonight, endorsing his proposal for modifying the Supreme Court and asking the inclusion of laymen representing various interests among its members.

Funeral services were held for James Neilson, member of the board of trustees and oldest alumnus of Rutgers University, today at the First Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Dr. Cordie J. Culp, pastor of the church, officiated.

Manuel Luis Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, who arrived in New York Friday afternoon en route to Washington for a conference with President Roosevelt, attended mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning.
The Paris Opera House, modernized and repaired after it was damaged by fire last September, reopened tonight with a gala performance of Jules Massenet's "Ariane."
Benito Mussolini, as Minister of War, has ordered a test mobilization of more than 1,000,000 men within the next few months, a communique announced tonight.

Sidney B.'Wood Jr., former Wimbledon champion and member, of the American Davis Cup team, willstage a comeback eampaign:on-the tennis courts this year- that will take him to Europe and embrace the leading grass court fixtures of the East. It may also-earn him a, berth again on the Davis Cup team.

Losing more than half its normal circulation because of heavy rains, the Rollins Animated Magazine, which is usually "published" outof-doors, presented its tenth annual edition today from three halls on the Rollins College campus as a Founder's week feature.

Labor must purge itself of racketeers within its ranks, M. D. Griffith, executive vice president of the New York Board of Trade, said yesterday at the monthly forum meeting held at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.
McGill University of Montreal and Harvard today entered the semifinal week of the International Intercollegiate Hockey League race unbeaten and with the championship definitely between them.

Miss Beryl Elise Fine, daughter of Harry Fine of Laurel, Mass., and the late Mrs. Fine, was married here yesterday to Nathan W. Goldstein, son of Mrs. Harry B. Goldstein of this city and the late Mr. Goldstein, in the Colonnades of Essex House.
The New York Rovers evidently can take so much and no more. Throughout the season they have been an almost constant victim of Atlantic City, but yesterday afternoon they struck back.

Rallying down the stretch as the leaders faltered under a par-cracking pace, big Ed Dudley of Augusta, Ga., and little Dick Metz of Chicago tied today for first place in the $3,000 Thomasville open golf tournament, with totals of 284, four strokes under standard figures for the Glen Arven course.

Edward Garnett, author, playwright and critic, died today at the age of 69. Through his and his wife's translations from the chief Russian novelists, the writings of some of the most honored names in Russian literature became familiar to the English-speaking world.

Victor Chenkin, who has made his character song interpretations an outstanding art, appeared in a program at the Alvin Theatre last night after an absence of two years. The recital was for the benefit of the medical bureau of the American Friends of Spanish Democracy. A large audience received Mr. Chenkin's performances warmly.

A pygmy orchid, a yellow, brown-flecked bloom about the size of a dime and the only known specimen of its kind, is on display at the annual exhibition of the Shaw's Garden orchid collection, one of the finest in the world.
A severe wind swept through Charlotte and neighboring Concord tonight, demolishing some houses and doing other heavy damage, but only one serious injury was reported.
Arthur Burgess McDonald died today, the second bank president in his family to die in a week. His age was 66. He was president of the People's Security Trust Company.

Slight earth tremors were reported here tonight, but there was no known damage. The Star-Gazette said that several persons had telephoned concerning "an earthquake," saying their homes trembled slightly.

Announcing that purchases of wool by United States interests increased more than 600 per cent in value in the final 1936 semester, compared with 1935, the totals being [Pound]3,003,444 and [Pound]424,750, Sir Henry S. Gullett, Minister in charge of trade treaties, has suggested that continuance of such purchases might induce Washington to review the high duties on Australian wool importation which have increased owing to a shortage of the staple for home consumption.

Every factor except labor uncertainties points to increasing activity in the steel industry, according to the magazine Steel, out today. All lines of domestic business are seeking steel in nearly every form and foreign countries are insisting on more American tonnage.

William Becker, travel bureau, in 137 4th av.; Francis W. Roudebush, architect, in 654 Madison Av.; Harry Miller, Shoe uppers, in 38 W. 48th St. Phillip-Jones Corp., store in 1,225 Broadway: Bernard Feldman, in 32 E. 57th St.: Sports Illusrated, Inc., in 139 E. 57th ST.: Ivan Liermark, in 66 W. 125 th St.: Pearl Weithzner and Beatrice Lassen, in 25 E. 48th ST. through Harry Thoens co.: Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker.

The Boston Bruins broke a deadlock with the idle New York Rangers and gained sole possession of second place in the American division of the National Hockey League tonight by coming from behind twice to tie the Canadiens, 2-2, in a stiring overtime game before a crowd of 16,800 at the Boston Garden.

The General Telephone Corporation and subsidiaries show in the preliminary report for 1936 a net income of $1,314,839, compared with $985,950 for 1935, and a balance, after preferred dividends, of $1,094,300, against $875,680. Preferred dividend allowances are not comparable, as the preferred stock dividend liability dates only from July 1, 1935.
Sixty were killed in a recent three-hour battle between Honduran rebels and government forces near Progreso, according to reports received here from General Justo Umana, commanding the rebel forces.

Dog teams from Nome or Kotsebue will speed emergency medical supplies to Barrow, Alaska's most northerly tip, where fire destroyed the government hospital, the Bureau of Indian Affairs office announced today.

Southern Boulevard, 775 (10-2720); Beinfish Realty Corp. to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 1 Madison Av., extends mtg. to Dec. 1, 194l, at 5 per cent; $92,000. Southern Boulevard (10-2720); same extends mtg. to Dec. 1, 1941, at 5 per cent; $101,200.
Nine agencies of the government awarded eighty contracts valued at $2,462,290 under the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Feb. 18, the Labor Department announced today.

There is no "policy"; there is no program; there is no stated ambition. But there is an unvarying tendency. This epitome of our country's Far Eastern policy, in an article, "America From Across the Pacific," by NATHANIEL PEFFER, in the current Pacific Affairs, will be questioned by few students of diplomacy.

Frank Bowden climaxed a week of brilliant play by downing Leon ard Hartman, the defending title holder, by 6-3, 6-4, 7-5, in the final round of the Brooklyn indoor tennis championship at the 106th Regiment Armory yesterday.

Miss Mildred Torrance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram V. Torrance of Erie, Pa., was married here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church to Dr. Edward Parker Dennis, also of Erie, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. David Nichols Dennis. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Murray S. Howland of this city.
The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin asserted in a radio address today that if "we forsake the Constitution we forsake all liberty--even though we barter it for a promise of new liberty."

Enactment of uniform national laws on marriage and divorce to protect individuals from the "injustices" resulting from their "exusable ignorance" of the varying State regulations was recommended by Justice Jacob Panken of the Domestic Relations Court in an opinion made public yesterday.

Charles Benzer, 22-year-old Y. M. C. A. worker of Brooklyn, N. Y., was killed and two companions slightly hurt here today in a collision between their automobile and a heavy truck. Joseph Barriser and Fred Steinweiss were treated in a local hospital.

Announcement that the international sugar conference for the restriction of production will be held in April, and that Cuba and Great Britain have signed a reciprocal trade treaty, has created considerable anxiety here.
The return of the Bank of France for Feb. 12 shows a decrease of 191,000,000 francs in bills discounted and one of 386,000,000 francs in advances against collateral and bonds.
An amateur league consisting of six Manhattan clubs and six Bronx teams was organized yesterday at a meeting of the Empire State Baseball Federation held at the Hotel New Yorker.

Announcement has been made by Miss Margaret Hayde of 642 Second Street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of her niece, Miss Marion O'Reilly, to Joseph F. Kelly, son of Mrs. James Edward Kelly of South Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Kelly.
Sir Walter Monekton, Attorney General of the Duohy of Cornwall, arrived here last night from Cologne and was met at the railway station by the Duke of Windsor who drove with him to Enresfeld Castle.

Foreign trade statistics show that while imports of raw materials have been greatly increased because of the industrial recovery in France, exports have remained stationary, with the result that there was an enormous increase in the trade deficit in the last month, to more than 1,500,000,000 francs for January.

The hesitation in last week's financial markets may have indicated a natural pause after the 30point average advance in stocks during 1936,' or it may have reflected a wish to see what would happen next in the labor-union controversy.
Lou Ambers, lightweight champion of the world, will meet Al Roth, sturdy Bronx battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight.

Now that the automobile strike has been settled and John L. Lewis's attention is temporarily distracted in negotiating a new coal contract, there has been a tendency to forget the danger of an industrial war which, if it occurs, may make the General Motors sit-down look like child's play.

The Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York will be the beneficiary of an entertainment to be known as a "Prophecy of Spring Fashion Review," which will take place the afternoon of March 18 at Sherry's. Later in the afternoon tea will be served.

The Civilian Conservation Corps during 1936 planted 460,000,000 young trees and seedlings, or three times the aggregate of such plantings by all agencies, public and private, yearly prior to 1933, Robert Fechner, director of Emergency Conservation Work, reported today.
HAVING WONDERFUL. TIME, a comedy in three acts and nine scenes, by Arthur Kober. Scenery by Stewart Chaney; staged and produced by Marc Connelly. At the Lyceum Theatre.

Colonel Clarence S. Ridley, Governor of the Canal Zone, sailed today on the Ancon for New York to appear at hearings on Congressional appropriations at Washington and also to confer with the Secretary of War on Panama Canal matters.

The Labor Ministry, led by Premier Albert G. Ogilvie, won a sweeping victory in the Tasmanian general election Saturday. The last previous election, in June, 1934, gave Labor fifteen seats and the Nationalists fourteen with the one Douglas Social Credit member supporting the Ministry.
Premier Leon Blum in his speech at Saint Nazaire today admitted that the government was meeting serious financial difficulties, but declared he would change neither his Cabinet nor his policy.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,849,555,000. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

The Rev. Leo Leonard Twinem, former rector of St. John's ??rotestant Episcopal Church, Sanford and Wilson Avenues, Flushing, Queens, announced yesterday that he had taken the initial step to enter the Roman Catholic Church as a teacher.

The Panama Pacific liner Virginia arrived yesterday from California via Colon and Cuba with 316 passengers, the first liner to come from the West Coast since the start of the seamen's strike last October.

The prevailing anxiety over price increases, which naturally have furnished a basis for clamors for salary increases, is an irritating problem of the moment. Living costs have been increased mainly by the rise in the cost of imported products as the result of devaluation of the franc.

Addressing meetings of steel and rubber workers here today, two organizers for John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization denounced Governor Hoffman for his warning that. sit-down strikes in New Jersey will be broken up at any cost.

A hundred years from now the historian will say that the underprivileged and the laboring man were "right about the main matters," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive. Discussing "The Dangers of Privilege," Dr. Fosdick said:
Although no fresh favorable impulse came from corporation reports, business sentiment improved this week.
Two thousand anarchist "pistoleros" govern Catalonia, and their incapacity to wage war seems likely to settle the fate of Madrid and give General Francisco Franco the victory.
Recent charges by Assemblyman Phelps that submetering is causing tenants to lose $10,000,000 a year and should be eliminated were disputed yesterday in a statement by Arthur C. Bang,

Lou Salica of Brooklyn failed tonight in an effort to win the world bantamweight championship from Sixto Escobar of Puerto Rico, losing the decision in a hard and cleanly fought fifteen-round bout. It was their third meeting and Escobar's second victory.

Boston today celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of the inauguration of the allbreed exhibitions of the Eastern Dog Club. It was a worthwhile occasion for Down Easters turned out in the greatest number that has ever been known for a first day in historic old Mechanics Building.

After a visit to Santo Domingo and inspection of the site for the Columbus Memorial Lighthouse commemorating the discovery of America, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, chairman of the United States committee said he would urge as strongly as possible that the project proceed without further delay.

Miss Helen P. McCormick, social worker and attorney, died yesterday morning in Brooklyn Hospital. She failed to rally after an operation performed Wednesday for an intestinal ailment. Miss McCormick, who was 47 years old and lived at 97 St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, entered the hospital Feb. 13.
A liquidating market in oats here last week was due to tired holders, who found the market thinly supplied with buying support.

The Macmillan Company annotices that it will move today to prevent further use of Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind" "as a football in price wars and 'Ioss' leader' sales." As a first step in this direction, the company reports, it will offer dealers in Illinois and California contracts under the Fair Trade Acts of those States, and will extend the agreement to other States as soon as the way is cleared legally.

The New York Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, yesterday advanced to the Eastern semi-finals of the national challenge' cup competition of the U. S. F. A. by defeating St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn, 2 to 1, before a crowd of 3,000 at Starlight Park.
Manhattan's second defeat of the season and the continued fine showing of Fordham featured a busy week in intercollegiate basketball.
United Air Lines today announced recovery from San Francisco Bay of the right motor and right wheel of the skyliner which plunged into the water Feb. 9, carrying eleven persons to death.

Publication of the government's plans for raising [Pound]1,500,000,000 for national defense in the next five years, while not daunting the City, has resulted in widely varying reactions in the security markets.

For the third time in forty-eight hours R. J. Aitchison, president of the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation, today rejected a proposal that he meet Governor Horner and a strike committee in Springfield to seek settlement of the sitdown strike which has halted work at the company's $1,500,000 North Chicago plant since Wednesday.

Before one of the largest crowds to gather around the tank at Grand Central Palace since the National Sportsmen's Show opened, sixty anglers yesterday tried to make the onlookers forget about the electric light shining down upon the water and transport them instead to the banks of a shaded pool.

Official Britain, having made the world aware of what it can and will do in the matter of rearmament to insure having a real influence in keeping Europe peaceful, is now more or less in the position of waiting to hear what Chancellor Adolf Hitler will do toward the same end.
The most important task today for Jews and Christians is to unite in a defense of the God of Democracy, Rabbi Morton M. Berman said yesterday in his sermon before the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall.

As artillery thundered and a score of bands played the Soviet funeral hymn, Joseph Stalin, Marshal Klementy E. Voroshiloff, Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Lazar M. Kaganovitch and other Soviet leaders carried the ashes of their dead comrade, Gregory K. Ordjonikidze, to the appointed place in the Kremlin wall.

Action was taken yesterday by Prosecutor John J. Breslin of Bergen County, N. J., foreshadowing a request for additional funds and assistance to investigate the murder of Norman Redwood and its background of labor racketeering by union leaders, contractors and politicians.

Many religious systems in American life will be "overthrown before the onrush of fascism and communism but the true Church will survive the storm of time," the Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The Rev. John Paul Jones of the Union Church, Eightieth Street and Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, defended "sit-down" strikers in a sermon at the church yesterday. "Of course sit-down strikes are illegal," Mr. Jones said, "but let the church point out that there is a question of industrial ethics as yet unanswered.

Charging that the profits of communism were directed to the coffers of international bankers, the Rev. Peter Baptist Duffee, a member of the Franciscan Order stationed at St. Francis Roman Catholic Church, 135 West Thirty-first Street, New York City, told the congregation of St. Mary's Abbey Church here this afternoon that both of Russia's Five-Year Plans were financed by international bankers.

George R. Nutter, well-known Boston lawyer, died this morning at the Massachusetts General Hospital. His age was 73. Mr. Nutter, past president of the Massachusetts Bar Association and of the Boston Chamber of Commerce, succumbed to the septic poisoning that had confined him to the hospital since September.

Since today is a holiday, most of the new exhibitions will open tomorrow. Today many galleries will be closed. The Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum and the Brooklyn Museum will all omit the customary Monday fee and admission will be free.

A slow, sagging market developed in corn here last week, with closing of spreads between the near and distant months and buying of near futures against sales of the more deferred deliveries. Country buying was not so keen as it had been.
Two thousand Ethiopians were arrested today for questioning in connection with the attempted assassination of Marshal Rodolfo Graziani by hatives hurling hand grenades.

A miniature of James Madison, painted by Charles Willson Peale when Madison was a Princeton undergraduate, has been lent to the university library for its first public exhibition, it was announced today by Dr. James Thayer Gerould, librarian.

To the Editor of The New York TIMES: The President's court retirement message has caused much uncalled-for fuss and fury. Some who have never read a Supreme Court decision and who know little of the actual history of the court have been most positive in their views. Perhaps this is as it should be; it provides entertainment for every one, and for many an outlet for pent-up partisan emotions.

What to do with hard liquor is a problem in five Southern States this week. Wet and dry Georgians, after arguments before a legislative committee last week, wait the committee's action on two bills to put the State into the wet column.
Despite its fast tempo, 1937 finds the statute books of many States still cluttered with obsolete laws enacted in the horse and buggy days.

Taxes cost $18 a room yearly for the average apartment dweller and $29 a room on the average city house, according to the report of a nation-wide survey made by the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company.

The question of whether the Mexican Supreme Court will be called upon to reverse its decision supporting the holding of oil leases by foreign companies is brought to the forefront here by the revelation that a law has been drafted looking toward eventual control by a government company of all petroleum leases.

The General Cable Corporation, of which Dwight R. G. Palmer is president, has sent communications to the chairmen of the Finance Committee of the United States Senate and of the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives citing reasons why the tax of 4 cents a pound on copper imports, which will expire on June 30, should not be extended.

" Irene," the 1919 Ziegfeld musical that played 670 consecutive performances at the Vanderbilt Theatre, with Edith Day and Walter Regan in the leads, and became a film vehicle for Colleen Moore in 1926, has been bought by R.-K.-O.Radio for Ginger Rogers, to follow her current "Vivacious Lady."

The city's new traffic code went into effect yesterday. Tomorrow the new uniform fines for some thirty-eight minor violations of the code will be effective in the magistrates' courts, and the crop of week-end violations will be made known.

E.M. DELAFIELD frequently blames some one else for her books. In the case of her new one, "I Visit the Soviets" (Harper, $2.50), she makes it plain that her American publisher is responsible for both the visit and the volume. She says that she was plied with champagne and caviar and promised money.

Almost Spring-like weather was marred yesterday by misty clouds that fulfilled threats of rain with intermittent drizzles during the afternoon and heavy rain last night. It was the seventh rainy Sunday of eight Sundays since the first of the year.

With yesterday afternoon's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, Carlos Chavez concluded his fortnight's activities as guest conductor of that organization. There was sturdy applause for the visiting leader from Mexico after all of his offerings, and especially at the termination of each half of the program. An audience of good size was present and left little doubt that the director had acquired a host of admirers during his stay.

At a time when the people of this country are considering constitutional questions of high importance, no more timely tribute can be paid to the memory of the statesman whose birthday we honor today than by recalling and weighing again the words of wisdom spoken in a familiar passage of his Farewell Address:

Four persons were killed and thirteen injured, several critically, last night when an automobile driven by William Tope, 20, of Payne crashed into a group of persons gathered at the scene of a previous accident, fifteen miles north of Van Wert.

New York City's new code of traffic regulations went into effect yesterday with a minimum of friction. The Police Department's Bureau of Operations will not receive reports on the number of summonses issued until this morning, but LieutenantHarry Schreiber. in charge yesterday, said that the new rules were operating smoothly.
Mrs. David P. Thomas of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Thomas, to Russell Bryden Waddell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Waddell of East Orange.

Under a stiff east-by-north wind twenty-six dinghies sailed today in the regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club and Frank Campbell came home a winner in the Class B one-design races with Bill Dodge of Mystic (R. I.), the leader in Class X.

Three subscriptions each of $25,000 lead a list of purchases of New York World's Fair debentures announced yesterday by Richard Whitney, head of the exposition's bond sales committee, which has distributed $19,162,000 of the $27,829,500 issue to date. The three $25,000 subscribers are The New York American, The New York Evening Journal, and the Christian Feizenspan Brewing Company.

Jose Iturbi, Spanish pianist, will give a concert in the Mosque Theatre here tomorrow night under the auspices of the Mount Carmel Guild, Catholic charity organization of Essex County. Proceeds will be used to pay the expenses of the guild's kitchens for the poor and homeless.
John Zenko, 35, of Coaldale, Pa., and A. J. Oswald, 25, of Perkasie, were killed and four others were injured in a head-on automobile crash during a fog near here today.

The engagement of Miss Mary Watkinson Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Cole of this city, to William Edward Jordan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis E. Jordan of Fairlawn, Cobourg, Ont., has been announced by her parents.

Lamb is the outstanding meat value, although pork and veal are both slightly less costly than at this period last year, it was reported yesterday by the weekly Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets. All poultry is selling at bargain prices, the guide said, with especially good values in turkeys, ducks and broiling chickens.

The electric lighting system in the Bergen district of the city began to fail about 7:15 tonight and for more than twenty minutes some neighborhoods were in total darkness and others had only flickering illumination. The interruption was attributed to a short circuit in the Garfield Avenue substation by officials of the Public Service Gas and Electric Company.
Louis P. Griswold will give a dinner on Wednesday at the Meadowbrook Restaurant for Miss Margaret Smith Salvage and James Potter Polk, who will be married on April 9.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh rested here today and an authoritative source said the colonel would visit Delhi, the Indian capital, shortly to discuss possibilities of linking India in a world-wide air mail chain formed by alliance of Pan American Airways with the British Imperial Airways.

Opposition to the Federal Child Labor Amendment which he characterized,as a means of "goosestepping youth" was expressed in his sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, 263 West Eighty-sixth Street.

Dr. Albert Plesman, director of the Royal Dutch Air Line, will arrive in New York Thursday on the Europa to discuss with the United States Government the opening of airplane service between Surabaya, Java, and Manila, Philippine Islands.
Jack and Dick Durrance, brothers and members of the Dartmouth team, took first and third places today their team won the Eastern amateur downhill skiing championship.

The will of Robert Morris, one of the men who financed the American Revolution, but who spent many of the later years of his life in prison because he was unable to meet his debts, has been found by the Federal Writers Project in the office of the Register of Deeds of McDowell County, at Marion, N. C.

Steel and copper shares rose on rearmament news; other stocks irregular on week; turnover, 13,100,150 shares. Second-grade rails higher, United States Government and other bonds mixed; transactions, $94,929,000.

The second act of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" formed the major offering of last night's opera concert at the Metropolitan. With the exception of a duet from "La Favorite" and two orchestral numbers, the rest of the program consisted of vocal solos from operatic works of Meyerbeer, Thomas and Verdi.
Walter L. Fry, who went on strike himself when his employes quit work, vowed today he would "sit right here indefinitely" and "show industry one way to end all sitdowns.
The Spanish Insurgents have launched a new major offensive in an effort to break through to the sea in the northeast, government dispatches reported today.

When Chancellor Adolf Hitler appeared at the automobile show Saturday, observers who had not seen him recently remarked that during the last year especially, his face had grown heavier and grimmer. His voice is vigorous, his color more florid and his straight hair untouched by gray.

Enough boxing to satisfy the most ardent ring fan will be on view at Madison Square Garden today when the intercity Golden Gloves amateur tournament, conducted by The Daily News A. A., will be presented. Two sessions are scheduled; with sixty-four fights listed for each performance.
Alvin O. Lombard, whose invention of the lag-tread tractor brought him world fame, died at his home here today. He was born in Springfield, Me., eighty years ago.

Albert Mead Peck, lifelong resident of Greenwich and one of the oldest members of Acacia Lodge, 85, F. and A. M., died today at the age of 83. For twenty years he was engaged with his brother, the late Elias Peck, Civil War veteran, in the plumbing and hardware business here.

Alexander Meyer, young Downingi town farmer, admitted today in a new signed confession, according to Philip J. Reilly, Assistant District Attorney, that -he deliberately rant down Helen Moyer, 16 years old with his truck so that he could attack her.

The renewed agitation by Austrian legitimists for a Hapsburg restoration is believed in diplomatic quarters here to have accelerated the visit by Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath of Germany, who will arrive in Vienna tomorrow for a two-day official stay.

Henry Brown, 24 years old, a Negro of 1,025 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, was held in $2,500 bail for the grand jury when he was arraigned in Felony Court yesterday after he had been arrested on a charge of stealing jewelry valued at $600 from the apartment of Mrs. Harry Simonian, 433 West Thirtyfourth Street.

The geological formation of the mineralized area of Western Quebec is similar to that in the rich copper, nickel, gold and silver areas of Ontario, according to reports prepared by the Quebec Bureau of Mines.

An organizer for the United Automobile Workers of America told a union mass meeting tonight that the organization's next objective would be recognition as the sole collective bargaining agency for employes of the Chrysler Corporation.
Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Levy gave a cocktail party today at their villa for Mr. and Mrs. Grover Whalen, guests of William Theodore Hopps at Casa Eleda.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is due to dock this afternoon with 1,000 passengers at the foot of West Fiftieth Street for the first time this year.
Nine persons were injured, three seriously, when a Greyhound bus bound from New York to the South struck a bridge abutment near here early today.
After some talk about forming two rival organizations of Broadway press agents, it was decided to merge both groups at a meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Algonquin.

All except one of Broadway's twenty-seven attractions will have special, or Washington's Birthday, matinees today. That single exception is "Victoria Regina," whose star-Helen Hayes-spends every Monday afternoon rehearsing for her radio appearance early that evening.

The church must regain her "conquering spirit," the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street. "This is not to be in an arrogant, superior manner," he said, "but in the humble, confident, certain spirit of the Master."
The Manhattan Symphony Orchestra, directed by Eugene Plotnikoff, presented the first of a fresh series of "new talent" concerts as a paid attraction at the WPA Theatre of Music last night.

A range of opinion in the faculty of Cornell University's Law School on President Roosevelt's proposal to revise the set-up of the Supreme Court was uncovered in a series of interviews conducted by The Cornell Daily Sun.

At least nine persons were injured, one of them critically, when the Milwaukee Railroad's Southwestern Limited passenger train was derailed in crossing a water-damaged culvert about 8 A. M., Central standard time, today near Rockton, Ill.. twelve miles north of here.

Special tribute to the United States naval policy in regard to big battleships is paid by Hector C. Bywater, British writer on naval subjects, in the current number of Army Ordnance, the journal of the Army Ordnance Association.

President Angell of Yale University, speaking tonight at exercises marking the semi-centennial of Dwight Hall, which carries on the social service and interdenominational Christian activities of the student body, said that there. would always be work for such an organization on the strictly intellectual and philosophical side of religious experience.

Annual memorial mass of the 165th Infantry (old Sixty-ninth Regiment) at Holy Cross Church, 329 West Forty-second Street, 10 A. M. Annual memorial mass of New York Chapter Knights of Columbus, St. Patrick's Cathedral, 10:30 A. M.
The waters of Lake Champlain today claimed the lives of a father and his two sons, who plunged through thin ice as they were returning from fishing. A fourth member of the party scrambled to safety.
Before Paavo Nurmi opened up a new vista for two-milers some twelve years ago, the world's outdoor record was Alf Shrubb's 9:09.6 and the indoor mark was Joie Ray's 9:08.4.
A driving snowstorm hindered warm-up competition for the national amateur ski-jumping tournament today, but could not prevent half a dozen jumpers serving notice the American record is in danger.

About 200-of the delegates to the American Youth Congress who yesterday marched on the White House and staged a "sit-down strike" in behalf of the Lundeen bill providing $500,000,000 for jobs, scholarships and vocational training. for American youth braved a soaking rain this morning to stand at the foot of the Washington Monument in honor of the nation's first President.

Despite a favorable trade balance in January, Reichbank officials refuse to admit the possibility of a replenishment of reserves. An explanation of the deterioration in the exchange situation is advanced by the Frankfurter Zeitung, which affirms that the officially reported export surplus of 550,000,000 marks is higher than the real figures.

The foreign exchange and stock markets this week were under the influence of various rumors. First, it was said that the Cabinet was about to be remolded to take in some members of the Centers not belonging to the Popular Front.

Trained experts, like physicians, should be set to the task of preventing divorce by re-establishing a sense of responsibility and reawakening love, John Haynes Holmes said yesterday in a sermon before the congregation of the Community Church assembled in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. Mr. Holmes also took the Hollywood motion-picture colony sharply to task for its attitude toward divorce.

Unemployment insurance laws cover about 46 per cent of the working population of thirty-five States and the District of Columbia, where such legislation has been enacted to conform with the Federal Social Security Act, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

Charles Coit Tyler, who was vice president in charge of all manufacturing operations of five Remington Arms Company plants during the World War, died today at his home here. His age was 75. He was born in Jewett City.

The slum-clearance conference called by Bishop William T. Manning for next Sunday at the Cathedral of St. John the' Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, was described yesterday as the result of vision and ideals inspired by the Holy Spirit.
Employers in the wholesale dry goods field carried out yesterday their threat to picket the offices of their employes' union-but the employers did their picketing by proxy.

The mothers of the First Presbyterian Church of Oyster Bay and the pastor, the Rev. Alfred J. Penney, were pleased today with the first test of the baby-parking nursery plan evolved with the hope that it would stimulate church attendance.

A foreign affairs debate in the House of Representatives today elicited a statement that in the five years since the foundation of Manchukuo there have been 2,400 border "incidents" between that protectorate of Japan and Soviet Russia and that the great majority never have been settled.

Prices of cotton for future delivery continued to fluctuate narrowly last week. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 4 to 9 points below those of a week earlier.

Two important upsets occurred In the eighth round of the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday when Frank J. Marshall, former United States champion and leader in the competition, lost his first game to Fred Reinfeld, a predecessor, and A. E.. Santasiere, club champion, bowed to Milton Hanauer, former State titleholder.

Talks in Washington on the restriction of foreign investments were naturally followed here with interest and some apprehension, owing to the large Dutch holdings in the United States and the continued preference among investors and speculators in the Netherlands for all kinds of United States securities.

A typical New York slum will be set up in the nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine next Sunday as the focus for a conference in which representatives of the three dominant faiths in the city will open a campaign for slum clearance.

After touring in Europe and Asia for seven years, Miss Chayele Grober, disease and folk singer, returned in a program of sketches that included Arabian, Yemenite, French and English folk material at the Adelphi Theatre last night.
The Detroit Red Wings, holders of the Stanley Cup, clinched a place in the 1937 National Hockey League playoffs tonight, overwhelming Chicago's Black Hawks by 6 to 0 before 11,681 spectators.

In connection with the departure of a ship for Christmas Island with a wireless operator and equipment, it .w disclosed today an island occupation permit was granted a French company with headquarters in Tahiti.
Comparing GEORGC WASHINGTON'S views on food with LEON TROTSKY'S, who can doubt that the world needs a great many more

The Leader Holding Corporation sold a vacant plot of 20,000 square feet on the south side of Cooper Street, 100 feet east of 207th Street, to a builder for a six-story apartment-house. The plot is 125 by 160 feet and was sold through the Halford Realty Corporation, as broker.
Twenty-five airplanes spent today unsuccessfully searching the coast between here and Brisbane for traces of an airliner missing since Friday with seven persons aboard.

A State subsidy to help the development of probation service in various communities is recommended to the Legislature by the Prison Association of New York in its annual report, made public yesterday.

Irving Epstein, organizer of Local 302 of the Cafeteria Workers Union and one of the eight defendants on trial in the restaurant racket case, will resume the witness stand before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury today.
Severe pain again afflicted Pope Pius today, the twelfth Sunday of his illness. He passed an almost sleepless night.

The improved international outlook and rumors that dividends impounded under the Securities Law will be disbursed induced a firm tone on the Boerse this week. After initial covering by bear speculators, the investing public resumed its buying.

Only three seeded players, two in Class B and one in Class C, survived the quarter-finalrounds in the Westchester division championship tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today. A. B.

Miss Ellen Marie Blakely of Claremont, Calif., for forty-four years a teacher in the Central Turkish Girl's College at Marash, Turkey, died in an emergency hospital here today after having become unconscious in an automobile.

With the opposition to his program to reorganize the Supreme Court growing in intensity, President Roosevelt and his supporters both in and out of Congress plan to concentrate all their forces at once to push through the program.
The third running of the Santa Anita Derby tomorrow promises to be a wild, wide-open scramble among a score or more of crack 3-year-olds battling for the purse of $50,000 added money.

Dr. and Mrs. Glenn Frank, who are house guests of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Mead of Wisconsin Rapids, at the Mead Winter home, were honored by their hosts at a luncheon at the Surf Club today. Mr. and Mrs. Mead were assisted by Mrs. D. Ray Mead, Mrs. George A. Steiner, Mrs. Frank E. Gannett and Mrs. Clark Holbrook.

Mrs. Anna L. Carlin, wife of Christopher L. Carlin, died here Friday at their home, 30 Sheridan Avenue, after a long illness. Two daughters, Margaret and Gertrude, and two sons, J. Herbert and James J. Carlin, also survive.

Still going strong after sessions Friday evening and all day Saturday, members of the National Puzzlers League were still seeking the perfect riddle yesterday at their convention at the Hotel New Yorker.
With the exception of one ranked player, who defaulted, seeded stars progressed as the metropolitan indoor tennis singles tournament started yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.

The-revolutionary battle flags of the thirteen colonies lined the chancel railing of St. Thomas Church yesterday afternoon as more than 2,000 members. and guests of the Sons of the Revolution of the State of New York commemorated the 205th anniversary of the birth of George Washington and paid trib-ute to the memory of members of the society who died during the past year.

Ralph Flanagan, Miami's Olympic swimmer, bettered Johnny Weissmuller's even-year-old national free style record for 200 yards over the short course when he splashed he distance in 1 minute 57.5 seconds in the Biltmore pool today.
Germain G. Glidden of New York, national squash racquets singles champion, and Neil J. Sullivan of Philadelphia, national ruler in 1934, tomorrow will decide ownership of the title for the next year.

Joseph C. Hyman, executive director of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, announced yesterday that a total of 8,831 German Jews had been assisted to emigrate from Germany and the refugee lands during the first ten months of 1936 through the efforts of service agencies affiliatedwith the committee.

Howard Quackenbush, founder and Past Commander of Big Six Post, 1522, Veterans of Foreign Wars, and a well-known member of Typographical Union No. 6, died late Saturday night at his home, 2,668 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, of injuries received the previous evening when he fell on an elevated railway stairway.

Due to a heavy rain lasting too long to permit the seventy-six starters in the seventh annual Winter handicap golf tournament of the New York Athletic Club to complete the-scheduled- eighteen-hole qualifying round today, play was put off until tomorrow.

Members of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., and their guests to the number of 700 occupied the grand ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt last night for the society's annual benefit ball, the proceeds of which are applied to its fund for needy teachers.

Purchase of six thirty-two passenger transport planes, the largest to go into service in the United States, was made public yesterday by Jack Frye, president of the Transcontinental and Western Air Line. The four-engined monoplanes will be built by the Boeing Airplane Company of Seattle. With a gross weight of 42,000 pounds, they will cruise at about 250 miles an hour at their best altitude.

Two youthful representatives of the Women's Swimming Association of New York-Miss Elizabeth Ryan and Miss Helene Rains-triumphed impressively in the feature races of the meet conducted in the Hotel Shelton pool yesterday under the auspices of the Shelton Dolphin Swimming Club.

16th St., 417 E., 25x92; Harry Konowitz to Sadie Levin, 417 E. 16th st.; mtges. $14,000. (Deed dated Jan. 4, 1933). 1st Av., 1,472, 25x85; Bank for Savings to Bosco Realty Corp., 39 Broadway ($38). 105th St., 228-232 E., 50x100.9; Rudolph Stand to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp.; consideration, $1,000; foreclosure.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 91.0, which compares with 90.7 a week before, 90.4 two weeks before, 90.4 three weeks before and 90.2 four weeks before.
Niagara's Purple Eagles resumed their winning ways again today, downing the St. Peter's quintet of Jersey City, 62-30. Frank Bello, New York City boy, starred with a brilliant floor game.

Current banking reports show that the home trade continues to make good progress. Heavy industries remain active, and for them the lack of raw materials and skilled labor is becoming a difficult problem.

Miss Kathleen Meehan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Francis Meehan of Montclair, N. J., will be married to Edward Lester Heywood, son of William Henry Heywood of Brattleboro, Vt., and the late Mrs. Heywood, on the morning of April 3 in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception, Montclair.

There still is life in the New York Americans. Red Dutton's skaters proved that last night when they humbled the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 to 1, in a bruising battle at Madison Square Garden and kept alive their hopes of gaining a play-off berth in the international group of the National Hockey League.
