Alonzo Church, former vice chancellor and first secretary of the Essex County Park Commission, who had a large part in the building of the Essex County park system, died suddenly last hight of a heart attack at his home here. He was 67 years old.

Finishing with 95 out of a possible 100, Peter Garino won the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. J. B. Grier also broke 95 but shot for targets only.
Nearly 1,000 persons attended the hunter trials of the Camden Hunt today. Fifty horses went over the mile course, including twelve fences, ten timber, one chicken coop and one aiken.

President Roosevelt's proposed changes in the Federal judicial system were criticized by several clergymen throughout New York City yesterday. Speaking at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, rector, said:

Many clergymen throughout the city delivered sermons yesterday on George Washington. "Brotherhood Day," the Sunday before Washington's Birthday, also was widely observed. Some of the Brotherhood Day sermons were delivered under the sponsorship of the National Conference of Jews and Christians.
The Crescent Athletic Club basketball team turned back Seton Hall College of South Orange, N. J., 28-26, on the victors' court in :Brooklyn yesterday.

Senator Nye proposed today that the navy manufacture its own armorplate and munitions, as a means to meet the difficulty caused by lack of bids from steel companies on material for the nation's shipbuilding program.
Mrs. F. S. Harris's 6-year-old Breezing Along registered a three-length victory in the mile and seventy yard feature event of the Sunday program at the Fair Grounds today.

The corroded wreckage of an airplane that might be a remnant of the missing Sikorsky amphibian that disappeared in the early Spring of 1929 with four men, including T. Raymond Finucane, a wealthy Rochester, N. Y., business man, was brought here today aboard the fishing schooner Irene and Mabel.

Calling of numerous small lots of foreign securities featured last week's announcements of bonds called for retirement before maturity. The largest individual calls of the week were for several entire issues of industrial and public utility securities.

The long somnolent German Christian Society has announced it will start its church election campaign this week with a regular voters' mass meeting of the type made familiar by the National Socialist party.
Crown Princess Martha of Norway gave birth today to a son at Crown Prince Olaf's palace at Skaugum, near Oslo. The infant is second in line for the throne. Both mother and child are doing well.

Tenants at 721 Walton Avenue, the Bronx apartment building in which nine service employes staged a sit-down strike last week, threatened yesterday to withhold rent payments unless the strikers were reinstated.
Charles L. Snowdon, Pittsburgh coal operator and banker. died in a hospital here today of injuries received in an automobile accident on Feb. 5. His age was 63.
Flames enveloped an altar boy before a congregation in St. Catherine's Church today but prompt action by the priest and a fireman saved him.
The WPA Music Project yesterday afternoon presented the second of its series of ten fortnightly programs dealing with "related forms in music and dance" at the Theatre of Music.

A memorial tablet to the Rev. Dr. Walter Duncan Buchanan, for thirty-five years pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street, was unveiled there yesterday morning by his grandsons. John Messer Lawrence Jr. and Douglass Buchanan Lawrence.

The year-old friction over smuggling into North China flared today into a clash between Korean smugglers, subjects of Japan, and police of the French Concession of Tientsin. After a running street battle in the concession, six Koreans were arrested.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had ordered the National Silver Company of 61-65 West Twenty-third Street, New York City, to "cease and desist" from misrepresentations in the use of the words "stainless" and "stainpruf" in the sale of its products. The company is a distributor of cutlery.

The use of taxation as an "instrument of social control" continues to exist in many forms in the United States, although such use is theoretically opposed by many influential groups, according to a report made public yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund.
Continuing his consistent performances, Victor Ronchetti of Chicago carried off the Northern New York outdoor speed-skating championship in the title meeet which ended today on Mirror Lake.
More than 3,500 employes of the Chevrolet Motor and Fisher Body plants here are scheduled to celebrate Washington's Birthday by returning to work tomorrow.
The Bureau of Mines reports that production of sulphur in the United States amounted to 2,015,231 tons in 1936, a gain of 23 per cent over the 1,632,590 tons in 1935.
The Rev. Hugh M. Smith, pastor of St. Joseph's Catholic Church for fourteen years, died today after a brief illness. His age was 71.
Hundreds of Winter sports enthusiasts gathered today to witness slalom and skiplane races. Despite mild weather, conditions were good.

The national office of the Boy Scouts of America, 2 Park Avenue, made public last night a message it had received from Lord BadenPowell, founder of the Boy Scout movement, who is celebrating his eightieth birthday today.
The National Lawyers Guild today endorsed President Roosevelt's plan to reorganize the Supreme Court.

Roland Hayes, who has not been heard in New York's major concert halls in the last two years, made his return in a recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The Negro tenor gave proof after proof that he remains a distinguished interpreter of songs.

The Indian Congress party, demanding complete independence, appeared tonight as a formidable obstacle to fulfillment of Britain's plan of federal government for India as counting neared completion in one of the most colorful elections -in political history.

The following were the nest sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Dowbleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Seribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

C. G. Y. King of West Palm Beach and London, England, retired British naval officer, died tonight. His age was 85. Gathering antiques was Mr. King's hobby. He owned what was said to be one of the largest collections of navigation instruments in the world.

Amendment of the Social Security Act by restoration of the "lost" provision in the original bill for annuity insurance, in an amount not to exceed $500, the premium to be the actuarial cost, was unanimously approved at the concluding session here today of the delegate conference of the American Association of Social Workers.

The entire Cabinet resigned last night to leave President Alfonso Lopez free to adjust the administrative set-up as a result of the changed political situation caused by the death of former President Enrique Olaya Herrera in Rome last Thursday.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 84 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week. Recovery from the flood was complete in steel production, but a few finishing departments were not in full operation.

Dr. Ernest M. Best, New York University graduate and former Professor of Education and Psychology at McGill University, was inaugurated today as the fifth president of Springfield College. Exercises in Trinity Methodist Church were attended by representatives of about fifty colleges and universities.
" Victoria Regina" acquired a new actress for one performance a week ago Saturday night, but the audience was unaware of it. She was Mary MacArthur, daughter of Helen Hayes.

Liquidation by holders of wheat and other grains in the last few days, coupled with short-selling, has had a demoralizing effect on the markets, forcing all grains to close yesterday on the Board of Trade at the lowest prices of the week.

Dr. Clarence J. West of the Institute of Paper Chemistry, affiliated with Lawrence College of Appleton, Wis., will receive the sixth Gold Medal award of the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry, it was announced yesterday at the opening of its annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The first definite move toward considration by Congress of President Roosevelt's proposals to reform the judiciary, which were presented more than two weeks ago, was made today when the Senate Judiciary Committee scheduled hearings to begin on March 9.

A surprising Princeton hockey team did the unexpected tonight when it defeated Yale, 4 to 2. Conceded little chance against the same team that had humbled them two weeks ago, the Jungletown puck-chasers upset advance calculations by registering their first important victory of the season.
Hope for a missing airliner with seven persons aboard, one an American, was virtually abandoned here today. Air Force planes searched hundreds of square miles without finding a trace of the liner.

Declaring that George Washington's warning against changing the Constitution "by usurpation" applied to the present issue, Frederick H. Stinchfield, president of the American Bar Association, said today that President Roosevelt's proposals to reorganize the Supreme Court would destroy the court and establish a tyranny.

The $139,000 museum building in the rear of Washington's headquarters in the Morristown National Historical Park reservation was dedicated this afternoon by Arno B. Cammerer, director of the National Park Service, at the annual meeting of the Washington Association of New Jersey in the auditorium of the new building.

Although many of those attacking the President's retirement-or-increase formula for the Supreme Court are too excited or partisan to admit it, there are excellent arguments on both sides, and there are good answers for almost all the. arguments pro and con.
A bill intended to keep America safe from foreign "ham" actors, was called "ridiculous" in a statement issued today by Samuel Goldwyn, pioneer motion-picture producer.

A little bill of [Pound]3,000 was submitted to the House of Commons by the government today to cover "an enormous amount of additional telegraphing" to the British colonies during the abdication crisis of last December.
Alfred R. Glancy, volunteer mediator, announced the settlement early today of the four-day sit-down strikes of President Walter L. Fry and 110 of the employes of the Fry Products Company.
The passenger revenue of the Reading Company increased 26.5 percent last year, or from $3,077,347 in 1935 to $3,893,133 in 1936, according to the report for last year, issued yesterday.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey renewed last night his attack on the Committee for Industrial Organization and John L. Lewis, its leader, by charging that this militant minority was "claiming governmental blessing as it seizes private property, defies the
Rollins College celebrated the fiftysecond anniversary of its founding today by conferring honorary degrees on five men, including two from abroad, and bestowing honors on two others.

Champion Nancolleth Marquis tonight won his twenty-fourth best-in-show award. To the acclaim of many thousands of New England enthusiasts Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge's grand liver and white pointer dog gained the highest honors in the twenty-fifth annual all-breed exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club, the rosette and

A murder, a murder threat and a knock-down blow figured yesterday in the testimony at the restaurant racket trial as Irving Epstein, defendant union official, continued his story of terror in the food industry.

The Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, in its ninetyfirst annual statement, reported total income for 1936 of $55,626,964. The largest items of income consisted of premiums of $37,717,376, and interest, dividends and rents of $11,894,326.

Finishing with a sensational eagle on the home green, Dick Metz, 27year-old professional from the Mill Road Farm Club of Lake Forest, Ill., defeated Ed Dudley of Augusta, Ga., today in the eighteen-hole playoff of the $3,000 Thomasville open golf tournament.

Renewing a rivalry that has extended over a period of several years, the two top-ranking badminton doubles teams of the metropolitan district clashed in the final of the second annual Middle Atlantic invitation tournament yesterday at the 165th Regiment Armory.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued, as of the dates indicated, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore.
American cotton traders were criticized here today by the National Socialist press chief, Dr. Otto Dietrich, who demanded in an article appearing in all party papers:

The United States supplied more than half of Canada's imports last month with goods valued at $33,177,000, compared with $26,285,000 in January, 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Announcement of former Governor James M. Curley's decision to accept the call of nearly 100,000 petitioners, and seek election as Mayor of Boston for the fourth time, was made by him today at a luncheon meeting of 250 members of the Massachusetts Department of the Spanish War Veterans Auxiliary.
More than 1,000 members of the A New York Postoffice Holy Name Society attended a memorial mass at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at the Church of St. Michael, 434 West Thirty-fourth Street.

James F. Campbell, chief of the Passaic Fire Department, died in the Passaic General Hospital tonight at the age of 55. He was stricken with acute indigestion at a fire on Feb. 4 and was taken to the hospital.
A study of whether the accumulation of enormous reserves for old-age pensions will be necessary was ordered today by the Senate Finance Committee.

Mayor La Guardia's committee on traffic problems will hold its organization meeting at City Hall today. One of the first tasks confronting it is to find a solution to the pressing parking problem in Manhattan.

At the moment when the right of collective bargaining is being disputed in the United States and other countries the House of Commons will debate tomorrow a report of a British Government commission that complains that all miners do no belong to unions.

Almost without exception, the twenty-six -Broadway shows that observed Washington's Birthday with special matinees were glad they did. Every hit had standees; so did the hold-overs from other seasons.

Germain G. Glidden of New York demonstrated the nimbleness and perseverance which made him the country's No. 1 squash racquets player today by defeating Neil J. Sullivan of Philadelphia to win the national singles championship for the second successive year.
Showing exceptional ability, Shanghai Express turned In what observers agreed was the outstanding opening performance of the forty-second annual national field trials today.
The same team of Chesapeake bird dogs that raced to victory over the snow-packed trail in the American Dog Derby a year ago, won again today for a hometown driver who thinks "patience pays."

Pope Plus was reported in informed Vatican sources today to be somewhat fatigued after a restless night. He remained in bed yesterday until almost noon and did not attempt to practice the halting steps he had been taking recently in an-effort to regain the use of his legs. Several sores on his legs, caused by bursting varicose veins, opened again.
Laws to abolish Washington's "mail-order" marriage license system were urged today by King County- officials -as the aftermath of a series of child marriages in Seattle.

Continued increase in business activity at a rate equal to that maintained between 1933 and 1936 would make a general labor shortage "highly probable" by 1940 and remove the fear that the United States is destined to support a permanent body of unemployed, the National Industrial Conference Board asserted in a study made public yesterday.
Government meat experts said today that imports of beef by the United States this year might exceed the 572,000,000 pounds that came into this country in 1936.
The first milestone was passed yesterday in the career of possibly the greatest amateur racquets player developed in this country.

The Rev. Dr. Stephen Joseph Herben, editor of The Epworth Herald, 1904-12, and retired Methodist Episcopal minister, died this morning at his home here of heart disease after an illness of about ten days and a long period of poor health. He was in his seventy-sixth year.

Following is the text of a proposed bill to amend the Multiple Dwelling Law, submitted to Governor Lehman yesterday by Mayor La Guardia: An act to amend the Multiple Dwelling Law, in--relation to assessments for the abatement of nuisances in old law tenements and authorizing the issuance of bonds therefore.

The Spanish Insurgent drive toward Almeria, along the Mediterranean coast, has progressed well beyond Motril, half way between Malaga and Almeria But it has been slowed up somewhat by the necessity for difficult cleaning-up operations in the mountainous country only a few miles inland, where isolated bands of government forces have taken refuge.

Rollo Ogden was born on Jan. 19, 1856, at Sand Lake, Rensselaer County, N. Y., of a family which traces back in this country to 1640. His father was the Rev. Isaac Gray Ogden, a Presbyterian minister who served various parishes in the western sections of New York State. His mother, Emma Huntington, came of a family of Canadian origin.

A new Schrafft's Restaurant, designed In the style of the Harvard University buildings close by, will be opened on Thursday at 23 Brattle Street, Harvard Square, Cambridge, Mass. It will be the sixth in the Schrafft chain in Boston. The walls will be decorated with large photo-murals of Boston scenes in the period from 1923 to 1840.
Three persons owed their lives today to the intelligence of a police dog which routed them from their burning home.

Mrs. Bessie Jordan Maxwell, wife of Henry L. Maxwell of this city and Greenwich, Conn., died suddenly last night of a heart attack in their apartment in the Hotel Berkshire, 21 East Fifty-second Street at the age of 53. Three sons.

On the basis that the "authority and dignity" of the Supreme Court would be impaired, Judge John C. Knox, senior judge of the United States District Court of the Southern District of New York, expressed disapproval last night of President Roosevelt's proposals to change the Supreme Court.

Washington's Birthday was celebrated today by seventy-one golfers of the New York Athletic Club, who engaged in the first two rounds of match play in their seventh annual Winter handicap golf tournament.
Steve (Crusher) Casey of Ireland defeated Hans Kampfer of Germany after 19 minutes and 57 seconds in the feature wrestling match at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night.
Conferences to end the sit-down strike of Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation employes in North Chicago were set tonight to begin in Governor Horner's office at 11 A. M. tomorrow.
Harold L. Williamson, United States Consul in Bermuda, today entertained 700 guests at a tea dance at the Princess Hotel in celebration of Washington's Birthday.

James Ernest G. Yalden, an organizer and for twenty-five years director of the Baron de Hirsch Trade School, which last year was absorbed by the New York City Board of Education, died this morning at his home here of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

Miss Kathleen McCormack, daughter of Mrs. Naomi Lyons McCormack of Kingston, Jamaica, B. W. I., was married to Alexander J. Alexander of Montreal yesterday afternoon at the home in Elizabeth, N. J., of the Rev. Dr. Raphael H. Melamed, who performed the ceremony. There were no bridal attendants. Philip Besser of New York was best man.
Mrs. Elizabeth G. Lavelle, active for many years in Catholic circles, died on Sunday at her home, 325 East Fiftieth Street, of pneumonia.

The marriage of Miss Florence Sellenings, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Eugene Sellenings of New York and Belle Terre, L. I., to Waldo Maitland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gillies Maitland of London, England, took place here yesterday afternoon in New Church in East Thirty-fifth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Wilde.
Closing of deals for several apartment properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn were reported yesterday. General trading was light on account of the holidays.
Automobile production, with General Motors back in operation, shot up sharply last week, when normally there is a seasonal dip, and the adjusted index has jumped to 108.8 from 79.0 (revised) for the

A sudden rise in the prices of metals resulting from frenzied buying was a feature of trading in all European exchanges today. It will have its effect upon rearmament if, as seems probable, the increased prices are maintained.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Poda of this place celebrated their fifty-sixth wedding anniversary at a reception in their home with their eight children, twenty-three grandchildren : and two great-grandchildren among the guests.

The so-called "standstill" agreement covering specific foreign indebtedness of the German provincial States, communes and public corporations was, with only minor changes in its broad outline, formally renewed today for another twelve months.

Long before the end of the Presidential campaign it was evident that Governor Smith had made it what it was. Whether he won or lost the election, he had conquered a great place for himself in our public life. He had, in the first place, revealed to his fellowcountrymen an extraordinary personalit. . His vigor, his frankness,

The dining room and bar space, aggregating more than 10,000 square feet in addition to the basement, in the Parc Vendome Apartments, 340 West Fifty-seventh Street, has been leased to the Castleholm Restaurant, Inc.
Germany today declined an invitation from a League of Nations committee to discuss in Geneva projects for the distribution of raw materials to ease the international economic situation.

Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw gave a dinner last night at her -home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street, for Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General at New York, and Lady Campbell, Mrs. James Roosevelt, Mrs. Gustav Stresemann, Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Belsterling and Thomas Kimball.

The steamer Benjamin B. Odell, carrier of freight and passengers on the Hudson River between New York and Albany for the last twenty-five years, burned to the water line tonight in her Winter berth here.

Of the new "Neutrality Bill," which has finally been reported to the Senate after much discussion in committee, Senator PITTMAN frankly says that it is not a neutrality bill at all. He is obviously right in this appraisal.
The United States destroyer Kane is taking R. D. Longyear, American Consul, from Marseilles to Malaga on Wednesday.
AMELIA EARHART'S flight round the globe will be the first trip that really meets people's notions of what

To the Editor of The New York Times: Eldon Bisbee in a letter to THE TIMES suggests with perfect accuracy that the manufacturing plants of the United States were quite as capable of production in 1933 as at any previous time and also that the calamities which followed 1929 were caused by "the paralyzing effect of the Great War-and the weaknesses inherent in human nature and the capitalistic system."
As a result of his thrilling triumph over C. Everett Bacon of Montclair today, Babe Ruth stands at the threshold of the first major triumph of his newly-found lovegolf.

Moving to meet a low-rent housing shortage affecting more than 4,000 New York families, Mayor La Guardia delivered copies of a new housing bill and a report from the New York City Housing Authority to Governor Lehman's office in Albany yesterday.

A tablet was unveiled on the side of a bank building in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday to mark the location of the Old Stone Church, which was built in 1699 and subsequently used an a town meeting hall and as a British prison during the Revolutionary War.

Rutgera University awards for service to the university were presented today by President Robert C. Clothier to Henry Marelli, '97, of Paterson, and Charles S. Aitkin, '80, of Trenton. The awards, consisting of bronze medals and citations, were conferred at the annual alumni dinner, which was the climax of the mid-winter Alumni Day program on the campus.

The trial of six men charged with second-degree manslaughter in connection with the collapse of a Bronx building last June 19 in which eighteen men were killed, will be resumed today in the Bronx County Court before Judge Lester Patterson. Those indicted are Louis

TT was with a slightly rumpled air of dignity that Red (Riot) Horner, the Ontario ice man, took his seat in the penalty coop at the Garden skating festivities the other evening. The other in-and-outers of the hockey calaboose were unimportant offenders, but Homer's twenty-minute sentence for attempted homicide in some degree -all in fun-put him in the lead for "bad man" honors on the hockey circuit.

A purse of $1,300 was presented last night to the Rev. Emil Roth, pastor of the Emmanuel Lutheran Church, and Mrs. Roth, by members of the congregation at a dinner at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, marking the couple's fiftieth wedding anniversary.
When "Uncle" Nelson Maury ambled by the court house today he wondered why people stared so. County officials in turn wondered how "Uncle" Nelson was able to amble by.
The reported five-mile advance of Black Rapids Glacier in four months is a speed record for glacial movement, Ernest N. Patty said here today.

Mrs. Helen Hill gave an involuntary example today of what the women sailors can do in Winter dinghy racing. Before the afternoon competition began in the final session of the three-day regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and impromptu offshore race was held.

Charles Smith, giant 29-yearold Harlem Negro, was shot and killed here tonight when he made a break to escape from police headquarters. He had been arrested Thursday on a charge of burglary by the Pelham Manor police, but was held here because the Pelham Manor jail is being repaired.

In a purchase made from the trustees of Series Q issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, Samuel Reznick, president of Claridge Equities, Inc., has acquired the four four-story apartment houses at 24-39, 24-51, 24-65 and 24-75 Thirty- eighth Street, Astoria, Queens.

Japan's armament program is in answer to the recent great expansion of Soviet forces in the Far East and in lesser degree has been necessitated by improvement in the Chinese Army, General Gen Sugiyama told the House of Peers today.

Sterling Products, Inc., reported yesterday for 1936 consolidated net earnings of $8,669,061, equal to $5.05 each on 1,715,563 outstanding shares, compared with $8,308,074, or $4.83 each on 1,717,670 shares, earned in 1935. For 1936 provision was made, before net earnings, for $80,898 tax on undistributed earnings.

The New York Hippodrome opened its doors to opera again yesterday as a preliminary to the regular season which is promised to begin on April 16. A total of about 10,000 persons attended matinee and evening performances.
The National Puzzlers League got down to business yesterday and wound up its 107th semi-annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker amid a welter of resolutions, points of order and vote-counting.

Cuba's vaunted clear blue sky retreated behind a complete network of gray clouds today, and a spanking breeze cracked down from the north that not only brought a refreshing coolness to the. Giants' swanky training quarters but a number of other unforeseen developments as well.

Harry V. Steen, Knoxville salesman, started a movement today to obtain a small pension for William Andrew Johnson, 79-year-old former slave of President Andrew Johnson. The aged Negro visited President Roosevelt at the White House last week.
The Rev. Lawrence J. Davitt, O. S. B., dean of St. Anselm College, died suddenly at a hospital here tonight of pneumonia. His age was 43.

The performance of "La Gioconda" tomorrow night and that of "Norma" next Monday night will be the last of those operas for the season at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday. Gina Cigna, who sings the title roles in both operas, must sail for Italy on March 3.

The principal investment companies in the United States had an unusually successful year in 1936, with results better than the gains in the theoretical market averages, according to a survey made by the Tri-Continental Corporation of eighty-four companies whose assets amounted to $2,350,000,000 at the close of 1936.

The large garden-type apartment houses of Tudor architecture at 55 and 65 Randolph Place, occupying the blockfront between Scotland Road and Vost Avenue, South Orange, N. J., have been purchased by Benjamin Roth of New York.

Henry J. Tynan of the Tynan Throwing Company has been reelected president of the Throwsters Research Institute, Inc. William Rossmassler of the Sauquoit Silk Manufacturing Company, and Arthur G. Schautz of the Grove Silk Company have been re-elected vice president and treasurer, respectively.
The Bank for Savings sold to the Bosco Realty Corp., Sadye Rhodes, president, the house at 1,472 1st Av. for $38,000, taking back a purchase-money mortgage for $32,000. payable ten years hence.
Friends of Sherman Schneider, advertising art representative, offered him today as the coun-. try's champion "stepper-upper."

Luncheon parties were a feature of the annual water sports program and fashion show in observance of George Washington's anniversary at the Surf Club here today. Mrs. Arthur H. Kudner of New York entertained Mrs. John Oliver LaGorce, Mrs. Thomas McKnew and Mrs. John Crosby of Washington; Mrs. Fred J. Fisher

Hames Van Alen, teamed with Pierre Etchebaster, world professional champion, defeated Ogden Phipps, American open singles champion, and William Standing, private professional, today in a special match game of court tennis, 4-6, 6-2, 6-5, 6--2.
Marshall Field Co. of Chicago reported today a gain of more than 1,300 per cent in earnings in 1936. and voted to clear up accumulated dividends on the prior-preferred stock.

The police searched today the home of Representative Antonio Bravo Acosta, Democratic floor leader of the lower house, after his presentation on Saturday of a bill embodying a new electoral code that displeased the military authorities.

Warren Sheppard, marine painter and formerly an amateur navigator of racing yachts, died on Sunday night at his home, 1,166 Pacific Street, Brooklyn. His age was 81. Mr. Sheppard had been active in his profession until six months ago, when ill health forced him to abandon it. He had recently completed an autobiography in fictional form and illustrated it himself.

March 3 was fixed today for the opening of the conference of experts representing the States adhering to the Oslo convention. Premier Hendryk Colijn will preside at the first sitting. The conference is expected to last five or six days.

The modern analogue of Plato's "Ideal Republic" could be attained only by giving the engineer a more important rle in the determination of national policies directed toward a program of social progress, Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusette Institute of Technology, declared today in an address at Johns Hopkins University.

A few concrete suggestions on buying clothes, in keeping with the "philosophy" of being well-dressed as good advertising for the individual and the nation, were put forward in clothing budgets for men in four income brackets yesterday at the opening of the eighteenth annual men's style show of the New York Custom Cutters Club in the Hotel Commodore.

Stains on his coat-sleeve led to the arrest and confession of a 20year-old youth last night of the hammer murder of a night watchman in a garage in Brooklyn. The arrest climaxed a twelve-hour investigation by detectives.

More than 2,500 men and boys from Protestant Episcopal churches in Kings, Queens and Nassau Counties attended the annual corporate communion breakfast of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew of the Diocese of Long Island yesterday morning at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

The Senate ran through its calendar quickly and passed several minor bills. The Assembly passed the Brownell bill to permit service of a subpoena by publication in the case of missing witnesses in criminal cases, the measure being an outgrowth of the Drukman murder case.

Remsen T. Williams of 15 Nassau Drive, Great Neck, L. I., a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-eighth Street and Park Avenue, of cancer, after an illness of six weeks, at the age of 53. Surviving are his widow, Gertrude D. Williams; a daughter, Dorothy S., and a son, Remsen T. Jr.

Negotiations neared completion today for the purchase by RKO-Radio of "The Muddled Deal," Aladar Laszlo's current Budapest stage success. The studio wants it for Janet Gaynor and Herbert- Marshall. The story is a comedy of

Earl Maiman, American pianist, appeared in recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The program consisted of Bach-Liszt's prelude and fugue in A minor, Brahms's variations and fugue on a theme of Handel and the twelve etudes of Chopin's Opus 25.
The New York American soccer team and the New York Germans played to a 1-all tie at Starlight Park yesterday.

More freight cars were on order on Feb. 1 than on any corresponding date since 1926, according to J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads. The figures include cars under construction in railroad shops.

Five men were found guilty today of conspiracy to defraud voters. A Federal court jury deliberated less than three hours on the government's charges of wholesale vote frauds in the Nov. 3 election and the defense contention that "ghost" voting and voter bribery do not violate Federal laws.

Viscount Cranborne, Under-Secretary in the Foreign Office, revealed in the House of Commons today that invitations to the coronation of King George VI had been sent to the Valencia government in Spain and Emperor Haile Selassie's government in Ethiopia.

Operations of the steel industry this week, according to the Iron and Steel Institute, are at the rate of 82.5 per cent of capacity, the highest since the institute began reporting the weekly operating rates in 1933.

His skull fractured in a skiing accident yesterday on Mount Mansfield, Ludwig von Graevenitz, 20 years old, a New York clerk, who came here on a snow train, was sent home tonight by train from Waterbury.

The principal cause of the barring of the American humorous weekly Judge from Germany until further notice was a special Jewish number issued recently, according to the Propaganda Ministry. Attacks on the German State and its leaders were contributory reasons, it was said.
To guard against "racial contamination" within the German nation, National Socialism officially advises Germans to marry young.

Tracy H. Lewis won the twentieth annual shoot for the George H. Lyon Memorial Trophy over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Lewis, who is a Class A gunner, took the prize in a field of eighty-two by breaking 194 out of 200 targets. His individual strings were 97 each.

In this column ROLLO OGDEN for many years made his daily contribution to American public opinion as editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Now his sorrowing fellow-workers on THE TIMES come forward here to pay a tribute of affection to their departed chief and friend. They salute the close of a career rich in achievement and bright with honor.

George M. Snow, former official of the Badishe Company of New York and of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company, died here today. His age was 77. He was a vice president of the People's Savings Bank here.
The Times of London devotes its leading editorial today to a study of "the American dream of a family-size farm owned by the family which operates it."

The Putnam Hill Chapter, Daughtters of the American Revolution, observed Washington's Birthday this afternoon with a reception and tea at which nine officers and members appeared in-Colonial costumes, some of which were worn by their ancestors during the Revolutionary War period.

Handling her mounts splendidly, Miss Carol Jane Adler of New York City monopolized the center of the stage by capturing four blues at the Metropolitan Equestrian Club's second horse show and carnival held on the spacious floor of the Squadron A armory yesterday.

Army's intercollegiate indoor championship trio won its thirtieth consecutive game this morning, defeating the Pennsylvania Military College poloists, 18 to 4. The Cadets, revealing an accuracy with their sticks that could not be denied, forged ahead rapidly after a slow first period.

Reviving the Washington's Birthday ball, highlight of each season at the Poinciana Hotel, discontinued a decade ago, and the annual Everglades Club costume ball, abandoned during the depression, was the brilliant red and white ball tonight at the club. Seven hundred members and guests attended.

The Westminster of plain, ordinary dogs, Bloomingdale's Pet Dog Show, will open today and will continue until best in show is decided on Saturday. The sixth annual exhibition is expected to top last year's high mark when more than 700 were entered.
MORNING EVENTS Class 1 Novice Horsemanship for Juniors-First, Mary O'Connell; second, Ruth Taussig; third, Susan Blumenthal: fourth. Phil Kiendl; fifth, Elizabeth O'Connell; sixth, Howard Fox.
The House closed a five-week investigation of law enforcement conditions at Hot Springs today by voting, 70 to 20, to exonerate Circuit Judge Earl Witt of charges of official misconduct.

The following is the chart showing how the Santa Anita Derby was run today: SIXTH RACE-The Santa Anita Derby; $50,000 added; 3-year-olds; one mile and a sixteenth. Start good; won ridden out; place same. Went to post 7:29 1/2, off 7:35 1/2. Winner, ch. g., by Messenger-Star Fairy, by Satrap. Trainer, R. E. Handley. Value to winner, $45,425; second, $10,000; third, $5,000; fourth, $2,500. Time-1:45 4/5.
The City Fusion party will open borough campaign headquarters in Manhattan, the Bronx Brooklyn and Queens, Ben Howe, its chairman, announced yesterday.

Only by the preservation of the university, the implacable foe of dogmatic partisanship, "in all its integrity can our democracy be assured of the fearles pursuit of saving truth," Dr. James Rowland Angell declared today in his last appearance as president of Yale before the university's graduates at the annual Alumni Day f~te.

With Frank P. Walsh presiding, the National Lawyers Guild in the final session today of its first convention, adopted a constitution and elected officers. John P. Devaney, retiring chief justice of the Minnesota Supreme Court, was chosen president.

A special committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America on unlisted trading has been appointed to determine whether the association shall oppose or support individual applications before the Securities and Exchange Commission for admission or removal of securities from unlisted trading privileges on Stock Exchanges, it was announced yesterday by Edward B. Hall, president of Harris, Hall Co., Chicago, and president of the association.
Although he has not yet presented his credentials, the Italian Minister, Enrico Bombieri, received a warm welcome from the press on his arrival here. The Prensa says:
To prevent chaos and reduce profiteering the government has had to take a hand in arrangements for accommodating the 200,000 or more visitors expected from overseas for the coronation.

Evidence that an automobile worker in the Fisher Body plant of General Motors at Baltimore had a key to the factory's stationery room and that he sent out propaganda in the interest of a company "Loyalty Union," mimeographed and addressed on company machines, with the aid of the payroll of employes, was presented today to the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage.

CHRISTINA ROSSETTI years ago wrote the lines that might well have been adopted as the platform of "The Big Sisters ": For there is no friend like a sister, In calm or stormy weather, To cheer one on the tedious way, To fetch one if one goes astray, To lift one if one totters down, To strengthen whilst one stands.

Supervisor Robert C. O'Grady, 40 years old, a lawyer, was arrested by detectives here today and charged with criminal negligence in the death of Mrs. Edna Grier, 26 years old, a Negro, who succumbed lastnight in Long Beach Hospital to injuries received when she was struck by an automobile said to have been driven by O'Grady early Friday morning. Before Judge J.

A resolution calling on President Federico Laredo Bru to give the House of Representatives details of- the commercial treaty between Cuba and Great Britain, signed last Friday before ratification by the Senate, was approved this afternoon by' the lower chamber.

Mr. and Mrs. David Sherman Baker of Greenwich and Whale Rock Point, Narragansett, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Candler Baker, to Jesse Fleet Sammis Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. J. F. Sammis of New York.

John Licari, 25 years old, of 117 Littleton Avenue, Newark, a former pugilist known in the prize ring as "Young Jack Dempsey," was shot dead and his brother, Anthony, 28, was seriously wounded by a lone gunman who attacked them in a tavern at 364 Fifteenth Avenue, corner of Bergen Street, here early this evening.
An unemployed painter who escaped injury with his wife and nine children last month when an airplane crashed into his home was killed here today when he was struck on the head by a falling tree limb.
Although Norris Dam generates power for the vast Tennessee Valley Authority, the town of Norris was without electricity today.

From. Rome,, Chancellor Benito Mussolini has decreed: 1. Summary execution for the natives who, on. pretense of receivinggifts, threw hand grenades that wounded Rodolfo Graziani, the Viceroy; Aviation General Aurelio Liotti and others.

The providing of adequate consumer credit was cited today by Dr. Luther A. Harr, State Secretary of Banking, as the chief problem his department would try to solve at the current session of the Legislature.

Catalysis, chestnut daughter of Stimulus-Catalpa, in the yellow and black silks of the Starmount Stable, owned by Edward Benjamin of New Orleans, today raced to a flashy victory in the seventh running of the Nursery Stakes No. 2, for 2-year-old fillies exclusively, at Hialeah Park.

Freddy Lindstrom, once a Giant protege of the late John J. McGraw, yesterday joined the growing army of ex-Dodgers, a bit abruptly but not altogether unexpectedly. Taking time out from his preparations to move to the Clearwater training camp, Secretary John Gorman announced that the Brooklyn club had given Lindstrom his unconditional release.

From the rear room of a grocery store where he had been forced at pistol point by two Negro hold-up men yesterday, Theodore Bemos, 16-year-old clerk, sneaked back to grapple with one of the men as the other fled with $21.70 from the cash drawer.
Lord Mildmay's Davy Jones, the 66-to-1 shot which nearly captured the Grand National Steeplechase last year, was scratched from the list of entries for the 1937 renewal of the Aintree classic today.
Riots and noisy demonstrations by Nazis marked the arrival here today of the German Foreign Minister, Baron Constantin von Neurath.

" Siegfried" constituted the third offering of the special Wagner matinee cycle at the Metropolitan yesterday. The audience, which filled the theatre to its last inch of standing room, heard an interpretation of the work by a cast which differed in only one particular from those of the earlier and memorable performances of Jan. 22 and 30.

England and Canada clinched places in the last round of the world amateur hockey championships tonight by scoring a pair of shutout victories. The English team crushed Poland, 11-0, while the Kimberley Dynamiters, Canadian entry, blanked Germany, 5-0.

Four young men who were set upon by passengers in a car of an Astoria line train of the I. R. T. in the Forty-second Street station early yesterday after, it was said, they had annoyed a young woman, were sent to jail in lieu of $50 fines by Magistrate Sylvester in.Jefferson Market Court.

There was a by-election in the North St. Pancras division the other day. The constituency was represented by a Liberal from 1906 to 1918. Then the Conservatives won the seat. They have held it since except in 1923 and 1929, when the Laborites got it.

Returning to William stown as "Lehman, '99," New York's Governor made :a plea today for greater interest in public problems. As guest of honor at a father and son alumni luncheon in Lasell Gymnasium, Mr. Lehman urged undergraduates to acquire training at Williams College to meet the "human and economic needs of society, rather than intensive specialization in narrow fields of interest.

The annual Washington's Birthday communion service was held yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. More than 400 men and boys of the Episcopal Diocese of New York participated in the service, which is held under the auspices of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew.

An 18-year-old American-born Finnish youth, Paul Bietila of Ishpeming, Mich., performed with a dash and skill that thrilled a large holiday throng today as he showed the way in one of the largest and finest fields ever assembled for an Eastern ski jump.
Four scholarshipss for study at the Academy of International Law at The Hague next Summer will be awarded by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Dr. James Brown Scott announced today.
The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed cotransfer agent for 800,000 shares of common stock of the Air Devices Corporation.

ACKERMAN-On Feb. 21, 1937 Albert h., beloved husband of Florence C. and father of Margaret Peto and Helen A. Blake. Services at his residence, 115 10th St. ,Garden City, Tuesday, at 2 P. M. Interment private. Please omit flowers.

About 150 of the 225' students at Green Mountain Junior College, at. Poultney, Vt., were on strike today in protest against the dismissal of two students for causing a disturbance in one of the dormitories. The boys dismissed are Benjamin Stymiest of Westport .N. Y., and Paul Dutton of Norwich, Vt.
Rollo Ogden, editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died at 3:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon. At the age of 81, he resisted a heavy cold and came to his office daily until a week ago.

With large trunks filled with butter, turkeys, hams and sausages added to his regular baggage, Colonel General Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, left this morning for Berlin after a five-day visit to Poland.

112-POUND SUB-NOVICE CLASS Preliminaries Daniel Sinnott, Police Athletic League, defeated Joseph Abbatiello, Nassau Daily Review. Frank Campbell, Hudson Dispatch: John Sinnott, Police Athletic League; Larry Blumenthal, unattached; Charles Allen, Philadelphia Inquirer; Jimmy Mingo, Trenton Times; Manuel Roderick, Boston Globe, and John Lorenzo, unattached, drew byes.

The stock markets generally were dull today with fluctuations confined to the securities which were most prominent at the end of the last account. Armaments continued active, while the base-metal shares, which were favored on Friday, again went higher. Gilt-edge issues were weaker and, among the foreign bonds, the volume of business was small.

A fire in Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday morning would have warmed a blue-lipped group of parade-watchers on the steps and given the marchers in the fortysixth annual turnout of the Kings County Volunteer Firemen's Association something right up their alley.

New York Chapter, United Daughters of the Confederacy, will hold its annual card party and tea in behalf of its charitable enterprises on Friday afternoon in the Florentine Room of Schrafft's on West Fiftyseventh Street. The occasion will mark the thirty-fifth anniversary of Mrs. James Henry Parker's installation as charter president.

The qualities that made George Washington not only the "greatest leader this country has ever had" but also a personification of the principles and -virtues upon which the nation has been built were extolled by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, and other speakers at the annual celebration of Washington's birthday yesterday in the Jumel Mansion at 160th Street and Edgecombe Avenue.

With one exception all points at issue among the twenty-seven nations represented in the non-intervention committee regarding supervision of Spanish coasts and frontiers to prevent foreign munitions and recruits from reaching the warring factions in Spain have now been ironed out.

The Rossia Insurance Company of America as of Dec. 31, 1936, had an indicated liquidating value of $17.37 a share, compared to $16.22 a share at the end of 1935, based on market values. Surplus of $2,396,949 showed an increase of $265,618 after taxes and other adjustments and the payment of dividends of $240,000.

The Right Rev. John A. Ryan of Catholic University told the Manchester City Club today that he favored President Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization program, but also thought steps toward a constitutional amendment should be taken so that "reform legislation would be safe against attack on the grounds of unconstitutionality by future Supreme Courts."
As the site for a 1,300-seat motion-picture theatre a plot 138 by 250 feet on East Front Street, Red Bank, N. J., has been bought by a syndicate operating theatres throughout the State.

The crucial battle of the Jarama River front southeast of here is now in what might be called its second phase, what General Jose Miaja, the defense commander, today designated as "defensive action with partial attacks."
Senator Maloney of Connecticut proposed today the establishment of a variable work week, based on the amount of unemployment in the country as determined by biennial census.
The Kingsley School quintet spoiled the homecoming ceremonies at Bordentown Military Institute today by defeating the Cadets, 26-21, in their annual match.
The National Assembly has started work on elaborating the new Constitution, which the Cabinet wishes completed promptly.

The Dartmouth basketball team withstood a determined Columbia rally in the second half tonight to defeat the Lions, 47 to 45, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest. Brilliant shooting by the Indians in the early stages built up a score the visitors could not overcome.
The proposal to move Auburn Theological Seminary to the ColgateRochester Divinity School campus reached the stage of definite action today.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrived yesterday afternoon looking spick and span after two months' lay-up at Southampton. In that period she was six weeks in drydock while several alterations were being made on deck and below.
Walter R. Stone, field representative of the New York State Conference of Mayors and a former Mayor of Syracuse, died unexpectedly tonight in his hotel apartment here.His age was 64.

A suspect in a clothing store hold-up on the lower East Side was wounded by a policeman after a chase that ended In a five-story tenement house at 68 Suffolk Street yesterday afternoon. He is Gustave Spano, 21 years old, of 38 Cherry Street.
An East Side Jewish congregation whose founding was made possible by a grant of $500'from a Roman Catholic Church celebrated its eightieth anniversary last night.

AS one enters the Irish village of 0-- from the south, off to the right lies a massive ruin barely visible from the highway. If one approaches in the other direction, down from the mountains of the north, another ruined building is the first thing to be seen.

The existing labor unrest to a certain extent is characteristic of periods of recovery after severe depression, according to the current issue of the Guaranty Survey. monthly review of business and financial conditions here and abroad published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.
The Greater New York Chapter of the American Musicological Society will meet tonight at the Beethoven Association's quarters. Joseph Moller will speak on "Musical Iconography."

Claims that Basque government troops in a general offensive on the Asturias front in Northern Spain had penetrated "far into the center of Oviedo" and had cut in two places the road to the neighboring Insurgent base at Grado, about twelve miles west, were made in a communique from the Basque Minister of Defense at Bilbao to Spanish Government sources here.

Glaziers, sign fixers and the police had a busy time yesterday clearing up the debris of a storm that swept the city with winds of gale force for a period of six hours late Sunday night and early yesterday morning.
The proper labeling and advertising of fabrics is expected to make substantial strides this year as a result of current agitation in favor of such practices, according to comment here yesterday.

Proposals have been submitted to the city government by private corporations seeking a contract to operate the free-trade zone at Staten Island which now is under municipal direction. They are in the hands of Dock Commissioner John McKenzie and eventually must be disposed of by the Board of Estimate.

With the domestic grain markets closed today, the foreign markets were quiet. Wheat futures in Winnipeg closed 1/4 cent lower to 1/4 cent a bushel higher than on Saturday. Buenos Aires finished 5/3 to 7/8 cent lower and Liverpool 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 cents lower.
The Commonwealth film censor, Cresswell O'Reilly, in his annual report says the quality of British feature films varies between greater extremes than those of other nations.

For the second straight year the University F. C., composed of Jose R. de Capriles, Kevis Kapner and Miguel A. de Capriles, captured the annual open epee team competition on the strips of the Fencers Club last night.

President Roosevelt's plan regarding the Supreme Court was described today as "timely and in the broad sense of the word conservative" by William Draper Lewis, head of the American Law Institute and former dean of the University of Pennsylvania Law School.
While the former King Alfonso of Spain was away former Queen Victoria spent the time playing with her grandchildren here, but she departed when her husband returned to Rome.

General Miguel Costa arrived here this morning from Sao Paulo, escorted by policemen, to appear before the Security Tribunal for trial on charges of having been a leader of the 1935 Leftist revolt. Some 480 other Sao Paulo prisoners must answer charges before the tribunal.

Priees on the Stock Exchange here advanced sharply today with gains in some issues of more than 3 points. A strong demand for metal issues rushed several to new high prices while the construction issues, the paper shares and rail equipment moved forward decisively.

The next to last session of the International Horse Show took place in Valparaiso's municipal stadium today before a crowd numbering thousands, including many government officials and civil and military authorities.

League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "George Washington," Edward Howard Griggs. Metropolitan Museum of Art, Eighty-second Street and Fifth Avenue. "The Egyptian Collection," general tour, 11 A. M.; "Color and Texture: Tapestries," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.;

The Rutgers University basketball team defeated Lafayette tonight, 48-30, before an Alumni Day crowd of 1,500. The Scarlet took an early lead of 14-3 at the quarter and increased it to 28 to 13 at halftime. Fred Thon of Lafayette was high-scorer for the evening with 14 points.

A petition bearing 110,000 names of residents of New York City and urging pas-sage of the Rapp bill, designed to restore to the city control of salt aries and other expenses totaling $56,000,000 in this year's budget, was brought here tonight by Harold Riegelman, counsel of the Citizens Budget Commission.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, returned yesterday on the steamship Coamo from a visit to Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic. He was accompanied by Mrs. Butler. The object of his trip to Santo Domingo was to determine the best location for an American memorial to Christopher Columbus, as head of a memorial commission appointed by President Roosevelt.

Francis Dana Winslow, a member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Munds, Winslow Potter, 40 Wall Street, who had been a stock broker for more than half a century, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-eighth Street and Park Avenue, of heart disease with complications after an illness of three months. He was 81 years old.

Yale scored its second basketball victory of the season over Princeton tonight, winning by 46-30 as a crowd of 2,000 looked on. This Eastern Intercollegiate League contest was the feature of a buoy Alumni Day of sports.

Lindley Johnson, an architect and member of a prominent family, died of pneumonia yesterday at his home in Haverford. He was 83 years old. Born in this city, he was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1875. He was a member
As Rhode Island's coast was swept by huge waves today, a Summer home at Long Meadow was knocked from its foundation by the surf and almost carried into Narragansett Bay.

What is said to be the biggest panorama picture in the world is now approaching completion in Moscow. It shows the Soviet capture of Perekop in North Crimea, which completed the defeat of General Wrangel, the last White commander on Soviet to soil, in the Autumn of 1920.

Mr. and Mrs. Morris S. Wadley of California, now visiting in New York, have announced the engagement of Mr. Wadley's sister, Miss Melissa Jane Wadley of 405 Park Avenue, to Thomas Southworth Childs Jr. of Farmington, Conn., son of Mrs. Thomas Southworth Childs of Holyoke, Mass., and the late Mr. Childs.

President Anastasio Somoza has given an automobile to Mgr. Lezcano y Ortega, Archbishop of Managua and head of the Catholic Church in Nacaragua. The aged prelate said it was the first automobile he had ever owned.

The labor situation in the wholesale dry goods trade, where thirtyfive employers are "striking" against their employes' union, became somewhat more orthodox yesterday when the employers withdrew their pickets from the union offices and the workers took up picket signs of their own.

THE EAST WIND, by Compton Mackenzie. (Dodd, Mead, $2.75.) The first volume of a long and ambitious novel by the author of "Sinister Street." THE CROQUET PLAYER, by H. G. Wells. (Viking, $1.25.) Described as "a new kind of ghost story."

A concert was given last night in Carnegie Hall by the National Orchestral Association-Leon Barzin, conductor; Frank Bishop, pianist, as assisting soloist-in memory of Ossip Gabrilowitsch and in acknowledgment of many subscriptions received by. the orchestra in aid of-its Gabrilowitsch Fund.

When President Roosevelt received a delegation of seven leaders of the National Youth Congress on Saturday he sought to put them at their ease by asking their views on his proposals to reform the judiciary.

Marriage "tryouts" and State curbs on religion were denounced yesterday by the Right Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, addressing 1,000 members of the New York Chapter Knights of Columbus at its annual Solemn Pontifical memorial mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Investigation by Bergen County detectives, assisted by amateu?? criminologists, disclosed yesterday that one of the pistols used in the murder of Norman Redwood, labor union leader, was purchased more than six years ago from a store in back of New York police headquarters.
To a majority of American citizens, conservation is just another four-syllable word. Millions of persons don't know what it is all about, and, at the moment, probably don't care.

Spokesmen for fifteen standard railway unions met here today and laid the groundwork for the adoption of a demand for increased wages which they will agree upon tomorrow, it was announced tonight by George M. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association.

President Federico Paez has decorated James H. Gray and Gerald F. Mulligan, American aviation instructors, with the Cross of Abdon Calderon of the First Class for their services in training army aviators.
TWO Steuben County women, one of whom lives alone and does her own housework, observed their 101st birthdays today.
Representative James P. Buchanan of Texas, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, died at 10:40 o'clock tonight at Naval Hospital of a heart ailment. His age was 69.

A banking group composed of Salomon Brothers Hutzler, Dick Merle-Smith and Stroud Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $6,700,000 of Bessemer Lake Erie Railroad 2 1/4 per cent serial equipment-trust certificates, maturing from March 1, 1938 to 1947, inclusive.

Impressed by what they saw in a three-day stay here, the sixty-five members of the National Council of the American Youth Congress voted this afternoon to reorganize the structure of the organization along the lines of the Federal Government.

If young Syl Apps goes on this way, you'll probably find a lot of National Hockey Leaguers taking up pole vaulting. Because, as a glance at the Toronto rookie's point standing would indicate, it hasn't done Sylvanus any harm at all around those nets.

Charles Morgan, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a partner in the brokerage firm of W. H. Goadby Co., 120 Broadway, died yesterday at his home, 36 East Seventy-second Street, of pneumonia. He was 51 years old.

The House Ways and Means Committee favorably reported the new GuffeyVinson bituminous coal bill this afternoon, and leaders, after. conferring with Speaker Bankhead, laid plans to bring the measure to the floor late this week.

A long lease on the buildings, railroad sidings and yards at 14 Fisher Lane, White Plains, has been taken by the Dravo Corporation of Pittsburgh, which recently received a contract for the construction of shafts for new links in the New York City water-supply system. William J. Sherry was the broker.

A comprehensive program for the promotion of industrial peace through improved relations between employers and employes was formulated yesterday by the committee on employment relations of the National Association of Manufacturers.
Marconi, from the King's stable, today won the Coventry Chase over two miles, finishing four lengths ahead of Tattenhall. Marconi, ridden by Danny Morgan, was backed at 11 to 2.
Steed makers here are making no secret of their reasons for refusal to bid on contracts for steel and armor plate for the United States Navy.

The two youngest squads in the National Hockey League circuit clash tonight on the ice at Madison Square Garden when the New York Rangers face Connie Smythe's Toronto Maple Leafs for the final struggle of the season between these two teams.

Hayim Bruck, a German Jewish immigrant, 22 years old, was shot dead this afternoon near the Jewish colony of Beth Alpha In Northern Palestine. On him was found a note that he apparently had scribbled before he died. It said:
The Princess Hotel's thirtieth annual tennis tournament opened today with high winds and threatening clouds marring play in one of the most popular sporting fixtures of the season.
Dinghy racing at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club was cut short today because of a series of accidents which necessitated the rescue of three crews.

The chemical by which the filed-down numerals on the pistol used to kill Norman Redwood were deciphered was kept a carefully guarded secret today by Charles H. Black of Roselle, who succeeded in tracing them, and his associate amateur criminologists in the Crime Detection Laboratory of New Jersey, which is located here.

In the Budget Committee of the House of Representatives today Ryozo Makino, a Seiyukai (chief of minority party) member, declared that the police tortured suspected persons under examination and that procurators encouraged such malpractices.

Mrs. Dorothy Busch of Los Angeles who, with Zasu Pitts, motionpicture actress, returned from England yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, disclosed upon arrival that she had been robbed of $500 in cash, jewelry valued at a similar amount and her passport somewhere between Southampton and Cherbourg.

168th St. (9-2439), s. e. cor. Morris Av., 101x92; College Properties, Inc., to Vera Fadiman, 19 E. 98th St.; mtg., $165,000. Valentine Av. (12-3303), s. e. cor. 201st St., 155x126; College Properties, Inc.. to Vera Fadiman, 19 E. 98th St.; mtg., $282,000.
A man identified by fingerprints as Gaeto Alaveria, about 40 years old, was shot and killed instantly early yesterday in front of a candy store at 172 East 112th. Street, near Lexington Avenue.

The programmatic declaration for "national consolidation of Poland" that Colonel Adam Koc, commander of the Pilsudski Legionaires, broadcast yesterday has been received in German political circles with satisfaction bordering on enthusiasm.

The annual report of the Pure Oil Company and subsidiaries, issued today by Henry M. Dawes, president, disclosed- a net income of $7,658,372 for 1936, compared with $8,150,027 in 1935. Last year's profit was more than $5,000,000 above the average of the preceding four years.

President Roosevelt motored to Mount Vernon today to lay a wreath at the tomb of George Washington on the 205th anniversary of his predecessor's birth. Earlier in the day he sent a wreath to be placed with others at the foot of the Washington Monument on the Mall here.

The Hon. Mrs. Evelyn Fitzgerald, who has been visiting Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan Jr. at their Winter home in Palm Beach, is expected to arrive tomorrow at the Pierre, where she will be until sailing for her home in London. Mr. and Mrs. Russel A. Cowles have gone to the Claridge, Atlantic

With three new chapters added to describe the development of Manhattan through the last decade, Will Irwin's "Highlights of Manhattan" will be published in a revised edition this week by Appleton-Century. E. H. Suydam has added four new drawings and a new end paper for this edition.

Fred Grubmeier, German grappler, downed Bob Managoff of Russia in the feature match at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 2,000 watched Grubmeier triumph in 32:35 with a body scissors. Grubmeier weighed 205 and Managoff 200.

Lifting the traditional tribute to the memory of George Washington high above the usual level of after-dinner speeches, Premier Leon Blum, in phrases that recalled Washington was a man of letters long before he became a politician, drew this evening a political moral in contrasting the achievements of the American national hero and Napoleon.

Smiling Alf Engen, Norwegian-born Utah ski master, won the National Amateur Ski Association championship today. Setting a new national ski jump record of 245 feet, he scored 226.3 points, barely beating his boyhood friend, Sigmund Ruud of Norway.

Although America has more persons with Doctor of Philosophy degrees per square mile than any other population has ever had, it cannot boast of as many first-class minds as could have been found in Attica around 430 B.C in a population about 1 per cent as large, Dr. Joseph K. Hart, Professor of Educational Sociology at Teachers College, declared in a study, "The War Against Ignorance," made public yesterday.
Weather conditions continued to restrict the movement of hogs to market and receipts here today were only 7,000 head. The scant supply sold quickly at generally 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight higher.
The recent flood took Finley Johnson's piano away, but it brought him another just as good.

The quarter-final bracket in the metropolitan singles indoor tennis championship was filled entirely by seeded players last night at the 102d Engineers Armory when, led by Leonard Hartman, the defender, they came through their third-round matches successfully.

Sinus infections, which afflict about 95 per cent of New York residents from time to time, have been found in animal researches at the Columbia University School of Medicine often to be closely allied with meningitis, changes in the blood vessels, and other serious conditions, according to a report made public yesterday by the university.
The steel industry is girding up its loins and gathering its forces to repel what promises to be the strongest attack ever made upon it as the citadel of the open shop in American industry.

Trustees of the Lafayette Avenue Friends Church, Lafayette and Washington Avenues, Brooklyn, offered yesterday to the Cadman Memorial Committee their church building and the site on which it stands for a memorial to the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman.

The Crescent Athletic Club quintet turned back the Seventh Regiment by a 37-to-25 score in an Eastern Athletic Club League game on the former's court yesterday. The triumph was the fifth in eleven tournament contests for the New Mooners, who held a 21-17 advantage at the half. Orville Terjesen and Joe Condict paced the attack with eight points each, while Beahan led the invaders with nine tallies.

More than 55,000 boys, out of a total membership of 255,163, were enrolled in vocational classes during 1936 under the auspices of the Boys Clubs of America, Inc., according to the annual report made public yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Crosby Kindleberger of Flushing, Queens, and June Cottage, Jamestown, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Wirt Kindleberger, to William H. Wetherill, son of Mr. and.Mrs. Herbert J. Wetherill of Philadelphia and Jamestown.

A community meeting, called in protest against President Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization plan, progressed serenely this afternoon until James C. Cleary, a New York attorney active in Democratic party affairs, declared:
Spokesmen for the Federal Communications Commission advocated today approval by Congress of the Copeland bill to extend regulations governing the use of the radio on American ships.

Fairy Hill, from the same stable that sent Rosemont out to win the San Antonio Handicap on Saturday, captured the $62,925 Santa Anita Derby today after a thrilling stretch battle with Military, Ptolemy and the California-bred Brown Jade.

President Roosevelt's program to reform the Federal judiciary was unanimously endorsed today at a meeting of the National Committee for Clarifying the Constitution by Amendment, but the delegates, terming the Presidential proposal only a temporary expedient, insisted that an amendment must also be inserted in the national charter.

Traffic on the city's transportation facilities increased 5.3 per cent for the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with the three months ended Sept. 30, 1935, the Transit Commission reported yesterday. The principal increases in

In the guise of a tribute to George Washington on. the anniversary of his birth, Assemblyman Laurens Hamilton, Republican, a nephew of J. P. Morgan, put through the Assembly tonight a resolution taking an indirect slap at President Roosevelt for his judiciary reform program.

We are often told that Great Britain has no Supreme Court and yet manages to get along very well. There are even reports that many Britons are incredulous regarding the power of our own Supreme Court to declare acts of Congress unconstitutional. These incredulous Britons cannot have studied very well the institutions of their own Empire. It is not merely that
President Roosevelt today appealed to the Assembly to concur with the Senate and add his own State to the list of those that have ratified the Federal Child Labor Amendment.

Dress purchases in the wholesale market here last week maintained a fair average, with the majority of orders stressing early delivery. In better price groups, black, navy and beige-and-black were important, with redingote and bolero styles coming to the fore. Dinner and bridesmaid dresses led in the demand for formal types.
A holiday crowd with a holiday spirit saw the National Sportsmen's Show yesterday, the 29,000 who visited Grand Central Palace setting an individual day's attendance record.

Brainerd H. Whitbeck Jr. of Bronxville today captured the Class A title in the fourth annual championship of the Westchester division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

Seeking a basis for lasting peace between General Motors and the United Automobile Workers of America, representatives of the corporation and the union continued today discussions of seniority rights with much apparently yet to be accomplished before an agreement on that issue.

The Mexican Official Gazette carries another notice today of a meeting March 1 of stockholders to carry out the liquidation of Petro-Mex, government-controlled oil company, of which 49 per cent of the stock is privately owned.

For the first time in the history of boxing in the East, fight fans enjoyed the novelty of witnessing a series of simultaneous bouts yesterday at Madison Square Garden, where The Daily News A. A. conducted preliminaries and quarterfinals in the fourteenth annual Golden Gloves competition.

President Lazaro Cardenas has removed General Rafael Navarro Cortina as Governor and Military Commander of the Northern District of Lower California on account of complaints that gambling had been resumed on the border.

William Alexander Jr. Chapter, United Daughters of the Confederacy, celebrated its twelfth anniversary and the ninety-second birthday of the late Mrs. Mary Alexander Field, honorary president of the general organization and mother of Mrs. Charles D. Lanier, the chapter president, with a reception yesterday afternoon, at which about seventy members and guests attended.

Richard K. Mellon of Pittsburgh scored a double victory in the Springdale course races today, taking the coveted Washington birthday plate with his Escape III, and winning the final event, the one-mile on the flat, with his Pool Box.

Some form of religious instruction should be given to the school children of New York City, Benjamin " Veit, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday at the tenth anniversary luncheon of the Jewish Teachers Association at the Hotel Commodore.
McGill's Red Raiders roared to the championship of the International Intercollegiate Hockey League tonight when they turned back Harvard by' the score of 7-2.

Lou Ambers, world's lightweight champion, had a workout for the defense of his title on April 2 against Tony Canzoneri last night at the St. Nicholas Palace, and his spar-mate was Al Roth, sturdy young Bronxite.

Lack of "good angels with fat pocketbooks" has caused the Democratic National Committee to adopt a policy of holding a series of dinners on March 4 as a method of raising money to pay its deficit of about $430,000, W. Forbes Morgan, its treasurer, explained last night.
The Merchants Association of New York took a firm stand yesterday in opposition to the proposal of President Roosevelt for enlarging the Supreme Court.
President Roosevelt conferred with a group of farm leaders on his judiciary reorganization plan and motored to Mount Vernon to lay a wreath on the tomb of George Washington.

Gross interest earnings of life insurance companies probably will not even approach the 1929 figure for many years to come, regardless of what happens to the money market in the immediate future, in the opinion of Don F. Roberts, treasurer of the Acadia Mutual Life, who addressed the mid-year meeting of the financial section of the American Life Convention held yesterday in the Palmer House, Chicago.
Dr. Herman Scheulein, in 1,136 Fifth Av.; Warren L. Marks, Danien Brener, Inc., broker. Mrs. Estelle Hyde, in 45 Christopher St.; Dr. Max Liebman, in 150 W. 79th St.; Bing Bing, Inc., broker.

President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth was the guest of the directors of the 1939 World's Fair on a tour of New York night clubs last night. The President 'and his party dined at the Crystal Room of the Ritz Carlton and later visited the Radio City Music Hall and the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center.

The snarled James J. BraddookMax Sohmeling-Joe Louis heavyweight championship. situation in boxing took a new turn yesterday when Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C., who holds contracts on the two challengers and is closely associated with the champion, held out what was interpreted by many as an olive branch to the Madison Square Garden Corporation.

The Pyne Honor Prize, highest general distinction. Princeton University can confer upon an undergraduate, was presented to Thomas Gucker 3d, a senior from Germantown, Pa., by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university, at the annual midwinter meeting of the National Alumni Association in Nassau Hall this morning.

Lady Lister Kaye is expected to arrive today from Washington. She will be at the Ambassador for several weeks before going to London. Miss Jane Robb Murdoch will give a luncheon today in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for Princess Daria Obolensky, who will be married on March 12 to Hans George Spitzer.
The text of the favorable report of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, recommending passage of the Pittman neutrality resolution, follows:

Music and the theatre are represented in the sailing of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary today, with the list including -John Gielgud, Frank Lawton and Edmund Gwenn, actors; Evelyn Laye, actress; Jascha Heifetz, violinist, and F. L. Harley, film producer, with Mrs. Harley.

Norman Bright of the Olympic Club, San Francisco, stole the limelight in the first annual Westchester County A. A. U. track championship by lapping his field in the two-mile event at the County Center tonight.

The United Aircraft Corporation and its subsidiaries realized a consolidated net profit in 1936 of $1,926,442 after Federal and Canadian income taxes, Federal surtax on undistributed earnings, depreciation, minority interest in the profits of the Canadian Pratt Whitney Aircraft Company, Ltd., and other charges, according to their report issued yesterday.

In all likelihood the John Golden Theatre will have for its next tenant "Arms for Venus," which should arrive there Tuesday evening, March 9. It is a comedy by Randolph Carter, the action taking place in Rome during the days of Nero. In it the author depicts Nero in one of his amorous episodes. A cast of five will include Hortense Alden and Felton Bickley.
Bright green wheat was sprouting here today, not in wheat fields, but on top of a trainload of grain from the Ohio River flood zone.

The Senate alone has power of impeachment and its acts are not subject to review by any court, the government maintained today as it replied to the petition of former Judge Halsted L. Ritter, who now seeks to have the Supreme Court overturn his removal from office last April.

Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, addressing representatives of workers in the Berlin arsenals and other military establishments, informed them today that they need nourish no hopes of increases in wages in the near future.
The Consolidated Steel Corporation's bookings to date exceed 2,150,000 tons, it was indicated by reports at the corporation's annual meeting on Friday.
