Carl P. Dennet and John G. Enderlin were elected directors of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad at the annual meeting yesterday to fill vacancies. Sixtyfive per cent of the outstanding stock of the company was represented at the meeting and 75 per cent of it was voted.

Conservation is the most pressing and vital domestic problem facing the United States today, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, asserted last night at the first annual dinner of the New York Rod and Gun Editors Association in the Hotel Commodore; Conservation, he held, should have the support of all Americans.

A decision upholding a Civil Service Commission ruling requiring court clerks to take qualifying examinations for their jobs was. handed down yesterday by Justice Leander B. Faber in a special term of Supreme Court in Queens.

Miss Lola M. Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Lee of Jamaica, Queens, and Idlewood, Adirondack State Park, will be married to Ross M. Turner, son of Mrs. Ross Miller Turner of this city, formerly of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Turner, on April 10.
A 21year-old Russian-born Norwegian, Edvard Belgonen, who has been arrested at Tana, North Norway, on a charge of espionage is alleged to have admitted his guilt.

Mrs. Clark Frazier and Woodruff Rankin Tappen were married here today by the Rev. Fred Niedringhaus. The fathers of the couple, Herbert Lincoln Clark of Philadelphia and George H. Tappen of New York, were present.
Guests came in beach pajamas and play suits to the beach party given today at the Surf Club by Mrs. Alfred J. Sweet of Swampsott, Mass.
To Report to Medical Chief The following ununiformed; firemen shall be directed to report to the chief medical officer, at these headquarters, at 10 A. M. Thursday, Feb. 25:

Rudy Dusek of Omaha threw Hank Barber of Cambridge, Mass., in the feature wrestling match at the St. Nicholas Palace before a crowd of 2,000 last night. Dusek, weighing 218, two pounds less than his rival, won in 35:45 with a body press.

Evidence that lead acetate and arsenic were administered to Mr. and Mrs. George Reeves on many occasions last August, September and early October, was introduced today in the trial of Chang Soo Lee, Korean houseman accused of attempted first-degree murder.

Another physician who issued fake medical certificates in the socalled Bornstein gang's conspiracy through which hundreds of fraudulent accident indemnity claims were filed with insurance companies in the last four years pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: CUSTOMS 3980-United States v. Irving P. Favor.Opinion by Judge Garrett. The United L States Customs Court judgment is affirmed. Dissenting. Judges Hatfield and Lenroot.
The boss moved out of his office after his employes had moved out of the plant at Fry Products, Inc., today, the first mutual strike in industrial history ended by agreement.

Transit Commissioner Reuben L. Haskell ordered the engineering deapartment of the commission yesterday to prepare estimates showing the cost of building a single escalator for the use of commuters in Grand Central Terminal.
A change in the prospect facing the Kleinfeld resolution to ratify the Federal Child Labor. Amendment had tonight put in jeopardy its adoption in the Republican-controlled Assembly.

The New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia. Brico, conductor, offered an unusually interesting program, which it performed brilliantly, last night in Carnegie Hall. This was the twelfth concert given by the present orchestra, which gave its first concert in Town Hall in February of 1935.

Secretary Morgenthau declared today that an addition by employers of 2 per cent to their bills or invoices with the notation that the increase is a Social Security tax is a "palpable misrepresentation" of the Social Security Tax Law.

Samuel Rosoff today requested police protection of his properties along the Hudson River, following the destruction by fire of the Hudson River night liner Benjamin B. Odell on the waterfront of this town late Monday night. Rosoff has property in Poughkeepsie, Newburgh, Troy and Albany.
Winston Guest, high-ranking polo player, and his mother left here tonight for New York to sail for London, where his father, Captain F. E. Guest, is suffering from a liver ailment.

United States PRINCIPAL. INDIAN COMMUNITY AND BOARDING SCHOOLS 33,200, $2,600 and $2,000 a year. Indian Field Service, including Alaska, Department of the Interior. Applications must be on file not later than March 23, if received from States other than those named below; March 26, if received from the following States: Arizona,

Fifteen of the twenty-five members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee agreed today upon a neutrality resolution vesting wide discretionary powers in the President in time of war abroad, and the measure will be reported favorably to the House tomorrow.

Daniel Joseph Sullivan, musical comedy and character actor, who had parts in many productions featuring Eddie Dowling, died yesterday morning at the Medical Arts Sanitarium, 57 West Fifty-seventh Street, at the age of 63.

Employers in the wholesale dry goods trade, who have been conducting a "strike" in defense of their right to collective bargaining, indicated last night that they would abandon their insistence on an unconditional -right to discharge or transfer workers, chief obstacle to negotiations between the employers' association and their employes' union.

Notices for about 16,000 bales, out of the total certificated stock of 34,000, were circulated yesterday on the New Orleans and New York Cotton Exchanges, Most of the cotton was taken up promptly by a spot firm and prices advanced 10 to 15 points before weakness in the stock market halted the rise and closed the list with gains of 4 to 13 points.

Frederick Hollin, 54 years old, of 1,587 Second Avenue, Manhattan, while working at Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn, today, was crushed to death by a vegetable truck which backed toward the storehouse of the institution.

Ralph Walter, one of the directors of The Times of London and also a contributor on a variety of subjects, died here today of at the age of 65. The youngest son of John Walter ??d, he was the uncle of John Walter, the present chief proprietor of The Times.
A building loan for $115,000 has been arranged by Byrne Bowman for the six-story apartment which is to be erected on the east side of Park Terrace East, 25.3 feet south of 215th Street.

Workmen began yesterday to set in place the first of a series of timber frames of thirty-two tons each to be used to brace the walls of the Manhattan ventilating shaft of the Thirty-eighth Street Midtown Tunnel to Queens.

Through inadvertence, THE NEW YORK TIMES on Monday announced that Assemblyman Edmund J. Delaney, Democrat, of New York, had voted last week with the other Democratic Assemblymen against the Brownell bill authorizing New York City to issue $19,000,000 in bonds to finance a new criminal court building. Mr.

Rear Admiral Henry Thomas Mayo, U.S.N. (retired), commander-in-chief of the Atlantic Fleet during the World War, died here at the home of his son, Captain Chester G. Mayo, this morning of a heart attack. His age was 80 years.
President Roosevelt today expressed dissatisfaction with the Copeland Pure Food and Drug Bill as now drawn and indicated that he might oppose its passage.
Any undue significance in the address delivered in Paris last night by William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador, was denied at the State Department today.

Thirty members of the Cuban Revolutionary party were seized early this morning when police raided a stenographic school. The prisoners asserted they had assembled to discuss plans to organize a new party for participation in the election of delegates for the coming Constituent Assembly.

The President of the United States' the Governor of New York, the Mayor of- the city, and others in public affairs, joined yesterday in expressions of regret that were a--tribute to the great influence of the late Rollo Ogden, editor of .THE NEW YORK TIMES through editorials to which he never attached his name during almost fifty years.
Artur Rodzinski, leader of the Cleveland Orchestra, will begin his term as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for eight weeks, beginning tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall.

Mrs. Nellie Stratton Sweetland, 33-year-old beauty-shop operator, won in Federal court today her suit claiming a widow's share of the estate of Louis R. Sweetland, 75-year-old millionaire banker and oil man.

The Rev. R. S. Tinnon, State superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, said today that the arrest of W. G. Gaston on a charge of drunkenness in Union City led to his dismissal as a field secretary by the organization.

Five places in the third round of the seventh annual Junior League invitation squash racquets tournament were filled yesterday, as members of the visiting English team and Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of the American Internationalists entered a final warming-up session before the Wolfe-Noel Trophy match on Saturday.

Former Lieut. Commander John S. Farnsworth, charged with conspiring to sell navy secrets to Japan, lost in District Court today a motion to withdraw a plea by which he threw himself on the mercy of the court.
Representatives of motorists' organizations opposed the establishment of: any fixed speed limit on State highways at a public hearing today on almost 100 bills affecting motor vehicles.

George W. Jacoby, an architect who had been associated with Trowbridge Livingston, 101 Park. Avenue, since 1905, died Sunday of pneumonia at his residence, 65 East Ninety-sixth Street, at the age of 56. His widow, the former Helen M. Lowengrund of Philadelphia; a daughter, Kathryn; a son, Donald, and two sisters survive.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Julia Schaefer Blundell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Blundell of this place, to Eric Adler, son of Mrs. Elsie Ehrich of New York and of Max Adler of Rochester, N. Y.

The Alabama Legislature received a proposal today that lobbyists wear distinctive uniforms to distinguish them from members of the Legislature. A resolution offered by Representative Chichester of Birmingham would specify the following distinctive garbs:

Sir Henry Jackson, Conservative member of Parliament and noted traffic expert, died at a public dinner here tonight. He assisted in coordination of all traffic service within the Metropolitan area and played a considerable part in the negotiations for the London Traffic Act.
Bedford Park Blvd. (12-3320), s. w. s., 123 ft. n. w. of Grand Concourse, 150x117; Flame Realty Corp. to Villford Realty Corp., 165 Broadway: mtg., $212,900.
Luxury items of a type rarely encountered in recent years stood out as active sellers at the fifteenth semi-annual New York Gift Show being held at the Hotel Pennsylvania this week.

One month before her 101st birthday, Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser, "dean of Brooklyn clubwomen," made her stage debut before about 200 members of the Kosmos Club of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. In the role of George Washington's mother,

The stock market here was dull and generally pessimistic today. The boom that developed yesterday in metal shares came to an abrupt halt when speculators began to take their profits from the gains. Gilt-edge issues,

Custom tailoring will reach a new high in volume of business within the next few years because of the greater variety in color and design of men's clothes, increased leisure and the more widespread attention being paid to good dress,

In some states proposals ror a onehouse Legislature are palpable borrowings from Nebraska. In Ohio the subject has been discussed for a number of years. The adoption of Mr. NORRIS'S experiment in his own State has stimulated the efforts of Buckeye reformers.

The directors of the Third Avenue Railway Company declared yesterday a semi-annual interest payment on the adjustment 5 per cent income bonds due in 1960, at the rate of 1 1/4 per cent, payable on April 1.
The undefeated Canadian and English teams, along with Germany and Switzerland advanced to the final round of the world amateur hockey championship tonight.
Governor Horner assumed the role of intermediary today in an effort to break the deadlock in the week-old sit-down strike at the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation in North Chicago.

Italian public opinion is aroused by what the Giornale d'Italia's London correspondent calls "the unexpected, almost unbelievable announcement" that former Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia had been invited to attend King George's coronation.

Marshall Field's 1935 Belmont Futurity hero, Tintagel, finally broke the jinx that had shadowed him this Winter and won the featured Tampico Handicap at Hialeah Park today. It was the bay colt's fifth start at the Miami Jockey Club track.

Church disturbances occurred again today in Orizaba, State of Veracruz, when hundreds of persons congregated in front of the Municipal Palace to demand that church keys be turned over to them as a means of solving the church problem in that center of the Veracruz religious tumult.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the Brooklyn Edison Company yesterday, Ralph H. Tapscott, vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, was elected a director to fill a vacancy caused by the death of D. J. Creem in 1936.
George A. Slater of Fort Chester, surrogate of Westchester. County, who was stricken with appendicitis here last Tuesday and removed to Moore County Hospital, died there today. He was 69 years old.
President Roosevelt joined members of Congress today in expressing deep sorrow at the death of Representative James P. Buchanan of Texas, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

The police were asked yesterday to help find Dr. Maurice Goldfinger, a physician, of 1,716 Avenue T, Brooklyn, missing since about 9 A. M. Monday. He was last seen by his wife, Pearl Goldfinger, just before he drove off in his automobile to make some professional calls.

Shouting threats of future trouble for a Roman Catholic priest who in a sermon had criticized certain Nazi proposals as pagan, two men who said they were Germans caused such a disturbance in the rectory of the Paulist Church, 415 West Fiftyninth Street, last Sunday that they were forcibly ejected.
Twelve newspaper men accompanied the German Foreign Minister on his trip to Vienna. It is hard to see why.

In a reserved, orderly meeting at which black ties and evening dresses. were conspicuous, some 700 citizens of Bronxville condemned tonight President Roosevelt's proposal to alter the Supreme Court when they adopted a resolution demanding that their elected representatives in Washington try to do something about it.

IF it is an ill wind that blows nobody good, we must look forward with pleasure to the future work of Compton Mackenzie. For Mr. Mackenzie, after thirty years of writing both trash and literature ("Sinister Street" no doubt belongs in the latter category), has seized time by the forelock and the compass by the needle and begun a long, literary and somewhat ventose tetralogy involving East, South, West and North.

AT the moment there are above the heavyweight horizon just about an even half dozen prominent figures, three of them in escrow, so to speak, and three on the loose. The three in escrow are James J. Braddock, Shufflin' Joe Louis and Herr Max Schmeling. The three on the loose are Gunnar Barlund, Nathan Mann and Arturo Godoy.

Gifts amounting to about $170,000 were announced today by the Yale University Corporation, following its February meeting. Among them were $60,000 from the estate of Elizabeth Evans; $67,916 from the Rockefeller Foundation, for immediate use in the university for research and publication;
About eighty sit-down strikers who refused to obey a police demand that they evacuate the Electric Boat Company plant here were arrested early today on charges of trespassing.
Public offering will be made today of 120,000 shares of $1 par value common stock of United Specialties Company at $16 a share by Russell Maguire Co., Inc., and Whitlock, Smith Co.

With Leonard Will setting the pace with nine tallies, the undefeated Scarborough School five downed Pawling, 37--26, at Pawling yesterday in one of the leading scholastic games of the day. The victory was the fourteenth of the season for the Scarborough players, who led by 25--10 at the intermission.

The Chicago Rapid Transit Company (elevated lines) incurred a larger deficit in 1936 than in the preceding year, although it carried more passengers and collected more revenue, stockholders were informed today at the annual meeting.

The NRA blue eagle will draw its last breath early next month when Miss Diana Rogovin cashes her final pay check. Miss Rogovin is the sole survivor of the huge staff which mushroomed to include 5,300 employes at the height of National Recovery Administration activities

Miss Sophie Kilbreth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Kilbreth of this city and Hewlett, L. I., has chosen April 17 as the date for her marriage to Ernest Patrick Bernuth. The wedding will take place that afternoon in Trinity Church, Hewlett.

Mrs. Maria Von Kreisler, wife of Alexander Von Kreisler, director of the opera department at the Conservatory of Music and chorus director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, died at Christ Hospital today after a short illness.

Steadily rising two inches an hour all day, the Connecticut River early this evening was nearly fourteen feet above mean low water, but reports from Vermont and Northern Massachusetts indicated that the Connecticut River Valley is not in immediate danger of serious floods.

Old colleagues were the sorrowing congregation at Westminster Cathedral this morning at funeral services for Ernest Marshall, London correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1908 to 1924. Who died Saturday.

Stockholders of the International Silver Company at their meeting on March 25 will be asked to create 108,000 shares of a new preference stock and to reduce the present par value of its 110,000 shares of $100 par-value common stock to $50 par value. If approved,

W. E. Hutton Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of having manipulated the market stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation, were charged today with having

Irving Epstein, one of the union officials who are defendants in the restaurant racket trial, was confronted yesterday with bank accounts showing deposits of $11,534 in thirteen months. His salary during that period was $75 weekly, or a total of $4,200.

MADRID, Feb. 23.--Reports were received today of an Insurgent offensive directed at Viver, thirtyfour miles northwest of Valencia on the Teruel front. Late advices said government troops had halted the advance in the neighborhood of Mora de Rubielos. [This town is about twenty miles north of Viver.]
Changing trends in the social life of Great Britain were revealed in the vital statistics of England and Wales for 1935, issued today by Registrar General S. P. Vivian.
Longview's householders grasped baby carriages, bird cages or anything else that would hold a fish and went down to meet the smelt run of the Cowlitz River today.

Most members of Congress agreed today that Representative Hobbs was asking altogether too much of them. Some said privately they would be glad to do almost anything else for him-lend him their best bird dogs or let him share their speaking time on the floor.

Stocks weakened and closed lower, leading shares falling 1 to 5 points; turnover, 2,869,150 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds generally lower, foreign loans irregular; transactions, $13,189,200.

Messages from India record some concern for the safety of Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, who are believed to be on a flight to Australia. They left Jodhpur, India, at 3:30 P. M. yesterday and since then they have been unreported.

Paraguay dropped out of the League of Nations officially today with a statement that the Geneva body no longer held jurisdiction over the territorial dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay, cause of the three-year Chaco War.

David W. Moore Jr., last of the old glass manufacturers who for many years provided this town with its principal industry, died today at his residence after an illness of two weeks. His age was 73. He was one of the founders of the Clayton National Bank and its president for the last twenty-one years.

The five-story store and apartment building at 151 East Fortyfifth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, has been sold by Arthur Knox, trustee, to Norman S. Riesenfeld, Inc. The property is assessed at $70,000 and was sold for cash. above a mortgage of $26,500.

The newshawks of the WPA's Living Newspaper are having themselves quite a time in "Power," which they put on at the Ritz last evening. After burrowing into history, court records and newspaper files they have come out impartially against the electric light and power industry and for TVA, practically defying the Supreme Court in the last scene to. sustain the injunction against TVA's construction of new power lines for new customers.

W. McQueeny of the Squash Club, third in the seeded list, and J. W. Taylor of the Montclair A. C., fourth in the rankings, both advanced to the second round in the metropolitan Class B. squash racquets championships, opened yesterday at the Harvard Club.

It is unusual in the history of education from the time of SOCRATES that the son has succeeded the father as a great teacher or school administrator. Among the few and notable exceptions is that of the ANGELLS--JAMES B. ANGELL of Michigan and JAMES R. ANGELL of Yale.
The National Dairy Products Corporation has asked stockholders to approve at their annual meeting on April 15 an increase in the authorized common stock from 7,000,000 shares to 8,000,000.

The steel structure of the seven-story apartment dwelling at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, which collapsed last June 19 killing eighteen men, was fabricated and erected by a concern whose executive officers knew nothing about iron and steel construction, the secretary of the company admitted yesterday.

Miss Judith Hamlin, daughter of Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin of New York and East Hampton, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to Charles Percy Frederick North, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick North of Rougham Hall, Norfolk, England, which will take place here the afternoon of March 11 in the Central Presbyterian Church.

Mrs. Osa Johnson was lifted today aboard the train that will carry her and the body of her husband, Martin Johnson, the explorer, back to the Kansas town from which the couple began their world-wide explorations years ago. "I'm taking my husband home," she said.

New Bowery, 21, 28.3x68.8x rreg.; Allied Metal Yards, Inc., to Marie J. and Clara M. Doscher, 195-14 90th Av., Hollis Park Gardens ($1). La Salle St., 100-102, 50x101: Central Savings Bank to Eulos Realty Construction Corp., 121 W. 79th St. ($40).
Members of the New York Stock Exchange were invited yesterday to meet the nominating committee on March. 8, 15 and 22 to consider the make-up of the official slate for the annual election on May 10.

Reeling off seven birdies and finishing four strokes under women's par, Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S. C., carried off the medal today in the qualifying round of the South Atlantic championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club. The 1936 champion of the Carolinas led a record field of seventytwo starters with a card of 39, 34--73.

Leonard Hartman, defending titleholder, came from behind to beat Sid Berger, former N. Y. U. netman, 2--6, 6--4, 6--4, in the quarterfinal round of the metropolitan indoor tennis championship at the 102d Regiment Armory yesterday.

Palestine is the one haven for oppressed Jews and the possibility of transferring 3,000,000 European Jews there is "by no means an idle dream," Lord Melchett, British industrialist, writes in "Thy Neighbour," a book published today by H. C. Kinsey Co. Inc.

Mobilization of liberal organizations of the city for a mass meeting in opposition to the President's Supreme Court proposal has been begun by the First Voters League, of which Alfred M. Lilienthal is president.

Governor Lehman will be the principal speaker at the dinner for Charles Poletti, his counsel, tomorrow night at the Hotel Astor, given by the New York Young Democratio Club, Anthony P. Ruffalo, chairman of the dinner committee, announced yesterday.
The War Department released the following orders today dated Feb. 20: MAJOR GENERAL Birnie, U. Jr., chief of Field Artillery, 2 days leave, Feb. 26.

The election of the Rev. Louis W. Spitz as president of Concordia Collegiate Institute, Lutheran junior college and high school on the White Plains Post Road, was announced today by the Board of Electors.

Alabama's 2 per cent general sales tax became law today under the signature of Governor Bibb Graves. Repealing the State's 1 1/2 per cent gross receipts tax law, it will go into effect March 1. The tax is to be levied on retail sales and amusement admissions, the State Tax Commission to issue brass and aluminum tokens to facilitate its payment by the consumer.
Hearings in the Securities and Exchange Commission's action against C. C. Wright and others for alleged manipulation of the stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd.,

CHICAGO, Feb. 23.--The most ambitious movement for a wage advance in the history of collective bargaining on the nation's railroads was opened here today when 1,000 general chairmen of sixteen standard railway unions decided to ask a general increase of 20 cents an hour for all employes.

Britain's proposed barrage of balloons designed to protect London and other large cities from raiding aircraft will rise so high that airplane pilots must be equipped with oxygen apparatus and ascend almost into the stratosphere to surmount it.
Charles G. Little, chairman of the board of Wilson Brothers, manufacturers and distributors of men's haberdashery, was today elected president of the company, effective March 1.
Mr. and Mrs. John M. L. Ruther furd gave a large party today at their home for those participating in the Washington Birthday regatta and many others.

The proposal of President Roosevelt to enlarge the Supreme Court was opposed by about 2 to 1 in the Trenton area, according to the results of a poll conducted by The Trenton Evening Times last Thursday.

Funeral services for the Rev. Brother Cantidius Thomas, former president of Manhattan College, were held yesterday morning in the De La Salle Chapel on the Manhattan campus. Almost a thousand persons, including many prominent clergymen and many members of the Manhattan faculty, alumni and student body, attended.

Walter Geer, who wrote six volumes on the Bonaparte family and the French Revolutionary period after he had retired in 1919 as a terra cotta manufacturer, died here today in his apartment at 65 Lincoln Boulevard after an illness of several months. He was 79 years old.

With the eyes of Bermuda's golfers on him today, the mighty Babe Ruth struck out. He proved no match for T. Suffern Tailer in the final round of the fourth annual Mid-Ocean invitation tournament, losing by 6 and 5.

Frank A. Ryan, known for nearly half a century in the ocean freight business in New York, died suddenly yesterday morning of a heart attack at his home, 261 Upper Mountain Avenue, Upper Montclair, N. J., in his sixty-second year.

A strike call was directed tonight against three score New England shoe factories and within a few hours seventeen firms reported that they would meet the demands of the United Shoe and Leather Workers Union. William Mahan, general organizer for the union, said:
Dr. Clarence H. Thurber has resigned as president of the University of Redlands under an agreement with trustees, whereby he will retire June 30 and receive- a year's leave of absence with full pay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a lawyer experienced in farming, I desire to commend THE TIMES editorial regarding the President's proposed bill on crop insurance. As you point out, what the farmer needs is only what every other business venture requires, namely, insurance against loss of investment to make the crop or the "cost of production."
Canada is paying off her international indebtedness and internally is recovering quickly but should take advantage of returning prosperity to balance budgets rather than reduce taxation.

There was not much news at President Roosevelt's press conference today, but reporters and the Chief Executive had some fun. A news man asked if there was any special reason why Ambassador William E. Dodd was returning from Berlin.
Elisha Lee Jr., unseeded Block Hall player, won the Group 2 championship of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association by vanquishing Donald Aitchison of Bayside at the City Athletic Club last night.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended the registration statement of the Bankers Union Life Company of Denver. It held that the statement "includes untrue statements of material facts and omits to state material facts required to be stated therein and omits to state material facts necessary to make the statement not misleading."
The Yankee holdout brigade lost one of its charter members yesterday when Jake Powell, fleet-footed outfielder who was a star in the world series last October, signed his contract.

United States Ambassador and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies have just returned to Moscow from a visit to Leningrad, and now Mr. Davies is planning a tour of the industrial region of the Donetz Kharkov, Kiev and Rostov, starting later thus week.
Sixteen daughters of Senators gave their annual party tonight at the Shoreham Hotel. They picked their own escorts. Only two "letter men" received invitations.

The Washington Award for 1987 was presented tonight by a commission representing five engineering societies to Dr. Frederick G. Cottrell, chemist, metallurgist and inventor, of Washington, D. C., widely known for his research in the production of helium.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Swan, a trained nurse, formerly director of the social service of the Fifth Avenue Hospital, this city, died on Monday night at the home of her sister, Mrs. William Weber of Oakland, Md., according to word received here. A heart ailment had forced her retirement from the Fifth Avenue Hospital several years ago.

Amendments to the Fischel-Steingut Minimum Wage Bill offered today in the Senate, were represented as being the limit to which the Lehman administration intends to go toward compromise with the Republicans.

The trucking business in the United States is steadily .being concentrated in the hands of a few large companies, it was indicated in figures made public today by the United States Bureau of the Census.

Richard C. Raddatz, an expert in the modern methods of mounting animals in habitat groups, died on Sunday in Nairobi, Africa, according to word received by the American Museum of Natural History. He died of a heart ailment after an illness of two days. Burial took place in Nairobi.
Due to the holiday on Monday the number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably less than in the preceding week.

The Administration's Reciprocal Trade Agreements Bill was called up in the Senate today and immediately was attacked on the Republican side as "unfortunate, ill advised, unwarranted and in direct violation of the Constitution of the United States."

Trust Co. of New Jersey took over the two four-story thirteen-family brick flats, 317-319 Fairmount Av., Jersey City, N. J. The parcel was owned by Hugh Meehan and is assessed at $95.800. The sale was under foreclosure of three mortgages totaling $174,786.

Mayor Joseph P. Conover of Eagle Rock Avenue, a dentist, with offices in Caldwell, who had been Mayor of Roseland for eighteen years, consecutively, except for an interval of two years, died this afternoon in St. Vincent's Hospital, Montclair, after an operation for appendicitis.

The big Douglas aircraft plant at Santa Monica stopped production operations today after about 500 of its 5,600 employes began a sit-down strike with a demonstration like that of college football fans between halves of a game.

Despite the advance of 1 cent a pound in the domestic price of copper to the highest level in about seven years, the mining shares generally were lower yesterday, although some of them sold at new high levels in the day's early tradding.
Mrs. Frode Rambusen of New York died suddenly last night. She was 71 years old. The body was placed on the Carinthia tonight.
The Friedrich Krupp Company, through its Istanbul representative, has signed a contract with the Turkish Government for the construction of fourteen merchant vessels in German shipyards.

The managers of Columbia College's varsity show, traditionally male in character until last year, when girls were admitted to the cast, were forced yesterday to recast six feminine roles when it was learned that the two leading actresses and four others in this year's review were ineligible. The basis was that they were not taking sufficient college work.

Steel ingot production last week increased by slightly more than the seasonal amount and the adjusted index has advanced to 113.9 from 113.8 in the previous week and compares with 71.9 for the week ended Feb. 22. 1936.

Mrs. Amelia Sanders, 36 years old, was critically injured at about 12:30 A. M. today when she fell or jumped from the thirteenth-floor penthouse apartment she occupied at 10 Monroe Street, in Knickerbocker Village.
Completely recovered from his recent siege of illness, which had detained him in Memphis, Colonel Bill Terry arrived today to take active command of the Giants' training campaign.

Dr. A. J. Doran, former head of the Federal Alcohol Control Administration, urged the liquor industry today to "support and obey wise public regulation," and forecast "more stable conditions ahead" for the dealers.

Everett Andrew Colson, former financial adviser to Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, died tonight in George Washington Hospital. Mr. Colson, who assisted the Emperor during the Italo-Ethiopian war, had returned to-this country after becoming ill in Europe.
Elections in the Protestant Church will be held April 11. Two non-Nazi groups, the Prussian Confessional Synod and the Lutheran Council, have agreed not to oppose each other's candidates.

The British shipping industry has emerged from a long period of depression and aided by a system of freight cooperation and backed by the assistance of the government, shipowners are taking full advantage of the rapid increase in the demand for tonnage.

A young physician, Dr. R. H. Herman of Cincinnati, hung up an apparent new world record for Class 225 hydroplanes today on a course so choppy that the Palm Beach Yacht Club's races were deplayed frequently until the water became smoother.
The government announced another public loan of 500,000,000 marks tonightthe first this year--"for the purpose of continuing the tasks assumed by the Reich Government."
A new $10,000 prize contest for the most interesting unpublished work of fiction submitted before Feb. 1, 1938, is offered jointly by the Atlantic Monthly Press and Little, Brown Co. of Boston.
Exemption of real estate improvements taxation is likely to become an issue in the movement to limit taxes on this type of property, according to research specialists of the Twentieth Century Fund.

With the field limited to metropolitan players, the national amateur Class B 18.2 balkline billiard championship got under way last night at the Capitol Health Center as Jerome Strauss of Manhattan and Joseph R. Johann of Jamaica recorded victories.

Dr. Fred E. Warriner, Mayor of Winnipeg, Canada, visited City Hall yesterday in connection with his survey of airlines in this country upon which he will base a proposed trans-Canadian air service in which Winnipeg will be one of the chief terminals.

No convincing reason has yet been given for the change of front which is responsible for the submission of the President's Supreme Court plan to Congress. It has been pointed out that the 1936 platform of the Democratic party made no mention of any plan to increase the membership of the court in order to obtain a different interpretation of the Constitution.

Frank Carcion, founder and president of Carcion-Manfre Co., Inc., 42 West Fifty-seventh Street, manufacturers and retailers of women's shoes, died yesterday in the Misericordia Hospital after an operation for an intestinal ailment.
Intermittent pain disturbed Pope Pius tonight, although his condition was reported fundamentally unchanged. The tight bindings on his legs added to his discomfiture, it was understood.

In formation received from authoritative sources in Germany that a showdown is approaching on economic policies is confirmed here and in Holland by business men and officials in close touch with developments across the border.

School men's present talk of educating for "a new social order" is playing into the hands of the Communists and the Fascists, Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, told thousands of school administrators

Having proved their ability to move surplus crops of.various farm commodities, special advertising and promotion campaigns will be used this year by both growers and distributors on a wider scale than ever before, according to comment here yesterday. Original advertising campaigns by grower groups has been followed by cooperative drives by food chains,. with the independent grocery retailers. the latest to join in this new marketing procedure.

A great deal of action is promised for today's session of the National Sportsmen's Show now in progress at the Grand Central Palace. The oyster shucking derby that is expected to provide a good many laughs (and oysters, too) will be one of the features.

Dock Commissioner John McKenzie disclosed last night that he had submitted a comprehensive plan for developing the municipal airport at North Beach, Queens, with the hope of having it designated as the international seaplane terminus for the proposed transatlantic service planned by the Pan-American Airways and Imperial Airways.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler, Dick Merle-Smith and Stroud Co., Inc., will offer today $840,000 of Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis Railway equipment trust, Series C 2 1/4 per cent equipment trust certificates, maturing $56,000 annually from March 1, 1938, to March 1, 1952.

Women may serve as delegates to the Quadrennial General Council of the Alliance of the Reformed Churches Throughout the World LHolding the Presbyterian System if a resolution is adopted which was presented yesterday to the Western Section of the alliance.
THY NEIGHBOUR, by Lord Melchett. (H. C. Kinsey, $2.) A survey of the history of the persecution of Jews, a description of the rise and progress of Zionism and the position of Jews in the world today.

The Cabinet crisis, lasting almost a week, was temporarily settled today when Demeter Iuca, Minister of the Interior, and Mircea Diuvara, Minister of Justice, resigned their portfolios, remaining in the Cabinet as Ministers without portfolios.

Enrico Venturi, 26 years old, of 32 West Seventy-third Street, lightweight boxer, who is scheduled to fight Pedro Martinez in the main event at Madison Square Garden Friday night, and his press agent, Carmine Tarantino, 38, of 316 West Fifty-first Street, were held in $100 bail each last night in Night Court for a hearing Monday on a charge of disorderly conduct.

Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, will appear before the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday of next week to be questioned concerning defaulted bonds of the Republic of Colombia. The Learing was originally scheduled to be held tomorrow.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. sought today a Supreme Court review of assessed valuations aggregating $2,623,890 which the village of North Tarrytown has placed on his properties for 1937. The petition said his holdings have been appraised at more than 100 per cent of true values,

Decreases in employment and pay, rolls, partly seasonal and partly due to the General Motors strike, which had repercussions in- many other industries, -were reported today by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

The committee on student organizations at Columbia University has been empowered by the university council to demand a prospectus from every campus organization not falling within the scope of King's Crown, regular supervisory body of extra-curricular activities, and to grant privileges accordingly, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of Columbia, disclosed yesterday.

Colonial Williamsburg Restoration Conference arranged by The New York Herald Tribune in cooperation with the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. to 4 P. M. Speakers: Dr. W. A. R. Goodwin, Burton Parish Church, William G. Perry, Kenneth Chorley, Mrs. Julian G. Goodhue.

Fillmore Van S. Hyde of the Harvard Club was eliminated yesterday from the national veterans' squash tennis tournament. In the quarterfinal round at the Yale Club, Hyde, four-time holder of the national title, met defeat at the hands of Rowland B. Haines, Columbia Club star who held national honors three years running, starting in 1927.

The match between the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team and Victoria was drawn today, with the State eleven ahead on the first innings by 105 runs Victoria made 292, the visitors' totals being 187 and 132 for three wickets. Rain prevented play yesterday.

Incendiary bombs, causing numerous fires to break out all over the city, constitute one of the greatest menaces of an air attack in the view of the Bitish Government, and fire-fight ing appliances, high-powered pumping engines and other equipment will be included among Britain's defense armaments, it was announced today.
The Indiana Legislature today pushed toward final enactment a bill which State administration leaders said would give Indiana "an easy- way out" of labor disputes.

The flats at 100-102 La Salle' St., formerly 125th St., were sold by the Central Savings Bank to the Eulos Realty and Construction Corp., Carlos L. Henriquez Jr., president, for 40,000, the bank taking back a purchase money mortgage for $39,500, payable in two years.

Paul Sterne, securities salesman, whose last-known address before he became a fugitive was 40 Journal Square, Jersey City, had deposited $25,000 in the Manhattan branch of the Brooklyn Trust Company between Nov. 1, 1932, and April 29, 1933, according to records introduced yesterday at the trial for mail fraud of Wallace G. Garland and Arnold C. Mason, former honor men at Yale University, and eighteen other persons.

The regret expressed yesterday in the literary and journalistic field at the death of Rollo Ogden, editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, indicated that his daily editorial anonymity did not obscure him within his own profession.

Opposition of the toilet goods industry to the current Federal tax of 10 per cent on its products was voiced yesterday- at a special meeting held in the Hotel Biltmore under the auspices of the Toilet Goads Association and attended by trade executives and editors of beauty publications.

Adam Krzyzanowski, chairman of the Polish Finance Ministry delegation, announced yesterday a plan for servicing of three interest coupons of its external debt beginning with the first coupon remaining unpaid in consequence of the declaration of the suspension of transfer in June, 1936.

MANHATTAN CASE, LOIS A. (Jan. 28). Estate, more than $25,000. To Charles E. Case, son, 57 Ferndale Rd., Summit, N. J., $5,000; Clara C. Edwards, daughter, 1 St. John's Lodge, Harley Rd., N. W. 3, London, England, $5,000; Adelaide T., and Mary C. Case, daughters, 309 W. 91st St., $5,000 and one-half residue each; several specific bequests. Frederick T. Case, son,

Estimated earnings of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway before the payment of taxes were $1,437,077 in January, or twice the total for January, 1936, according to Samuel T. Bledsoe, president. Traffic this month is running about 20 per cent ahead of the corresponding total for last year, he added.

The possibility of a record field of twenty-one looms for the third running of the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap on Saturday, according to a statement from Racing Secretary Webb Everett of the Los Angeles Turf Club. All betting records are expected to be shattered, and attendance figures also are likely to go by the board.

Battery candidates for Columbia's baseball team reported yesterday for their first workout of the year under the direction of Coach Andy Coakley. Twelve aspirants, along with a few infielders and outfielders, practiced for about an hour in the Morningside Heights gymnasium.

Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, who was accused of rocking the Olympic boat last Summer, added fortune to her fame yesterday by signing a $30,000 contract to appear in the Great Lakes Exposition in Cleveland next Summer.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy denied yesterday an application for freedom under bail made by Nellie Gutowsky, 23 years old, also known as Norma Parker. She was sent to the House of Detention last week by Magistrate
Acting under the Public Utility Act of 1935, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today various technical rules of procedure.
Irish Eddie Brink, Scranton lightweight, won an eight-round decision from Maxie Fisher, Newark veteran, in the feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 7,500 watched the fighting.

Speakers at the opening of the thirty-third annual convention of the American - Concrete Institute yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt compared American methods of large structure and road building with those employed by England and Germany.

Offering of a new issue of $1,400,000 of 3 1/2 per cent serial notes of the Pennsylvania State College will be made today by Stroud Co., Inc. The notes, dated Feb. 1, 1937, and maturing $100,000 each on Feb. 1, 1939 to 1952, inclusive, will be priced to yield from 2.25 to 3.50 per cent, according to maturity.

Constitutional changes permitting the mixing of amateurs and professionals in national and international hockey competition and settling the status of players in world, Olympic and European championships were approved today by the congress of the Ligue Internationale de Hockey sur Glace.
Alfred Salmaggi and his company concluded a two-day stay last night at the Hippodrome with the presentation of another Puccini opera, "La Boheme," which attracted 4,400 persons.

President Roosevelt's contemplated program to regulate working hours and wages, now in the "conference" stage, is making steady progress toward the formulation of definite legislative proposals, according to statements made today at the White House and the. Department of Labor.

Undefeated in four previous ring engagements in this country, Gunnar Barlund, hard-hitting Finnish heavyweight, will battle Nathan Mann of New Haven in the main bout of ten rounds tonight at the Hippodrome.

Governor Lehman conferred with William R. White, Banking Superintendent; Louis H. Pink, Insurance Superintendent, and Benjamin Rabin, head of the State Mortgage Commission, about legislation affecting mortgages.

A report that Joseph M. Sheehan, Associate Superintendent of Schools, would be denied re-election when his term expires on April 7 was called "premature speculation" yesterday at the Board of Education. The report indicated that Dr. John L. Tildsley, Assistant Superintendent, who will retire in June under the compulsory age rule,

Venezuela's Cabinet resigned yesterday, a dispatch from Caracas said tonight, to allow President Eleazar Lopez Contreras to reor ganize the federal executive branch The Ministers, according to the text of their resignation published here, said:
Bringing their regular league schedule with the Toronto Maple Leafs to a close, the New York Rangers defeated Connie Smythe's aggregation in Madison Square Garden last night, 2 to l.

Governor Earle announced today that he and trustees of the University of Pittsburgh had ended the differences over alumni represenstation on the board, which had brought a threat from the Governor to withdraw the institution's State grant of more than $1,000,000.
P. A. S. Franklin, chairman of the board of directors of the Ininternational Mercantile Marine Company, sailed yesterday on the Panama Pacific liner Virginia for California via Cuba and Colon.

A group of institutional investors headed by Frederic W. Ecker, vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, announced yesterday that it had intervened in the bankruptcy proceedings of the Spokane International Railway, a subsidiary of the Canadian Pacific Railway.

Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, is keenly interested in the forest lands of this country and has worked on them for a great many years. Commenting recently on how the interests of wildlife are

The Rev. George U. Preuss, pastor of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Ascension, Glendale, Queens, died on Saturday at his home in Glendale of pneumonia after an eleven-day illness. His age was 68.

A henna-haired woman, who wore a nurse's uniform, apparently unperturbed by the recent wind-up of Norma Parker's brief career as a cap-pistol expert, held up a corset shop in Brooklyn yesterday morning and escaped with $214.

Extension of the fair trade activities of the Industrial Council -of Cloak, Suit and Skirt- Manufacturers, Inc., to apply to "all phases of members' merchandising and mar keting procedure,herever practieal," was approved last night at the organization's annual membership meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.
Anti-government Honduran refugees here continue to receive reports of rebel advances and victories over Honduran Government troops.

The first chain-store hearings by the Federal Trade Commission on complaints issued under the Robinsonpatman act will be held in the case of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company on Monday at Cambridge, Md., the commission an-, nounced today.

Old soldiers exclaimed in amazement tonight when they heard of new, luxurious three-story "villa residences" with central heating that are to be constructed in place of barracks to attract recruits to Britain's new army.
By GEORGE J. KEARNS 175th St., 496 E., 35x106.7, 2-story dwelling; Home Owners Loan Corporation against Maurice Rosenckrantz; due ;10,748, taxes, , $593;- to plaintiff for $6,480.

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Feb. 22 unless specified: At San Diego: Bridge, Feb. 20; Altair. At San Pedro: California, Feb. 21; Utah, Feb. 20. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Charleston, Feb. 21: Decatur.

A gift of 2,283 rare works of Hebrew literature from the H. G. Enelow collection of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America has been made to Harvard University by Lucius N. Littauer, '78, of New York City.

The Maritime Commission announced today a series of conferences with shipping companies beginning on Thursday and extending through March for the purpose of adjusting the ocean mail contracts in accordance with the new Merchant Marine Act.

The text of the Neutrality Bill that the Foreign Affairs Committee will report to the House of Representatives tomorrow, giving the President considerably more discretion in directing the country's policy in time of war abroad, follows:
Military rule, set up here on Feb. 13 after violence developed between union and non-union automotive craftsmen, ended late today by order of Governor M. Clifford Townsend.

By turning back the City A. C., 4--1, in the final match of the season last night, the Princeton Club team registered its eighteenth consecutive victory and remained undefeated in the Metropolitan Class B Squash Tennis League.
Memebers of the Illinois State Bar Association, in a poll ended today, voted 2,062 to 367 against the proposal of President Roosevelt to enlarge the United States Supreme Court.

Mary T. Falck Wister, daughter of Frederick McQ. Falck of Chestnut Hill and of the late Mrs. Falck, was married this morning to George Harrison Frazier Jr., son of Mrs. George Harrison Frazier and the late George Harrison Frazier, Philadelphia banker.

Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath of Germany left here today for Berlin after a two-day visit. The day passed quietly, for the government, prepared for renewal of yesterday's Nazi demonstrations, took elaborate precautions.

The Equitable Life Insurance Company of Iowa, which is celebrating its seventieth anniversary, reported yesterday that the insurance it had in force at the end of 1936 amounted to $555,707,437, a gain of $7,369,700 from a year before.

Trading was slow in practically all classes. Some sales steer hinds and ribs were stronger. Veal sold weak to lower, lamb and fresh pork mostly steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated weaker markets in all classes.

Mrs. Monica Barry O'Shea Muray received a divorce today from lickolas Muray, New York photographer. She charged cruelty. There was a property settlement and she received permission to resume her maiden name.
Overcoming a 6-point lead early in the first half, Notre Dame completely subdued a game but outclassed Marquette basketball team before 4,500 tonight for its ninth straight victory, 41 to 24.
Topsy, a, milky white toy poodle owned and shown by Mrs. Ernst Aberg of the Bronx was selected as best toy dog at the opening session of Bloomingdale's sixth annual pet dog show yesterday.

A gale-driven fire whipped through near-by Douglas today, defying a small army of trained and volunteer fire fighters and virtually wiped out the town of 300. The fire started at 5:30 A. M. and four hours later almost the entire community was in ashes.

The above photograph of the model of the new America's Cup yacht Ranger, which is being built at the Bath Iron Works in Bath, Me., is the first one to be taken. It shows her profile, with long, graceful stern,
Seymour Prince conquered Lucien Collart, 150--108, in fifty innings in a Metropolitan Class C 18.2 balkline billiard match at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night.

Plans for a $185,000 apartment house in Brooklyn, a two-story taxpayer at the corner of Madison Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, and for alterations to many old Manhattan buildings were filed yesterday.
Railroad employes were warned today to shift trains cautiously in one yard here after police found 100 sticks of dynamite attached to several freight cars.
Miss Rebecca Brownstein, daughter of Mrs. Max Brownstein of 440 West Thirty-fourth Street and the late Mr. Brownstein, was married to Iver Rose yesterday at the home of her mother.

Judge and Mrs. Charles W. Appleton will entertain with a dinner at the Boca Raton Club tomorrow evening for Mr. and Mrs. Owen D. Young. Mrs. Young, the former Mrs. Louise Clark, was married to the chairman of the General Electric Company at St. Augustine on Saturday.

Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, world famous American book collector and president of the Shakespeare Association of America, disclosed today after six weeks here that the purpose of his visit was to trace the authority for the statement that Shakespeare based "The Tempest," containing the line beginning "From the stillvex'd Bermoothes," upon Bermuda.

The New York team of Gerald Dunphy and C. L. Turner scored easily in the first round of the annual two-ball invitation foursome golf tournament today, trouncing H. A. Bedford of New York and G. K. Morgan of Bellport, L. I., 4 and 3.

Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry has adopted an entirely new method of speeding settlements in strike litigation, which, to put it simply, is this: He offers to buy dinners for the opposing lawyers who bring about an amicable settlement.

Secretary Perkins said today that while navy steel was "still a problem" she expected "within forty-eight hours" one or two bids from steel companies for warship plate which would probably avert Congressional action.

A Conservative colliery owner declared before the House of Commons today that the loss of 265 lives in the Gresford pit disaster of 1934 might have been averted if the miners had been more effectively unionized.

The Long Lines Department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company should earn a net revenue of $25,186,000 in 1937, Magnus Anderson, an accountant for the Federal Communications Commission, testified today at a hearing in the investigation of the affairs of the utility.

The Senate passed the Stokes bill providing for courses in schools on highway safety and motoring. The Feld bill, which would allocate additional State funds for kindergartens and under which New York City would get $1,000,000 more for this type of instruction, was shifted back to the Finance Committee for further inquiry.

One of the most perfect golfing days of the season greeted members of the New York Athletic Club today as they set out for the semi-final and final rounds of their seventh annual Winter handicap tournament.

The shadow of a bird Drifted across the grass. I had not heard its song Nor had I seen it pass. And yet my faith is strong That somewhere in the blue A burning spark of life Through sunlit ether flew.
Mrs. Kate Page Biddle of Pinehurst, N. C., obtained a divorce today from Livingston L. Biddle 2d of New York. She charged cruelty. An agreement for custody of their child was filed.

Establishment of official control was hinted today to halt the London Metal Exchange's boom in prices for materials of war. Bulls feared that either the government or authoritative financial interests would fix prices or take other measures to curb the rapidly rising values.
Pennsylvania oarsmen engaged in their first outdoor practice on the Schuylkill River today, Coaches Rusty Callow and Jim Matthews boating twelve crews.

Chokyuro Kadono, chairman of the board of Okura Co., one of Japan's big business combines, today accepted chairmanship of a Japanese economic mission to the United States. Mr. Kadono, well known to many American business leaders, and his colleagues are expected to sail for the United States in April.
The engagement of $6,629,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $1,129,000 in England and $5,500,000 in Egypt was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

John Rawle Brotherton of White Haven, Pa., retired New York attorney and widely known whist tournament player, died in Springfield Hospital today, at the age of 78. Mr. Brotherton was born in Waterford, Pa., was graduated from Western Reserve University in 1879, and received his law degree from the University of Pennsylvania.

Democrats and Republicans here believed today that Governor Lehman would appoint William J. Sheils, New Rochelle Democrat, to the vacancy caused by the death of George A. Slater, Surrogate of Westchester County. Surrogate Slater died today in a hospital in Pinehurst. N. C.

It is sometimes claimed by the opponents of the child labor amendment that the amendment is not necessary because the evil with which it deals has been gradually "curing itself" and is already one of minor proportions. There is a measure of truth in this contention.

The Knickerbocker Greys eclipsed their elders when the smart junior cadet corps went through intricate military evolutions at their annual fathers and sons review yesterday afternoon at the 107th Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixtysixth Street.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at his home in Congers, N. Y., of Henri Mollat, formerly proprietor of Mollat's restaurant, at 112 West Fortyninth Street. He was 63 years old. A son, Robert of Congers, and a daughter, Yvonne Mollat of Paris, France, survive.

Manhattan BABCOCK, EARLE B. (March 1, 1935). Gross assets $30,843, net $24,903. To Alfred R. Babcock, son, temporary estate in residue, principal at 25; several contingent bequests. 'Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $18,981. Gwinn Pell, attorney. 522 5th Av.

Leonard Stocker, young American baritone, who while not pursuing his vocal studies engages in the occupation of curtain puller at the Metropolitan Opera House, appeared in a recital last night at Steinway Hall and was enthusiastically applauded by a large audience.

The annual report of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal subsidiaries, the Southern California Telegraph Company and the Bell Telephone Company of Nevada, for 1936 shows a net income of $20,240,020, which, after payment of dividends on the 6 per cent preferred stock, was equal to $8.49 a share on the outstanding common stock. In 1935,

The former owners of three parcels of property recently acquired by the city for the site of the new Appellate Division courthouse in Brooklyn received awards totaling $111,500 from Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in BrookIyn yesterday.

The German Foreign Minister, Baron CONSTANTIN VON NEURATH, was not well served by the Austrian Nazis on his arrival in Vienna last Monday. While their reception for him-so riotous that it resulted in two deaths and more than 100 arrests-may be diplomatically overlooked by Chancellor KURT SCHUSCHNIGG, it can scarcely conduce to the success of the German mission.

Better weather conditions in the Central West resulted in the arrival today of hogs intended for Monday's market and with the increased supply prices declined 25 cents to as much as 40 cents from the high point on Monday with lights and underweights showing the most loss.

Investigation of a broadcast of whippings of two pupils at St. George's School was ordered today by the Board of Education. The inquiry followed a request from the London Home and School Club for removal of a public address system connected with every class room in the school building.
Paul Hartnek, Creighton University football star and 1936 Golden Gloves heavyweight champion, battled his way to the third round of the tournament tonight by defeating Herman Smith of Quincy, Ill.

Because of the enthusiasm engendered at the studio showing of "Captains Courageous," Metro has decided to follow the Kipling yarn with another story of the sea, "All the Brothers Were Valiant," by Ben Ames Williams.

Marty Spellman, 33 years old, of 327 East 100th Street, suspected gunman in the slaying of one man and the wounding of another last Friday in a shooting in the bar at 1,998 First Avenue, surrendered in District Attorney Dodge's office yesterday.
